title: Mirella Freni and the Italian Tradition
description: It used to be that a great prima donna making her first entrance at the Metropolitan Opera would routinely be greeted by an ovation. That seldom happens any more. But recently there has been a striking exception.

title: Executive Changes
description: AMERICAN EXPRESS FINANCIAL ADVISORS, Minneapolis, the money management subsidiary of the American Express Co., said William H. Dudley had stepped down as chief investment strategist. He will be succeeded by Peter Anderson, senior vice president. Mr. Dudley will remain as a senior consultant, focusing on international investment opportunities, particularly in Japan.

title: When Money Counts
description: THEY are accessories that work. From Bali to Burkina Faso, in West Africa, designers and craftspeople are creating stools, tables and perches that solve a home's practical problems. These small landings are hard to classify, and that's the point. Some can serve as tables when needed, or as extra chairs for unexpected guests, or as ledges for laptop computers or telephones. These art objects make a room complete -- and at the same time they are functional.

title: Stevens Rides His Way Into the Hall of Fame
description: Gary Stevens thought it was both symbolic and appropriate that the announcement that he had been elected to the Racing Hall of Fame occurred this morning at Churchill Downs. The 34-year-old jockey has never won a national championship as the country's leading rider, but he has won more than 4,000 races, two that stand out.

title: Student Is Shot Outside School In Manhattan
description: A 19-year-old student was shot and critically wounded during a dispute outside an alternative high school in lower Manhattan yesterday, the police said.

title: For Chelsea Clinton, It's Stanford
description: Chelsea Clinton will attend Stanford University beginning this fall, the White House announced today, and the university said it was delighted.

title: At Kips Bay, Ideas for the Borrowing
description: WHAT Central Park is to flocking birds, the Kips Bay decorator show house is to design ideas. But at Kips Bay, you don't need binoculars. Design scouts visiting the show house, at 603 Park Avenue (64th Street), might consider appropriating ideas (although it's doubtful there will be a run on Mylar wallpaper, which Richard L. Ridge and Roderick R. Denault chose for their breakfast room and painted with chinoiserie scenes).

title: Saying No to Young Smokers
description: Minors in New Jersey are finding it harder these days to buy cigarettes, the State Department of Health and Senior Services said yesterday. Teen-age volunteers recruited by local health officials were sent to 780 businesses licensed to sell cigarettes. The survey found that 65 percent of them refused to sell to teen-agers, Dana Sullivan, a spokesman for the department, said.

title: Rand McNally Studies Sale
description: Rand McNally & Company, the world's largest commercial map maker, said today that it was exploring the possible sale of the company. It said it had decided to consider a sale to insure Rand McNally's future growth and because of the high value of media properties in today's market. The company has retained the New York investment bank Goldman, Sachs & Company to assist in exploring its options. Rand McNally, which is privately held, was founded in 1856.

title: Jets Sign Their Last Pick
description: Ten days after the draft, the Jets became only the second club to sign one of their picks yesterday when they enrolled the last player they had selected: JASON FERGUSON, a defensive tackle from Georgia. Ferguson, the Jets' second pick of the seventh and final round, was the 229th player chosen over all.

title: VIGOROUS ECONOMY EXPECTED TO EASE DEFICIT IN BUDGET
description: The economy grew at its fastest pace in more than nine years during the first quarter, the Government said today, and Administration officials predicted that the spectacular surge would help drive down this year's Federal budget deficit to about $75 billion, its lowest level in more than 20 years.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROSEN, HOROWITZ, MILDRED
description: ROSEN-HOROWITZ-Mildred. Of New York City, on April 29, 1997. Beloved wife of Jack Horowitz, loving sister of Ruth Post and Marcy Rosen, and devoted aunt to many nieces and nephews. Funeral service at 11:00 AM on Friday, May 2 at Sanctuary of Abraham and Sarah, New Cedar Park Cemetery, Forest Ave., Paramus, NJ.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CORNWALL, DOROTHY R.
description: CORNWALL-Dorothy R., on April 26, 1997, of Bellerose. Interment took place on Wednesday, April 30, at Gate of Heaven Cemetery.

title: Reno Steadfast in Her Refusal To Name Independent Counsel
description: Attorney General Janet Reno today defended her refusal to seek an independent prosecutor to investigate campaign finance issues and said she would accept the consequences of her decision.

title: Matters of Life, Death and Prevarication
description: In the densely populated world of rock music, great things can happen when pop perfectionism is mixed with a restless sense of experimentation. That's how seminal albums like the Beatles' ''Sgt. Pepper's Lonely Hearts Club Band'' or the Beach Boys' ''Pet Sounds'' come about. It's also at the heart of one of the most interesting rock collectives to emerge this decade: Elephant 6, a group of Louisiana-bred bands that includes Olivia Tremor Control and Neutral Milk Hotel, both of which performed at Brownies on Monday night.

title: In Lush Tropics, a Flowering of Murderous Gangs
description: Lonbun is a rascal. He has been one for most of his life, and now, at the age of 27, he says he will probably always be one.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DEITCH, MORTON
description: DEITCH-Morton. He was a man devoted to his profession and colleagues, unfailingly generous to his family and who knew above all the urgency of friendship. We shall sorely and unceasingly miss him. Mary and Morton Bogdonoff

title: Man Arrested in Lodi Slaying
description: A masked gunman man who shot and killed a Paterson man in a Lodi pool hall early Tuesday had been indicted in the robbery of the same man two years before, officials said yesterday. The gunman, Angelo Luis Burgos Jr. of Lodi, was arrested yesterday when he showed up at the Passaic County Courthouse to answer charges in the July 1995 robbery of Robert Price, prosecutors said. Mr. Burgos killed Mr. Price during a holdup at the Billiards Cafe, said John Higgins, an assistant Bergen County prosecutor.

title: House Passes Bill to Encourage Adoption of Abused Children
description: The House of Representatives today passed a bill that would increase and speed up adoptions of children who have been abused or abandoned by their parents.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RUSSINI, JOSEPH A.
description: RUSSINI-Joseph A., of the Bronx, Wednesday, April 30, 1997. Retired member, public relations officer and president of Plumbers Local #

title: Zaire's President and Rebel Agree to Shipboard Meeting
description: After weeks of fruitless attempts to bring them together, President Mobutu Sese Seko of Zaire and Laurent Kabila, the leader of a rebellion that threatens to topple him from power, agreed today to meet on Friday aboard a South African ship off the Atlantic coast.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GANNES, MAURICE
description: GANNES-Maurice, formerly of the Bronx. Residing at Fair Harbor, Fire Island and High Falls, NY. Passed away Wednesday, April 30, leaving his wife Gerrie, children Warren and Robin and grandson Seth. Maurice was a former member of Columbus Lodge #

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LAWRENCE, ELIZABETH
description: LAWRENCE-Elizabeth. Formerly Betty Ann Anson, wife of George J., MD. Former spouse of Sam B. Anson. Mother of three sons and four daughters. Memorial mass Saturday, May 3, at 11:30 am at St. Mark's Roman Catholic Church, Shoreham, New York.

title: An Economy Confounding The Experts
description: The stunning 5.6 percent annual rate of growth in the first quarter surpassed even the most optimistic forecasts and confounded assumptions of a few months ago that the economy would slow in the new year.

title: Impostor Still Hard to Tackle
description: Police in Woodbridge now know that the man who appeared at one of their news conferences last month is not John Brockington, the former football star. But they are still not certain just who he is.

title: Yanks May Be on Channel 11
description: The possibility of a deal to put up to 50 Yankee games on Channel 11 this season has suddenly increased.

title: Charity Officials Charged With Theft
description: Seven directors and employees of five Bronx nonprofit organizations for the poor and elderly were charged yesterday with stealing more than $300,000 to repay loans, build swimming pools, pay off mortgages and lease cars.

title: Delta's new agency aims to take the airline beyond its usual bounds, but not too far beyond.
description: WHEN Saatchi & Saatchi Advertising Worldwide won the Delta Air Lines advertising account in March, the news was a bit of a shock. The agency, after all, was considered a long shot to replace the incumbent, the BBDO Worldwide unit of Omnicom Group. Delta executives also wore out some superlatives in announcing the winner, hailing Saatchi & Saatchi's approach as everything from new and fresh to strategic and out-of-the-category.

title: Celebrations as a TV Lesbian Goes Prime Time
description: Across the country, thousands of people celebrated at private and public parties as ABC Television made history last night when the leading character on its comedy ''Ellen'' acknowledged her lesbianism in prime time.

title: A Natural for New York: A Skyscraper Museum
description: AS any analyst or dream interpreter can tell you, skyscrapers are one of the baldest metaphors around, representing energy, virility and success on a big scale. And it's no accident that New York's skyline is crammed with them.

title: Police Say Youth Robbed and Killed His Grandmother
description: A 61-year-old woman, living alone and struggling with diabetes, was killed Monday by her 17-year-old grandson during a robbery at the woman's apartment in the Bronx, the police said yesterday in announcing the arrest of the teen-ager.

title: Lustful, Ludicrous, Lovable
description: Just under the wire (the annual one that exists for Tony nominations, that is) comes the comic performance of the season. It is turned in by that master thespian, Brian Bedford, who plays the preening, lascivious, utterly adorable Sir Harcourt Courtly in Joe Dowling's stylish new production of Dion L. Boucicault's ''London Assurance.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PALESTIN, IRA J.
description: PALESTIN-Ira J., age 97, on April 30th. Beloved husband of Beatrice. Dear brother of Seymour. Devoted uncle of Dr. Jonathan Pincus of Washington, DC and Dr. Matthew Pincus, fond grand and great grand uncle. Former member of the NYC Council and member of the NY State Tax Commission. Services Friday, May 2nd, 10:45AM at ''The Riverside'', 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Brazil Wins Friendly Match
description: The Bra zilian national soccer team which at $200 million over 10 years is a bigger financial investment for Nike than either Michael or Tiger -- opened its commercial world tour tonight with a 4-0 exhibition victory over Mexico before 51,500 at the Orange Bowl.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MITRANI, IDA
description: MITRANI-Ida, 93, on April 29. Beloved wife of the late Albert. Cherished mother of Sam, Zelda Frankel and the late Eddie. Loved grandmother and great grandmother. Adored sister of Esther. Service today, 10:15AM at ''Sinai Chapels'', Fresh Meadows, NY.

title: Isringhausen, Awaiting Test Results, Is One of Team's Pitching Questions
description: There are lockers in the Mets' clubhouse waiting for the pitching returns of Paul Wilson, Bill Pulsipher and Jason Isringhausen, placards and all. But there is no telling when that will happen.

title: Stanford White Runs Away and Joins the Circus
description: IT is a genuine ersatz New York happening. Le Cirque -- a restaurant known as much for its social theater as for its excellent food -- moves to the Henry Villard residence, one of New York's prominent landmarks, surrounded by an extravaganza of hoopla and display reminiscent of the compulsively conspicuous 80's.

title: Leader of Armed Group Breaks Off Talks on Settling Standoff in West Texas
description: The leader of an armed group claiming to represent the independent nation of Texas has broken off all negotiations with the state authorities who have surrounded him here, a spokesman for the state's Department of Public Safety said today.

title: Bridge
description: One of the few East-Coast bridge families that can field an effective foursome in tournament play suffered a tragedy in Manhattan on Sunday. Jerome Sprung, 65, of Purchase, N.Y., had spent 10 days by the side of his wife, Shirley, while she underwent therapy for throat cancer in Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center. When he left the hospital he was struck by a hit-and-run driver, thrown into the path of another car and killed. The hit-and-run driver has not been found.

title: Pressing the Flesh, One More Time
description: Britons vote today after a six-week general election campaign that left Prime Minister John Major's Conservative Party divided and disorganized and the opposition Labor Party, unified and full of fresh energy under Tony Blair, continuing its surge in public opinion polls.

title: Jordan to Let Terror Suspect Held in U.S. Into Kingdom
description: Jordan announced yesterday that Mousa Mohammed Abu Marzook, the Hamas political leader who has been jailed in Manhattan for 22 months on shadowy accusations of terrorism and immigration violations, would be allowed to enter the kingdom.

title: Peter Coleman, 77, Governor of American Samoa
description: Peter Tali Coleman, a native of American Samoa who was its first popularly elected Governor, from 1978 to 1985, died on Monday in Honolulu. He was 77 and a longtime resident of Pago Pago, the capital of American Samoa.

title: Now Pursue Big Alcohol Just Like Big Tobacco
description: To the Editor:

title: Miscellany
description: * Andrew Jarchin, former marketing director at MLM/Yellowbook Publishing Corp., Rockville Centre, N.Y., has formed the Jarchin Group, Plainview, N.Y., a marketing, advertising and media communications agency. He is president of the shop.

title: CHRONICLE
description: When JOAN MONDALE, a lifelong potter, was in Japan while her husband, Walter F. Mondale, was Ambassador there from 1993 to 1996, she gave clay pots that she had made as gifts.

title: 12 Battered Women Assail Move to Hotel
description: A dozen residents of a battered- women's shelter under investigation by New York City complained yesterday that they had been transferred to what they described as an inadequate single-room occupancy hotel for homeless women.

title: Firm Is Expelled
description: One of the most audaciously named brokerage firms ever -- Kennedy, Mathews, Landis, Healy & Pecora of Minneapolis -- is officially barred from the business.

title: No Nicotine Increase
description: To the Editor:

title: Study Bolsters Idea That Exercise Cuts Breast Cancer Risk
description: A study of more than 25,000 Norwegian women suggests that regular exercise protects against breast cancer.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GILMOUR, MARGERY BLYTH
description: GILMOUR-Margery Blyth of Palm Beach, Fla. and Locust Valley, L.I. on April 30, 1997. Beloved wife of the late Llyod S. Survived by son, Lloyd S. of NYC and daughter, Blyth Gilmour Patel of Boca Raton, Fla. Grandmother of four and several great grandchildren. Interment at Locust Valley Cemetery will be private.

title: Richter Is Eager to Stop in New Jersey
description: Raised in suburban Philadelphia, educated at the University of Wisconsin and well-traveled across North America, Mike Richter is also a young man of Manhattan. He lives there, works there and sometimes takes college courses there.

title: Grants to Musicians
description: Four young instrumentalists have been awarded Avery Fisher Career Grants for 1997, the Avery Fisher Artist Program has announced. They are the pianists Mia Chung, 32, of Cambridge, Mass., and Orli Shaham, 21, of Manhattan, the violinist Tamaki Kawakubo, 17, of Scarsdale, N.Y., and the violist Nokuthula Ngwenyama, 20, of Paris. Each receives $10,000. The Fisher program was established in 1974.

title: Q: How Many Women Have Won the Top Math Contest?
description: Every year on college campuses across the United States and Canada, the most brilliant math students face the ultimate challenge. For six hours, they struggle with problems from the merely intractable to the seemingly impossible.

title: A Shift to Rigorous Tradition Gains Influence in Judaism
description: To draw a sellout crowd to Madison Square Garden, not for sports or rock music, but to celebrate the reading of a religious text, is no mean feat.

title: Leapin' Evolution Is Found in Lizards
description: Darwin's theory of evolution is the foundation of biology, yet the process is so slow that it has seldom been witnessed outside the laboratory.

title: Earnings Climb 6.5% At Rhone-Poulenc
description: Rhone-Poulenc S.A., France's biggest drug and chemical company, said yesterday that its first-quarter earnings rose 6.5 percent as lower financial costs offset losses at its blood plasma unit. The company, whose products range from Frontline flea repellent to Taxotere cancer treatment, had a net profit of 674 million French francs ($116 million), up from 633 million francs a year earlier. Sales rose 2.2 percent, to 21.6 billion francs.

title: Gerry Adams Expected to Win Commons Seat
description: After the most crucial election battle of his life, Gerry Adams, the political leader of the Irish Republican Army, is widely expected to win a Northern Ireland seat in the British parliamentary election on Thursday.

title: Bundesbank Leaves Rates Unchanged
description: As expected, Germany's Bundesbank left interest rates unchanged at historic lows yesterday, as moderate economic growth appeared to harbor no inflation dangers. Rates have been unchanged since Aug. 22.

title: Fidelity Names Three Officers To Rejuvenate Mutual Funds
description: Robert C. Pozen, the newly appointed president of Fidelity Investments' troubled mutual fund business, moved quickly to shake up the operation yesterday, naming three lieutenants to oversee Fidelity's equity fund managers.

title: Calendar: Art, Gems And Cherry Blossoms
description: Blossoms in Brooklyn

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TACONA, ANGELO
description: TACONA-Angelo. Devoted father of Robert. Cherished grandfather of LisaAnn. Loving brother of Joseph, Carmela and Margaret. Reposing Scarpaci Funeral Home, 1401 86th St, Bklyn until Friday 9AM. Mass St. Brendan's Church, 9:30AM. Viewing hours 2-5 & 7-9:30.

title: Volunteer Summit Didn't Aim to Bash Business
description: To the Editor:

title: Bulls Prevail, but Bullets Go Out Fighting
description: The Chicago Bulls left behind a pile of rubble tonight. It was the Washington Bullets. Their name, their building and their hearts were in a collapsible state by the end of Game 3.

title: Teledesic Faces Challenges on Satellite Plan
description: Despite hiring the Boeing Company as its lead contractor, the Teledesic Corporation still faces years of challenges to its ambitious plan to establish an ''Internet in the sky'' to deliver high-speed voice and data communications anywhere on the planet.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCCULLOCH, IDA
description: McCULLOCH-Ida. On Apr. 22, '97. Friends around the world will miss her charm, magnetism, and acts of individual kindness. Advancing time overtook her. She is survived by a brother George Searle, CBE of New Zealand and only daughter Judith Heath of New York City.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  WEINGARTEN, CHERYL
description: WEINGARTEN-Cheryl. Love and rainbows Mom

title: Mayor Expects Record Surplus For Fiscal Year
description: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani said yesterday that New York City would finish its fiscal year with $800 million more than his budget experts predicted less than a year ago.

title: Judge Throws Out Verdict On Keyboard Stress Injuries
description: In a setback for plaintiffs seeking damages from computer keyboard makers, a Federal judge has thrown out a $5.3 million verdict against the Digital Equipment Corporation.

title: Partisan Poker Game Snags Disaster Relief Bill in Senate
description: The Senate played partisan poker today with billions of dollars in flood relief. The high-stakes game not only threatened the assistance for disaster victims, but also complicated the negotiations over a balanced budget.

title: Law Firm on the Move
description: In an expansion move, King & Spalding, a major law firm based in Atlanta, has leased 53,000 square feet, the 34th and 35th floors, at 1185 Avenue of the Americas, a 1.1 million-square-foot office building between 46th and 47th Streets.

title: Give Nynex Customers a Choice
description: Phone customers in the Northeast, especially in New York City, will almost certainly be harmed by the Justice Department's recent decision to approve a merger between Bell Atlantic and Nynex. They lose any hope of turning to Bell Atlantic as an alternative to Nynex, which offers its customers some of the worst service in the country.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SARETSKY, BENSON
description: SARETSKY-Benson, 89, April 30, in Boca Raton, FL., formerly of Mount Vernon, N.Y. Beloved husband of Pauline, dearest and devoted father of Howard and Suzanne Corton. Dear brother of Mortimer and sisters Mildred Danziger and Pearl Marcus. Cherished grandfather of Jeffrey Silverberg, Amy Kotlar, and Michael Saretsky. Adored great grandfather of three. Graveside services Mount Pleasant Cemetery, Hawthorne, New York, Friday at 10 A.M.

title: Good Profits Spur Stocks, But Aid Case For Rate Rise
description: The Dow Jones industrial average moved to within striking distance of its all-time closing high yesterday on the back of better-than-expected corporate earnings and relief that the economy's strongest quarterly growth in nine years has not led to a surge in inflation.

title: A Flower Reopens in the Bronx
description: THE Victorians were the first to hate Victorian architecture. With one major exception, they detested their own buildings. The exception was the great glass greenhouse. The conservatory, the winter garden, the Crystal Palace: this type of building Victorians passionately admired.

title: HOLLINGER TO SEEK FULL CONTROL OF NEWSPAPER CHAIN
description: Hollinger Inc. said yesterday that it would offer $660 million (United States) to take full control of Southam Inc., Canada's largest chain of daily newspapers. Hollinger, based in Toronto and controlled by the millionaire publisher Conrad M. Black, already owns 50.45 percent of Southam, also based in Toronto. Hollinger will offer $23.50 (Canadian), or $16.81 (United States), for each Southam share -- $13.50 (Canadian) in cash and $10 (Canadian) in new nonvoting special shares of Hollinger Canadian Publishing Holdings Inc. Shares of Southam, which publishes 32 daily newspapers, rose $2.75, to $23.15 (Canadian). Hollinger's shares were down 1.5 cents, to $9.4375 (United States) in Nasdaq trading. Hollinger's newspapers include The Chicago Sun-Times and The Daily Telegraph in London.

title: Debt Relief for Model Countries
description: The World Bank and the International Monetary Fund recently agreed for the first time to write off some loans to one of its borrowers, Uganda. Uganda is special because of a decadelong policy of pro-growth economic reform. But the importance of the decision goes well beyond a single African country. It means that the bank and the fund have at last put into effect a policy to reward poor, highly indebted countries that are serious about reforming their economies.

title: Hero of Grant's Tomb
description: To the Editor:

title: UNITED DOMINION TO SELL ITS BUILDINGS DIVISION TO LTV
description: United Dominion Industries said yesterday that it had agreed to sell its Varco-Pruden buildings division to the LTV Corporation for $187.5 million in cash. Varco-Pruden, based in Memphis, makes buildings for the commercial and industrial markets. Varco-Pruden has eight United States plants and three international joint ventures. It reported sales of $305 million in 1996. United Dominion, based in Charlotte, N.C., makes industrial and building products. LTV, of Cleveland, is an integrated steel producer.

title: New York Has Plan to Combat Illegal Housing
description: To the Editor:

title: A Saudi-Iranian Schmooze
description: Crown Prince Abdullah of Saudi Arabia and President Hashemi Rafsanjani of Iran met recently in Islamabad, Pakistan, to try to ease tensions between their two countries. Here's what I imagine their conversation sounded like.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DIBBELL, CHARLES W.
description: DIBBELL-Charles W. Attorney, April 30, at his Greenwich Village home, at 89. His poems of everyday life gave joy to his family, neighbors and Yale '28 classmates. He will be remembered with special affection by his four children, their families and his wife of 65 years, Helen Hope Dibbell.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BADECKER, WILLIAM J.
description: BADECKER-William J., retired CPA, died April 24, in Florida, following a stroke. My sympathy to Kay and family. A memorial service will be held in New Jersey at a later date. Eugene L. Crupi

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEISS, MAX
description: WEISS-Max. Of Lake Worth, Fla. Formerly of Tarrytown, N.Y. On April 30, 1997. Loving husband of Shirley and the late Ruth. Beloved father of Linda Weiss Sachs. Dear brother of Abe. Cherished Pop Pop of Pamela and David. Stepfather to Cynthia, Robert and Lee. Graveside services Friday, 10:30 AM, Mount Hope Cemetery, Hastings, New York. Family and friends are welcome.

title: Lord Taylor of Gosforth Is Dead; Chief English Appeals Judge, 66
description: Lord Taylor of Gosforth, a former Lord Chief Justice of England who was a critic of the British criminal justice system, died on Monday at his home in Guildford, near London. He was 66.

title: For New Media, an Old-Time Forum
description: The invitation, as usual, came via electronic mail, 24 hours in advance: cocktails and dinner for a group of Internet experts at the Flatiron Diner and Baking Company on West 18th Street in Manhattan.

title: Goldman Says It Will Buy Asset Adviser
description: In its latest move to expand and diversify its asset management business, Goldman, Sachs & Company said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire the Commodities Corporation, a managed futures, currencies and commodities investment firm.

title: Andrews Chided on Absences
description: State Senator James E. McGreevey accused one of his rivals in the Democratic gubernatorial primary yesterday of neglecting his job in Congress. Representative Robert A. Andrews of Haddon Heights has missed 27 of 91 votes in the House since January, and 17 of 24 votes since March 20, Rich McGrath, a spokesman for Mr. McGreevey, said.

title: MEXICO SHAKES UP ANTI-DRUG FORCE
description: Mexico today dismantled its main anti-drug force, which was disgraced in February when its director and many of its agents were discovered to be working for traffickers, and announced that it had been replaced by a new organization to be built from a small nucleus of trusted agents.

title: Garden Q.&A.
description: Pruning Forsythia

title: CAI WIRELESS SYSTEMS TO BUY BACK DEBT FROM BABY BELLS
description: CAI Wireless Systems Inc. said yesterday that it had renegotiated an option to buy back $100 million of debt held by the Bell Atlantic Corporation and the Nynex Corporation from an abandoned joint venture. CAI Wireless agreed to exchange $40 million in cash and 100,000 convertible junior preferred shares for the debt. It said repurchasing the debt could save it $100 million. Bell Atlantic and Nynex invested $100 million in CAI in a joint venture to develop CAI's wireless TV services. The companies decided to abandon the venture in December, and CAI said it would not have any further obligations to Bell Atlantic and Nynex if it bought back the debt under the plan announced yesterday.

title: Corrections
description: A front-page article last Thursday about a woman from the Los Angeles area who gave birth at age 63 referred incorrectly to Dr. Mark V. Sauer, an infertility researcher who has established pregnancies in older women. He is the former director of the donor egg program at the University of Southern California, not the former director of the infertility program there.

title: INSIDE METRO
description: STRAYING HUSBAND WINS CASE -- A Queens man who, in 1962, was convicted of having his ex-girlfriend blinded, was acquitted of threatening his ex-mistress. B3.

title: Official Killed In Chechnya As Fighting Flares Anew
description: The tenuous peace between Russia and Chechnya, its rebellious southern republic, dissolved this week into the kind of violence, threats and recriminations that have been common there for three centuries.

title: Prodigy in China
description: Prodigy Inc. has become the first Government-approved foreign Internet provider in China, which closely controls access to the global computer network. The Prodigy service, to be introduced in Shanghai, stems from a venture with the state-run China North Industries Company. Prodigy, which is based in Medford and owns an 80 percent stake in the venture, plans to invest $50 million in it and expand to nine other Chinese cities.

title: Heir Apparent Quits At Lazard Freres
description: Edouard Stern, the senior partner at Lazard Freres & Company who was once considered the heir apparent to his father-in-law, the firm's chairman, Michel David-Weill, has left the firm, a partner said today.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KAUFMAN, POSEY W.
description: KAUFMAN-Posey W. The National Women's Division of the Albert Einstein College of Medicine of Yeshiva University is deeply saddened by the loss of our dear friend and devoted member of our National Board of Directors, who served for many years as chairwoman of our benefit shop, Connoisseur's Corner. She was also a member of the College's Society of Founders. We extend our heartfelt condolences to her son, Paul, a member of the Executive Committee of Einstein's Young Men's Division, her daughter-in-law, Marsha, and to the entire family. Nancy Oelbaum, President National Women's Division Albert Einstein College of Medicine Judy R. Rosenberg, Chairwoman Executive Committee

title: Lukas Gets In Under the Wire With a Horse For the Derby
description: Thirteen colts were entered today for the 123d Kentucky Derby, the smallest field in 12 years despite the late addition of Deeds Not Words by D. Wayne Lukas, who conceded that he was ''rolling the dice.''

title: Audits Indicate Misuse of Funds By Aid Agency In Harlem
description: Over its 23-year history, the Harlem Urban Development Corporation received almost $100 million in state funds to help rebuild Harlem. Millions of dollars were spent on lawyers, hundreds of thousands went for telephone calls around the world and perks like cellular phones and cars, and hundreds of thousands more are still unaccounted for.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RACKMAN, RUTH
description: RACKMAN-Ruth. The Officers, Board of Directors, faculty and staff of Bar-Ilan University in Israel, and the American Friends of Bar-Ilan, mourn with great sorrow the passing of the beloved First Lady of our university, Mrs. Ruth Rackman. A woman of quiet strength, character and dignity, she was a devoted mother, grandmother and great-grandmother who was loved and respected by all who knew her. The adored wife of Bar-Ilan Chancellor Rabbi Emanuel Rackman, Mrs. Rackman was a full partner and guiding influence in all of Rabbi Rackman's achievements and efforts on behalf of the Jewish People. A driving force in her own right, she attained professional success as Associate Professor of Guidance at Bronx Community College as well as in her role as a full-time Rebbetzin. Her love for Israel, the Jewish People and our university is embodied in the Maria Finkle & Ruth Rackman Student Counseling Building at Bar-Ilan University, a testament to her abiding concern and commitment to serving the needs of students. She will be sorely missed. May the entire Rackman family draw solace from inspiring memories and pride in the sterling example she set for others to emulate. May her memory be for a blessing. Professor Moshe Kaveh, President, Bar-Ilan University Jane Stern Lebell, President, American Friends, Bar-Ilan University Brig Gen. (Res.) Yehuda Halevy, Executive Vice-President Bar-Ilan University

title: Soybeans Reach 9-Year Peak; Oil Prices Fall as Supplies Rise
description: Soybeans soared yesterday to their highest price since a drought devastated crops in 1988, after a closely watched forecaster said that reserves, already low, could be wiped out before the next harvest.

title: Harnisch's Perfect Pitch
description: If William Styron's memoir of battling depression, ''Darkness Visible,'' were retold by a plain-spoken baseball player out of a Ring Lardner story, the voice might sound a little like this:

title: Blair or Major? Britain Is Choosing Today
description: Britain's election campaign came to an end tonight with the refashioned Labor Party of its young leader, Tony Blair, maintaining its substantial lead in the polls and threatening a rout of the long-dominant Conservative Party showing the wear of 18 years in office.

title: Almost Moribund Itself, a Courtesy Pause for Death
description: For generations, good manners have been one of the rusted rivets that held Southern culture in place. In the past, even if death itself needed to pass by, Southerners would say, ''After you.''

title: Outside Magazine Wins Reporting Award
description: An article on the boom in commercially guided expeditions to the summit of Mount Everest won the National Magazine Award for reporting yesterday for Outside magazine.

title: Man vs. Machine: A Rematch
description: The challenger, eight years old, is 6 feet 5 inches tall and weighs, oh, maybe 2,800 pounds. Despite the sound thrashing it took from the champion a year ago, it maintains the unrufflable demeanor of a machine, which of course it is. Right now it is sitting placidly in a stuffy room on the 35th floor of a Manhattan office tower.

title: 13 Going on 14, Not 40. Imagine That.
description: City children often make the least convincing comic characters. Writers tend to treat them, and the actors to play them, as miniature adults. You've seen them dozens of times in films and plays and certainly on television: articulate as college philosophy professors, sophisticated as Parisian couturiers, these children are often figments of the imagination of grown-ups who have not spent enough time with real ones.

title: Youth Is Key Target
description: To the Editor:

title: U.S. Threat Over Drug Is Lifted in California
description: A Federal judge here today forbade the Clinton Administration to carry out a plan to punish doctors who recommend marijuana to their patients under a new California law.

title: Elliott Merrick, 91; Wrote Stories Set in Labrador
description: Elliott Merrick, a writer, editor, teacher, farmer and sailor who distilled his experiences into acclaimed, enduring books about Labrador and northern Vermont, died on April 22 at his home in Asheville, N.C.. He was 91.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  YONAN, RAY
description: YONAN-Ray. In loving memory of our dear and beloved friend, Ray Ray. Your music will play in our hearts forever. We will miss you always. All Your Friends at Club Getaway

title: Rude Awakenings From 60's Dreams
description: The pungent scent of tear gas has been on my mind in recent months, accompanied by memories of droning helicopters, nervous National Guardsmen and the voice of Abbie Hoffman urging that something provocatively rude be done to a particular college president. The memories seem to arise from some eerie universe in which different laws are in effect.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLDMAN, S. HOWARD
description: GOLDMAN-S. Howard. The Brodsky Organization mourns the loss of a beloved friend and partner, Howard Goldman, and sends condolences to his wife, Dorothy, sons Jim Goldman and Jeff Goldman, and the rest of his family.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SMITH, MARY ALLEN GREGG
description: SMITH-Mary Allen Gregg on April 30. Beloved wife of the Rev. John C. Smith and mother of John Clark Smith and Alexandra Gregg Smith. A service will be held at 11:30 on May 2 at St. James Episcopal Church, Madison Avenue at 71 Street. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be sent to the Blue Ridge School in Dyke, VA. 22935.

title: Government Securities Prices Move Higher
description: Prices of Government securities made a another run at higher ground yesterday, fueled in part by investor optimism that a budget agreement could be reached. But the path higher was not direct, as economic reports first dragged prices lower, then provided the impetus for a rebound.

title: Familiar Victim Lets Torre Have A Grand Time
description: Dennis Martinez gained his first victory at Yankee Stadium 11 days before Joe Torre got his first victory anywhere as a manager. Last night, Torre made it 1,000 as the Yankees edged the Seattle Mariners, 3-2, and Martinez is still looking for No. 2 at Yankee Stadium.

title: Terrorism's Worldwide Toll Was High in 1996, U.S. Report Says
description: International terrorist attacks killed 311 people worldwide last year, one of the highest death tolls recorded, the State Department said today in its annual report on political terror.

title: 16 Black Employees Sue United Parcel Service
description: Sixteen black employees filed a discrimination suit today against United Parcel Service of America Inc., the nation's largest package-delivery company, saying they had been angered by racist graffiti and blocked promotion paths.

title: Yamaichi Securities Closing Several Offices
description: The Yamaichi Securities Company of Japan said yesterday that it would close offices in Milan, Berlin and Madrid by next March in preparation for a common European market. The operations will be transferred to the brokerage firm's London office, which will coordinate European business, a Yamaichi spokesman said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DIAMOND, REBECCA
description: DIAMOND-Rebecca. Age 92. Passed away on April 29. Beloved mother of Beverly and Marvin Morse. Sister to Betty Pinsly and Sylvia Lattman. Adored grandmother of Jonathan and Nancy, Elizabeth and Peter, Arnold and Cecilia, Robert and Lori. Cherished great grandmother of Laura, Evan, Casey, Joanna, Chelsea, David, Benjamin, Elyssa, Gabrielle and Jesse. Funeral services Thursday, May 1, at Nassau North, Great Neck, 1:30 P.M.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: Media More Likely to Show Women Talking About Romance Than at a Job, Study Says
description: Across a broad range of media, in films, in television, including commercials, and in magazines for teen-agers, women are more likely to be shown preoccupied with romance and personal appearance than they are having jobs or going to school, according to a new study released today by Children Now, a children's advocacy group based in Oakland, Calif.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BARKER, ELIZABETH
description: BARKER-Elizabeth. The officers and members of the AmeriCares Family deeply mourn the passing of their dear friend Elizabeth Barker. Her warmth and generosity gave comfort to countless others. Our sincere condolences to the Barker family.

title: Justice Dept. Links Debates to Dollars
description: New York City can require candidates for mayor, comptroller and public advocate to participate in debates as a condition for receiving public campaign dollars, the Justice Department has ruled.

title: Green, and Mostly Real
description: THE plants are so healthy in the newly renovated Enid A. Haupt Conservatory they look as if they are on steroids. There's a muscular-looking bromeliad with a six-foot flower. It suffered 30 years sitting in gravel in the old tropical house and never bloomed. But this spring, nestled in a rich soil mix in the pocket of a volcanic rock, constantly misted in the cool, computer-controlled climate of the fabricated upland rain forest -- bingo! -- Vriesa imperialis sent up a big rose and cream flower stalk.

title: Emotions Run High For Devils' Daneyko
description: He is the only member of the Devils who has played in all of the team's 90 playoff games. He has lived the rivalry against the Rangers more than anyone on this side of the Hudson. As a result, Ken Daneyko's dislike for the Blue Shirts is perhaps greater than that of any other Devil.

title: From the Ground Up
description: If the polls are correct, voters today will make Tony Blair the first Prime Minister from the Labor Party in nearly two decades. The Labor Party, like the Democrats in the United States, once represented workers in an industrial age but failed miserably to represent them in a new one.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KIRCHNER, ROBERT
description: KIRCHNER-Robert. On April 28, 1997. Beloved husband of Frieda. Precious brother of Marian and the late Virginia. Memorial service will be held at the Alley Pond Environmental Center, 228-06 Northern Boulevard, Douglaston, New York, on May 7, 1997 at 3 P.M.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: Basketball

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Growth Soars to 5.6% Rate With Inflation Modest

title: After Slayings, Anger Goes On Display
description: LORI CLAYTON scrawled the sign on a piece of her daughter's construction paper in a furious fit the morning after.

title: Doughnuts and Bagels Just Don't Compare
description: To the Editor:

title: A New Generation of Treatments For Cancer Will Soon Reach Market
description: The biotechnology industry is poised to deliver a host of cancer drugs in the next two to three years. Some of them promise to extend lives -- or at least make treatment more bearable than chemotherapy and radiation.

title: Peace, Love and Profits
description: To: Alan Gerry, chairman and C.E.O., Woodstock Nation Inc.

title: Man Charged in '63 Killing That Ex-Prostitute Couldn't Forget
description: On Thursday, Nov. 28, 1963, Lawrence J. Bart, a quiet, unremarkable man who worked as an executive in his family's printing business in the Flatiron District, missed Thanksgiving dinner. He had been at work the day before, and had never called to say he would not be coming. The next morning, his younger brother and a friend found him murdered in his Chelsea apartment, strangled with a dog chain, the blade of a steak knife imbedded in his chest.

title: Fighting Africa's Enemy Within
description: I WAS waiting outside a Cuban restaurant on Amsterdam Avenue when Wole Soyinka, the Nigerian Nobel laureate, stepped up behind me. ''You didn't recognize me,'' he said without expression. ''You looked right past me.''

title: U.N. Health Official, Opposed by U.S., Won't Seek Re-election
description: The director general of the World Health Organization, who has come under strong criticism in the United States, Europe and Africa, said today that he would not seek another term in office.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SILVERSTONE, BEATRICE, S.
description: SILVERSTONE-Beatrice, S. Of Pleasantville, NY, on Tuesday, April 29. Wife of the late Jonas. Beloved mother of Scott Silverstone and Stacy Curchack, loving grandmother of Jocelyn and Jonas Curchack, cherished motherin-law of Walter Curchack, and devoted sister of Arthur L. Schleifman. Services Thursday May 1, 11 am at Temple Beth El, 229 Bedford Rd, Chappaqua, NY.

title: Europe to Study Coke-Carlsberg Deal
description: Europe's antitrust regulators will start a full investigation of a proposed joint venture by the Coca-Cola Company and Carlsberg A/S to bottle and distribute Coke products, industry sources said today.

title: Computer Associates Presents Dilbert
description: The popular comic strip ''Dilbert'' is now being featured in advertisements running in The Wall Street Journal.

title: Accounts
description: * Cellnet Data Systems Inc., San Carlos, Calif., to Grey Advertising, San Francisco, as the first agency to handle advertising for the wireless communications network. Billings were estimated at $3 million.

title: Struggling To Carry On The Graham Tradition
description: The sounds of music and pounding feet filled the air the other day at the Martha Graham headquarters on the Upper East Side. A class was in session in one studio, a rehearsal in another. In a third studio, a longtime Graham lead dancer coached a younger company member for a forthcoming engagement.

title: The Price Factor
description: To the Editor:

title: Don't Filter the Law
description: To the Editor:

title: Ellen and 'Ellen' Come Out
description: After all the hype and exploitation surrounding the actress Ellen DeGeneres and Ellen Morgan, the woman she plays on television, it was easy to lose sight of what actually was taking place on ABC last night. The ''coming out'' of the title character on ''Ellen'' was accomplished with wit and poignancy, which should help defuse the antagonism toward homosexuals still prevalent in society.

title: From the Battery to the Bronx, New York Seeks Corporate Sponsors
description: In an ambitious bid to turn New York City into a brand name, the Giuliani administration has chosen a leading marketing agency to help the city get corporate sponsors for things like playgrounds, snack bars, litter baskets and even police patrol cars, officials said yesterday.

title: Prosecution Witness Says She Defended McVeigh Out of Fear
description: Lori Fortier, a principal witness for the prosecution in the Oklahoma City bombing trial, stood her ground today during four hours of cross-examination by Stephen Jones, the lead defense lawyer for Timothy J. McVeigh.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: HOCKEY

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LITTELL, BLAINE
description: LITTELL-Blaine. In Stonington, Ct, April 29th, Blaine Littell, correspondent and producer for CBS News, ABC News, and NBC News, author and professor at Boston University. Beloved husband of Penelope, loving father of Philip of Los Angeles, CA, Peter of Sunderland, MA, Anita Repp of Wilton, CT, and Eliakim of Schenectady, NY, and seven grandchildren. Brother of Alisa Storrow and Philip Littell of Stonington, CT and Walter Littell of Somerville, MA. Memorial Service will be held at Union Church, Tyringham, MA on Saturday at 12 noon. Arrangements by The Dinoto Funeral Home, Mystic Ct.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BERG, BENJAMIN
description: BERG-Benjamin, on April 29, 1997. Beloved husband of the late Rheta. Devoted father of Jay and Lennie. Adored uncle and great-uncle. U.S. Naval veteran, World War II. Services 12 Noon, I.J. Morris, 46 Greenwich St., Hempstead, NY. Interment New Montefiore Cemetery, West Babylon, NY.

title: Sonics Sputtering Again In Round 1
description: The 3-point line may be the ruin of him either that, or Shawn Kemp's clock radio -- but, then again, George Karl has struck this sorry pose before. His Seattle SuperSonics have again saved their worst for the first round, and four crises in four years confirms there is a hole in their infrastructure.

title: Despairing Refugees Start to Stream Home to Rwanda, With a New Set of Fears
description: An airlift to send home thousands of Rwandan refugees trapped in Zaire got under way today, while thousands more of the ragged refugees, uncertain and terrified, were emerging from the rain forest and gathering in the camp near this jungle town.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DUBB, FAITH
description: DUBB-Faith, on April 21, 1997. Beloved wife of Allen. Adored mother of Marjorie, Michael, Joanne. Precious grandmother of Robby, Stacy, Caryn, Steven, Tracy, Lindsey, David, Adam and Carly. Sister to Harry and Allen Selinger. Interment April 23, 1997 at New Montifiore Cemetery.

title: Knicks' Latest Celebrity Ends Silent Treatment
description: He shot down his former team on Monday, but did not feel the need to discuss it with anyone afterward. His numbers have improved markedly in the post-season, but he says it is only perception.

title: Republicans Finance WIC Based on New Data
description: To the Editor:

title: B.A.T. Pretax Profit Hurt by Stronger Pound
description: B.A.T. Industries P.L.C. said yesterday that its pretax profit rose $:1 million, to $:591 million ($963 million), in the first quarter, held back by the stronger pound and lackluster earnings in a British insurance business.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROMER, MURRAY M.
description: ROMER-Murray M., cherished husband, beloved father and adored grandfather died at the age of seventy on April 27, 1997, at Stamford Hospital. He had coronary artery disease. He held a Bachelor's Degree in Aeronautical Engineering and a Master's Degree in Industrial Engineeringboth from New York University. Murray was a graphic arts executive and consultant for nearly five decades, whose most recent position was Sr. Vice President, Manufacturing and DistributionDiamandis Communications, Inc. He was President of the Printing Industries of America, and his accomplishments included the printing industry Man of the Year Award from the American Jewish Congress; membership in the Ash Khan Society (honor society of outstanding publishers and printers); and the Gravure Cylinder Society. He served on the Executive Board of the Graphic Arts Research and Engineering Council and was a Senior Member of the American Institute of Industrial Engineers. Mr. Romer was Past President of Congreation Agudath Sholom, and a longstanding member of their Executive Committee and Board of Directors. Other civic positions included: Chairman of Dayton, Ohio's CORE committee (chartered by the President of the United States); and President and Chairman, Community Return Program (sponsored by the Council of Churches and Synagogues). His interests and hobbies were varied. He was a member of the Masonic Order of the Scottish Rite, a jazz clarinet and saxophone musician, a breeder of Weimaraners and a salmon fisherman. Mr. Romer is survived by his wife, Lila; the North Carolina RomersLewis, Betsy, Megan Faye and Samuel Bernard; and the Manhattan Rosenfields - Susan, Joseph, Shoshana Tanya and Shirah Chaya. Memorials to: Stamford Hospital, American Heart Association and Chabad Lubavitch of Stamford.

title: Pataki Supports Rent Protection for Middle-Income Tenants
description: In another indication that he is seeking a middle ground in the fierce battle over state rent laws, Gov. George E. Pataki said today that he agreed with Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato that rent protections should be maintained for middle-income tenants, though both men have failed to explain just how they would do that.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NIV, MOLLY
description: NIV-Molly, Dr. The loving mother of Nava and Gideon is also survived by her sister Zika and her two grandsons, Caleb and Nathaniel. She fought for Israel's independence in the Irgun and became a doctor, practicing originally as a pediatrician and later as a psychiatrist. She authored a book about existential psychiatry titled ''Reason in Madness''. Funeral services will be held Friday, May 2, 11:00AM at the Gannon Funeral Home, 152 East 28th Street, NYC

title: Woman Sentenced to Life For Ax Killing of Husband
description: Quietly insisting ''I did not do that,'' Rita Gluzman was sentenced today to life in prison for killing her husband, Yakov, a prominent microbiologist, with an ax after he told her he was divorcing her for another woman.

title: Barney's Case: Wait, See, Wait Some More
description: Well over a year into the acrimonious and litigious bankruptcy of Barney's, the reorganization and possible sale of the retailer appears to be far from coming to a close. That was underscored yesterday when people involved in the case said that the judge handling the bankruptcy case favored the installation of a mediator to oversee the process.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SILVER, SALLY (NEE SARAH GANY)
description: SILVER-Sally (nee Sarah Gany), on April 29th from a weak heart despite a tenacious will. Born on April 14, 1918, she lived until the end ''at age 27'' in Riverdale, and is survived by many siblings, a loving husband of fifty-six years Al Silver, children Victor Silver and Sharon Silver-Regent, grandchildren Stacey Simensky, Nicole Regent, and Rebecca Silver, and great-grandchildren Amanda and Jamie Simensky. All will dearly miss her quirky charm, straightforwardness, baked sweets, and lemon soup. In lieu of flowers send contributions to American Heart Association.

title: Corrections
description: A chart in Business Day on Tuesday with an article about Louis A. Simpson of Geico Inc., who is expected to take over investing for its parent company, Berkshire Hathaway, misstated the compounded annual return from 1980 to 1996 on the stock investments of Geico and Berkshire, and the article misstated the period they covered. Geico's annual return was 23.2 percent, not 24.66 percent, and Berkshire's was 25.6 percent, not 26.77 percent. The period was 17 years, not 18.

title: Judge Imposes Fines Over Lead Paint Removal
description: Angered by what he called New York City's repeated failure to enforce laws requiring the removal of lead paint, a judge has threatened to jail the Housing Commissioner.

title: 3 Agencies Get Foreign Accounts
description: Overseas offices of Bates Worldwide, McCann-Erickson Worldwide and TBWA International were awarded accounts.

title: Joint Venture Delays Chip-Plant Venture
description: The Tohoku Semiconductor Corporation, a joint venture between the Toshiba Corporation and Motorola Inc. plans to delay its investment in a computer chip plant because of the sluggish semiconductor market, a Tohoku Semiconductor official said yesterday.

title: Irma Wilkinson, 91, Collector and Donor Of Islamic Artworks
description: Irma Bezold Wilkinson, a benefactor and former staff member of the Metropolitan Museum of Art, died on April 24 at the Noble Horizons Nursing Home in Salisbury, Conn. She was 91 and had homes in Sharon, Conn., and Manhattan.

title: New York, Withholding
description: To the Editor:

title: Dow Advances by 46.96 to Top 7,000 Again
description: The stock market staged another broad rally yesterday, buttressed by rising bond prices and renewed investor optimism.

title: After Impasse, Senate Confirms Clinton's Choice for Labor Post
description: After months of delay, the Senate today approved Alexis Herman as Secretary of Labor. Her nomination, held up initially over her role in campaign fund-raising, was cleared after a compromise with the White House ended an impasse over union labor on Federal contracts.

title: Rate of Expansion Slackens in Region
description: The New York City regional economy continued to expand in April, but at a significantly slower pace than was the case through most of last year, a national business group said yesterday.

title: INGRAM MICRO BUYING UNIT OF INTELLIGENT ELECTRONICS
description: Ingram Micro Inc. said yesterday that it was buying Intelligent Electronics Inc.'s computer distribution business for $78 million in cash and assumed debt. Ingram, based in Santa Ana, Calif., is the world's largest distributor of personal computers and accessories, with $12 billion in revenue last year and operations in 19 countries. The acquisition will add $3 billion in annual sales, analysts said. Intelligent Electronics, based in Exton, Pa., said the sale of its Reseller Network Division would allow it to focus on its business of selling directly to computer equipment users. Ingram's shares were unchanged at $22.75; Intelligent Electronics' shares rose 31.25 cents, to $3.

title: INSIDE
description: House Backs Adoption Bill

title: U.S. Is Investigating Bids For Cellular Phone Licenses
description: The Justice Department is investigating allegations that bidders for cellular telephone licenses may have illegally manipulated recent wireless spectrum auctions, officials said today.

title: CHRONICLE
description: DAN RATHER, the ''CBS Evening News'' anchor, will give the keynote address in observance of World Press Freedom Day at the United Nations General Assembly tomorrow, and he says the news is not good.

title: Motive a Puzzle in a High School Murder
description: In so many ways, Nielsa Mason and the high school classmate accused of beating her to death were two peas from the same pod: forwards on the basketball court, speedsters on the track team, good students from good families, nice-looking, popular 16-year-old sophomores who might have had futures well beyond the diminishing farmland and boarded-up factories of Cumberland County.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GRAINE, MICHAEL S.
description: GRAINE-Michael S. May 3, 1930April 29, 1997. Son of the late Dr. Al and Rosalind Graine. Burial at Washington Cemetery on Friday, May 2, at 3 P.M. Leaves a family he loved.

title: Stalin, Mon Amour: Ideological Love
description: The rendition of ''You're the Top'' that congratulates Stalin's killer, with a trio that includes Nikita Khrushchev dancing happily in the background, is one of many reasons to regard ''Children of the Revolution'' as something different. Clearly Peter Duncan's arch, zany comedy is not the usual post-mortem on the collapse of Soviet Communism and the disillusionment of ideologues around the world.

title: A Lab Breeds a Mighty Mouse, With a Variety of Implications
description: A new breed of mice with more than twice the normal amount of muscle may lead to meatier chickens and cows and, eventually, new treatments for people with muscle diseases, researchers are reporting.

title: Manufacturer Is Told to Pay
description: A glass and plastics manufacturer and his Cumberland County shipyard were ordered on Tuesday to pay $40 million to settle charges by the Internal Revenue Service accusing them of filing fraudulent tax returns from 1979 to 1990.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ADLER, MARVIN
description: ADLER-Marvin. Devoted husband of Frances, loving father of Helen and Stuart (Merav). Dearest brother of Keva, cherished grandfather of Etamar. Services Friday, 12 noon. Parkside Chapels, Queens Boulevard at 66th Avenue, Forest Hills. Contributions to The Heart Association would be greatly appreciated.

title: Chief Justice of Illinois Faces Censure in Misconduct Case
description: As he was being handcuffed for resisting arrest after he was stopped for speeding last year, James H. Heiple said imperiously to the police officers, ''Do you know who I am?''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HERMAN, SEYMOUR
description: HERMAN - Seymour. Devoted husband of Frances. Beloved father of the late Patricia. Services Thursday, 10AM, at Riverside Nassau North Chapel, 55 North Station Plaza, Great Neck, opposite LIRR.

title: Anheuser-Kirin Venture
description: Anheuser-Busch, the maker of Budweiser beer, has entered a joint venture with the Kirin Brewery Company to market Kirin Lager, Kirin Ichiban and Kirin Light in the United States. Terms were not disclosed. Anheuser-Busch, of St. Louis, said it would own 10 percent of the new company, to be based in Los Angeles, while Kirin, Japan's main brewery, will own 90 percent. Anheuser-Busch and Kirin have been partners in the Japanese market since 1993.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MARKS, JOSEPH
description: MARKS-Joseph, on April 26 at his home in Kalamazoo, MI. Joe was born June 18, 1922 in NY, NY, the son of Nathan and Lillian (Duklauer) Marks. He was a pilot in the 308th Bomb Group, 425th Squad in W.W. II. A graduate of CCNY he went on to spend 40 years in corporate finance before retiring in 1985. His many passions included reading, The New York Times crosswords, tennis, golf, acting, fishing, sculpting, pottery, and traveling around the world. He will be missed but not forgotten by his son Bruce Marks; 2 grandchildren Justin and Andrew Marks; his sister Betty Phillips; his former wife Joanne (Hauptman) Marks; his extended family Debra and Leslie Pullen and many loving and caring friends. According to his wishes, a cremation has already taken place. A private memorial service will be held at a later date. For a more lasting memorial please consider Kalamazoo Civic Players.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-13

title: Conseco Planning to Acquire Colonial Penn
description: Conseco Inc., continuing a string of acquisitions that helped its earnings more than double in the first quarter, said today that it had agreed to buy a unit of the Leucadia National Corporation for $460 million.

title: Jury Clears Man, 70, of Abuse Charges
description: Thirty-five years after Burton N. Pugach was convicted of blinding his girlfriend by having lye thrown in her face, a Queens jury acquitted him yesterday of charges that he had sexually abused and threatened to kill another woman after she ended a five-year affair with him.

title: Doughnuts and Bagels Just Don't Compare
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  LAST, AARON
description: LAST-Aaron. There can be no closure until your tennis friends say the game is over. It's over, Aaron. Thanks for bringing the balls.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: E.I. DU PONT DE NEMOURS & CO., Wilmington, Del., the chemicals and plastic giant, said its directors had voted to increase its quarterly dividend by 11 percent, to 63 cents a share, while its stockholders had approved a 2-for-1 stock split.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STEIN, MELVIN
description: STEIN-Melvin. Beloved husband of Elaine. Devoted father of Stuart M. and Roger H. Adored father-inlaw of Roni. Loving brother of Toby Rozen. Cherished grandfather of Jason W. and Alissa A. Stein. Service 10 A.M. Friday, at Lincoln Park Jewish Center, South Central Avenue, Yonkers. Contributions to Joseph F. Stein Foundation Inc., 30 Glenn Street, White Plains, New York 10603, appreciated.

title: Many Stores Found to Sell Cigarettes to Minors
description: Last week, a lanky 17-year-old with a silky smooth face, turned-around baseball cap and knapsack visited Liberty International, a convenience store in the Bronx, to buy cigarettes and test a state law that forbids the sale of tobacco to minors.

title: Long lines outside the best colleges are likely to get longer.
description: IT'S the season for choosing colleges and, by tradition, time to lament the astounding cost of America's elite private institutions. Astounding is no exaggeration: tuition at the Ivy League schools and their competitors has increased fivefold in the last two decades, nearly double the rate of inflation.

title: Netscape Chief To Forgo Salary
description: The Netscape Communications Corporation said yesterday that its chief executive, James L. Barksdale, had chosen not to receive any salary or cash bonuses for 1997 because the company's stock price had fallen by two-thirds in the last year.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LOEW, CURT M.
description: LOEW-Curt M. Of White Plains, New York. Husband of Melita C. Loew. Father of George LoewAliserti and Vivien Susan Kaslin. Grandfather of Tamara and Christian. Funeral Service Thursday, 12 Noon, at the Ballard-Durand Funeral Home, 2 Maple Avenue, White Plains, N.Y. Friends may call at the funeral home Thursday 11 A.M. until 12 Noon. Memorial contributions to O.P.U.S. C/O St. Andrew's Church, 101 North Central Avenue, Hartsdale, New York 10530, would be appreciated.

title: No Headline
description: ''If I do what I think is right and I don't have a job, too bad.''

title: Something Brahmsy, Please
description: Putting together a program for the Philadelphia Orchestra's coming European tour, Wolfgang Sawallisch had the excellent idea of asking Wolfgang Rihm to write something to go with Brahms. What emerged was ''Ernster Gesang,'' or ''Serious Song,'' a title that not only alludes to one of Brahms's late works but also describes what is going on here. The music is slow, cloudy, pensive and Brahmsishly dark, scored for an orchestra from which all the upper instruments have evaporated.

title: MERFIN ACCEPTS REVISED TAKEOVER BID OF $140 MILLION
description: Merfin International Inc. accepted a sweetened takeover offer yesterday of $140 million (United States), including assumed debt, from the Buckeye Cellulose Corporation. The latest proposal, valued at $7 (Canadian) a share, comes after Merfin's board rejected a bid of $6 (Canadian) a share last month. Merfin, based in Vancouver, British Columbia, had said Buckeye was not offering enough for the company, which makes material used in feminine-hygiene and adult-incontinence products. Buckeye, based in Memphis, makes specialty pulps for disposable diapers, plastic films and cigarette filters.

title: The Only Real Rivalry Resumes
description: WHEN asked for one snapshot of the Rangers-Devils duel in the Eastern Conference finals of the 1994 Stanley Cup playoffs, most people mention Mark Messier's three goals in Game 6 that kept the Rangers alive. Or they think of Stephane Matteau's winning goal in double overtime in Game 7 that enabled the Rangers to go on to win the cup.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  LACOVARA, PETER J., M.D.
description: LACOVARA-Peter J., M.D. May 1, 1992. Deepest gratitude and love always. Your Family

title: People
description: * David Arnold, New York manager for advertising at Town & Country magazine, New York, published by the Hearst Magazines division of the Hearst Corp., was promoted to the long-vacant position of advertising director.

title: John Beal, 87, Actor In Films and Theater
description: John Beal, an actor whose long career embraced film, theater and television, died on Saturday in Santa Cruz, Calif. He was 87.

title: U.S.-Europe Pact on Meat Inspection Rules
description: Negotiators for the United States and the European Union reached a last-minute agreement today on meat inspection standards, according to Paul Drazek, the United States Agriculture Department's top trade negotiator.

title: New Chairman at Comsat
description: The Comsat Corporation said today that C. J. Silas, 64, had resigned as chairman and director for health reasons after open-heart surgery. Comsat, the satellite communications company, said it had named Edwin I. Colodny, 70, to replace Mr. Silas. Mr. Colodny, a Comsat director, was chairman of the USAir Group, now known as the US Airways Group, until 1992.

title: Bowe Retires From Ring at 29
description: He was pummeled twice by Andrew Golota. Then he washed out of Marine boot camp. Now Riddick Bowe, a former heavyweight champion, is quitting boxing.

title: Plan to Lower Power Bills
description: State regulators approved a plan yesterday that would require utilities to lower their electrical bills by 5 percent to 10 percent by October 1998, officials said.

title: Baerga Springs To Life For Mets
description: Once upon a time, Carlos Baerga might have treated a two-hit game as an afterthought. Two hits probably meant some infielder robbed him of a third. But when you are 28 and trying to reverse a professional free-fall, coming off the bench and getting two hits has a deeper meaning. Hearing a chorus of boos, Baerga had a single and a double and scored the go-ahead run in the Mets' 6-2 victory over San Diego last night at Shea Stadium.

title: South Korean Company Cuts Costs and Workers
description: Ssangyong Group is merging three units and selling one, aiming to cut costs as some of South Korea's biggest companies fight for survival. Quoting Ssangyong officials, the news agency Yonyap said the concern, which is based in Seoul, would cut the work force at its headquarters by 20 percent and reduce the number of Ssangyong's companies to 21 from 25.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JOHNSON, UNA E.
description: JOHNSON-Una E. The Board of Trustees and the Staff of the Brooklyn Museum of Art record with deep sorrow the passing of their long time colleague and good friend Una E. Johnson and extend their condolences to her family. Ms. Johnson joined the Museum in 1936 as Assistant Curator of Prints and Drawings. In 1941 she was appointed Curator, a position she held until her retirement in 1969. Responsible for the growth of the Museum's collection of 20th century American prints, she also created the National Print Exhibition and organized sixteen during her tenure. Her memory will endure through these and her many other invaluable contributions.

title: Russia Is True to West, in Its Fashion
description: When President Boris N. Yeltsin wants to play the nationalist card he simply rolls out the red carpet for the United States' most vexing rivals and bitter adversaries.

title: Makoto Namba, 46, Top Sailor; Led Japan's America's Cup Bid
description: Makoto Namba, a world-class match racer and an America's Cup skipper who became the first Japanese sailor to break into the top 10 in the world ranking, fell overboard during an ocean race on April 23 and is presumed lost at sea off Japan. He was 46.

title: Auto Researcher Bought by K-III
description: The K-III Communications Corporation has acquired Intellichoice Inc., a research concern that publishes information about the automotive market. Terms were not disclosed.

title: WHX AMENDS OFFER TO INCLUDE ALL SHARES OF DYNAMICS
description: The WHX Corporation, which is making a hostile bid to take over the Dynamics Corporation of America, said yesterday that it had amended its tender offer to include all of Dynamics' shares. WHX had previously offered $45 a share for as much as 17 percent of Dynamics, which is based in Greenwich, Conn., and makes electronic parts. WHX, based in New York, is a holding company. WHX originally said it was seeking only 17 percent of Dynamics shares to prevent Dynamics' poison-pill defenses from kicking in. WHX said its amended offer was conditional on Dynamics canceling its poison pill.

title: Giuliani Chooses Democrat to Run With Him
description: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani has decided to ask a little-known Democratic Assemblyman from Coney Island to run with him on a political ticket, a strategy designed to enhance the Mayor's appeal among Democrats and in Brooklyn, senior aides said yesterday. The Assemblyman, Jules Polonetsky, would run for Public Advocate on the Republican and Liberal lines.

title: Off to Camp Without Wrecking the Budget
description: WITH summer right around the corner, many parents in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut are beginning to panic about finding a camp for their children. If money is tight, the task is even more daunting: summer camps can cost thousands, and many that offer financial aid have already given out this year's allotment.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  ACHSEN, DAVE
description: ACHSEN-Dave. 5/1/11-8/2-72. A loving family remembrance on the 86th anniversary of his birth. Pearl, Norma, Bonnie, Andy

title: Lucent Wins Supply Deal
description: Lucent Technologies Inc. said yesterday that it had won a multiple-year contract to provide as much as $1 billion of wireless telecommunications equipment to the U S West Communications Group. Lucent, which split from the AT&T Corporation last year, initially would provide $500 million of equipment for personal communications services over three to five years for a network that would be built throughout U S West's 14-state region. Lucent later could provide as much as another $500 million in such equipment. Lucent won the deal over Northern Telecom Ltd. of Canada.

title: Captain Marvel, the Dodgers and a Catbird Seat
description: SNOW IN AUGUST

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROTER, LOUIS
description: ROTER-Louis. Riverdale Jewish Center extends profound condolences to Frieda Kabak on the loss of her beloved father, Louis Roter. May the family be comforted amongst the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Jonathan I. Rosenblatt, Rabbi Tobias B. Schapiro, President

title: Clinton and Gingrich View Hong Kong as Test for China
description: President Clinton pronounced himself ''quite satisfied'' with the assurances on the future of Hong Kong he received today from the Chinese Foreign Minister, Qian Qichen, but said he was waiting to see if China's words matched its actions.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SPRUNG, JEROME S.
description: SPRUNG-Jerome S. Suddenly and tragically on April 27. Beloved and cherished husband of Shirley, devoted father of Sara and Daniel, dear brother of Ileen Rogers, adoring grandfather of Juliet. Service 1 PM Sunday, Stephen Wise Free Synagogue, 30 West 68 St. Interment private. Contributions to American Cancer Society would be appreciated. For information call Plaza Memorial, 212-769-4400.

title: Pentagon to Name Adviser on Gulf Illnesses
description: A White House panel said today that the Government was still not doing enough to investigate the cause of health problems reported among gulf war veterans, criticism that helped prompt the Pentagon to appoint former Senator Warren B. Rudman as a special adviser on the issue.

title: Red Lobster USA Sets Account Review
description: Red Lobster USA, the seafood restaurant chain owned and operated by Darden Restaurants, said yesterday that it had placed in review the creative and media planning portions of its account, with billings estimated at $70 million to $90 million. The account had been handled for 12 years by Grey Advertising in New York.

title: J.P. Snyder, 71; Used Satellites to Map Earth
description: John P. Snyder, a chemical engineer who made cartography history by developing a set of mathematical equations to convert images of the Earth taken from space into accurate maps, died on Monday in Olney, Md. He was 71.

title: France Linked to Defense of Mobutu
description: France has conducted a covert military operation to prop up Mobutu Sese Seko, the Zairian leader, as rebels advanced across the country, according to American intelligence reports and an official in a company that French intelligence used as cover for the operation.

title: Something From Space Is Biting
description: It used to be, the Russians are coming, the Russians are coming. Now it's the germs (or the viruses or the bacteria) are coming. Humans, the poor darlings, apparently love to be scared out of their wits. The latest disaster specimen is ''Robin Cook's 'Invasion,' '' an NBC two-parter that is hoping to cook up, so to speak, national willies on Sunday and Monday evening.

title: Change the Clock
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  CIRKER, MINETTE
description: CIRKER-Minette. May 2. Happy Birthday. All sweet memories remain in my mind. I miss you. ''Rest, my sweet Darling'', Stanley

title: Texaco Completes Sale of Oilfield Stake
description: Texaco Inc. has completed the sale of a 15 percent stake in its Captain oil and natural gas field in the North Sea to the South Korea Petroleum Development Corporation.

title: Airplane Incidents Climbing Sharply In New York Area
description: Incidents in which planes have come too close together in flight have risen sharply in the New York City area, and some managers at the New York Air Route Traffic Control Center have suggested that air traffic should be cut back sharply.

title: It's a Mod, Mod, Mod, Mod World
description: Only in the mind of Mike Myers is the swinging, go-go private eye a figure in need of reinventing. Nonetheless, Mr. Myers throws himself wholeheartedly into the job of bringing a desperately hip, sweetly funny throwback named Austin Powers to life. Austin returns in 1997 after 30 years' worth of cryogenic freezing, and his ruffled shirt and silly grin remain unchanged. Don't blame yourself for never having noticed he was gone.

title: Base Varsity Slots on Demand, Not Gender
description: To the Editor:

title: Thou Shalt Not Ask Why
description: The Book of Job gets a Hollywood makeover in ''Commandments,'' an amusing and unpredictable new romantic comedy that taps the Bible for everything from a run through the Ten Commandments to a reprise of Jonah in the whale.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BANNER, SY
description: BANNER-Sy. Loving husband of Dorothy. Cherished son of Anne Banner. Loving father of Vicki, Lori and Jonathan. Dear brother of Harvey. Adored grandfather. Service today 10 AM at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 21 West Broad Street, Mt. Vernon, New York.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COOPER, ELLEN F. (C.C.R.N.A.)
description: COOPER-Ellen F. (C.C.R.N.A.) of Long Beach, Long Island formerly of Albertson, Long Island on April 30, 1997. Beloved daughter of Frances E. and the late Frank J. Cooper. Devoted sister of Walter, Ann Cooper-Williams, Peter, Grace Schroff, Veronica CooperFry, Terry Auletta, Gregory and the late Frank. Also survived by a large family and many friends. Visiting Friday, 3-5 and 7-10 PM at Weigand Bros. Funeral Home at 49 Hillside Ave., Williston Park, Long Island. Funeral Mass Sat., 9:45 AM, St. Aidan's R.C. Church, Williston Park, Long Island.

title: N.A.S.D. Fines Prudential on Disclosure
description: Prudential Securities and a former broker have been ordered to pay a Houston customer $813,000, including $500,000 in punitive damages, for failing to disclose that a company recommended by the broker had given him free stock.

title: Home Video
description: In 1919, a polo match was in progress at the Douglas Fairbanks estate near Hollywood when out of the azure a Spad appeared, flown by a barnstorming daredevil and World War I ace named William Wellman. Landing smartly on the grounds, the young pilot, a rakishly handsome fellow in military uniform with all decorations, reintroduced himself to Fairbanks. They had met when Wellman was a schoolboy hockey player in Boston. How about helping him get a job in the movies?

title: Intensive English
description: To the Editor:

title: Art in Review
description: James Hyde

title: Messier Brushes Aside All Issues but the Cup
description: This time, he made no guarantees. Not yet.

title: 2 Guilty in Murder of Bronx Policeman
description: Two men were convicted yesterday in the murder of a Bronx police officer, Kevin Gillespie, whose killing set off a fiery political debate over whether a third man, the gunman, should face the death penalty.

title: Racism Found Aboard Government Dredge
description: An investigation by the Department of Defense has concluded that black deckhands on a Mississippi River dredge operated here by the United States Army Corps of Engineers have for years endured racial slurs and discriminatory personnel practices by white authorities on the boat.

title: Sparring With Ms. Reno
description: What is the difference between the ''appearance of a conflict of interest'' and the ''potential for an actual conflict of interest''? To Attorney General Janet Reno, the difference is big enough to keep her from seeking the appointment of a special counsel to investigate possibly corrupt fund-raising practices in President Clinton's re-election campaign last year. Both law and tradition, Ms. Reno contended in testimony before the Senate Judiciary Committee this week, say that a ''potential'' conflict would suffice, but that the mere ''appearance'' of a conflict would not.

title: Quentin C. Crommelin, Retired Navy Captain and Pilot, 78
description: Quentin C. Crommelin, a retired Navy captain who was the last of five Alabama brothers who created a sibling sensation as Navy aviators in World War II, died on Monday at a hospital in Montgomery, Ala. He was 78 and lived on the family plantation outside Wetumpka.
