title: Bo Widerberg, 66, Director Of 'Elvira Madigan,' Is Dead
description: Bo Widerberg, the lyrical, socially conscious Swedish director of the popular ''Elvira Madigan'' and three films nominated for Academy Awards, died on Thursday at a hospital in Angelholm in southern Sweden. He was 66.

title: PLATINUM TECHNOLOGY SAYS IT WILL ELIMINATE 400 JOBS
description: Platinum Technology Inc., a producer of system software, said yesterday that it would cut 400 jobs and take a charge of $40 million to $45 million in the second quarter to pay for the reduction. The company, based in Oakbrook Terrace, Ill., said it was eliminating redundant positions resulting from the 40 acquisitions it had made in the last two years. The cuts equal about 9 percent of the work force. Platinum Technology has lost money for nine consecutive quarters. The company's stock rose 50 cents yesterday, to $12.50, on Nasdaq.

title: Old Men, Young Brides
description: To the Editor:

title: Reinventing Blather
description: To the Editor:

title: Art in Review
description: Fairfield Porter

title: Dynamo Who Left Her Mark as Curator
description: SHE looked more like an elegant lady from an earlier era than the driven curator she was. Trained for polite society and impeccably dressed, she wore broad-brimmed ''coolie'' hats designed for her by a friend, walked to work every day from her home at the Carlyle Hotel and punctiliously answered every letter the day she received it.

title: A Device to Stay Alert: Will the Smell Sell?
description: Anyone who has logged many hours behind the wheel has most likely had to fight off drowsiness with stops for coffee, fresh air or something to eat.

title: Lease for Office Space
description: In a deal that involves almost $5 million in tax incentives from New York City, Information Builders Inc., a software company, has leased 210,000 square feet of Manhattan office space for its new headquarters.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SPRUNG, JEROME S.
description: SPRUNG-Jerome S. Suddenly and tragically on April 27. Beloved and cherished husband of Shirley, devoted father of Sara and Daniel, dear brother of Ilene Rogers, adoring grandfather of Juliet. Service 1 PM Sunday, Stephen Wise Free Synagogue, 30 West 68 St. Interment private. Contributions to American Cancer Society would be appreciated. For information call Plaza Memorial, 212-769-4400.

title: U.S. and Russia Still Mired in Talks on Links to NATO
description: Just weeks away from a target of May 27 for completing a NATO-Russia charter, the United States and Russia remain far apart over fundamental military issues.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEV, DR. MEIR
description: LEV-Dr. Meir. Riverdale Jewish Center mourns the loss of its member, Dr. Meir Lev. May the family be comforted amongst the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Jonathan I. Rosenblatt, Rabbi Tobias B. Schapiro, President

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ZIRIN, KATE
description: ZIRIN-Kate. Of Palm Beach, FL, February 1, 1997. Devoted wife of Morris G. Zirin. Beloved mother of James D. Zirin. Loving grandmother of Anne E. and David M. Zirin. Dear mother-in-law of Marlene Hess. Memorial service Friday, May 2, 11:30 AM, at Temple Emanu-El, Fifth Ave and 65 St.

title: The Play Of Childs Is Steady For Knicks
description: Before the playoffs began, Chris Childs said he would be ''like a kid in a candy store'' in his first trip to the National Basketball Association's post-season.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GIANNETTA, IDA C.
description: GIANNETTA-Ida C., a 53-year member of CBS, Radio Division, on May 1, 1997. Beloved sister of Catherine, Lucy and Carmella. Devoted aunt, grand-aunt and godmother. Reposing at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave. at 81st St., today, Friday, May 2, 2-5 & 7-9 PM. Mass of Christian Burial, St. Raymond's R.C. Church, 1759 Castle Hill Ave. and Tremont Ave., Bronx, NY, Saturday, 9:45 A.M. In lieu of flowers, a donation in her memory to the American Heart Assoc. would be appreciated.

title: INSIDE METRO
description: PLANS FOR THE COLISEUM -- A look at the plans to develop the Coliseum site in midtown, now that five finalists have been chosen for the project. Metro Business, B5.

title: Good Guys Like Kangaroos And Bad Guys . . . Don't Ask
description: Maybe it's time to expand the ratings system to include the designation P, as in painful to watch. Movies like ''Warriors of Virtue'' inspire that sort of thinking. ''Warriors of Virtue'' is 10 cents' worth of comic book buried under a few million dollars' worth of effort that might be considered worthwhile if tedium were a marketable commodity.

title: New York Charges Hirschfeld With Evasion of Income Taxes
description: Abraham Hirschfeld, the real estate developer, repeat political candidate and onetime short-term owner of The New York Post in 1993, was charged yesterday with multiple counts of state income tax fraud.

title: An Operating Chief to Calm The Ferment At Fidelity
description: The turmoil at Fidelity Investments moved up the corporate ladder yesterday as James C. Curvey was named chief operating officer and chairman of the company's operating committee, putting him in charge of day-to-day business and making him second in command to Fidelity's chairman, Edward C. Johnson 3d.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PASSARETTI, ANTHONY J.
description: PASSARETTI-Anthony J. Beloved husband of Julia (nee Bonfiglio) father of Anthony Jr., Michael and Gerard. Father-in-law of Anna and Patricia. Grandfather of Andrew, Joanne, Jessica and Julianna Smith. Great-grandfather of Travis Smith. U.S. Army W.W. II. Retired Treasury Agent and N.Y.C. DA's Office. Member of Watergate Prosecution Force. Reposing at Martin A. Gleason Funeral Home, 149-20 Northern Blvd, Flushing, NY. Mass of Christian Burial, Mary's Nativity RC Church, Monday, 10:30AM. Visiting Friday, Saturday, Sunday 2-5, 7-10PM.

title: Base Varsity Slots on Demand, Not Gender
description: To the Editor:

title: Fairfax Shares Rise On Takeover Rumors
description: The shares of John Fairfax Holdings Ltd., a newspaper publisher, rose yesterday amid speculation that the Australian Government would relax media ownership laws, allowing Australia's richest man, Kerry Packer, to buy it. Stock in Fairfax, which publishes The Australian Financial Review and The Sydney Morning Herald, rose 10 cents, to $3.27 (Australian).

title: Australian to Head U.N. Effort To Monitor Curbs on Iraqi Arms
description: An outspoken Australian diplomat and arms control expert was named chairman today of the commission in charge of locating and destroying Iraq's offensive weapons.

title: It's Spring Fever: Art Has a Date With Its Lovers
description: AS the art world prepares for the important spring auctions of Impressionist, modern and contemporary art that begin next week in Manhattan, it is speculating about just how much nerve -- and how many millions -- the serious collectors will muster.

title: Like It or Not, Devils Are Tagged Favorites
description: The Devils are considered the favorites for the first time in their three playoff series with the Rangers, but it is a designation they do not relish. They have always embraced the role of underdogs, especially in the series with the Detroit Red Wings in the Stanley Cup finals two years ago, when the Devils captured the National Hockey League championship trophy in a sweep.

title: Man in Parking Dispute Stabbed With Umbrella
description: A man involved in a dispute over a parking spot in Queens was critically injured yesterday when he was stabbed in the chest with an umbrella, the police said.

title: CHRONICLE
description: GEORGE BUSH has certainly been taking to the skies lately. In March, he parachuted down to the Arizona desert 50 years after having bailed out of a bomber in the Pacific.

title: Billboard Operators Set $1 Billion Merger
description: Outdoor Systems Inc., the nation's biggest outdoor advertising company, said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire the billboard unit of the Minnesota Mining and Manufacturing Company for $1 billion.

title: Some Good News After Loss Brings Mets' Sigh of Relief
description: When the Mets were informed they would be addressed by Fred Wilpon, the team president, and by Dr. Allan Lans after yesterday afternoon's 7-3 loss to the San Diego Padres, they immediately began to brace themselves for some more bad news.

title: Solis Finds the Surroundings Cozy
description: Alex Solis remembers his first Kentucky Derby. He just did not understand it.

title: Arafat Is Reported Set to Resume Talks With Israel
description: An aide to Yasir Arafat said today that the Palestinians were prepared to enter talks with Israel on how to emerge from the current impasse, signaling a readiness to break the two-month freeze in relations.

title: The New Face at No. 10: Anthony Charles Lynton Blair
description: When Tony Blair was 11, his father, a lawyer and university lecturer in the northern English city of Durham, suffered a disabling stroke, and the boy thought his world had ''fallen apart.'' By Mr. Blair's account, a man who had been ''very ambitious, successful, a go-getter,'' was stilled and speechless, and the son was uncomprehending.

title: Eddie Bauer Splits With Black Rocket
description: Eddie Bauer Inc., the retailer that is part of Spiegel Inc., and its agency for the last year, Black Rocket in San Francisco, said yesterday that they had mutually agreed to part ways on its account, with billings estimated at $5 million to $10 million. As a result, Eddie Bauer has placed its account in review.

title: CHRONICLE
description: ROBERT S. WOODS, who plays Bo Buchanan on the ABC soap opera ''One Life to Live,'' was mapping out steps for a jitterbug competition yesterday afternoon instead of memorizing his lines. ''I'm racking my brain to put together 13 little steps,'' he said. Mr. Woods and his wife, LOYITA CHAPEL WOODS, who danced together in their high school days more than 30 years ago, will compete in a dance contest tomorrow at a spring carnival at the Calhoun School on West 81st Street at West End Avenue. Their son, Tanner, 6, is in kindergarten at Calhoun, which is celebrating its 100th anniversary.

title: ING Is Negotiating to Buy Remainder of Dillon, Read
description: ING Group N.V., the Dutch financial services giant, is in talks to acquire the 75 percent of Dillon, Read & Company it does not already own, as yet another venerable Wall Street firm becomes a target for foreign and domestic banks.

title: Sonics Force a Game 5 With Overtime Triumph
description: There was a cardiologist in the house for Cedric Ceballos -- but he might want to take George Karl's pulse.

title: Nelson's New Relief Role A Good Setup for Yanks
description: They have not trumpeted the news on the signboard atop Yankee Stadium, nor have they posted it on the message board adjoining the Major Deegan.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Zaire Refugees Bear Signs of Rebel Atrocities
description: When Zairian villagers and rebel soldiers attacked refugee camps near here last week, Donatien Nkerahahizi, a 32-year-old teacher from Burundi, was set upon by a villager with a machete who slashed his head, back and legs, then left him for dead.

title: VNU to Buy 50% Of Distributor
description: VNU N.V., one of the three largest Dutch publishers, said yesterday that it planned to buy a half-stake in RCV Entertainment, the biggest independent entertainment distribution company in the Benelux region. No financial details were given.

title: Art in Review
description: Mimi Smith

title: Keep Family Court Closed to News Media
description: To the Editor:

title: NEW VIDEO RELEASES
description: Get On the Bus

title: France Suspends Sale Of Film Company
description: The French Government has decided to suspend the sale of Societe Francaise de Production after the media company Havas S.A. and the utility Compagnie Generale des Eaux withdrew their bid for the state-owned film production company, the Finance Ministry said yesterday. The Government selected the joint takeover offer last fall, while agreeing to inject 2.5 billion francs, or $430 million, in the film company.

title: U.S. Modernism: The Domestication Of Parisian Beasts
description: THE Atlantic Ocean must have seemed a lot wider a century ago than it does now, at least to New York painters waiting for news of European art to arrive on slow boats from Paris or London or Dusseldorf.

title: Playing Poker in Zaire: Rebel Leader Holds the Aces
description: If President Mobutu Sese Seko and the rebel leader Laurent Kabila meet on a South African ship on Friday as scheduled, the encounter will be a first between two men whose fates have been loosely linked for three decades but whose destinies are now streaking in opposite directions.

title: A Change at 10 Downing Street
description: It has been a long time between jubilant pints for British Laborites. When Labor last ruled, for those Americans who may have forgotten, Ronald Reagan was not yet President, Michael Jordan was in high school and ''The Deer Hunter'' won top honors at the Academy Awards. That was 1979, the year Margaret Thatcher's Conservatives swept into office, presaging Mr. Reagan's victory in America a year later. Twice more the Iron Lady was unbeatable, and her successor, John Major, scored a fourth straight Tory triumph five years ago. Yet this election season his party was visibly tired and deeply divided over monetary union with Europe.

title: Mirror, Mirror: Style Makes the Coach; Coaches Make the Team
description: Jacques Lemaire, a 51-year-old French Canadian from the province of Quebec, was a star center on an elite team, the Montreal Canadiens, from the late 1960's through the entire 1970's. His playing career yielded eight Stanley Cup rings and landed him in the Hall of Fame. In his first three seasons as coach of the Devils, Lemaire's teams have experienced one Stanley Cup championship and one narrow defeat in the Eastern Conference finals.

title: Seeking New Smokers
description: Let's be clear. The tobacco companies want and need your kids. They could not survive without enticing adolescents into using their products. They would go bankrupt.

title: Federal Official Goes to Jail
description: A former high-ranking immigration official, who was convicted in November of accepting bribes in exchange for falsifying documents, was placed into custody Wednesday, four weeks ahead of schedule, after the authorities said he failed to abide by the terms of his house arrest. John F. Lonergan, 50, of Belmar, was supposed to leave home only to go to work or visit his lawyer and was being monitored through an electronic bracelet. But he violated those restrictions twice this week, Jeffrey D. Smith, an assistant United States attorney, said. Mr. Lonergan, the former deputy assistant director of the Federal Immigration and Naturalization Service office in Newark, was scheduled to begin a 42-month sentence on May 27.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption yesterday about a dinner series for leaders in the new-media industry misidentified the man shown at the far left. He was Jerry Michalski, not Jonathan M. Guttenberg.

title: Adoption Age Limits
description: To the Editor:

title: Reynolds Completes Sale of Coal Lands
description: The Reynolds Metals Company said today that it had completed the sale of its coal properties in western Kentucky to the Kentucky Emerald Land Company for an undisclosed amount.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: Baseball

title: INSIDE
description: Practicing 'Paper Terrorism'

title: Bill Financing House Panels Passes as G.O.P. Rebels Gain
description: The House approved the financing for its 18 committees in the 105th Congress today, but only after a group of Republican renegades had wrung several unrelated concessions from Speaker Newt Gingrich.

title: NEW VIDEO RELEASES
description: The Portrait of a Lady

title: News Summary
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-10

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  GERALDS, ROBERT ATKINS ROMMEL
description: GERALDS-Robert Atkins Rommel. A memorial celebration for the life of Bob Geralds will be held on Friday, May 2 at 5:30 PM at the University Club, 1 West 54 St, NYC.

title: For Children
description: Children's Day at the World Trade Center

title: WARNER-LAMBERT BUYS IRISH PLANT FROM HICKSON
description: The Warner-Lambert Company said yesterday that it had bought the Irish plant of Hickson International P.L.C. for $46 million. The plant makes the active ingredient in Accupril, Warner-Lambert's treatment for high blood pressure. Warner-Lambert's purchase of the money-losing factory, which makes chemicals for several pharmaceutical companies, secures the primary source of Accupril for sale outside the United States. It also gives Warner-Lambert, which is based in Morris Plains, N.J., additional overseas manufacturing capacity for its new cholesterol-lowering drug, Lipitor. The sale is part of Hickson's plan to reverse falling profits.

title: Additional Share Offer For Machines Bull
description: Compagnie des Machines Bull S.A., France's biggest computer maker, said yesterday that it would offer a further 1.46 million shares to individual investors after its initial sale of 1.62 million shares was 21 times oversubscribed. The move will nearly double the number of Bull shares sold to the public, to 3.08 million, and will help the French state raise 110 million francs, or $18.9 million, from private investors. A total of 70,833 individuals have offered to buy Bull shares at 36 francs a share.

title: Old-Timers Show Their Brass
description: Don't tell GORDIE HOWE that MARK MESSIER and WAYNE GRETZKY are too old to lead the Rangers to the Stanley Cup finals.

title: Parents Wait Hours and Days For Places at Local Schools
description: It was 2:30 in the morning yesterday in Long Island City, Queens, when Carol Velky gently roused her 7-year-old daughter, Christina, and 4-year-old son, John, for what she said would be ''an adventure.''

title: Albany Finds Tax Revenue Goes Up Again
description: In the latest evidence that the region's economy continues to grow at a robust pace, Gov. George E. Pataki said today that the state has collected $500 million more in tax revenues than his budget officials had anticipated just weeks ago.

title: Veiled Discrimination
description: To the Editor:

title: Problems Aside, Washington Seeks to Be Host of Olympics
description: In the same week that District of Columbia officials said 11 public schools would be closed and the widow of a slain city policeman pleaded for the death penalty for police killers, Mayor Marion S. Barry Jr. announced today that Washington would seek to be host for the 2008 Summer Olympics.

title: Old Le Cirque's Former Chef Is Buying Restaurant's Site
description: With exquisite timing, just as the new Le Cirque 2000 opened in the New York Palace Hotel at Madison Avenue and 50th Street this week, the fate of the space that was the old Le Cirque, at 65th Street and Park Avenue, was being decided.

title: Park Board's Chairman Orders Minutes Changed
description: The head of the state's Adirondack Park Agency, under fire for a plan to permit a form of forest clear-cutting, ordered his subordinates to change the minutes of a board meeting to show that he had not called for a vote on the plan, internal agency documents show.

title: Negotiators Move to Rein In Medicare, Medicaid and Social Security
description: The budget deal shaping up on Capitol Hill would significantly restrain the growth of spending on Medicare, Medicaid and Social Security, further reducing the Federal deficit. But lobbyists for the elderly and governors of both parties said today that they found parts of the agreement unacceptable.

title: Only Real Surprise on 'Ellen' Was Lineup of Advertisers
description: Because the ''coming out'' story line for ABC's ''Ellen'' sitcom on Wednesday night was well known in advance, perhaps the only real surprise was the lineup of advertisers during the show.

title: Isringhausen's Condition Believed to Be Tuberculosis
description: Doctors treating Jason Isringhausen said yesterday that they are reasonably confident the Mets pitcher has contracted tuberculosis and believe that with medical treatment he should be able to resume his career in six to eight weeks. For the Mets and Isringhausen, the doctors' pronouncement was good news after four days of concern that a spot found on Isringhausen's lung might have indicated something worse.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  SHAPIRO, BERNSTEIN, JANE
description: SHAPIRO - BERNSTEIN - Jane. Happy Birthday, Angel. I know you are safe in the arms of Daddy and Richard. Rest in peace. Mom

title: Choosing to Join Giuliani, Democrat Is in Spotlight's Glare
description: A two-term Democratic Assemblyman from Coney Island swept into New York City's political spotlight yesterday, eagerly embracing an invitation from Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani to run at his side in November and brushing aside complaints from fellow Democrats that his actions verged on treason.

title: Curb on Officers' Speech Is Attacked in a Lawsuit
description: Accusing the Police Department of violating officers' rights to free speech, the New York Civil Liberties Union filed a lawsuit yesterday challenging city regulations that require officers to get commanders' permission before speaking publicly about any matters involving the police.

title: Credit Card Debt Hits a Record
description: Bad credit card debt reported in April rose $62 million, to $821 million, among banks and other lenders tracked by Fitch Investment Service.

title: Supporting Insurance Plan
description: Hoping to defuse the auto insurance revolt that has been gathering steam on radio talk shows, Chuck Haytaian, the state Republican Party chairman, sent out a letter Tuesday asking party leaders and contributors to call radio station WKXW-FM (101.5) to push for Gov. Christine Todd Whitman's latest reform proposal. The radio station helped spread the word about a rally in Trenton last week, where about 500 people protested the state's insurance rates, the highest in the nation.

title: British Airways Halts A Planned Spinoff
description: British Airways P.L.C. said yesterday that it would not spin off its aircraft maintenance division until at least 2000, shelving a plan it had hoped would cut costs. Several outside investors -- the General Electric Company reportedly among them -- had expressed interest in a stake in the business, which has annual sales of more than $650 million.

title: Inmates Injure 15 Guards At Prison In Newark
description: Inmates armed with meal trays and full cans of soda attacked guards in a dining hall at Northern State Prison this morning, injuring 15 of them in what prison officials described as a premeditated assault. The injured correction officers were all released from the hospital later in the day.

title: Art in Review
description: Michel Auder

title: Oh, You Think You're So Smart, Don't You?
description: If you think you're so special because you appreciate the poetry of John Donne and pal around with the literati while the rest of the world dopes itself up on television, think again. For when all is said and done, what does your refined, sensitive, highly educated, superior self -- the self that looks down on the rest of humanity -- really consist of?

title: Small-Business Awards
description: The New York City Partnership and Chamber of Commerce, the civic and business organization, presented its annual small-business awards yesterday to the restaurateur Danny Meyer and two companies, Doubleclick, an Internet advertising network, and Cellularvision USA, a wireless communications company.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PALESTIN, IRA J.
description: PALESTIN-Ira J., age 97, on April 30th. Beloved husband of Beatrice. Dear brother of Seymour. Devoted uncle of Dr. Jonathan Pincus of Washington, DC and Dr. Matthew Pincus, fond grand and great grand uncle. Former member of the NYC Council and member of the NY State Tax Commission. Services Friday, May 2nd, 10:45AM at ''The Riverside'', 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Panel Seeks Inquiry on Fund-Raising Event
description: A Senate panel asked the Justice Department today to open a criminal investigation into whether a Democratic fund-raiser lied to Congress when he denied promoting a $10,000-a-plate dinner for President Clinton as an opportunity to influence Federal bankruptcy policies.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GLASS, HENRY JOSEPH
description: GLASS-Henry Joseph. Beloved husband of Ruth. Cherished father of Linda (Daniel) Breen and Howard (Arlene). Devoted brother of Abraham and the late Clara Semel. Loving grandfather of Erin and David. Services on Sunday, May 4, 1:45 PM at ''Sinai Chapels'', 162-05 Horace Harding Expressway, Fresh Meadows, New York.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HIRSCH, MICHAEL
description: HIRSCH-Michael. On April 30, 1997, of Monsey, NY. Known on stage as ''The Tray Man''. Funeral service today 10:00AM at Hellman Memorial Chapels, 15 State Street, Spring Valley, New York.

title: Prime Time in the Parks
description: This is showtime in New York City's parks and gardens. For one reason or another -- a cool spring, perhaps -- nature has produced a rare and visually spectacular coincidence of crabapples, dogwoods, tulips, daffodils and cherry trees. That makes all of New York's botanical preserves worth a visit this weekend, but two of these merit special attention for quite a different reason.

title: Surprising Central Park, Nature's Pied-a-Terre
description: EVERY year, some 15 million people visit Central Park. That may be an impressive number, but not when you consider that about 20 million people live in the New York region and about 25 million tourists visit annually. That means that every year, 30 million people don't go to Central Park.

title: Memorial Recaptures Roosevelt Era
description: Standing dead-still in his slouch hat, Leon Bibel waits at the head of this city's newest bread line, mutely testifying to the way things can be for some Americans.

title: Live Better, Live Longer, in My Home, Sweet Cave!
description: At the end of a long day in his Town Hall office here, Mayor Mustafa Mizrak drinks a last glass of tea, stuffs his papers into a briefcase and heads back to his cave.

title: Treasuries Rally for 4th Straight Day
description: The Government securities market rallied for the fourth straight day yesterday, as a string of reports suggested the economy might be cooling enough to allow the Federal Reserve to keep interest rates on hold when it meets to set policy on May 20.

title: Before His Armed Standoff, Texan Waged War on Neighbors in Court
description: From a trailer in the sun-bleached mountains of West Texas, Richard L. McLaren declared himself at war with the United States five days ago. But as far as the people of Fort Davis are concerned, he has been at war with them for the past 14 years.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HOLME, ANNE M.
description: HOLME-Anne M., of Pleasantville, NY on April 26, 1997. Wife of John C. Holme. Mother of John C. Holme, Jr. and Heather Holme Schmidt. Grandmother of three, Great Grandmother of one. Aunt of Donald Mackey. Resting Beecher Funeral Home, Pleasantville, NY, Friday (Today) 6-8 PM. Funeral Service Saturday 11 am, United Methodist Church of Pleasantville. Interment Amenia Island Cemetery, Amenia, N.Y.

title: Consumer Still the Big Spender
description: The national economy has just turned in its best performance in nine years, and the American consumer's surprisingly exuberant spending is the main reason. In no other six-month period in this decade have increases in consumer spending been as large as they were in the six months through March.

title: Keep Family Court Closed to News Media
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about Chelsea Clinton's decision to attend Stanford University misidentified the Spanish official with whom President Clinton met yesterday, just after saying he supported his daughter's decision. It was the Prime Minister of Spain, not the President.

title: Art in Review
description: Jac Leirner

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SMITH, MARY ALLEN GREGG
description: SMITH-Mary Allen Gregg on April 30. Beloved wife of the Rev. John C. Smith and mother of John Clark Smith and Alexandra Gregg Smith. A service will be held at 11:30 on May 2 at St. James Episcopal Church, Madison Avenue at 71 Street. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be sent to the Blue Ridge School in Dyke, VA. 22935.

title: A Daughter's Lot
description: To the Editor:

title: Short-Shifting Announcers Won't Give Series Short Shrift
description: John Davidson will be benched for Game 1 of the Rangers-Devils series. ''Ah, jeez,'' the Rangers' analyst for MSG said from his home. ''I'll watch the ESPN and SportsChannel feeds, tape them and rewatch them to get some ideas.''

title: Internet Art: Turning a Web Into a Maze
description: WHEN Walter Benjamin wrote ''The Work of Art in the Age of Mechanical Reproduction'' in the 1930's, he was grappling with film, photography and the proliferation of newspapers, magazines and lithographs. ''Today there is hardly a gainfully employed European who could not, in principle, find an opportunity to publish somewhere or other comments on his work, grievances, documentary reports or that sort of thing,'' he said. ''Thus the distinction between author and public is about to lose its basic character.'' Benjamin was right, just off by half a century or so. He was predicting what has come to pass with the World Wide Web.

title: Phantom on Tour Impresses In Serious Derby Workout
description: All 13 horses entered in the Kentucky Derby exercised on the track at Churchill Downs this morning, but only one had serious work in mind: Phantom on Tour, who has run first or second in all eight of his races but who has been battling a mild blood disorder in the countdown to the most important race of his career.

title: Manufacturing and Construction Slow a Bit
description: Manufacturing activity grew at a slower rate in April than the month earlier, although the economy continued to grow for the 72d consecutive month, the National Association of Purchasing Management said today.

title: Sophia Mumford, 97, Editor And Wife of the Social Historian
description: Sophia Wittenberg Mumford, the wife and sometime editor of the critic and historian Lewis Mumford, died on April 22 at her home in Amenia, N.Y. She was 97.

title: The Other 'Cradle of Aviation' Unveils a Museum
description: No offense intended to the Wright Brothers and Kitty Hawk, N.C., but Long Island is staking its own claim as ''the cradle of aviation.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SPECTOR, FLORENCE
description: SPECTOR-Florence, on May 1, 1997. Beloved wife of the late George. Devoted mother of Barbara Albert and the late Adrienne Spector. Cherished grandmother of Allyson and Ian. Services are on Friday, 9:45 at ''Gutterman's Inc.'', 175 Long Beach Road, Rockville Centre, New York.

title: No Headline
description: ''It is an honor to serve you and I feel this evening a deep sense of honor, a deep sense of responsibility and a deep sense of humility. You have put your trust in me and I want to repay that trust.''

title: Money Is Tight at Hospitals
description: Time is running out to find a permanent way to reimburse hospitals for treating the uninsured, representatives of the state's 26 urban hospitals said yesterday. The Hospital Alliance of New Jersey found that the institutions themselves are in precarious health because the hospitals are now spending almost as much as they take in, Suzanne Ianni, the organization's executive director, said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHAFF, WILLIAM, J.
description: SCHAFF-William, J., suddenly on April 30, 1997 of Garden City. Former Federal Tax Manager for W.R. Grace and Company for 20 years. Beloved husband of Stephanie. Loving father of Dennis, Kenneth, and William. Adored grandfather of Michael. Cherished son of Anne Schaff. Dear brother of MaryAnn Chernovsky. Visiting at the Fairchild Chapel, Franklin Avenue at 12th St, Garden City 2-5 & 7-9 PM Friday. Mass of Christian Burial St. Joseph's Church, Garden City 9:45 AM Saturday. Interment Private. Donations to the Marfan Foundation appreciated.

title: A Family of Eight
description: On my seventh birthday, my sister Elizabeth gave me a book, as she had on my sixth. On the flyleaf she wrote ''I love you.'' I rushed off to show it to my parents and to the others in their bouquet of daughters, Bess, Rose, Ruth and Anne.

title: Girls Becoming Women in a Man's World
description: Chanting ''fe, fi, fo, fum'' in a menacing growl, a hunter follows two squealing 14-year-old girls into their hideaway, throws open the closet door and points the barrel of his shotgun at their quivering bodies. The instant of discovery pulses with such explosive tension that for a moment you wonder if what seems to be an intense game of hide and seek played by a father and his daughters is really a prelude to a grisly crime. But no, it is just a children's game. Still, when one of the girls, recalling those days, dismisses her father with an angry obscenity, it doesn't seem quite so innocent.

title: Man Blows His Hand Off in Booby-Trapped Apartment
description: A Bronx man who booby-trapped his apartment with homemade bombs accidentally blew his left hand off yesterday morning, the police said, prompting the evacuation of dozens of families from the area while the remaining explosives were dismantled.

title: A Paris Link to Mobutu
description: France tried to prop up President Mobutu Sese Seko of Zaire in January by running a covert military operation against rebels, according to intelligence reports. It could not be determined whether the operation, which involved mercenaries and combat aircraft, has continued.

title: INFORMATION TECHNOLOGY COMPANY ACQUIRES A RIVAL
description: Looking to expand, BDM International Inc. said yesterday that it had acquired Largotim Holdings Ltd., an information technology company, for $39 million. Largotim, with about 400 employees and operations in 10 countries, had revenue of $50 million for the year that ended on March 31. BDM International, based in McLean, Va., is also an information technology provider. The company's shares fell $1, to $22.25, in Nasdaq trading.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  BUDOW, SUNNY ''SHPRINTZIE''
description: BUDOW-Sunny ''Shprintzie''. Hello love. 13 years without you. Your partner needs you. We think and talk about you constantly. You were special. Love ya. Saul, Fern, Stephen and family

title: Awaiting 'Santa Claus' At Labor Headquarters
description: The mood was festive and the scent of victory already in the air when crowds of Labor supporters -- party organizers, campaign volunteers and general hangers-on -- began arriving at the party's election-night headquarters by subway, by taxi and on foot late last night.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: HOCKEY

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COLLINGE, MILDRED
description: COLLINGE-Mildred. On April 29, 1997. Age 95. Remembered by daughter Patty, son-in-law Jan, granddaughters Caitlin and Shannon. Member of Church of the Heavenly Rest.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DOLLY, RALPH ERROL
description: DOLLY-Ralph Errol. Died suddenly in Queens, NY, April 27, 1997. Viewing 2-8 P.M., May 2, Woodward Funeral Home, 1 Troy Ave., Brooklyn, NY. Funeral 9 AM, May 3, St. Philip's Episcopal Church, 334 MacDonough Street, Brooklyn, NY. Floral tributes accpeted or contribtutions to UNCF, NAACP or Lions Club International.

title: L.B.J. and Civil Rights
description: To the Editor:

title: Cancer Study Is Proposed
description: Governor Whitman received a warm reception yesterday when she asked a House appropriations subcommittee to spend $5 million to examine why a disproportionate number of children in the Toms River area have contracted cancer.

title: Jacor Buys 2 Concerns
description: Jacor Communications Inc. said today that it had bought the closely held traffic-reporting companies Airtraffic Communications in Los Angeles and Airwatch Communications in San Diego for $16 million in cash. The two companies have been providing traffic reports in the two cities for several years, and their clients include television and broadcasting stations in both cities. Jacor, based here, has 137 radio stations throughout the United States and owns WKRC-TV in Cincinnati.

title: Hope And Glory?
description: Will a tamed Labor Party, in power for the first time in 18 years, be bold enough to address Britain's real political needs? That is one question raised by Tony Blair's landslide victory in yesterday's general election.

title: Up With Their Rents! Albany Aims at the Rich
description: Raoul Felder, divorce lawyer to the rich and famous, fought like a bull to hold on to his rent-regulated apartment overlooking Central Park. In a white-glove building on Fifth Avenue, it was his three-bedroom home of 18 years. He could stand at his windows and gaze upon New Jersey here, Queens there, all for $4,000 a month.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: SOUTHERN NATIONAL CORP., Winston-Salem, N.C., agreed to acquire the investment banking firm Craigie Inc., Richmond, for an undisclosed amount.

title: Cocaine Price Soars, and Officials Seek Answers
description: The price of cocaine has soared in New York City in recent weeks after a dozen years of decline, according to law enforcement officials and undercover investigators.

title: EGGHEAD TO BUY SURPLUS SOFTWARE FOR $25.9 MILLION
description: The computer retailer Egghead Inc. said yesterday that it had agreed to buy Surplus Software Inc. for about $25.9 million. Egghead said it would also assume about $5.6 million of Surplus Software's debt in the transaction. Under the agreement, Egghead, based in Spokane, Wash., will issue 5.6 million new shares in exchange for Surplus, a direct marketer of older-version computer hardware and software. Surplus, of Hood River, Ore., had sales of $35 million and a net loss of $1.2 million for the nine months that ended on Feb. 28.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STEIN, MELVIN
description: STEIN-Melvin. Beloved husband of Elaine. Devoted father of Stuart M. and Roger H. Adored father-inlaw of Roni. Loving brother of Toby Rozen. Cherished grandfather of Jason W. and Alissa A. Stein. Service 10 A.M. Friday, at Lincoln Park Jewish Center, South Central Avenue, Yonkers. Contributions to Joseph F. Stein Foundation Inc., 30 Glenn Street, White Plains, New York 10603.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LOMUSCIO, NICHOLAS JOHN
description: LOMUSCIO-Nicholas John. Beloved husband of Josephine (nee Sanna). Devoted father of Bill G. and Angela Trovato. Dear father-in-law of Mary and Gary. Cherished Poppi of Dana, Mia, Nicholas and Alyssa. Dear brother of Frances Loretta, Laura Palmieri and Grace Knowles. Reposing at the Frederick Funeral Home of Flushing, Northern Boulevard at 193 Street until Monday, 2-5PM and 7-10 PM. Mass of Christian Burial 10:30 AM at St. Anastasia R.C. Church, entombment Ave Maria Garden Crypt, St. John's Cemetery, Middle Village, N.Y.

title: CHRONICLE
description: CHARLAYNE HUNTER-GAULT, the national correspondent for ''The Newshour With Jim Lehrer,'' who has been on the PBS program for 19 years, will be leaving in the middle of June to move to Johannesburg.

title: Hussein's Refuge Offer: Risky Strategy
description: King Hussein of Jordan has long shown a liking for sailing close to the wind, with sharp and frequent tacks, so there is more wonder than puzzlement here about his latest innovation: offering refuge to a jailed Islamic militant leader radically opposed to the King's peace policies.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCCARTHY, THOMAS RAYNOLDS
description: McCARTHY-Thomas Raynolds, 76, died at his home in Manhasset, New York, on Thursday, May 1, 1997. Former Executive Vice President of Austin Nichols & Company, Inc., and the third generation of his family to become an officer of the company. Proud producer of Wild Turkey Bourbon, he established the Austin Nichols Distillery in Lawrenceberg, KY. Mr. McCarthy was born in New York City and graduated from Choate School, Class of '39. In World War II he served in the U.S. Marines on Guadalcanal, Iwo Jima and the Occupation of Japan. He was a member of the New York Athletic Club and Nassau Country Club. He leaves behind Peggy, his wife of fifty-one years; daughter, Lee Huber of Houston, TX; son, Thomas C. of Roslyn Harbor, NY; and son, Robert R. of Enfield, CT, and six grandchildren. Also, two brothers, John C. and Ronald W. McCarthy. Visiting hours, Sunday, May 4, 3-5 PM and 7-9 PM with a brief memorial service at 8PM at Fairchild Funeral Home, 1570 Northern Boulevard, Manhasset, NY. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to Hospice Care of Long Island, Inc. or to the charitable organization of your choice.

title: Best for the Child?
description: To the Editor:

title: Restaurants
description: A romantic restaurant is hard to find.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  MECHANIC, SONNY (SAM)
description: MECHANIC-Sonny (Sam), May 2, 1995. You were my life for 65 years, my everything, my love, you are locked in my heart forever. I love you dearly. Carolyn.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FREEMAN, PHYLLIS
description: FREEMAN-Phyllis. Of New York City, on April 29, after a courageous battle with cancer. The family, friends, and colleagues of this extraordinary woman mourn her loss with profound sorrow. A memorial service will be announced. Contributions may be made in her memory to Smith College or to a cancer-care facility of your choice.

title: 42 Million Tune In To Watch a Coming Out
description: The coming out on ''Ellen'' turned into a party beyond ABC's wildest expectations as the situation comedy attracted the biggest rating of any regularly scheduled show on the network this season, attracting an estimated 42 million viewers.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RUSSINI, JOSEPH A.
description: RUSSINI-Joseph A., of the Bronx, Wednesday, April 30, 1997. Retired member, public relations officer and president of Plumbers Local #

title: Clinton and Congress in Accord On Budget, Except for Tax Cuts
description: White House and Congressional negotiators agreed today on nearly all elements of a plan to balance the Federal budget in five years, but failed to reach a final deal largely because of continuing differences over tax cuts.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  POTENZA, CONNIE
description: POTENZA-Connie. May 2, 1988. Without you, I will never laugh or dance again. I miss you terribly. Time will outlive all things, but not my love for you. Jack

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCENTIRE, CELIA H.
description: McENTIRE-Celia H. The Board, staff and members of United Cerebral Palsy of New York City note with sorrow the passing of Celia H. McEntire, mother of Michael H. Simonson. Our sincere condolences to Michael, Beth, and the entire family. Jack Hausman, Founder Leo Hausman, President UCP/NYC, Inc.

title: NEW VIDEO RELEASES
description: Palookaville

title: Clinton to Go Outside Aviation Circles for New F.A.A. Chief
description: President Clinton is preparing to break with tradition and reach outside the aviation industry and the military for a new head of the Federal Aviation Administration.

title: Laboratory's Managers: Unpaid Experts
description: The Energy Department owns Brookhaven and all the other national laboratories but does not run them; like the Atomic Energy Commission, the cold war agency that preceded it, the department hires contractors for that job.

title: New Regents Tests Make Educational Sense
description: To the Editor:

title: SUN HEALTHCARE TO SELL CLINICS AND THERAPY BUSINESS
description: Sun Healthcare Group Inc. said yesterday that it planned to sell its outpatient rehabilitation clinics in the United States and its therapy business in Canada and focus on its nursing home operations. Sun Healthcare said the sales were not expected to result in a gain or a loss. The 15 clinics in the United States were part of its acquisition of Mediplex Group Inc. in 1994 for about $330 million. The 31 Canadian clinics, called Columbia Health Care Inc., were acquired in 1995. Sun Healthcare, based in Albuquerque, N.M., operates about 300 nursing homes and provides therapy and pharmacy services in the United States and Britain.

title: Japan Panel's Plan For Postal Savings
description: Japan's postal savings system, with its 200 trillion yen ($1.57 trillion) in deposits, should be privatized, a panel of business leaders and academics convened by Prime Minister Ryutaro Hashimoto said today.

title: Last Chance
description: Here is a sampling of shows and exhibitions in Manhattan that are to close soon:

title: AVTEL SAYS IT WILL BUY MATRIX FOR $114.6 MILLION IN STOCK
description: Avtel Communications Inc. has agreed to buy Matrix Telecommunications Inc. for about $114.6 million in stock. Avtel, a telecommunications carrier based in Santa Barbara, Calif., said late Wednesday that it was offering about 34.6 million shares for all shares of the closely held Matrix. Matrix, a long-distance phone service company in Fort Worth, with more than 250,000 customers, expects to take in revenue of $60 million this year. Avtel said that once the acquisition was completed, Matrix would be a wholly owned subsidiary. Avtel shares rose 31.25 cents yesterday, to $3.625.

title: A Ripple of Recognition Follows Robinson
description: One of the lasting benefits of the celebration of Jackie Robinson and the breaking of baseball's color barrier has been the recognition brought to the many great players in an exceptional cast that made it happen.

title: Deadliness of Military Life
description: Mixing extreme naturalism with surreal reveries and disembodied voices distractedly chattering jump-rope rhymes and fragments from ''Macbeth,'' Nina Menkes's eerie experimental film ''The Bloody Child'' demands a great deal of patience for it to weave its depressing spell. But once you surrender to the rhythm of its maddeningly repeated images and its laborious accretion of somber detail, the movie offers a suffocating vision of American military life as a lethal social malignancy.

title: On Stage, and Off
description: The Best of the Rest

title: Meaning and Choice
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CUTHBERTSON, DIANA KEESHAN
description: CUTHBERTSON-Diana Keeshan. Former Director and Founder of New Jersey SPAN and past President of the National Parent Network on Disabilities. Loving wife of Harry (Hank) and mother of David. For information, please call the Raymond Funeral Home (203-847-7291).

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  BALANCHINE, GEORGE
description: BALANCHINE-George. A memorial service in memory of George Balanchine will be held on Monday, May 5, 7:30 PM, at The Cathedral of Our Lady of the Sign, 75 East 93rd Street, New York.

title: NEW VIDEO RELEASES
description: Blood and Wine

title: CONSERVATIVES ARE ROUTED AFTER 18 YEARS OF CONTROL
description: Tony Blair and the Labor Party swept to a victory of historic proportions in Britain's national election on Thursday, ending 18 years of Conservative control.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NIHDA, FREDERICK
description: NIHDA-Frederick. Beloved brother of James Nihda and sister Elizabeth Tokarsky. Memorial service to be held in Toronto, Canada. Any and all donations can be made in his memory to the Cabrini Hospice, 227 East 19th Street, New York, New York 10003.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  AHRENS, BEATRICE E.
description: AHRENS-Beatrice E. On May 1, 1997, beloved wife of the late Milton, loving mother of Burton, adoring grandmother of Matthew and Russell, dear sister of Florence Leinwand. She was much loved and will be sorely missed. Service Sunday 11 AM, at ''The Riverside'', 76th Street and Amsterdam Ave.

title: The Gods Are in the Details Of Objects Spanning 3,000 Years
description: THE arts formerly known as ''primitive'' are not exactly terra incognita these days. But for a thrilling immersion in their power and sophistication, I recommend ''Affinities of Form: Arts of Africa, Oceania and the Americas From the Raymond and Laura Wielgus Collection'' at the Equitable Gallery.

title: Parents Deny Role in Beauty Queen's Slaying
description: Breaking a four-month silence, the parents of JonBenet Ramsey emphatically proclaimed their innocence today in the killing of their 6-year-old daughter.

title: U.S. ENERGY CHIEF REMOVES MANAGER FOR BROOKHAVEN
description: Saying safety had taken a back seat to science, the Federal Government today dismissed the nonprofit organization that has operated the Brookhaven National Laboratory since its inception 50 years ago.

title: Classics at Meadowlands
description: Giants Stadium will wrap itself in the traditions of college football next season on four weekends.

title: Kierkegaard As a Prelude To Seduction
description: In the age of telephone sex, Dr. Ruth and Internet chat rooms, there's something quaintly romantic about the notion of a college student orchestrating a seduction that could be accomplished much more easily with a blunt proposition. Compound that quaintness with the idea that magical erotic powers could reside between the covers of a musty 19th-century philosophy book, and you have the nostalgic premise behind Daniele Dubroux's surreal romantic comedy, ''Diary of a Seducer.''

title: Zagat Survey Puts New York on a Disk
description: The popular Zagat guide to New York City restaurants is now available on disk. The latest offering from Zagat Survey LLC goes beyond the company's 15-year-old, burgundy-colored guidebook and Zagat information available through on-line services and over the Internet, by allowing users to search for restaurants according to any criteria.

title: Belarus Fines Soros Foundation $3 Million in Apparent Crackdown
description: Belarus has imposed a $3 million fine on the Soros Foundation for what the Government said were currency exchange violations, apparently in an effort to shut down the country's largest independent nongovernmental organization, spokesmen for the foundation said yesterday.

title: Ethics Code Is Given Prosecutors
description: Stressing the need for public confidence in New Jersey's criminal justice system, the State Attorney General said today that he had created a code of ethics for the state's 21 prosecutors and ordered them to file detailed annual statements about their personal finances.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHIMKIN, REBECCA
description: SHIMKIN-Rebecca, on May 1, 1997. Beloved wife of the late Leon. Loving mother of Emily Shimkin Gindin and Michael W. Shimkin. Also survived by seven grandchildren, two step-grandchildren and four great-grandchildren. Services on Sunday, 1:30PM at ''The Riverside'', 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GRUPPO, BRUNO
description: GRUPPO-Bruno, 75, of Cos Cob, CT. On Wednesday, April 30, 1997 at Greenwich Hospital. Beloved husband of Ellen, father of Claire Gruppo, Paul, James, David, Stephen Gruppo and Ellen Gruppo Loomis. Also survived by 11 grandchildren and several nieces and nephews. A Memorial Mass will be held (today) at 10:00 A.M., at St. Agnes Church, Greenwich. Interment will follow 11:30AM at Putnam Cemetery, Greenwich. There are no calling hours. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made in his memory to Alzheimer's Research Association, 919 N. Michigan Ave. Suite 1000, Chicago, IL 60611. For information, contact the Leo P. Gallagher & Son Funeral Home, Greenwich, CT.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCGRATH, JANE TUCK VAIL
description: McGRATH-Jane Tuck Vail, on April 24, 1997 of New Hyde Park, New York, wife of the late Franklin W. Vail (1967) and the late Edward E. McGrath (1986). Mother of Gabrielle Baksa and Christine Warren. Grandmother of Jennifer Baksa Haight, Jessica Baksa, Robert Douglas Warren and Cynthia Warren. Sister of the late Alvin James 2nd, Mary S., Richard and Robert Tuck. Member of the St. Ann's Guild, Sunday School Teacher, and fund raising committee of Zion Episcopal Church and Girl Scout Leader. Services will be held in the Zion Episcopal Church on Saturday at 1 PM. Interment in the Zion churchyard.

title: Thinking Big and Talking Tough, French Rightist Aims at Chirac
description: The bete noire of French politics, Jean-Marie Le Pen, and his far-right National Front mounted a 555-candidate assault on France's legislature today, but only after Mr. Le Pen declined to run for a parliamentary seat himself.

title: A Western Gone Cynical
description: An argument could be made that the western didn't fade away into the sunset. It merely curdled into a cynical new genre in which the alienated progeny of Bonnie and Clyde gallivant through the American heartland wreaking death and destruction until they are mowed down in geysers of gore.

title: A Shocking Reminder Of Our Frailty
description: JASON ISRINGHAUSEN was a 22-year-old right-handed pitcher for the Mets' Class AAA Norfolk team in the summer of 1995, strong and handsome and healthy. He was a coming major league star, his baseball dreams close to being realized. But in a game in mid-July he ran into problems, got hit hard and was sent to the showers in the third inning. He lost, 7-1.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  BLECHER, MILTON
description: BLECHER-Milton. May 2nd, 1914. Dear Daddy, Happy Birthday. I miss you. Love, Nanie

title: Democrats in Congress Fume Over Clinton Budget Process
description: Democratic Congressional leaders exploded at the Clinton Administration today, accusing it of dealing with Republicans on the budget behind their backs.

title: General Motors gambles on a do-or-die strategy to reinvigorate the Oldsmobile marque.
description: EVERYONE agrees it is a tough assignment.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LAVINE, JOAN V.
description: LAVINE-Joan V., died May 1, 1997, in Cupertino, Ca., aged 103. Widow of A. Lincoln Lavine. Sister of the late John Bragman. She lived for 85 years in Manhattan. She leaves a daughter, Nancy Roberts; a son, David Lavine; five grandchildren and one greatgranddaughter.

title: Defendant Tried To Buy Bomb Device, Jury Hears
description: A Virginia gun dealer testified today at the Oklahoma City bombing trial that six months before the blast, Timothy J. McVeigh was so eager to buy detonation cord, used to ignite explosives, that he offered to drive from Arizona to Virginia to pick it up.

title: A Freedom Fighter for Love
description: The men drink, laugh and play cards, accompanied by a couple of stunning young women in skimpy clothes. At first the setting goes deliberately unexplained, but this turns out to be a cozy domestic scene. In ''Broken English,'' an impassioned, offbeat film from New Zealand by Gregor Nicholas, these are the Croatian Capulets, and their Juliet is a reckless, wanton beauty. ''She make him remember,'' says one of the Croatian men, in the language of the title, ''what fine race we are.''

title: Sales for G.M. And Chrysler Fell in April
description: The General Motors Corporation and the Chrysler Corporation said today that their car and truck sales cooled off last month, even as Japanese auto makers, benefiting from favorable exchange rates, reported stronger sales.

title: KEYS TO THE SERIES: EASTERN CONFERENCE SEMIFINAL
description: For the Devils to Win

title: No Illusion: Hardaway and Magic Dazzle Again
description: Anfernee Hardaway has been brilliant. The Orlando Magic's comeback has been shocking. And if the Magic beat the Miami Heat again on Sunday, it will complete one of the most dramatic playoff upsets in National Basketball Association history.

title: Chicago Membership Sale
description: A membership in the Chicago Board Options Exchange sold for a record $650,000 on Wednesday, up from the $635,000 price set on March 31, the exchange said. Volatility in United States markets makes options trading more lucrative and raises the value of memberships on the exchange, the world's largest for stock options.

title: But Can a 77-Year-Old Raise a Teen-Ager?
description: To the Editor:

title: Spain's Government Joins Soccer-Tinged TV Fight
description: Most homes in Spain can receive only about five channels of television. So you might think the Spanish Government would welcome a new satellite service offering more than 25 channels and pay-per-view movies.

title: Diner's Journal
description: How did they do it? Balthazar is only a week old, but it already has a patina of age. With its high ceilings, huge mirrors, white tile floor and yellowing walls, it has the weary, slightly cynical look of an old Paris brasserie.

title: Seeing Double: New Literary Optics
description: TROPICAL CLASSICAL

title: Corrections
description: An article on Wednesday about new Federal guidelines that prohibit employer discrimination against qualified workers with mental illness misstated the date they were issued. It was March 25, not this week.

title: Acclaim to Dismiss 15% of Its Employees
description: Acclaim Entertainment Inc. said today that it would dismiss 115 workers, or 15 percent of its work force, as part of plans to save $40 million annually and return the troubled video software maker to profitability.

title: Art in Review
description: Ok-Sang Lim

title: Art in Review
description: 'Confrontations'

title: And Then There Were Five: Finalists' Plans for Coliseum Site
description: The Metropolitan Transportation Authority announced five finalists yesterday in the competition to select a developer to build on the site of the New York Coliseum in Manhattan, one of the most valuable pieces of real estate in the city. E. Virgil Conway, the authority's chairman, showed the designs proposed by the finalists, who were chosen from a pool of nine developers who submitted bids last year. The designs vary architecturally. But all call for the construction of at least one tower, and most include proposals for hotels, offices, residential apartments and retail stores.

title: $25 and Under
description: If you've made a reservation at a restaurant and kept your end of the bargain by showing up on time, what can you reasonably expect from a restaurant if your table is not ready?

title: Alleged Brothel Is Shut Down
description: The police on Tuesday closed down a two-year-old brothel in Manalapan Township that had been catering to as many as 100 men a night, officials said yesterday. ''This is a bedroom community, but not that kind,'' Mayor Noreen Hanlon said.

title: H.E. Simmons Jr., 67, Du Pont Executive
description: Howard E. Simmons Jr., the former head of research and development at E. I. du Pont de Nemours & Company, died on April 26 at his home in Greenville, Del. He was 67.

title: F.D.A. Taking Cautious Path In Its Regulation of Tobacco
description: When a Federal judge in North Carolina declared last week that the Food and Drug Administration could regulate nicotine as a drug, he opened the way for tobacco foes to realize a once-distant dream -- a world where cigarettes could be so radically altered that the whole country, in the words of one addiction expert, ''would become detoxified.''

title: Developer Is Trying to Meet Strong Demand for Large Apartments
description: Demand for family-size condominium apartments is outstripping the supply in Manhattan's hearty for-sale market, with one developer combining units in his newly built 25-story residential tower to help close the gap.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PAGE, DONALD ORMSBY
description: PAGE-Donald Ormsby, 69, died April 27th, suddenly but peacefully at home. The son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Donald Ormsby Page of New York City and Far Hills, New Jersey. Loving brother of Shirley P. Schneirla of Stanton, New Jersey, and beloved uncle to Dorothy S. Hover, Peter C. Schneirla, of New York City, and the late William Sutfin Schneirla, Jr. He will be sorely missed. Funeral and interment were private at Woodlawn Cemetery, New York City. Services were conducted by his devoted brother-in-law, the Very Reverend William S. Schneirla.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DASHIELL, SARA SKILLERN
description: DASHIELL-Sara Skillern. Of Croton-on-Hudson, NY, on April 29, 1997. Wife of the late Alfred S. Dashiell. Funeral services will be held on Saturday May 3, 1997 at 10 am at St. Augustin's Episcopal Church in Croton-on-Hudson. For information contact the Edward F. Carter Inc. Funeral Home, Crotonon-Hudson, New York.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DELCAU, JOSEPH G.
description: DELCAU-Joseph G., co-founder & former President and Chairman of the Board of Directors of Del Electronics Corporation, now Del Global Technologies, of Valhalla, NY and former resident of Mount Vernon and Eastchester died on April 30, 1997, at the Hallandale Rehabilitation Center in Hallandale, FL. While living in Westchester he & his wife were supporters of the Westchester Symphony Orchestra and members of the Free Synagogue in Mount Vernon. He was the beloved husband of Lili; loving father of Dennis & Frances Delcau of Pegram, Tennessee and grandson, Mitchell Robert Delcau of Fort Collins, Colorado. Gravesite services to be held at Cedar Park Cemetery in Westwood, New Jersey, at 1:30 P.M., today. Condolences may be sent to Mrs. Joseph Delcau, P.O. Box 105, Pegram, Tennessee 37143.

title: Strange Fate of a Couple In Trouble on the Road
description: A new American director once made his mark with a tight, sinister action film about a cryptic road battle through the American West. That was Steven Spielberg's ''Duel,'' and while there may not be extraterrestrials or rampaging dinosaurs in Jonathan Mostow's future, Mr. Mostow certainly gives his first theatrical feature some of that ''Duel'' power.

title: News Corp. Official Who Led Satellite Talks Quits
description: The executive who spearheaded the News Corporation's troubled efforts to start a satellite service that could deliver both local and national television programming resigned late yesterday.

title: Reform Teaching, Too
description: To the Editor:

title: A Booming Economy Made It All Much Easier
description: In the end it cannot be Democrats or Republicans who are credited for coming up with a plan that balances the budget by 2002. It won't even be Treasury Secretary Robert E. Rubin or the Senate majority leader, Trent Lott, though their opposing teams played the leading roles.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Consumer Spending Soars, But Other Gauges Slow

title: The City That Never Shuts Up
description: WALKING around with Nancy Nadler can be unsettling. Don't misunderstand. Ms. Nadler is good company. But her specialty is noise. She tracks it and combats it as director of the Noise Center at the League for the Hard of Hearing. And sometimes she carries a gizmo that looks like a walkie-talkie but is in fact a sound-level meter.

title: Art in Review
description: Bill Scanga

title: Western Pacific Airlines to Serve Denver
description: Western Pacific Airlines Inc. said yesterday that it would begin service at Denver International Airport on June 29, offering 45 departures daily along with 24 departures by its commuter carrier, Mountain Air Express.

title: 3 On-Line Services in Accord on Abusive-Billing Complaints
description: In another blow to the mixed reputation of computer on-line services, three of the nation's biggest providers have entered into a settlement with the Federal Trade Commission over complaints of abusive billing and marketing practices.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SISCA, MICHAEL
description: SISCA-Michael, on April 29th, 1997, of Riverdale, NY. Loving brother of Helen Angelino of NYC and Carmen Fabrizio of Harrison, NY. Also survived by nine nieces and nephews. The family will receive friends Thursday, 7-9 PM, at the William H. Graham Funeral Home, 1036 Post Road, Rye. Mass of Christian Burial Friday, 10 AM, at St. Gregory the Great Church, Harrison, New York. Entombment Woodlawn Cemetery.

title: Judge Rejects Trump's Suit
description: Donald J. Trump cannot use the Federal courts to try to block a $330 million tunnel in Atlantic City that would benefit his rival, Steven A. Wynn, a judge ruled yesterday. Mr. Trump had argued that under the State Constitution, the Casino Reinvestment Development Authority, which plans to subsidize about one-third of the tunnel's cost, can spend its money only on projects for the elderly and disabled.

title: Backlog in Naturalization Process Is Worsening, Agency Says
description: As record numbers of immigrants seek citizenship to avoid losing benefits, the Immigration and Naturalization Service is falling behind schedule with a growing backlog that will worsen until safeguards are in place to prevent criminals from becoming citizens, Justice Department officials say.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about luxury decontrol rules for rent-regulated apartments referred incorrectly in some editions to the percentage of tenants with rent protections in New York City who have incomes over $250,000. According to an analysis by the Census Bureau, there are 3,840 such tenants, or 0.35 percent of the roughly 1.1 million regulated apartments -- not 0.003 percent.

title: Kennedy Family Values
description: The Kennedys always embraced hypocrisy as a family value. Now they have embraced stupidity. It's an unfortunate combination.

title: Piping Plovers Undisturbed
description: When plans were announced to replenish the beach in Brigantine, some people worried that the piping plovers that build their nests there would be disturbed.

title: 3 Indicted in Stock Fraud Said to Be Mob-Related
description: Three men, including one identified as an associate of the Colombo crime family, were indicted yesterday on stock fraud charges in one of the first cases to arise from what the authorities have described as a shift to white-collar crime by the region's Mafia families.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  BALANCHINE, GEORGE
description: BALANCHINE-George. A memorial service in memory of George Balanchine will be held on Monday, May 5, 7:30 PM, at The Cathedral of Our Lady of the Sign, 75 East 93rd Street, New York.

title: Robert Danly, 50, Translator of Japanese
description: Robert Lyons Danly, a translator from the Japanese and an editor and teacher, died on Sunday at his parents' home in Burr Ridge, Ill. A resident of Ann Arbor, Mich., he was 50.

title: The Mets Keep Winning As Hitters Start to Jell
description: They might be all banged up. But right now, the Mets are on a roll.

title: Mexican Chief Turns Down U.S. Requests On Drug War
description: Three days before President Clinton's first visit here, President Ernesto Zedillo today strongly rejected two proposals by American law enforcement officials aimed at improving security for United States drug agents in Mexico and at detecting police corruption. He characterized the proposals as outrageous encroachments on Mexican sovereignty.

title: The Mantra For 1997: It's the Best Of Times
description: When it comes to economic news, it does not get much better than this.

title: SHARES OF PETSMART POST A DECREASE OF 24%
description: Petsmart Inc. shares fell 24 percent on concerns about lower sales and higher-than-expected acquisition costs. Pet owners are buying more medications for fleas and ticks from veterinarians, while the cold spring reduced use and hurt Petsmart's sales of nonprescription powders, soaps and other products. Petsmart, the largest United States pet food and supply company, is expected to report same-store sales growth of about 7 percent, down from 9 percent, according to a report by Gary Balter, an analyst with the Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette Securities Corporation, who lowered his rating to a ''buy'' from ''recommend.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SMITH, MARY ALLEN GREGG
description: SMITH-Mary Allen Gregg. The Theatre Committee of the Onteora theatre wish to convey their condolences to the family of Allen Smith. For dedicated service and friendship, we will honor and miss this remarkable lady. Kathryn Clay, President

title: Russia Drops Major Demand on Limiting NATO Forces
description: Russia dropped a major demand today on limiting NATO's military forces, improving the prospects that the two sides will meet a May 27 target date for completing an agreement between the alliance and its former adversary.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BREUER, SAMSON
description: BREUER-Samson, a very special person and uncle. Together with his beloved late wife, Tante Myra, Of Blessed Memory, we shared many good times and Yom Tovim. I'll really miss him. Very sincere condolences to daughters Janie Rosenfeld and Judy Lorch and the whole family. Peter Schwalbe

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CAREY, EMILY
description: CAREY-Emily. Boys Harbor, Inc (The Harbor for Girls and Boys) deeply mourns the untimely passing of our dedicated and cherished Trustee, Mrs. Francis J. (Bitsy) Carey on April 30. Bitsy was a very special person who made everyone she met feel equally special and loved. Our deepest and loving sympathy to Frank Carey and Bitsy's entire family. The Board, Staff and Children of Boys Harbor

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WALLACH, MILDRED
description: WALLACH-Mildred. On May 2, 1997. Beloved wife of the late Emil. Adored and cherished mother of Eugene Wallach and Alice Kulick Klein and mother-in-law of Howard Klein. Loving grandmother of Genevieve and Robert, Peter and Ann Mette, Phillis and Renee and Tommy. Great grandmother of Bret, Nicole, Siri Lynn and Isabella. Services Sunday, 10:30 A.M., ''Schwartz Brothers-Jeffer Memorial Chapels'', 76th Road and Queens Boulevard in Forest Hills.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCCARTHY, THOMAS RAYNOLDS
description: McCARTHY-Thomas Raynolds, 76, died at his home in Manhasset, New York, on Thursday, May 1, 1997. Former Executive Vice President of Austin Nichols & Company, Inc., and the third generation of his family to become an officer of the company. Proud producer of Wild Turkey Bourbon, he established the Austin Nichols Distillery in Lawrenceberg, KY. Mr. McCarthy was born in New York City and graduated from Choate School, Class of '39. In World War II he served in the U.S. Marines on Guadalcanal, Iwo Jima and the Occupation of Japan. He was a member of the New York Athletic Club and Nassau Country Club. He leaves behind Peggy, his wife of fifty-one years; daughter, Lee Huber of Houston, TX; son, Thomas C. of Roslyn Harbor, NY; and son, Robert R. of Enfield, CT, and six grandchildren. Also, two brothers, John C. and Ronald W. McCarthy. Visiting hours, Sunday, May 4, 3-5 PM and 7-9 PM with a brief memorial service at 8PM at Fairchild Funeral Home, 1570 Northern Boulevard, Manhasset, NY. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to Hospice Care of Long Island, Inc. or to the charitable organization of your choice.

title: New Power to Redesign Cigarettes
description: When a Federal judge in North Carolina, of all places, concluded last week that the Food and Drug Administration had the power to regulate tobacco, he unleashed a strong new weapon against the industry. If the decision is upheld after further court wrangling, Federal regulators will gain control, for the first time ever, of the actual content of this lethal product, not just the ways it is sold or marketed. This must not be lightly yielded or diminished in the current settlement negotiations over how best to control the renegade industry.

title: Allan Francovich; Film Maker Was 56
description: Allan Francovich, an award-winning documentary film maker, died on April 17 in Houston. He was 56.

title: Prosecutor Forms Bureau Fighting Crime On Children
description: The Brooklyn District Attorney announced yesterday that he had created a bureau to deal exclusively with prosecuting crimes against children, a bureau that he said was part of a stepped-up drive to combat such crimes.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHWARZ, JAMES H.
description: SCHWARZ-James H. A good person with a wonderful sense of humor. You'll be missed by so many. Bill Imershein, and Charlie Teschner

title: Gina Berriault Wins Short Story Award
description: Gina Berriault has been named this year's winner of the Rea Award for the Short Story. The $30,000 prize was given to Ms. Berriault for the power and originality of her work, which includes ''The Mistress and Other Stories'' (1965), ''The Infinite Passion of Expectation: 25 Stories'' (1982) and ''Women in Their Beds: New and Selected Stories'' (1996).

title: One Dreams, One Fidgets
description: When they shared a program at Context Studios on Wednesday night, Rachel Thorne Germond offered three short, enigmatic dances and Deborah Kayton presented one long and very obvious work. Nevertheless, Ms. Kayton's ''History of Worrying, Part II'' aroused interest simply because of its theme: worrying.

title: D'Amato Warns of Air-Controller Shortage
description: Accusing the Federal Aviation Administration of ''playing Russian roulette with people's lives,'' Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato called on the agency to address a growing shortage of air traffic controllers.

title: Budget Negotiators Soften Impact of Cuts for Elderly
description: The economic windfall that put billions of additional dollars into the budget pot allowed negotiators today to soften the impact of their proposed cutbacks in Medicare, Medicaid and Social Security.

title: U.S. JOBLESS RATE HITS 23-YEAR LOW
description: America's unemployment rate dropped in April below 5 percent, a level not seen since December 1973, when Richard M. Nixon was President, the Government reported today.

title: 'Ellen' Showed That Being Gay Is About Identity
description: To the Editor:

title: Out of Office One Day, Out of a Home the Next
description: There is nothing brisker about the British than the speed with which they dispatch defeated Prime Ministers.

title: Crashing, Tumbling, Whew!
description: The pianist Yosuke Yamashita is usually forgotten in the roll call of tradition-stretchers: those who have forged a link between Bud Powell's be-bop and Cecil Taylor's polytonality. It's probably because he's even more inclusive than that, drawn to Eastern and classical forms. During an early set on Tuesday at Sweet Basil, he played an Indian song as a rhumba, a Bach-based piece by Jacques Loussier and his own crashing, tumbling compositions with ostinatos and intermittent swing.

title: Heat Tries to Devise a Plan To Cool Magic's Hardaway
description: For two games, the Miami Heat has been mesmerized by the Anfernee Hardaway show. One more episode could end the Heat's season.

title: MetroStars Sign Rizi
description: MARCO RIZI, 28, a defender who has played with three teams in the indoor National Professional Soccer League, has been signed by the MetroStars, CHARLIE STILLITANO, the team's vice president and general manager, announced yesterday.

title: Green's Opponent Pledges To Finish Term if Elected
description: Jules Polonetsky, the Democratic Assemblyman picked by Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani to run on the Republican and Liberal party lines for Public Advocate this fall, issued his first campaign promise yesterday: Yes, he will serve out his four-year term if elected.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FLATEMAN, IRWIN (PETE)
description: FLATEMAN-Irwin (Pete). Beloved husband of Alice. Devoted father of Brina Rosenblatt, Charles Flateman and Bernard Flateman. Dear brother of Eleanore Rukin, Iris Klarfeld and Lila Dryer. Loving grandfather of Ira, Craig, Jennie, Sadie, Jonah, Timothy and Gabriel. Services Sunday, 9:45AM, Gutterman-Musicant, 402 Park Street, Hackensack.

title: Reebok and Leo Burnett End Their Alliance
description: Reebok International Ltd. and its agency, the Leo Burnett Company in Chicago, have parted ways on their advertising account after four years. Reebok spends $100 million in billings in the United States.

title: Brothers Charged in Fraud
description: Three Hudson County brothers were arrested yesterday and charged with cheating three banks, a mortgage lender and dozens of credit card companies out of more than $1.4 million while they were awaiting sentencing for other, similar crimes, prosecutors said.

title: COLLEGE LACROSSE REPORT
description: Women's Streaks

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LOMUSCIO, NICHOLAS JOHN
description: LOMUSCIO-Nicholas John. Beloved husband of Josephine (nee Sanna). Devoted father of Bill G. and Angela Trovato. Dear father-in-law of Mary and Gary. Cherished Poppi of Dana, Mia, Nicholas and Alyssa. Dear brother of Frances Loretta, Laura Palmieri and Grace Knowles. Reposing at the Frederick Funeral Home of Flushing, Northern Boulevard at 193 Street until Monday, 2-5PM and 7-10 PM. Mass of Christian Burial 10:30 AM at St. Anastasia R.C. Church, entombment Ave Maria Garden Crypt, St. John's Cemetery, Middle Village, N.Y.

title: Delightedly Unleashing Nostalgia's Endorphins
description: No, you weren't imagining it, though it's been hard to believe in these last weary weeks of the Broadway season. There really were musicals once that existed only to make people happy: when pure, bubbling silliness took on a stylized grace that released a rush of endorphins among even the most gray-souled of urban audiences.

title: The Giving And Taking
description: As a political matter, the budget-balancing accord announced today was a substantial accomplishment for a Democratic President and a Republican-led Congress.

title: A Toy Maker in Search of a New Blockbuster
description: Mayumi Nishiguchi loved her pet chicken Hanako like a child and took it everywhere. So when Hanako died Thursday, the 35-year-old shopkeeper held a funeral, putting its body on a pedestal, praying over it and lighting a cigarette in lieu of Japan's traditional incense-burning.

title: Commissioner Of Health Blames Ouster On Politics
description: Dr. Mary E. Hibberd, who gained a reputation for standing up to powerful figures as Suffolk County's Health Commissioner for the last six years, is being forced out, and she is blaming politics in County Executive Robert J. Gaffney's office.

title: An Uneven Budget Agreement
description: Hours after the Government announced that the nation's unemployment rate had fallen below 5 percent for the first time in 24 years, President Clinton and Republican leaders crowed that they had produced another piece of historic economic news -- an agreement to erase the Federal budget deficit by the year 2002. The plan appears to have clear sailing in the Senate and only marginal opposition from liberals in the House. But it is too early to tell how much praise is warranted.

title: Lode of Brazilian Nationalism: A State Mine Goes Private
description: The unexpected court-ordered delay in the Brazilian Government's sale of of shares in its state-owned mining company, after a barrage of legal challenges backed by popular protests, called upon ideas and images that many South American leaders had taken for dead as they moved toward privatizing their economies.

title: Architects' Visions Of How the Modern May One Day Appear
description: The Museum of Modern Art has set itself the task of trying to figure out what modernism is, was or will become. The occasion for this exercise is the museum's plan to expand its midtown campus. ''Toward a New Museum of Modern Art,'' a show that opens today, presents ideas by 10 architectural firms invited to compete for the commission.

title: Fuzzy Zoeller's Apology
description: To the Editor:

title: White House Vows to Appeal Order to Open Whitewater Notes
description: The White House said today that it would appeal a Federal appeals court ruling ordering it to turn over to Whitewater investigators notes taken by Government lawyers of conversations they had with Hillary Rodham Clinton.

title: Donald and Marla Are Headed for Divestiture
