description: The moral of this story is that money can't buy happiness.

title: Libel Suit at College
description: The president of Richard Stockton College has filed a lawsuit charging a faculty member with libel over a letter written about events more than 10 years ago.

title: Troopers Move Closer to Texas Separatists' Encampment
description: State authorities significantly tightened their perimeter around the Republic of Texas encampment late last night, increasing the pressure on the group's leader.

title: Blair Takes Charge, Vowing 'Practicable' Policies
description: Tony Blair became Prime Minister of Britain today, and his predecessor, John Major, said he would give up the leadership of the Conservative Party, which suffered its worst defeat of this century in the election Thursday.

title: Blaine Littell, TV Journalist, 71
description: Blaine Littell, an author, former television news correspondent and retired journalism professor, died on Tuesday at the Pendleton nursing home in Mystic, Conn. He was 71 and lived in nearby Stonington.

title: Statements by Clinton and Congressional Leaders on the Agreement
description: Following are excerpts from the statements of President Clinton; Senator Trent Lott of Mississippi, the majority leader, and Speaker Newt Gingrich in announcing the agreement between Democrats and Republicans yesterday on balancing the budget, as provided by the Federal News Service, a private transcription service:

title: OBITUARY : Patricia High Painton, 67, Former Journalist in Paris
description: PARIS (IHT)  Patricia High Painton, 67, a former business journalist and longtime Paris resident, died April 29 of genetic emphysema at Roper Hospital in Charleston, South Carolina.

title: Despite Angry Colleagues, Clinton Unites His Party
description: On Thursday evening, with a budget deal imminent, Bill Clinton was once again being accused of treason by the liberal wing of his party.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SAX, MARY
description: SAX-Mary. Age 41. Of Flushing, New York, May 1, 1997. Beloved daughter of Dr. Sheldon Sax and Frances Sax. Step-daughter of Mary Lou Sax. Beloved sister of Susan Sax O'Grady and David Sax. Sister-in-law of Pam Sax and Brian O'Grady. Cherished aunt to Caitlin and Molly O'Grady, Alex and Megan Sax. Video-Tape Editor, 10 years, at WCBS-TV Channel 2 News. Dearest friend of all whose lives she touched. We all will carry her in our hearts. Services Sunday, May 4th, 9:45AM ''Sinai Chapels'', 162-05 Horace Harding Expwy, Fresh Meadows, N.Y. Interment Beth Moses Cemetery, Babylon, L.I. Memorial contributions may be made to American Cancer Society or Cabrini Hospice.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL 3-7

title: The Mets Require TB Tests
description: A day after doctors said they believed that Jason Isringhausen was suffering from tuberculosis, the Mets pitcher underwent further testing yesterday and began receiving medication to combat the disease.

title: Budget Agreement Gives Treasuries a Lift
description: It was a clean sweep for the bulls in the Treasury market this week. Although prices slipped early yesterday in response to the mixed labor report, after posting significant gains through the week on data that suggested the economy might be slowing, they rallied again in the afternoon on news that President Clinton and Republican Congressional leaders agreed on a balanced budget plan.

title: INTERNATIONAL HOME FOODS TO BUY BUMBLE BEE SEAFOODS
description: International Home Foods Inc. said yesterday that it had agreed to buy Bumble Bee Seafoods Inc. for $163 million in cash, adding the 100-year-old canned tuna brand to its Chef Boyardee, Jiffy Pop and other food lines. The agreement was reached as Bumble Bee, the nation's No. 2 tuna producer and a subsidiary of the Unicord Public Company of Thailand, filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection in Federal Bankruptcy Court in San Diego. Hicks, Muse, Tate & Furst, the investment firm based in Dallas, bought International Home Foods from the American Home Products Corporation for $1.3 billion last September.

title: Another Soldier Convicted in Race-Based Killings
description: A jury today convicted a second white former Army paratrooper on murder and conspiracy charges in the killings of a black couple in North Carolina in 1995.

title: As Red River Crests, Manitoba Holds Its Breath
description: Since people here first got a look at the frightening images of the flood that devastated Grand Forks, N.D., two weeks ago, tensions have been rising as fast as the water of the Red River, which was headed straight this way.

title: OIL DISCOVERY OFF COAST OF ALASKA CONFIRMED
description: The British Petroleum Company said yesterday that it had confirmed a new oil discovery off the north coast of Alaska, where the company is the state's largest producer. B.P. said the United States discovery, called Liberty, had an estimated 120 million barrels of recoverable reserves and is near the company's Endicott oilfield. The discovery will help B.P. maintain production at 450,000 barrels a day in Alaska, where production has declined in recent years. The Liberty well was drilled from a man-made gravel island that should make developing the field cheaper than having to build an offshore platform.

title: Composer Turns Spotlight on Herself
description: Having devoted installments of her Making Music series to the works of Steve Reich, Ned Rorem and Alvin Lucier, Ellen Taaffe Zwilich brought the first year of the series to a close on Wednesday evening at Weill Recital Hall by turning the spotlight on her own works as well as a few favorite pieces by other composers.

title: JAZZ
description: The Sax Is Racing

title: Question After Hong Kong: Is Taiwan Next for Beijing?
description: As champions of the Taiwan independence movement, Wesley J. D. Yu and his family have built a political dynasty in this seaport city, where harbor cranes soar above a horizon of cargo containers stacked along a vast waterfront. It is a vista that evokes the economic vibrancy of this island off China's southeastern coast.

title: In Best Tally Ever, Sinn Fein Wins 2 Seats in Westminster
description: In its strongest showing ever in a British national election, Sinn Fein, the political wing of the Irish Republican Army, won two seats in the British Parliament, according to results announced today from the voting on Thursday.

title: Bridge
description: One of rarest opening bids in bridge is four no-trump, and when it does occur it can easily generate a misunderstanding. Half a century ago it was used to mean a very powerful balanced hand, with perhaps 28 high-card points. British players then introduced the idea that the bid should ask partner to show an ace: Five clubs denies an ace, and other bids show the ace of that suit. There are two modern interpretations involving the minor suits: Two very long minor suits, or one very long minor suit with slam interest.

title: The Drama Hits Peak For Sonics And Suns
description: Eyewitnesses saw a trick shot, a trick ankle, a taunting foul and a 53-minute player.

title: 'The Most Despised'
description: To the Editor:

title: 3 Arrested in Swastika Painting
description: A 20-year-old and two teen-agers were arrested by police in Suffolk County today for painting swastikas and hate messages at 12 locations during a six-month period that ended in February.

title: FISHER SCIENTIFIC SHARES RETREAT BY ABOUT 16%
description: The stock of Fisher Scientific International Inc. dropped as much as 16 percent yesterday after the company posted first-quarter profits that were below Wall Street's expectations. Fisher, a Hampton, N.H., maker of scientific instruments, said it earned $11 million, or 53 cents a share, for the quarter ended March 31, compared with $4.5 million, or 27 cents a share, in the period a year ago. Analysts had predicted earnings of 56 cents a share. Fisher provides a variety of products and services to research, health care, industrial, educational and government markets in 145 countries. The company blamed unfavorable foreign exchange rates for the weak earnings.

title: After Censure, Chief Justice Of Illinois Quits
description: Facing possible impeachment for trying to use his position to escape speeding tickets, James Heiple resigned today as chief of the Illinois Supreme Court. He remains on the court as a justice.

title: Know Thyself
description: To the Editor:

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: Baseball

title: Bleeding Zaire
description: As the United States and Europe try to broker a resolution to the crisis in Zaire, they should carefully consider who or what might replace President Mobutu Sese Seko.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: GOLF

title: Ward, Down And Struggling, Plans to Follow Revived Rivals
description: Many American retailers suffer from one or two of the problems that plague the Montgomery Ward Holding Corporation. Few suffer them all.

title: Gilmour's Great in Shutting Down the Great One
description: It's a new spring and Doug Gilmour is again in his familiar spot in the Stanley Cup playoffs. For the fifth time in his playoff career, Gilmour was matched face to face with Wayne Gretzky tonight, this time in New Jersey of all places.

title: Playing to Fear
description: To the Editor:

title: Two Officers Are Cleared In a Killing
description: A Brooklyn grand jury has cleared two police officers in the killing of an unarmed man whom they shot 18 times after he entered a stolen car they had under surveillance, prosecutors said yesterday.

title: Ruling on Waste Disposal
description: In a decision that could result in huge savings for New Jersey cities and towns, a Federal appeals court ruled Thursday that the state cannot stop municipalities from trying to negotiate the best possible deal for waste disposal.

title: Russell G. Cleary, 63, Dies; Ex-Head of Heileman Brewing
description: Russell G. Cleary, who built the G. Heileman Brewing Company into one of the largest breweries in the country, died on Thursday in the Gundersen Lutheran Medical Center in La Crosse, Wis., of complications from heart surgery. He was 63.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GREEN, JOSEPH
description: GREEN-Joseph. On May 1 after a courageous battle with cancer. The family, friends and colleagues of this brilliant man mourn his loss. A memorial service will be held at Ethical Humanist Society, Garden City, on May 22 at 7P.M.

title: Voices From the 60's, in Harmony
description: Bella Abzug, whose voice and posture were once as vigorous as the cascades of political sparks she set off, approached the podium at Town Hall on Thursday night using a cane and looking frail. Then she looked around, began to speak, and a generation of time seemed to drop away. She wished she could clone everyone she saw: ''Then we could really change the world,'' she said, ''as we hoped to in the 60's.''

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Clinton and Republicans Agree to Balance Budget

title: DANCE
description: Mixing Traditional Hula

title: POLYGRAM OF THE NETHERLANDS IN U.S. EXPANSION
description: Polygram N.V. of the Netherlands said yesterday that it had set up a new United States distribution company, Polygram Films, in Hollywood to market 10 to 12 major movies each year. It said the new unit would distribute five films in its first year of operation, starting with Michael Douglas and Sean Penn in ''The Game,'' a thriller, and ''The Gingerbread Man,'' based on a John Grisham screenplay and featuring Kenneth Branagh, Daryl Hannah and Robert Duvall. Robin Williams will star in ''What Dreams May Come'' next year, when two other films are also planned.

title: Steinbrenner's Derby: Another Day, Another Run for the Glory
description: For George Steinbrenner, relaxed and easygoing at Churchill Downs on the day before the main event, winning the Kentucky Derby with Concerto would mean as much as winning the World Series with the Yankees six months ago. ''It would be a dead heat,'' he said.

title: From Welfare To Workfare, A Dead End
description: BEFORE Yolanda De Jesus got her workfare assignment recently, she had high hopes for her high-tech background. Maybe she would get a chance to use the computer skills she had learned in school or the managerial experience from her last job at an office machine company.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STEIN, MEL
description: STEIN-Mel. The Westchester Jewish Center records with great sorrow the passing of Mel Stein, the brother of our late past President, Allen A. Stein. Our condolences are offered to our members Elaine Stein Roberts and Bernie Roberts, to Sharon, Margot, Eric and Loren Stein, to Aryeh, Sammy, Alexander and Jonah. His philanthropic support of the Center will long endure. May his soul be bound up in the bonds of everlasting life. Howard Lazarus, President Jeffrey Segelman, Rabbi Dr. Irving Koslowe, Rabbi Em.

title: Add Elway to the List of Fassel's Successes
description: Much has been made about Giants Coach Jim Fassel's work with quarterbacks Boomer Esiason and Kent Graham. But what about what he did with John Elway?

title: Seeking Women Voters
description: The state Republican Party yesterday unveiled a new political action committee meant to attract women voters without political affiliation.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Beliefs
description: It has been many years since the poet and essayist Peter Viereck called anti-Catholicism ''the anti-Semitism of the intellectuals.'' For Roman Catholics who encounter hostility, condescension and stereotypes among circles that consider themselves singularly free of prejudice, Mr. Viereck's quip remains the last word on the topic.

title: Gasoline Is Sharply Lower On Signs of Adequate Supply
description: Gasoline prices tumbled yesterday on the New York Mercantile Exchange on signs that production and imports were keeping supplies ample in the United States.

title: Strongman In Albania Fights Back
description: As Albania tries to pick up the pieces after an insurrection and aims at the improbable goal of quick national elections, President Sali Berisha, the target of much of the fury, still acts like a man in charge.

title: Airline Passengers Have Reason to Rebel
description: To the Editor:

title: AFTER YEARS OF WRANGLING, ACCORD IS REACHED ON PLAN TO BALANCE BUDGET BY 2002
description: The Clinton Administration reached agreement with the Republican leadership today on a plan to balance the Federal budget in five years, using a last-minute financial windfall to help forge a deal that could alter the nation's economic and political landscape.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about Central Park misstated the telephone number for skating classes at the Wollman Rink. It is (212) 396-1010, extension 15.

title: INSIDE METRO
description: THE ART OF THE SPLIT -- The lesson to be taken from the breakup of Donald J. Trump and Marla Maples may have more to do with money and sex than with happiness and love. Page 27.

title: Prosecutors in McVeigh Trial Construct Case for Building of Bomb
description: Piece by piece, prosecutors in the Oklahoma City bombing case today introduced evidence about a three-week period in the fall of 1994 during which, they contend, Timothy J. McVeigh and his co-defendant, Terry L. Nichols, obtained and stored ingredients to build a giant bomb.

title: Paul Khan, 73, Food Safety Expert
description: Paul Khan, a consultant on food safety and regulatory compliance, died on April 21 at Sound Shore Hospital in New Rochelle, N.Y. A New Rochelle resident, he was 73.

title: Cone Gets Out of Jam, Then Gets Some Help
description: David Cone hustled from the pitcher's mound to the dugout after a precarious seventh inning tonight, exhaling and sweating with each quick step. Cone wanted a safe seat because he had narrowly avoided ruining a productive night. He was still clinging to a 2-1 lead, so he was happy.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCKEW, PATRICK ANTHONY
description: MCKEW-Patrick Anthony, of Malverne, on Thursday, May 1, 1997. Beloved husband of Maureen. Devoted brother of Mary and Joseph Sherry. Cherished brother-in-law of Ann and Jim Krebs. Also survived by several nieces and nephews. Reposing Saturday and Sunday 2-4 and 7-9 PM at the Flinch and Bruns Funeral Home, Inc. 34 Hempstead Avenue, Lynbrook. Mass of Christian Burial Monday May 5, 10:45 AM at Our Lady of Lourdes R.C. Church, Malverne. Interment Holy Rood Cemetery, Westbury. In lieu of flowers contributions to Nursing Sisters Home Visiting Service 1600 Stewart Avenue Westbury, NY 11590 would be appreciated.

title: Functioning Reactor at Three Mile Island May Be Sold
description: One of the two units of the Three Mile Island nuclear plant, the site of the nation's worst nuclear accident, may be put up for sale, the owner, GPU Inc., said yesterday.

title: Clinton Hails F.D.R. At Memorial's Opening
description: Hailed by President Clinton as ''the greatest President of this great American century,'' Franklin Delano Roosevelt was placed alongside Washington, Jefferson and Lincoln in the nation's political pantheon today with the opening of a sprawling outdoor memorial honoring his leadership during World War II and the Great Depression.

title: Constitution Protects Illegal Immigrants, Too
description: To the Editor:

title: The Earth Does a Slow Burn
description: We live on a new planet. That's what a string of recent scientific studies demonstrates. Because of global warming, caused by cars, factories and burning forests, the earth is shifting beneath us with stunning speed and unpredictability. Consider:

title: Isn't It a Crime?
description: To the Editor:

title: Harsh Rule
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: A chart of British election results in some copies yesterday reversed the totals for two parties in the old Parliament. The Conservative Party had 323 seats and the Labor Party 274. An updated chart appears today on page 7.

title: Firms Slice Big Board Stock Into Yet Smaller Fractions
description: Get ready for sixteenths.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  YAP, WILLIAM UY
description: YAP-William Uy, I (67). April 30, 1997. Survived by wife Lucita, children Rosemarie, Allan, Miriam, Lorna, William II, Melizza and ten grandchildren. Interment is on May 6 in San Fernando, Pampanga, Philippines.

title: S. Howard Goldman, 67, Owner Of Rare Copy of the Constitution
description: S. Howard Goldman, a New York real estate developer and a private collector of American autographs, documents and manuscripts, died on Tuesday at Memorial Sloan-Kettering Hospital. He was 67 and lived in New York City and New Canaan, Conn.

title: Democrats Divided on Price of Saving Rent Control
description: The Democrats in the State Assembly have seemed to speak with one voice throughout the bitter debate over the fate of the state's rent regulations: keep them intact, at all costs, because millions of their constituents would be hurt by changes.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about French politics misidentified one of four city governments controlled by the right-wing National Front. Along with Marignane, Orange and Vitrolles, the National Front controls Toulon, not Toulouse.

title: Checks After a Fatal Crash Find Flaws in Other Copters
description: The type of tail crack that caused a helicopter to crash in the East River on April 15 has been found in three other helicopters of the same design around the country, forcing their grounding, the Federal Aviation Administration said today.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DAVIS, RITA D.
description: DAVIS-Rita D. Of White Plains, NY, on May 2, 1997. Wife of Walter D. Davis. Mother of Edward D. Davis and the late Gary Davis. Mother-in-law of Irene Davis. Grandmother of Jesse, Gregory and Dylan. Funeral service on Sunday 12:30 PM at Temple Israel Center, White Plains, NY. Interment Sharon Gardens Cemetery. Memorial Contributions to Temple Israel Center, 280 Old Mamaroneck Road, White Plains, NY 10605, would be appreciated.

title: PLATINUM TECHNOLOGY STOCK INCREASES BY 10%
description: Platinum Technology Inc. stock gained 10 percent yesterday on news that it plans to cut about 400 jobs as part of a consolidation of its operations. Platinum Technology of Oakbrook Terrace, Ill., said it expected annual savings of $40 million from the consolidation of its sales, marketing, business development and product development operations. The maker of systems-software products said it expected its United States work force to be cut by about 280 and its international work force by about 120. The company employs about 4,400. Platinum Technology said costs associated with the job cuts are expected to reduce second-quarter earnings by $40 million to $45 million.

title: Jury in Florida to Decide Landmark Tobacco Case
description: Norwood S. (Woody) Wilner asked a six-member jury today to ''send a message'' to the nation's second-largest tobacco manufacturer, the R. J. Reynolds Tobacco Company, for selling what he called ''a poisonous product.''

title: New Brookhaven Lab Manager Says He's Sure Drinking Water Is Safe
description: After one day on the job, the interim manager of the Brookhaven National Laboratory said yesterday that he was confident the public drinking water around the laboratory was safe, even though the laboratory has leaked radioactive water for years, and he praised the lab as ''one of the premier research facilities in the country.''

title: Technology and Small Stocks Join Surge
description: The stock market finished a stunning weeklong rally yesterday that sent the Dow Jones industrial average within 14 points of its record high and saw the first sharp recovery in smaller stocks and technology issues since the selloff in March and April.

title: The Negotiators Forgo A Cut in Inflation Index
description: Congress and the Clinton Administration backed down yesterday, declining to impose on the nation an outsized reduction in the Consumer Price Index as part of their budget agreement. Instead, they decided simply to accept a future change expected to be made in the index, the nation's best-known inflation measure, by the statisticians and the economists who calculate it.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KELLNER, FLORA
description: KELLNER-Flora. Beloved wife of the late Irving. Devoted mother of Frances Heller, Caroline Lesser and dear sister of Harry Kosmacher. Adored grandmother of Keith and Kirby Heller, Stacey and Jill Lesser. Cherished great-grandmother of Jared, Gregory and Rebecca. Services Sunday 12 noon at the Riverside Nassau North Chapel, 55 North Station Plaza, Great Neck, opposite LIRR.

title: For Messier, A Record Isn't Enough
description: IF Reggie Jackson is Mr. October, Mark Messier is Mr. April-May-and-June.

title: The Battle for 'Gifted' Education
description: Public school programs for so-called ''gifted'' students have become an explosive issue in New York City. Many middle-class parents see gifted-student programs as safe havens in an otherwise mediocre system -- and threaten to withdraw if the programs are weakened. Advocates for minority groups attack the programs for remaining overwhelmingly white, while the school districts from which they draw students have become largely black and Hispanic. This is not just a local problem. Nationally, black and Latino children make up about 27 percent of the school population, but constitute less than 13 percent of students in gifted programs. Impoverished children tend to be poorly prepared. But racial stereotypes sometimes make it difficult for teachers to recognize gifted minority students when they actually appear.

title: Jewels of Romanovs Leave Russian Embassy for Tour
description: A tractor-trailer filled with priceless czarist artifacts left the Russian Embassy today, bound for a tour stop at a Texas museum, after three weeks of haggling between the Russian Government and a cultural foundation.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: ITT INDUSTRIES, New York, won a contract worth as much as $510 million from the Army to supply a single-channel radio system.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GREENBERG, BERNARD, MD.
description: GREENBERG-Bernard, MD. Beloved husband of Bernice. Devoted father of Dr. Steven Greenberg and Dr. Judith Greenberg. Cherished grandfather of Matthew Berman. Service Sunday May 4, 12:30PM, at The Riverside, 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: With Speed and Clarity, 'Sleeping Beauty'
description: The duel between light and darkness is at the heart of every Tchaikovsky ballet score and there is no doubt about which side triumphed on Thursday night. Opening its season at the New York State Theater with ''The Sleeping Beauty,'' the New York City Ballet rushed in with a blaze of glory.

title: CLASSICAL MUSIC
description: Subject, Chappaquiddick;

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PRICE, REBECCA (NEE: JOFFE)
description: PRICE-Rebecca (nee: Joffe), of Lakewood, N.J., on Wednesday, April 30, 1997. Age 89. Beloved wife of Jerome. Devoted mother of Matthew and Bennett. Dear sister of Edith Siegel. For information, contact Belkoff-Goldstein Jewish Memorial Chapel, Lakewood, New Jersey. Tel: 908-364-0900.

title: Renewed Calls For Expansion Of Javits Center
description: In New York City, where hotel, restaurant and convention executives have long complained about a space shortage at the 11-year-old Jacob K. Javits Convention Center, the opening of a new Atlantic City rival has only renewed calls for expansion.

title: The Most Valuable? It May Be Malone
description: Utah Jazz forward Karl Malone will be named the National Basketball Association's most valuable player, a published report said today. The Deseret News of Salt Lake City contacted 112 of the 115 voters and said it learned that Malone will unseat the Chicago Bulls' superstar, Michael Jordan, for the league's top honor, which will officially be announced later this month.

title: Convention Center Leads Effort To Broaden the Revival of a City
description: Atlantic City's new convention center opened this week, a muted steel, glass and sand-colored granite structure as long as six football fields and as wide as two that officials hope will be the key to transforming the city into a place travelers will want to visit for more than just a day of gambling.

title: Unfair Air Fare
description: To the Editor:

title: French See Lesson in Britain But Can't Agree on What It Is
description: There was a lesson in the British Labor Party's landslide victory this week. That much both French Socialists and the governing conservatives could agree on today as they battled in their own campaign for elections here at the end of the month. But they differed on what that lesson was exactly.

title: Culp Buying Fabric Units
description: Culp Inc. intends to acquire the upholstery fabric businesses of four operating units of Phillips Industries for $47 million. The transaction includes factories in Monroe, N.C., and Jamestown, N.C.; a printed fabrics converting business in High Point, N.C., and distribution centers in High Point; Tupelo, Miss., and Los Angeles. Both companies are based in High Point. Phillips Industries is privately held.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MEYERS, LAWRENCE H. M.D.
description: MEYERS-Lawrence H. M.D. Beloved husband of Rosalinde. Devoted father of Sandra Lieberman, Dr. Michael Meyers and Joy Berner. Dear brother of Sylvia Pine. Cherished grandfather of Adam, Alison, Rebecca and Jackson. Services Sunday 2 PM at Riverside Nassau North Chapel, 55 North Station Plaza, Great Neck, opposite LIRR.

title: Prince vs. Professor in a Legal Battle Over a Painting
description: When Donald L. Turcotte, a Cornell University geology professor, decided to sell an oil painting that had been in his family 40 years, he never expected to find himself ensnared in a legal battle involving a Polish prince and the Sotheby's auction house that has wended its way into two separate courthouses in New York State.

title: MATTEL IS PLANNING TO CLOSE A PLANT IN ENGLAND
description: Mattel Inc. of Los Angeles said yesterday that it would close a plant in Peterlee, in northeast England, cutting 250 jobs, and shift production of its Fisher-Price toys and Spears Games to Italy. Mattel, the world's largest toy maker, said the transfer would reduce production costs and was part of a broader reorganization of its European manufacturing. After buying the rival toy maker Tyco Toys Inc., the company took a $275 million pretax charge in the first quarter to combine operations at the two companies and cut some product lines. Mattel shares rose 62.5 cents, to $28.

title: Question in Boy's Arrest
description: The lawyers for a 16-year-old accused in the beating death of a girl whose body was found Monday in a Cumberland Regional High School locker room said yesterday that the arrest may be a case of mistaken identity.

title: Maybe the Winner Should Get Ellis Island
description: ''Dear Governor Pataki:''

title: Rangers Right Back in Hole Again After Game 1
description: Picking up right where they left off three years ago, the Devils and the Rangers opened another playoff round with another exquisitely tense game.

title: Chess Program for Kids

title: BOMBARDIER OF MONTREAL SELLS 4 PLANES TO BRAZIL
description: Bombardier Inc. of Montreal said yesterday that it had sold four de Havilland Dash 8Q aircraft to Brazil's Transportes Aereos Regulares S.A. for $48 million in United States currency. Bombardier said the Brazilian airline had taken delivery of two Dash 8 Series 200 freight or passenger aircraft from its Bombardier Regional Aircraft division. Two more aircraft, which carry 29 passengers, will be delivered later this year. The Brazilian airline operates in the country's tropical west and central regions, where the only alternative for freight transport is river barge.

title: No Way Out
description: To the Editor:

title: Blushing K.D. Leaves Oaks Field Reeling
description: Blushing K. D. left her rivals stunned, staggering and soaking wet while roaring to a powerful victory in today's $584,700 Kentucky Oaks, for 3-year-old fillies.

title: A Subdued Richter Has Praise for Brodeur
description: Even before this 2-0 loss to the Devils started, Mike Richter wished he had not insulted the Devils -- who already labor under a bit of an inferiority complex when their address is compared to that of the urban, urbane Rangers -- by feigning ignorance about the actual location of the Devils' off-ramp headquarters.

title: Seeking to Jump-Start Leasing, G.M. Cuts Prices on Electric Car
description: In an effort to bolster flagging lease rates of the EV1, a limited-range electric car introduced in Southern California and Arizona last December, the General Motors Corporation yesterday lowered the effective cost 25 percent and agreed to partly finance quick construction of 50 public charging stations.

title: A Toy With a Present, And Maybe Even a Future
description: Shoppers prefer blue or white, but for the last two days egg-shaped Tamagotchi cyber-pet toys in any of six colors have been flying off the shelves of selected toy stores across the country.

title: Battlefield Records Victory of Its Own
description: In October 1777, cannon and musket fire echoed across the Hudson River here as American troops, who were dug in on bluffs above the western shore, stopped the British advance toward Albany, 23 miles downstream. The battle of Saratoga was a turning point in the Revolutionary War.

title: No Headline
description: ''When the curtain falls, it's time to get off the stage and that's what I propose to do.''

title: Food, Race and Tragedy
description: The world of sport has been in shock for days about dietary remarks made by one golfer about another.

title: Lew Dietz, Writer, 90
description: Lew Dietz, who celebrated his native Maine in some 20 books and hundreds of magazine articles, died on April 26 at a hospital in Rockport, Me. He was 90.

title: Zaire Negotiations Collapse as Rebel Balks on Security
description: After a day of relentless confusion, diplomatic efforts to bring President Mobutu Sese Seko and the rebel leader, Laurent Kabila, together for shipboard talks fell through this evening when Mr. Kabila stood up his rival, refusing to fly to the vessel for security reasons.

description: The Knicks used to be the team that played long series and made their foes and NBC wait, but now they are checking their own watches and yawning while Miami and Orlando go the distance.

title: Crews Are Scarce To Put Up Towers For New Digital TV
description: In Austin, Tex., construction had to be halted for several months during the nesting season of the golden-cheeked warbler.

title: Rock's Green Party
description: TRAPPED between trays of Krispy Kreme Rainforest Crunch Doughnuts for a benefit reception at the John McEnroe Gallery on Monday, Sting, dressed in a fitted leather jacket, looked every bit the Englishman in New York. He was there with his wife, Trudie Styler, on behalf of their high-concept, low-key charity, the Rainforest Foundation International, which had its eighth annual Carnegie Hall benefit concert on Wednesday.

title: A Truth Self-Evident: American History Was in Part a Thing of the Pasta
description: LAST week in Washington, the Library of Congress opened what it describes as the largest permanent exhibition it has ever presented. It is the centerpiece of events marking the renovation of the library's 100-year-old Thomas Jefferson Building.

title: At Yale, Irish Traditions in Recital
description: IT is another very vocal Sunday, starting at 2 o'clock today when Themselves, comprising the singer Maura Molloy and three instrumentalists -- the guitarist Edward Wright, the violinist Kate O'Brien and the harpist Wendy Kerner Lucas -- explore Irish traditions in a free recital at the Yale Center for British Art.

title: When Paar Gently Ruled the (Late) Night
description: COULD Jack Paar make time for an interview about the public television documentary on his broadcasting career? ''We'll try for an hour,'' said the publicity man for WNET. ''But be prepared to stay longer,'' he added. ''Jack likes to talk, you know.''

title: T.W.A. Flight 800 Riddle Persists as Criminal Inquiry Ebbs
description: Nearly 10 months after the crash of Trans World Airlines Flight 800 off Long Island unleashed strong suspicions of terrorism, law enforcement officials are now in the last stages of their criminal investigation, still having found no evidence of sabotage.

title: Nicole Laurent And Michael Kern
description: Nicole Laurent, a daughter of Virginia and Pierre-Henri Laurent of Wellesley Hills, Mass., was married yesterday to Michael Edward Kern, a son of Lannie Woodside Kern of Springfield, Va., and Robert Edward Kern Jr. of Lake Winola, Pa. The Rev. Scotty McLennon, a Unitarian-Universalist minister, performed the ceremony at the Unitarian Society of Wellesley, Mass.

title: Two Ports, Hundreds of Jobs, Saved in Unusual Pact
description: THE sun glistened on Long Island Sound one day last fall, as an unlikely group gathered on shore at the former Cilco Terminal on Bridgeport Harbor. Bankers, business people, civic leaders and even a few members of Congress, all in business attire, mingled with longshoremen in jeans and T-shirts. Over a celebratory lunch of hamburgers and sodas, they listened as speakers, one by one, praised an unusual partnership. The longshoremen had bought both the terminal and its New Haven counterpart, in the process rescuing the two ports from bankruptcy, saving hundreds of jobs and sweetening Connecticut's commercial prospects.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GREEN, JOSEPH
description: GREEN-Joseph. On May 1 after a courageous battle with cancer. The family, friends and colleagues of this brilliant man mourn his loss. A memorial service will be held at Ethical Humanist Society, Garden City, on May 22 at 7P.M.

description: FOR investors, the cost of complaining seems about to go up.

description: Visitors to Rhode Island have always had a choice of land and water activities, and this summer, there will be two more.

description: In the following reports, the ''listed at'' price is the asking price when negotiations began that ended in the sale. Time on market is from most recent listing to contract.

description: ZAX-Harry. Of Paterson, NJ, on Saturday, May 3, 1997. Beloved husband of Shirley (nee Hollander) Zax. Devoted and loving father of Leonard A. Zax and his wife Helen, of Washington, DC. Cherished grandfather of David and Laura Zax. Brother of Helen Butler and Shirley Dinerman of NY. Services 1 PM, Monday, at Louis Suburban Chapel, 13-01 Broadway (Route 4 West), Fair Lawn, NJ. Contributions in his memory may be made to the National Building Museum in Washington, DC.

title: He Follows Own Advice On Tobacco
description: LITTLE boys wanted to bounce off walls just like Lenny. They wanted to wallow in the dirt just like Lenny. And they wanted that bulge in their cheek just like Lenny.
