description: MONDAY

title: New York City Celebrates A Century of Uneasy Unity
description: The Mayors of Brooklyn and New York vetoed the idea, only to be overridden by the State Legislature. Preachers in Brooklyn railed against it. The State Senate defeated it, then changed its mind.

title: Nameless No More
description: This weekend, millions of people around the world are taking time to remember the six million Jews and five million other people who died in the Holocaust.

title: Next, the Cruise Ship Rams the Village
description: THE DIRECTOR JAN DE BONT has loaded ''Speed 2: Cruise Control'' with just about every imaginable sea-going disaster short of a collision with an iceberg. The biggest stunt, he says, came to him in a dream: an out-of-control ocean liner running smack into a tranquil Caribbean village. And once he had the scene fixed in his mind, there was no turning back. The entire screenplay was written backward from that image, he says.

title: Ellen Frank And Peter Cohen
description: Ellen Frank, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Paul E. Frank of Meadowbrook, Pa., was married last evening to Peter Cohen, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Joel J. Cohen of New York. Rabbi David Lincoln officiated at the University Club in New York.

title: Then as Now, a City of Great Contrasts
description: The day before the consolidation of Greater New York became official, Juda Sielkopelowitz jumped off the roof of his Ludlow Street tenement.

title: The Island's Academic Excellence
description: THE news that students from Long Island public high schools captured 11 of the 40 national finalist spots in the Westinghouse Science Talent Search competition, and had some of the top finishers, was news that all Long Islanders must have welcomed. For too long, unfortunately, there seems to have been two public education systems on the Island. There is the one that most readers are familiar with from their local media. That is the system that is failing, the one that turns out children who cannot read, write or do math, the one with too many employees, the one dominated by teacher unions which protect overpaid and underworked teachers.

title: School Theater in Dire Need
description: The theater at Edward R. Murrow High School was packed on a Saturday night in January. The students were in the middle of the finale of a variety show. Then the stage lights flashed and went dim.

title: Give Workers Credit
description: To the Editor:

title: Braves, Not Marlins, May Have Done Best Remodeling Job in the N.L. East
description: The architect and his foreman reacted swiftly to the idea, and wasted no words in rejecting it.

title: A Compromise for 2002: Balancing the Federal Budget
description: President Clinton agreed on Friday to a compromise plan with Republicans to balance the Federal budget by 2002. Whether the plan will be enacted as written remains unclear, and murkier still is the question of whether it would actually eliminate the deficit in five years.

title: Look, Ma, No Pixels: Plastic Triumphs On the Set
description: ''BUBBLES UP! ACTION!'' the director said. The actor Jason Patric, trailed by two camera operators in wet suits, began thrashing waist-deep through a submerged corridor as the water rose around him. The movie was ''Speed II: Cruise Control,'' and Mr. Patric, portraying a passenger on a runaway cruise liner, was trying to find a missing girl before the leaking vessel tangoed with an oil tanker.

title: ALSO INSIDE
description: F.Y.I 2

title: Eclectic Menu That Demands an Appetite
description: ''WHAT kind of food do you serve?'' we asked when making a reservation at the Metro Grille & Bar in Shelton. Pause. ''I guess you could call it nouvelle,'' the voice on the phone responded. Well, not exactly. We'd call it eclectic -- a bit of Italy, Thailand, California and Mexico. In short, this large space inside a low-slung shopping center-strip mall touches many popular culinary bases. The only thing remotely nouvelle is the attempt to prettify the plates served.

title: Grueling Race Reborn After 8-Year Absence
description: It has been an eight-year hiatus for the Worrell 1000, a grueling catamaran race along 1,000 miles of coastline from Florida to Virginia. But now it's back, with 13 teams expecting to push off from the beach tomorrow at Fort Lauderdale, Fla. The realists among them are expecting the worst.

title: INSIDE
description: Nation on Trial in Bangladesh

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GROPPER, SYLVIA
description: GROPPER-Sylvia, on May 1, 1997 of Long Beach. Beloved wife of the late Morris Gropper. Mother of John Gropper and Liz Taffet. Beloved grandmother of six and great-grandmother of 9. Funeral at Gutterman's, Rockville Centre, Sunday, May 4, 12:45 PM. Memorial donations may be made to Franklin Hospital Medical Center.

title: Sent to For-Profit Home for Aid, Girl Dies at 15
description: Mystie Kreimeyer's childhood was marked by hard knocks and hard times, but she had a family that loved her and a place to call home until the State of Iowa removed her for her own good.

title: Antichromatic
description: From Fifth Avenue to SoHo, black and white is a popular combination this spring. Those who can't give up all black can walk with a friend in all white. There are black leather coats and jogging suits edged in white, coats with chevron stripes, and little black dresses with artful white lines. Women who lunch can't get enough of black and white Chanel (right top and bottom, and bottom far right). In Central Park, at a gathering of Dalmatians, a black and white dog wore a Dalmatian-patterned coat and hat with a black ostrich feather.

title: TAKING THE CHILDREN
description: Volcano

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  MAISLER, HERBERT
description: MAISLER-Herbert. May 5, 1996. To ''Papa'', our father of lightit has been one year since you entered the spiritual world and we have loved and missed you day in and day out. Our only consolation is you have found peace and tranquility. Your legacy of love, caring and compassion will remain in our hearts and minds forever. Fuddle, DeeDee-Doll, Kenendoyle, Audie, Neenie

title: Bad Habit
description: THE STORY OF JUNK

title: A Machine to Call Your Own
description: YOU may be miffed about paying surcharges for using automated teller machines. But be careful if think you see a way to cash in on the trend.

title: Chicago News Anchor Quits After Station Hires Jerry Springer
description: The decision by a Chicago television station to hire Jerry Springer, the host of a syndicated talk show, to provide commentaries on its nightly newscasts has led to the resignation of one of that city's most popular and respected television news anchors.

title: Tobacco Firms Appear Ready To Back Down On Immunity
description: Cigarette producers, faced with pressure from state attorneys general and public health groups, have dropped their demand for complete legal protection as a condition in the tobacco settlement talks, people involved in the negotiations said.

title: When Radio Comes to the Rescue
description: DURING the intense late winter storm that struck on April 1 and resulted in power failures in the northern part of the county, Dwight Smith left his Chappaqua home and went to an emergency shelter that had been set up by the Red Cross at Camp Smith in Peekskill. Mr. Smith, an amateur radio operator licensed by the Federal Communication Commission, took his radio equipment with him and kept county official in White Plains informed of developments at the shelter.

title: Smaller Is Wealthier
description: To the Editor:

title: A Gay Spring Ritual: Choosing Fire Island Shares
description: They came seeking succor, the promise of refuge from a scorching, unkind city. Theirs was a simple hope, a yearning for a place in the sun, maybe even a Jacuzzi. For a mere $2,500, the lucky might find a bed of their own -- every other weekend, that is -- in a house shared with 10 complete strangers.

title: When a Beagle in Distress Asks a Boy for Help
description: Shiloh

title: Cleaning Up Government (Park)
description: According to Skip Blumberg, a TV producer, there are rats down at City Hall. No, not those kind of rats, but real, honest-to-goodness rats, brazenly scavenging for food in City Hall Park, within sight of the Mayor's office.

title: A New York Fort Opens as U.S. Park Site
description: Fort Wadsworth, an important part of the defense of New York City for more than 200 years, is New York's newest National Park site.

title: Drugs! Aliens! Washington, Wake Up
description: IN the fifth year of his presidency, Bill Clinton is finally venturing into the United States' backyard, traveling to Mexico, Costa Rica and Barbados this week to meet with the heads of Caribbean nations. But as he opens what the White House grandly calls a ''new dialogue,'' the discussion is likely to be defined, as always, by a decades-old dependency on one side and cold strategic considerations on the other.

title: Hot Dog Emporium Closes, With No Relish
description: When Leo Cohen closed Leo's Famous, his hot dog emporium in Herald Square, last week, regular customers were saddened but not surprised.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WERTHEIMER, LAWRENCE
description: WERTHEIMER-Lawrence. Beloved husband of the late Rose. Devoted father of Joan Bernstein and Stephen Wertheimer. Dear brother of Mathilda Gladstone. Loving grandfather of Jan, John, Susan and Stacey. Adored greatgrandfather. Services, Cedar Park Cemetery, Emerson, NJ, Sunday 12:30 P.M. For information, ''Wien & Wien'', 1-800-322-0533.

title: Candy's Sweet, Debate Bitter
description: Vincent De Luca, a fund-raiser from the Pelham section, has heard about the candy bar debate, but he doesn't think much of it.

title: Critics Say P.S. 3 Plan Will Sap Character
description: Dozens of parents and teachers at Public School 3 are seething at the decision by the district superintendent, Anthony J. Alvarado, to restrict this fall's kindergarten class to pupils who live in the immediate neighborhood or who have a brother or sister already attending the school.

title: Lest a Sister's Memory Be Erased
description: On a dreary day last week, as we drove from her Fulton Street office to a synagogue in Woodmere, L.I., I tried to lighten Sharon Mear's mood with a story. I told her that when I was at Columbia I lived in a dorm called Livingston Hall. When I went back a few years ago, the dorm had been renamed Wallach Hall. The resident joke was that Robert Livingston signed the Declaration of Independence but that Ira Wallach signed the check.

title: Carol Palumbo Waits for Her Heart
description: I felt a rush of excitement as I glanced at the cover of your magazine and read the words ''Miracle in a Picnic Cooler.'' I was overjoyed to see Charles Siebert's article ''Carol Palumbo Waits for Her Heart'' (April 13). Less than six months ago, I sat in a hospital room 1,200 miles from home and waited anxiously for the telephone to ring. Every day, the hope of seeing my 20th birthday seemed more and more impossible, as the cystic fibrosis I was born with attacked my lungs. Late one night, I finally got the call, after generous parents made the difficult decision to donate their child's organs. I am eternally grateful to that family and feel a special bond with my donor that only transplant recipients can understand.

title: Kelly L. Martin, Gordon E. Muir Jr.
description: Kelly Lee Martin, the daughter of Denise R. Martin of New York and John H. Martin of Litchfield, Conn., was married yesterday to Lieut. Gordon Ely Muir Jr., the son of Sally and Gordon Muir of South Windham, Conn. The Rev. Henry Galganowicz performed the ceremony at the Episcopal Church of the Heavenly Rest in New York.

title: Alisann McGloin, Erik B. Fatemi
description: Alisann McGloin, the daughter of Mary and Hugh McGloin of Bronxville, N.Y., was married yesterday to Erik Byrd Fatemi, a son of Mona and Mohammad Fatemi of McLean, Va. The Rev. Lane J. Davenport, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony at the Church of the Ascension and St. Agnes in Washington. The Rev. Lawrence J. Madden, a Roman Catholic priest, took part in the ceremony.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SPRUNG, JEROME S.
description: SPRUNG-Jerome S. Suddenly and tragically on April 27. Beloved and cherished husband of Shirley, devoted father of Sara and Daniel, dear brother of Ilene Rogers, adoring grandfather of Juliet. Service 1 PM Sunday, Stephen Wise Free Synagogue, 30 West 68 St. Interment private. Contributions to American Cancer Society would be appreciated. For information call Plaza Memorial, 212-769-4400.

title: The Best Seller of Byzantium
description: Orhan Pamuk is sitting in his study on a hill overlooking Istanbul. Before him gleams the Bosporus, panning into the Sea of Marmara. On one shore lies the Greek-Ottoman Old City, with its sultans' palaces and Byzantine cathedral-turned-mosque. The other shore is Asia, shipyards and lighthouses. And at Pamuk's feet, cargo ships from Turkey's ancestral enemy Russia are parked in the harbor, disgorging traders from the ex-Soviet bloc who, since the collapse of Communism, have helped make Istanbul once again a multinational boom town.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FLATEMAN, IRWIN (PETE)
description: FLATEMAN-Irwin (Pete). Cherished Dad and Grandpa of Brina and Harold Rosenblatt, Ira and Craig; Bernard and Diane Flateman, Jennie and Sadie; Charles and Celia Flateman, Jonah, Timothy and Gabriel. We'll sing your songs, hear your guidance, feel your strong hugs. Always.

title: Kathleen Hines And David Roth
description: Kathleen Taylor Hines, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Bernard G. Hines Jr. of Tuscaloosa, Ala., was married there yesterday to David Ernest Roth, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Herbert F. Roth of New York. The Rev. Charles M. Durham performed the ceremony at the First Presbyterian Church.

title: Jennifer Farrin, Richard Emerson
description: Jennifer Lynn Farrin, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James Smith Farrin of New York, was married yesterday to Richard Parker Emerson, the son of Dr. and Mrs. Wayne L. Emerson of Hadley, Mass. The Rev. Dr. Thomas K. Tewell performed the ceremony at the Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church in New York.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHWARTZ, JEAN
description: SCHWARTZ-Jean. Died May 1, 1997, age 85, at Village Nursing Home. Dearest mother of Paul and Betty Schwartz, grandmother of Rachel and Raphael, sister of Shirley Panken and Edward Adler, beloved of Joseph Viola. You will be sorely missed and remembered forever. Viewing and service Tuesday, May 6, at 9 AM, at Crestwood Memorial Chapel, 33 Spring Street (near Mott St.), NYC.

title: Don't Be Fooled
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  SABSEVITZ, RHODA
description: SABSEVITZ-Rhoda. March 1, 1992 and Meyer for April 22, 1993. Even though your voices are no more, your love and guidance will always be a part of us. We shall always miss you. Your loving children, grandchildren and greatgrandchild.

title: Baffert Makes Good on a Second Chance
description: A quest that began eight years ago and that came tantalizingly close to being realized last year was completed in all its glory today for the trainer Bob Baffert. It was picture perfect.

title: Corrections
description: A front-page picture caption on April 20 about fishermen in Jamaica Bay reversed the names of two men shown in a group of five. Bobby Raduazzo was standing at the far left; Richie Knauer was immediately to the right of him.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  MARKFIELD, ELLEN
description: MARKFIELD-Ellen, May 5th, 1996. You are never away from your home in my heart. There is never a day when you don't play a part. Love, Bill Enrich

title: The Buzz in Lincoln Park Is a Model Airplane Club
description: From the sound, you might think a swarm of killer bees has made it north and is waiting around the bend of wooded Two Bridges Road in Lincoln Park. Instead, you find a field full of people spinning buzzing model planes, at the end of steel cables, in circles above their heads. A sign announces they are the Garden State Circle Burners. Considered one of the oldest control-line clubs in the country, the group has been meeting in Lincoln Park for 40 years. The grassy field has three small concrete runways and three concrete circles where members fly their balsa airplanes, which can vary in wingspan from 2 to 10 feet, with most of them around 4 feet. It was named the George L. Gaydos Memorial Field a few years ago, after a longtime member.

title: With No. 3, Stevens Joins Fast Company
description: He got his fix. The jockey Gary Stevens this week described the Kentucky Derby as a drug he craved ever more since winning the race on two previous occasions, in 1988 and 1995.

title: Live and Learn
description: FILL out the one-page application form, and drop it off at the admissions office. Ask your high school to send a copy of your transcript -- you need not worry about the D you got in chemistry -- and answer some questions about your health. Then, presto: you are admitted to Brookdale Community College, a two-year institution with 28 programs to choose from and a pastoral campus here just off the Garden State Parkway.

title: Empty or Not, Lot Catches City's Eye
description: A game of bureaucratic musical chairs nearly ended the American dream of an immigrant family.

title: On the Trail of Rogue DNA
description: Cellmark diagnostics, based in Germantown, Md., performed DNA tests for the prosecution in what company brass proudly call ''O. J. 1'' and ''O. J. 2.'' True, the first jury didn't buy its results. But Cellmark's lab-of-record fame has steadily increased, and it has been hired to help solve this year's marquee mystery: the JonBenet Ramsey case. With experts now working on an analysis that is expected soon, Cellmark opened its doors for a peek behind the scenes.

title: Sand Plan Encounters Skepticism
description: A PLAN to mine sand from a park in Smithtown and use the site for a transfer station for trash first encountered fierce opposition and later -- after Supervisor Patrick Vecchio had made a change -- skepticism.

title: A Banquet Of Classics On the Table In London
description: ''OFF, OFF YOU LENDINGS!'' bawls King Lear as madness overwhelms him, and, in every production of Shakespeare's play that I recall, he is stopped from stripping naked by a solicitous Fool.

title: Learning More About Some City Icons
description: Some of the city's architectural signatures can be seen from its highest heights, through a camera lens and from the vantage point of brownstone experts in forthcoming tours, talks and an exhibition.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: GOLF

title: Bringing It All Back Home
description: INVISIBLE REPUBLIC Bob Dylan's Basement Tapes. By Greil Marcus. 286 pp. New York: Henry Holt & Company. $22.50.

title: The Myriad Sides Of Rent Regulation
description: THE 54-year-old rent regulatory system has grown so complex that in a 50th-anniversary report on it in 1993 the State Division of Housing and Community Renewal took 26 pages to provide a glossary of terms.

title: Students' Visit to Narnia Is Lost to Bad Scheduling
description: It was their once-a-year day: a field trip to the Paper Mill Playhouse in Millburn, with lunch a half-hour before the performance, in Taylor Park, two blocks away. Kay Rosenberg's fifth graders from the Nathan Hale School in Northvale had the lunch.

title: In School, and Saving
description: Children aren't so different from you and me. They like to spend money -- whether on video games or Nikes. But more and more of them seem to be learning about saving and investing for the future from their parents and guardians.

title: Stores
description: How could you pay so little attention to Internet retailing, the fastest-growing and most significant trend in the way people browse, and buy, products?

title: Fast-Growing Gateway to Litchfield
description: STANDING at the gateway to Litchfield County, New Milford is geographically the largest and one of the fastest growing municipalities in Connecticut, with more than 20,000 acres of undeveloped land.

title: All-Terrain Boards: Where No Board Has Gone Before
description: WHAT The all-terrain board -- a warm-weather answer to snowboarding and a downhill answer to skateboarding. A hybrid of both, with a little mountain bike thrown in, the all-terrain board is mounted on four beefy off-road tires that can carve fluid snowboardlike ''S'' curves on everything from asphalt to grass to rocky trails. Unlike the more horizontally happy skateboard, all-terrain boards are designed for hills. Average cruising speed: 10 miles an hour.

title: The Case for Rent Regulation
description: Here's where Bill Eimicke comes out on rent regulation: ''Fundamentally, I have a problem with it, and I can understand anyone who believes in the United States system of capitalism would have a problem.'' Despite these reservations, he's for keeping some version of rent regulation -- doing away with it would be even worse. ''There's more to risk than there is go gain.''

title: MetroStars Set To Face Galaxy
description: Antony De Avila and Giovanni Savarese, the MetroStars' top scorers this season, have returned from World Cup qualifying and will start today against the Los Angeles Galaxy at Giants Stadium.

title: At the Casinos
description: What's happening onstage at all the Atlantic City casinos this week.

title: I Am More Than Hands
description: Bendetson writes of the road that I, too, have traveled. When my spouse suffered a massive stroke at the age of 44, I was pregnant with our second child. There was no one in my circle of acquaintances who was like me: struggling with the problems of chronic illness at the same time I was involved in the challenges of child rearing.

title: A La Mode
description: To the Editor: Michael Mewshaw's essay ''The Existential Burger'' (April 6) was a delight. It recalled my own experience in the Mysterious East, a k a France.

title: Opening a Window to the Inner Souls of Artists, in a New Novel
description: FERNANDA EBERSTADT grew up with a gold Marilyn Monroe silkscreen by Andy Warhol in her parents' Victorian living room on the Upper East Side of Manhattan.

title: Reading Bill's Mind
description: Just when I should feel terrific about my economic boom making possible my budget deal, I can feel the damn prosecutors closing in.

title: Where the Street Meets the Strip
description: ALL I needed to hear was that investment guru Howard J. Ruff was going to be at ''The Money Show'' this past week here, the gambling mecca of the Western world. I didn't care that I would be lunching with the legendary Louis Rukeyser. I was blase about partaking in seminars where I could quiz famous forecasters like Elaine Garzarelli.

title: Iranian Jews Blend Into Island Life
description: SEVERAL decades ago, in Iran, in the holy Muslim city of Mashad, Alfred Dilamani's grandfather was forbidden to touch the fruit on a vendor's stand. Instead, he had to point to his selection from a distance, for fear of contaminating it by virtue of being Jewish.

title: Environment Is Added As a Spoleto Performer
description: For its 21st season, the Spoleto Festival U.S.A. will add an environmental art exhibition exploring the changing landscape of Charleston, S.C., the performing arts festival's home. The exhibition, ''Human-Nature: Art and Landscape in Charleston and Low Country,'' will be on view from May 23, the festival's opening day, through July 20. Stretches of the city's waterfront and an allee of live oaks on a historic plantation are among the 14 sites for works created by artists from the United States, Europe and South Africa.

title: Corrections
description: An article on April 13 about the Turkish city of Bursa referred incorrectly to its history as a capital. It served in that role for only one empire, the Ottoman, not two. The article also misstated the date Bursa became the capital; it was in the 14th century, no the 15th.

title: Books in Brief: Nonfiction
description: SPINELESS WONDERS

title: A Use for Governors Island: Clubs People Love to Hate
description: To the Editor:

title: Some of Their Best Friends Are Jews
description: Your article evoked a lot of comments from the folks around the pool. I'd like to share some of them with you: ''I don't know whether to laugh or cry. We give them a nice Jewish boy to worship, five books -- no charge. And what do we get in return? Crusades, the Inquistion, pogroms, the Holocaust. And now they want us to join them in heaven? I'll take hell any day!''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WARSHAWSKY, ROY I.
description: WARSHAWSKY-Roy I. age 81; beloved husband of Sarita, nee Sherman; loving father of Ilene (Michael) Shaw and Carol (Michael Steinberg) Warshawsky; proud grandfather of Caroline and Elizabeth Shaw, Daniel, Andrew and James Steinberg; fond brother of Lowell Warshawsky, dear uncle of many nieces and nephews; devoted son of the late Nellie and Israel Warshawsky. Services were held Tuesday, April 29, 1997, in Chicago, IL. In lieu of flowers, memorials in his name may be made to the charity of the donors choice. For information, please call The Piser Chapel 1-888-67-PISER

title: Where Gay People Find Community
description: IN a major success story for the practical application of knowledge, John D. Allen's master's thesis was transformed into a community center -- specifically, the New Haven Gay and Lesbian Community Center, which officially opened just before Valentine's Day.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PECHENIK, NORMA
description: PECHENIK-Norma. Beloved wife of the late Charles Isaac. Devoted mother of Stephen, Marjorie Rosenthal and Linda Montague. Dear sister of Sue Shapiro, Barry Berns and Lilly Edelstein. Loving grandmother of Anthony, Rebecca Elovic, Jacob, Ana, Pamela Rosenthal, Lisa Rosenthal, Eric Rosenthal, Timothy Montague, Peterpaul Montague and Benjamin Montague. Cherished great grandmother. Funeral service Monday, 12 noon, at ''Plaza Memorial Chapel,'' 91st and Amsterdam Ave. In lieu of flowers, contributions to the Norma B. Pechenik Alzheimer's Respite Fund or UJA Federation, 130 E. 59th St., NY, NY.

title: A Divided Jersey City Prepares for an Election
description: Voters here, by most accounts, are an unyielding and unforgiving lot. In nearly three decades, no mayor has been elected to two successive full terms. But this is politics at its most pragmatic, and candidates are more likely to be judged by what they can deliver than by where they have been.

title: The Bulbs of Summer in Their Graceful Frocks
description: Every spring, I fall a little more in love with species, or unhybridized, tulips, which come back year after year. Tulipa tarda is shaped like a white star, and it has a center as yellow as an egg yolk. It was my favorite last year, but then I planted T. wilsoniana, which is a deep vermilion with a black center and yellow anthers. Its leaves are blue-gray edged with red.

title: Realizing a Dream at an Appliance Store
description: AN appliance store in downtown White Plains would hardly seem to be the stuff dreams are made of, but for Stuart M. Royal it is just that.

title: Track Games to Draw Stars to White Plains
description: CRAIG A. MASBACK and Aimee Mullins are extraordinary athletes. He became a champion. She continues to compete with no hope of winning. Yet they are bringing strikingly similar messages to the nearly 1,000 elite high school track and field athletes from Virginia to Canada who will converge here next Friday and Saturday for the 30th annual Loucks Games.

title: Making a Dime's Worth of Difference
description: IN many government buildings, visitors are made to feel like annoyances, deadbeats or potential terrorists.

title: What's Up at the New Old Shubert Theater
description: CAROLINE WERTH, ''a New York City kid,'' as she puts it, is the president and chief operating officer of the Shubert Performing Arts Center and one of New Haven's most enthusiastic cheerleaders. ''You come into a city that is fun, has life, that is safe,'' she said.

title: The Stronger Dollar Chases Fewer Bargains Abroad
description: IF Americans picked their foreign destinations by the breaks they get when the dollar strengthens, there would be a flood of tourists to Turkey, Ecuador, Hungary and Japan this summer.

title: Who Financed Surplus?
description: To the Editor:

title: The Last of a Historic Plant Making Way for a Mall
description: ALL that is left of a 91-acre industrial complex on Conklin Street east of Route 110, where the Republic Aviation Corporation and successor companies once produced thousands of fighter planes, is a squat, 607,600-square-foot brick-and-concrete structure known as Building 17.

title: ZAIRIAN PRESIDENT IS READY TO QUIT, U.S. DIPLOMATS SAY
description: With rebel forces closing in on the capital, President Mobutu Sese Seko of Zaire has said he will resign after nearly 32 years in power, American diplomats said today.

title: The Newest Tour Guide Is on a Computer
description: Sidewalk, a new city guide by the software giant Microsoft, is a knowledgeable and suave electronic escort.

title: Social Responsibilities
description: To the Editor:

title: Using Auctions to Your Advantage
description: THERE are a number of places to buy furniture for your home: department or furniture stores, thrift shops, flea markets and antique stores. Auctions are another good source for furnishings.

title: Revival of the Hudson Remains a Challenge
description: THE Mayor of this village, Dennis P. Flood, always knew it would be a tough sell, but that didn't stop him from dreaming.

title: Hillary Clinton Loses Her Rights
description: On July 11, 1995, and again on Jan. 26, 1996, Hillary Rodham Clinton met with her private attorney and White House lawyers. The first meeting was about Mrs. Clinton's activities following the death of Vincent Foster, the deputy White House counsel. The second meeting was about her grand jury testimony.

title: Critiquing the Critics: Every Director's Dream
description: IT WAS THE ULTIMATE ''man-bites-dog'' idea. Four London theater critics swapped places with four directors: the critics would direct plays and the directors would write the newspaper reviews. Entertainment, on stage and off, seemed assured. Would the critics prove to be talented or simply arrogant? Would the directors go for the jugular or demonstrate how reviews should be written?

title: Figaro Isn't What It Was But Still Pushes Forward
description: To the Editor:

title: Carol Palumbo Waits for Her Heart
description: The economics of organ transplantation are too disconcerting to dismiss with the flippant remark that ''those without coverage don't make the cut.'' There are now more than 40 million Americans who do not have health insurance. In this brave new world of managed care, even some people who think that they have coverage can find that their H.M.O. may not authorize a transplant or may delay authorization until it is too late.

title: Breaks for Mental Illness: Just What the Government Ordered
description: IMAGINE, for a moment, that you are Joe Widgetmaker, chief executive of a small family-owned company. You hire a blind person, you install Braille buttons in the elevator. You hire a paraplegic, you build a ramp and lower the water fountain. You do this because you are a nice guy. Not to mention that Federal law requires it.

title: Giving Writers, And Films, Credit
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WYMAN, MARJORIE (NEE WEINSTOCK)
description: WYMAN-Marjorie (nee Weinstock). 64, of St. Louis, on May 1, 1997. Died of complications of lung cancer. Survived by her children Frank of Short Hills, NJ, Jean of Beverly Hills, CA; and grandchildren Alice and Bert; devoted companion Maynord C. Rosen; loving sister Dorothy Marks and brother Charles Weinstock. Marge was a graduate of Dalton School, NYC, 1950, and Vassar College 1954. She was an accomplished interior designer, past president of Eastern Missouri Section of ASID and board member of the national group. A discriminating collector of American Folk Art, she was a benefactor of the St. Louis Municipal Arts Society, the St. Louis Opera Theater and St. Louis Art Museum, where she was a board member. A woman of great intellect, sharp wit, generous spirit and great courage, Marge will be missed by her family and her many friends in St. Louis, Baltimore, and New York.

title: Samantha Berg, Marc Tishkoff
description: Samantha Corey Berg, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Frederick L. Berg of New City, N.Y., was married last evening to Marc Adam Tishkoff, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Dennis B. Tishkoff of Columbus, Ohio. Rabbi Dennis N. Math performed the ceremony at Windows on the World in New York.

title: AT&T Takes Lead on a Plan To Cut Long-Distance Rates
description: Residential long-distance telephone rates will fall significantly in the next several years under a new plan negotiated by the AT&T Corporation and the Federal Communications Commission, officials said today.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL 3-20

title: Knicks Fly Home and Await a Foe
description: The Knicks' three-day retreat to Charleston ended today as the team flew back to New York knowing that by late Sunday afternoon they will know who they play in the second round of the Eastern Conference playoffs.

title: In Albanian Countryside, Chaos Yields to Tradition of Civility
description: In the tiny house that sits on top of a mountain with no roads, the women of the Beci family brought into the main room the first dishes for the Muslim celebration of Bairam, which marks the end of the fasting period of Ramadan.

title: None Dare Call It Pilates
description: Joseph Pilates, inventor of a popular exercise system featuring yogalike stretches on resistance machines, never sought a trademark. Instead, says Deborah Lessen, who has been teaching Pilates (puh-LAH-tiss) from her SoHo home since 1982, he bequeathed it to the world, through a core group of followers who ''went out and spread the work.''

title: I Am More Than Hands
description: In her article, Bendetson criticized ''Marvin's Room'' for its romanticized view of care-giving. As another care-giver -- of elderly parents -- I had a similar reaction to ''The English Patient.'' In the real world, not a picturesque Italian ruin, a thin, young woman would not be able to lift or turn that patient, and he would, in all likelihood, be soaked in his own urine, covered with festering bedsores.

title: Shazam!
description: SNOW IN AUGUST

title: Not Even One
description: To the Editor: Tom Simmons's list of souvenirs in ''Truckin' '' (March 23) contains one item that should definitely not be there. Point Reyes National Seashore is part of the national park system, and as such, everything there is protected by law. If everyone took ''just one'' piece of chert, as Mr. Simmons did, soon there would be none left for the rest of us to enjoy. With the increasing numbers of visitors to our national parks, we must treat them even more gently. ''Take only photographs, leave only footprints.''

title: Denise Dubin and Max Parker
description: Denise de Bourbon Dubin, a daughter of Maria de Bourbon Dubin of New Canaan, Conn., and Ronald N. Dubin of Greenwich, Conn., was married yesterday to Max Everett Parker, a son of Jane Everett Parker of Jupiter, Fla., and John R. Parker of Chestertown, Md. The Rev. William A. Evertsberg performed the ceremony at the First Presbyterian Church of Greenwich.

title: Shuffleboard Without a Shuffle
description: The game of shuffleboard takes a certain finesse, a particular stamina and an exact playing field.

title: Casino Board Bans Wholesaler, Citing Ties to Organized Crime
description: A Gloucester City seafood company has been barred from doing business with Atlantic City casinos because it hired a salesman who the authorities believe is the head of one the largest organized crime families in Philadelphia and South Jersey.

title: Corrections
description: An article in the Neighborhood Report on April 20 about the proposed expansion of a roller hockey rink on East 96th Street misidentified a community group that commented and misstated the title of a staff member. The group is the Stanley M. Isaacs Neighborhood Center, not the Stanley M. Isaacs Neighborhood Association. The staff member, Howard Knoll, is director of youth services, not president.

title: Lynn Dennis, Stanley Fried
description: Lynn Carol Dennis and Stanley Fried are to be married today in New York. Rabbi Robert Block is to perform the ceremony at the Eldridge Street Synagogue.

title: May to September, A Lot of the Action Occurs in the Heart
description: ''I DO.'' TWO LITTLE WORDS. IN classical theater, marriage signals the audience that the world is a benevolent place, safe for love. And when the movies came along, with stories about a woman and a man finding their way toward each other, that tradition continued.

title: Rianne Rosenberg, Matthew Sappern
description: Rianne Edith Rosenberg, a daughter of Dr. Ruth Rosenberg and Rabbi Roy A. Rosenberg of Brooklyn, was married last evening to Matthew David Sappern, a son of Judith and Donald Sappern of Westport, Conn. The bride's father performed the ceremony at Bridgewaters, a catering company in New York.

title: Narciso Yepes, Spanish Guitarist And an Innovative Musician, 69
description: Narciso Yepes, a Spanish guitarist who expanded his instrument from its normal 6-string configuration to a setup using 10 strings and who made dozens of recordings of a repertory that ran from Renaissance to contemporary works, died yesterday in Murcia, Spain. The Spanish news agency EFE said the cause was cancer. He was 69 years old.

title: WESTCHESTER BRIEFS
description: Bomb Investigation

title: An Opportunity to Cozy Up To an Elusive Genius
description: AS IF FRANZ SCHUBERT HADN'T left puzzles enough for posterity with his many incomplete works and other abandoned trails and blind alleys. After his death, the manuscript of his song ''Death and the Maiden'' was cut into pieces by a stepbrother to furnish ''relics'' of the composer, and it has been only incompletely reassembled. With its gaping holes, it stands as a poignant symbol of how hard it is to piece together an understanding of the life and works of this elusive genius from so distant a perspective.

title: Asking a Lawyer to Lift Tobacco's Haze
description: LAWSUITS are Calvert D. Crary's bread and butter. A managing director of the securities firm of Auerbach, Pollak & Richardson in Stamford, Conn., Mr. Crary, a 53-year-old lawyer, is what is known as a litigation analyst: he helps investors figure out how court actions might affect them.

title: Ridding the City of Riley And Other Imponderables
description: The ghost in the New York sports machine is still Pat Riley, that leather-haired glibster, floating through the Kingdom of Hoopla with a motivational language all his own. Who can forget how the ''winner within'' overcame ''the disease of me'' to hurl ''thunderbolts'' and ''crack the core''? Was it any wonder that Patrick Ewing did not speak complete sentences for years at a time?

title: An Alternative To Costly Funerals
description: To the Editor:

title: Books in Brief: Fiction
description: Billy Gashade

title: Beetle Battles Begin Long Before Heat
description: ALTHOUGH the beetles themselves will not be around until the hot summer months, their larvae (grubs) may be at work now. And these underground nibblers represent a double whammy that gardeners could do without.

title: A Virtuoso's Personal Songbook
description: BOBBY SHORT'S FANS HAVE LONG known that he is the proverbial walking encyclopedia of great popular songs, but what are his favorites? ''I'm a sentimentalist who likes songs that are pretty and intelligent and that an audience can relate to,'' he said. Here are 10 of his selections, in no particular order.

title: Illegal Immigrants Who Missed Amnesty Period Lose Suit Again
description: Upholding a provision of the new immigration bill, a Federal appeals panel has dismissed a lawsuit filed on behalf of thousands of illegal immigrants who missed a deadline for a 1980's amnesty program.

title: Melinda Weir, Erik Sorensen
description: Melinda Grace Weir, a daughter of Joan Battin Weir of Delray Beach, Fla., and the late Mahlon Slane Weir, was married yesterday to Erik Thomas Sorensen, a son of Mr. and Mrs. David F. Sorensen of Ramsey, N.J. The Rev. Dr. Richard M. Cromie, a Presbyterian minister, performed the nondenominational ceremony at the the Royal Poinciana Chapel in Palm Beach, Fla.

title: Truth in Feminism
description: NOTES FROM AN INCOMPLETE REVOLUTION

title: Pariahs of the City: 24 Hours in a Cab
description: AT 4:11 A.M., Tasneem Khan carefully spread a green prayer rug across the linoleum floor in his apartment in Ridgewood, Queens. Dressed in jeans, a navy blue golf shirt and a white Muslim prayer cap, he was a study in contrasts. Softly murmuring prayers in Arabic, he turned his stocky frame toward Mecca. Slowly rocking back and forth, Mr. Khan, a 35-year-old Pakistani immigrant, readied himself for a grueling 12-hour-shift as New York's work horse, pariah and ambassador to the world.

title: Opera's Fountain Of Youth
description: The 27th annual conference of Opera America, which ended Wednesday in Philadelphia, was unusually festive. Small wonder! At a time when classical-music audiences are said to be aging and declining, opera seems exempt.

title: Booking Cruises
description: To the Editor: An enthusiastic letter from Harold F. Goodman of Los Angeles on March 16 referred to ''Penguins and Politics in Antarctica,'' an article by Rebecca Pepper Sinkler a year ago. Like Mr. Goodman, my husband and I were fascinated by the account of the trip sponsored by the Philadelphia Academy of Natural Sciences. We, too, quickly telephoned the academy, on a regular business day, not Sunday, and were greeted by a recorded message requesting our phone number and request, etc. We indicated an interest in the Antarctic trip. Unlike Mr. Goodman, we did not receive a response (we have an answering machine), and so called again on another business day, with the same lack of response. No success!

title: G.O.P. Edge on Budget
description: With a broad agreement on balancing the Federal budget in hand, the power to make it law rests largely with the four House and Senate chairmen, all Republican, who control the tax writing and appropriations committees. Each has a different style, temperament and agenda.

title: Lost Something?
description: You're sure you put those documents on your desk yesterday, but now they're gone. Or at least you can't find them under the stacks of other papers that have arrived in the last 24 hours. Have you ever misplaced some important work? What happened when you did? Send your best stories to On the Job, Money and Business, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036. Or send them by electronic mail to onthejob@nytimes.com. Include your telephone number. Deadline is Tuesday. All submissions become the property of The Times and may be republished in any medium.

title: The Permanently Poor
description: MYTH OF THE WELFARE QUEEN

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PRAGER, ELEANOR
description: PRAGER-Eleanor. April 20, 1997. Beloved wife to Sig Prager for sixty-six years, devoted mother to Nancy Prager Benett Kamel and the late Judith Prager and loving aunt to Barbara Land. Adored grandmother to Lara Benett Adler, Andrew Benett and Ariane Benett. Services private. In lieu of flowers, kindly send memorials to NY Metro Committee for UNICEF, 633 Third Avenue, New York, New York 10017.

title: In Moscow, U.S. Hushes Walls That Have Ears
description: For more than a decade, the chancery building of the United States Embassy in Moscow -- red brick, empty and forlorn -- was a historical landmark, a cautionary monument to cold war espionage.

title: A Literary Tour of Small-Town Maine
description: ''WE unconsciously catch the tone of every house in which we live,'' Sarah Orne Jewett once wrote, ''and we are influenced by surroundings nearer and closer still than the climate of the country which we inhabit.'' I recalled those words, by an author I have admired for years, as I drove along busy I-95 on a literary pilgrimage to Jewett's beloved hometown, South Berwick, in southern Maine.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LUTZ, WILLIAM CHARLES
description: LUTZ-William Charles. December 12, 1911-April 14, 1997. Bill Lutz was born in Brooklyn, NY. He met ''the light of my life,'' Natalie Trentowski, at the end of a fencing foil in 1937. They were married in 1940 and had three daughters: Winifred, Barbara, and Beverly. In 1945/46, he served as an Army Corps of Engineers 1st Lieutenant in Manila, the Philippines, utilizing his real estate appraisal skills in the reconstruction efforts. He had joined the New York Life Insurance Company at age 14 as office boy, and rose to Senior Vice President in charge of Real Estate and Mortgage Loans during his 51 years there. He was highly regarded for his ethical integrity, social conscience, and irreverent humor. His business career included membership in the Institute of Real Estate Appraisers, Institute of Real Estate Management, Chicago Real Estate Board, Mortgage Advisory Committee of the New York State Employees' Retirement System, and Advisory Board of NYU's Real Estate Institute. Bill's energy was boundless and his ability to focus this energy over a breadth of interests was amazing. A skillful self-taught carpenter, he obtained a patent on an adjustable rocking horse, remodeled four homes, built exquisite bookcases for his bibliophile wife. He exercised his considerable flair for drama at church play-reading groups and took his family camping in the national parks every summer. He served on the boards of the many Unitarian Universalist Churches he joined as his family moved across the U.S. due to his promotions at NYLIC. He also found time to write eloquent letters to the government against the Vietnam War, supporting reproductive rights, decrying pollution, advocating gun control and the fight against racism. On retirement, he embarked on an active schedule of Elderhostels, and also served as an RTM member in Greenwich, CT. Late in his 70's, he became a volunteer income tax counselor for ''the old folks,'' ESL tutor, and blood donor to age 80. He will be remembered for his creativity, commitment to family and friends, his love of laughter, his embrace of life. After his wife died, Thanksgiving Day, 1996, Bill dreamt he heard her say, ''why don't you join me?'' A confirmed secular humanist, he responded, ''where are you?'' All of us who loved this remarkable, generous man are sure that he will find her. Memorial service, May 31, 3:30 PM, Unitarian Society of Stamford, CT (203-348-0708). In lieu of flowers, the family requests contributions in his name to Environmental Defense Fund, 257 Park Ave., NY, NY or Unitarian Society, 20 Forest St., Stamford, CT 06901.

title: Still Far to Go
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Cooking School Opens
description: FOR those who want more than takeout food for dinner, Peter Kump's Cooking School opened last Thursday in the new D'Agostino supermarket in the Rye Ridge Shopping Center in Rye Brook.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STEIN, MELVIN
description: STEIN-Melvin. The officers, leadership, and staff of UJA-Federation of New York mourn the passing of Melvin Stein. Mr. Stein, his wife, Elaine, and his family have long been generous & devoted supporters of UJA-Federation. His sister-in-law, Elaine Roberts, is a longtime, dedicated friend of the Women's Campaign. We extend our deepest sympathies to his wife, Elaine; his children, Stuart and Roger; his sister, Toby Rozen; Elaine Roberts; his grandchildren; and the entire family. May you be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Larry A. Silverstein, Board Chair Louise B. Greilsheimer, President Stephen D. Solender, Exec. V.P.

title: Alexandra Mairs And Brian Tart
description: Alexandra Mairs, a daughter of Tanya E. Mairs and James L. Mairs, both of New York, was married yesterday to Brian Sullivan Tart, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Brian J. Tart of Fairfield, Conn. The Rev. George W. Busler performed the ceremony at St. Mark's Episcopal Church in Westhampton Beach, N.Y.

title: Overwhelmed by Good News
description: Journalism -- An ability to meet the challenge of filling the space.

title: Still Lifes and Sculpture Mark Spring
description: A CRABAPPLE tree outside my window is marking the onset of spring with blossoms the color of raspberries and cream. Two Westchester galleries, Sound Shore in Cross River, and Nardin in Somers, are celebrating the moment but with longer-lasting shows.

title: Indonesia's Programmed Elections
description: Although Indonesia's parliamentary elections will not be held until May 29, the Government has already announced that it expects to get 70.02 percent of the vote. This is not evidence of advanced polling techniques, but rather of old-style political control. Elections in Indonesia are just another way to rally support for President Suharto and his Government. Since this year's elections are the least free in decades, it is safe to assume the Government thinks its popularity is slipping.

title: Some of Their Best Friends Are Jews
description: As one of the people Jeffrey Goldberg contacted for his thoughtful article on Southern Baptist efforts to share the good news among Jews, I was impressed with his overall balance, although I wish he had brought up several related issues.

title: Ways of Doing Time
description: For six years, between his defeat at Waterloo in 1815 and his death in 1821, Napoleon Bonaparte languished on the windswept South Atlantic island of St. Helena. A prisoner of the British, he survived on a diet of memories -- the Egyptian campaign, Austerlitz, Eylau, Jena -- recounted to a diminished entourage. Relentlessly scouring his fate, convinced that Waterloo might have been won, he vainly sought the precise moment when his military ascendancy peaked and decline set in. But not even Napoleon could overcome, through imagined victories, the drudgery of defeat. The weight of the past and the exhaustion of hope crushed him at the age of 51.

title: SPACEY PRICING
description: 1. Superior Stamp and Coin of Beverly Hills thought it had a real coup for its spring auction of space-age stuff, which ends today in Beverly Hills: 1 of the 5 original satellites made for the 1957 launch of Sputnik I. 2. Such relics don't go cheap: Sotheby's has sold a 1959 Soviet dog spacesuit for $25,300. 3. Superior has raked in $36,800 for a vial of moon dust. 4. Unfortunately, after seeing Superior's catalogue, an official from the Russian space company Zvezda wrote in, saying it might only be a model of the original. Out went the satellite, an item expected to fetch up to $100,000. 5. Then again, what the heck? Michael Orenstein, the auction's manager, decided to sell it anyway. ''It's legitimate as a model or it's legitimate as an original in the eye of the beholder,'' he says, floating a nifty sci-fi concept of value. ''It's worth X. Let the buyer decide.''

title: Big Government Doesn't Eliminate the Need for Volunteerism
description: To the Editor:

title: It's Words, Not Deeds, For Lukas This Time
description: Talk, talk, talk. On Wednesday morning, there was the trainer D. Wayne Lukas justifying running a hopeless long shot in today's Kentucky Derby to a doubting press. Then that night he was on a national telecast as a commentator, offering spin while somehow keeping a straight face. And today he was interviewed on ABC, still putting up a brave front.

title: Texas Judges Rule to Stop Weevil Sprays
description: A controversial boll weevil eradication program that was financed by assessments on state cotton farmers has been found unconstitutional by the Texas Supreme Court.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GROSS, FRANCES FELDMAN
description: GROSS-Frances Feldman, on May 2, 1997. Beloved widow of Harry, mother of Ira and Michael, mother-in-law of Irene and Jeanice, grandmother of Howard, Karen and Keith, and great-grandmother of Sydney and Jordan.

title: Separatists End Texas Standoff As 5 Surrender
description: The seven-day standoff between Texas authorities and an armed separatist group ended this afternoon when the group's leader, who had vowed to wage an Alamo-style fight to the death, walked out of his trailer with three other members and surrendered here in the high desert of West Texas.

title: Grand Survivor of Another Age
description: THERE'S something about staying at a seasonal hotel that makes you feel as if you've really got hold of the season; after all, you can visit a year-round resort any time, but when you stay at a place that only opens for a few months each year, you enter an era that predates central heating and high-speed transport -- those modern efficiencies that made year-round hostelry possible even in climates as unpredictable as New England's. It was an era when guests promenaded along seaside boardwalks and mountainside verandas, when ladies traveled in the company of maids, and gentlemen in the company of their favorite horses, to be boarded for the season at the hotel stables.

title: Ms. Cunningham, Mr. Shimshak
description: Cynthia Elizabeth Cunningham and Stephen John Shimshak, who are lawyers in New York, were married yesterday in Montreal. The Rev. Dr. Edward Furcha, a minister of the United Church of Canada, performed the ceremony at the McGill University Chapel.

title: Dahl Children's Gallery Brings Stories to Life
description: A new attraction for children has opened at the Buckinghamshire County Museum in Aylesbury, 35 miles west of London. The Roald Dahl Children's Gallery was built in memory of the late author, who lived nearby in Great Missenden. His widow, Felicity Dahl, contributed $125,000 of the $1 million total cost.

title: A Dilettante of Consequence
description: Stendhal By Jonathan Keates. 478 pp. New York: Carroll & Graf Publishers. $28.

title: A Lot of Life Backs Up Their Words
description: AS a child growing up in Atlanta 60 years ago, Ann Thorpe was steeped in her family's tales of the rural South and recollections of the Civil War, unfailingly called The Late Unpleasantness by her elders.

title: Another Reason to Work Out
description: Exercise appears to protect against breast cancer. Although not conclusive, a study published in The New England Journal of Medicine last week showed that women who exercised at least four hours a week had a 37 percent lower risk of developing the disease than sedentary ones. The investigators, who conducted research on 25,000 Norwegian women, concluded that the more women exercise, the less likely they were to get the disease.

title: To Fetch The Bidders, Brandish A Princess
description: ONE Christie's official describes them as ''a walk amongst the sequins,'' so detailed are the photographs of 80 dresses from the closet of Diana, Princess of Wales, to be auctioned for charity on June 25 at Christie's on Park Avenue.

title: A Lot to Be Seen, A Lot to Be Desired
description: JOE ROTH, CHAIRMAN OF WALT DISNEY STUDIOS, has a dream: that ''The Horse Whisperer,'' a romance based on Nicholas Evans's best-selling novel, will come out this summer, somewhere among blockbusters like ''The Lost World: Jurassic Park,'' ''Titanic,'' ''Speed 2: Cruise Control,'' ''Fathers' Day,'' ''Contact,'' ''Men in Black'' and ''Batman and Robin.'' But the movie, for which filming has just begun in New York, probably won't be ready until Christmas.

title: Memento Mori
description: THE LEAST OF THESE MY BRETHREN A Doctor's Story of Hope and Miracles on an Inner-City AIDS Ward. By Daniel Baxter. 254 pp. New York: Harmony Books. $24.

title: To the Dead Sea, And Beyond, On A Treasure Hunt
description: AS the Hashemite Kingdom of Jordan experiences a steady increase in the number of foreign visitors, it has been opening up its rich and varied countryside with new highways, including the stunning Dead Sea road that was completed in 1995, extending all the way to Aqaba. Last year I traveled from Amman to the Dead Sea, along the freshly paved two-lane road, then up to Kerak and back to Amman via the millenniums-old King's Highway. The trip can easily be done in a day, with a total of around four and a half hours of driving, but a night in Kerak is an attractive option.

title: Deals and Discounts
description: FLYING DOWN UNDER -- A fare of $999 round trip to Sydney from any gateway in the continental United States (not just those on the West Coast) has been introduced by Qantas Airways, United Airlines and Air New Zealand. Tickets must be purchased by May 31 for travel beginning July 1 to Aug. 31. Visitors must stay at least seven days and not more than one month on the fare.

title: PAPERBACK BEST SELLERS: May 4, 1997
description: Weeks

title: 4 Decades of Thunderbird Heaven
description: JIM CAPPUZZO JR. is 32 years old, two years younger than his favorite automobile, the 1963 Ford Thunderbird. He has six of the 1963 models, some quite rare, and he just plain loves T-Birds. So it seems odd when he reacts in fairly ho-hum manner to the Ford Motor Company's recent decision to kill the Thunderbird, one of the great names in classic American metal.

title: Supporting the Study of Israeli Culture
description: A POET, lecturer and Professor of Hebrew literature, Dr. Zvia Ginor was born in Israel and has lived in Great Neck for 21 years. Earlier this year, she endowed the Jewish Theological Seminary in Manhattan, Conservative Judaism's nerve center, with a $1 million gift toward a new chair in Israeli Society and Culture. The gift to the seminary, where Dr. Ginor is a faculty member, was fashioned by both Dr. Ginor and her husband, Amos Ginor, a pioneer in the aeronautics industry who died in 1994. They hoped to make the gift a bequest after their deaths. But Dr. Ginor's recent bout with illness, coupled with the worsening relations between Israel and the Diaspora, made her decide to give the money now. The chair will be dedicated today at 7:30 P.M. at the Jewish Theological Seminary in Manhattan.

title: Corrections
description: An article on page 38 of The Times Magazine today, about housing in New York City, misidentifies the branch of the New York State Legislature for which Manfred Ohrenstein was minority leader. It was the Senate, not the Assembly.

title: Miracles of Grace and Charm From an Ancient Tradition
description: THE ANCIENT ROMANS outdid almost everyone in making glorious glass objects. Their Italian descendants repeated that feat twice during two different periods. And while the impressive achievements of the Renaissance have been well documented, those of the mid-20th century are only now becoming widely known.

title: The Quiet Route To Winning Acclaim
description: MOST instrumentalists, Eliot Fisk among them, begin musical studies because their parents want them to. Some of those parents try to push gifted children into the limelight, but Mr. Fisk, one of the world's pre-eminent guitarists, was hardly even nudged. His renown, the reviews of his spectacular playing and the letter of extravagant praise from no less a kingmaker than Andres Segovia are unsought byproducts of his quiet Philadelphia Quaker family's intentions.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LOMUSCIO, NICHOLAS JOHN
description: LOMUSCIO-Nicholas John. Beloved husband of Josephine (nee Sanna). Devoted father of Bill G. and Angela Trovato. Dear father-in-law of Mary and Gary. Cherished Poppi of Dana, Mia, Nicholas and Alyssa. Dear brother of Frances Loretta, Laura Palmieri and Grace Knowles. Reposing at the Frederick Funeral Home of Flushing, Northern Boulevard at 193 Street until Monday, 2-5PM and 7-10 PM. Mass of Christian Burial 10:30 AM at St. Anastasia R.C. Church, entombment Ave Maria Garden Crypt, St. John's Cemetery, Middle Village, N.Y.

title: The Burden of Duty
description: The Hawaiian village they call home might look like a tropical paradise, but since their mother's recent death, life for the Ogata children resembles anything but an idyll. Lois-Ann Yamanaka cultivates a stifling, pungent and cruelly charged atmosphere in her second novel, BLU'S HANGING (Farrar, Straus & Giroux, $22), as she fluidly explores the brutal divide between family duty and self-preservation, between the power of love and the power of shame. While her moody father drowns his grief in ''hemp tea'' and descends into poverty, 13-year-old Ivah, the eldest child and the book's narrator, becomes a surrogate mother to her two siblings. And they're a handful: her brother, garrulous, overweight Blu, compulsively flirts with the neighborhood perverts; her sister, Maisie, although barely able to speak, manages to incur the racist wrath of her white teachers. Textured with sometimes inscrutable streams of Hawaiian pidgin, the narrative is propelled by the strange illnesses and sexual molestations that plague and scar the characters. When Ivah wins a scholarship to a prestigious boarding school, she faces an excruciating choice: to save herself or protect her vulnerable family. Ms. Yamanaka depicts the children's misfortunes and humiliations in the same clarified yet sensuous detail she uses to render the lush landscape around them. Though the tragedy that besets the Ogatas can feel unremitting, Ms. Yamanaka inventively explores its alchemical nature in the face of love, providing a redemptive conclusion that is as arresting as her characters. Megan Harlan

title: BYE BYE, BIRDS
description: Martin Lowney, a Federal Government wildlife specialist, has been called in to handle a vulture problem in upscale Leesburg, Va., and his proposed solution -- forced relocation -- has some people asking: Uh, where exactly are they relocating to? Every fall and winter, some 300 vultures roost in Leesburg's trees. They leave in the spring, but because vultures are perceived as gross, Leesburg deeply wants them not to come home again next October. Lowney proposal -- capturing the vultures in baited cages and carting them off to the wild -- has made southern Virginians fret that they'll be getting unwanted immigrants. Lowney says that the birds will go to the woods, not to a town, and that people could lighten up about these generally helpful carrion eaters. ''Up to 75 birds, folks tolerate vultures,'' he observes. ''But you get more than 75, tolerance goes out the window.''

title: New Roofs, No Fiddlers
description: Amid the discordant notes heard in Jewish communities these days come sounds of harmony. Four leading historical institutions not notably attracted to one another previously will form the Center for Jewish History, which will be one of the world's largest repositories of Jewish documentation.

title: QUESTIONS FOR: Jon Lee Anderson
description: Jon Lee Anderson is the author of ''Che Guevara: A Revolutionary Life,'' just published by Grove Press.

title: Ground Zero
description: The Band

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CAHN, EVELYN GORDON
description: CAHN-Evelyn Gordon. 85, died May 2. Beloved wife of the late Ernest Cahn. Memorial service at Mary Manning Walsh, Sunday, May 4, 11:30 AM-1:00 PM.

title: The True Cost Of the Lilco Bailout
description: Brian McCaffery, a vice president of the Long Island Lighting Company, and Richard M. Kessel, a trustee of the Long Island Power Authority, both seek to attack Gregory Palast for his criticism of the Pataki-LIPA Plan $(''Lilco and the Outlook for Lower Rates'' Opinion, April 20$).

title: Libby Pierpont, Erik Engstrom
description: Elizabeth Hobson Pierpont, an executive recruiter, was married yesterday to Erik Engstrom, a publishing executive. The Rev. Mary T. Cushman, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony at St. James' Church in New York.

title: A Maverick Continues To Mosey
description: SOMEONE SHOULD GIVE THE CONDUCTOR Franz Welser-Most a medal. Not because his concerts and recordings are always spectacularly satisfying, although they sometimes are, but because of his uncommon bravery. Mr. Welser-Most is bucking the system. Especially in the studio, he has forsworn convention and steered clear of the standard repertory. Instead of churning out yet another bland traversal of Beethoven's nine symphonies or Tchaikovsky's six, rather than foist one more Puccini ''Boheme'' or Bizet ''Carmen'' on an uninterested public, Mr. Welser-Most has chosen to explore the outer limits of classical music.

title: Exotic Tastes Of Persia Come To Great Neck
description: ENTERING the A-Z Food Market or Fresh Food Market on Middle Neck Road in Great Neck is like stepping into a Middle Eastern wonderland.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GEWIRTZ, ABE
description: GEWIRTZ-Abe. Beloved husband, father, grandfather and brother on May 2, Boca Raton, FL. Funeral service Monday, May 5, 10 A.M., Parkside Chapel, 98-60 Queens Blvd., Rego Park, New York.

title: An Effect, Not a Cause
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BANNER, SY
description: BANNER-Sy. Four Winds mourns the loss of Sy Banner, a superb hospital administrator, outstanding corporate Vice President and warm, caring personal friend to all of us. Sy stood for the best in health care. We offer our profound sympathies to his wife Dorothy, their children and the family. In his memory we are naming our administration building where he worked for so many years ''The Banner Building.'' Sy, you will be deeply missed. Samuel C. Klagsbrun, M.D. Four Winds Hospital

title: Why Blair's Victory May Not Travel Well in Europe
description: AFTER Tony Blair's election victory for the Labor Party in Britain last week, the rest of the leftists in Europe found new reason for hope. Elections will take place in France at the end of this month, in Germany next year and soon after in other places across the continent where Socialists and Social Democrats have found themselves frozen out of power in recent years.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  MILLER, SAMUEL
description: MILLER-Samuel. April 29, 1965. Remembered with Love.

title: Corrections
description: An article last Sunday about the growth of the Cablevision Systems Corporation misstated the ITT Corporation's profit on the sale of its 50 percent stake in Madison Square Garden to Cablevision. It was $290 million, not $125 million.

title: Making Noise to Find Quiet
description: If residents of the South Bronx want a little peace and quiet -- a reprieve from stereos blasting, boom boxes blaring and even the unrelenting tinkle of an ice-cream truck's bells -- they must, well . . . make a lot of noise.

title: Asian Love Story
description: Adapted from a James Michener novel of postwar Japan, Joshua Logan's SAYONARA (1957) scores on two counts: as a moving love story between an American Navy officer (Marlon Brando) and a beautiful, lovelorn Geisha (Miiko Taka); and as a lasting showcase for an electric stage actor whose Hollywood career has had its highs and lows. The color photography is stunning. Red Buttons and Miyoshi Umeki do well as a tragic young couple. But it is the magnificent Brando who makes it spin. Here is a man who overcomes prejudice and finds love and tragedy. Here is a Southerner to savor -- THUR. at 10:35 P.M. and THUR.-FRI. at 4:35and 9 A.M. on AMC. Howard Thompson

title: Rangers Say First Goal Will Change Everything
description: It has been seven frustrating periods, 156 minutes to be exact, since the Rangers last put a puck past Devils goaltender Martin Brodeur. It is yet another advantage, even if it is only a psychological one, that the Devils now hold on the Rangers in this intense, cross-river, second-round playoff series.

O'Sullivan, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony at St. Peter's Church in Washington.

title: Immigration Rule Barring Citizenship Irks a Cuban Virtuoso
description: Since defecting from Cuba in 1990, the jazz trumpeter Arturo Sandoval has built a stellar career in the United States, winning three Grammy Awards, soloing at events like the Academy Awards and rubbing shoulders with President Clinton.

title: Fair Game
description: IT now seems so many years ago, and it is. Weehawken, Hudson County, a very busy working-class district in 1944. My father came home from work on a spring Friday. He was a tool and machinery salesman. I told him that on Saturday morning my friends and I were going to have a baseball game down at the main field and Pants Doughgan would be the starting pitcher.

description: Elvis, who tested the seams of his jumpsuit here when this desert city's biggest nongambling attraction was a few over-the-hill superstars, is truly dead.

title: Publishing Straight Talk About Sex, By Teen-Agers for Teen-Agers
description: If you're a senior in high school, buying condoms at the neighborhood drug store isn't a laughing matter. It's more like an exercise in humiliation.

title: Che, Warm and Cuddly Revolutionary
description: Thirty years after his execution by gunfire, the mythic leftist revolutionary Ernesto (Che) Guevara has gone from dormitory poster of the 1960's to cultural icon of the 1990's.

title: Leslie George Katz, 78, Founder of Eakins Press
description: Leslie George Katz, the founder of Eakins Press and a writer on art and literature, died on April 18 at his home in Manhattan. He was 78.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  BERLER, ANDREW
description: BERLER-Andrew. On the third anniversary of his ''departure'' his family and friends wish to recognize and express appreciation for the opportunity to have known a man who was warm, humorous, loveable and an outstanding intellectual.

title: What to Do Until the Ambulance Arrives
description: ANYONE who has watched on television as an emergency line operator coolly takes a frantic caller through a lifesaving medical procedure probably takes comfort in believing such help is only a 911 call away.

title: Ms. Herman's Lock On the Cabinet
description: After weeks of political mudwrestling, Alexis Herman won confirmation as Secretary of Labor. But the bigger fight that had engulfed her nomination -- union labor on Federal contracts -- ended in a draw despite claims of victory from the combatants.

title: U.S. Dispatches an Army of Tree-Hungry Beetles to Fight Everglades Menace
description: Under a scorching midmorning sun, researchers released a foreign army of 60 bugs into three marked plots of the Everglades today to accomplish a mission that herbicides, fires and machetes have failed to complete: intercepting the advancing melaleuca.

title: Separation Anxiety
description: Reporters in the newsroom at Women's Wear Daily, socialites lingering over Sunday brunch at Mortimer's, patternmakers cutting miniskirts at Michael Kors -- everybody's playing the new party game: Six Degrees of Gavin Macon. Invented late one night by a group of fashion wags over dinner at the Independent, this new pastime of the chic set is based on the premise that Gavin Macon is the center of the fashion universe and everyone in the business can be linked to him in six degrees or less (inspired by John Guare's play ''Six Degrees of Separation''). Skeptics may scoff. ''Surely there's someone who can't be linked,'' Oscar de la Renta said, ''and I'm going to find that person.'' Kate Moss said that's how most people begin the game and gradually become compulsive players. ''It's addictive!'' she admitted. Valentino is publishing a book in which he links himself to Gavin Macon via 60 different routes. Nan Kempner maintains a Web page.

title: TAKING THE CHILDREN
description: Romy and Michele's High School Reunion

title: Now, the Ennui of Outrage
description: DENNIS RODMAN would like your attention. Again.

title: Kasparov Beats Computer In First Game of a Rematch
description: After a tense, seesaw battle that made at least one side sweat, Garry Kasparov, the world chess champion, defeated his inanimate adversary, Deep Blue, the world's strongest chess-playing machine, yesterday in the first game of their scheduled six-game match in midtown Manhattan.

Services 12:30PM Sunday, Temple Israel Cemetery, Hastings on Hudson, New York.

title: The Reuniter: A Bureaucrat Who Is Thanked for His Work
description: Unlike most employees at the State Division of Youth and Family Services, Gerald R. Gioglio is thanked for his work. Lots of people try to send gifts, but he prefers photographs. The images are usually the same: people hugging and crying, or posing at a family reunion. He has never met them but he knows their secrets, their history.

title: Mexico's Latest Drug Agency
description: In Mexico there is constant tension between traffickers' efforts to corrupt the anti-drug agencies and Government efforts to clean them up. The competition continued last week with the dismantling of the country's main narcotics force and creation of another to take its place.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MAESTRO, MARCELLO T.
description: MAESTRO-Marcello T., on May 1, 1997, age 89. Born in Trieste, 1907, naturalized U.S. citizen 1944. Journalist, bookdealer, writer, humanist & cat lover. Devoted husband of Edna. Loving father of Giulio and Vittorio, and father-inlaw of Betsy and Laura. Proud grandfather of Daniela & Marco.

title: A Literary Pilgrimage With Diaper Bag
description: ON a recent Saturday morning, in an uncharacteristic impulse to complicate my life by venturing somewhere rather than simplify it by staying at home, I decided to coax my family into our station wagon for a visit to Walden Pond. It's not far from where we live, and lately I have been rereading Henry David Thoreau's ''Walden,'' which is what gave me the idea of escaping my quiet desperation at facing laundry and the dishes to reflect instead on Nature, self-reliance and the beauty of solitude. Or at least go for a drive.

title: Watershed Filtration Choice Is Sought
description: IN an unusual alliance between residents in the county's northern communities bordering the Croton watershed and equally concerned residents of the Bronx who live near the Jerome Park Reservoir, efforts are under way to explore alternatives to a proposed $600 million filtration plant, which is intended to clean drinking water from the Croton watershed.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RACKMAN, RUTH
description: RACKMAN-Ruth. Congregation Shaaray Tefila in Lawrence, mourns the loss of its beloved former Rebbetzin, Ruth Rackman, who ably assisted her husband, Rabbi Emanuel Rackman, as a true ''Ezer'' during his long tenure as our Rabbi. We extend heartfelt condolences to the Rabbi and his family. David Weinberger, Rabbi Martin Klein, President Norman Newman, Chairman

title: Overdosing on Health Risks
description: Americans follow news of medical research as closely as sports or the stock market. We are particularly avid for new findings about the health effects of diet and life style, because we have come to believe that no one gets sick anymore just because of bad luck. Instead, we see health as largely a matter of doing the right things, with the corollary that illness is a failure of some sort. If we can keep up with all the new research and change our habits accordingly, we will stay well.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHAPIRO, ARTHUR
description: SHAPIRO-Arthur. Our friend and colleague for so many years. We will miss you. Our deepest sympathy to his loving wife, Ina. Florence and Stan Hausner

title: Oversupply of Office Space Is Starting to Dwindle
description: THE recently announced decisions by the Standard & Poors Corporation and the Chubb Insurance Company to commit to long-term leases totaling almost 1.1 million square feet of space in an underutilized building at 55 Water Street in lower Manhattan are drawing more attention to what has been happening downtown in the last few years.

title: Housing Site in Yonkers After All
description: IT is an action that Mayor John D. Spencer of Yonkers says will return to the city control of its own destiny for the first time since it was found guilty of racial discrimination 11 years ago. It is an action that a County Legislator predicts will lead to a lawsuit, and it is an action that environmentalists say they will be watching closely.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FRAME, TERENCE R.
description: FRAME-Terence R., of Rosner and Nocera Law Firm, on May 2, 1997. Beloved son of Mary and the late Robert V. Frame. Devoted brother of Rosemary Mohr and Robert J. Frame. Friends may call at the Andrett Funeral Home, 353 2nd Ave. (at 20th St.), NYC, Monday, 2-5 and 7-9 PM. Mass of Christian Burial Epiphany R.C. Church, Tuesday, 10 AM. Interment St. Charles Cemetery.

title: Lots of Noise Being Made Over Quiet in U.S. Parks
description: CONCEIVED as havens of tranquillity, national parks have recently been at issue in some noisy disputes. In just the last few months, two efforts to preserve or restore to the parks ''natural quiet'' -- widely defined as the absence of manmade sound -- has sparked legal and legislative fights.

description: Either one team or one player was going to be gone too early -- either the Seattle SuperSonics or Kevin Johnson -- and that was Johnson turning in his mesh uniform late this afternoon.

title: The Beetle Battles Begin Before Summer
description: ALTHOUGH the beetles themselves will not be around until the hot summer months, their larvae (grubs) may be at work now. And these underground nibblers represent a double whammy that gardeners could do without.

title: Is Recovery in Store for FPA Shares?
description: UNTIL October, prospects for FPA Medical Management seemed limitless. Like other companies that help manage medical practices, it has seen its stock price soar -- in its case, more than double in three months. And the industry's potential market has barely been scratched, with only 8 percent of the country's doctors signed up. FPA could have stood for Future Price Appreciation.

title: When the Rent Laws Don't Apply
description: LARGELY unremarked in the current confrontation in Albany over rent regulation, a debate more heated than usual this year, is the fact that New York City already has a substantial stock of unregulated, privately owned rentals -- 575,600 of them, according to last year's survey by the Census Bureau.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DALE, FLORENCE JOHNSTON

Mass of Christian Burial Wednesday, 10:30 AM, at Holy Family Church, 315 East 47 St. Interment to follow in Island Pond, VT. In lieu of flowers contributions may be made to a charity of your choice.

description: A DECISION last month by the New Jersey Supreme Court gives added protection to home buyers and places an extra burden on real estate brokers.

For centuries, Jews did conduct a vigorous campaign, which ended for two reasons: political and theological.

Memorial Contributions to Temple Israel Center, 280 Old Mamaroneck Road, White Plains, NY 10605, would be appreciated.

title: Pat Boone, Minus Those White Bucks
description: AS FANS FILED OUT OF MADISON SQUARE GARDEN after a Metallica concert last month, some did a double take when the group's signature song, ''Enter Sandman,'' began playing over the loudspeakers. What caught their attention was that after the familiar opening guitar riff, the song dissolved into a jazzy, big-band version. Even more puzzling was the person who was singing: Pat Boone.

description: Press freedom groups, concerned that the United Nations might be drawn into a renewed campaign for worldwide regulation of the news media, are lobbying against efforts to convene a world conference on communications gaps between developed nations and the third world.
