Next month, American Express will take three more countries off the list of places where its card holders can get free damage coverage in lieu of buying the rental company's collision damage waiver.

title: 'Where's-the-Beefization'
description: ALL THE PRESIDENTS' WORDS The Bully Pulpit and the Creation of the Virtual Presidency. By Carol Gelderman. 221 pp. New York: Walker & Company. $23.

title: Some of Their Best Friends Are Jews
description: We've survived the Assyrians, Babylonians, Egyptians, Persians, Romans, Syrians, Crusaders, Inquisitors, Czarists, Nazis (from whom Larry Lewis, past president of the Home Mission Board, must have learned that Judaism is a race), Klansmen, Arab terrorists and the like. We're still here. We'll survive the Southern Baptists.

title: Jennifer Lee, Scott A. Klein
description: Jennifer Amy Lee, a freelance photographer who manages a photo studio, and Scott Alan Klein, an assistant district attorney in the Bronx, were married last evening in Alpine, N.J. Rabbi Peter Kasdan performed the ceremony at Tamcrest.

title: Ellen's Out-and-Out Hit
description: Proving everything from the power of hype, to the continuing ability of network television to create national events, to the growing acceptance of homosexuality, the much publicized episode of the ABC comedy, ''Ellen,'' in which, for the first time, a lead character announced herself to be gay, attracted an estimated 42 million people last week.

title: Making Art From Trees and Tape
description: Five thousand feet of yellow traffic tape is tied to a chain-link fence along the Rahway River in Meadowland Park. Yellow-and-black-striped ''Caution'' tape -- 1,500 feet of it -- is sticking to the concrete embankment. Several more feet of it dangle like octopus tentacles from the bridge over the river.

title: John C. Eccles, 94, Nobel Physiologist, Dies
description: Sir John Carew Eccles, an Australian neurophysiologist whose research illuminated some of the most mysterious yet most basic functions of human nerve cells and won him a share of a Nobel Prize, died on Friday at his home in Switzerland. He was 94 and for the last 22 years had lived in retirement in Contra, a small town in the southeastern part of the country.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FEUER, ARTHUR
description: FEUER-Arthur, on May 2nd, 1997. Beloved son of the late Mollie and Harry Feuer. Graveside services on Sunday, 11 A.M., at Wellwood Cemetery, Pinelawn, New York.

title: In a Bahrain Port, No More Sailors on the Town
description: As a liberty port, Manama cannot compete with the raunchiness of Manila or Bangkok, but the men and women of the United States Navy still regard it as an oasis in the heart of the Persian Gulf.

title: Maybe Not on the High Road, but They Travel Well
description: JON THOMPSON, DIRECTOR OF cultural affairs for the city of Memphis, faced a challenge in Beijing a few years ago. He had to persuade the Chinese Government to allow more than 250 relics and fine-art objects out of the country for almost three years. Worse, he had to explain that its cherished national treasures were not going to some world-renowned museum.

title: Selling of the Green
description: Offering alternatives to canned peas and wilted lettuce heads, Greenmarkets will be in operation in more than 20 locations this year, in all five boroughs. They are open 8 A.M. to 5 P.M. unless otherwise specified.

title: Tests, Too, Have Their Failings
description: NEW York's Education Commissioner and Governor offered opposing views last week on an issue that goes to the heart of educational quality and opportunity in an increasingly diverse America: should the state offer its college-preparatory Regents examinations in languages other than English?

title: Fighting Cancer's Prophecy of Doom
description: IT is a word that until a few months ago Anne Mann had never heard of -- let alone knew how to pronounce or spell it. Now, Mrs. Mann, a resident of Chappaqua, has learned how to live with it and is doing her best to help others with it as well.

title: Lyn A. Hogan, Stephen Diorio
description: Lyndell Aileen Hogan, the associate director of welfare policy for the White House Domestic Policy Council in Washington, was married yesterday to Stephen Gregory Diorio, the president of Oxford Consulting Inc., a management consulting company in Bethesda, Md. The Rev. Mark Hallinan performed the ceremony at the Roman Catholic Church of St. Ignatius Loyola in New York.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CAPARN, STEEL, RHYS
description: CAPARN-STEEL-Rhys, age 87, Danbury, CT, a noted sculptress, died Tuesday in Danbury, CT. She was formerly of Newtown, CT., and was the widow of H. Johannes Steel. Mrs. Steel was born in Onteora Park, NY, July 28, 1909, daughter of Harold and Clara Jones Caparn. From 1927 to 1929 she attended Bryn Mawr College and from 1929 to 1930 studied at Ecole Artistique des Animaux in Paris, France and from 1931 to 1933 studied at Archipenko School of Art in New York City. She taught Sculpture at the Dalton School in New York for 21 years. Following her first exhibit in 1933, at the age of 24, Ms. Caparn received many awards, including the Medal of Honor for Sculpture from the National Assoc. of Women Artists, and a major prize for American Sculpture at the Metropolitan Museum. She was a life member of the International Institute of Arts and Letters and Italian Arts and Labor. Her work is in the permanent collection of the Whitney Museum, Corcoran Gallery of Art, Fogg Art Museum, St. Louis Art Museum, and the US State Dept. Collection for US Embassies around the world as well as numerous private collections. There are no immediate survivors. Memorials may be made to the Bryn Mawr Club of Fairfield County, c/o Grace Papp, 110 Dunn Ave., Stamford, CT 06905-1113. There are no services or calling hours. Cremation will be in Ferncliff Crematory, Hartsdale, NY. Hull Funeral Service, Danbury, CT is in charge.

title: Coalition to Gather Food in Drive on Hunger
description: SAYING that unemployment, budget cuts and welfare changes are straining hunger-relief efforts, a coalition of groups is planning to participate, for the first time, in the third Stamp Out Hunger Food Drive, on Saturday.

title: Giving Savings Bonds a Shot in the Arm
description: FACED with dwindling sales, the Treasury moved suddenly last week to rejuvenate its savings bonds, still the world's most widely held security.

title: A Kept Husband, 357 Affairs
description: SIMON GRAY has written a multiplicity of noteworthy plays. Especially ''Otherwise Engaged.'' Even ''Molly'' and ''Hidden Laughter.''

title: Four Companies Get Governor's Citation
description: IN recognition of their contributions to the county, Gov. George E. Pataki has awarded four Westchester companies his Business Partnership Award.

title: The Marble Manor That Turkish Tobacco Built
description: THE new exterior iron doors on the old Schinasi house, at the northeast corner of 107th Street and Riverside Drive are among the final touches on the restoration of the 1909 marble mansion, one of the biggest private houses left on the West Side. Prof. Hans Smit, its owner, has been working on the project for almost two decades.

title: Ever-So-Witty Ghosts, Onstage and Off
description: A writer's work is his ghost,'' John Lahr wrote in ''Coward; The Playwright.'' And Sir Noel ''took solace in the belief that his spirit would haunt the world long after his body had departed it.''

title: Poison Pens
description: THE LETTERS OF NANCY MITFORD AND EVELYN WAUGH Edited by Charlotte Mosley. Illustrated. 527 pp. Boston: Houghton Mifflin Company. $40.

title: Elizabeth Trostler And Craig LaBan
description: Elizabeth K. Trostler, the daughter of Mrs. Arthur Trostler of Mamaroneck, N.Y., and the late Mr. Trostler, was married last evening to Craig A. LaBan, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Myron M. LaBan of Bloomfield Hills, Mich. Rabbi David Cahn-Lipman performed the ceremony at the Coveleigh Club in Rye, N.Y.

title: Handmade Bathing Suits Draw Divers
description: ''TURN around and let me see your tush,'' said Gay Silverman of White Plains to a Junior Olympic diver trying on one of her handmade bathing suits at the Lords of the Boards Springboard Invitational Meet last month in New Jersey. ''You need the next size, hon,'' she advised.

title: Lynn Burmester and Stephen Enquist
description: Lynn Rebecca Burmester, a retail manager, and Stephen Paul Enquist, a financial executive, were married yesterday at St. Luke's Episcopal Church in Darien, Conn. The Rev. Dr. James A. Kowalski performed the ceremony.

title: How to Add a Little Variety to the Lunch Menu
description: Fast-food joints meet Steve DeMicco's need for a fast lunch, but not his cravings for fresh Greek salads, homemade ravioli bursting with ri otta and hot-from-the-oven choco late chip cookies. So he has made the Rafferty Groumet, a takeout shop and specialty grocer, his regular lunch spot since it opened in downtown. New Brunswick three years ago. ''It's a habit,'' he said, surveying the deli case. ''They know me by height, by weight and by my order.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CARLTON, MILDRED
description: CARLTON-Mildred. Cedarhurst, NY, on April 22, 1997. Loving wife of William, devoted mother of Barbara and Barry Goodman and Gary and Debby Carlton. Adored grandmother of Alison, Todd, Kimberly and Gregory Goodman and Lindsay and Julie Carlton. She will remain alive in the memories of those she loved and those who loved her. Contributions can be made in her name to The National Kidney Foundation, NYC Chapter.

title: Taking the State Master Plan Beyond Paper, Into Action
description: When the New Jersey Development and Redevelopment Plan was adopted in 1992, it was widely hailed as a pioneering blueprint for managed growth, one of the most advanced of several statewide efforts in the country. The plan, which was nonbinding, offered local governments the tools they needed to turn the tide of suburban sprawl, concentrate development in town and city centers and preserve vanishing farmland and open space.

title: Society's First Aid
description: To the Editor:

title: Loyalty to French Cuisine in Hartsdale
description: HAVING held steady through various culinary trends and upheavals for almost two decades, Auberge Argenteuil has shifted its course slightly. For those long loyal to this restaurant's version of the French experience, be assured that this is no sea change; comforting old marrons still dot the new menu. While goat cheese, polenta, gossamer sauces and spectacular wild mushrooms signify an expanded vision in the kitchen, diners are still greeted with the familiar relish tray, albeit with excellent marinated olives replacing the bland greens and blacks of old.

title: Karyn Cohen, Joshua Zweback
description: Karyn Amy Cohen, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Norman I. Cohen of Chestnut Ridge, N.Y., is to be married today to Joshua David Zweback, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Samuel Zweback of Brooklyn. Rabbi Louis Frishman is to officiate at Temple Beth El in Spring Valley, N.Y.

title: Q and A
description: From Cancun to Tulum

title: English as a Foreign Language
description: ALL I wanted was some chocolate chips to bake cookies. At the corner bodega, I could not find them on the shelf. I asked the clerk, who spoke a little English. He spoke in Spanish to another man, who brought me cocoa. No, that wasn't what I wanted. More discussions in Spanish. Then Chips Ahoy were proffered. No, but close. We went on a few minutes, and they were trying so hard I couldn't just say, ''Forget it.'' I was touched by how hard we all were trying to communicate. But finally I left, thanking the men profusely for their effort, shaking my head for what seems to be all too often the ultimate end of such an encounter.

title: Janus Lives
description: ''I'm pondering the difference between boned and boneless chicken,'' writes Alan Levy, editor in chief of The Prague Post. He is even more troubled about words like sanction, which is a verb for ''allow, authorize,'' and a noun for ''punishment,'' almost the opposite. ''Is there a lexicographical term for words that become antonyms of themselves through distortion, if not misuse?''

title: The Pioneer Valley
description: About five years ago, friends from New York City who had essentially used my house in Northampton, Mass., some 160 miles north of New York City, for a quick pit stop when they sped by to ogle autumn leaves, began to fish for overnight invitations. Once again, the Pioneer Valley was not merely a detour, but a destination, just as it had been in the 19th century, when Jenny Lind was so taken with the Northampton countryside that, according to local lore, she called it ''The Paradise of America.''

title: Smarter Than Us? Who's Us?
description: Even before the world chess champion Garry Kasparov faced the computer Deep Blue yesterday, pundits were calling the rematch another milestone in the inexorable advance of artificial intelligence, the effort to create machines that mimic human thought. Computers will soon become ''smarter than us,'' the supercomputer designer Danny Hillis asserted in a Newsweek essay.

title: New & Noteworthy Paperbacks
description: MISSISSIPPI: An American Journey

title: Ms. VanderPoel and Mr. Jorgensen
description: Deborah Billings VanderPoel, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Halsted Billings VanderPoel of Washington, was married yesterday at Lester Manor, her family's house in King William, Va., to Craig Anders Jorgensen, the son of Mrs. Robert Quandt of Arcade, N.Y., and the late Carlton A. Jorgensen. Emmett M. Upshaw, the clerk of King William County, officiated.

title: Emotions Race as the Adopted Seek a Law to Open Records
description: Sanford S. Gershkowitz was preparing for a vacation to Israel 23 years ago when he realized he needed his birth certificate to apply for a passport. Weeks later, a document arrived in the mail that said ''certificate of adoption.'' At age 34, Mr. Gershkowitz was stunned.

title: Corrections
description: An article last Sunday about Miki Sakaguchi, a Japanese-born jazz singer who performs in Harlem, misidentified a gospel song she sang at a recent Red Cross benefit. It was ''Precious Lord,'' not the Lord's Prayer. The article also misidentified a prominent jazz vocalist who performed. She was Melba Joyce, not Ruth Brown.

title: Custody Battles And the Children
description: There is an important question which remains unanswered in the many news articles I have read regarding ''innovative'' custody arrangements $(''Fathers Play Larger Roles in Custody,'' April 20$). Does anyone really know the long-term effect that joint physical custody will have on the children involved?

title: When a Company Bows To a Neurotic Boss
description: SOME chief executives are so unbearable that companies display warning labels. ''He's awful,'' a midlevel manager said of her organization's chief during a job interview I had some years ago. ''A megalomaniac,'' declared the next-tier interviewer, using the same you've-been-warned tone. ''He'll interfere with projects, blame you for things; we're not just talking about an annoying boss here.''

title: MOVIES THIS WEEK
description: A sensible adaptation of a Ernest Hemingway milestone, a fine DeMille epic, a sophisticated bauble and a suspenseful romantic melodrama brighten the week's movie offerings.

title: Architects Find Right Rx For Former Medical Lab
description: THE refrigerator had a big red sticker that shouted ''Caution -- Bio Hazards.'' There was another notice that informed anyone looking at the abandoned medical laboratory building that the lab had been licensed by the city to work with viruses and microorganisms.

title: Iranian Food Stores and Restaurants
description: Iranian resources in Great Neck and surrounding areas, most of which are closed on the Sabbath:

title: Bangladesh Hopes Trial Shows a Nation of Laws
description: More than 21 years after this poverty-stricken nation lost its first leader and most of his family in an assassination that marked the start of a long and turbulent period of military rule, a trial of the accused assassins has finally begun.

title: Struggling To Stay Avant
description: AN eerie stillness pervades the strip of darkened warehouses and car repair shops on 19th Street between 10th and 11th Avenues. The only pedestrians in sight on a recent Saturday evening are heading to the Kitchen, one of the city's oldest avant-garde performance spaces, which is presenting Hybrid No. 11, a lineup of live performances, video and music.

title: 3 Decades in a Cab: 'It Was About People'
description: PATRICK COYNE moved to New York from his home state of Texas in 1960. He was 25. In the middle of a night in the early 70's, I took Patrick's cab home from The New York Times, where I worked the late shift. We struck up one of those humorous conversations that seem only to occur in New York City cabs.

title: Princeton Crew Defeats Brown
description: The Princeton University men's varsity heavyweight crew prevailed over wind, rain and a Brown crew on Lake Carnegie today to win the Content Cup. The battle of unbeaten teams helped to answer any questions about which crew should be ranked No. 1 in Eastern rowing.

title: Measuring Responsibility For Drinking and Driving
description: To the Editor:

title: Scarborough's Familiarity Breeds Comfort
description: HE doesn't get as many mash notes from adoring women as he used to, and he seldom pilots a plane these days, but after 23 years at the Channel 4 anchor desk, Chuck Scarborough is still soaring.

title: Perfect Start for Devils? Don't Tell Lemaire
description: Jacques Lemaire proved one more time this afternoon that he is not the easiest person to please. Although it was less than 24 hours since his Devils had shut out their across-the-river rivals, the Rangers, 2-0, in the opening game of their Eastern Conference semifinal, Lemaire was not doing figure eights on the ice.

title: The World of Still Lifes and Landscapes
description: Spring in a New Light

title: Corrections
description: A report in the Travel Advisory column on April 20, about the Triple Crown horse races, omitted events to be held in connection with the Belmont Stakes at Belmont Park on Long Island. The race is indeed confined to a single day, June 7. But in addition, the Long Island Belmont Stakes Festival will be held May 18 to June 8. Information is available from the Long Island Convention and Visitors Bureau at (516) 951-3440, extension 500.

title: Actors Suffered, Too
description: To the Editor:

title: Complicated Libretto
description: During the 1993-94 season the Royal Opera House in London's Covent Garden allowed a camera crew to film all aspects of its operation. The result is THE ROYAL OPERA HOUSE, a six-part series that examines the glamorous and not so glamorous side of Britain's prestigious institution, home of opera and ballet, to see how it really works. From the wings it captures on-stage drama as an American diva, Denyce Graves, collapses at her debut performance in ''Carmen'' -- a substitute is flown in from Paris. It goes to board meetings where difficult artistic and financial decisions are made. And before the curtain goes up, it peeks backstage -- THURSDAY at 10 P.M. on CHANNEL 13. Yolanda A. Andrews

title: An Immigrant Owns the Store That Rescued Him
description: There was a time, 17 years ago, when Abel Mendez spent his days trying in vain to sell encyclopedias in the Bronx and his nights scavenging for food in supermarket Dumpsters. These days, he sells toys to customers on Manhattan's Upper East Side and spends his evenings thinking about how to renovate his assortment of houses.

title: LaJoyce Hunter and Gus Brookshire Jr.
description: MORE than 20 years ago, LaJoyce Celeste Hunter met Gus William Brookshire Jr. when he rode his blue bicycle down the middle of the street in Chicago, where she lived. He had just started a new paper route, and her house was on it. She was sitting on the hood of a car, and as soon as she saw him, she thought he was so cute that she remembers closing her eyes and praying that he would stop and talk to her.

title: Corrections
description: A chart last Sunday with an article about buying a high-definition television set referred incorrectly to the types of digital televisions that are expected to be priced at $2,500 to more than $10,000. That is the expected range for all digital sets of any size, not those with 31-inch screens.

title: The Asian Con, Part 2
description: In the mid-1980's, i sat on a Wall Street trading floor and watched the Japanese stampede the United States Treasury bond market. ''How now long bond?'' the customer from Tokyo would ask; the American bond salesman would giggle and then sell to him or buy from him staggering amounts of our national debt. The losses suffered by the Japanese in this activity were breathtaking. Every time the American bond market moved, it seemed, Japan lost a month's worth of trade surpluses. The American bond salesman could see this and, as a result, he was not so frightened by Japan's financial clout. Some part of him grasped that the Japanese were partly mad, and that their behavior doomed them to financial oblivion.

title: Texas, Where History Stings
description: THE scene was a ramshackle trailer off a dirt road in the mountains that was stocked with snack foods and a video collection including ''Thelma and Louise.'' But some people said the bizarre standoff that unfolded here last week between the armed Texas separatists inside the trailer and the state authorities surrounding it evoked an earlier embattled spot: the Alamo.

title: Glittering Prizes
description: THE PULITZER DIARIES Inside America's Greatest Prize. By John Hohenberg. 344 pp. Syracuse: Syracuse University Press. $29.95.

title: F.Y.I.
description: Hollywood East

title: Airlines Share Blame for Passengers' Behavior
description: To the Editor:

title: Stores
description: I enjoyed Tibor Kalman's ''Bag Crit'' in your special issue ''Stores'' (April 6). I believe, however, that there are several other key members of the New York bag family. The sleek Barneys bag is, indeed, the Rolls Royce of bags, but the red Macy's bag is the most functional and respectable -- a good bag to use for giving a gift (a plate of brownies, perhaps, or several old books). A wrinkled, white Woolworth's bag is inoffensive, suitable for carrying things like shoes. The Pathmark bag is useful for lending tools.

title: Stores
description: You showed a bit of East Coast bias in your time line of developments in retailing (''Back to the Future,'' April 6). It cites 1930 expansions, in New York and Chicago, as the initial suburban forays of department stores. But these were preceded by the opening of Bullock's Wilshire, a magnificent Art Deco shopping palace in Los Angeles.

title: Julian's Becomes Yet Another Piece of Pool History
description: In a Shakespearean tragedy, Fast Eddie Felson would be Hamlet. In a Jimi Hendrix song, he would be the Voodoo Chile, chopping down the mountain with the edge of his hand. At the end of the 20th century, Fast Eddie, the pool shark played by Paul Newman in the 1961 film ''The Hustler,'' would be nearly extinct.

title: From the Folks Who Brought You 'Ishtar'
description: LISTEN to producers, talent agents and studio executives after a screening in Hollywood of yet another awful film. Publicly, they rush up to the film's creators and ooze coded expressions like ''I've never seen anything like it!'' or ''You've done it again!'' or, better yet, ''What can I say?'' In other words, the film is a bomb. Privately, they whisper to each other, ''What were they thinking?''

title: LONG ISLAND JOURNAL
description: Walls That Please

title: Young Artist Seeks Brush With Subject
description: Who, or what, has bumped Charles Oakley, who bumped Dwight Gooden? An enormous new mural on a West 42d Street building is provoking an enormous number of long stares and short questions. The stares are all upward. The questions are ''What is that?,'' ''Who is that?'' and ''Why?''

title: Figaro Isn't What It Was But Still Pushes Forward
description: To the Editor:

title: TAKING THE CHILDREN
description: Warriors of Virtue

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  LIEBSTER, SHEILA
description: LIEBSTER-Sheila 25 years. BRECHER-Jules, 20 years. BRECHER-Martha, one year In our hearts forever. Jeffrey, Jill and Elizabeth

title: Let's Give Parents An Extra Right to Vote
description: RECENT debate on income distribution in the United States has focused on a widening gap between the rich and the poor. This is a valid concern. But within this growing imbalance is an even more insidious discrepancy in income and wealth distribution between the old and the young. Even politicians have noticed this -- hence the cutbacks in Medicare and the wrangling over Social Security in the budget-balancing deal shaped late last week.

title: PLAYING IN THE NEIGHBORHOOD
description: LINCOLN CENTER

title: Mandela Moving to Center of African Peace Efforts
description: Soon after the 1994 election in South Africa, when President Nelson Mandela's heroic stature gave new moral authority to his country's already substantial economic and military power, world leaders began urging him to take an active role in solving his continent's seemingly intractable problems. Mr. Mandela told those petitioners -- among them the former United Nations Secretary General, Boutros Boutros-Ghali, and his successor, Kofi Annan -- that he had too much work to do at home, as South Africa made a sometimes-rocky transition to democracy.

title: Israeli Founders Sought Religious Rights for All
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GLASS, HENRY
description: GLASS-Henry. The Officers and Employees of Arma Container Corp. note with sorrow the passing of their longtime friend and partner. We extend our heartfelt condolences to his family. Board of Trustees and Employees Arma Container Corp. Jack Hausman Bruce Margolis Howard Gottfried Howard Glass

title: Honey, I'm Home. Call Room Service.
description: CLIVE DAVIS, the president of Arista Records, lives in a lavish two-floor penthouse atop the 37-story Ritz Tower, at 59th Street and Park Avenue, with an unobstructed 360-degree view. The hallway paneling is of rich brown Makassar ebony, the same wood used in custom guitars. His Art Deco screening room has remote-controlled shades. But the way Mr. Davis sees it, what makes the Ritz ritzy is the fact that he hasn't used his two kitchens since moving in 10 years ago.

title: How U.N. Keeps Pace, With Fewer Troops to Keep the Peace
description: In 1994 the United Nations was running 18 peacekeeping operations, fielding a total force of some 80,000 peacekeepers from 82 countries at an annual cost of almost $3.3 billion.

title: The Men Have Leaped Into the Limelight
description: BALLET IS A WOMAN'S ART, OR SO IT HAS BEEN SAID. But is it? For all the magic of toe shoes and tutus, men have often soared and spun through ballet in ways unmatched by women, casting a special light on the dance of their era. That we are now in such a time can be seen with just a quick look through the roster and repertory of American Ballet Theater.

title: Gallipoli
description: To the Editor: I have visited Turkey twice and I thoroughly enjoyed your April 13 articles on the country. My great-grandparents came from Istanbul. Speaking of ''Gallipoli: Landscape of Sacrifice,'' the museum there contains letters from youthful Turkish soldiers and at least one young British soldier. A letter from a Turkish law student, Hassan Ethem, praised the beauty of Gallipoli and the taste of the milk he received with his tea. He was killed a few days later.

title: Free-Land Lottery Withers on a Prairie in Texas
description: ALL that's missing are the Conestoga wagons, bison herds and sod cabins of homesteading lore.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MALE, LEONORE EDEL
description: MALE-Leonore Edel, artist, photographer, interior/graphic designer and mother died April 27, 1997. Graduate of Hood College in 1938 and tech draftsperson during W.W. II. Lee designed the original RCA showroom in 1948. She was an award winning painter & photographer while raising her family. At 64 she opened Ledel Gallery, Soho's first photographic gallery, in 1981. Known for enthusiasm and love of life, we will miss her. Donate in Lee's memory to ICP, International Center of Photography inner city schools program of NYC The Males

title: Great Minds Live Alike
description: IF any pilgrims to the 19th-century literary shrines of Concord, Mass., should unluckily find that they only have time to visit a single hallowed site, I'd recommend the lonely gray-painted old house by the Concord River, the Old Manse. Not only did all the most revered Concord authors and thinkers -- Emerson, Hawthorne, Thoreau, the youthful Louisa May Alcott and her father, Bronson Alcott -- hang out here, but it's also only a field away from the little wooden Old North Bridge.

title: Suffolk Lawmakers Near Vote on Lilco Review
description: SAYING details of a proposed partial state takeover of the Long Island Lighting Company remain murky, the Suffolk County Legislature is nearing a decision on hiring a special counsel to review the plan.

title: Who Should Be Sorry?
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Savannah's River
description: To the Editor: Kevin Sack gives rather short shrift in ''What's Doing in Savannah'' (April 6) to a charming aspect of Savannah every bit as abiding as its rightfully famous historic district.

title: Summer, and Time to Find a Camp That Fills the Bill
description: JANET RUBEL, of Westport, said sending her son to a camp that had a caring, well-trained staff made all the difference. Her son wasn't athletic; eye surgery in the months before camp was the reason. ''We explained our problem to the director. They took a child who couldn't throw a ball and made him a jock,'' said Ms. Rubel.

title: NEW YORKERS & CO.
description: Sea Legs for Landlubbers: Sailing School on a Pier

title: Let Shareholders Decide
description: To the Editor:

title: Jill C. Lipton, Adam Haberfield
description: Jill Caryn Lipton, the daughter of LenEsta and Fredric Lipton of Woodcliff Lake, N.J., is to be married this afternoon to Adam Matthew Haberfield, a son of Bonnie and David Haberfield, also of Woodcliff Lake. Rabbi Philip Berkowitz is to perform the ceremony at the Edgewood Country Club in River Vale, N.J.

title: For Those Who Like Their Politics Messy
description: Political spectators who find this year's gubernatorial race too clean and civilized for their taste might think about taking a look at the Assembly and Senate contests in the 28th District in Essex County. When it comes to name-calling, insults and scurrilous accusations, it just doesn't get any nastier than these intertwined battles.

title: Marsh McCall and Cristin Clarke
description: Cristin Lynne Clarke, a screenwriter, and Marsh Terrell McCall, a television producer, were married last evening in Los Angeles. The Rev. Robert Hamerton-Kelly performed the ceremony at the Wilshire United Methodist Church.

title: Don't Pick on Business
description: To the Editor:

title: Books in Brief: Nonfiction
description: A Bride's Passage Susan Hathorn's Year Under Sail. By Catherine Petroski. Northeastern University, cloth, $42.50; paper, $15.95.

title: The Story Behind the Story
description: It was a relationship not all that unusual. One man was the team doctor for the St. Louis Cardinals, the other the lead baseball writer for the New York Herald Tribune, then one of the two morning broadsheets in the largest city.

title: Lessons From the Attic
description: FOR years now I have collected all sorts of things -- small folk art pieces, Victorian picture frames, cups and saucers, owl figurines, pitchers, bowls, cabinets, tables, chests and wooden letters and signs. Nothing worthy of a Sotheby's auction, but valuables nonetheless to me and certainly worth something to someone when I die.

title: Pressure Is on Heat To Fulfill Promise
description: Perspiration poured from Alonzo Mourning's face after Friday's practice, and that was appropriate. The entire Miami Heat organization is sweating.

title: U.S. Pupils Score High on Science Facts but Falter on Reasoning
description: American students have some understanding of basic scientific facts and principles, but their ability to apply scientific knowledge, design an experiment or clearly explain their reasoning is ''disappointing,'' according to the latest national test of science education.

title: Saudi Case Casting a Light on How Militants Infiltrate and Exploit Canada
description: The recent arrest of a Saudi man linked to a deadly attack against Americans in the Middle East last year has provided a glimpse, officials say, of how a largely hidden network of militant groups uses Canada to raise money, recruit members, provide refuge and plan attacks.

title: Outlet Center Opens Near 6 Flags Park
description: These days a ride to Six Flags Great Adventure Theme Park and Safari in Jackson Township, N.J., may provide a different kind of adventure for both children and their parents.

title: BUSINESS BEST SELLERS
description: HARD COVER

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HOFSTADTER, NEWTON
description: HOFSTADTER-Newton. Formerly of Forest Hills and Florida. Residing in Ventura, California. We mourn the sudden loss of a lifelong, beloved friend who knew the urgency of friendship. He will be remembered as sportsman and a man who gave of himself. We shall sorely miss him with a memory enduring. Helene and Ron Rosson

title: Correction
description: An article on April 20 about Fred W. Friendly referred imprecisely to the producers of two television programs in the Fred Friendly Seminars series. ''Before I Die: Medical Care and Personal Choices'' was produced by Amy Schatz; Richard Kilberg was the executive producer. ''Liberty and Limits: 'The Federalist' Idea 200 Years Later'' was produced by Barbara Margolis, Andy Halper and Anne Reingold; Mr. Kilberg was the executive producer. Stuart F. Sucherman is executive in charge of the Fred Friendly Seminars.

title: A Performing Arts Center?
description: Correspondents debated the need for The $180 million New Jersey Center for the Performing Arts, which will open this fall in Newark.

title: Asian-Americans' Bold Expressions of Tradition Meeting Modernism
description: THE Zimmerli Art Museum specializes in bringing neglected 19th- and 20th-century art movements to the fore. But rarely do these revivals have the thunder of ''Asian Traditions/Modern Expressions,'' an exhaustive examination of the abstract work of American artists of Chinese, Japanese and Korean descent made from 1945 to 1970. The period coincides with the flowering of Abstract Expressionism, and the subsequent branching off into Pop Art and color field painting. Asian-American artists incorporated these Western developments into their styles, but the exhibition also demonstrates that many of Abstract Expressionism's major tenets have long been the basis of Asian art.

title: 2 Men, 1 Woman, and Talk of Love and War
description: The way the New York City police tell it, a businessman from Nassau County came to Brooklyn to try to hire a hit man to kill his girlfriend's estranged husband. The police say he was arrested after they learned of his effort and after an undercover officer, posing as a killer for hire, met with the businessman and worked out a deal.

title: CONNECTICUT GUIDE
description: OPTIMISM TO CYNICISM

title: Some of Their Best Friends Are Jews
description: What's with the Southern Baptists' obsession to convert the Jews (''Some of Their Best Friends Are Jews,'' by Jeffrey Goldberg, March 16)? In 1845, they split the Baptist Church over slavery and, ever since, have been on the wrong side of every social and economic issue. They were among the most recalcitrant racists in the civil-rights struggle and even today are usually found side by side with the ''neanderthal right.''

title: Shareholders' Burden
description: To the Editor:

title: Bar Is Too Popular for Some
description: The wrought-iron gates of the Rome Bar in Chelsea swing open around 4 P.M. to receive deliveries. But it is what happens after midnight that has some residents concerned.

title: Architects to Study Soundness of Fort Totten
description: An architecture firm based in Manhattan will begin testing the structural soundness of Fort Totten this fall as part of an effort by government and civic leaders to come up with a redevelopment plan for the historic fort in Bayside, Queens.

title: Desert Serenade
description: American Owned Love

title: Stores
description: Barneys is in Chapter 11. Those ''sorry looking'' Century 21 shopping bags are leaving the store by the thousands, loaded with merchandise. I guess a lot of shoppers know it's not about real estate.

title: U.S. Economy Keeps Booming
description: The economy has been chugging along recession-free for more than six years, but it is now roaring down the track. Economic output grew 5.6 percent in the first quarter, the strongest performance since 1987, the Government said last week. The momentum carried over into April, pushing the unemployment rate down to 4.9 percent, the lowest rate in 24 years.

title: Biologists Track Hatching That Gives Hope in Face of Pollutants
description: Sixty-eight feet up in a cottonwood tree on an island in the Hudson River, Peter Nye peered over the rim of a stove-size bald eagle nest and looked a bit of history in the eye.

title: Airlines Share Blame for Passengers' Behavior
description: To the Editor:

title: Haunted by Drama
description: IT is good to arrive in New London on a Sunday night in a chilly April because after leaving the railroad station and the small fleet of cabs that waits outside, one walks through streets that are as barren as the moon. This is, while not a ghost town, a city of ghosts, and there is no better way to sense a spook than in silence.

title: Booking Cruises
description: To the Editor: I read with great interest ''By Sternwheeler Along the Columbia'' on Feb. 2.

title: A Prize Question
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHAPIRO, MALCOLM
description: SHAPIRO-Malcolm. Beloved son of Jean. Dear brother of Arvin. Funeral service Monday, 11:30 AM, ''Plaza Memorial Chapel,'' 91st and Amsterdam Ave., NYC.

title: Mairs & Power Growth Fund
description: MUCH of the Upper Midwest was under water in April, as was a mutual fund that invests heavily in the region.

title: In a Hollywood Arms Race, The Guns Have Gone Crazy
description: EVER SINCE DIRTY HARRY unholstered his long-barreled .357 Magnum and urged villains to make his day, exaggerated artillery has played a central role in the appeal of Hollywood action movies.

title: The Good, Bad and Ugly At a British Showplace
description: ALL IS NOT WELL AT THE Royal Opera House, Covent Garden, home of Britain's premier opera and ballet companies. The star of ''Carmen,'' the American soprano Denyce Graves, dramatically loses her voice and has to be replaced overnight by Magali Damonte, a French singer whose ignorance of English is matched only by the opera staff's ignorance of her (''All we know is she sounds like a tin of fruit,'' one staff member sniffs).

title: Trouble Spots on the State's Roadways
description: A look at trouble spots you can expect to encounter in the next week -- or month, or months -- courtesy of the State Department of Transportation.

title: New Horizons In Chinatown
description: CANTON

title: Custody Case With Crimes At the Center
description: FOR now, Sayeh and Arash Rivazfar live with their father, stepmother and three half-sisters in a cozy beige house with forest green shutters and a picnic table out front. It sits in a neighborhood where Saturdays are lawn days and the trash is put out after dark. Sayeh, 17, and Arash, 13, say they would be content to lead typical suburban kids' lives here.

title: Gaslight Becomes You
description: Victoriana has long been in fashion in literary circles, but for art lovers, fine examples from the period are hard to come by in American museums. So the genre's fans will welcome THE VICTORIANS: British Painting 1837-1901 (National Gallery of Art/Abrams, $49.50), by Malcolm Warner with contributions by Anne Helmreich and Charles Brock. Those who pick up the book expecting languidly draped ladies of the popular Pre-Raphaelite painters will not be disappointed; they may be pleasantly surprised, though, by some of the other color plates (and substantial explications) in the book. Mr. Warner, a curator at the Yale Center for British Art in New Haven, writes that the paintings were selected for their quality rather than for how accurately they represent the period, and this admirable strategy has yielded some lesser-known gems. As science (most potently Darwinism) and industrialization encroached on the traditional concepts of landscape, family and religion, many painters looked backward and employed symbols of the past, particularly of medieval and biblical origin. As Mr. Warner writes, almost all Victorian painting can be seen as ''constantly aspiring toward the condition of faith.'' These works from a self-conscious and anxious age may prove to be surprisingly resonant today. Ted Loos

title: Veteran of Los Angeles District Will Be School Superintendent
description: Ruben Zacarias, a 31-year veteran of the Los Angeles Unified School District, was chosen on Friday by the city school board to lead the district, second-largest in the nation.

title: Dana Dorfman And Scott Grubin
description: Dana Carrie Dorfman, the daughter of Judy and Joel Dorfman of Allendale, N.J., was married last evening to Scott Geoffrey Grubin, the son of Ruth and Harold Grubin of West Hartford, Conn. Rabbi Marc Disick officiated at Temple Emanuel in Woodcliff Lake, N.J.

title: Sondheim Is Hardly 'Self-Limiting'
description: To the Editor:

title: Show House Party, Utterly Buatta
description: IT could have been a television sit-com.

title: Jayne Mansfield's Head
description: ''Her head was attached as much as mine is,'' says Jim Roberts, gently dismissing a longstanding myth about Jayne Mansfield's grisly demise. The accepted version (now playing in the movie ''Crash'') has it that Mansfield was beheaded when she died in a car accident just outside of New Orleans on June 29, 1967. Roberts says the beheading part is hooey, and he should know -- he was her undertaker. ''People always figured wrong about Jayne,'' he laments. ''About the way she lived and the way she died.''

title: Pettitte Does His Job, But He's Left Stranded
description: When the Yankees have needed a life preserver during the last three seasons, Andy Pettitte has almost always provided it. He is resilient and he is remarkable. But when Pettitte needed modest help from the Yankees tonight, they failed him. No one provided a life preserver for Pettitte as the Kansas City Royals scooted to a 2-1 victory.

title: Are Big Stocks Really Best?
description: A funny thing is happening to aggressive-growth mutual funds, the ones that go for the biggest winners. Investors have -- shudder -- taken money out of them.

title: Housing Sales Set a Record for a First Quarter
description: By WESTCHESTER'S housing market soared to a record-breaking sales level in the first quarter this year, with 1,448 closings between Jan. 1 and March 31.

title: Helen James, James Dolan 3d
description: Helen Charlene James, the daughter of Elaine LaValle James and George James of Ridgewood, N.J., was married there yesterday to James Patrick Dolan 3d, a son of Cecilia A. Dolan and James P. Dolan Jr. of Mahwah, N.J. Msgr. Edward J. Ciuba performed the ceremony at Our Lady of Mount Carmel Church.

title: U.N. Refugee Chief Warns Zaire Crisis a 'Nightmare'
description: The head of the United Nations' refugee agency said today that she was pleased that the United States was finally asserting leadership in the Zairian crisis.

title: Rouen Has A Way With The Classics
description: ROUEN as a mecca for food lovers? Well, it's not about to unseat Lyons, but, lured by its cathedral and Monet's paintings of it, a friend and I recently spent five days there and were surprised to find the dining as outstanding as the city's best architecture, faience and excellent museums.

title: A Small Congregation With a Wide Demographic Reach
description: THE members of St. Mary's Episcopal Church here like to joke about the fact that their house of worship began in a distinctly un-churchlike way -- in a tavern.

title: Ferry to Be Free, but Queens-to-Queens Bridge Is Still $1.75
description: For years, residents of this small island community situated in the middle of Jamaica Bay have protested the toll they pay to travel the half-mile-long Cross Bay Veterans Memorial Bridge to the Rockaway Peninsula, a neighborhood with which they share a ZIP code and a high school. Many Broad Channel people work on the peninsula.

title: Comptroller Tosses His Support to Council Challenger
description: In announcing her candidacy for the City Council last week, Pauline Chu got a lift in her bid to unseat Julia Harrison, who has represented the 20th District, when Alan Hevesi, the City Comptroller, endorsed Ms. Chu.

title: Sotheby's Stirs East End Realty
description: WHEN an internationally known agency like Sothebys makes a power move in the Hamptons, it's sure to cause tongues to wag in the real estate industry, even if no one is quite sure what to make of it all.

title: In Budget Battle, Advantage Goes to G.O.P. Chairmen
description: With a broad agreement in hand that promises a balanced budget, the deal-making has shifted from President Clinton and Republican leaders to a new set of negotiators, the Capitol Hill tax writers and appropriators who will make it law.

title: I Am More Than Hands
description: Jane Bendetson's account of the emotional, physical and financial toll of caring for her chronically ill husband is a compelling statement that will resonate with a growing number of people in similar circumstances (Lives: ''I Am More Than Hands,'' by Jane Bendetson, April 13). The current revolution in health care financing and delivery is shifting even more costs and responsibilities to family members.

title: The Ghost Baby
description: As the midwife moved the fetal monitor across my belly, she frowned. She tried the top, underside and sides of my expanded body. I was 20 weeks pregnant, and the heartbeat should have been loud and strong. But no matter where she placed the monitor, the same deafening silence resounded.

title: Table Talk
description: To the Editor: While reading Louis Inturrisi's critique of six depictions of the Last Supper (March 23), I was reminded of a 1950 visit to Milan where I hastened to pay homage to Leonardo's masterpiece. The junior member of an English family standing nearby voiced this poser: ''Ma, why did they all sit on the same side of the table?''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROSENBERG, GERTRUDE BOB
description: ROSENBERG-Gertrude Bob. Devoted mother of Marcia Sherson, Geoffrey Bob, and stepsons Herbert and Robert Rosenberg. Loving grandmother of Melinda and Michael Bob, Meri, Debi and David Sherson. Dear sister of Leonard Gold and Mildred Herman. Graveside services Monday, May 5, 10 AM, at Mt. Lebanon Cemetery, Glendale, NY.

title: Flying Home, but Not for Fun
description: A MAN was dying in a hospice in White Plains and his daughter, a college student in New Orleans, wanted to get home immediately.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FREEDMAN, ELIZABETH
description: FREEDMAN-Elizabeth. The officers, leadership, and staff of UJA-Federation of New York mourn the passing of Elizabeth Freedman, mother of Joan Bernikow and mother-in-law of Alan S. Bernikow, a former officer of UJA-Federation and a major leader in both the Jewish and general philanthropic communities. We extend our deepest sympathies to Joan, Alan, and the entire family. Larry A. Silverstein, Board Chair Louise B. Greilsheimer, President Stephen D. Solender, Exec. V.P.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ISAACS, LEWIS M., JR.
description: ISAACS-Lewis M., Jr. Died April 26, 1997, 89 years old. Leaves loved daughter, Carol. His loving soul is more immortal than the stars and this will shine in our hearts forever. Donations can be made in his name to Stanley M. Isaacs, Neighborhood Houses, 415 East 93rd Street, NYC 10128

title: The Last of the T-Birds (Maybe)
description: IT says a lot about the latest -- and possibly the last -- Ford Thunderbird that the '97 model seems old, even to a retro sort of guy like me.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ALFANO, MICHAEL A.
description: ALFANO-Michael A. On April 30th in Massachusetts. Husband of the late Lorraine (Shields). Beloved friend of Nellie Furtado. Father of Michael of Long Island and Joanie Alfano. Brother of Anthony Polcari. Army Veteran of World War II. Contributions in his memory may be made to the Italian Childrens Home, 1125 Centre Street, Jamaica Plain, MA 02130. For information contact Rogers Funeral Home, 380 Cambridge St., Cambridge, MA 617-876-8964.

title: Books in Brief: Nonfiction
description: TROPICAL CLASSICAL

title: Classical Music Apolitical? Not in Turkey
description: WHEN THE REVERED Turkish maestro Hikmet Simsek lifted his baton to conduct Ahmed Adnan Saygun's oratorio ''Yunus Emre'' at the Turkish State Opera House here recently, he was making a political as well as a musical statement.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KELLNER, FLORA
description: KELLNER-Flora. Beloved wife of the late Irving. Devoted mother of Frances Heller, Caroline Lesser and dear sister of Harry Kosmacher. Adored grandmother of Keith and Kirby Heller, Stacey and Jill Lesser. Cherished great-grandmother of Jared, Gregory and Rebecca. Services Sunday 12 noon at the Riverside Nassau North Chapel, 55 North Station Plaza, Great Neck, opposite LIRR.

title: Delivery Woman
description: MIDWIVES

title: Students May Be Seeing Fewer Marlboro Men
description: Peter F. Vallone, the Speaker of the City Council, has proposed a ban on billboard and store-window advertising of cigarettes within 1,000 feet of any school or day care center in New York City. ''We have to get children to understand what we didn't know or understand when we were their age,'' he said.

title: Horrors! Now I Have to Use the Cellular Phone
description: CONGRATULATIONS! You have purchased one of the most sophisticated cordless telephones on the market!'' This kind of message always sends a chill down my spine, especially when it is accompanied by two exclamation points and an ''Operation Manual'' the size of a college textbook.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEINSTOCK, DAVID J., M.D.
description: WEINSTOCK-David J., M.D. He was 39 years old of Stamford, Connecticut; died April 23, 1997. Funderal services were held at Gallagher's Funeral Home, Stamford. Interment at Beth El Cemetery in Oradell, New Jersey. Dr. Weinstock was a pediatric intensivist who set up critical care units in hospitals specifically for the most difficult pediatric cases. He was the first Pediatric Fellow at Cornell Medical Center in New York City. Dr. Weinstock earned earned his M.D. at age 23. Survivors include his daughter Caitlin Weinstock of Stamford; sisters Debby Simon of New York and Jacqueline Granath of Atlanta; nephews Dr. Michael B. Simon and Brian Granath; and niece Elissa Granath. Contributions may be made to the March of Dimes.

title: The Gospel According to the Grouch
description: Some 30 miles southeast of Dodge City, on the outskirts of tiny Mullinville, Kan., sits the 100-acre property of M.T. Liggett -- prairie philosopher, folk artist, supremely disgruntled citizen. You can't miss his place, what with the hundreds of brightly colored metal sculptures rising from the rich farmland. This layout is Liggett's untitled masterpiece, a scrap-metal garden of populist rage and crotchety enthusiasms that he has worked on since 1989, at an estimated cost of ''a bunch.'' Liggett, a burly 66-year-old, proudly notes that ''My political ideas will be here 150 years from now -- they're made out of quarter-inch iron. That's why I done it this way.'' A typical example of his vision is a bristling work that clearly states his feelings about authority figures -- President Bill Clinton, depicted as a bright red hog labeled ''razorback draft dodger.'' Here's a larger look at dyspepsia -- immortalized.

title: Kathryne Lyons, Jonathan Teplitz
description: Kathryne Josephine Lyons, a daughter of Kay and Tom Lyons of Newtown, Pa., is to be married today to Jonathan Bruce Teplitz, a son of Iris and Philip Teplitz of Pittsburgh. The Rev. Donald G. Clifford, a Roman Catholic priest, is to officiate at the Downtown Club in Philadelphia. Rabbi Burt Aaron Siegel will take part in the ceremony.

title: Sprawling Works, 13 Sculptors
description: THE national juried exhibition that Creative Arts Workshop in New Haven sponsors every year avoids tedium by changing its theme each time out. Sculpture that alludes to ''nature and human experience'' is the wide subject of this year's competition, and work for the exhibition was selected by Petah Coyne, a sculptor whose work has this quality in abundance.

title: Marymount to Honor Female Composers
description: EARLY and modern music, choral and chamber music are all on the schedule today.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DILL, ELIZABETH MCKNIGHT
description: DILL-Elizabeth McKnight of New Suffolk on May 1, 1997. Beloved wife of the late James G., devoted mother of James G. Dill, Jr., David McKnight Dill and Johnathan C. Dill. Also survived by three grandchildren and one great-grandson. Funeral service Tuesday, 1PM at the First Presbyterian Church of Southold. Memorials may be sent to Eastern Long Island Hospital, Greenport, N.Y. 11944

title: Guessing the Next Chapter Of Virtual Bookselling
description: AMAZON.COM, the Internet company that bills itself as ''Earth's Biggest Bookstore,'' will open its doors to investors later this month.

title: In Anatolia, Town Curse Is a Legacy Of Cancer
description: Although this place looks like any small farming village in central Anatolia, people in the area believe it bears a special curse.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEINGARTEN, LEONARD A., M.D.
description: WEINGARTEN-Leonard A., M.D. On May 2, 1997. Beloved husband of Joan; loving father of Leslie (Scott) Singer and Mark (Nancy Greenstein) Weingarten; cherished grandfather of Jordan Taylor Singer; devoted son of Dr. Michael and Beatrice Weingarten; dear brother of Muriel (Sam) Dachs. Service today Sunday, May 4, 3:30 PM, at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street. Contributions to Beth Israel Hospital in his memory would be appreciated.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  GILSON, GOODWIN W. MAY
description: GILSON-Goodwin W. May 3, 1991. Six years and a day... and not a day's gone by... Larry.

title: Smiles All Around
description: The environment, along with the worlds of art, photography, dance and charity, benefit from parties.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PORTER, KEITH R., PH.D.
description: PORTER-Keith R., Ph.D., of Beaumont at Bryn Mawr, PA and formerly of Boulder, CO, died on Friday, May 2, 1997. Husband of the late Elizabeth L. Porter. He is survived by a nephew, Keith M. Pineo, and a niece, Mary Holman. A memorial service will be held at a later date. Contributions may be made to the Keith R. Porter Endowment for Cell Biology, c/o Lee D. Peachey, Trustee, 606 Old Gulph Road, Narberth, PA 19072.

title: It's Only Golf
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Correction
description: Because of a production error, the front-page Jersey column on April 27 omitted a final line. The column, about Russell Kucinski, a Rutgers University student who was arrested because the police thought his art project looked like a bomb, should have ended with this quotation from Kathy Kucinski, his mother: ''Everybody's talking about it around here, that's for sure.''

title: Steak-Filled Rooms
description: PETE LORENZO, a former police officer, opened the cafe bearing his name in 1918. He was 6 foot 4, which was big -- ''especially for Italians,'' said Anthony Merlino, a descendant of Mr. Lorenzo's wife, Nancy, and a co-owner of the restaurant. Mr. Lorenzo's size may explain the famously huge steaks that hardly anyone finishes.

title: More Than Advise and Consent
description: Under the Constitution, the President makes nominations to the Federal judiciary and the Senate decides on them.

title: Before It Was Iran
description: BLOOD AND OIL

title: Books in Brief: Nonfiction
description: BURNING DOWN THE HOUSE

title: The Shell Game
description: Second only to the question of which came first, the chicken or the egg, is that other confounding enigma: Which is more useful, the white or the yolk?

title: Conjuring Up 'Those Old Auerbach Players'
description: IT was that time of year again, the blossoming of the professional basketball season. A famous father felt the rite of spring, the call of the playoffs. He decided to fly south, like a backward migratory bird.

title: No Headline
description: ''Please, please, don't make us bring your two-and-a-half-year-old grandson to your funeral.''

title: Josina Reddy, Jonathan Weissman
description: Dr. Josina C. Reddy, the daughter of Dr. Josina M. Arfman of Pound Ridge, N.Y., and Dr. Thomas B. Reddy of Bronxville, N.Y., was married yesterday to Dr. Jonathan S. Weissman, the son of Dr. Myrna M. Weissman of New York and Dr. Sherman M. Weissman of New Haven. Rabbi Charles D. Lippman performed the ceremony at the Williams Club in New York.

title: A Better Quality of Life, In the Days Before Death
description: Saying that the failure of patients and doctors to talk about death compounds the agony of dying, the United Hospital Fund has awarded $1.1 million to five hospitals in New York City to improve emotional and physical care at the end of life.

title: The News She Wanted Could Not Be Found
description: To the Editor:

title: Susannah Hayes And John Jones
description: Susannah Rachel Hayes, a daughter of Sheila and Michael A. Hayes of Briarcliff Manor, N.Y., was married there yesterday to John Jude Jones, a son of Rose Anne and John J. Jones of Mahopac, N.Y. Msgr. Francis Boyle performed the ceremony at St. Theresa's Church.

title: Brian Cooper, Ruth Fortunoff
description: Ruth Fortunoff, a vice president of jewelry merchandising for Fortunoff, the jewelry and giftware retailing company based in Westbury, N.Y., was married last evening to Brian Todd Cooper, the director of new media in the entrepreneurial services group of Ernst & Young, the accounting firm in New York. Rabbi Aaron Petuchowski performed the ceremony at the Glen Oaks Country Club in Old Westbury, N.Y.

title: Celebrating The Man Who Casts a Spell At the Carlyle
description: WHEN BOBBY SHORT performs ''Just One of Those Things,'' Cole Porter's genial epitaph to a love affair that was ''too hot not to cool down,'' the feeling he conveys isn't regret, anger or bitterness over a failed relationship but an irresistible joie de vivre.

title: Two Troupes, One 'Oz' Transformed
description: ''THE WIZARD OF OZ'' is one of America's most enduring and beloved fantasies. But that's only one reason two New Haven area theater companies are collaborating to put on a gender- and race-blind version of the classic this month. The groups say it's a perfect vehicle to showcase many values while entertaining audiences with its story and songs.

title: An Incredible Shrinking World Is the Focus for a Virtual Tour
description: GEOGRAPHY is not just looking at maps. Travel and communication have shrunk the world and made geography at once more relevant and more complex.

title: Science Fiction
description: Robert L. Forward holds a doctorate in gravitational physics. As you might guess, when he writes science fiction he gets the science right. If a space pilot in his latest novel, SATURN RUKH (Tor/Tom Doherty, $22.95), declares, ''I'm going to make our new periapsis point right over the eastern terminator,'' you can be sure that this orbital maneuver will work as planned, even without consulting the mathematical tables and astronomical diagrams that the author has thoughtfully provided in the back of the book.

title: Books in Brief: Fiction
description: The Players

title: Senate Panel Opposes Use Of Sampling In Next Census
description: The Senate Appropriations Committee dealt a serious setback this week to the Census Bureau, ordering it not to spend money developing statistical tools to estimate how many people are missed in the census for 2000.

title: Corrections
description: A report in Metro News Briefs in some editions yesterday about the indictment of three men on stock fraud charges misidentified the Assistant United States Attorney in Brooklyn. He is Zachary W. Carter.

title: The Chanel Under the Chador
description: On a street blocked to traffic in the wealthiest section of Teheran, a white-gloved honor guard salutes a parade of women swathed in black as they hurry into an opulently furnished guest house that once belonged to the Shah.

title: Jill Gushwa, Steven Josephson
description: Dr. Jill Patrice Gushwa, a daughter of Emma and Roy Gushwa of Pembroke Pines, Fla., and Dr. Steven Arthur Josephson, the son of Jeri Josephson and Dr. Bertram Josephson of Scarsdale, N.Y., were married last evening at Disney's Yacht Club Resort in Orlando, Fla. The Rev. Theodore Costello, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony, in which Rabbi Robert Lefkowitz took part.

title: Deletion of Word in Welfare Bill Opens Foster Care to Big Business
description: It sounds like an old-fashioned Hollywood movie. A dedicated couple start a boarding school for autistic children in a faded mansion in rural Delaware. Struggling to make ends meet, they pool their personal resources to buy a racehorse named Silk Stockings. The filly not only wins thousands but also makes harness-racing history, all for the sake of the children.

title: Because Summer Can Be Swimming, Sunshine and Smiles
description: For 11 months of the year, Shana Brown, 9, lives in a three-bedroom apartment in Harlem with her mother and two brothers. But in the summer, she goes to Seaford, Del., to a house with three trees out front and a garage -- even a porch and a backyard. And although she is tickled by the memory of her first time riding the Atlantic waves on an inner tube, Shana's favorite thing about Delaware is not going to the beach, and it is not climbing trees, either.

title: Showing Children Another World
description: ''In the country, everything isn't always a rush. You have time to play.'' That revelation came to 11-year-old Satoya after she spent two weeks last summer with a family in a rambling house just outside Allentown, Pa. Satoya, who is growing up in a Brooklyn apartment, is one of the many children who have been exposed to a whole new world by the Fresh Air Fund.

title: The Real Africa?
description: To the Editor:

title: Catherine Brown, Scott Paterson
description: Catherine Allison Brown, a daughter of Betty C . Brown of Charlotte, N.C., and Walter F. Brown Jr. of Brooksville, Fla., was married yesterday to Scott Lindsey Paterson, a son of Susan B. Paterson of Melville, N.Y., and Thomas F. Paterson of Northport, N.Y. The Rev. Benjamin Riddle performed the ceremony at the Dilworth United Methodist Church in Charlotte.

title: The Warrior Spies
description: Of the myriad problems facing the next Director of Central Intelligence, the most important and intractable is the clandestine service, the center of America's espionage activities and covert operations. Since this elite group first took form at the dawn of the cold war, it has dominated and defined the Central Intelligence Agency, sometimes by brilliant achievement, often by humiliating failure. To date, the insular service has resisted every effort to make it accountable and hold it to high standards of integrity and professional conduct.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WINTER, HAROLD
description: WINTER-Harold, died on April 22. Dearly beloved husband of Susan. Adored father of Peter, and Robin and David Bailey. Joyous and devoted ''poppa'' of Emily. We have lost ''our best friend''. He was a gentleman, who touched so many lives with his goodness and genuine concern. The warmth he radiated gave everyone immediate comfort. He gave so much in heart and deed, but never asked for anything in return. The kindness and quiet wisdom that he gave to all of us will live on like a legacy of love and will forever remain with us to cherish.

title: Ms. Podeszwa And Dr. Suratt
description: Christine Ann Podeszwa, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Eugene Podeszwa of Lisbon, Conn., was married yesterday to Dr. Benjamin Tate Suratt, a son of Sue Suratt of Brooklyn and Samuel T. Suratt of Manhattan. The Rev. Eugene Pilatowski officiated at St. Joseph's Roman Catholic Church in Norwich, Conn.

title: Elaina Pirro and John Lombardi
description: Elaina Anne Pirro, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas J. Pirro of Syracuse, was married there yesterday to John Victor Lombardi, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Francis T. Lombardi, also of Syracuse. The Rev. Michael Carmola performed the Roman Catholic ceremony at the Le Moyne College Chapel.

title: Disney's Homosynergy
description: If a politician trashes lesbians in Washington and no one hears him, did he really do it?

title: The Web of Obligations
description: To the Editor:

title: A Move to Restore Benefits to Some Immigrants
description: President Clinton forced reluctant Republicans to restore disability and health benefits to several hundred thousand legal immigrants as part of the budget agreement announced this week.

title: Fever Dreams
description: NO MERCY

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article last Sunday about the passenger flights begun by the United Parcel Service omitted the attribution of a comment. It was Paul J. Harjes, a mechanic, who noted differences between cargo and passenger flights but the importance of avoiding delays on both. ''When I take a delay on a cargo flight, I don't see the people involved,'' Mr. Harjes said. ''But there's people behind the boxes,'' who rely on the packages' timely arrival.

title: Morels? The Curtain Finally Rises on Spring
description: FRESH morels come into season in the spring. These dark brown mushrooms have wrinkled honeycomb caps and grow mainly in California, Oregon, Washington and Wisconsin. For many people they are a delicacy on a par with white truffles. Their deep, earthy taste goes with spring vegetables like asparagus, young peas and new potatoes, and is a perfect foil for bland meats like chicken or veal.

title: An Unmellowed Editorialist
description: IN the last few weeks, Virginia Franklin, chief editorial writer for The Patent Trader, a weekly newspaper covering northern Westchester, has taken some strong positions.

title: City Has $309 Million Invested in Tobacco
description: Urging the city to divest its $29 billion pension fund of tobacco holdings, Mark Green, the Public Advocate, announced yesterday that the fund currently has $309 million invested in tobacco stocks.

title: Monuments Are a Risky Business
description: THE Great Cigar Controversy, as they called it, unfolded 32 years ago as William Mozart McVey was working on a nine-foot statue of Sir Winston Churchill to be placed outside the British embassy here. Someone pointed out that Mr. McVey was sculpturing a big stogie in Sir Winston's left hand. There was an ugly fight in the press and in diplomatic circles over this vulgar accessory. Chop it off, critics demanded. Stuff it, Mr. McVey responded; he looked at 300 photographs of the guy before he designed this thing, and only 22 of them showed him sans cheroot. The English Speaking Union, which was footing the bill, polled its chapters. The cigar won, 7 to 5. Today the statue is one of the most recognized sculptures on earth.

title: ON THE TOWNS
description: An opinionated guide to cultural and recreational goings-on around the state this week. To submit items for consideration, write to On the Towns, Sunday New Jersey Section, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036, or send a fax to (212) 556-7219.

title: Baerga's 4-for-4 Day Backs Up Mets' Reed
description: Carlos Baerga's bats arrived yesterday. So did his hits.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SAPERSTEIN, ALLEN LEE
description: SAPERSTEIN-Allen Lee. Originally from Detroit. On Friday, April 25. Died at home in Brooklyn. Beloved father of Linnee and Michah. Ex-husband and lifelong friend of Barbara Henning. Brother of Herbert and his wife Audrey. Dear friend of Michael Kanter. Former owner of Copy Cat on 7th Ave. Brooklyn. He will be missed by all who knew him.

title: Robin Leinwand, James Helburn
description: Robin Michelle Leinwand, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Edward W. Leinwand of Commack, N.Y., was married last evening to James Landmann Helburn, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Richard L. Helburn of Weston, Conn. Rabbi Robert Orkand performed the ceremony at Flowerfield, a catering concern in St. James, N.Y.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WALLACH, MILDRED
description: WALLACH-Mildred. On May 2, 1997. Beloved wife of the late Emil. Adored and cherished mother of Eugene Wallach and Alice Kulick Klein and mother-in-law of Howard Klein. Loving grandmother of Genevieve and Robert, Peter and Ann Mette, Phillis and Renee and Tommy. Great grandmother of Bret, Nicole, Siri Lynn and Isabella. Services Sunday, 10:30 A.M., ''Schwartz Brothers-Jeffer Memorial Chapels'', 76th Road and Queens Boulevard in Forest Hills.

title: One Piece of Vacant Land, With Two Views of Its Worth
description: Where Howard Snyder, the president of the Mariner's Marsh Conservancy, sees 111 acres of freshwater wetlands offering leafy succor to pheasants and frogs and eco-starved urbanites, others see the perfect location for an after-hours chop-shop.

title: 'Let's Go, Devils!' and Unsavory Slurs
description: Finally, Devils fans have their own identity, at least around their home rink. When their heroes beat the Rangers by 2-0 on Friday night in the opener of the Eastern Conference semifinals, the vast majority of the customers cheered for the home team in Continental Arena.

title: Doctor in Forefront of Overseas Adoptions
description: NO secretary. No assistant. A jangling phone. The calm eye of an apparent storm of activity, Dr. Jane Aronson sits in the center of a small but power-packed office, while the world -- via every conceivable modern communication device except a videophone -- is but a chair-swivel away. No more than five specialists in the United States do the kind of work that Dr. Aronson does: she screens children for international adoptions, and is the sole such practitioner on the East Coast.

title: Combining Apartments
description: To the Editor:

title: Lisa Silfen, Matthew Lamstein
description: Lisa K. Silfen, a daughter of Norma Silfen of New York and Martin Silfen of Virginia Beach, Va., is to be married today to Matthew Cary Lamstein, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Benjamin Lamstein of Rockville Centre, N.Y. Cantor Meredith Stone is to perform the ceremony at the Brooklyn Botanic Garden.

title: Genetic Testing Gives Glimpse Into Future
description: FORTUNETELLERS would have us believe that our fate is revealed in the milky reflection of their crystal balls. What lies ahead? Something thrilling? Something devastating? Now geneticists and molecular biologists are making it scientifically possible for us to glimpse into our futures through an analysis of our genes. There are those in the field who regard this genetic information as sacred.

title: Fabled Images From a Fabled Land
description: LIKE THE DRAGON, THAT CLOUD-BORNE emblem of cosmic vitality, Chinese art is soaring these days. Auction sales are sky-high. In China, collectors are scrambling to secure a patrimony that threatened to slip through their hands during the years of the Cultural Revolution.

title: L.I. Vines
description: Merlot

title: Masako Tamura and Eric Yap
description: Masako Tamura was married last evening in West Orange, N.J., to Dr. Eric Wei Yap. Jewelnel Davis, the chaplain of Columbia University, performed the nondenominational ceremony at the Manor, a restaurant.

title: Books in Brief: Fiction
description: The Right Man for the Job

title: The Blue Lagoon It Isn't
description: THE model was stretching her long body into the sunlight in a scene too tropical to be true. Her photograph was on the cover of the new Victoria's Secret catalogue, her curves adeptly restrained by a purple Malia Mills bikini.

title: Born on Third Base
description: To the Editor:

title: Is Your A.T.M. Ripping You Off?
description: ASK Pat Bond about his visit to an automated teller machine near his home several weeks ago, and he will tell you how he was almost robbed -- not by a mugger, but by the A.T.M.

title: Smiling Batman, Killer Dinos
description: ALL THE NEW SUMMER MOVIES aren't about comic-book characters or terrorists. There are beekeepers, taxi drivers, dance instructors, fairy godmothers and dogs who shoot hoops. Here are the films in store for moviegoers between now and Labor Day, 113 of them at last count. Those starred are considered particularly noteworthy, for better or worse. As always, opening dates are subject to change -- and more change. ANITA GATES

title: Hong Kong From A to Z and Britain to China
description: ON July 1, the British are to relinquish the crown colony of Hong Kong to Chinese control. But how much more than that do most Westerners know about the several islands and the piece of the mainland that make up this fascinating territory?

title: Miss Livingston, Mr. Netchvolodoff
description: Catherine Ellen Livingston, a Treasury Department lawyer in Washington, and Nicholas Alexander Netchvolodoff, a manager of strategic planning at Bell Atlantic in Arlington, Va., were married last evening at the Cosmos Club in Washington. The Rev. Francis H. Wade, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony, in which Judge Stanley Sporkin of United States District Court in Washington took part.

title: Catherine Ismay, E. D. McGahren 3d
description: Catherine Carns Ismay, the daughter of Capt. and Mrs. Arthur P. Ismay of McLean, Va., was married yesterday to Dr. Eugene D. McGahren 3d, a son of Mr. and Mrs. McGahren Jr. of Yonkers. The Rev. Thomas J. Connellan Jr., a Roman Catholic priest who is the bridegroom's uncle, performed the ceremony at Holy Trinity Church in Washington.

title: Cynthia Bonanni, Simon Hudson
description: Cynthia Diane Bonanni, the daughter of Diane and John Bonanni of Chappaqua, N.Y., was married there yesterday to Simon Mark Hudson, a son of Jacqueline and Reginald Hudson of London. The Rev. John A. Vigilanti performed the ceremony at the Roman Catholic Church of St. John and St. Mary.

title: Muslims Fitting Right In On Island
description: MUSLIMS are the majority in Iran and Jews are a minority. But the reverse is true on Long Island.

title: Nixon Bowled Here, but Owner Looks to the Future
description: Richard M. Nixon still hangs out at Bowlmor Lanes on University Place. In a 1950's-era photograph, Mr. Nixon extends a shiny black bowling ball behind his back, his eyes transfixed by the pins ahead. It is one of many celebrity photos and other bowling memorabilia that fill a glass case opposite the bar at Bowlmor, which, at 59, is Manhattan's oldest bowling alley.

title: Silver Charm Gives Trainer a Photo Worth Framing
description: Silver Charm came out of the West today and outdueled Captain Bodgit by the length of his gray head to win the 123d Kentucky Derby in a photo finish for Bob Baffert, the white-haired trainer who lost the Derby by a nose in a photo finish one year ago.

title: How to Marry a Millionaire
description: MRS. HORNSTIEN

title: It Looks Like a Pub and Acts Like a Pub
description: WE stood three deep at the bar, waiting for a table and asking ourselves why we were here. It was Saturday night at 660 West and the new Garden City restaurant was jumping.

title: Debra Pomerantz, Kenneth Bass
description: Debra Ann Pomerantz was married last evening to Kenneth Alan Bass. Rabbi Morris Friedman performed the ceremony at Temple Emanuel in Kings Point, N.Y.

title: Putting Sewage Where It Belongs
description: To the Editor:

title: Price Wars In Index Funds
description: Fidelity Investments has reduced the annual expenses on two index funds that track the Standard & Poor's 500 to levels just below those charged by the popular Vanguard Index 500.

title: Giants Turn West Upside Down
description: If you examine the roster of the San Francisco Giants, you will not find a host of Cy Young Award winners, batting champions or candidates to break Roger Maris's record 61 home runs in a season.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption on April 20 about silk weaving in Cambodia misstated the location of the Lotus Pond Shop. It is in Phnom Penh, not Kompong Chhnang.

title: How to Find a Style From One Who Lives It
description: GRACE MIRABELLA, former editor in chief of Vogue magazine and founder of Mirabella magazine, says a woman who discovers her own fashion style is giving herself a gift and can do so without a closetful of clothes.

title: Restaurants Roll Out the Carpet for Mom
description: NEXT Sunday, Mother's Day, is the biggest restaurant day of the year. This week, the Island's eating places will be busily trimming and simplifying their menus, bolstering their wait staffs and preparing for the expected onslaught.

title: BEST SELLERS: May 4, 1997
description: Weeks

title: Mailer, Mark, Luke and John
description: THE GOSPEL ACCORDING TO THE SON By Norman Mailer. 242 pp. New York: Random House. $22.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GREENBERG, BERNARD, M.D.
description: GREENBERG-Bernard, M.D. Beloved husband of Bernice. Devoted father of Steven Greenberg, Ph.D. and Judith Greenberg, M.D., and son-in-law, Eugene Berman. Cherished grandfather of Matthew Berman. Service Sunday, 12:30 PM, at ''The Riverside,'' 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue. In lieu of flowers, donations in his memory would be appreciated to Pediatric Intensive Care Unit of Maimonides Hospital.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HARRIS, JONATHAN
description: HARRIS-Jonathan, of Roslyn Heights, NY, on May 1, 1997. Devoted husband of Martha. Loving father of Paul and Seth. Caring father-in-law of Martha and Karen. Dear grandfather of Lydia. Author and retired teacher at Port Washington's Schreiber High School. Private memorial today. Contributions to the YIVO Institute for Jewish Research, 555 W. 57th St., Suite 1100, NY, NY 10102-0583.

title: Scrapping Start to Finish, Richter and the Rangers Get Even
description: When hockey players drop their sticks and gloves, it usually means they are about to fight. Goalies rarely shed this equipment, especially when they are trying to make the most important save of the day.

title: Special-Interest Power
description: To the Editor:

title: Cue From Broadway And Films
description: There are now two Joffrey Ballet companies, each based in a different community. The main group is known as Joffrey Ballet Chicago, after the city that has become its home. But over the years the Joffrey has also sponsored second companies that train young dancers and allow choreographers to prepare new works. Last year, it founded the latest troupe of this type, the Joffrey II Concert Dancers, which has its headquarters at the Joffrey Ballet School in Greenwich Village.

title: Una E. Johnson, 91, An Expert on Prints Who Led a Museum
