description: Una E. Johnson, who built the print collection of the Brooklyn Museum of Art into one of the country's largest and best, died April 28 at St. Vincent's Hospital in Manhattan. She was 91 and lived in Manhattan.

title: Tearful Plea Led to Surrender in West Texas
description: The emotional catalyst to end the siege of the ragtag group that calls itself the Republic of Texas came Friday night, in a few short words spoken through sobs by 29-year-old Julie Hopkins.

title: A Name From the Past On Rent Fights
description: FOUR years ago, Andrew J. Stein abandoned his mayoral bid, ditched his plans to run for re-election as City Council President and promptly sank beneath the waves of New York City politics. Unlike so many former high-ranking city officials -- Edward I. Koch and David N. Dinkins spring to mind -- Mr. Stein did not seek out continued public attention, and it seems fair to say that he did not receive any.

title: Covering Up Crimes
description: A Government official becomes aware that secret information shows corruption and criminality in a Federal agency. He wants to inform Congress, but he is forbidden to do so unless he first gets the approval of the very agency involved. And Congress has no power to change those rules so it can get the facts.

title: Arthur Miller Visits the Sins of the Fathers Upon the Children
description: They're young, in love and as radiantly American looking as anyone who lived on Andy Hardy's block. He's a military hero, she's (literally) the girl next door, and a paradise of postwar prosperity seems to stretch before them.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FELDMAN, MICHAEL
description: FELDMAN-Michael, 82, in Key Biscayne, May 3. Adored husband of 56 years of Grace. Revered father of Judith, Daniel and Richard. Loving father-in-law of Michael, Laurie and Barbara. Beloved grandfather of Nicholas, Jesse, Jaron, David, Jack, Ethan, Eric and Jill. Never one to settle for second best, he led a rich, full live and pushed everyone to their limit. Funeral Wednedsay, May 7, 10:45 AM, Riverside Chapel, 76th and Amsterdam, 362-6600. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the Miami Lighthouse for the Blind, 601 SW 8th Ave., Miami.

title: Maryland Plans Web Sites for Schools
description: On Monday, Maryland will become the first state to seek to have a customized World Wide Web site for each of its school districts.

title: U.S.-Mexico Wrangle: Closeness Breeds Friction
description: A labor leader unintentionally insulted President Ernesto Zedillo during May Day ceremonies here, showing something about how rocky relations are between the United States and its southern neighbor.

title: States Outlaw Late Abortions As a Federal Ban Faces a Veto
description: While Congress tries again to ban what abortion opponents call ''partial-birth abortion,'' several states have outlawed the procedure on their own and numerous others are considering doing so.

title: Glick Joins Borough Race In Manhattan As 5th Entry
description: In an atmosphere similar to an old-fashioned political rally, Deborah J. Glick, an Assemblywoman from Greenwich Village, yesterday became the fifth candidate to officially enter the Democratic primary for Manhattan borough president.

title: TV Debate on Wednesday
description: Democratic voters will be able to get a closer look at all three of the party's three candidates for governor at their first televised debate on Wednesday. State Senator James E. McGreevey of Woodbridge, Representative Robert A. Andrews of Camden County and W. Michael Murphy, a former Morris County prosecutor, will answer questions from a moderator, audience members and each other at a debate sponsored by The Star-Ledger and News 12, a 24-hour cable news channel. The event will be broadcast live starting at 8 P.M. on News 12. There will be at least one more debate, on May 22 on New Jersey Network, before the June 3 primary.

title: Nothing Worth Mining Found on Bre-X Site
description: An independent consulting company has found no sign that there is gold worth mining at the Indonesian site discovered by Bre-X Minerals Ltd. of Canada, which had contended that it had found the gold strike of the century.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GURWIN, ROSALIND
description: GURWIN-Rosalind. Beloved and devoted wife of Joseph. Adored and cherished mother of Laura Flug, Eric Gurwin, mother-in-law of Karen, twin sister of Murray Brizel, loving grandmother of Danielle, Jeffrey, Jason and Jaclyn. Services Tuesday, 12 noon, Temple Beth-El of Great Neck, corner Middle Neck Rd and Old Mill Rd. Contributions can be made in her name to the Gurwin Jewish Geriatric Center, PO Box 9017, Commack, NY 11725, or to the charity of your choice.

title: Metricom Says New Network To Lift Speed Of Its Modems
description: A small company that is a dark horse in the race to offer wireless digital Internet access plans to introduce equipment on Monday that is expected to provide data speeds approaching those of the high-speed access lines known as I.S.D.N. by next year.

title: 'Megan' Trial Is Set to Begin Amid Scrutiny
description: When the jurors file into the old Mercer County Courthouse here on Monday morning for the murder trial of the man accused of killing 7-year-old Megan Kanka, they will be taking their places in one of those rare cases that shape American attitudes. And that is likely to be the biggest challenge for the defense.

title: Turning Rough Takes Into Summer's Big Hits
description: Jan De Bont, the director of ''Speed 2: Cruise Control,'' a mega-budget action sequel due this summer, was at a film lab in Los Angeles at 7 A.M. last Thursday, to review color corrections.

title: Broadcast Lobby Excels at the Washington Power Game
description: Early last month, the broadcast television industry received what critics have said is the kind of ''corporate welfare'' benefit that many television news programs love to expose. Ending a three-year fight, the Government lent the industry, free of charge, new space on public airwaves worth $7 billion to $15 billion, according to Federal estimates.

title: A Remarkable Show
description: To the Editor:

title: Microsoft Took WebTV Risk, Despite Loss
description: Selling out to the Microsoft Corporation, truth be told, is the dream of many a high-technology start-up -- and many new ventures have done just that in recent years.

title: Culture's 2 Personas Face Off In a Shop
description: A small bookstore fights with its landlord, which wants to maximize its profits from a valuable storefront. The bookstore says it cannot pay such high rents and will close. The landlord says sorry, we're not in the business of subsidizing poor booksellers and prepares to rent the bookstore's space to a fancy boutique instead.

title: Including Poland in NATO Is a Weighty Step
description: To the Editor:

title: The Mets' Break-Even Day Comes Unraveled After a Rough Opening
description: Manager Bobby Valentine insisted that a .500 record was no big deal.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FLEISCHMANN, LILLIAN KEISCH
description: FLEISCHMANN-Lillian Keisch. On May 2 at 90. Fondly remembered by her family for her pioneering spirit as an attorney. Prominent in Bronx Women's Bar Association. Survived by sons Robert and David, grandchildren Sharon, Julie, Mark, and Melanie.

title: Schools Merger Possible
description: Tomorrow, residents of the communities of Wood-Ridge and Hasbrouck Heights may take the unusual step of authorizing the two school boards to merge.

title: IN PERFORMANCE: THEATER
description: Dreams of Ginger and Fred

title: Rent Contortions
description: The showdown over rent regulations is coming and most of the chips are on the side of the table controlled by the landlords and the Republicans. Their strategy has been to characterize the beneficiaries of rent control and rent stabilization as a group that consists largely of men and women of means who are abusing the system by clinging to apartments worth far more than they are paying. In other words, pity the poor landlord.

title: Dividend Meetings
description: A partial list for this week.

title: In Bike Ride, a Fatal Heart Attack and Deadly Injury
description: A cyclist participating in the annual Bike New York ride was left brain dead yesterday after hitting his head on the pavement, and another rider died after a heart attack, the police and tour organizers said.

title: F.B.I. Discounts Terror Theories In T.W.A. Blast
description: Stopping just short of ruling out sabotage as the cause of the crash of Trans World Airlines Flight 800, the F.B.I. Director, Louis J. Freeh, said yesterday that the evidence in the case points to a ''catastrophic mechanical failure'' and emphasized the need to draw the criminal inquiry to a close.

title: Simon & Schuster Recalls Books, Easing Muslim Anger
description: After complaints from a Muslim organization, Simon & Schuster moved last week to recall more than 4,000 copies of a children's book that portrayed the prophet Muhammad, founder of Islam, as a man who despised Jews and Christians and took pleasure in beheadings.

title: Kennedy Shaw, Consultant, 68
description: Kennedy Shaw, a consultant on municipal development and the environment, died April 23 at UCSF Medical Center in San Francisco. He was 68 and lived in Guerneville, Calif.

title: ZAIRIAN FOES MEET BUT FAIL TO AGREE ON END TO CRISIS
description: In his first meeting with the rebel leader who is trying to overthrow him, Zaire's President, Mobutu Sese Seko, said today that he would relinquish power but only to a transitional authority that would organize national elections.

title: Landlords Quietly Increased Donations to Fight Rent Law
description: In the five years leading up to the current battle over rent controls, New York City landlords and developers mounted a quiet concerted effort to build their influence in state government through a large increase in campaign contributions, with one of the stated aims being to do away with the rent laws.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CLOSTER, RICHARD REUVEN
description: CLOSTER-Richard Reuven. 46 years old, after a very long and courageous battle with AIDS. Beloved companion of Stephen B. Goldman, devoted father of Jake, loving son of Doris and Bill and brother of Howard. He is deeply loved and admired and will be greatly missed by his family, friends, colleagues in the psychoanalytic community and the many patients he has helped with his wisdom, intuition and humor. Please consider donations to God's Love We Deliver. Funeral services Tuesday, May 6, 11 a.m. at Plaza Memorial Chapel, Amsterdam Avenue at 91st, NYC.

title: Robert A. Beck, 71, Dies; Former Head of Prudential
description: Robert A. Beck, who rose from door-to-door selling to the top position at the Prudential Insurance Company of America, died yesterday at his home in Vero Beach, Fla. Mr. Beck, who also had a home in Rumson, N.J., was 71.

title: Harnisch Spends Day With Mets
description: Pete Harnisch was back in uniform yesterday. It was only for one day, but it was a first step.

title: 'Ring' Fans: Beyond the Libretto
description: Listeners looking for guidance to Wagner's ''Ring of the Nibelung'' last week found their bookstores bulging with suggestions: ''The Perfect Wagnerite'' (Bernard Shaw), ''The Dream of Self-Destruction'' (L. J. Rather), ''The Rhine as Musical Metaphor'' (Cecelia Hopkins Porter), ''Richard Wagner and the Anti-Semitic Imagination'' (Max A. Weiner), ''I Saw the World End'' (Deryck Cooke), ''Wagner's 'Ring' and its Symbols'' (Robert Donington), ''Aspects of Wagner'' (Bryan Magee).

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROTH, IDA E. (POSEN)
description: ROTH-Ida E. (Posen). Jamaica, NY, April 28, 1997 after 102-2/3 years dedicated to her late husband David, two children, five grandchildren, their spouses, six great grandchildren; her strong work ethic, education, public service and Hadassah. ''A fantastic lady.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RACKMAN, RUTH
description: RACKMAN-Ruth. We extend our Kos Tanchumim to Rabbi Emanuel Rackman, Michael and Honey Rackman, Bennet and Ruth Rackman and Joseph and Elian Rackman, upon the loss of his beloved wife and their cherished mother and mother-in-law. May the family have loving memories of a wonderful wife and mother and may they be comforted amongst the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. American Committee for Shaare Zedek Medical Center in Jerusalem Charles H. Bendheim, President Erica Jesselson, Chairperson of the Board

title: Merger Plan to Form an Italian Apparel Giant Is Called Off
description: A merger that would have united some holdings of two of Italy's most prominent families, the Marzottos and the Agnellis, and created one of the world's largest clothing conglomerates, has been called off.

title: Plight of Four Polish Immigrants Comes to Light After a Fatal Fire
description: Jan Kamieniec moved into the house in Maspeth, Queens, because the price was right: $250 a month for a room and kitchen privileges in someone else's third-floor apartment.

title: 5 Homers, 19 Hits: The Kind of Yankee Day Even Rogers Can't Give Back
description: The Yankees were thrilled by Tino Martinez's two homers, by additional long balls from Bernie Williams, Cecil Fielder and Jorge Posada, by a dominating relief outing from Brian Boehringer and by their 13-5 trashing of the Kansas City Royals today. Absolutely thrilled.

title: Paralyzed Since Fall in 1962, Man Is Still Seeking Benefits
description: As Bob Manning descended a utility pole near the St. Lawrence Seaway one cold February afternoon, a jolt of electricity sent him flying. The novice lineman, a young father with a pregnant wife, hit the pavement head first.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COHEN, BLANCHE
description: COHEN-Blanche. On May 3, 1997. Beloved wife of the late Charles Tully. Cherished mother of Marcia Singer and Harvey Cohen. Loving grandmother and great-grandmother. She was the ultimate mother. Services Tuesday, 11 AM, at ''The Riverside,'' 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: A Troubling Audit for Harlem
description: The Pataki administration has released a damning audit of the Harlem Urban Development Corporation, which was supposed to spur new enterprises and renovations in Harlem but instead spent more than $100 million in New York State money with little to show for it. The audit charges lax bookkeeping and millions of dollars of wasteful, undocumented spending that should give the State Commission of Investigation plenty to delve into. Gov. George Pataki dissolved the agency two years ago and created a successor controlled by the state.

title: CHRONICLE
description: ''Me Tarzan, you Jane?''

title: Backers of Balanced Budget Plan Take Their Bipartisan Case to TV Viewers
description: White House officials and Republican leaders took to the airwaves today trying to sell their balanced budget deal, confidently predicting that the plan would be approved by Congress with a majority of Republicans and Democrats supporting it.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BEATTY, ANN LEAHY
description: BEATTY-Ann Leahy. On May 3, 1997. Elementary school teacher in New York City school system for many years. Beloved aunt of Mary S. Hammel, Leonard L. Sutter, Virginia S. Gregory, Richard P. Sutter, Ann S. Carville, David J. Sutter, Robert G. Sutter and James F. Sutter. Cherished grandaunt and great-grand-aunt of many nieces and nephews. Family will receive friends at John J. Fox & Sons, Inc., 201st Street and Grand Concourse, Bronx, Tuesday, 2-4 and 7-9 PM. Mass of Christian Burial St. Philip Neri Church, 11 AM, Wednesday. Interment Calvary Cemetery.

title: IN PERFORMANCE: DANCE
description: A Friend's Disappearance

title: No Joe Camel? Here is an imagined world if Big Tobacco is faced with new Federal Regulations
description: Negotiations between the tobacco industry and the Government could mean tighter regulation of cigarette advertising, include banning the use of people and cartoon characters in ads.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   L.A.P.
description: L.A.P. Feb 4th, 1944-May 5, 1991 ''Whatever we were to each other that we are still.''

title: Helping Gretzky Shake His Shadow
description: Unlike Peter Pan, Wayne Gretzky badly wanted to lose his shadow. He never did get away from Doug Gilmour in Game 1 of this rancorous playoff series between the Rangers and the Devils, and it cost him. But today he got a little help from his friend Mark Messier, and in the moment that Messier helped Gretzky lose Gilmour, Gilmour's team lost the game.

title: Gerald Freund, 66, Philanthropies Administrator
description: Gerald Freund, a veteran foundation administrator who was the first director of the MacArthur Foundation's Prize Fellows Program, giving large awards that became known unofficially and perhaps enviously as ''genius grants,'' died yesterday in his home on the Upper East Side of Manhattan. He was 66 and also had a home in Wilton, Conn.

title: Scam Is Up as Study Finds No Gold Mine
description: An independent consultant has found that a location in the Indonesian jungle said to have been the site of the gold strike of the century appeared to contain no gold worth mining.

title: Seeing Bodies Within Changed Worlds Without
description: NAKED TO THE BONE

title: New Law on Church Arson Leads to 2 Convictions
description: Two white men on Friday became the first defendants in Texas to be convicted under a new Federal law that was written to combat the burning of black churches.

title: In Ticketmaster vs. Microsoft, it's tough to know whom to root for.
description: IT was practically oozing from the complaint filed in Federal court in Los Angeles last Wednesday -- the sense that if two corporate empire builders ever deserved each other in the first big legal dispute over cyberspace commerce, they are Bill Gates and Fredric D. Rosen.

title: Justice on Trial in Denver
description: Two years after the deadliest terrorist act ever committed on American soil, the trial of the Oklahoma City bombing case is just now getting under way in a packed Federal courthouse in Denver. It is too early to predict whether Timothy McVeigh's defense lawyer, Stephen Jones, will be able to puncture the prosecution's largely circumstantial case sufficiently to establish reasonable doubt and win an acquittal. But the incriminating accounts presented by key prosecution witnesses in testimony last week suggest that Mr. Jones does not have an easy task.

title: O'Neal Has Rough Time With Jazz and Referees
description: Three sumo wrestlers took care of Shaquille O'Neal today, and then three referees finished the job.

title: Market Closed in Japan
description: The stock market was closed here today in observance of a national holiday, Children's Day. On Friday, the benchmark Nikkei index of 225 issues rose 239.42 points, or nearly 1.25 percent, to 19,514.75.

title: Cordiant Names Outsider to Lead Saatchi Unit
description: Just two weeks after the British-based advertising giant Cordiant P.L.C. announced that it would dismantle itself, the agency said Friday that it had named an outside marketing executive to take over the reins of its Saatchi & Saatchi Advertising Worldwide unit.

title: TV Makeover in Romania: It's Not Just Cosmetic
description: On Anca Toada's first day back at her former television station, she received what in the old days would have been a routine though unwelcome telephone call. The parliamentary protocol officer demanded that the nightly news remind legislators to show up for the next day's session.

title: Ex-Nurse Sues Over Abortions
description: A former nurse at Hackensack University Medical Center is suing the hospital, saying she was fired for refusing to help perform abortions, The Associated Press has reported. A lawyer for Constance A. DeJoseph of Hillsdale, a former administrative head nurse of the Maternal Fetal Medicine Unit, said she had informed her employer when she was hired about her religious objections to abortion and had been told she would not have to assist in them. But the hospital changed Ms. DeJoseph's duties, then dismissed her in October when she refused to participate in abortions, the lawyer, Lisa Barre-Quick, said.

title: Dignity for Holocaust Victims
description: My mother, Dr. Hadassah Bimko Rosensaft, has been honored as a heroine of the Holocaust. At Auschwitz, she risked her life to save hundreds of women from the gas chambers. And at Bergen-Belsen, from December 1944 until the camp's liberation by British troops in April 1945, she organized efforts to keep 149 orphaned children alive during epidemics of typhus, typhoid fever, diphtheria and other diseases that killed tens of thousands of inmates.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MANDEL, ELEANOR
description: MANDEL-Eleanor. On May 1, 1997. Devoted mother of only child Daniel, and dynamic partner in the firm of Dufour, Limited. Her presence will be missed by all who knew and loved her. Private services were held for family members on Saturday, May 3. Plans for a memorial service will be announced at a later date.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-8

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SEYMOUR, SONYA
description: SEYMOUR-Sonya. May 3, 1997, in her 90th year. Beloved wife of the late Walton Seymour. A lifetime of service in social work. Survived by her sister Paula Ariel, nephews and nieces, and Martha and Charles Seymour.

title: Dance Magazine Awards
description: Claude Bessy, director of the Paris Opera Ballet School; Anna-Marie Holmes and Bruce Marks, directors of the Boston Ballet, and Dudley Williams, of the Alvin Ailey Dance Company, will receive the 1997 Dance Magazine Awards today in a private ceremony at Asia Society. Hernando Cortez and Dancers Responding to AIDS will receive a citation. Violette Verdy will be master of ceremonies. The awards, established in 1954, are given for contributions to dance.

title: Bridge
description: Bridge is now recognized by the International Olympic Committee, but there is little prospect of its inclusion in the Olympic Games. But it will be included in a competition that is smaller than the Olympics in one way but bigger in another: the second World Scholar-Athlete Games, June 22 to July 2 in Newport, R.I.

title: MetroStars Miss Chances and Settle for Shootout Victory
description: The MetroStars got what they deserved for today's performance.

title: Microsoft to Help Train Computer Workers
description: On another front, Microsoft over the weekend introduced a program to recruit and train computer and software professionals, saying 190,000 American jobs were unfilled for a lack of trained applicants.

title: Defending Tree Commissions
description: Nearly a third of New Jersey's 167 municipal shade-tree commissions -- volunteer groups that oversee the planting and maintenance of trees along sidewalks and in parks -- have disbanded during the 1990's because of fears of lawsuits prompted by falling limbs or protruding roots, state officials said. To help stop the trend, the state's Community Forestry Council has started drawing up standards that shade-tree commissions may use to review towns' shade-tree plans and to train commission members. A town with an approved plan and trained shade-tree commissioners has an extra layer of protection against lawsuits, G. Lester Alpaugh, the state forester, said yesterday. ANDY NEWMAN

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: GOLF

title: O'Connor Is to Address Rent-Stabilization Issue
description: John Cardinal O'Connor said yesterday that sometime this week he planned to address the issue of rent stabilization from ''a moral perspective,'' though he would not say yet how he would come down on the debate.

title: Report Says H.M.O.'s Treat Women Unfairly
description: Women who belong to local health maintenance organizations have 68 percent more out-of-pocket expenses than men because things like contraceptives and screenings for osteoporosis are not covered in most managed care networks, according to a report released yesterday by Representative Charles E. Schumer.

title: Spanish Martyr Is First Gypsy Beatified by Catholic Church
description: Not all of the Gypsies who arrived in caravans this weekend at the Fabulous Camping trailer park on the outskirts of Rome had a very clear idea of who Ceferino Jimenez Malla was.

title: Toiling Through the Drab, Oily Dregs
description: Maybe it was mere coincidence.

title: Killings Bring 2 Bills
description: The murders of two pizza deliverymen in Sussex County last month have spurred new bills by Federal and state lawmakers.

title: Factions Weigh In on Hong Kong Under Chinese Rule
description: There must be a reason so many of the World Wide Web sites about Hong Kong open with a scene of that city's skyline.

title: Mega-Merger In Italy Dies As Marzotto Withdraws
description: ROME  In a development that could mark a shift in Italian capitalism and the erosion of power of Italy's leading financial player, the Marzotto clothing group has abruptly pulled out of a merger that would have created a $5 billion-a-year European fashion powerhouse.

title: The Issue of Europe Haunts the Stunned Tories
description: Britain's Conservatives, in power so long that they had come to think of themselves as the natural party of government, have suddenly found themselves in the political wilderness -- with no leader, no consensus, no presence in large parts of the nation and drastically reduced representation in Parliament.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: WEEKEND

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MAHER, EILEEN GILMORE
description: MAHER-Eileen Gilmore. On May 2, 1997. Beloved wife of the late Robert D. Beloved sister of Kathleen E. Gilmore, Georgette M. Gilmore, Lillian G. Larson and the late Sally M. Driscoll. Cherished aunt of Robert and Julie Larson, Bruce and Alice Larson and grand-aunt of Robert Sean and Lauren Ann. Also survived by her sister-in-law Eileen Anne Maher. Devoted godmother of six. Friends may call at the Andrett Funeral Home, 353 2nd Ave (at 20th St), NYC, Monday and Tuesday, 2-5 and 7-9 PM. Mass of Christian Burial Wednesday, 10 AM, at Epiphany R.C. Church. Interment Gate of Heaven Cemetery.

title: Wave goodbye to the Bundys, blue-collar champions of the Fox network.
description: NOW that the geyser of publicity surrounding ''Ellen'' has finally subsided, television viewers can turn their attention to a milestone of a different sort: the final episode of ''Married . . . With Children,'' which will be shown at 9 tonight on the Fox network.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KELLEY, FLORENCE M.
description: KELLEY-Florence M. Prominent retired New York City Judge. May 3, 1997, age 85. Of Little Compton, RI, formerly Manhattan, New York City, NY. Wife of David S. Worgan, retired Executive Assistant D.A. of New York County. Sister of Augustus M. Kelley and Nicholas Kelley, Jr. Her funeral services and burial will be private. Memorial contributions may be sent to the Little Compton Nursing Association, P.O. Box 545, Little Compton, RI 02837. For information, contact the 'Cherry Place' Home of Waring-Ashton and Coughlin - D.D. Sullivan - Driscoll, Fall River, MA, 508-676-1933.

title: On Saving Electricity
description: To the Editor:

title: 'Sleeping Beauty' as a Spectacle of Individuality
description: As a dazzling spectacle for children and adults, Peter Martins's staging of ''The Sleeping Beauty'' for the New York City Ballet is not to be missed. It is also a lesson in interpretation.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TANEY, JOHN CHARLES II
description: TANEY-John Charles II, on May 3. Beloved husband of Amie, beloved father of eight children, grandfather of eight and greatgrandfather of one. Funeral Mass will be held on Wednesday, May 7, at 10 AM, at Holy Family Chapel at the College of New Rochelle. The family will receive friends at the George T. Davis Funeral Home, New Rochelle, on Monday and Tuesday evenings from 7 to 9 PM; on Tuesday afternoon from 1 to 4 PM. In lieu of flowers, donations may be sent to Food for the Poor, 550 SW 12th Avenue, #

title: Phone Company to Move
description: Midcom Communications Inc., a provider of long-distance telephone service, said last week that it would move its headquarters to Southfield, Mich., from Seattle by this fall. The move will affect about 130 employees.

title: Offerings of Equity and Debt That Are Expected This Week
description: The following equity and convertible debt offerings are expected this week:

title: F.D.R.'s Legacy of Hard-Won Goals Helps the Disabled Achieve
description: To the Editor:

title: Antsy Knick Coach Ready for Miami
description: Jeff Van Gundy is glad the wait is almost over, but now he must deal with the hype. The Knicks coach would probably much rather watch Miami and New York trade baskets and forearms today than endure another question about what it was like to work under the great and omniscient Pat Riley.

title: Dudley Pope, 71; Wrote Novels of the High Seas
description: Dudley Pope, a British author of a series of historical novels about a Royal Navy lieutenant named Ramage and of books of naval history, died on April 25 in Marigot, St. Martin, in the French West Indies. He was 71 and lived on St. Martin.

title: INSIDE METRO
description: BIKE TOUR ACCIDENT A bike rider was left brain dead after an accident at the annual Bike New York ride. B3.

title: Deep Blue Gently Shows It Has Developed a Nose for Nuances
description: Once again, Garry Kasparov set out to play a quiet, positional game yesterday against the I.B.M. chess computer Deep Blue, but this time the machine matched him in sophisticated judgment and beat him soundly. On Saturday, Deep Blue had forced Kasparov to give up his strategic approach, only to be defeated at the end when the world champion put on a scintillating display of human tactical brilliance.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  LEE, NITA (ABRAHAMS)
description: LEE-Nita (Abrahams). Our darling Nita. You remain an everlasting inspiration to all of us who adore you and carry you in our hearts. Her loving family.

title: Using the World Wide Web to Enhance Music Compact Disks
description: It was an idea whose time never really came. But the music industry wants to keep trying.

title: Physics May Hold Key to Measuring Mind
description: To the Editor:

title: Jacob M. Snyder, 80; Aided Jewish Causes
description: Jacob M. Snyder, an advocate of Israeli and Jewish causes and a former administrator of the Board of Jewish Education of Greater New York, died on April 22 at New York University Medical Center.

title: 'Ellen' Opened Our Eyes to Gay Humanity
description: To the Editor:

title: Two Sides in Unabom Case Bring Out Pretrial Strategies
description: The trial of Theodore J. Kaczynski, the man accused of being the Unabomber, is still at least six months away, but his lawyers are already filing technical pretrial motions intended to test defense tactics and probe for weakness in the prosecution's case.

title: Wanted: Photo Op
description: To the Editor:

title: For Silver Charm, Days of Glory Before the Preakness
description: They started humming softly, then the song grew louder and evolved into a yell. As Silver Charm was led from Stall 28 in Barn 33 at Churchill Downs this morning, the trainer Bob Baffert and a few friends started humming the theme from ''Rocky.'' And then they all started laughing.

title: Creating Respect
description: To the Editor:

title: Partnership
description: To the Editor:

title: Physics May Hold Key to Measuring Mind
description: To the Editor:

title: A company says it has a method of determining which people are more likely to get skin cancer.
description: The end of this century may go down as the era in which science began mass-marketing genetic tests to determine whether people are predisposed to cancers, degenerative conditions and disease.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MAGID, HERBERT

title: No Headline
description: ''We need to get a conclusion. We have to get some closure as to this case. But the evidence is certainly not moving in the direction of a terrorist act. It is, in fact, moving in the other direction.''

title: The Prime Movers Behind Landlord PAC's
description: The main political action committees involving landlords, the Rent Stabilization Association PAC and the Neighborhood Preservation Political Action Fund, favor Republicans heavily at the state level.

title: CHRONICLE
description: Today, at 9:30 in the morning at Public School 175 in Rego Park, Queens, the 300 students from the third, fourth and fifth grades won't be doing their regular classwork. Instead, they will be sitting at a concert, where MIDORI, the 25-year-old violinist, and her pianist, TOM SAUER, are to play music ranging from Rimsky-Korsakov's ''The Flight of the Bumblebee'' to Aaron Copland's ''Hoe-Down'' from ''Rodeo.''

title: Compaq Plans A Big Change In Its PC Sales
description: The personal computer industry, never known for its stability, is about to enter a new period of upheaval that could mean lower prices and a shakeout of weaker competitors.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WALSH, CORNELIUS STEPHEN
description: WALSH-Cornelius Stephen. Mr. Walsh, 89 years old, of Palm Beach, Florida, died Friday May 2, 1997, at Good Samaritan Medical Center in West Palm Beach. Born in New York City, he was a long time resident of Palm Beach, New York and Spring Lake, NJ. Mr. Walsh was a Founder of States Marine Corp., which was begun in 1931 and which operated in the Merchant Marine Service that supported our troops during World War II. From 1946 to 1965 he served as President and Director of States Marine Lines which owned and operated more than 100 vessels in service throughout the world from Atlantic, Gulf and Pacific ports under the States Marine flag or those of affiliated concerns. Retiring after 35 years of service with States Marine Lines, Mr. Walsh purchased Waterman Steamship Co. of Mobile, AL. Mr. Walsh served as Chairman of the Board of Waterman Steamship and Waterman Industries from 1965 to 1989 and was Chairman of Hammond Leasing Corp. from 1967-1990. He served as Chairman of the Board of Waterman Lijnen, Rotterdam, Netherlands; Waterman Linen of Bremen, Germany. Mr. Walsh was also an Honorary Director of the Japan Society, New York City, NY, and served as Director of the Far East American Council of Commerce and Industry. He was a member of the syndicate which built the 12 Meter Yacht ''Weatherly,'' which successfully defended the America's Cup in 1962. Mr. Walsh held memberships in the American Bureau of Shipping, New York City, NY; the Society of Naval Architects and Marine Engineers, also of New York City, NY; The Metropolitan Opera of New York; Sewanaka-Corinthian Yacht Club in Oyster Bay, NY; The Pine Valley Golf Club of Clementon, NJ. Other memberships included: The Society of the Four Arts, The Bath and Tennis Club, The Everglades Club and the Palm Beach Civic Association, all of Palm Beach, FL. Mr. Walsh was a long-time member of St. Edward's Catholic Church in Palm Beach, FL. Survivors include his son: Richard S. Walsh of Millbrook, NY; two daughters: Jane W. Weed of Puerta Vallarta, Jalisco, Mexico and Greenwich, CT, and Suzanne P. White of Bryn Mawr, PA. Also surviving are five grandchildren and five greatgrandchildren. Additional survivors include a sister: Frances Moore of Yorktown Heights, NY, and a brother: Edward P. Walsh of New York City, NY. Friends may call at Quattlebaum-HollemanBurse Funeral Home, 1201 South Olive Avenue, West Palm Beach, FL, on Wednesday, May 7, 1997, from 10:00 until 11:30 AM. Private services will be held at 12 Noon. In lieu of flowers, those who wish may make contributions to Good Samaritan Medical Center, 1309 North Flagler Drive, West Palm Beach, FL 33401. A memorial service will be held in New York City at a future date.

title: Playing With His Best Friend, A Sixth Grader Is Fatally Shot
description: A 13-year-old Brooklyn boy was shot and killed Saturday night as he and his friends played with a gun, the police said, and yesterday detectives were trying to determine how the shooting occurred.

title: TV Networks Believe It Pays to Advertise
description: NBC News and ABC News are waging a little advertising war. A week or so ago, for example, NBC promised that Tom Brokaw himself would be covering the Oklahoma City bombing trial, live from Denver. Countless viewers must have tuned in to discover what the anchorman could do there that mere reporters could not do, given that the judge had ordered all parties not to confide anything of consequence to the press.

title: Arena Football Season Opens
description: Madison Square Garden's venture into Arena Football begins tonight when the New York CityHawks play host to the Orlando Predators at 7:30.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KAUFMAN, SAMUEL
description: KAUFMAN-Samuel. On May 4. Loving husband of Dorothy, cherished father of Elisa, Sonya, Neil and Stephen. Adored grandfather of Erica, Lauren, and Daniel. Services private. For information call Plaza Memorial Chapel, 212769-4400

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  BALANCHINE, GEORGE
description: BALANCHINE-George. A memorial service in memory of George Balanchine will be held on Monday, May 5, 7:30 PM, at The Cathedral of Our Lady of the Sign, 75 East 93rd Street, New York.

title: One Jet in Crash Over India Ruled Off Course
description: Investigators studying the world's deadliest midair collision have established that the crash near here last November occurred after a Kazakstan Airlines Ilyushin-76 descended nearly 1,000 feet below the 15,000-feet altitude assigned to it by Indian air traffic controllers, putting it in the path of a Boeing 747 of Saudi Arabian Airlines that had taken off minutes earlier from New Delhi. When the planes collided, 349 people were killed.

title: Lobstermen See Threat in Whale Protection Plan
description: Federal fishing authorities have thrown Maine's lobster industry into an uproar by proposing costly changes in lobster traps to insure that whales can easily escape if they become entangled in the ropes.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ZAX, HARRY
description: ZAX-Harry. Of Paterson, NJ, on Saturday, May 3, 1997. Beloved husband of Shirley (nee Hollander) Zax. Devoted and loving father of Leonard A. Zax and his wife Helen, of Washington, DC. Cherished grandfather of David and Laura Zax. Brother of Helen Butler and Shirley Dinerman of NY. Services 1 PM, Monday, at Louis Suburban Chapel, 13-01 Broadway (Route 4 West), Fair Lawn, NJ. Contributions in his memory may be made to the National Building Museum in Washington, DC.

title: The Other Hardaway Insures a Heat-Knicks Series
description: It was no surprise that a player named Hardaway was a hero. However, today it was Tim Hardaway. And because he met the challenge, the Heat will meet the Knicks.

title: A Streak That Shouldn't Have Continued
description: The 123d Kentucky Derby proved to be the most orderly in recent memory, and maybe in recent history. It was run almost strictly according to form, unlike the chaotic free-for-alls of years past. The first five across the line were expected to be there, and the eight who trailed them were expected to trail them, except for the small Irish-bred colt Hello, fifth in the odds but eighth in the race.

title: House Owner Defended Illegal Housing
description: Nearly eight months before a fire engulfed 60-01 56th Road in Maspeth, Queens, and Frank Glowacki died in its illegally renovated cellar, he stood in front of the house defending illegal conversions.

title: Economic Calendar
description: Expected dates for the release of major economic indicators this week.

title: William Lewers, 69, Notre Dame Trustee
description: The Rev. William M. Lewers, a trustee and professor of law at the University of Notre Dame, died on April 19 at Holy Cross House in Notre Dame, Ind. He was 69.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ZULLER, PHILIP A.
description: ZULLER-Philip A. On Saturday, May 3, 1997. Beloved husband of Esther (nee Ditkowsky). Devoted father of Phyllis and Rabbi Phillip Goldman, Helene and Fred Zauder and Joel and Eva Zuller. Cherished grandfather and greatgrandfather. He served as a Licensed Public Accountant for over 60 years and he was loved by all who knew him. Active in the Young Israel movement, Kingsway Jewish Center and supporter of many charitable causes. Burial was on Sunday, May 4, 1997 at Montefiore Cemetery. Shiva period will be observed at 1546 East 31st Street, Brooklyn, N.Y. until Friday, May 9, 1997.

title: Letters From a Chinese Jail
description: For nearly 20 years, the Chinese Government has sought to silence one of the world's most important political prisoners, Wei Jingsheng. Once an electrician in the Beijing Zoo, Mr. Wei is the strongest voice of China's democracy movement. He has spent all but six months of the last 18 years in prisons and labor camps, most in solitary confinement in conditions that would have killed a less stubborn man long ago and may soon kill Mr. Wei, who is 46 and very ill.

title: Treasury's Scheduled Auctions Include 3- and 10-Year Notes
description: The Treasury's schedule of financing this week includes today's regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills and auctions of 3-year and 10-year notes Tuesday and Wednesday.

title: Cannes Festival Is Turning a Very Lively 50
description: It takes special talent to idolize glamour and money and still appear intellectual, yet this peculiarly French gift may well explain the perennial success of the Cannes International Film Festival. Year in, year out, paparazzi-driven exhibitionism and frantic deal making invade the balmy Cote d'Azur resort, yet the festival's arty image somehow prevails.

title: Celebration Begins For City's Charter
description: To start the 20-month centennial celebration of the consolidation of New York City's five boroughs, a small group gathered yesterday at the Museum of the City of New York to laud -- and playfully lament -- the three-inch-thick Charter of Greater New York. The charter, which was signed into law in May of 1897 by Governor Frank S. Black, redefined the city to include not only Manhattan and the Bronx, but also the other three boroughs.

title: All About Maggie
description: There are only two facts to keep in mind about the British election: The winner was Margaret Thatcher. The loser was Margaret Thatcher. Everything else is just commentary.

title: Son a Passenger in Crashes
description: A car driven by a man who had his 8-year-old son with him hit two police cars and a police officer Saturday night, the Newark police said yesterday. The police said the driver, Walter Harris of Newark, hit a police cruiser after running a stop sign, then fled. Several miles later, the police said, the 1996 Nissan Mr. Harris was driving struck another police car that was trying to pull him over, then stalled. As Officer Ronald Polhill approached the car on foot, Mr. Harris started it up and ran into Officer Polhill, causing bruises but no serious injuries, Sgt. Anthony Ambrose said. When another officer approached the car with his gun drawn, he noticed the boy in the car. Mr. Harris, 28, was charged with aggravated assault.

title: For Black Scholars Wedded to Prism of Race, New and Separate Goals
description: Taunya Lovell Banks, a law professor at the University of Maryland, was traveling by train to Baltimore a few years ago when a man exposed himself to her and then ran into the next car.

title: Conde Nast Makes High-Level Changes At Two Magazines
description: In a late-game lineup change, the publisher of Conde Nast Sports for Women, Deanna Brown, was replaced last week by Suzanne Grimes, the publisher of TV Guide.

title: Computer Defeats Kasparov, Stunning the Chess Experts
description: Responding to defeat with the pride and tenacity of a champion, the I.B.M. computer Deep Blue drew even yesterday in its match against Garry Kasparov, the world's best human chess player, winning the second of their six games and stunning many chess experts with its strategy.

title: Acceptable Affection
description: To the Editor:

title: As Digital TV Arrives, Cable's Picture May Not Be So Clear
description: While the broadcast television networks are busily buying equipment so they can begin offering crystal clear, digital high-definition programs starting next year, the nation's cable operators are going in the opposite direction.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Test of Bre-X Gold Site Finds Nothing to Mine

title: Corrections
description: An obituary on Wednesday about Norman J. Kelman, a New York psychoanalyst, misstated the date of his death and misspelled the surname of his first wife. Dr. Kelman died on April 20th; his former wife was Catherine Sugarman.

description: The Devils' special teams, so efficient in the elimination of Montreal and the shutout victory in the opening game of the series with the Rangers, were inept this afternoon, costing New Jersey dearly.

title: Progress and Provision
description: To the Editor:

title: 2 ADVISERS KNEW OF HUBBELL PLIGHT
description: The White House has maintained that President and Mrs. Clinton did not know that Webster L. Hubbell faced possible criminal charges when their close associates started organizing a string of business contacts to help support him in the spring of 1994.

title: INSIDE
description: Clinton's Mexico Trip

title: Richter's Biggest Save Over in Shutout City
description: BEFORE these Rangers-Devils theatrics began, Mike Richter created what might have been an embarrassing story line when he was asked if he knew what New Jersey town the Devils' arena was in.

title: To Win Half the Time Has Become a Noble Goal
description: Major League Baseball, making a parody of parity, saw 11 of its 28 teams, including the Mets and the Yankees, enter play yesterday residing in the vicinity of .500.

title: Researchers on Complexity Ponder What It's All About
description: IT is a tribute to the power and precision of science that it was able to predict so far in advance that on April 1, Comet Hale-Bopp would make its closest rendezvous with the Sun. But what science could not reliably say was whether, in any particular part of the country, clouds would congeal to block the view -- a cosmic April Fool's joke.

title: The Luster And Power Of Spring
description: The series of three Lincoln Center concerts by the Los Angeles Philharmonic that concluded on Sunday, all of them with their conductor Esa-Pekka Salonen, were stunning. The orchestra sounded disciplined and thoroughly prepared: the long, even crescendos and the tempo shifts they provided in Bruckner's Fourth Symphony would have been impossible otherwise. But there was also eagerness and pleasure in the music making, a sense of occasion.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  UNGAR, NICHOLAS
description: UNGAR-Nicholas. On May 3, 1997. Beloved husband of Zsofi. He is survived by his sisters-in-laws, nieces, nephews and his devoted help.

title: WAINOCO TO SELL NUMAC CANADIAN ASSETS FOR $96 MILLION
description: The Wainoco Oil Corporation said yesterday that it would sell its Canadian oil and gas interests to Numac Energy Inc. for about $96 million. Numac, based in Calgary, Alberta, will keep many of Wainoco's Canadian employees in Calgary and in three field offices. Wainoco, which is based in Houston, said it would use the proceeds from the transaction to repay debt. Wainoco said it would focus on refining and selling petroleum products, building on its existing operations in Denver and Cheyenne, Wyo.

Respected and admired by all who knew her. Services at ''Gutterman-Musicant,'', Hackensack, NJ. Tuesday, 12 Noon. Dear Annie-we will love you forever.

title: For Exchanges North of Border, A Fresh Fraud
description: The Bre-X Minerals fraud, in which a gold find said to be worth billions of dollars turned out to have no gold worth mining, may turn out to be the most costly stock market fraud ever. But in one respect, it was a case of deja vu. Once again, American investors had lost big by purchasing Canadian stocks.

title: A Newark Group Says It Lost Aid Because It Opposed a Ball Park
description: Officials of a Newark community organization that has fought city and county plans to build a minor league baseball stadium at a park in their East Ward neighborhood charged today that their opposition has cost them county financing for two programs they have run for 19 years without complaints.

title: Thomas Took Orders a Step Too Far
description: Steve Thomas of the Devils admitted to doing nothing other than following the orders of his coach, which were to skate hard to the net.

title: Mount Everest Has Only One Kind of Luck: Bad
description: INTO THIN AIR

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KWASHA, H. CHARLES. (CHICK)
description: KWASHA-H. Charles. (Chick). Age 90. Of North Miami, FL. Born in Providence, R.I. December 2, 1906. Passed peacefully on May 4, 1997. Graduated Magna Cum Laude, Sigma Psiand Phi Beta Kappa from Brown University in 1928. Founded the Kwasha-Lipton Company, a pre-eminent actuarial consulting firm, in 1944. His company has provided actuarial services to many Fortune 500 corporations for more than fifty years and was recently purchased by Coopers and Lybrand. He contributed to many charities in his lifetime, among which are Brown University, The Alzheimer's Foundation, Boys Town of Jerusalem and Juvenile Diabetes. Survived by his wife Sylvia H. Kwasha, his children Linda D. Kwasha, Bruce C. Kwasha and Robert D. Kwasha and his seven grandchildren. Funeral service to be held graveside at Mount Nebo Memorial Gardens, 5505 N.W. 3rd St, Miami, Wednesday, 2:45pm. In lieu of flowers, the family requests donations be made to the Diabetes Research Institute Foundation.

title: Dangerous Decline Reported in South American Flamingos
description: FOR the first time, biologists from four South American countries have done a simultaneous census of the high-altitude lakes where two little-known flamingo species live year-round. Their reports confirm fears of a precipitous decline in one species, the Andean flamingo, over the last 25 years.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: CARSON INC., Savannah, Ga., a maker of hair-care products, acquired the Cutex nail-care product line from the Unilever N.V. unit Chesebrough-Pond's USA Co. for exclusive use in the United States and Puerto Rico, in a deal valued at $41 million.

title: CNBC Shakes Up Schedule to Compete Better With CNN
description: CNBC, the business news cable channel owned by NBC, will shake up its prime-time schedule in an effort to program more aggressively against the Time Warner's Cable News Network and to raise the profile of a rising NBC news star.

title: New Liaison With the U.N. Leaves His Job After a Week
description: One week after City Hall's liaison to the diplomatic community stepped down under fire, the man named to replace her announced yesterday that he too was leaving the post.

title: Q & A
description: Flood Stage

title: NEWMONT ACQUISITION OF SANTA FE PACIFIC GOLD APPROVED
description: Shareholders of the Newmont Mining Corporation of Denver and its operating unit, the Newmont Gold Company, yesterday approved the acquisition of the Santa Fe Pacific Gold Corporation of Albuquerque, N.M., for $2.06 billion in stock, creating the largest gold producer in North America. In a separate vote in Albuquerque, Santa Fe Pacific Gold shareholders also accepted the offer to exchange one Santa Fe share for 0.43 of a Newmont share. Newmont shares gained 25 cents yesterday, to $36.50; Santa Fe shares closed unchanged at $15.50 apiece. Santa Fe has 131.22 million shares outstanding. Falling gold prices have eroded the value of the transaction about 16 percent since the two companies agreed on March 10 to merge.

title: Questing Spirit, Well Met
description: Charles Ives and Duke Ellington prove good, congenial company for John Adams in Composer Week at the New York Philharmonic. Mr. Adams's questing, innovative spirit and jazzy, populist bent are both well demonstrated here, in ''Slonimsky's Earbox,'' of 1996, and the Violin Concerto, of 1994.

title: New Labor Finds Itself Lionized
description: The Queen noted the presence of the seeing-eye dog of David Blunkett, the new Education Secretary, and wondered out loud if it wasn't a first in tradition-minded Britain, a dog attending the Buckingham Palace swearing-in of a Cabinet.

title: Close Votes in N.R.A. Elections Quash Hope for Internal Unity
description: At a fractious board meeting here, the strife-torn National Rifle Association today narrowly turned back an internal challenge that had threatened to paralyze it and then elevated one of its most prominent spokesmen, Charlton Heston, the actor, to one of its highest posts.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BORNEMANN, HELLEN
description: BORNEMANN-Hellen. The people of Saint Peter's Lutheran Church are deeply saddened by the untimely death of our beloved friend and co-worker Hellen Bornemann this past Thursday morning, May 1. Hellen is survived by her son, Paul, her daughter-in-law, Heather, her grandsons, Zachary and Alexander, and of course, the family of Saint Peter's. A Memorial Eucharist and Inurnment in thanksgiving for Hellen's life and gifts will be held on Saturday, May 10, at 6:00 P.M. with a reception to follow. Donations may be made to Saint Peter's Church in loving memory of Hellen.

title: Salad Days Now a Feast Of Fiction
description: There is a wisp of amazement in the gaze of William Phillips as he is questioned about his 60-year evolution at Partisan Review from happily failed Communist to heroically enduring editor.

title: Gold Surges as Audit Reveals Faked Indonesian Discovery
description: Gold prices surged in New York yesterday after the report that an audit had found no gold worth mining at the Indonesian site discovered by Bre-X Minerals Ltd. of Canada. The disclosure erased any lingering expectations for a surge in worldwide gold production.

description: As more people with AIDS survive longer, many are confronting yet another serious health problem: cancer.

description: With his aching knees limiting his mobility and raising the issue of whether he could endure a grueling post-season at 34, it was clear a few weeks ago that Patrick Ewing, more than anyone, could use some time off.

title: Mother of Slain Girl Takes the Stand as Trial Begins
description: In the time since her 7-year-old daughter's death, Maureen Kanka has become a national figure, known for her fight for what has become known as ''Megan's Law.'' But today, she was just a mother in anguish.

title: Where's the latest trend? At the intersection of Madison Avenue and the paths of righteousness.
description: IN a current print ad for Campari, a priest, stuck at a garden party where the guests sip wine instead of the Italian aperitif, pleads for his soul.

description: Eugene Vale, author of the best-selling 1959 novel ''The 13th Apostle,'' and of ''The Technique of Screen Play Writing,'' a 1944 textbook that remained in print for more than four decades, died on Friday at his home in Los Angeles. He was 81.

title: When the Bartered Bride Opts Out of the Bargain

description: Incentive A.B., a holding company controlled by the Wallenberg family of Sweden, said yesterday that it had agreed to buy Vivra Inc., a chain of kidney-dialysis centers, for $1.59 billion in cash.

title: More Pieces of the Hubbell Puzzle
description: It gets progressively easier to see why Kenneth Starr, the Whitewater Independent Counsel, believes he may have the makings of an obstruction of justice case in the White House treatment of Webster Hubbell. The latest piece of the puzzle, and one of the most important, is the disclosure that close associates of President Clinton and Hillary Rodham Clinton recognized the severity of Mr. Hubbell's legal troubles in early 1994 as top Administration officials were helping him find work.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  EBENAU, SELMA
description: EBENAU-Selma, on May 4, 1997. Beloved wife of the late David. Survived by her sister-in-law, Betty Brown, niece and nephews, Nancy Brown, Judge Franklin R. Weissberg and Fred Brown.

title: Rivalry Aside, Ex-Mayors Join to Lambaste Giuliani
description: Two former Democratic Mayors of New York put aside animosities and, on the steps of City Hall, engaged yesterday in a leisurely one-two pounding of Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani, agreeing that he was doing a bad job, but differing on whether they would vote for him in November.

title: Clinton Flies To Mexico For Talks
description: President Clinton and most of his Cabinet arrived in Mexico City today at a moment of high tension between the two nations, to test his Administration's policy of using praise rather than pressure to secure cooperation from Mexico on issues including efforts to combat drug trafficking.

title: Winged Foot Readies for P.G.A.
description: Assuming that Tigermania makes it through August of 2005, the P.G.A. Championship can do little to accommodate it. Except for 2001 and 2004, each course for this major tournament has already been selected. This August, the Winged Foot Golf Club here will fit up to 25,000 spectators per day, which is 15,000 fewer than the capacity at Mark Brooks's playoff victory last year at Valhalla Golf Club in Louisville.

title: Monuments Are No Strangers to Outrage
description: To the Editor:

title: Finance Peace, Not War
description: To the Editor:

title: For the Bride Who Wants a Simple, Sensuous Look
description: Styles in wedding gowns, it seems, go on for about as long as Uncle Joe's or Aunt Mary's toast to the bride. That is, forever. For decades, brides have been offered the same operatic full-skirted gowns with overblown sleeves, yards of lace and enough bead tonnage to sink a ship.

title: DANCE
description: Of Kokoschka, Painter

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HANRAHAN, G. MICHAEL
description: HANRAHAN-G. Michael. Founder and senior partner in the Pelham law firm of Hanrahan & Hanrahan, died Sunday, May 4, 1997, at his home in Somers, NY. He was 85. In addition to his wife, Florence, he is survived by four daughters, Florie H. Welch, Ellen H. Allen, Nancy H. McKinney, and Kathleen J. Hanrahan; three sons, Michael G., George A., & William F., and thirteen grandchildren. Visiting hours today at the Pelham Funeral Home. Funeral service at 10 A.M., on Wednesday, in St. Catharine's Church in Pelham.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STATHIS, LOU
description: STATHIS-Lou. On May 4, 1997. Loving companion of Shelly Roeberg. Beloved son of Mary K. and the late James. Devoted brother of Marguerite Stathis and Florence Stathis Farrat. Dear Uncle of Angelo Stathes, James and Gregory Farrat. Reposing at Barrett Funeral Home, 424 West 51st, NYC on Wed. 2-4 and 7-9 P.M. Religious Services Thurs. 10 A.M. at Funeral Home. Interment Woodlawn Cemetery. Donations to: Bone Marrow Transplant Fund, Presbyterian Hospital/Millstein Pavilion, 177 Ft. Washington Ave., 6th Floor Room 435, New York, New York 10032, Attn: Joanne.

title: TWO HIGH-LEVEL EXECUTIVES RESIGN AT SILICON GRAPHICS
description: Silicon Graphics Inc. said yesterday that its chief financial officer, Stanley J. Meresman, and Michael Ramsey, a senior vice president, had resigned to pursue other opportunities as the company restructured. Mr. Meresman, 50, had been with the maker of high-end computers for eight years. William Kelly, senior vice president of corporate operations, will take over his duties until a replacement is found. David Orton, formerly head of the company's scalable systems group, will assume Mr. Ramsey's duties as senior vice president of the desktop and graphics group. Mr. Ramsey, 46, had been with the company, which is based in Mountain View, Calif., for 11 years.

title: States Offer to Limit Costs Of Suits Over Cigarettes
description: In talks in Dallas with cigarette producers, state attorneys general offered a plan yesterday that would give full legal rights to smokers suing tobacco companies but would limit the amount of money the industry would have to pay out annually, a person close to the talks said.

title: Regulators Suspect Inside Trades At Big German Software Maker
description: German prosecutors have begun an investigation into suspected illegal insider trading at SAP A.G., the world's fourth-largest software company.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HILL, ROY LEE
description: HILL-Roy Lee. Of White Plains, NY. Father of Michael D. Hill. Grandfather of two. Funeral service Friday 11 AM, at the Alcova Baptist Church, Monroe, GA. Reposing at the Ballard-Durand Funeral Home, 2 Maple Avenue, White Plains, NY, Tuesday 7-9 PM and Wednesday 2-4 and 7-9 PM. Memorial contributions to the American Cancer Society, 2 Lyon Place, White Plains, NY 10601, would be appreciated.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KIMPER, OLLA MARIE
description: KIMPER-Olla Marie. On Friday, May 2, 1997. She was 74 years old. She was born on July 3, 1922 in Talladega, Alabama, to Oscar and Maxie Lawless. Mrs. Kimper had been the high school guidance supervisor for the city of New York, borough of Manhattan until her retirement in 1981. Mrs. Kimper graduated from Hunter College in 1943 and received her Master's degree in physical education from the University of Michigan. She was a member of the Delta Sigma Theta Sorority. She was the financial secretary of the Ninevah Beach Association. She is survived by her husband of 37 years, Richard, a sister Gertrude Boddie and two nieces and four grand nieces and grand nephews. A Memorial Service will be held at a later date. In lieu of flowers, the family requests donations be sent to the American Lung Association.

title: Fire Fells Building and Snarls Midtown Traffic
description: Fueled by piles of shoes in a shoe store's basement, a fire destroyed a five-story building on the Avenue of the Americas yesterday and continued to burn early this morning, threatening two neighboring buildings and sending torrents of thick smoke and fumes throughout midtown.

title: White House Says Clintons Didn't Know Scope of Hubbell Matter
description: The White House said today that the Clintons and their aides did not ''fully'' know the seriousness of the allegations against their close friend Webster L. Hubbell until he pleaded guilty to fraud charges at the end of 1994.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FARKAS, MIRIAM
description: FARKAS-Miriam. Riverdale Jewish Center extends profound condolences to Peter Kellner on the loss of his mother, Miriam Farkas. May the family be comforted amongst the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Jonathan I. Rosenblatt, Rabbi Tobias B. Schapiro, President

title: Art as a Virtual Feast
description: To the Editor:

title: Keith R. Porter, 84; Set Groundwork for Field of Cell Biology
description: Keith R. PorterKeith R. Porter, a biologist who made the first photographs of tissue cells with the aid of an electron microscope and thus helped found the modern field of cell biology, died on Friday at a retirement home in Bryn Mawr, Pa. He was 84.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GREENBERG, BERNARD, M.D.
description: GREENBERG-Bernard, M.D. The Medical Staff of Maimonides Medical Center records with deep sorrow the death of Dr. Bernard Greenberg. Dr. Greenberg was a pediatrician with the Department of Pediatrics for over fifty years, practicing until he became ill a few months ago. He was active in the governing body of the Medical Staff, serving as President in the late 1960's. He served as Chairman of the Memorial and Dedication Committee for over twenty-five years. He will be sorely missed by all his colleagues, friends and patients. Sincere condolences are extended to his entire family. David Eddi, M.D., President Warren Wexelman, M.D. President Elect Jacob Shani, M.D., Secretary David Feldman, M.D, Treasurer

title: On Clinton Itinerary: Mexico City Counterpart of the Alamo
description: Exactly 150 years ago, an American invasion force was fighting its way toward Mexico's capital in a war engineered by President James K. Polk that claimed 50,000 Mexican lives and allowed the United States to slice off and annex half of Mexico.

title: Work on Ziploc Shifts to BBDO
description: Dowbrands in Indianapolis, a unit of the Dow Chemical Company, named BBDO Chicago to handle the creative and media planning responsibilities for its Ziploc brand of storage bags, which had been handled by Campbell Mithun Esty in Minneapolis. Billings were estimated at $20 million to $25 million.

title: On Standardized Tests
description: To the Editor:

title: Police Say House Fire Killed 3 As Their Mother Sought Drugs
description: Angel Melendez, 6 years old, spent the sunny hours of Sunday afternoon playing outside. He ran up and down the sidewalk on his block and shot baskets with friends on a makeshift court across the street.

title: Good Nose, Great DNA
description: IT is not often that the phrases ''remarkably supple'' and ''deep, silky nose'' appear in Nature Genetics, but they do in the May issue. The journal published a paper, a commentary and an editorial on a topic it obviously considers of great importance: the origin of what is often called the world's most noble grape, the cabernet sauvignon.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHATZ, ARTHUR H.
description: SCHATZ-Arthur H., 79, died Saturday (May 3, 1997) at his home in Palm Beach Gardens, Fl. Mr. Schatz was a graduate of Cornell University and Cornell Law School and started practicing law in 1945. He was the managing partner of Schatz & Schatz, Ribicoff & Kotkin. Mr. Schatz was elected for inclusion in ''Best Lawyers in America'' and was a frequent lecturer at, among others, Cornell Law School, University of Connecticut Law School and the Law-Science Institute of the University of Texas. He was a past Vice President and General Counsel of the International Congress on Forensic Science; a founding member and General Counsel of the International Reference Organization in Forensic Medicine; a member and past vice chairman of the Connecticut Commission on Medicolegal Investigations; a Trustee of the Forensic Science Foundation and the Law Science Foundation of America; a fellow of the American Academy of Forensic Sciences and Chairman of its jurisprudence section and a member of the British Academy of Forensic Sciences. He served on the Board of Directors of the Hebrew Home (Hartford, CT) and on the Executive Committee of the Cornell Law Association, the Cornell University Council and the editorial boards of INFORM Journal, the American Journal of Forensic Medicine and Science and the International Journal of Medicine and Science. Mr. Schatz is survived by his wife, Cecil (Ruskay) Schatz and three children; Ellen Levine of West Hartford, CT, Robert Schatz of Glastonbury, CT and Daniel Schatz of Haworth, NJ. In lieu of flowers, memorial contributions may be made to the Schatz Memorial Scholarship Fund at Cornell Law School, Ithaca, N.Y.; the Schatz Memorial Fund at Hartford Jewish Federation or to a charity of the donor's choice.

title: 'We Never Knew'
description: As of May 5, 1997, it became impossible for me to believe it happened the way President Clinton and his wife said it had.

title: Frank Robinson Returns to the Game
description: The Hall of Famer FRANK ROBINSON, who spent 42 years in professional baseball as a player, coach, manager and assistant general manager but had been out of the sport since the end of 1995, was named director of baseball operations for the six-team Arizona Fall League and consultant to the commissioner for special projects, Major League Baseball announced yesterday.

title: Hong Kong's Chief-to-Be Defends His Plan to Cut Back Rights
description: The man chosen by China to run Hong Kong after the British leave on July 1, Tung Chee-hwa, vigorously defended tightening the territory's civil liberties today and urged the United States to renew China's trading privileges without conditions.

title: Studies Outline Clever Tricks Of Viruses
description: AFTER a war has been waged for many years, ingenious tricks and countermeasures and counter-countermeasures emerge on both sides. When a war has gone on for millions of years, like that between viruses and the human immune system, the stratagems can attain a high level of refinement.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COOPER, ESTELLE R.
description: COOPER-Estelle R. On May 4, 1997. Loving wife of John, dear mother of Melanie and Armin, devoted daughter of Bernice Schmukler. Memorial service today, 3PM at the Jewish Home and Hospital for the Aged, Manhattan.

title: Griffin Bacal Wins 2 Reviews
description: Griffin Bacal Inc. in New York, a unit of Omnicom, was awarded two accounts, with combined billings estimated at $18 million to $23 million.

title: STATE OF CALIFORNIA SUES BANKAMERICA OVER TRUST FUNDS
description: The California Attorney General, Dan Lungren, sued the BankAmerica Corporation yesterday, accusing it of cheating state and local governments out of hundreds of millions of dollars by mishandling their bond fund trust accounts. The suit, filed four days after BankAmerica was sued by San Francisco in a similar case, accuses the bank of conspiracy, unfair business practices and breach of contract, among other claims. BankAmerica's general counsel, James Roethe, said in a statement: ''This claim stems from unintentional errors the bank committed in handling municipal bond trust accounts. We stand ready to make full repayment to the state and to any bond issuer that was affected by these errors.''

title: Stocks Rise in Japan, Led by Exporters
description: Stocks rose here today, bolstered by expectations that a strong United States economy and a weak yen would increase demand for Japanese exports.

title: Rangers Now Know What Devils Knew: First Goal Is the Key
description: The goal is to score some goals. Though they share little else, the Rangers and Devils still share that humble problem in a series that must become undeadlocked Tuesday night when the feuding teams reconvene at Madison Square Garden.

title: Merger Plan's Collapse Depresses Italian Stocks
description: Italian stocks fell yesterday, dragged lower by declines in shares of Mediobanca S.p.A. and Holding di Partecipazioni Industriali S.p.A. after the weekend collapse of plans to merge HPI with another company to create a fashion and clothing conglomerate. The merger with Marzotto e Figli S.p.A. was canceled because of ''irreconcilable differences.'' Mediobanca was the investment bank in the merger.

title: Sports Authority Goes to Lord Group
description: The Sports Authority Inc., the sporting goods retailer in Fort Lauderdale, Fla., has named the Lord Group in New York, a joint venture of Dentsu Inc. and Young & Rubicam Inc., to handle its advertising and marketing account, with billings estimated at more than $20 million. The account was most recently handled by Ross Roy Communications in Bloomfield Hills, Mich., a unit of Omnicom Group, until that agency resigned it in July after five years.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROSS, RITA
description: ROSS-Rita. On May 4, 1997. Devoted wife of James. Loving mother of James, David, Rita, Gerard, Brian and Jo Ann. Beloved grandmother, sister and friend. Funeral to be held on Wednesday, May 7, 1997 in Kennebunk, Maine at St. Monica's Church.

title: Dow Hits Another High and Small Stocks Join Surge Again
description: The stock market rallied across the board yesterday as the Dow Jones industrial average soared to a high and stocks of smaller companies continued a resurgence that has seen them climb almost 8 percent in a little more than a week.

title: Software on Queens
description: The Queens Economic Development Networking Council has developed a computer program that will offer detailed information on all of Queens's 58,000 businesses: what they are, their location, number of employees, annual sales, and where their competitors and suppliers are.

title: Kennedy Observes Environmental Tradition
description: To the Editor:

title: A Display of Hubris
description: To the Editor:

title: Jury Holds a Drunken Driver's Life in the Balance
description: For more than 16 years, ever since he lost part of his left leg in a lawn mower accident, Thomas Richard Jones has popped narcotic painkillers like jelly beans. Often he chased the pills down with streams of beer.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Sunday about New Yorkers who live in luxury hotels misstated the location of the Ritz Tower. It is at Park Avenue and 57th Street, not 59th Street. The article also misspelled the given name of a media figure living there. She is Cheri Kaufman, not Sherry.

title: CHRONICLE
description: Well, yes, of course, that was BRUCE SPRINGSTEEN yesterday in Stockholm with King Carl XVI Gustaf. Maybe you didn't recognize Mr. Springsteen because he was dressed a little differently, wearing a tuxedo, not jeans and an open-necked shirt.

title: Joseph C. Swidler, 90, Lawyer Who Shook Up Power Agencies
description: Joseph Charles Swidler, one of the last New Dealers of 1933 and a Washington utilities lawyer who overhauled the Federal Power Commission and its regulatory equivalent in New York, died on Thursday at Suburban Hospital in Bethesda, Md. He was 90 and had lived in Chevy Chase.

title: Valentine's Prodding And Hundley's Power Keep Mets Looking Up
description: If Bobby Valentine were an English teacher, he would flunk any student whose paper contained a careless misspelling. If he ran a bagel bakery, he would throw out dozens if they were overboiled and force his bakers to start over.

title: Giuliani Proposes That New York Help Immigrants Become Citizens
description: In a reflection of the rising political and economic influence of immigrants in New York City, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani will call this week for the creation of a city agency to recruit and assist legal immigrants who want to become citizens.

title: Paul Lambert, 74, Actor in Films and on TV
description: Paul Lambert, a character actor in movies and on television, died on April 27 at St. John's Medical Center in Santa Monica, Calif., where he lived. He was 74.

title: Drops in Circulation Continue for Most Big Newspapers
description: A broad decline in newspaper circulation sales that began early in the decade continued for most big metropolitan dailies during the winter months, figures released by the Audit Bureau of Circulations showed yesterday.

title: Privatizing Is Better
description: To the Editor:

title: If Composer Hesitates, Soprano Does Not
description: For all its lovely music, Dvorak's ''Rusalka,'' which returned to the Metropolitan Opera on Saturday afternoon, is a difficult work to put across. The composer was clearly entranced by this lyric fairy tale, in which a water nymph falls for a handsome prince and persuades a forest witch to turn her into a mortal.

title: Injured Cyclist Wore A Helmet, Friends Say
description: A Long Island man who fell to the pavement during the annual Bike New York group ride on Sunday remained in extremely critical condition yesterday as friends and fellow riders disputed reports that he was not wearing a helmet.

title: Lawyers' Obligation
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BEATTY, ANN LEAHY
description: BEATTY-Ann Leahy. On May 3, 1997. Elementary school teacher in New York City school system for many years. Beloved aunt of Mary S. Hammel, Leonard L. Sutter, Virginia S. Gregory, Richard P. Sutter, Ann S. Carville, David J. Sutter, Robert G. Sutter and James F. Sutter. Cherished grandaunt and great-grand-aunt of many nieces and nephews. Family will receive friends at John J. Fox & Sons, Inc., 201st Street and Grand Concourse, Bronx, Tuesday, 2-4 and 7-9 PM. Mass of Christian Burial St. Philip Neri Church, 11 AM, Wednesday. Interment Calvary Cemetery.

title: Terror Suspect Freed by U.S.; Flies to Jordan
description: Mousa Mohammed Abu Marzook, the political leader of the Hamas movement jailed in Manhattan for 22 months on suspicion of terrorism, was deported yesterday and flown to Jordan aboard a United States military jet.

title: Growth's Limits in Latin America
description: When President Clinton meets Central American and Caribbean leaders later this week, he will find that some basic economic assumptions have changed. A few years ago, despite warnings from many economists, politicians in Latin America and Washington assumed that economic growth alone would take care of even the poorest Latin Americans. Many people believed them. They do not anymore. Growth has been too slow, and in Latin America, which has the largest gap between rich and poor, the gains have gone mainly to the rich, buying too many cell phones and not enough rice.

title: Small Investors and Big Money Taken by Tale of Jungle Gold
description: Late last year, the guardians of the retirement savings of millions of ordinary Americans waded into the steamy jungle of Indonesia to get a piece of what looked like the investment opportunity of a lifetime. Bre-X Minerals Ltd., a previously unknown Canadian exploration company, was issuing ever-growing estimates of the century's largest gold discovery, and dozens of mutual fund managers could not get into the action quickly enough.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KASTOFF, DAVID, M.D.
description: KASTOFF-David, M.D. Of Southbury, Connecticut. Treasured husband of Gertrude (Kusher) Kastoff for almost 55 years. Died May 5, 1997 at Hartford Hospital. He was the adored and devoted father of Stephen, Peter and Geraldine, grandfather of Jonathan and Robert, and brother of Hyman Kastoff, Martha Doskow, and the late Pauline Winkler. He leaves also a multitude of devoted friends and relatives. He was a dedicated physician for over 50 years, most of them as a Solo Practioner in New York. He served gallantly with the Medical Corps of the Armed Forces during WWII and was awarded the Bronze Star. Everyone he touched recognized and benefitted from his uncompromising dedication to family, friends and patients. Funeral services will be Wednesday, May 7 at 11 AM at Munson-Lovetere, 235 Main Street North, Southbury, Connecticut. A period of mourning will be observed at the home of his wife, 932A Heritage Village, Southbury, Connecticut.

title: Hydrogen May Not Have Caused Hindenburg's Fiery End
description: SIXTY years ago today around 3 P.M., crowds of schoolchildren like me packed midtown street corners to watch a show at least as eye-popping as the Macy's parade: the stately passage of the airship Hindenburg over Manhattan.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PECHENIK, NORMA
description: PECHENIK-Norma. The officers, leadership, and staff of UJA-Federation of New York mourn the passing of Norma Pechenik. Her daughter, Marjorie Rosenthal, is a longtime leader and supporter of the Women's Campaign, a member of the Board of Directors, and chair of the Resource Line Governing Committee. We extend our deepest sympathies to her children, Marjorie, Stephen, and Linda Montague; her sisters, Sue Shapiro and Lilly Edelstein; her brother, Barry Berns; her grandchildren; great-granchildren; and the entire family. May her memory be for a blessing. Larry A. Silverstein, Board Chair Louise B. Greilsheimer, President Mady Harman, Campaign Vice Chair, and Women's Campaign Chair Stephen D. Solender, Exec. V.P.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LIPPER, GEORGE
description: LIPPER-George. Died on Sunday, May 4, 1997. Beloved husband of the late Sally, devoted father of Kenneth and the late Jerome, respected father-in-law of Evelyn and Binnette, adoring grandfather of Allen, Joanna, Daniella, Tamara, Julie and the late David, dear brother of Milton. Services held. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to the Riverdale YMYWHA, 5625 Arlington Avenue, Bronx, NY 10471

title: Operating Profit Falls At Hoechst of Germany
