description: Hoechst A.G., Germany's largest maker of chemicals and pharmaceuticals, said yesterday that its operating profit fell 22 percent in the first quarter because of a revamping charge of 195 million marks ($113.4 million) and a drop in sales at its Trevira polyester unit. Operating profit fell to 1.03 billion marks ($600 million), from 1.32 billion in the first quarter of 1996, when Hoechst took a revamping charge of 85 million marks.

title: Politicians Play Doctor
description: To the Editor:

title: U.S. READIES RULES OVER PREFERENCES AIDING MINORITIES
description: The Clinton Administration will announce a new approach in the awarding of Government contracts that may suspend race-based preferences for some minority-owned businesses while making available billions of dollars in Federal contracts for others, officials said today.

title: Changing Insurance Rules
description: Health insurance for some people who buy their own policies could become less expensive if a bill released yesterday by the Assembly Insurance Committee becomes law.

title: Ford Sales Fell 4.3% in April as Big 3 Lost Share to Foreign Makers
description: The Ford Motor Company said today that its sales dropped 4.3 percent last month, as the Big Three American auto makers lost ground to Japanese auto makers that benefited from favorable exchange rates.

title: 2 Consolidations In Consumer Brands
description: The Black & Decker Corporation in Towson, Md., has named McCann-Erickson New York to handle the consolidated domestic responsibilities for its consumer power tools group. The account, with billings estimated at $30 million, had been previously divided between McCann New York, which is a unit of the Interpublic Group of Companies, and Fallon McElligott Berlin in New York, which is an affiliate of Fallon McElligott in Minneapolis. The decision came without a formal review. McCann New York is also the agency for Black & Decker's household product group and for the consolidated North American media assignments. McCann Worldwide also handles other international assignments including the company's consumer power tools account in Europe.

title: Guilty Plea in Murder Of Three in a Family
description: One of two men charged with murdering three members of a Washington Heights family last October pleaded guilty yesterday in exchange for a minimum sentence of 50 years in prison.

title: Unesco Award to Imprisoned Chinese Journalist Angers Beijing
description: Unesco, an agency attacked by Western nations little more than a decade ago for its involvement in efforts to regulate the world's news organizations, is now under threat of retaliation from China because of a press freedom award it presented on Saturday to an imprisoned Chinese journalist.

title: Swiss Resist Disclosing Any Mobutu Bank Funds
description: With Mobutu Sese Seko's power waning, the Swiss authorities have come under pressure to disclose, and freeze, whatever part of the vast sums he is believed to have looted from Zaire that he may have deposited or invested here. So far, however, they have decided not to do so.

title: Northern Exposure
description: Editor's Note Appended

title: A Tiny Strip of New York That Feels Like the Suburbs
description: On a narrow sliver of land between the gabled mansions of Westchester County and the wild brambles of Pelham Bay Park in the Bronx, 35 lucky homeowners live on the literal divide between city and country, with the advantages of both and the disadvantages of neither.

title: Tobacco Industry Cleared In Florida Smoker's Death
description: A jury here ruled today in favor of the R. J. Reynolds Tobacco Company, declining to order the cigarette maker to pay compensatory and punitive damages to the family of a Jacksonville woman who smoked for 34 years and died in 1995 of lung cancer at the age of 49.

title: In Zaire's Encircled Capital, A War of Words and Nerves
description: To walk the streets of this nervous capital is to discover quickly that the battle for Kinshasa is well under way. Bullets and bombs are not yet flying, but rumors of the imminent arrival of the rebel leader, Laurent Kabila, are -- and they leave no one here indifferent.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about the chess match between Garry Kasparov and the I.B.M. computer Deep Blue misstated the day of the next game, the third of the contest. It is today; Game 4 is tomorrow.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PROSE, YVETTE
description: PROSE-Yvette. The Board of Governors and members of Fairview Country Club note with profound sorrow the passing of our beloved member, Yvette Prose. On behalf of all Fairview members we express our deepest condolences to her family. Andrew J. Frankel, President Stephen A. Leber, Secretary

title: Bill Links Housing Aid To Service By Recipients
description: With a rousing speech, Gen. Colin L. Powell closed a Presidential convention on volunteerism last week in Philadelphia by urging all Americans to become more involved in helping others. A bill being debated in the House would make sure that the new volunteers include some of the poorest people in the country.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DALE, FLORENCE JOHNSTON
description: DALE-Florence Johnston. May 2, 1997. Beloved wife of the late George N. Dale. Loving sister of Robert and his wife Mildred. She was active as a volunteer for the United Nations Service and other charities. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave. at 81 St., Tuesday, 2-5 and 7-9 PM. Mass of Christian Burial Wednesday, 10:30 AM, at Holy Family Church, 315 East 47 St. Interment to follow in Island Pond, VT. In lieu of flowers contributions may be made to a charity of your choice.

title: Huntington to Buy First Michigan Bank
description: Huntington Bancshares, expanding its presence in Michigan, said today that it had agreed to buy the First Michigan Bank Corporation for $908 million.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOODKIND, ROBERT H.
description: GOODKIND-Robert H. May 4, 1997. Beloved husband of Irene, father of Thomas and James and Patricia French, brother of Richard and grandfather of four. Contributions to Renaissance Village Inc., for At Risk Youth, 11380 Prosperity Farms Road, Suite 209A, Palm Beach Gardens, FL. 33410, Phone 561-776-0890.

title: Judge Says Canada Can Deport Suspect in Lethal Saudi Bombing
description: A Canadian judge upheld a deportation order against a Saudi terror suspect today, opening the way for the United States to question the man about the bombing of a military residence in Saudi Arabia last year that killed 19 Americans.

title: RIVAL TOPS SELECT MEDICAL'S BID FOR HOSPITAL COMPANY
description: Shares of the Transitional Hospitals Corporation rose 42 percent yesterday after the company, a hospital operator, said a potential bidder offered on Sunday to pay it $15 a share, topping the bid of $14.55 a share that it had accepted earlier from the closely held Select Medical Corporation. Transitional Hospitals' stock rose $4.25 a share, to $14.25. A Transitional Hospitals spokeswoman said that it might cancel its agreement to accept the $565 million bid from Select Medical within five days if the undisclosed company made a formal offer and Select, based in Mechanicsburg, Pa., did not top it. Transitional, based in Las Vegas, Nev., formerly known as Community Psychiatric Centers, operates 16 hospitals and three other facilities.

title: Mrs. Clinton Can't Claim Attorney Privilege
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MAGNUS, LILLIAN
description: MAGNUS-Lillian. Riverdale Jewish Center mourns the loss of its member, Lillian Magnus, wife of Lewis Magnus and mother of Leah Frohlich. May the family be comforted amongst the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Jonathan I. Rosenblatt, Rabbi Tobias B. Schapiro, President

title: Heat-Seeking Beetles
description: Certain kinds of missiles have heat-sensing devices. So do snakes. No other living thing was thought to respond to infrared radiation, but it never pays to underestimate beetles, particularly those in the genus Melanophila, which lay their eggs in freshly burned wood and have been observed heading toward forest fires from 30 miles away like clouds of miniature smoke jumpers.

title: Education Plan Unveiled
description: W. Michael Murphy Jr., one of three Democratic candidates for governor, called yesterday for a 25-cent-per-pack increase in the cigarette tax to help pay for education. Mr. Murphy, a former Morris County prosecutor, said the tax would raise $150 million that could be used to increase state aid to local school districts and reduce property taxes. His education proposal also includes pre-kindergartens for the state's 30 urban districts, the elimination of tenure for principals and more sharing of services between school districts.

title: Donaldson Fund Buys a Company
description: The Decision One Holdings Corporation, the largest computer maintenance company in North America, said yesterday that it had agreed to sell 85 percent of its shares to a unit of Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette Inc. for about $660 million.

title: THEATER
description: Urinating on the Homework

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MAGNUS, LILLIAN E.
description: MAGNUS-Lillian E. On May 5, 1997. Beloved wife of Lewis B. Magnus. Mother of Leah M. Frohlich and Fanni Magnus Monson. Grandmother of Howard Glickman, Julia Frohlich Erlbaum, Rachel Frohlich and Jennifer Glickman. Sister of Shoshana Bilowit and Judith Michaelis. Funeral Services at Riverside Chapel, 180 West 76th Street, Tuesday, May 6, 12 noon. Internment at Riverside Cemetary, Lodi, New Jersey. Contributions may be made to: Riverdale Jewish Center, Jewish Theological Seminary and Alzheimer's Foundation.

title: Leaders Reach Accord to Extend Stopgap Budget in Albany
description: With the state budget already 35 days late, Gov. George E. Pataki and the leaders of the Legislature said today that they had agreed to extend a stopgap budget through June 20, a tacit admission that a real spending plan will not be in place for at least six more weeks.

title: IMES SQ. SIGN TURNS CORNER INTO SILEN
description: They may not have been the most memorable of headlines: ''PAPER GOODS COMPANIES JAMES RIVER AND FORT HOWARD TO MERGE IN PACT VALUED AT $3.4 BILLION.'' ''SECRETARY OF STATE ALBRIGHT OPENS TALKS IN MEXICO ON IMMIGRATION DRUG ENFORCEMENT AHEAD OF CLINTON'S TWO-DAY STATE VISIT.''

title: Hearing Starts in Shooting
description: A grand jury will begin hearing evidence tomorrow to decide whether excessive force may have been used on an unarmed suspect who was fatally shot by law enforcement agents.

title: CHRONICLE
description: SIR PAUL McCARTNEY is giving the Internet a spin. At least a million fans have signed up to pose questions to the former Beatle in a 90-minute on-line chat to be televised live on VH1 in the United States, Britain and Germany on May 17.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HERBERT, BERTRAM
description: HERBERT-Bertram. On May 2, 1997. Beloved father of Peter and daughter-in-law Geraldine. Loving brother of Lenore Marcus and brother-in-law Paul. Cherished grandfather of Benjamin and Jonathan, and three loving friends, Margaret Rey, Juliet Hayes and Oliver Stone. Services were held Monday.

title: Saint Laurie Moving
description: Saint Laurie, an 84-year-old company that produces made-to-measure men's and women's clothing in one of the few remaining men's suit factories in New York City, is moving its retail store from the Flatiron District to 350 Park Avenue, at 51st Street.

title: Rescuer of Bank Papers Gets a Hero's Welcome
description: A Swiss night watchman who was dismissed from his job and subjected to death threats and police interrogations in Switzerland for saving Holocaust-era bank documents from a shredder was offered work and a new life in America yesterday by benefactors who brought him to New York and say he is a hero.

title: One Texas Secessionist Who Fled Into Mountains Is Killed
description: A member of the militant secessionist group known as the Republic of Texas was shot and killed today in a gun battle with the Texas authorities in the Davis Mountains here.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLDBERGER, LILLY
description: GOLDBERGER - Lilly. Fifth Avenue Synagogue records with profound sorrow the passing of its esteemed member, beloved wife of Mr. Murray M. Goldberger, and extends heartfelt sympathy to the bereaved family. Dr. Sol Roth, Rabbi Hermann Merkin, Founding Pres. David Yagoda, Chairman Prof. William Schwartz, Pres.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HALPERT, ANNE
description: HALPERT-Anne. Our grandmother, who was a woman of strength, bravery, inspiration and beauty. May you be at peace with Grandpa Irv. we will miss you and love you forever. Debra, Robert, Brittany, Chelsea and Julian.

title: No Headline
description: ''People who drive drunk and recklessly can kill people just as much as they can kill them with a gun or a knife.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FITZSIMMONS, ELEANOR D. (NEE D'AGOSTINO)
description: FITZSIMMONS-Eleanor D. (Nee D'Agostino) age 92 of New York on May 4, 1997. Funeral Tuesday May 6 at 9 am from the Damiano Funeral Home, Third and Franklin Aves, Long Branch, NJ. Interment 11:30 am at Sleepy Hollow Cemetery, N. Tarrytown, NY. Memorial donations requested to the American Heart Assoc., 2550 Highway 1, N. Brunswick, NJ 08902-4301.

title: Mischievous Senate Lawmaking
description: The Senate will vote as early as today on whether to attach harmful census and environmental measures to an emergency spending bill for flooded areas in the Midwest and for peacekeeping in Bosnia. President Clinton has threatened to veto the bill if it includes these offensive Republican-sponsored provisions. Before he is put to the test, the Senate should drop the unrelated measures and approve an emergency bill to provide relief for the victims of war and nature.

title: North Korea's Famine Strains Quality of Mercy
description: One of Kwan Young Bom's brothers was killed fighting North Korea in the Korean War and another lost some fingers. But standing outside Seoul Station, where volunteers were collecting money for North Korean famine relief, Mr. Kwan explained why he had given a donation.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FLEISCHNER, MARY FRANCES
description: FLEISCHNER-Mary Frances, on May 4th, 1997, of Scarsdale, New York. Wife of Peter R. Fleischner. Mother of Catherine Patterson Fleischner and Molly Leigh. Sister of Edward Nash Mathews, Jr. of Coconut Grove, FL. Sister-in-law of Robert E. Fleischner. Funeral services will be private.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHAPIRO, LILLIAN
description: SHAPIRO-Lillian. The officers, members and staff of the Jewish Labor Committee mourn the death of Lillian Shapiro, loving mother of our President, Lenore Miller. Our heartfelt condolences to Lenore and family. Martin Lapan, Acting Executive Director Jewish Labor Committee

title: Equanimity Before The Storm
description: THE basketball series as a metaphor for brutal conflict is upon us, matching teams that live to bang and love to hate. But we interrupt the massing of Knick troops at the Miami border for a word of reason from General Charles Linwood Williams, otherwise known as Buck.

title: Irving Kaplan, 84, Nuclear Physicist
description: Irving Kaplan, a professor emeritus and founding member of the department of nuclear engineering at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, died on April 10 at Massachusetts General Hospital. He was 84 and lived in Belmont, Mass.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DISTEFANO, ROSARIA (SADIE)
description: DISTEFANO-Rosaria (Sadie). Beloved daughter of Rosa. Loving sister of Mary (Chelly), John and Fr. Simeon. Reposing A. Ribustello & Son, 811 Morris Park Ave, Bronx. Funeral Mass, Our Lady of Pity Church, Thursday, 10AM.

title: INSIDE METRO
description: MEGAN KANKA TRIAL BEGINS -- Testimony began yesterday in the trial of Jesse Timmendequas, above, the convicted sex offender accused of killing Megan Kanka. B4.

title: Pilots at American Airlines Approve a 5-Year Contract
description: Pilots at American Airlines approved a new five-year contract by a wide margin yesterday, putting to rest a dispute that had threatened to lead to a second strike this year at the nation's second-largest carrier.

title: Skirts' Time Has Come
description: After a winter of wearing trousers, many women are finding that skirts look and feel good again. For the very young, that may mean minis, but for everyone else the choice is between knee-length and ankle-length.

title: Riley Looks Forward To Knicks Roadblock
description: One of the many intriguing elements in the Knicks-Miami Heat playoff matchup is that people on both sides enjoy close relationships.

title: Northrop to Purchase Logicon in a $750 Million Stock Swap
description: Seeking to bolster its position in the highly competitive market for military electronics and information services, the Northrop Grumman Corporation said yesterday that it had agreed to buy Logicon Inc., a military information technology company, in a stock swap valued at $750 million.

title: First Lady Isn't Elected
description: To the Editor:

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Jury Rejects Suit Against R. J. Reynolds

title: Transactions
description: Baseball

title: Defense Lawyer Is Removed From Inquiry of Police Union
description: A Federal judge in Manhattan yesterday removed the prominent criminal defense lawyer Gerald B. Lefcourt from his role as the counsel in a case stemming from the government's investigation of corruption in the city's transit police union.

title: America Online Posts Surprising Earnings
description: America Online Inc. said yesterday that it had returned to profitability in its third quarter after six months of heavy losses. The results surprised Wall Street analysts, who had predicted another loss for the nation's largest on-line service provider.

title: A Judge Is Accused of a Legal, but Unusual, Deception
description: If there is one place that strives to be free of deception, it is the courtroom. But one prominent judge in Manhattan is accused of undermining that ideal, going through the elaborate ruse of staging fake hearings so that a potential witness at a drug conspiracy trial would not be compromised.

title: Teach Acid-Rain Facts, Not Fears and Fiction
description: To the Editor:

title: For Illinois Woman, at Age 56, It's Around the World in 2,900 Days
description: It has been almost a hundred years since the first man sailed alone around the world. But no American woman had been able to make that claim until yesterday, when a 56-year-old architect maneuvered her small sailboat into the docks at Acapulco, Mexico.

title: RISER FOODS IS STUDYING TAKEOVER OFFER OF $42 A SHARE
description: Riser Foods Inc. said yesterday that it was considering an unnamed supermarket chain's cash offer of $42 a share for all of Riser's outstanding shares. Riser, based in Bedford Heights, Ohio, operates 36 retail supermarkets in northeast Ohio. Riser's stock jumped $3.50 a share yesterday, to $41.125, giving the company a market value of about $360 million.

title: Scientists Widen the Hunt for Alien Life
description: DIM or brainy, fair or hideous, extraterrestrial life forms are often pictured by scientists and writers of science fiction as inhabiting worlds just the right distance from stars -- neither too hot nor too cold. Rays of starlight in such temperate zones are seen as warming planetary surfaces and alien races, providing a ready source of energy and, most important, the right amount of heat to keep life-giving water from boiling away or turning into ice.

title: Sabres Can't Stop the Flyers
description: The Buffalo Sabres tried to intimidate the Philadelphia Flyers, slamming their captain, Eric Lindros, into the boards and slashing him from behind. When that did not work, they tried to unnerve goalie Garth Snow by complaining to the referee that his uniform did not fully cover his bulky pads. Neither strategy worked.

title: Monuments Are No Strangers to Outrage
description: To the Editor:

title: Pitcher's Tests Inconclusive
description: Test results from Jason Isringhausen's bronchoscopy offered no conclusive evidence that the Mets pitcher has tuberculosis, Steve Phillips, the team's assistant general manager, said today. Isringhausen, however, says he's feeling better since receiving medication aimed at treating tuberculosis.

title: Share Price Surges For Swiss National Bank
description: The shares of Swiss National Bank soared 45 percent yesterday on speculation that shareholders could profit from the Swiss central bank's plan to reduce gold reserves, traders and analysts said. The bank rejected the speculation as ''unrealistic.'' The shares closed with a gain of 685 francs, at 2,185 francs ($1,485).

title: The Politics Of the I.R.A.
description: The convincing gains made in British elections by Sinn Fein, the political wing of the overwhelmingly Roman Catholic Irish Republican Army, have changed the face of Northern Ireland. But they have also raised essential new questions about the future of the flagging effort to end sectarian violence in this Protestant-dominated British province.

title: James River to Acquire Fort Howard in $3.6 Billion Deal
description: The James River Corporation said yesterday that it would acquire the Fort Howard Corporation for $3.6 billion in stock in a deal that would create the largest maker of tissues, napkins and paper towels in the United States.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KEMPTON, MURRAY
description: KEMPTON-Murray. On May 5th, 1997. Service Thursday, May 8th, 11 AM, at St. Ignatius of Antioch, 87th St. at West End Ave. Friends are invited to offer a contribution in his memory to a charity of their choice, in lieu of flowers.

title: Cleveland, Tie-Dyed, as Woodstock Nation
description: Today Cleveland is a rock nexus, as new members gather to be inducted into the Rock-and-Roll Hall of Fame. Michael Jackson and his four brothers in the Jackson Five are expected for the ceremony on Tuesday. So are the Bee Gees, Crosby, Stills and Nash, Parliament-Funkadelic, the Young Rascals and Buffalo Springfield. To praise them, Diana Ross, Tom Petty, James Taylor, the Artist (formerly known as Prince) and Brian Wilson are also to appear Tuesday night.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RABB, NORMAN S.
description: RABB-Norman S. The Board of Governors of The Palm Beach Country Club expresses its sorrow at the passing of its esteemed member and dear friend, Norman Rabb, and offers its heartfelt sympathy to his family and friends. David L. Rudnick, President Robert S. Puder, Secretary

title: Lucent to Build New Plant
description: Lucent Technologies Inc. said today that it would build a cellular-equipment factory and systems design center in Sao Paulo. Lucent, based in Murray Hill, N.J., said the factory would develop software and systems for local markets but would eventually export products to Argentina, Chile, Paraguay and Uruguay. Production is expected to begin late this year at the plant.

title: Malaysian Concern Gets Bid for Appliance Stake
description: Berjaya Group Bhd. of Malaysia said yesterday that it had received a ''third party'' offer to buy its stake in Berjaya Singer Bhd. for 1.196 billion ringgit ($478.4 million). Berjaya Group did not identify the bidder.

title: DAMES & MOORE/BROOKHILL BUYING SITES FOR $72 MILLION
description: Dames & Moore said yesterday that its joint venture with the Brookhill Group, Dames & Moore/Brookhill L.L.C., had agreed to acquire 10 properties and the mortgages of 14 other properties from the failed Canadian insurer Confederation Life Insurance Company for $72 million. Of the 24 sites, 12 are in California, and the others are in 11 other states. Dames & Moore, based in Boca Raton, Fla., is an environmental engineering and consulting company. Brookhill Group is a real estate turnaround specialist. Confederation Life, based in Toronto, was seized by Canadian and United States regulators in 1994 after the company collapsed under the weight of soured real estate loans.

title: The Mentally Ill Deserve Job Protection
description: Some years ago, I was referred a patient for an unusual reason. The company Jill worked for was about to fire her, and the new owner was concerned that Jill might commit suicide. She had been a competent middle manager. But the new C.E.O. favored an upbeat style of management-by-consensus. Jill's dour deliberateness was out of place.

title: Yankees' Rally Falls Short In Ninth
description: Not even Tino Martinez's hot bat could save the Yankees this time.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KOLBRENER, FRANCES (NEE SINDEBAND)
description: KOLBRENER-Frances (nee Sindeband). Beloved wife of the late Samuel. Loving mother of Susan Reiter and Frederick Kolbrener. Loving grandmother of Sandra Harvey and Judith Long. Great grandmother of Shannon Harvey and Paige Long. Dear sister of Robert Sindeband. Services ''Boulevard-Riverside'', 1450 Bdwy, Hewlett, L.I. 11:30AM Wednesday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STEIN, KATHRYN WALTER
description: STEIN-Kathryn Walter, on May 5, 1997. Beloved daughter of the late Alfred and Estelle Stein. Beloved sister of the late Josephine Stein. A generous contributor and active in many charities including the UJA, 92nd Street Y. Also for many years an active volunteer in Call For Action. In lieu of flowers contributions can be made to 92nd Street Y, Senior Citizen Fund.

title: C.I.A. Nominee Seems Set for Quick Approval
description: George J. Tenet, the fifth nominee for Director of Central Intelligence in the last four years, will be questioned by a Senate committee on Tuesday, and the betting is that his nomination will be quickly approved by the panel and then promptly confirmed by the full Senate.

title: Murray Kempton, 79, a Newspaperman Of Honor and Elegant Vinegar, Is Dead
description: Murray Kempton, whose independence and unpredictability as a newspaper columnist in New York made him a model of conscience for five decades of journalists and readers, died yesterday at the Kateri Nursing Home in Manhattan. Mr. Kempton was 79 and lived for many years on the Upper West Side.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEISS, SAMUEL
description: WEISS-Samuel. On May 5, 1997. Beloved husband of the late Regina. Loving father of Arline Levine, Andrew Weiss, David Weiss and father-in-law of Ronnie and Marcia. Cherished grandfather of Steven, Shari, Todd, Pamela and Gina, and great-grandfather of Lily, Eli and Joshua. Dear friend of Ann Binder. Services Wednesday, 12PM, at ''The Riverside,'' 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Baby Is Left in Beer Box
description: The caretaker of St. Paul's Episcopal Church said he was surprised to find a beer case just outside the church's day-care center yesterday morning, the authorities said. He was even more surprised by what was inside: a healthy 2-week-old baby girl who prosecutors said had been abandoned shortly before she was found.

title: Someday My Prints Will Come
description: WATCHING the 8-by-10 print emerge from the new color printer brought back memories of seeing my first photo magically spring to life in a darkroom's developer tray. Now, for the first time in my experience, a picture was coming out of a computer printer looking for all the world like a traditional photograph.

title: Patterns
description: Gaultier's Men's Show

title: Martinez Rings Up Runs and Believers
description: Tom Kelly hadn't seen Tino Martinez play in person this season and yet he was rhapsodizing about the Yankees' first baseman.

title: Los Angeles Police Report Says Fuhrman Overstated Brutal Exploits
description: After an exhaustive review, the Los Angeles Police Department said today that Mark Fuhrman had grossly exaggerated most if not all of his accounts of his racist brutality as a patrol officer but had been allowed to ''act out his prejudices,'' especially against female officers at work.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Sister Says McVeigh's Anger Led to a Vow for Vengeance
description: Testifying for the prosecution, Jennifer McVeigh told a Federal jury today that her brother, Timothy J. McVeigh, railed against Federal agents as ''fascist tyrants'' and had said he was moving from ''the propaganda stage'' to ''the action stage'' in the months before the bombing of the Oklahoma City Federal building.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FREUND, GERALD
description: FREUND-Gerald. It is with profound sadness that his friends and colleagues at the Harlem Educational Activities Fund, Inc. note the passing of Gerald Freund, HEAF's first Executive Director and for many years its Senior Consultant. The HEAF programs he developed, the talented and dedicated HEAF staff members he recruited and trained, and the improved lives of Central Harlem children stand as permanent memorials to this fine man. Daniel Rose, President

title: A Message For Kasparov: Ego Will Out
description: LET'S hear it for humankind, which held its own against machinery at the Equitable Center. There, in case you were weekending on Jupiter and did not hear, a flesh-and-blood creation named Garry Kasparov played to a tie against Deep Blue, a chess-playing whiz of a computer capable of examining 200 million moves per second -- more moves than even George Steinbrenner can contemplate. In all, it was an encouraging weekend for the human race, although four remaining games will tell us if Deep Blue's bark is worse than its byte.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  ARMSTRONG, FRANK
description: ARMSTRONG-Frank. Born October 8, 1895. Died May 6, 1959. Always remembered, never forgotten.

title: S.E.C. Backs Trades Using Smaller Figures
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission approved an American Stock Exchange request today to narrow stock-quote increments to one-sixteenth of a dollar from one-eighth.

title: 'The Life,' 'Steel Pier' and 'Chicago' Lead the Pack in Tony Nominations
description: In a theater season teeming with new American musicals, ''The Life'' and ''Steel Pier'' broke away from the pack when the nominations for this year's Tony Awards were announced yesterday. Each of the shows collected more than 10 nominations, far outdistancing their nearest competitors among the new musicals, ''Titanic'' and ''Juan Darien,'' which received five nominations each. Among musical revivals, the highly acclaimed ''Chicago'' received eight nominations, double the total for its nearest rival, ''Candide.''

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  VAUGHN, HELEN, DR.
description: VAUGHN-Helen, Dr. A memorial service in memory of Dr. Helen Vaughn will be held on Thursday, May 8, 4:30 PM, at Fordham University, Lincoln Center Chapel.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GUNDELL, PETER F.
description: GUNDELL-Peter F. On May 3, 1997 after a courageous battle with Cancer. Beloved husband to Ruth, devoted father to Andy, Jim and Jane. Father-in-Law to Carolyn. Friend to Ed Brill and loving grandfather to Amanda. A man of great intellect, compassion, and humor. Admired for his achievements in computers and retail. A lover of the links, the Alps, but most of all his family and friends. We will miss him dearly. Funeral service will be today 11:00 A.M., at the Community Synagogue of Rye, 200 Forest Avenue, Rye, New York. Contributions to Memorial Sloan-Kettering, Cancer Care Center, Box E, 1275 York Avenue, New York, New York 10021 would be appreciated.

title: Paulo Freire, 75, Is Dead; Educator of the Poor in Brazil
description: Paulo Freire, a radical Brazilian educator known for his methods of using everyday words and ideas to teach illiterates to read -- and to be skeptical about prevailing social and political systems -- died on Friday in Albert Einstein Hospital in Sao Paolo. He was 75 and had lived in Sao Paolo since 1981.

title: Bond Prices Recover From Early Losses
description: Treasury securities turned mixed yesterday, erasing early losses when bonds followed stocks higher.

title: 'Ebonics' Omitted in Oakland Report on Teaching English
description: Four months after Oakland, Calif., became the nation's first school district to declare that blacks speak a separate language called ebonics, the Oakland schools task force studying the subject has come up with final recommendations in a report that does not mention ebonics at all.

title: Bre-X: From Rags to Riches, Back to Rags
description: The American and Indonesian companies that only a few months ago were fighting for the right to help Bre-X Minerals Ltd. of Canada mine in what had been touted as this century's richest gold strike walked away from the project today and left Bre-X on its own to defend what is being called one of the scams of the century.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LUTKOFF, DAVID M.
description: LUTKOFF-David M. 80. Longboat Key, FL on May 3, 1997, after a brief illness. Beloved husband of Suzanne (nee Goddin), devoted son-in-law of Mildred Mallets, cherished father of Andrew A. (Catherine) and Steven J. Lutkoff, dear brother of Mollie Sumner and adored grandfather of Isaac, Rebekah, Aaron and Hannah Lutkoff. Funeral services and interment are today. Memorials to Temple Beth Israel, 567 Bay Isles Rd, Longboat Key, FL 34228. For information call Tishman Funeral Home-Jewish Funeral Directors, 5750 Swift Road, Sarasota, FL 34231. (941)923-2000.

title: The Chess Column
description: Because of the match between Garry Kasparov and the I.B.M. computer, the chess column by Robert Byrne will not appear today. The column will resume after the match ends.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-15

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: HOCKEY

title: CHRONICLE
description: When Britain's Labor Party picked up all the marbles in last week's general elections, it didn't stop with the Conservatives.

title: Reliance Bancorp To Buy Continental
description: Reliance Bancorp Inc. said yesterday that it would buy Continental Bank for stock valued at $24.2 million.

title: Officials Vow To Intervene In Injury Case
description: State officials yesterday were quick to support a former lineman for Niagara Mohawk who is still seeking compensation for a 1962 accident that left him paralyzed, with Gov. George E. Pataki calling the situation ''a disgrace'' and the head of the Workers' Compensation Board threatening legal action to force payment.

title: F.D.A. Allows American Home to Retain Its Monopoly on a Drug
description: Dealing a significant blow to Duramed Pharmaceuticals Inc., the Federal Government today allowed the American Home Products Corporation to retain its monopoly on Premarin, an estrogen replacement that is the most frequently prescribed drug in America.

title: Texas Relaxes Its Pursuit Of Secessionist
description: A day after law-enforcement officers killed a member of a secessionist group in a gunfight in the mountains here, the authorities said today that they had significantly scaled back their search for the group's sole remaining fugitive.

title: Insurer Refuses to Pay Worker Despite Urging by His Ex-Boss
description: Responding to a letter from the New York State Attorney General, an insurance company said yesterday that it had no obligation to pay workers' compensation benefits to a former lineman for Niagara Mohawk Power Corporation who was paralyzed in a 1962 accident.

title: Brazil Awards Big Mining Stake To Group Bidding $3.13 Billion
description: The on-again, off-again privatization of Companhia Vale do Rio Doce, the Brazilian state-owned mining giant, proceeded today, with a group financed by the Nationsbank Corporation emerging as the winning bidder.

title: Another Magazine by Bellow
description: At the age of 81, Saul Bellow is embarking on his third literary magazine as editor.

title: 'Ellen' by the Numbers
description: Riding the huge wave of attention attracted by last week's ''coming-out'' episode of ''Ellen,'' ABC managed a rare weekly victory in the prime-time ratings, beating NBC by almost a full rating point for the week.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROSENBLATT, MILDRED
description: ROSENBLATT-Mildred, died May 5, in Florida. She is survived by four sons: Sidney, Murry, Paul and Bernard, and a sister, Betty. Funeral service Thursday, May 8, 12 Noon, at Gutterman's, Jericho Turnpike, Woodbury, Long Island.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STRYER, EVA
description: STRYER-Eva. On May 3, 1997. Beloved wife of the late Norbert, mother of Lubert, mother-in-law of Andrea, grandmother of Michael and Daniel, grandmother-inlaw of Barri and Stacy. Greatgrandmother of Leah and Rachael, sister of Difa, and aunt of Anthony. Donations to the American Heart Association.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WARNER, DR. TRUMAN A.
description: WARNER-Dr. Truman A. Of Newtown CT, retired Professor of Anthropology at Western Connecticut State University, Danbury, CT died in Danbury on May 5th, 1997. Dr. Warner had taught at Briarcliff High School, Briarcliff Manor, NY for 10 years, prior to joining the Staff at Western Connecticut State University in 1957. He retired in 1995. Funeral services will be held at the Central Christian Church, 71 West St., Danbury on Friday afternoon at 2 P.M. Friends may call at the Green Funeral Home, 57 Main St., Danbury on Thursday afternoon and evening from 3 to 5 and 7 to 9 P.M. Contributions may be made to the Truman A. Warner Scholarship Fund, C/O W.C.S.U., 181 White St., Danbury, CT 06810.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SINOPOLI, C. RICHARD
description: SINOPOLI-C. Richard. On May 3, 1997, of California/Brooklyn. Brother of Gregory, Joseph, Flavia and Carla Sinopoli. Funeral from the D'Agostino Funeral Home, 881 Ringwood Avenue, Wanaque/Haskell, NJ, Saturday, 8 AM and a 8:30 AM. Mass at St. Francis Church. Interment Gate of Heaven, Hawthorne, NY, Thursday 7-9PM, Fri. 2-4 and 7-9 PM.

title: In Zaire, a Signal That Mobutu May Depart Today
description: With rebel forces pressing ahead in a campaign to capture this city, state television announced this evening that President Mobutu Sese Seko would leave the country on Wednesday for a three-day visit to nearby Gabon -- a trip that is widely seen here as a way for him to escape before his capital falls.

title: Not Another Counsel
description: To the Editor:

title: Efforts to Fight Eating Disorders May Backfire
description: WHAT better way to prevent eating disorders among young women in college than to let them hear firsthand the harrowing tales of others who have had those conditions? It is an approach used on many campuses in this country.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHAPIRO, SANFORD N.
description: SHAPIRO-Sanford N. Age 48. On May 4, 1997. Beloved son of Rita and George M. Shapiro. Dear brother of Karen Spector. He was a graduate of Williams College, the Woodrow Wilson School of Public and International Affairs at Princeton University and Boalt Hall School of Law at the University of California, Berkeley. Services Thursday, 12 Noon at Plaza Memorial Chapel, Amsterdam Ave at 91 Street. Shiva period will be observed at the home of his parents. May he at last know peace.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BECK, ROBERT A.
description: BECK-Robert A. As fellow graduates of the class of June, 1942, Bronx High School of Science, we express heartfelt sympathy on the passing of one of our most distinguised classmates. Sincere condolences to the family. Jerome R. Jakubovitz Martin F. Mertz

title: The Best Seller of Byzantium
description: Orhan Pamuk is sitting in his study on a hill overlooking Istanbul. Before him gleams the Bosporus, panning into the Sea of Marmara. On one shore lies the Greek-Ottoman Old City, with its sultans' palaces and Byzantine cathedral-turned-mosque. The other shore is Asia, shipyards and lighthouses. And at Pamuk's feet, cargo ships from Turkey's ancestral enemy Russia are parked in the harbor, disgorging traders from the ex-Soviet bloc who, since the collapse of Communism, have helped make Istanbul once again a multinational boom town.

title: Mentally Ill Needn't Make Workplace Inefficient
description: To the Editor:

title: A Hong Kong-Based Chain Will Buy U.N. Plaza Hotel
description: The Giuliani administration said yesterday that it would sell the United Nations Plaza Hotel, at First Avenue and 44th Street, to a Hong Kong-based hotel chain, producing an $85 million windfall for the city and more than doubling the yearly tax revenue from the property.

title: A Success Story With More Trimmings Than Christmas
description: Hanson seems too good to be for real: three angelic-looking brothers (aged 11 to 16) from Oklahoma with heaven-sent voices, the ebullience of the Jackson 5 and a single at No. 4 on the pop charts that is expected to climb to No. 1 next week.

title: NORCEN ENERGY TO BUY BASIC PETROLEUM INTERNATIONAL
description: Norcen Energy Resources Ltd. said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire Basic Petroleum International Ltd. for $303 million, including the exploration and royalty rights on certain lands. Basic Petroleum, which is based in Paris, is Guatemala's only oil producer, and all of its operations are based in that country. Norcen Energy is based in Calgary, Alberta. Under the agreement, Norcen will make an offer of $40 a share to Basic shareholders starting Monday. The offer is conditional on more than 50 percent of Basic's shares being tendered. Norcen said shareholders with more than 47 percent of Basic's shares had already agreed to the deal.

title: Chief U.S. Statistics Official Is Leaving
description: The Government's leading statistics official, Everett M. Ehrlich, will leave his post as Under Secretary of Commerce for Economic Affairs at the end of the month to set up a Washington consulting firm.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Nationsbank in Winning Bid For Brazilian Privatization

title: After Another Stodgy Start, a Small Gamble Doesn't Help
description: In an attempt to pep up still another conservative opening against I.B.M.'s monster computer, Deep Blue, Garry Kasparov took a risk in the middle game yesterday. But it was a small one -- a speculative pawn sacrifice -- and in the end it did not succeed in steering Game 3 away from a draw.

title: No Death Sentence For Drunken Driver In Student Killings
description: A jury here spared a man from the death penalty today and sentenced him instead to life in prison without parole in the first case that has produced first-degree murder convictions for homicides caused by impaired driving.

title: Makers Offer Liability Caps For Cigarettes
description: In talks in Dallas with state attorneys general and public health advocates, cigarette industry negotiators yesterday offered a hard-line settlement proposal that would sharply limit both the types of lawsuits smokers could bring and the money they would receive, said several people familiar with the meeting.

title: Californians Win Five of the Beard Awards
description: CALIFORNIANS dominated this year's awards from the James Beard Foundation, presented Monday at a black-tie gala at the Marriott Marquis in New York.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FREUND, GERALD
description: FREUND-Gerald. It is with profound sadness that his friends and colleagues at the Harlem Educational Activities Fund, Inc. note the passing of Gerald Freund, HEAF's first Executive Director and for many years its Senior Consultant. The HEAF programs he developed, the talented and dedicated HEAF staff members he recruited and trained, and the improved lives of Central Harlem children stand as permanent memorials to this fine man. Daniel Rose, President

title: Depression's Realities
description: To the Editor:

title: Charges Fly: She's Snoozed! He's Unfit
description: Forget taxes, crime, the homeless or the future of New York City's embattled neighborhoods. The city's mayoral campaign devolved yesterday into a quarrel over such issues as which candidate can stay awake at extended public events and who can ride a meaner bicycle.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  EWEN, NETTIE
description: EWEN-Nettie. Beloved wife of the late Louis. At the age of 102 on May 5, 1997. Loving mother of Ira. Loving grandmother of Rani Dalgin, Jessica Kahan, Lara Ewen and Britt Ewen. Adoring great grandmother of Rebecca and Elana Dalgin and Daniel Kahan. Graveside service Mount Hebron Cemetery, Queens, 1:30 P.M., on Friday, May 9th.

title: Grabbing Life and Limb at Contemporary Art Auction
description: The tough really got going at Sotheby's last night. If an artwork was in the form of a body part or an alien creature or even a pig -- the subjects of difficult works from the late 1980's and early 90's -- there was a passionate group of buyers wanting it.

title: Vitamin E May Enhance Immunity, Study Finds
description: A new study suggests that the near-universal decline in the health of the immune system that accompanies aging may be slowed by supplements of vitamin E.

title: Wheat Prices Fall on Signs That Crop Survived a Freeze
description: Wheat prices slumped on the Chicago Board of Trade yesterday as reports signaled that an April freeze damaged the winter wheat crop less than expected.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JOSEPH, JULIAN
description: JOSEPH-Julian, on May 4, 1997, born in the Bronx, NY, Dec. 20, 1907. He worked in retail luggage sales and repairs in the theater district for many years and had many famous customers ask for ''Joe'' when they came to town. Julian was a beloved son, brother, husband, father and grandfather. Graveside service today, 10:30 AM at Riverside Cemetery, Rochelle Park, New Jersey.

title: Fire Safety Rules for Cargo Holds Still Months Away, F.A.A. Says
description: A year after a fire in the cargo hold of a Valujet Airlines DC-9 caused the plane to crash into the Florida Everglades, the Federal Aviation Administration is still months away from finishing a draft rule that would require smoke detectors and fire suppression systems in the cargo holds of passenger planes, the agency said today.

title: Success at Stand-Up Comedy Leads to the Pursuit of Television Stardom
description: Maybe, in a few years, John DiResta will be driving a Porsche along the Ventura Freeway, wearing shades, heading for the Disney studios in Burbank and the sound stage where his top-rated situation comedy is taped every Wednesday night.

title: U.S. Charges Ex-Officer With Aiding an Escape
description: A former state police lieutenant who was acquitted of state charges that he helped two criminally insane killers escape from a psychiatric institution was arraigned here yesterday on Federal charges stemming from the incident.

title: Hong Kong Fears Unraveling of Rule of Law
description: When protesters lay in the street earlier this year to oppose China's plans for the colony and were arrested for doing so, they knew they would be judged under a centuries-old legal system, the common-law tradition of the British colonial government.

title: Tikkanen Cannot Mask His Joy for Scoring Post-Season Goals
description: First there is the ghoulish grin, centerpiece of a face that only a marketer of Halloween masks could love. Even when Esa Tikkanen was a toddler back in Helsinki, Finland, in the late 1960's, his must have been a cat-that-ate-the-canary grin. There is menace behind its delight.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HARRIS, CHRISTOPHER MARC
description: HARRIS-Christopher Marc. On May 2. Cherished son of Joan Madeo Harris and the late Henry C. Harris, beloved brother of Claudia Harris and nephew of Matthew Madeo. Devoted and beloved of Terese Santos. Friends may call at the Frank E. Campbell Funeral Chapel, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81 Street in Manhattan, 6-8 PM, Tuesday, with services at the chapel on Wednesday at noon. Contributions in memory of Terese and Christopher may be made to the Franciscan Friars of the Renewal, 420 East 156 Street, Bronx, NY 10455 or to St. Paul's Evangelical Lutheran Church, 1891 McGraw Avenue, Bronx, New York 10462.

title: Court Overrules Judge in Child Neglect Case
description: A Family Court judge in the Bronx was wrong to dismiss charges of neglect by a mother who officials said believed that her 2-year-old daughter was possessed by the devil, an appeals court ruled yesterday.

title: Easy Going At Hearing For Nominee To the C.I.A.
description: Praising the nation's much-maligned spies and promising to hold them to ''the highest degree of personal integrity,'' George J. Tenet breezed through a short and relatively sweet Senate hearing today on his nomination to be Director of Central Intelligence.

title: 'Drive' and 'Violet' Win Critics' Awards
description: ''How I Learned to Drive,'' Paula Vogel's play about the seduction of a young girl by her uncle, was voted the best new play of the 1996-97 theater season yesterday by the New York Drama Critics Circle.

title: 2 Die in Fume-Filled Garage
description: The license plate holder on the car in the garage read, ''Chris Loves Anne Marie.'' What Raymond Martinez found inside the car when he got home from work Monday night and smelled exhaust fumes were the bodies of his daughter and her boyfriend, who died in what the police say was a double suicide. Autopsies were being performed yesterday on Anne Marie Martinez, 18, and Christopher Peterson, 24, to determine just how they died, said Chief Robert Kugler of the Saddle Brook Police. The couple had been seeing each other for three years, he said.

title: Medicare Rift Becomes Sequel Of Earlier Budget Agreement
description: Just 96 hours after celebrating a bipartisan agreement to balance the Federal budget, Republicans and Democrats started squabbling today over details of the provisions affecting Medicare.

title: G.M. Is Trying to Make a Go Of Its Electric Car
description: It has been five months since General Motors introduced the country's first mass-produced electric vehicle in Southern California and Arizona, and demand is just about what the company said it would be: lackluster at best.

title: Document Lists First Lady as an Inquiry Focus
description: Hillary Rodham Clinton was identified as a central figure in the Whitewater investigation by the independent prosecutor Kenneth W. Starr, who also charged that her sworn testimony had changed over time or differed from that of other witnesses, according to documents unsealed today in a courthouse in Little Rock, Ark.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KWASHA, H. CHARLES
description: KWASHA-H. Charles. The members of the firm of Ash & Parsont express our deepest sorrow at the passing of our esteemed client and dear friend, H. Charles Kwasha. He will be greatly missed. Our heartfelt condolences to his entire family. Joel Ash Allan Ash Neil Ash

title: Theater in Review
description: A Chekhov Play With Lots Of Action (for the Audience)

title: FLUOR PREDICTS LOSS OF $70 MILLION FOR SECOND QUARTER
description: The Fluor Corporation said yesterday that it expected to report a second-quarter loss of $70 million, or 83 cents a share, because of future losses at some power projects and costs associated with cutting jobs and consolidating at its main subsidiary, Fluor Daniel Inc. Analysts had expected the company to earn 75 cents a share, the same as in the quarter a year ago, when it reports earnings on May 21. The loss includes charges totaling $140 million for the restructuring, a cost-reduction program and provisions for possible losses related to two power projects. The company has consolidated or closed 17 of its 80 offices and plans to reduce the number of its operating companies from 24 to 17. The company, based in Irvine, Calif., announced the expected loss after the stock market closed. Earlier, its shares fell $5.625, to $50.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: HOCKEY

title: Stanton Allowed to Go Home
description: Relief pitcher Mike Stanton, who had another inconsistent outing Monday night, has been given permission by the Yankees to return home to Houston to handle a personal matter. The Yankees would not divulge specifics about Stanton's problem, but one club official admitted that it was family-related.

title: INSIDE
description: Mobutu to Leave Zaire

title: Factory Orders Declined 1.6% in March
description: Orders placed with factories fell 1.6 percent in March, the largest decline in seven months, indicating that the manufacturing economy might be cooling.

title: Accounts
description: * Kraft Foods, White Plains, a unit of the Philip Morris Companies, to FCB Direct, New York, a unit of True North Communications, to handle direct marketing for its Gevalia Kaffe business, which had been handled by Wunderman Cato Johnson, New York, a unit of Young & Rubicam. Billings estimated at $10 million.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SMALLWOOD, ARTHUR LEON
description: SMALLWOOD-Arthur Leon. On May 5, 1997. Brother of Percy A. Smallwood, Irene S. Steele and Lauretta V. DeHaney. Dear uncle, relative and friend. Reposing Wednesday 2-6 P.M., at Riverdale-onHudson Funeral Home, 6110 Riverdale Ave. Funeral services Thursday, 10:30 A.M., at Christ Church, Riverdale. Interment is on Saturday at the Lincoln Memorial Cemetery, Washington D.C. In lieu of flowers contributions may be made to Christ Church or your favorite organization.

title: CHRONICLE
description: COLIN L. POWELL, currently the country's premier promoter of volunteerism, does not need to urge his wife, ALMA POWELL, to do her part.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SUKENICK, MARTIN
description: SUKENICK-Martin, former president of Broadway Bank Trust in Paterson, NJ, died March 13, 1997 in Salem, MA. He was 79. Mr. Sukenick joined the bank in 1945 and quickly moved up the ranks to become its vice president, president and in 1968, chairman of the board. He was a key figure in the building of Passaic County Community College and the new elementary school in Clifton, NJ. Surviving are his wife Helen, a daughter, Carol Phillips of Swampscott, MA. and 2 grandchildren, Maddie and Sammy. He was father of the late Leslie Sukenick. Services were held March 18 in Salem, MA.

title: Chicken Strips: Quick, Hot And Tart
description: If you're in a great hurry -- with less than 30 minutes to put a meal together -- the following menu is worth trying. Even without much cutting or chopping, the dishes are loaded with flavor, from the tartness of fruit juices to the sweetness of cherries and brown sugar. Mustard adds a bit of heat.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STONE, J. JACQUES
description: STONE-J. Jacques, on May 6th, in his 90th year. The good times will always be remembered by his wife Janet, by his beloved children Toni & Freeman Shore, and Carol and Alan Pomerantz; and by his adored grandchildren Peter and Julie Strauss & Michael Romano. Services on Thursday, 12 Noon, Central Synagogue, 55th St. and Lexington Ave. For those wishing to make a contribution in his memory, donations to The Stone Family Fund, 22 E. 40th St, NYC 10016, would be appreciated.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STILES, BARBARA
description: STILES-Barbara. We extend our heartfelt condolences to our dear friend, Mr. Nostalgia, Danny Stiles and family upon the loss of their beloved wife and mother. Koved Ihr Undenk. Corey and Rose Breier

title: Clinton and Mexico Chief Pledge Joint Effort on Border and Drugs
description: President Clinton and President Ernesto Zedillo wrapped up two days of meetings today by signing joint statements on managing the border and fighting illegal drugs. They emphasized close cooperation and shared goals but proposed no novel strategies or solutions.

title: Theater in Review
description: Trying to Cast the Spell Of 'Carmen' Without the Music

title: Ex-Cultist Dies In Suicide Pact; 2d Is 'Critical'
description: A former member of the Heaven's Gate cult was found dead today in a copycat suicide in a motel room near the scene of the group's mass suicide in San Diego County, and another former member was found unconscious in the same room, the authorities said.

title: Cutting Welfare Rolls but Raising Questions
description: The welfare rolls are crashing through the floor here.

title: Redefining the Home
description: After my grandparents landed at Ellis Island early in the century, they were welcomed into homes of relatives. No one had much money or space, but so long as a floor was available, they had a roof over their heads. Many people of limited means still help family members this way. But they will have to do it all the more surreptitiously, fearing eviction, if a measure proposed by Congressional Republicans becomes law.

title: CENTURY TELEPHONE SELLS LOCAL EXCHANGE CARRIERS
description: Century Telephone Enterprises Inc. said yesterday that Brooks Fiber Properties Inc. had bought its local exchange carriers for $107 million in stock. Brooks Fiber bought the Century carriers for 4.3 million shares of its stock, which was unchanged yesterday at $25. Century will post a gain of $45 million, or 75 cents a share, on the sale. Shares of Century fell 25 cents, to $30. Brooks Fiber, based in St. Louis, provides telecommunications services in several cities. Century, based in Monroe, La., is the holding company for Universal Telephone Inc., which provides service in the Midwest and South. Brooks Fiber's acquisition will allow it to own fiber optic networks in Texas.

title: Newsweek Recalling Special Issue on Children
description: Newsweek is recalling a special issue of its magazine, titled ''Your Child,'' because it contained a recommendation that parents let their 5-month-olds hand-feed themselves raw carrot chunks and zwieback -- foods that can cause choking in children so young.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KAHN, SHIRLEE
description: KAHN-Shirlee. The leadership and staff of UJA-Federation of New York are profoundly saddened by the passing of Shirlee Kahn, wife of William Kahn, former executive vice president of the Federation of Jewish Philanthropies, a predecessor of UJAFederation. Shirlee was an active partner, with her husband, in providing vision and leadership to the New York Jewish community for many years. Shirlee was a social worker with Westchester Jewish Community Services, a beneficiary of UJA-Federation, where she brought her special expertise in family therapy and marriage counseling. Mr. Kahn served as executive vice president of the Federation from 1981 to 1986. His leadership was crucial in planning and bringing about the merger, in 1986, of the Federation and the United Jewish Appeal of Greater New York. We extend deepest sympathies to Shirlee's husband, Bill, to their four children, 13 grandchildren, and to the entire family. Larry A. Silverstein, Board Chair Louise B. Greilsheimer, President Stephen D. Solender, Exec. V.P.

title: Virgin Group to Sell Two Radio Stations
description: Capital Radio P.L.C. agreed yesterday to buy Virgin Radio Holdings for $:86.7 million ($140.5 million) in stock and assumed debt, giving it two more music radio stations and a bigger share of the London market. Capital, Britain's largest commercial radio company, said Virgin Radio's parent, the privately held Virgin Group, would receive shares in Capital worth $:64.7 million, which amounts to a 14 percent stake in the company. Capital will also take on $:22 million of Virgin Radio's debt.

title: Alan Gussow, 65; Painted and Protected Nature
description: Alan Gussow, an artist and conservationist, died on Monday at his home in Piermont, N.Y. He was 65.

title: Metropolitan Diary
description: DEAR DIARY:

title: Artist With a Local Lens
description: With his death this week at the age of 79, the distinguished columnist Murray Kempton left an enormous void in his craft. Mr. Kempton was as comfortable with Chekhov or Shakespeare as with the police blotter. When he covered the courts, divorce and corruption cases would remind him of plots from the Greek tragedies.

title: Remembering Fiery Fall Of the Airship Hindenburg
description: As the setting sun shot fiery rays through storm clouds that had drenched this vast Lakehurst airship field today, a crowd gathered for a modest remembrance of the destruction of the German airship Hindenburg 60 years ago.

title: Wary Kasparov and Deep Blue Draw Game 3
description: Garry Kasparov, the world chess champion, opened the third game of his six-game match against the I.B.M. computer Deep Blue yesterday in peculiar fashion, by moving his queen's pawn forward a single square. Huh?

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLDBERG, SHIRLEY
description: GOLDBERG-Shirley. Wife of John M. Goldberg. Mother of Perter Goldberg. Died May 6, 1997. Services on Thursday, 1:15 P.M., at ''The Riverside'', 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Theater in Review
description: A Writer at 7, Just as Mother Said

title: Shares of Bre-X Plummet, Becoming Nearly Worthless
description: Stockholders dumped the shares of Bre-X Minerals Ltd. at a blistering rate today, reducing the value of the widely held company to little more than the cost of the paper on which its certificates are printed.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SPELLER, FLORA MAXINE ELLIOTT (NEE WATKINS)
description: SPELLER-Flora Maxine Elliott (nee Watkins), on May 5, 1997, in NYC, age 90. Wife of Robert Speller, President, Robert Speller & Sons, Publishers. Mother of Robert and Jon. Grandmother of Michael & Jon Speller, and Flora Speller Petti. Great-grandmother of Kelly and Katherine Speller, and Courtney, Alexandra, John and Karina Petti. Mrs Speller was born on Oct 25, 1906, in Roseboro, N.C. and was the daughter of the Rev. Daniel Watkins and Louise Patterson Watkins. Mrs. Speller graduated from Louisburg College '26 and Duke Univ., A.B. '32. She was Vice-President and Art Director of Robert Speller & Sons, Publishers. She also had a career as a costume and lingerie designer. She is listed in ''Who's Who of American Women''. Interment will be at Kensico Cemetery, Valhalla, N.Y., on Friday, May 9th, at 1 PM.

title: No Headline
description: ''I don't want to say he's afraid. But when the world champion with the white pieces doesn't want to attack, what do you do?''

title: Japan Stocks, German Views And British Rates Hurt Dollar
description: The dollar fell against most leading currencies yesterday, dragged down by a Japanese stock rally, remarks by a Bundesbank official and a rise in British interest rates.

title: When Math 'Wranglers' Weren't Women
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: An entry in the Addenda listing on the Media Business page on Thursday about two accounts won by Delvico Bates Madrid misidentified the agency's parent company. It is the Bates Worldwide division of Cordiant P.L.C., not Omnicom Group.

title: Rangers Top Devils
description: A goal that was disallowed because a New Jersey player illeaglly entered the goal-crease area deflated the Devils as they lost to the Rangers, 3-2, and fell behind, 2 games to 1, in their hockey playoff showdown. It was the second straight game in which the Devils lost a potential tying goal because of that infraction.

title: Personal Health
description: THERE is hope for the millions of women who worry about getting breast cancer. A fatalistic attitude that either you will get it or you will not is no longer justified. There is fast-growing evidence that simple adjustments in the way one lives can help reduce the risk of developing this increasingly common disease.

title: Zoeller's Real Offense
description: To the Editor:

title: Yankees Join With Adidas in a Lawsuit
description: The Yankees and Adidas sued Major League Baseball in Federal court yesterday for interfering with the implementation of the team's controversial 10-year, $95 million sponsorship that it signed with the footwear company two months ago.

title: Oxford Pays Some Claims
description: Oxford Health Plans Inc. said it is experiencing further delays processing bills and will advance $110 million to appease some New York hospitals with unpaid claims.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HOFFMAN, LYNN MURPHY
description: HOFFMAN-Lynn Murphy, 42, of Manhattan, died Tuesday, May 6. Beloved wife of Bobby. Devoted mother of Ryan, cherished daughter of Edward and Vera Murphy. Sister of Vera, Bunny and Matthew. Aunt of Bethany. Loving daughter-in-law of Carmela Hoffman and sister-in-law of Richard, David, Nancy, John, Thomas, Therese, Derrick and Glenn. Lynn was a graduate of Our Lady of Mercy Academy and Nassau Community College. She was an Emmy-award winning make-up artist for many television shows and commercials and was the principal make-up artist for CBS coverage of the 1992 Olympics in Lillehammer. Lynn worked for many years at WCBS-TV News and leaves many friends. Lynn lived her life with endless enthusiasm. She was passionate about New York, passing on her love of the theatre to Ryan. SHe also was the biggest supporter of Bobby's CYO-Manhattan Youth Baseball League. Visiting hours Thursday, 12-4 and 5-9 at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave. Service Friday at 11:00 AM at St. Ignatius Church, 980 Park Ave. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made in Lynn's name to the Sloan-Kettering Memorial Breast Cancer Unit.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ELLIOTT, ANDREW M.
description: ELLIOTT-Andrew M. of Teaneck, N.J. on May 5, 1997. Beloved husband of Mary. Devoted father of Joann Elliott and Michelle and Jim Tampakis. Visiting at Volk/Leber Funeral Home, 789 Teaneck Road, Teaneck, N.J. on Wednesday 2-4 & 7-9. Funeral Thursday at St. John the Theologian, 353 E. Clinton Avenue, Tenafly, N.J. at 12 PM.

title: A Dissection of Hunger, Metaphysical and Physical
description: EVE'S APPLE

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HOWARD, JOE
description: HOWARD-Joe. On May 5, 1997. Loving father of Emily Joyce. Former husband of Barbara. Beloved of Nan A. Canter. Brother-inlaw and friend of Christine. Uncle of Janice. Service Thursday 12:00 noon at the ''Riverside'', 76 Street & Amsterdam Avenue. Interment at Pinelawn Memorial Park Cemetery, Farmingdale, New York.

title: Silver Offering Landlord Help In Rent Debate
description: Offering the first clear glimpse of his strategy for resolving the bitter debate over state rent laws, Assembly Speaker Sheldon Silver strongly suggested today that he would support increasing government tax abatements and subsidies to landlords in exchange for preserving the rent rules, which the real estate industry has been pushing hard to abolish.

title: Israeli Held In Iran Traffic In Nerve Gas
description: An Israeli businessman has been indicted here on charges of selling ingredients of mustard and nerve gas to Iran from 1990 to 1994.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROSENSHEIN, CAROL JUDITH
description: ROSENSHEIN-Carol Judith. Beloved and devoted wife of Bernard, adored and cherished mother of Lisa, Michele and Julie, daughter of Louis Kane, niece of Sylvia Kahan, mother-in-law of Mark Todes, friend of Maltese Reggie, honored member of her community. Services: Wednesday, May 7, 1997, 1 P.M., at Beth El Synagogue, 1324 North Ave, New Rochelle. Carol was a woman who touched everyone she knew in deep and personal ways. She was uniquely empathetic & generous. Her insight, intelligence, honesty, and sensitivity were evident in all facets of her life. Carol served as Executive Director of the Mamaroneck Beach and Yacht Club for over 15 years. She held a degree in design from the New York Institute of Design, a master's in elementary education from Yeshiva University and a Bachelor of Arts in History from Brandeis University. She will also be remembered for her charitable work with Hadassah, the UJA Federation & the American Cancer Society. With deep sadness and respect, her family & friends will be sitting Shiva at the home she shared with her husband, 35 Kenilworth Rd in Harrison from Wednesday, May 7 through Monday, May 12. Contributions to the Carol J. Rosenshein Memorial Cancer Research Fund at the Albert Einstein College of Medicine are deeply appreciated.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: BELL ATLANTIC CORP., Philadelphia, has agreed to sell its real estate unit, Bell Atlantic Properties, to a fund run by the investment bank Lazard Freres & Co., for undisclosed terms.

title: Hong Kong Phone Shares Rise on Sale Rumor
description: Hong Kong Telecommunications Ltd. staged its biggest rally in six months yesterday on new speculation that its London-based parent, Cable and Wireless P.L.C., will soon sell control to China. Two days before the concern, Hong Kong's largest telephone company, is to report annual profit, its shares rose 85 cents (Hong Kong), or 11 cents (United States), to $14.10 (Hong Kong), or $1.82 (United States).

title: An Auctioneer's Song For a Literary Haven?
description: The Gotham Book Mart, the 77-year-old literary landmark in midtown whose regulars have ranged from the Gershwins to J. D. Salinger and Norman Mailer, is embroiled in a lawsuit that its owner, Andreas Brown, says could put him out of business.

title: Compensate Mr. Manning
description: Bob Manning, who has been waiting 35 years to be compensated for a crippling injury suffered on the job, now has New York's Governor on his side. George Pataki has rightly called Mr. Manning's situation ''a disgrace,'' and the state's Attorney General, Dennis Vacco, agrees. This should be reason enough for the insurance company fighting the case to abandon its miserly interpretation of the law and pay up at last.

title: Disney Played No Role in ABC News Coverage
description: To the Editor:

title: Pentagon Plans to Ask for Closing of More Bases
description: Defense Secretary William S. Cohen will ask Congress to authorize the closing of more military bases to hold down spending by the armed forces, the Pentagon said today.

title: At This Site, Russian Nerds Get Together, Virtually
description: Cafe society never really caught on in Russia. Before the Revolution there was no need for it: serfs were too poor to spend time lounging in taverns or coffee shops. The landed gentry had ornate personal cafes built into their mansions. There was never much of a middle class.

title: Clinton's Good Deed
description: How many political heroes can you name offhand people who put their principles ahead of their lives?

title: Lost Goals Are Bane To Devils
description: Devils Coach Jacques Lemaire has always advocated protecting his goaltender: keep attacking players out of Martin Brodeur's crease.

title: Suspect in 'Megan' Case Made Police Wary
description: In the hours after Megan Kanka was killed, Jesse K. Timmendequas, the man now on trial for her murder, chain smoked, perspired heavily, shook visibly and changed his story, prosecution witnesses testified today.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEISS, SAMUEL
description: WEISS-Samuel. On May 5, 1997. Beloved husband of the late Regina. Loving father of Arline Levine, Andrew Weiss, David Weiss and father-in-law of Ronnie and Marcia. Cherished grandfather of Steven, Shari, Todd, Pamela and Gina, and great-grandfather of Lily, Eli and Joshua. Dear friend of Ann Binder. Services Wednesday, 12 PM, at ''The Riverside,'' 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Racing Career Over for Traitor
description: Traitor, the 3-year-old colt who carried the silks of 84-year-old Alfred Gwynne Vanderbilt and was considered a possible Preakness starter, tore the suspensory ligament in his left foreleg while galloping in Maryland last Thursday and will race no more.

title: At Key Moment, Look for Hardaway
description: He has recovered from major knee surgery in 1993 to regain All-Star status. He has stepped forward to make pressure shots, leading the Miami Heat to the second round of the playoffs.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GURWIN, ROSALIND
description: GURWIN-Rosalind. The Officers, Board and staff of National United Jewish Appeal mourn the passing of Rosalind Gurwin, a committed philanthropist, devoted to Jewish and other causes. With her husband, UJA Trustee and Honorary National Vice Chairman Joseph Gurwin, she offered vision and gave generously of her time and resources, touching the lives of thousands abroad and at home. She will be greatly missed. To her husband, Joseph, their children, Laura Flug, and Eric and Karen Gurwin, grandchildren, and her entire family, we extend our deepest condolences. Richard L. Wexler, UJA National Chairman Richard L. Pearlstone, UJA President Bernard C. Moscovitz, UJA Vice President, Chief Operating Officer

title: CHRONICLE
description: Awards are not always presented in surroundings particularly meaningful to their recipients. But when the Central Park Conservancy Women's Committee gives ELIZABETH BARLOW ROGERS the Frederick Law Olmsted Award today, it will be in a place she knows well: the Conservatory Garden near Fifth Avenue and 105th Street.

title: V, S and L? O Canada!
description: Seldom are Jack Valenti and Edward J. Markey found on the same side of an issue. Mr. Valenti, president of the Motion Picture Association of America, led the industry group that devised the new content-ratings system to help parents screen television shows. Representative Markey, Democrat of Massachusetts, led the fight for V-chip legislation that spurred the industry to develop a rating system.

title: After Collecting 20 Hits, Mets Still Fall One Short
description: Coors Field is a shrine to offensive baseball, and today, the Mets and Rockies hitters honored their gods. Their sacrificial offering: pitchers.

title: Continental Ponders Consolidated Account
description: Continental Airlines Inc. has placed its worldwide account in review and is considering a consolidation. The account, with billings estimated at $50 million, is now handled by more than 10 agencies, including the Richards Group in Dallas, which has handled the $30 million domestic part of it since 1993.

title: Parking Rules
description: Because of Ascension Thursday, alternate-side street-cleaning regulations will be suspended in New York City tomorrow. Other regulations will remain in effect.

title: Politics, Better Sex, Whatever, Can We Talk?
description: ''The History of Talk Radio'' is a once-over-gently review of yakkers from Barry Gray, whom you may not remember, to Oliver North, whom you may prefer to forget. Unlike such merchants, who peddle opinions about everything at the flick of a switch, the Bravo producers soft-pedal whatever opinions they may have about the talk-radio flea market. This ''history'' is mainly a gallery of personalities with labels attached.

title: Regents Test Proposal Is Divisive and Unsound
description: To the Editor:

title: CHRONICLE
description: ERIC DOUGLAS, the youngest of the actor Kirk Douglas's four sons, pleaded guilty on Monday to accepting a package containing 1,085 antidepressant pills last year and was sentenced to 10 days of community service.

title: Poppe Tyson Names a New Chief
description: Poppe Tyson Inc. in New York, the integrated marketing and communications unit of Bozell, Jacobs, Kenyon & Eckhardt that has struggled in recent months, said yesterday that it had named Kevin C. Clark, 36, a member of the agency's executive committee and a director, to succeed Fergus O'Daly, 53, as president and chief executive. Mr. O'Daly, who held those posts for six years and was a co-founder of the agency, will continue as chairman but will report to Mr. Clark.

title: Egypt Condemns Persecution of Its Copts
description: To the Editor:

title: 20 Times '60'
description: If television fans were to guess what show has finished most often in the ratings Top 10, some obvious candidates would come to mind: ''M.A.S.H.,'' ''Dallas,'' perhaps ''Cheers.'' Or, further back, maybe ''I Love Lucy'' or ''Gunsmoke.''

title: Fierce Winds Whirl In, Stealing Roofs in Path
description: Furious, brick-busting winds -- which some witnesses said looked like a tornado -- twisted down over Jersey City and Staten Island yesterday afternoon, uprooting trees, whipping up garbage cans and ripping off roofs, one of which whizzed across a block before it smashed down onto three empty cars.

title: Divorcing Central Banks and Politics: Independence Helps in Inflation Fight
description: In granting more independence to the Bank of England, the new British Government is a late entrant in a trend that has seen nations give increasing autonomy to their central banks, distancing monetary policy from direct political control. The practice has spread across the globe in response to demands from investors in financial markets for proof that governments will remain committed to inflation-fighting.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BRETT, MARY B.
description: BRETT-Mary B., 71, of East Hampton, N.Y. and Vero Beach, Florida. Widow of Philip M. Brett and H. Lawrence Pool. Mother of Katharine B. Schmidt of Fairfield, Ct., W. Henry Pool of Greenwich, CT., and James L. S. Pool of Sherborn, MA. Sister of Hermann C. Schwab, Ruth S. Galpin and Walter P.B. Schwab, and half-sister of Anne Corcos. Grandmother of nine. Died of cancer at Vero Beach, May 6, 1997. Services at East Hampton to be scheduled.

title: Pitino Moves On to His Next Fixer-Upper: Celtics
description: There is a search-and-rescue part of Rick Pitino, a slice of his fluorescent personality that seems attracted to crestfallen basketball programs. He sees the shambles of a great, heroic past and wants to put the pieces back together again. Pitino has always been this way as he reversed fortunes at Providence College, the New York Knicks and the University of Kentucky.

title: Gender Gap in Testing Narrower Than Believed, Study Finds
description: An ambitious study of the differences in how well girls and boys perform on tests has found much less of a gender gap than is commonly assumed.

title: J. Walter Thompson Shuffles Managers
description: The New York and San Francisco offices of the J. Walter Thompson Company unit of WPP Group announced a series of management changes.

title: British Petroleum Posts 19.3% Profit Gain
description: The British Petroleum Company posted a stronger-than-expected 19.3 percent rise yesterday in first-quarter profit, reflecting higher oil prices and cost-cutting efforts. The concern said profit before one-time items rose to a first-quarter record $:755 million ($1.22 billion) from $:633 million a year ago.

title: Ad for Teacher Worked
description: Avalon school officials said they had counted on a heavy response to the advertisement they ran in early April for an opening in their elementary teaching staff, but they had not expected to be inundated. The district received nearly 300 applications for the job, with 17 pounds of paperwork, the schools superintendent said.

title: Feldman Elected Head of National Teachers Union
description: Just minutes after being elected president of the 940,000-member American Federation of Teachers, Sandra Feldman made clear today in her spirited style that she had multiple missions, not just to raise teachers' pay but to improve public education and defend it against its attackers.

title: Making Old Offices New Hotel Space
description: With occupancy rates near record levels and with room rates up almost 11 percent since last year, developers are scrambling to bring new hotel rooms to market, particularly in Manhattan. Since there are few vacant building sites available, most of the focus in the recent past has been on upgrading existing properties, such as Gotham Hospitality Group's renovation of five small hotels in midtown and on the Upper East Side.

title: GILLETTE PLANS TO CUT 1,700 JOBS IN RESTRUCTURING
description: The Gillette Company plans to cut about 1,700 jobs as it eliminates duplicated operations after its acquisition of Duracell International Inc. The maker of Gillette razors, Braun household appliances and Duracell batteries had eliminated 119 of the targeted jobs as of March 31, the company said in a quarterly filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission.
