It expects to make the cuts through dismissals and attrition, mostly from international operations, a company spokesman said yesterday. Gillette, based in Boston, took a fourth-quarter charge of $283 million for expected restructuring costs and other expenses associated with the Duracell acquisition.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ADELSON, ROTH, BECKY
description: ADELSON-ROTH-Becky. On May 6, 1997. Beloved wife of Bernard Roth and the late Edward T. Adelson, loving mother of Marcia and Jonathan, cherished grandmother of Marisa Erin, Eliza Sara, Daniel Everett and Arielle Rebecca. Dear sister of Sadie Altstein. Services Thursday, 12:15 PM, at ''ParkwestRiverside'', 333 Amsterdam Ave.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  EDELMAN, DAVID
description: EDELMAN-David on May 6, 1997. Survived by his beloved wife Ruth (Gidden), loving son James and caring sister Evelyn Friedman. Passed away after a long illness. Retired partner of BDO Seidman. Services Thursday, May 8 at 2:30PM at ''The Riverside'', 76 St & Amsterdam Ave. Donations may be made to Women's Division, American Society for Technion.

title: Officials Defend Calling a Fire-Damaged Building 'Stable' Hours Before It Collapsed
description: As demolition crews cleared the wreckage of a cluster of buildings that collapsed Monday night after a stubborn fire in midtown Manhattan, officials at the City Buildings Department yesterday defended their initial assessment that one of the fire-ravaged building was ''stable'' three hours before they began crumbling.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KOLBRENER, FRANCES
description: KOLBRENER-Frances. Temple Israel, Lawrence, NY, mourns the loss of its devoted congregant and extends deepest sympathy to his family. Brooks R. Susman, Rabbi Jeffrey Scherr, President

title: Andrews Gains Backing
description: On the eve of a televised debate among the three candidates for the Democratic gubernatorial nomination, one of them, United States Representative Robert E. Andrews, picked up the support of the state's largest environmental group. The New Jersey Environmental Federation gave Mr. Andrews, of Haddon Heights, an ''A'' and described him as the ''clear choice'' among the three candidates, said Jane Nogaki, a board member.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HYATT, JAMES P.
description: HYATT-James P. At home, May 3, 1997. Husband of Alice, father of Keith, brother of Pamela. Second generation owner of Air & Marine Travel Service, established 1931 by Thaddeus. May 9, 3 PM, at St. Michael's Church, 225 West 99 Street, NYC. Contributions to Cancer Care, in lieu of flowers.

title: Balanced-Budget Plan
description: To the Editor:

title: Auto Union And Chrysler Reach Deal To End Strike
description: Top negotiators from the United Automobile Workers union and the Chrysler Corporation have reached an agreement to end a costly engine factory strike that has shut down the company's production of pickups and Jeep Grand Cherokees for nearly a month, people close to the talks said today.

title: UJA Nominates a Chief With Link to Cigarettes
description: James S. Tisch, whose corporation owns the Lorillard Tobacco Company, has been nominated to head the UJA-Federation of New York, the nation's leading Jewish charity, despite protests from several prominent Reform rabbis, Jewish leaders and anti-smoking groups.

title: NATO and Russians Make Some Progress on Expansion Charter
description: Negotiators for NATO and Russia said tonight that they had made some progress in Luxembourg toward an accord on a security charter to govern their relations after the alliance expands eastward, but not enough to sign a deal.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GATHERAL, SABINA ROBINSON
description: GATHERAL - Sabina Robinson. After a long illness, on May 5, 1997 in Falmouth, MA. Beloved wife of the late William. Loving mother of Robbie O'Hara and Peggy McGarrahan. Grandmother of Sabina, Ellen, Sally, Katie, Mary, Jennie, Maggie and Peter. Great grandmother of Jack. Sister of Henry S. Robinson. Mass of Christian Burial at the Church of Saint Thomas More, 65 East 89 Street, NYC, 1PM Saturday, May 10. In lieu of flowers, contributions to the Society of Helpers, 385 West 263 St, Bronx, NY 10471, would be appreciated.

title: BRITAIN SHIFTING MONETARY POLICY TO CENTRAL BANK
description: Britain's newly elected Labor Government, signaling a historic change in economic policy, granted control over interest rates to the central bank today, a move that cheered its opposition, European leaders and financial executives, some of whom had been skeptical of Labor's resolve.

title: Giuliani Says the Next Budget Includes Package of Tax Cuts
description: Laying a cornerstone for his re-election campaign, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani said yesterday that his next budget would include a new package of tax cuts for New York City residents.

title: S.E.C. BEGINS FORMAL INVESTIGATION OF NINE WEST
description: Nine West Group Inc. said yesterday that the Securities and Exchange Commission had started a formal investigation of company policies for recording revenue. Nine West shares fell $7.125, to $32.50, before being halted because of an order imbalance. The company, based in Stamford, Conn., makes and sells women's shoes and accessories with brands including Nine West and Easy Spirit. The formal order turns the investigation into the company's revenue recognition policies and practices up a notch from an informal inquiry by the S.E.C. Under a formal investigation, the S.E.C. has the authority to subpoena documents. The S.E.C. entered a formal order of investigation on April 10, according to a Federal filing yesterday. Nine West said in the filing that it planned to cooperate with the formal inquiry.

title: An Auteur Who Defies Hollywood And Lives
description: Robert Levin wasted little time calling his first meeting last fall after joining Sony Pictures Entertainment as its new president of worldwide marketing. The natural topic was plans for one of the studio's biggest-budget summer films, ''The Fifth Element,'' which opens the Cannes Film Festival tonight and arrives in American theaters on Friday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SULLIVAN, MAE V.
description: SULLIVAN-Mae V. On May 6, 1997. Retired Principal of P.S. 11 Queens and P.S. 171 Queens. Beloved mother of Joan F. Sullivan and John B. Sullivan. Visiting hours at Krtil Funeral Home, 1287 First Ave. (69-70 St.), Thursday, May 8th, 2-5PM and 7-9PM. Funeral service at the Chapel in Mary Manning Walsh Home, 1339 York Ave. (71-72 St.), Fri., May 9th. Viewing 9AM and Mass at 9:30AM.

title: Swissair Celebrates Trans-Atlantic Flight
description: Celebrating 50 years of trans-Atlantic service, Swissair brought a vintage DC-4 aircraft to Kennedy International Airport yesterday. The plane carried 34 passengers who had left Switzerland on Friday and flown a total of 25 hours, stopping in Shannon, Ireland, and Gander, Newfoundland.

title: Crawfish Wars: Cajun Country Vs. China
description: THEY glisten, boiled bright red, heaps and heaps of spiced whole crawfish spread across a dinner table deep in the heart of Cajun country. It's a weeknight at Dwight Landreneau's house, not a weekend, but zydeco music fills the room, and someone has popped open a beer.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KEMPTON, MURRAY
description: KEMPTON-Murray. On May 5th, 1997. Service Thursday, May 8th, 11 AM, at St. Ignatius of Antioch, 87th St. at West End Ave. Friends are invited to offer a contribution in his memory to a charity of their choice, in lieu of flowers.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOODKIND, ROBERT H.
description: GOODKIND-Robert H. May 4, 1997. Beloved husband of Irene, father of Thomas and James and Patricia French, brother of Richard and grandfather of four. Contributions to Renaissance Village Inc., for At Risk Youth, 11380 Prosperity Farms Road, Suite 209A, Palm Beach Gardens, FL. 33410, Phone 561-776-0890.

title: Open-Ended Program
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DOLGENOS, DAVID
description: DOLGENOS-David, on May 6th, 1997. Husband of Nancy Dunbar; father of Peter, Peggy, Carey, and Tom. Step-father of Jennie and Gabe. Survived also by Sally Ashley. Grandfather of Jake, Annika, and Kate. Father-in-law of Chris Neklason, Sarah Ricks and Luca Padulli. Service Thursday, May 8, 3:30 P.M., at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st St.

title: Eating Well
description: THE five-a-day program, designed by the National Cancer Institute to encourage people to eat five fruits and vegetables a day, is so far removed from the reality of what most children eat that its creators may need to go back to the drawing board and produce something more realistic. That's the only conclusion that can be drawn from reading a week's worth of dietary diary records that were kept by 87 students in three schools on Long Island and one in Brooklyn.

title: News Summary
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-15

title: An Unjustified Claim of Privilege
description: A Federal appeals court has ordered White House lawyers to turn over notes of conversations they had with First Lady Hillary Rodham Clinton to the Whitewater Independent Counsel, Kenneth Starr, thereby igniting a debate over whether government lawyers can withhold information from criminal investigators under a claim of attorney-client privilege. The White House plans to appeal, potentially setting the stage for a Supreme Court showdown over the issue.

title: Arafat and Israeli President Hold Talks on Security Cooperation
description: On the eve of a new attempt by the American mediator to get Israelis and Palestinians talking again, President Ezer Weizman of Israel met with Yasir Arafat today and declared that the Palestinian leader had agreed to revive security cooperation with Israel.

title: Theater in Review
description: Silent Stars Come to Life In a Tribute by Students

title: Man, woman, garden, snake. . . . What else is this but a campaign for a superpremium tequila?
description: THERE are no pictures of glamorous women or men in tuxedos sipping drinks in a new campaign for the tequila Tres Generaciones. Instead, Domecq Importers, which distributes the brand in the United States, is sponsoring a photography exhibition with subtle references to the mystique of tequila and its origin in the area around Guadalajara along Mexico's Pacific coast.

title: Overdue Fame For Preserving That Rhythm
description: IT don't mean a thing if nobody hears you swing. That's not in the Harlem Blues and Jazz Band's repertoire. It's in their hearts. Surely, Duke Ellington wouldn't mind their improvising on his classic. Some of these octogenarians played with him, after all, as well as with Louis Armstrong, Count Basie and Fats Waller.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LIPPER, GEORGE
description: LIPPER-George. The American Friends of Bar-Ilan University mourn the passing of George Lipper, father of our esteemed benefactor, Kenneth Lipper and extend to him and his beloved wife, Dr. Evelyn Gruss, as well as their gifted children, our sincerest condolences. We pray that they will derive solace from inspiring memories and continue their philanthropy for the welfare of our people and all vital humanitarian causes. Rabbi Emanuel Rackman, Chancellor Bar-Ilan University Jane Stern Lebell, President American Friends Brig. Gen. (RES) Yehuda Halevy, Executive V.P.

title: Brokerage Pays $750,000 in Harassment Case
description: In one of the largest settlements stemming from a Federal investigation into sexual harassment in the workplace, the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission said yesterday that Gruntal & Company, the Manhattan brokerage firm, has agreed to pay $750,000 to six current and former female employees.

title: Veteran Governor to Have Freer Invisible Hand on Rate Policy
description: It's Eddie's show now.

title: Celtics Land Pitino
description: Rick Pitino has joined the growing list of salary superstars who don't have to dunk, hit home runs or score touchdowns. Pitino, who revived the basketball program at the University of Kentucky, where he won a national championship, accepted a record $70-million, 10-year offer from the Boston Celtics. The contract makes him the highest-paid coach in sports.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CARMALT, WOOLSEY
description: CARMALT-Woolsey, on Saturday, May 3, 1997. Beloved husband of Sarah R. Carmalt. Father of Samuel W., Charles R., and William S. Carmalt and Anne C. Stokes. He is also survived by 9 grandchildren. Memorial services will be held at St. John's ChurchLafayette Square, 1525 H Street N.W., Washington, DC, Saturday, May 10, 11 AM. Interment private. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to the International Student House, 1825 R Street NW, Washington, DC 20009 or a charity of your choice.

title: Messier Makes the Call, and Devils Lose the Game
description: Rules are made to be obeyed. Rules rule. But one of them is creating plenty of anguished debate this spring in the Stanley Cup playoffs, especially when it is applied to the Devils.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KEMP, ETHEL DICKSTEIN
description: KEMP-Ethel Dickstein, on May 6, 1997. Beloved wife of the late Henry, devoted mother of Joan and Bruce and daughter-in-law Barbara, cherished grandmother of Wendy and Charles. Services Thursday, 11:30AM at ''The Riverside'', 76 St. and Amsterdam Ave.

title: Corrections
description: A concert listing on Sunday in the Arts and Leisure Guide misidentified the Manhattan church that is to present ''The Bach Family: An Intimate Portrait'' at 8 P.M. on Friday. It is Holy Trinity Lutheran Church, at Central Park West and 65th Street (not the Church of the Holy Trinity).

title: Game 3 Rhythm Segues From Sinatra to Gretzky to the Crease
description: AS the Rangers and Devils circled and slid to a stop before the opening face-off last night, Frank Sinatra's voice suddenly thundered through Madison Square Garden.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MARSHALL, ALLAN S.
description: MARSHALL-Allan S., of Glen Rock, New Jersey, on May 6, 1997. Beloved husband of Joan L. Marshall. Devoted father of Robert M. Marshall and Sally A. Schwartz. Loving grandfather of Harris S. Marshall. Funeral service are at 12:00 P.M., May 7, 1997. Robert Schoem Menorah Chapel, 150 Route 4 East, Paramus, N.J.

title: Court Rules Against Hasidic School Plan
description: The eight-year effort by the state's elected leaders to accommodate a small Catskills community of religious Jews by giving them their own school district for handicapped children foundered again today as the state's highest court ruled it unconstitutional for a second time.

title: TCW GROUP TO REMAIN PRIVATE MONEY MANAGEMENT FIRM
description: TCW Group Inc., a money management firm in Los Angeles with more than $50 billion in assets, is no longer for sale. TCW's chairman and chief executive, Robert Day, wrote yesterday in a letter to the firm's 1,200 clients that TCW would ''continue as an independent, privately owned company.'' Mr. Day disclosed in October that TCW was considering a sale. Analysts had estimated TCW would bring $800 million in a sale. TCW is best known for its aggressively managed fixed-income and emerging markets funds.

title: A Fourth Chicago Alderman Is Indicted on Charges of Corruption
description: This city's long parade from the halls of local government to Federal court got a little longer today when, for the fourth time in 17 months, a member of the City Council was indicted on corruption charges.

title: Threats Are a Price For Backing Gun Control
description: Representative Carolyn McCarthy said yesterday that her continued support for stronger gun-control laws had brought threats serious enough to require police protection during most public appearances.

title: Adidas Says Profits Jumped 33% in Quarter
description: The German sports-equipment maker Adidas A.G. said yesterday that its profit jumped 33 percent in the first quarter, to 169 million German marks ($97.5 million), from 127 million marks a year earlier on booming sales for clothing and sports shoes. Sales rose 42.5 percent, to 1.71 billion marks, from 1.2 billion marks a year earlier; shoe sales rose 32 percent, to 785 million marks. Pretax profit soared 42 percent, to 243 million marks, well above the 235 million marks the company had forecast last month.

title: France's Prime Minister Stumps, but Where's That Elan?
description: Prime Minister Alain Juppe's re-election campaign theme is ''A new elan for France.'' His campaign here needed so much more elan, or maybe even artificial respiration, that President Jacques Chirac let it be known that he would give a helping hand.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: Baseball

title: Chocolates for Mother's and Art's Sake
description: AMONG the more charming and delicious possibilities for a Mother's Day gift are chocolates covered with children's designs from Richart, the French chocolate shop at 7 East 55th Street. The square, filled chocolates, on which children's drawings have been silk-screened, come in boxes of 16 pieces for $25 and 27 pieces for $45. The whimsical drawings of people, animals, boats, trees and even cable cars were done by French children in a contest the company held three years ago.

title: Korean Lust After Cures Is a Threat To Species
description: As a pharmacist measured the clumps of grass and crushed stems on the table, Park Sun Yeop, 29, kept turning to one item not yet on the pile: the budding antler of a deer.

title: Tyranny or Democracy in Zaire?
description: As Laurent Kabila and his guerrilla army close in on Zaire's capital and victory, the outside world has an important role to play. Western and African governments helped to persuade Zaire's dictator of 31 years, Mobutu Sese Seko, to announce he would leave for Gabon today, thus reducing the possibility of bloodshed during the last days of the guerrilla campaign. But his departure probably means that Mr. Kabila will take power alone and unchecked. African and world leaders must press him to govern democratically.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOURDJI, NADJI
description: GOURDJI-Nadji. Great Neck Synagogue notes with sorrow the passing of its esteemed member and extends its condolences to the entire bereaved family. Dale Polakoff, Rabbi Dr. Ephraim Wolf, Rabbi Emeritus David Werber, President

title: Corporate Cooperation
description: To the Editor:

title: David Scherman, 81, Editor Whose Photos Sank a Ship
description: David E. Scherman, an editor and photojournalist who survived the sinking of an ocean liner by a Nazi warship disguised as a merchant vessel before the outbreak of World War II, and whose photos from a lifeboat enabled the British Navy to track down the German ship and sink it, died on Monday at his home in Stony Point, N.Y. He was 81.

title: INSIDE METRO
description: DISPUTE OVER NOMINEE -- The UJA-Federation of New York is being urged not to choose James S. Tisch as its president because of his ties to the tobacco industry. B3.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BARTNOFF, RABBI DEVORA
description: BARTNOFF-Rabbi Devora. The Conference of Presidents expresses sincerest condolences to our distinguished colleague, Rabbi Mordechai Liebling, and his children, on the untimely loss of their beloved wife and mother. We pray that he and his family will be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Leon Levy, Chairman Malcolm Hoenlein, Executive Vice Chairman

title: This Coach Has Earned His Control
description: RICK PITINO is 45 years old and has never failed at coaching basketball. He put one more championship banner in the gym at the University of Kentucky, and his next standard for success is at least one more championship banner in the Boston Celtics' gym.

title: Robbins & Myers in Deal
description: Robbins & Myers Inc. has acquired Industrie Tycon S.p.A., an Italian maker of glass-lined reactor and storage vessels. Financial terms of the transaction were not disclosed. Industrie Tycon has annual sales of about $20 million. Robbins & Myers, of Dayton, Ohio, reported sales of $351 million in 1996.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  FINCK, FURMAN AND MILDRED
description: FINCK-Furman and Mildred. Memorial celebration Friday, May 9, 1997, 4-6 PM, Players, 16 Gramercy Park South, NYC. In lieu of flowwers, contributions gratefully accepted to DuCret School of the Arts, 1030 Central Ave, Plainfield NJ 07060 or National Academy of Design, 5 E. 89 St, NYC 10128.

title: Military Ends Conflict Of Career and Religion
description: As a Navajo, Staff Sgt. Shawn Arnold always had trouble reconciling his Marine Corps career with his religion, whose ancient rituals clashed with military anti-drug policy.

title: AETNA INC. (AET,N)
description: Aetna Inc. reported first-quarter earnings yesterday that were better than expected, and its stock surged.

title: When Math 'Wranglers' Weren't Women
description: To the Editor:

title: Happy in Free Fall
description: So how weird is this? The Clinton Presidency that began with such grandiose designs has become so becalmed, so shrunken, so defeated, so aimless, so anomic, so technical that George Bush now looms as a giant who bestrode the earth.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MOLINARI, ATTILIO (TED)
description: MOLINARI-Attilio (Ted). Former Maitre D' of the Plaza Hotel. Beloved husband of the late Antoinette (nee Matthews). Loving father of Robert P. Fond father-inlaw of Gale. Adored brother of Mario, Anna, Josephine Cipriani and the late Angelo. Reposing at Perazzo Funeral Home, 199 Bleecker Street, New York City, Wednesday 7PM to 9:30PM, Thursday 2PM-5PM and 7PM-9:30PM. Funeral Mass Friday 9:30AM, Our Lady of Pompei Church. Entombment, St. John's Cloister. In lieu of flowers, donations to Calvary Hospital, 1740 Eastchester Road, Bronx, NY, would be appreciated.

title: Who Needs a Conductor?
description: It would be easy to take Orpheus for granted. When it was founded, this chamber orchestra's claim to attention was its resolute refusal to work with a conductor, an approach that was both daring and endearing. There was considerable novelty in the way its interpretations, though shaped by consensus, seemed to have both a personal touch and all the polish and precision one expects of a conducted ensemble.

title: Eisner Wins Lottery Account in Maryland
description: The Maryland State Lottery yesterday named Eisner & Associates in Baltimore to handle its account, with billings estimated at $60 million over a five-year contract. The account had been handled by Trahan, Burden & Charles in Baltimore. Eisner won it after a five-month mandated review that also included Trahan, Burden and two other Baltimore agencies: Gray Kirk/VanSant and Richardson, Myers & Donofrio.

title: Spider-Man, Fighting Evil, Gets Help From Giuliani
description: In his titanic struggle with the menacing mummy known as Tut Ammon, Spider-Man has turned to a fellow crime fighter whose name inspires fear in the hearts of criminals: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani.

title: Springer In, Priests Out
description: Jerry Springer's career as a local television news commentator continued to produce protest at a Chicago television station yesterday, as two Roman Catholic priests, including the Rev. Andrew Greeley, the best-selling author, notified the station that they would not participate as planned in its coverage of the installation today of the Rev. Francis George as the new Archbishop of Chicago.

title: Claims by Eurotunnel Rejected by Panel
description: A British-French panel set up to address disputes between Eurotunnel and its consortium of contractors, Trans Manche Link, ruled yesterday that ''a large number'' of Eurotunnel's claims were inadmissible. The panel said that Eurotunnel was entitled to damages for deficiencies in some of the rolling stock, but it rejected demands relating to losses in revenue. The panel also ruled a counterclaim by Trans Manche Link inadmissible.

title: Parent Volunteers Help Affluent Schools Fill Needs
description: All the attempts by a succession of governors to equalize educational programs in New Jersey's richest and poorest school districts -- including Gov. Christine Todd Whitman's new statewide curriculum standards -- never factored in people like Linda McCabe.

title: Six Children Die in a Fire In Passaic
description: Six young children, all members of an extended family, were killed last night in Passaic, N.J., by a tempestuous blaze that tore through their three-story wood-frame apartment house, apparently trapping them at play on the top floor, the police and witnesses said.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  MONROE, SYLVIA (FOXTOW)
description: MONROE-Sylvia (Foxtow). My beautiful war bride, how we danced with love lights in our eyes under twinkling stars on our 54th year. Barbara, Eric, Scott and Harold

title: Suit Against Gun Maker Is Dismissed by Judge
description: A state court judge here today dismissed a lawsuit against the manufacturer of the guns used by a deranged gunman in a 1993 shooting spree that killed eight people and wounded six others.

title: SOUTHERN NATIONAL TO ACQUIRE VIRGINIA FIRST FINANCIAL
description: The Southern National Corporation said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire the Virginia First Financial Corporation for $148 million. Under the agreement, Southern National will pay six-tenths of one of its shares for each Virginia First share. Shares of Virginia First rose $8, or 58 percent, to $21.75, in Nasdaq trading. Shares of Southern National fell 12.5 cents, to $40.50, on the New York Stock Exchange. The acquisition will give Southern National, based in Winston-Salem, N.C., assets of $2 billion and deposits in Virginia of $1.5 billion. Virginia First, based in Petersburg, Va., has assets of $817 million.

title: 2 Phone Companies Deny Report on 10,000 Job Cuts
description: The merger of Bell Atlantic and Nynex may produce $200 million more in cost savings than the two phone companies predicted when they announced the $22 billion deal last year. But the companies denied a report yesterday that they planned to lay off 10,000 employees within five years.

title: U.S. Petroleum Data
description: In millions of barrels except refinery utilization

title: ESPN Punishes Olbermann
description: KEITH OLBERMANN's absence since last week from ESPN's ''Sportscenter'' can now be explained: management ordered him off for two weeks, partly to punish him for promoting his new book last month on Comedy Central's program ''The Daily Show,'' whose host, CRAIG KILBORN, formerly worked on ''Sportscenter.''

title: S.&L. Merger Battle Has a Flair for the Petty
description: When media moguls or even railroad barons clash over takeovers, they seem to produce grand battles of ego and ambition. Now the nation's two largest savings and loan institutions have awakened from their languorous ways to fight over the third largest, the Great Western Financial Corporation, but the conflict has all the pettiness of a schoolyard brawl.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BLUM, JEAN S.
description: BLUM-Jean S. Age 76. Died at home May 6, 1997 of cancer. Beloved wife of the late Milton. Devoted mother of Wendy and Andrea Blum. She also leaves her brother Steven Sheinhouse, her aunt Peggy Sprung, her sister-inlaw Jeanne K. Blum and many devoted friends. Her courageous spirit and good humor was an inspiration to us all. Memorial service at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue, Friday, May 9th, 2 P.M. Contributions may be made to Central Synagogue Program for the Homeless or Cabrini Hospice.

title: How a Taste for the Offbeat Led to an Institution
description: Forty years ago, an ordinary looking guy from Jackson, Mich., walked onto a small stage in a Manhattan NBC studio and almost single-handedly created the astonishingly successful genre of late-night television.

title: Burglary Charges for Officers
description: Four Irvington police officers suspected of running a burglary ring were arrested yesterday in a sting operation run by the state police, the authorities said.

title: 10 in U.S. Win Churchill Scholarships
description: Ten American college students have been awarded scholarships by the Winston Churchill Foundation for graduate study in engineering, mathematics and the sciences at Churchill College, Cambridge University.

title: Hawks Miss a Chance, And the Bulls Escape
description: Both the Bulls and the Hawks had the best and the worst of all possible worlds tonight. Both had excuses why they should be playing well or poorly in this first game of their second-round playoff series at the United Center.

title: Get Physical: Knicks and Heat Ready
description: The coaches wished each other luck over the phone around 6:30 this morning. In post-season parlance, their conversation was the calm before Game 1.

title: Bond Prices Drop Slightly For 2d Day
description: The prices of Treasury securities were slightly lower for a second day yesterday, as the market had difficulty absorbing the first of two legs of the Government's quarterly debt refunding this week.

title: Barbados, All Business, Awaits Clinton
description: According to the map and the tourist brochures, this is the easternmost country in the Caribbean. But when Bill Clinton and his staff arrive here on May 9 for two days of meetings with the Prime Ministers of the English-speaking Caribbean, they will be landing in a place that is not really interested in providing the easygoing, fun-in-the-sun atmosphere for which the region is known.

title: 21 Face Drug Charges Involving Midtown Hotel
description: Federal prosecutors have charged 21 people with turning a single-room occupancy hotel in midtown Manhattan into a ''stash house'' to sell crack, cocaine and heroin, using as a weapon a law that increases penalties for selling drugs near schools.

title: Were Pollen And Allergies A Problem In Eden, Too?
description: LISTENING to Jessye Norman's gasp of pleasure upon seeing an enormous pink azalea at the New York Botanical Garden last week, you would never have guessed that she is allergic to most flowers.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHAPIRO, LILLIAN
description: SHAPIRO-Lillian. The Retail, Wholesale and Department Store Union mourns the loss of Lillian Shapiro, beloved mother of our President, Lenore Miller, and Barbara Sachs; beloved grandmother of Jessica Miller and Richard Sachs. She was a great friend of our Union and we will miss her. Retail, Wholesale and Department Store Union, AFL-CIO, CLC Stuart Appelbaum, Secretary-Treasurer

title: 3,100 Gallons of Good Beer Down a Drain
description: THE morning Kirby Shyer poured 3,100 gallons of good beer down the drain was the morning he stopped worrying about the competition. Mr. Shyer was the owner of the Zip City brew pub, which closed on April 6 after a year of bad business and nearly six years of success. Zip City had been the city's oldest working brew pub and an inspiration for more than two-dozen competitors, with about six of them having opened within the last year.

title: Funeral for Kempton
description: A funeral service for Murray Kempton, the Pulitzer Prize-winning newspaper columnist who died of heart failure at age 79 on Monday, has been scheduled for tomorrow at 11 A.M. at St. Ignatius Episcopal Church, 522 West End Avenue, at 87th Street.

title: California to Let Small Customers Pick Their Power Suppliers in '98
description: California regulators said yesterday that they would speed up a plan to allow utility customers to buy electricity from any supplier of their choosing by 1998.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BORNEMANN, HELLEN
description: BORNEMANN-Hellen. The people of Saint Peter's Lutheran Church are deeply saddened by the untimely death of our beloved friend and co-worker Hellen Bornemann this past Thursday morning, May 1. Hellen is survived by her son, Paul, her daughter-in-law, Heather, her grandsons, Zachary and Alexander, and of course, the family of Saint Peter's. A Memorial Eucharist and Inurnment in thanksgiving for Hellen's life and gifts will be held on Saturday, May 10, at 6:00 P.M. with a reception to follow. Donations may be made to Saint Peter's Church, 619 Lexington Ave, NY, NY, 10022 in memory of Hellen.

title: Food Notes
description: A U.S. Cookbook by Sheila Lukins

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHAPIRO, BERNIE
description: SHAPIRO-Bernie, passed away Monday evening. He was a graduate of the United States Coast Guard Academy who served his nation well and thereafter entered the business world. He founded Polaris Plastics Corp. which was sold to Ashland Oil Company in 1970 and thereafter organized Rhodes Plastics Corp. which was sold to Dutch Boy (Artra) in the late 1970's. He is survived by his sister, Dorothy Garbus, his brother, Stanley Shapiro, four nephews and one niece. Services will be held Wednesday, May 7 at 11:00 A.M. at Riverside Memorial Chapel, between 75th and 76th Street on Amsterdam Avenue, New York. Persons wishing to make contributions in his memory should transmit these to Dr. Gavril Pasternak, Department of Neurology, Memorial Sloan Kettering Cancer Center, 1275 York Avenue, New York, NY 10021.

title: Marriott International is switching to a much broader reward program for its frequent guests.
description: WITH frequent-travel awards practically a second national currency, Marriott International is scrapping its popular 14-year-old Honored Guest Awards program and starting a much broader one called Marriott Rewards.

title: McVeigh's Sister Tells Why She Aided U.S. Case Against Him
description: Under cross-examination by her brother's lawyer, Jennifer McVeigh explained today why she agreed to tell agents for the Federal Bureau of Investigation what she knew about Timothy J. McVeigh and the Oklahoma City bombing.

title: Officer Cleared in Death
description: An Essex County grand jury cleared a Newark police officer yesterday in a shooting death last year during a car chase.

title: U.P.S. Pilots Vote to Authorize a Strike
description: Pilots for the United Parcel Service of America Inc. voted overwhelmingly today to strike if an agreement on wages was not reached with U.P.S., the nation's largest package-delivery company.

title: Wine Talk
description: WHEN Mike Higgins, 61, sold his wine shop in Oakland, Calif., last year, he retired to Oregon, an easygoing, sparsely populated state, where personal freedom is still highly valued and everyone works hard not to step on anyone else's toes.

title: Even Fit Men Add Fat With Age
description: IT is not only sedentary men who are finding that the pants they wore comfortably at 40 are hard to button at 50. Middle-age spread seems to be a near-inevitable consequence of advancing age, even among men who regularly run long distances. A study of nearly 7,000 male runners 18 years old and older has shown that even those who run long distances and maintain their youthful level of exercise can expect to accumulate abdominal fat when they reach middle age.

title: I.B.M. Researchers Develop A New Encryption Formula
description: I.B.M. plans to announce today that two of its researchers have come up with a new computer encryption formula that they say is nearly impossible to crack.

title: Queen Mother Moore, 98, Harlem Rights Leader, Dies
description: Queen Mother Moore, a civil rights worker and black nationalist, died on Friday in a nursing home in Brooklyn. She was 98 and a longtime resident of Harlem.

title: Excluded Disabilities
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RABB, NORMAN
description: RABB-Norman. The Brandeis University Community mourns the death of a cherished founding father. For 50 years, Mr. Norman Rabb devoted his imagination and wisdom to the task of bringing this precious new academic asset to a place of dignity in the family of American universities. He was the youngest of the eight Founding Trustees of Brandeis University and the first Secretary of the Board. He served as Chairman of the Board from 1961 to 1967, when the University underwent its greatest period of expansion. In 1956, together with his brothers and other members of the family, Mr. Rabb supported the construction of the Graduate Center which bears the family name. The Rabb School of Summer, Special and Continuing Studies is named in honor of Mr. Rabb and his wife, Eleanor. In appreciation of Mr. Rabb's leadership and generosity, the University awarded him the honorary degree of Doctor of Humane Letters in 1958, the Medal for Distinguished Service to Higher Education in 1967, and the Jacob A. Goldfarb Medal in 1981. We extend our deepest sympathies to his wife, Eleanor, his daughters, Hope and Jane, his brother, Irving, his sister, Jeanette, and his entire family. Jehuda Reinharz, Pres. Barton J. Winokur, Chairman, Board of Trustees

title: 15,000 Pounds, and Then Some
description: On the first weekend in May, this plain-featured town where the police have shoulder patches with little crawfish emblems lives up to its nickname: the crawfish capital of the world. This year was no exception.

title: Wells Goes Distance And Bats Do the Rest
description: David Wells loves pitching at Yankee Stadium. Derek Jeter loves batting leadoff. Mark Whiten loves seeing his name in the lineup. Paul O'Neill loves demolishing left-handers. And Joe Torre loves managing games that do not involve constant calls to a tired bullpen.

title: Babies at Risk
description: When my son celebrates his birthday later this month, he will be -- according to new studies on infant brain development -- pretty much over the hill, cognitively speaking. In other words, he's turning 1.

title: GTE Discloses 3 Big Deals In Growth Bid
description: Bidding to become a major operator of corporate data networks, the GTE Corporation said yesterday that it had agreed to pay $616 million in cash to acquire the BBN Corporation, one of the nation's biggest Internet service companies.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NELSON, LEAH (NEE BOROWITZ)
description: NELSON-Leah (nee Borowitz). On May 6, 1997, at age 94. Beloved wife, for 66 years, of the late Murray. Devoted mother of Melvin J. Nelson and Paula, and of the late Stanley I. Nelson. Cherished grandmother of Wendy, Lisa, John and Jane Nelson, and Mark and Christopher Nelson. Loving great grandmother of Carly, Adam, Lindsay and Annie, and Noah Nelson. Adored aunt and cousin. Her passing signals the end of an era. She was truly unique, and will be dearly missed. Interment private.

title: Opposition In Mexico Gets To See Clinton
description: Throughout most of this century, Washington gave such unqualified backing to Mexico's governing party that successive Presidents, from Franklin Roosevelt to George Bush, visited Mexico without so much as acknowledging that other political parties existed here.

title: Pastoral and May Madness
description: The Brooklyn Philharmonic and the New York Choral Society have just completed a mutually beneficial arrangment. Two weeks ago the orchestra hired the society for two performances of an ambitious program of Britten and Ravel at the Brooklyn Academy of Music. On Sunday afternoon, the respected 180-member chorus reciprocated, sponsoring the same program at Carnegie Hall.

title: Seattle Brewers Use Innovation to Keep the Pitchers Filled
description: THE Redhook Ale Brewery in Woodinville, a half-hour's drive from Seattle, is not just a brewery. It is a beer theme park.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEY, HENRY F.G. JR.
description: WEY-Henry F.G. Jr., of Rye, NY, on May 6, 1997. Beloved husband of the late Elizabeth. Loving father of Henry F.G. Wey III, Peter R. Wey & Thomas A. Wey. Devoted brother of Mary Frances Pratt and the late Barbara Wey Ward. Survived by 11 grandchildren and 6 great grandchildren. A memorial service will be held at Christ's Church of Rye, Friday, May 9 at 10 AM. Interment private. In lieu of flowers, donations to Christ's Church of Rye and/or United Hospital Medical Center, 406 Boston Post Road, Port Chester, New York 10573 would be appreciated.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TURIN, EDICE LOUISA CHARON
description: TURIN-Edice Louisa Charon. Departed this life April 27th, 1997. Survived by her devoted husband, Dr. Joseph Turin; sorrowing daughter and son-in-law, Susan and Alan Dechter and grandchildren, Bradley, Ira, and Amie. For information call ''Gutterman-Musicant'', Hackensack, New Jersey (800-522-0588).

title: Bomb Trial Testimony Turns to Phone Records
description: Prosecutors spent most of today laying the foundation for telephone records that they said would help to show that Timothy J. McVeigh was the caller who reserved the rental truck that carried a bomb to the Federal building in Oklahoma City, where it killed 168 people and injured 850 more.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HALPERN, NEEL, NEE REISLING
description: HALPERN-Neel, nee Reisling. After a long illness on Sunday, May 4, in Rome, Italy. Beloved wife of Mike Halpern, adoring mother of Lisa and Michele. Burial on Friday in Denmark. In lieu of flowers, the family request donations be made in her name to Dance of the Danish-American Society or the American cancer society.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: CARIBBEAN CIGAR CO., Miami, the maker of the Havana Classico and Signature Collection brand cigars, acquired most of the assets of American Western Cigar Co. Terms were not disclosed.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NELSON, LEAH (NEE BOROWITZ)
description: NELSON-Leah (nee Borowitz). On May 6, 1997, at age 94. Beloved wife, for 66 years, of the late Murray. Devoted mother of Melvin J. Nelson and Paula, and of the late Stanley I. Nelson. Cherished grandmother of Wendy, Lisa, John and Jane Nelson, and Mark and Christopher Nelson. Loving great grandmother of Carly, Adam, Lindsay and Annie, and Noah Nelson. Adored aunt and cousin. Her passing signals the end of an era. She was truly unique, and will be dearly missed. Interment private.

title: Kasparov and Deep Blue Draw Again in a Tied Match
description: During the fourth game of the man-versus-machine chess match yesterday between Garry Kasparov, the world champion, and the I.B.M. computer Deep Blue, Louis V. Gerstner, the chairman of I.B.M., visited the Deep Blue war room on the 35th floor of the Equitable Center in midtown Manhattan.

title: Bulls Overcome Rodman's Latest Self-Destruction
description: When Dennis Rodman was thrown out of the game early in the third period on Tuesday night, after Referee Joey Crawford called him for his second and, thus, ejectable technical foul, the neon-tressed one left the court in a huff, feeling, obviously, that he had been grievously wronged.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  MALLER, JULIUS B.
description: MALLER-Julius B. May 8, 1959. Beloved husband and father. Thirty-eight years. In our hearts like yesterday.

title: James Washington, 49, Expert On Black Religious History
description: Dr. James Melvin Washington, an expert on black American religious history who taught at Union Theological Seminary for two decades, died on Saturday in St. Luke's Hospital. He was 49 and lived in the Morningside Heights section of Manhattan.

title: Wage Pressures Accompany Growth in Productivity
description: The pro ductivity of American businesses ultimately the main factor determining the nation's standard of living -- grew at an annual pace of 2 percent in the first quarter, the best performance in more than three years, the Bureau of Labor Statistics reported today.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ADELSON, ROTH, BECKY
description: ADELSON-ROTH-Becky. On May 6, 1997. Beloved wife of Bernard Roth and the late Edward T. Adelson, loving mother of Marcia and Jonathan, cherished grandmother of Marisa Erin, Eliza Sara, Daniel Everett and Arielle Rebecca. Dear sister of Sadie Altstein. Services Thursday, 12:15 PM, at ''ParkwestRiverside'', 333 Amsterdam Ave.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ATWELL, SHIRLEY BARBARA
description: ATWELL-Shirley Barbara. May 4, 1997 after a brief illness. Mother of Pamela Frances and Asa Timothy Spaulding. Sister of Doris, Roger, Richard, Joan, Charles, Lois, Sandra, Pat, Judi and Eddie. The family will receive friends on Friday from 5:00-9:00 P.M.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: Baseball

title: BRISTOL-MYERS TO BUY MEXICAN FOOD-SUPPLEMENT MAKER
description: The Bristol-Myers Squibb Company said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire Choco Milk from Procter & Gamble de Mexico S.A. de C.V. Terms were not disclosed. Bristol-Myers Squibb, based in New York, is a drug maker. Procter & Gamble de Mexico S.A. de C.V. is a unit of the Procter & Gamble Company, the consumer-products giant based in Cincinnati. Bristol-Myers Squibb said Choco Milk, a chocolate-flavored powder that is added to milk, is Mexico's leading milk-based nutritional supplement, containing 17 vitamins and minerals. It had 1996 sales of $50 million.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MACAULEY, CATHERINE A.
description: MACAULEY-Catherine A. Of Bronxville, NY, May 7, 1997. Sister of the late Margaret O'Donnell. Surviving are numerous nieces and nephews. Calling hours at the Fred H. McGrath & Son Funeral Home, Bronxville from the hours of 7-9PM Thurs. Mass of Christian burial, St. Joseph's Church, Bronxville Friday, May 9 at 10 A.M.

title: When Money Counts
description: IF you have your heart set on the look of old bathroom faucets and handles, you are in luck. Contemporary and reproduction faucets, as well as antique bathroom fittings, are abundant, and there are even some good buys. But changing a faucet presents a plumbing problem, not just a cosmetic one. If you choose antique parts, they will have to fit in -- literally -- with your existing sink.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  ROBERTS, MARVIN, M.D.
description: ROBERTS-Marvin, M.D. May 8, 1927 to February 10, 1991. Forever in our hearts. Your Family

title: Focusing on Pride in Whitman Television Commercials
description: This is the first television advertisement in this year's gubernatorial race in New Jersey. It is a 60-second spot for Gov. Christine Todd Whitman.

title: INSIDE METRO
description: MAN VS. MACHINE -- For the second straight day, Garry Kasparov and the I.B.M. computer Deep Blue played to a draw. B3.

title: Ex-Analyst Pleads Guilty In Spy Case
description: A former Navy intelligence analyst, Robert C. Kim, accused of spying for South Korea, pleaded guilty today to a reduced charge of conspiracy to commit espionage.

title: Utilities Index Shifts Lineup
description: The Southern Company, the Duke Power Company and four other utilities will be added to the Dow Jones utilities average, replacing six existing members.

title: For Mexicans, Clinton's Visit Is a Serenade
description: Midterm federal elections may be approaching here, but no politician has been campaigning harder over the last three days for the trust and approval of the Mexican people than the President of the United States.

title: Nazi Loot: Passages From Government Report
description: Following are excerpts from a United States Government report published today about the disposition of assets looted by Nazi Germany during World War II.

title: As Chrysler Strike Ends, Other Walkouts Loom in Auto Industry
description: The United Automobile Workers publicly agreed today to end its biggest strike against the Chrysler Corporation in 30 years, but further strikes seemed likely soon in the auto industry, notably against the General Motors Corporation.

title: Volunteer Killed on a Street She Protected
description: Like thousands of auxiliary police officers around New York City, Alberta Genevieve Kenney gave her own time to patrol the streets. A retired emergency room nurse, she was at once fearless and caring when she patrolled the Upper East Side neighborhood that she called home, colleagues said.

title: EASTERN CONFERENCE SEMIFINAL: GAME 1
description: Allan Houston led a 16-0 third-quarter run and scored 27 points, and Patrick Ewing had 24 points and 16 rebounds to lead the Knicks in the N.B.A. playoffs.

title: New Cancer Drugs Don't Offer a Breakthrough
description: To the Editor:

title: Reed Deal With Microsoft
description: Reed Elsevier P.L.C. has signed a five-year publishing agreement worth $30 million with the Microsoft Corporation. The deal allows Reed Elsevier to use Microsoft's commercial Internet system applications for future electronic offerings in the scientific, legal, business and travel information markets. Reed Elsevier, a joint British and Dutch publishing company, owns the Lexis-Nexis on-line information service.

title: A Game of Strategy They Take Seriously: Dominoes
description: There was a competition yesterday in a game of strategy, played with ceramic pieces, involving deep concentration and formidable opponents. But it is a safe bet that no one at this competition was named Garry, and the only things that brought deep blue to mind were the crepe-paper streamers hanging from the ceiling.

title: Backstage and Not Always Pretty
description: The ''Wizard of Oz'' syndrome is with us once again. This time the little dog pulling back the curtain to reveal the generally pedestrian manipulators, with warts and still more warts, behind the magical effects is a mutt called Television. In 1995, the BBC was given extraordinary access to the backstage corridors and offices of the Royal Opera House at Covent Garden. The results: six hourlong documentary programs under the umbrella title ''The House.''

title: A Critic Distills American Art to 8 Hours
description: During the many intense months that Robert Hughes spent on the road filming a new eight-hour television documentary about American art called ''American Visions,'' he frequently yearned for a break from his role as both scriptwriter and host. ''He'd always say, 'Let's not bother with this, let's go fishing,' '' the program's executive producer, Nicholas Rossiter, recalled recently.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RABB, NORMAN S.
description: RABB-Norman S. The officers, members and staff of The American Jewish Committee are deeply saddened by the death of Norman Rabb, a devoted and long-time leader of AJC. He gave generously of his time, energy & resources, serving as an AJC Vice President, member of our Board of Governors, Chair of the Interreligious Affairs Commission, Honorary President of the New England Region, and Chairman of our Palm Beach Campaign. We were proud to honor him with our Distinguished Service Award and our National Human Relations Award, along with his wife Eleanor. His infectious spirit, wise counsel and unyielding commitment to the Jewish people and to the betterment of the human condition will be sorely missed. We send our heartfelt condolences to Eleanor and the rest of the grieving family. Robert S. Rifkind, President David A. Harris, Exec. Dir.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHLAIFER, CHARLES
description: SCHLAIFER-Charles, on Monday, May 5. Beloved husband of Ann Mesavage Schlaifer, cherished father of Arlene Silk and Roberta Semer, devoted grandfather of Nicole Silk, Bruce and Scott Semer. His ''Heart's Work'' was his love for his family, his work in entertainment advertising, and his unflinching commitment in the field of mental illness and health. He co-authored several books and advocated throughout his life for those unable to. He will be remembered for creating and defining the marketing and promotion of movies. His keen sense of what would sell a movie and his creative eye were responsible for the first blockbuster hits. He has left a lasting legacy of goodwill behind and will be missed. Services will be private. He has blessed our lives.

title: Governors Stress Tax Cuts and Austerity
description: The nation's governors are calling for state tax cuts of $4.4 billion next year, the largest aggregate reduction in at least two decades, and are seeking to keep spending increases at their lowest level since 1993, state officials reported today.

title: Windy? Yes. Twister? No.
description: The winds that tore through Jersey City on Tuesday had gusts of up to 70 miles an hour, ripped off three roofs and disrupted the set for a ''Godzilla'' movie, but did not qualify as a tornado, the National Weather Service said yesterday.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  LOGES, LYNN
description: LOGES-Lynn. Paris, May 8, 1996. You are in our hearts and prayers. Venetia Selz, daughter and Wendy, sister.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHWARZ, JAMES H.
description: SCHWARZ-James H., passed away April 30, 1997. Son of the late Louis and Lillian Schwarz. Mr. Schwarz was active for years in the garment industry. He served in the armed forces World War II. Survived by a brother and sisterin-law, Richard and Jan Schwarz, Washington, DC, and many loving friends.

title: A School Board Gets Its First Black Majority
description: For the first time, the school board of this predominantly black city will be controlled by black members, five of whom won seats on Tuesday in the election for the nine-member board.

title: Corrections
description: Articles yesterday and on Tuesday about the case of Thomas Richard Jones, the North Carolina man who was convicted of first-degree murder for a homicide caused by impaired driving, referred imprecisely to precedents. The case -- involving the deaths of two students at Wake Forest University -- was not clearly the first on record.

title: Corrections
description: Articles yesterday and on Tuesday about the case of Thomas Richard Jones, the North Carolina man who was convicted of first-degree murder for a homicide caused by impaired driving, referred imprecisely to precedents. The case -- involving the deaths of two students at Wake Forest University -- was not clearly the first on record.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DOLGENOS, DAVID
description: DOLGENOS-David. We mourn the passing of a very special man. Your wisdom, counsel and humanity will guide us forever. Our deepest condolences to Nancy and to your entire family. Services Thursday, May 8th, 3:30 P.M., at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street. The firm of Dolgenos Newman & Cronin

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  EDELMAN, DAVID
description: EDELMAN-David on May 6, 1997. Survived by his beloved wife Ruth (Gidden), loving son James and caring sister Evelyn Friedman. Passed away after a long illness. Retired partner of BDO Seidman. Services Thursday, May 8 at 2:30PM at ''The Riverside'', 76 St & Amsterdam Ave. Donations may be made to Women's Division, American Society for Technion or a charity of your choice.

title: Not Sex Instruction
description: To the Editor:

title: Learning Not to Depend on a Politician's Promise
description: ECHO HOUSE

title: Houston Takes Over Miami Arena
description: UP in the stands a half-dozen rows behind the Knick bench, Dave Checketts and Ernie Grunfeld were playing it cool, real cool. The free agent who is turning out to be the real prize of last summer's $150 million shopping spree had taken over the game, taken over Miami Arena.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MILLER, HANNAH
description: MILLER-Hannah. Yeshiva Beth Abraham of Jerusalem mourn the loss of a dear friend and generous supporter since the inception of our organization. Our heartfelt condolences go to her daughter Professor Naomi Miller of Boston and son Dr. David Miller of Berkley, CA. Jacob Dyckman, President Men's Organization Dina Dyckman, President Women's Division Rabbi David Weinberg Dean of the Yeshiva

title: Corrections
description: The caption for a floor plan yesterday with the Commercial Real Estate column, which described conversions of buildings to hotels, misidentified the structure involved and the company converting it. The building is a jewelry factory and warehouse at 130 West 46th Street, not the Macmillan Building; the company is Apple Core Hotels, not the Stellar Management Company.

title: Music That Has No Past
description: It isn't often that music comes around without much precedent, but Guillermo Klein's orchestrations for his big band, which is playing at Smalls (183 West 10th Street, Greenwich Village) for the next two Tuesdays, are source-free. On Tuesday the band had its own sound, thick and full and loaded with melodies that sounded as if they should be sung; on one piece, the band's two trumpeters did just that, singing the tune.

title: Milbury Is Hoping Luck Will Help in the Lottery
description: While today marked the third consecutive year the Islanders have held a draft lottery luncheon, General Manager Mike Milbury was emphatic when he said, ''We don't want to be back here.''

title: The budget deficit problem will be back, with a vengeance.
description: SOMEBODY up there must like Bill Clinton, Trent Lott and Newt Gingrich. The last-minute projection that the Federal deficit would be $225 billion smaller over the next five years than previously estimated smoothed the way to a painless deal on the budget and may have spared the leaders the embarrassment of ideological rebellions among the troops.

title: Viacom Reports Loss for the First Quarter
description: Viacom Inc. said yesterday that it swung to a loss in the first quarter, although the deficit was kept below analysts' expectations as a strong performance by the MTV Networks operation, and the release of the movie ''Private Parts,'' offset a deterioration at the Blockbuster Entertainment unit.

title: Proletarian Harvard Turns 150, Its Mission Expanding
description: City College alumni in tuxedos and evening gowns packed the ballroom of Manhattan's Sheraton Hotel last month to show their affection for a school that turned 150 years old yesterday. These sons and daughters of the working class paid $500 a plate for the pleasure, more than their entire college educations had cost them (books and subway tokens included).

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEY, HENRY F.G. JR.
description: WEY-Henry F.G. Jr., of Rye, NY, on May 6, 1997. Beloved husband of the late Elizabeth. Loving father of Henry F.G. Wey III, Peter R. Wey & Thomas A. Wey. Devoted brother of Mary Frances Pratt and the late Barbara Wey Ward. Survived by 11 grandchildren and 6 great grandchildren. A memorial service will be held at Christ's Church of Rye, Friday, May 9 at 10 AM. Interment private. In lieu of flowers, donations to Christ's Church of Rye and/or United Hospital Medical Center, 406 Boston Post Road, Port Chester, New York 10573 would be appreciated.

title: Panel Advises Telling Troops of Possible Mustard Gas Exposure
description: Investigators for a White House panel of experts called on the Pentagon today to tell some American and British troops that they may have been exposed to Iraqi mustard gas when they examined a leaking 300-gallon tank in a girls' school in Kuwait several months after the 1991 Persian Gulf war.

title: INSIDE
description: Retreat on Managed Care

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BLUM, JEAN S.
description: BLUM-Jean S. Age 76. Died at home May 6, 1997 of cancer. Beloved wife of the late Milton. Devoted mother of Wendy and Andrea Blum. She also leaves her brother Steven Sheinhouse, her aunt Peggy Sprung, her sister-inlaw Jeanne K. Blum and many devoted friends. Her courageous spirit and good humor was an inspiration to us all. Memorial service at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue, Friday, May 9th, 2 P.M. Contributions may be made to Central Synagogue Program for the Homeless or Cabrini Hospice.

title: Whitman Begins Her Television Advertising Push
description: Gov. Christine Todd Whitman began her television advertising campaign tonight with a 60-second commercial that was broadcast at the same time that the Democratic candidates were sparring in their first televised debate.

title: DURA ACQUIRES RIGHTS TO NASAL MEDICATIONS FROM ROCHE
description: Dura Pharmaceuticals Inc. said yesterday that it had agreed to buy the rights to two nasal steroids, Nasarel and Nasalide, from Syntex Inc., a unit of Roche Holding A.G. of Basel, Switzerland, for $70 million. Dura, based in San Diego, makes drugs for the treatment of allergies, asthma and other respiratory conditions. Its stock rose $2.50, to $37 a share, on the Nasdaq market. The patent covering the products' key ingredient, flunisolide hemihydrate, expires in 2007.

title: REPUBLIC REPORTS BIG GAIN ON SALE OF ADT STOCK
description: Republic Industries said yesterday that it had sold 15 million shares of ADT Ltd. for $27.50 each, or $412.5 million, making a 38 percent profit in little more than a month. Republic, the waste-collection and auto dealership company controlled by the billionaire H. Wayne Huizenga, used a warrant to buy the stock for $300 million, or $20 a share, in late March. The warrant was a consolation prize for Republic's failed bid for ADT, which is based in Hamilton, Bermuda, and is the largest provider of electronic security systems in the United States and Britain. Republic, which is based in Fort Lauderdale, Fla., sold the ADT shares to five unidentified institutional buyers. ADT's shares closed yesterday at $28, down 25 cents.

title: It All Comes Back To Family
description: '' 'STAY at home,' my mother always said,'' Mario Puzo declares, '' 'Only bad things happen to you outside.' ''

title: Shattering Into Emotional Shards
description: Margie Gillis's dances originate not in the head but in the gut, from which a torrent of images poured pell-mell on Tuesday night. That some of her program's new works were choreographed with guest artists at the Joyce Theater did not make them any less her own.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WALLIS, BRUCE E.
description: WALLIS-Bruce E. April 26, 1997 of Osprey, Florida. Husband of Kate Butler Wallis. Father of Gillian Wallis Johnston of Montreal and Peter Wallis of Toronto. Grandfather of Kristina Johnston and Ryan Wallis. Brother of Angela Price. Uncle of Myfanwy Payne of West Sussex, England. Funeral service was held at Christ Chapel of Trinity Episcopal Church in Buffalo on May 1. Flowers gratefully declined. Memorials may be made to: Stroke Center in care of Dr. James F. Toole, Bowman Gray School of Medicine, Medical Center Blvd., Winston-Salem, North Carolina 27157-1068.

title: 61 Arrested in Air Cargo Sting Near Kennedy
description: It was three years ago that undercover agents took over a trucking business in the gray world of car repair shops, fast-food restaurants and overgrown fields off Kennedy International Airport.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KELLY, MARTIN JAMES
description: KELLY-Martin James. On May 5, 1997, after a long illness. Beloved husband of Edithe, devoted father of Alexis M. and Matthew J. Kelly and Gregory A. Cox with Dorothy M. Powers. Loving grandfather of Struan K. Brodie and cherished brother of Patricia. Recently retired senior investigator with the New York State Insurance Fund. Former New York State Assemblyman, 1959-61, Tenth A.D. Reposing at Riverdale-on-Hudson, 6110 Riverdale Avenue, Bronx, Thursday 2 to 4 PM and 7 to 9 PM. Funeral Mass Friday at 11 AM St. Gabriel's RC Church, W. 235 Street, Riverdale. Interment in Kensico Cemetery, Valhalla, New York.

title: Wetteland in Bronx: Phone Rings in Left
description: John Wetteland, who hates almost every phone except the ones that ring in the bullpen, knows enough about Ma Bell to understand that he doesn't work in the 718 area code anymore.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BOLDER, SOLOMON J.
description: BOLDER-Solomon J. Beloved husband of Alba. Loving father of Arthur and Paula, Larry and Eva, and Sara. Dearest step-father of Marco and Gabriela. Adored grandfather of Anna, Aaron, Amalia, Anessa and Tess. Cherished brother of Ruth Grayson, Natalie Lavner, Sally Ivker and his late brother Al. Services Friday, 12 Noon, Schwartz Bros Chapel, 11403 Queens Blvd, Forest Hills, N.Y.

title: Pop Art Rules at Week's Second Auction
description: There wasn't an exposed body part to be seen at Christie's last night, unless you count the foot with highly polished toenails in Tom Wesselman's ''Bedroom Painting.'' Yet the more conventional offerings by tried-and-true artists like Andy Warhol and Roy Lichtenstein, Jasper Johns and Mark Rothko, still managed to excite a salesroom crowded with contemporary-art buyers, even if a work had a recent history at auction.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: HOCKEY

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MACDONALD, SUSAN E.
description: MacDONALD-Susan E. On May 5, 1997. Dear sister of Kathleen MacDonald Tesoriero and Mary MacDonald Byrne. Beloved aunt of five nieces and nephews. Funeral Fri. From the McManus Funeral Home, 2001 Flatbush Avenue, Brooklyn. Funeral Mass, 10:30 A.M. Our Lady Help of Christians. Interment Holy Cross Cemetery. Visiting Thursday, 7-9 P.M.

title: Mad as Hell II
description: Some artists can see where our culture is going before anyone else does, and one of them is Larry Gelbart, a writer who has been making America laugh, ever more darkly, since he broke into radio as a teen-ager a half-century ago.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHULDINER, GERTRUDE (SHASKAN)
description: SHULDINER-Gertrude (Shaskan). A gracious, talented and intelligent woman who brought happiness to all who knew her-mother, father, husband, son, daughter, sister, brothers, in-laws, nieces, nephews, friends and neighbors. She was much appreciated and loved.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KWASHA, CHARLES
description: KWASHA-Charles. Boys Town Jerusalem mourns with profound sorrow the passing of a cherished friend and a charter member, together with his wife Sylvia, of the Society of Chai Founders. Their support of the school spans three decades, and has given the gift of hope and opportunity to underprivileged Israeli youth. The individual and collective accomplishments of Boys Town's students shall remain as a lasting tribute to Mr. Kwasha's memory. We extend heartfelt sympathy to the entire family and pray they be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Josh S. Weston, Chmn Alexander S. Linchner, Vice Chmn Rabbi Ronald L. Gray, Exec. V.P. Rabbi Simcha Freedman, Exec. Dir., Florida Friends of BTJ

title: News Corporation Says Profits Soared Fourfold in 3d Quarter
description: The News Corporation, Rupert Murdoch's global media company, said today that its earnings rose roughly fourfold in the most recent quarter, helped by the inclusion of New World Communications Group Inc. and the re-release of the ''Star Wars'' movie trilogy.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Timing Set for Possible Cut In Gains Tax to Take Effect

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KIRBY, BERTICE (NEE WYTHE)
description: KIRBY-Bertice (nee Wythe), on May 6, 1997. Beloved wife of the late Harry John. Loving mother of Joyce Vincent, Jane McCamis and Mary Lou Littrell. Cherished grandmother and great grandmother. Services private.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GURWIN, ROSALIND
description: GURWIN-Rosalind. The American Committee for the Weizmann Institute of Science mourns the loss of a deeply cherished friend who, in partnership with her husband Joseph, was a warm-hearted leader in support of the Weizmann Institute and numerous other philanthropic causes for the enhancement of human life in the U.S., Israel and around the world. Among their generous gifts to the Weizmann Institute was the Rosalind and Joseph Gurwin Vacuum Processing Laboratory in the Submicron Research Center. We extend our profound sympathy to Joseph Gurwin, distinquished member of the ACWIS Board of Directors, and to the entire family. Gershon Kekst, Chairman Weizmann Institute of Science Haim Harari, President S. Donald Sussman, Chairman American Committee Robert G. Begam, President Fran Ginsburg, Exec. Director

title: Candidates Unite in Attack on Whitman
description: Often sounding more like allies than foes, the three men seeking the Democratic nomination for governor of New Jersey met in their first televised debate tonight, using the occasion to attack the policies of Gov. Christine Todd Whitman relentlessly, while keeping their criticism of each other at a minimum.

title: The 800-pound gorilla among advertisers, the auto industry, gained a little more weight in 1996.
description: AUTO makers, traditionally the nation's largest advertisers, nailed down the industry's premier position even more securely last year by raising their ad spending 9.4 percent over 1995.

title: Mayors Visit, and Flood Bill Moves
description: Their communities ravaged by floods and fire, two Midwestern Mayors pleaded with senators today to approve $8.4 billion in disaster relief aid.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  STEEL, ROBERT
description: STEEL-Robert. Robby, always in our thoughts, forever in our hearts. Hold dear to Courtney. Fare you well my honey Fare you well my only true love All the birds that were singing Have flown except for you alone. Love, Mom, Charles & Eric

title: Bridge
description: In general, tournament players in North America win glory but not cash. An exception is the Calcutta event, in which entrants are purchased before play begins, by themselves and others, perhaps other contestants. The money is then distributed according to the results.

title: Adoption for Foster Children
description: About half a million American children are in foster care, a number that has nearly doubled since 1982 as drugs, sexual and physical abuse and other ills have afflicted more and more families. For many of these children, the temporary haven called foster care has become a permanent way of life.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BLINKEN, ETHEL H.
description: BLINKEN-Ethel H., died in Palm Beach, Florida on May 7 after a long illness. She was born in New York City in 1903 and married Maurice H. Blinken in 1964. He died in 1986. She is survived by her sons, Ambassador Donald Blinken of Budapest, Robert Blinken of Bedford Hills and Ambassador Alan Blinken of Brussels, as well as nine grandchildren and six great grandchildren. Interment will be private.

title: People
description: * Deborah Jurgeleit was named to the new post of executive vice president and account management director at RBT/Strum, Cherry Hill, N.J. She had been senior vice president and senior account director at BBDO New York, a unit of Omnicom Group. Also at RBT/Strum, Linda M. Smith was named senior vice president and management supervisor. She had been senior vice president for account services at Paolin & Sweeney, Mount Laurel, N.J.

title: 3 Plead Guilty to Enslaving Migrant Workers in South Carolina
description: Three men pleaded guilty yesterday to enslaving migrant workers in South Carolina as part of a scheme in which the workers were threatened with violence if they sought to escape.

title: Crackle of Icy Lakes Means It's Spring
description: It was 32 degrees here this morning. There is still snow on the ground. The trees are bare. Everyone is waiting for ice-out.

title: Grandmother Is Charged
description: The grandmother of three children who died as a fire swept through their Trenton apartment on Sunday has been charged with child endangerment, the police said.

title: F.B.I. Inquiry: Is Israel Using Mole in U.S.?
description: The F.B.I. is investigating an intercepted conversation that suggested the Israeli Government has an intelligence source that can obtain confidential American diplomatic material, United States officials said today.

title: Help Hispanic New Yorkers Become Citizens
description: To the Editor:

title: Want to Pop the Question? Here's Where
description: To the Editor:

title: 'Play On!' to Close
description: ''Play On!,'' a musical with book by Cheryl L. West and music and lyrics by Duke Ellington, is to close after the matinee on Sunday at the Brooks Atkinson Theater, 256 West 47th Street, Manhattan. The matinee of the show, directed by Sheldon Epps, will be its 61st regular performance; it had 19 previews.

title: LOUISIANA-PACIFIC TO GET $50 MILLION FOR TIMBER TRACT
description: The Louisiana-Pacific Corporation said yesterday that it had agreed to sell 38,000 acres of timberland in Northern California to the privately held Sierra-Pacific Industries for $50 million. Louisiana-Pacific, a building products company based in Portland, Ore., said the timberland, known as the Feather Falls tract, is in the northeast part of the Sacramento Valley. Louisiana-Pacific said the tract is too far from the company's remaining California sawmills, which are along the coast. Sierra-Pacific, based in Redding, Calif., is California's largest timberland owner.

title: Another Disagreement, on Education, Afflicts the Budget Deal
description: For the second time since they announced a deal to balance the Federal budget, White House officials and Congressional Republicans found themselves in disagreement today over the details, with much uncertainty about the terms of tax relief for families with children in college.

title: Toronto Stock Exchange Delists Bre-X
description: Bre-X Minerals Ltd., whose shares collapsed this week after its Indonesian mining property was revealed as worthless, was delisted today by the Toronto Stock Exchange and suspended by the Montreal and Alberta exchanges.

title: Fixing the Phone Rates
description: The Federal Communications Commission voted yesterday to set new phone rates that will shuffle billions of dollars around the economy. The new rules will lower long-distance rates by up to 15 percent, and even more as the rules create a more competitive industry. Under the plan, every school and library will connect to the Internet. Basic rates for households with one telephone line should not change. It is probably the best plan that could be devised within constraints imposed by Congress.

title: Sprint Establishes More Ties to Grey
description: The Sprint Corporation said yesterday that it had expanded its relationship with Grey Advertising in New York by naming it the first agency to handle its corporate brand development strategy. Trade publications estimated the billings, which were not disclosed, at $40 million.

title: U.S. Issues Dredging Permits and Announces Plans to Remove New York Harbor Pollution
description: Federal environmental and harbor officials moved ahead yesterday with two components of a plan to clear mud-choked shipping channels in New York Harbor and clean up pollution at a century-old ocean dump site for harbor mud near New Jersey's beaches.

title: Sure, Today the 60's Look Like Age of Unreason
description: To the Editor:

title: Garden Q.&A.
description: Growing Food in the Shade

title: Dollar Retreats a Second Day; Report on Intervention Cited
description: The dollar fell yesterday for a second day after a Japanese news agency reported that the central banks of Japan, Germany and the United States were preparing to sell it in an effort to halt its two-year rally.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: U.S. Report Says Swiss Reneged On Accord to Return Nazi Gold
description: In a searing historical indictment, a United States Government report concluded today that the Swiss Government deliberately failed to respect a 1946 agreement to return hundreds of millions of dollars in assets that Nazi Germany looted from European banks and Holocaust victims while the United States stood by.

title: Riley Offers a Rationale On Impact of Pitino's Deal
description: Here is what Pat Riley said today when asked to comment on the reported 10-year, $70 million contract that Rick Pitino signed with the Boston Celtics on Tuesday.

title: Looking Back For a Future In the Catskills
description: WHENEVER she passes the old President Hotel, Esterita (Cissie) Blumberg can't help telling the Bugsy Siegel story.

title: Giants Sign Lineman
description: The Giants announced the signing yesterday of offensive lineman CAYETANO CASTRO, a product of Kennedy High School in the Bronx and the University of Wisconsin.

title: Steinbrenner Angers Executive Council
description: The last time George Steinbrenner engaged in a war in the upper echelons of Major League Baseball, he took on the sport's last commissioner, Fay Vincent, and lost. Now he has declared war on the executive council, the body that runs baseball in the absence of a commissioner and the body of which he is one of 10 members.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DECHTER, MARTIN
description: DECHTER-Martin. For many years a well known and respected leader of the children's wear industry and an active participant in Jewish and civic philanthropies, died Saturday, May 3, at Mt. Sinai Hospital in Miami Beach, FL. He was 92. Arriving in the United States at age 16 from Odessa, Russia, Mr. Dechter went to Columbia University at night while working during the day to help support his family. In 1936, Martin Dechter along with Henry Riegel, founded Riegel & Dechter which became a leading manufacturer of children's clothing in the United States. A pioneer in the children's wear industry for over three decades, Riegel and Dechter's Fashions were featured in every leading department store in America. Founder of the B'Nai Brith chapter in Borough Park, Brooklyn and its president for many years, an active member of the AntiDefamation League, he was also recognized by the American Jewish Committee for his work on their behalf industry-wide. Mr. Dechter is survived by his wife of 66 years, Helen, his brother and sister, a daughter and a son, three grandchildren and three great grandchildren. Memorial services will be held at The Riverside Memorial Chapel, 180 West 76th Street, on May 8th at 1:30 PM.

title: Perfect Strategy as Huskey Swings Away
description: If Bobby Valentine had sat in the stands and watched somebody else manage the ninth inning the way Valentine managed the Mets tonight, he admitted he would have had two thoughts -- either the manager knew something special, or he was incredibly stupid.

title: Band-Aids as Couture, Boats as Accessories
description: Metal detectors at screenings and ''I Survived the 50th Festival'' T-shirts are new items here this year. And forget the diamonds, darling. The accessory of choice is the speedboat for escaping Croisette traffic jams. That was how Bruce Willis and the rest of the delegation from ''The Fifth Element,'' the splashy, kinky-looking sci-fi adventure that opened the Cannes International Film Festival today, made an exit from the chilly press conference that greeted their film's arrival. The extravagant ''Fifth Element'' unfolds in high comic book style, and the crowd that convened here to celebrate 50 years of world cinema doubtless has something different in mind.

title: Parking Rules
description: Because of Ascension Thursday, alternate-side street-cleaning regulations are suspended in New York City today. Other regulations remain in effect.

title: Knicks Hold Hardaway In Check
description: The object was for the Knicks to erode the granite-like figure of Tim Hardaway, to splash him over and over again with Chris Childs and Charlie Ward.

title: Britain Is Bullish on Blair as New Labor Sets a Hectic Pace
description: A week ago ''blur'' was the sarcastic surname his critics gave the head of Britain's Labor Party to mock his bent for fuzzy pronouncements. Today the word best describes the pace of activity around 10 Downing Street since Tony Blair became Prime Minister.

title: Some H.M.O.'s Pulling Away On Medicaid
description: The state's ambitious drive to place nearly all of its three million Medicaid recipients in managed care plans is facing serious obstacles as many of the companies that run those health plans have begun to scale back their efforts to enroll new recipients or pulled out of the state program altogether.

title: Split Opens Between Chiefs Of Justice Dept. and F.B.I.
description: A highly unusual and potentially serious split is emerging between F.B.I. Director Louis J. Freeh and Attorney General Janet Reno over the need to seek an independent prosecutor to investigate possible wrongdoing in Democratic fund-raising for President Clinton's reelection.

title: Nine West Faces Problems on Two Fronts
