description: The question is whether Nine West Group, the shoe manufacturer and retailer, has a bigger problem with accounting or investor relations. It's a close call.

title: What if You're Having a Fund-Raiser and Not Too Many Come?
description: THERE were 10 seats at Table 15. Nine of them were empty. This left Margaret Walsh sitting alone through the salmon course, the five before-dinner speakers and finally the filet mignon.

title: Rock-and-Roll Laureates
description: The Rock-and-Roll Hall of Fame kept its promise to Cleveland when it held its 12th annual induction ceremony here on Tuesday night. Just 19 months after the opening of the Rock-and-Roll Hall of Fame here, rock's household names -- including the Jackson Five, the Bee Gees and Crosby, Stills and Nash -- arrived to gather trophies at a black-tie event. The audience, at $1,500 a seat, mixed Cleveland's business elite with music executives, and the proceedings were videotaped by the cable channel VH-1, to be shown on Friday night at 8 and 10.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEISS, MOLLY R.
description: WEISS-Molly R. Of Boca Raton, FL. On May 4, 1997. Beloved wife of the late Charles B. Loving mother of Robert and Howard Weiss. Cherished grandmother of Jodi and Mara and great grandmother of Jessica, Samantha and Kayla. Contributions to Hospice by the Sea, 1531 W. Palmetto Park Rd, Boca Raton, FL 33486. Graveside services 1 P.M., Friday, May 9, Beth David Cemetery, Elmont, L.I. For further information call ''Gutterman's'' 1-800-992-9262.

title: David Dolgenos, 66, Lawyer and Investor
description: David Dolgenos, a lawyer and real estate investor who set aside much of his own office in SoHo as a contemporary art gallery, died on Tuesday in a taxi on his way to New York Hospital-Cornell Medical Center. He was 66 and lived in Manhattan.

title: States Slow to Take U.S. Aid To Teach Sexual Abstinence
description: A little-noticed provision in the welfare overhaul that sets aside $250 million to teach children about sexual abstinence has touched off a nationwide debate, as states try to decide how to use the money or even whether to take it.

title: French Futurists: No Honor at Home
description: LUC BESSON was a bit mystified when he was informed by the tailors executing Jean-Paul Gaultier's costume designs for the science fiction epic ''The Fifth Element'' that one outfit would cost $50,000.

title: School Merger Plan Defeated
description: For the second time since 1993, Hasbrouck Heights residents have voted against merging their schools with neighboring Wood-Ridge schools. Wood-Ridge approved the merger, 1,073 to 308. But Hasbrouck Heights rejected the proposal on Tuesday, 1,711 to 1,378.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STONE, J. JACQUES
description: STONE-J. Jacques, on May 6th, in his 90th year. The good times will always be remembered by his wife Janet, by his beloved children Toni & Freeman Shore, and Carol and Alan Pomerantz; and by his adored grandchildren Peter and Julie Strauss & Michael Romano. Services on Thursday, 12 Noon, Central Synagogue, 55th St. and Lexington Ave. For those wishing to make a contribution in his memory, donations to The Stone Family Fund, 22 E. 40th St, NYC 10016, would be appreciated.

title: A Gifted Young Violinist Gives Something Back
description: The violinist Midori has certainly faced tougher audiences than the schoolchildren she performed for recently at P.S. 144 in Forest Hills, Queens. The expectant students, some 350 youngsters from grades three through six, had been carefully prepped for the concert. Most of them adhered to what their teachers call ''concert protocol,'' which meant that the girls wore nice dresses, the boys wore shirts with ties, and everybody tried to be especially quiet.

title: Bill Seeks to Ease Secrecy Overload
description: Senator Jesse Helms, the conservative chairman of the Foreign Relations Committee, was thinking out loud today about the countless classified closed-door Pentagon briefings he had received.

title: TOP ARMY SOLDIER NAMED IN SEX CASE
description: The Army today charged its highest-ranking enlisted soldier with sexual misconduct and indecent assault involving four servicewomen over nearly three years.

title: No Headline
description: ''We were informed in great detail of everything that was in The New York Times and The Washington Post that morning. We couldn't talk about it -- because it was classified.''

title: British Vote System Skewed Labor Victory
description: To the Editor:

title: CKS Group Forms New Agency Network
description: CKS Group Inc. in Cupertino, Calif., which owns a number of agencies including CKS Partners, an integrated marketing communications agency, said yesterday that it had formed a new network to oversee all the agency company's newly acquired shops.

title: Britain Hates Europe
description: The British press had a field day with headlines after Tony Blair's landslide victory over John Major. The banners ranged from the simple ''BURIED'' to the playful picture of the Blair kids under ''DAD IS PM.'' But one headline struck me as wildly premature. It was in the leftist Observer and it blared: ''GOODBYE XENOPHOBIA.''

title: Devils Bemoaning Their Bad Breaks
description: The term ''off day'' means different things to different teams, especially to the Rangers and the Devils and their coaches.

title: Yankees Show How It's Done
description: On the night John Wetteland returned to Yankee Stadium as a Texas Ranger for the first time since becoming the most valuable player of the World Series, the Yankees dusted off the blueprint that produced a championship. They placed a lead in the hands of their relievers, even as their former closer sat and watched in the visiting team's bullpen on the other side of Monument Park.

title: In the Dreamscape Of Chelsea Market
description: IN a world where the generic is advertised as classic, and replication spells retail success, there is a certain gratification to be found in a place of raw exuberance whose strange outcroppings look as though they belong in a recently excavated cave.

title: Yanks Back on Channel 11 After Deal Is Worked Out
description: Channel 11, which has broadcast Yankee games since 1951, will televise 40 games this season and 50 in 1998, ending months of talks that nearly put the telecasts on Channel 31.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KAHN, SHIRLEE
description: KAHN-Shirlee. The miles and the years did not dim our love for Shirlee. We grieve for our beloved Bill and all of Shirlee's family. The Konecky's, Dreyer's, Dobrof's

title: CHRONICLE
description: Some months ago, KATHY ENGEL, a poet, heard the actor ROY SCHEIDER talking about the profound effect mentors have had on his life, and she asked him, ''How would you like to do a dialogue on this subject?''

title: The Stain of Nazi Gold
description: The honest excavation of history can bring sobering discoveries, as the American Government has now found in an examination of Nazi Germany's stolen gold and its redistribution after the war. No nation emerges unscathed from this investigation, including the United States, and many are disgraced. It is saddening but not altogether surprising to learn that morality and justice, especially the international obligation to look after the survivors of the Holocaust, were swiftly sacrificed to expediency when the gold was divvied up after the war. Remedying this failure, as the report rightly notes, is the unfinished business of World War II.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROSENSHEIN, CAROL
description: ROSENSHEIN-Carol. The Board of Governors, Trustees and Board of Directors of The American Friends of Beit Issie Shapiro are deeply saddened by the sudden passing of Carol Rosenshein. We extend our compassion and sympathy to our dedicated Board Treasurer, Mark Todes and wife Lisa Rosenshein Todes and the entire Rosenshein family. May all your treasured memories bring you solace in this time of grief. Naomi Stuchiner, Exec. Director Beit Issie Shapiro Lucille Strauss, National Consultant

title: Rushing to Auction: The Harriman Haul
description: ESTATE sales used to be relatively sober affairs. A very important person's old master daubs and Faberge bibelots were knocked down to the highest bidder, while the flotsam -- the mismatched juice glasses, the cereal bowl with the chipped rim -- ended up at a thrift shop or on the curb.

title: Black and Blue, but Smiling: Knicks Win Round 1
description: Everything was turning black and blue around him, people running into each other and falling to the Miami Arena floor in pain. It was a game with which Allan Houston was not familiar.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-17

title: Campaign Inquiry Splits Justice Dept.
description: The question of whether a special prosecutor is needed to pursue an investigation into Democratic fund-raising for President Clinton's re-election is provoking a potentially serious division between Attorney General Janet Reno and the head of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, Louis J. Freeh.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BUTTERMAN, GOLDIE (NEE GOLDSMITH)
description: BUTTERMAN-Goldie (nee Goldsmith). Beloved wife of the late Harry. At the age of 85. On May 7, 1997. Loving mother of Donald, Edward and Ellen Brown. Motherin-law of Mae, Heywood and Rosalind. Cherished grandmother and great grandmother. Graveside service Mount Ararat Cemetery, Farmingdale, L.I. Fri 11AM.

title: BIG RESTRUCTURING OF PHONE CHARGES APPROVED BY F.C.C.
description: In the most sweeping effort yet to set the ground rules for a coming battle in telecommunications, the Federal Communications Commission took steps yesterday to reshuffle billions of dollars of telephone rates -- raising prices for some services and lowering them for others.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEINSTEIN, FANNIE
description: WEINSTEIN - Fannie. Devoted wife of the late David. Loving mother of Deborah and Charles Yaker and Gabriel and Roberta Weinstein. Cherished grandmother of Richard, Michael and Susan Yaker, Rachel Weinstein Sweeney and Mark Weinstein. Devoted great-grandmother of Jesse and Leah Nuese-Yaker. Dearest sister of the late Hannah Shapiro, Frieda Lazer and Reuben Scherl. Services Thurs., 12 noon, Hirsch Chapel, 167th St & Jerome Ave, Bronx NY.

title: France Charges 6 Libyans With '89 Sahara Jet Bombing
description: French anti-terrorism investigators said today that they had asked a court to try the brother-in-law of Libya's leader, Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi, and five other Libyan operatives in absentia next year on charges of blowing up a French airliner and killing 171 people over the Sahara in 1989.

title: Beer Advertising Isn't Aimed at Teen-Agers
description: To the Editor:

title: Imperial to Buy A Unilever Unit For $8 Billion
description: Imperial Chemical Industries of Britain said today that it would buy the specialty chemicals division of Unilever for $8 billion in cash, one of the biggest transactions in British history.

title: In Israel, Coercing Prisoners Is Becoming Law of the Land
description: For a 20-year-old Palestinian student named George, the ordeal began with his arrest at a checkpoint between Jerusalem and Bethlehem. He was taken first to the Jerusalem jail known as the Russian Compound, and after three days transferred to the interrogation center at the Ashkelon Prison.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STRAUCH, JULES RALPH
description: STRAUCH-Jules Ralph. From the fullness of our hearts we always send love. Brothers Joe and Jim; children Carrie and Marc; and good friend Lily.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GIACALONE, JOHN PAUL
description: GIACALONE-John Paul, passed away on May 5, 1997. At the time of his death, he was a corporate attorney in private practice in New York City. Mr. Giacalone was born and raised on Long Island. He was one of six siblings starting life as a New Years Eve baby in 1961. Mr. Giacolone graduated magna cum laude from The State University of New York at Stony Brook, where he received degrees in English and History in 1983. He than went on to receive his Juris Doctorate from Fordham University in 1986. Mr. Giacalone was also a member of the distinguished MENSA, a member of the New York Bar Association, and also was admitted to practice before the Eastern District of the United States Supreme Court in 1995. He is survived by his mother, Anna Giacalone and by his brothers and sisters, Paul, Tammy, Rosanna, Vito, and Louis. He is also survived by his grandmother, Sadie Tumminia and best friend, Gary Gillis. This obituary was written by dear friend, Pat Canole. For further information, call (212) 799-9072.

title: Cockroaches Cited as Big Cause of Asthma
description: Researchers said today that a national study conclusively showed that allergic reaction to cockroaches is a major cause of the high level of asthma in children in inner cities.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RANGELL, ANITA
description: RANGELL-Anita, of Los Angeles, died on April 27 at the age of 81, following a brief, tumultuous struggle against a sudden, rapidlyadvancing malignancy of the brain. Born in Brooklyn, NY, Sept. 18, 1915, she married Leo Rangell Feb. 22, 1939. The two left their New York life via the Air Force during World War II, and relocated to the West Coast in 1946 following the War. Her husband went on to become a scientific and organizational leader in the field of psychoanalysis, holding positions up to the Presidency of the International Psychoanalytic Association in the 60's and 70's. Active throughout the world at the side of her husband, who continued as an Honorary Officer of the International, Anita has been loved and admired as a psychoanalytic ambassador, as well as for her own scholarly and wise insights, for over four decades. Besides her immersion at the acme of the field of psychoanalysis, Anita was also in the vanguard of the world of art. A docent at the Los Angeles County Museum of Art since 1975, and of the Hammer Museum since its inception, she was known for her prodigious store of information and her generosity in sharing it with others. Besides her husband, Anita leaves three children, Judith (Mrs. Louis G. Alley), Susan (Mrs. Wm. Harris) and Paul (Emily) Rangell, seven grandchildren, and a sister. She was pre-deceased by her son Richard, who died at the age of twenty-eight in 1977.

title: Report Faults Day Care Agencies
description: Despite repeated allegations of abuse over the last 14 years, the authorities took no action against a day-care provider and foster mother who has been charged with killing a child in her care, a state ombudsman said today.

title: Along Rutted Streets, Few Mourn Departure
description: With his motorcade's lights flashing and two truckloads of soldiers in camouflage uniforms, President Mobutu Sese Seko once again sped through the potholed, garbage-strewn streets of the capital this morning in his long black Cadillac on his way to the airport, where he boarded a plane out of the country.

title: Vencor Makes Hostile Offer For Transitional Hospitals
description: In an attempt to consolidate its status as the nation's largest network of acute care hospitals, Vencor Inc. announced yesterday that it was making a $639 million hostile bid for the Transitional Hospitals Corporation, topping a rival offer by $74 million.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HOFFMAN, LYNN MURPHY
description: HOFFMAN-Lynn Murphy. The families, faculty and administration of The Town School are deeply saddened by the death of Lynn Hoffman, wife of Bobby Hoffman and mother of sixth grader Ryan. Lynn was an active, supportive, and committed member of The Town School community, generously volunteering her time and talent to many school activities. Her strength and courage during her illness never faltered. She was a wonderful wife, mother and friend. Our sincerest sympathy goes out to the entire Murphy and Hoffman families.

title: Interactive Services Venture in Britain
description: British Telecommunications P.L.C. and British Sky Broadcasting Group P.L.C. formed a joint venture yesterday to provide digital satellite-television, home banking and other interactive services in Britain. British Telecom and B Sky B will each own 32.5 percent of the venture, called British Interactive Broadcasting Ltd. In addition, HSBC Midland Bank will own 20 percent and Matsushita Electric Industrial will own 15 percent.

title: Rock Band to Play On
description: The New Jersey Sports and Exposition Authority will have to allow the controversial rock group Marilyn Manson to appear as scheduled at Giants Stadium on June 15, a Federal judge ruled yesterday. Last month, the agency canceled ''Ozzfest '97,'' featuring Ozzy Osbourne and about 10 other bands, concluding that Marilyn Manson, whose latest album is ''Antichrist Superstar,'' posed a security risk.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WASHINGTON, REVEREND DR. JAMES MELVIN
description: WASHINGTON - Reverend Dr. James Melvin. The Riverside Church expresses its profound sorrow at the passing of its esteemed member and chairperson of the Church Council, The Reverend Dr. James Melvin Washington, Ph.D., May 3, 1997, age forty-nine of hypertensive stroke. Beloved husband of Patricia. Beloved father of Ayanna. Loving son of Annie and the late James W. Washington. Brother of Louise Hill, Helen Brown, Howard Moore, Willie Moore, Charles Washington and the late Ray Washington. Professor of Church History, Union Theological Seminary of New York City, scholar, author, clergyman. Viewing May 9th, 3-6:45PM. Funeral services 7 P.M., The Riverside Church, 490 Riverside Drive, NYC. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to The Riverside Church/James Melvin Washington Memorial Trust Fund, The Riverside Church, 490 Riverside Drive, New York, NY 10027.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHAPIRO, SANFORD N.
description: SHAPIRO-Sanford N. Age 48. On May 4, 1997. Beloved son of Rita and George M. Shapiro. Dear brother of Karen Spector. He was a graduate of Williams College, the Woodrow Wilson School of Public and International Affairs at Princeton University and Boalt Hall School of Law at the University of California, Berkeley. Services Thursday, 12 Noon at Plaza Memorial Chapel, Amsterdam Ave at 91 Street. Shiva period will be observed at the home of his parents. May he at last know peace.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BRUECK, BEATRICE
description: BRUECK-Beatrice, 90, of Albuquerque, NM, died Monday, May 5, 1997. She is survived by her son, Steven and his wife Cynthia of Albuquerque; her brother, Max Reiss of Wheeling, WV; and by 3 grandchildren: Jeffrey and Laura of Albuquerque and Gregory of Redwood City, CA. In New York, she was active in the Washington Heights Y Senior Center where she led sculpture classes. Services will be at Mount Hope Cemetery in Hastings-On-Hudson, New York, on Friday, May 9th at 12 Noon.

title: Mourning Looks On As Knicks Run for It
description: Last night was nothing new for Alonzo Mourning against the Knicks. He missed foul shots. He got in foul trouble. He did not do enough to help his team win.

title: Giuliani Withdraws Tax Break for Developer of Coliseum Site
description: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani has decided to withdraw a generous tax break originally promised to the builder that wins the right to develop the New York Coliseum site, one of the most prized pieces of real estate in Manhattan.

title: New Cancer Drugs Don't Offer a Breakthrough
description: To the Editor:

title: Giuliani Urges Speedup in Naturalization of Immigrants
description: At a time when Republicans in Congress are regularly questioning the integrity of the naturalization process, New York's Mayor, Rudolph W. Giuliani, yet again struck a very different note from his Republican brethren today.

title: From Cat Condominiums To Blankets With Sleeves
description: Donald and Lynn Jaeger were getting nervous about their 15 minutes.

title: Emily Norris Carey, 62, a Philanthropist
description: Emily Norris Carey, a foundation executive and philanthropist, died on April 30 at the Hospital of the University of Pennsylvania in Philadelphia. She was 62 and had homes in Manhattan, Ambler, Pa., and Biddeford Pool, Me.

title: In Texas, Labor Is Feeling Trade Accord's Pinch
description: Even after 15 years of work, Maria Consuelo Garcia made only slightly more than the $4.75 minimum wage stitching together Polo, Fila and Sassoon jeans in the Sun Apparel Inc. factory here. Seeing friends laid off at her plant and others, she kept her sewing machine whirring to beat her quotas.

title: Bond Plan on the Road
description: Complaining that Gov. Christine Todd Whitman has done a poor job of selling her pension bond plan to the public, the measure's sponsor took his show on the road yesterday.

title: Changes at Carnegie Hall
description: Carnegie Hall has declined to renew the lease of the adjacent Cineplex Odeon Theater and two longtime tenant stores on Seventh Avenue, paving the way for the nonprofit music organization to expand its operations.

title: CHRONICLE
description: BEL KAUFMAN, the author of ''Up the Down Staircase,'' will be celebrating her 86th birthday on Saturday -- with more than 1,000 people.

title: Sprucing Up Journal Square
description: Two years after 200 property owners began paying a special assessment for extra maintenance and security in Journal Square, crime and grime are down and potential investors are showing interest in the square, said Brian Coleman, executive director of the Journal Square Restoration Corporation.

title: What Medicare Reform?
description: Medicare is in for some big cuts under the balanced-budget agreement that was reached last week. But those cuts, however necessary, will do almost nothing to address the crisis the program will face when the first baby boomers start receiving benefits in little more than a decade. Nor do these savings require the 38 million current participants to bear a more equitable share of the burden of this middle-class entitlement.

title: Borough Chief Race By Victim's Mother
description: Iris Baez, a political novice whose son died three years ago in a case that focused citywide attention on police brutality, said yesterday that she would run an independent campaign for Bronx borough president.

title: FIRST MONTH BRINGS 100 SATURN SALES IN JAPAN, G.M. SAYS
description: The General Motors Corporation's Saturn division sold about 100 cars in its first month of sales in Japan, a spokesman said yesterday. Saturn had firm orders for about 100 vehicles, with 60 of those officially registered as sales. It can be two weeks or longer after a buyer orders a car until it is registered. The introduction of the Saturn on April 5 came days after Japan raised its consumption tax to 5 percent from 3 percent. Consumers rushed to buy cars in March before the increase, setting the industry up for a decline in April. Saturn did not announce a monthly sales target when it opened for business last month.

title: Rent Board Recommends Small Rises
description: As legislative leaders in Albany continued to clash over rent controls, New York City's Rent Guidelines Board recommended one of the lowest increases in its history yesterday for rent-stabilized apartments.

title: Manuel Elizalde, 60, Dies; Defender of Primitive Tribe
description: Manuel Elizalde Jr., a wealthy Filipino official who caused a sensation in 1971 when he announced that he had discovered a tiny tribe of people who had lived for thousands of years in such blissful Stone Age isolation that they had no word for war, died on Saturday at his home in Makati, a Manila suburb. He was 60, and some scientists say he was one of the world's master hoaxers.

title: Efforts at Retraining Have a Blurry Impact
description: When President Clinton decided in 1992 to support the North American Free Trade Agreement, he said that a side accord on labor was crucial. The accord guaranteed retraining for those who lost their jobs to Mexico.

title: Judge Not
description: The supreme jewel of our Constitution is a fiercely independent Federal judiciary. But Congressional Republicans are attacking this gem.

title: Teen-Ager Charged In School Stabbing
description: A Long Island teen-ager was charged with two counts of attempted murder yesterday after he stabbed a classmate in the chest at Smithtown High School while shouting, ''I hate Jews,'' the police said.

title: COLLEGE LACROSSE REPORT
description: Taking It Slow

title: In Savage Theater of War, Soothing Music Is Back
description: There are reasons that this place has an unsavory reputation.

title: Treasury Securities' Prices Tumble
description: A disappointing conclusion to the Government's quarterly refunding of the nation's debt weighed down on the Treasury securities market yesterday, cutting prices sharply.

title: Sydney J. Freedberg, 82, Art Historian, Dies
description: Sydney J. Freedberg, an art historian who taught for nearly three decades at Harvard and was chief curator of the National Gallery of Art in Washington, died on Tuesday at his home in Washington. He was 82.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LIPPER, GEORGE
description: LIPPER-George. The Board of Directors, residents and staff of The Hebrew Home for the Aged, Riverdale, mourn with sorrow the passing of George Lipper, a true and valued friend of the Home. We offer our sincere condolences to Kenneth Lipper, Dr. Evelyn Gruss Lipper and the entire Lipper family. We hope that your loving memories of George will ease your sorrow during this time of sadness. Milton A. Gilbert, President Bernard Goldberg, Chairman Jacob Reingold, Vice Chairman Daniel Reingold, Exec. V.P.

title: Accounts
description: * Shop Vac Corp., a vacuum manufacturer in Williamsport, Pa., to Bozell Detroit, Southfield, Mich., a unit of Bozell, Jacobs, Kenyon & Eckhardt, to handle advertising previously at Hanft Byrne Raboy Abram & Partners, New York. Billings were estimated at $5 million.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BRETT, MARY B.
description: BRETT-Mary B., 71, of East Hampton, N.Y. and Vero Beach, Florida. Widow of Philip M. Brett and H. Lawrence Pool. Mother of Katharine B. Schmidt of Fairfield, Ct., W. Henry Pool of Greenwich, CT., and James L. S. Pool of Sherborn, MA. Sister of Hermann C. Schwab, Ruth S. Galpin and Walter P.B. Schwab, and half-sister of Anne Corcos. Grandmother of nine. Died of cancer at Vero Beach, May 6, 1997. Memorial service St. Luke's Church, East Hampton, Tues. May 13th, 11 A.M. In lieu of flowers, contributions to St. Luke's would be appreciated.

title: HONDA SUES TO THWART REPUBLIC DEALERSHIP PLANS
description: The Honda Motor Company said today that it had sued Republic Industries to block Republic's acquisitions of Honda and Acura dealerships in major markets. The Japanese auto maker's United States sales unit, the American Honda Motor Company, said it believed Republic wanted to buy more than 60 Honda and Acura franchises in major markets in the next 18 months, which would give it as much as 20 percent of American Honda's total sales volume. American Honda said Republic refused to recognize dealer pacts and ownership policies that limit the number of dealerships any one person or company may own. American Honda's dealer network includes 1,000 Honda dealerships and 270 Acura dealerships. Acura is Honda's luxury car line.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GROSSMAN, SHIRLEY
description: GROSSMAN-Shirley. On May 4, 1997. Beloved wife of the late Ralph. Devoted mother of Andrea McFarren. Loving sister of Grace Margolis and Walter Wyman. Cherished grandmother of Josh and Alicia McFarren.

title: EX-S.E.C. Lawyer Pleads Guilty in Stock Fraud
description: A former lawyer for the Securities and Exchange Commission has pleaded guilty to criminal charges of securities fraud and money laundering.

title: After a New Gamble, A Fiery Counterattack
description: For the second time in his match against Deep Blue, Garry Kasparov spent a pawn for a counterattack, and this time he got his investment back and then some. But how long can he go on giving the I.B.M. computer pawns without getting burned?

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLDBERG, SHIRLEY
description: GOLDBERG-Shirley. Wife of John M. Goldberg. Mother of Perter Goldberg. Died May 6, 1997. Service, 11 AM, Friday, at ''The Riverside'', 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Senators Say Finances Won't Hurt C.I.A. Nominee
description: The Federal Bureau of Investigation still has unresolved questions about the personal finances of George J. Tenet, President Clinton's latest nominee for Director of Central Intelligence, but members of the Senate Intelligence Committee said tonight that the issue did not endanger the nomination.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Saturday about a balanced-budget agreement between the White House and Congressional Republicans referred incorrectly to the party makeup of Congress in the early 1980's. While Democrats controlled the House, Republicans held the Senate.

title: Defense in Megan Death May Blame Someone Else
description: Three years after Jesse Timmendequas was charged with the rape and murder of 7-year-old Megan Kanka, there was the first hint yesterday that his defense may be that someone else committed the crime, which drew national attention to the suburban block where he lived with two other convicted sex offenders.

title: Mobutu Leaves Capital of Zaire In What Many See as End to Rule
description: Leaving a capital that is bracing for the arrival of rebel forces trying to topple him, President Mobutu Sese Seko flew to neighboring Gabon today on an official visit that many Zairians saw as his final departure from the country that he has ruled for nearly 32 years.

title: EQUITABLE COS. (EQ,N)
description: The Equitable Companies said yesterday that first-quarter earnings rose 57 percent, buoyed by annuities, money management and its Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette Inc. securities unit.

title: American Topics : Word at the NOW Meeting:'Polygamy Is Empowering'
description: The Utah members of the National Organization of Women heard from an unlikely speaker at their recent conference in Salt Lake City, Utah: a polygamist wife who says she has the ultimate feminist lifestyle.

title: Newsier Approach At Channel 2 News
description: With a handful of new anchor people and a new philosophy more akin to all-news radio than to television, Channel 2 News in New York yesterday introduced its latest effort to improve its poor ratings.

title: Protecting Big Oil
description: To the Editor:

title: Korean Company Files for Bankruptcy
description: One of South Korea's largest textile companies filed for bankruptcy yesterday after defaulting on some of its debt. The Yusung Company was declared insolvent as bankers are still grappling with a bailout of the Jinro Group, the country's 19th-largest industrial group. Two steelmakers also collapsed earlier this year.

title: More Minority Students Enter Elite Schools
description: The New York City school system's citywide effort to increase the number of black and Hispanic students at the city's best high schools has met with what school officials call striking success in its first year.

title: Nassau's Democratic Leader Is Accused of Business Fraud
description: Stephen J. Sabbeth, the Nassau County Democratic leader and a commissioner on the County Board of Elections, was indicted yesterday on charges of trying to hide $750,000 from creditors when his lumber business went bankrupt.

title: Banco Santander Buying Part of Colombian Bank
description: Banco Santander said yesterday that it had agreed to buy a 55 percent stake in Colombia's Banco Comercial Antioqueno, or Bancoquia, for $146 million. Banco Santander is a Spanish banking group. Bancoquia, a private bank, has assets of $1.55 billion.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SULLIVAN, MAE V.
description: SULLIVAN-Mae V. On May 6, 1997. Retired Principal of P.S. 11 Queens and P.S. 171 Queens. Beloved mother of Joan F. Sullivan and John B. Sullivan. Visiting hours at Krtil Funeral Home, 1297 First Ave. (69-70 St.), Thursday, May 8th, 2-5PM and 7-9PM. Funeral service at the Chapel in Mary Manning Walsh Home, 1339 York Ave. (71-72 St.), Fri., May 9th. Viewing 9AM and Mass at 9:30AM.

title: Stern Lauds Coaches' Deals
description: Commissioner David Stern said tonight that he was not concerned about the enormous contracts being handed to National Basketball Association coaches, calling such deals a reflection of the growing responsibility and pressure placed on the job.

title: House Rejects Bill to Soften Provisions In Species Act
description: The House tonight rejected a bill that would have weakened the Endangered Species Act by allowing flood control projects to take precedence over protection of threatened animals and plants.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Tuesday about the Tony Award nominations misstated the showing for the musical ''Big'' last year. It received nominations in five categories, though not for best musical; it was not entirely overlooked.

title: Senators on Abortion
description: To the Editor:

title: Want to Pop the Question? Here's Where
description: To the Editor:

title: Apartheid-Era Defense Chief Defends Role in Ordering Raids on Neighboring Countries
description: South Africa's Minister of Defense for 11 years during the apartheid era told the country's Truth and Reconciliation Commission today that he had ordered raids into neighboring countries that resulted in civilian deaths and that he set up a branch of the army that became notorious for its brutal handling of dissidents.

title: In France's Heart, Support for Strong Europe
description: Was President Jacques Chirac clever or foolhardy to call an election to ask voters for a new legislative mandate for the economic sacrifices he says are necessary to get France in on a European common currency in 1999?

title: U.N. Panel Convicts Bosnian Serb of War Crimes
description: A United Nations war crimes tribunal concluded its first trial today by convicting a Bosnian Serb of killing two policemen and of torturing and persecuting many Muslim civilians in Bosnia in 1992.

title: Gilbert Green, 90, Communist Party Leader Jailed for Conspiracy
description: Gilbert Green, a Communist Party leader who spent six years in a Federal penitentiary for ''conspiracy to teach and advocate'' the overthrow of the United States Government, died on Sunday at a nursing home in Ann Arbor, Mich. He was 90 and had lived in the Chelsea section of Manhattan until three months ago.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KOSHLAND, WILLIAM A.
description: KOSHLAND-William A. On May 7, 1997. Greatly loved uncle of Kathryn K. and Anthony D. Blue, great uncle of Caitlin, Toby, Jessica, and Amanda Blue, and Stephen A. Koshland, treasured cousin of Sally J. Kuhn, & devoted friend of Tibor S. Heredy. Memorial service to be announced at a later date. Donations in his memory may be made to Harvard University, Phillips Exeter Academy, & the UJA-Federation of Jewish Philanthropies.

title: British Vote System Skewed Labor Victory
description: To the Editor:

title: Israel Defends Use of Force in Interrogation
description: Appearing before a skeptical panel of United Nations experts, Israeli officials today strenuously defended their nation's use of physical coercion in questioning detainees who might have information about terrorism.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RAVLIN, JAMES N.
description: RAVLIN-James N., died May 6, 1997. We extend our heartfelt condolences to our President Agnes Eisenberger on the loss of her beloved Jim. He was also our great friend and his humor and his loyalty to us and to our artists will be missed. Devotedly the staff of Colbert Artist Management

title: Piecing Together the Last Moments of 6 Young Lives
description: The oldest of six children who died in a fast-moving fire on Tuesday knelt with her 2-year-old cousin on the living room floor as poisonous black smoke filled their apartment, the authorities here said today. At the same time, the four other children huddled on the floor of a bedroom, apparently immobilized by fear and confusion as the blaze spread.

title: Strong Selloff Pushes Dow Down 139.67
description: Maybe exuberance has its limits.

title: Last Chance
description: Here is a sampling of shows and exhibitions in Manhattan that are to close soon:

title: Teacher's Aide Faces Sexual Abuse Charges
description: A teacher's aide was arrested yesterday and charged with sexually abusing a 14-year-old male student in a teacher's lounge at a Brooklyn intermediate school.

title: Charles Schlaifer, 87, Mental Health Crusader
description: Charles Schlaifer, an advertising agency owner and movie executive whose promotion of the film ''The Snake Pit'' inspired him to become an important advocate of improved mental health care in the United States, died on Monday at his home in Manhattan. He was 87.

title: Home Is Best For MetroStars
description: Giants Stadium has been good to the MetroStars so far, and they will have a chance to improve their Major League Soccer record to .500 with another victory there tonight against the San Jose Clash.

title: In a Magnified World, Seeing May Not Be Believing
description: Almost anything viewed through a microscope looks like something else. In the magnified world of ''Four Million Houseguests,'' the new Imax three-dimensional film that opens today at Sony Theaters Lincoln Square, enlarged grains of salt resemble layered pyramidal sheets of white-tinted plastic, and pepper grounds look like dark craggy rocks. As the camera explores this salt-and-pepper universe, you have the sensation of traveling in a glass-bottom boat through an undersea environment of eerie grottoes.

title: Explosion Kills 3 Firefighters In Arkansas
description: Three firefighters died today and 16 people were injured in an explosion and fire that heavily damaged a farm chemical distribution plant in West Helena, Ark., about 80 miles south of Memphis.

title: NEW VIDEO RELEASES
description: The Evening Star

title: After Outcry, Agency Drops Housing Plan
description: Facing staunch opposition from public housing tenants and their advocates, the New York City Housing Authority retreated yesterday from a plan to seek a waiver from Federal regulations that restrict the rents it charges, the kind of people it houses and the way it spends huge but shrinking Government subsidies.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Stock Market Ends Higher, But Early Gains Are Pared

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MARCUS, NETTIE (NEE COHEN)
description: MARCUS-Nettie (Nee Cohen). Beloved wife of the late Max Marcus and loving mother of Arnold Marcus and Roberta Serota Doben. Cherished grandmother of Harvey Serota, Sloane and Jonathan Marcus and Steven Serota. Greatgrandmother to Joshua, Daniel and Luis.

title: Outer-Borough Speak
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  SCHWARTZ, BEATRICE
description: SCHWARTZ-Beatrice. Died 2/3/95. Remembered with deepest affection and love. Sylvia and Paul Schwartz

title: Rivera, Put to Test, Survives
description: Jolted by the last thing they wanted to see last night -- the sight of bases loaded with Texas Rangers and Juan Gonzalez at the plate in a one-run game -- the fans at Yankee Stadium stood and screamed. There was no command of NOISE from the center-field scoreboard, no need for anything artificial. The continuing growth of Mariano Rivera as the Yankee closer, and the possibility of a sudden setback at a very bad time, created a small slice of post-season urgency in the Bronx.

title: A Report on Jobless Claims Aids a Rally in Bond Prices
description: Treasury prices recovered yesterday from Wednesday's selloff, helped by a report that showed initial claims for unemployment benefits remain at a five-month high.

title: Local Touches and Low Prices Pay Off for Applebee's
description: Planet Hollywood names drinks after Demi Moore and Arnold Schwarzenegger movies. Hard Rock Cafe displays glitzy memorabilia like Billy Joel's old piano. At the Applebee's Neighborhood Bar and Grill in this suburb of Kansas City, the closest things to celebrity memorabilia are the autographed sneakers of Bill Elliott, a former basketball star at nearby Olathe South High School.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BOLDER, SOLOMON J.
description: BOLDER-Solomon J. Beloved husband of Alba, loving father of Arthur and Paula, Larry and Eva, and Sara, dearest step-father of Marco and Gabriella, former husband of Claire, the mother of Arthur, Larry and Sara. Adored grandfather of Hannah, Aaron, Amalia, Anessa and Tess, Cherished brother of Ruth Grayson, Natalie Levner, Sally Ivker and his late brother Al. Services Friday, 12 Noon, Schwartz Bros Chapel, 11403 Queens Blvd, Forest Hills, N.Y.

title: Accounts
description: * Papa Gino's Inc., Dedham, Mass., to Clarke Goward, Boston, to handle its account, which had been at the Evans Group, Seattle. Billings were estimated at $4 million to $5 million.

title: 'Ellen' Advertiser Back in Fold
description: The only known advertiser to pull out of ABC's controversial ''Ellen'' coming out episode last week was back in the advertising lineup on the show this week.

title: Officials Trying to Shut Down Two Haulers Linked to Cartel
description: New Jersey officials said yesterday that they were trying to close two garbage-carting companies and were investigating two others that had been linked to a cartel in New York City that the authorities said was controlled by the Mafia.

title: Strange Secrets of the Ocean Depths
description: THE UNIVERSE BELOW

title: A Familiar Complaint For an Election Year
description: After four years of relative silence on the subject, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani unleashed a surprisingly pointed attack yesterday on the many ways in which the state shortchanges the city, placing a demand for fairness at the very heart of his election-year budget.

title: Rosalind Gurwin, 73; Aided Jewish Causes
description: Rosalind Gurwin, a benefactor of Jewish causes in the United States and Israel, died on Saturday at Long Island Jewish Medical Center. She was 73 and lived in Kings Point, N.Y., and Palm Beach, Fla.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WASHINGTON, JAMES M.
description: WASHINGTON-James M. The entire Union Theological Seminary Community, its Alumni/ae and Friends mourn the loss of our esteemed colleague, teacher and friend, Dr. James M. Washington. Union will long treasure the rich legacy of scholarship, teaching and preaching he left to generations of grateful students. Our hearts reach out to his wife Patricia, daughter Ayanna and all members of his family. Holland L. Hendrix, President

title: VARIAN TO SELL THIN FILM SYSTEMS UNIT TO NOVELLUS
description: Varian Associates said yesterday that it had agreed to sell its Thin Film Systems unit to Novellus Systems for $150 million. Varian, based in Palo Alto, Calif., said the unit makes machines that deposit thin metallic films on the surface of silicon wafers. Novellus, based in San Jose, Calif., makes automated wafer fabrication systems. The sale includes a factory in Palo Alto and sales and service offices in the United States and abroad. Varian makes health care equipment, semiconductor equipment and analytical instruments. Its shares rose $1 yesterday, to $50.50. Novellus gained $1.25 a share, to $79.75.

title: Mr. Giuliani's Budget Challenge
description: The $34 billion budget proposed by Mayor Rudolph Giuliani yesterday asked for little change in the way New York City's government runs and little sacrifice from New Yorkers. That is because the city, like the Federal and state governments, is rolling in cash from an improved economy, especially on Wall Street, and has no need for the austerity pushed by the Mayor when he first took office. Nevertheless, he is missing a rare opportunity to put the city's long-term finances in balance.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BUTTERMAN, GOLDIE
description: BUTTERMAN-Goldie. Congregation Sons of Israel, Woodmere, records with sorrow the passing of its member, and extends its condolences to the bereaved family. Bruce Ginsburg, Rabbi Dr. Saul I. Teplitz, Rabbi Emeritus Alan S. Roth, President

title: Despite Changes, a Gallery Scene That's Resilient and Vital
description: THIS was to have been the year of SoHo's demise as an art neighborhood. A number of major dealers have moved northwest to Chelsea, the next art frontier. Meanwhile, SoHo, whose preponderance of late-19th-century cast-iron buildings makes it one of Manhattan's architectural gems, has become the greatest mall in America. It is a retail mecca -- a bit of mail-order heaven on earth -- overrun each weekend by thousands of people who wouldn't know a cast-iron column if they tripped over one.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PROSE, YVETTE
description: PROSE-Yvette. On May 4, 1997, of White Plains, New York. Beloved wife of Leonard. Loving mother of Samuel, Robin, Merry and David. Dear sister of Ann Getelman. Adored grandmother of six. Service, Sunday, May 11, 9:30AM, at The Community Synagogue of Rye, 200 Forest Avenue, Rye, New York. Interment, Sharon Gardens Cemetery, Valhalla, New York. Contributions to The Hospice of Naples, 1095 Whippoorwill, Naples FL 34105, would be appreciated. For more information, call the William H. Graham Funeral Home.

title: GIULIANI PROPOSES A RISE IN SPENDING IN HIS NEW BUDGET
description: With New York City benefiting from the boom on Wall Street, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani proposed a $33.5 billion election-year budget yesterday that, for the first time in his tenure, calls for an increase in spending and in the size of the municipal work force. Much of the new money would go to education and other services for children.

title: Olivetti Predicts Yet Another Loss
description: Olivetti S.p.A. forecast yesterday that it would a have first-half loss of 264.2 billion lire ($155 million) before taxes and before accounting for its cellular phone unit Omnitel.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FREUND, GERALD
description: FREUND-Gerald. The Hunter College community mourns the loss of Gerald Freund, our first Dean of Humanities and the Arts (1971-1979). He shaped the course of study for liberal arts students, served as a mentor to students and faculty, initiated the Hunter Galleries, and obtained vital funding for innovative programs in the liberal and performing arts. We extend our condolences to his family. David A. Caputo, President, Hunter College

title: With Pitino In Boston, Bird Goes to Pacers
description: On a day of sweeping changes in the National Basketball Association, Larry Bird elected yesterday to return to his native Indiana to coach the Pacers instead of remaining in Boston, where Rick Pitino initiated a new era by taking over as coach and president of the Celtics.

title: The Spoken Word
description: ''PIECEWORK,'' Studio Museum in Harlem, 144 West 125th Street. Artists will discuss the quilts they created on the theme of motherhood, which will be on view through June 21. Sunday at 2 P.M. Admission on Sunday is free, in honor of Mother's Day. Information: (212) 864-4500.

title: Ghost in the Chess Machine: A Brain, or Just a Black Box?
description: Whether the machine or the man ultimately wins the rematch between Deep Blue and Garry Kasparov, it is probably just a matter of time before a computer prevails. What is far less certain is just what to make of such a victory.

title: Market's Strength Enables Bigger, More Rapid Price Increases for New Condos
description: In Manhattan's residential market, pricing has always been used as a strategy to find what the market will accept. But these days, developers of high-end condominiums, capitalizing on the strength of the market, are raising prices more quickly and more frequently than even in the mid-80's boom.

title: Tiny Tribe in Remote Arctic Is Jolting Alaska
description: From this log-built bogland village of barely 200 Athabaskan Indian souls, high in the Arctic Circle, deep in the Alaskan interior, a snowball began to roll.

title: A Budget Fit for Fantasyland
description: To the Editor:

title: Unilever uses gentle humor in its national campaign for ovulation predictor kits.
description: YOU mean I came all this way . . . for nothing?'' reads the copy over a magnified image of a sperm, part of an advertisement in the first national campaign for an ovulation predictor kit that began appearing in May issues of national women's magazines, including Redbook and Ladies' Home Journal.

title: Troubled Christian Minority Awaits the Pope in Lebanon
description: On this mountaintop high above the Mediterranean, the beatific gaze of Our Lady of Harissa stands as an emblem of the special bond that has long linked part of Lebanon to Rome.

title: Religion Amendment Is Introduced
description: Religious conservatives in Congress today introduced a ''religious freedom'' amendment to the Constitution that would explicitly allow prayer in public schools, religious symbols on government property and tax dollars for private religious schools.

title: House Passes Bill to Combat Juvenile Crime
description: The House voted overwhelmingly today to offer states $1.5 billion to fight juvenile crime if they change their laws and require that young people accused of violent crimes in state courts be tried as adults.

title: After Warnings, US Airways Acts To Cut Routes
description: US Airways followed through on recent warnings that it might start shrinking the airline by announcing yesterday that it would cut jet service to nine cities, close some unneeded operations, ground 22 planes and lay off some pilots.

title: Extra Highway Money
description: New Jersey stands to get an extra $32 million in Federal highway money under a measure that was approved yesterday by the United States Senate.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MACAARON, JAMES
description: MacAARON-James. On may 7 1997, (aka James J. McGoldrick). Member of Actors Equity. Beloved husband of Suzanne. Cherished father of Alexandra, Francesca and David. Dear brother of Patricia Anzalone and Lawrence McGoldrick. Reposing at Edward D. Lynch & Son Funeral Home, 4307 Queens Blvd., Sunnyside, NY. Funeral Mass, Queen of Angels R.C. Church, Saturday, 9:45 AM. Interment St. Raymond's Cemetery. Visitation Friday, 7-9:30.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: New Ferry Service To Ply the Harbor
description: The waters of New York Harbor are getting crowded as entrepreneurs and city officials rediscover the uses of water transportation. The latest entry: New York Water Taxi, which is set to begin a shuttle service in two weeks along the Hudson River.

title: Judge Orders Counseling In Harassment Sentence
description: Despite his protests that he did not need therapy, Burton N. Pugach was sentenced yesterday to a year of counseling and ordered to stay away from the ex-lover he was found guilty of harassing.

title: Trade Storm Imperils Caribbean Banana Crops
description: For 20 years, Alfred Prosper has earned a living growing bananas on a six-acre plot that he owns near here. He is not a rich man, he will tell you, and the work is hard, but he has always made enough money to feed his family and to hire half a dozen workers to help him.

title: Gun Safety Locks Will Save Children
description: To the Editor:

title: Bruce Willis Drops Project, Leaving Town More Troubled
description: While thousands of fans waited to catch a glimpse of the actor Bruce Willis as he opened a Planet Hollywood in France today, residents here in his hometown could talk of little but how he had just let them down.

title: $25 and Under
description: These days it seems as if an American restaurant can't open without whistling the same old song. So the ears tend not to hear yet another chorus of meatloaf, steak and chicken. But Drovers Tap Room, the new American restaurant that was opened last month by the owners of Home, is hitting such distinctive notes that even the tuned-out are taking notice.

title: Riley: Top Coach Has Work to Do
description: When Pat Riley left practice yesterday, he had two problems. Where would he put his latest award? And how would he beat the Knicks?

title: Bre-X Files For Bankruptcy
description: Bre-X Minerals Ltd. was granted protection from creditors today by an Alberta court as it oversees the liquidation of the company, which was described this week as having perpetrated the biggest mining fraud in history.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HOFFMAN, LYNN MURPHY
description: HOFFMAN-Lynn Murphy. Lynn, we will miss our biggest fan and cheer leader. You made our league the best of its kind. Our hearts go out to our teammate and good friend Ryan, and our leader Bobby, and the entire Murphy family. The Devil Rays

title: Using Torture in Israel
description: No democracy is as stalked by terrorism as Israel. Because of that threat, Israeli law allows its security service to use what it calls ''a moderate measure of physical pressure'' when interrogating Palestinians. These measures, which include violent shaking and hanging shackled prisoners in painful positions, clearly come under the definition of torture in the international conventions that Israel has signed. Israel must vigorously protect its security, but not by the use of torture.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LORD, SUSAN
description: LORD - Susan Stackpole, of Charleston, SC, and Syosset, NY, died Wednesday, April 30. Mrs. Lord, born in New York City, where she graduated from Miss Chapin's School, was the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William Stackpole of Tuxedo Park, New York. She was a championship horsewoman and bridge player. Mrs. Lord was formerly married to Franklin B. Lord Jr., a partner in the law firm Lord Day & Lord, who died in 1971. Surviving are her two daughters, Susan F.B. Lord of Grey Shadow Farm, Lugoff, S.C., and Robin L. Sheldon of Sand Point, Idaho; her brother, William Stackpole of Lawrenceville, New Jersey, and four grandchildren. At Mrs. Lord's request, there will be no funeral or memorial services. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the American Cancer Society of either Charleston or New York City.

title: Killers Who Hum Broadway Tunes
description: This is a very strange bunch of criminals. They have the eyes of hardened men, they kill with deliberate casualness and they are all huge fans of Broadway musicals.

title: A $3.5 Million 'Soup Can' Leads Christie's Auction
description: There wasn't an exposed body part to be seen at Christie's Wednesday night, unless you count the foot with highly polished toenails in Tom Wesselman's ''Bedroom Painting.'' Yet the more conventional offerings by tried-and-true artists like Andy Warhol and Roy Lichtenstein, Jasper Johns and Mark Rothko still managed to excite a salesroom crowded with contemporary-art buyers, even if a work had a recent history at auction.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WILSON, JAMES J.
description: WILSON-James J., May 7, 1997, of Scarsdale, New York. Husband of Marie. Father of James J. III, Kevin J., Timothy M., Therese, Maura Harvey, & Claire. Brother of Bridgett Hartman. Grandfather of 7. Family will receive friends at the Bennett Funeral Home, 824 Scarsdale Avenue, Scarsdale, New York, Friday, 2-4 and 7-9 PM. Mass of Christian Burial Immaculate Heart of Mary Church, Saturday, 9:30 AM. Those who wish may make donations in his memory to their favorite charity.

title: Cooke Bequeaths Wealth To Gifted and Poor Youths
description: In the years before he died last month at the age of 84, Jack Kent Cooke often talked with his young daughter, Jacqueline, about people in need. Suzanne Martin Cooke, the third of Mr. Cooke's four wives, remembered one conversation between her daughter and husband that began with Jacqueline saying, ''Here's an idea: Why don't you give money to homeless mothers and children?''

title: In a Letter, McVeigh Told Of Shifting To 'Animal'
description: In a letter written shortly before the bombing of the Federal Building in Oklahoma City, Timothy J. McVeigh told a Michigan woman that his mind-set had shifted from ''intellectual'' to ''animal,'' and seemed to imply that he thought he was part of a network that shared his anti-Government views.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FREEDBERG, SYDNEY JOSEPH
description: FREEDBERG - Sydney Joseph. Arthur Kingsley Porter Professor of Fine Arts Emeritus, Harvard Univ.; Chief Curator Emeritus, National Gallery of Art; on May 6, 1997, at his home in Washington, DC; in the company of his wife of 30 years, Catherine Blanton Freedberg, & his youngest son, Sydney Joseph, Jr. Survived also by his sons William and Nathaniel, his daughter Kate, and his younger brother Charles. A memorial service will be held at Harvard University in the fall. Contributions in memory of Professor Freedberg may be sent to the Sydney J. Freedberg Directors' Fund for Villa I Tatti and the Harvard University Art Museums, at 32 Quincy Street, Cambridge, MA. 02138.

title: Drug for Lou Gehrig's Disease Is Rejected by F.D.A. Panel
description: An advisory panel to the Food and Drug Administration recommended yesterday against approval of Cephalon Inc.'s drug for the treatment of Lou Gehrig's disease. The panel said there was not sufficient evidence that the drug, Myotrophin, worked.

title: Republicans Return Foreign Donation
description: WASHINGTON  The Republican Party returned a campaign contribution of more than $100,000 on Thursday, acknowledging that the money originated from a Hong Kong company and not from a subsidiary incorporated in Florida.

title: For Shoppers, Serious and Not So
description: Art dealers from the United States and Europe bring top-notch wares to the annual International Fine Art Fair. And at least a few of the visitors to the show, which opens its six-day run at the Seventh Regiment Armory today, will have serious shopping in mind.

title: Nynex's Local Wire Rates Are Based on Cost
description: To the Editor:

title: Russia's Oil Grab
description: As the West celebrates the apparent expansion of NATO into Central Europe, Russia is making a concerted bid to achieve a strategic victory of its own: dominance of the energy resources in the Caspian Sea region. If Moscow succeeds, its victory could prove more significant than the West's success in enlarging NATO.

title: Rangers Pay High Cost for Pushing Devils to Brink
description: The Rangers are now one victory away from the final four of the Stanley Cup playoffs, but their status comes at a precious price. While beating the unraveling Devils again last night at Madison Square Garden, the Rangers lost Niklas Sundstrom, one of their top forwards, with a broken bone in his left forearm.

title: Mexican Police Protest; 7 Officers Are Injured
description: Hundreds of protesting police officers battled today with an antiriot force that used clubs and tear gas. The officers had blocked a major expressway to protest transfers and the rising role of the army in policing Mexico City.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WALLIS, BRUCE E.
description: WALLIS-Bruce E. April 26, 1997 of Osprey, Florida. Husband of Kate Butler Wallis. Father of Gillian Wallis Johnston of Montreal and Peter Wallis of Toronto. Grandfather of Kristina Johnston and Ryan Wallis. Brother of Angela Price. Uncle of Myfanwy Payne of West Sussex, England. Funeral service was held at Christ Chapel of Trinity Episcopal Church in Buffalo on May 1. Flowers gratefully declined. Memorials may be made to: Stroke Center in care of Dr. James F. Toole, Bowman Gray School of Medicine, Medical Center Blvd., Winston-Salem, North Carolina 27157-1068.

title: Manuel Nardy, 92, Brazilian Character in Life and Literature
description: Manuel Nardy, a hard-drinking, tale-spinning cowboy of such hardscrabble simplicity that he didn't learn until years after the fact that he had been translated into one of the most memorable characters in Brazilian literature, died on Monday in a hospital in Belo Horizonte, 200 miles north of Rio de Janeiro. He was 92 and known throughout Brazil as Manuelzao, or Big Manuel.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STONE, J. JACQUES
description: STONE-J. Jacques. The officers, leadership, and staff of UJAFederation of New York mourn the passing of J. Jacques Stone, an active supporter of UJA-Federation and a devoted Jewish communal leader who was particularly focused on assuring our Jewish continuity. Mr. Stone served on UJA-Federation's Domestic Assembly and on the boards of our agencies, the Hebrew Immigrant Aid Society & the Board of Jewish Education, where he was a pastpresident. We extend our deepest sympathies to his wife, Janet, his children, Toni and Freeman Shore and Carol and Alan Pomerantz, his grandchildren, Peter and Julie Strauss and Michael Romano, and the entire family. May you be consoled among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Larry A. Silverstein, Board Chair Louise B. Greilsheimer, President Stephen D. Solender, Exec. V.P.

title: New Israeli Ghetto
description: To the Editor:

title: Caribbean Policy Has Gone Into Hiding
description: To the Editor:

title: ALAMCO IN TALKS ABOUT POSSIBLE SALE OR MERGER
description: Alamco Inc. said yesterday that it was in talks about ''a possible business combination.'' No agreement has been signed, and the company, an oil and gas producer based in Clarksburg, W. Va., would not comment further. Alamco's shares closed up $1, at $14.625, giving it a market value of almost $70 million. In January, Alamco hired Principal Financial Securities Inc. to explore putting all or some of the company up for sale. Michael Spohn, an analyst with Petroleum Research Group, speculated that the company would be bought by or merge with another midsize oil and gas producer.

title: Behind Cast-Iron Facades, Dreams Are Wrought
description: DOWNTOWN dead? SoHo finished?

title: Simmons Says He Declined Offer to Settle Lawsuit
description: Harold C. Simmons, the Dallas investor, said today that he had refused a $50 million settlement proposed by two of his daughters, who have sued for control of his billion-dollar corporate empire.

title: Budget Deal Killed Money For Repairing The Schools
description: A major element of President Clinton's education plan -- a proposal to spend $5 billion to repair the nation's crumbling schools -- was among the items quietly killed in last week's agreement to balance the Federal budget, Education Department officials acknowledged today.

title: Air Safety, Delayed
description: To the Editor:

title: Patent Bill Would Permit Theft of Ideas, Inventors Say
description: Congress is considering changes to the nation's patent system that would remove some of the confidentiality of patent applications -- a step that independent inventors say could ruin them and that big businesses contend is needed to help them remain competitive.

title: Correction: Putnam Competition Math Problem
description: A sample question published May 1 in the Metro Section with an article about the first woman to win the Putnam mathematics competition misstated a term in the solution. The expression (5/3) sould have been (6/3). Here are the question and the correct solution.

title: From the Lost Continent of Baroque
description: Rameau's ''Hippolyte et Aricie'' at the Brooklyn Academy of Music this week dances delicately between the past and present. Les Arts Florissants, its singers and musicians, would seem the principal players here, but this splendid act of revivification, a production shared by four French opera companies and and the academy, owes even more to its director, Jean-Marie Villegier.

title: On Stage, and Off
description: Winners and Losers

title: Another Nursing Home Deal Is Set, for $1.8 Billion
description: In the second large deal in two days in the long-term health care industry, Living Centers of America announced yesterday that it would merge with Grancare Inc. in a two-step, $1.8 billion transaction.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: Baseball

title: Hopes for Quick End to Age of Mobutu Are Fading Fast
description: The hopes among some Western Governments and many Zairians that when President Mobutu Sese Seko left here on Tuesday, he would not return, were crumbling today.

title: I.B.M. and Sears Sever Tie on Technology Venture
description: I.B.M. said yesterday that it would buy the 30 percent stake in a networking services joint venture with Sears, Roebuck & Company that it does not already own, ending the last of two technology partnerships between the companies.

title: No Headline
description: ''The nice thing about an agnostic is you don't think anybody is wrong.''

title: Student's 'Rage' Is Cited
description: A 16-year-old Cumberland Regional High School student, accused in the killing of a female classmate whose body was found in the boys' locker room last month, came close to making what the police construed as an admission of guilt, a state police detective testified yesterday.

title: Finding Drama on the Streets
description: ''Amazing,'' one woman said to another in the dark screening room. ''That's why I love Helen Levitt,'' the other one said.

title: CHRONICLE
description: Until yesterday, Senator JOHN F. KERRY, the Massachusetts Democrat, had been reticent about his efforts to have his first marriage annulled, issuing only a terse statement last month. But that changed, as he joked on national radio that the process of annulment can be confusing to non-Catholics, The Associated Press reported.

title: Where Would Central Park Be Without Them?
description: To the Editor:

title: Late Selloff Blunts Sharp Rise as the Dow Ends Up 50.97
description: If investors want volatility, they have it.

title: Even With a 3-1 Edge, No Joy in Rangerville
description: The mood in the Rangers' post-game dressing room was more gloomy than jubilant. Mark Messier emerged from the team lounge, a grim visage beneath his crew-cut pate. Players congregated around the big-screen television to make what they could of replays of the most serious incident of the series.

title: Detective in 'Megan' Trial Chokes Back Tears While Testifying About Puppy
description: He said it started with the little girl's interest in his puppy.

title: World Saved by a Nude Babe? Cool!
description: When the laid-back 23d-century New York City cabdriver meets the orange-haired, genetically engineered punk babe in ''The Fifth Element,'' they cannot communicate directly because they don't speak the same language. But there is one shared phrase they understand: ''Big badda-boom.'' Well, who doesn't grasp that concept at the start of the summer blockbuster sweepstakes? Flash, gimmicks, special effects and noisy pyrotechnics are so pervasive that they've even reached France.

title: Harris Drury to Handle Celebrity Cruises
description: Celebrity Cruises Inc. in Miami said yesterday that it had named Harris Drury Cohen in Fort Lauderdale to handle its account, which had been previously handled by Korey, Kay & Partners in New York. Billings were estimated at $15 million. The decision came after a review that had been narrowed to Harris Drury; Korey, Kay and three other finalists: Austin Kelly Advertising in Atlanta; BBDO South in Atlanta, a unit of Omnicom Group, and Loeffler Ketchum Mountjoy in Charlotte, N.C.

title: Toyota Plans to Offer Compact Car in Europe
description: The Toyota Motor Corporation said yesterday that it was planning to introduce an entry-level compact car in the European market as part of its strategy to expand local operations and sales in Europe. A spokeswoman for the Japanese auto giant said that the new model would be built at its planned second auto-assembly plant in Europe, which will start operating in the beginning of the next century.

title: China Seen to be in Hong Kong Phone Deal
description: China's two state-owned telecommunications providers will acquire 15 percent of Hong Kong's largest telephone company as part of a joint venture, investment bankers said early today.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Monday about the first beatification of a Gypsy by the Roman Catholic Church referred incorrectly to Jose Maria Escriva de Balaguer, the founder of the Catholic movement Opus Dei. He was beatified in 1992, not canonized.

title: Swiss Eye U.S. Report on Nazi Gold With a Yawn
description: If the aim of the United States report on what is called here the ''Nazi Gold affair'' was to bring Switzerland up short against the flawed morality of its ambiguous wartime neutrality, then, today at least, the point seemed to pass this languid lakeside city by.

title: A Budget Fit for Fantasyland
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CAVE, VERNAL G., M.D.
description: CAVE-Vernal G., M.D., The Board of Trustees, Medical Staff, Administration and employees of The Brookdale University Hospital and Medical Center express with great sorrow the passing of its esteemed member of the Board. He was a generous philanthropist who was sincerely committed to helping the hospital and its patients. To his wife, Natalie, and his family, we extend our profound and heartfelt condolences. Edwin L. Schulman, Chairman, Board of Trustees; David I. Schachne, Chairman, Executive Committee; Frank J. Maddalena, President and CEO

title: A Victory for the G.O.P.'s Moderates
description: In the last session of Congress, a small band of Republican moderates organized by Representative Sherwood Boehlert of New York succeeded in blocking nearly every attempt by their right-wing colleagues to gut the country's basic environmental statutes.

title: A Perot Comes to Town But Then Leaves With It
description: For four years, Ross Perot Jr., son of the two-time Presidential candidate and a multimillionaire in his own right, has owned more than half the land in tiny, once peaceful Westlake, Tex., just north of Dallas and Fort Worth.

title: April Sales Show Retailers Still Lag Behind Economy
description: Are American retail stores operating in the same economy as the rest of the country?

title: Elie Wiesel Says $70 Million Ought to Go to Nazi-Era Survivors
description: Aging Holocaust survivors ought to receive the roughly $70 million in Swiss gold of Nazi origin that has been stored for more than half a century in New York and London, Elie Wiesel, a spokesman for survivors, said here today.

title: Critical Race Theory
description: To the Editor:

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: PRO FOOTBALL

title: Democratic Leader Proposes Measure to Limit Abortions
description: In an attempt to resolve the bitter battle over what critics call partial-birth abortion, Senator Tom Daschle, the Democratic leader, proposed legislation today that would ban all abortions after a fetus is viable, allowing exceptions only if the pregnancy posed a ''grievous injury'' to a woman's physical health.

title: New Jersey Assembly Votes To Ban Abortion Procedure
description: The New Jersey General Assembly overwhelmingly approved legislation today that would ban a procedure described by abortion opponents as ''partial-birth abortion,'' putting Gov. Christine Todd Whitman in a difficult political position.

title: South African Producer Expands Sugar Empire
description: Illovo Sugar Ltd., South Africa's biggest sugar producer, said yesterday that it had agreed to buy Lonrho P.L.C.'s African sugar unit for 1.62 billion rand ($365 million) cash to extend its reach across the continent. Illovo said the acquisition of the British company's 94.25 percent stake in Lonrho Sugar Ltd., which owns plantations in Swaziland, South Africa, Mauritius and Malawi, would give it access to lower-cost production in sub-Saharan Africa.

title: Landlord Group Begins Drive to Reassure Elderly Tenants
description: Joining the battle for public opinion on the issue of rent regulation, New York City's largest landlords' group began mailing brochures yesterday to about 200,000 elderly residents of rent-regulated apartments, seeking to reassure them that they would not be affected if the laws were changed.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RICHMAN, GERTRUDE
description: RICHMAN-Gertrude. On May 8, 1997. Beloved wife of the late Bernard. Loving mother of David and Susan. Devoted grandmother of Alexa and Stephanie. Services at Temple Beth-El, 280 Summit Avenue, Hackensack, N.J., Friday, at 1:30 P.M. In lieu of flowers, donations to Temple Beth-El or a favorite charity appreciated. For info: ''Gutterman - Musicant'', Hackensack, NJ. (800-522-0588).

title: BAY VIEW CAPITAL AGREES TO BUY AMERICA FIRST EUREKA
description: The Bay View Capital Corporation said yesterday that it had agreed to buy America First Eureka Holdings for $300 million in cash and stock, in a combination of two banking organizations in the San Francisco Bay area. Bay View Capital, the parent of Bay View Bank, would pay $90 million in cash and $210 million in stock for First Eureka, which owns the Eurekabank savings and loan. A fund that owns First Eureka -- having acquired Eurekabank from the Federal agency in charge of turning around troubled savings and loans -- said it would wind up its affairs after the completion of the transaction, expected by Jan. 1.

title: Enriched by His Friendship With an Agnostic, a Rabbi Finances a Storied Legacy
description: One man speaks to God. The other speaks to the stock market. Both of them hear things that no one else does.

title: NEW VIDEO RELEASES
description: Ransom

title: G. N. Aagaard, Medical Dean, Is Dead at 83
description: Dr. George N. Aagaard, former dean of the University of Washington School of Medicine, died on Wednesday at the university's Medical Center in Seattle. He was 83 and lived in Seattle.

title: A Detective Is Accused of Robbing Drug Dealers
description: A New York City narcotics detective lived a corrupt second life by joining an old friend's murderous gang in robbing drug dealers and trafficking in guns, a Federal prosecutor told a Brooklyn jury yesterday.

title: A Redeeming Adornment, If Nature Turns You On
description: Nature programs feed the dreams of the sedentary adventurer with views -- exotic, spectacular, intimate -- that no safari can match. With their ingenious photography and colorful content, they are unarguably a redeeming adornment of television. So if I reveal a reservation or two here, take it as a confession and not as any sort of reproach.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DUBOIS, DUKE
description: DuBOIS-Duke. We will miss his generosity, humor and friendship. Most of all we will never forget what he has done for our children. The Kinberg Family

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PEZZATTI, JOHN THOMAS
description: PEZZATTI-John Thomas, of West Harrison, New York. Husband of Rosemarie Sarvaideo Pezzatti. Father of John Paul Pezzatti. Funeral Mass Monday, 10AM, at Saint Anthony of Padua, West Harrison, NY. Interment Ferncliff Cemetery. Reposing at the Ballard-Durand Funeral Home, 2 Maple Ave., White Plains, NY, Friday, 7-9PM, Sat. 2-4 and 7-9PM.

title: Exel Is Buying Reinsurance Competitor
description: In a continued consolidation of the catastrophe reinsurance business, Exel Ltd., a property and casualty insurer based in Bermuda, said it had agreed to buy GCR Holdings Ltd., which is also based in Bermuda, for $637 million, or $27 a share.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  ZEGERS, KORT, HERMINA J.
description: ZEGERS-KORT-Hermina J. Remembered on this your birthday with great affection and fondest memories. Your family

title: Maggie's Influence
description: To the Editor:

title: Chief of United Paramount Network Is Quitting
description: Lucie Salhany, the chief executive of United Paramount Network, said yesterday that she had decided not to renew her contract this fall as head of the fledgling television network, which is jointly owned by Viacom Inc., the parent company of Paramount Pictures, and Chris-Craft Industries.

title: By Way of Mario Puzo, All in the Family, Again
description: You want the Mafia? Get Mario Puzo, author of ''The Godfather,'' which the director Francis Ford Coppola made into the film that is now celebrating its 25th anniversary. CBS is obviously hoping that the magic carries over into the six hours of ''Mario Puzo's 'The Last Don,' '' which begins on Sunday and continues Tuesday and Wednesday. Don't hold your breath.

title: Zaire's Capital Is Counting the Days With Hope and Dread
description: Although six years have passed, not a day goes by when Antoine Nehme fails to recall the morning in September 1991 when he arrived at his general merchandise store downtown to discover that he had lost everything to looting soldiers.

title: Student Held in Bomb Plot and Stabbing of Classmate
description: Apparently intent on blowing up a Jewish classmate, 16-year-old Gregory Rohr showed up at Smithtown High School on Monday with some gasoline, a makeshift fuse and a bottle, planning to assemble a homemade bomb, the police said.

title: Oil and Gasoline Prices Surge On Concern About Refineries
description: Crude oil and gasoline prices surged on the New York Mercantile Exchange yesterday, hurt by worries over refinery shutdowns and a strike in Nigeria.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MALKIN, EDGAR W.
description: MALKIN-Edgar W. Beloved father of Harold and Jill Malkin Addeo, loving father-in-law of Jennifer Porter and Geoffrey Addeo, dear friend of Ruth Neale and loving guardian of Seth. His devotion, warmth and wit will be sorely missed by all whose lives he touched. He cared deeply for his family and dear friends. We pray that he may rest in peace knowing how much we loved him. Funeral services on Friday, May 9 at 10AM at ''The Riverside'', 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: FORD AND LENDER REVIEW MINORITY CHARGES
description: The Ford Motor Company and the Associates First Capital Corporation, a consumer and commercial lending company 80.3 percent owned by Ford, are reviewing allegations that Associates took advantage of borrowers who were poorly educated or from low-income or minority groups, Ford's chairman, Alex Trotman, said yesterday at a news conference after the Ford shareholders annual meeting. He added that executives and outside directors of Associates were conducting the review with Ford officials. It should be completed within two weeks, and the two companies will decide then whether any action is warranted, Mr. Trotman said, adding that Ford and Associates frequently review their business practices. Mr. Trotman acknowledged that isolated instances of unethical conduct might have taken place, but he expressed strong doubt that any large-scale problem existed.

title: Geometry, Man's and Nature's
description: ''Moondog,'' Tony Smith's 17-foot-high, open-structured behemoth at the Paula Cooper Gallery, has a grand, austere but slightly lumbering and off-balance presence, like that of a tipsy Titan. Recently fabricated in aluminum painted the artist's usual matte black, it's an imposing sight, a good example of what scale can do (although not always) for a piece well conceived to start with.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FREDRICKSON, ROBERT K.
description: FREDRICKSON-Robert K., May 7, 1997, of Manhasset, NY. Beloved husband of Karen (McMahon). Cherished father of Christine Pilotte, Madeline, and James. Dear brother of Kenneth, the late James Fredrickson, Michael McCarthy, and Kathleen McCarthyHiggins. Son-in-law of william and Edna McMahon. In repose at the Fairchild Funeral Chapel, 1570 Northern Blvd, Manhasset, Friday, Saturday and Sunday 3-5 & 7-9PM. Funeral mass 9:30AM, Monday, St. Mary's R.C. Church, Manhasset. Burial at Nassau Knolls Cemetery. In lieu of flowers, please send contributions to the Robert K. Fredrickson Scholarship Fund/Rice High School, 74 West 124 Street, NY, NY 10027. (212) 369-4100.

title: Asia's New Red Revolution?It Comes in a Wineglass
