description: HONG KONG  As Filipino singers crooned "Love is a wonderful thing" amid a blaze of colored strobe lights, Edmund Wu relaxed against a large pink cushion on a sofa with his left hand caressing the shoulder of a pretty nightclub hostess and his right hand cupping a glass of Chateau Lafite-Rothschild.

title: UNION PLANTERS TO ACQUIRE MISSISSIPPI BANK COMPANY
description: The Union Planters Corporation agreed yesterday to acquire Magna Bancorp Inc. of Hattiesburg, Miss., for $323 million in stock, expanding its franchise and making it the third-largest bank in Mississippi. Union Planters, based in Memphis, will add 46 branches in neighboring Mississippi and 15 in southern Alabama. It agreed to pay 0.5165 share, or $23.50, for each Magna share. The deal was announced after Magna closed at $18.25, up 75 cents, and Union Planters closed at $45.50, down 62.5 cents. With the acquisition, Union Planters will have $15 billion in assets in seven states.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WALKER, NANCY
description: WALKER-Nancy. Beloved sister of James W. and Louis Walker. Beloved aunt of President George Bush and 20 nephews and nieces. A volunteer nurse's aide for 30 years at Roosevelt Hospital. A point in light in many lives. Funeral Services will be private.

title: White House Aide Pushed Plan Benefiting Chinese Shipping Concern
description: During a tough battle last year over how a closed Navy base in Long Beach, Calif., would be used, a Clinton Administration official made what several people involved describe as highly unusual telephone calls to push for construction there of a container terminal that would be leased to a shipping company owned by the Chinese Government.

title: Clinton's Choice: Press the Swiss, or Close Books
description: A half-century ago President Truman faced the question of whether to force Switzerland to disgorge millions in Nazi plunder. In a decision that a Government report concluded on Wednesday was an enormous blunder, he decided that the United States had bigger interests at stake -- rebuilding Europe and fighting Communism -- and settled for token reparations for the victims of Nazism.

title: HONG KONG MONEY RETURNED BY G.O.P.
description: In the first confirmation that the Republican Party accepted substantial illegal foreign donations, the Republican National Committee announced today that it was returning more than $100,000 in donations from a Hong Kong aviation-services and real estate company.

title: Heat's Mourning Seeks A Friendlier Whistle
description: The personal fouls appeared too personal. That is what ruffled Heat Coach Pat Riley, fresh from a film session today of Wednesday's Game 1 defeat to the Knicks, which revealed Alonzo Mourning as a victim of circumstance. At least that is what Riley argued.

title: N.H.L. EASTERN CONFERENCE SEMIFINAL: GAME 4
description: Adam Graves's power-play goal in the first period gave New York the lead, and Mike Richter made it stand with his second shutout of the series as thhe Rangers took a three-games-to-one lead over the Devils in their four-of-seven-game playoff. Game 5 will be on Sunday in East Rutherford, N.J.

title: People
description: * Steven Wold, creative director, and Steven Marsho, account services director at Bender, Browning, Dolby & Sanderson, Milwaukee, were promoted to the additional positions of managing partners, succeeding Richard L. Upton, the executive vice president and managing partner, who is leaving to join the Martin Agency, Richmond, a unit of Interpublic Group of Cos., as senior vice president and group management supervisor.

title: Violinist Pays the Piper
description: Judge Harold Baer Jr. has long lamented that the naturalization ceremonies in which new citizens swear their allegiance to this country are dry and lifeless affairs, with none of the soul-stirring pomp befitting such momentous civic occasions.

title: Humiliation Business And Its Customers
description: One male client insists on being dressed up and painted into a garish parody of a teen-age girl and then told that ''being a big girl means pain in this world.'' Another, who is Jewish, wants ethnic slurs hurled at him in a Nazi setting that he specifies not be as demeaning as a concentration camp. A black man in shackles grovels at the feet of the make-believe mistress of a Southern plantation. All three are patrons of Pandora's Box, an emporium in the Flatiron district of Manhattan that gratifies the elaborate fantasies of submissive men in sessions that can cost upward of $1,000.

title: Corrections
description: A brief report by Dow Jones in the Company News column of Business Day on Tuesday about a proposed purchase of properties from the Confederation Life Insurance Company, a failed Canadian insurer, by Dames & Moore/Brookhill L.L.C. misstated the headquarters location of Dames & Moore. It is Los Angeles, not Boca Raton, Fla.

title: Lakers Take Advantage As Jazz Shots Go Awry
description: The basket shrunk on the Utah Jazz tonight. Utah's most valuable player candidate was 2 for 20, its All-Star point guard was 0 for 6 and its 3-point threat was 2 of 11.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article yesterday about a domino tournament in the Bronx omitted the given name of the coordinator of the Morris Senior Center, which sponsored a team. She is Nilda Ayala.

title: Senate Backs Disaster Aid Bill Despite Veto Threat Over Government Shutdown Issue
description: The Senate tonight endorsed an emergency $8.4 billion spending bill triggered by floods in the Dakotas, despite a firm veto threat over a provision intended to prevent Government shutdowns during budget disputes.

title: Good Advice From Mr. Freeh
description: According to numerous news accounts, the head of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, Louis Freeh, has given Attorney General Janet Reno some sound advice for carrying out her duty in the White House fund-raising scandals. Unfortunately, Ms. Reno still refuses to heed it, despite the mounting damage to the Justice Department's reputation and her own.

title: Frank Capra: A Full Range
description: His films had a heart as big as all Hollywood, and they came to epitomize Hollywood's most stirring idea of heart. The legacy of Frank Capra, appreciated for grace and finesse as well as for the fundamental decency of the world these films described, will be celebrated at the Film Forum during a monthlong series, ''Capra 100,'' commemorating the centennial of the film maker's birth. (He died in 1991.) Here, in this comprehensive retrospective featuring rare silents alongside the classics, is the chance to get beyond ''It's a Wonderful Life'' and explore Capra's full range.

title: Northern Italy Separatists Seizex Bell Tower in St. Mark's Square
description: A small group of men raced two vans with Venetian flags through Saint Mark's Square just after midnight today and broke into the historic bell tower to demand a separate state in northern Italy. The police said the men were armed, but no shots were fired and no one was injured during the takeover.

title: More Money for Schools and Child Welfare and Less for Police
description: After shearing more than $1 billion from the Board of Education's projected spending in the first two years of his administration, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani yesterday proposed increasing the board's budget next year. He wants to add $172 million for new programs, and nearly $1 billion over several years for new classrooms and computers.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEY, HENRY F.G. JR.
description: WEY-Henry F.G. Jr., of Rye, NY, on May 6, 1997. Beloved husband of the late Elizabeth. Loving father of Henry F.G. Wey III, Peter R. Wey & Thomas A. Wey. Devoted brother of Mary Frances Pratt and the late Barbara Wey Ward. Survived by 11 grandchildren and 6 great grandchildren. A memorial service will be held at Christ's Church of Rye, Friday, May 9 at 10 AM. Interment private. In lieu of flowers, donations to Christ's Church of Rye and/or United Hospital Medical Center, 406 Boston Post Road, Port Chester, New York 10573 would be appreciated.

title: Nothing Clicks as Devils Begin to Feel Frustrated
description: The Devils had not lost three games in a row all season, but they picked the worst time to do it. They had acknowledged before last night's Game 4 of their series with the Rangers that the game was of the utmost importance for them, the first time they made such a statement all season. Yet they failed to perform up to the level of importance they placed on the matchup.

title: Restaurants
description: Look up and the horses are galloping straight at you, coming on ferociously. In the dim light, the Sienese Palio swirls around your head with dizzying intensity. Sandro Chia has painted murals on all four walls of the square room, putting you smack in the middle of the race. It is exciting art and it makes the bar at Palio one of New York City's most magical spaces.

title: Springer Quits News Show, Citing Attacks
description: Jerry Springer, the talk show host whose hiring as a commentator by a Chicago television station created an uproar of opposition, quit that job yesterday after less than a week on the air.

title: Olbermann Still Visible Despite a Forced Exile
description: Keith Olbermann yesterday marked his ninth day of involuntary exile from ESPN's ''Sportscenter'' for a rap sheet of alleged naughtiness against the network that culminated on April 16, when he appeared on Comedy Central's ''The Daily Show'' without ESPN's say-so.

title: Van Gundy Not Ecstatic Over Game 1 Victory
description: Pat Riley used his off day to complain about referees in love with the sound of their own whistles. Jeff Van Gundy? He wonders why everyone is patting the Knicks on the back.

title: In Victory for U.S., Europe Ban On Treated Beef Is Ruled Illegal
description: The European Union's ban on hormone-treated beef is illegal, a panel of the World Trade Organization has decided, potentially giving the American cattle industry a big victory but also turning over new ground on issues of national sovereignty.

title: A Bad Pair of Twins
description: The dark current of class resentment that played a role in ending nearly two decades of Conservative rule in Britain last week comes to the surface in the gleefully anarchic black comedy ''Twin Town.''

title: UMass and UConn Lose '96 Honors
description: The National Collegiate Athletic Association came down hard yesterday on both the University of Massachusetts and the University of Connecticut, stripping each school of its victories in the 1996 men's basketball tournament.

title: The Seeds Of History: A Find In Mexico
description: An analysis of squash seeds from a Mexican cave has cast new light on the beginnings of agriculture in pre-Columbian America. It showed that ancient Americans began domesticating a few plants at least 4,000 years earlier than previously thought. But then they took a much longer time to become full-fledged farmers than did people in the Middle East, the first agriculturalists.

title: Giant and the Waffler
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MILLER, HANNAH
description: MILLER-Hannah. AMIT is deeply saddened by the passing of our generous benefactor and beloved sister-in-law of our most devoted Honorary National President, Dina Dyckman. Heartfelt condolences to her children and the entire family. Evelyn Blachor, National Pres. Marvin Leff, Exec. Dir,

title: A Dizzying Selection in a Mini-Milan of Home Design
description: Given the number of shops in SoHo selling scented candles and imported soaps, one might expect the streets to smell like an explosion of roses or gardenias or lemons. They don't. But what SoHo lacks in sweet street scents, it makes up for in spirit. Shoppers these days are a serious lot and many seem more intent on finding the perfect plate than the perfect painting.

title: CYRK INTERNATIONAL AGREES TO BUY SIMON MARKETING
description: Cyrk International said yesterday that it would buy the closely held promoter Simon Marketing for as much as $63 million in stock and cash. Cyrk said the purchase would add 450 employees and 10 offices worldwide. Simon, based in Los Angeles, handles promotions for McDonald's, Blockbuster and Chevron. Cyrk, based in Gloucester, Mass., promotes products for Philip Morris, Pepsico and Volkswagen's American division. Cyrk said it would pay $45 million to Simon's stockholders when the transaction closes and about $13 million to other equity holders and key employees. An additional $5 million will be paid two years after the closing if certain goals are met.

title: Even Funeral Is Journalism At Its Best
description: MURRAY KEMPTON said goodbye yesterday in his own fashion, which is to say with a maximum of dignity and a minimum of self-reference.

title: Queens Man Is Arrested After Cocaine Is Found
description: A Queens man was arrested after the police found 65 kilograms, or more than 140 pounds, of cocaine stuffed in the trunk of a car he was driving on Wednesday night. The cocaine would be worth as much as $10 million on the street.

title: ICI Australia Shares Drop Sharply
description: The shares of ICI Australia Ltd. plunged yesterday after the company's parent, Imperial Chemicals Industries P.L.C., said on Wednesday that it would sell its 62.4 percent stake in its Australian subsidiary. The sale, which contradicts earlier speculation the British parent would buy out minority shareholders in ICI, comes as ICI P.L.C. prepares to buy the specialty chemicals of Unilever N.V. for $8 billion in cash.

title: Mastectomy Measure Vetoed
description: Governor Whitman yesterday vetoed a bill to require health insurers to let women remain in a hospital up to 72 hours after mastectomy surgery.

title: Clinton, at Costa Rica Talks, Gives Pledge on Immigrants
description: After meeting here today with the leaders of seven Central American and Caribbean nations, President Clinton said he would seek to blunt a new law to restrict illegal immigration and compel deportations.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FLECHNER, ABRAHAM J.
description: FLECHNER-Abraham J., died May 7, 1997. Beloved husband of Brenda. Devoted father of Neil, Carol, and Roberta. Cherished brother of Max. We will miss him.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHWARTZ, TILLIE
description: SCHWARTZ-Tillie, of White Plains, NY. Mother of Professor Eli Schwartz, Claire Walden and the late Dr. Harold Schwartz. Sister of Esther Boykan. Grandmother of seven. Great-grandmother of six. Graveside service Friday, 2 P.M., at Mount Hebron Cemetery.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SITZER, ANNA P.
description: SITZER-Anna P. Beloved wife of the late Frank Sitzer. Loving mother of Thelma Feldhamer of Denver, CO, and Stanley (Carole) Sitzer of Miami Beach and Henedersonville, NC. Beloved motherin-law of Marcia for many years. Cherished grandmother of David (Beth), Steven (Pauline) and Marc (Valerie) Stitzer, Abbe (Mitchell) Lewites, Randy Morris and Mark (Marnie) Feldhamer. Adored great-grandmother of Amanda, Carly and Michael Sitzer, Jordan and Adam Lewites, Shane Morris and Morgan and Meryl Feldhamer. Services were held in Miami Beach on May 8.

title: NEW VIDEO RELEASES
description: The Funeral

title: Sony Posts Huge Increases In Net for Quarter and Year
description: The Sony Corporation said today that earnings surged more than tenfold in its fiscal fourth quarter, helped by the weak yen and sales of its Playstation video game.

title: No Insurance? No Car
description: A bill that would allow the state to impound and ultimately sell -- cars belonging to uninsured drivers cleared the Senate Commerce Committee yesterday.

title: Rocky going in stocks didn't faze fund investors in April.
description: MUTUAL fund investors, apparently unfazed by the stock market's rampant volatility in April, added some $13.5 billion to equity funds last month, a trade group reported yesterday.

title: Breast-Feeding Law Revised
description: Acceding to requests from Gov. Christine Todd Whitman, the State Assembly adopted a revised version of a bill yesterday that allows women the right to breast-feed in public.

title: For Children
description: 'Meet the Animal Mommies'

title: H. Myles Jacob, 84, A Copper Executive
description: H. Myles Jacob, a former chief executive of the Inspiration Consolidated Copper Company, died yesterday at his home in Pittstown, N.J. He was 84.

title: Teen-Agers Who Have Too Much Free Time
description: Every lurid, tacky, overheated fantasy you've ever had of depraved Hollywood youth careening down the fast lane into the millennium is splattered comically across the screen in ''Nowhere,'' the overstuffed finale of Gregg Araki's ''Teen Apocalypse'' trilogy. This live-action cartoon might be described as a surreal ''American Graffiti'' crossed with a kinky ''Beverly Hills 90210,'' as imagined by a punked-out acolyte of John Waters or Andy Warhol.

title: Magic Heard From 2 Teams
description: Magic Johnson's jersey apparently will remain on a Forum wall. The Orlando Magic and the Utah Jazz each offered contracts this season to the former Los Angeles Laker guard -- Orlando's offer coming only three weeks before the playoffs -- but Johnson resisted the temptation to play again.

title: D.M.B.& B. Splits Asia-Pacific Region
description: D'Arcy Masius Benton & Bowles Communications, a unit of the MacManus Group, said yesterday that it had split its Asia-Pacific region into two separate divisions and named two presidents to head them.

title: Steinbrenner Suspension Would Be Risky Legally
description: Although George Steinbrenner has angered people throughout baseball by suing 29 clubs, 3 subsidiaries and 14 officials, owners and lawyers, Major League Baseball will tread carefully in considering the view of some officials and owners that Steinbrenner should be suspended.

title: Fathers Going Farther (Or Is It Further?)
description: Considering the number of tepid French comedies that have been remade for American audiences, it's a wonder that ''Les Comperes'' took so long. That spirited odd-couple farce, starring Gerard Depardieu and Pierre Richard and released here in 1984, was a big French hit for good reason. As written and directed by Francis Veber, who readily recycled the tone of his screenplay for ''La Cage aux Folles,'' this was another giddy star vehicle for the right comic talent. Enter Billy Crystal and Robin Williams: for American audiences, the casting couldn't be any more right than that.

title: Watson Can Trim Hours
description: Bob Watson has received the support he said he had been waiting to hear. On Wednesday, two weeks after Watson, the Yankee vice president and general manager, was hospitalized overnight with high blood pressure, Watson heard George Steinbrenner's endorsement of the end of the 105-hour work week.

title: Old Guard Has Spring Offensive
description: THEY are grumpy old men, these people named Tikkanen and Gretzky and Messier, Oakley and Williams. They learned their lessons in other places and then they were brought to New York, a French Foreign Legion for millionaires.

title: Corrections
description: A report in the Chronicle column on Wednesday about the sentencing of Eric Douglas, the youngest son of Kirk Douglas, included an erroneous reference from The Associated Press to the charge to which he pleaded guilty on Monday. It was one charge of misdemeanor possession of cocaine, not accepting a package containing 1,085 antidepressant pills.

title: Corrections
description: A sample question on May 1 with an article about the first woman to win the Putnam math competition misstated a term in the solution. The problem and the correct solution are printed today on page B4.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: AMERICAN BRANDS INC., Old Greenwich, Conn., said the Internal Revenue Service had approved the company's planned spinoff of its Gallaher Tobacco business as tax free, clearing the way for the transaction.

title: CHRONICLE
description: Eight years ago, BOB HOPE and ROSEMARY CLOONEY teamed up during a summer theater appearance to do a song called ''Old Friends.'' On Sunday, Mr. Hope's wife, DOLORES HOPE, will do the same number with Ms. Clooney when they open an engagement at Rainbow and Stars.

title: INSIDE METRO
description: RENT-LAW FIGHT -- Landlords are stepping up their campaign to change rent laws, using a mailing to play down the impact of a free-market system. B6.

title: INSIDE
description: Venice Bell Tower Is Seized

title: William A. Koshland, 90, Former Knopf President, Dies
description: William A. Koshland, chairman emeritus and former president of the publisher Alfred A. Knopf, died on Wednesday at Mount Sinai Medical Center in Manhattan. He was 90 and lived in Manhattan.

title: PNC BANK IS SAID TO BE IN TALKS WITH OPPENHEIMER
description: The PNC Bank Corporation of Pittsburgh is in talks to acquire Oppenheimer & Company, the Wall Street brokerage firm, for about $500 million, a person familiar with the talks said yesterday. PNC is discussing acquiring Oppenheimer, which is privately held, with a combination of cash, stock and options. The two sides have not determined a firm price, and a formal agreement could be two weeks or more away, the person said, adding that the talks could still fall apart. PNC's shares fell $1.625, to $40.875, yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange after the discussions were reported in The Wall Street Journal.

title: State Senator Weighing Run for Comptroller
description: State Senator Larry B. Seabrook, a Bronx Democrat and the former chairman of the Black and Puerto Rican Legislative Caucus, said yesterday that he was considering challenging City Comptroller Alan G. Hevesi for the Democratic nomination for that post, in part to protest Mr. Hevesi's willingness to run on the Liberal Party line with Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani.

title: Fuji to Start Making Film at U.S. Plant
description: The Fuji Photo Film Company said today that it would begin manufacturing photographic film in the United States.

title: A City at Death's Door Turns the Doctors Away
description: ''They weren't even a year old, maybe just a few months,'' said an elderly man wandering one corner of the city cemetery, where rows of rock shards are the sole markers of the young dead. ''They were just babies.''

title: U.S. to Ease Rules on Export of Finance Encryption Technology
description: Giving ground on the Clinton Administration's computer-data privacy policy, the Commerce Department said yesterday that it would begin in some cases to allow export of the most powerful data-scrambling technologies when used for securing financial transactions.

title: Three Goldman Managers Start a Firm
description: Three money managers said yesterday that they had left Goldman, Sachs & Company to set up Entrust Capital Inc., an investment firm that manages money for wealthy clients.

title: The Real Guilt
description: It is as if the Nuremberg tribunal after World War II had found a German soldier guilty of war crimes while the Nazi leaders who directed the Holocaust went free -- and continued to control half of Germany.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BLINKEN, ETHEL H.
description: BLINKEN-Ethel H., died in Palm Beach, Florida on May 7 after a long illness. She was born in New York City in 1903 and married Maurice H. Blinken in 1964. He died in 1986. She is survived by her sons, Ambassador Donald Blinken of Budapest, Robert Blinken of Bedford Hills and Ambassador Alan Blinken of Brussels, as well as nine grandchildren and six great grandchildren. Interment will be private.

title: President Houdini
description: Don't ever bet against him. Bill Clinton appears to spend most of his time being pummeled by scandals and other problems. He seems always on the verge of being punched out politically. And then, somehow, to the amazement of his friends and the consternation of his enemies (or vice versa), he comes off the ropes to fashion some dazzling new triumph.

title: White House and Senate Clash On a Cash-Poor Loan Program
description: The White House has refused to give a Senate committee three documents on a popular small-business loan program that is running short of money, and Republicans responded today by accusing the Administration of simply trying to avoid political embarrassment.

title: News Summary
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-13

title: Pair of Aggressive Plays Backfires for Mets
description: There are times when an athlete's aggressiveness and instinct, which normally make the athlete successful, are counterproductive. It happened twice to the Mets today, two crucial plays in their 4-2 loss to the Houston Astros. For the third time in a week, the Mets (16-18) tried and failed to achieve a .500 record.

title: Israeli Drug Maker Reports Strong Quarter
description: Teva Pharmaceutical Industries Ltd. reported yesterday that its net income rose 68 percent in the first quarter, helped for a second straight quarter by sales of two newer products: an anti-epilepsy drug and an ulcer medication.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KOSHLAND, WILLIAM A.
description: KOSHLAND-William A. On May 7, 1997. Greatly loved uncle of Kathryn K. and Anthony D. Blue, great uncle of Caitlin, Toby, Jessica, and Amanda Blue, and Stephen A. Koshland, treasured cousin of Sally J. Kuhn, & devoted friend of Tibor S. Heredy. Memorial service to be announced at a later date. Donations in his memory may be made to Harvard University, Phillips Exeter Academy, & the UJA-Federation of Jewish Philanthropies.

title: NEW VIDEO RELEASES
description: The Visitors

title: Home Video
description: Trying Something New

title: Trump Fights Tunnel Plan
description: Lawyers for Donald J. Trump are to argue in Superior Court today that casino tax revenues cannot be spent to help another developer build a casino complex.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary on Wednesday about David E. Scherman, an editor and photojournalist who survived the sinking of an ocean liner by a Nazi warship, misstated the timing of the incident at one point. The sinking, on April 17, 1941, was during World War II, not before it.

title: Greenspan Defends Fed's Rate Policy
description: Clearly stung by widespread criticism that the Federal Reserve had been too quick to raise interest rates six weeks ago, Alan Greenspan, the central bank's chairman, aggressively defended the action last night, saying that failure to act would have constituted ''a threat to the job security and standards of living of too many Americans.''

title: Jerome Alden, 76, Stage and TV Writer
description: Jerome Alden, a writer for stage, television and screen whose works included the play ''Bully'' and the musical ''Teddy and Alice,'' died on Sunday at his home in Manhattan.

title: Cement Gloves Are Off As Graves Finds Mark
description: Until he scored last night's early ice-and-Devil-breaker, the Rangers' first goal in a 3-0 victory, Adam Graves had been unable to perform anything resembling a handy maneuver around any opponent's net this playoff season. So Graves had to settle for being the Rangers' resident handyman.

title: Be a Great Employer. Give a Hologram Lollipop.
description: So what happens at the Javits Convention Center when high-profile events like the Auto Show are not around? Well, something called the Premium Incentive Show, for one.

title: Pataki Considers Tenant Safeguards in a Rent-Law Plan
description: As he pieces together his plan for brokering a deal on rent control, Gov. George E. Pataki is considering a proposal to impose criminal penalties on landlords who try to harass tenants into vacating their apartments, aides to the Governor said today.

title: Diner's Journal
description: Julia Child is at one table. Jacques Pepin is at another. Nobu Matsuhisa is in the corner, with Maguy Le Coze nearby. Opulent Le Cirque 2000 is finally open, and the entire food world is there.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  POLKOWITZ, LOUISE (NEE NIERENBERG)
description: POLKOWITZ-Louise (nee Nierenberg) on May 8, 1997. Beloved wife of Maurice Polkowitz. Devoted mother of Gary Polkowitz and Ellen Kleiner of Santa Fe, New Mexico. Grandmother of Jordi and Devin Kleiner, Santa Fe. Sister of Harry Nierenberg of Florda, and Irving Nierenberg, Atlanta, Georgia. Service Sunday, 11:30AM Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave at 81 Street. Remembrances to American Friends of Tel Aviv University, 360 Lexington Avenue, New York, New York 10016.

title: European Vintage Cars In a Tour of Their Own
description: Just after noon on a bright, clear spring day, we were outside the town of Albi in the South of France, completing Day 3 of the Tour de France Auto. Suddenly the gearbox on our Alfa Romeo race car exploded, filling the interior with transmission fluid, dust, hot shrapnel and blood. The left leg of my co-driver, Giuseppe Tomasetti, a lawyer from Milan, was sliced open in two places and required immediate medical attention. The intensity of European vintage racing had caught up with us.

title: Execution and Torture
description: The Israeli Government announced today that Israeli Jews who sell land to Palestinians will face execution.

title: Where the Restaurants Just Keep Springing Up
description: IF you have an appetite for fancy restaurants, it will not be satisfied in SoHo. But if you are hungry for any particular sort of food, you're sure to find it there. SoHo just seems to keep on drawing new restaurants; in the last year or so it has acquired the prettiest bistro in New York (Balthazar), a terrific place to eat fish (Aquagrill) and two exciting young chefs (Johannes Sanzin at Sanzin and Katy Sparks at Quilty's).

title: Chicago's Late Heroics Fail to Arrive in Game 2
description: Bulls fans have grown accustomed to their team falling behind early in games, and then, in the third or fourth periods, watching as Michael Jordan seems to emerge from a telephone booth and Scottie Pippen from a Pippenmobile as one or both save the day with a variety of super shots and plays.

title: $532 Million Deal Set In British Electronics
description: Siebe P.L.C., a British electronics manufacturer, agreed yesterday to buy APV P.L.C. for about $:345 million ($532 million) in stock and debt to expand its industrial valves and controls business into the food and beverage industries. Holders of APV will get 0.10955 of a new Siebe share for each APV share or cash worth 97.5 pence ($1.50) a share. The stock offer values an APV share at 105 pence ($1.62).

title: Bronx Man Is Acquitted In Death of Police Officer
description: A Bronx jury acquitted a man of homicide and assault charges last night in the death of a police officer who fell on the shards of a broken mirror while trying to handcuff the man after a domestic dispute nearly a year ago, the Bronx District Attorney's office said.

title: Jazz Seeks Better Shot, As Does Lakers' O'Neal
description: It might be safe to re-enter the Western Conference playoffs, now that the Utah Jazz cannot make a layup. Or maybe that was just its one off night of the decade.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MOHINK, JOHN GENE
description: MOHINK-John Gene. On May 8, 1997. Beloved father of Francine Mohink and Steven. Cherished grandfather of Todd, Nicole and Adina. Beloved father-in-law of Sharon. Services Sunday, May 11, 10AM, at The Garlick-Riverside Memorial Chapel, 1439 Unionport Road, Bronx, New York.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GIACALONE, JOHN PAUL
description: GIACALONE-John Paul, passed away on May 5, 1997. At the time of his death, he was a corporate attorney in private practice in New York City. Mr. Giacalone was born and raised on Long Island. He was one of six siblings starting life as a New Years Eve baby in 1961. Mr. Giacalone graduated magna cum laude from The State University of New York at Stony Brook, where he received degrees in English and History in 1983. He than went on to receive his Juris Doctorate from Fordham University in 1986. Mr. Giacalone was also a member of the distinguished MENSA, a member of the New York Bar Association, and also was admitted to practice before the Eastern District of the United States Supreme Court in 1995. He is survived by his mother, Anna Giacalone and by his brothers and sisters, Paul, Tammy, Rosanna, Vito, and Louis. He is also survived by his grandmother, Sadie Tumminia and best friend, Gary Gillis. This obituary was written by dear friend, Pat Canole. For further information, call (212) 799-9072.

title: Citing Security, U.S. Jails Iraqis It Used in Plot
description: A group of Iraqis who worked with the Central Intelligence Agency in a failed attempt to undermine Saddam Hussein and were offered refuge by the United States Government are now in jail in California, facing expulsion from this country.

title: Pitino Sets Dominoes In Motion
description: RICK PITINO finally walked, and the basketball landscape shook. The salary ceiling for coaches landed with a thud, an old racial stereotype began to crumble, and the rumbling on the road out of Boston was a legend named Larry going home.

title: Zaire's Absent President Keeps the World Guessing
description: After another day in which he kept Zairians and the world in suspense about his intentions, President Mobutu Sese Seko failed to return home today, contrary to earlier assurances from his Government and aides.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GIGANTE, YOLANDA
description: GIGANTE-Yolanda, 95 years old, born in Naples, Italy and a resident of Greenwich Village for 76 years. Beloved wife of the late Salvatore Esposito Vulgo Gigante. Devoted mother of Mario, Vincent, Rev. Louis and the late Pasquale, Vincenzo and Ralph. Loving sister of Dolores Santasilia. Also survived by 17 grandchildren and 32 great-grandchildren. Reposing at Perazzo Funeral Home, 199 Bleecker Street, NYC. Mass of the Resurrection, Monday, 10:30 AM, Our Lady of Pompei R.C. Church. Entombment St. John's Cloister. Visiting hours Saturday and Sunday, 2-5 PM, 7-9:30 PM. The family requests in lieu of flowers, that contributions be sent to SEBCO Development Inc., 923 Simpson Street, Bronx, New York 10459.

title: Look! Up in the Sky!
description: About 600 experienced birdwatchers are expected to descend on marshes, fields and pine barrens throughout the state today to try to identify as many wild birds as possible during a 24-hour period.

title: Immigrants Don't Know What to Believe About S.S.I.
description: Two years ago, the Federal Government sponsored advertisements broadcast on foreign-language radio stations telling immigrants to apply for Supplemental Security Income -- the 23-year-old welfare program for the elderly and disabled. Last year, President Clinton signed a welfare reform law that denies the benefits to immigrants who are not citizens. Government letters, 85,000 of them to New Yorkers, warned immigrants that the checks that sustain them, which average $410 a month, would end this August.

title: INSIDE METRO
description: LAWSUIT OVER LANDMARK -- A lawsuit charges that the owner of the Chrysler Building has not kept up with mortgage payments. Page 22.

title: Ordway Injures Right Shin
description: Ordway, one of last year's star juveniles who missed the Kentucky Derby with various ailments last Saturday, was declared out of the Preakness yesterday after bucking the shin on his right hind leg.

title: Bob Devaney, 82, Nebraska Coach, Dies
description: Bob Devaney, a raconteur and humorist whose coaching made the University of Nebraska a national football power and whose leadership as athletic director modernized the athletics program, died yesterday at the Eastment Towers, a retirement home in Lincoln, Neb. He was 82.

title: Beijing Buys a Stake in Hong Kong Phone Company
description: A company controlled by China's central Government has bought a minority stake in Hong Kong Telecommunications, the territory's dominant telephone company and a major subsidiary of Cable and Wireless of Britain.

title: From Here to Eternity
description: Bill Clinton is not adrift. He has been working behind the scenes on a daring, innovative plan.

title: Police End Armed Protest for 'Free Venice'
description: Their armored car proved to be no more than a farm tractor draped in sheet metal, and their sole accomplishment was to unfurl the flag of the long-defunct Republic of Venice, but the separatists who stormed the Campanile in St. Mark's Square early this morning were carrying real automatic weapons, and the police mounted an assault to recapture the landmark tower.

title: Florence M. Kelley, 85, Judge In New York's Family Court
description: Florence M. Kelley, the first administrative judge of the modern Family Court in New York City and an advocate for the legal rights of the poor, died last Saturday at her home in Little Compton, R.I. She was 85.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  YEARWOOD, WESLEY
description: YEARWOOD - Wesley. Passed away May 6, 1997. Services at Benta's Funeral Home, Monday, May 12, 1997, at 10 A.M. Wake hours from 4-7PM, Sunday, May 11, 1997.

title: Prices of Treasury Securities Gain After Greenspan Remarks
description: Prices of Treasury securities gained ground yesterday as some investors interpreted comments by Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve chairman, as a hint that the Fed would not raise interest rates this month.

title: Disney Sights Set On Japan Project
description: The Walt Disney Company is negotiating to buy a stake in the Japan Sky Broadcasting Company, a satellite broadcaster owned by the News Corporation, which is headed by Rupert Murdoch, and the Softbank Corporation of Japan, a J Sky B official said today.

title: N.B.A. EASTERN CONFERENCE SEMIFINAL: GAME 2
description: Miami's Tim Hardaway beat the Knicks single-handedly last night, capping a 34-point performance with a short jump shot that gave Miami the lead with 50 seconds to go in the game. The vicory by the heat evened the second-round playoff series between the two teams at one game apiece. The third gam will be played tomorrow afternoon at Madison Square Garden.

title: Corrections
description: The Advertising column yesterday, about a national campaign for Clearplan Easy, an ovulation predictor kit, misidentified the agency responsible. It was Ogilvy & Mather in New York, not Ogilvy Adams & Rinehart.

title: For the Heat, 3 Is Definitely a Charm
description: The game and pretty much the season were on the line. And where did Pat Riley's Miami Heat put the ball? In John Crotty's southpaw dribble he did trust.

title: Giuliani Hires a Consultant To Boost His Hispanic Support
description: In another indication of the importance that Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's re-election team has attached to Hispanic voters, Mr. Giuliani has retained one of New York City's leading Puerto Rican consultants as a senior political consultant to his campaign.

title: CEPHALON SHARES SLIDE AFTER F.D.A. PANEL BARS DRUG
description: Shares of Cephalon Inc. fell 35 percent yesterday after a United States Food and Drug Administration advisory panel refused late on Thursday to recommend the company's drug, Myotrophin, for use in treating Lou Gehrig's disease. The company's shares were down $7, at $13 yesterday, as almost 8.4 million shares were traded on the Nasdaq stock market. Cephalon, based in West Chester, Pa. developed Myotrophin with the Chiron Corporation of Emeryville, Calif. Chiron's shares were down 87.5 cents, to $19.125 yesterday. Panel members voted 6 to 3 against recommending agency approval of the drug, saying the companies' study could not prove the drug's benefits.

title: Huskey And Gilkey Are a Hit For Mets
description: Butch Huskey needed to get away from third base to start hitting. Maybe what Bernard Gilkey needs is a weekend in his former home, Busch Stadium.

title: Bond Rally and Dollar Drop Send Market Indexes Higher
description: Stocks ended the week higher, as a rally yesterday in bonds lifted bank shares and a sharp drop in the dollar bolstered exporters.

title: A Fresh Start in Northern Ireland
description: Britain's elections have given a lift to the possibility of peace in Northern Ireland. Six months ago the stalemate between the Irish Republican Army, the British Government and Northern Ireland's Protestant Unionists seemed overwhelming. Today the I.R.A. may be more inclined to declare another cease-fire. Britain's new Prime Minister, Tony Blair, ought to reward such a commitment by announcing that if the cease-fire holds, Sinn Fein, the I.R.A.'s political wing, will be welcome at the peace talks on a definite date, perhaps in late summer. That would mark the group's first presence in the negotiations.

title: Elusive Budget Pact
description: Was there, in fact, a budget agreement between President Clinton and Congressional Republicans, and what precisely did it contain?

title: Corrections
description: A headline yesterday about an experimental vaccine given to some soldiers in the Persian Gulf War referred imprecisely in some editions to a decision by the Food and Drug Administration. The F.D.A. decided to permit the Pentagon to use the drug. The F.D.A. did not decide that the drug should be used.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MALKIN, EDGAR
description: MALKIN - Edgar. Businessman, humanist, raconteur. Shalom. Miller Advertising Julia Jacobs, VP

title: Tilting at Destroyers, Philip Berrigan Still Protests for Peace
description: His thinning white hair, faded blue eyes and slow limp show his age, but at 73 years old, Philip F. Berrigan is in jail again because of an anti-war demonstration.

title: The Contest Is Toe-to-Toe and Pawn-to-Pawn
description: After the I.B.M. computer, Deep Blue, won Game 2 against Garry Kasparov, the world chess champion told friends he had been stopped on the street by a Baptist minister who told him to buck up, that help was on the way.

title: The New Assault on Abortion
description: The Senate is gearing up for another contentious round on so-called ''partial-birth'' abortion, the controversial procedure saved from a Congressional ban last year by President Clinton's veto. In the meantime, many states have moved to outlaw the procedure on their own. Many of the state laws are as flawed as some of the bills rushing through Congress. They intrude on a woman's right to an abortion using the safest possible method as decided by her and her doctor.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CAVE, VERNAL G., M.D.
description: CAVE-Vernal G., M.D. The Officers, Trustees and members of The Medical Society of the County of Kings mourn the loss of its former president and colleague, Vernal G. Cave, M.D. Joseph C. Amico, M.D., President L. P. Hinterbuchner, M.D. Chairman, Board of Trustees

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: Baseball

title: Furry Hazard: Bear Caught on Golf Course
description: Civilization long ago conquered the wilderness along Central Avenue, bringing with it such outposts of progress as Barnes & Noble, Computer City and Bed Bath and Beyond.

title: In 1970's, Rent Decontrol Led to New Housing
description: To the Editor:

title: McGreevey Is Ahead in Cash
description: State Senator James E. McGreevey has raised and spent more money than either of his two opponents in the Democratic gubernatorial primary, but Gov. Christine Todd Whitman's war chest dwarfs any of her potential rivals', according to campaign finance forms released yesterday.

title: Russia and NATO: No Accord Yet on Military Goal
description: Even though President Boris N. Yeltsin says a deal governing relations between Russia and an expanding NATO is ''98 percent complete,'' senior American officials and alliance diplomats cautioned today that difficult military issues have yet to be settled and could delay a signing this month.

title: What's Fairer Than a Test?
description: Schools Chancellor Rudy Crew has been pushing for more diversity in New York's gifted and specialized schools. He has attacked schools for not informing more parents about gifted programs, and he has criticized school districts for charging a fee for admissions exams. Both are valid complaints.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WILLIAMSON, FREDERICK E.
description: WILLIAMSON-Frederick E. Age 45 on May 5, 1997. Beloved son of Jean and the late A. Fred Williamson. Dear brother of Jean Cole and Joan and Janet Williamson and uncle of Christine and Robert Cole. Memorial service to be held at Resurrection Church, Rye, NY on May 12, 1997 at 11A.M. In lieu of flowers contributions can be made to Gay Mens Health Crisis, 121A West 20 St., New York, New York.

title: Croatia Doesn't Endorse Ethnically Pure State
description: To the Editor:

title: Once Again, A Landmark Faces a Suit To Foreclose
description: A Japanese bank filed a lawsuit today charging the owner of the Chrysler Building, one of New York's most famous landmarks, with failing to maintain its mortgage payments, and said it would try to foreclose on the property.

title: A Book and a Cup of Coffee
description: To hear Martha Oxley go on about espresso, it would be easy to mistake her for a cafe owner or a restaurateur. But Ms. Oxley is the assistant director of the Cherry Hill Library, which yesterday became the latest library in the state to start selling cappuccino to its customers.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CLANCY, THOMAS NOEL
description: CLANCY-Thomas Noel, on May 7, 1997 of Manhasset NY. Mayor & Trustee of Plandome Heights. He was also President of Manhasset Community Fund and Volunteer for Long Island Association for Aids Care, Inc. (LIAAC). Beloved husband of Barbara. Dear father of Barbara Martino & Tracey Guarini. Grandfather of Kyle Thomas, Hannah Lee and Nicholas James. Brother of Charles and Michael Clancy. He was a member of Immaculate Heart of Mary National Advisory Council for Development; associated with the education efforts for the Diocese of Rockville Centre; former Development Director St. Mary's Manhasset and an active member of St. Mary's Parish where he was a Eucharistic Minister, Head Usher, Nocturnal Adoration Society and Ongoing Formation Committee for St Marys. In repose at The Fairchild Funeral Chapel, 1570 Northern Blvd., Manhasset, NY, Saturday and Sunday from 3-5 and 7-9 P.M. Funeral Mass Monday 10:45 AM St. Mary's RC Church, Manhasset, with interment in Holy Rood Cemetery. In lieu of flowers, donations in his memory may be made to St Mary's Elementary School or the Sisters, Servants of The Immaculate Heart of Mary.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLDEN, BARBARA
description: GOLDEN-Barbara. On May 9, 1997. Loving mother of Russell Morganstern sister of Suzanne Golden, daughter of Rebecca and Mortimer Golden. Creator of ''Can't Bear To Part'' Teddy Bear Company. Services Sunday 1 PM, at the George T. Davis Funeral Home, New Rochelle, New York.

title: Berlioz Fits the Concert Stage Snugly
description: L'Opera Francais de New York showed on Wednesday night how brilliantly well Berlioz's ''Beatrice et Benedict'' works as concert opera, done by singers performing in their evening clothes, with a few props and bits of furniture, and with the orchestra near at hand onstage at Alice Tully Hall. This solves a lot of difficulties, including the big difficulty that the piece isn't so much a dramatic transmutation of its Shakespeare source, ''Much Ado About Nothing,'' as an act of homage: a set of glorious musical illustrations.

title: PINKERTON'S TO ACQUIRE SENSORMATIC ELECTRONICS UNIT
description: Pinkerton's Inc. said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire the United States Enterprise Accounts division of the Sensormatic Electronics Corporation for an undisclosed amount. Sensormatic, based in Boca Raton, Fla., makes shoplifting detection devices and other security systems. Its Enterprise Accounts division, which had full-year revenues of about $80 million, provides security systems integration services. Pinkerton's is a security and investigations team based in Encino, Calif. In 1996, it reported revenues of about $906.2 million.

title: The Landlords Forgotten In Rent Debate
description: IN a city of renters, Patricia Eaton refused to be one. She lives in Harlem, where she owns her own home and an eight-unit brownstone on West 120th Street that she rents out. She sat in one of the brownstone's empty apartments, where the room was sunny. Her mood was not.

title: Hardaway Takes On All Comers as the Heat Wins
description: Tim Hardaway went one on five in the second quarter tonight, carrying his team on his shoulders as only a few point guards can. Miami center Alonzo Mourning saw this effort and was inspired. He and his teammates began to pitch in.

title: POLYMER GROUP IN BID FOR MERFIN INTERNATIONAL
description: Polymer Group Inc. offered yesterday to buy Merfin International Inc. for more than $130 million, topping the Buckeye Cellulose Corporation's bid to buy the Canadian company. Polymer, based in Charleston, S.C., is offering $7.15 (Canadian) for each share of Merfin. On April 30 Merfin agreed to be acquired by Buckeye, based in Memphis, for $7 (Canadian) a share. Merfin, based in Vancouver, British Columbia, makes an absorbent material used in feminine hygiene and adult incontinence products. Polymer Group, a maker of nonwoven fabrics, said Merfin shareholders would also have the choice of receiving $7.60 a share in cash for 55 percent of the payment and a later payment on May 31, 1999, to be determined by Merfin's earnings for 1998.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHNEIDER, PEARL
description: SCHNEIDER-Pearl. Beloved wife of the late Dr. Samuel. Devoted mother of Alice J. Kurs and Barbara S. Jost. Loving grandmother of David, Elizabeth and Sean. Services Sunday, 12:00 noon at ''Schwartz Brothers-Jeffer Memorial Chapels'', 114-03 Queens Boulevard, Forest Hills, NY.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Wednesday about the Beard Foundation awards misspelled the surname of the author of ''1000 Vegetarian Recipes'' (Macmillan USA), who was a winner in the cookbook category. She is Carol Gelles, not Geller.

title: No Headline
description: ''I'm like, 'Stop lying.' I'm like telling him it's like probably a raccoon.''

title: Marco Ferreri, 68, Is Dead; Directed 'La Grande Bouffe'
description: Marco Ferreri, the fiercely satiric Italian director perhaps best known for ''La Grande Bouffe,'' in which four charming middle-age men gorge themselves to death in a suicide pact, died yesterday in a hospital in Paris. He was 68.

title: Corrections
description: An article on April 17 about medical researchers who said they had been assailed by vested interests referred imprecisely to an action by Albert Donnay of a patient advocacy group, MCS Referral and Resources, relating to Dr. Gregory Simon, who conducted a study of multiple chemical sensitivity. Mr. Donnay sent documents to a medical licensing board asserting scientific misconduct by Dr. Simon. He did not explicitly seek revocation of the doctor's medical license. (As the article noted, the complaints against Dr. Simon were dismissed.)

title: Morton L. Deitch, 95, Partner in Law Firm
description: Morton L. Deitch, a Manhattan lawyer affiliated for seven decades with the firm of Stroock & Stroock & Lavan and long active in the cause of child care, died on April 26 at his home on the Upper East Side of Manhattan. He was 95.

title: Ex-Leaders of Harlem Agency Defend Development Record
description: Former officials of the Harlem Urban Development Corporation, responding to criticism from the Pataki administration that their organization was rife with mismanagement and did little in 23 years, are mounting a defense of their record and have dismissed the attacks as politically motivated.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FULKERSON, W. NEAL, JR.
description: FULKERSON-W. Neal, Jr. On May 8, 1997 of Garden City, N.Y. Beloved Husband of the late Ethel (nee Reilly). Loving Uncle of Adele Nagy, Fr. Paul Dahm and Marjorie Pozderec. Visiting at The Fairchild Chapel, Franklin Ave. at 12th St., Garden City, 2-5 and 7-9 P.M., Monday. Mass of Christian Burial 10 AM Tuesday St. Joseph's R.C. Church, Garden City. Mr. Fulkerson was a Senior V.P. at Bankers Trust Company, a past President of The Municipal Bond Club of N.Y. and a member of The Garden City Golf Club and past member of The Cherry Valley Country Club. In lieu of flowers, donations to The L.I. Humane Society, Freeport, N.Y. appreciated.

title: Three Steps Toward Justice
description: The Government report released this week on gold and other assets looted by Nazi Germany shines a harsh spotlight on the role of the neutral countries, particularly Switzerland, and on the Allies themselves. Because of indifference by the neutral nations and inaction by the United States and its Allies, the horrors of the war were compounded by the injustices of the postwar period.

title: Hardaway's Efforts Shift the Momentum
description: The Miami Heat's smallest player may have the team's biggest heart.

title: In 1970's, Rent Decontrol Led to New Housing
description: To the Editor:

title: Commissioner Search
description: Heidrick and Struggles, an executive search firm, was hired by Major League Baseball to conduct a search for a commissioner, the commissioner's office said yesterday.

title: DAILEY PETROLEUM TO ACQUIRE TWO DRILLING CONCERNS
description: The Dailey Petroleum Services Corporation said yesterday that it would acquire two closely held drilling services companies for a total of $112.5 million in cash and assumed debt. The two companies -- Air Drilling International Inc. of Denver and Phoenix Drilling Services Inc. of Houston -- both provide specialized drilling techniques used in the drilling of oil and natural gas wells. Dailey, a drilling-services provider based in Conroe, Tex., will buy Air Drilling for $45.5 million in cash and assumed debt and pay about $67 million in cash for Phoenix Drilling. Dailey has annual revenue of about $59 million. Its shares were unchanged at $7.25 in Nasdaq trading yesterday.

title: Greenhouse Theory Inflates Human Significance
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FISHMAN, SEYMOUR
description: FISHMAN-Seymour, 82, of Aventura, Florida. Formerly of NYC, N.Y., passed away May 7, 1997. Survived by his beloved wife Sylvia; and his loving children, Steven and Judith; and by his adored grandchildren, Stephanie and Laura and devoted brother of the late Bernard. He loved life and lived with passion, seasoned with humor. Having pursued widely various careers, he successfully served as psychologist, owner/ founder of a stock brokerage business and professional fundraiser. Strong supporter of Israel and its education, he last retired April 26, 1980 as Executive Director of the American Friends of the Hebrew University, then moving permanently to Florida. He motivated others to contribute and be the best that they can be. His memory will live on. Contributions are to be made to the American Friends of the Hebrew University, 11 East 69th Street, New York, New York 10021. Memorial services to be held Monday, May 12th, 11:00 AM at Menorah Chapels in Aventura, Florida. For information please call 1-800-327-9192.

title: Operating Profit Up 25% At Munich-Based Bank
description: Bayerische Landesbank Girozentrale, Germany's sixth-largest bank, said yesterday that its operating profit in the first quarter rose 25 percent, led by commission income. Operating profit rose to 397 million marks ($233 million). Net commission income was up 30 percent and net interest income rose 4 percent.

title: Budget Called More Prudent but With Short-Term Focus
description: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's $33.5 billion election-year budget received mostly favorable reviews yesterday from experts on New York City's finances, though some said the Mayor had wasted a chance to use a large surplus to address troubles down the road.

title: Arkansas Town Mourns 3 Firemen Killed in Blast
description: The small city of West Helena grieved for three firefighters today as it worked to prevent environmental damage from the chemical explosion in which they were killed on Thursday.

title: Nassau Democrats in Stew After Indictment of Leader
description: The Nassau County Democratic Party, which is about to nominate candidates for this fall's elections, has been thrown into turmoil by the indictment of its leader, Stephen J. Sabbeth, on bank fraud and perjury charges.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  POLKOWITZ, LOUISE
description: POLKOWITZ-Louise. Central Synagogue records with profound sorrow the passing of its member Louise Polkowitz. We extend heartfelt sympathy to her bereaved family. Peter J. Rubinstein, rabbi Martin I. Klein, president

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RASEMAN, ELIZABETH HARDING
description: RASEMAN-Elizabeth Harding, 73, of Old Field, L.I., on May 7, 1997, after a brief illness. Born in Vicksburg, MS, October 20, 1923, daughter of James B. Harding of Vicksburg and Elizabeth Morrison Harding of Chattanooga, TN., she married Chad J. Raseman on February 7, 1945. She is survived by her children Kit Raseman of NYC, Kim Raseman of Milford, CT, Kyle Paden of Sudbury, Ont., Karl Raseman of Setauket, NY and Kate Thompson of Bridgeton, NJ. Grandmother of Sebastien, Sophie, Genevieve, Elizabeth, Delphine, Jacqueline, and Quinn. She is also survived by her sister Kate Dossett of Knoxville, TN. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to St. Charles Hospice or 3 Village Meals on Wheels. Services today at the Caroline Church in Setauket at 1:00 P.M.

title: If Puppets Step Offscreen, They'll Get Torn Apart
description: It is rehearsal time for Spain's most irreverent television show and, in one studio, 10 bullfighters are lining up to debate the state of the nation. The toreros are on two rival teams, representing the country's two main political parties.

title: Mexican War Wasn't a U.S. Invention
description: To the Editor:

title: Umpire's Reversal Gives Yankees a Loss
description: Kenny Rogers was not the problem in the Yankees' 12-inning, 7-5 loss to Kansas City that ended at 12:27 this morning. The problem was two errors -- a bad throw by Derek Jeter that gave the Royals the go-ahead run, and a reversal of an admitted mistake by Dale Ford, the third-base umpire, that extended a bizarre sixth inning.

title: Pentagon Might Unify Rules on Fraternizing
description: The Defense Department has begun a wide-ranging review to determine whether all branches of the military should adopt the same rules governing social and sexual contact among troops, Pentagon officials said today.

title: At Bombing Trial, Prosecutors Focus on Time Span Before Truck Rental
description: Questioning the owners of a taxi company, a fast-food restaurant and a truck rental shop, prosecutors in the Oklahoma City bombing trial tried today to establish a meticulous time line leading up to 4:19 P.M., April 17, 1995 -- the time they say Timothy J. McVeigh rented the Ryder truck used in the blast on April 19.

title: Political 'Party' Goes So Far, Even San Francisco Is Aghast
description: There is no shocking the citizens of San Francisco, it has been argued; it takes some doing just to entertain them.

title: Large Returns Are Now Bringing In Stock Promoters With Rap Sheets
description: In the annals of public disclosure, few news releases can match the chutzpah of one issued less than a month ago by Genesis Insurance and Financial Services Inc., a Chattanooga, Tenn., company whose stock has recently taken an extraordinary beating.

title: Police Foil Bank Robbery in Greenwich and Capture 7 in a Wild Chase
description: A crew of heavily armed bank robbers, under surveillance by the Federal Bureau of Investigation for a string of bank robberies, abruptly called off a heist at a bank in Cos Cob, Conn., yesterday morning, and led law enforcement agents on a wild chase on Interstate 95, the authorities said. Seven suspects were eventually arrested in New Rochelle.

title: A Tale of Dueling Inquiries Into Campaign Finances
description: Senator Fred Thompson of Tennessee, the chairman of the Senate committee investigating campaign finance abuses, is saying that he feels pressure to begin public, televised hearings by early July, that he is mostly satisfied with the cooperation he is getting from the White House and that the public should not expect his inquiry to produce a bombshell.

title: Traffic Fine Collection
description: To the Editor:

title: Mind Over Matter
description: The epic struggle between Garry Kasparov and Deep Blue has brought more than the usual hand-wringing over whether computers can be considered ''intelligent,'' a trait usually thought of as the defining characteristic of humanity. Mr. Kasparov is clearly awed by the powers of his implacable opponent. Last year, when he dropped the opening game to a lesser version of Deep Blue, he exclaimed: ''I could feel -- I could smell -- a new kind of intelligence across the table.'' This year he is so spooked he has abandoned his usual slashing style, complained of mental fatigue, implied that the computer's handlers are cheating and blundered badly once or twice, apparently because he overestimated what the computer knew. The man who claims to be championing the human intellect seems to be falling apart under the pressure of a machine.

title: PGA TV Pacts Expected
description: The PGA Tour is expected to announce on Sunday that ABC, NBC and CBS will remain its broadcast television partners in four-year contracts that begin with the 1999 season, people familiar with the negotiations said. The tour is expected to reap much more than the $95.6 million paid this year.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROBINSON, JANE D.
description: ROBINSON-Jane D., 77, of Rumson, NJ, on May 8, 1997. Wife of William W. Mother of William W., Jr., Martha Bliss and Alice Robinson. Sister of George Dimock and Charlotte Rousseau. Grandmother of five. Funeral services private.

title: Quarter for His Thoughts: Saroyan Memorabilia
description: For most people, finding a quarter on the street means 25 more cents to add to the pocket. But for William Saroyan, a writer who had a mania for collecting, the incident held myriad literary possibilities.

title: Devils Shift A Routine To Change Their Luck
description: Coach Jacques Lemaire is searching for ways to change the Devils' approach for the rest of the series with the Rangers. So, uncharacteristically, he gave his players the day off yesterday and sent many of them home to stay with their families and friends.

title: Schools Can Find the Gift in 'Average' Students
description: To the Editor:

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: HOCKEY

title: Corrections
description: A front-page chart on May 2 about rent regulation referred incorrectly to the apartments described. There are 1.1 million rent-regulated apartments in New York City; that is not the total number of rental apartments. In addition, the chart gave an incorrect percentage for the units occupied by families earning $100,000 or more. About 5 percent of the rent-regulated apartments not 8 percent, are in that category.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LUBKEMEIER, WALTER
description: LUBKEMEIER-Walter. The Board of Directors, Tenant Shareholders and staff of 900 5th Avenue mourn the loss of our long time Resident Manager. We extend our deepest sympathy to his wife and children. Viewing at Frank E. Campbell, Madison Avenue and 81st Street, from 3-5 and 7-9 PM, Saturday and Sunday. Interment Monday at 10 A.M.

title: Justice Nominee's I.R.S. Request Endangers Easy Confirmation
description: An unusual request of the Internal Revenue Service by President Clinton's nominee to become the second-ranking official at the Justice Department could impede what was expected to be an easy confirmation.

title: Judge Denies Request by Barney's to Offer a Breakup Fee
description: As expected, a Federal bankruptcy judge yesterday rejected a request by Barney's Inc. to offer $10 million in breakup fees to a potential bidder for the company. The judge also said that he would appoint a mediator to oversee the bidding, possibly as early as Monday.

title: Double Green
description: To the Editor:

title: SBC COMMUNICATIONS INC. (SBC,N)
description: SBC Communications Inc. said yesterday that rainstorms in Northern California and expenses for new ventures weakened first-quarter profits, the first report combining its results with Pacific Telesis Group, which it acquired on April 1.

title: Lagardere Stock Rises; Bid for Thomson Is Cited
description: The shares of Lagardere Groupe rose yesterday on expectations that it will win a battle with Alcatel Alsthom S.A. to buy the French Government's majority stake in the Thomson-CSF unit of Thomson S.A., after securing the backing of other European makers of military equipment.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BLINKEN, ETHEL H.
description: BLINKEN-Ethel H., died in Palm Beach, Florida, after a long illness on May 7. She was born in New York City in 1903. In 1924, she married Maurice H. Blinken who died in 1986. She is survived by her sons, Ambassador Donald Blinken of Budapest, Robert Blinken of Bedford Hills and Ambassador Alan Blinken of Brussels and nine grandchildren and six great-grandchildren. Interment will be private.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Dow Average Up for Week, Bolstered by Bond Rally

title: Bridge
description: The Cavendish Invitational Teams, a curtain-raiser to the main event beginning today in Las Vegas, was a three-session event and attracted a strong field of 28 teams. Leading after the first session was an Italian foursome headed by a former world champion, Soldano de Falco.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BIBER, DONALD R.
description: BIBER-Donald R. Age 69, of Fort Lee, New Jersey, formerly of Fair Lawn, NJ. Survived by his beloved wife Sandra Schneeweiss Biber; cherished father of Hugh, and Amy Barr; sister, Lois Shapiro; and six adored grandchildren. Predeceased by his wife Rita Spiegel Biber in 1978. A mourning period will be observed through Wednesday evening at the Biber residence in Fort Lee, NJ. Donations in his name gratefully accepted to the American Cancer Society or to the charity of your choice. Services are Sunday, 10:30AM at Robert Schoem's Menorah Chapel, 150 Rt. 4 East, Paramus, New Jersey.

title: Charge in Mayoral Race
description: City Councilman Andrew Amato is running for mayor of Hoboken on a simple platform: ''To stop all this corruption.''

title: Philadelphia Exchange Goes to 16ths
description: The Philadelphia Stock Exchange has approved quoting shares that are listed on the New York Stock Exchange in sixteenths.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GRAY, AUSTEN T.
description: GRAY-Austen T., died May 9 at the age of 89. Beloved husband of Milo, loving father of Phyllis Heaton, Alice Standteiner, Pamela Resse and Austen T. Gray Jr. Adored grandfather of 13 and great grandfather of 7. Mr. Gray was managing director of Trainor Wortham, honorary director of the New York Eye & Ear Infirmary and Trustee Emeritus at Fay School, Southboro, MA. Service on Monday, May 12, 11 AM, St. John's Episcopal Church, Cold Spring Harbor, LI. Donations appreciated to New York Eye & Ear Infirmary, 2nd Ave & 14th Street, NYC 10003.

title: WALDEN RESIDENTIAL IS ADDING DREVER PARTNERS
description: Walden Residential Properties Inc. said yesterday that it had agreed to buy the closely held Drever Partners Inc. for $380 million in securities and assume $290 million in debt, forming one of the largest public owners of apartment properties in the United States. The purchase will increase the Dallas-based Walden's total market value to more than $1.5 billion and its apartment holdings by about 80 percent, to 154 communities with 41,000 units in the Southeast, Southwest and California. Walden's shares rose 75 cents, to $24.625, on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday. Drever is based in San Francisco and Houston, and owns 18,900 apartment units in 80 communities.

title: Ethics Complaint Settled
description: A former state transportation commissioner agreed yesterday to pay $1,200 to settle an ethics complaint accusing him of discussing job opportunities with companies that had ties to bidders for the state's electronic toll collection contract.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  POSTAL, MILDRED
description: POSTAL-Mildred, on May 9, 1997. Beloved wife of the late William. Devoted mother of Marie Rozakis and Anita Burke. Loving grandmother of Lisa, Kate and Craig Jackson. Dear sister. Reposing at Westchester Funeral Home, 190 Main St, Eastchester, NY. Visiting hours Sunday 2-4PM and 7-9 P.M. Religious Services Mon. 10 A.M. Interment Mount Hope Cemetery.

title: Higher Revenues Collected
description: The Wall Street boom is pouring extra tax revenues into New Jersey's coffers, state officials said yesterday.

title: Kennedy Family Values
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DINTENFASS, DR. JULIUS
description: DINTENFASS-Dr. Julius. Sigma Kappa Alpha Fraternity records with sorrow the death of our esteemed brother. Eugene Cummings, Scribe

title: When Work Is The Cure
description: After the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission recently announced that employers had to make special accommodations for mentally ill workers, the loudest protests, understandably, came from business. The ruling could mean that mentally disabled workers who feel ''stressed'' can demand time off. Those who are irritable, erratic or depressed can expect bosses and co-workers to tolerate their behavior.

title: CABLEVISION SYSTEMS PLANNING TO SELL MAINE UNITS
description: The Cablevision Systems Corporation said yesterday that it would sell its cable television systems in Maine for about $78 million in cash as part of its strategy to focus on certain geographic areas and reduce debt. Cablevision, a cable TV operator in Woodbury, N.Y., has reached a definitive agreement with Frontiervision Partners L.P. for the sale of systems in Bangor and Lewiston that have 53,000 customers. Cablevision, the nation's sixth-largest cable company, is seeking buyers for other cable systems that have an aggregate of 475,000 subscribers, said Bill Bell, vice chairman, in a statement. The privately held Frontiervision has its headquarters in Denver.

title: Threat of Intervention Sends Dollar Plunging
description: NEW YORK  The dollar dropped against the yen Friday as traders began to worry about central-bank intervention to limit the strength of the U.S. currency.

title: In Our Own Backyard
description: To the Editor:

title: One Angry Slash Later, There's Frustration on Both Sides
description: It all happened in a corner in the waning minutes of the game that put the New Jersey Devils on the precipice of playoff extermination Thursday night. According to the Rangers, the play didn't involve the puck. Instead, it involved anger and revenge and it left their gentlemanly wing, Niklas Sundstrom, with a broken arm.

title: INSIDE
description: Timeline in McVeigh Trial

title: Hutu Mustn't Flee Charges of Genocide
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GRANT, MARGARET L.
description: GRANT-Margaret L. On May 8, 1997 of Elmhurst. Beloved wife of the late Donald. Loving aunt of Catherine Viscardi and Mary Kiley and great aunt of eight great nieces and nephews and greatgreat aunt of fifteen great-great nieces and nephews. Visiting at the Fairchild Chapel, Franklin Ave. at 12th Street, Garden City, N.Y. 24 and 7-9 P.M. Sunday. Mass of Christian burial St. Bartholomew's Church, Elmhurst, 10:30 A.M. Monday. Interment Mt. St. Mary Cemetery, Flushing. Donations to Dominican Village, Amityville, New York 11701, appreciated.

title: 253 Minutes Later, MetroStars Still Empty
description: The MetroStars were playing on new turf, but the playing surface was all that was new at Giants Stadium tonight.

title: Clinton Urges Action on Global Warming
description: Drenched by a misting rain, President Clinton stood before the soaring forest here today to issue a hedged warning about global climate change and to declare that the world has much to learn from Costa Rica's environmental stewardship.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: LRC ELECTRONICS INC., Horseheads, N.Y., announced that about 200 temporary assembly jobs created in 1995 would be eliminated by its new parent company, Thomas & Betts Corp., Memphis, which is moving much of its assembly operations to Mexico.

title: Steinbrenner to Step Back
description: While other owners waited to see what action the executive council might take against George Steinbrenner for his antitrust lawsuit against baseball, the Yankees' owner said yesterday that he would remove himself from any council deliberations about the suit.

title: Germany Defends Pensions for SS Veterans
description: More than half a century after World War II, the German authorities have acknowledged that war disability pensions are still being paid to members of Waffen-SS units and even to war criminals.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  ADLER, PHILIP
description: ADLER-Philip. May 10, 1987. Such wisdom, kindness and gentleness. So deeply missed. Always thinking of you. A.B.K.

title: Varied Reasons Found for Welfare Rolls' Drop
description: Armed with a complex mathematical model, the Council of Economic Advisers today tried to shed light on the perplexing question being asked in welfare offices across the country: why are the rolls falling so fast?

title: Alabama Gun Shop Linked To Illegal Flow of Firearms
description: The Federal agents tailing a Mazda van and its load of illegal guns lost their quarry when a train rumbled between them, cutting them off. When it had passed by, on that fall day in 1993, there was just the empty Alabama blacktop on the other side of the tracks, stretching into a mystery.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KAPLAN, ESNA
description: KAPLAN-Esna. Devoted wife of Philip. Beloved mother of David (Rona) Kaplan & Karen (Michael) Lefkowitz. Loving grandmother of Lee, Calli, Jaime and Sydney. Devoted sister of Libby Krackow, Dr. Arthur Wolintz and Florence Stachel. Services Sunday, 10 AM, Gutterman's, Woodbury, N.Y.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL 3-6

title: U.S. IS SUPPLYING ARMY IN SARAJEVO WITH 116 BIG GUNS
description: The United States said today that it was sending the Bosnian Federation 116 large artillery pieces in an effort to correct one of the main weaknesses of the Muslim-Croat Federation and set the stage for the withdrawal of American peacekeeping forces from Bosnia by July 1998.

title: The Tax Pipeline to Albany: Does It Flow North or South?
description: The Mayor bitterly protested that the people of New York City, the state's great economic engine, sent more to Albany in taxes than they got back in services. The city, he said, was always shortchanged, forced to subsidize upstate regions.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KEANE, REV. BROTHER ALFRED X.
description: KEANE-Rev. Brother Alfred X. C.F.C Member of the Christian Brother community for 55 years. Devoted brother of Rev. Eugene Keane, Pastor of St. Augustine R.C. Church Highland, NY. Visiting will be at the Christian Brother's Provincial Center, 21 Pryer Terrace, New Rochelle, New York, Monday from 1-6:30 PM. Mass of the Resurrection, Monday, 7 PM, at the Church of the Holy Family, New Rochelle, NY. Interment Tuesday, 11 AM, Christian Brother's Cemetery, West Park, N.Y.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CARTER, JOSEPH
description: CARTER-Joseph. The Laura Rosenberg Foundation extends deepest sympathy upon the death of Joe Carter, beloved father of Judy Shatz, founder and trustee. Our sincere condolences to the Carter, Shatz and Max families. The Laura Rosenberg Foundation

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHLAIFER, CHARLES
description: SCHLAIFER-Charles. On May 5. Love, Roberta, Bruce, Scott, Gigi Semer. For info re: Shiva, 212580-1843. Donations to Rodeph Sholom (a special fund), 7 West 83 Street, New York City 10024.

title: Loving Sendup of an Artist's Instincts
description: For the second time this spring, the wit and wisdom of Will Scheffer is evident on a New York stage. As a production of the author's impassioned 90-minute play ''Easter'' completes an extended engagement this week at Naked Angels on West 43d Street, nine blocks away, on West 52d, the Ensemble Studio Theater is mounting a shorter work by this inventive and intriguing playwright.

title: Foes' Air Forces to End War Games Over Cyprus
description: Greece and Turkey, after talks with American diplomats, agreed separately today that they would no longer fly military aircraft in combat exercises over the divided island of Cyprus, the State Department announced.

title: Dollar Plunges Against Yen In Big Setback
description: The dollar plunged yesterday against the Japanese yen, ending the week with a 5 percent loss in value, its biggest setback to date in its rally from a record low just over two years ago.

title: Discovering That What's Usual Is Not Necessarily What's Normal
description: In the phantasmagoric world of Susan Streitfeld's new film, ''Female Perversions,'' everything usually deemed normal for a woman becomes a perversion. Dressing up just to please men, coveting nice clothes, removing body hair: they are perversions. Plastic surgery, in Ms. Streitfeld's universe -- now that's a perversion!

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GREENBERG, SELMA WEINTRAUB, ED.D.
description: GREENBERG-Selma Weintraub, Ed.D. Hofstra University is profoundly saddened by the death of Professor Emerita of Education Selma Weintraub Greenberg. Professor Greenberg was a nationally known researcher on early childhood education, a leader in the field of teacher education, & an advocate for women and girls. She received her B.S. at SUNY at Oswego, M.A. at CUNY at Queens, & the Ed.D at Columbia University, Teachers College. In her 29 years at Hofstra University, she served as professor and chairperson of the Department of Curriculum and Teaching, served two terms as Speaker of the Faculty and a term as the University's Affirmative Action Officer. Among other honors, she received the Outstanding Alumna Award from Teachers College, Columbia University; the Robert S. Guttchen Memorial Award from Hofstra University; the Willystine Goodsell Award from the American Education Research Association, the Woman of the Year Award from Women on the Job, and the Educational Equity Concepts 1996 Woman of Valor Awards. She is survived by her husband, William, daughters Lisa and Ellen, son Andrew, brothers Walter and Robert, sons and daughter-in-law Jan Woltizky, Duncan Watry, and Vivien Greenberg; and four grandchildren. In tribute to the memory of Professor Greenberg, all Hofstra University flags have been lowered to half-staff. James M. Shuart, President Helene Fortunoff, Chairperson, Board Of Trustees Hofstra University

title: U.N. Panel Rules Israel Uses Torture
description: A United Nations committee today condemned Israeli techniques in questioning suspected terrorists, including violent shaking, painful restraints and sleep deprivation, as state-sanctioned torture.

title: Anthony Lake to Join Faculty at Georgetown
description: Anthony Lake, President Clinton's former national security adviser, who withdrew from consideration as Director of Central Intelligence in March, will join the faculty of the Georgetown University School of Foreign Service, officials said tonight.

title: Less of a Grinch: Some Softening For the Image Of Greenspan
description: In nearly 10 years as chairman of the Federal Reserve, Alan Greenspan has developed a reputation as the Grinch, an economic killjoy railing against ''irrational exuberance,'' willing to sacrifice jobs and the nation's full growth potential to spare Wall Street millionaires from the merest whiff of inflation.

title: Is Satan Real? Most People Think Not
