description: Polls tend to show that Americans are a largely religious people, with something close to 95 percent claiming a belief in God, and large numbers saying they think that Heaven exists, and so too do angels.

title: Refs Give Ewing Long Rest This Time
description: Patrick Ewing was waving on the Miami crowd's jeers like someone trying to park an airplane. A little more to the left, a little more to the right. It appeared Ewing wanted the boos to land on him as he tilted his head back and stretched out a wide, picket-fence smile.

title: V.I.P.'s Aplenty Flock to Bill Gates's 'Summit'
description: Forget Davos. Forget the Bohemian Grove Retreat. Bill Gates, the richest man in America and considered by some the most important man in the world, has put in his opening bid to become the host with the most -- the most ability to pack the most chief executives and political heavyweights into one party of his creation, that is.

title: A Re-awakened 'Beauty'
description: ''The Sleeping Beauty'' without a stunning Princess Aurora is like water without fish.

title: SAPUTO GROUP IN CANADA IS SEEKING AULT FOODS
description: Saputo Group Inc. said yesterday that it planned to make a takeover offer worth $257.5 million (Canadian), or $185.5 million (United States), for Ault Foods Ltd., a food processing company in Toronto. Saputo, based in Montreal, a processor and distributor of dairy and food products, said it currently owns about 1.8 million, or 16.4 percent, of Ault's shares outstanding. Saputo's planned offer would equal $28 (Canadian) a share. Ault's shares rose $3.75, to $29.50, in Toronto.

title: 2 Guards Delivering Cash Are Ambushed and Shot in Queens
description: A frenzied crossfire broke the morning calm of a quiet Queens neighborhood yesterday as masked robbers ambushed the two guards of a payroll shipment, leaving the security men -- a retired police officer and an off-duty detective -- bleeding on the sidewalk with more than a dozen bullet wounds, the authorities said.

title: SPX SET TO REPURCHASE 2.14 MILLION OF ITS SHARES
description: The SPX Corporation said yesterday that it would buy back 2.14 million of its shares for $56 each under a previously announced Dutch auction tender offer. In a Dutch auction, a company sets a price range within which stockholders can tender shares. The highest price necessary to acquire all the shares becomes the purchase price. Last month, SPX said it would buy back up to 2.7 million shares for between $48 and $56 a share. Because the offer was undersubscribed, SPX said yesterday, it would buy back up to 750,000 shares on the open market. SPX, based in Muskegon, Mich., is an automotive industry supplier specializing in specialty service tools and equipment. SPX shares rose 87.5 cents yesterday, to $56.25, on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: News From America
description: The mail brings a sad letter from an angry man who wants to know how he can join one of those agin-the-government outfits whose members thirst for war with Uncle Sam.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Internet Commerce Pioneer Files for Bankruptcy
description: A pioneering company in the field of Internet commerce led by Jim P. Manzi, the former chairman of the Lotus Development Corporation, filed for bankruptcy protection yesterday.

title: The First War Crimes Convict
description: Four years after its creation, the United Nations tribunal to deal with atrocities committed in the former Yugoslavia finished its first full-length trial.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BEISER, LOUIS
description: BEISER-Louis, 86 years old. He passed away on Thursday, May 1, 1997. For 60 years Louis was the beloved husband of Dorothy who passed away in December 1996. Louis retired from private practice as a certified public accountant in New York City in 1975. After moving to Tamarac, FL. he became involved in golf, carpentry and his granddaughters. He was a warm, gentle, loving man with a wonderful sense of humor. He will be missed by his daughter Lynn, son-in-law Stephen, son Bernard, daughter-in-law Wendy and granddaughters: Jodie, Melissa, Mara and Ashley. Services were held at Star of David, Bailey Rd., North Lauderdale, FL. Donations may be made to The American Parkinsons Disease Association or the American Cancer Society.

title: Lucy Appleton, A. J. Barraclough
description: Lucy Kate Appleton, a daughter of Jane Scovell of New York and Dr. William Appleton of Cambridge, Mass., was married yesterday to Andrew James Barraclough, the son of Nicola and Mark Barraclough of Gerrard's Cross, England. The Rev. Richard E. Spalding, a Presbyterian minister, officiated at Harvard Memorial Church in Cambridge.

title: Torre Is Out at Home Plate, But Bell's Still Safe at Third
description: The Yankees' controversial loss to the Royals on Friday night gnawed at Joe Torre when he put his head on the pillow in the wee hours of Saturday morning. It bothered him when he stumbled into his office hours later. And the aggravation finally caused Torre to explode yesterday, when he carried the lineup card to home plate before the game, fully expressed himself to the umpires and was ejected.

title: Starting Pitching Carries the Surprising Pirates Into First Place
description: Six Cy Young Awards reside on the mantelpieces or in the trophy cases of the Atlanta Braves' starting pitchers. The Pittsburgh Pirates' starters don't even have any meaningful baseballs as keepsakes. The Pirates' pitchers started 37 games collectively for them last year. Tom Glavine of Atlanta started 36.

title: Little Jenny
description: She was the little sister he adored. He called her ''Jenny'' and bared his soul to her in letters. Last week those letters came back to haunt Timothy J. McVeigh, who is charged with murder and conspiracy in the Oklahoma City bombing.

title: Mother's Day Amnesty for The Bad Boys
description: There has been too much spanking going on lately. Fuzzy got spanked for cracking wise and Tiger got spanked for telling jokes and the Worm got it merely for being the Worm. They're just kids; for goodness' sake, they have nicknames. Spanking is daddy work, as in, ''Just you wait till he comes home!'' But since this is Mother's Day, when all is forgiven so long as you show up, let's unspank these guys. Give them some hugs.

title: Brazilian Twist Takes the Blahness Out of Mondays
description: By midnight, the party had begun. On stage, musicians offered up a percussive feast, while Brazilian singers captivated the audience with jazzy riffs, swiveling hips and red-lipstick smiles. The crowd waved their arms and swayed in their seats. By 1 A.M., they squeezed between tables to dance. At 3 A.M., ushers forced them out the door, so ending a typical Monday night at Cafe Wha? on Macdougal Street.

title: A Safe Place to Take Risks Near the Rockies
description: STRETCHING AGAINST THE EASTERN edge of the Rocky Mountains the foothills, they call them here, but they are mountains, so perfectly sculptured in deep greens against a peacock sky as to seem created by Hollywood set makers -- this city seems about as far as you can get from the urban sources of modern dance.

title: Judge Orders Tobacco Data for Inspection
description: A Minnesota state judge has ruled that cigarette companies must turn over thousands of scientific documents and other papers for court inspection and possible release to the public.

title: Honey, I'm Not Home
description: The Time Bind

title: Sonic Booms, Mellow Croons Fill the Air
description: This list is selective, and performances are subject to change.

title: The Way We Were, and Were, and Were
description: RETRO. It won't go away. Screen out cell-phone chatter, David Helfgott's incessant tinkling on the ivories and ''Ellen'' mania, and the world looks like one giant flashback.

title: Glittering Gala Benefits Westchester Hudson Opera Company
description: THERE were neither red velvet curtains nor crystal chandeliers nor gilded balconies. But there were plenty of people in satin and velvet -- on stage and off -- and there were big, beautiful voices and a definite air of formality and festivity.

title: In, Damned Spot!
description: ZEBRA never quite made the cut. Snake has had its good years and bad. Ostrich? Only the frivolous have made that skin work. But leopard lives on.

title: Fairy-Tale Ending for Students Who Missed a Performance
description: The show will go on after all for at least 600 of the 1,200 youngsters who were shut out of the Theaterworks U.S.A. production, ''The Lion, the Witch and the Wardrobe'' because of a scheduling mistake last month at the Paper Mill Playhouse in Millburn.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GRAY, AUSTEN T.
description: GRAY-Austen T., died May 9 at the age of 89. Beloved husband of Milo, loving father of Phyllis Heaton, Alice Standteiner, Pamela Resse and Austen T. Gray Jr. Adored grandfather of 13 and great grandfather of 7. Mr. Gray was managing director of Trainor Wortham, honorary director of the New York Eye & Ear Infirmary and Trustee Emeritus at Fay School, Southboro, MA. Service on Monday, May 12, 11 AM, St. John's Episcopal Church, Cold Spring Harbor, LI. Donations appreciated to New York Eye & Ear Infirmary, 2nd Ave & 14th Street, NYC 10003.

title: Luke Lion Squaring Off With Joe Camel
description: JOE CAMEL may not be dead yet, but Luke Lion is working to expedite his quick departure. Luke, a cheerful cartoon-like character who promotes nonsmoking, was developed by Ellen Shapiro of Irvington, a designer, working with Jessica Schwartz of Tarrytown, vice president of communications for the American Cancer Society's New York City division.

title: The Thinking Men's War
description: Egyptians reading their daily newspapers in recent months must have thought that their nation's peace with Israel was over. Government and opposition papers have been filled with vehement attacks on Israel and Benjamin Netanyahu's Government. Israel has been accused of having ''declared war on peace.'' It has supposedly threatened the Arab world with nuclear annihilation. Israelis are said to be monsters who kill small Arab children and destroy Muslim holy places.

title: New Signs of Wear at a Nuclear Plant That's For Sale
description: The sale of the Oyster Creek nuclear plant, a possibility floated by its owners last month, could be complicated by reports of unexpected signs of wear in a key safety component of the reactor, industry analysts say.

title: Aboard Gentlemen, Stevens Wins Pimlico
description: When you're hot, you're hot. And Gary Stevens continued to be the hottest jockey in racing when he won the Pimlico Special aboard Gentlemen yesterday, one week after winning the Kentucky Derby with Silver Charm.

title: 2 Suspects Arrested in Payroll Ambush
description: Two armed men suspected in the ambush-shooting of a retired police officer and an off-duty detective during a $50,000 payroll robbery in Queens on Friday were chased and seized by the police on streets in Elmhurst yesterday after they emerged separately from a house that had been placed under surveillance.

title: Army Sex, Again
description: The Army leveled 18 charges of sexual misconduct against its highest-ranking enlisted soldier last week. The soldier, Gene C. McKinney, the Sergeant Major of the Army, angrily denied the accusations made against him by three Army soldiers and one Navy sailor.

title: Meir Lev, 67, a Microbiology Researcher
description: Meir Lev, the director of research services and a professor of microbiology at City University of New York Medical School-Sophie Davis School of Biomedical Education, died on May 1 at his home in Riverdale, the Bronx. He was 67.

title: A Character in One of God's Dreams
description: REALITY AND DREAMS

title: A Hospital Chain's Brass Knuckles, and the Backlash
description: MOTORISTS in West Palm Beach, Fla., were recently confronted by a billboard 100 yards from the Wellington Regional Medical Center. ''Why Stop Here?'' it asked.

title: There's No Place Like Work
description: Parenthood, when done right, is a full-time gig. There is no such thing as quality time. Either you have time for the ''job'' or you don't.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  BRUN, MARCIA
description: BRUN-Marcia. April 11, 1922May 10, 1996. Happy Mother's Day. It's painful living without you.

title: Sexing the Cosmos
description: GUT SYMMETRIES

title: Starr Contends White House Poses Obstacle To His Inquiry
description: Kenneth W. Starr, the Whitewater prosecutor, said today that the White House was posing an impediment to his investigation by denying him lawyers' notes of conversations with Hillary Rodham Clinton.

title: Correction
description: Captions on Aug. 24 in Fashions of The Times, about plaid clothing, omitted copyright credits for murals that were backdrops for two photographs. The mural ''I of Motion, Us of Movement'' is Copyright $; 1996 Percita Eyes Muralists Association/Catalina Gonzales. The mural ''Carnaval'' is Copyright $; 1995 Joshua Sarantitis and Emmanuel Montoya. This correction was delayed by an editing lapse.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FISHMAN, SEYMOUR
description: FISHMAN-Seymour, 82, of Aventura, Florida. Formerly of NYC, N.Y., passed away May 7, 1997. Survived by his beloved wife Sylvia; and his loving children, Steven and Judith; and by his adored grandchildren, Stephanie and Laura and devoted brother of the late Bernard. He loved life and lived with passion, seasoned with humor. Having pursued widely various careers, he successfully served as psychologist, owner/ founder of a stock brokerage business and professional fundraiser. Strong supporter of Israel and its education, he last retired April 26, 1980 as Executive Director of the American Friends of the Hebrew University, then moving permanently to Florida. He motivated others to contribute and be the best that they can be. His memory will live on. Contributions are to be made to the American Friends of the Hebrew University, 11 East 69th Street, New York, New York 10021. Memorial services to be held Monday, May 12th, 11:00 AM at Menorah Chapels in Aventura, Florida. For information please call 1-800-327-9192.

title: Don't Penalize the Poor for Their Poverty
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MILGROM, SHELDON M.
description: MILGROM-Sheldon M., 64, on May 7, 1997, in Durham, NC. Beloved husband of Natalie; father of Jeffrey and Victoria; brother of Harold and Rochelle; grandfather of Paige, Lindsey, and Shelby Anne. With many devoted relatives and friends, Sheldon was a man of great wit and heart.

title: Investigate the Republicans, Too
description: After months of claiming that only the Democrats have taken illegal foreign campaign money, the Republican Party has discovered that it has been guilty of the same thing. The $122,000 now being returned by the Republicans to a Hong Kong company is not nearly as big as the $3 million the Democrats have returned to sources overseas. But the Republican action raises the same kinds of troubling questions that have swirled around Democratic fund-raising in the last year. The Senate Government Affairs Committee, which has promised a bipartisan approach in its investigations of the fund-raising scandals, has an obligation to give these allegations a careful review.

title: E-Mail: Lean, Mean And Making Its Mark
description: I REACHED a watershed in written communications the other day by sending an electronic-mail message composed of a single word. The ultimate in digital pith.

title: MARKET TIMING
description: MONDAY

title: Don't Penalize the Poor for Their Poverty
description: To the Editor:

title: Hot Mamas
description: Drag queens and supermodels have had their moment; now mothers are back. Since last year, Madonna has gone mother. So have Ricki Lake, Melissa Etheridge and that 63-year-old in California. The Uber-mom Mia Farrow birthed a memoir. Frank McCourt won a Pulitzer for ''Angela's Ashes,'' named for his mom, and Hal Sirowitz, author of ''Mother Said'' (containing the classic line ''You're a disgrace to the Jews if you don't tuck in your shirt'') was nominated for poet laureate of Queens. The Academy Awards were utterly mother. James Woods took his mom. Joan and Melissa Rivers were hosts together on E! channel. Lauren Bacall got nominated for her role as least supportive mother in ''The Mirror Has Two Faces,'' and Debbie Reynolds, the star of ''Mother,'' gave out an Oscar after doing shtick with her daughter, Carrie Fisher.

title: General's Words Shed a New Light on the Golan
description: It is an article of faith among Israelis that the Golan Heights were seized in the 1967 Middle East war to stop Syria from shelling the Israeli settlements down below. The future of the Golan Heights is central to the search for peace in the Middle East, and much of the case against giving the Golan Heights back to Syria rests on the fear of reviving that threat.

title: California Dreamin'
description: GARDEN STATE PLAZA houses almost 280 shops, including the only J. Crew in New Jersey, but my friend Joelle and I have come to eat. The Napa Valley Grille opened between Neiman Marcus and Lord & Taylor last September, and already it has a following.

title: Memoirs of an Orkneys Addict
description: Shreds of emerald scattered on a silver sea -- the first sight of the Orkney Islands as you fly in on the little plane from Aberdeen, Scotland, is unforgettable. For Orkney addicts (of whom I am one), it becomes part of a sequence of images that keeps the place forever fresh in the mind: sea birds riding the wind, a cliff studded with the tiny, magenta, rare Scottish primroses, glowing brown cattle up to their bellies in buttercups. The rich red sandstone of Kirkwall Cathedral, the thin pointing gray fingers of ancient stone circles, the ruined brochs.

title: Form Follows Fancy
description: The history of 20th-century design encompasses movements as exuberant and varied as the Wiener Werkstatte, Art Deco, Scandinavian Modern and Memphis. Yet the official design history of this century sees these diverse directions simply as interesting little cul-de-sacs off the high road of rational, form-follows-function modernism. It's as if the true story of design could be told in an austere still life consisting of a Le Corbusier chaise, a Mies van der Rohe coffee table and, for that token decorative touch, an Alvar Aalto vase. (The term decorative arts made High Modernists squirm, anyway.)

title: That Was No 'Lady': Pilfering Literature
description: IN A BEAUTIFUL GLADE, A DOZEN YOUNG women in jeans and tank tops and diaphanous tunics recline on the grass, smiling enigmatically at one another and at the camera. Soon, some start dancing to the gentle tootling of recorder music. Nearby, one Pre-Raphaelite beauty stretches out catlike on the branch of a sturdy tree as a friend lovingly braids her lustrous hair. Meanwhile, on the soundtrack, we hear disembodied voices speaking frankly of the pleasures and pitfalls of an intimate romantic encounter.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  SAMBER, ROY GARRETT
description: SAMBER-Roy Garrett. 2/2/55-4/3/92. When you were born, I exclaimed, ''It's a miracle.'' My doctor replied, ''You deserve a miracle.'' You deserved a miracle too, Roy. Your strength, bravery and unconditional love remain with me always. Love, Mommie

title: Major Acquisition in New Era of Global Real Estate
description: WHEN the Lend Lease Corporation of Sydney, Australia, agreed to acquire Equitable Real Estate Management and its $25 billion portfolio last month, it was an indication of how the real estate service business is consolidating internationally as well as nationally.

title: Erin Pitt, Gregory Richards
description: Erin Lee Pitt, the daughter of Ina and Murray C. Pitt of Bloomfield Hills, Mich., was married last evening to Gregory David Richards, a son of Carol J. Richards and Dr. Terry D. Richards, both of New York. Rabbi M. Robert Syme performed the ceremony at the Ritz Carlton in Dearborn, Mich.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COLE, KRISTINE
description: COLE-Kristine. The Faculty, Staff, Parents and Students of Grace Church School extend their deepest sympathy to the family of Kristine Cole upon her passing on May 9, 1997. She was a caring teacher, an innovative and dedicated educator and a wonderful colleague. We will miss her smile. Grace Church School

title: No Heroes: From Plunder To Greed to Expediency
description: OF the many mysteries shrouded by Swiss banking secrecy, none has been more inaccessible than the full story of how Switzerland helped the Nazis finance World War II. A year ago details began to dribble out in a Senate investigation prodded by Jewish groups seeking reparations for Holocaust survivors. Last week the Clinton Administration presented the most comprehensive account yet.

title: Jennifer Klein, Howard Baldinger
description: Jennifer Madison Klein, a daughter of Robyn Klein-Jacknow of Mamaroneck, N.Y., and David Klein of Larchmont, N.Y., was married last evening to Howard Jay Baldinger, the son of Marjorie and Daniel Baldinger of Manhattan. Rabbi Robert Rothman officiated at the Rye Town Hilton in Rye Brook, N.Y.

title: Shows Mirroring Penchants for Absurdity
description: THE news from the Neuberger Museum at Purchase College here is of a major exhibition with a convoy of smaller displays, and hence it parallels that from the Hudson River Museum.

title: Books in Brief: Nonftion
description: TRACK CONDITIONS A Memoir. By Michael Klein. Persea, $22.

title: Useful Phrases for the Adventurous Traveler
description: Sometimes you need the right words in a hurry. Herewith an emergency glossary that can get you out of trouble, fast. Or maybe into it.

title: Hello to All That
description: THE WHOLE SHEBANG

title: Keeping Carpenter Ants Away
description: DON't look now, but foraging hordes of carpenter ants are preparing to tear parts of your house to shreds. Then again, maybe you better look.

title: That Old-Time Religion
description: Southern Cross

title: The New Light Brigade
description: Flowered hats and white gloves, worn by many of the 1,100 guests attending the 15th annual Frederick Law Olmsted Awards Luncheon on Wednesday, recalled a nearly vanished age of elegance and appropriate dress. The fashion world's uniform of all black was eclipsed by the real world's love of color. The lunch, given by the Women's Committee and the board of trustees of the Central Park Conservancy and held in the gloriously restored Conservatory Garden in Central Park, at Fifth Avenue and 105th Street, raised $1.5 million. In the last 15 years, the luncheons have raised over $30 million for the restoration and maintenance of the park.

title: A Heath Care Giant Has a Taste of Defeat
description: The Columbia/HCA Healthcare Corporation has become the world's largest health care company by aggressively competing in an industry dominated by institutions named for saints and samaritans. But now its practices have inspired a backlash.

title: 'Partial Birth' Baloney
description: As the Senate assumes its fetal positions this week for yet another bout of posturing about ''partial-birth'' abortion, here's the only fact pro-choice and pro-life partisans alike can bank on: Almost every ''fact'' spouted by either side will be a sham.

title: Elizabeth Lubetkin, Barry Lipton
description: Elizabeth Lubetkin, a mediator and labor arbitrator, was married in New York on April 20 to Barry Frederick Lipton, the president of the Newspaper Guild of New York. Justice Felice Shea of State Supreme Court in Manhattan officiated at the apartment of the bride's mother, Alice G. Lubetkin.

title: Mendoza's Right Arm Does All the Talking
description: Ramiro Mendoza is easy to overlook. He rarely speaks in the boisterous Yankee clubhouse, and he prefers Spanish to English when he does whisper some words. He has even gone unnoticed by his teammates while snoozing behind piles of clothing in his locker. That is being invisible.

title: When Youngsters Become Their Elders' Teachers
description: JANET KLINGNER, seated in front of a computer at the Brunswick School in Greenwich, listened in rapt attention as Paul Wilford clarified a point about the Windows aspect of her computer. At about the same time at nearby Greenwich Academy, Karrie Martineau and Katherine McGirr showed Frank and Faye Simon how to play solitaire on the computers in front of them.

title: Creating a Bond Beyond U.S. Borders
description: TEACHERS and carpenters, students and union members, artists and medical professionals from Connecticut have been going to Nicaragua since 1984 as part of the New Haven/Leon Sister City Project. The project is an unconventional program run from a small office on Whitney Avenue in New Haven.

title: For Africa's Dictators, No Exit Is Graceful
description: FOR weeks now, drawn as if by a sordid but captivating piece of theater, Africa and much of the world have watched the power of Mobutu Sese Seko, the continent's longest reigning dictator, slip like sand through his fingers.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GIGANTE, YOLANDA
description: GIGANTE-Yolanda, 95 years old, born in Naples, Italy and a resident of Greenwich Village for 76 years. Beloved wife of the late Salvatore Esposito Vulgo Gigante. Devoted mother of Mario, Vincent, Rev. Louis and the late Pasquale, Vincenzo and Ralph. Loving sister of Dolores Santasilia. Also survived by 17 grandchildren and 32 great-grandchildren. Reposing at Perazzo Funeral Home, 199 Bleecker Street, NYC. Mass of the Resurrection, Monday, 10:30 AM, Our Lady of Pompei R.C. Church. Entombment St. John's Cloister. Visiting hours Saturday and Sunday, 2-5 PM, 7-9:30 PM. The family requests in lieu of flowers, that contributions be sent to SEBCO Development Inc., 923 Simpson Street, Bronx, New York 10459.

title: Pamela Burian, Thomas Badger Jr.
description: Pamela Elizabeth Burian, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Ward Burian of Fairfield, Conn., was married there yesterday to Thomas Ashby Badger Jr., the son of Mr. and Mrs. Badger Sr. of Readington, N.J. The Rev. Thomason L. Newcomb performed the ceremony at St. Timothy's Episcopal Church.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEWIS, MINNA MARGULIES
description: LEWIS-Minna Margulies. Of Fifth Ave., NY on May 7, 1997. Beloved wife of the late Duffy. Devoted mother of Donald Lewis, Jane Rosenberg and son-in-law, Joel Rosenberg. Loving grandmother of Jennifer and Dawn Rosenberg. Her charm, wit, beauty and zest for life made a lasting impression on all who knew her. To know her was to love her. Services Monday, 1 PM at Riverside Cemetery, Lodi, New Jersey.

title: The Dominican Republic: Above the Clouds
description: Pico Duarte looms in the Caribbean imagination like a tropical magic mountain. In the heart of the Cordillera Central region of the Dominican Republic, it is the tallest point in the Antilles, taller, in fact, than any mountain east of the Mississippi on the North American continent. Intriguingly, its height keeps shifting, depending on what guidebook or map you look at.

title: Bag Crit
description: Except for those few who need Prozac to control the urge to shop, Tibor Kalman's ''Bag Crit'' (''Stores,'' April 6) made it clear why the rest of us trek willingly and even happily from store to store. We do it for the shopping bags.

title: Kasparov Becomes Human
description: Playing an uncharacteristically passive brand of chess that he apparently has deemed his best strategy against a mechanical foe, Garry Kasparov expressed frustration and fatigue after a week of games against the I.B.M. computer, Deep Blue. Perhaps this is because he has the burden of defending man against machine; or perhaps it's because he knows that by playing the computer's game instead of his own, he has already, in some sense, yielded.

title: ALSO INSIDE
description: F.Y.I. 2

title: Istanbul's Glitter Domes
description: Reluctantly, I'd have to admit that Istanbul's Buyuk Londra Hotel is not for everyone. Some people find its gloom oppressive, and it is undeniably eccentric, but when I stepped into the lobby I fell in love at first sight. Its air of faded grandeur was deeply sympathetic. In the lobby and the adjacent lounge there were six chandeliers, two of them resembling exotic, underwater blooms. Stucco decorations were picked out with gold paint. There was also a large mirror with a wildly baroque frame, but it was only when my eyes adjusted to the dim light that I became aware of the hotel's most unusual feature: arrayed all around me was a world-class collection of defunct radios, no two of them exactly alike. I learned later that this was only the tip of the iceberg. A storeroom behind the reception desk was entirely filled with radios that probably hadn't emitted a whisper in decades.

title: Scenes From a Mismarriage
description: SNAKE By Kate Jennings. 157 pp. Hopewell, N.J.: The Ecco Press. $21.

title: Into the Past At China's Edge
description: I WAS on the summit of a 10,000-foot holy mountain in Yunnan Province, and it was one of those rare moments when the immensity of China was almost tangible. To the north I could see the snow-covered peaks of the Himalayas, rising and falling to the horizon like great uneven waves -- a vast rough sea suddenly frozen into silence.

title: America's Role in Hong Kong
description: The coming transfer of Hong Kong from Britain to China is a case study in the limits of American power. Customary levers of diplomacy and military pressure are ill suited to defending Hong Hong's freedoms, and the most severe economic penalty -- revoking all Chinese trade privileges -- seems mismatched to the problems ahead. A mix of strong Presidential pressure, quiet diplomacy and carefully targeted trade sanctions imposed jointly with other countries offers the best hope of influencing Chinese conduct.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NISSEN, SALLY
description: NISSEN-Sally. Beloved wife of the late Bernard. Adored mother of J. Harold and Eleanore Geringer. Much loved mother-in-law of Sylvia O. Nissen and Harold I. Geringer. Cherished grandmother and great-grandmother. Services Sunday 11:30am at the Riverside Memorial Chapel, 21 West Broad Street, Mount Vernon, NY.

title: Anne Seel and Austen Furse 3d
description: Anne Goff Seel, who was until last month the executive director of the New York City Landmarks Preservation Commission, was married yesterday to Austen Henry Furse 3d, the owner of Matagorda Capital, an investment company in Houston. The Rev. David F. Sellery performed the Episcopal ceremony at St. Thomas Church in New York.

title: Architect Offers His Guidelines for Success
description: GOOD relationships, good fortune and good timing. ''And a lot of hard work,'' John Kenney said, in describing the transformation of his one-man architectural practice into one of the largest architectural firms in Westchester.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KELLEY, FLORENCE MAHER, R.N.
description: KELLEY-Florence Maher, R.N. Mother of Paul Kelley, O.D. of Branford, CT., sister of Eileen Maher of NYC, sister of the late Helen Porter Maher-McKernon, Sister Mary Gratia Maher, R.S.M., Arthur C., Stuart E., Robert D. and Rev. Gordon H. Maher. She was an alumna of Lenox Hill Hospital School of Nursing, Class of 1927.

title: There's No Place Like Work
description: I have long thought that today's communication technologies could be utilized by overworked family members looking for ways to spend more quality time at home. After reading your article, I wondered whether these technologies might not be used to introduce a kind of telecommuting from work to home, enabling parents to put their kids to bed by video teleconference.

title: A Lifetime Full Of Playing With Words
description: To the Editor:

title: CHEAT FEATS
description: With college graduates surging into the marketplace, a sour note: According to Stephen Davis, a professor at Emporia State in Kansas, half of all college students now admit to cheating at least once. In a 1941 study, only 20 percent said they cheated. Today's methods include the obvious -- like loading Walkmans with answers. And the bizarre.. . .On Feb. 8, a man taking the L.S.A.T. at U.S.C. stole the test at knifepoint and fled. Officials believe he or others phoned in answers to the pager of Danny Khatchaturian, a U.S.C. undergrad who took the test two hours later in Hawaii. Some cheaters claim they're making a valid statement. ''The stuff on my site stinks,'' says Kenneth Sahr, who runs a Web site that features free downloadable term papers. ''Doesn't that tell you something about the quality of our professors?''

title: Eugene Lee and Sally Park
description: Sally Eran Park, a daughter of Kumok and Jae Chun Park of Overland Park, Kan., was married yesterday to Eugene Lee, a son of Sun Whi and Jae Won Lee of East Northport, N.Y. The Rev. Janet H. Legro, a minister of the United Church of Christ, performed the ceremony at the Memorial Church at Harvard University in Cambridge, Mass.

title: There's No Place Like Work
description: I was not surprised by the revelation, in Arlie Russell Hochschild's article ''There's No Place Like Work'' (April 20), that people rate their performance at the office more highly than their performance at home. We spend years training to be workers, but are never taught how to care for a family. In my case, I had four years of college, four years of grad school and eight years of work experience that prepared me to be good at my job, but I had never even held an infant until the obstetrician put my newborn daughter in my arms. Of course, I was a better employee than I was a mother.

title: Would You Like That in 10's and 20's?
description: Is a bird in the hand worth two in the bush when it comes to the lottery? Some people apparently think so and the New Jersey Lottery Commission is changing the way it pays out its top prizes to accommodate them.

title: Looking for High Ground As the Slugfest Starts
description: Michael Murphy is finally beginning to benefit from the advantage of being the candidate who no one thinks stands a chance.

title: New Public Facilities Should Help in '98
description: Although books have been written and maps drawn to direct people to the public toilets in the city, New Yorkers have long complained about their scarcity in public places.

title: Mr. Europe's Daughter Is a Voice for France's Left
description: Martine Aubry, a Socialist who is running for Parliament in this month's national elections, practically has Europe written all over her face.

title: Island Family Enfolds A Child Each Summer
description: At night, if the wind is right, you can hear the ocean from the Savage Wasleys' house on Fishers Island, N.Y.

title: Dionis C. Riggs, New England Poet, Dies at 98
description: Dionis Coffin Riggs, a poet, author, newspaper columnist and civic leader who made Martha's Vineyard her home and her passion for the better part of a century, died on April 20 at Cleaveland House, the West Tisbury, Mass., boardinghouse where she had listened to seafaring tales as a child and told them as an old woman. She was 98 and had conducted her regular living room poetry seminar there less than a week before her death.

title: Whose Money Is It, Anyway?
description: To the Editor:

title: Who's Keeping I-95 Clear?
description: LOU TAMMARO, 31 years old, bearded, and with a wry sense of humor, was piloting a big State Department of Transportation rig on Interstate 95 one recent day, keeping his eyes intently on the road but also managing to divest himself of many opinions about life in the fast lanes of Connecticut's busiest highway.

title: Hardaway's Foul on Starks Quickens Steps of the Knicks
description: Jeff Van Gundy's players were talking about double standards, about how the rugged style of the old Knicks hampers the way these Knicks are perceived. About how Miami's Tim Hardaway would have been in a world of trouble had he been wearing orange and blue when he sent John Starks to the floor in the fourth quarter on Friday night.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GILL, STEVEN LYNN GILL II
description: GILL-Steven Lynn Gill II. Beloved son of Maureen Parent and husband of Karen Ricketts died on April 29, 1997 at the age of 26. A memorial service will be held Tuesday, May 13 at 6 PM, at the United Nations Chapel, 777 U.N. Plaza, New York, NY. Memorial donations may be sent to Unicef or Bridges to Communities.

title: A Different Perspective: The Critic as Judge
description: FOR six years, the Art Center of Northern New Jersey here has conducted a nationwide competition each spring. This time, I agreed to be the judge because it was a rare opportunity for a critic to put his money where his mouth is, to make the leap from singling out a work in writing to making an actual endorsement.

title: By an Ancient Cave, The Classics Flourish
description: ''WE'RE A KENTUCKY-MULE theater,'' says the director Warren Hammack in a sly drawl. He is referring to the stubbornness that has allowed Horse Cave Theater to endure as one of the country's more ambitious summer theaters in the face of considerable obstacles.

title: Teaching Children to Read: Politics Colors Debate Over Methods
description: When 15,000 reading teachers and education professors gathered here this week against the backdrop of the increasingly politicized debate over reading instruction, there was little consensus about the answer to the crucial question of what is the best way to teach children to read.

title: Mayor Trumpets Budget As Boon for All Boroughs
description: If there was ever any question whether the mayoral race was going to be fought in every borough of the city, it is being put to rest by Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's strategy for promoting his new $33.5 billion budget, which often focuses on the benefits to residents in the Bronx, Brooklyn, Queens and Staten Island.

title: What's Wrong With Getting the Call Right?
description: The puck goes in, the red light goes on and the Devils celebrate what appears to be the game-tying goal. But because a Devil's skate was in the goaltender's crease, that blue-shaded semicircle in front of the net, the goal is disallowed.

title: Nancy Rabinowitz, Alan Friedman
description: Nancy Jean Rabinowitz, a daughter of Anna and Martin J. Rabinowitz of New York, was married last evening to Alan David Friedman, the son of Doris and Jack Friedman of Jamesburg, N.J. Rabbi Nancy Wechsler-Azen performed the ceremony at the Pegasus Suite of the Rainbow Room in New York.

title: Q and A
description: Bill Gates's House

title: Residents Want Answers on State Money
description: Ever since Gov. George E. Pataki eliminated millions of dollars in state subsidies for Roosevelt Island last year, the Governor's administrator for the island, Jerome H. Blue, has found himself the lightning rod for residents angry over the cuts.

title: Maria Kozloski and Lance Crist
description: Maria Chiara Kozloski and DeLanson Douglas Crist, international investment specialists in Moscow, were married yesterday in Chevy Chase, Md. The Rev. John J. Mudd, a Roman Catholic priest, officiated at Woodend, the headquarters of the Audubon Naturalist Society.

title: Up in the Valley, The Valley So High
description: IF THE GRAND TETON MUSIC FESTIVAL remains off the beaten path, it is certainly through no fault of Joseph Robinson's. Mr. Robinson, the principal oboist of the New York Philharmonic, has been campaigning for years to raise the public profile of the festival, in Teton Village, Wyo. Then again, ''fault'' may not be the word.

title: Pope Lands In Beirut Issuing Call For Healing
description: Arriving here today in a capital that still shows the scars of a civil war that ended seven years ago, Pope John Paul II began a two-day visit with an appeal for reconciliation destined not only for Lebanon but other countries where Christians and Muslims live together.

title: Mom-and-Pop Web Cops
description: While she talks, Joanne Fazel (leftmost in photo) scrolls through a medical Web site, hunting for references to illicit drug use. What she sees -- text about the medicinal value of marijuana -- passes muster, so she moves on. ''You're just trying to determine if something's wrong and get out,'' she says, sounding more like a fighter pilot than the mother of a 9-year-old.

title: On Toe and Off In Every Corner Of the Land
description: This list is selective. It is national in scope but concentrates on the Northeast.

title: PUERTO VALLARTAS WILD ENVIRONS
description: Along the beachfront Malecon in Puerto Vallarta, the pinwheel man hawked his shiny wares. A parachutist sailed overhead as the sun melted into the Pacific. The faux pirate ship on a sunset cruise hoisted its Jolly Roger. Long-legged girls with sunburned legs bopped to the salsa beat; on our way to dinner, a female cop with almond eyes and orange lipstick followed my husband with her gaze.

title: The Pickle Has a Place in My Heart
description: WHEN I stumbled upon a listing of annual events, I was amused to see May 16 declared the beginning of International Pickle Week. Those few words dredged up a holographic image of nostalgia for me. You see, I've heard about pickles ever since the year 1956 when I met Ken Stern. He was my best friend during those teen-age years, and became my husband several years later. It was his grandfather Aaron Stern, who founded Stern's Pickle Works on Powell Place off Melville Road in Farmingdale in 1894.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DOLGENOS, DAVID
description: DOLGENOS-David. January 9, 1931-May 6, 1997. ''Buffalo Bill's'' by e.e. cummings. Buffalo Bill's defunct who used to ride a watersmooth-silver stallion and break onetwothreefourfive pigeons-justlikethat jesus he was a handsome man and what i want to know is how do you like your blueeyed boy Mister Death With love from, Peter, Peggy, Carey, Tom and Sally

title: Making Room for a City Clown
description: MOST summer days, Kathleen O'Toole, a nurse and water safety instructor, and her three children splash around in a public pool in Floral Park pool. One day in July 1994, Mrs. O'Toole brought along a child from Manhattan, Jonathan Smith, then 7.

title: U.S. Calm Over Cuba-Grenada Ties
description: The United States invaded this tiny island nation in 1983 in large part because the Reagan Administration considered the Government in power at the time to be aligned with Cuba. So when Keith Mitchell, the current Prime Minister, headed off to Havana on an official visit in late April, it sent shock waves from one end of the Caribbean to the other.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KEANE, REV. BROTHER ALFRED X. C.F.C
description: KEANE-Rev. Brother Alfred X. C.F.C Member of the Christian Brother community for 55 years. Devoted brother of Rev. Eugene Keane, Pastor of St. Augustine R.C. Church Highland, NY. Visiting will be at the Christian Brother's Provincial Center, 21 Pryer Terrace, New Rochelle, New York, Monday from 1-6:30 PM. Mass of the Resurrection, Monday, 7 PM, at the Church of the Holy Family, New Rochelle, NY. Interment Tuesday, 11 AM, Christian Brother's Cemetery, West Park, N.Y.

title: Pearl T. Tsai, Stephen Renaker
description: Pearl Tan Tsai, the daughter of Elizabeth and Nien-Tszr Tsai of Potomac, Md., was married yesterday in Brooklyn to Stephen James Renaker, the son of Joyce Renaker of Berkeley, Calif., and David Renaker of San Francisco. The Rev. Joyce Fuchs-Gioia, an interfaith minister, performed the nondenominational ceremony at the Brooklyn Botanic Garden.

title: QUESTIONS FOR: Wil Haygood
description: Wil Haygood is the author of The Haygoods of Columbus, a memoir about growing up in Columbus, Ohio, in the 60's and 70's.

title: Computers vs. Humans: Clashing Symbols
description: To the Editor:

title: Of Hydrogen and the Hindenburg
description: Ever since 1783, when a hot-air balloon first carried human beings into the sky, people have found the effortless buoyancy of balloons and airships entrancing. Lighter-than-air travel, freed from the noisy machinery of airplanes and helicopters, has always been chic.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  REEVES, MINNA
description: REEVES-Minna. Fond and esteemed remembrances today and every day of a mother whose beauty, charm, and talent were exceeded only by her filial devotion.

title: Books in Brief: Nonftion
description: THE LOST ART OF HEALING By Bernard Lown. Houghton Mifflin, $24.95.

title: The Bag Ban of the Taliban
description: The Taliban religious police, who have imposed their strict version of Islamic law in two- thirds of Afghanistan, have reiterated their ban on paper bags. ''If we catch people using paper, they will face serious punishment,'' said a Taliban official. The Taliban allow only plastic bags, since recycled paper, they say, may include pages of the Koran.

title: BEST SELLERS: May 11, 1997
description: Weeks

title: The Arts Benefit From Festivities
description: Opera and art in Brooklyn; readings, dance, art and fashion in Manhattan.

title: Just Like That, Bulls Are Back To Unbeatable
description: It was as if the Chicago Bulls served everyone a sedative today, a game that calmed and soothed the jangled nerves of those worried about the state of the champions. Settle down. Everything will be all right.

title: It's Choice Pizza, No Matter How They Slice It
description: Steps away from the PATH train exit on Hudson Street, tucked beneath the law offices where Vince Wilt works, sits the tiny pizzeria he opened six years ago: Enzo's Pizza Cafe.

title: FUNDS WATCH
description: Twice the Power, In Only Six Years

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROSE, EDMUND S.
description: ROSE-Edmund S. Of East Hampton, NY. On May 8, 1997. Husband of Sally; father of Gillian; brother of Ray and Annette; uncle; and loyal friend of Bill, Leif, Roven, Jo and many others. ''Laughter is not a bad beginning of a friendship, and it's the best ending for one.'' Your humor, wisdom, love and counsel will be severely missed. An intimate gathering will be held at a later date.

title: It's Florida Meets the East End
description: THE Hamptons are becoming Florida North. No fewer than four new East End restaurants (Pacific East, Jenny's and the new Savanna's and Post House) are from the Sunshine State. Restaurateurs from Palm Beach, Miami and Boca Raton have discovered what their Manhattan counterparts did a few years ago: that when the high season ends in Florida, it begins on Long Island. This natural hand-in-glove relationship enables them to stay busy year round and retain their staffs by moving them north for the summer, much the same as Manhattan spots with Long Island outposts send some of their people east for the warm-weather months.

title: In Japan, Use of Dead Has the Living Uneasy
description: She knew that only a liver transplant could save her life, but Wakana Kume was still undecided about going ahead with it.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BERNSTEIN, HYMAN
description: BERNSTEIN-Hyman, on May 9, 1997. Beloved husband of the late Helen, devoted father of Ira and Lynne; Arnold and Arlene; Barbara and Michael. Loving grandfather of Eric and Valerie; Brian and Deana; Marc and Allison; Lisa, Debra, Lee, Adrienne and Jared. Cherished great grandfather of Alexis Hope, and Zachary Laurence. Devoted friend of Lillian Straus. Services today 10 AM at ''The Riverside,'' 76 Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: There's No Place Like Work
description: In my affluent suburb, many women are fortunate to be in a position to afford to stay home. However, we (former corporate achievers or lawyers) agree that the combination of housework and child care is more difficult than anything we undertook at the office. Many of us have created an ersatz work environment by taking on less-than-challenging part-time jobs or massive amounts of volunteer work, in an effort to find an arena in which our efforts are appreciated. A corollary to this is the changing nature of volunteer activities, owing to the availability of these former career women. At my children's school, what started as a bake sale years ago is now an extravaganza of elaborate decorator items and baked goods that raises $40,000 in one morning. Our other fund raiser -- a two-day event that includes a black-tie dinner dance and auction -- nets $250,000 to $300,000. That's more than some small businesses make in a year. And that's the point. For the mothers who work on these events, this is a job. It provides the structure, socializing opportunities and tangible results that work did.

title: Vancouver
description: To the Editor: ''Waterfront Weekend in Vancouver'' (March 23) brought back memories of a thoroughly enjoyable few days there last July. Suzanne Carmichael covered a lot but neglected to mention the free Museum of Anthropology and its superb collection of West Coast First Nations art. It is on the University of British Columbia campus at 6393 Northwest Marine Drive, on the Point Gray Cliffs. The building, which has been extolled in architectural publications, includes totem poles, feast dishes, canoes and carvings in gold, silver, stone and wood.

title: When Prosciutto Is a Souvenir
description: FRANK DiSTEFANO of Long Island City, Queens, had a dismaying return from Italy in January. At the duty-free shop at the Rome airport, he had bought $30 worth of prosciutto to take home. Two people, one apparently the manager of the shop, assured him he would have no problem bringing it into the United States in its vacuum-packed plastic.

title: NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y.
description: Summer is nowhere more its dreamy self than in a meadow. In my 17th June I would throw myself on the green breast of a field in a hidden corner of the Bronx, and there, in the company of grasshoppers, ladybugs, bee-buzzes and buttercups, read ''The Faerie Queene': it was Spenser's own ''greensward.'' That long-ago meadow is lost, decimated, crisscrossed by highways. And does anyone now remember the autogiro that, one Decoration Day -- to mark the inauguration of a World War I soldiers' monument -- poured down cascades of flowers into the reaching arms of children?

title: Trying to Stoke the Campfire Again at Coleman
description: IT'S Jerry W. Levin to the rescue. Again.

title: Venerable Beech Makes It to Her Party
description: When a woman grows old, her limbs become brittle, her elbows show knots and her hair thins. But this does not mean she should be hauled off to the woodshed.

title: Mmm, Mmm, Raw
description: If your rigid vegan diet is becoming a bore, you might step up to Raw, a ''living foods'' restaurant in San Francisco that proudly claims to have staked out the next frontier in meatless cuisine -- nothing is cooked here. So? Can't that simply mean mounds of raw fruits and vegetables? Yes, but Raw's ambitious menu (which relies very heavily on fruit) transcends mere produce-shoveling. It also features items that you might hope would be cooked, like the fruit-topped pizza pictured above. The ''crust'' for this baby is created from a mulch of activated buckwheat groats that is solidified in the sun for 10 to 12 hours.

title: Christine Lubiak And Mark Leahy
description: Christine Barbara Lubiak, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Henry W. Lubiak of Bridgewater Township, N.J., was married yesterday to Mark Robert Leahy, the son of Dr. Mary Leahy and Dr. Robert Leahy of Olympia, Wash. The Rev. John D. Savard officiated at the Roman Catholic Church of St. Ignatius of Loyola in Chestnut Hill, Mass.

title: Some Regulatory Rain On the Managers' Parade?
description: THE mutual fund industry, the guardian of the retirement money of millions of Americans, has enjoyed a remarkable run in the last year.

title: Spike Lee's 30 Seconds
description: Those who ask Spike Lee why there are no white actors in his films are not paying attention (''Spike Lee's 30 Seconds,'' by Lynn Hirschberg, April 20). How could they have forgotten the characters created by Annabella Sciorra in ''Jungle Fever,'' Danny Aiello and John Turturro in ''Do the Right Thing'' and Harvey Keitel in ''Clockers,'' in which Lee made a Jewish cop the hero in a movie set in an urban ghetto. One of Spike Lee's most admirable qualities is his fairness; in ''Do the Right Thing,'' the situation is evoked with so much empathy that a black person, watching it, can understand the feelings of Sal, the pizzeria owner, and a white person can understand why Mookie, the pizza deliveryman played by Lee, acts as he does.

title: Penatagon Used-Jet Sales Lot Helps Keep World Supplied
description: With row upon row of mothballed warplanes on the desert floor near here, the Air Force's ''Boneyard'' has become the largest concentration of military aircraft in the world.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HORNBOSTEL, LENA
description: HORNBOSTEL-Lena. Of Savannah, GA, May 8, 1997. Formerly of Weston MA, New Canaan and Wilton, CT and Eastman, NH. Loving wife of the late Charles C.; devoted mother of Charles C., Jr. of Manchester, CT, Karen L. of Littleton, CO and the late Patricia Humphries; grandmother of Michelle of Springfield, VA, Patricia and Sarah of Manchester, CT; great-grandmother of Caleb of Manchester, CT; sister of Neva M. Baine, of Atlanta, GA formerly of Weston. Funeral from the George F. Doherty & Sons Funeral Home, 477 Washington St., Wellesley, MA, Tuesday at 9:00 AM. Funeral mass in St. Julia's Church, Weston Center at 10 AM. Visiting hours Monday, 2-4 and 7-9. Interment Linwood Cemetery Weston. Donations to the American Cancer Society, 30 Speen St., Framingham, MA, 01701. Graduate of Wellesley College, Class of 1935.

title: Authentic Tastes In Queens Nooks
description: DAVID'S TAIWANESE GOURMET +

title: As for Cy Coleman . . .
description: To the Editor:

title: Correction

He is survived by daughter, Stacey; sons, Joshua and Gary; grandsons, Matthew & Max; brother, Morton. In lieu of flowers, family requests donations to be made in his memory to the National Brain Tumor Foundation - 785 Market Street #

title: LONG ISLAND JOURNAL
description: From Radio's Golden Age

title: The Way We Were, and Were, and Were
description: RETRO. It won't go away. Screen out cell-phone chatter, David Helfgott's incessant tinkling on the ivories and ''Ellen'' mania, and the world looks like one giant flashback.

title: G.M. Shapes Up Around the Middle
description: FOUR midsize General Motors cars appeared on the cover of a 1983 issue of Fortune magazine. Parked side by side on a lawn, they wore the same hue of burgundy paint and they struck identical profiles. Few readers could tell the Chevrolet Celebrity from the Buick Century or the Oldsmobile Ciera from the Pontiac 6000.

title: Like No One on Earth
description: The family at the center of the Canadian writer Barbara Gowdy's third novel, MISTER SANDMAN (Steerforth, $24), is uniquely, whimsically dysfunctional. But it is the unexpected birth of Joan Canary, half idiot savant and half changeling, that catalyzes the individual idiosyncrasies and personal secrets of the people around her, melding them into a clan defined by its eccentricity. Before the arrival of Joan, Gordon, a repressed homosexual, considered himself a devoted homebody, content in his marriage to Doris, a compulsive liar and concealed lesbian. But their attempt at 1950's normalcy comes undone when their placidly slow-witted 15-year-old daughter, Sonja, bears an out-of-wedlock daughter and they decide to raise the dwarfish, nearly albino infant as if she were their own. Doris and Gordon's younger daughter, Marcy, is left out of the loop, but with her telepathic closeness to the ''sister'' who is really her niece, her childhood and adolescence gain a magical quality. Resembling no one in the family (or on earth), Joan proves so sensitive to light that she can play outside only at night; she is so attuned to music that she can perform Bach's ''Goldberg'' Variations at 8, though she never bothers with intelligible speech. Using Joan as a sounding board, the person in whom all the others confide, Ms. Gowdy gently and humorously pries into everything they try to conceal from one another, including Gordon's first extramarital affair and Marcy's promiscuity. These secrets flit in and out of their lives the way snatches of popular songs play in their heads. Joan's possibly brain-damaged brilliance lies at the heart of both the narrative and the symbolism of this delightfully quirky novel, in which the Canary family's life emerges as a weird yet often affecting group composition. Allen Lincoln

title: New Jersey Underground: Fossils, Gems and Glowing Rocks
description: When a guide in the Rainbow Room of the Sterling Hill Mining Museum in Ogdensburg introduces an ultraviolet light to the darkness 150 feet underground, and schoolchildren gasp and yell as the calcite and zinc minerals in the tunnel fluoresce into reds, greens and yellows, the visitors are witnessing a natural phenomenon that can hardly be reproduced anywhere else -- except two and a half miles away, in Franklin.

description: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani yesterday assailed the acquittal of a man who was charged in the death of a police officer last year, saying that prosecutors in the Bronx had mishandled the case.

title: From New York to Los Angeles, and Back
description: MARGARIDA JATOBA said that now she could live in China if she wanted to. ''Thank God for computers,'' she said.

title: 'Noise From Garage Elevator'
description: To the Editor:

title: An Italian Enclave Of Wine and Ham
description: THE name Friuli and that of its most famous dish, cjalzons, sound exotic and vaguely trans-Alpine. Indeed, this northeastern corner of Italy, the Friuli-Venezia Giulia region, borders Austria, Slovenia, Croatia and, within Italy, the Veneto region -- a very tasty crossroads of gastronomic influences. Friuli began as Forum Iulii, the name of the Roman colony founded by Julius Caesar; and cjalzons, related to calzone, are ravioli. The idea of something Italian wrapped in something foreign was much with us during the long Easter weekend that my companion, Franco, and I spent in this area northwest of Trieste, mostly in the southeastern quadrant of Friuli.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ORTIZ, ANTHONY JOHN
description: ORTIZ-Anthony John. Tony died May 6, 1997, at age 42, after a long battle with AIDS. His Christmas cards for MOMA delighted thousands every year. Known to many in the AIDS community as the ''little guy with the big voice at demos,'' he will be remembered for his high spirits, spectacular smile and love of white McCoy pottery. Survived by his lover, Michael Longacre; Vanessa Longacre; his mother, Petra Ortiz, sister, Rita Linn, and brother, Bart Ortiz of Greensboro, NC; sister, Patty Grace of Mason, MI; his father, Antonio Ortiz preceded him in death in 1994. Memorial contributions to Housing Works, 594 Broadway, New York City 10012.

title: Singapore's Airport Is Rated Best in Survey
description: A survey that ranks airports around the world by travelers' ratings on overall convenience lists airports in Singapore; Manchester, England; Melbourne, Australia, Amsterdam and Zurich as the five best, according to the International Air Transport Association. The best United States airport was Cincinnati's, which was rated sixth over all, on the strength of the friendliness of airport's staff, its restaurants and the ease of check-in. The airport in Orlando, Fla., was rated seventh.

title: Top Dog
description: Fifty-eight judges took a look at 4,201 dogs last Sunday at the annual Trenton Kennel Club competition.

description: The largest American showing of artifacts from the Titanic, now on display in Memphis, is being denounced by the International Congress of Maritime Museums.

title: Crash
description: Last fall, I wanted to get away. I was staying in suburban Milwaukee at the time, in the house I had grown up in. I had left New York, where I live, in August, when my mother went into the hospital for what turned out to be the final time -- she had been ill for years, though her death, at the beginning of September, was relatively unexpected. Now it was Thanksgiving. I had spent week after week wandering around the house in a state of cool confusion, a wakeful sleepiness that I now recognize as what the mind does to itself when it gets bored with grieving.

title: Notes From the Underground on Another Balkan Rift
description: An Albanian immigrant, wearing a pair of black jeans, a gray jacket and purple T-shirt, sat late one afternoon in the cafe of a Geneva train station.

title: Vietnam Memorial to Have Scaled-Down Education Center
description: The need to cut costs has delayed the groundbreaking for the Vietnam Era Education Center, which is to be built next to the Vietnam Veterans' Memorial at the PNC Bank Arts Center in Holmdel Township.

title: Grand Designs
description: Several architects and planners have had larger roles than Henry Dreyfuss (1904-72) in creating the look of 20th-century America, and other industrial designers were flashier. But none were more creative in making common objects -- sewing machines, vacuum cleaners, tractors, wall thermostats, telephones (a single series of one of his Bell phones sold 162 million units) -- attractive, unobtrusive and easy to use. Dreyfuss was the surrogate for ordinary people when new products were on the drawing boards, as Russell Flinchum says in HENRY DREYFUSS, INDUSTRIAL DESIGNER: The Man in the Brown Suit (Cooper-Hewitt National Design Museum, Smithsonian Institution/Rizzoli, $50). Dreyfuss never went to college, but he did study with that erratic design genius Norman Bel Geddes before he began a career as a Broadway stage designer in the 1920's and then set up his own industrial design shop in the 30's. He could produce eye-popping marvels, the New York Central Railroad's sleek 20th Century Limited of the late 30's, for instance; Dreyfuss designed everything from the gleaming locomotives to the dishes in the dining car. He designed the Pentagon's war room during World War II and a fabulous flying car after the war. But, as this book demonstrates, his real passion was for everyday objects. The 200 photographs are intensely evocative of the great age of design from the 30's through the 60's, and Mr. Flinchum's account of the designer's life and work is judicious, if not eloquent. One hopes it will lead people to read Dreyfuss's own books, especially ''Designing for People,'' ''The Measure of Man'' and the great ''Symbol Sourcebook: An Authoritative Guide to International Graphic Symbols,'' completed by him and his wife, Doris Marks, in 1972. What Mr. Flinchum does make clear is that, whatever one's estimate of the work of Henry Dreyfuss, he was for decades the outspoken conscience of design in this country. That is just. No one has taken his place. That says a lot about why things look the way they do now. D. J. R. Bruckner

title: Weatherproof in Seattle
description: Make sure you get a good look at the sun as your plane descends through the clouds prior to landing at Seattle-Tacoma International Airport. You won't be seeing it again until you leave. Seattle is surrounded by snow-capped mountains, clear lakes and a vast expanse of cedar and fir trees, but, much of the year, the sky is the color and consistency of a wet wool gym sock. To live in Seattle is to know the depths of despair that lousy weather can drive people to. Think Gore-Tex, caffeine addiction and lucrative employment at the suicide hot line.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  ROSENSOHN, WILLIAM
description: ROSENSOHN-William. May 11, 1995. You live on in so many hearts and minds. So many of us trying to fill your shoes. Sam, Marguerite, Dan and Elizabeth

title: Talking to Mother
description: According to a poll taken by the Pew Research Center for the People and the Press, 65 percent of women speak to their mothers several times a week.

title: Deep Blue Escapes With Draw to Force Decisive Last Game
description: Outfoxed by a cagey computer in a complex endgame, Garry Kasparov was held to a draw yesterday by the I.B.M. computer Deep Blue, keeping their match tied but forcing Mr. Kasparov into a difficult position if he is to successfully defend the supremacy of the human chess player in the final game of the match today.

title: UMass Holds Off Hofstra
description: Hofstra made it interesting, at least. Trailing Massachusetts by 6-0 with 10 minutes left today, the Flying Dutchmen scored four goals and put some fear in the hearts of the Minutemen. But UMass held on for a 6-4 victory in a first-round match of the National Collegiate Athletic Association lacrosse tournament.

title: When the Cat's Away
description: Vacation season is about to begin, and one boss after another will take some extended time off, trusting that their underlings will run the office efficiently without them. But is that what really happens when the boss is away? Or does everyone put their feet up until just before the boss returns? What happens in your office? Send your best stories to On the Job, Money and Business, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036. Or send them by E-mail to onthejob@nytimes.com. Include your telephone number. All submissions become the property of The Times and may be republished in any medium.

title: Machinations
description: Clearly, we Americans are obsessed with the medium, not the message. Inventors, investors, producers, consumers -- we are all hooked on the new technologies of communication. Our great minds, energies and wealth are engaged in wiring and unwiring humanity, casting and cabling, faxing and phoning, Webbing and satelliting and multiplexing the earth. We are eradicating borders and homogenizing cultures. We are turning homes into offices and offices into video arcades. The very air we breathe heaves with digitized words and images.

Yee of Fort Lee, N.J. Pastor Kenneth Tom, a Baptist minister, performed the nondenominational ceremony at the Palisadium, a restaurant in Cliffside Park, N.J.

title: Betting on Security as Crime Takes a Holiday
description: Q. Now that everyone's telling us how much safer the streets are, is it still possible to make money investing in the personal-security business?

description: GUIDEBOOK

title: Natural Allies? Guess Again.
description: ON paper, Councilmen Thomas K. Duane and Antonio Pagan look like natural allies. The two men, both Democrats, represent adjacent districts in lower Manhattan and are the city's first and only openly gay Council members. But here the similarities end.

title: The Holocaust Is Focus Of Events in Michigan
description: A comprehensive look at the Holocaust, ''Anne Frank and Us: Insights into Cruelty, Discrimination and Hope,'' runs through May 25 in Flint, Mich. Events at the city's museums and theaters, coordinated by the Flint Cultural Center and the Flint Jewish Federation, will explore the Holocaust and its implications today.

title: Food for the Present and Building a Future
description: WHEN Linda A. Coons, an instructor at Manchester Community Technical College, teaches about the danger zone, she is referring to food safety -- the temperature range between 40 and 140 degrees Fahrenheit when illness-causing bacteria may grow in foodstuffs.

title: Triplets Share Biking In Business and Fun
description: VIRTUALLY every day at 4:30 P.M., the Whalen triplets fasten their helmets, click into their pedals and seek cycling refuge along the back roads of the Hudson Valley.

title: Savoring Three Cultures
description: ON the 4,947-foot peak of Mount Forno, rising from a southeastern spur of the mighty Alps, stands a wooden signpost marking one of the most significant frontier points in Europe. Under its conical shingled roof, three guide boards pointing the way to different regions read: ''Friuli,'' ''Karnten'' and ''Slovenija.''

title: Fewer Toilets Are Left Without Locks
description: On Wednesdays, the line for the ladies' room at the Hotel Edison often snaked through the lobby and onto West 46th Street in the Theater District. Hotel management thought that a few of those waiting might be guests at the hotel or its restaurants. But they suspected that many women were going to Broadway shows and knew that the hotel's lobby bathrooms were not locked.

title: A Religious Feel to Mother's Day Fishing Along the Yellowstone
description: When aquatic insects metamorphose from bottom-crawling larvae into winged flies and lift off the surface of the water, anglers call it a hatch. There are famous mayfly hatches on the Beaverkill and Willowemoc Rivers in New York State, on Fishing Creek in Pennsylvania and on Hat Creek in northern California. But perhaps the most legendary -- if not the most holy -- flyfishing event in the country is the Mother's Day caddis hatch on the Yellowstone River, near this little trout-daft cowboy town, 60 miles north of Yellowstone Park.

title: Unspoken Dissent
description: To the Editor:

title: A Voice in the Middle, Though in Range Only

title: German Social Democrats Take Heart in British Labor Victory
description: Imagine a country whose conservative leaders are well into their second decade of uninterrupted power and whose opponents cling to the past while the world moves on to the free-market free-for-all and the global economy.

title: Noir York
description: WALL STREET is surging. The crime rate is falling. Once seedy Times Square is on its way to becoming an urban Disneyland. It seems as if the sheen is returning to New York. Yet the city's reflection in the mirror of recent fiction is grim, anxious, full of dread.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  WEINTRAUB, SHEILA
description: WEINTRAUB-Sheila. Oct. 16, 1940Oct. 20, 1990. Cherished mother, you are always on my mind. Allison

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CAVE, VERNAL G., M.D.
description: CAVE-Vernal G., M.D. The Board and staff of the Bedford Stuyvesant Family Health Center, Inc., say again to you what you've heard many times before, and that is-you have been and shall remain our guiding light. What a joy it has been to have you with your great wisdom, love of people and unflinching quest for justice to point the way for us. Yes, the struggle goes on but the load is far lighter and we are much stronger because of you. May you know peace and our love always.

title: TUCSON, ARIZ.
description: Most places, summer is the fat part of the year, the idea that gets you through February with the promise of fly fishing, hammocks and gin rickeys.

title: Shut Out of Excellence
description: New Yorkers have heard a great deal from both Schools Chancellor Rudy Crew and State Education Commissioner Richard Mills about the need to strengthen course requirements -- and how teachers, principals and superintendents should be evaluated on their students' performance. A study released last week by an advocacy group called Acorn amplifies this point, showing a widespread failure to prepare students for the elite public high schools like Bronx Science and Stuyvesant, with black and Latino students paying the heaviest penalties.

title: Deal With 'Seinfeld' Co-Stars Clears Way for a New Season
description: After protracted negotiations that for a time left the future of television's most popular comedy series in doubt, NBC announced yesterday that it had reached agreement with the three co-stars of ''Seinfeld'' and that another year of episodes would be produced, and possibly two.

description: EVEN before Pandora's box blew open, Rick Moore had this feeling the Val Birches boardinghouse was a crime waiting to happen.

description: Remember when the managerial geniuses promised us the paperless office? They were right, but maybe not in the way we expected. Unfortunately, many of the papers that disappear are the valuable ones, and occasionally the vanishing act includes other precious goods, too.

Columbia BA '28, MA '29, DDS '32, Tau Delta Phi. Devoted father of Babette (Owen) Fortune of Clifton, NJ and Dr. Sally Faith Dorfman (Steven) Sirota of Cornwall & NYC. Beloved grandfather of Carrie Beth Kingsley (Rutgers '98, Phi Beta Kappa). Memorial service June 28, 2 P.M., Temple Beth Jacob, Newburgh, New York.

title: A World's Fair of Lilacs Is Blooming in Brooklyn
description: I spent a whole morning last week with my nose buried in lilacs at the Brooklyn Botanic Garden, wandering through a collection of about 150 shrubs, from the old Chinese lilacs, with their wonderfully gnarled limbs and delicate, airy flowers, to the latest hybrids, with big voluptuous flower heads, or panicles, a bit too showy for my taste.

title: Former Convent To Be AIDS Center
description: A former Roman Catholic convent on a hilly two-acre site in Yonkers overlooking the Hudson River is being transformed to provide housing and an adult day-care center for people living with HIV/AIDS. The nonprofit Greyston Foundation, which was founded by Roshi Glassman, a Zen Buddhist priest, acquired it for $2.7 million in December 1995.

title: Carol Palumbo Waits for Her Heart
description: Perhaps because I will soon be 66, I wondered when reading Charles Siebert's article ''Carol Palumbo Waits for Her Heart'' (April 13) whether the Columbia-Presbyterian ''exclusion criterion'' that a heart-transplant candidate be under 65 is held inviolate. Might not, say, a 67-year-old cardiac surgeon who is still capable of transplanting hearts and thus saving lives be a more appropriate recipient of a new heart than, say, a 46-year-old hairdresser?

description: LEDER-Evelyn (nee Wolffson). Born in October, 1894, in NYC, died May 4, 1997, in St. Paul, MN. Mother of William, grandmother of three, great-grandmother of two. Interment was private.

title: Alison Glaser And John Mahon
description: Alison Tracy Glaser, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Frank S. Glaser of Old Greenwich, Conn., was married there yesterday to John Carl Mahon, the son of Mr. and Mrs. John J. Mahon of Port Washington, N.Y. The Rev. Dr. Thomas Stiers performed the ceremony at the First Congregational Church. Msgr. Walter Schroeder took part in the service.

title: Leaf-Blower Noise Needs Addressing
description: The advent of spring and warmer weather is unfortunately accompanied in our community, as in many others, with the mind-numbing noise of the leaf blowers. These machines are invading our surroundings, preventing us from enjoying the simple pleasures of the outdoors and even from opening windows in our own homes. In addition, they significantly pollute the air in their area of operation and create a haze of unhealthy pollen, dirt, residue of chemical pesticides and fertilizers in the neighborhood which can remain airborn for hours. Further, debris from the leaf blowers are washed down storm drains and contaminate water around us.

title: TODAY'S SECTIONS
description: Special Today: The Sophisticated Traveler

title: New Law to Change Broker-Client Relationships
description: CONFUSION and controversy are swirling around a Connecticut law effective June 1 that alters the relationships among brokers, buyers and sellers of homes.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SITZER, MARCIA NEWMAN
description: SITZER-Marcia Newman, 63, of Aventura, Florida, on Friday, May 9, 1997. Devoted mother of Abbe Lewites (Mitchell), David (Beth), Steven (Pauline), and Marc (Valerie). Loving sister of Linda Wattenberg (Paul). Beloved niece of Sylvia Schwartz (Milton). Adored and cherished grandmother of Jordan, Amanda, Adam, Carly and Michael. She was a life member of Hadassah. Service Sunday 10:45 am at ''The Riverside'', 76 Street and Amsterdam Ave. Contributions in her memory to The American Cancer Society or Oxalosis Hyperoxaluria Foundation.

title: Arguing With a Ghost In Yosemite
description: PITY the National Park Service. Keep the parks pristine but accessible? That's an oxymoron of a mandate. Time was, I had a simple answer: Ban all the cars. Tear up the roads. If you're not willing to hike in, you shouldn't be here.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BEYDA, SHIRLEY ATTIE
description: BEYDA-Shirley Attie, 1909-1997. Beloved matriarch, mother, grandmother, great-grandmother, leader in community service and role model. Her passing is the end of an era. She leaves us a legacy of intelligence, integrity, dignity, compassion, tolerance, grace and courage. She continues to inspire us to seek knowledge, to help others, and to love life. ''She walks in beauty.''
