title: Taking a Bike
description: To the Editor: I have found air travel with a bicycle much easier than described in your article. Two years ago my wife and I rode through France and Spain. We took our bikes to Paris and returned with them from Madrid on Continental Airlines.

title: Leigh Culver, Eric Brodnax
description: Catherine Leigh Culver, the daughter of Dr. Anne C. Brower of Norfolk, Va., and Dr. James E. Culver of Cleveland, was married yesterday to Charles Eric Brodnax, a son of Mr. and Mrs. William F. Brodnax 3d of St. John, the United States Virgin Islands. The Rev. Craig Eder officiated at St. Columba's Episcopal Church in Washington.

title: Pass the Marshmallows! It's Time for Fun with Science
description: In Harding Township, children learned Bernoulli's principle by blowing on balloons. In Dover, they stacked stale marshmallows joined with toothpicks to explore shapes and forms and to build cities. (Stale marshmallows work better than fresh ones.) And in Mountain Lakes, about 300 children became detectives, identifying fingerprints with masking tape and talcum powder.

title: Waterfront Mansions, New England Look
description: RYE, the smallest city in Westchester County, is renowned for its picturesque neighborhoods of detached homes, imposing waterfront mansions and, of course, the Art Deco, county-owned Playland Amusement Park, which is listed on the National Register of Historic Places.

title: Opening a Door to a Distant, Tumultuous Era
description: HARRISON E. SALISBURY DID not report on the Russian Revolution in 1917. No doubt he would have, if given the chance, but he was only 8 at the time.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  ROSS, SANDY
description: ROSS-Sandy. Mother's Day, 1993. Brave, gentle soul. Forever in our hearts. David, Michele, Todd, Vivien and Peter

title: Unlikely Tales Told by the Homely Woven Basket
description: BASKETS TODAY ARE A largely rustic conceit: quaint receptacles for magazines or bathroom bouquets of dried statice and cornflowers. Not so long ago, however, a hand-woven basket was one of life's necessities, a tool, not a trifle.

title: Brilliant Talk, Visceral Ideas
description: ONCE the Broadway theater exulted in the sound of words. Ideas danced. A play by George Bernard Shaw was a glittering occasion. Even a section of a play by Shaw in which four actors appeared, ostensibly reading, behind music stands in evening clothes, was a smash. Does anyone still wear evening clothes?

title: Abby R. Gans, John D. Solomon
description: Abby Ruth Gans, the director of casting and talent development at Nickelodeon, the cable-television network in New York, and John David Solomon, a freelance journalist in New York, were married last evening in Brielle, N.J. Rabbi David Posner performed the ceremony at the Manasquan River Golf Club.

title: Mimi Spurr, J. R. Gallagher Jr.
description: Jessica Ann Spurr, a daughter of Anne and Arnold Spurr of Chappaqua, N.Y., was married yesterday to Joseph Robert Gallagher Jr., a son of Kathleen and Joseph Gallagher of Westwood, Mass. Msgr. Charles Kavanaugh performed the ceremony at St. Patrick's Church in Bedford, N.Y.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GROSS, MICHAEL
description: GROSS-Michael. Age 58. Of Westport, CT and Boca Raton, FL. Died April 22, 1997. He was a graduate of MIT and Columbia University. Survivors include his wife Esta, daughter Joli and many relatives and friends, all of whom miss him dearly. Contributions may be made to Ronald McDonald House.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DICHELLE, RUTH
description: DICHELLE-Ruth, 87, May 9, 1997. Beloved wife of the late Herman; devoted mother of Roslyn Talbot and Andrea Rosen; adored grandmother of James, Cary and Lesley and David.

title: Theresa Moser, James Loprest
description: Theresa Beth Moser, a law clerk, and Frank James Loprest Jr., a lawyer, were married yesterday at St. Andrew's Roman Catholic Church on Block Island, R.I. The Rev. Donal R. Kehew performed the ceremony.

title: None of Their Business
description: To the Editor:

title: Foam at Bar, but Not in Mugs
description: It is an incongruous sight: large blobs of multicolored foam dripping from the roof of a TriBeCa bar onto the sidewalk below, where little wooden sailboats bob on a blue-green urethane foam sea.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LIPPER, GEORGE
description: LIPPER-George. The officers, leadership, and staff of UJAFederation of New York mourn the passing of George Lipper. His son, Kenneth Lipper, is a devoted friend and supporter of UJA-Federation and an active leader in the Jewish philanthropic community. His wife, Evelyn, shares his devotion to Jewish communal leadership. We extend our deepest sympathies to Kenneth; his daughters-in-law, Evelyn and Binnette; his brother, Milton, his grandchildren, Allen, Joanna, Daniella, Tamara, and Julie; and the entire family. May you be consoled among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Larry A. Silverstein, Board Chair Louise B. Greilsheimer, President Stephen D. Solender, Exec. V.P.

title: Berkley, Scholarly and Revolutionary
description: I came to Berkeley in 1960, to join the department of English, and stayed for 18 years. When I was away, I remembered the town as a signature -- tendrils of fog in redwood and eucalyptus. Or I remembered standing at my window in a small redwood-shingled house high in the hills, watching the sun set over San Francisco's Golden Gate, the fog rolling toward us across the bay and enveloping the bridge. Visiting friends would remark upon the spectacular, postcard-famous view.

title: Barring Russia From NATO Would Be Mistake
description: To the Editor:

title: MOVIES THIS WEEK
description: The vintage Hollywood novelties topping this week's list of films on television include a famous screen debut, a sumptuous pirate adventure, a fine political comedy and a Hitchcock puzzle.

title: Joys of Cooking
description: HOW I GAVE MY HEART TO THE RESTAURANT BUSINESS

title: Good News For Japan. Bad News For Us?
description: Things are looking up in Japan. Big companies like Sony are reporting phenomenal profits, and the Japanese stock market is showing signs of life. The yen, after a long period of weakness, is rallying.

title: Crotty Becomes a Key In Heat's Game Plan
description: It took Pat Riley most of two games, but the Miami Heat coach believes he finally has found a way to break down the Knicks.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: TRACK AND FIELD

title: Calling All Callers
description: Your monthly phone bills are about to change, thanks to a sweeping overhaul of telephone rates announced last week by the Federal Communications Commission. In an effort to deregulate the industry, the commission is rejiggering billions of dollars of rates.

title: Abortion Coalition Observes Anniversary
description: THE Westchester Coalition for Legal Abortion is celebrating its 25th anniversary this month, and though abortion has been legal in the state since 1970, the controversy surrounding the issue is no less intense than it was a quarter of a century ago.

title: Liar, Liar
description: MY LIFE, STARRING

title: A Welcome 'Intrusion'
description: To the Editor:

title: Carolyn A. Hagn And Paul Adam
description: Carolyn Anne Hagn, the daughter of Jane and Joseph Hagn of Stony Brook, N.Y., was married yesterday to Paul Adam, a son of the late Norma and Walter Adam Jr., who lived in New York. The Rev. Peter Colapietro performed the ceremony at St. James Roman Catholic Church in Setauket, N.Y.

title: Andrea Emmerich, Patrick O'Meara
description: Andrea Elle Emmerich, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Ralf Emmerich of Franklin Square, N.Y., was married yesterday to Patrick Benedict O'Meara, a son of Elizabeth O'Meara of Arlington, Va., and Gerard J. O'Meara of Fredericksburg, Va. The Rev. Karen Albers, a United Methodist minister, performed the ceremony at Troutbeck, a historic house in Amenia, N.Y.

title: Traversing the Regulatory Maze
description: THEY weren't the world's worst delays -- 30 to 60 days, maybe. And not all of the 23 two-family homes with the undulating facades along Chester Street in Brownsville, Brooklyn, were mired in what one builder brands ''bureaucratic limbo.'' Only about half.

title: History Under Dust
description: To the Editor:

title: Adolescence Rules!
description: When did we become a nation of 12-year-olds? People used to joke that show business was high school with money; these days, it seems that all of America has entered seventh grade.

title: Near the Cow Barn, Bluegrass Twangs
description: ROBBIE STEELE, THE OWNER OF A small dairy farm here in the Berkshires, and Mark Pitsch, his head milker, are cooking up a plan. They need a way to publicize their annual three-day bluegrass festival, which begins July 25. Some promoters would take out ads in newspapers or magazines or buy radio commercials. But not these two. Instead, they are making a deal with a nearby shopping mall.

title: Bookshelf
description: NORTH COUNTRY SPRING. By Reeve Lindbergh. Illustrated by Liz Sivertson. Houghton Mifflin. $15.95. (Ages 4 to 8) The paintings that accompany this catchy verse about the buzz, excitement and vigor of spring in the Far North are luminous and impressionistic. There are notes on the animals mentioned, which range in size from mice to moose.

title: Books in Brief: Fiction
description: McNally's Gamble

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TERZUOLI, MARYANN M. (AKA MARYANN MILLBANK)
description: TERZUOLI-Maryann M. (aka Maryann Millbank). Attorney and proprietor of Wordperfect Professionals. Beloved daughter of Andrew J. and Frances R. Loving sister of Andrew J., Jr., Richard J. and Robert J. Dear sister-in-law of Janice L. Cherished aunt of Christine. Funeral Wednesday, 9:15 AM, from the Marine Park Funeral Home, 3024 Quentin Road, Brooklyn. Mass Resurrection Church, 10:15 AM. Interment Resurrection Cemetery, Staten Island.

title: What Rye Residents Think of Home Depot
description: We were dismayed at the position taken by Mayor Christine Korff in regard to the issue of Home Depot $(''A Proposal for a Home Deport in Port Chester Draws Fire in Rye,'' March 23$). Her ''class wars'' comments were divisive, simplistic and clearly demonstrate her blatant disregard for the residents of her own city as well as those of neighboring towns. Mayor Korff shortchanges the residents of Port Chester by misrepresenting the facts. She states that Port Chester ''welcomes the traffic'' Home Depot will bring -- but in reality, if situated where proposed, a significant portion of the truck and car traffic will flow through Rye, not Port Chester.

title: His Master's Voice Echoes In a Shell of a Manufacturing Past
description: There's not much left of Camden's old industrial waterfront. The buildings that once housed corporate giants like Campbell's Soup and Esterbrook Pen have mostly been replaced by new office complexes, parking lots or empty spaces. But the Nipper Building, once home to the Radio Corporation of America and its predecessor, the Victor Talking Machine Company, is still standing, though barely.

title: Family Welcomes Back Fresh Air Fund Guest
description: AS a child, Beatrice Stein spent summers in country houses in various parts of France, surrounded by members of her immediate and extended family. Besides her parents, there was usually a collection of cousins, some of whom might not have been able to summer elsewhere.

title: Police Arrest 2 Suspects In Ambush of Guards
description: Two armed men suspected in the ambush and shooting of two security guards were seized on the streets of Queens yesterday afternoon, after they emerged separately from a house that had been placed under surveillance by the police. Weapons and an unspecified amount of cash were seized with the suspects.

title: Holiday Gift
description: THE eight women who live with their children in the Salvation Army's Emergency Family Shelter in Atlantic City sat around a long table in the shelter's dining room after lunch last Monday and fretted about what to make for dinner on Mother's Day.

title: New & Noteworthy Paperbacks
description: HELEN AND TEACHER: The Story of Helen Keller

title: Home of the Brave
description: Expert political comedies from Hollywood are rare, but THE FARMER'S DAUGHTER (1947) exudes class, imagination and amusing wisdom. A splendid cast knew exactly what to do under H. C. Potter's direction. Loretta Young won an Oscar as a naive but down-to-earth servant in a Midwest mansion who runs for Congress. Close behind were a charming Joseph Cotten, Ethel Barrymore as a political matriarch and a ruggedly informal Charles Bickford. The tone is light, the dialogue smart and the plot has an almost crackling pace. It's diverting entertainment -- THUR. at 6:15 P.M. and FRI. at 6 A.M. on AMC. Howard Thompson

title: Rent Fight Spreads to Homeowner Country
description: Glendale, with its quiet streets of single-family homes, is not the sort of place where one would expect to find tenant organizing. Traditionally, tenant advocates have ignored this small bedroom community near the Brooklyn border, where homeowners far outnumber renters.

title: As U.S. Economy Races Along, Upstate New York Is Sputtering
description: Sunshine, a scarce commodity through the long upstate winter, has returned, bearing hope. Nature bursts with promise.

title: Books in Brief: Nonftion
description: ON TOLERATION

title: No Headline
description: ''If you're a United States Senator, unless you're under indictment or in detox, you're considered a candidate for President when you come into this state.''

title: Great Songs Don't Quite Add Up to Musicals
description: NOW playing in New Jersey: two shows in celebration of theater songs, embracing the world of penthouses and the world of the underground, of the poor little rich girl and of the gutter lily, of Mrs. Wentworth-Brewster and of Pirate Jenny.

title: AD MAD
description: Given that the host of this week's Clio Awards is Thomas Haden Church (a.k.a. Ned, the ultimate sleazy ad guy, on the Fox sitcom ''Ned and Stacey''), advertising's answer to the Oscars may have it covered in the self-mockery department. Just to be sure, on Tuesday a posse of media critics will convene in New York -- for the first Counter-Clios, an acid comment on advertising's alleged evils. Winners will get negative ''awards'' in various categories (like ''Excellence in Blaxploitation''), but somehow one senses that the ad world will press on. ''Most advertising is not very good,'' acknowledges Bill Westbrook, whose Minneapolis firm was just named Agency of the Year by Adweek. ''But then, neither is most journalism.''

title: No Ordinary Idiot
description: KWAKU Or, The Man Who Could Not Keep His Mouth Shut. By Roy Heath. 254 pp. New York: Marion Boyars. Paper, $14.95.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DUFFY, PETER A.
description: DUFFY-Peter A. May 8, 1997. Beloved husband of Jean M. Brother of Maureen O'Donnell. Father of John, Eileen and Elizabeth. Grandfather of Caitlin, Natalie and Tara. Friends may visit at Follett & Werner, Westhampton Beach, May 11, 2-4 and 7-9 PM. Funeral Mass May 12, 11 AM, at Immaculate Conception, Quiogue. Requiescat in pace.

title: Cannes by Internet
description: WHAT The Cannes International Film Festival's 50th anniversary T-shirt, $46 from the festival's Internet boutique (www.festival-cannes.fr).

title: The Various Uses for Wood Planes
description: PLANES are important hand tools. They are used to smooth surfaces, square up the ends of boards and shave the edges of doors or windows to make them fit their frames. Planes have been around since antiquity, although it's doubtful that ancient Egyptian carpenters used them.

title: Elizabeth Briggs, David McKown
description: Elizabeth Cottrell Briggs and David Rodney McKown were married yesterday at St. James' Episcopal Church in New York. The Rev. Brenda G. Husson performed the ceremony.

title: A Resplendent Palace for 'King David'
description: THERE WON'T BE A Ziegfeld girl in sight next Sunday night onstage at the Walt Disney Company's newly restored New Amsterdam Theater on West 42d Street. Trading pulchritude for pageantry of a purely biblical nature, Disney will re-open Ziegfeld's long-neglected former Follies home with ''King David,'' a new musical by Alan Menken, the composer of a number of secular Disney musical successes.

title: Glory to the 6-String Guitar and Its Fans
description: IT has helped create dozens of new millionaires, turned some of its players into icons and sounded the anthem of American youth for the last three decades. It is the guitar. And this weekend, Long Island will become the six-string capital of the world.

title: Bonnie Club Gave Lessons In Interracial Teamwork
description: To the Editor:

title: City Youngsters Find Backyards Are Fun
description: A FEW years ago, Meg Krasko read an article about the Fresh Air Fund in her local newspaper. The idea of taking a city child into her home for two weeks during the summer appealed to her, but the demands of a two-career household and two small children overcame her enthusiasm. She put the article aside.

title: Man and Tonyman
description: ''Americans used to look to church for spiritual nourishment,'' says Peter Lowe, who produces a 26-city road show called Success 1997. ''Now they come to seminars with a great hunger.'' Lowe serves up Colin Powell, George and Barbara Bush, Dan O'Brien and many others, but it's not these people who turn his arena-filling, full-day shows into secular tent revivals. Rather, it's the motivator's motivator, the sultan of Uber-ness: Tony Robbins, a 6-foot-7-inch, mesomorphic wild man who is fond of expressions like ''Quadruple the intensity!'' Recently Robbins did his thing at the Rose Garden arena in Portland, Ore., before a crowd of 19,500 souls. Here's a report.

title: Hemophiliacs Organizing to Sue Over Blood-Clotting Product
description: For years after discovering he had AIDS, Mathew Kleiner refused to blame anyone for his illness, even the makers of the product that almost certainly infected him: a blood-clotting agent known as factor. Particularly not the makers of factor.

title: De Klerk Abruptly Disbands Panel Formed to Refocus His Party
description: In a sign of the turmoil that has gripped South Africa's largest white political party, its leader, former President F. W. de Klerk, has abruptly disbanded a special task force set up only months ago to chart new directions for the party.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BLINKEN, ETHEL H.
description: BLINKEN-Ethel H., died in Palm Beach, Florida, after a long illness on May 7. She was born in New York City in 1903. In 1924, she married Maurice H. Blinken who died in 1986. She is survived by her sons, Ambassador Donald Blinken of Budapest, Robert Blinken of Bedford Hills and Ambassador Alan Blinken of Brussels and nine grandchildren and six great-grandchildren. Interment will be private.

title: Musings on Collage: The Photomontages of Romare Bearden
description: COLLAGE is the most important innovation in art of the 20th century, and this can be said with confidence because there is nothing parochial about the medium. It has attracted international artists and has been adapted to all styles of two-dimensional work. Some artists, of course, have used it only occasionally, but one master of collage who relied on it was Romare Bearden (1912-1988).

title: Monaco
description: On Jan. 8, 1297, a political refugee from Genoa named Francesco Grimaldi and a few trusted associates in monks' clothing climbed a huge rock that projects into the Mediterranean near Nice and persuaded the defenders of the local castle to shelter them overnight. Once inside, they tore off their hoods, seized the castle and a piece of the coastline beyond, and made it their own -- the Principality of Monaco, which has remained in Grimaldi hands ever since.

title: Face in the Crowd From Ireland, Via Outer Space
description: IN THE MID-1980'S, THE IRISH character actor Colm Meaney bought a shiny gray Hugo Boss suit that he couldn't afford. ''Casting directors can smell fear and desperation,'' said Mr. Meaney, who strolled into every audition wearing the flashy garment and exuding confidence. ''My suit put me in the position of saying, 'We're not starving here.' ''

title: Some Private Views Open to the Public
description: Views of the city from heights normally off limits to the public are among the attractions of a self-guided tour with 10 stops, including skyscrapers, plazas and interiors, built in the Wall Street area from 1960 on. The open house is being sponsored by the Alliance for Downtown New York next Sunday from noon to 5 P.M.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  YOUNG, FRANK T.
description: YOUNG-Frank T. On May 8 at Royal Palm Beach, FL. Loving husband of Joan Soo Young, dear father of Frank C.H., Joanna Young Weirs, Philip, and Lincoln C. Services Wednesday, 8 PM at Howard L. Hallett, Inc. (Gleason Building), 149-20 Northern Blvd., Flushing, NY. Visiting Wednesday 2-5 and 7-10 PM. Funeral Thursday 10 AM. Interment Flushing Cemetery. In lieu of flowers donations to The Evangelical Covenant Church of Royal Palm Beach, 660 Royal Palm Beach Blvd, Royal Palm Beach, FL 33411 or to the Alzheimer's Assoc. of Greater Palm Beach, 6401 Congress Ave., Ste. 265, Boca Raton, FL 33487.

title: Cars Stolen in Chicago and Jersey Link Slayings in 3 States
description: A cemetery caretaker who was found shot to death in Pennsville, N.J., on Friday is believed to be the latest victim of a fugitive who is wanted in connection with three recent homicides in Illinois and Minnesota, the authorities said yesterday.

title: PAPERBACK BEST SELLERS: May 11, 1997
description: Weeks

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BIBER, DONALD R.
description: BIBER-Donald R. Age 69, of Fort Lee, New Jersey, formerly of Fair Lawn, NJ. Survived by his beloved wife Sandra Schneeweiss Biber; cherished father of Hugh, and Amy Barr; sister, Lois Shapiro; and six adored grandchildren. Predeceased by his wife Rita Spiegel Biber in 1978. A mourning period will be observed through Wednesday evening at the Biber residence in Fort Lee, NJ. Donations in his name gratefully accepted to the American Cancer Society or to the charity of your choice. Services are Sunday, 10:30AM at Robert Schoem's Menorah Chapel, 150 Rt. 4 East, Paramus, New Jersey.

title: MacLean Avoids Suspension; Rangers Are Furious
description: When the Rangers take the ice on Sunday afternoon in Game 5 of their playoff series with the New Jersey Devils, they will be without Niklas Sundstrom, the valuable second-year forward who underwent surgery today for a broken left forearm. But John MacLean, the equally valuable 12-year veteran who broke Sundstrom's arm with a two-handed stick slash at the end of Game 4, will be skating for the Devils.

title: If He Can Conjure Magical Ratings, That's Some Trick
description: HIS FRIENDS THINK HE'S magic. And fortunately for David Blaine, he has friends in some very high places.

title: Loving and Hating a Loop
description: Here's a case where the engineering sounds complicated but the controversy seems simple. That is, until you hear every side of the story.

title: Fears of Asthma Fuel Protests Over a Waste Incinerator
description: Martin Brandon Ortega, who is 4, breathed through a clear plastic asthma mask as he walked with his grandmother, Aida Ayala, through their neighborhood Monday evening.

title: Er, Thanks, Mom
description: I WAS staring at the third draft of a letter to Aaron, who hadn't called in two weeks, when the doorman buzzed to say a package had arrived. I imagined roses with a note that said: ''I changed my mind. Let's get married. Love, Aaron.'' Instead I found a box from my mother in Michigan.

title: Prep Schools for Prison
description: To the Editor:

title: Relax. The Geraniums Will Do Just Fine.
description: POTS of geraniums are lining the benches of garden centers and discount markets, ready to move off to patio tubs, window boxes, hanging baskets and flower borders -- anywhere they provide a great splash of summer color.

title: A Summer of Peruvian Art in San Francisco
description: Five exhibitions of historical and contemporary Peruvian art will be on display in San Francisco over the next several months. The first, ''The Spirit of Ancient Peru: Treasures from the Museo Arqueologico Rafael Larco Herrera,'' runs May 17 to Aug. 10 at the M. H. deYoung Memorial Museum.

title: Maureen Martin, William Valus 3d
description: Maureen June Martin, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert A. Martin of Fairfield, Conn., was married yesterday to William Stephen Valus 3d, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Valus Jr., also of Fairfield. The Rev. Paul D. Whitmore performed the ceremony at the Southport (Conn.) Congregational Church.

title: T. Rowe Price: Why Has This Stock Climbed So Fast?
description: IT'S not just T. Rowe Price's mutual funds that are stirring investor interest these days.

title: A New Cigar Club Comes With Airs
description: IT was sometimes difficult to see the stars under the clouds of cigar smoke. But among the 300 guests at a recent party to inaugurate the Grand Havana Room, a private cigar club that is to open tomorrow, were Tom Selleck sharing a smoke with Gregory Hines, Laurence Fishburne puffing away with Stephen Baldwin and Carol Alt lighting an Arturo Fuente for Jennifer Tilly.

title: 'Death and the Maiden': Singling Out Ideas
description: AFTER dispensing extra helpings of trifles by Neil Simon and A. R. Gurney Jr., Lee Pope, producer of the Schoolhouse here, is really cooking.

title: Crime
description: Ed McBain taught the American police procedural its best song-and-dance steps. But just in case anybody thought the 47 earlier novels in his 87th Precinct series were a fluke, he's gone and revitalized the routine with NOCTURNE (Warner, $24).

title: New Jersey Doctors Offer Least Access to Medicare
description: New Jersey physicians and other health-care providers have the lowest Medicare participation rate in the nation, the United States Department of Health and Human Services reported last week.

title: Devils Catch a Break: Obvious 'Makeup' Call
description: For the first four games of their Stanley Cup series with the Rangers, the Devils complained constantly about bias and breaks. The league favored the Rangers, the Devils said, particularly their veteran stars, especially Captain Mark Messier.

title: A Caution to All Who Undercut Tax System
description: To the Editor:

title: Blacks Join Conservative In a Meeting On Religion
description: With his eyes shut and his hands linked with those of black religious leaders, Ralph Reed nodded and swayed and shouted ''Amen!'' with a roomful of 400 church-going black people today at a conference here on racial harmony.

title: Children's Books
description: IN ROSA'S MEXICO

title: The People v. Sol Wachtler
description: To the Editor:

title: Clinton In Caribbean: No Bananas Today
description: President Clinton met today on this island nation with the leaders of 15 Caribbean countries, promising freer trade and receiving assurances of more help in fighting illegal drugs.

title: Smooth Start Turns Rocky for F.B.I. Director
description: Three and a half years ago, when Louis J. Freeh took charge at the Federal Bureau of Investigation, he brought what veteran agents praised as a decisive and aggressive style to a damaged law-enforcement agency that had been struggling since the 1972 death of J. Edgar Hoover to recover a sense of purpose, primacy and prestige.

title: Amtrak Gets Late Start On Summer Schedule
description: Amtrak's summer timetables go into effect today, a month later than usual. The railroad continued its fall-winter schedule after the change to daylight time in April, the usual switchover date. R. Clifford Black 4th, the railroad's chief spokesman, said the anomaly arose from actions by Congress extending the operation of certain trains for six months, a period that ended yesterday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FAIRBACK, WILLIAM DICKSON
description: FAIRBACK-William Dickson, 61, in Southampton, New York, on May 2, 1997. Of Tustin, California, Rumson, New Jersey, Nantucket, MA and NYC. Graduate of Knickerbocker Greys, Canterbury School, Nichols College. Survived by loving son Dwight and his wife Krisen of NYC; daughter Dianne Wright of Flanders, New York; grandchildren Sara, Dylan and Bentley and wife Deirdre K. Fairback of New London, CT and Tustin, California. Christian Service Saturday. Interment Nantucket Is.

title: Fans Seek a Shop's Survival
description: Within a year after Marvin and Rhoda Mayer bought the Essex Card Shop on Avenue A and Third Street in late 1974, the area plunged into an era of drug dealing, crime and burning buildings that would last two decades. Many old-time business owners packed up and left, but some who remained, along with priests from the Most Holy Redeemer Church nearby, pleaded with the Mayers not to abandon them.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KLEIN, MARTIN D.
description: KLEIN-Martin D. Devoted brother of William J. and Joan L., on May 8, after a long battle with emphysema. Born in NYC, he was a resident of Cleveland area for many years. 10 years after working with General Electric Company he co-founded the interior design firm of Barnaby-Klein which the partners dissolved after 25 successful years. Interment private. Contributions in his memory may be sent to Visiting Nurse Association Hospice of Cleveland, 2500 East 22nd St, Cleveland, OH 44115

title: It's My Party and I'll Spend if I Want To, Spend if I Want To . . .
description: BABY boomers are breaking into their 50's at the rate of one every seven seconds, but few are likely to celebrate with as much elan as Josie Natori, the diminutive sleepwear designer. On Tuesday, May 20, at 7 P.M., Ms. Natori will raise her hands above the ebony and ivory at Carnegie Hall in Manhattan, where Churchill once thundered, Tchaikovsky once wept and Frank Sinatra once crooned, and plunk out Schumann's Piano Concerto in A Minor for 2,800 of her closest friends.

title: Managed-Care Limits
description: To the Editor:

title: Up in Smoke
description: It was the tobacco trial that was supposed to upend the cigarette universe. But after a six-member jury in Jacksonville, Fla., delivered its verdict last week, the world looked remarkably the same.

title: Democracy in Russia: Women's Lib Is Just Cosmetic
description: GLIMPSED on a street corner or subway, even the prettiest Russian girl looks severe, sullen or remote.

title: Quill vs. Computer
description: THE invitation section at Kate's Paperie in SoHo was packed with brides to be, flipping relentlessly through giant portfolios of wedding invitations. Mothers paced, friends hemmed and hawed and sisters calculated. When the portfolio of hand-done invitations surfaced, the crowd fell silent, and women circled around as a wedding consultant explained the high cost and the presentation of a hand-lettered invitation.

title: A Lot to See (But Not an Artwork in Sight)
description: IT'S SAD WHEN ARTISTS AND curators don't like museums or art, and seem to find them lacking in true social value. That was my first thought when walking through ''Uncommon Sense,'' an earnest, community-oriented display of ''projects'' at the Geffen Contemporary, the huge industrial shed that is the annex of the Museum of Contemporary Art in Los Angeles.

title: Seeing the Light
description: There's a home movie shot 30 years ago of my grandmother, my mother, my sisters and me at a cottage on Lake Ontario. My sisters and I are in bikinis; Mom has on a one-piece suit, and Gran is wearing a dress, stockings, broad-brimmed hat, a towel across her shoulders to protect her arms from the sun, and she's sitting in the shade. Today, of course, with all that we know about how sun exposure causes skin cancer and premature aging of the skin, Gran seems prescient. But, in fact, she simply hated the way tanned skin looked. A century ago when she was growing up on the farm, having a pale complexion said you did not work in the fields. It spoke class. To the rest of us, reared in a post-agricultural economy, having a tan said you had money and time enough to indulge in sunbathing. It spoke leisure class.

title: Books in Brief: Fiction
description: FALL ON YOUR KNEES

title: At Forum, Democratic Candidates Say Giuliani's School Plan Is Too Little, Too Late
description: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's handling of education was denounced yesterday by four Democrats seeking to unseat him, as they asserted that the burst of school financing proposed in his new budget was an election-year sop that belied his indifference to public schools.

title: Border Vigilantes
description: The California-Mexico border has never been a safe place. Illegal immigrants to the United States face the perennial gantlet of harsh desert, Border Patrol and unreliable ''coyotes,'' whom they pay for help in crossing. Those whose homes are near the line on the U.S. side must deal with constant incursions by strangers who may simply be looking for work -- but who may intend to rob, burglarize or something worse.

title: The Way We Were, and Were, and Were
description: RETRO. It won't go away. Screen out cell-phone chatter, David Helfgott's incessant tinkling on the ivories and ''Ellen'' mania, and the world looks like one giant flashback.

title: J. Jacques Stone, 89, Commercial Lawyer
description: J. Jacques Stone, a Manhattan lawyer and a leader in Jewish educational, religious and philanthropic causes, died on Tuesday at his home on Manhattan's East Side. He was 89 and also lived in Westport, Conn.

title: Clintonian Contempts
description: Consider a quartet of contemptuous acts.

title: There's No Place Like Work
description: The traditional boundaries between work and home are evaporating. With computers and modems, people can work almost anywhere and anytime, as long as they have a place to plug in. If you always have your laptop with you, when do you get ''home'' from work? Having interviewed more than 1,000 young people in the workplace today, I can tell you that this is what most mean when they talk about ''home becoming work.''

title: Giuliani's Plan To Ease Way To Citizenship Is Questioned
description: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's $12 million plan to help turn immigrants into citizens might well be good for the immigrants and for New York City. It would probably be good for the Mayor himself.

title: 3 Officers Are Suspended After Smoking at Stadium
description: Three New York City police officers were suspended yesterday after they were caught smoking cigarettes during a baseball game at Yankee Stadium on Friday night, the police said.

title: At Mobutu Villa, Only the Peacocks Are Calm
description: With rebel troops closing in on this small Ubangi River town, the site of President Mobutu Sese Seko's palatial residence, inhabitants are desperate to get out.

title: Correction
description: A picture caption last Sunday about the Kitchen, the avant-garde performance space, misidentifed the woman shown. She was Caroline Stone, a board member of the Kitchen, not Lauren Amazeen, its former executive director.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GROSS, IRWIN
description: GROSS-Irwin. Suddenly on April 30, 1997. Beloved husband of Lynn, cherished father of Robin and Richard, loving grandfather of Max and Wyatt, loving brother of Tena Rubin. Dr. Irwin Gross was a giant in the fields of creative art and art education. He was principal of the High School of Art and Design, recognized as one of the outstanding art high schools in the United States. Prior to that he had been selected as the New York City Board of Education's Director of Art. This followed a three year period during which he served as the Director of the federally funded Project Outreach headquartered at the Detroit Institute of Arts. Among his many contributions to art education were numerous writings of curriculums, keynote addresses to numerous art education associations and the presidency of the Queensboro Association for the Visual Arts. Dr. Gross' paintings are displayed in assorted corporate and private collections in the United States and Canada, including the Riverside Museum in New York City and the Detroit Institute of Arts. He is listed in Who's Who in American Art and was a Fellow of the National Endowment for Humanities. Dr. Gross had a zest for living. His constant curiosity and insatiable thirst for new projects made life a series of great adventures for him. One could not escape the magnetism of his personality and his enthusiasm for what he was doing was contagious. Since he enjoyed sharing his joys and interests with us, our lives were immeasurably enriched. The feelings of great loss by family, friends, & colleagues are beyond measure. His passing signals the end of an era. He was truly loved and will be dearly missed.

title: There's No Place Like Work
description: Hochschild's article is another thinly veiled condemnation of working mothers. I am absent from my home 55 hours a week (including 300 miles commuting) because my job -- like most in today's competitive marketplace -- requires more than a 9-to-5 commitment in order to attain the kind of job security and success that it takes to provide for a family. To suggest that many parents work long hours for money they don't need so that they can avoid being with their families is ridiculous. Would I spend more time at home with my husband and children if I could afford it? Are you kidding?

title: In a Once-Booming Downtown, Merchants Wonder Where the Customers Went
description: Mike Jordanopoulos remembers when the center of this affluent town was filled with the buzz of shoppers who jammed his pizza counter from noon until early evening. ''When I opened here 23 years ago, it was alive and really kicking. People filled the streets and sidewalks all the time,'' Mr. Jordanopoulos said.

title: Gretzky Leads Rangers' Surprising Run
description: Despite adding Wayne Gretzky, the most celebrated player of his era, the Rangers generated lukewarm interest in New York during the regular season. Gretzky scored a respectable 97 points, tied for fourth in the National Hockey League. But it was the lowest total of his 18-year career for a full season, and he went 21 consecutive games without a goal, his longest slump ever.

title: Songs To Ease A Child's Illness
description: WHAT do you get when you match a classical pianist with a roomful of suburban school children and an enthusiastic crew of long-haired musicians prone to play something called acid jazz? Music, of course.

title: There's No Place Like Work
description: Many thanks to Hochschild for saying publicly what many of us have admitted privately for years: that work outside the home pays more, has more status and is far easier than raising children. The question remains: Does that mean it's better?

title: Exploring the Gardens of Generations of Rockefellers
description: GRACEFUL, subtle and here and there even playful, the new Sculpture and Garden Tour of Kykuit reveals much about the times and tastes of the Rockefeller family.

title: Fresh Produce Takes a Bow for an Italian Spring Dinner
description: THE inspiration for spring menus comes from the produce stand. Artichokes are starting to appear in abundance. Some tropical fruits like mangos are widely available. And fresh California strawberries are at their peak. In a simple Italian spring dinner, some of this produce stars in each course.

The lucky castaways find Keri, who takes them into her noisy Great Meadows home, already packed to the rafters with adults, kids and pets.

description: BILOXI, Miss., May 10 (AP) - Billy Joe Clegg, a minister who ran for President seven times, died of a heart attack on Monday. He was 69.

The Mother's Day cards that her younger son, Roy, sent in 1994 and 1995 are propped against the back of the chair, flanking the music box that plays ''The Star Spangled Banner.'' As she wound the key, the little American flag moved up the little silver pole.

description: His Foreign Minister has reportedly cleared out his office in preparation for a quick exit. His Prime Minister is said to have pocketed the last month's oil import royalties, the Government's last source of revenue. And one of President Mobutu Sese Seko's closest advisers is holed up in Paris, providing counsel only by telephone.

title: CHICAGO
description: Your figure you're safe by Memorial Day. The sky gods owe you this. You came out of the other side of a Chicago winter, survived the snow and the so-called wind chill and endured the faux sympathy of coastal voyeurs, the easterners whose weather is only 10 degrees warmer, for heaven's sake, not to mention the Californians. Now that it can safely said to be summer, there is really only one place to go. The lake. Or, more specifically, the beach. Maybe no other city worships its waterway like Chicago bows down before Lake Michigan. Practically every major institution is planted on its shores -- Northwestern University to the north, the Museum of Science and Industry to the south, the grand museums and parks in between.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LOVEJOY, ALLEN F.
description: LOVEJOY-Allen F. The Council and membership of The American Numismatic Society, New York, mourn the loss of their esteemed Councillor and Patron, Allen F. Lovejoy, who died May 8, 1997. A member of the ANS governing board since 1988, he served as First Vice-President and member of the Executive Committee. Dedicated to the financial well being of the Society, he headed the ANS Development Committee. To his wife, Betty, his children and his grandchildren, the Society extends its deepest sympathy.

description: DRATT-Rose. Since that May, our heart aches for you each day. Your boundless love and wisdom is still felt with each heartbeat. No dancing, but the tears are in my eyes because the one in my arms isn't you, my cherished and adored mother. Your one and only

title: 12 Topics, Thousands of Titles
description: THE success of the super-bookstores like Borders and Barnes & Noble has led many to regard independent bookstores as a dying breed. But some quirky independents are quietly persisting. These stores have carved out narrow specialties, devoting themselves to a particular topic and carrying thousands of titles. They stock reprinted and out-of-print books, as well as imports, which they may leave on the shelves for years.

title: How Dark? How Stormy? I Can't Recall
description: I can't remember the spread on my parents' bed. If it was quilted satin, I can't remember running my small hand over its smooth surface when I was 6 or 7 years old. If it was chenille, I can't recall feeling the bobbles beneath my palm as I sat and watched in the mirror as my mother braided my long hair.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PORTER, KEITH
description: PORTER-Keith. The Rockefeller University mourns the passing of Keith Porter, who began his career at the university's predecessor, The Rockefeller Institute for Medical Research. He left a 50year legacy of significant accomplishments as a pioneer of a new science, modern cell biology. His innovative methodology for the use of the electron microscope, design of the Porter-Blum microtome, and techniques for tissue culturing opened the field of cell biology by allowing much greater insight into the structure and function of cells. While at Rockefeller, Porter co-created the first electron micrograph of an intact cell, along with colleagues Albert Claude and Ernest Fullam. Also, with the aid of the electron microscope, Porter discovered the cell's endoplasmic reticulum, elucidated the structure of collagen fibers, cilia and microtubules, and defined the microtrabecular lattice. In addition, Mr. Porter was a founder and the organizer of the Tissue Culture Association (1946), the Journal of Cell Biology (1955), the premier journal in his field, and the American Society of Cell Biology (1961). Porter was a founding father of modern cell biology, along with two Rockefeller colleagues, Albert Claude and George Palade, who were honored with Nobel Prizes, an award that inexplicably eluded Porter. Torsten Wiesel, M.D., President Faculty of The Rockefeller Univ

description: STALLED in a roadside rest area of the information highway as friends and neighbors whiz by? A volunteer group wants to flag you into the fast lane.

title: Gallipoli and Troy
description: To the Editor: Catharine Reynolds's article ''Gallipoli: Landscape of Sacrifice'' (April 13) vividly described this failed battle. We had similar emotions at the site a few years ago. You should also be aware that it can easily be combined with an exploration of the nearby ruins of ancient Troy, Heinrich Schliemann's historic 19th-century discovery. Troy, only 30 miles from Gallipoli, is easily reached by crossing the Dardanelles, by ferry from Eceabat to Canakkale, then taking a short ride to the ruins. On the ferry, one sees on each shore the heart-shaped Ottoman forts that for centuries protected this renowned waterway.

title: With Eye on 2000, Campaigns Begin
description: It is too warm for ski season in the mountains north of here, and, to the south, it is too chilly to swim in Lake Winnipesaukee. But the political season is well under way, with White House aspirants for 2000 practically tripping over one another.

title: Blaming It All on 'Them'
description: IN a new Australian film, ''The Castle,'' a little guy stands up to big business and big government as they try to force him from his jerry-built house to make room for an airport expansion. He reacts with disbelief, then anger, then depression, but finally he achieves victory and saves his home.

title: Abstinence Pays
description: With a little-noticed provision in last summer's welfare-reform law, Congress jumped squarely into one of the most charged issues in education -- what to teach children about sex.

title: Now in a More Nuanced Role, Jason Alexander as Anti-George
description: IT WOULD BE EASIER, OF COURSE, if he were a lesbian. At the precise historic moment when lesbians have become the very definition of outre hip in Hollywood, Jason Alexander has chosen to out himself as a serious actor in the film ''Love! Valour! Compassion!'' Replacing the formidable Nathan Lane, who appeared on Broadway as the screaming musical comedy queen Buzz, Mr. Alexander is, however, one of America's most emphatically self-declared non-lesbian, not-even-gay-if-you-must-know actors. (He is also non-tall, non-thin and has a nonexistent hairline, violating some of Hollywood's truly sacred taboos.)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FROMAN, ELEANOR

Beloved mother of Ann Froman, sculptor, and Jane and Dr. Jerry Godfry, grandmother of Pam, Jamey, Jen and Jill. Graveside service New Montefiore Cemetery, LI, 1 PM, Monday.

title: New Haven's the Lure For Quinnipiac AM
description: LIKE most college radio stations, WQAQ-FM can barely be heard beyond the campus boundary, in this case the Quinnipiac College campus in Hamden. For some time now, the Federal Communications Commission has been trying to get such low wattage stations to upgrade to at least 100 watts. But Lou Adler, the director of the Ed McMahon Mass Communications Center at Quinnipiac, had a better idea: Why not buy an AM station and, as he put it, make it into a ''real life lab.''

title: 14-Screen Multiplex Is Bringing Jobs, Along With Protests
description: A crowd of 30 protesters had gathered outside the fenced-in construction site at Linden Boulevard and Elderts Lane in East New York. It was 11 A.M. Friday, and when City Councilwoman Priscilla A. Wooten arrived to attend the ground-breaking ceremony for a new 14-screen theater, the protesters let her have it.

title: CLINTON REINING IN ROLE FOR BUSINESS IN WELFARE EFFORT
description: The Clinton Administration has blocked a plan that would give businesses a significant new role in administering social-service programs in Texas, aligning the White House with unions and against companies' seeking profits from the privatization of such programs nationwide.

description: THE bikers hit the bend in the road, slowed their engines and filed past a Roman Catholic priest who was sprinkling what appeared to be consecrated water from a pail.

title: Frederick Ballon, Bankruptcy Lawyer, 88
description: Frederick E. M. Ballon, a practitioner of bankruptcy and insolvency law and a founder of the Manhattan law firm of Ballon Stoll Bader & Nadler, died on April 25 at a hospital in Palm Beach, Fla., where he had a winter house. He was 88 and lived on the Upper East Side of Manhattan.

title: What Could Top It?
description: To the Editor:

title: Like Its Teams, the Garden Is Under Pressure to Succeed
description: As the Knicks and the Rangers advance through their second-round playoff series dreaming of championships, Madison Square Garden is again a nexus for the kind of sold-out, nationally televised excitement that the arena was built for, then rebuilt for. But the teams' surprising post-season runs underscore the many burdens on management, which go beyond re-signing Patrick Ewing and Mark Messier to long-term contracts or buying new video screens for the scoreboard.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  VAN LIMBURG STIRUM, COUNT WIGBOLD A.W.
description: VAN LIMBURG STIRUM-Count Wigbold A.W. At his home, May 9, 1997 at LaGrangeville, New York. Survived by his wife Lucy, his children Linda and Frans, his daughters-in-law Susan and Clara, his grandchildren Tristan and Marina. Pre-deceased by a son Leopold Franklin, 1988. Also survived by his sister Baroness F.C.H. Van Tuyll Van Serooskerken, sister-in-law Countess F.W. Van Limburg Stirum and nephew Count Leopold Van Limburg Stirum. Memorial services Thursday, 11AM, Grace Episcopal Church, Millbrook, NY. Memorial donations may be made to Hospice Inc., 70 North Hamilton St, Poughkeepsie, NY 12603 or Grace Church, Millbrook, NY 12545. Inquiries Allen Funeral Home, Millbrook, N.Y.

title: Spirited, Independent Slovenia
description: I LOVE border crossings. They somehow make me feel as though I'm in a black-and-white movie with subtitles. So the border between Trieste, Italy, and Kozina, Slovenia, was a minor disappointment. The most challenging question we were asked by the cheerful customs officers was whether we could demonstrate that our red Fiat was properly insured. In the restaurant of the nearby tourist information center, equally friendly personnel served us Slovenian beer and wine. We then bought a detailed road map, collected several pamphlets and a hotel rates booklet, and, armed with a guide to Slovenia written by Ed Lenarcic, a Canadian of Slovenian descent I'd met on the Internet, set off with no particular destination beyond Lipica (called Lipizza under the Austro-Hungarian empire), home of Lipizzaner horses.

title: At the Casinos
description: What's happening onstage at all the Atlantic City casinos this week.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHLOEDER, FRANCIS X., M.D.
description: SCHLOEDER-Francis X., M.D. Of Brooklyn. Age sixty-seven. Of a heart attack in Houston, TX, on May 4, 1997. Renowned nephrologist in the Canal Zone, Houston and Montgomery. Beloved husband of Ilana Reisz. Loving father, stepfather, proud grandfather, cherished brother and dear uncle. He will be remembered for his lovability, humor, generosity, ceaseless quest for truth and knowledge and love of naturea loss to all, much too soon.

Karl Malone followed the worst game of his career with one of his loudest (''I'm the man,'' he told a heckler in the front row), and now he has a series to end.

The Rev. Marla R. Abraham, an interfaith minister, performed the ceremony at the Fabbri mansion, a retreat house in Manhattan.

description: ON May 20 the residents of the Hewlett-Woodmere school district will vote to decide the future of a historic -- but extremely deteriorated -- 250-year-old farmhouse where eight generations of the Hewlett family lived.

title: What's Wrong With This Picture? (Too Much Green)
description: IT has the look of a classic Washington power struggle. But the titans in this battle seem to have forgotten about a huge group of people who will be directly affected by the outcome: 100 million American households that may be forced to buy expensive new digital television sets or converter boxes by the year 2006.

title: PLANTS NEED MEAT
description: Starting Friday, scientists and conservationists from around the world will gather at the Atlanta Botanical Garden for the first meeting of the International Carnivorous Plant Society. Along with the familiar Venus flytrap, conventioneers will get a chance to see exotics like Nepenthes (pictured), a gorgeous tropical pitcher plant that actually drowns its prey. Plus, there's a field trip: a 48-hour tour (via cars and feet) of swamps and marshes in Florida, Alabama and Georgia. The plant buffs are gathering, in part, to call attention to the habitat loss that threatens some species, but they're also in it for fun. ''With something like a Sarracenia alabamensis nearby,'' says Madeleine Groves, a botanist who is flying in from London's Kew Gardens, ''it's like having a panda in your backyard.''

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  SIMON, ANN R. (NEE STOLL)
description: SIMON-Ann R. (nee Stoll). March 5, 1933-May 8, 1996. In fond memory of Ann, devoted daughter of Mae M. Stoll. Loving sister and confidante to Ellen F. Pearlman. Sadly Missed

A boxing fan since her childhood in Vineland, where she grew up listening to fights on the radio with her father, Ms. Fischer, 50, had not expected an ''uphill battle.''

title: Sewer Project Strains Neighborliness Up and Down a Hill
description: Rick Greengus has had his television repair shop on the corner of 179th Street and Union Turnpike for 17 years. Business has been good. Last summer he repaired more than 800 air-conditioners.

title: Words of Praise For Mayor Schulman
description: Your article $(''County Offers Tougher Rules in Ethics Code,'' April 27$) is the first even-handed piece of information I have read about Mayor Sy J. Schulman of White Plains.

title: PROVENCE
description: Relaxing in the summer can be nerve-racking. The beach isn't much good -- with the crash of every wave, I think of projects postponed, deadlines looming, world problems waiting to be solved and, below the water's surface, millions of fish engaged in their hectic, pointless commute.

title: Exploring India's Far Northeast
description: Just about anyone can picture the map of India: it's triangular, an elephant's head seen from the front. But what about the elephant's right ear? Don't be ashamed if you didn't remember India's northeast. That irregular area between China and Bangladesh, Myanmar (formerly Burma) and Bhutan has been missing from the map of the world. Restricted, protected, excluded, backward: these have been its official designations since British colonial times. It's still a fair bet that most Indian citizens can't list all seven northeast states: Assam, Meghalaya, Tripura, Nagaland, Mizoram, Manipur and Arunachal Pradesh.

description: LAST September, Dr. Richard Horn was apppointed executive director of the Nafta Intermodal Transportation Institute, a component of the National Aviation and Transportation Center at Dowling College.

title: Cheryl Khaner And Hugh Cole
description: Cheryl Nina Khaner, an associate director of national promotions at Columbia Records in New York, was married yesterday to Hugh Bennett Cole, who owns Huge Ink, a company that manages rock musicians, in New York. Cantor Joseph Portnoy, the bride's great-uncle, performed the ceremony at the Rihga Royal Hotel in New York.

title: Books in Brief: Fiction
description: DAIRY QUEEN DAYS

title: Sweden Takes On Canada
description: The decade's dominant bowler was at his steadiest. His opponents were at their shakiest. The combination made for predictable theater here today at the Johnny Petraglia Open.

title: Potential Power Woes Now a Regional Worry
description: MAYBE it is true that misery loves company. Consider: The potential power shortage Connecticut faced last summer will be shared this year by all of New England. Last year three out of four Connecticut plants were shut down, but at least the Connecticut Yankee nuclear power plant at Haddam Neck operated through July. Then last fall, its operator, Northeast Utilities, closed the Connecticut Yankee permanently after officials determined it made no economic sense to continue running the unit. Now, with all four of the state's nuclear plans shut down, the region as well as the state faces possible power shortages.

title: There's No Place Like Work
description: Many companies now provide employee training in communication and human relations (as in ''Value the Internal Customer''). Part of the problem that Linda Avery described in the article is that her family doesn't give her the same courtesy at home. What is the home equivalent of a manager who is held accountable (or denied a promotion) for not being ''a people person''? What is the equivalent of a meeting facilitator, etc.? If we can bring these values from the workplace home, we will have reaped an unexpected benefit of the Total Quality principles.

title: In West Windsor, Toll Wins a Mt. Laurel Wrangle
description: IN the wake of an earlier decision that linked a town's zoning with market conditions in fulfilling the town's obligations under the state's Mount Laurel housing doctrines, a developer has won subsequent court approval to build 1,165 residences at a site in West Windsor. Subject to an expected appeal by the town, the project would rise on 300 acres of farmland at the corner of Bear Brook and Meadow Roads in the Mercer County township.

title: Racetrack Plan Stirs Uproar
description: A 1994 magazine ad for the Staten Island Homeport Redevelopment Project boasts an aerial photo of 36 waterfront acres with a 1,400-foot pier bisecting the Verrazano-Narrows like the mullion in a window pane, and the text extols the land's ''expansive vistas of lower Manhattan, up to 1,000 parking spaces and easy access to New York City.''

title: There's No Place Like Work
description: Children are not something we should be squeezing into our schedules. Contraception and Roe v. Wade have given women the power to decide independently whether or not to have children. If one feels she is more committed to her career than to raising children, why in the world have a child? Focus on what is important to you.

title: When Sullivan Was Master Of the Big Show
description: IT'S MAY, THE MOST IMPORTANT sweeps month, and what the networks badly need as they search for the really big television events that will assure them ratings success is another Ed Sullivan. As the country's leading television impresario -- and thus the national arbiter of taste -- Sullivan appeared on CBS on Sunday night for 23 years and sold the masses on everyone from Dean Martin and Jerry Lewis to Elvis Presley and the Beatles.

title: Joyce Furman And Neil Minkoff
description: Joyce Rachel Furman and Dr. Neil Bruce Minkoff are to be married today in Bedford, N.Y. Rabbi Robert A. Rothman is to perform the ceremony at Temple Shaaray Tefila.

title: Living Dangerously
description: Although a yolk is just a little more than one-third of an egg's weight, it accounts for 100 percent of its personality. Known to the tongue as rich, smooth and satiny, the yolk is the tiny sun in the center of its universe. And just as we've come to fear the sun's killer rays, we've come to fret over this most basic of foods.

title: Bowing to Jenny Lind
description: To the Editor:

title: Holocaust Collection Is Educator for Young
description: It's a love letter written from a very personal hell -- the Polish script scrawled on paper now yellowed with age and posted from the notorious Nazi death camp at Auschwitz.

title: Mayor Barry Could Face Unified Field In an Election
description: With much of the mayoral power here usurped by a federally appointed financial control board, now entrenched in efforts to improve life in the nation's capital, the future of Marion S. Barry Jr. has become a favorite political topic.

title: Vocal Works, Classic and Popular
description: VOICES can be heard in several concerts today. At 3, a free performance of Brahms's German Requiem will be offered at the Ives Concert Hall, Western Connecticut State University, Danbury, with Eileen Clark Reisner and William Fleck the soprano and bass-baritone soloists, and Leslie Eckstein conducting the Danbury Concert Chorus and Orchestra.

title: The City's Oldest Traffic Cop
description: Any weekday morning, if you're bumper to bumper on the exit off the F.D.R. Drive, the one marked Brooklyn Bridge and Civic Center, chances are you'll notice the traffic cop waving you through the intersection at Pearl Street. If this officer's gray mustache and gray hair under his hat look a bit out of date, they are. At 59, with 36 years and counting of service, Kenneth Dean is New York's oldest traffic cop.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BARKAN, GRACE, (NEE COHEN)
description: BARKAN-Grace, (nee Cohen). Of South Orange, NJ. Beloved wife of Abram, mother of Marty and Julie Barkan, Irwin and Lindsay Barkan and the late Leonard. Grandmother of Melanie, Zachary, Taylor and Wesley. Funeral service from Temple B'nai Abraham, 300 East Northfield Rd., Livingston, NJ today at 2 PM. Interment B'nai Abraham Memorial Park, Union, NJ. Further information BernheimApter-Goldsticker, 201-763-3505.

title: NEW YORKERS & CO.
description: Bowling Is Latest Addition To Chelsea Piers' Lineup

title: Player's Incident at Club Is Raising Questions
description: The Arizona Cardinals drafted Jake Plummer in the second round of the National Football League draft, hoping he would be their quarterback of the future. He still may be, but Plummer has more important things on his mind these days.

title: A Lively Irish Public House in Yonkers
description: IRISH pubs have sprouted here and there on Central Park Avenue South in the vicinity of Woodlawn, becoming more frequent as one travels a few blocks east on McLean Avenue. Standing tall among the Irish delicatessens and bakery shops along this route is Rory Dolan's, one of the largest and liveliest.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  GETTINGER, ANNA J.
description: GETTINGER-Anna J. Dearest Mother. Our love and our thoughts are with our wonderful mother every day. Martin and Gloria

title: Votes in Congress
description: Tally Last Week in Connecticut, New Jersey and New York

title: Riley Is Back To Torment The Knicks
description: THERE would be no high drama at high noon today if Pat Riley's team were coming into the Garden whipped and whimpering. Riley's return for the playoffs is one of the great morality plays of our time, at least from a classically righteous New York perspective. Riley could not wait to get out of Gotham in 1995, which at the time seemed to be one of the great insults in Dave Checketts's estimable career as a sports executive.

title: Lynn Boudreau And Jeffrey Heuer
description: Lynn Marie Boudreau, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Donald L. Boudreau of Larchmont, N.Y., was married yesterday in Scarsdale, N.Y., to Jeffrey Wahl Heuer, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Alan J. Heuer of Darien, Conn. The Rev. Phillip S. Washburn performed the ceremony at the Scarsdale Congregational Church.

title: Cultural Intrusion Is a Blockbuster Best Seller
description: GOETHE and Schiller are probably spinning in their graves: last week only two books on Germany's fiction best-seller lists were actually written by Germans. Legal potboilers by John Grisham, by contrast, appeared four times -- twice among the top 15 hard-covers, twice on the separate list of 15 paperbacks.

title: HUDSON, N.Y.
description: I wish I were a person who could while away five minutes without fleeing back to my study in a fit of anxious dread. Still, there are summer afternoons when the warm air echoes with the sighs of weekend visitors, the shouts of arguing children, and sanity depends on loading everyone in the car, driving through this pretty section of upstate New York and crossing the Hudson River to Olana, a place so paradisiacal, so conducive to delight that it gives me a glimpse of indolence untainted by restless guilt.

title: Pasts Recaptured
description: THE PAPER TRAIL

title: Books in Brief: Fiction
description: The Big Picture

title: Trieste, Filtering Tradition
description: BY 7 A.M. the aroma of coffee and the clink of espresso cups resonates through Trieste, on the northern shore of the Adriatic Sea, the last major city in Italy before Slovenia. Hundreds of cafes shiny with mirrors and polished bars serve the 230,000 residents of Trieste some of the best coffee in Italy.

title: Reconstructing T.W.A. 800
description: Inside the old Grumman hangar in Calverton, N.Y., they call it the ''jetosaurus rex,'' an appropriate label for the 65,000-pound dinosaur that is the reconstructed remains of Trans World Airlines Flight 800.

title: Working Harder to Earn The Same Old Vacation
description: PAID vacation has been a protected benefit of most American workers since the late 1940's. A week at the shore, maybe two, symbolized hard-won prosperity and was meant to be savored, even flaunted.

title: Residential Resales
description: MANHATTAN

title: Cheryl Emerson, Michael Adams Jr.
description: Cheryl Jean Emerson, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Charles Emerson of Granby, Conn., was married yesterday to Michael Blair Adams Jr., the son of Mr. and Mrs. Adams Sr. of Rye, N.Y. The Rev. Dr. Peter J. Meister, a Congregational minister, officiated in the Thompson Memorial Chapel at Williams College in Williamstown, Mass.

title: A Palace for a New Magic Kingdom, 42d St.
description: THE AGE OF DISCOVERY may be past, but the Age of Rediscovery is still young. One of the most important treasures unearthed by today's intrepid explorers is the Great American Street. The opening next Sunday of the New Amsterdam Theater, the magnificently restored 1903 show palace on West 42d Street, is above all an occasion to celebrate one of the most spectacular of these treasures.

title: Murder, With Laughs on the Side
description: IT'S THE SORT OF TWISTED, high-concept story that Hollywood finds irresistible: a professional hit man, in the throes of a career crisis, returns home to Michigan to attend his 10-year high school reunion.

title: Girls' Coming of Age Explored in a Novel
description: ''SILENCE was another way to tell a lie,'' says the adolescent narrator in Karin Cook's first novel, ''What Girls Learn'' (Pantheon Books).

title: WESTCHESTER BRIEFS
description: Sound Efforts

title: Designing a War Against Crime
description: The corner of Armstrong Avenue and Martin Luther King Drive is conspicuous these days, mainly because of what is absent.

title: Taking a Bike
description: To the Editor: Concerning Sue Halpern's Practical Traveler column on bicycles, ''To Pack a Bike, Pack a Bag'' (April 13), the best solutions are easy. Buy a bike at your destination. You can get the machine you want, and don't have to put up with Rube Goldberg contraptions. Additionally, many bike shops, here and abroad, offer used bikes or will repurchase your new one for almost full price at journey's end.

title: The Right Stuff, in Just the Right Portions
description: YEARS ago when we dined at this scenic site in Farmington, its name was the Reading Room. Now, the agreeable, ground-level space inside a grist mill dating from 1901 has been rejuvenated, with a new owner, chef and name: the Grist Mill. The wonderful views are the same, overlooking the surging Farmington River and a waterfall. The small, well-kept dining room, with creamy walls contrasting with dark wood posts and beams, exudes stylish rusticity and, more importantly, features Italian food that is very good indeed.

title: Donna Dever, Matthew Downing
description: Donna Patricia Dever, a daughter of Eileen M. Dever of Merrick, N.Y., and the late Peter F. Dever, was married yesterday to Matthew Martin Downing, a son of Dolores and Franklin G. Downing of Orchard Park, N.Y. The Rev. James O'Shea performed the ceremony at the Roman Catholic Church of the Sacred Heart in North Merrick, N.Y.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHILLINGER, SHAW, FRANCES
description: SCHILLINGER - SHAW - Frances, on May 8, 1997. Beloved wife of the late Joseph Schillinger. Funeral private.

title: Shorting Against the Box, Before It's Too Late
description: ALTHOUGH White House and Congressional negotiators agreed to include capital gains tax relief in their potentially historic budget deal, they provided nothing in the way of specific terms. But last Wednesday, Republican leaders announced that any reduction would take effect on that day, May 7, and this was enough for some nervous or impatient investors to promptly cash in some profits without even knowing how big their tax breaks would be.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  POLKOWITZ, LOUISE
description: POLKOWITZ-Louise. Dear Louise, we will miss your wit, your style and your grace. We love you. Mabel, Saul, Hope and Robin

title: Power Dinners: The Early Bird Special
description: FOR years and years in this town, later has been cooler.

title: Switching From Y'All to Buon Giorno
description: SAVANNA'S in Southampton is not the same restaurant it was. The first inkling of that comes when the maitre d' hotel murmurs ''buon appetito.'' This two-year-old, which once served Southern coastal food, is now Italian.

title: New Hub of Gay Life, New Attacks
description: In the last few years, as gay bars, bookstores, coffee bars, gyms and nightclubs have opened and flourished along Eighth Avenue, gay New Yorkers have cheered the growth of a hub other than Greenwich Village. Now, they say, a darker side is emerging: an increase in bias attacks against gay men and lesbians in Chelsea.

title: Wood, Silver and All, Here Come the Crafts
description: ALTHOUGH casual in atmosphere, sprawling from a hilltop site overlooking Bruce Park in Greenwich, the Bruce Museum's annual Outdoor Crafts Festival holds to museum standards.

title: Head Injuries Force Schools To Ponder Policy
description: TWO weeks after Josh Ramer suffered his first concussion while playing football for Syosset High School, he got clearance to return to play ball. Several months later, while playing basketball on the school team, he banged heads with another player and suffered a second concussion.

title: Sarah Taylor, Kevin Looper
description: Sarah McFarland Taylor, a daughter of Marion McFarland Taylor of Summit, N.J., and Arthur R. Taylor of New York, is to be married today in Santa Barbara, Calif., to Kevin Charles Looper, the son of Carol Weiss Looper and Ronald S. Looper, both of Omaha. The Rev. Carol W. Powers, a Unitarian Universalist minister, is to perform the ceremony at the Santa Barbara Coastal Bluffs.

title: The Knock on the Door
description: VIOLETS dot the lawn; a mockingbird serenades. It's time for proms and parties, graduations and dreams. It's a youthful season. A time for top-down convertibles that will take you anywhere and everywhere. Anywhere.

title: The Philosopher-King Is Mortal
description: On Nov. 18 of last year, Vaclav Havel was found to have pneumonia and given treatment. But the pneumonia failed to subside.

title: Ms. Goldwasser And Mr. Haller
description: Lauren Audrey Goldwasser, a marketing manager, and Peter Erich Haller, a lawyer, were married yesterday in New York. Rabbi Daniel S. Wolk officiated at the Essex House.

title: Another View On Foster Care
description: The article (''Just Who Should Care for the Children?'' April 20) offered a fine overview of all the problems besetting Connecticut's foster care system since the deaths of three children ''known to the system'' two years ago.

title: Romantic Songs End Warner Library Recitals
description: THE voices of spring continue to be heard. Today at 2:30 P.M., the soprano Allison Hartshorne and the pianist Patricia Walter conclude the cycle of free recitals at the Warner Library in Tarrytown with a program fit for Mother's Day, offering romantic songs by Fanny Mendelssohn, Amy Beach, Charles Griffes and Franz Liszt.

title: Riding The Buzz In SoHo
description: THE noise level at Balthazar, the new boite on the corner of Spring and Crosby Streets, was not unlike that of the pit at the stock exchange. Under his boyish mop of hair, the usually calm Keith McNally, the owner, looked positively frazzled as he made an emergency call to Pravda for extra champagne glasses. The waiters seemed somewhat shell-shocked as the sous-chefs, Riad Nasr and Lee Henson, churned out bistro dishes at a furious rate.

title: In Washington, It's Never Farewell to Arms
description: THE Government bureaucracy that manages the sale of American weapons overseas would by itself be a respectable-sized military contractor: 6,500 employees, a $500 million operating budget and sales of about $12 billion a year.

title: Modern Romantic
description: Lar Lubovitch lies sprawled on the floor of a large rehearsal hall at the headquarters of American Ballet Theater in downtown Manhattan. His eyes are bloodshot, cheeks pale, chest heaving, T-shirt dark with sweat.

title: One Sky, Many Owners
description: IT'S 1999. To reduce the risk of global warming, the United States and other industrial nations have agreed to cut carbon dioxide emissions by 10 percent in the coming decade.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  ANHALT, HARVEY
description: ANHALT-Harvey. 3/7/20-5/10/59. In loving memory of our dear brother. Stanley and Amy

title: Library Network Gets New Home
description: WHEN the Westlynx computer system recently shut down for a day in the county's public libraries, a veil descended on the basic kinds of information gathering that many library patrons take for granted. Librarians, too, were thrown into the dark ages trying to fill in for the machines. ''The books piled up, piles and piles of books we couldn't discharge,'' said Penny Wolff, a reference librarian at the Scarsdale Public Library. ''It was an inconvenience, but everyone got through it.''

title: PLAYING IN THE NEIGHBORHOOD
description: FLUSHING

title: CENTRAL NEW HAMPSHIRE
description: Waking on a summer morning, the first thing I hear, paradoxically, is the silence. The house, an old Cape Cod, is on a dirt road in central New Hampshire. Trees line the road and stone walls disappear into the woods. Often among the tire tracks I see moose tracks and sometimes the sprawling prints of a black bear. When I first came here 40 years ago, there were cows in the field and the bells around their necks jangled all night. But now the silence seems to extend a hundred miles as the morning sun is filtered through the sugar maples. Then perhaps I hear a woodpecker hammering its bill against the beach tree.

title: Envisioning a Nassau 'Downtown,' With Trolleys
description: FROM his ninth-floor law office in 90 Merrick Avenue, Morton L. Certilman can see most of what he calls Central Nassau, a shopping, entertainment and cultural area that he says will soon be a linked by its own transportation system.

title: Crossing the Atlantic, in Gracious Competition
description: A desire to return to a grander era in yacht racing -- one less grueling and austere than many of the long-distance ocean races today -- has spawned a trans-Atlantic competition among 16 of the world's largest private sailing yachts.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CLARKE, JAMES J.
description: CLARKE-James J. Retired Vice President of American International Group, Inc. Died on Wednesday, May 7, 1997. He is survived by his wife Irene; his sisters Virginia and Anna; and his nieces Anne, Marie and Alice. Mass of Resurrection was celebrated on Saturday, May 10, 1997, at St. Vincent Ferrer, R.C. Church.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOODKIND, ROBERT H.
description: GOODKIND-Robert H. May 4, 1997. Beloved husband of Irene, father of Thomas and James and Patricia French, brother of Richard and grandfather of four. Contributions to Renaissance Village Inc., for At Risk Youth, 11380 Prosperity Farms Road, Suite 209A, Palm Beach Gardens, FL. 33410, Phone 561-776-0890.

title: DEL MAR, CALIF.
description: Ah, those long, lazy, placid summer afternoons in a hammock or on a beach armed with a good book!

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LANDAU, JANETTE
description: LANDAU-Janette. May 1, 1997. Beloved mother and friend, missed by daughter Iris Scharer, son Charles Landau and persons all over the world. She was a talented sculptress and artist and a generous supporter of many charities. Her compassion and understanding benefitted many. A memorial service will be held at the Theosophical Society, 242 East 53 St., 6:30 PM, Friday, May 23.

title: F.Y.I.
description: Not for the Birds

title: E Pluribus Unum: An Exploration of Diversity
description: A HISPANIC teen-ager writes his ''illegal alien play.'' The characters are on a raft, about to discover they're dead. It is a surrealist abstract tragedy in a post-Expressionistic mode, he says. Or something like that. His parents, fed-up liberals, enter. Dramaturgical intervention ensues. The play about the play and, presumably, that play are titled ''Dead Bolivians on a Raft,'' written by Guillermo Reyes.

title: Distribution of Clean Needles?
description: Some opinions from a debate over whether the state should continue to ban distribution of clean needles to drug addicts to slow the spread of AIDS.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CARTER, JOSEPH H.
description: CARTER-Joseph H. May 8, 1997. Beloved husband of Bea. Loving father of Bonnie and Les, and of Judy and Howard. Devoted grandfather of Jennifer, Susan, Daniel, Benjamin and Barbara, and great grandfather of Sarah and Lindsay. Dear brother of Mary Surry and Bill Cohen. Greatly loved by all.

title: Author of Children's Books Works for Library's Cause
description: CAMPBELL GEESLIN entered the kingdom of Babar and Winnie the Pooh after his twin granddaughters were born and he was nearly 70. As a child growing up in Texas, he said, he never saw a children's book. Now he is the author of one, ''In Rosa's Mexico,'' and two more are on the way.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  GIBBONS, MARY I.
description: GIBBONS-Mary I. May 15, 1898February 15, 1969. Dear Mom, Happy Birthday in Heaven. We miss and love you very much. Bunky, Mary, Anne, Lilly, Michael.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: I.B.M.'s Deep Blue Beats Kasparov in Chess Match

title: If the Chorus Dresses Up, That's Really a Gala
description: The annual Metropolitan Opera Pension Fund Gala Concert is usually fun: popular artists sing favorite arias; the chorus for once gets to perform in formal concert attire instead of lolling about in peasant rags, and the company's crucial retirement fund gets replenished.

title: Stocks Rise in Japan
description: Stocks traded higher here today.

title: CHRONICLE
description: HENRY A. GRUNWALD, the former editor in chief of Time Inc. and ambassador to Austria, also sounded a Shakespearean note the other day: ''It occurs to me that there are four ages of man,'' he said. ''Youth, middle age, late middle age and award time. This is obviously award time for me.''

title: Mini-Vans Facing a Midlife Crisis at Age 14
description: Barbara J. Byer couldn't take it any more.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SMITH, JOAN MCALLISTER
description: SMITH-Joan McAllister, on May 9, 1997, of Garden City. Beloved wife of the late J. Read Smith. Loving mother of Janet Daddario, J. Read, Jr., Eric, Gerard and the late Andrew Smith. Fond grandmother of Beth Masker, Thomas and Jeffrey Flaherty, J. Read III, Brett, Katherine, Madeline and Gerard Smith. Also survived by five great-grandchildren.
