Visiting at the Fairchild Chapel, Franklin Ave. at 12th St., Garden City, Tuesday, 2-5 and 7-9. Mass of Christian Burial Wednesday, 11 AM, St. Joseph's Church, Garden City.

title: How One Champion Is Chewed Up Into Small Bits by Another
description: By the standards of top chess, it was a complete breakdown. As the grand finale of a historic contest, it was just no contest.

title: Enthusiastic Crowds Greet Woods at Clinic
description: Early last week, Bill Daniel, on behalf of the Tiger Woods Foundation, regretfully announced that today's long-planned youth golf clinic and exhibition here was going to be closed to the public. The reason? There was too much interest in the young Masters Champion: ''It's like he's a rock star on a rainbow tour.''

title: PGA's TV Pacts Keep Balance of Power
description: The PGA Tour's new four-year television deals that start in 1999 will double revenues while maintaining the three-network golfing balance of power: CBS Sports with 17 tournaments annually, NBC Sports with 5 and ABC Sports with 11.

title: Mets Better Look Out: This Could Be a Habit
description: Seasons have passed since the Mets have felt like this, the veteran reliever John Franco said today, after his team stunned the St. Louis Cardinals, 6-4, with a ninth-inning rally.

title: Now a Genius, Soupy Is Off the Barbecue
description: AS soon as Colin Campbell was named the Rangers' coach after Mike Keenan deserted the 1994 Stanley Cup champions, the man his players call Soupy had been on the barbecue.

title: Score One for Sleight Of Hand
description: The book on Martin Brodeur says that if the Devils' goaltender has a weakness, it is that he is vulnerable to wraparounds.

title: For Devils, Clincher Is Hauntingly Familiar
description: Martin Brodeur and the rest of the Devils did not try to hide from the truth today: The series-winning goal in overtime by Adam Graves was painfully similar to the wraparound shot that the Rangers' Stephane Matteau put past Brodeur in 1994 in the second overtime of Game 7 of the Eastern Conference finals.

title: Arab's Death (and the Selling of Land to Jews)
description: Behind shuttered doors on an empty side street in East Jerusalem, the Bashiti family grieved alone today for the head of the household, Farid Bashiti, whose bludgeoned and bound body was found Friday in the West Bank town of Ramallah.

title: A Settlement Saves Literary Landmark
description: The owner of Gotham Book Mart and Joanne Carson, a former wife of Johnny Carson, have settled a lawsuit that the owner said had threatened to close the 77-year-old literary landmark in midtown Manhattan, Ms. Carson's lawyer said last night.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: Hockey

title: Economic Calendar
description: MONDAY

title: India and Pakistan to Hold Talks on Reducing Tensions
description: The Prime Ministers of India and Pakistan will meet here on Monday in an encounter that will test their readiness to reduce tensions that have poisoned relations between the two countries for 50 years.

title: 'There Is No Stopping'
description: In Jerusalem years ago I was interviewing Jacobo Timerman, who had survived 29 months of detention and torture by an Argentine military regime. He asked me a question.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GURWIN, ROSALIND
description: GURWIN-Rosalind. The Officers and Directors of Metropolitan Jewish Geriatric Center sadly mourn the untimely passing of Rosalind Gurwin, beloved wife of Joseph Gurwin, a cherished friend, humanitarian and esteemed supporter. Rosalind will be greatly missed. May her legacy act as a source of inspiration to all those whom she touched. Our profound sympathy and sincere condolences to the family. Mark L. Goldstein, President Eli S. Feldman, Executive VP Chief Executive Officer

title: Pay, and Pay, for Oil
description: To the Editor:

title: No Stepping on Oakley's Toes
description: What was apparently the deciding moment -- as well as one of the most dramatic -- yesterday in Game 3 of the Knicks-Heat playoff series occurred when Voshon Lenard fouled John Starks as the Knick guard was taking a 3-point shot with 2 minutes 42 seconds left in the fourth quarter and the score tied, 73-73.

title: Arizona Governor Facing Trial on Fraud and Extortion
description: Barring a last-minute plea-bargaining agreement, Gov. Fife Symington will go on trial here on Tuesday on 22 charges of fraud, lying and extortion, the second of Arizona's chief executives to be accused of felonious wrongdoing in less than a decade.

title: Pro Bono Accounts
description: * The Holocaust Memorial-Museum of Jewish Heritage, New York, to DDB Needham New York, a unit of Omnicom Group, as the first agency to handle advertising for the museum, which is expected to open in the fall.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DOBKIN, TILLIE (ENGLANDER)
description: DOBKIN-Tillie (Englander). On May 10, 1997. Devoted wife of the late Ben. Beloved mother of Charles and Jay. Religious service today, 10:30 AM, at ''Parkside Memorial Chapels,'' Queens Blvd., corner 66th Ave., Forest Hills

title: Jobs, but Few New Skills, for Those on Welfare
description: Diana Goodrich, 33, has had a hard time finding a steady job since a decade ago, when the nursing home where she worked closed. She had been getting along on temporary jobs and food stamps until she came up against a provision in the new Federal welfare law restricting adults without children at home to just three months of food stamps every three years.

title: A Pair of Foxy Grandmas Who Tangle With a Wolf
description: You know this setup like the back of your canasta hand. A stereotyped Jewish mother -- she of the mink coat, chicken soup, guilt-inflicting variety -- moves in with a walking cliche of an Irish Catholic mother, who carries with her everywhere a plaster statue of Jesus and a lifetime supply of martyrdom.

title: Value Education, C.W. Post Graduates Told
description: Graduates getting ready to enter the work force were reminded of the value of education yesterday, during the 40th annual commencement ceremonies of the C. W. Post Campus of Long Island University.

title: British Election
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  METZGER, CAROL J.
description: METZGER-Carol J., of Ridgefield, CT, on May 10, 1997, at the age of 48. Wife of John F. Metzger. Mother of James and Ted. Funeral services Tuesday at 10 AM at Temple B'Nai Chaim, 82 Portland Ave., Georgetown, CT. Burial to follow in Fairlawn Cemetery, Ridgefield, CT. Contributions Temple B'Nai Chaim Children's Library, POB 305, Georgetown, CT 06829.

title: People
description: * Bob Seltzer was named president and chief executive of Ogilvy Adams & Reinhart, New York, a unit of WPP Group, succeeding John Margaritis, who will become a consultant to the agency. Mr. Seltzer was previously general manager of the New York office of Porter Novelli, a unit of Omnicom Group.

title: Camden Mayor Is Embattled
description: Mayor Arnold W. Webster faces a tough time this month with four challengers vying for his post and state legislators weighing whether it should take control of city finances.

title: Pharmacia and Upjohn Names Its New Chief and President
description: Pharmacia and Upjohn Inc., the troubled international drug giant, named an official of the American Home Products Corporation today as its president and chief executive.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOTTLIEB, HAROLD
description: GOTTLIEB-Harold, on May 10, 1997. Service Monday, 11 AM, at Clark Assocs. Funeral Home, Katonah, NY, 914-232-3033.

title: The Internet as Commerce: Who Pays, Under What Rules?
description: Names and handshakes, it would seem, are simple matters of identification and etiquette. But the digital equivalents of names and handshakes are now subjects of fierce debate, international negotiations and accusations of corporate skulduggery. The bedrock issue is who will determine the commercial rules of the road on the Internet, as the global web of computer networks increasingly becomes a mainstream medium of communication and commerce.

title: G.O.P. Remains Hostile to Census Sampling
description: Republican leaders in Congress have hardened in their opposition to the use of statistical sampling to arrive at final population figures in the next census, setting up a probable showdown with the White House on an issue of huge political and social importance.

title: Families Emerge as Silent Victims Of Tuskegee Syphilis Experiment
description: It has been 25 years since the nation learned that more than 400 black men infected with syphilis went untreated for decades in a federally financed experiment in this rural Southern town laced with sandy roads and pine forests.

title: Alcohol Advertising
description: To the Editor:

title: Equity and Debt Offerings Expected This Week
description: The following equity and convertible debt offerings are expected this week:

title: There's Gold in Them Thar Pictures
description: Few of the scores of thousands of fortune hunters who set off for the Klondike in 1898 lucked into a big gold strike, but they left behind a rich lode of photographs. The producers of ''Gold Fever'' must give thanks for the cameras among the tons of goods hauled from Seattle across Alaska and into Canada and for the presence of a few experienced photographers among the inexperienced prospectors.

title: Accounts
description: * The Seagram Beverage Co., New York, a unit of the Seagram Company, to Gearon Hoffman Inc., Boston, to handle advertising for Grolsch beer, which had been previously inactive. Billings were estimated at $2 million to $3 million. Gearon Hoffman already handles advertising for Seagram Beverage's Devil Mountain beer brand.

title: Unions Seize on Surplus With Call for Hiring, Not Raises
description: Even though it was Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's talk of ballooning deficits that persuaded most municipal unions to accept a two-year pay freeze, many union leaders have reacted to the recent news of a record budget surplus not with demands for higher wages, but with calls for hiring more workers.

title: Congress's Duty in the Everglades
description: President Clinton's budget for the next fiscal year lays out a blueprint for the largest environmental rescue project ever undertaken in this country -- the restoration of Florida's Everglades. In a few weeks, the Senate and House appropriations committees will begin making decisions that will determine the future of this once-wondrous ecosystem. Members of these committees can emerge from this process as environmental heroes or as accomplices in the further degradation of South Florida.

title: Can a Sacred Island Keep a Pushy World at Bay?
description: After draining a fifth of Australia, the continent's longest river, the Murray, splits into channels around this egg-shaped island, then finds its shallow mouth to the sea between two protective headlands.

title: As tourism stagnates, Hawaii fights back with a campaign to invigorate its image.
description: THERE is trouble in paradise, at least in getting people to visit.

title: Free Transit Rides Offered
description: New Jersey Transit kicks off a weeklong push to increase ridership on its train and bus lines today with offers of free-ride coupons and festivals designed to publicize its system.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COHEN, ALICE
description: COHEN-Alice. Beloved wife of the late Alex. Loving mother of Gerald Cohen and Elaine Siegel. Loving grandmother and friend. Graveside services Kensico Cemetery, Sharon Gardens, Valhalla, NY, Monday, 1 PM.

title: Bridge
description: A star Italian pair was on track to score a remarkable double in the Cavendish Calcutta tournament in Las Vegas this weekend. Alfredo Versace and Lorenzo Lauria, who have had outstanding results in Europe recently, were lying second at the midpoint of the Cavendish Pairs.

title: Coming to Terms With Family Secrets
description: Playing a savvy professional photographer, Mira Sorvino responds to the news of her mother's death by pulling a long black dress out of her closet. ''Is it Italian enough?'' she yells at her boyfriend. ''Do I shroud myself in black and mourn for the rest of my life?'' Soon she has returned to her old neighborhood to sell her childhood home, and a family friend delivers her mother's legacy: a huge scrapbook filled with clippings, recipes and a violent story that reveals a family secret.

title: Pope Calls on Lebanon to Resume Special Role for Peace
description: By early morning, hours before Pope John Paul II was to celebrate Mass here today, several hundred thousand people were already streaming into a vast landfill reclaimed from the sea with the debris of buildings destroyed in Lebanon's long civil war.

title: Hard Times for Europe's Gypsies
description: Last week, the Catholic Church beatified a Gypsy for the first time. Ceferino Jimenez Malla was a Spanish Gypsy, executed during the Spanish Civil War for protecting a local priest and refusing to surrender his rosary. The beatification, which is the first step toward canonization, was a rare public acknowledgment of the contributions of a reviled and persecuted minority in Europe.

title: In Megan Case, a Passive Suspect With a Violent Past
description: In the third row of the courtroom at the trial of the man accused of killing their 7-year-old daughter, Maureen and Richard Kanka usually sit with a few friends and relatives.

title: Some highly graphic CD-ROM's offer on-screen close-ups of life and death.
description: IT is astonishing how death haunts computer images of life. New software releases display objects that until recently have never really been studied outside the morgue or off a dissecting table: a skull whose seams open to view the internal acoustic meatus superior; a torso, with skin stripped away, bathed in crimson. One can rotate a heart or slice up a cadaver.

title: Block Party at the Garden: Ewing Leads the Festivities
description: Patrick Ewing might smile when he sees the replay. There he was at midcourt, hollering, urging the crowd to cheer, celebrating his blocked shot against Tim Hardaway that helped to seal the Knicks' 77-73 victory over the Miami Heat yesterday.

title: Princeton Men's Varsity Finishes Undefeated Season
description: The Princeton men's varsity heavyweight crew capped an undefeated collegiate season today, winning the Eastern Sprint Championships and carrying home a busload of trophies in testimony to its dominance of this regatta and the season's racing.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: TENNIS

title: Grocery Shopping in Cyberspace Means No Squeezing the Produce
description: Attention all grocery shoppers! Proceed to the nearest computer to take advantage of today's specials!

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLDBERG, JACK
description: GOLDBERG-Jack. Survived by beloved wife Ruth; brother Philip; sister-in-law Ruth; loving children Vivian, Raymond, Stephen and Fumiko; adored grandchildren Andrea, Mark, Michelle, Daniel, Joan, Adam, Victoria and Edward; cherished great-grandsons Branden and Samuel. Graveside services.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RAUTENBERG, KATE
description: RAUTENBERG - Kate. Beloved wife of the late Adolph. Devoted mother of Eva (John) Englander. Loving grandmother of Jeffrey, Cynthia and Diane. Cherished great-grandmother of Jacob, Rachel, Sam, Alexander and Noah. Services 9:30, Tuesday, May 13, 1997, at Schwartz Bros.-Jeffer Memorial Chapel, 114-03 Queens Boulevard (76th Road), Forest Hills, New York

title: 2 Suspects Are Charged In Queens Payroll Heist
description: After a day of police interrogations, two men arrested in the ambush and shooting of a retired police officer and an off-duty detective during a payroll robbery in Queens were charged yesterday with attempted murder.

title: Forbes Set to Bring Out a New Web Site
description: Forbes magazine says six sponsors have committed $250,000 each toward one area of the magazine's new Web site, Digital Tool, for one year.

title: The Clintons' Caribbean: TV, a Pool and Time Off
description: For Bill Clinton, one of his closest aides once explained, ''words are actions.''

title: Dr. Vernal G. Cave, 78, Dies; Led in Medical and Civic Issues
description: Dr. Vernal G. Cave, a Brooklyn physician and civic leader whose series of imposing titles tended more to obscure than to reflect his almost half-century of quiet, day-to-day work on behalf of black medical, political and social causes, died on Wednesday at University Hospital of Brooklyn. He was 78 and had been a founding director of both the New York City Health and Hospitals Corporation and the Bedford-Stuyvesant Restoration Corporation.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLOD, MIRIAM
description: GOLOD-Miriam, on May 10, 1997. Interment private. For information call Plaza Memorial Chapel 212-769-4400.

title: New Bid for Blender Maker
description: The CTS Corporation said yesterday that it had agreed to buy the Dynamics Corporation of America, maker of Waring blenders, for $208.8 million in cash and stock, surpassing a hostile bid by the WHX Corporation. Under the agreement, CTS will buy about 50 percent of Dynamics stock at $55 a share, a 24 percent premium over Friday's closing price. Shares that are not purchased will be converted into 0.88 share of CTS stock, which closed at $61.75 on Friday. WHX has offered $45 a share, or about $167 million. CTS, based in Elkhart, Ind., makes electronic and electrical components for a variety of industries.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BEARD, ANSON MCCOOK
description: BEARD-Anson McCook, age 88. After a long illness, died peacefully at his home on Long Island on May 10. Beloved husband of the late Roseanne Beard, he is survived by three sons, Anson McCook, Jr., of Greenwich, CT, Peter Hill of Montauk, NY, Samuel Sherwood of New Castle, DE, and seven grandchildren. Funeral services are private.

title: At Cannes, the talk may be of cinema as art; the substance is selling movies.
description: SURELY the 50th edition of the Cannes International Film Festival is the right occasion to look back, perhaps even with moistened eye, at the great films and the no-longer-with-us actors and directors of the postwar era. Well, yes, but it is not what actually interests the great majority of movie folk crowding this resort.

title: Heat's Turn To Regret Close Loss
description: Outside on a sweet spring day, people scurried around bearing plants or boxes of candy as Mother's Day gifts. But as far as the Miami Heat players were concerned, they had already given at the office.

title: Promoting Its Ideas, the Manhattan Institute Has Nudged New York Rightward
description: Amid the powerful conformist currents of midtown Manhattan, there is something unexpected about Myron Magnet's sideburns -- bushy white whiskers that billow out from his bespectacled face like something out of Dickens.

title: Nigerian Asylum Seeker Claimed False Identity
description: To the Editor:

title: Childs Brings Hardaway, and the Heat, to a Screeching Halt
description: THE inscription in the just-published book at Chris Childs's locker-room stall was something of an order from the Knicks' most renowned bystander on how to deal with the Miami Heat's most dangerous threat.

title: Machine Tool Orders Rose 9.3% in March
description: Orders for American-made machine tools jumped 9.3 percent in March from February, according to an industry survey released this weekend.

title: CHRONICLE
description: WILLIAM C. WARREN, 87, had a significant impact on Columbia Law School during his tenure as its dean from 1952 to 1970 following six years on the faculty, but he will leave a legacy beyond his lectures or writing. Ground is to be broken today on an eight-story building at Amsterdam Avenue and 115th Street to be named the William and June Warren Hall, for Mr. Warren and his wife. Mr. Warren gave $12 million for the building, which will be occupied by the law and business schools.

title: Rich Can Fail, Too
description: To the Editor:

title: Newark Runway Reopens
description: The lights are on, the stripes are painted and Newark International Airport's longest runway is again ferrying planes. The $8.5 million project required the airport to pare traffic by 62 planes a day and called for a fleet of 160 trucks to chug more than 100,000 tons of asphalt from Rockway Township to the site. Round-the-clock work started on April 26.

title: Blame Britain, Not Truman
description: The sighs of relief in Switzerland are unmistakable. True, last week's American Government report on the failure of the Swiss to honor their legal and moral obligations to Holocaust survivors and the Allies was damning. But the document pointedly criticizes President Truman and his State Department for not compelling Switzerland to return assets that Nazi Germany looted during the war. Now the current Swiss Government has a convenient scapegoat: The United States cannot hold itself up as a moral paragon in the current debate.

title: ENTERING DEBATE, GOVERNOR OFFERS RENT COMPROMISE
description: In his first attempt to broker a compromise on rent regulations, Gov. George E. Pataki today proposed lifting protections for a small number of wealthy tenants immediately and appeared to lay the groundwork for a broader plan to remove controls from apartments as they become vacant.

title: A Great Wee Place
description: I just visited Northern Ireland and I have some bad news: The status quo there is too comfortable.

title: I.B.M. and Fujitsu agree to end arbitration.
description: I.B.M. and Fujitsu Ltd. of Japan, longtime bitter rivals, have buried the hatchet, agreeing to terminate an arbitration panel set up a decade ago to mediate a dispute about software.

title: Growing Latin Market Creates New Battleground of Cable TV
description: With more than 450 million potential viewers, Latin America offers a cable television market ripe for the plucking, and with that idea in mind, CNN began giving Latin Americans news around the clock in their own language in mid-March. But there is a complication: CBS already provides such a service, as do networks based in Mexico, Brazil and Spain.

title: On-Line Shopper Challenges the On-Foot Variety
description: In some parts of the country, consumers can do their grocery shopping on-line through services offered by companies like Illinois-based Peapod. To see how the shopping experience of an on-line shopper compared with that of a traditional on-foot shopper, The New York Times set up a race against the clock. Here is the scenario: It's 10 A.M. and a long-lost friend calls. She will be in town tomorrow, and our shopper invites her and her husband to dinner. Our shoppers decides to serve vichyssoise with aoili and grilled salmon with asparagus, pea and lime potato salad.

title: Kodak Account Gets Media Chief
description: The J. Walter Thompson Company and its sibling agency, Ogilvy & Mather Worldwide, named Bob Zach to the new position of worldwide media director for the two agencies' shared Eastman Kodak Company account. Mr. Zach's appointment comes six months after Thompson and Ogilvy, both owned by WPP Group, decided to jointly handle Kodak's worldwide media planning and buying account.

title: Victory, If No Ring, For Wells At Stadium
description: Moments of perfection were scattered throughout Yankee Stadium yesterday, and they had little to do with the splendid sunshine, the blue skies or the hot pretzels, all pleasant touches. They had everything to do with David Wells, in a sharp 3-2 victory over the Royals, and with one more flashback to 1996, when the Yankees were more nearly perfect than any other major league team.

title: Rural Callers May Pay More in Deregulation
description: On a lonely ribbon of road in Vermont, where ramshackle barns and brooding silos are the only milestones, you would not expect to find a thoroughly modern telecommunications company.

title: Joining the New Media: ABC News Begins an On-Line Service
description: New media is a curious hybrid of the traditional and the cutting edge, a blend of Gutenberg text and Internet software.

title: A Complete 'Cinderella,' But Short on Pumpkins
description: The Boston Ballet's new production of ''Cinderella'' introduces a British choreographer to watch on this side of the Atlantic: Michael Corder.

title: Ewing Levels Hardaway And the Heat With One Swipe
description: Patrick Ewing could see that Tim Hardaway was about to launch again. Half fearful, half fed up, Ewing remembered how the Miami Heat's chatterbox point guard had already shot the Knicks down once.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GIGANTE, YOLANDA
description: GIGANTE-Yolanda. The Board of Directors and employees of SEBCO Development, Inc. mourn the loss of Yolanda Gigante, mother of our Chairman, Father Louis R. Gigante. To her family, we extend our profound and heartfelt condolence.

title: Clamorously, Pacifica Radio Dances Toward Mainstream
description: Its name means ''peaceful'' in Spanish and its stated mission is to promote understanding among different groups of people. But financial pressure to reach a wider audience has supporters of Pacifica Radio, the left-oriented network based in Berkeley, Calif., in a rancorous argument over what goes on the air and who should decide.

title: A Grandmaster Sat at the Chessboard, but the Real Opponent Was Gates
description: Now that it has defeated the chess champion Garry Kasparov, can Deep Blue beat Bill Gates?

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GROSS, LEO
description: GROSS-Leo. On May 10, 1997. Age 82. Survived by his wife, Norma; his children, Alan (Penni Harmon), Terry (Victoria Kelly) and Jody (Perk Larsen); and his grandchildren Mowgli, Crystal, Lily, Daniel and Elliot. Memorial service May 16 at 2 PM, at the Ethical Culture Society, 2 West 64 Street at CPW. In lieu of flowers, donations can be made to the Visiting Nurse Service of NY, Hospice Care, 1250 Broadway, NY 10001, or Hospice of the Florida Keys, 1319 William Street, Key West, FL 33040.

title: Water Torture: The Politics Of Filtration
description: TURN on the tap in the East Village, East Harlem or other low-lying areas of Manhattan, and water comes gurgling through the pipes from New York City's Croton reservoir system. Aside from a dose of chlorine, this water reaches the faucet in a state of nature, untreated and unfiltered. Except, that is, during the summer, when the city shuts off the Croton system out of fear of burgeoning bacteria.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KLEIN, LOUIS F., JR.
description: KLEIN-Louis F., Jr., on May 10, 1997, of Douglaston, NY. Worked for the Jesuit Seminary and Mission Bureau. Beloved brother of Joan Mathilde Klein and Catherine Gloria McCawley. Son of the late Louis F. and the late Mary W. Klein. Devoted uncle of Joseph and Mary Theresa McCawley. Visiting in the Doyle B. Shaffer, Inc., Funeral Home, Little Neck Pkwy. and Northern Blvd., Little Neck, NY, on Monday, 2-4 and 7-9 PM. Mass of Christian Burial will be offered in St. Anastasia R.C. Church on Tuesday at 9:45 AM. Interment Mt. St. Mary's Cemetery. In lieu of flowers donations to the Jesuit Mission would be appreciated.

title: Fewer Challengers for Silver Charm
description: This is what it's like after you have won the Kentucky Derby, have two weeks to spend at Pimlico preparing for the Preakness and have the only horse in the universe who can sweep the Triple Crown: You go to a baseball game and throw out the first pitch.

title: Spider-Man and Mayor
description: To the Editor:

title: Optimism Dims For Agreement Over Tobacco
description: The initial optimism over the tobacco settlement talks has faded as negotiators head for a potential showdown over the pivotal issue of industry liability for smoking-related claims, people familiar with the talks say.

title: A Date With Brunnhilde? Come Prepared!
description: To the Editor:

title: A Logjam Of Openings, Then Angst
description: In the final weeks before the April 30 eligibility deadline for this year's Tony Awards, eight extremely expensive musicals opened on Broadway, four of them with entirely new scores, the largest cluster of spring musical openings since 1992 and the most with new scores in this decade.

title: 3 Concert Pieces, 3 Distinct Events
description: Although the typical symphony concert offers three pieces, relatively few offer three genuine and distinct events. Franz Welser-Most, a fast-rising Austrian conductor, and the New York Philharmonic did just that in the orchestra's series of subscription concerts that ended on Saturday. The program veered from mystical introversion, in Giya Kancheli's Third Symphony, to bravura extroversion, in Saint-Saens's First Cello Concerto, to an evolutionary process repeating that progression, in Sibelius's Second Symphony.

title: Ireland's Hard-Pressed Premier Seeks National Election in June
description: Prime Minister John Bruton, his integrity and his Northern Ireland policy under attack and his coalition Government slipping in the polls, said today that he would dissolve Parliament this week so a national election could be held in early June.

title: Poor Residents in Louisiana Fight Plan for Chemical Site
description: Emelda J. West said she believed that President Clinton was thinking of her when he signed an executive order on environmental justice in February 1994.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHOSBERG, THELMA
description: SCHOSBERG-Thelma. Devoted mother of Paul and Peter. Loving grandmother of Dr. Jill Stoller, Richard and Samantha Schosberg. Darling great-grandmother of three. Services were held May 11.

title: Allen F. Lovejoy, 77, a Lawyer And an Expert Collector of Dimes
description: Allen F. Lovejoy, a retired lawyer who was an eminent and single-minded collector of American coins, specializing exclusively in dimes, died on Thursday in the Mediplex rehabilitation center in Stamford, Conn. He was 77 and lived in Riverside, Conn.

title: Abalone Divers Face Sharks, Tides and Now Officials
description: When the seas and weather co operate about 50 days a year -- the fishermen guide their boats from a harbor just north here to the Farallon Islands, one of the last abalone beds open to commercial harvesting.

title: Dancing to Sound Bites Both Soothing and Jolting
description: As marketing and curiosity nudge electronica into the rock mainstream, the music is changing along with its audience. When the Orb performed on Friday night at the new Hammerstein Ballroom at Manhattan Center, the schedule was typical of dance-club shows.

title: Swiss Divestment Is Opposed
description: An alliance of 80 multinational companies has asked Gov. Christine Todd Whitman to block a bill that would force the state to divest its pension fund of $305 million in Swiss investments and deny state contracts to those who do business with the country, saying it would hurt the state's economy. The measure is intended to pressure Swiss officials into honoring their pledge to set up a $5 billion fund for Holocaust survivors and their families, said its co-sponsor, State Senator Robert W. Singer, Republican of Jackson.

title: INSIDE METRO
description: CHARGES IN SHOOTING -- Two men have been charged with attempted murder in the ambush and shooting of a retired police officer and his off-duty colleague in Queens on Friday. B3.

title: No Headline
description: ''I'm a human being. When I see something that is well beyond my understanding, I'm afraid.''

title: Graves's Overtime Wraparound Wraps It Up for the Rangers
description: The Rangers won the first round of the Stanley Cup playoffs but lost an important player to a broken leg. They clinched the second round today, three days after losing another important player to a broken arm.

title: CHRONICLE
description: AARON FEUERSTEIN, president and chief executive of Malden Mills Industries, and JEFFREY HOROWITZ, artistic director of the Theater for a New Audience, have much in common for two men who are strangers. They both survived catastrophic fires and both found strength in William Shakespeare.

title: From a Chinese Prison, Defiance
description: THE COURAGE TO STAND ALONE

title: How to get persnickety enzymes to do all those things that researchers want them to do.
description: Researchers have struggled for the last 30 years to harness for industrial and medical uses some of the 5,000 known enzymes, which act as miniature chemists by setting off chemical reactions. But because enzymes are so temperamental, this quest has proved difficult.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  FELDMAN, CLAIRE
description: FELDMAN-Claire. May 12, 1922November 3, 1996. My dearest sister, with your passing part of me has gone too, never to be replaced. We were inseparable for so many years, but not long enough. We share so many memorable experiences and confidences for which I am very grateful. You were a most loving and devoted daughter to Mom and Pop, and a beautiful and rare sister and best friend to me. Your intellect, integrity, sensitivity and ESP made you a very special person. Your high moral principles, never to be compromised, and your adherence to the truth were rare qualities. But it was your genuineness and humility that made people from all walks of life respond to you with friendship and respect. Those shining brown eyes and that magnetic smile reflected your God-given gift of caring and kindness. You were so proud to be a Hunter Class of '42 graduate, and had looked forward to your 55th Alumni Luncheon on May 10. Your love of learning was innate and all encompassing, as was your profound appreciation of the arts -music, avant garde films, ballet and theater. Attending lectures on religion, philosophy and literature was an important part of your life. How fortunate I was to be able to share these wonderful interests with you. As a public housing idealist, you undertook a 41 year career with the NYCHA, devoting yourself as an Assistant Manager. Your sense of responsibility was beyond the ''call of duty.'' Your utmost concern for your tenants, as well as your staff, won you much respect and many friendships. As a mentor who imparted your own life experiences, you motivated and inspired so many whose lives were turned around by your influence. The world is a lesser place without you. You graced it with dignity, decency and beauty. How very much you are missed by so many, especially me. You will be remembered and loved always. May you rest in peace. Your loving sister, Miriam

title: Battling Teen Pregnancy
description: According to recent Federal surveys, sexual activity among American teen-agers is down -- the first decline in nearly three decades -- and use of contraceptives is up. That is promising news as the nation with the highest teen pregnancy rate in the industrialized world tries for a 33 percent reduction in teen pregnancies by the year 2005. But no national effort can be successful without a focus on community-based solutions.

title: Company to Study Internet Advertising
description: Competitive Media Reporting in New York, a unit of VNU N.V. that tracks advertising spending, has formed a new company that will monitor advertising on the Internet. The new company, called Intermedia Advertising Solutions, will be headed by Joseph C. Philport, 48, as president. He has been an executive vice president at Competitive Media.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KELLY, JOHN A.
description: KELLY-John A. On May 9, 1997. Retired vice-president of Miller Druck Company, New York City. Loving husband of the late Dorothy (nee McAuliffe). Beloved father of John and Edward Kelly. Cherished grandfather and great grandfather. Reposing Monday, 25 and 7-9 PM, at Riverdale-on-Hudson Funeral Home, 6110 Riverdale Avenue. Mass of Christian Burial Tuesday, 10 AM, at St. Margaret of Cortona Church. Interment Gate of Heaven Cemetery.

title: For Cover Subject Of Time Magazine, A Time Warner Deal
description: Time Inc. knows synergy.

title: Canadian Birders Win
description: A team of Canadians defeated 56 other groups with names like Bird Nerds, Ternimatorsc and Team Dodo to win the 14th annual World Series of Birding on Sunday. The winners, the Kowa Optimed, sighted 217 species, beating their closest rival, the Birders World magazine team, the Butcherbirds, by six sightings.

title: Swift, Hard Attack in Bombing Trial
description: The Government's case against Timothy J. McVeigh, which appeared in pretrial hearings and disclosures to be based on coincidences, dubious witnesses, and problematic physical evidence, has turned out instead to be a compelling tale of conspiracy and revenge told by the defendant's family and closest friends and in words he wrote himself.

title: Barnes & Noble Set to Open Its On-Line Service
description: After a year of preparation, Barnes & Noble Inc. -- the nation's largest bookselling chain -- is poised to open the virtual doors of a new electronic bookstore that will offer discounts that are more generous than its superstore bargains.

title: INSIDE
description: The Price of Arab Land

title: 2 Shops Merge In Toronto
description: The Toronto office of D'Arcy Masius Benton & Bowles Communications has merged with another shop in Toronto, Bensimon-Byrne. The combined agency, which becomes the 15th largest in Canada, has billings estimated at $88 million from clients like Procter & Gamble and Blockbuster Entertainment.

title: Treasury Schedules Bill Sales
description: The Treasury's schedule of financings this week is confined to today's regular weekly auction of three- and six-month bills.

title: Rome Stung by Cool Reception to Efforts To Join Club of the Common Currency : Italy Wants the Euro, But Does Euro Want It?
description: ROME  A few weeks ago, when a European Commission interim report found Italy falling short of the requirements to join Europe's common currency in 1999, the newspaper La Repubblica published this headline:

title: Reduced to Dust
description: Dr. William Cahan remembers dropping by the dressing room of Yul Brynner during the original run of ''The King and I'' in the early-1950's. ''You could barely see that famous bald head through the cloud of cigarette smoke,'' said Dr. Cahan, a renowned cancer surgeon and at the time the son-in-law of Mr. Brynner's co-star, Gertrude Lawrence.

title: Surprise Starter Hextall Helps Set Up Flyer-Ranger Series
description: It has been 10 years since Ron Hextall starred in the playoffs. In 1987, as a brash and combative rookie, he loudly slapped the goal posts in a pre-game ritual, broke with convention to chase down loose pucks and won the most valuable player award for the playoffs in leading the Philadelphia Flyers to the Stanley Cup finals.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KOLATCH, ESTHER H.
description: KOLATCH-Esther H. Beloved sister of Jean Pickman, Pearl Goodman, and the late Isidore, Philip, Bernard and Rabbi Ephraim. Cherished aunt and great-aunt. Shiva at her home through Friday morning.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BENDHEIM, CHARLES HENRY
description: BENDHEIM - Charles Henry. Passed away Saturday, May 10, at his home in Jerusalem, Israel, and was interred there on May 11. He will be sorely missed by wife, sister, children, grandchildren and great-grandchildren, and by everyone he came in contact with. The family will sit shiva in Jerusalem until Tuesday evening, May 13; Fax 972-2-625-3843; email bendheim@inter.net.il. Thereafter, shiva will continue at 4680 Livingston Ave., Riverdale, NY, through Friday, May 16.

title: Rangers Move On; Knicks Win, Too
description: The long reach of Adam Graves and Patrick Ewing helped give the Rangers and Knicks dramatic victories in their playoff series yesterday, with the Rangers' triumph over the Devils putting them in the semifinals of the Stanley Cup tournament.

title: 2 Shot at Fashion Show
description: A charity fashion show turned into a bloody brawl early Saturday, ending in an attempted carjacking and leaving two people with gunshot wounds, officials said. Fighting erupted in a ballroom of the Clinton Manor Banquet Hall in Union around 1 A.M., then spilled outside, the police said. A 19-year-old man from Plainfield was shot three times in the chest during the attempted carjacking, and a 35-year-old man was shot in the leg and buttocks, the police said. Both were in stable condition, and one faced charges.

title: Two States Investigate Film Company's On-Line Request for Investors
description: Officials in California and New York are investigating whether Destiny Pictures, a fledgling film production company in Los Angeles, violated any securities regulations when it offered stock in a low-budget movie over the Internet.

title: Swift and Slashing, Computer Topples Kasparov
description: In brisk and brutal fashion, the I.B.M. computer Deep Blue unseated humanity, at least temporarily, as the finest chess playing entity on the planet yesterday, when Garry Kasparov, the world chess champion, resigned the sixth and final game of the match after just 19 moves, saying, ''I lost my fighting spirit.''

title: Checkmate, Mr. Blue?
description: To the Editor:

title: Lots of Nostalgia, But Still No Bolt From the Blue
description: The elevator opened and out came a few of the visiting all-stars: Francis Ford Coppola, Pedro Almodovar, Sydney Pollack, Emir Kusturica and the juror Tim Burton, all heading for the group photo session to commemorate today's lavish celebration of the Cannes International Film Festival's 50th birthday. Robert Altman, Mike Leigh, Chen Kaige and Martin Scorsese had arrived a few moments before. All over town, the world's pre-eminent veteran film makers had begun to materialize, and when any two of them turned up in the same place, flashbulbs started popping. The concentration of talent clearly dazzled even the directors. Some of them brandished pocket cameras and took souvenir snapshots of one another.

title: Two Shot at Brawl During Fashion Show
description: A charity fashion show turned into a bloody brawl early Saturday, ending in an attempted carjacking and leaving two victims with gunshot wounds, officials said.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-11

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GRAY, AUSTEN T.
description: GRAY-Austen T., died May 9 at the age of 89. Beloved husband of Milo, loving father of Phyllis Heaton, Alice Standteiner, Pamela Resse and Austen T. Gray Jr. Adored grandfather of 13 and great grandfather of 7. Mr. Gray was managing director of Trainor Wortham, honorary director of the New York Eye & Ear Infirmary and Trustee Emeritus at Fay School, Southboro, MA. Service on Monday, May 12, 11 AM, St. John's Episcopal Church, Cold Spring Harbor, LI. Donations appreciated to New York Eye & Ear Infirmary, 2nd Ave & 14th Street, NYC 10003.

title: Harbor to Be Dredged, but Much Tainted Mud Lacks Home
description: Sometime this week, after years of delays, a floating dredge is scheduled to begin scooping thousands of tons of accumulated mud from one of the main channels plied by the container ships that carry televisions, orange juice, furniture and almost every other imported or exported product into and out of New York Harbor.

title: Canadian Team Wins Birding Competition
description: A team of Canadi ans beat out 56 other groups with names like Bird Nerds, Ternimators and Team Dodo -- to win the 14th annual World Series of Birding yesterday.

title: Your Own Law Library (No Shelves Required)
description: If you picture the classic tomes lining legal chambers, it seems that law and publishing go hand in hand. So the match looks perfect for putting law on the Internet, where the subject's vastness suits the limitless medium, and electronic searching is a godsend.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCGINTY, JEROME
description: McGINTY-Jerome. Huntington, formerly of Brookville. Retired President, Mill Master Onyx Corp. Beloved husband of the late Constance Donnelly McGinty. Devoted father of Constance Tallman, Gregory, Mark, Sean and William. Loving grandfather of Matthew and Sarah Tallman, Michael, Brendan, Caroline, Haley, Kerri, Sean, Kimberly and Luke McGinty. Dear brother of Mary Piderit and Kathleen. Visitation Monday, 2-5 and 7-9 PM at Connell Funeral Home, 934 New York Avenue, Huntington. Mass Tuesday, 9:45 AM, St. Patrick's Church. In lieu of flowers donations to Fordham University or VNS-Hospice, 505 Main St., Northport, NY 11768.

title: Ring Means Different Things to Different People
description: The valuable possessions were perched inside World Series championship mahogany boxes and were arrayed two by two on a long, wooden table in front of home plate yesterday afternoon at Yankee Stadium. The Yankees sat on the edge of the dugout or peeked through the sunshine for glimpses at the rings they had waited six and a half months to receive.

title: Bulls' Laugher Suddenly Turns Serious
description: Chicago's extra-large lead seemed to become a laughing gas for some of the Bulls today, turning them into a giddy team all but skipping down the Atlanta Hawks' home floor.

title: Prototype Internet Name Is Sold for $100,000-Plus
description: What's in a name? On the Internet, plenty. And if you ask Robert Raisch, at least $100,000.

title: Importance Of Being Modern
description: There is something extremely moving about artists who are at the crossroads between two centuries. The best ones sum up what is past, embody what is passing and intimate what is to come. Or, as Oscar Wilde said, more stringently: ''The past is what man should not have been. The present is what man ought not to be. The future is what artists are.''

title: Dividend Meetings
description: MONDAY

title: O'Connor, Seeing Housing as a Right, Calls for a Panel to Advise Lawmakers
description: Calling ''dignified affordable housing'' a human right and a moral imperative, John Cardinal O'Connor urged state lawmakers yesterday to preserve the current rent regulation laws until a panel could examine changes that would not hurt the poor and middle class.

title: Critical Race Theorists Perpetuate Stereotypes
description: To the Editor:

title: Correction
description: An article Saturday about war disability pensions paid to SS veterans by the German Government misidentified the group that criticized the payments in newspaper advertisements. It is the American Jewish Committee, not the American Jewish Congress.

title: Inscrutable Conqueror
description: When it was all over yesterday, when the greatest chess player in history had been crushed, the machine that had done it -- I.B.M.'s RS/ 6000 SP, alias Deep Blue -- did the magnanimous thing: it kept its monastic silence. After days of Man-versus-Machine hyperbole, those who had looked to Garry Kasparov as the last best hope could now only bemoan the coming days of ascendant computers.

title: Palestinian Land Edict
description: To the Editor:

title: Cognitive Game Isn't Up by Baby's First Year
description: To the Editor:

title: Defining Deviancy
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STERN, YANA
description: STERN-Yana. Beloved wife of the late Elliot. Devoted mother of Leslie and Vicki. Cherished grandmother of Ami. Services Tuesday, 10 AM, at ''Gutterman's, Inc.,'' 175 Long Beach Road, Rockville Centre, LI. In lieu of flowers, please contribute to Cancer Care.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KREICHMAN, LILLIAN
description: KREICHMAN-Lillian, 87. Beloved mother of Jerry (Ellen) and Nikki Wilkenfeld (Merrel). Grandmother of Steven, Mindy, Randi, Scott, and Brian. Great-grandmother of five. Funeral services were held in Florida.

title: Muslims Protest Turkish Curbs on Religion
description: In a graphic sign of the growing conflicts shaking Turkish society, a large crowd packed one of Istanbul's historic plazas today to protest a military-backed plan to restrict religious education.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LOVINGER, JOSEPH
description: LOVINGER-Joseph. Beloved husband of Abbie. Devoted father of Dawn and Gary Rosenfeld, Elizabeth and John Lane, Daniel and Linda Lovinger, and Nicole Lovinger. Dear brother of Merle and Steve Brenner. Loving grandfather of Alexander, Nicholas, Casey, Matthew, Thomas and Courtney. Cherished son-in-law of Harry Greene and favorite uncle of many. Services today, 12:30 PM, at Westchester Reform Temple, 255 Mamaroneck Rd., Scarsdale, NY.

title: Isringhausen Feeling Fine, But Still Awaits Answers
description: More than a week has passed since doctors told Jason Isringhausen they believe he has tuberculosis. Today, the Mets' pitcher said he feels ''100 percent better,'' physically and mentally.

title: Battery Park City Authority Chooses Builder for First Hotel
description: The Battery Park City Authority said yesterday that it had selected the Forest City Ratner Companies to build a 14-story, 400-room Embassy Suite Hotel and entertainment complex, breaking a logjam that had delayed construction of Battery Park City's first hotel.

title: Party Led By Mandela Now Owns Up To Atrocities
description: South Africa's governing party admitted today that it used torture, executions, and land mines during its fight against apartheid, opening a new chapter in this country's efforts to come to terms with its past.

title: F.A.A. to Require Ice Detector on a Brazil-Made Turboprop
description: The Federal Aviation Administration said today that a Brazilian-built turboprop of the type that crashed near Detroit in January was unusually vulnerable to icing and that the agency would require all planes of that model flying in the United States to be fitted with ice-detection equipment.

title: Expose on Crack Was Flawed, Paper Says
description: In a highly unusual critique published in his own newspaper, the editor of The San Jose Mercury News acknowledged on Sunday that a series of articles last year on the rise of crack cocaine in urban America was marred by shortcomings, including its strong implication that the Central Intelligence Agency had countenanced the drug's spread in league with Nicaraguan dealers.

title: Straws to Clutch
description: When the sandals come out and the boots are put away for the season, it's also time to replace heavy leather handbags and totes with lightweight straws.

title: Europeans to Attach Terms To Boeing-McDonnell Deal
description: The European Commission's top antitrust official, calling the Boeing Company's plan for buying the McDonnell Douglas Corporation ''totally unacceptable,'' said a letter would be sent within 10 days detailing conditions Boeing must meet to win European approval of the deal.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GROSS, LEO
description: GROSS-Leo. On May 10, 1997. Age 82. Survived by his wife, Norma; his children, Alan (Penni Harmon), Terry (Victoria Kelly) and Jody (Perk Larsen); and his grandchildren Mowgli, Crystal, Lily, Daniel and Elliot. Memorial service May 16 at 2 PM, at the Ethical Culture Society, 2 West 64 Street at CPW. In lieu of flowers, donations can be made to the Visiting Nurse Service of NY, Hospice Care, 1250 Broadway, New York 10001, or Hospice of the Florida Keys, 1319 William Street, Key West, Florida 33040.

title: Global Central Bank Says It Held Gold Looted by Nazis
description: In another tangled chapter in the ''Nazi gold'' affair, the Swiss-based Bank for International Settlements, which American officials suspected during World War II was acting in collaboration with Nazi leaders, confirmed today that gold transactions with the Germans included looted gold and ingots re-smelted in Nazi Germany to disguise their origin.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Emerging From Obscurity, Andy Bey and His 3 Voices
description: At least a generation has passed since male singers ceased to be a common embodiment of jazz. They began disappearing with the decline of the big bands in the 50's, and by the time Miles Davis and John Coltrane had fully replaced Billy Eckstine and Cab Calloway as the music's symbolic masculine heroes, the vocalist was a role generally designated for women.

title: Paxson to Buy WBIS From Dow Jones and ITT
description: Paxson Communications, the king of infomercials, completed an agreement yesterday to acquire the New York television station WBIS for $257.5 million from its co-owners, Dow Jones Inc. and the ITT Corporation.

title: The liquor industry may now wind up in a big merger spree.
description: THAT the chairman of Grand Metropolitan P.L.C. would sit down to dinner with the chairman of Guinness P.L.C. to discuss a merger was no surprise in a global liquor industry that has been consolidating for years. But the proposed combination of the two companies yesterday into a $22.27 billion giant that mixes Johnnie Walker whisky and Gordon's gin with Smirnoff vodka is expected to spur a new round of megamergers.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KELLY, JOHN A. MILLER
description: KELLY-John A. Miller Druck Co, Inc. regrets to announce the passing of John A. Kelly. Mr. Kelly was a long-time, valuable member of our family. It is with deep sympathy that we offer our condolences and prayers to his family and friends.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WALSH, MARGARET A. (MAGUIRE)
description: WALSH-Margaret A. (Maguire), 75, of Elizabeth NJ on May 11, beloved wife of the late George R. Walsh devoted mother-in-law of Mrs. Beverly J. Walsh and Mrs. Georgina Hackett. She will be deeply missed by her 11 grandchildren & 17 great grandchildren. Mass of Christian burial Thursday 9:30 A.M., St. Michael Church, Cranford. Friends may visit Dooley Funeral Home, 218 North Avenue Cranford, New Jersey, on Wednesday 2-4 and 7-9. Interment Evergreen Cemetery, Hillside, NJ. Please make donations in her name to the Humane Society.

title: Adolph Rupp, Rick Pitino, Tubby Smith
description: A black man is coaching basketball at the University of Kentucky. The school of Adolph Rupp has hired Orlando (Tubby) Smith, an insider, an establishment guy.

title: Steepest Hikes Are Expected Chiefly in Parts of Manhattan
description: Under one scenario, the character of dozens of neighborhoods in New York City would be radically altered within a decade, as gentrification swept the poor and middle-class out of areas with the best schools, the best views and the least crime.

title: Tattoo Bill Clears Committee
description: Teen-agers looking to get their ankles tattooed or their navels pierced might soon have to undergo a potentially more painful procedure first: getting permission. Yesterday, an Assembly committee cleared a bill requiring tattoo and body-piercing parlors to get written consent from a parent of any customer under 18 for anything other than pierced ears.

title: Second Ex-Paratrooper Gets Life In North Carolina Racial Killings
description: A former Army paratrooper who is white and who was found guilty of murdering a black couple in Fayetteville, N.C., was spared the death penalty today.

title: Poodle Still at Large
description: A 30-pound show poodle that escaped from its carrying crate at Atlantic City International Airport and bit a baggage worker in the face remained at large for a third day yesterday, evading a dozen animal control officers and causing occasional delays by scurrying in terror across active runways, airport officials said. Rusty, an 8-month-old chocolate poodle, arrived on a plane from Florida Saturday. The baggage worker needed 70 stitches and possible reconstructive surgery.

title: BANKERS TRUST REPORTEDLY DISCUSSING SALE OF CHILE UNIT
description: The Bankers Trust New York Corporation is in talks to sell its Chilean life insurance unit, Consorcio Nacional de Seguros de Vida, to a local investment group for about $400 million, people familiar with the discussions said yesterday. If an agreement were reached, the New York bank would sell Consorcio to a group controlled by the Said and Massu families, the sources said. Consorcio, Chile's largest life insurer, generated $61 million in premium revenue in the first quarter. Bankers Trust does not break out profit from the unit. The Said and Massu families own the Coca-Cola bottler Embotelladora Andina S.A. and the life insurer Bhifamerica.

title: Philadelphia Seeks To Market Itself
description: New York City's diet of culture and entertainment is so rich that many residents are hard pressed to sample even a small part of the exhibitions, concerts, readings, walking tours and must-try restaurants that vie for attention. And now they have Philadelphia to consider.

title: INSIDE METRO
description: THE SECRETS OF DEEP BLUE -- The people who program Deep Blue let out some of its secrets. B2.

title: Students Chosen for Grants To Attend Private Schools
description: Each day over the last two months, Mayra Oliveras stopped whatever she was doing for a moment, closed her eyes and asked God to answer a simple prayer: that her two young sons, Michael and Angel, would be awarded scholarships to enable them to attend a Catholic school.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCGINNESS, ARTHUR F.
description: McGINNESS-Arthur F. On May 11, 1997. Beloved husband of the late Mary Dailey McGinness. Loving father of Eugenia Singer. Devoted grandfather of Gregory, Maureen and Sheila. Dear brother of Josephine Connelly. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave at 81 St, Wednesday, 4-7 PM. Mass of Christian Burial at Saint Ignatius Loyola Church, Park Ave at 84 St, Thursday, 11 AM. In lieu of flowers, contributions in his memory may be made to Regis H.S., 55 East 84 Street, NY NY 10028.

title: Excerpts From Letter by San Jose Editor
description: Following are excerpts from a column by the executive editor of The San Jose Mercury News as recorded from its Web site:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NEUBERGER, MARIE SALANT
description: NEUBERGER-Marie Salant, 88, died on May 11th, 1997. Beloved wife of Roy R. Neuberger for nearly sixty-five years. Devoted mother of Ann Aceves, Roy S. and Linda Neuberger, and James Neuberger. Treasured grandmother of Andrea, Patricia and Matthew London, Sarah Lancry, Yaffa Jungreis and Miriam, Aharon and Nechama Neuberger, great-grandmother of seven. Cherished sister of Walter and Edna Salant and the late William Salant and his widow, Dorothy. Mrs. Neuberger was a past president of the Women's City Club of New York, former chairman of the Board of Governors of The Ethical Culture Schools for thirteen years and a member of the Board of Trustees of Bryn Mawr College, her alma mater. In lieu of flowers, a contribution to any of the above organizations would be appreciated. Graveside services were held at Mount Neboh Cemetery, Queens, on Monday, May 12. A memorial service will be announced.

title: Return of Antarctic Seals
description: In the 19th century, American and British sealers nearly wiped out Antarctic fur seals. But in recent years, scientists and Antarctic tourists have noticed a seal population explosion.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  AMSTER, MILDRED LOEB
description: AMSTER-Mildred Loeb, passed away May 12, 1997 in Los Angeles. Widow of Philip; mother of Judith (Lawrence) Cowan; grandmother of Andrew and Jennifer Cowan.

title: Lawyers May Seek Delay In Gigante Murder Trial
description: Lawyers for the suspected Mafia boss Vincent Gigante said yesterday that they may seek another postponement in his long-delayed murder and racketeering trial, because doctors found he might have Alzheimer's disease.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FELDMAN, FLORENCE (ROSS)
description: FELDMAN-Florence (Ross), of Scarsdale, NY peacefully on Mother's Day. Beloved wife of the late Joseph Ross and Arnold Feldman. Beloved mother of Joan Israel and James Ross. Loving grandmother of John, Lynn, Diane, Robert Israel and Robert, Richard, James, Jennifer and Michael Ross. Proud grandmother of Jorin Israel Becker, Avi Becker, and Corry Ross. Companion of Montelle Prescott. Memorial service to be announced later. Donations in her memory to Westchester A.R.C., 74 Westmoreland Avenue, White Plains, New York 10606.

title: No Skin Off Oakley's Knees: Youth Served Another Playoff Loss
description: This was the night when the Knicks might have been limping around like the old buzzards they truly are. Patrick Ewing could have been eating Alonzo Mourning's dust, and Charles Oakley could have been looking up at P. J. Brown's heels. Pat Riley's team, annually anointed the most physically fit in the history of modern sports, was said to have the Knicks exactly where it wanted them: back at Madison Square Garden 29 hours after they had previously met.

title: A Man of Few Words Is Sent Up by a Man of Few Acts
description: With ''Mere Mortals and Others,'' a collection of six fast and ferociously funny comedies, that professional tease of a playwright, David Ives, is back at the top of his game. He has fashioned a madcap evening of one-acts at Primary Stages on West 45th Street that reconfirms his status as a maestro of the short form. By evening's end, your mood may be so improved that you may want to hunt him down and pinch his cheek.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LESSNER, GEORGE
description: LESSNER-George, beloved husband of the late Lorraine. Devoted father of Alford and Helen Lessner, Robert and Patricia Lessner. Dear brother of Lucy Gemes. Loving grandfather of Joanne and Katherine Lessner, Debra Gioquindo, Peter Lessner and Donna Green. Loving great-grandfather of six. Services Wednesday 10AM, May 14, at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 21 West Broad Street, Mount Vernon, New York.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HANFLING, PAULINE
description: HANFLING-Pauline, on May 12, 1997. Beloved wife of the late Louis. Devoted mother of Elaine Dannheisser and the late Herbert and Marilyn. Loving grandmother of Jason and Griffith, and great grandmother of Ryan, Caitlin, Alexandra and Austin. Dear sister of Helen. Service today, Tuesday, May 13, 2PM, Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave. at 81 Street.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PLOTTEL, FRANCES
description: PLOTTEL-Frances. The Jewish Center mourns the passing of our longtime member. May her entire family be comforted among all who mourn for Zion and Jerusalem. Dr. Jacob J. Schacter, Rabbi Samuel Goldman, President Elza Weinman, Sisterhood

title: South African Jet Order
description: Bombardier Inc. said today that South African Express of Johannesburg had agreed to buy six Canadair regional jet aircraft for about $130 million. Deliveries are scheduled to be made between August 1997 and May 1998. The 50-seat jetliners will be used on South African Express and South African Airways routes. The airlines are units of Transnet, the South African transportation conglomerate. Bombardier is based in Montreal.

title: Palestinian Christians
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CAIATI, ELIZABETH D.
description: CAIATI-Elizabeth D. of Bronxville, N.Y. on May 12, 1997. Beloved wife of the late Michael. Devoted mother of Vito and Joseph. Mother-in-law of Judith and Joana. Grandmother of Joseph Jr., Lauren, Jennifer, Michael A., Michael E., Kimberly, Christopher, James, and Suzanne. Sister of Grace Tangorra, F. Joseph D'Andrea and the late Katherine Genovese. Calling hours at the Fred H. Mc Grath & Son Funeral Home, Bronxville, between the hours of 8:30AM-9:30AM Thursday. Mass of Christian burial St. Joseph's Church, Bronxville on Thursday, May 15 at 10 A.M.

title: A Foolish Distraction The Mets Don't Need
description: What's the old saying about how the only luck someone has is bad luck? That description fits the Mets perfectly today.

title: Silver Charm Sails
description: Silver Charm, the Kentucky Derby winner, worked out at Pimlico Race Course in Baltimore yesterday, his last serious training session for the 122d Preakness Stakes on Saturday afternoon.

title: SAKHALIN ENERGY STAKE BRINGS MCDERMOTT $122 MILLION
description: McDermott International Inc. said yesterday that the sale of its 20 percent stake in the Sakhalin Energy Investment Company would raise its first-quarter profits by $95 million. McDermott, based in New Orleans, is an energy services company. Sakhalin Energy Investment is a consortium that plans to develop an oil and natural gas field offshore from Russia's Sakhalin Island. McDermott's interest in Sakhalin was bought for $122 million last month by its partners in the consortium, the Marathon Oil Company, with 37.5 percent; Mitsui & Company of Japan, with 25 percent; the Royal Dutch/Shell Group, with 25 percent, and the Mitsubishi Corporation, with 12.5 percent.

title: Treasuries Flat Ahead Of New Data
description: Prices of Treasury securities ended little changed yesterday in thin trading. Bonds were supported by expectations that today's retail sales report would be weak, providing new signs of a slowing economy.

title: Met Pitcher Is Taking a New Path From Japan
description: Hideo Nomo is a hero in Japan, having demonstrated, as a star pitcher for the Los Angeles Dodgers, that the best and the brightest baseball players from his homeland could compete in major league baseball.

title: Policewoman Talks Man Down From a Bridge
description: Perched on a narrow cable high atop the George Washington Bridge, roughly 40 stories above the Hudson River, a policewoman talked a distraught New Jersey man out of committing suicide yesterday morning, the police said.

title: Japan's Ambassador to Peru Resigns Over Hostage Crisis
description: The Japanese Ambassador to Peru, whose fighting spirit helped keep peace of mind among his 70 fellow hostages for four months in Lima, announced his resignation this morning to the Japanese Parliament.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROSENBERG, MAURICE N.
description: ROSENBERG-Maurice N. On May 10, 1997. Beloved husband of Ruth and uncle of Andy.

title: Now Every Problem Will Become a 'Disability'
description: To the Editor:

title: How Smart Can It Be?
description: To the Editor:

title: WHITE HOUSE SEEKS TO REVERSE RULING ON LAWYERS' NOTES
description: The White House asked the Supreme Court today to overturn a Federal appeals court ruling that notes taken by White House lawyers in meetings with Hillary Rodham Clinton must be surrendered to the Whitewater independent counsel.

title: Hard Liquor in a Tough Market
description: The huge merger announced yesterday by two of the world's food and drink giants, Grand Metropolitan P.L.C. and Guinness P.L.C., represents a multibillion-dollar version of a bar bet between friendly rivals.

title: AMERICAN TOPICS : City Dwellers Rush to Purchase A Piece of Nowhere in Nevada
description: For city dwellers tired of soot, smog and congestion, it seemed a dream: to own a square mile of land in the vast, empty expanses of Nevada, far from the madding crowd, in a place without squealing brakes or barking dogs or slamming doors, where at night, as one admirer put it, "the stars come all the way down to the ground.'

title: Why Did Kasparov Lose? Perhaps He Tried Too Hard
description: Looking back over the match between Garry Kasparov and Deep Blue, it seems clear that the outcome was determined by a combination of two factors: a slightly flawed strategy by the world champion and tremendous, bone-wearying resistance by the marvelous machine.

title: A Way to Compromise on Rents
description: Only a month before the expiration of New York City's rent laws, Gov. George Pataki has proposed a reasonable compromise to phase out rent regulations while protecting tenants from drastic rent increases. Under the measure he put on the table yesterday, landlords could raise rents freely only after current tenants or their families move out or die. This idea, known as ''vacancy decontrol,'' would be accompanied by another measure known as ''luxury decontrol,'' raising rents immediately for tenants making $175,000 or more. The Legislature may want to tinker with some features of Mr. Pataki's proposal, but over all it deserves support.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  EPSTEIN, SYLVIA B.
description: EPSTEIN-Sylvia B., on May 11th, 1997. Beloved wife of the late David. Loving mother of Daniel and Joel. Cherished grandmother of five. Services Tuesday, 1:15 PM, at ''The Riverside'', 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Ahmanson Starts Exchange Offer
description: H. F. Ahmanson & Company began an exchange offer yesterday for the stock of the Great Western Financial Corporation, but the deal is contingent on a repeal of Great Western's poison pill shareholder rights plan.

title: D'Amato Starts TV Ads 19 Months Before Vote
description: Nearly 19 months before his name will appear on the ballot, Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato has launched a series of television advertisements in selected parts of New York State, aimed at burnishing his image on two areas where he is seen as particularly vulnerable: the environment and women's issues.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KREICHMAN, LILLIAN
description: KREICHMAN-Lillian, 87. Beloved mother of Jerry (Ellen) and Nikki Wilkenfeld (Merrel). Grandmother of Steven, Mindy, Randi, Harriet, Scott, and Brian. Great-grandmother of five. Funeral services were held in Florida.

title: IVACO SELLS 138-ACRE ATLANTA PARCEL FOR $76 MILLION
description: Ivaco Inc., a Canadian steelmaker, said yesterday that it had agreed to sell a 138-acre property in midtown Atlanta to Jacoby Development Inc. for $76 million. Ivaco, based in Montreal, is the parent company of Atlantic Steel Inc., which has owned the property for nearly a century. In November, Ivaco agreed to sell its Atlantic Steel plants in Cartersville, Ga., and Jackson, Miss., to the Birmingham Steel Corporation for $75 million. Jacoby, based in Atlanta, is a retail development company. It wants to use the property as the site for 600,000 square feet of retail establishments, two hotels, an entertainment center, 2,000 apartment units and 2 million square feet of office space.

title: Study Finds Public Science Is Pillar Of Industry
description: A NEW study has found strong evidence that publicly financed scientific research plays a surprisingly important role in the breakthroughs of industrial innovation in the United States, suggesting that impending cuts in the Federal science budget might eventually hurt the economy.

title: Coaches Hit Links and Talk Shop
description: The Cadillac National Football League Golf Classic began its fifth season today at the Upper Montclair Country Club with practice rounds for several PGA Senior Tour players, 56 National Football League players and 8 head coaches.

title: Finding Out Who the Man Called Daddy Was
description: ANYTHING YOUR LITTLE HEART DESIRES

title: Computer Morale
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HAWKS, GRAHAM G., DR.
description: HAWKS-Graham G., Dr. The council and fellows of the New York Obstetrical society record with profound regret the death of their life fellow Dr. Graham Hawks on February 15, 1997. Livia Wan, M.D., President Richard Berkowitz, MD, Secretary

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ELLISON, ARNOLD
description: ELLISON-Arnold. Young Israel of Fifth Avenue mourns the death of our distinguished Chief Financial Officer and dear friend, and extends to Abby and to Ian and Steven our empathy and our love.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WHITSETT, CURTIS MOSLEY
description: WHITSETT-Curtis Mosley. Beloved husband of Patricia, devoted father of Curice, Camille, Jackline and Tamara. Cherished son of Vera and L.T. Whitsett, friend and counsellor to many, died May 10, 1997 in New York of congestive heart failure. Curtis was a friend, in his youth, of Martin Luther King, Jr., and participated in several civil rights marches with Dr. King. At his death, he was the director of Intake at Reality House, a drug rehabilitation program. Curt was equally proud of his career and his family. He was principled and a gentleman in the finest sense of that word. The world has been enriched by his presence. He will be missed by all who knew him. Funeral May 14, 6:30 P.M., at Walter B. Cooke, West 72nd Street. The family requests that in lieu of flowers contributions be sent to the Children's Blood Foundation, 333 East 38th Street, New York City 10016.

title: In NBC's Prime-Time Shuffle, Changes for the Fall
description: After ending their game of chicken with the co-stars of ''Seinfeld'' on Friday, NBC executives could breathe a sigh of relief because the most popular show on television will be back on Thursday nights next season.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHWARZFARB, ROSE
description: SCHWARZFARB-Rose. Riverdale Jewish Center extends profound condolences on the loss of its member, Rose Schwarzfarb. May the family be comforted amongst the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Jonathan I. Rosenblatt, Rabbi Tobias B. Schapiro, President

title: Brilliant Scanning, Dumb Design
description: IN the computer world, wonders and blunders never cease. The latest wonder is a photo scanner that can deliver quality previously unavailable at anything resembling a reasonable price. The latest blunder is peripheral hardware and software that can make getting the scanner installed and keeping it running about as easy as spinning a plate on the end of a very long stick. Unless luck is with you, this precision instrument can quickly become an instrument of torture.

description: The Power of Tenderness,

title: Apple to Preview New Operating System
description: Apple Computer Inc., still trying to find the comeback trail, will reach a crucial milestone on Tuesday, when the company demonstrates an early version of the new operating system software on which Apple is staking its future.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SARETSKY, PHILIP
description: SARETSKY-Philip. His family mourns the loss of their beloved father, grandfather and greatgrandfather at the age of 99 years. Philip was a husband of 72 years to his late wife Estelle and is survived by his children Ruth Brooks, Muriel and Mel Brown, Erwin Raffle, 8 grandchildren and 16 great-grandchildren. Born in NYC in 1897. He was a Shriner and a Mason for over 70 years. Services will be held in Los Angeles.

description: Venezuelan Coke Bottler In $1.2 Billion Sale

title: Lean, Mean, Love Ya
description: Why is it that when gigantic corporations say they are in business to enrich our lives, 250 million Americans do not rise as one and cry out, ''Oh, stuff it!''?

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ZAKARIAN, BEVERLY
description: ZAKARIAN-Beverly. On May 11, 1997. Beloved wife of Robert. Devoted mother of Daisy Zakarian Madison and son-in-law of John Madison. Co-Founder and Executive Director of C-A-N-A-C-T, the first cancer patient advocacy group. Mrs. Zakarian represented patient issues before Congress, the President's Cancer Panel and FDA committees. She was the first FDA Oncology Fellow appointed as a representative of cancer survivors to participate in the review process for new cancer therapies. Mrs. Zakarian is the author of ''The Activist Cancer Patient'' and numerous articles which appeared in the popular press and medical journals. Her unswerving commitment and passionate voice for cancer patients will be greatly missed. Services at Riverside Chapel, 180 West 76th Street, N.Y. at 6PM, Tuesday, May 13th. Contributions may be made to The Chemotherapy Foundation, 183 Madison Ave., NY, NY 10016.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DERSHANSKY, JEAN
description: DERSHANSKY-Jean. Loving wife of the late Jack. Devoted mother of Sandra, Barry and Anita. Cherished grandmother and greatgrandmother. Funeral services Tuesday, 11:30 AM, at Gramercy Park Memorial Chapel, 152 2nd Avenue, New York City.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  YOUNG, ALEXANDER WILLIAM JR.
description: YOUNG-Alexander William Jr. The faculty and staff of the Department of Dermatology at the College of Physicians and Surgeons of Columbia University, Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center, & the St. Luke's Roosevelt Medical Center mourn the passing of our esteemed friend and colleague. Dr. Young was a distinguished member of the faculty in our department since 1967 when he was appointed the first full-time Director of the Dermatology Service at St. Luke's Hospital. He was a dedicated teacher to generations of students & house officers and was a valued member of our community who contributed to its quality in a unique way. We extend our deepest sympathy and sincere condolences to his family.

title: Rules Tightened At Occidental
description: The Occidental Petroleum Corporation said yesterday that it had adopted policies to strengthen its internal controls in its dealings with foreign governments and businessmen.

title: New Meaning for Children's Cruelty to Children
description: What is to be done with a 6-year-old boy who beats a month-old baby nearly to death? ''Little Criminals'' comes up with no satisfying answer to that uncomfortable question, but it does bring out the painful perplexities of dealing with terrible crimes committed by those who ought to be below the age of criminality.

title: Hong Kong Paper Cuts Newsstand Price
description: The Oriental Press Group, the publisher of Hong Kong's biggest-selling newspaper, said yesterday that it would cut its newsstand price, causing concern that a price war might force smaller competitors to close. Oriental Press, which publishes the Chinese-language Oriental Daily News, said it would cut its price to $2 from $5 (Hong Kong), or to 26 cents from 65 cents (United States), ''to celebrate Hong Kong's return to China.'' More than a dozen newspapers in the city serve a population of six million.

title: Telefonica de Espana Posts 16% Profit Gain
description: The telecommunications company Telefonica de Espana S.A. said yesterday that its net income rose 16 percent in the first quarter of 1997 to 27.87 billion pesetas, from 24.08 billion pesetas a year earlier.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BENDHEIM, CHARLES HENRY
description: BENDHEIM - Charles Henry. Passed away Saturday, May 10, at his home in Jerusalem, Israel, and was interred there on May 11. He will be sorely missed by wife, sister, children, grandchildren and great-grandchildren, and by everyone he came in contact with. The family will sit shiva in Jerusalem until Tuesday evening, May 13; Fax 972-2-625-3843; email bendheim@inter.net.il. Thereafter, shiva will continue at 4680 Livingston Avenue, Riverdale, New York, through Friday, May 16.

title: Gehe Reports Sales Rose 13% in Quarter
description: Gehe A.G. said yesterday that sales rose 13 percent in the first quarter, helped by the acquisition of the British pharmacy chain Lloyds Chemists P.L.C. The company said it expected a rise in pretax profit to between 450 million marks ($268 million) and 500 million marks this year, from 407 million marks in 1996, not counting one-time items. First-quarter sales rose to 6.107 billion marks ($3.6 billion), from 5.407 billion marks in the first quarter last year.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MILOVIC, MILOMIR D.
description: MILOVIC-Milomir D., on May 11, 1997. Beloved husband of Stana, nee Daisevic. Loving father of Dragan and Zoran. Also survived by 3 grandchildren. Funeral from Broadway Chapel of Thomas M. Quinn & Sons, Inc. 35-20 Broadway, LIC, NY. Visitation Tuesday 2-5 and 7-9:30 PM, services at 9 PM. Interment in Kraljevo, Yugoslavia.

title: The Chess Column
description: Because of the match between Garry Kasparov and the I.B.M. computer that ended on Sunday, the chess column by Robert Byrne does not appear today. Analysis of the match appears on page B2. The column will resume next week.

title: Rangers Suddenly Look Formidable For Flyers Series
description: A sports tournament, especially one as big and long as the two-month, 16-team Stanley Cup playoffs, writes its own script, one that confounds the prognosticators. What was vague in the first month seems obvious in the second as the plot lines evolve and the characters develop.

title: New Rapport From India-Pakistan Meeting
