description: The Prime Ministers of India and Pakistan met today in the first such encounter in eight years and vowed to seek ways around deep enmities that both acknowledged as having contributed to entrenching the poverty of tens of millions of their people.

title: FELCOR IN $83 MILLION DEAL FOR 4 DOUBLETREE HOTELS
description: Felcor Suite Hotels Inc. said yesterday that it had agreed to buy four Doubletree Guest Suites hotels for $83 million from a closely held master-limited partnership, PSH. Felcor, which is based in Irving, Tex., said the price included a payment to terminate four existing management agreements, although it said Doubletree would continue to manage the hotels, which are in Lake Buena Vista, Fla.; Raleigh/Durham, N.C.; Tampa, Fla., and Nashville. The deal brings to 12 the number of Doubletree Guest Suites hotels in Felcor's portfolio.

title: Former Executive Is Charged With Bilking Foster Agency
description: The former chief executive officer of a Harlem foster care agency was arrested yesterday on charges that he stole nearly $3 million from the agency in hopes of buying 45 acres of land in Westchester from the wife of Randolph A. Hearst, the chairman of the Hearst Corporation, prosecutors said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GASSTROM, VALMA J.
description: GASSTROM-Valma J., of White Plains, NY. Beloved wife of Evald H. Gasstrom. Devoted mother of Lisa L. and John Nylund Gasstrom. Devoted sister of Laimi Reynolds and the late Vuokko Leaman. Grandmother of John Evald Mascari. Funeral service Thursday 1 PM, at The Church in the Highlands, White Plains, New York. Reposing at the BallardDurand Funeral Home, 2 Maple Avenue, White Plains, New York, Wednesday 2-4 and 7-9 P.M.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEMONNIER, JEANNE
description: LEMONNIER-Jeanne. Mother of Joe and John Paul, wife of the late Ernest LeMonnier, died peacefully in her home in Manhattan after a long illness. Services scheduled for Wednesday, May 14, 1:30 P.M., at Riverside Chapel, Amsterdam Avenue between 75th and 76th Streets, in Manhattan. Shiva to follow at the home of Joe and Janet LeMonnier in Hoboken, N.J.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: VERTEX COMMUNICATIONS CORP., Kilgore, Tex., a maker of satellite communications earth station antennas, agreed to acquire the closely held TIW Systems Inc., Santa Clara, Calif., a maker of telecommunication equipment, for $19.6 million in cash and stock.

title: 7 Mount Everest Climbers Are Reported Missing and Feared Dead
description: As many as seven mountain climbers may have died high on the exposed ice and rock of Mount Everest's north face over the weekend, according to incomplete but ominous accounts emerging from places as far afield as Russia, Kazakstan, Nepal and New Zealand.

title: Patterns
description: Bendel's Narrows Its Focus

title: A Swinging Travelogue, With Ellington as Guide
description: How Chinese is Duke Ellington's ''Chinoiserie,'' how African is his ''Liberian Suite''? Do they become more so by a particularly forceful rendering of a little pentatonic melody, a particularly dense malleting of the tom-toms?

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MALAKOFF, EDWARD
description: MALAKOFF-Edward. Suddenly in Iceland. Formerly of NYC and Andover, Mass. Lately of Chester, N.H. Devoted father of Sarah and Rebecca. Beloved son of Henrietta. Dear brother of Joyce Wallace. Memorial service at the Village Temple, 33 East 12th Street on Wednesday, May 14 at 11 A.M.

title: CLASSICAL MUSIC
description: A Wisdom That Comes

title: DANCE
description: Soulful Poses, and Subjects

title: Deep Blue Can't Triumph in the Game of Life
description: To the Editor:

title: Executive Changes
description: BORLAND INTERNATIONAL INC., Scotts Valley, Calif., named Kathleen Fisher chief financial officer, succeeding Paul Emery, who left the company.

title: For Youth, Bargain Rent Is Just a Ticket
description: IT seems only right, given the political climate, that one of Broadway's hottest tickets is a high-wattage musical that dwells on tenant-landlord relations. ''Rent'' remains so popular that people, generally those too young to clearly remember any President before Ronald Reagan, start lining up the night before for the 30-odd tickets available for each performance at the rock-bottom price of $20 apiece.

title: No Headline
description: ''If you don't consider what happened in Oklahoma, Tim is a good person.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RICHMAN, EVELYN S.
description: RICHMAN-Evelyn S., age 81, beloved wife of the late Jack B. Richman, after a long illness, died peacefully at her home in Hollywood, FL., on May 11. She is survived by her children: Benjamin (Buddy) and Sandy Richman, of Bedford, NY; Penny and Irwin Abouaf of New York City; & David and Janet Richman of Phoenix, AZ; grandchildren: Michelle, Mark, Nicole, Samantha, Mary and Bobby; and great grandchildren Sandy and Alexandra. Funeral services will be held at Riverside/Gordon Chapel, Hollywood, Florida, on Tuesday, May 13, 1997 at 3:30 PM. Interment at Sharon Gardens, Valhalla, NY at 11 AM, on Thursday, May 15, 1997. All participants to meet at Sharon Gardens, Valhalla, NY. In lieu of flowers donations to Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center, 1275 York Avenue, New York, New York 10021, telephone #

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-11

title: Is China Coveting 'Lost' Lands?A Wary Asia Looks On
description: HONG KONG  While the handover of Hong Kong to China next month will have no direct impact on the military balance of power in Asia and the Pacific, some officials and analysts worry that it may embolden Beijing to intensify its quest to recover other "lost" territory in the region.

title: Dow and S.& P. Index Hit Highs As the Rally in Stocks Surges On
description: The Dow Jones industrial average and the Standard & Poor's index of 500 stocks both jumped more than 1.5 percent and set closing highs yesterday, continuing the rally that has seen these indexes climb about 14 percent since the spring selloff that ended on April 11.

title: Honoring Six Police Officers Who Died Last Year
description: The metal detectors were removed yesterday and the fresh-cut flowers carried in, as the drab lobby of Police Headquarters was once again transformed into a room of remembrance for police officers lost in the line of duty. Six officers were killed last year, and so six names were added to the hundreds of others set in bronze along the lobby's wall.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GIDAL, SOL
description: GIDAL-Sol, 93 years, of Brooklyn and Lake Mahopac, N.Y. Master Furrier, husband for fifty-nine years of the late Lottie Gidal, beloved father of George, Jules, and daughter-in-law, Toby. Cherished grandfather of Eric and Marc, dear brother of Leni Goldberg, Friedl Gidal and the late Nachum and George Gidal. Services were held May 11, 1997 at Beth David Cemetery, Elmont, New York.

title: The Legendary Dodgers Aren't Coming Back Yet, But the Borough Is
description: For generations, the consolidation of New York City in 1897 was known in Brooklyn as ''the Great Mistake.''

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: TENNIS

title: Study Didn't Change Need to Reduce Acid Rain
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KOLATCH, ESTHER
description: KOLATCH-Esther. Congregation Kehilath Jeshurun and its Sisterhood mourn the passing of their senior member and extend heartfelt condolences to all members of the bereaved family. Rabbi Haskel Lookstein Fred Distenfeld, President

title: Bozell and WPP Make Acquisitions
description: Two agency companies have made acquisitions.

title: Man, Victorious
description: To the Editor:

title: Heat Heads South One Last Time
description: Their heads were down when they left the court last night. So was their confidence. And unless the Miami Heat's players solve their offensive problems, their season will be over soon.

title: QUALITY DINING BACKING AWAY FROM BRUEGGER'S BAGELS
description: Quality Dining Inc. said yesterday that it planned to sell Bruegger's Bagels, possibly back to the co-founders Nordahl Brue and Michael Dressell, less than a year after buying it for $176 million in stock. Quality Dining, which is based in Mishawaka, Ind., said it would take a pretax charge of $140 million to $170 million to write down assets and dismiss staff and said it expected a ''significant loss'' in the second quarter. The company had been expected to earn 13 cents a share in its fiscal second quarter. Stephen Finn, Bruegger's president and chief executive, resigned. Quality Dining's shares rose 18.75 cents, to $8.0625, yesterday.

title: Fred Meyer Is Acquiring Smith's Food for $700 Million in Stock
description: Fred Meyer Inc. said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire Smith's Food and Drug Centers Inc. for about $700 million in stock, in a deal that would create a supermarket and general merchandise chain with 374 stores in 17 Western states.

title: Q&A
description: Escaping Helium

title: Marie Neuberger, 88, Philanthropist Devoted to Art and Education
description: Marie Salant Neuberger, a New York foundation executive and philanthropist who was long active in civic affairs, died on Sunday at Greenwich Hospital in Greenwich, Conn. She was 88 and lived on the Upper East Side of Manhattan and in Peekskill, N.Y.

title: Exchange Offices to Open
description: The New York Mercantile Exchange said it would begin trading and back-office operations in its new offices in the World Financial Center on May 27.

title: Ex-Trader to Get Account Access
description: A panel of the National Association of Securities Dealers has ordered Kidder, Peabody & Company to release an additional $1 million to Joseph Jett from his account to cover Mr. Jett's legal fees and expenses, according to the N.A.S.D. order.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  SPADA, DAVID
description: SPADA-David. Just in loving memory of David Spada. December 5, 1961-May 13, 1996.

title: The Bipartisan Subpoena Squeeze
description: The main noise on Sunday's talk shows was provided by a chorus of important Republicans agreeing that their own party should be investigated for possible illegal campaign contributions from foreign sources. House Speaker Newt Gingrich in particular seemed to sense that the credibility of the inquiry into White House fund-raising depended on Congress's willingness to pursue with equal zeal reports that the Republican National Committee received millions in mysterious financial help from corporate interests in Hong Kong.

title: Using the 'Parts Left Out' As Well as 'Spectral Forms'
description: Amanda Miller and her Pretty Ugly Dancecompany seldom appear in New York. A performance of two pieces by this American choreographer, who was recently appointed director of Ballett Freiburg in Germany, on Sunday night at the Performing Garage in SoHo made one regret their absence all the more. Presented as part of the 1997 Whitney Biennial, the dances stood out for their witty imagination and authority and a physicality that was both lush and plain.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SERWER, BERNSTEIN, BLANCHE
description: SERWER-BERNSTEIN-Blanche, 86, on May 11 after a long battle with ALS. Beloved mother of Philip (Ellen), Daniel (Jacquelyn) and Jeremy (Nancy) Serwer. Grandmother of Zachary, Tammy, Rebecca, Jared and Adam. Wife of the late Zachary Serwer and of the late Nahum Bernstein. Author and psychologist who never accepted injustice or lost hope. Contributions in lieu of flowers to the Muscular Distrophy Assoc, E.L.E.M., Givat Haviva, Interns for Peace, or any charity that promotes reconciliation between those in conflict. Services Thursday 12:30PM, ''The Riverside'', 76 St and Amsterdam Ave.

title: Police Chief Says Officers Violated Policy in Beating
description: In the latest case of a police beating that was captured on videotape, Atlanta's police chief concluded today that departmental rules were violated by a sergeant who repeatedly bludgeoned a man with a baton during an arrest last month.

title: Senate Is Lacking Veto-Proof Vote for Ban on an Abortion Method
description: With the Senate to begin debate Tuesday on what critics call ''partial-birth abortion,'' opponents of abortion are still scrambling for enough votes to override an expected veto from President Clinton.

title: Graduates Protest Whitman Appearance
description: When the senior class president at William Paterson College was asked to choose a commencement speaker this year, she immediately set her sights on Gov. Christine Todd Whitman. The reasons were simple, she said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ASCH, JOHN
description: ASCH-John. Died May 10, 1997 at the age of 90. Beloved husband of Mary Blume-Asch, devoted son of author Sholem Asch, loving brother of Ruth Shaffer, of Brighton, England, and Nathan and Moses Asch, both deceased. Stepfather of James and Frederick Blume, father-in-law of Kathryn Frank and Mary Blume, grandfather of Zach, all of whom greatly mourn his loss. We will sorely miss him.

title: Media Match
description: To the Editor:

title: Transactions
description: Baseball

title: Curb on U.S. Role in Redistricting
description: Ruling in an important voting rights case, the Supreme Court today curbed the Justice Department's ability to insist on greater representation of minority voters as the price for approving redistricting plans.

title: Friend Says McVeigh Wanted Bombing to Start an 'Uprising'
description: Timothy J. McVeigh cased the Federal Building in Oklahoma City several months before the bombing in April 1995, and planned to blow it up ''to cause a general uprising in America,'' Mr. McVeigh's former Army friend Michael J. Fortier told a jury here in Federal Court today.

title: Wasps to the Rescue
description: SCIENTISTS have discovered another ingenious partnership between plants and animals. To fight beet armyworm caterpillars, corn plants release a ''cocktail'' of airborne chemicals that attract parasitic wasps. The wasps, natural enemies of the caterpillar, home in on the scent and deposit their eggs on the enemy's body. When the wasp larvae hatch, they devour the caterpillar.

title: Bah! Who Says Science Must Seem Like Fun?
description: SCIENCE, one often hears from educators, should be fun.

title: Calpers Urges Changes at Bassett Furniture
description: The California Public Employees' Retirement System said today that it had filed a shareholder proposal with Bassett Furniture Industries, seeking to separate the positions of chairman and chief executive.

title: INSIDE
description: Knicks Defeat Heat; Utah Advances

title: Opposition Leaders Join Bandwagon as Zaire Rebels Tighten Noose on Capital
description: With rebel forces preparing a final assault on the capital, political support for President Mobutu Sese Seko eroded further today as opposition parties and moderate politicians called for strikes in support of the rebels and began organizing welcoming committees to greet them.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PLOTTEL, FRANCES BANNER
description: PLOTTEL-Frances Banner. March 11, 1906-May 12, 1997. Beloved wife of the late Charles. Devoted mother of Rhea, Marilyn, Roland and his wife Jeanine. Cherished grandmother of Claudia and Lawrence; Michael and Daniella; Philip and Gloria. Loving great grandmother of Charles, Elisabeth, Julia and Jacob. Service Tuesday, 9:45AM, at ''The Riverside'', 76 St. and Amsterdam Ave.

title: Alton Blakeslee, 83, Is Dead; A.P. Science Writer and Editor
description: Alton Blakeslee, a longtime science editor of The Associated Press whose reporting covered everything from the first polio vaccine to heart transplants and space exploration, died on Sunday night at North Shore University Hospital in Manhasset, N.Y. He was 83 and lived in Port Washington.

title: Voters Heading to Polls
description: Voters in Jersey City, Camden, Hoboken and 25 other towns and cities will go to the polls today to elect mayors and other local officials. Polls are open from 7 A.M. until 8 P.M. The races are technically nonpartisan, which means that the candidates' party affiliations do not appear on the ballot. Such contests are intended to keep political bosses from hand-picking elected officials in towns dominated by one party, said Joseph F. Britt, director of the state Division of Elections.

title: A Day Into Trial, a Settlement To Save Gotham Book Mart
description: The owner of the Gotham Book Mart and Joanne Carson have agreed to settle a financial dispute that the bookshop owner, Andreas Brown, claimed could have forced him to close the legendary midtown Manhattan store.

title: Law Firm's Conflict Is Blow For Steinbrenner's Lawsuit
description: George Steinbrenner's lawsuit against Major League Baseball's executive council, its other 29 franchises and assorted officials and lawyers is about to suffer a setback because of a potential conflict of interest for the law firm representing him.

title: Pataki Urges End of Rent Cap When Apartment Is Vacated
description: Gov. George E. Pataki yesterday proposed eliminating rent protections on apartments once they become vacant, but the Democratic Speaker of the Assembly vowed to fight the plan.

title: Mrs. Clinton's Lawyers
description: To the Editor:

title: Yeltsin Signs Peace Treaty With Chechnya
description: In a move to normalize relations without resolving their fundamental dispute, President Boris N. Yeltsin of Russia and the leader of Chechnya signed a peace treaty today that both officials described as the end of a centuries-old conflict between Russia and the rebellious region in the Caucasus.

title: NATO's Quality of Life
description: As I follow the debate over whether NATO should be enlarged, I have the strong sense that the arguments are often purely mechanical, somehow missing the real meaning of the alliance. The process of expansion must be accompanied by something much deeper: a refined definition of the purpose, mission and identity of NATO.

title: Starks Lights Up and Leaves the Heat in Darkness
description: John Starks has a T-shirt that reads, ''You miss 100 percent of the shots you don't take.'' The idea, of course, is that when you make only 5 shots in 24 attempts through three games of a tense series, you do not worry. You keep believing the next one will drop.

title: Whether Cup of Joe or Gourmet's Cafe, Coffee's Price Is Soaring
description: From a cappuccino grande at Starbucks to a plain cup of black no-sugar at a street vendor's cart, from a pound of Swiss water-processed decaf beans at Zabar's to a can of ground Folgers at the grocery store, the price of coffee is going up.

title: CHRONICLE
description: From one lofty job to another: CATHARINE R. STIMPSON, director of the Fellows Program of the John D. and Catherine MacArthur Foundation, the organization that gives out ''genius prizes,'' is moving on. She will become the dean of the New York University Graduate School of Arts and Science, it was announced during the graduate convocation at Carnegie Hall yesterday morning.

title: Whimsy and Grace In All-American Recital
description: It was intriguing, if not downright scary, to calculate the significance of Karen Beardsley's all-American song program at Weill Recital Hall on Friday night. What a lineup of smiling faces. What relentlessly gracious music. What intense compositorial needs to amuse and endear. At home on this particular range, the discouraging word was seldom to be heard.

title: Quiet No More: Starks Comes Out Shooting
description: Three seconds. That's how long it took for John Starks to fire his first shot after coming off the bench last night. Missed it, too, but that did not deter Starks in the slightest.

title: Unexpectedly, Delta Air Lines' Chief Will Retire
description: In an announcement that raised more questions than it answered, Delta Air Lines said yesterday that Ronald W. Allen, its chairman, chief executive and president, would retire this summer from the carrier, the nation's third largest.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LACHER, CINDY
description: LACHER-Cindy. In loving memory of Cindy Lacher, beloved wife of Mark Lacher and mother of Ami and Randy. From Howard and Daniel Koeppel and all your friends and family at Koeppel Auto Group. Wake to be held from 2PM to 5PM and 7PM to 9PM on Tuesday, May 13, at Gleason's Funeral Home, 10-25 150 Street, Whitestone, N.Y. Funeral to be held at 9:45AM on Wednesday, May 14 at Holy Trinity Church, 14th Avenue and Whitestone Expressway, Whitestone, N.Y.

title: Guinness and Grand Met in $22 Billion Deal
description: Faced with a steady decline in liquor consumption in their traditional markets, the world's two biggest distillers, Grand Metropolitan P.L.C. and Guinness P.L.C., agreed today to a merger valued at about $22.27 billion, the fifth-biggest deal in history.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLDBERG, JACK
description: GOLDBERG-Jack. Survived by beloved wife Ruth; brother Philip; sister-in-law Ruth; loving children Vivian, Raymond, Stephen and Fumiko; adored grandchildren Andrea, Mark, Michelle, Daniel, Joan, Adam, Victoria and Edward; cherished great-grandsons Branden and Samuel. Graveside services.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RESNIK, LILYAN
description: RESNIK-Lilyan, of Hollywood, Fl and Baldwin, LI. Beloved mother of Joan and Herbert, Arthur and Susan. Grandmother to Sue, Billy, Cliff and Ben; great-grandmother of Ben, Sophie, Amanda, Michael, Noa and, Annie (private graveside services.)

title: MANVILLE BUYS BRITISH TEXTILES MAKER FOR $65 MILLION
description: The Johns Manville Corporation said yesterday that it had purchased Mitex, a closely held European maker of wall coverings for commercial and industrial buildings, for $65 million. Mitex has 200 employees at its three weaving factories in Helsingborg and Stromsund, Sweden, and St. Helens, England. It has annual revenue of $65 million. Johns Manville, based in Denver, makes insulation and building products and has annual revenue of $1.6 billion. Johns Manville said the acquisition would allow it to pursue its international growth strategy. The company, which has 8,300 employees, has 53 factories in North America, Europe and China.

title: Study Questions Cost of Shift To Harsh Cocaine Sentences
description: Meting out harsher prison terms to drug dealers provides fewer benefits per taxpayer dollar than old-fashioned law enforcement or simply treating addicted offenders, according to a new study released today.

title: Experts to Test-Fire Rifle in Dr. King's Killing
description: Lawyers for James Earl Ray and Tennessee prosecutors have agreed to begin tests on Wednesday on the rifle the authorities said he used to kill the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King, Jr. on April 4, 1968.

title: Motorola Plans A Consolidation
description: Motorola Inc. said yesterday that it was seeking to consolidate its accounts for products like cellular telephones, pagers, modems and personal-use two-way radios, with combined billings estimated at $40 million. Those accounts have been handled by various agencies.

title: Gooden Is Pounded in Return
description: Dwight Gooden's first pitch against Class AAA Columbus yesterday was blasted for a home run by Matt Howard. He also surrendered a home run in the second inning to Marc Ronan and left the exhibition game in the fourth after Shane Spencer ripped a three-run homer.

title: Zaire's Decay Slows Return of Refugees
description: Overhead, it could hardly have been more beautiful -- the Southern Cross and Big Dipper hung in the sky and a sliver of moon, punctuated by shooting stars, shone on the Congo River.

title: Hardier Breed of Antarctic and Lunar Explorers: Robots
description: IF a place like Antarctica was discovered on another planet, scientists from Earth undoubtedly would send hardy robot spacecraft to explore such an intriguing but desolate frozen world.

title: Prosecutor Is Replaced
description: Governor Whitman nominated a former deputy attorney general yesterday to replace the Middlesex County Prosecutor, Robert W. Gluck. The nominee, Boris Moczula, 40, who is now the first assistant Passaic County prosecutor, was also ethics officer in the state Division of Criminal Justice.

title: $33 Billion Giant Guinness to Unite With Grand Met
description: LONDON  A conversation over dinner on April 10 between the chairmen of two of Britain's leading companies bore fruit Monday in the form of a plan to merge Grand Metropolitan PLC and Guinness PLC into a $33 billion conglomerate.

title: Gore Reflects on His Emerging Vulnerability
description: The nation knows much about its Vice President: scion of a proud Southern political family, product of elite private academies, a self-described ''raging moderate'' who has spent a lifetime seeking the unexceptional center of American politics, a singularly influential adviser to President Clinton who is usually the last man left in the room after the President's aides have departed.

title: Those 'Liberal' Judges Are Less Offensive
description: To the Editor:

title: Panamerican Beverages and Venezuelan Bottler to Merge
description: Panamerican Beverages Inc., Latin America's largest soft drink bottling company and one of the world's largest Coca-Cola bottlers, said yesterday that it had agreed to merge with Coca-Cola y Hit de Venezuela, Venezuela's leading soft drink bottler, in a cash and stock transaction valued at about $1.2 billion.

title: WAL-MART STORES INC.(WMT,N)
description: Wal-Mart Stores Inc. said yesterday that first-quarter earnings rose 14 percent as sales and profit improved in each of its divisions.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KRAMER, E.E., DR.
description: KRAMER-E.E., Dr. The council and fellows of the New York Obstetrical society record with profound regret the death of their life fellow Dr. E.E. Kramer on 4/19/97. Livia Wan, M.D., President Richard Berkowitz, MD, Secretary

title: I.B.M.'s Stock Surges by 3.6%
description: One day after its chess computer defeated Garry Kasparov, the world chess champion, I.B.M. stock surged to a 10-year high and was only a bit shy of its record.

title: Creating a Ripple Effect in the Bronx
description: Fernando Ferrer's campaign for mayor created a ripple effect in Bronx politics, with one group of politicians seeking his job of borough president and yet another planning to capture the City Council seats of those running to replace him.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEISS, ALAN
description: WEISS-Alan, 70, suddenly on May 10, in Palm Coast, FL. formerly of Great Neck, New York. Survived by beloved wife Trudi. Devoted father of Julie (Phil) and Richard (Kristie). Loving grandfather of Alexandra and Kasandra. Dear brother of Robert (Ilene).

title: Humane Responses
description: To the Editor:

title: Sale of Coveted Art Collection Brings $92 Million
description: New money ran after the trappings of the old last night at Christie's, where one of the most important private collections ever to come to auction was sold: 29 Impressionist and Post-Impressionist paintings, drawings and sculptures from the collection of the investor and philanthropist John Langeloth Loeb and his wife, Frances Lehman Loeb.

title: DANCE
description: An Evening Full of Debuts

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DEBOER, FREDRICK E. ''FRITS''
description: deBOER-Fredrick E. ''Frits'', 60, of 35 West Street, Middletown, CT., in Los Angeles, California, on May 9th. One of leading national scholars of Balinese studies; winner of the Dharama Kusuma Medal in 1993 and professor at Wesleyan University, Middletown, CT. Member of the Society for Balinese Studies, editing their newsletter. He is survived by his wife, three sons, one daughter and one grandchild. Memorial services at the South Congregational Church, Middletown, CT., May 14th at 1:00 P.M. No calling hours. Memorial contributions to the Middletown Notable Tree Fund., P.O. Box 1300, Middletown, CT. 06457. For more information, contact Doolittle Funeral Service, Middletown, CT.

title: Malone and Stockton Star in Same Old Story
description: The Utah Jazz has outlived its warranty.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DOYLE, JON C.
description: DOYLE-Jon C. Passed away on May 9 at the Mount Sinai Hospital in Manhattan. Mr. Doyle is survived by his wife, Nancy of Brooklyn, and his two daughters by a former marriage, Megan and Courtney of Manhattan. Memorial services will be held at 11 AM on Thursday, May 15 at the Madison Avenue Presbyterian Church at 73rd and Madison. In lieu of flowers donations can be made to the Jerry Lisker Foundation, 331 W. 57 Street, Suite 219, NYC 10019.

title: COMCAST CORP. (CMCSK, NNM)
description: The Comcast Corporation reported a larger-than-expected first-quarter loss yesterday, partly because of its share of the costs to start a personal communications partnership.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  REICHERTER, BETSEY BRUCKNER
description: REICHERTER-Betsey Bruckner, of Selinsgrove, PA. on May 10, 1997. Survived by husband Robert Charles, three sons, parents Jack L. and Marion Johnson Bruckner of Oyster Bay, Long Island and two sisters. Contribtutions in her memory may be to Betsey's Fund, C/O Snyder County Trust Co., Shamokin Dam, PA. 17876.

title: Devils Look for Answers After a Surprise Ending
description: It was the day after the New Jersey Devils were eliminated from the Stanley Cup playoffs, and Lou Lamoriello, the Devils' president, was in a lousy mood. Discussing what went wrong in a four-games-to-one loss to the Rangers in the Eastern Conference semifinals, Lamoriello said he would leave ''no stone unturned'' in searching for answers.

title: Grenfell Hires Merrill Banker
description: Continuing its drive to establish a major Wall Street firm, Deutsche Morgan Grenfell Inc. said yesterday that it had hired C. Edward Carter to head its American investment banking division.

title: Ferrer to Withdraw From the Campaign To Unseat Giuliani
description: Fernando Ferrer, one of the two leading Democrats seeking his party's nomination for mayor, has decided to abandon the race after a short-lived campaign plagued with miscues, and will endorse Ruth W. Messinger, Mr. Ferrer's associates said last night.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption with the Vows column on Sunday misstated the bride's surname. She is Bobbie Lloyd, not Wright. (Dusty Wright is the name used by the bridegroom, Mark Petracca, when he performs as a country singer.)

title: Town Rolls Back Last Call
description: For decades, Wildwood has been synonymous with the honky-tonkish side of the Jersey Shore, with a vibrant bar culture and its attendant disruptions of civic life. But lately, city officials have been looking to attract a more wholesome breed of tourist. Last night, the city's board of commissioners voted unanimously to roll back closing hour at the bars from 5 A.M. in the summertime to 3 A.M.

title: With Supplies Down, Coffee Prices Are Up
description: From a cappuccino grande at Starbucks to a plain cup of black no-sugar at a street vendor's cart, from a pound of Swiss water-processed decaf beans at Zabar's to a can of ground Folgers at the grocery store, the price of coffee is going up.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DINTENFASS, JULIUS, DR.
description: DINTENFASS-Julius, Dr., 86, of Woodsburg, NY, died May 8, 1997, in Florida. Beloved husband of Ruth of 58 years. Beloved father of Ellen, Marylyn and Nancy. Sons-in-law Julius Berger and Bruce Gurewitz. Ten adored grandchildren and two greatgrandchildren. Graduate of Columbia Univerisity, Eastern Chiropractic College. MS from New York University. Attended University of Heidlberg College of Medicine. Chiropractic licence #

title: The N.B.A. Is Must-Stay TV
description: Now that the PGA Tour has completed its new TV deals, the next big contracts awaiting negotiation are for National Basketball Association and National Football League rights.

title: Seconds of 'Panic Time' Aided Nonhuman Player
description: What would you call it? A no-brainer?

title: Judge Rejects a Formula For Benefits in Workfare
description: A state judge in Manhattan ruled yesterday that New York City's workfare system unfairly calculates the number of hours that more than 35,000 welfare recipients must work to receive benefits.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KENNER, HELEN
description: KENNER-Helen, of Lake Worth, FL. on May 10, 1997. Beloved wife of the late George B. Kenner. Devoted mother of Jeffrey Kenner and Marion Baker. Loving mother-in-law of Patti Kenner and Les Baker. Dear sister of the late Murray Martin and sister-in-law of Roz Martin. Cherished grandmother of Julie, Robin, Steven & Gary. Adored great grandmother of Geoffrey and Dylan. Grateful charge and companion of Eunice Jones. Dear friend for many years of Mildred Rosenbaum & Evelyn Levy. Services are private.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SOUBRY, KENNETH W.S.
description: SOUBRY-Kenneth W.S., on May 11, 1997 in Greenwich, CT. Former Chairman and Chief Executive of Alexander & Alexander Services, Inc. In addition to his wife Irene, he is survived by a daughter Clara, a sister Moira Esdaile of Toronto, Canada, two nephews and a niece. Services will be private. Donations in memory may be made to Camphill Village, Copake, NY 12516.

title: William R. Cannon, 81, Methodist Theologian
description: The Rev. Dr. William Ragsdale Cannon Jr., a Methodist bishop and theologian whose ministry included national and international church activities that led to a friendship with President Jimmy Carter, died on Sunday at Crawford W. Long Hospital in Atlanta. He was 81.

title: THEATER
description: Louis Armstrong Strikes Back

title: Artificial Intelligence
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  UNGERLAND, ADELAIDE G.
description: UNGERLAND-Adelaide G., on May 10, 1997. Beloved mother of Thomas, loving grandmother and step-grandmother, dear sister of Eleanor Holmewood. Friends may call at FranK E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street, Tuesday and Wednesday, 3-5, 7-9 PM. Funeral Mass at St. Ignatius Loyola Church, Park Avenue at 84th Street, Thursday 10 A.M.

title: Whistle-Blower Law Widens
description: Nurses and other health professionals who report evidence of poor patient care to the authorities are now protected from retaliatory dismissal under an expansion of the state's whistle-blower law signed by Gov. Christine Todd Whitman yesterday. Existing measures protected employees who reported illegal acts by their employers or refused to participate in an illegal activity, but not health workers who speak out against hospital cost-cutting.

title: Trial May Turn on DNA
description: A bloodstain found on the carpet in the room of Jesse K. Timmendequas, the man charged with killing 7-year-old Megan Kanka, was consistent with Megan's blood, an F.B.I. agent testified yesterday. The agent, Jennifer Lindsey Smith, head of the Federal Bureau of Investigation's DNA analysis unit, said that only 1 in about 3,000 people has blood with a similar DNA profile. She said tests showed that the blood could not have been that of Mr. Timmendequas, who is being tried on charges of rape, sodomy and murder. Ms. Smith also testified that tests of an anal swab from the child's body showed traces of semen, but that no DNA was obtained from the semen.

title: New Debate Over Surgery On Genitals
description: FOR those who think that genital cutting and the excision of a girl's clitoris are tribal practices largely restricted to the countries of sub-Saharan Africa, consider the case of Martha Coventry, a lanky, genial, springy-haired Minnesotan of 45.

title: Logging Sets Off an Apparent Chimp War
description: LOGGING of tropical forests in the central African country of Gabon appears to have touched off a savage territorial war among chimpanzees in which four of every five chimps die, says a field biologist for the Wildlife Conservation Society.

title: The C.I.A.'s Men in Iraq
description: The American Government has a nasty habit of disowning foreigners who risk their lives supporting Washington's intelligence operations abroad. The latest victims are a small group of Iraqis who worked with the Central Intelligence Agency in recent years in an unsuccessful effort to weaken Saddam Hussein. They are now in California jails, facing deportation as threats to American security.

title: Another Ancient Innovation: City Planning
description: A CITY that throbbed with vitality in the third millennium B.C. lies buried, forlorn and silent, beneath the wind-blown soil of the Upper Euphrates River Valley in southeastern Turkey. Gone are the din of commerce, the clatter on cobblestones and the cries and murmurs of family life behind mud brick walls. But the ruins speak to archeologists of a time when a revolutionary idea may have shaped the newest cities in antiquity.

title: New York's Cancer Tax
description: To the Editor:

title: An Operatic Voice Caresses Songs Lightly
description: For singers with big operatic voices, floating soft, high-spun phrases is the greatest vocal challenge. Few singers before the public today practice this art more splendidly than the American soprano Ruth Ann Swenson.

title: In Los Angeles, a Modern Muse
description: In the way that all roads in Los Angeles lead to a freeway, all trails of style here seem to lead back to Lisa Eisner. It isn't just that both Tom Ford of Gucci and Isaac Mizrahi have cited her as inspiration. She's also prescient about all things in style here. For instance, the Rat Pack may be in vogue again, but four years ago, Ms. Eisner bought Sammy Davis Jr.'s entire wardrobe at auction. And wears it.

title: POP
description: Radiance and Sentiment,

title: A Past Etched in Stone, a Budget Weak as Water
description: Clambering up a metal scaffold about 60 feet up the crumbling red sandstone north face of the Strasbourg Cathedral, Bernard Blaizeau, the chief Government buildings inspector here, tapped the head of a three-foot-high stone angel that had been standing for about 500 years in a niche on top of a buttress and watched as it rocked.

title: Shirai Concert Canceled
description: Tonight's recital by the mezzo-soprano Mitsuko Shirai and the pianist Hartmut Holl, at Alice Tully Hall, has been canceled because Mr. Holl is ill. To get a refund, mail tickets with a self-addressed stamped envelope to the Alice Tully Hall box office, attention GP/Shirai, 1941 Broadway, New York, N.Y. 10023. Information: (212) 875-5050.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BEARD, ANSON MCCOOK
description: BEARD-Anson McCook, age 88. After a long illness, died peacefully at his home on Long Island on May 10. Beloved husband of the late Roseanne Beard, he is survived by three sons, Anson McCook, Jr., of Greenwich, CT., Peter Hill of Montauk, NY, Samuel Sherwood of New Castle, DE, and 7 grandchildren. Funeral services are private.

title: FERRO PLANS PLANT CLOSINGS AND JOB CUTS
description: The Ferro Corporation said yesterday that it would cut about 1,200 jobs, close 30 plants and take a $100 million charge in the second quarter in an effort to reduce costs and improve profit margins. The company, a maker of industrial materials like coatings, colors, ceramics, chemicals and plastics, said the restructuring would take two to three years to complete and would reduce costs by about $30 million annually. Ferro shares reached a 52-week high of $34.50 before closing at $33.875, up $2. Ferro, based in Cleveland, plans to cut its plants to about 50 from 80. Cuts in its work force, currently 6,900, will occur mainly outside the United States, the company said.

title: CHRONICLE
description: NEIL SMITH, the president and general manager of the New York Rangers, is ecstatic over the victory of the team on Sunday in the Eastern Conference finals of the Stanley Cup playoffs.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KRAVER, RICHARD M.
description: KRAVER-Richard M. The Stern School of Business at New York University has lost a close friend and alumnus, Richard M. Kraver, who received his undergraduate degree in 1968. He was an active member of the Stern Alumni Association Board of Directors, having joined the Board in 1987, and was instrumental in helping the School build a strong alumni network that today is the foundation for the School's global status as a leading school of management education. Mr. Kraver founded the law firm of Kraver & Levy and was generous in offering his professional expertise to fellow graduates seeking a legal career. He received his law degree from Syracuse University in 1971 and appeared in ''Who's Who in American Law.'' Richard Kraver was born in Brooklyn in 1946 and is survived by his wife, Harriet, and sons, Barry and Michael.

title: Frick Finds Its Director In Detroit
description: After six months of searching and art-world speculation, the Frick Collection announced yesterday that Samuel Sachs 2d, director of the Detroit Institute of Arts, will become the director of the Frick in September.

title: Chance for Americans
description: Beginning May 20, Americans will get a specific opportunity to decide whether they want the U.S. to use at least some part of its political and economic influence to help Christians persecuted for being Christian.

title: Executive Leaving Saatchi & Saatchi
description: Michael J. Jeary, a longtime top executive at Saatchi & Saatchi Advertising Worldwide, said yesterday that he would leave at the end of the month to pursue what he described in a statement from the agency as ''new and challenging ways to maximize my contributions to the business we all love.''

title: Tractor-Trailer Rams Delta Jet at La Guardia
description: Two Delta Air Lines passengers were injured, one seriously, at La Guardia Airport yesterday when a tractor-trailer rammed the wing of a plane bound for Dallas, pushing it six feet from the boarding ramp as passengers were boarding, the authorities said.

title: Clinton Wreaks Havoc on Research and Policy
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BRADLEY, LUCY GLAZEBROOK
description: BRADLEY-Lucy Glazebrook, 79, beloved wife and mother, died May 9th, in Sagaponack, NY. Educated at Dobbs and Bennington. Married Vivian Mercier and later George Crawford Bradley. Predeceased by her brother Otis Allan Glazebrook III, she is survived by her sister Anne Kehoe, as well as by her husband George, four children (Ciaran Mercier, Christine Wooding, George Bradley, Jr., Anne Bradley), two grandchildren (Martha Mercier, Beatrice Bradley) and numerous nieces and nephews. Memorial service 2PM, Saturday, May 17th, St. Ann's Church, Bridgehampton, NY.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CAVE, VERNAL G., MD.
description: CAVE-Vernal G., MD. The SUNY Health Science Center at Brooklyn Community mourns the passing of Dr. Vernal G. Cave, physician and civic leader. His vision and tireless efforts improved the lives of countless New Yorkers. Our sincerest condolences are extended to his wife, relatives and friends. Eugene B. Feigelson, MD, Interim President

title: Continental Carried Devices Tied To Jet Crash
description: In an eerie reminder of the crash of a Valujet Airlines DC-9 last year, the Federal Aviation Administration said today that Continental Airlines unknowingly carried a shipment of oxygen generators in the cargo hold of a passenger jet.

title: What's Like 'Primary Colors' and Read All Over?
description: The re-election of President Boris N. Yeltsin over his Communist challenger last year was a pivotal moment in Russia's rocky transition to democracy. So it is not surprising that a roman a clef about that no-holds-barred campaign should follow.

title: Slap at Yeltsin as Legislators Veto Return of Art Booty
description: The Russian Parliament has taken the extraordinary step of overriding a presidential veto in order to hold onto millions of dollars of art and historical documents taken by Soviet troops during World War II, Russian news agencies reported this evening.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: AAMES FINANCIAL CORP., Los Angeles, said it had promoted its chief operating officer, Cary Thompson, to chief executive and named vice chairman Neil Kornswiet president to replace its chairman, Gary Judis, in those posts.

title: Personal Health
description: HEALTH writers often warn readers about high rates of unnecessary surgery and caution them to beware of surgeons who are too quick to operate. But there is at least one circumstance in which surgery that turns out to be unneeded may be more than justified.

title: A Choice of Power Supplies
description: Taking another step toward deregulating New Jersey's electrical industry, state regulators voted yesterday to approve a program allowing 12,000 residents of Monroe Township in Middlesex County to choose their own electricity supplier beginning July 1.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SERWER, BERNSTEIN, BLANCHE L.
description: SERWER - BERNSTEIN - Blanche L. The Jerusalem Foundation mourns the passing of its dear friend, Blanche L. Serwer-Bernstein. Blanche's late husband, Nahum Bernstein, was a founder and the first Chairman in the U.S. of The Jerusalem Foundation. Blanche, a great lover of Jerusalem, supported a program bringing together Arab and Jewish youth. To her brother, Sydney Luria, and to the Serwer and Bernstein families, we extend our deepest sympathy. Teddy Kollek, Chairman Int'l Council Ruth Cheshin, Int'l President Mendel Kaplan, Int'l Chairman Alvin Einbender, Nat'l Chairman Michael Neiditch, Nat'l President

title: Treasury Securities' Prices Fall
description: The prices of Treasury securities fell yesterday as economic signals were mixed. An initial gain in bond prices caused by a report of slow retail sales quickly gave way to cautious trading as investors waited for more economic data as they try to anticipate whether the Federal Reserve will raise interest rates next week.

title: Making Food Safer
description: The United States' food supply is among the safest in the world. Nevertheless, there is room for improvement. The ambitious food safety initiative that was announced by the Clinton Administration this week deserves full, enthusiastic support from Congress.

title: For Boston Conductor, Success and Debate
description: The cover of ''Runnin' Wild,'' the latest CD of the 112-year-old Boston Pops Orchestra, catches its 37-year-old conductor, Keith Lockhart, in full stride as he flies along in tails -- and a white Armani T-shirt, black slacker shorts and high-tops, one red, one black.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MOCK, EDNA
description: MOCK-Edna, May 13. Beloved wife of the late David. Loving sister-in-law of Jean Eisner. Devoted aunt of Eleanor Hanley and Jane Paulson. For funeral information call Frank E. Campbell at 212 288-3500. In lieu of flowers contributions to a charity of your choice.

title: Yada Yada Yuppies
description: There was a moment, a decade ago, when yuppies felt a soupcon of shame.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCGINNESS, ARTHUR F.
description: McGINNESS-Arthur F. On May 11, 1997. Beloved husband of the late Mary Dailey McGinness. Loving father of Eugenia Singer. Devoted grandfather of Gregory, Maureen and Sheila. Dear brother of Josephine Connelly. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave at 81 St, Wednesday, 4-7 PM. Mass of Christian Burial at Saint Ignatius Loyola Church, Park Ave at 84 St, Thursday, 11 AM. In lieu of flowers, contributions in his memory may be made to Regis H.S., 55 East 84 Street, NY NY 10028.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FIORI, JEAN L.
description: FIORI-Jean L. On May 12, 1997. Loving husband of Inge. Beloved father of Charles and father-in-law of Deborah. Adoring grandfather of Lauren and Bryan. Jean, Dad, Opa, we will miss you very much and will love you always. You are in our thoughts and prayers as you are now with God. Memorial service Saturday, May 17 at 10:00 AM, St. Francis Xavier Cabrini Chapel, Roosevelt Island.

title: Strong-Boned Girls
description: WHILE much concern has been voiced about the potentially damaging effects on bones of delayed menarche among girls who are competitive gymnasts, a new study has shown that, at least before puberty, the youngsters are likely to develop far denser bones than girls who are not athletes.

title: 10 Years Later, I.B.M. Sets a New High in a Changed Market
description: This is a tale of how the dominant can fade, and how technology, unlike most other industries, can see huge companies shrink and smaller ones become behemoths.

title: Sony and Fuji TV Join In Murdoch Venture
description: The Sony Corporation and the Japanese broadcaster Fuji Television Network Inc. said yesterday that they would become partners in the Japan Sky Broadcasting Company, headed by Rupert Murdoch. Sony, Fuji, the News Corporation and the Japanese media company Softbank will each own 20 to 25 percent of J Sky B after the sale, said Masaya Matsumoto, a spokesman for Fuji TV. He and officials at Sony and J Sky B declined to elaborate, saying Mr. Murdoch would announce the details today.

title: Yes, Computers Can Think
description: Last year, after Garry Kasparov's chess victory over the I.B.M. computer Deep Blue, I told the students in my Introduction to Artificial Intelligence class that it would be many years before computers could challenge the best humans. Now that I and many others have been proved wrong, a lot of people have been rushing to assure us that Deep Blue is not actually intelligent and that this victory has no bearing on the future of artificial intelligence.

title: Switzerland's Debts
description: Recent disclosures about Switzerland's duplicitous role in World War II and its hoarding of Nazi assets have been wrenching for the Swiss people, many of whom long believed the myth that their country was truly neutral. But the reckoning is not yet over. Switzerland has amends to make, and they must be commensurate with the Nazi wealth Switzerland failed to surrender after the war.

title: The Cupboard Is Bare. Surf the Web!
description: To the Editor:

title: Inflation Rate Down In Western Germany
description: The Bundesbank, Germany's central bank, said yesterday that western German consumer prices rose at an annual rate of seven-tenths of 1 percent in the six months through April, down from a rate of 1.2 percent in March. The Bundesbank's inflation figure, which is adjusted for seasonal factors, is based on revised unadjusted data reported yesterday by the Federal Statistics Office.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KESTIN, ETHEL FRINDEL
description: KESTIN-Ethel Frindel, of Los Angeles, CA, formerly of NY, NY on May 13. Cherished wife of the late Samuel S. Kestin, beloved mother of Alice, Larry and Patty, loving grandmother of Alex, Sam and Olivia. Beloved sister of the late Edward (Buddy) Frindel. For information regarding funeral servies contact Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81 Street, NY 212-288-3500. Remembrances in lieu of flowers may be made to Metropolitan Jewish Geriatric Center, 4914 Fort Hamilton Parkway, Brooklyn, NY 11219-3399. Family will be receiving condolences at 995 Fifth Ave NY 212-288-5800.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ULLMAN, RUTH
description: ULLMAN-Ruth. Of Ossining. On May 12, 1997 at her residence. Survived by one son, David, one granddaughter, Stephanie. Services Wednesday, 9 A.M., at the Temple Israel of Northern Westchester, Glengary Rd, Croton on Hudson, N.Y. Interment Sharon Gardens, Valhalla, N.Y. For information contact Dorsey Funeral Home, Ossining, N.Y.

title: Wine Talk
description: IT'S actually rather romantic. They came together by chance, probably sometime in the 15th or 16th century. It was in France, it was springtime and everything was beginning to bloom. They hit it off almost at once, created something truly extraordinary, then went back to their own ways. And no one ever suspected a thing.

title: Martinez Leads Offense And Cone Does the Rest
description: As each day passes, the Yankees are making their 5-10 start a more distant scene in their rearview mirror.

title: Lakers' O'Neal Is Willing to Accept Some of the Blame
description: The moral is $120 million can't buy you love, or the conference finals.

title: Corrections
description: An article in some editions yesterday about the sale of paintings from the collection of John and Frances Loeb at Christie's on Monday misstated the title of a work by Manet that set an auction price record for his work. It is ''Rue Mosnier, Paris, Decorated With Flags on June 30, 1878''; the date was not 1978.

title: A Licensing Deal By 2 Drug Makers
description: Cocensys Inc., a biotechnology company based in Irvine, Calif., said today that it had agreed to license its new anti-anxiety drug to Wyeth-Ayerst Laboratories, a division of the American Home Products Corporation, for a combination of fees and payments worth as much as $59 million.

title: New Management Team Takes Over a Terminal at Kennedy and Begins Redesign
description: The master panel displaying incoming flights at the International Arrivals Building at Kennedy Airport is mounted on the back wall of the second floor, its position so remote that people waiting for passengers have to mount a flight of stairs and slalom through a food court to see it. It is a 1960's relic, made of little black and white letters that flip over like an alarm clock of similar vintage.

title: Bodies and Stolen Vehicles Leave a Trail Heading East
description: Evil is not supposed to visit places like East Scott Street, one of the richest blocks in the country. Money, privilege and state-of-the-art home security systems are usually more than enough to keep menace and mayhem away.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KRAVER, RICHARD M.
description: KRAVER-Richard M. Beloved husband of Harriet, loving father of Michael and Barry, cherished brother of Frederick J. Funeral services May 14th, 10 AM, at Congregation Kol Ami, 252 Soundview Ave, White Plains, NY. Donations to Memorial Sloan Kettering Cancer Center or Congregation Kol Ami Youth Activity Committee.

title: Baron Firm and 13 Charged With Cheating Thousands
description: A. R. Baron & Company and 13 former employees were indicted yesterday on charges that they created and ran a criminal enterprise that cheated thousands of investors, including New York University, a Consolidated Edison worker and the 10th Duke of Atholl, the late Scottish aristocrat, out of more than $75 million over several years.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BUMGARDNER, HARVEY E., JR.
description: BUMGARDNER-Harvey E., Jr. passed away in South Burlington, VT., on May 12, 1997. He will be missed by his wife, Dong-Sook Kim, son Gregory, daughters Deborah & Pamela, ex-wife Barbara & six grandchildren. Pre-deceased by son Harvey E., III. He will be buried in North Hero, Vermont. For info call Minor FH 802-893-6323

title: Brooklyn Pier's Collapse Puts 7 Fishermen in River
description: Seven people fishing off the end of Indian Street Pier, a crumbling wharf in Greenpoint, Brooklyn, were dropped into the East River last night when the end of the pier collapsed into the cold, murky waters, fire officials said.

title: Maultsby Cancels
description: The mezzo-soprano Nancy Maultsby has canceled her Alice Tully Hall recital on Monday because of illness in her family. Refunds are available by mailing tickets with a self-addressed stamped envelope to Alice Tully Hall Box Office, Attention GP/Maultsby, 1941 Broadway, New York, N.Y. 10023. Information: (212) 875-5050.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: RAYTHEON CO., Lexington, Mass., said it had won orders worth $710 million in separate contracts with the Air Force and Executive Jet Inc.

title: BBN Discloses a Bid Higher Than GTE's
description: The BBN Corporation has disclosed that it received a bid in April that was ''nominally higher'' than the $29 a share accepted from the GTE Corporation.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KIMBALL, HARRISON
description: KIMBALL-Harrison. April 28, 1997 at Los Angeles, CA, age 80. Son of the late Professor Everett Kimball of Smith College and the late Elizabeth McGrew Kimball. Preceded in death by brothers McGrew Kimball and Everett Kimball, Jr. Survived by wife Bernice Burr Kimball, son Geoffrey Kimball, former wife Elizabeth Kimball, daughters Deborah Kimball, Margaret Crawford and Judith Moss, niece Sr. Saraphina Kimball, and four grandchildren. A private memorial services was held May 10.

title: City's Survey Of Cleanliness Of Its Streets Is Questioned
description: Members of a City Council committee said yesterday that they were skeptical of the Giuliani administration's assertion that 83 percent of New York City's streets are acceptably clean, and they criticized the city's methods of rating street cleanliness.

title: Big U.S. Utility Spreads Its Reach to Berlin
description: The Southern Company, a huge utility based in Atlanta, said yesterday that it and two German utilities had formed a consortium that would seek to buy a controlling interest in the utility that serves the city of Berlin for $1.7 billion.

title: From the Birdhouse to (Maybe) the Jailhouse
description: In this suburban city, bird feeders are as common as swing sets and backyard barbecues. But one bird feeder has been declared illegal and its owner hauled into court to face a trial, complete with witnesses.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  EISINGER, ARNOLD
description: EISINGER-Arnold. Beloved husband of Fleuret. Dear step-father of Edmund Rothschild. Loving brother of Edward. Services are on Thursday 11:30 A.M., at ''Gutterman's'', Long Beach Road, Rockville Centre, Long Island.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: TENNIS

title: PENNEY (J.C.) CO. (JCP,N)
description: The J. C. Penney Company said yesterday that earnings fell 2.1 percent in its fiscal first quarter as markdowns eroded profits at its stores and catalogue business.

title: Scallops Round Out A Creamy Risotto
description: IN the beginning, there was Arborio, and it was not easy to find. Today, there are several varieties of short-grain rice like Arborio that are meant specifically for risotto. For those who like to experiment, a good Italian grocery store will offer an opportunity to buy two or three kinds, and they can cook them up to see the difference. The one style of rice that does not work is the American short-grain rice, because even when cooked according to risotto directions, it does not produce a creamy mass.

title: Housing Bill Doesn't Include Occupancy Limit
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STARK, HORTENSE GOLDBERG
description: STARK-Hortense Goldberg on May 13, 1997. Resident of Reston, Va and formerly of Miami Beach FL. Wife of the late Joseph Stark, mother of Martin with (Roslyn Stark) and Myrna with (the late Marvin Spodek). Also survived by three grandchildren, Andrew Stark, and Rachelle and Judd Spodek and one sister Anna Utrecht. Service will be held at Beth David Cemetery, Elmont NY on May 15, 1997 at 11AM. Memorial contributions may be made to the Alzheimer's Association or to the charity of one's choice.

title: Wake Up Call
description: People who say they can wake up at a specific time without having to rely on an alarm clock or the insistent nudging of a companion are often right, according to a study published in the journal Sleep.

title: Republican Incumbent Leading In Mayoral Race in Jersey City
description: Mayor Bret D. Schundler declared victory over two Democratic opponents in a citywide election today, but it was unclear tonight whether he had enough votes to avoid a runoff.

title: Israeli Labor Party Paves the Way for Replacing Peres as Its Leader
description: Israel's opposition Labor Party shut the door tonight to the continued leadership of Shimon Peres by voting down a proposal to create for him the post of party president. This set the stage for the election of a new party leader next month.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SERWER, BERNSTEIN, BLANCHE
description: SERWER-BERNSTEIN-Blanche, ELEM/Youth in distress in Israel mourns the passing of Blanche Bernstein, founder and hard working board member and professional of ELEM. Blanche's love of Israel and children showed in her persistent work at ELEM. She helped found our successful program for many Israeli families and children. Her alert mind remained during her long, courageous struggle against dying. Her love of life was conveyed by her many efforts up to her passing to bring peace and well being to troubled families in both Israel and America. Our heartfelt sympathy goes to her brother Sydney, and all her devoted children and grandchildren.

title: Rolls-Royce Wins Order
description: Rolls-Royce P.L.C. said today that a subsidiary, the Allison Engine Company, had received a $120 million contract to supply the Brazilian airline Rio-Sul Aeros with 10 jet engines. The London-based engineering company said Rio-Sul ordered 10 AE3007A engines and options for five more, for use in Embraer EMB-145 regional aircraft.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DINTENFASS, JULIUS, DR.
description: DINTENFASS-Julius, Dr., 86, of Woodsburg, NY, died May 8, 1997, in Florida. Beloved husband of Ruth of 58 years. Beloved father of Ellen, Marylyn and Nancy. Sons-in-law Julius Berger and Bruce Gurewitz. Ten adored grandchildren and two greatgrandchildren, and sister Tess Sommers. Graduate of Columbia University, Eastern Chiropractic College. MS from New York University. Attended University of Heidlberg College of Medicine. Chiropractic licence #

title: Return Engagement Likely for Devils' Lemaire
description: The Devils cleaned their lockers out today, exchanged phone numbers for the summer and said goodbye until training camp in the fall. Coach Jacques Lemaire and a couple of unrestricted free agents suggested that they would probably return.

title: Rent Decontrol Study: From No Impact to 30% Increases
description: A study commissioned by New York City has found that allowing rent increases once an apartment falls vacant, a policy recommended by Gov. George E. Pataki, would have a limited impact on the rent of most apartments during the next two years. But a few areas, including the Upper West Side, would see rent increases as high as 30 percent, the study found.

title: IMC TO ADD POTASH PRODUCER WESTERN AG-MINERALS
description: IMC Global Inc., based in Northbrook, Ill., agreed yesterday to buy the potash producer Western Ag-Minerals, a unit of Rayrock Yellowknife Resources Inc. of Toronto, for $53 million to expand in the Southwest. IMG, a mining and fertilizer company, said it would combine Western Ag's mine and processing plant in Carlsbad, N.M., with its own adjacent plant, forming an operation capable of producing 1.5 million tons of potash annually. IMC, with revenue of $2.98 billion in the year ended June 1996, produces potash, phosphate and sulfur used in agriculture and industry. IMC's shares fell $1.125, to $37.

title: People
description: * Daniel J. Osheyack, vice president for promotion and public affairs at Entertainment Weekly magazine, New York, owned by Time Warner Inc., was promoted to associate publisher, a new post.

title: With Focus On Messinger, Mayor Sounds Battle Theme
description: Suddenly free of the challenger he considered the most moderate, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani showed yesterday how he planned to campaign against his most likely opponent, portraying Ruth W. Messinger as a left-wing captive of Manhattan incapable of understanding the larger city.

title: Hot Prices but Cool Bidders for Impressionists at Sotheby's
description: There's no fooling today's millionaire. When it comes to buying Impressionist and modern art, he's cool and controlled and refuses to be swept away by the excitement of an auction. Yet when the work had the right ingredients at Sotheby's in Manhattan last night, the big spenders didn't hold back.

title: Corrections
description: A front-page picture caption yesterday about refugees in Zaire misstated the time of the action shown, in which orphans were evacuated on a cargo plane. It was May 3, not this Monday.

title: I Drive, Therefore I Am
description: To the Editor:

title: CHRONICLE
description: NELL CARTER, who is starring on Broadway as the nasty Miss Hannigan in ''Annie,'' will assume a more humane persona on Sunday at the 12th annual AIDS Walk New York in Central Park.

title: Ex-Officer Is Convicted
description: A former Palisades Park police officer convicted of stealing thousands of dollars from a private home while responding to a burglary alarm was sentenced to two years in prison yesterday.

title: Last Clink for Token-Only Turnstiles
description: High above the steel beams of the elevated Myrtle Avenue subway station in Bushwick, Brooklyn, transit workers yesterday sawed off and carted away a New York icon: the last ancient, token-gobbling mechanical turnstile.

title: Steinbrenner Banned as Executive Council Member
description: George Steinbrenner, the owner of the Yankees who is suing every other team and every high-level official in Major League Baseball, suffered a double-barreled blow today. The ruling executive council, calling the lawsuit a ''blatant violation'' of the Major League Agreement, suspended him indefinitely as a member.

title: Saudi Prince Buys 3% Stake in Cordiant
description: Cordiant P.L.C. and Prince Walid bin Talal, a Saudi, said yesterday that he had bought more than 3 percent of the company's shares in the open market. Though they did not disclose a purchase price, news services reported that the prince paid about $40 million.

title: Of Streets Paved With Sadness
description: With only a few dollars in his pocket, Amir (Pavan Malhotra), an illegal Pakistani immigrant arrives in London huddled in a vegetable crate. Rushed to the north of England in a van, he finds himself crammed into a dingy brick house with 17 other Pakistani ''illegals,'' all cowering in fear lest they be discovered and deported.

title: No Charges Seen In Racing Inquiry
description: Dennis Vacco, the attorney general of New York State, said yesterday that no criminal charges would be filed on $8 million in construction contracts awarded by officials of the New York Racing Association. The contracts have been under investigation by the state.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day yesterday about a proposed purchase of the New York television station WBIS by Paxson Communications misidentified two Florida stations that Paxson recently sold. They are WPBF and WTVX, both of Palm Beach Gardens, Fla.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KATZ, GRACE
description: KATZ-Grace, formerly of Great Neck, NY. Loving and devoted wife of Leonard, mother of Susan and Frances, sister of Arnold Grossman, sister-in-law of Ruth Grossman, Joan & Herbert Katz, Phyllis & Stanley Spielman. After a valiant and courageous fight against cancer-she was a true inspiration to us all. Contributions to a Cancer Society or Hospice of your choice. Services at Beth Israel Memorial Chapel, 5808 W. Atlantic Ave., Delray Beach, FL 33484 Wednesday, 5/14 at 12:30 PM

title: Franklin Spier to Expand
description: In an expansion move, Franklin Spier Inc., an advertising agency that specializes in book publishing, has leased 21,300 square feet at 450-460 Park Avenue South, adjacent buildings at 31st Street with several interconnected floors. The company is to move in July from 650 First Avenue, at 37th Street. The 10-year lease was valued at about $5 million.

title: Bad Blood Between Rangers and Flyers
description: It began in 1995, when the coaches, Terry Murray and Colin Campbell, did not shake hands after Murray's Flyers handed Campbell's Rangers four straight defeats in the second round of the playoffs. Each perceived that he was snubbed by the other.

title: Jell-O Grows Up: It's Refined But Still Fun
description: LIKE rice pudding, mashed potatoes, glazed doughnuts and other Proustian comfort foods, sweet gelatins are beginning to sneak into decidedly adult dining experiences. All shimmer and quiver, the vivid grown-up versions are virtuous and often witty riffs on the cherished Jell-O classic. And like the commercial gelatins, the new wave variations seem to be almost irresistible.

title: Lincoln Center Honors Drummer and Dancer
description: Stefon Harris, a percussionist with Jazz at Lincoln Center, and Christopher Wheeldon, a member of the New York City Ballet, are the recipients of this year's Martin E. Segal Awards, given annually to promising young artists associated with Lincoln Center. They each received an award of $5,000 yesterday at a luncheon at Lincoln Center.

title: The Mercury News Comes Clean
description: The San Jose Mercury News made a courageous gesture on Sunday when it admitted that articles charging the Central Intelligence Agency with complicity in the drug trade had been poorly written and edited and misleadingly packaged. The executive editor, Jerry Ceppos, told readers the articles fell short of the paper's standards at every step along the way. His candor and self-criticism set a high standard for cases in which journalists make egregious errors.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CARLTON, RICHARD E.
description: CARLTON-Richard E. of Bedford, New York, and New York City, in Bath, England, on May 11, 1997, age 57. Beloved husband of Elizabeth and loving father of Beth Carlton Camp and Catherine. He is also survived by his father, Edwin Carlton, Jr., his brothers, Stephen B. Carlton and Edwin Carlton, and his son-in-law, Lawton M. Camp. Funeral at 2:30 PM on Saturday, May 17, at St. Matthew's Church, Route 22, Bedford, NY, followed by a reception.

title: Silence In Venice: Bad Sign For Biennale
description: The two years between Venice Biennales is not a long gestation for a major international exhibition. But for the 1997 Biennale, which will open to the public on June 15, the time has been even shorter.

title: Harbaugh Is Champion, But Only on Golf Course
description: Jim Harbaugh, the Indianapolis Colts quarterback known as Captain Comeback, may deserve a new nickname after his performance today in the Cadillac N.F.L. Golf Classic.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: Baseball

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROSSELL, RAFAEL
description: ROSSELL-Rafael. Passed away unexpectedly Sunday, May 11, 1997, of heart failure. Beloved husband of Ana. Father of Roxana, Robert and Roman. Grandfather of Jocelyn. A dedicated father, psychoanalyst, critical intellectual and educator throughout his life. His family, friends, colleagues and students will miss his wit, insight and sensitivity. Memorial service Thursday, May 15th, Cobble Hill Chapels, 171 Court Street at Dean Street, Brooklyn, 6-8 P.M.

title: Dean Kelley, 70, Advocate for Religious Freedom, Dies
description: The Rev. Dean M. Kelley, a leading proponent of religious liberty who used his position at the National Council of Churches to speak out for the rights of religious groups large and small, died Sunday at his home in West Swanzey, N.H. He was 70.

title: College's Ripple Effect
description: To the Editor:

title: Dollar Drops for a Sixth Day; Off 6% in Week Against Yen
description: The dollar declined against the yen yesterday for a sixth consecutive day even as Japan's top finance official suggested it had fallen enough.

title: Reprimand Urged for Lawyer
description: The New Jersey Supreme Court's Disciplinary Review Board recommended yesterday that a lawyer be reprimanded for his actions after the 1994 explosion of a natural gas pipeline in Edison. Lawyers had flocked to the scene to drum up business hours after the blast, which injured 100 people and left 300 homeless.

title: Are Nordstrom's Efforts Eroding Profits?
description: There is probably no one who does not know that Nordstrom Inc. is the ultimate in customer service among mainstream retailers. Far fewer people, it seems, can explain why the company has just started to crawl out from under almost two years of dismal results.

title: WITH FERRER OUT, MESSINGER FOCUSES ON FACING GIULIANI
description: With her main Democratic adversary stepping aside, Ruth W. Messinger yesterday sought to transform the mayoral race into a two-person contest with Rudolph W. Giuliani, ignoring her remaining Democratic rivals as she demanded a one-on-one debate with the Mayor.

title: Bacharach and His Place in the Pop Pantheon
description: Long before Lite FM, there was Burt Bacharach, the composer with a genius for hummable tunes. He is profiled tonight on a PBS ''Great Performances'' special called ''Burt Bacharach: This Is Now,'' which was made for the BBC. The British (and the Irish) have a knack for preserving and honoring music that, while perhaps no longer on the fashion cusp, is very much a part of the pop pantheon. Good is good.

title: Clinton Wreaks Havoc on Research and Policy
description: To the Editor:

title: Freight Elevator's Plunge Injures 10 in Queens
description: A freight elevator carrying 13 workers and 30 or more boxes of computer paper fell two stories at a city welfare office in Queens yesterday afternoon and landed with a jolt in the elevator pit in the basement, breaking the legs of one worker and slightly injuring nine others, the Fire Department said.

title: Rent Debate: Drama Is Familiar
description: The day after Gov. George E. Pataki announced his plan to broker a compromise that would gradually end rent regulations, Assembly Speaker Sheldon Silver was still saying that he wanted the laws extended, untouched. The Senate majority leader, Joseph L. Bruno, arguing that the Governor's plan did not go far enough, was still saying he wanted the laws abolished in a handful of years. Compromise seemed as distant as ever.

title: Retail Sales Down 0.3% Last Month
description: The nation's consumers, after spending at a surprisingly strong pace during the first months of the year, have sharply cut back on shopping, with April posting the first monthly decline in retail sales since the start of the Christmas holiday season.

title: TV Notes
description: Families Valued

title: Suit by Digital Says Intel Stole Pentium Design
description: The Digital Equipment Corporation stunned the computer industry and Wall Street yesterday by filing a lawsuit contending that the Intel Corporation stole some of its patented chip designs to create the popular Pentium microprocessors, the key component in more than 85 percent of the world's personal computers.

title: The Rogue Has Not Changed a Bit
description: GEORGE STEINBRENNER, never known for his deft touch, seemed to have finally mastered the art of being a solid citizen during the Yankees' championship season last year.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NEUBERGER, MARIE SALANT
description: NEUBERGER-Marie Salant, 88, died on May 11th, 1997. Beloved wife of Roy R. Neuberger for nearly sixty-five years. Devoted mother of Ann Aceves, Roy S. and Linda Neuberger, and James Neuberger. Treasured grandmother of Andrea, Patricia and Matthew London, Sarah Lancry, Yaffa Jungreis and Miriam, Aharon and Nechama Neuberger, great-grandmother of seven. Cherished sister of Walter and Edna Salant and the late William Salant and his widow, Dorothy. Mrs. Neuberger was a past president of the Women's City Club of New York, former chairman of the Board of Governors of The Ethical Culture Schools for thirteen years and a member of the Board of Trustees of Bryn Mawr College, her alma mater. In lieu of flowers, a contribution to any of the above organizations would be appreciated. Graveside services were held at Mount Neboh Cemetery, Queens, on Monday, May 12. A memorial service will be announced.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEBER, JOSEPH
description: WEBER-Joseph. Beloved husband of Elisabeth. Devoted father of Susan & Steven. Loving fatherin-law of Barbara and Stephen. Cherished grandfather of Jason, Jordan, Matthew & his wife Carrie.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  DONOHUE, ANNA
description: DONOHUE-Anna. May 14, 1996 In loving memory. Bill, Tara, Eileen and Johnny

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Domingo, in Role of the Restaurateur, Takes a Deep Breath
description: WHEN Placido Domingo's restaurant, Domingo, opened last November on East 49th Street, musicians, diplomats, a cross section of New York's food world and Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani helped celebrate what promised to be an elegant Spanish restaurant worthy of the world-famous tenor. But the excitement quickly died down.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-11

title: Bank Profits Hit A Quarterly High
description: United States commercial banks reported net income of $14.1 billion in the first quarter, according to a survey by SNL Securities, a Charlottesville-based research firm. It was a high for any three-month period.

title: Parsons Dean Offers a Farewell
description: In his farewell commencement speech yesterday, the dean of Parsons School of Design told this year's 701 graduates that creating things that convey beauty and good taste but that also acknowledge competing cultural values, new technology and social responsibility would be among their most difficult challenges.

title: B.C. Lets Penn Out of Scholarship
description: Boston College said yesterday that it has granted its starting point guard, SCOONIE PENN, a release from his basketball scholarship.

title: Girl, 16, Leaving for School, Is Fatally Shot in Co-op City
description: A 16-year-old girl was fatally shot in the hallway outside her Co-op City apartment yesterday morning as she left for school, the police said.

title: City College's Flavor
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MORRIS, JAMES M.
description: MORRIS-James M. On May 12, 1997. Beloved husband of Maureen (nee Fay). Loving father of James Jr., Kathryn Fowler, Madelyn Strickland, Diane Spizzirro, Christopher, Stephen and Brian. Devoted grandfather of Ashley, Christopher James and Cullen James. Visiting Thursday & Friday 2-4 & 7-9PM at the John J. Fox Funeral Home, Inc. 2080 Boston Post Road, Larchmont, NY 10538. Mass Saturday 10AM, at Sts. John and Paul Church. Interment Gate of Heaven Cemetery. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to The Padre Pio Shelter C/O Father Benedict Groeschel C.F.R. of Trinity Retreat House, 1 Pryer Manor Rd., Larchmont, NY 10538.

title: Haute Cuisine, At Its Very Highest
description: SPRINGTIME in Paris. The air smells of violets and chocolates. Every tree is in bloom. ''Venez, goutez,'' call the fruit vendors, holding out handfuls of fragrant red strawberries as you stroll past their stalls.

title: Wilde and Oedipus
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  UNGERLAND, ADELAIDE G.
description: UNGERLAND-Adelaide G., on May 10, 1997. Beloved mother of Thomas, loving grandmother and step-grandmother, dear sister of Eleanor Holmewood. Friends may call at FranK E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street, Tuesday and Wednesday, 3-5, 7-9 PM. Funeral Mass at St. Ignatius Loyola Church, Park Avenue at 84th Street, Thursday 10 A.M.

title: TYCO PLANS TO BUY INBRAND FOR $320 MILLION
description: Tyco International Ltd. said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire the Inbrand Corporation, a maker of disposable adult incontinence products, for $320 million in stock. Under the agreement, Inbrand shareholders will receive 0.43 Tyco share for each Inbrand share held. Shares of Inbrand surged $10.875 a share, or 68 percent, to $26.875, in Nasdaq trading. Shares of Tyco were up 62.5 cents, to $63.875, on the New York Stock Exchange. Tyco, based in Exeter, N.H., is a conglomerate best known for its fire-safety products. It also makes disposable medical products, packaging materials and electrical components. Inbrand, based in Atlanta, makes adult incontinence and feminine hygiene products. It had full-year revenue of $240 million.

title: United and 4 Others to Detail Air Alliance Today
