description: United Airlines, Lufthansa and three other carriers are expected today to announce details of a plan to stitch together their operations and marketing efforts to a degree that goes beyond any current alliance.

title: Coca-Cola will take a new tack to appeal to diet-soda drinkers.
description: THE Coca-Cola Company, tinkering again with the advertising approach for Diet Coke, is seeking to convince consumers to buy the brand not just for the taste of it but just for the heck of it.

title: If His Party Was Unsurprised by Ferrer's Move, Some Voters Are Crestfallen
description: The rumors had been rampant for weeks, churning themselves into the central topic of discussion at Democratic political events in the Bronx and beyond.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GROSS, LEO
description: GROSS-Leo. On May 10, 1997. Age 82. Survived by his wife, Norma; his children, Alan (Penni Harmon), Terry (Victoria Kelly) and Jody (Perk Larsen); and his grandchildren Mowgli, Crystal, Lily, Daniel and Elliot. Memorial service May 16 at 2 PM, at the Ethical Culture Society, 2 West 64 Street at CPW. In lieu of flowers, donations can be made to the Visiting Nurse Service of NY, Hospice Care, 1250 Broadway, New York 10001, or Hospice of the Florida Keys, 1319 William Street, Key West, Florida 33040.

title: Regaining Control Of Body and Game
description: Terry-Jo Myers still remembers the moments of pain and fear on the golf course, a pain so intense that she couldn't bend over to read a putt, and the fear of knowing she couldn't make it four, or three, or even two more holes without stopping at a rest room.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BRAVERMAN, MILLICENT
description: BRAVERMAN-Millicent, of Los Angeles, CA., on May 9, loving mother and grandmother, cofounder, the Braverman-Mirisch Agency, popular radio host of ''Millicent Braverman On Books'', and wonderful friend, sadly missed.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROSS, ANNETTE BURR
description: ROSS-Annette Burr. Died at the age of 102 in Sarasota, Florida, on May 11. Formerly of Westport, CT. and NYC. Widow of Gustave Ross. Survived by her daughter, Sheilah Gignoux, son, Christopher, granddaughters, Amanda Cross, Lisa Pownall-Gray, and Victoria Green; grandson Nicholas Ross and six great grandchildren. Service in Sarasota on November 9.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LACHER, CINDY
description: LACHER-Cindy. In loving memory of Cindy Lacher, beloved wife of Mark Lacher and mother of Ami and Randy. From Howard and Daniel Koeppel and all your friends and family at Koeppel Auto Group. Funeral to be held at 9:45AM on Wednesday, May 14 at Holy Trinity Church, 14th Avenue and Whitestone Expressway, Whitestone, New York.

title: Displays of Virtuosity in Relays
description: Like weddings, ballet galas can make you laugh and cry. A genuine jubilee is harder to come by nowadays than a thinly veiled pitch for money. But, happily, American Ballet Theater came up with a clever theme benefit to open its spring season on Monday night at the Metropolitan Opera House.

title: WNYC Advertises On Buses and Kiosks
description: WNYC, the public radio station that offers classical music on its FM band and news and talk on its AM band, has started its biggest advertising campaign ever to recruit more listeners and assert its newly acquired independence from New York City government.

title: Corrections
description: A credit with a diagram in Science Times yesterday about evidence of city planning in the early Bronze Age misstated the affiliation of a data source. Dr. Timothy Matney is a visiting assistant professor of anthropology at Whitman College in Walla Walla, Wash., not the University of California at San Diego.

title: CHRONICLE
description: It is the time of year for old grads to assemble on college campuses to renew ties and immerse themselves in nostalgia.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FAXON, HENRY H. JR.
description: FAXON-Henry H. Jr., of Boston, May 10, 1997. Memorial Service Trinity Church, Boston, Saturday, May 17 at 1 P.M.

title: The Gamblers' Bid
description: Although casino profits on the garish Las Vegas strip have slumped more than 9 percent in the past year, organized gambling still has reason to cheer: its lobbyist in Washington hit the jackpot. Of the nine members appointed to the National Gambling Impact and Policy Commission, three are in the pocket of the Las Vegas casino crowd.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DRISCOLL, WILLIAM NOTT
description: DRISCOLL-William Nott. Age 80. Of Plymouth, MN. Died Sunday, May 11th, 1997. LaRose School, Switzerland, The Hill School, Yale, 1940, U.S. Navy Pilot during W.W. II, Board President United Theological Seminary, New Brighton, MN, Board President, Minnesota Outward Bound School. Survived by sister Jessica D. Dean, his wife Judith Russell Driscoll and children Rosalyn, William, Jr., Peter, Thomas and Conrad. Services at 3 P.M., Thursday, Saint Martin's By The Lake, Minnetonka Beach, MN. Inquiries David Lee Funeral Home, 612-473-5577.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TEPLITZ, ANNA
description: TEPLITZ-Anna. On May 12, 1997. Age 94. Widow of Gilbert Teplitz. Mother of Dr. Harold and Phyllis, Dr. Carl and Mary, Dr. Gerald and Barbara. Grandmother of Dr. Ellen and Barry Warhit, Sharon and Dr. Alan Boykin, Dr. Donald and Hildy Teplitz, Dr. Glen & Dr. Stephanie Teplitz, Beth Teplitz, Jeff and Pamela Teplitz. Great-grandmother of Margo and Benjamin, Max and Emma, Corey and Julie, Justin, Brett and Eric. Services today 12:30PM Boulevard Chapel, Hewlett, Long Island.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ITZEL, JOSEPHINE M.
description: ITZEL-Josephine M. Age 91, Died April 15, 1997. Daughter of Pauline and Carl Itzel. A Bronx resident her entire life, for over 35 years she taught swimming in New York City public schools, retiring from Walton High School in 1962. She is survived by a sister and brotherin-law Pauline and Frank Kolinek of Freedom, New Hampshire. Burial in Woodlawn cemetary at a later date.

title: McVeigh's Friend Sticks to Story Despite Stiff Questioning on Blast
description: In a high-stakes assault on the Federal Government's star witness, Timothy J. McVeigh's defense lawyer today sought to portray his client's former close friend as a liar and an opportunist, motivated by the hope of avoiding many years in prison himself.

title: New Refugee Crisis Builds in Zaire
description: A refugee catastrophe is unfolding on another front here as Zairian rebel troops continue rolling up territory. Tens of thousands of Rwandan refugees, who have braved some of harshest jungle on the planet for the last eight months to escape Zairian rebels, are now massed for an exodus into neighboring Congo.

title: A nationwide survey indicates more people will spend more money on vacations this summer.
description: SUMMER vacation travel is expected to grow 2 percent over last year's record, and travelers are expected to spend 2 percent more, or $1,112, on their longest trip of the summer.

title: 'Unchecked' Experiments on People Raise Concern
description: On the outskirts of the nation's capital, tucked away on the sixth floor of a suburban office building, there is a little-known computer data base: a state-by-state accounting of the experiences of every cat, dog, hamster, guinea pig, chimpanzee, rabbit or farm animal used in a laboratory experiment.

title: Love May Be Blind, but Envy Is Evil
description: If the romantic comedy ''Sprung'' runs out of distinctive invention well before it runs out of plot and proves in the end to be an essentially silly contrivance, it remains a movie that holds the prospect of better times for its director and star.

title: A Market of Mood Swings
description: Its been a wild two months for the stock market.

title: Conner Meets Cup Deadline
description: Dennis Conner, a veteran of seven America's Cup campaigns, met the final deadline yesterday for challenging New Zealand in the 1999-2000 racing series.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BENDHEIM, CHARLES HENRY
description: BENDHEIM - Charles Henry. Passed away Saturday, May 10, at his home in Jerusalem, Israel, and was interred there on May 11. He will be sorely missed by wife, sister, children, grandchildren and great-grandchildren, and by everyone he came in contact with. The family will sit shiva in Jerusalem until Tuesday evening, May 13; Fax 972-2-625-3843; email bendheim@inter.net.il. Thereafter, shiva will continue at 4680 Livingston Avenue, Riverdale, New York, through Friday, May 16.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KENT, ILSE ABELES
description: KENT-Ilse Abeles, on May 12, 1997. Beloved wife of the late Otto Abeles and the late Robert Kent. Loving mother of Dr. Ernest D. Abeles, cherished grandmother of Eddie, Jennie and Evelyn. Service on Wednesday at 2:30 P.M., Beth El Cemetery, New Jersey.

title: Restaurant to Fill Niche Under Park Ave. Viaduct
description: For five years, the space beneath the Park Avenue viaduct opposite Grand Central Terminal at 42d Street has sat vacant and forlorn, a retail space in search of a retailer. But by the end of the year, street pigeons nibbling on crumbs are to be replaced by tourists, commuters and city residents dining in what its new proprietor calls ''a place where people can come in tuxedos or T-shirts.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ASCH, JOHN
description: ASCH-John. Died May 10, 1997 at the age of 90. Beloved husband of Mary Blume-Asch, devoted son of author Sholem Asch, loving brother of Ruth Shaffer, of Brighton, England, and Nathan and Moses Asch, both deceased. Stepfather of James and Frederick Blume, father-in-law of Kathryn Frank and Mary Blume, grandfather of Zach, all of whom greatly mourn his loss. We will sorely miss him.

title: Soccer Replay Is Ordered
description: Declaring that the referee made a bad call when he stopped a 13-year-old Indian boy from competing in a weekend soccer match because he was wearing a turban, officials of the United States Soccer Federation ordered yesterday that the game be replayed, the A.P. reported.

title: Accounts
description: * Nokia Americas, Dallas, to the Richards Group, Dallas, to handle advertising in the United States for its mobile phone division, which had been handled by Grey Advertising, New York. Spending last year for all Nokia brands was estimated at $3 million; billings this year for the mobile-phone account are expected to reach $15 million to $20 million.

title: AURUM SOFTWARE IS ACQUIRED FOR $250 MILLION
description: The Baan Company, a Dutch software concern, said yesterday that it had agreed to buy Aurum Software Inc. in a stock deal worth about $250 million. The transaction values Aurum at about $21 a share. Baan will issue about 0.3559 common share for each outstanding share of Aurum stock. Baan stock ended yesterday at $60.50, down $1.625 a share, in Nasdaq trading. Aurum was halted before the close at $17.125, up 50 cents a share. Baan makes business software solutions for clientserver networks. Aurum, which is based in Santa Clara, Calif., makes automation software for sales and telemarketing.

title: In His Own Words
description: FERNANDO FERRER

title: No Headline
description: ''How are we ever going to progress if people only say nice things?''

title: In the Vegetable Garden, Rhubarb Tartly Rears Its Head
description: MARY EVANS trudged across the grounds of Longwood Gardens on a visit the other day. ''Now it's official,'' she said in the stately botanical park on the former estate of the chemical tycoon Pierre S. du Pont, in Kennett Square, 30 miles west of Philadelphia. ''The rhubarb's up. It's spring.''

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Stock Prices Recede On Worries About Rates

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NOMBURG, HARRY
description: NOMBURG-Harry. Born in Coburg, Germany, on November 17, 1923, he was sent with a ''Kindertransport'' to Scotland in May 1939. As a member of a British Commando Unit, he participated in the D-Day invasion of Normandy and fought Nazi Germany until its collapse. In 1948 he came to the US where he served as a Paratrooper with the 82nd Airborne Division. He was demobilized in 1952 and worked for the US Postal Service for forty-two years. A friendly and generous man, he was always mindful of family ties and was very helpful throughout his life to his many friends scattered all over the world. He bettered the lives of all he touched and he will always live in our hearts.

title: Lessons From Los Angeles
description: There was a radical shift in American politics when Richard J. Riordan was re-elected Mayor of Los Angeles last month. For the first time, Hispanic voters outnumbered blacks as a share of the electorate in Los Angeles, becoming the city's largest minority voting bloc. Mr. Riordan, a Republican, not only survived this realignment; he actually profited from it.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PARLIN, JOHN J. (JACK)
description: PARLIN-John J. (Jack). Died on May 13, 1997, at the Morristown Memorial Hospital, Morristown, New Jersey. Advertising executive for The New York Times, retired 1992 after 38 years. Born in NYC and lived in Parsippany, NJ for last thirty years. W.W. II Navy veteran, Mason for St. John's Lodge, Mountain Lakes, NJ, and also member of their bowling team; volunteer for Special Olympics and volunteer tutor with the Literacy Volunteers of America; also had B.A. in English from Fairleigh Dickinson Univ., Rutherford Campus, 1982. Survived by his wife, B. Leslie (Immerman), one daughter, Janice Parlin of Hyde Park, MA, one brother, Laurence Parlin of NYC, and one sister, Joanne Ryan of San Rafael, CA., and two grandchildren, Daniel and Falasha Parlin. Funeral services private. For information: Par-Troy Funeral Home, 95 Parsippany Road, Parsippany, New Jersey.

title: Free House Creates Some Sparks in Practice Run
description: ''There's no Seattle Slew out there,'' said Gary Capuano, the trainer of Captain Bodgit, who lost the Kentucky Derby by a head. ''It's a solid crop of 3-year-olds. There's no one horse who stands out.''

title: Peter Stackpole, 83, Chronicler Of California Trends for Life
description: Peter Stackpole, an original staff photographer for Life magazine, who chronicled the building of the Golden Gate Bridge, the invasion of Saipan, the glamour of Hollywood and life beneath the sea, died on Sunday at Novato Community Hospital in Novato, Calif., where he lived. He was 83.

title: Riley Scolds the Heat: Don't Be So Pessimistic
description: Pat Riley, coach of the Miami Heat, sharply criticized his players at practice today for showing little confidence in the wake of their 89-76 loss to the Knicks Monday night in New York.

title: Making Art That Imitates One Man's Life
description: Work and art swirl together in Ralph Fasanella's palette. A self-taught painter, he captures the color and energy of blue-collar characters in his kinetic cityscapes. They reflect his life and politics. So when somebody called his style naive, he swore he didn't know the meaning of the word.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RESNICK, LILYAN
description: RESNICK-Lilyan. The NY Young Leadership Division of the Alyn Hospital expresses condolences to our esteemed executive director Joan Mendelson and her family on the loss of her beloved mother. Our thoughts and love are with you at this difficult time. Marilyn and Scott Ostro Laura Anreder, The Young Leadership Board

title: Don't Label Critics Of Expanded NATO
description: To the Editor:

title: Class Notes
description: Audi Thompson, 17, sat on the edge of her seat in the crowd yesterday, gasping as the two teams traded points in quick succession.

title: The Pop Life
description: The Ins and Outs of Touring

title: Zairian Rebels Push Past Army In Final March Toward Capital
description: Zairian rebel forces broke through the Government's last major defensive position short of the capital today and announced that they would arrive in the city within hours, in their final push in a seven-month fight to topple President Mobutu Sese Seko.

title: L. J. Selznick, Producer and Philanthropist, 64
description: L. Jeffrey Selznick, a film and television producer and the president of the Louis B. Mayer Foundation, died on Monday in Los Angeles. He was 64 and lived in Miami.

title: A Family Turns Night Into Day for a Child With a Rare Skin Disease
description: Caren and Dan Mahar thought about sending their 5-year-old daughter, Katie, to school once a week this fall, but decided against it. It would have meant her having to wear a sleeping bag over her head while she was being transported and finding a windowless room where she could play and learn.

title: In Her Own Words
description: RUTH W. MESSINGER

title: Bus Driver Held Hostage
description: A gunman held a New Jersey Transit driver hostage in a bus on a downtown street for four hours yesterday before being taken into custody, The Associated Press reported.

title: Procter & Gamble Agrees To Deal With Regeneron
description: The Procter & Gamble Company and Regeneron Pharmaceuticals Inc., a biotechnology company that has had trouble bringing promising research to market, said yesterday that they had signed a 10-year agreement to jointly develop and market new drugs.

title: Harcourt General, Not Sylvan, To Acquire National Education
description: With a sweetened $800 million offer, the publisher Harcourt General Inc. announced yesterday that it would acquire the National Education Corporation in a deal to expand into ripe markets for computer training and workbook materials.

title: Bundle Up
description: Don't forget to dress warmly is better advice than your mother may have realized, according to a study published in the May 10 issue of The Lancet, an international medical journal published in Britain.

title: CHRONICLE
description: One of Israel's best-known fathers, BENJAMIN NETANYAHU, took his son's kindergarten class on a field trip in Jerusalem yesterday, The Associated Press reported.

title: PENN TRAFFIC TO CUT COSTS AND DISMISS 325 WORKERS
description: The Penn Traffic Company said yesterday that it was dismissing 325 employees and eliminating five divisional headquarters in a plan to cut costs by $12 million. The company, a supermarket chain based in Syracuse, said it was eliminating about 20 percent of its nonstore work force and closing divisional headquarters in Columbus, Ohio; in Syracuse and Jamestown, N.Y., and in DuBois and the Wilkes-Barre-Scranton area of Pennsylvania. Penn Traffic operates a wholesale food distribution business and 265 supermarkets in New York, Pennsylvania, Ohio and West Virginia mainly with the name Big Bear.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: Toddler, Left Outside Restaurant, Is Returned to Her Mother
description: A 14-month-old girl who was taken away from her parents after being left alone in her stroller outside an East Village restaurant while her parents dined was ordered returned to her mother by a Family Court judge yesterday.

title: Bulls, Led By Rodman, Keep Going
description: The Chicago Bulls pulled out their eye-popping display, complete with bells, whistles and Dennis Rodman.

title: For a Flood-Stricken Town, Hope Is a Next-Door Neighbor to Despair
description: Rigg Street will never be the same. The Licking River made sure of that when it tore through the block and the rest of this small town like a tornado two months ago, ripping houses off their foundations and floating away cars, trucks, mobile homes, people and dreams in its angry, fast-moving flood waters.

title: HOUSE PASSES BILL ADDING RESOURCES TO TEACH DISABLED
description: The House today passed legislation that gives public schools more money and flexibility to educate children with disabilities, along with greater authority to discipline them in cases involving guns and drugs.

title: Panel Meets To Consider Bill of Rights For Patients
description: A Presidential advisory commission heard sharply conflicting testimony today about whether more Government regulation was needed to define and protect the rights of health care consumers.

title: School Ruling Is Due
description: The New Jersey Supreme Court will issue its much-awaited ruling today on whether the new school financing law meets a state constitutional requirement that children from poor districts receive an education that is equal to what is offered in wealthier districts.

title: In Medieval Aragon, the Jews and Christians Face Off
description: The Middle Ages were a troubled time for the Jews of Europe. It was an era when the Church of Rome spread its influence across the Continent, using the threat of excommunication to keep the myriad kings in check and encouraging the persecution of Jews as a Catholic duty.

title: MetroStars to Face Colombia
description: The MetroStars will play the first of three international games scheduled for Giants Stadium when they take on Colombia's national team tonight. They will also play Alianza of Lima, Peru, on June 25 and Galatasaray of Istanbul, Turkey, on July 16.

title: What Pompeians Drank in the Last Days
description: HOW about a volcano that spews wine, not terrifying molten lava? Piero, Antonio and Carlo Mastroberardino, the owners of the Mastroberardino Winery in Atripalda, near Naples, have started a project to study winemaking in the days of Pompeii.

title: Firms Set a Record in Lobbying of City
description: Lobbyists reported earning a record $9.95 million last year to represent clients on matters involving New York City government, an increase of 9 percent over 1995, according to a new report.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SELZNICK, L. JEFFREY
description: SELZNICK-L. Jeffrey. The Trustees of The Louis B. Mayer Foundation mourn the death on May 12, 1997, of their fellow Trustee and President, L. Jeffrey Selznick. Mr. Selznick, a grandson of the Foundation's Founder, Louis B. Mayer, guided the Foundation in recent years to focus on bio-medical research and entertainment film preservation. We will miss Mr. Selznick's leadership, dedication, and friendship. A memorial service will be announced at a later date.

title: Sugar Industry Isn't the Villain in Everglades
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FLAMENBAUM, NATHAN
description: FLAMENBAUM-Nathan. Congregation Orach Chaim records with sorrow the passing of the father of our devoted member, Michael Flamenbaum. Our heartfelt sympathy to the entire family. Dr. Michael D. Shmidman, Rabbi Abraham Sinnreich, M.D., Pres.

title: Deutsche Telekom Sees Profit Doubling in '97
description: Deutsche Telekom A.G. said yesterday that it expected its profit to more than double this year as growth in Germany's phone market offsets rising price competition. Deutsche Telekom, the state-run phone company, also reported a first-quarter sales increase of 8 percent and a pretax profit of 2.2 billion marks ($1.29 billion), which some analysts found disappointing.

title: Croatia Resettling Its People In Houses Seized From Serbs
description: The Croatian Government has quietly confiscated tens of thousands of houses that once belonged to ethnic Serbs who were expelled from southern Croatia and has undertaken a program to settle ethnic Croats from Bosnia and Serbia in the seized property, relief workers and diplomats say.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BEEBE, RODERICK, JR.
description: BEEBE-Roderick, Jr. 85, educator at The Gunnery, died in CT., on Sunday.

title: From Purple Mohawks to Prosthetic Wigs
description: WHEN Cher, Diana Ross and Madonna come to Barry Hendrickson's Bitz-n-Pieces, they come to buy a wig. When RuPaul and Lypsinka, two prominent drag artists, come to Bitz-n-Pieces, they buy wigs, too (along with that other prominent drag artist, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani, whose blond do stole the recent Inner Circle show). But when chemotherapy patients come to Bitz-n-Pieces, Mr. Hendrickson and his staff are adamant: they are not buying wigs. They are buying medical hair prosthetics. Or their insurance won't pay for them.

title: White House Hints at Backing of Ban on Some Abortions
description: White House officials indicated today that President Clinton might support a bill that would curb late-term abortions, a measure that if enacted would mark a roll-back of abortion rights.

title: Study Links Memory Loss To Nerve Gas, As in Gulf
description: The Defense Department said today that Pentagon-sponsored research had produced ''important'' results suggesting that exposure to low levels of nerve gas and some pesticides can lead to memory loss, a common complaint among veterans of the 1991 Persian Gulf war.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHMIER, ANN
description: SCHMIER-Ann. Died Thursday May 8, of natural causes at the age of 89. She was the daughter of Asaac and Rose Revkin Mintzer. Mrs. Schmier was a principal in the NYC school system. She is survived by a brother, George Mintzer of San Francisco, her daughter, Frances Lourie of Stamford, CT., and two grandchildren. She was predeceased by her husband Maurice Schmier, a chiropractor.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KEARNEY, MARCIA
description: KEARNEY-Marcia, 46, of St. Petersburg, FL. Died unexpectedly May 12, 1997. Beloved daughter of Lee Froehlich Kearney and the late Paul. Dear sister of Marilee Bleetstein and Maureen Jacobs, and sister-in-law of Gary Bleetstein. Cherished aunt of Desiree, Michelle and Alix. We will miss her. Private graveside service.

title: A Co-op Must Pay $640,000 For Denying Sublet to Black
description: When Gregory and Shannon Broome, two young lawyers, found the apartment of their dreams a few years ago in the elegant Beekman Place neighborhood on Manhattan's East Side, they were ready to move in.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HAMILTON, OLIVIA KEITT
description: HAMILTON-Olivia Keitt. Of Palm Beach, FL., and Southbury, CT., on May 12. Wife of the late Frederick J. Hamilton. Winner of countless badminton trophies. Mother of Olivia McCulloch, Elizabeth Hamilton and Alice Hyatt of NY City. Grandmother of Katherine Keitt and Robert James McCulloch, Cary Hamilton and Keith Hyatt. Service Tuesday, May 27 at Church of the Heavenly Rest Chapel, at 90th St. and Fifth Avenue, at 1:00 PM.

title: HON INDUSTRIES TO ADD ALLSTEEL OFFICE FURNITURE
description: Hon Industries said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire Allsteel Inc. from the British conglomerate BTR P.L.C. for an undisclosed amount. Hon, an office-furniture maker based in Muscatine, Iowa, said it intended to finance the acquisition with cash and bank debt. Allsteel, a maker of midpriced office furniture, has five manufacturing plants in Tennessee, Mississippi and Pennsylvania. Last year it had about $150 million in sales. In 1996, Hon earned $68.1 million, or $2.26 a share. It had 1996 sales of $998.1 million.

title: On Zaire, Maybe U.S. Can Now Get It Right
description: To the Editor:

title: U.S. Petroleum Data
description: In millions of barrels except refinery utilization

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HODES, SIDNEY S.
description: HODES-Sidney S. Beloved uncle to Maxine Lax & Michael Hodes, friend and benefactor to many people. GVSD svc will be held at 1 PM, Wednesday, 5/14/97 at Mount Hebron Cemetery, Flushing, N.Y.

title: Prosecutors Are Asked to Charge Nomura
description: Japanese securities regulators asked prosecutors today to charge the Nomura Securities Company and three executives with illegally compensating a racketeer for trading losses.

title: Merck Unit to Novartis for $910 Million
description: Novartis A.G., the Swiss pharmaceutical and chemical giant, announced yesterday that it would acquire Merck & Company's crop protection business for $910 million.

title: These Days, Most Things Are Going the Mets' Way
description: On the field, at least, the Mets can do no wrong right now.

title: INSIDE METRO
description: A TOKEN GOODBYE -- All the subway stations in New York City have now been outfitted for the Metrocard, signaling the impending demise of the token. B3.

title: Heir Sentenced Up to 30 Years For Killing of Olympic Wrestler
description: John E. du Pont, the mentally disturbed heir to a chemical fortune, received a 13- to 30-year sentence today for the murder of David Schultz, an Olympic wrestler who lived at Mr. du Pont's training center in suburban Philadelphia.

title: A Guitarist's Return, Contd.
description: David Leisner was at the start of a promising career as a concert guitarist in the early 1980's when a hand injury forced him to abandon the stage and concentrate on teaching and composing. Mr. Leisner gradually rehabilitated himself, though, and he found a way to diminish some of the purely physical stress of performance. Instead of using his hands and arms to balance the guitar while playing, he has attached a stand to the back of the instrument so that it rests in position on his lap, leaving his hands free. Now fully recovered, he presented a series this season that included concerts devoted to Bach, the Romantic literature and, in the finale on Monday evening at Weill Recital Hall, a survey of works composed since 1976.

title: Nobelist and AIDS Researcher Is Named President of Caltech
description: Dr. David Baltimore, an AIDS researcher who won a Nobel Prize in 1975 for his work in virology and was later caught up in science-fraud scandal that, though unfounded, cost him the presidency of Rockefeller University, has been appointed president of the California Institute of Technology.

title: Food Notes
description: Changes at Chelsea Market

title: Headaches Come in Icy Flavors
description: WARM weather ushers in warnings about deer ticks, poison ivy, sunburn and a host of other seasonal hazards. But one risk factor that is often overlooked by health officials and picnickers alike is ice cream.

title: NATIONAL SEMICONDUCTOR REALIGNING CHIP MAKING
description: The National Semiconductor Corporation said yesterday that it would realign its chip manufacturing operations to stay competitive with rivals. The move by the company, which is based in Santa Clara, Calif., is expected to reduce profits for its fourth quarter, ending May 25, by $75 million to $85 million. Production at two Santa Clara wafer manufacturing plants will be shifted to factories in Arlington, Tex., and Greenock, Scotland, in the next 15 months. The Santa Clara plants employ 500 people. The company's stock fell $1 a share, to $25.375.

title: Knicks Whisper: Forget Chicago
description: Neither Patrick Ewing nor the Knicks will admit to the thought, but they basically have one foot on South Beach and another ready to dip into the Illinois side of Lake Michigan. After all the pre-series blather, going through Miami to get to Michael Jordan has not been that bad.

title: Push for School Safety Led to New Rules on Discipline
description: Almost every school district has a story about the problems of disciplining children with disabilities -- the wild kindergartner who disrupts classes for everyone else but cannot legally be removed from class, or the gang of youngsters caught selling drugs in which all are expelled except the one diagnosed with a disability.

title: A Dining-for-Dollars Gala Fattens the G.O.P.'s Coffers
description: In a lucrative display of the resilience of big-money campaign fund-raising, the Republican Party raised $11.3 million tonight at a black-tie gala that saw the political arena's generosity bar raised -- and cleared -- by a new class of $250,000 donors.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BUSEL, PAULINE
description: BUSEL-Pauline, on May 13, 1997. Devoted mother of Joel Busel and loving mother-in-law of Sandra Busel. Her love and courage have been an inspiration to us and she will forever remain in our hearts. Services Thurs., 12 noon at Gutterman's, 8000 Jericho Tpke, Woodbury, L.I. Interment Mt. Ararat.

title: Texas Instruments Deal
description: Robert Bosch G.m.b.H. said today that it would buy the Multipoint Systems wireless communications unit of Texas Instruments Inc. for an undisclosed price. The operation develops wireless systems for cable and broadcast television, telephone services and other applications. Texas Instruments, based in Dallas, has been selling various businesses to concentrate on semiconductors.

title: Woods Has Empathy for Zoeller And a Rebuke for the President
description: He is the youngest Masters champion ever, pop culture's latest icon, and today he spoke. About the Fuzzy Zoeller flap. About declining to appear with President Clinton at the Jackie Robinson tribute at Shea Stadium. About the whole dizzying life of Tiger in the wake of his record 12-shot victory.

title: Metropolitan Diary
description: DEAR DIARY:

title: Le Cirque Overload
description: To The Living Section:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HAMMER, ELSIE B.
description: HAMMER-Elsie B. On May 12, 1997. Beloved wife of Murray, loving mother of sons Richard and Jon and daughters-in-law Ellen and Pat. Devoted grandmother of Jeffrey, Dale and Mark.

title: For Milton in the New World, Trouble in Paradise
description: MILTON IN AMERICA

title: Mr. Ferrer Drops Out
description: Fernando Ferrer may be the first mayoral candidate whose hopes were undone by an empty room. All those televised pictures of vacant tables at Mr. Ferrer's fund-raiser last week, symbolizing his difficulty raising money and winning popular support, could qualify for a list of the top ten signs that your candidacy is in trouble. If Mr. Ferrer did the sensible thing in withdrawing, however, it should also be said that in four months of campaigning he showed an impressive command of city government, a feel for its issues and a personable style. As a strong favorite for re-election as Bronx Borough President, Mr. Ferrer still has an excellent future in city politics.

title: Corrections
description: A chart on Monday with an article about the influence of the Manhattan Institute misstated the headline of an article published in the institute's magazine last year. It was ''Why Catholic Schools Work,'' not ''Why Public Schools Work.'' A separate chart misidentified the company headed by John M. Hennessy, a trustee of the institute. He is chief executive of CS First Boston, not CS First Bank of Boston.

title: INSIDE
description: Russian Vote on War Art

title: Winning Friends for Foreign Policy: Albright's First 100 Days
description: When Madeleine K. Albright appears in public or walks along the street, ordinary people rush up to her, as if they know her, and often call her by her first name. She is astonished and pleased, still on a high after 100 days as the first woman to be Secretary of State, and even her security detail is getting used to the attention.

title: Talks to Buy Dillon, Read Are Ended by Dutch Suitor
description: The ING Groep said yesterday that it had withdrawn from talks to buy Dillon, Read & Company because the two companies could not agree on how to combine their businesses.

title: Alyssum Wins Nassau As Belmont Park Opens
description: With the Belmont Stakes a little more than three weeks away, 92-year-old Belmont Park opened its ornate iron gates yesterday afternoon, hoping for Silver Charm to emerge from Saturday's Preakness as the first Triple Crown contender of the decade.

title: Not Once, but Twice, O'Neill Saves Day
description: The Yankees won a game of contradictions today. Andy Pettitte manufactured the second double-digit strikeout game of his career while feeling terrible. His effort to become the second seven-game winner in the major leagues failed against the team tied for the worst record in the American League.

title: Laurie Lee, 82, a Memoirist Of War and Village Life, Dies
description: Laurie Lee, a poet, novelist and scriptwriter who grew up in a small Cotswold village, walked across Europe, fought in the Spanish Civil War and wrote about all three in a highly regarded series of memoirs, died yesterday at his Gloucestershire, England, home. He was 82.

title: Islamic Scholar Seeks to Oust Cairo Professor Over Writings
description: In a new sign of tension beneath the surface of Egyptian society, a prominent Islamic scholar has begun a campaign to oust a leading professor at Cairo University from his post on grounds that his writings have insulted Islam and ''contradicted the clear teachings of the Koran.''

title: Bill to Redesign Housing Policy Clears Hurdle
description: Challenging decades of housing policy that favored the neediest, the House voted today to change the face of public housing by providing shelter to more of the working poor.

title: Assemblywoman Switches to Democratic Party
description: A Republican state assemblywoman from Long Island defected today to the Democrats, accusing her former party of being hostile to women's interests when the state's Republican leaders are openly fretting about their standing among women.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: DOW CHEMICAL CO., Midland, Mich., said its polyurethane unit, Dow Polyurethanes, had agreed to buy Eastman Chemical Co.'s thanol polyols business for an undisclosed amount.

title: Corrections
description: An article on May 6 about the Rock-and-Roll Hall of Fame, in Cleveland, misstated its location. It is on the south shore of Lake Erie, not the north.

title: Music That's a Refuge From Life's Frantic Pace
description: Spiritual and sultry, thoughtful and sly, Erykah Badu has a persona that links make-out music to a higher purpose. ''Knowledge and wisdom I manifest/If you want to go to heaven lay upon my breast,'' she sang at Tramps on Monday night, to the cheers of a sold-out crowd. Her debut album, ''Baduizm'' (Kedar/Universal), has sold a million copies, making her one of pop's new iconic figures.

title: Columbia/HCA in Cable Network Deal
description: The Columbia/HCA Healthcare Corporation said today that it had agreed to buy a majority stake in the A. H. Belo Corporation's health care cable television network. Terms were not disclosed.

title: U.S. Senate Votes to Let Russia Shift Troops
description: The Senate unanimously agreed today to amend a 1990 treaty governing conventional forces in Europe to allow Russia to keep more heavy weapons for a longer time around sensitive southern republics like Chechnya.

title: 180 Maiden Lane Fills Up
description: IBJ Schroder Bank and Trust Company, the American investment banking arm of one of Japan's largest banks, is moving its headquarters to 180 Maiden Lane in lower Manhattan, real estate executives said yesterday.

title: Federated Has Profit On Store-Brand Sales
description: Federated Department Stores Inc. reported robust first-quarter earnings yesterday, helped by higher sales of store-brand clothing and lower expenses.

title: Jurors See Chilling Images of Truck Before Bombing
description: Second by second, with a series of chilling images taken by a surveillance camera, the prosecution in the trial of Timothy J. McVeigh today showed the jury what happened on Fifth Street in Oklahoma City in the minutes before 9:02 A.M. on April 19, 1995, when a bomb carried by a Ryder rental truck destroyed the Federal Building.

title: Protecting Refugees: Nagging Problem at U.N.
description: As evidence accumulates in Zaire that significant numbers of Hutu refugees have been killed or abused by the rebel forces of Laurent Kabila, the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees finds herself in a familiar trap:

title: Garden Q.&A.
description: Reminders of Home

title: Associated Banc-Corp Sets Merger With First Financial
description: In a combination that will create the third-largest bank in Wisconsin, Associated Banc-Corp agreed yesterday to buy the First Financial Corporation of Stevens Point, Wis., in a $1.05 billion stock swap.

title: Where Were the Media?
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BARTLETT, DAVID
description: BARTLETT-David. Died May 13. Survived by his wife Stefane Abeille-Demay; his daughters Linda Miller, Victoria Donaldson & Stefane Bartlett; 4 granddaughters & his brother, Charles L. Bartlett. Memorial mass is at 4 P.M., on Tuesday, May 20, Saint Vincent Ferrer, 869 Lexington Avenue.

title: $3 Million Zoo Gift Revoked Because Plaque Is Too Small
description: Chagrined that their $3 million gift would earn an official acknowledgment only two inches tall, the philanthropists Edith and Henry Everett have withdrawn the donation, which was to pay about half the cost of the new Children's Zoo in Central Park.

title: An MTV Look for MTV Central
description: AT the new West Coast headquarters of MTV Networks, which opened last month at 2600 Colorado Boulevard in Santa Monica, Calif., the design is distinctly indigenous. It is about sun, sand, surf -- and television.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHNEIDER, MAX
description: SCHNEIDER-Max. Beloved husband of Sophie. Adored father of Lora Reichman, Jerry and Fred Schneider. Cherished grandfather and great-grandfather. Graveside services will be private. Period of mourning will be observed Friday at the Reichman residence and Sunday at the Schneider residence.

title: When Money Counts
description: SUMMER is coming, and these accessories can brighten a bathroom and easily contain the dripping-bathing-suit-and-towel brigade, indoors or out.

title: MEDIATOR APPOINTED TO HELP BARNEY'S SORT OUT FUTURE
description: A mediator was appointed yesterday to help Barney's Inc. attract an investor and resolve its dispute with its former partner, the Isetan Company. Judge James L. Garrity Jr. of Federal Bankruptcy Court in Manhattan appointed Raymond L. Shapiro as the mediator after denying Barney's request on Friday to offer a potential bidder $10 million in breakup fees and expenses. A breakup fee is given when a party makes an offer that is accepted but then is later outbid. Mr. Shapiro will try to help Barney's, which operates 13 specialty stores, secure an acceptable investment bid and resolve its rent dispute with Isetan, a Japanese retailer that financed Barney's three biggest stores.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day last Thursday about a hostile bid by Vencor Inc. for the Transitional Hospitals Corporation misstated the sequence of events surrounding Transitional's earlier acceptance of an offer of $14.55 a share from the Select Medical Corporation. Transitional accepted the Select offer on May 2, not May 5. Later that day, Vencor proposed to increase its offer to $15 from $14.25.

title: Testing the Welfare System:EU Finds Poverty at 17%
description: BRUSSELS  The first pan-European study of income distribution has found a surprisingly high level of poverty, with one European in six living in a poor household, the statistical agency Eurostat reported Wednesday.

title: On Becoming a Hub For Birds in Flight
description: IT looked like a jungle gym for birds: chickadees, cardinals, redwinged blackbirds, nuthatches and woodpeckers diving in and out of a dozen feeders in a backyard garden at the Cornell University Laboratory of Ornithology in Ithaca, N.Y.

title: Showdown in Milwaukee
description: In the 1960's, the economist Milton Friedman provoked a furor when he argued that students should be permitted to transfer from failing public schools to successful private schools -- taking public dollars with them. Mr. Friedman predicted that free-market pressure would force the worst schools to close and mediocre ones to shape up. His critics countered that such a system would ''skim off'' the brightest students, promote white flight and leave inner-city schools black and poor. The proposal went nowhere.

title: Rangers Set a Neutral-Zone Trap and Find It Catching
description: A lot of attention has been devoted to the disciplined defensive approach that the Rangers have embraced during the Stanley Cup playoffs.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HEILIG, MORTON L.
description: HEILIG-Morton L., on May 14, 1997, in California. Beloved husband of Marianne. Loving father of Leslie (Lebowitz), Gregory and Jeffrey. Loving father-in-law, adoring grandfather. Beloved brother of Gladys Wiesenthal and Joan Kahn, and adored uncle. A man of all seasons and many talents, Mort was a documentary film maker of note, a teacher, cinematographer, newsman, director and inventor. His seminal articles, publications & inventions in the field of Virtual Reality caused him to be called the ''Father of Virtual Reality.'' His inventive mind ran the gamut from lenses for the original wide screen theater to his Supercruiser line of scooters and all-terrain skateboards. His sweet spirit and elan will be sorely missed by all who knew him and whose life he touched. Services and interment will be private.

title: Great Art Has Been Known to Beat S.&P. 500
description: To the Editor:

title: Making Erte's Furniture
description: ERTE, who was born Romain de Tirtoff in Russia in 1892, was a stylist, illustrator, sculptor -- and little-known furniture designer.

title: A Nature Center Develops Naturally
description: THE ground breaking for a visitors' center takes place today at the Mohonk Preserve, a 6,300-acre protected area in New Paltz, N.Y. The architects, Lee H. Skolnick and Paul Alter of Manhattan, make clear that nature is the big draw, not their building.

title: Mets' Reed Is Good; Astros' Kile Is Better
description: The fan trapped within the body of Rick Reed glanced at the scoreboard in the sixth inning last night and took stock of all that was good and great. Two pitchers dueling, lots of zeros, the Mets saving run after run with spectacular defense. How much fun, he thought, to be part of this game.

title: Speechless And Nameless In Newark
description: TO see them in their small room in the pediatric ward, this much is obvious: they are related. They have the same high cheekbones, long, Roman noses and beige skin. And judging by their ages -- he in his late 40's or so, she in her mid-70's or so -- that would most likely make them mother and son.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SELZNICK, L. JEFFREY
description: SELZNICK-L. Jeffrey. The President, Board of Trustees, staff and extended family of Dana-Farber Cancer Institute mourn the passing, on May 12, of our esteemed friend & benefactor L. Jeffrey Selznick. Mr. Selznick will be remembered for his loyal commitment to Dana-Farber's mission of providing expert, compassionate cancer care and pursuing innovative, life-saving research. In the tradition of his grandfather, Louis B. Mayer, and his mother, Irene Mayer Selznick, Mr. Selznick has played a major role in the growth of Dana-Farber through the Louis B. Mayer Foundation, a five-decade supporter of the Institute. We extend our deepest sympathies to his wife, Barbara, and to his family and friends. David G. Nathan, M.D., President Dana-Farber Cancer Institute

title: Theater in Review
description: A Girl as a Boy Takes

title: Demigods in Pinstripes
description: Next week, when a Federal Reserve Board committee meets behind closed doors to discuss interest rates, the press will be expectantly crouched by the keyhole. Is there another governmental planning body, in this country or the former Soviet Union or points in between, whose deliberations inspire even a small charge of electricity, let alone reverence?

title: Reverse Exodus
description: My first brush with organized religion was as part of a hopelessly disorganized Sunday kindergarten class, praying in a makeshift sanctuary in a Jewish Community Center in downtown Washington. But this was the 1950's, so we didn't remain in chaotic quarters for long. A gleaming new synagogue was being built closer to the suburbs where families of all religions were moving as fast as the boom could carry them. By 1969, a year after the post-King-assassination riots nearby, the J.C.C. itself fled 16th Street for the sylvan promised land of Rockville, Md.

title: CHRONICLE
description: Think military, and who springs to mind? Not PHYLLIS DILLER. But never mind. She is to be the master of ceremonies tomorrow at the Plaza for a night billed as a Military Ball.

title: Affiliate of Cypress Holding to Buy Fund
description: The Cypress Holding Company's mutual fund affiliate has agreed to acquire control of the North American Funds, which have about $800 million in assets, from the North American Security Life Insurance Company.

title: No Headline
description: ''This is going to kill recruitment.''

title: Amazon.com Stock Sale Raises $54 Million
description: Amazon.com Inc. sold shares today at $18 each in a $54 million public offering, according to Deutsche Morgan Grenfell, which is managing the sale.

title: Flyers' Question: Who Will Start in Goal?
description: On the curb outside an auto repair shop near the Flyers' practice facility stands a life-sized, mechanically powered scarecrow of unusual aspect. Dressed in a Flyers uniform, the moving mannequin holds a hockey stick in one hand and in the other a plastic replica of the head of the Statue of Liberty.

title: INSIDE
description: A Busy British Agenda

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: TENNIS

title: The Leverage of Federal Research
description: An exhaustive study for the National Science Foundation has discovered that the novel ideas conceived by American patent holders depend far more on research paid for by government than on research paid for by private industry. The finding belies the glib assertion, heard often in Congress last year, that as private industry expands its research budget, Washington can scale back its research activities. The implication is that proposed cutbacks in Federal research would damage the economy.

title: Return Mobutu's Loot
description: To the Editor:

title: ENRON OFFERS TO BUY REMAINDER OF ENRON GLOBAL POWER
description: The Enron Corporation said yesterday that it offered to buy the 52 percent of Enron Global Power and Pipelines L.L.C. it does not already own for $400 million, or $32 a share, in stock to simplify its corporate structure. Enron Global Power said its oversight committee, consisting of its three outside directors, would appoint financial and legal advisers to evaluate the offer. Shares of Enron Global Power rose $2.125, to $32.375. Enron announced the offer after the close of trading. Its shares fell 37.5 cents, to $40.875. Enron, based in Houston, is one of the largest sellers of electricity and natural gas to American power companies.

title: Wilander and Novacek Are Banned
description: The former world No. 1 MATS WILANDER of Sweden and the Czech-born KAREL NOVACEK were suspended for three months after withdrawing appeals for failing drug tests, the International Tennis Federation announced yesterday.

title: In Rome, Do as the Romans Do and Watch Where You Park
description: One evening this spring, without warning, an army of giant potted palms was moved into strategic positions around Trastevere, the old neighborhood across the Tiber of narrow streets, artisan workshops, boutiques, restaurants and until now some of the most imaginative parking in Rome.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CAMPBELL, IVOR E.
description: CAMPBELL-Ivor E. Of New Albany, OH, May 5, 1997. Chief of the Inorganic Chemistry Division of Battelle Memorial Institute, Director of Research and Development, National Steel Company and a research chemist at Westinghouse. Returning to Columbus, he was a member of a consulting firm and an Attorney in private practice in New Albany area. A member of the Electro-Chemical Society serving as president for two years, and a member of the American Chemical Society. He received a Ph.D. in Inorganic Chemistry from Ohio State University, a Jl.D. from Capital University, and an Honorary Ph.D. in Science from the University of Evansville. Survived by wife, Agnes Morgan Campbell; brother, Dr. Edwin (Patricia) Campbell, New York; sisters, Ruth (Dr. Donald) Tuomi, Arlington Heights, IL and Mary L. Campbell, New York; nieces, Dr. Donna (Dr. Paul) Beck, Champaign, IL., and the Rev. Mary (the Rev. Steven) Hammond, Oberlin, OH; greatnieces and nephews; brother-inlaw, Rollin (Betty) Morgan of New Albany. He was a member of the Central College Presbyterian Church of Westerville. Private services were held at The Schoedinger Chapel in Gahanna, OH.

title: Goodby, Silverstein Wins 24 Clios
description: For the third consecutive year, Goodby, Silverstein & Partners in San Francisco took top honors at the Clio Awards ceremonies, winning the most awards.

title: De Klerk Denies Authorizing Killings During Apartheid
description: Former President F. W. de Klerk categorically denied today that his Government ever authorized killings or torture in its effort to combat anti-apartheid forces.

title: Fair Financing
description: FEB. 3, 1970 -- A lawsuit, Robinson v. Cahill, charges that the method of financing public schools discriminates against poorer districts.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NEUBERGER, MARIE
description: NEUBERGER-Marie. S. The employees and principals of Neuberger&Berman, LLC mourn the passing of Marie S. Neuberger. From her work with the Women's City Club and the Ethical Culture Society, to her commitment to Bryn Mawr, Purchase College and better education for all New York City children, Marie made the world a better place. Since Neuberger&Berman's founding in 1939 through the last years of her life she cared about Neuberger&Berman, our employees and our clients. She was our first partner and our friend. We are fortunate to have known her. To Marie's husband and our firm's founder Roy Neuberger, to their children, grandchildren and great grandchildren, and to the Salant family, we extend our sincere condolences. The Employees and Principals, Neuberger&Berman, LLC

title: U.S. Judge Rules Against Marvel
description: Bondholders fighting Marvel Entertainment Group's plan to merge with Toy Biz Inc. and emerge from bankruptcy won a round in court yesterday when a Federal judge ruled that the bondholders could take control of the 80 percent stake in Marvel stock that secured the bonds.

title: Sloan-Kettering Planning A Care Center in Midtown
description: Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center yesterday bought nine floors in a midtown Manhattan office building, where it intends to build an outpatient care center.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RAFF, EVA
description: RAFF-Eva. National Council of Jewish Women, Peninsula Section mourns the passing of one of our most dedicated volunteers and the mother of our past president, Enid Lederer. We express our heartfelt sympathy to the entire family. Joan Butwin, President

title: Such a Deal: A Security That Thrilled Short-Sellers
description: Why would a company issue a security that was virtually certain to drive down the price of its stock?

title: Seeking Light: Manhattan Project Murder Mystery
description: LOS ALAMOS

title: 35 Years Later, Injured Man Is to Receive Benefits Check
description: A former Niagara Mohawk lineman learned last night that he would finally be getting $1.2 million in workers' compensation benefits, 35 years after a jolt of electricity knocked him from a utility pole and left him paralyzed.

title: 5 Airlines Extend Limits Of Alliances
description: United Airlines, Lufthansa and three part ners with considerable fanfare and a $25 million advertising budget -- announced today that they would expand individual agreements now linking their operations into a broad single alliance.

title: For a Master Builder, It's Hands Off At Home
description: AT the office, they refer to him as Mr. New York, for all the New York icons he has brought back from the brink of oblivion, including the Rainbow Room, the Joyce Theater and most recently the New Amsterdam Theater on 42d Street. But at home, the architect Hugh Hardy is simply ''Yew,'' as pronounced in the most velvety of Italian accents by his wife, Tiziana.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: Baseball

title: The Street.com Joins ABC News on Web
description: ABC News has chosen the Street.com, a fledgling on-line financial news service, to provide business news to its new Internet service, ABCnews.com.

title: Senate Passes Bill on Teaching the Disabled
description: By a 98-to-1 vote, the Senate today passed and sent to President Clinton legislation to give public schools more money and flexibility in educating children with disabilities.

title: Balanchine in Four Different Flavors
description: On Tuesday night, the New York City Ballet left the 19th-century world of ''The Sleeping Beauty'' and started to display its 20th-century repertory. The season's first program of one-act ballets was made up of four fine works by George Balanchine. The pieces were shrewdly chosen to suggest how varied his choreography could be, for they displayed Balanchine's talents as master of both dramatic plot and abstract pattern.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SERWER, BERNSTEIN, BLANCHE
description: SERWER-BERNSTEIN-Blanche, 86, on May 11 after a long battle with ALS. Beloved mother of Philip (Ellen), Daniel (Jacquelyn) and Jeremy (Nancy) Serwer. Grandmother of Zachary, Tammy, Rebecca, Jared and Adam. Wife of the late Zachary Serwer and of the late Nahum Bernstein. Author and psychologist who never accepted injustice or lost hope. Contributions in lieu of flowers to the Muscular Distrophy Assoc, E.L.E.M., Givat Haviva, Interns for Peace, or any charity that promotes reconciliation between those in conflict. Services Thursday 12:30PM, ''The Riverside'', 76 St and Amsterdam Ave.

title: AIR FORCE'S CHIEF SAID TO SEEK DEAL ON COURT-MARTIAL
description: Less than a week before the court-martial of the nation's first female B-52 pilot on adultery and other charges, the Secretary of the Air Force has told associates she would consider allowing the officer to resign with an honorable discharge, senior Air Force officials said today.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CRANDELL, EDWIN HAWLEY
description: CRANDELL-Edwin Hawley, died on May 7th, 1997 at the age of 82. Devoted husband of the late Maxine Hothorn Crandell who died on November 30, 1996. Mr. Crandell was also a beloved uncle to Cathy Crandell Long of Summit, NJ, Laurie Roberts of NYC and many other nieces and nephews. Mr. Crandell was a longtime resident of Rye, New York. A retired partner of N.J. Meehan, he was a member of the New York Stock Exchange for more than fifty years. Mr. Crandell attended the Westminster School, Bronxville High School & New York University. He was a Captain in the Army Engineering Corps during World War II. He was a member of the Apawamis Club, the American Yacht Club, the US Seniors and the Buttonwood Club. In addition to his nieces and nephews he is survived by 2 sisters-in-law, Mary Elizabeth Crandell of Ponte Verde, FL, and Cynthia Hothorn Williams of Aiken, SC. He will be sorely missed by all who knew him. In lieu of flowers donations may be made to the Alzheimer's Association - West chester Chapter, 785 Mamaroneck Avenue, White Plains, NY 10605 or the American Lung Association, 35 Orchard St., White Plains, NY 10605. A memorial service for both Maxine and Edwin Crandell will be held at 1 PM, on Sunday, May 18th, at Rye Presbyterian Church in Rye, New York. Any questions please call 914-967-0129.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JOHNSTON, KENNETH F. SR.
description: JOHNSTON-Kenneth F. Sr., of Manhasset, New York (retired NYPD), suddenly on 13 May 1997. Beloved husband of the late Catherine M. (nee Crichton). Cherished father of the late Kenneth Jr. (Stephanie), Rev. Jeffrey, Beth Perchuk (Mark), Janice Abdenour (Michael), Donna Cardone (James) & Douglas (JeanMarie). Adored ''Gumpy'' of Kenneth III, Matthew, Kathleen, Heather, Nolan and Kaylyn Johnston, Kyle and Kendall Cardone, Michael and Keith Abdenour. Devoted brother of Audrey Reed, and brother-inlaw of Ivy Voelbel and Anne Crichton. Also survived by nieces, nephews, many friends and ''his kids,'' the hundreds of youngsters he coached during the past 30 years in St. Mary's CYO program. Visiting at the Fairchild Chapel, 1570 Northern Boulevard in Manhasset on Thursday from 7-9 PM and on Friday from 3-5 and 7-9 PM. There will be a Vigil Service at 8 PM on Friday. Funeral mass at 10:45 Saturday, 17 May at St. Mary R.C. Church in Manhasset. Interment at Holy Rood Cemetery in Westbury. Memorial offerings may be made to ''The Bear Foundation,'' a not-for-profit organization established by the Johnston family in support of childrens' athletic programs. P.O. Box 138, Manhasset, New York 11030.

title: Ruler Eyes Candidacy In Nigeria
description: Although new elections have been scheduled for next year, Nigeria is beginning to see strong signs that the military elite, which annulled the last elections four years ago, intends to hang on to power here indefinitely.

title: Excerpts From Justices' Opinions in School Financing Ruling
description: Following are excerpts from the New Jersey Supreme Court's 5-to-1 decision yesterday that Gov. Christine Todd Whitman's school financing plan was unconstitutional. Associate Justice Alan B. Handler wrote the majority opinion, and Associate Justice Marie L. Garibaldi wrote the dissent. Chief Justice Deborah T. Poritz did not participate in the case.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-18

title: U.S. Withholds Approval of Utility Merger
description: A Federal regulatory agency told two utilities in the upper Midwest yesterday that it would withhold approval of their merger agreement as it is now structured, saying that it would give them too much dominance over the electricity market in their regions.

title: Last Indignity for Jews
description: To the Editor:

title: The Films At Cannes Are Also Hot
description: A week's worth of rain clouds has finally lifted here, and suddenly the films are as hot as the weather. Gangbusters: ''L.A. Confidential,'' a shrewd, elegant film noir set in the moral quicksand of 1950's Los Angeles, with a flawless ensemble cast and style to burn. Directed by Curtis Hanson and boiled down beautifully from James Ellroy's labyrinthine novel, it's also a rare bird for Cannes: the big Hollywood movie ready to face the crazy, cutthroat atmosphere here and take a chance.

title: Pied Piper of the Second-Floor World
description: MATTHEW HOEY is lugging his furniture down his apartment stairs, across the sidewalk, into his truck and heading east, 80 miles, to New York City.

title: Airlines to Put Fire Extinguishers in Cargo Holds
description: The major airlines promised today to install fire extinguishers in the cargo holds of their passenger planes as soon as possible, without waiting for a Federal rule requiring them to do so. The goal is to prevent fires like the one that brought down Valujet Airlines Flight 592 in the Florida Everglades a year ago.

title: Producer Prices Fall A Sharp 0.6%
description: In an inflation report better than the most optimistic predictions, prices paid to American manufacturers and other producers fell six-tenths of l percent in April, the biggest monthly drop in nearly four years, Government figures showed today.

title: Bulls' Jackson: Chase Is On
description: The distractions are dangling over the Chicago Bulls like a mobile, an array of spinning figures that ranges from Dennis Rodman to Coach Phil Jackson.

title: Indiana Court Bars Mixing Of Young and Adult Inmates
description: The Indiana Court of Appeals has ruled that incarcerating juveniles with adults violates the state's Constitution and ordered the Indiana Department of Correction to transfer a 16-year-old girl to an institution for youthful offenders.

title: The 'Drama Library'
description: To The Home Section:

title: Mining Berlin's Hidden Gold
description: Trust Irving Berlin to have located the one essential trait shared by love and the weather: ''They can't be depended upon.'' ''Love and the Weather,'' the obscure, gently bouncy Berlin song that includes this observation, is one of several freshly unburied nuggets in Susannah McCorkle's absorbing new cabaret show remembering Berlin, who died eight years ago.

title: Short Strike Ends At G.M. Plant
description: Hourly employees at an important parts-making complex of the General Motors Corporation in Warren, Ohio, returned to the job today after the auto maker and a union reached a tentative settlement ending a day-old strike.

title: Japanese Regulators Order S.& L.'s to Merge
description: Regional authorities in Japan have ordered the merger of five savings and loans to rescue the Chogin Osaka Credit Cooperative, the government of Osaka Prefecture said yesterday.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: Suit Seeks to Increase Yankees' Revenue
description: In his 25 years as principal owner of the New York Yankees, George Steinbrenner never quite made his presence felt the way he did yesterday.

title: NATO Can't Be a Watchdog of Cultural Values
description: To the Editor:

title: Chinese Officials Replace Top Securities Regulator
description: China has replaced its top securities regulator, stock exchange officials and traders said today, prompting speculation that the Government will crack down further on the country's surging stock markets.

title: Entrepreneur Plans to Open Profit-Making AIDS Centers
description: The doctor turned entrepreneur who brought for-profit cancer care to New York City is planning a new profit-making health care venture for the city: a chain of AIDS and H.I.V. treatment centers.

title: Bruno Makes Concessions On Rent Rule
description: The Senate majority leader, Joseph L. Bruno, said for the first time today that he could support rules allowing immediate family members to inherit rent-regulated apartments, but that homosexual and other unmarried couples should not be granted such rights.

title: Silver Charm's Pedigree Finishes 2d
description: He does not come with the blue-blooded pedigree of, say, Claiborne Farm's Pulpit, whose sire was A. P. Indy, the Horse of the Year in 1992, and whose dam was Preach, a daughter of the renowned Mr. Prospector, and whose grandsire was Seattle Slew, who swept the Triple Crown in 1977.

title: On-Line Museum Raises Questions
description: The Museum of Woodworking Tools opens its south wing today with a series of lectures, discussions and tours centered on a new exhibition dubbed ''Stanley Combination Planes in Use at the MacLachlan Woodworking Museum.''

title: Ex-Executives of Nomura Securities Arrested
description: Tokyo prosecutors arrested one current official and two former managing directors of the Nomura Securities Company today on charges of illegally paying money to gangsters.

title: MERFIN ACCEPTS BUCKEYE CELLULOSE'S INCREASED OFFER
description: Merfin International Inc. said yesterday that it had accepted an increased takeover offer of $210 million (Canadian), or $151 million (United States), in cash from the Buckeye Cellulose Corporation, spurning a rival offer by Polymer Group Inc. Buckeye will pay $7.50 (Canadian) for each Merfin share and assume $60 million in debt. Polymer, which raised its offer on Tuesday to $7.20 a share, withdrew its bid after being told of Merfin's decision. Buckeye, based in Memphis, makes specialty pulps for disposable diapers, plastic films and cigarette filters. Merfin, based in Vancouver, British Columbia, makes paper for feminine hygiene and adult incontinence products.

title: Four-Wheel Drive Doesn't Spell Freedom
description: To the Editor:

title: Next Time, Deep Garry
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  LILIEN, HELEN H.
description: LILIEN-Helen H. Dear Sister, gone so long ago, but vivid memories of your nobility of presence, your indulgent spirit, your compassionate heart, your constant goodness, these memories will always be with me. Herbert

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MASON, HILDA AGELOFF
description: MASON-Hilda Ageloff. Sister of Alan Ageloff, Ruth Poulos and the late Lillian Lupka, Sylvia Mohr and Monte Ageloff. Aunt of Andrew Ageloff, Alan and Naomi Lupka, Bernard Mohr, Steven and Eric Poulos, Bette Rosen. Funeral private. For information Parkside Memorial Chapel, 718-338-1500.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DEANGELIS, ADOLPH
description: DeANGELIS-Adolph, on May 13, 1997, of Syosset, New York. Beloved husband of Dorothy (nee Gatsos). Loving father of Helene Nahm and Lissa G. DeAngelis. Dear grandfather of Joshua and Kimberly. Dear brother of Lucia Russo and the late Arnold J. Reposing at the Beney Funeral Home, Inc., of Syosset, 79 Berry Hill Road. Visiting Thursday 2-4 & 7-9 PM. In lieu of flowers donations to Friends of the Planting Fields, (516-922-9200 ext 107).

title: For Havel, a NATO Open to All Democracies
description: An expanding NATO should welcome any European democracy as a member, President Vaclav Havel of the Czech Republic said yesterday in a discussion with editors and writers during a visit to The New York Times.

title: Ex-Boyfriend Is Charged With Killing 16-Year-Old
description: A 22-year-old Bronx man was arrested yesterday and charged with fatally shooting his 16-year-old former girlfriend on Monday morning in the hallway outside her Co-op City apartment as she left for school, the police said.

title: Zaire Talks Collapse
description: Talks on Zaire's crisis collapsed yesterday when the rebel leader, Laurent Kabila, refused to meet with President Mobutu Sese Seko. That set the stage for an armed takeover of the capital, Kinshasa.

title: School Plan Rejected
description: The State Supreme Court ruled yesterday that Gov. Christine Todd Whitman's plan to improve urban schools by emphasizing curriculum standards instead of spending violated the State Constitution. No Governor in three decades has come up with a plan that satisfied the Court, but yesterday's 5-to-1 ruling is the first to order a specific amount of spending.

title: Ratify Biodiversity Pact
description: To the Editor:

title: A Coming Biography Embroils Solzhenitsyn and a Publisher
description: It is a story with all the elements of a Russian novel -- passion, betrayal, K.G.B. intrigue -- set against an epic backdrop of 20th-century Russian history. And there is even a surprise ending.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HINDELS, CONSTANCE
description: HINDELS-Constance, on May 14, 1997. Beloved wife of Dr. George. Loving mother and mother-in-law of Dorothy and Dr. Lawrence Brown and of James and Carol Hindels. Adored grandmother of Jordana, Rebecca, Sarah, Sam and Naomi. Sisterly cousin of Toni Auspitz and Milly Filbert. She was deeply loved by all and will be sorely missed. Services Friday, 11:30 A.M., at The John J. Fox Funeral Home, Inc., 2080 Boston Post Road, Larchmont, New York. Interment at Mt. Hope Cemetery, Hastings on Hudson, New York.

title: Washday's Frontier: The Front-Loaders
description: SO you need to do the laundry, and while you're at it you wouldn't mind cleaning up the planet, too. Would it be worth spending close to $1,000 on an energy-efficient washing machine to help do your part of the global chore?

title: Shell Shareholders Reject A Human Rights Initiative
description: Filing past some 150 noisy demonstrators, shareholders of Shell Transport and Trading P.L.C. rejected a resolution today calling for greater attention to environmental and human rights policies. Operations of the giant oil company in places like Nigeria have been criticized on those grounds.

title: Hawaii Tourism Boost
description: To the Editor:

title: Mutant-Gene Study Alters Estimate of Risk to Women
description: Three genetic mutations that increase the risk of breast and ovarian cancer are less dangerous than expected in women with no family history of the cancers, researchers report. But the risks are still high.

title: A Once-Shabby Bullpen Has Turned It Around
description: There is nothing overwhelming about the Mets' bullpen, except its recent success. There are no overpowering throwers, nobody with a split-fingered pitch that seems to explode. All they've been doing is getting outs and collecting saves.

title: Road to Approval Is Rocky, And the Gamble Is Perilous
description: The decision to extend membership in NATO to former Soviet-bloc countries in Central Europe, which Russia explicitly if grudgingly accepted today, is almost certainly the most significant United States foreign policy initiative since the end of the cold war. It represents a redrawing of the world security map as basic as Washington's decision to recognize Communist China.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BRENNER, ESTHER
description: BRENNER-Esther. On May 9, 1997. Beloved sister of the late Maxwell Brenner. Service and interment private. Contributions in her memory may be made to the Fresh Air Fund for the Career Awareness Program, 1040 Avenue of Americas, N.Y., N.Y. 10018.

title: Party Animals in Fraternities Face the Threat of Extinction
description: As bashes go, the party at the Alpha Tau Omega house was an old rerun: fraternity members donned leis, frolicked with sorority sisters and drank gallons of beer.

title: Bruins in Milbury's Future?
description: Even though Mike Milbury has consistently denied them, rumors persist in Boston that the Islanders' general manager is headed for the Bruins, perhaps to fill the coaching vacancy or even as a replacement for General Manager Harry Sinden.

title: Day of Flurry and Debate On Late-Term Abortions
description: The Senate plunged once again today into a debate over late-term abortions, as three bills competed to appear more civilized, more reasonable or more fair.

title: Pentagon Plan On Shaping The Military Is Under Fire
description: Even before the Pentagon makes public its blueprint for the military of the 21st century, the strategic review is drawing biting criticism from lawmakers, military scholars and analysts who say it should have called for more dramatic changes in the size and mission of the armed forces.

title: Cork to Perch On
description: CORK -- as seen in wine bottles, soles for sandals and bulletin boards -- is about to be seen in furniture as well.

title: Calendar: Exhibitions And Talks
description: An Architect's Work

title: Later, Dual Finger-Pointing
description: P. J. Brown, the Miami Heat power forward, blamed Charlie Ward of the Knicks for starting tonight's fourth-quarter melee.

title: Bonds Rise As Producer Prices Slide
description: A report of the largest decline in producer prices in nearly four years sent bond prices higher yesterday, as evidence continued to suggest that an economic slowdown is at hand and as the likelihood of an interest-rate increase by the Federal Reserve faded.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHONBERG, BESSIE
description: SCHONBERG-Bessie. The Juilliard School mourns the passing of its distinguished choreography teacher, Bessie Schonberg, whose life itself was an example of creativity, generosity and heart. We shall miss her. Mary Rodgers Guettel Chairman, Board of Trustees Joseph W. Polisi President Benjamin Harkarvy Director, Dance Division

title: Stars Flock to a New York Suburb That Is Wealthy but Unassuming
description: Somewhere between the time Chevy Chase abandoned Los Angeles for horse country and this spring, when Michael Crichton paid $2.8 million to add five acres to his own estate, this quiet stretch of Westchester County began to evolve into one of the most glittering addresses in entertainment and society circles.

title: Magnanimous Gesture
description: To the Editor:

title: Talks Between Zairian Foes Collapse Before They Start
description: Talks between President Mobutu Sese Seko and Laurent Kabila, the Zairian rebel leader, collapsed before they started tonight, setting the stage for an armed takeover of the capital.

title: Germany May Sell Deutsche Telekom Stock
description: The German Finance Minister, Theo Waigel, said yesterday that the Government might hold an emergency sale of shares in Deutsche Telekom A.G., the state-controlled phone company, to reduce debt and keep European monetary union on track.

title: Bessie Schonberg, 90, a Mentor for Dancers
description: Bessie Schonberg, one of America's most influential teachers of dance composition and a mentor to several generations of dancers, died yesterday at her home in Bronxville, N.Y. She was 90.

title: Blast Hits Car After Man Sells to Blacks
description: A white Yonkers man who sold his house to a black family got an unwelcome send-off Monday night, one day before he was to move to Florida. An explosive device was set off, shattering the windshield of his rented 1996 Jeep Cherokee, which was parked outside his house on Troy Lane.

title: Voucher Plan Is Scrapped
description: The school board decided Tuesday to scrap a school voucher plan that had been deemed illegal by the State Education Commissioner.

title: To Avoid Conflict Over Yankees Suit, Lawyer Quits Firm
description: David Boies, the superstar litigator who was virtually synonymous with the premier Wall Street law firm of Cravath, Swaine & Moore, announced yesterday that he was leaving the firm because he wants to represent clients whose interests collide with some of the giant companies that the law firm represents.

title: Judge Recuses Himself From Gigante Mob Case
description: The judge who was to preside at the trial of the suspected Mafia boss Vincent Gigante said yesterday that he had taken himself off the case because he did not feel he could be fair, after Mr. Gigante's lawyers said their client might have Alzheimer's disease.

title: AHMANSON TO BUY BACK $250 MILLION MORE OF ITS STOCK
description: H. F. Ahmanson & Company, based in Irwindale, Calif., said yesterday that its board had approved the purchase of an additional $250 million in stock after the completion of its existing buyback program. Ahmanson, parent company of Home Savings of America, said it had bought 19.2 million shares, or 16 percent of all outstanding shares, at $27.11 a share through March. It now has 100.6 million shares outstanding. Since February, the company has been engaged in a hostile bid for the Great Western Financial Corporation.

title: 'Gee, One More Thing': It's You-Know-Who
description: ''Oh, gee,'' says the overly polite police lieutenant in the rumpled raincoat, ''just one more thing, sir.'' Fans don't need to be told that ''Columbo'' is back, still periodically churning out the routine that got its start as a series back in September 1971. Playing the Los Angeles detective, Peter Falk has parlayed shrewd bumbling into a lifetime annuity.

title: Bridge
description: In a thrilling finale, Harry Tudor of Miami and Michael Seamon of Miami Beach snatched victory on the last deal of the Cavendish Invitational Pairs in Las Vegas, Nev., on Sunday. They were apparently out of contention before the final session, but gained 1,000 imps to edge out two favored Italian partnerships.

title: Parity in Schools
description: With its ruling today that Gov. Christine Todd Whitman's education finance plan is unconstitutional, the State Supreme Court dealt more than a mere blow to the Governor's fiscal and legislative agenda.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ENO, LAWRENCE R.
description: ENO-Lawrence R., 83, on May 13, 1997. Husband of the late Ruth Smolen Eno, survived by his sister Rosalind Milman, his sons Richard and Robert, his daughters-in-law Janet Van Fleet and Candice Pong Eno, his grandchildren Jonas and Berrian Eno-Van Fleet and Jared and Daniel Eno, his brothers-inlaw Seymour and George Smolen, his nephews Stephen and Jeffrey Milman, and his niece Katheryn Havemann. He was co-author of ''The Basic Equities of the Palestine Problem'' (1947). Counsel to and former partner in the law firm of Rosenman & Colin, a founder and benefactor of the Museum of the Mountain Man in Pinedale, Wyoming. He strove gallantly for virtue through reason and never failed his conscience. May his memory be a blessing to all who knew him. Services Friday, 11:15AM, at ''The Riverside'', 76 St. and Amsterdam Avenue. Interment at Mt. Lebanon Cemetery. Reception following at the Carlyle Hotel. Visiting hours Thursday 7-9.

title: Danish Mother Is Reunited With Her Baby
