description: A tourist from Denmark who left her child in a stroller outside a restaurant while she ate inside got her baby back from foster care yesterday evening, a day after a Family Court judge ordered that the child be returned to her.

title: Accused of Hiring a Hit Man
description: A Lincoln Park man was arrested Tuesday night after trying to hire a hit man, the police said.

title: Four-Wheel Drive Doesn't Spell Freedom
description: To the Editor:

title: Executive Changes
description: COFFEE, SUGAR AND COCOA EXCHANGE, New York, elected Adolph G. Reinhardt as its chairman for a two-year term.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KATZ, GRACE
description: KATZ-Grace. Our memories together will be cherished. Your friendship surely will be missed. Renee and Phil Kriegel

title: Better Act Now to Prevent Another Balkan War
description: To the Editor:

title: New Jersey's School Financing Is Again Held Unconstitutional
description: The New Jersey Supreme Court ruled today that Gov. Christine Todd Whitman's plan to improve urban schools by emphasizing curriculum standards instead of spending violated the State Constitution. No Governor in three decades has come up with a plan that satisfied the Court, despite three previous rulings on the issue.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BACHMAN, LINDSEY BLAKE
description: BACHMAN-Lindsey Blake. Beloved daughter of Steven and Debbie. Loving sister of Jessica & Chelsea. Cherished granddaughter of Victor and Midge Bachman, and Marilyn Siegel. Adored niece, cousin and friend. Services on Thursday, 10 AM, at ''Gutterman's, Inc.'', 175 Long Beach Road, Rockville Centre, Long Island.

title: NATIONAL-OILWELL IN STOCK DEAL FOR DRECO ENERGY
description: National-Oilwell Inc. agreed yesterday to acquire Dreco Energy Services Ltd. in a deal that could top $366 million in stock. Dreco's shares jumped $8.25, or 21.4 percent, to $46.75, in Nasdaq trading. Shares of National-Oilwell rose $2.125, to $41.25, on the New York Stock Exchange. National-Oilwell, based in Houston, makes equipment for oil and gas drilling and production. Dreco, based in Edmonton, Alberta, makes motors for drilling oil and natural gas wells. National-Oilwell will issue 9.4 million shares, or 1.2 shares for each Dreco share. The deal is contingent on National-Oilwell's average stock price ending between $36 and $47.25 for 20 trading days before the deal closes. If the price is outside that range, the exchange ratio will be adjusted.

title: Kuwait Sells 170 Million British Petroleum Shares
description: Kuwait yesterday sold 170 million shares of the British Petroleum Company for $2 billion to Goldman, Sachs & Company in what several bankers said was the largest trade ever of a single block of shares.

title: 4 Officers Reprimanded For Behavior in a Hotel
description: The New York City Police Department reprimanded four officers yesterday for what it said was inappropriate behavior during this week's National Police Week ceremonies in Washington. The incident resurrected memories of the annual event in 1995, when the antics of drunken New York officers attracted embarrassing national attention.

title: Airline Alliance Picks Y.& R.
description: The Star Alliance, a joint venture marketing operation announced yesterday by five airlines, has named the New York office of Young & Rubicam Advertising to create a worldwide campaign to introduce the partnership program. The campaign, with a budget of $25 million, begins this week with a gatefold print advertisement that opens to reveal an imaginary airplane bearing the logos of all five carriers: the UAL Corporation's United Airlines, Lufthansa, Air Canada, Thai Airways International and Scandinavian Airlines System.

title: Knicks See Themselves As Victims in the Fracas
description: Jeff Van Gundy blamed P. J. Brown. Buck Williams blamed Pat Riley's win-or-die coaching mantra. Chris Childs wondered aloud what has got into his former teammate, Brown, the nice guy he used to know on the Nets.

title: Kurds No Longer X-Rated Topic in Turkish Film
description: On the mean streets of this crowded, depressed Kurdish city, the war that insurgent guerrillas are waging against the Turkish Army is the great unspoken topic.

title: A Shutout for Civility, Too
description: Though exhibition games between teams are often known as friendly matches, the players certainly were not cordial at times in the MetroStars' match with Colombia tonight.

title: Blue Cross Forms Alliance of Plans
description: Blue Cross and Blue Shield's national association said this week that half of its regional health insurance plans had formed an alliance to help big companies consolidate employee benefits under one roof.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JONES, EDWARD MURRAY
description: JONES-Edward Murray, on May 12, 1997 at his residence. Husband of the late Mary Margaret Jones, father of Mary Patricia Piller, Michael Edward Jones, and Brian Edward Jones. Visiting hours are from 7-9 PM, Friday, May 16 at the Everly Funeral Home, 10565 Main Street, Fairfax, VA. Services will be held on Sat.. May 17 at 11 AM, St. Ambrose Catholic Church, 3901 Woodburn Road, Annandale, VA. Interment Fairfax Memorial Park. Memorial contributions may be made to the Association of Former Agents of U.S. Secret Service. (Make checks payable to ''Crisis Fund''), P.O. Box 848, Annandale, Virginia 22003.

title: Secret Army Chemical Tests Did Not Harm Health, Report Says
description: The spraying of a potentially toxic chemical in several cities in Army tests in the 1950's and 60's apparently had no adverse health effects, a National Research Council committee said today.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SKOLNIK, NATHAN
description: SKOLNIK-Nathan. The Community Synagogue Max D. Raiskin Center joins the Skolnik family in mourning the loss of a pillar of our Jewish community center, Past President and Past Member of our Board of Directors. He will be sorely missed by his wife, children, grandchildren and all of us. May the family be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Dr. Meyer Tendler, Chairman Al Lerman, President Alan Morgenthal, Treasurer Herbert Latner, Secretary

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MILLER, SADIE
description: MILLER-Sadie, on May 14, 1997. Beloved mother of Martin and Anita, Ira and Myrna, and Jerome and Lynn. Devoted sister of Ann Kramer and Samuel Norman. Cherished grandmother of Alan, Tracy, Scott, Robin, Cheryl, Lori, Debbie and Stacy, and greatgrandmother. Services Friday, 12 Noon, ''Schwartz Bros.-Jeffer Memorial Chapels,'' 76th Road and Queens Blvd. in Forest Hills.

title: Editors' Note
description: An article on April 27 reported the resignation of two members of the Turkish Cabinet. The article included remarks by a university professor in Ankara who described the governing coalition headed by Necmettin Erbakan and Tansu Ciller as ''a coalition between a hypocrite and a criminal.'' The professor spoke on condition that his name not be published.

title: Competition at Every Turn Has Post Office on the Run
description: What snow, rain, heat and gloom of night cannot stay, U.P.S., fax machines and the Internet just might. That is the view of the Postmaster General, Marvin Runyon, who predicted last month that his giant quasi-government enterprise would lose about $1.4 billion next year, setting the stage for an increase of 2 to 3 cents in first-class postage in 1998.

title: A Device To Disable Airbags
description: With parents worried that their children could be hurt or killed by an airbag, an Oklahoma man has begun selling a device by mail that lets car owners disable the passenger-side bag more easily.

title: A Struggle to Catch Up With Competitors : Swiss Caught Off Guard By Shift in Client Needs
description: LONDON  After decades at the top of the gilded heap, the big three Swiss private banks suddenly find themselves facing unprecedented challenges from all sides at a time when they can least afford it.

title: S.& P. Lifts Debt Ratings of Hong Kong and China
description: The Standard & Poor's Corporation said today that it had upgraded its credit ratings for Hong Kong and China, delivering a vote of confidence in the colony's future less than two months before it returns to the Beijing Government's control.

title: Creating a Garden, One Bead at a Time
description: LIZA LOU, the artist who has chosen to bead the world, to make it sparkle and glitter, is at it again.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BRADLEY, LUCY GLAZEBROOK
description: BRADLEY-Lucy Glazebrook, 79, beloved wife and mother, died on May 9th, in Sagaponack, New York. Educated at Dobbs and Bennington. Married Vivian Mercier and later George Crawford Bradley. Predeceased by her brother Otis Allan Glazebrook III, she is survived by her sister Anne Kehoe, as well as by her husband George, four children (Ciaran Mercier, Christine Wooding, George Bradley, Jr., Anne Bradley), two grandchildren (Martha Mercier, Beatrice Bradley) and numerous nieces and nephews. Memorial service 2 PM, Saturday, May 17th, Saint Ann's Church, Bridgehampton, NY. Brockett Funeral Home, Southampton.

title: Theater in Review
description: Deadened to a Mother's Pain,

title: A Genius Who Mapped the Future in Mazurkas
description: We have killed him with kindness, poor Chopin. His remarkable works are as ubiquitous as bars of Ivory soap, and hardly less successful in the marketplace. When we complain about the public's indifference to great art, let us remember Chopin and be equally wary of the public's suffocating embrace.

title: Mourning Still Flat, But Heat Survives
description: Clinging to life against the Knicks in the Eastern Conference semifinals, the Miami Heat won tonight despite Alonzo Mourning, not because of him.

title: Spring Art Auctions Conclude With a $119 Million Impressionist and Modern Sale
description: The titans of the Impressionist and modern art world went to war at Christie's last night, and they were in fighting form. The competition to win a Renoir or a Monet, a Picasso or a Brancusi, often became a fierce, drawn-out battle of the millions.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  FULLER, CLARENCE REXFORD
description: FULLER-Clarence Rexford. Clary, it's been five years since you left us. We miss you every day. Ray, Don and Lou, Frank, John and Janet, nieces and nephews

title: South Asian Summit Talks End With Hope for Enhanced Trade
description: A summit meeting of the seven Asian nations that share the subcontinent ended here today with what their leaders acknowledged was a wake-up call to themselves and to the 1.3 billion people they represent.

title: German Growth Is Seen Above 0.5% in Quarter
description: Germany's gross domestic product could grow a real 0.5 percent to 1 percent in the second quarter, exceeding that of the comparable period a year ago by 2.5 percent, DIW, one of Germany's main economic research institutes, said yesterday.

title: Drug Inquiry Drags For Angered Slaney
description: Mary Slaney's brilliant but often-interrupted running career is facing yet another hurdle as she continues her comeback at age 38, this time the investigation of a drug test taken from her at the 1996 Olympic trials in Atlanta.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GORTZ, DORIS W.
description: GORTZ-Doris W., 81, of Lake Worth, May 13, 1997. Beloved wife of Norman; loving mother of Nancy (Gilbert) Rose, Albert (Jane) Gortz, and David (Linda) Gortz. Devoted grandmother of seven. In lieu of flowers contributions to SPSP Inc. (Society for Progressive Supranuclear Palsy), C/O Johns Hopkins Outpatient Cntr, 601 No. Caroline St, Suite 5065, Baltimore, MD. 21287 or The Wellness Community, 5700 No. Federal Highway, Boca Raton, FL 33487. Services on Friday, Boca Raton. Information, Gutterman - Warheit Memorial Chapel, 1-800-992-9262.

title: Q & A /J. Michael Giles, Chairman of Merrill Lynch Private Banking Group : Clients Are Becoming 'More Sophisticated and More Demanding'
description: J. Michael Giles is chairman of London-based Merrill Lynch Private Banking Group, the highly successful and closely watched seven-year-old effort by America's largest brokerage house to break into the broader world of international private banking. In London he spoke with the International Herald Tribune's Erik Ipsen:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ANDERSON, CAROLINE MCCORMICK
description: ANDERSON-Caroline McCormick. David's long-time companion, on May 12. Author, Army officer, fashion model, gourmet cook, cat fancier, voyager to remote and exotic places.

title: NATO Expansion, Ready or Not
description: While America has been occupied by other concerns, President Clinton has set in motion an epochal change in the map of Europe that is now racing toward realization. The change is the eastward expansion of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization, and it picked up momentum yesterday with completion of an agreement to govern Russia's relationship with the alliance.

title: Money for Tunnel Is Cleared
description: Revenue from casino operations can be used to help build a $330 million tunnel to make it easier for gamblers to reach new casinos planned for Atlantic City's marina district, a judge ruled yesterday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BENDHEIM, CHARLES
description: BENDHEIM-Charles. It is with profound sorrow that Shulamith School for Girls expresses its deepest sympathies to the Bendheim family upon the loss of Mr. Charles Bendheim, distinguished philanthropist, a giant in the Jewish community at large, whose deep respect for Torah and its institutions is his lasting legacy. His spirit, courage, counsel and friendship helped Shulamith obtain its school campus in Flatbush. He will be sorely missed. Rabbi Henoch Morgenstern, Pres. Douglas Jablon Chairman of the Board Rabbi Moshe C. Zwick, Exec. Dir. Richard E. Jacobs, Honorary Pres. Leo Schachter Honorary Chairman of the Board

title: RUSSIA AGREES TO NATO PLAN PUSHED BY CLINTON TO ADMIT NATIONS FROM EASTERN BLOC
description: Russia reluctantly agreed today to the Clinton Administration's push to expand the NATO military alliance to include Moscow's former satellites in Central Europe.

title: Philip Morris Acknowledges Investigation
description: The Philip Morris Companies said yesterday that the Federal Trade Commission was investigating how the company distributes its cigarettes.

title: Developer Ranks No 1. in Spending on Lobbyists
description: Forest City Ratner, a prominent developer in New York City, spent more on lobbying the municipal government last year than any other business or group, a new study has found. The company paid $436,382 to hire lobbyists to help insure the success of several real estate projects, from shopping centers to office buildings to parking lots.

title: CHRONICLE
description: It's been a long time coming, but KAYE BALLARD, the actress and comedian, is finally getting to sing ''My Coloring Book,'' the song that was popularized by Barbra Streisand but that Ms. Ballard said was actually written for her 36 years ago.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an error in a technical test, differing sets of result summaries for the Eastern Sprints Regatta rowing competition appeared in the sports pages on Monday. The correct results appear today on page B16.

title: New Digital Firm Is Established
description: Three former executives at the Chicago office of Northern Lights Interactive, an agency owned by True North Communications, have opened a digital marketing and consulting company in Chicago, Four Points Digital L.L.C.

title: Asbestos Closes Schools
description: Three schools serving the developmentally disabled and children with special needs have been closed temporarily so that traces of asbestos can be removed, officials said yesterday.

title: NBC's Storm to Work the W.N.B.A.
description: The NBC sportscaster HANNAH STORM will serve as play-by-play announcer during the inaugural season of the Women's National Basketball Association, the network said yesterday.

title: Subaru leads a pack of auto makers into the great outdoors, hunting the wild niche sport enthusiast.
description: BACK in 1993, Subaru was reeling from steadily declining car sales and was desperate to turn things around. So it splurged and spent $2 million on six 15-second commercials during the Super Bowl.

title: Messinger Attacks Giuliani Over Rent Issue
description: For the third time in a week, Ruth W. Messinger sought yesterday to link Republican efforts to repeal rent regulations to Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani, arguing that he had failed to fight the drive in Albany to scale back rent laws.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PENCHINA, EDITH
description: PENCHINA-Edith, on May 13, 1997. Devoted wife of the late Max. Beloved mother and motherin-law of Michael, Steven, Diane, Roberta, Debbie and Bill. Cherished grandmother of Laurie Mitchell, Jodi, David, Arik, Ditti, Daniel, Josh and Neil.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FREUDENBERG, YVES
description: FREUDENBERG - Yves. Died May 9, 1997. Funeral services will be held at Plaza Memorial Chapels, 630 Amsterdam Avenue, NYC, Friday, May 16. For further information call 1-800-624-8282.

title: German Bank Merger Is Under Consideration
description: Bankgesellschaft Berlin A.G. said yesterday that it had begun talks to acquire Norddeutsche Landesbank Girozentrale, which could lead to the creation of one of Germany's biggest banks. The banks' combined assets at the end of last year were 567 billion marks ($332 billion), about two-thirds the size of Deutsche Bank, Europe's largest bank.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLDMAN, ESTELLE
description: GOLDMAN-Estelle, 89, of Long Beach, NY. Loving mother, wife & friend. Passed away Wednesday, May 13. She is survived by her three children, Michael Goldman, Jerrold Goldman & Rae Kudysch and her grandchildren Melissa Goldman, Kevin Goldman, Judy Kule, Pamela Kudysch, Andrew Kudysch, Seth Goldman and Matthew Goldman. Services private. In lieu of flowers, contributions to Gurwin Jewish Geriatric Center, Commack, New York.

title: Judge Limits City's Using Offices to House Children
description: A Federal judge ordered the city's child welfare agency yesterday to stop its practice of housing foster children for more than one night in city offices.

title: GIANT EAGLE TO BUY RISER FOODS FOR $403 MILLION
description: Riser Foods Inc. agreed yesterday to be acquired by Giant Eagle Inc. for $403 million in cash and assumed debt. The transaction would create a food retailer and wholesaler with sales of $4 billion next year and stores stretching from Pittsburgh to Cleveland. The closely held Giant Eagle, a supermarket chain and wholesale distributor based in Pittsburgh, will pay $42 a share for Riser's class A and class B shares. Shares of Riser Foods, based in Bedford Heights, Ohio, closed yesterday at $41.625. Giant Eagle will also pay for outstanding stock options and assume $47 million of Riser's debt.

title: Tobacco Researcher Said to Decline to Testify
description: A former top research official at the Philip Morris Companies invoked his constitutional right against compelled self-incrimination during pretrial testimony on Tuesday in a lawsuit brought by the State of Texas, a person familiar with his testimony said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MARACHE, NANCIE ALLEN
description: MARACHE-Nancie Allen. Age 65. Beloved wife and mother, died May 14, 1997 in Greenwich, CT. Born in Milwaukee, WS and educated at Westover and Briarcliff. She is survived by her husband Herbert W. Marache, Jr., five children Nina King, Victoria Marache, Eugenie Pavelic, Herbert Marache, III and Mark Marache, six grandchildren, her sister Jebb Allen Miller and brother Nathan R. Allen, Jr. Memorial service 2:30 P.M., Monday, May 18th, In Christ Church, Greenwich, CT. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to Eagle Hill School, Greenwich, Connecticut.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KESTIN, ETHEL
description: KESTIN-Ethel. The Officers and Directors of Metropolitan Jewish Health System sadly mourn the untimely passing of Ethel Kestin, beloved and esteemed former Board member of Metropolitan Jewish Geriatric Center. Her involvement with MJGC dates back, along with her late husband Samuel, more than half a century to the Brooklyn Hebrew Home and Hospital for the Aged, the Town League and other Affiliates. A devoted friend and ardent supporter, Ethel will be greatly missed. May her legacy act as a source of inspiration to all those whom she touched. Our profound sympathy and sincere condolences to the family. Mark L. Goldstein, President Eli S. Feldman, Executive VP Chief Executive Officer

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  NELSON, DORIS SIEGEL
description: NELSON-Doris Siegel. In loving memory of our dearest mother, grandmother and mother-in-law who remains always in our thoughts. We miss you, Merezy. Elizabeth, Margery, Jonathan, Karen, Amy, Andrea, Meredith, Laurie, Bill

title: Zairian Insurgents Keep U.N. From Suspected Massacre Sites
description: Facing two soldiers on the other side of a stick across a jungle road, a high-level United Nations delegation today tried to get into an area where a team of Rwandan soldiers is rumored to be massacring refugees, burning their bodies and scattering the ashes in the forest.

title: Amid Fears of Overheated Markets, Investors Look for Ways to Diversify
description: NEW YORK  Investing private assets when prices in many markets are hovering at record highs is no mean feat. Shares in the United States and much of Europe have soared as have real estate values in most developed countries. At the same time, low interest rates make bonds unattractive and savings accounts even more unappealing.

title: On Nazi Gold, Swiss Face a Double Standard
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GROSS, LEO
description: GROSS-Leo. On May 10, 1997. Age 82. Survived by his wife, Norma; his children, Alan (Penni Harmon), Terry (Victoria Kelly) and Jody (Perk Larsen); and his grandchildren Mowgli, Crystal, Lily, Daniel and Elliot. Memorial service May 16 at 2 PM, at the Ethical Culture Society, 2 West 64 Street at CPW. In lieu of flowers, donations can be made to the Visiting Nurse Service of NY, Hospice Care, 1250 Broadway, New York 10001, or Hospice of the Florida Keys, 1319 William Street, Key West, Florida 33040.

title: Clinton Expects Delay on Nafta
description: President Clinton does not expect Congress to grant him the negotiating authority to expand the North American Free Trade Agreement to Chile and other Latin American countries until next year, his press secretary said today.

title: Not for the Faint-Hearted: Knicks-Heat Turns Nasty
description: When they separated the sea of bodies from the pile, the ones at the bottom belonged to P. J. Brown, the congenial Miami Heat forward and winner of the league's citizenship award, and Charlie Ward, the unassuming Knicks point guard who brings two things to every game: himself and his Bible.

title: Blood Center to Shut Down Screening Lab
description: The New York Blood Center, under pressure from the Food and Drug Administration and facing allegations of improper testing procedures, will close its laboratory in Manhattan that screens for a variety of infectious diseases and hire an independent lab to do the testing, center officials said yesterday.

title: Accusations Of C.I.A. Ties To Drug Ring Are Renewed
description: Even though the editor of The San Jose Mercury News has said an internal review found serious flaws in his newspaper's ''Dark Alliance'' series of reports, people who believed the articles' implication of a direct link between the C.I.A. and the crack epidemic continue to press for a Congressional investigation.

title: RAMBUS SHARES MORE THAN DOUBLE IN PRICE IN OFFERING
description: The shares of Rambus Inc. closed at more than double the offering price after a $33 million initial public offering of the company, a designer of technology that speeds communication among computer chips. The shares of the company, based in Mountain View, Calif., closed at $30.25 in Nasdaq trading. Almost 5.2 million shares changed hands, some of them more than once. Rambus sold 2.75 million shares at $12 each. Rambus is the first initial offering in several months in which the share price doubled on opening day.

title: Blair, Keeping Up Pace, Pledges Package of Reforms
description: Prime Minister Tony Blair pledged his hyperactive Government to an ambitious package of legislative promises today to bring the changes to Britain he said were owed the country by his Labor Party's overwhelming victory in the May 1 election.

title: A Series Spins Out Of Control
description: IT got wild in Miami last night. And suddenly, a series that the Knicks looked like they controlled spun out of control.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BALSKY, BELLE
description: BALSKY-Belle. Loving wife of the late Theodore. Beloved mother of Estelle Strassler (David) and Susan Friedman (James). Cherished grandmother of Jason, Douglas, Allison and Erica. Services Thursday, 11:00 A.M., at Mt. Moriah Cemetery, Fairview, New Jersey.

title: Group Seeks Regulations To Make Eggs Safer
description: Once considered nature's perfect food, the egg has become the primary contributor to food poisoning in the United States. Yesterday, a nutrition advocacy group in Washington called for Federal regulations that could make raw eggs reliably safe to eat. Under current regulations, eggs are rarely inspected for safety.

title: Crossroads For France
description: When the Gaullist president of the National Assembly, a man previously known for his caustic views on American capitalism, enters the electoral fray by praising the way a free-market economy ''rewards those who dare, those who take risks,'' it seems safe to say that something is stirring in France.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  O'HAGAN, WILLIAM J.
description: O'HAGAN-William J. On May 14, 1997. Loving husband of Theresa (nee Bamonte). Beloved father of William and Michael. Devoted grandfather to Lauren, Connor and Ross. Fond father-in-law of Theresa and Sylvia. Mass of Christian Burial Saturday 9:30 A.M. at St. Patrick R.C. Church. Visitation Thursday 7-9 P.M. and Friday 2-5 and 7-9 P.M. at Ridge Chapels, 405 91st Street, Brooklyn. Interment in Greenwood Cemetery.

title: Giving Comedy a Darker Hue
description: There is a brief moment in Larry Gelbart's dark new television film, ''Weapons of Mass Distraction,'' when there is suddenly hope that this bleak comedy about the tabloidization of America might ease back into mere satire, pleasant if somewhat cynical entertainment.

title: The War Within
description: On Israel's Independence Day the Army Chief of Staff, Amnon Shahak, was asked by the Yediot newspaper whether he was more worried about the eroding status of the Israeli Army in the eyes of the Israeli public or by Syria's steady buildup of missiles and chemical weapons. General Shahak answered: ''Neither.''

title: INSIDE METRO
description: ACCIDENT PAYMENT 35 YEARS LATER -- More than three decades after an accident left him paralyzed, Bob Manning, a former utility lineman (left), will get $1.2 million in compensation. B7.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Midwest Utility Merger Back to Drawing Board

title: Election Lead Narrows
description: Mayor Bret D. Schundler's apparent margin of victory in Tuesday's election in Jersey City narrowed yesterday, increasing the possibility of a runoff election, officials said. After the tally sheets were proofread, Mr. Schundler had 19,535 votes, or 50.03 percent of the total, just 11 votes more than he needed to avoid a runoff. Jerramiah T. Healy, former chief judge of the Municipal Court, received 16,031 of the vote (41.06 percent) and City Councilman Jaime Vasquez received 3,381 (8.66 percent).

title: Events: Walking Tours And a Show House
description: Morningside Heights Tour

title: The Lesser Evil
description: To The Home Section:

title: Harlem Teacher Charged in Sex Abuse of Student
description: A teacher who was an assistant director of a Harlem program for students with behavior problems had sex with a 15-year-old student, giving the boy money and promising he would be promoted in return, the police and prosecutors said yesterday.

title: PIONEER AGREES TO BUY CHEMICAL PLANT FROM OCCIDENTAL
description: The Pioneer Companies said yesterday that it had agreed to buy a chemical plant in Tacoma, Wash., from the Occidental Chemical Corporation for $102.5 million in cash and stock. Pioneer, a Houston-based chemical company, said the acquisition would add to its production of chlorine and caustic soda. Pioneer is to pay $97 million in cash and $5.5 million in preferred stock for the plant. The preferred stock is convertible into 440,000 shares of common stock. Pioneer also agreed to supply a portion of the Tacoma plant's chlorine production to Occidental Chemical for up to five years. Occidental Chemical is a subsidiary of the Occidental Petroleum Corporation of Los Angeles.

title: Ex-Policeman Who Told of Apartheid Crimes Is Guilty of Killing
description: South Africa's best known whistle- blower the first white police officer to expose the former Government's dirty war against anti-apartheid activists -- was convicted of murder today in a Durban court.

title: No Headline
description: ''If you want to make change in the world, you don't have to become a huge, wealthy, powerful person. You agree? Then pay off your student loan, damn it.''

title: 'Stun Shields' Are Being Tested on Rikers Island
description: Correction officers have begun using electric ''stun shields'' to subdue violent inmates on Rikers Island, city officials said yesterday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GUEST, JOHN SPENCER, CHURCHILL
description: GUEST-John Spencer-Churchill. Age 84 of New Canaan, CT and Fishers Island, NY on May 14. Husband of Margaret Guest, father of Cornelia and Richard Guest, father-in-law of Cynthia Guest and Robert Mitchell, grandfather of Sarah Guest, Andrew Mitchell, Aune Mitchell and John Mitchell, uncle of Henry Smith-Miller. Memorial service Wednesday, May 21 at St. Mark's Church, Oenoke Ridge, New Canaan, CT at 3:00P.M. Donations in lieu of flowers may be made to the Fishers Island Fire Department Sea Stretcher Fund, Fishers Island, NY 06390.

title: Sure Sign of Spring: Bobby Short Is Back
description: To a drum roll, Bobby Short approached the piano, beginning the first show of the first night of his second week of his 30th spring season at the glamorous Cafe Carlyle. (Don't think he didn't say it just that way.) He thereupon threw himself into a kind of supersonic, fortissimo interweaving of two Cole Porter songs, ''I've Got My Eyes on You'' and ''From This Moment On.'' For the first time in his residence at the Carlyle, he has expanded his group beyond a trio of piano, bass and drums, adding three saxophones, a trumpet and a trombone. They loosely swaddled him in tasteful arrangements as he went through his very idiosyncratic paces.

title: NATO's Bad Bargain
description: To soften the pain of NATO expansion, the West has offered Russia a number of carrots: Membership in the Group of Seven industrialized nations, steps toward a new strategic arms treaty, economic aid packages, no nuclear weapons in new NATO member states and the establishment of a NATO-Russia council for security matters.

title: NEW VIDEO RELEASES
description: Heavy

title: Sparks Fly Over Aide's 'Elevator Tapes'
description: From the top of the World Trade Center to the ground 106 floors below, the campaign manager for Rudolph W. Giuliani fenced tensely yesterday with a reporter before an audience of campaign aides and tourists, as the Rev. Al Sharpton offered a taunting, floor-by-floor commentary on the encounter.

title: For a Father Or a Friend
description: ''La Promesse'' was shown as part of last year's New York Film Festival. Following are excerpts from Stephen Holden's review, which appeared in The New York Times on Oct. 7. The film -- in French with English subtitles -- opens today in Manhattan.

title: Big Talent, Big Pay
description: To the Editor:

title: A Parade of Immigrants Passing Before the Lens
description: AT first glance, there seems a metaphorical aptness to the idea of a photography show about immigration to America. Few subjects vary so abruptly in reaction to altered angles of vision or shifts in focus, and few are so protean in their response to changes of viewing distance. Like a flock of birds or a school of minnows, the whirl of immigration seems to reorganize itself whenever you approach it, then find new shapes as you back away or climb to higher ground.

title: Involuntary Sex
description: To the Editor:

title: City Budget Shuns Tricks and Election Ploys
description: To the Editor:

title: Judge Revokes Gigante's Bail, Confining Him to Hospital
description: Moving to take swift control of a long and and tortuous case, a newly assigned judge revoked the bail of the reputed Mafia boss Vincent Gigante yesterday, and set out a strict schedule to bring him to trial next month after six years of delays.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, a front-page article yesterday about the nation's first female B-52 pilot misstated her rank. Kelly Flinn is a first lieutenant, not a second lieutenant.

title: With His Own Money, Gingrich Pays First Part of Ethics Fine
description: Speaker Newt Gingrich began paying his $300,000 ethics fine today and promised the House ethics committee that he would reduce the amount he planned to borrow from former Senator Bob Dole to no more than $150,000.

title: The View From the Driver's Seat
description: This is a 30-second television advertisement from the gubernatorial campaign of Michael Murphy, a former Morris County Prosecutor.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SAFIR, PEARL RASHKIN
description: SAFIR-Pearl Rashkin. on May 14, one week before her 100th birthday. Beloved wife of the late Leo C. Safir. Beloved mother of the late Marvin R. Safir. Adored grandmother of Lisa and Shelly. Great grandmother of Ethan and Lea. May she rest in peace and love in the arms of her husband, her son and God.

title: Game 6 at Garden: Van Gundy Needs a Strategy
description: They were on the cusp of moving swiftly into the next round two days ago, their date with a dynasty as firm as Charles Oakley's biceps. Yet sometime between the tense and waning moments of Game 5 and today, the Knicks' season took an abrupt turn.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about Vaclav Havel's view of an accord between NATO and Russia referred incorrectly to a New York-based organization that scheduled a tribute to him last night. It is the Institute for East-West Studies, not the Institute for East-West Relations.

title: NEW VIDEO RELEASES
description: One Fine Day

title: Indiana Girl to Transfer Out of Women's Prison
description: A 16-year-old girl from Indiana who became a symbol of the plight of juveniles in adult prisons will be transferred to a private treatment center for young people, Gov. Frank L. O'Bannon said yesterday.

title: EDISON INTERNATIONAL PLANS TO BUY BACK MORE SHARES
description: Edison International said yesterday that it planned to buy back up to $1.5 billion of its common shares. Edison, a utility company based in Rosemead, Calif., said the move was in addition to a program to buy back $800 million of stock. As of Wednesday, the company had repurchased about 40 million shares for about $765 million under that program. Edison's shares closed at $22.875 yesterday, up 37.5 cents, on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: Courage in South Africa
description: On the last day that South Africans could apply for amnesty from apartheid-era crimes, leaders of the governing African National Congress disclosed their involvement in hundreds of misdeeds. One of those seeking amnesty is Deputy President Thabo Mbeki, who is likely to become South Africa's next president. He and his party colleagues have done the right thing in so clearly demonstrating their respect for the rule of law.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ZEMACH, RABBI ABRAHAM
description: ZEMACH-Rabbi Abraham. 81, of Deerfield, IL on May 12, 1997. He held masters and doctoral degrees from The Jewish Theological Seminary of America and was ordained as a Rabbi in 1941. Commissioned in 1942, he served as a U.S. Army Chaplain in Europe during World War II; then, as Advisor on Jewish Affairs to General Mark Clark, he helped establish settlements for displaced persons in Austria, aiding in the rescue and care of more than six thousand Jews. He also assisted the AngloAmerican Committee of Inquiry on Palestine, and was awarded the Bronze Star and the Army Commendation medal. He served as Director of B'nai B'rith Hillel FoundationS at several universities, received a Master of Public Health degree from the University of Michigan in 1972, and served with the Michigan Department of Public Health until his retirement in 1986. Rabbi Zemach is survived by his wife Rita, sister Sarah Reuler, and brother Mordecai; his son Brian, daughter Marilyn Greene, and three grandchildren.

title: What Postal Service?
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  SHARP, EVELYN
description: SHARP-Evelyn. A memorial service in remembrance of Evelyn Sharp will be held on Tuesday, May 20, 1997, at 5:00 P.M., at The Solomon R. Guggenheim Museum, 1071 Fifth Avenue at 88th Street, New York City, in The Peter B. Lewis Theater.

title: Tender Simplicity in Early America
description: WHEN it comes to purity of heart and form, early American folk art is hard to beat. Its recurring victories in this regard dominate ''A Passion for the Past,'' at the Museum of American Folk Art. This often incandescent exhibition presents 75 works from the legendary folk art collection of Bertram K. and Nina Fletcher Little of Brookline, Mass.

title: AMAZON.COM STOCK RISES 30% AFTER PUBLIC OFFERING
description: Amazon.com Inc.'s newly public stock began trading yesterday nearly $12 higher than its offering price as investors chased after one of the hottest offerings this year. Amazon.com stock was priced Wednesday night at $18 a share and it opened yesterday at $29.15 on the Nasdaq stock market. After climbing as high as $30 a share, it retreated and finished at $23.50, up 30.5 percent. Amazon.com, an Internet bookseller, has said that it sold $16 million worth of books in 1996 to 180,000 customers in 100 countries. Average daily visits to the company's Web site rose to 50,000 in December 1996 from 2,200 in December 1995.

title: Two Charged With Perjury After Trading Lotus Options
description: Two New Jersey investors have become the first publicly identified targets in a Federal investigation into possible insider trading in the shares of the Lotus Development Corporation before it was bought by I.B.M. in 1995.

title: White House Defeats Prosecutor In a Small War About Wording
description: Kenneth W. Starr, the Whitewater independent counsel, thought the Supreme Court was about to make a big mistake.

title: East Side Condo Plan Meets Resistance
description: Reflecting the continuing demand for luxury condominiums in Manhattan, developers have announced plans for a new 32-story building with apartments as large as five bedrooms on Third Avenue between 77th and 78th Streets.

title: The Real Choice
description: And now NATO will expand its membership, to help protect democracy and Western civilization in Europe. But outside Europe, in Asia and the Middle East, its members and partners will continue doing everything they can get away with to strengthen dictatorships that are the enemies of democracy and Western civilization.

title: Art in Review
description: 'Broken Home'

title: Union Points Finger at Disney In Contract Dispute With ABC
description: Mickey Mouse and Minnie Mouse -- or at least union supporters dressed up as the famous rodents -- demonstrated against all things Disney yesterday as the union representing technicians at ABC escalated a contract dispute with the network by attacking its image-conscious parent, the Walt Disney Company.

title: Western Thought, Bound By Greek Book Designers
description: The Greeks who fled to Europe, manuscripts in hand, after the fall of Constantinople in 1453 were impressively quick to take advantage of the new invention of printing. Emigre scholars and scribes, especially in Italy, became printers, type founders and book designers, imitating manuscript traditions and modeling delicately graceful Greek type on their own calligraphy. A small but stimulating exhibition at the Onassis Center for Hellenic Studies at New York University, with books lent by H. P. Kraus Inc., illustrates the evolution of their art, as well as their profound influence on Western intellectual life.

title: ANALYST'S REPORT PUSHES ORACLE STOCK HIGHER
description: The stock of the Oracle Corporation rose yesterday in heavy trading after an analyst speculated that the company was on the verge of making an acquisition. The analyst, Rick Sherlund of Goldman, Sachs & Company, said in a research note that the company was set to make a technology acquisition ''of some significance.'' Oracle officials were not immediately available for comment. In the note, Mr. Sherlund said Oracle indicated it would address the applications business with more vertical market products, ''including a soon-to-be-disclosed effort in the energy market'' against SAP A.G., a German software developer. Oracle provides data base software and applications software. Its stock rose $1.625 yesterday, to $45.9375, in Nasdaq trading of more than 7.1 million shares.

title: Woman Alters Testimony In Rape Retrial
description: For the second time in seven months, a young woman who accused Alex Kelly of raping her 11 years ago took the stand today to identify him as her attacker, but changed her testimony on an issue that proved pivotal in the first trial, which ended with a deadlocked jury.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SKOLNIK, NATHAN
description: SKOLNIK-Nathan. Died on May 10, at the age of 85. Beloved husband of Rose for over 60 years, father of Richard (Louise) and Phyllis, grandfather of Seth, Sari, Deborah, Rebecca. A man of unswerving rectitude, boundless energy, immense curiosity and generosity, he was held in enormous esteem by all who knew him. He will be greatly missed but the lessons of his exemplary life will long remain to guide us.

title: Ghosts of Earlier Day Still Haunt the Fed
description: To the Editor:

title: Interest Rate Concerns Push Dollar Lower Against Yen
description: The dollar fell against the Japanese yen yesterday to near the level at which it started the year amid diminished expectations that the Federal Reserve will raise interest rates next week. But it rose slightly against the German mark.

title: The Captain Is Happy In His Barn, Sweet Barn
description: The trainer Gary Capuano is not out of his mind, even though his horse Captain Bodgit is out of sight.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KOZEL, BERNARD I.
description: KOZEL-Bernard I. On May 12, 1997. Beloved husband of Shirley. Devoted father of Shelly and Laurie. Loving grandfather of Lauren, Jason and Marc. Dear brother, brother-in-law, uncle, father-in-law and son-in-law. Services were held. He is missed by all.

title: Harry Blackstone Jr., 62, Master of the Magic Arts, Dies
description: Harry Blackstone Jr., a magician who made handkerchiefs dance across a Broadway stage and globes of light float above his audience, who made elephants vanish and turned beautiful women into Bengal tigers, who sawed his wife in half 17 times a week during their 23 years of marriage, died on Wednesday at a hospital in Loma Linda, Calif. He was 62, and lived in Redlands, Calif.

title: Penalty in Unabom Case
description: Attorney General Janet Reno has authorized prosecutors to seek the death penalty for the suspect in the Unabom case despite arguments that executing him would be an injustice and devastating to the relatives who turned him in.

title: Swiss Aide, Changing Tone, Snipes at U.S. on Nazi Gold
description: After a week of spreading conciliatory messages that Switzerland was ready to make amends for its actions as bankers to Nazi Germany, a senior Swiss official changed his tone today, warning a Senate panel that his country was growing tired of being ''treated as an international outcast.''

title: Time Warner Is Again Criticized For Distributing 'Gangsta' Rap
description: Time Warner was drawn back into the dispute over ''gangsta'' rap music yesterday, as a small crowd picketed its annual meeting in New York to protest the lyrics of one of its popular rap performers.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PORTER, GEORGE L.
description: PORTER-George L., a long time resident of Greenwich Village, died May 15, 1997. Beloved husband of Doris Woodell Porter. Born in Vienna, Austria he became Vice President for Business and Finance, as well as controller, of the National Audubon Society, from which he retired in 1975. He was the author of ''The World of the Frog and the Toad'' a well reviewed book published by J.B. Lippincott and was author, as well, of the ''Reptile and Amphibian'' section of ''Hammond's Nature Atlas of America''. His amphibian photographs appear world-wide.

title: The Boys Go Into Business
description: It isn't just its Irish working-class characters who emerge as endearingly larger than life in Stephen Frears's fine, full-blooded new comedy, ''The Van.'' The beer is beerier, the spice burgers are spicier and Christmases more Christmassy. As for the clogged arteries and heaving stomachs of characters who seem never to have heard of the concept of fat-free anything, the best defense against an astronomical cholesterol count, this boisterous movie suggests, is a roaring lust for life, come grease or high water.

title: After a Veto, Pataki Offers His Own Solar-Panel Plan
description: Seven months after he vetoed a similar bill, Gov. George E. Pataki offered his own proposal yesterday to allow New Yorkers to install rooftop solar panels and sell excess electricity back to their utilities, earning credit on their electric bills.

title: For Children
description: Children's Dance Performances

title: Boutique for Shoes Quietly Closes Down
description: For a time, it seemed, the shoes with the very long name occupied a hallowed spot in the closets of the fashionable. Made from alligator or ostrich, Susan Bennis Warren Edwards shoes attracted everyone from Bruce Springsteen to Jacqueline Kennedy Onassis.

title: Ending a Chapter, Mobutu Cremates Rwanda Ally
description: In what may be one of his last acts as head of state, President Mobutu Sese Seko today ordered the cremation of the body of Rwanda's former President, Juvenal Habyarimana, who died in a suspicious airplane explosion over his country in April 1994.

title: 3 Democratic Rivals Attack Giuliani, Not One Another
description: In their first appearance together since Fernando Ferrer dropped out of the mayoral race, the three Democratic candidates politely sidestepped invitations to criticize one another at a forum yesterday while they attacked the record of Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani.

title: Shuttle Takes Off to Fortify the Mir Station
description: An international crew of astronauts aboard the space shuttle Atlantis took off today on a planned nine-day mission for a critical visit to the aging Russian space station Mir.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ENGEL, MARJORIE
description: ENGEL-Marjorie. Beloved wife of Philip. Loving mother of Elyse, Terri, Steven and Wendy and sonin-laws Robert Lipkowitz and Adam Cohen. Cherished grandmother of Jordan, Garett, Carly, Alexandra, Juliann, Zachary, Luke and Remi.

title: WHITE HOUSE CALLS FOR MINIMUM WAGE IN WORKFARE PLAN
description: Weighing in on one of the most contentious issues from last year's landmark welfare bill, the White House said today that most of the recipients being placed in work programs should be covered by minimum-wage laws.

title: Pushing the Speed Limit On the Yellow-Brick Road
description: IF it only had a brain.

title: Price Waterhouse to Receive State Grants in Exchange for More Jobs
description: In exchange for a pledge to add more than 1,000 workers in its Manhattan offices over the next five years, the accounting firm of Price Waterhouse will receive $2 million in state grants, Gov. George E. Pataki said yesterday.

title: BARNETT BANKS AGREES TO ACQUIRE REPUBLIC BANKING
description: Barnett Banks Inc., based in Jacksonville, Fla., agreed in principle to buy the privately held Republic Banking Corporation for an undisclosed sum, expanding Barnett's leading market share in Florida. Republic's 25 branches in Dade County operate under the name Republic National Bank of Miami. The acquisition would add $1.5 billion in assets and $1.3 billion in deposits to Barnett's $40 billion in assets. Barnett's shares rose 12.5 cents yesterday, to $50.75.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GERTZ, DIANA RADIN
description: GERTZ-Diana Radin. Died May 15, 1997. Beloved wife of the late Louis Simon Gertz. Last survivor of the five siblings who, together with their father Benjamin, founded the Gertz Department Stores of Long Island. Loving mother of Joan Gertz Wilner and Benjamin Ira Gertz and mother-in-law of Dr. Howard I. Wilner and Kathryn Rose Gertz. Adoring grandmother of Dr. Scott Lawrence Wilner, Stephanie Jeanne-Lee Gertz and Margaret Ellen Gertz. Services at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81 Street, Sunday 9AM. In lieu of flowers, contributions in her momory may be made to the Alzheimer's Disease and Related Disorders Association, 420 Lexington Avenue NY, NY 10170.

title: China to Buy 30 Planes for $1.5 Billion From Airbus Industrie
description: In the politically charged battle for China's enormous aircraft market, Airbus Industrie won a round over the Boeing Company today by netting an order for 30 new airplanes, worth $1.5 billion.

title: Limited Shelf Life
description: To the Editor:

title: Passaic and Other Communities Are Eager to Find Out
description: Half the schools in this tightly packed city have no libraries. More than a few have classrooms in basements, where boilers hiss and cloudy windows afford no view. Schools lack art and music rooms; playgrounds lack grass.

title: News Summary
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-14

title: CHRONICLE
description: MADISON COX, a garden designer, is about to achieve a trans-Atlantic horticultural feat. His garden at the Chelsea Flower Show in London will be viewed by judges on Sunday, by the royal family on Monday and by the public through Friday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COHEN, IKE
description: COHEN-Ike. On May 15, 1997 of Plainview, L.I. Beloved husband of Fae. Devoted father of Allan, Jill Sherman and Bob. Loving fatherin-law of Roberta, Arnie and Lynne. Dear brother of Dave, Hy and Sam. Adored grandfather of Evan, Stacie, Michael, Andrew and Tyler. Services Friday, 10AM at ''Gutterman's'', 8000 Jericho Turnpike, Woodbury, L.I.

title: Art in Review
description: Mark Tansey

title: Filial Love And Duty In Conflict
description: Sidney Lumet, the poet laureate of urban police corruption, is on apparently safe ground with ''Night Falls on Manhattan,'' the story of a brash young district attorney and his unsentimental education. Mr. Lumet finds a rainbow of moral shadings in a tale that begins with a police raid on a drug dealer, then has repercussions throughout the criminal justice system. Not surprisingly, Mr. Lumet gives this film a wide array of characters and a solid sense of place. He has made 29 films in New York City without duplicating a location, and he knows his territory inside and out.

title: Swiss Bank Steps Up to Buy Dillon, Read on Rebound
description: The Swiss Bank Corporation said yesterday that it would acquire Dillon, Read & Company, the New York investment company, for about $600 million, one day after the ING Groep of the Netherlands said that its talks with Dillon had broken off.

title: Tenderness and Rage Residing in Men's Hearts
description: Tenderness expressed among friends and between lovers is one of the most difficult qualities to dramatize without stumbling into a quagmire of tear-drenched schmaltz. One reason the film version of Terrence McNally's play ''Love! Valour! Compassion!'' is so moving is that this complicated group portrait never loses its slippery emotional footing. As it follows the troubled lives of the gay men who share three country weekends one summer in upstate New York, the film sustains a perfect, if precarious, balance between sweet and sour. Even when its characters are sniping viciously at one another, their underlying camaraderie is palpable.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  SCHOEN, RITA
description: SCHOEN-Rita. Happy Birthday. With Love, Marcos Del Forn and Family

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCKEOWN, DOROTHY OLDING
description: McKEOWN - Dorothy Olding. Longtime resident of 447 East 57th Street, where she was fondly admired by neighbors and staff alike. Her longtime service on our Board of Directors was much appreciated, as was her indomitable, dignified and elegant presence. We will miss her. The 447 East 57th Street Corp.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: Baseball

title: NEW VIDEO RELEASES
description: Star Trek: First Contact

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BRADLEY, LUCY GLAZEBROOK
description: BRADLEY-Lucy Glazebrook, 79, beloved wife and mother, died on May 9th, in Sagaponack, New York. Educated at Dobbs and Bennington. Married Vivian Mercier and later George Crawford Bradley. Predeceased by her brother Otis Allan Glazebrook III, she is survived by her sister Anne Kehoe, as well as by her husband George, four children (Ciaran Mercier, Christine Wooding, George Bradley, Jr., Anne Bradley), two grandchildren (Martha Mercier, Beatrice Bradley) and numerous nieces and nephews. Memorial service 2 PM, Saturday, May 17th, Saint Ann's Church, Bridgehampton, NY. Brockett Funeral Home, Southampton.

title: Clinton and G.O.P. Spell Out Details for Balanced Budget
description: After two weeks of haggling and a day of high-level negotiating, Senator Trent Lott, the majority leader, announced this evening that Congressional Republicans and the White House had agreed in writing to the details of their balanced budget deal. He said he expected Congress to approve a budget resolution within a week.

title: Knicks Can Blame Only Themselves
description: THERE is the quaint notion in some corners of the world that New York teams receive preferential treatment from all the league headquarters located in New York. Gotta get that gigantic television audience into the next round.

title: Food on Ninth Avenue
description: Ninth Avenue will become a 20-block-long buffet table this weekend for the 24th Ninth Avenue Food Festival. Tables piled high with cannoli, tamales, spring rolls and other items prepared by merchants and food vendors will line the avenue from 37th to 57th Streets in Manhattan tomorrow and Sunday, from 11 A.M. to 7 P.M. In addition, music and dance will be performed on stages at 37th and 46th Street and games and rides for children will be at 39th Street.

title: Goldman Earns Millions on Deal
description: Goldman, Sachs & Company made an estimated $15 million this week from its purchase and resale of 170 million shares of British Petroleum P.L.C., according to people familiar with the transaction.

title: Price Inflation Held to Scant Rise in April
description: As part of a last flurry of statistics before the Federal Reserve meets on interest rates, the Government reported today that declines for energy and food held consumer inflation to a scant one-tenth of 1 percent in April.

title: Croat Refugees Rampage Through 4 Serbian Villages in Croatia
description: Mobs of Bosnian Croat refugees rampaged through at least four Serbian villages here over the last three days, breaking into homes, smashing property, and forcing dozens of terrified Serbs to flee to the surrounding woods, international relief officials and local residents said today.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Consumer Price Index Shows Only a Small Rise

title: Restaurants
description: ''There are no restaurants like this in Rio,'' say my Brazilian friends, seating themselves in the warm and festive room that is Circus. ''Nobody wants to go out to eat the food they cook at home.''

title: Woods's 64 A Shot Back
description: The Future of Golf was welcomed back to the PGA Tour today with a barrage of low scores put up by a collection of not quite as young up-and-comers. But Tiger Woods answered in scrambling fashion, recovering from back-to-back bogeys, to stand one shot out of the lead at the GTE Byron Nelson Classic.

title: After Latin Venture Fails, VW Succeeds And Ford Scrambles
description: Supported by concrete posts and topped with five lines of barbed wire, the six-foot-high chain-link fence zigzags through the heart of what used to be a blossoming auto-making partnership here. On one side of the fence are the operations of the Ford Motor Company, on the other side those of Volkswagen A.G., now divided by a nasty corporate divorce -- a case study of the difficulties in breaking up a big-company joint venture.

title: Senate Tries to Define Fetal Viability
description: From the moment in 1973 that it made abortion legal, giving states authority to restrict the procedure only if a fetus could live outside the womb, the United States Supreme Court created a doctrine that Justice Sandra Day O'Connor would later describe as ''at war with itself.''

title: Anti-Smoking Bills Cleared
description: Three anti-smoking measures cleared the Senate Health Committee yesterday, but the American Cancer Society did not claim victory.

title: Hewlett Net Falls Below Estimates
description: The Hewlett-Packard Company reported second-quarter earnings today that fell below Wall Street analysts' estimates, citing a slowdown in its crucial printer business, as well as in some of its computer lines. The strong dollar was also a factor, the company said.

title: Just as Williams Had Feared
description: Like Nostradamus of the hardwood, Buck Williams could see this all coming as clearly as he could see a rebound falling off the rim. He had been around the Knicks for all of one season, never when Pat Riley was their coach. But he has played pro basketball for 16 years, with some of the game's nuttier stage acts, and he knows potential trouble when he sees it.

title: The Spoken Word
description: ''LIBERALISM AT THE CROSSROADS, A CONFERENCE IN HONOR OF ARTHUR SCHLESINGER JR.,'' Graduate School and University Center of the City University of New York, 33 West 42d Street, Manhattan. A daylong program devoted to the writer and historian. Among those taking part are Stanley Crouch, a columnist for The Daily News in New York; William J. vanden Heuvel, a former United States deputy permanent representative to the United Nations, and Mr. Schlesinger. Today, 9 A.M. to 6 P.M. Free. Information: (212) 642-2684.

title: Poll Finds Few Support Label Of Multiracial
description: A new Census Bureau study released today has again determined that few people would opt to describe themselves as multiracial if given the chance on the census form. And, with the exception of Asian-Americans, few racial groups would see their numbers significantly diminished if such a category were added to the census.

title: Dangerous Times for a Jungle Prince
description: Perhaps in the mannerly days of Queen Victoria the sight of a child behaving like an animal could attract a paying audience. For better and worse, those days are probably long gone, but the premise of the wild child as a valuable curiosity underlies the feeble new juvenile adventure that goes by the jaw-breaking title ''Rudyard Kipling's 'The Second Jungle Book, Mowgli and Baloo.' ''

title: Art in Review
description: Gary Hume

title: New Buyers Turn Art Sales Into Expensive Parties
description: The feel-good factor that economists and real estate brokers keep talking about has infected the market for Impressionist, modern and contemporary art at virtually every price level. For the last two weeks, bidders at the important spring sales at Sotheby's and Christie's in Manhattan spent staggering sums on everything from ultra-sweet Impressionist paintings to hard-edged modern ones. There were even takers for the tough subjects tackled by avant-garde contemporary artists in the late 1980's and early 90's.

title: What Is NATO? Europe's Glue, Not Kremlin's Foe
description: Western Europeans who support NATO's expansion to take in the new democracies of Central Europe do not see the move, primarily, as insurance against the possibility that Russia might one day emerge again as a threat to their security.

title: Lord Byron Checks Out Tiger's 64
description: OFFICIALLY, the golf tournament is known as the GTE Byron Nelson Classic, the only PGA Tour event named for a golfer. And here in the Dallas area it's known as ''the Byron'' for the

title: Wild West Supermoms, Waging the Right Wars
description: ''True Women'' is a mini-series dedicated to the anxiety-provoking idea that Supermoms existed in frontier days, too. Dana Delany plays Sarah McClure, who can give birth, lead a wagon train, shoot straight and stare down Comanches, all at the same time. Between Sarah and her younger sister, Euphemia (played as a child by Tina Majorino and as an adult by Annabeth Gish), the family interferes in most of 19th-century Texas history. Prettily photographed, smoothly acted and overloaded with heroic melodrama, ''True Women'' has the surface sweep and the deep-bred silliness of the generic network mini-series.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CAVE, VERNAL M.D.
description: CAVE-Vernal M.D. It is with deep gratitude that we remember our colleague and fellow board member of the Arthur Ashe Institute for Urban Health, Dr. Vernal Gordon Cave. Early in the Institute's founding, Dr. Cave gave unselfishly of his expertise, commitment and financial support. His deep understanding of the health needs of the disenfranchised communities of New York helped the Institute launch much needed programs. His warm and gentle spirit will be sorely missed by all of who were privileged to serve with him at the Institute. Edgar Mandeville, M.D., Chairman, Board of Directors Arthur Ashe Institute for Urban Health

title: Brokers Offered Property For Brothels, Police Say
description: Law enforcement officials arrested three real-estate brokers in Queens yesterday, saying the brokers were offering rental properties for use as houses of prostitution.

title: Satire's Point
description: To the Editor:

title: Fisticuffs Fever Spreads to Seattle
description: Thursday night at the fights wasn't much different than Wednesday night at the fights, other than everyone staying chained to their benches.

title: INSIDE METRO
description: THE TWO LIVES OF JOSE GOMEZ -- Jose Gomez appeared to be mute when he showed up at a Newark Hospital, but his neighbors know a much different man. B2.

title: House Passes Disaster Aid, With Wrinkle
description: The House tonight followed the Senate in passing an emergency $8.4 billion spending bill spurred by floods in the Dakotas, despite a White House veto threat directed at a provision intended to prevent Government shutdowns in budget fights.

title: Mysterious Pair Identified, but Answer Raises Questions
description: Many of Jose Gomez's neighbors in Bushwick, Brooklyn, know him as not deaf and not mute. Yesterday, they said he was not particularly shrewd, either.

title: Canada's Leader Finds Hometown Fretful
description: Prime Minister Jean Chretien's Liberal Party holds a commanding lead as the June 2 national elections approach, but Mr. Chretien himself is in one of the toughest fights of his long political career.

title: Perilous Journey Home Upon the Wine-Dark Sea
description: As befits a Homerian epic, NBC's ''Odyssey'' is big, beginning with the credits. The executive producers are Robert Halmi Sr. (''Gulliver's Travels''), Francis Ford Coppola (''The Godfather''), Fred Fuchs (''Don Juan de Marco'') and Nicholas Meyer (''The Day After''). The director and co-writer is Andrei Konchalovsky (''Runaway Train''). And the director of photography, brimming with splendid location shooting in Turkey and Malta, is Sergei Koslov.

title: Hoping to Raise Profiles, 2 Whitman Foes Begin TV Ads
description: With less than three weeks to go before New Jersey's gubernatorial primary, two Democratic candidates seeking to unseat Gov. Christine Todd Whitman have begun television advertising campaigns aimed at overcoming a major obstacle: Few voters seem to know their names.

title: Accused B-52 Pilot Considers Her Options, Including Resignation
description: The civilian lawyer representing a B-52 bomber pilot charged under military law with adultery and other crimes said today that she had not decided whether to ask to be allowed to resign rather than face court-martial next week.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JOHNSTON, KENNETH F. SR.
description: JOHNSTON-Kenneth F. Sr., of Manhasset, New York (retired NYPD), suddenly on 13 May 1997. Beloved husband of the late Catherine M. (nee Crichton). Cherished father of the late Kenneth Jr. (Stephanie), Rev. Jeffrey, Beth Perchuk (Mark), Janice Abdenour (Michael), Donna Cardone (James) & Douglas (JeanMarie). Adored ''Gumpy'' of Kenneth III, Matthew, Kathleen, Heather, Nolan and Kaylyn Johnston, Kyle and Kendall Cardone, Michael and Keith Abdenour. Devoted brother of Audrey Reed, and brother-inlaw of Ivy Voelbel and Anne Crichton. Also survived by nieces, nephews, many friends and ''his kids,'' the hundreds of youngsters he coached during the past 30 years in St. Mary's CYO program. Visiting at the Fairchild Chapel, 1570 Northern Boulevard in Manhasset on Thursday from 7-9 PM and on Friday from 3-5 and 7-9 PM. There will be a Vigil Service at 8 PM on Friday. Funeral mass at 10:45 Saturday, 17 May at St. Mary R.C. Church in Manhasset. Interment at Holy Rood Cemetery in Westbury. Memorial offerings may be made to ''The Bear Foundation,'' a not-for-profit organization established by the Johnston family in support of childrens' athletic programs. P.O. Box 138, Manhasset, New York 11030.

title: Next Stop: The Stanley Cup Finals
description: The battle between the Rangers and the Flyers to earn a place in the Stanley up finals begins tonight. JOE LAPOINTE

title: Tenant Groups Say End to Rent Caps Would Be a 'Disaster'
description: Three tenant advocacy groups have produced a 30-second commercial on rent regulations that will begin appearing on local stations today.

title: SENATORS REJECT DEMOCRATS' BILLS TO LIMIT ABORTION
description: After more than eight hours of impassioned debate, the Senate today rejected two Democratic proposals that would have rolled back abortion rights by outlawing a broad category of abortions except to save the life of the woman and, to varying degrees, protect her health.

title: Union Cites Productivity As an Issue In Police Pact
description: The Patrolmen's Benevolent Association is taking some jabs at Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani because the Mayor, who likes to boast that he has made city workers far more productive, does not want to negotiate with the police union about increased police productivity.

title: Executive Changes
description: EQUITABLE COS., New York, named Stanley Tulin chief financial officer. He will remain chief financial officer of Equitable's main insurance unit, the Equitable Life Assurance Society of the United States. He succeeds Jerry de St. Paer, who left to join J. P. Morgan & Co.

title: NATO Pact Clouds Fate of Arms Cuts, A Yeltsin Aide Says
description: The Russian Government's top national security official said today that NATO's decision to expand had hurt the chances that Parliament would approve the latest strategic arms reduction treaty negotiated with the United States.

title: Art in Review
description: 'Matisse and Teriade'

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about genetic mutations that increase the risks of breast and ovarian cancer misstated a study finding. Mutations in the BRCA2 gene are less likely than mutations in the BRCA1 gene to cause breast cancer in young women, not more likely.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ENO, LAWRENCE R.
description: ENO-Lawrence R., 83, on May 13, 1997. Husband of the late Ruth Smolen Eno, survived by his sister Rosalind Milman, his sons Richard and Robert, his daughters-in-law Janet Van Fleet and Candice Pong Eno, his grandchildren Jonas and Berrian Eno-Van Fleet and Jared and Daniel Eno, his brothers-inlaw Seymour and George Smolen, his nephews Stephen and Jeffrey Milman, and his niece Katheryn Havemann. He was co-author of ''The Basic Equities of the Palestine Problem'' (1947). Counsel to and former partner in the law firm of Rosenman & Colin, a founder and benefactor of the Museum of the Mountain Man in Pinedale, Wyoming. He strove gallantly for virtue through reason and never failed his conscience. May his memory be a blessing to all who knew him. Services Friday, 11:15AM, at ''The Riverside'', 76 St. and Amsterdam Avenue. Interment at Mt. Lebanon Cemetery. Reception following at the Carlyle Hotel. Visiting hours Thursday 7-9.

title: Study Seeks Standards For Protecting Children
description: Cars have been made a lot safer in the last 20 years, but policy makers here have been wincing lately when asked, ''Safer for whom?'' Cars are designed to protect the 50th-percentile male, the man who is exactly in the middle in height and weight.

title: A Wrongful Death
description: Palestinian leaders have a history of self-inflicted wounds in their long struggle for a national homeland: acts that hurt their political cause. Now, at a time when they have widespread sympathy for their position in an unraveling peace process, they have done it again.

title: British Fund Manager Says Profits Rose 22%
description: Mercury Asset Management, Britain's largest fund manager, said yesterday that its pretax profit for the year that ended on March 30 rose 22 percent, to $:171.3 million ($277.5 million), from $:140.4 million last year. Some analysts had expected Mercury to announce a special dividend for shareholders, which did not occur.

title: Telling It All To a Friend: Dear Diary . . .
description: ''MY journal is that of me which would else spill over and run to waste.'' This sentence, written by Henry David Thoreau in a marbled, word-swollen, sun-bleached notebook during the winter of 1841, goes a good way toward encapsulating one of the most rooted and mysterious of human impulses: the need to stop the spillage and make a record of the behavior of the self.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Prudential Insurance Is Fined $1.3 Million
description: The Prudential Insurance Company of America has been fined $1.3 million by a National Association of Securities Dealers panel for dismissing an employee who reported improper sales practices in 1993.

title: Tallying the Mayor's Race
description: Residents of Jersey City could learn as soon as this afternoon whether there will be a runoff election for mayor, if a judge grants a request for an expedited recount of Tuesday's results, officials said yesterday.

title: Pataki Weighs Portable Rent Protection for Some Elderly
description: Gov. George E. Pataki said tonight that he was considering a proposal to let elderly tenants take rent protections with them if they moved from regulated apartments into unregulated ones.

title: Relax, 'Seinfeld' Is Just a Boomer Lovefest
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MILLER, SADIE
description: MILLER-Sadie, on May 14, 1997. Beloved mother of Martin and Anita, Ira and Myrna, and Jerome and Lynn. Devoted sister of Ann Kramer and Samuel Norman. Cherished grandmother of Alan, Tracy, Scott, Robin, Cheryl, Lori, Debbie and Stacy, and greatgrandmother. Services Friday, 12 Noon, ''Schwartz Bros.-Jeffer Memorial Chapels,'' 76th Road and Queens Blvd. in Forest Hills.

title: High Set for Chicago Seat
description: A Chicago Board of Trade membership sold today for a record $825,001, surpassing the previous high price of $775,001, set last month. A full member has the right to trade any contract on the C.B.O.T. Buyers are now offering $825,000 for a seat, while sellers are seeking $900,000, the exchange said.

title: India Brewer Set to Enter U.S. Market
description: In a new consolidation of the troubled American microbrewery industry, India's largest beer maker and distributor plans to buy up small United States brewers and create a more efficient national network of local beer makers.

title: Smoky Haze Often Clouds Morality
description: HOW their leaders earn their keep is not usually high on the list of concerns for Jewish groups in New York City. They have more pressing issues to deal with, like the imperiled Middle East peace talks and the threat to Jewish life presented by high rates of intermarriage.

title: SUPPLIER OF AVIATION PARTS AGREES TO BUY A RIVAL
description: The AAR Corporation agreed yesterday to buy the closely held Cooper Aviation Industries for an undisclosed amount of stock. Cooper Aviation, based in Elk Grove Village, Ill., is one of the world's largest distributors of new aviation parts and accessories. It had sales of $45 million in the most recent 12-month period. AAR, based in Wood Dale, Ill., is a leading supplier of replacement parts, equipment and services for the aviation market. It had 1996 sales of $505 million. AAR expects the acquisition to close in early June.

title: Rogers's Stand-Up Pitching Is Welcome
description: If problem-solving is as important a part of pitching success as Joe Torre believes it is, Kenny Rogers took a significant step forward tonight in the eyes of the Yankee manager. He may also have solidified some friendships with his teammates.

title: Giuliani Sues Auto Insurers, Demanding Rate Reductions
description: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani stepped up his efforts yesterday to lower automobile insurance rates in New York City by filing a lawsuit against seven major insurers to obtain cheaper rates for residents.

title: Unabom Case: U.S. Is Seeking Death Sentence
description: Attorney General Janet Reno authorized prosecutors today to seek the death penalty for the suspect in the Unabom case despite arguments that executing him would be an injustice and devastating to the relatives who turned him in.

title: Last Chance
description: Here is a sampling of shows and exhibitions in New York City that are to close soon:

title: Conviction in Two Murders
description: A Newark man was convicted yesterday of murdering two men after arguing with them about a Halloween mask. The man, Oscar Caraballo, was arrested two weeks after Antonio Montiero and Jorge Silva Jr. were killed. Mr. Montiero was wearing a horror mask while hanging out on a Newark street corner with Mr. Silva last March.

title: Dangerous Times for a Jungle Prince
description: Perhaps in the mannerly days of Queen Victoria the sight of a child behaving like an animal could attract a paying audience. For better and worse, those days are probably long gone, but the premise of the wild child as a valuable curiosity underlies the feeble new juvenile adventure that goes by the jaw-breaking title ''Rudyard Kipling's 'The Second Jungle Book, Mowgli and Baloo.' ''

title: Corrections
description: Because of a production error, the main front-page article yesterday about the agreement between NATO and Russia was truncated in some editions. The last sentence, referring to leaders in Western and Central Europe, should have read, ''And they are clearly relieved that they have finally secured Russia's approval.''

title: Zairian Rebels Nearing Capital as Mobutu's Forces Flee
description: With Government troops fleeing their defensive positions, Zaire's rebel army pushed to the edge of this capital city tonight, setting off a panic among allies of President Mobutu Sese Seko who raced to get out of the country before being caught up in a widely feared bout of pillaging by soldiers.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STAHL, VINCENT JAMES
description: STAHL-Vincent James. Of Little Silver, NJ formerly of the Locust and Fairview sections of Middletown Township, NJ on May 14, 1997. Husband of Marie M. (nee McGarvey) Stahl. Father of Catherine S. Farber, Virginia S. Baldwin, Michael J., Thomas V., Lawrence E. and John J. Stahl. Grandfather of ten. Visitation Friday 2-4 and 7-9 PM at the John E. Day Funeral Home, 85 Riverside Ave., Red Bank, NJ. Funeral Mass Saturday 10AM at Holy Cross R.C. Church, Rumson, NJ. Interment to follow in Mount Olivet Cemetery, Middletown, NJ.

title: Lindros Carries a Mean Stick and Rangers See It Coming
description: Last time the Rangers faced Eric Lindros of the Philadelphia Flyers, Big 88 used his big stick to break the nose of Shane Churla, smack the cheek of Darren Langdon and split the lip of Ulf Samuelsson. These are three of the toughest Rangers, and these deeds cost Lindros a two-game suspension.

title: Small Lives Enlarged by a Heroic Air
description: It has been more than 50 years since the Library of Congress commissioned ''Appalachian Spring,'' a quintessentially American work by Martha Graham and Aaron Copland. Now the library has returned to dance commissioning, with Danny Buraczeski's ''Among These Cares,'' a piece that in its very different way is every bit as much a part of American culture.

title: Jones Learned Art at Father's Knee
description: The boy was quiet, a paternal gene passed on. When his father spoke, the boy listened intently, never looking away, never distracted. Especially when his father talked about baseball.

title: GATEWAY 2000 ANNOUNCES 2-FOR-1 STOCK SPLIT
description: Gateway 2000 Inc. said yesterday that it would split its stock 2 for 1 and move its listing to the New York Stock Exchange from the Nasdaq stock market. Gateway, based in North Sioux City, S.D., is a computer retailer with full-year revenue of $5 billion and profit of $250 million. The stock split will double the number of shares, to 154 million, but halve their value. The new shares are to be issued about June 16 to shareholders of record as of June 2. The company also said it would buy back up to 10 million shares of its stock. Gateway is to switch its stock listing to the New York Stock Exchange on Thursday. Gateway's stock rose $7.50 yesterday, to $68.875.

title: Art in Review
description: Ray Parker

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHONBERG, BESSIE
description: SCHONBERG-Bessie. Sarah Lawrence College mourns the death of its longtime colleague and Chairperson Emeritus of its Department of Dance. An extraoardinary teacher who taught dance and directed opera and lyric pieces at the college for 35 years, her students at the college included such diverse dancers and correographers as Lucinda Childs, Meredith Monk, Elizabeth Keen and Carolyn Adams. On behalf of generations of faculty and students, we salute and honor her memory and offer sympathy to her family. Alice Stone Ilchman President Barbara Kaplan, Dean Dean of the College Marilyn Katz Dean of Studies & Student Life

title: Hong Kong's Government-to-Be Gives a Bit on Rights Cutbacks
description: Reacting to an avalanche of local and international criticism of its plans to roll back a range of civil liberties for Hong Kong, the territory's government-in-waiting announced plans today to slightly relax its proposals to curb public demonstrations and control political groups.

title: It's Payback Time, Cosby Tells 7,000 Graduates at N.Y.U. Ceremony
