description: In a brisk, sun-dappled ceremony in Washington Square Park, marked by bagpipes and a brass band, Bill Cosby had an ultimatum yesterday for more than 7,000 New York University graduates:

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: OLSTEN CORP., Melville, N.Y., said it had acquired 70 percent of Sogica S.A. of Paris., to expand into the temporary-employment markets in France and Spain.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FRIEDEL, IRVING
description: FRIEDEL-Irving. Beloved husband, father, grandfather, great grandfather, uncle and great uncle. Survived by his wife of 65 years, Dora; loving children, Celia and Charles Reiner, Dr Walter and Dorothy Friedel; caring grandfather of the late Michael Reiner; and Eric, Rose and Donald Reiner, Evan, Erika, Jay, and Gregory Friedel; great grandfather to Daniel Reiner. Cherished by Bernard, Myra, Debbie, Mitchell, Monica, Nina, Dr. Evan Fox, Gary and Nina Cowen and all their children plus many other loving nieces and nephews of the Friedel family. Funeral service Sunday, May 18, 1:30 PM, Riverside Chapel, Mt Vernon N.Y. Interment Mt Hebron Cemetery. Shiva at the residence.

title: Art in Review
description: George Rickey

title: Flying Is a Pain That United Wants to Share
description: After more than three decades of peddling the ''friendly skies,'' United Airlines is changing course for a bold but risky alternative: acknowledging just how problematic the skies, the gates, the planes and even its employees can be for travelers, particularly frequent fliers.

title: Drug War Strategies
description: To the Editor:

title: Germany Opts Not to Pursue Iranian Leaders
description: German authorities backed away from further confrontation with Iran today, saying they would not pursue a high-level investigation of the country's top leaders, accused by a Berlin court last month of complicity in the killings in 1992 of four Kurdish exiles.

title: F.B.I. Expert Tells of Failure to Find McVeigh's Prints
description: A fingerprint examiner for the Federal Bureau of Investigation testified today, under-cross-examination, that no fingerprints of Timothy J. McVeigh were found in many of the places in which prosecutors say he prepared for the bombing of the Federal Building in Oklahoma City.

title: CHRONICLE
description: EUGENE LANG, the philanthropist, is giving a Sweet 16 party for a group he calls ''my children'' on Sunday at the Union Settlement House on East 104th Street. When they were sixth graders at Public School 121 in East Harlem 16 years ago, he made a pledge that changed their lives: if they completed high school, he would pay for college.

title: Budget Hammered Out
description: Two weeks of haggling over a budget agreement announced by the Republican leaders of Congress and the White House ended when the two sides agreed in writing to the details to make the deal work.

title: Prodigy Has Begun Review on Account
description: Prodigy Inc. in White Plains has begun a review on its account, which has been handled since August by Weiss, Whitten, Stagliano in New York. Billings were estimated at $8 million to $10 million.

title: Grow Up
description: To the Editor:

title: Seagram Wins Small Victory Over Viacom
description: The Seagram Company won a victory in its rancorous feud with Viacom yesterday when a Delaware judge ruled that Viacom had breached its contract with Seagram on the joint ownership of USA Network.

title: Accounts
description: * PSINet, Herndon, Va., to Arnold Communications, McLean, Va., for the commercial Internet service provider, whose account had been at Woolward & Partners, San Francisco. Billings were estimated at $3.5 million.

title: A Mouse Helps Explain What Makes Us Tick
description: ''Oh dear, oh dear, I shall be too late,'' the White Rabbit exclaimed as he examined his pocket watch.

title: Kmart Posts Profit, and Earnings Gain at Saks and Gap
description: The Kmart Corporation said yesterday that it swung to a net profit, and to a profit from continuing operations, in its fiscal first quarter as it reduced expenses and benefited from sales of new lines like its Martha Stewart bed and bath collection.

title: Accuser on Admiral's Medals Faces Scrutiny About His Own
description: A retired Army colonel turned journalist whose reporting on the validity of combat medals worn by the Navy's highest-ranking admiral was blamed for the admiral's suicide last year acknowledged today that he, too, claimed military decorations that he might not have earned.

title: Heat Takes a Hard Hit As Brown Gets Bounced
description: While the Knicks will try to cope with the loss of three players for Game 6, Pat Riley and the Miami Heat will have to play without P. J. Brown, its starting power forward and best defender. In the aftermath of Wednesday night's melee in Miami, Brown was suspended for two games and fined $10,000.

title: A Surprise Guilty Plea In '95 Rape and Slaying
description: In a case closely watched by many lesbians in Brooklyn, a man accused of killing a Boerum Hill, Brooklyn, woman and raping the woman's companion during a 1995 robbery made a surprise turnabout in a Brooklyn courtroom yesterday and pleaded guilty to the crimes days before his trial was to start.

title: Late Rally Sends the Dow Above 7,300-Point Level
description: Stocks surged yesterday, with the Dow Jones industrial average closing at more than 7,300 points for the first time.

title: Former Securities Executive Is Fined $5 Million
description: The regulatory arm of the National Association of Securities Dealers has levied a $5 million fine, one of the largest ever imposed on an individual, on the former chief executive of Duke & Company, a Manhattan brokerage firm, saying that he manipulated the stock of a bedding company in mid-1993.

title: Ferrer's Outta Here
description: Some politicians are deceptively tough. They come across as low-keyed, soft-spoken, amiable. But behind the mild facade is an intense and enduring drive, an endlessly competitive, even combative spirit, and an unshakable will. They would walk through fire to win an election, or, in the most admirable instances, to achieve something in which they truly believed.

title: $25 and Under
description: 'The I Love Stacey Show'

title: Oil Spill in Arthur Kill
description: A fuel line loading a barge in Carteret was left unattended for at least 18 minutes early yesterday, causing 40,000 gallons of diesel oil to overflow into the Arthur Kill, officials said.

title: On Stage, and Off
description: Striving for 'Raquel-ness'

title: Columbia Award Honors a Times Columnist
description: The Columbia University Graduate School of Journalism has awarded the 1997 Meyer Berger award for distinguished reporting to Joyce Purnick of The New York Times for her Metro Matters columns on city life, the school announced yesterday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CRANDELL, EDWIN HAWLEY
description: CRANDELL-Edwin Hawley, died on May 7th, 1997 at the age of 82. Devoted husband of the late Maxine Hothorn Crandell who died on November 30, 1996. Mr. Crandell was also a beloved uncle to Cathy Crandell Long of Summit, NJ, Laurie Roberts of NYC and many other nieces and nephews. Mr. Crandell was a longtime resident of Rye, New York. A retired partner of M.J. Meehan, he was a member of the New York Stock Exchange for more than fifty years. Mr. Crandell attended the Bronxville Schools and Westminster School and New York University. He was a Captain in the Army Engineering Corps during World War II. He was a member of the Apawamis Club, the American Yacht Club, the US Seniors and the Buttonwood Club. In addition to his nieces and nephews he is survived by 2 sisters-in-law, Mary Elizabeth Crandell of Ponte Verde, FL, and Cynthia Hothorn Williams of Aiken, SC. He will be sorely missed by all who knew him. In lieu of flowers donations may be made to the Alzheimer's Association - West chester Chapter, 785 Mamaroneck Avenue, White Plains, NY 10605 or the American Lung Association, 35 Orchard St., White Plains, NY 10605. A memorial service for both Maxine and Edwin Crandell will be held at 1 PM, on Sunday, May 18th, at Rye Presbyterian Church in Rye, New York. Any questions please call 914-967-0129.

title: INSIDE
description: Swiss Irritation Shows

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CARLTON, RICHARD E.
description: CARLTON-Richard E. of Bedford, New York, and New York City, in Bath, England, on May 11, 1997, age 57. Beloved husband of Elizabeth and loving father of Beth Carlton Camp and Catherine. He is also survived by his father, Edwin Carlton, Jr., his brothers, Stephen B. Carlton and Edwin Carlton, and his son-in-law, Lawton M. Camp. Funeral at 2:30 PM on Saturday, May 17, at St. Matthew's Church, Route 22, Bedford, NY, followed by a reception.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GROSS, LEO
description: GROSS-Leo. On May 10, 1997. Age 82. Survived by his wife, Norma; his children, Alan (Penni Harmon), Terry (Victoria Kelly) and Jody (Perk Larsen); and his grandchildren Mowgli, Crystal, Lily, Daniel and Elliot. Memorial service May 16 at 2 PM, at the Ethical Culture Society, 2 West 64 Street at CPW. In lieu of flowers, donations can be made to the Visiting Nurse Service of NY, Hospice Care, 1250 Broadway, New York 10001, or Hospice of the Florida Keys, 1319 William Street, Key West, Florida 33040.

title: Corrections
description: An entry in the Addenda listing of Business Day on Monday about Wendy Riches, chairwoman and chief executive of the New York office of Ogilvy & Mather Direct, misstated her new assignment. She was named to the additional position of chairwoman of Ogilvy & Mather Direct North America, not Ogilvy & Mather Direct Worldwide.

title: 5 Knicks Barred for Melee; 3 to Miss Game 6
description: In the most severe penalty ever imposed during the playoffs, the National Basketball Association suspended five Knicks, including Patrick Ewing, and one Miami Heat player today for their part in a fight at the end of a game Wednesday night.

title: Crowd in Chinatown Reveals an Unexploited Market for Metrocards
description: Ask a transit official why the Metrocard has been so unpopular and you will get a variety of reasons, ranging from the fact that the electronic fare card is not accepted by the entire system, to New Yorkers' deep affection for the token.

title: Ralph Wendell Burhoe, 85; Reconciled Science and Faith
description: Ralph Wendell Burhoe, an educator and writer esteemed for his interpretations of the relevance of religion in a technological society, died on May 8 at his home in the Hyde Park section of Chicago. He was 85.

title: Medieval Blasphemy With Modern Excess
description: Not even Ken Russell could have dreamed up the stew of grotesque religiosity, slavering voyeurism and sexual violence that is Peter Greenaway's 1993 movie, ''The Baby of Macon,'' the English director's only feature film not to have been distributed in the United States. This elaborate play within a play within a play, in which the audience and the actors become thoroughly confused, stars Julia Ormond and Ralph Fiennes, who are both shown in full frontal nudity in a blasphemous scene parodying the birth of Jesus in a manger.

title: Treasury Prices Edge Up Amid Mixed Economic Data
description: Treasury prices ended slightly higher yesterday as investors remained divided over whether the Federal Reserve would raise interest rates next week.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STEINBERG, ABRAHAM H.
description: STEINBERG-Abraham H. A very special man. Beloved husband of Jean. Died peacefully at home on May 15. Memorial service to be announced.

title: Palestinian Realities
description: To the Editor:

title: Woman of Many Themes and Styles
description: NEARING 80, June Wayne is still pursuing the highly productive career that began when she dropped out of high school at the age of 15. Her most renowned achievement was founding, in 1960, the Tamarind Lithography Workshop -- now the Tamarind Institute of the University of New Mexico -- credited with reviving fine art lithography in this country. But she's also a painter, printmaker, creator of tapestries and jungle fighter for the arts.

title: Murdoch Bids for Dodgers Simply to Bolster a Lineup
description: If Rupert Murdoch's Fox Group is able to acquire the Los Angeles Dodgers, the team would move from the hands of the O'Malley family, whose only business has been baseball, into the embrace of an aggressive conglomerate that wants to use the team to enhance its domestic and global media interests.

title: An Appeal to Longtime Democrats
description: This is a 30-second television advertisement from the gubernatorial campaign of State Senator James E. McGreevey, who is also the Mayor of Woodbridge Township.

title: NEW VIDEO RELEASES
description: Daylight

title: Russia Resumes Spending on Space Station
description: Russian money is once again flowing into the international space station program, and work has restarted on crucial components, United States space agency officials said today.

title: Even Among Refugees in Zaire, the Free Market Thrives
description: As far as Tarasisi Uwimana can see in any direction, there are hundreds of people around him whose bare feet are broken and pustuled from tramping unshod through the Zairian jungle for seven months.

title: Another Weapon in the Diet Wars
description: When it comes to diets, Americans are constantly searching for a quick fix. After all, it is a lot easier for many couch potatoes to pop a pill than to push away that greasy hamburger and french fries or spend 20 minutes on the treadmill.

title: Corrections
description: A listing in the Benefits column on Sunday for a picnic this Sunday for the Hudson Riverkeeper Fund, an environmental organization, misstated the site. The event, from 1 to 6 P.M., will be held at the Boscobel Restoration, on Route 9D in Garrison, N.Y., not at the organization's headquarters. Ticket information: (800) 217-4837.

title: Nathan Skolnik, 86, Enemy Of Wrongdoers in New York
description: Nathan Skolnik, long the bane of organized crime, bureaucratic inefficiency and official skulduggery in New York State, died on Saturday at New York University Hospital. He was 86 and had been deputy commissioner of the State Commission of Investigation from 1958 to 1975.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CUOMO, ROSA (NEE DEGENNARO)
description: CUOMO-Rosa (nee DeGennaro) on May 14, 1997 of North Bergen, NJ. Age 68. Beloved wife of John. Devoted mother of Elizabeth (Belli) Cuomo Zeller, Yolanda Cuomo and Anthony Cuomo. Devoted mother-in-law of Craig Zeller, Dr. Joseph McLaughlin and Lisa Bruckman. Dear sister of Padro Giuseppe DeGennaro, Anna Sorrentina, Vincenzo, Ciro and Antonio DeGennaro. Loving grandmother of Nicole Zeller and Gianni McLaughlin. Funeral from the A.K. Macagna Funeral Home, 495 Anderson Ave., Cliffside Park, NJ on Monday, May 19th, at 9:15AM, thence to St. Joseph of the Palisades R.C. Church, IHM Chapel, North Bergen, NJ where the Funeral Mass will be offered at 10:00 AM. Interment at Fairview Cemetery, Fairview, NJ. Visiting hours Saturday and Sunday 2-4 and 7-9 PM. In lieu of flowers, donations can be made in her memory to Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Hospital or the American Lung Association.

title: Diner's Journal
description: Early fans of John Schenk, who went from West Broadway to be chef at Monkey Bar, are delighted that he is once again cooking downtown. And he is doing it in a space that is easy to love: Clementine, the former One Fifth, still has the romance of an old luxury liner.

title: Two Americans Out of French Open
description: TODD MARTIN, who is ranked No. 14 in the world, and MALIVAI WASHINGTON, the 1997 Wimbledon runner-up, have withdrawn from the French Open because of injury, a tournament official said yesterday.

title: Why Fatten NBC?
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  O'HAGAN, WILLIAM J.
description: O'HAGAN-William J. On May 14, 1997. Loving husband of Theresa (nee Bamonte). Beloved father of William and Michael. Devoted grandfather to Lauren, Connor and Ross. Fond father-in-law of Theresa and Sylvia. Mass of Christian Burial Saturday 9:30 A.M. at St. Patrick R.C. Church. Visitation Thursday 7-9 P.M. and Friday 2-5 and 7-9 P.M. at Ridge Chapels, 405 91st Street, Brooklyn. Interment in Greenwood Cemetery.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KRIEBLE, ROBERT H.
description: KRIEBLE-Robert H. Scientist, entrepreneur, and a founder of the Loctite Corporation, died on May 8th at his home in Old Lyme, CT. He was 80 years old. He attended Phillips Academy, Andover; Haverford College; and received his Ph.D. in Chemistry from Johns Hopkins University where he was a member of Phi Beta Kappa and Signa Xi. He held various positions with the General Electric Co. He was a patentee in silicone chemistry there, and later head of commercial chemical development. Dr. Krieble with his father, Vernon, developed the first commercially successful anaerobic adhesive and founded the Loctite Corporation which later became a Fortune 500 company. Dr. Krieble always believed that private free enterprise was a better promoter of world peace and international cooperation than any governmental organization. At retirement, he founded the Krieble Institute, dedicated to promoting political and economic freedom within the still existing Soviet Empire. In 1989 he was declared an agent of influence and an enemy of the State by the Supreme Soviet for his success in encouraging democracy throughout the Empire, an act which he considered one of his greatest achievements. After the dissolution of the Soviet Empire, Krieble institute volunteers went on to teach the basics of political technology in eleven time zones contributing to the election of over 4,000 elected officials committed to democratic principles. Volunteers also taught basic business techniques and capitalist principles to hundreds of young entrepreneurs. Dr. Krieble was a trustee of Johns Hopkins University as well as the Heritage Foundation, a director of the Hoover Institution, Mont Pelerin Society, Free Congress Research and Education Foundation, Citizens Democracy Corp. (a Reagan Presidential Appointment), Jamestown Foundation, Empower America and many more. Among his many awards were the Commerical Development Association Honor Award, The Eagle Award in Public Affairs and The Chemical Industry Association's Entrepreneur of the Year award in 1979. He is survived by his wife, Nancy Brayton Krieble, his son Frederick B. Krieble, daughter Helen E. Krieble (Fusscas) and five grandchildren. A Memorial service will be held at the Trinity College Chapel in Hartford, CT on May 22nd at 2:p.m.

title: Two Palestinian Suspects Held in Death of Arab Real Estate Dealer
description: The Israeli police said today that they were holding a Palestinian man and woman on suspicion of involvement in the killing of an Arab real estate dealer accused of selling land to Jews.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  KLAPHOLTZ, ANNE
description: KLAPHOLTZ-Anne. March 22, 1902 to May 16, 1994. Remembered. Francene

title: Sony Increases Ad Agency Stake
description: The Sony Corporation said yesterday that it had gained control of a midsized Japanese advertising agency in a bid to tap into the rapidly growing market for ads on the Internet and satellite television.

title: Facing the Rubicon, Italy's Separatists Start to Test the Water
description: The eight men who stormed the bell tower in St. Mark's Square in Venice last week in support of secession for northern Italy appear simply to have put into action the program of the region's small but boisterous separatist movement.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PARKER, FRANCES
description: PARKER-Frances This 14th day of May saw the passing of Frances Parker, devoted wife of the late Irving Parker, loving mother of James Parker and the late Joan Cohen, adoring grandmother of Kevin and Bret, and loyal friend to so many whose lives she touched. Her strength, wisdom and wit will be missed by all who enjoyed her friendship and by the family who cherished her for all of her 82 years. James Parker Bret Parker Kevin Cohen

title: Move Toward Mostly Public Financing of Statewide Races Is Rejected
description: The State House of Representatives has narrowly rejected a measure that sought to virtually eliminate private contributions from statewide election campaigns, leaving many members of the Democratic majority stunned.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: TENNIS

title: Reflections of a Splintered Era
description: IN the hierarchy of art forms, drawing stands down a step or two. It is usually seen either as a rehearsal for grander things (painting, say) or as the visual version of thinking out loud (as in doodles or sketchbook entries).

title: Abstinence Education Will Now Get Its Due
description: To the Editor:

title: Kennedys Behaving Badly
description: On the floor of the House, Representative Joseph P. Kennedy 2d fought a losing battle this week against a bill that would reduce the number of poor tenants in public housing. Back in Boston, however, Mr. Kennedy's associates were embroiled in an even tougher fight to salvage his political career. Their sudden fear in recent weeks is that Mr. Kennedy, who plans to run for Governor of Massachusetts next year, could be the first member of his family to fail in a quest for public office.

title: $25 Million In Endowment To Be Sought By A.C.L.U.
description: The American Civil Liberties Union, the nation's oldest and largest civil liberties group, is preparing to announce on Sunday its first endowment campaign, with the goal of raising $25 million by 1999, $10 million of which has already been raised.

title: Bids by U.S. Cities Deferred Beyond 2008
description: New York and seven other American cities seeking to bid for the 2008 Summer Olympics essentially had their hopes delayed by four years yesterday. Leaders of the United States Olympic Committee recommended that any American bid be deferred until 2012, which disappointed New York organizers and left them uncertain about a future attempt to attract the Summer Games.

title: Few Volunteers Sighted
description: Despite calls for increased volunteerism during last month's Presidents' Summit for America's Future, a survey of nonprofit organizations in New York City has found that, so far at least, people are not responding.

title: Sprucing Up Old Areas
description: New Jersey is rich in history, but many of the neighborhoods that could attract tourism are dilapidated and not worth a detour. Yesterday, a bipartisan measure to provide tax incentives for enhancing the historic districts in the state's 100 poorest municipalities was introduced in the Assembly.

title: CHRONICLE
description: A. J. BENZA, the former gossip columnist for The Daily News, was arrested yesterday after he punched a taxicab driver in the face during a dispute in midtown Manhattan, the police said.

title: Home Video
description: Being First in Line

title: Corrections
description: An article on May 1 about differences among Orthodox Jews identified the speaker in a verse from the Bible, Joshua 5:13 incorrectly. The question, ''Are you on our side, or are you on the side of the adversary?'' was spoken by Joshua to an angel, not by an angel to Joshua.

title: In Rare Case, Doctor Faces Jail Time for Negligence
description: After four years of court battles, a New York doctor is to be jailed today as a criminal for his treatment of an ailing nursing home patient who later died.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HALPERN, ETHEL
description: HALPERN-Ethel. The Board of Governors and Members of High Ridge Country Club acknowledge with deep sorrow the passing of our esteemed member Ethel Halpern. We extend our deepest sympathy to her beloved husband Bernard and their beloved family.

title: No Headline
description: ''The settlement train is leaving. I want you on that train. But it is leaving anyway, and I will not allow it to wait for you.''

title: Pop-Up Pastries Growing As First Meal of the Day
description: No food defines the baby-boom generation like Pop-Tarts. When they came on the market in 1964, they were newfangled, convenient, sweet-tooth friendly and relatively cheap. Children grew up eating them long before the advent of the harried family with two working parents.

title: Rangers Try, but Can't Stop Lindros
description: The Rangers did everything they could to bait Eric Lindros out of his game tonight.

title: How to Turn a Love Story Into a Moral Metaphor
description: American Ballet Theater, following up on its opening night gala, has plunged into its repertory with a ''Swan Lake'' marathon at the Metropolitan Opera House.

title: Arrest, Touched With Drama, Ends Flight of Romance Writer
description: A romance writer's two-year flight from justice ended in a style befitting one of her novels this week, when law enforcement agents knocked on her door at a low-budget motel just outside Los Angeles. Rather than surrender without a struggle, Barbara Joslyn stabbed herself in the chest.

title: Rules Are Rules, for Good Reason
description: IT may not change the course of Western civilization, but yesterday's basketball ruling was one step for, well, mankind. As well as for the Heat.

title: FAMILY CHANNEL OWNER CONFIRMS MERGER TALKS
description: International Family Entertainment Inc. of Virginia Beach, Va., confirmed yesterday that it was in merger talks and said the family of its controlling holder, Pat Robertson, would be treated the same as other investors. People close to the transaction said on Wednesday that the News Corporation was in talks to buy International Family, which operates the cable Family Channel, for more than $1 billion. Mr. Robertson, the evangelist, and his son, Tim, control 100 percent of the company's class A shares, which retain most of the voting control. Earlier reports said that News Corporation was offering $26 to $28 a share for the widely traded class B shares and that the Robertsons were demanding as much as $40 a share for their shares. Shares of International Family rose $1.50, to $24.125.

title: PRESIDENT OF AETNA RESIGNS FOR PERSONAL REASONS
description: Aetna Inc. said its president, Joseph Sebastianelli, resigned, effective June 1, after serving a little more than two months in the job. Mr. Sebastianelli's responsibilities will be assumed by the chairman and chief executive, Ronald E. Compton. Mr. Sebastianelli, 50, was promoted to his position in March as part of the insurance company's efforts to build its health care business. Before becoming president, he served as co-president of Aetna U.S. Healthcare and executive vice president of the company. The executive cited personal reasons for his departure. A company spokeswoman said Mr. Sebastianelli would not remain with the company and had not disclosed his plans. Shares in Hartford-based Aetna fell $2.125, to $94.75.

title: Music in Review
description: A Pianist at Home in Works

title: Equity for New Jersey's Schools
description: For nearly three decades, New Jersey has struggled with school aid formulas to meet the State Constitution's requirement that quality education be available for rich and poor students alike. Small wonder, then, that the state's Supreme Court this week seemed to lose patience when it threw out yet another funding plan, this one assembled under the leadership of Gov. Christine Todd Whitman. In effect, the court told politicians that it meant what it had said earlier, that raising the quality of the schools serving the poorest students requires more money. The court's message should be heard in New Jersey and throughout the country.

title: Unemployment Rate Drops
description: Bringing good news for Gov. Christine Todd Whitman in an election season, New Jersey's unemployment rate continued to decline for the fourth month in a row, dropping to 5.2 percent in April, its lowest level since August 1990, officials said yesterday.

title: Big Sale Expected Of Italian Bank Shares
description: Cariplo S.p.A. said yesterday that it would announce on Monday the sale of shares to a partner in what is expected to be Italy's biggest banking acquisition. The company, Italy's largest savings bank, said its controlling foundation would evaluate offers of all or part of its 100 percent holding in the Cassa di Risparmio delle Province Lombarde, or Cariplo. Analysts estimate the bank is worth 9 trillion lire ($5.5 billion).

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GUTTERMAN, LEO
description: GUTTERMAN-Leo. Beloved husband of Lillian. Devoted father of Phyllis Raucher. Dear brother of Edith Gaines. Loving grandfather of Glenn, Abby and Robyn. Adored great grandfather of Dominick. Services Sunday, 12 Noon at ''Gutterman's'', 8000 Jericho Turnpike, Woodbury, L.I.

title: A Man of Opinion And of History
description: From across the political spectrum they came yesterday to pay tribute to a scholar who still wears his liberalism like a bright badge of honor.

title: House Panel, 31-7, Advances the Balanced-Budget Deal
description: Using the tax-cutting and spending deal struck by President Clinton and Republican leaders as a blueprint, the House Budget Committee took the first legislative step today toward enactment of a balanced-budget bill.

title: Once Held in Esteem, Riley Is Now Reviled
description: The most hated man in New York appeared moments before the starting lineups were announced. He came through the tunnel, a pair of security guards on both his arms, and stepped out onto the Madison Square Garden court last night. A few scattered shouts gave way to a swelling of boos.

title: An Anatomy Of Autocracy: Mobutu's Era
description: In more than three decades at the center of his country's political stage, Mobutu Seso Seke was nothing if not an extraordinary survivor. But his tenacity and resourcefulness finally failed him today as he stealthily left his capital, a defeated man.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: GOLF

title: Charges Possible in Spill
description: The tankerman who is being blamed for a spill that sent 40,000 gallons of diesel fuel into the Arthur Kill was dismissed yesterday and may face criminal charges, officials said. The tankerman, Donald D. Lamb, had alcohol on his breath when he was questioned after the incident at the GATX Marine Terminal in Carteret, a state police official said. He will be questioned by a state grand jury on Monday, said Sgt. Daniel Cosgrove, a state police spokesman.

title: Ex-Union Business Agent Will Serve a Prison Term
description: After a Manhattan judge took the unusual step of overturning his previous plea bargain, a former union business agent pleaded guilty to accepting a bribe and agreed to serve a year in prison, a spokesman for the Manhattan District Attorney's office said yesterday.

title: A Painful Encounter: Rangers Lose Flatley and Game 1
description: Since midway through the 1994 post-season, the Rangers have habitually lost the first game of every Stanley Cup playoff series. They did it again tonight, for the ninth consecutive time, when they fell by 3-1 to the Philadelphia Flyers in the opener of the Eastern Conference finals.

title: Milbury Is the Islanders' Man, Period
description: Despite his denials, speculation persisted that General Manager MIKE MILBURY was thinking about leaving the Islanders. So JOHN SPANO, the team's owner, issued a statement yesterday to try to end any doubts about Milbury. ''Mike Milbury -- and nobody else -- will be in charge of the hockey operations for the New York Islanders,'' Spano said. ''Therefore, I will refuse any requests from N.H.L. teams to talk to Mike regarding employment. Mike is entirely in agreement and will remain our general manager.''

title: Saadallah Wannous, 56, Arab Playwright
description: Saadallah Wannous, whose courageously caustic plays and social criticism about the Arabs' political decline made him one of the Arab world's leading playwrights, died on Thursday in Damascus, Syria. He was 56.

title: If the Plaque Doesn't Fit
description: To the Editor:

title: Bomber Pilot Is Denied a Delay of Her Trial
description: Four days before the nation's first female B-52 pilot is to be court-martialed on adultery and other charges, her lawyer asked the Air Force today to delay the trial for two weeks. But the judge in the case swiftly denied the request.

title: Coffee, Cups and Costs
description: To the Editor:

title: CORPORATE GIFTS HELP GAIN ACCESS TO U.S. GOVERNORS
description: In the past several years, a select group of the nation's biggest corporations have given millions of dollars to the National Governors' Association and an affiliated research arm. In return for their tax-deductible contributions, the corporations' lobbyists have gained unusual access to the governors' policy-making apparatus.

title: ENVIRODYNE HOLDERS REJECT ZAPATA NOMINEES TO BOARD
description: Shareholders of Envirodyne Industries elected the company's slate of directors and rejected three nominees from the Zapata Corporation, which is trying to gain control of Envirodyne. Zapata wanted its directors on the board so it could eliminate anti-takeover provisions that make it too expensive to acquire Envirodyne, a maker of food packaging products. The Houston-based Zapata is Envirodyne's largest shareholder, with 40 percent of the shares outstanding.

title: Basketball's State of War
description: The National Basketball Association and its players' union spent yesterday haggling over whether the four suspended New York Knicks were in violation of the letter or the spirit of the league rules against fighting. For the players' union, however, the argument was fruitless, because the spirit is included in the letter. The rule doesn't say the players will be suspended for fighting; it says in no uncertain terms that players will be suspended for one game and fined up to $20,000 for leaving the vicinity of the bench during an altercation.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Starts of Housing Rise, But Weakness Is Seen

title: Making a Virtue of Virtuosity
description: It must be a constant temptation for a pianist as prodigiously gifted as the young Russian Yevgeny Kissin to flaunt those gifts. In any case, Mr. Kissin did just that at his recital on Tuesday evening at Carnegie Hall, in effect flexing his biceps and kicking sand in the face of every other virtuoso alive.

title: Blair Makes Offer To Renew Contact With I.R.A. Wing
description: In a speedy change in London's policy toward Northern Ireland, the new Prime Minister of Britain, Tony Blair, said today that he would allow British officials to resume contact with Sinn Fein, the political wing of the Irish Republican Army.

title: Children and Separation
description: To the Editor:

title: For Market, a Rate Rise Now May Be Better Than None
description: Will the Fed just wait?

title: Murdoch Gets Some Bad News In Dispute With Time Warner
description: Rupert Murdoch lost a round in his bitter feud with Time Warner yesterday when a Federal judge dismissed two claims by Mr. Murdoch's News Corporation that Time Warner had fraudulently backed out of a deal to carry the Fox News Channel on its New York City cable system.

title: U.S. Acted to Provoke War With Mexico
description: To the Editor:

title: I2 TECHNOLOGIES IS ADDING TWO SOFTWARE CONCERNS
description: I2 Technologies Inc., a maker of industrial planning software, said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire two software companies for a total of $201 million in stock. Under the separate agreements, I2 will pay $53.2 million, or 1.4 million shares, for the Optimax Systems Corporation in Cambridge, Mass., and $148.2 million, or 3.9 million shares, for the privately held Think Systems Corporation in Parsippany, N.J. I2 shares rose $1.75 yesterday, to $39.75, in Nasdaq trading. I2, of Irving, Tex., makes software to help manufacturers keep track of production, orders and problems like supply interruption.

title: Woods, Fiery if Not on Fire, Shares Lead With Rinker
description: On the 16th hole today, with the record for the low round in the GTE Byron Nelson Classic in reach, Tiger Woods displayed some of the competitive meanness that has impressed the tournament's namesake.

title: Catherine McLeod; Film Actress Was 75
description: Catherine McLeod, an actress whose headache-induced outburst -- ''Mother, please! I'd rather do it myself!'' -- became a national catch phrase in the early 1960's, died on Sunday at the Encino-Tarzana Medical Center in Encino, Calif. She was 75 and lived in nearby Sherman Oaks.

title: Entrenched Problems in the Emerging Peruvian Market
description: Bruce Heafitz made and lost a $50 million fortune in the oil business in the United States in the 1980's and then regained much of it, only to sink millions into an ill-fated venture to look for sunken ships, ancient Egyptian tombs and other lost treasures.

title: When Standardized Tests Cheat Students
description: To the Editor:

title: Fugitive Mexican Prosecutor Is Arrested in Spain
description: Authorities in Spain have arrested the senior official who was prosecuting Mexico's most sensitive murder and corruption cases until his dismissal and disappearance after charges of rigging evidence, Mexico's Government announced today.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  LUNDIN, DORIS.
description: LUNDIN-Doris. Gentle woman, graceful soul. Two years-time passes but your memory never will. Your family

title: For Knicks' Nine Men, It's Mission Impossible
description: The events of the past three days have hit the Knicks like thunderbolts. First the melee in Miami. Then the suspensions. Then last night's loss. And it remains to be seen if the Knicks can weather the storm.

title: Army's Adultery Rule Is Don't Get Caught
description: The big man with brush-bristle hair the telltale trait of a soldier -- seemed neither ashamed, nor especially proud of himself, as he emerged from a private room of the Casa Colorada here.

title: Giuliani Speech Is Cut
description: Trying to avoid the appearance of politics, a tenants' group has asked Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani not to speak to a large rent control rally in Albany next week.

title: Cheevy Pumping Gas
description: It's pumping gasoline that brings out the Miniver Cheevy in me. Cheevy, born too late to walk in Thebes and Camelot or know the medieval grace of iron clothing, yearned for an antiquity ridiculously remote.

title: It's Still Too Early to Judge School Vouchers
description: To the Editor:

title: U.S. Mediator Fails to Break An Impasse In the Mideast
description: An American envoy's attempt to revive deadlocked talks between Israel and the Palestinians ended today with no signs of progress, and both sides declared that they were no closer to resuming negotiations.

title: In Alex Kelly's New Trial, Defense Accuses Accuser
description: Accusing her of trying to fill in holes in her story, Alex Kelly's lawyer today continued his aggressive cross-examination of the young woman who accused Mr. Kelly of raping her 11 years ago.

title: James M. Fox, 59, Is Dead; Led the F.B.I. in Bomb Case
description: James M. Fox, who ran the New York office of the F.B.I. when it solved the World Trade Center bombing and built the case that finally sent John Gotti to prison, died yesterday morning at The Mount Sinai Medical Center. He was 59 and a resident of Manhattan.

title: Rookie Stifles Yankees As Rangers Get to Wells
description: Once again, the Yankees did not see John Wetteland.

title: A Clash of Manipulators Vying Over the Manipulatees
description: Gabriel Byrne is deliciously wicked as a megalomaniac media czar: handsome, smoothly articulate, with just enough crassness accidentally seeping through so the world knows he's a sleaze. ''My only interests,'' this owner of newspapers, book publishers and a television network announces to the public, ''are in gaining your attention, so that I might more easily redirect it.'' Mr. Byrne's Lionel Powers is the most shrewdly devised character in ''Weapons of Mass Distraction,'' a pitch-black satire written by Larry Gelbart. Powers is realistic enough to make Rupert Murdoch squirm, yet exaggerated enough so he can't sue.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  RACH, DAVID.
description: RACH-David. 4/2/64-5/17/87. Many waters cannot quench love, neither can floods drown it. Love is stronger than death. Your Family

title: Seat on Big Board Is Sold
description: A seat on the New York Stock Exchange sold yesterday for $1.2 million, a decrease of $85,000 from the previous sale on Dec. 30. Owning one of the 1,366 stock exchange seats is the admission ticket to trading. Membership gives holders the right to trade stocks and vote at exchange meetings. The highest price for a Big Board seat was $1.45 million on May 7, 1996. The exchange does not release the names of buyers or sellers.

title: Bond Prices Off as Traders Warily Await Fed Meeting
description: With the Federal Reserve's meeting on interest rates drawing near, bond market participants became more sensitive to economic data yesterday and sold off after reports showed strength in housing and a rise in consumer sentiment.

title: A Chance at Real Money
description: A paper plant in Milford may get a new business opportunity as a result of a measure passed Thursday by the United States House of Representatives: making the paper for national currency.

title: Corrections
description: An article last Saturday about declining belief in the Devil as a physical entity misidentified the author of the book ''The Death of Satan'' (Farrar, Straus & Giroux, 1995). He is Andrew Delbanco.

title: N.B.A. Fines Willis and Kemp
description: The National Basketball Association decided yesterday to take Seattle forward SHAWN KEMP's money, not his uniform. It was Kemp who threw an open-handed slap at KEVIN WILLIS on Thursday night, in retaliation for an elbow. The Houston Rockets were calling for Kemp's suspension, but the N.B.A. fined Willis $10,000 and Kemp $5,000, and each will be allowed to play today in Game 7 of the Western Conference semifinals in Houston.

title: Congress Starts Trek To Balanced Budget
description: Working from the deal reached by the White House and Republican Congressional leaders, the House Budget Committee approved a resolution to serve as a guide for action on tax cuts and spending.

title: Effort to Delay Four Bans Is Rejected
description: The Federal judge, in his sophomore season on the bench, seemed to be in a four-corner stall.

title: The Danes Call It Fresh Air
description: Last January I was home in Denmark with my American husband. As we walked through the wintry streets of Copenhagen with our 1-month-old son, we saw baby carriages, with babies in them, parked on the city's sidewalks. Inside the local cafes, mothers chatted with their friends.

title: HOUSTON INDUSTRIES IN DEAL FOR STAKE IN UTILITY
description: Houston Industries Energy Inc., a unit of Houston Industries, and its partner, Electricidad de Caracas, said yesterday that they would acquire a majority interest in Empresa de Energia del Pacifico S.A. (EPSA) of Colombia for $498 million. The Hoston Industries Energy-Electricidad de Caracas consortium won the right to acquire a 56 percent interest in EPSA and will take over operations on June 5. The sale, which includes transmission and distribution as well as 807 megawatts of hydroelectric generation, is the first privatization of an integrated utility in Colombia. Houston Industries has electric utility operations in the United States and also will have natural gas distribution, pipeline and wholesale gas and electricity trading operations upon completion of its pending merger with the Noram Energy Corporation later this year. Electricidad de Caracas serves more than one million customers.

title: Corrections
description: A news analysis article on Sunday about Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's $12 million plan to help immigrants become citizens misidentified a group that he addressed last week on the subject of immigration. It was the American Jewish Committee, not the American Jewish Congress.

title: Case of Jitters Trims the Dow By 138 Points
description: Oh, what a jittery, volatile market.

title: Pataki Assails White House On Workfare
description: Gov. George E. Pataki, whose state has the largest workfare program in the country, yesterday assailed the new White House policy requiring states to use minimum wage laws when calculating the hours that welfare recipients must work for their monthly benefits.

title: INSIDE METRO
description: JAIL TIME FOR DOCTOR -- A New York doctor will go to jail today after being convicted of criminal negligence in his treatment of a nursing home patient. Page 23

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  O'HARA, MARY W.
description: O'HARA-Mary W., 58, on May 15, 1997. After a difficult five-year battle with cancer. Died at peace at her home in Bronxville, New York. Director of Special Events at The College of New Rochelle. Educated at College of New Rochelle and Harvard University. Wife of Charles Schramm (predeceased), daughter of Eileen O'Hara of Riverdale, New York and Thomas (predeceased), sister of Thomas and Diane O'Hara, and loving aunt of Sean and Eileen O'Hara. In lieu of flowers, donations can be made to Jansen Memorial Hospice, 69 Main Street, Tuckahoe, New York 10707. Visitation will be at the Fred H. McGrath & Son Funeral Home, Cedar and Kraft Avenues, Bronxville, New York on Sunday, May 18, from 2-4, 7-9 P.M. Mass of Christian Burial celebrated on Monday at St. Joseph's Church, Bronxville at 10 A.M.

title: SBC COMMUNICATIONS IN SETBACK ON SERVICE
description: In a setback to SBC Communications Inc.'s quest to provide long-distance service to its own customers in Oklahoma, the Justice Department recommended yesterday that Federal regulators reject the application. In a filing to the Federal Communications Commission, the department's antitrust division said the request was premature because the company had not taken steps to open its local phone market to competition. The F.C.C. will ultimately decide SBC's request, but the law requires the commission to give the Justice Department's opinion substantial weight. The F.C.C. must act by July 10. The San Antonio-based company owns Southwestern Bell, which provides local phone service to nearly 1.6 million people in Oklahoma.

title: Stakes of Game 7 Compel Mourning to Battle Ewing
description: Alonzo Mourning's respect for Patrick Ewing, his friend and onetime mentor at Georgetown University, has never wavered during their professional careers. But he will have to put aside that admiration tomorrow at Miami Arena.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  CAMHI, STEPHEN B.
description: CAMHI-Stephen B. 5/17/47-6/8/90. We miss you and love you now and forever. Randi, Jason, Joshua and Melissa

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DANIEL, ELSA M.
description: DANIEL-Elsa M. May 15, 1997. Wife of the late Simon Daniel. Mother of Allan and his wife Kendra. Grandmother of Peter, Anthony and Nora. She was a past President of the Eisman Day Nursery and a Founder of SCAN and an active member of Congregation Emanu-El, NYC. Service Monday, May 19, 2 PM, at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st St. In lieu of flowers contributions may be made to SCAN or the Eisman Day Nursery.

title: Music in Review
description: Complementary Trumpeters, One 23 and the Other 92

title: A Bogey Band to Scare Parents With
description: Fans lined up around the block at Tower Records downtown on a Saturday morning last month to buy tickets to Ozzfest '97, a hard-rock extravaganza at Giants Stadium featuring a reunion of Black Sabbath and performances by Marilyn Manson and Type O Negative.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: Baseball

title: Waiting For Lefty
description: It was probably over the minute Jane Fonda married Ted Turner. But liberalism has continued its free fall out of fashion.

title: 'Megan' Juror Is Dismissed Over Gesture
description: The judge dismissed a juror in the Megan Kanka murder case today for making an exultant gesture as prosecutors presented one of their strongest items of forensic evidence.

title: Weakened Knicks Can't Finish Heat
description: The Knicks came into last night's game at Madison Square Garden undermanned and undersized, and -- less than a week after they seemed to have sewn up their playoff series with the Miami Heat -- they were clearly the underdogs.

title: Across the EU, Amazement At Bonn Plan To Bend Books
description: FRANKFURT  Finance Minister Theo Waigel, undaunted by critics who accuse him of engaging in the sort of budgetary sleight-of-hand that he has long scorned, said Friday that a revaluation of German gold and foreign-currency reserves would help the nation meet both of the most critical budget criteria for a European monetary union.

title: News Vendors Face Prospect Of Last Stand
description: ADAM PETRELLA'S newsstand sits on the northwest corner of Canal Street and the Bowery. He calls it Petrella's Point and gussies it up with bright red paint and drawings of Bruce Lee, Marilyn Monroe and the Shroud of Turin.

title: Responsible Drinking
description: To the Editor:

title: Starts of Housing Up 2.6%, But Key Category Is Weak
description: Construction of single-family houses was weak last month, providing another sign of economic slowing. But a survey found that consumer confidence remained strong.

title: Corrections
description: A front-page article on Wednesday about legislation on educating disabled children misstated the judicial history of the right of the disabled to public education. That right was established in Federal District Court decisions in 1971 and 1972. The decisions were not appealed.

title: Hard Lives, Affirmed
description: To the Editor:

title: The Rockland Legislature Is Ruled Unconstitutional
description: A Federal judge declared the 21-member Legislature of Rockland County unconstitutional yesterday, finding that its unusual system of apportioning a different number of legislators to each of the county's five towns violated the principle of one person one vote.

title: Cheating the Child to Save the 'System'
description: Maybe next they'll build jagged fences. Bring in fierce dogs. Anything to keep out those 8-year-olds whose offense is wanting to learn the three R's in a safe school, one that is outside the city where they live.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROTHENBERG, RICHARD, DR.
description: ROTHENBERG-Richard, Dr. On May 15, 1997. The entire Stuyvesant Family - students, staff, administration, alumni and parents, deeply mourn the sudden and untimely loss of their dear friend, teacher and colleague, Richard Rothenberg, Assistant Principal, Mathematics. A graduate, Class of 1963, Dr. Rothenberg epitomized the best of the academic and scholarly tradition of Stuyvesant High School. This kind and compassionate, gentle man, will be sorely missed for the strength of his character and his contributions to this Institution. His memory will live on in the hearts of his thousands of devoted students. We extend our heartfelt condolences to his wife, Rita, his children, Terri, Fran, and Jonathan, and his entire family. Stuyvesant High School Family

title: Daschle Considers Voting for Ban on Late-Term Abortion
description: Senator Tom Daschle of South Dakota, the Democratic leader, said today that he was considering changing his position from last year and voting for a ban on what abortion opponents call partial-birth abortion.

title: Mystery Mother and Son Are Sent to New Hospital
description: The mother and son from Bushwick, Brooklyn, who arrived in a Newark hospital on Sunday without identification or the apparent ability to speak were transferred yesterday by New York City officials to Woodhull Medical Center, a municipal hospital in Williamsburg, Brooklyn.

title: Prosecutor Drops Charges Against John Gotti Jr.
description: The Brooklyn District Attorney dropped charges yesterday against John Gotti Jr., the son of the jailed mob boss, stemming from an April 10 incident in which Mr. Gotti and a friend were accused of tailing two undercover police officers.

title: Robert Campbell, 79, Ex-Head of Newsweek
description: Robert D. Campbell, a former chairman, publisher and president of Newsweek magazine, died of complications from Parkinson's disease on Monday in Rancho Santa Fe, Calif., his son, William, said. He was 79.

title: Iranian Film Makes It Past Censors to Cannes
description: The Iranian film maker Abbas Kiarostami received a standing ovation here today simply for showing up. His film ''The Taste of Cherries'' had narrowly escaped censorship in Iran and was granted permission to be entered in competition here only at the last minute. And Mr. Kiarostami is a great favorite on the festival circuit. Thus, as demonstrated by a thunderous hand before the film began, ''The Taste of Cherries'' arrived here with extra baggage.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  KERNS, ERNEST G.
description: KERNS-Ernest G. It's been three years since you left us. You remain always in our daily thoughts. We miss you. Mom, Dad, Family

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GERTZ, DIANA RADIN
description: GERTZ-Diana Radin. Died May 15, 1997. Beloved wife of the late Louis Simon Gertz. Last survivor of the five siblings who, together with their father Benjamin, founded the Gertz Department Stores of Long Island. Loving mother of Joan Gertz Wilner and Benjamin Ira Gertz and mother-in-law of Dr. Howard I. Wilner and Kathryn Rose Gertz. Adoring grandmother of Dr. Scott Lawrence Wilner, Stephanie Jeanne-Lee Gertz and Margaret Ellen Gertz. Services at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81 St, Sunday 10AM. In lieu of flowers, contributions in her momory may be made to the Alzheimer's Disease and Related Disorders Association, 420 Lexington Avenue, New York, NY 10170.

title: Clinton Regrets 'Clearly Racist' U.S. Study
description: A quarter of a century after the infamous Tuskegee experiment came to an end, President Clinton, his voice cracking with emotion, apologized today to the few remaining survivors and to relatives of 399 black men who for 40 years were left untreated for syphilis as part of the Federal Government's study.

title: Treasury Counsel Under Nixon Is Charged in Investment Scheme
description: Paul W. Eggers, a Texas lawyer who served as General Counsel at the Treasury Department during the Nixon Administration, has been arrested and accused of selling $8 million worth of fake investments, the Justice Department announced yesterday.

title: Corrections
description: An article and a front-page picture caption on Wednesday about the installation of new subway turnstiles to accept the Metrocard included incorrect information from the Transit Authority about the status of the change. Some of the old turnstiles are still in use at the Woodside station on the No. 7 line in Queens; the turnstiles removed on Tuesday from the Myrtle Avenue station in Brooklyn were not the last of the old type.

title: Deep Blue and Freedom
description: To the Editor:

title: Bridge
description: The Cavendish Club in Manhattan, home to many world-famous players, died six years ago, but the name lived on in the Cavendish Pairs and Cavendish Teams. This year these migrated to Las Vegas, Nev., where they were played last weekend. The Calcutta pool in the pairs amounted to $1,288,500, by far the biggest in the history of bridge.

title: Bruno Seeks Limit on Inheriting Protections
description: The Senate majority leader, Joseph L. Bruno, said today that he could support allowing immediate family members to inherit rent-regulated apartments, but only for one generation, arguing that granting so-called succession rights to additional generations would extend the current rent system ''for the next two centuries.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEVENTHAL, MAE (STONER)
description: LEVENTHAL-Mae (Stoner). On Thursday, May 15, 1997 at the age of 87. Beloved mother of Lawrence and Richard Stoner. Loving stepmother of Howard and Gerald Leventhal. Cherished grandmother. Graveside services 1 PM, Sunday, Cedar Park Cemetery, Paramus, NJ. Information, Sherman's Flatbush Memorial Chapel, 1-888-377-7303.

title: Mentally Ill Don't Need Lessons on 'Real Work'
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TURNER, JACOB
description: TURNER-Jacob. Died in his sleep May 16, 1997. Loving father of Liebert and Pilar. Devoted grandfather of Peter, Michael, Robert, and Neil. Private Services.

title: Beliefs
description: Catholic annulment policy has long attracted the attention of cynics. And it is doing so again with the recent publication of ''Shattered Lives,'' Sheila Rauch Kennedy's attack on the Roman Catholic procedures that have allowed her former husband, Representative Joseph P. Kennedy 2d of Massachusetts, to seek an annulment of their 1979 marriage.

title: A Capital At Ease, Awaiting The Rebels
description: The President has fled, the rebels are within a few miles of the city and there is a dusk to dawn curfew, yet today, as throughout the week, this city of five million people has exhibited a remarkable level of normality, going about life with its usual bustling, cacophonous vibrancy.

title: U.S. SURGICAL SHARES SLIDE AFTER PATENT CASE RULING
description: Shares of the U.S. Surgical Corporation fell 7 percent yesterday after the company disclosed a jury ruled against it in a patent case in late April. A Federal District Court jury in Alexandria, Va., ruled on April 29 that U.S. Surgical had infringed patents held by the Applied Medical Resources Corporation. The judge is expected to enter a final judgment and set damages next week, said a U.S. Surgical spokesman. U.S. Surgical will appeal the ruling, he said. The company's shares fell $2.50, to $30.50, their lowest since July. Applied Medical sued U.S. Surgical over the company's trocar products, hollow tubes used for minimally invasive surgery.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FOX, JAMES M.
description: FOX-James M. In loving memory of a friend, patriot and fellow founding board member. With deepest sympathies to his family. The Board of the Federal Law Enforcement Foundation, Inc.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: PRICE REIT INC., San Diego, a real estate investment trust, announced the acquisition of the Smoketown Stations Center, a shopping center in Woodbridge, Va., for about $46.5 million.

title: Music in Review
description: Playing Popular Works

title: Payment in Harassment Case
description: The state has agreed to pay $210,000 to settle a sexual harassment suit against a director in the State Office of Legislative Services, according to court papers filed yesterday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SOLAR, JOSEPH J.
description: SOLAR-Joseph J., 84, of Toms River, NJ on May 12, 1997 at Green Acres Manor, Toms River, NJ. He was a labor leader in New York State & City with the International Association of Machinists and Aerospace Workers, AFLCIO. He joined the IAM, Lodge #

title: INSIDE
description: De Klerk Breaks With Panel

title: SIMON DEBARTOLO IN DEAL WITH CHELSEA REALTY
description: Simon DeBartolo Group Inc. and Chelsea GCA Realty Inc. said yesterday that they had formed a joint venture to buy and develop factory outlet centers. Each company has a 50 percent stake in the venture. Simon DeBartolo, the largest United States shopping mall developer, will invest $50 million in Chelsea by purchasing 1.41 million of its shares for $35.50 each. Shares of Chelsea, based in Roseland, N.J., were up 37.5 cents, to $34.875. Stock of the Indianapolis-based Simon DeBartolo rose 37.5 cents, to $29.875. Chelsea owns 19 outlet centers.

title: Rangers Back in the Hole
description: In a familiar start, the Rangers lost, 3-1, to Philadelphia last night in Game 1 of the Eastern Conference finals. SportsSaturday, page 27.

title: Democrats Give Health Benefits To Gay Couples
description: Following in the footsteps of many top American companies, the Democratic National Committee said today that it would offer same-sex partners the same health benefits available to spouses of its employees.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JOSEFFBERG, SYLVIA
description: JOSEFFBERG-Sylvia. Sister of Albert Joseffberg and Martha Schecter. Beloved aunt of five nephews and one niece; grandaunt of eight. Service Sunday, May 18, 1:45 PM at Sinai Chapels, 162-05 Horace Harding Expressway, Fresh Meadows, NY.

title: An African Tyrant Departs
description: President Mobutu Sese Seko no doubt fled Kinshasa yesterday to save his life and his fortune rather than to spare Zaire a final spasm of violence as rebel forces closed in on the capital. Anything else would have been out of character for a man who misruled his country for nearly 32 years, impoverishing his people as he skimmed millions, perhaps billions of dollars from the Government to enrich himself.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLDMAN, MURIEL F.
description: GOLDMAN-Muriel F. ''A woman of beauty and grace.'' Beloved wife of David. Devoted mother of William and Dr. Irene Goldman. Dear sister of Richard Friedman. Funeral services Sunday at noon at Gutterman-Musicant, Hackensack. Contributions to Wurzweiler School of Social Work of Yeshiva University, NYC, appreciated.

title: Walker's Home Run Seals Loss For Mets
description: Larry Walker, right fielder for the Colorado Rockies and the National League's top home-run hitter, is strong, as Paul Bunyan was strong. Give him a pitch over the middle of the plate, and he can drive it a very long way.

title: Boys and Girls of Old '27
description: Pass by the Shore Diner this afternoon and you may hear the Atlantic City High School fight song coming from the back room. That will be a sign that the Class of 1927 is holding its 70th reunion.

title: Violations of the Heart
description: This has got to be one of the saddest ways for a promising military career to crash in flames. Lieut. Kelly Flinn, the first woman to become a B-52 bomber pilot, a virtual recruiting poster for women in the military, faces a court-martial that could lead to dismissal and a possible jail term on charges related to a love affair gone sour. At this point her violations of military rules seem too formidable for the Air Force to ignore, even when those rules are admittedly antiquated. She has, unfortunately, lied to an official investigation and disobeyed a direct order while trying to hide her affair with a married civilian, which is itself the crime of adultery under military law. But the bigger crime here is that this case was allowed to spiral out of control when some managerial common sense and discreet advice might have quietly resolved it.

title: Education Law Center Never Lost Its Focus in 27 Years
description: Over the last 27 years, as the successive rulings by the New Jersey Supreme Court in the landmark Abbott v. Burke school financing case added Roman numerals to its name like some parade of ''Rocky'' movie sequels, there have been two constants: state resistance to change and the Education Law Center.

title: Now, Now, Just Swallow the Medicine, Please
description: If there is still valor in the music world, it survives in men like Petr Kotik. Mr. Kotik crowded his Orchestra of the S.E.M. Ensemble into Merkin Concert Hall on Thursday night and played the music he thought his audience should be hearing. Some of these pieces worked better than others. Most had a distinguishable character of their own. All would have made classical-music marketing departments blanch.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: De Klerk Pulls Party Out of Inquiry Into Apartheid Era
description: Former President F. W. de Klerk today ended his National Party's cooperation with South Africa's Truth and Reconciliation Commission, in a break that could make it far more difficult for the commission to accomplish its goal of healing deep divisions over past atrocities.

title: U.S. Influence Over Zaire Now Appears to Be Limited
description: With the downfall of Mobutu Sese Seko whom it helped become President of Zaire three decades ago, then finally turned against -- the United States no longer need apologize for a corrupt and dictatorial client whom it was at first unwilling and at the end unable to influence.

title: U.S. Lays Out Its Fraud Case Against Governor of Arizona
description: Opening the Government's fraud case against Gov. Fife Symington of Arizona, a Federal prosecutor told jurors here today that Mr. Symington had concocted an elaborate web of financial lies in a desperate effort to salvage a crumbling real estate empire.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ENO, LAWRENCE R.
description: ENO-Lawrence R.. The tenants, friends and Board of Directors of 173-175 Riverside Drive acknowledge with gratitude the many years of honorable and devoted service Larry Eno provided everyone in this building. We all send sincere sympathy to his family. The Board of Directors 173-175 Riverside Drive

title: Germany's Growth Put at 0.5% in Quarter
description: Germany's economy probably expanded around five-tenths of 1 percent in the first quarter of this year from the final quarter of 1996, the Economics Ministry said yesterday, predicting stronger growth in the next few months. In a summary of its May monthly report, the ministry said the first-quarter growth was ''even more notable'' in view of lost production over the freezing months of January and February.

title: MOBUTU GIVES UP, LEAVING KINSHASA AND CEDING POWER
description: Ending nearly 32 years of rule in Africa's third-largest country, President Mobutu Sese Seko yielded power on Friday. He quietly slipped out of this besieged capital aboard a flight to his northern hometown, which diplomats described as a brief stopover en route to permanent exile.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHULL, MARILYN SEVEN
description: SHULL-Marilyn Seven. On May 16, 1997. Beloved wife of Richard B. Shull. Adored sister of Conrad Swartz and Alison Weissman. Services Sunday, May 18, 9:30AM, at ''The Riverside'', 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue, New York.

title: Charges Against Danish Mother Are Dropped
description: A state judge dismissed charges yesterday against a Danish tourist who was arrested for leaving her baby in a stroller on the sidewalk while she ate inside an East Village restaurant. Charges against the baby's father, who lives in Brooklyn, are still pending.

title: ADT IN TALKS TO END BID BY WESTERN RESOURCES
description: ADT Ltd. said yesterday that it was holding preliminary discussions with Western Resources Inc. on a possible end to Western's hostile bid for ADT, the largest provider of electronic-security systems in the United States and Britain. The talks have also touched on the settlement of outstanding litigation between the two companies, according to a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission. Western Resources, based in Topeka, Kan., is offering $22.50 a share to acquire ADT, including $10 in cash and $12.50 of company stock. The Bermuda-based ADT, though, accepted a friendly stock offer by Tyco International Inc., originally valued at $29 a share, or a total of $5.6 billion. There is no assurance that any agreement will be reached, ADT said.

title: To Protect Airliners, U.S. and Britain Prepare to Bomb One
description: After trying for years to assure security by keeping bombs off airplanes, American and British aviation experts are preparing for an elaborate test here on Saturday to audition another strategy: making the planes invulnerable to small explosions.

title: Democrats Use 2d Debate For Attacks on Each Other
description: The three candidates competing in the Democratic primary for governor met in their second televised debate here tonight. And with little more than two weeks to go before Primary Day, they continued their chorus of attacks on Gov. Christine Todd Whitman, but also became much more aggressive in their attempts to discredit and stand apart from one another.

title: Coffee Prices Fall as Supplies In the U.S. Show an Increase
description: Coffee prices retreated yesterday on the market in New York as a rise in inventories in the United States gave temporary relief to concern about shortages in the months ahead.

title: Gigante's Bill Is the Subject Of Haggling In Courtroom
description: A Federal judge, a hospital lawyer and the family of a suspected Mafia boss haggled in court yesterday over who should pay for hospital care that everybody agreed the man does not need.

title: Baltimore's Poor Brace for Round 2
description: In an unmowed courtyard of the Flag housing project, two little boys and a girl crawl over the steel jungle gym, its white paint worn down to rust. The mother of one, Sharron Sturdavant, watches from the stoop of the apartment she rents for $96 a month. From the window behind her wafts the distinctive odor of leaking gas.

title: Answer Is Snow In Guess The Goalie
description: For nearly a week, Flyers Coach Terry Murray kept everyone guessing who would be the starting goaltender for the Flyers in Game 1 of the Eastern Conference finals.

title: GENERAL MOTORS LOSES SUIT OVER CREDIT CARD
description: A New York jury awarded $24 million to a New York promotional marketing agency Thursday in a breach of contract lawsuit against the General Motors Corporation over the origins of the G.M. Mastercard. The agency, Communications Diversified, contended that in the early 1980's it talked with Chevrolet officials about creating a credit card that would offer rebates on cars and trucks. G.M. researched and rejected the idea, During the 1990's, G.M. began the G.M. Mastercard program. Officials of Communications Diversified said G.M. had violated an agreement by offering a credit card without involving them. The jury agreed.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL 3-7

title: Republicans Resort to Slur on 2000 Census
description: To the Editor:

title: For Baffert, Hardest Part Is Already Out of the Way
description: If Silver Charm withstands Captain Bodgit and Free House in the Preakness Stakes on Saturday, can he go on three weeks later and become the 12th horse to sweep the Triple Crown? Or will he become the 13th horse to fall short in the Belmont Stakes?

title: Guard Accused of Smuggling
description: An Essex County corrections officer was arrested yesterday and accused smuggling marijuana into the Essex County Jail to sell to inmates, prosecutors said. After a six-week investigation, county authorities caught the corrections officer, Mark Davis, 24, sneaking three foil-wrapped packets of the drug into the jail, said Ray Weiss, the prosecutor's spokesman. Along with marijuana, Mr. Davis was charged with selling prisoners sedatives, Mr. Weiss said. Mr. Davis, who had worked at the jail since October 1994, was suspended without pay.

title: Corrections
description: A report in the events column on Thursday about a walking tour of Morningside Heights tomorrow misstated the address for the Faculty House of Columbia University, where the tour begins. It is at 116th Street and Morningside Drive, not Morningside Avenue.

title: Sex and the Argentines: The Anatomy of a Scandal
description: Three years ago, Federico Andahazi, an unknown psychologist, decided to write a novel about a 16th-century Italian anatomist who made what the author calls one of the greatest discoveries of all time.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  YURKOFSKY, SARA
description: YURKOFSKY-Sara. Beloved mother of Dr. Abraham. Loving mother-in-law of Liliane. Cherished grandmother of Mark, Denise, David, Daniel. Beloved great-grandmother of Jessica, Max, Sabrina. Devoted aunt of Sophie Letuchy. Funeral service Riverside Memorial Chapel, 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue, Sunday, May 18, at 11 A.M.

title: Thelma Carpenter, 77, Singer With Big Bands
description: Thelma Carpenter, whose long roller-coaster career as a singer took her to the heights with the big bands of the 1930's and 40's, out of show business into years as a file clerk and back to the big-time on Broadway in the 60's, was found dead on Thursday in her apartment in Manhattan. She was 77.

title: Knicks Take Knocks, And Others Take Sides
description: Pity those poor New Yorkers. There they were, caught between their two basic sensibilities: ''Everybody hates us'' and ''Get over it. The world's a tough place.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JACOBS, FRANCES BATT
description: JACOBS-Frances Batt, 72, of Bayside, NY, on May 15th, 1997. Beloved wife of Jack. Loving mother of Richard and Wendy. Devoted grandmother of Lee and Matthew. Dear sister of Ruth Alenick, Irving Batt and Yvette Levitt. Service Sunday, May 18, 12 noon, Schwartz Brothers, Queens Blvd. and 76th Road. In lieu of flowers, contributions to the Scleroderma Federation, 1182 Teaneck Road, Teaneck, New Jersey 07666.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  EHRLICH, DR. HERMAN
description: EHRLICH-Dr. Herman. Of Holly lle, NJ. Passed away on May 15, 1997 at the age of 90. Beloved husband of 57 years of the late Lillian Ehrlich; adored and adoring father of Amy Tobin, Hollywood and Joan Ehrlich-White, NY; loved and admired father-in-law of Jack Tobin and Arthur White; loving, proud and cherished grandfather of Michael and Lisa Tobin. Donations in his memory may be sent to American Cancer Society or Temple Solel of Hollywood, FL.

title: Musings of a Mob Man With a Price on His Head
description: A quarter-century after mobsters enhanced their self-esteem by studying the ''Godfather'' movies for tips on fashion, attitude and tribal mythology, the Mafia is in such sorry shape that the Federal Witness Protection Program looks like Central Casting.

title: Death on the Highest Peak
description: Since the first ascent back in 1953, more than 600 people have stood atop Mount Everest, giving the world's tallest peak an allure of accessibility to anyone with a zest for adventure and, lately, enough money to pay as much as $65,000 for the thrill of going. Overlooked is the fact that about 150 of those attempting Mount Everest over the years have died.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROSS, CHARLES J.
description: ROSS-Charles J. Beloved husband of Anita, devoted father of Dr. Robert (Dr. Linda), David, and the late Douglas. Loving son of Tessie. Dear brother of Stanley. Adored grandfather of Rachel and Danielle. Graduate of Columbia University and lifelong aerospace engineer. Services today, 12:45 PM, at ''Gutterman's,'' 8000 Jericho Tpke, Woodbury, LI. Contributions may be made in his memory to the Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BOELITZ, MARIANNE (VIERKE)
description: BOELITZ-Marianne (Vierke). Beloved wife of the late Charles. Devoted mother of Lux Vidal, Marcel, Martin and Lorenzo. Also survived by 7 grandchildren and 4 great - grandchildren. Memorial service to be announced later.

title: Defining a War to Determine the Crime
description: THE name of Slobodan Milosevic, President of Serbia, is rarely spoken in the pristine courtroom where war crimes in the former Yugoslavia are being scrutinized. But his spirit is very much present. In fact, the Serb leader appears to have scored something of a victory here in recent days. Infamous for outmaneuvering Western governments, Mr. Milosevic has now by some accounts hoodwinked two of the tribunal's judges.

title: Corrections
description: A pop music listing on page 47 of the Arts and Leisure section today carries an outdated schedule for Memorial Jam, a salsa and merengue concert at Madison Square Garden. It will take place next Sunday at 8 P.M., not Saturday.

title: 4 Held in Retaliatory Rape of Girl, 15
description: Four teen-age boys were charged with raping a 15-year-old girl in a revenge attack here on Tuesday, after she encouraged a friend to report that she had been raped and sexually assaulted by two of the suspects a week earlier, the authorities said today.

title: A Troubadour From the 70's In Search Of Serenity
description: WITH TYPICALLY SLY humor, James Taylor describes the mystical songs on his new album, ''Hourglass,'' as ''spirituals for agnostics.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FOX, JAMES M.
description: FOX-James M. Mutual of America, its Board of Directors, together with all of its Officers and Employees, mourn the passing of our Executive Vice President and respected Colleague Jim Fox. After his long and distinguished career with the FBI, we were proud and pleased that he joined our organization and considered us part of his extended family. While his association with us was all too brief, his contributions to the strength and character of the company will be a guide for those who follow. We will deeply miss his wit, wis dom, and warmth, and extend our most sincere sympathy to his family. William J. Flynn Chairman of The Board Thomas J. Moran President and CEO Mutual of America LIfe Insurance Company

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WILLIAMS, JAY COLER, JR.
description: WILLIAMS-Jay Coler, Jr. of Stony Brook, NY, died May 14, 1997 at Mather Hospital in Port Jefferson. He is survived by his wife, Marie-Angele Williams of Paris, France, by five children, Jennifer Williams Ketay and Jay Keith, both of New York City, from his first marriage to the late Barbara M. Donaldson; Sebastien, Nicolas and Albertine of Paris; and by two grandsons and two granddaughters. Born in Mount Vernon, Illinois in 1913 to Mary Lee Arendale and Jay Coler Williams, he lived on the Upper West Side of New York City until 1920 when his family moved to River Forest, Illinois. A student first at Rollins College, where he was a member of the first men's crew, he received his B.A., M.A. and Ph.D degrees from the University of Chicago, where he subsequently taught in the Social Sciences Division. He taught also at Grinnell College and joined the State University of New York at Stony Brook faculty in the second year of the school's existence in 1958. There he served as Chairman of the Social Science Division and also of Political Science, retiring in 1983. A person of intellect and taste, an educator to all, his family and friends will miss his wit and caring. A memorial service will be announced.

title: For a Shelter, Talk of Move But Just Talk
description: Marsha Meyers placed two bulging folders on the dining room table of her Boerum Hill apartment. Inside were fliers, letters from politicians, legal documents and photographs that outline her neighborhood's six-year fight to close a homeless center.

title: Where Welfare Stands
description: Nine months have gone by since the passage of the 1996 welfare reform law. Welfare rolls are plummeting across the country. Caseloads fell between 1993 and 1996 by 31 percent in Indiana, 30 percent in Wisconsin and 22 percent in Arizona. These are indeed startling numbers and the politicians, not surprisingly, are crowing. From President Clinton to Representative Clay Shaw of Florida, who led the House subcommittee that drafted the law, they are congratulating themselves and the reform act they supported.

title: Sometimes a Great Nation
description: The American Century

title: The Great Outdoors
description: BATHED in the region's superlative light, outdoor sculpture -- whether on open fields, village greens or the sheltered grounds of private estates -- is shown to advantage on the East End. Some pieces date to the turn of the century, and with a sizable pool of artist residents to draw on, the area has a potential supply for the next hundred years.

title: U.S. Boom Plays Big In Politics Abroad
description: TONY and Cherie Blair abandoned their official car for a ''Westminster walkabout'' on their way to the Opening of Parliament last week, and The London Times approvingly noted the American inspiration of such politics, especially the way Mrs. Blair's scarf fell, like Hillary Clinton's, ''with a length hanging down from the left shoulder.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  O'HARA, MARY W.
