description: O'HARA-Mary W., 58, on May 15, 1997. After a difficult five-year battle with cancer. Died at peace at her home in Bronxville, New York. Director of Special Events at The College of New Rochelle. Educated at College of New Rochelle and Harvard University. Wife of Charles Schramm (predeceased), daughter of Eileen O'Hara of Riverdale, New York and Thomas (predeceased), sister of Thomas and Diane O'Hara, and loving aunt of Sean and Eileen O'Hara. In lieu of flowers, donations can be made to Jansen Memorial Hospice, 69 Main Street, Tuckahoe, New York 10707. Visitation will be at the Fred H. McGrath & Son Funeral Home, Cedar and Kraft Avenues, Bronxville, New York on Sunday, May 18, from 2-4, 7-9 P.M. Mass of Christian Burial celebrated on Monday at St. Joseph's Church, Bronxville at 10 A.M.

title: A City Ballet Rite of Spring Gets Back on Schedule
description: TRADITIONS CAN BE DIFFICULT to build, even in a tradition-loving world like ballet. Consider the New York City Ballet's Diamond Project. What began in 1992 as a one-time festival of 11 new works by 11 choreographers returned two years later with a dozen new works by a dozen choreographers. A biennial rite of spring seemed in the making. But reviews were wildly mixed, and many of the dances were never seen again. Last spring, the Diamond Project failed to show up on schedule.

title: Kristina Trippe, Robert Thorson Jr.
description: Kristina Harper Trippe, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Edward Stettinius Trippe of Greenwich, Conn., was married yesterday to Robert Douglas Thorson Jr., the son of Mrs. Abram Claude Jr. of Katonah, N.Y., and the late Mr. Thorson. The Rev. Sandra H. Stayner performed the Episcopal ceremony at Christ Church in Greenwich.

title: Smokers Win Reprieve In Toronto Restaurants
description: Toronto's City Council imposed the toughest antismoking law in North America in March, making it illegal to smoke anywhere in the city's 4,500 restaurants, bars or nightclubs. The only exception was for establishments with an enclosed, separately ventilated room, which few businesses could afford.

title: Son of Darien
description: Cheever's view of Darien is highly selective. she ignores the real community of people here for whom Alex Kelly is an example of everything we teach our children not to be. For the record, Kelly has spent his life not ''on the wrong side of the tracks'' in Darien but on the wrong side of the law.

title: A Savoy Sensibility Takes On South Beach
description: ''I HEARD a bloodcurdling scream as hot water gushed up and scalded her behind,'' said John Pringle, recalling the poignant discomfort of the wife of the Governor of Jamaica when a newly installed toilet erupted on the opening night of Round Hill, the legendary Jamaican resort he founded in 1951.

title: On the Beach
description: THE WATCHER

title: Philip-Lorca diCorcia: STREET THEATER
description: Philip-Lorca diCorcia says his work is an ''investigation of how people project or withdraw themselves on the street.'' DiCorcia, 43, hides several synchronized strobe lights on signs or buildings, places his camera on a tripod and steps aside, giving ''a cinematic gloss to a commonplace event.'' This technique allows his subjects no warning that they're being photographed, which seems to rankle New Yorkers more than most. ''They think I'm violating their rights,'' says diCorcia, a New Yorker himself. ''Maybe I am.''

title: Singing the Blues For Billie Holiday
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CREEL, DANA SHANNON
description: CREEL-Dana Shannon, 84, of Sharon, CT, died at his home on Haisdan Farm on May 15, 1997. Beloved husband of Jane Haislip Creel; brother of Virginia Creel Clark and uncle of David Clark. He graduated from Emory University, its Law School and the Harvard Business School, and served in the Counter Intelligence Corps of the U.S. Army in World War II. He served as John D. Rockefeller, Jr's principal philanthropic advisor and worked closely with other members of the Rockefeller Family for more than 50 years. He was president of the Rockefeller Brothers Fund from 1950-1975. After his retirement, he remained active with many conservation and preservation organizations, including the Hudson River Valley Association, Sleepy Hollow Restorations, Boscobel and the Young-Morse Restoration Site. He was a board member of the Berkshire Taconic Community Foundation. Haisdan Farm is noted for its scenic beauty and has won state and national awards for its corn production. The funeral service will be private. The date of a memorial service will be announced. Contributions, in lieu of flowers, may be made to the Dana S. Creel Fund of the Berkshire Taconic Community Foundation, Lakeville, CT 06039.

title: Bias Still a Concern At Private Golf Clubs
description: LAST weekend at St. Andrew's Golf Club in Hastings-on-Hudson, Wall Street brokers and corporate executives took time out from their daily pressures to commune with nature on the links and possibly break 90 -- all for the price of a $20,000 initiation fee and about $9,000 a year.

title: Nod to Women
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: TAKING THE CHILDREN
description: Rudyard Kipling's 'The Second Jungle Book: Mowgli and Baloo'

title: Sun Fun: East End's Beaches
description: LIKE Elizabeth Bishop's Sandpiper, we are all obsessed by a search, and in the summer, we search for the perfect beach.

title: Accolades Roll In for L.I. Wines
description: LONG ISLAND wineries, on something of a roll, aspire not merely to regional but also to full-scale national and international recognition.

title: The Charms Of Dior
description: Move over, Chanel, Gucci and Hermes. The women who lunch have fallen in love with a new $1,200 handbag, with signature dangling metal charms that spell out ''Dior.'' The roomy bag comes in two kinds of leather: plain, or quilted like Chanel's famous bag, but with handles instead of a gold-color chain. The Dior bag was first popularized last year when the Princess of Wales carried it. And already, $300 copies are appearing in Paris and New York, like the one in diamond-shape quilting above. But even its carrier admitted that the knockoff, whose charms do not spell ''Dior,'' misses.

title: Westhampton Beach
description: Walking down Main Street in Westhampton Beach in May, one would never guess a human tragedy like the beating of a black teen-ager by an off-duty white police officer and his friends took place on such a seemingly peaceful street a year ago. The former storefront of Marakesh, the nightclub where the assault started, is about to be reborn. James Orioli of Brooklyn has raised a banner proclaiming the opening of Cafe Le Mer, which will serve ''15 types of exotic coffees, cakes and pastries.'' Mr. Orioli plans to present comedy acts, music and fashion shows. Several other storefronts have changed hands this season on Main Street. The Golden Pear cafe opened its latest addition to the Hamptons along with Paula Evans Great Food, a caterer. New home furnishings include the lucky Rabbit's Foot and La Maison Modern. Women's retail shops, Rix and Cool Wear, are added to the contemporary junior selections at Shock and Fahrenheit 451 and the more conservative Rags, Abs and Erik Stewart. Knock them down at West Hampton Bowl's 24lanes. Adventurous types can head to the Suffolk County Airport, better known as Gabreski Airport, where the Soaring Society of America offers a wide variety of glider lessons and packages.

title: A Chance to Be Heard
description: To the Editor:

title: Giving Southampton Hospital an Identity
description: ''IF you build it, they will come,'' a voice told Kevin Costner in the film ''Field of Dreams.'' And that same brand of optimism is behind the resurgence of Southampton Hospital, the major health facility on the East End of the Island.

title: Q and A
description: Airline Rebate Cards

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GLICKMAN, RUTH S.
description: GLICKMAN-Ruth S. Beloved wife of the late Samuel. Loving mother of Marvin and Barbara, Morton and Alice, Herbert and Carole. Adored grandmother and greatgrandmother. Graveside service Montefiore Cemetery, Queens, New York, at 1 P.M., Sunday.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: N.H.L.

title: Seeking Euro Club Inclusion, Italy Still Faces Hazing
description: If Prime Minister Romano Prodi were still in school, he would be the kind of pupil who arrives in the classroom early, gets his homework done on time, puts his hand up in front of the teacher's nose -- and still fails to get straight A's.

title: Ms. Schnyder And Mr. McCarthy
description: Christina Marie Schnyder, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Walter Richard Schnyder of Forest Hills Gardens, Queens, was married yesterday to Stephen Garretson McCarthy, the son of Dr. and Mrs. Joseph G. McCarthy of Englewood, N.J. Msgr. Joseph P. Nagle performed the ceremony at the Church of Our Lady Queen of Martyrs in Forest Hills.

title: Penguins and Friends Get New Home in Bronx
description: In February 1995, the De Jur Aviary at the Bronx Zoo collapsed during a snowstorm. Built in 1899 as one of the New York zoo's first exhibits, the arched, wire-covered structure was home to more than 100 South American sea birds, about 30 of which were lost when they flew off. But many of the remainder are settled in a new Bronx home, the Aitken Aviary, which was to open officially yesterday.

title: Scenes de Ballet
description: SECRET MUSES

title: Restaurant Grows Roots, Some Fear
description: No one disagrees that the Hudson River waterfront property between 25th and 26th Streets looks a lot better than it did about a year ago. Once littered with mounds of concrete and home to prostitutes and a dilapidated garage housing homeless people, the area has been transformed into a scenic complex with a landscaped 600-foot cedar walkway, a sculpture garden, a park and a restaurant, recently renamed 26 Hudson.

title: Even Plato Would Puzzle Over the Name
description: PLATO'S Alternative Steak House still looks like the warehouse it once was. The walls are massive and concrete, the ceilings two stories high and the dining room -- well, Hollywood could build a city in here, a whole Manhattan with a waterfront and an Intrepid docked on the Hudson.

title: I Keep Missing the Excitement, and That's All Right With Me
description: WHENEVER I read about the Hamptons in the papers, the life always sounds so downright frenzied and high-wattage that you have to wonder where the people who spend weekends there go to relax. Perhaps back to New York. What with the mass of celebrities and ceaseless benefit parties and throngs to contend with, it's hard to imagine much peace. But the thing about the Hamptons is that there are many rewarding moments that you just never read about. To be specific:

title: Women's Lib in Russia Isn't Just Cosmetic
description: To the Editor:

title: Military Can't Have It Both Ways in Flinn Case
description: To the Editor:

title: F.Y.I.: English At Work
description: WHEN the 3:15 buzzer sounds at the Guest Packaging plant, most of the first-shift workers leave their soap-cutting machines, their enormous mixing vats filled with raspberry fragrance, their stacks of boxes of ginseng body lotion, and head for home. But six men and four women -- packers, compounders, label operators -- climb a flight of metal stairs past a towering silver tank of propylene glycol and file into a windowless room isolated from the chugs and beeps of the factory floor.

title: Casting Pebbles in the War Against Adultery
description: TO the Air Force, a 26-year-old bomber pilot who fell hard for a four-star bad boyfriend deserves to be court-martialed for a handful of military crimes including adultery, the quintessentially biblical sin. To most Americans, she does not. They have been reacting with amazement, not least because for decades, civilian courts have responded to adultery with a big yawn.

title: Western North Fork and Greenport
description: In 1757, a surveyor, George Washington, recommended that a navigational light for the bluff overlooking Dead Man's Cove on Cliff Lot in Southold, the first town west of Greenport. It took 100 years, but the Horton Point Lighthouse continues to keeping sailors safe at sea, without the whale oil. On the bay side of Southold, the public can roam around the grounds of the Southold Historical Society at Main Road and Maple Lane. The Thomas Moore House dates from the 1650's. The Ann Currie Bell Hallock House and Buttery is 200 years old, as are the Blacksmith Shop, the Pine View Barn and Bay View School.

title: Western North Fork and Greenport
description: Greenport is a gem, an emerald if you will, as opposed to the diamonds and rubies of the South Fork. The town revolves around the harbor. A ferry comes and goes from the north side of Shelter Island, from New London, Conn., to Orient Point or a pleasant drive through the North Fork's wine country.

title: A Guided Tour of Columbia's Ivy Halls
description: Sooner or later most students at Columbia University discover the owl hidden within the folds of Alma Mater's gown, the 1903 bronze sculpture in front of the campus's Low Library, and many rub the owl for good luck before exams.

title: Allison Sellery, Henry O'Connor 3d
description: Allison Burke Sellery, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert A. Sellery Jr. of Washington, was married there last evening to Henry Robinson O'Connor 3d, a son of Mr. and Mrs. O'Connor Jr. of Avalon, N.J. The Rev. C. C. Campbell Gillon performed the ceremony at the Georgetown Presbyterian Church.

title: Tri-Continental Directors Turn Deaf Ear on Wake-Up Call
description: INDEPENDENT directors are supposed to act as the voice of shareholders. Whether they do so or merely endorse management is a matter of concern to mutual fund regulators, who are looking more closely at the issue.

title: Three Fast Rivals Electrify the Triple Crown
description: The rivalry began in California, with Silver Charm and Free House. They went to the Kentucky Derby, picked up Captain Bodgit and brought their show here.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HEIDE, THE RIGHT REVEREND MONSIGNOR HERMAN L.
description: HEIDE-The Right Reverend Monsignor Herman L. On May 17, 1997. Son of the late Herman L. and Gertrude Amend Heide. He is survived by his sisters Sister Muriel Heide, R.S.C.J. Kenwood, Albany, Constance H. Sullivan, Tequesta, FL, and Rumson, NJ, Ruth H. Kane, Glen Cove, NY, Anne H. Quigley, Geneva, NY, and his brother a trappist monk, Father Paul Heide O.C.S.O., Azul, Argentina, and 30 nieces and nephews and numerous grand-nieces and nephews. He is predeceased by his sisters Genevieve H. McCrossin and Dorothy H. Hynes. Reposing at the McMahon, Lyon and Hartnett Funeral Home, 491 Mamaroneck Avenue, White Plains, on Sunday 3-8 PM, and Monday 24 PM. Mass of the Eucharist Monday, 7:30 PM, and Mass of Christian Burial Tuesday, 11 AM. Both to be held at St. Anthony of Padua Church, West Harrison, NY. Interment Calvary Cemetery, Queens, NY. In lieu of flowers donations may be sent to St. Joseph's Abbey Azul, Spencer, MA 01562.

title: Silver Charm, by a Head, Takes Aim at the Crown
description: Silver Charm, who won the Kentucky Derby over Captain Bodgit by the length of his gray head, provided a smashing encore today when he won the 122d Preakness by the same head over Free House, with Captain Bodgit third by another head in a three-horse blanket finish. And he set the stage for the Belmont Stakes in three weeks, when he will be racing to become the first colt in 19 years to sweep the Triple Crown.

title: The Work of Reconstruction
description: ''Different things get taken from you in the course of a life,'' reflects the heroine of Brian Keith Jackson's affecting first novel. Set in a black community in the rural South, THE VIEW FROM HERE (Pocket Books, $22) is a quiet story about a woman's odyssey from powerlessness to self-possession. Anna Thomas has been awash in a sea of domestic duty and obligation for as long as she can remember. Cut off from her one source of emotional sustenance, her free-spirited friend Ida Mae, Anna has been consumed by the needs of her five sons and her husband, Joseph, a taciturn man who takes to the bottle after losing his job at the lumber mill. When Anna discovers she is pregnant with a sixth child and Joseph insists that she give the infant to his treacherous sister, Anna reluctantly agrees to yet another sacrifice, even though she's sure the new baby will be a daughter. Isolated and lonely, she writes letters in her head to Ida Mae and talks to her child. Mr. Jackson's prose has a visceral pungency, and if at times his imagery veers toward the sentimental, such excesses never undermine the drama of his story. Rebellious Ida Mae, who has fled the trap of domesticity, serves as a foil to Anna's dutiful self-effacement. But when Anna learns what has befallen her friend, her inner world shifts; at last she is able to obey the imperatives of her heart. ''Certain things must end before others can begin,'' she reflects. Or, as her daughter later puts it, ''Even the faintest of lights begin in darkness.'' Andrea Barnet

title: Books in Brief: Fiction
description: I Saw a Man Hit His Wife

title: Independent Directors
description: To the Editor:

title: Curiosities in Every Corner
description: AS a resident of London, I make regular pilgrimages to view the Impressionist paintings at the National Gallery and the Elgin Marbles at the British Museum. But during my six years here, I've discovered that some of London's best museums are small, specialized collections. Most evolved from one person's devotion to a particular item and the desire to share the results. All are either in central London or near enough for a half-day outing.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHERMAN, BERNARD
description: SHERMAN-Bernard. Loving husband of Sari. Beloved father of Marcy and Marina and Stan. Adoring grandfather and great-grandfather. Also known as ''Mr. Yardstick,'' 568 consecutive games. Founder of De Witt Clinton High School Football Alumni Association. Funeral Services today, 12 noon, ''Sinai Chapels,'' 162-05 Horace Harding Expressway, Fresh Meadows, NY.

title: Cuba Sees a New Threat to Recovery: A Weak Sugar Harvest
description: In a severe blow to efforts to revive the Cuban economy, this year's sugar harvest, the country's largest source of much-needed foreign exchange, will fall considerably short of the Government's target, President Fidel Castro has acknowledged.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  VALENTE, BEVERLY EDELMAN
description: VALENTE-Beverly Edelman. Devoted wife of Gene. Loving mother of Susan E. Edelman and Bruce and Susan B. Edelman.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KUBLIN, PEARL BARU
description: KUBLIN-Pearl Baru. May 8, 1997. Beloved wife of the late Dr. Hyman Kublin. Devoted mother of Barbara and Michael. Loving mother-in-law of Jack and Janet. Cherished Grammy of Heather. Forever in our thoughts and hearts.

title: A Good Family Man
description: UNDERBOSS

title: Creme de la Creme
description: THIS is horse country, so it's not unusual to see Governor Whitman or a Forbes in any of the five comfortable dining rooms at 89 Main Street, which opened in December in quiet, beautiful Peapack.

title: Some Regulated Units Unaffected by State
description: Lost in the furor over the overhauling of New York's rent laws has been the fact that thousands of apartments in New York City could continue to be regulated no matter what state lawmakers decide.

title: Real Kennedy Issues
description: To the Editor:

title: BENEFITS
description: A Romantic Evening

title: Meeting With a Group of Cronies to Chew the Fat, but There's a Catch
description: ''I DON'T eat that much,'' Joseph Heller said before ordering ''a half a grilled chicken sandwich on rye toast with a slice of tomato and no mayo.''

title: Animal House
description: THE musty smell of dog wafted through the bedroom as I thought about having to put my cat to sleep. I had had my cat since the city. I had had her when I was depressed and lonely. I still had her when I took the bus crosstown every Friday afternoon, cat carrier in hand, to spend the weekend with my boyfriend. I had had her when I married my boyfriend and even when our baby was born.

title: The Knicks' Chance to Make Amends
description: Unsmiling and walking briskly, Patrick Ewing broke through a wall of cameras and microphones today en route to a flight for Miami. Before he left practice, Ewing, with his team's season in the balance, issued a single proclamation: the Knicks in seven.

title: Michael O'Neill: CROSSROADS AT A CROSSROADS
description: ''I was born in the 40's,'' says Michael O'Neill, a lifelong New Yorker. ''I remember the twinkly, diamond-lit Fred Astaire sense of the city of black-and-white films, and it was beautiful.'' This mood can best be captured in Times Square at dusk, he says, when the buzz and commotion of the pre-theater crowd is ''magnified by that moment when the sky is purple.'' O'Neill planned to visit the area at least once before shooting, to get a feel for what would work. ''But I saw a bus turning and clicked,'' he recalls. He was later struck by how clearly the tourists in the lower left of the picture came out. ''It's amazing that those people were actually standing still enough to look like they were waiting and looking and maybe overwhelmed, who knows.''

title: Life After 'Rent' for a Little Theater With Big Ideas
description: IN THE WORLD OF NONPROFIT theater, success is a relative thing. ''Two years ago, I'd come to work and and wonder whether we'd be here tomorrow,'' said James C. Nicola, the artistic director of New York Theater Workshop. ''Now I wonder whether we'll be here two or three years from now.''

title: Andrew Leynse, Mary Bacon
description: Mary Christine Bacon, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Jack Bacon of Denver, was married yesterday to Andrew Dirk Leynse, a son of Judith L. Leynse of New York and the late Humphrey W. Leynse. The Rev. Dr. James M. O'Brien, a Unitarian Universalist minister, performed the ceremony at Gansett Green Manor in Amagansett, N.Y.

title: Activities Abound From the Western Part of the East End to the Eastern Parts of the North and South Forks
description: THE East End of Long Island is unarguably one of the most picturesque places in the world, inspiring arts and writers for centuries. This time of year, late spring, you are apt to find a fox pup, a tiny hairless body with a mane of fluffy red fur, wandering along the woods, piping plovers nesting in the dunes, undistinguishable from the grains of sand, a sudden appearance of fuchsia or buttercup in the still sleepy landscape. Come summer, color saturates every visible frame and the air and population thicken.

title: As the Field Closes In, Woods Gains the Lead
description: There are other golfers competing in the GTE Byron Nelson Classic besides Tiger Woods. Today, they introduced themselves to the Tiger-centric galleries here, then painted the scoreboard with enough low numbers to spell out the message: ''No gimmes will be offered as a welcome back to the Masters champion.''

title: Karen Iker, Kendrick McLish
description: Karen Lea Iker, a daughter of Jean and Samuel Iker of Chevy Chase, Md., is to be married today to Kendrick McLish, a son of Margot and Holmes McLish of Littleton, Colo. Judge Peter J. Messitte of Federal District Court for Maryland officiated at the Washington International School.

title: Sampling French Tradition in Banksville
description: WHEN sated with the tension of novelty, the virtuosic flights of culinary daring, we gravitate toward La Cremaillere. True, we have always found the rooms too small for comfort (we prefer the tables in the airier room of the entry bar), tables much too closely spaced and service sometimes clumsy. Nonetheless, here, sitting on plush in the comely landmarked structure, we easily recollect this restaurant's virtues -- consistency, elegance, tradition, finesse -- which can hold their own against the new.

title: Ann Friedrich and Gregory Lundberg
description: Ann Louise Friedrich, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. David E. Friedrich of Radnor, Pa., was married yesterday to Gregory Hartman Lundberg, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Marshall B. Lundberg of Portsmouth, R.I. The Rev. Anita E. Keire, a United Church of Christ minister, performed the ceremony at the American Yacht Club in Rye, N.Y.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLDMAN, MURIEL F.
description: GOLDMAN-Muriel F. ''A woman of beauty and grace.'' Beloved wife of David. Devoted mother of William and Dr. Irene Goldman. Dear sister of Richard Friedman. Funeral services Sunday at noon at Gutterman-Musicant, Hackensack. Contributions to Wurzweiler School of Social Work of Yeshiva University, NYC, appreciated.

title: New Releases
description: ABBEY LINCOLN: 'WHO USED TO DANCE'

title: Populist Pomp: 'Just Call Me Tony'
description: EXCEPT for the coronation of a monarch, there isn't a more richly traditional occasion on the British ceremonial calendar than the State Opening of Parliament.

title: Indulging a Passion For the Baroque
description: BY now, Gavin Black has decided which harpsichords he will play in his recital today. They may already have been moved into Bristol Chapel. Ten days ago, he was still choosing: one instrument was out, and of two others, one was a maybe. But the elaborately decorated Tyre & Goudzwaard, built for Mr. Black and his repertory, is a yes.

title: WESTCHESTER BRIEFS
description: Student Killer

title: Books in Brief: Fiction
description: BOMB GRADE

title: Jack Pierson: BROADWAY DREAMSCAPE
description: Jack Pierson is smitten with show business. ''It's a big eye-roller in the art world -- art at its most base,'' says the 36-year-old New Yorker. ''But I think it's art at its most exalted. I believe all the myths, that it's important to become a success on Broadway.'' Slipping in the stage door at ''Chicago,'' chatting up the stage manager and seeing the star in leg warmers did nothing to dim his ardor. ''All the myth making begins backstage,'' he says. ''Even if you've never been there before, you feel like you've been there. I take comfort in the cliche.'' Pierson then set out to shoot the streets of Times Square ''with added warmth and romance.'' He worked without a flash on a rainy night and left the shutter open for a minute or more, creating a blurry paean to an earlier era: ''I still like to believe that the signs say 'Franks One Nickel' not 'Casio' or 'TDK' -- so if they're out of focus, I've got my New York Dream.''

title: Sag Harbor
description: To get a feel for Sag Harbor, your first stop should be the Whaling Museum. Head to the white pillared Masonic Temple and walk through Moby Dick's mouth. The home originally belonged to the whaling ship owner Benjamin Huntting, who had a very lucrative career.

title: Corrections
description: The Practical Traveler column on May 4, about car rentals, misstated the given name of an Avis spokesman. He is Gerard M. Quirk, not John.

title: WESTCHESTER GUIDE
description: ASSESSING KATONAH

title: The Home Front
description: LILY'S CROSSING By Patricia Reilly Giff. 180 pp. New York: Delacorte Press. $14.95. (Ages 8 to 12)

title: 10 Residents Under Siege By Proposal For Big Mall
description: In a battle between homeowners and a shopping mall, it appears that the mall is winning in this city of 36,000 a dozen miles northeast of downtown Fort Worth.

title: Pamela Lyons, Jonathan McLean
description: Pamela Jamie Lyons, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. George M. Lyons of White Plains, was married yesterday to Jonathan Morris McLean, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Clarence D. McLean of Bladenboro, N.C. Canon Nancy A. Roosevelt, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony at the Biddle House in Tarrytown, N.Y.

title: The 40-Minute Class, Out Like Bobby Socks
description: REMEMBER high school? Remember heading for the hall every 40 minutes or so, as class periods changed? And the parting yells from teachers: ''For homework, do those 15 questions!'' as they prepared for yet another wave.

title: Hey, Waddya Read? Papers Slake the Thirsts
description: IF there is no new best seller to catch your eye in the book stores in the Hamptons this summer, there's always the East End newspapers with their local mysteries, political intrigues, food, fashion and entertainment.

title: Burmese Officials Return Fugitive in U.S. Heroin Case to Thailand
description: The chief suspect sought by the police after the biggest heroin seizure in United States history has been captured in Myanmar and was returned today to Thailand, where he had jumped bail earlier this year, authorities in Myanmar said.

title: For Want of a Kitchen . . .
description: THEY had found themselves in what they called a Catch-22 situation: They wanted to buy a terrific apartment whose dated kitchen had been ripped out and never replaced; the bank would not lend them the money to buy the place unless it had a functioning kitchen; they couldn't put in a kitchen if they didn't yet own the apartment.

title: Treetops: An Aura of Glamour, a Trail of Tragedies
description: IN florid prose, newspaper advertisements sing the praises of a neo-Georgian 30-room-plus mansion set on 110 acres lying in both Stamford and Greenwich. The property is replete with an art studio, four greenhouses, a two-story caretaker's cottage and hiking trails. A large-scale renovation in the 80's resulted in the elimination of a tennis court and a swimming pool; at one time there were 14 bedrooms and now there are 7. But all over the estate remain millions of daffodils, including a strain named after the property's longtime owner, the torch singer and actress Libby Holman.

title: Lessons of Tiger Woods Will Not Be Easy Ones
description: It almost seemed as if America was golfless for these last four weeks. Finally, the return of the Tiger came this week when Tiger Woods rejoined the tour at the GTE Byron Nelson Classic in Irving, Tex. I missed him.

title: Reviving Greenwich's 'Most Conspicuous House'
description: EVEN though radically reduced from its original 1896 design, the old Benedict house is still one of the most notable places on the waterfront in Greenwich, Conn. Since 1994 new owners have been working on bringing back its unusual combination of architecture and landscape, and they have at least another year to go.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  EISLAND, NETTIE
description: EISLAND-Nettie. On May 16, 1997. Beloved wife of the late Manny. Devoted mother of Paul and June Eisland and Karen and Ben Selig. Loving grandmother and greatgrandmother of Evan, Jane, Marla, Dana, Steven, Laura, Jake, and Scott. Dear sister of Rose Greenblatt and Ruth Mironson. Funeral service today, 1 PM, at Plaza Memorial Chapel, 91st Street and Amsterdam Avenue, NYC.

title: 2d Vote Sought By Schools On Budgets
description: TO the relief of most school district superintendents, who presented 1997-98 budgets for public vote early this month, voters endorsed what was on the ballot, but there were at least five exceptions.

title: 'Passing Apartment To Next Generation'
description: To the Editor:

title: WITH MOBUTU OUT, ZAIRE REBEL CHIEF CLAIMS PRESIDENCY
description: With his forces entering Zaire's capital, the victorious rebel leader, Laurent Kabila, declared himself President on Saturday and gave the first indications of his plans for governing Africa's third-largest country.

title: Laura Klatt, Andrew M. Fine
description: Laura Caroline Klatt, the daughter of Mary M. Klatt of Brookline, Mass., and the late Dennis H. Klatt, is to be married today to Andrew Morton Fine, the son of Ellen H. and Stuart L. Fine of Bryn Mawr, Pa. Rabbi Donald Berlin is to perform the ceremony at Castle Hill, a historic house in Ipswich, Mass.

title: Barnum and Lind
description: To the Editor:

title: The Images That Gave the Stars Their Faces
description: HOLLYWOOD STUDIO portraits of the 1930's, once considered as passe and nearly as laughable as fancy Jell-O molds at formal dinners, were rehabilitated in a major way in the 1970's. This was probably inevitable, considering how many revivals of kitsch have been brought on by insistent nostalgia, camp sensibility and the general elevation of lowly commercial objects to the expensive level of art.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FELDMAN, IRVING
description: FELDMAN-Irving. Beloved brother, father, grandfather and great grandfather. Passed away May 15, 1997. We shall miss him.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  YOUNG, ALEXANDER, MD.
description: YOUNG-Alexander, MD. The medical staff and administration of St. Luke's-Roosevelt Hospital Center are deeply saddened by the death of our esteemed colleague, Alexander Young, MD. Dr. Young was a distinguished member of the Dermatology Department for over four decades and served as the first Director of Dermatology at our St. Luke's Division. He was an outstanding teacher and mentor to generations of medical students and house officers. Our heartfelt condolences are extended to his family and all his loved ones. Laurence Huntington, Chairman Ronald Ablow, MD President Robert Campbell, MD Medical Director Richard Fried, MD President, Medical Board Vincent DeLeo, MD Director, Dermatology

title: Suit Seeks To Put Chains On Courthouse
description: The decade-old battle over the construction of a new Federal Courthouse in downtown Brooklyn is either on its last gasp or about to receive a powerful second wind.

title: Fearing (646), Some (212)'s Doubt Phone Officials' 411
description: It won't happen until 1999, but Nynex's move to add an area code in Manhattan is already stirring suspicions among Manhattan's businesses, neighborhoods and interest groups.

title: AIDS Onrush Sends Russia To the Edge of an Epidemic
description: Fueled by a convergence of surging drug abuse and increased sexual activity, Russia stands on the precipice of an AIDS epidemic every bit as explosive as the one that swept through Europe and the United States 15 years ago.

title: Life as News, News as Life
description: From little children on a tumbledown porch to a woman in a stunning evening gown, from cowboys at the Harlem Rodeo to workers in a Hewlett-Packard factory, Eli Reed has spent the last 16 years documenting the lives of black people in the United States. Mr. Reed, a member of Magnum, the photojournalists' cooperative, earns his living covering wars and making portraits of movie stars. BLACK IN AMERICA (Norton, $29.95), his second book, is a personal project, a record of the moments that do not make the news. Mr. Reed treats everyday life like a front-page story and transforms monumental events into intimate moments. For example, he depicts a girl, in the aftermath of the 1992 riots in South Central Los Angeles, holding objects she has rescued from the wreckage of her home, literally picking up the pieces of her life. His images of Yusef Hawkins's funeral in Brooklyn in 1989 show a sea of glaring faces looking anxious and lost. The book's final image, taken at the Martin Luther King Jr. Memorial in Montgomery, Ala., in 1995, shows a child reaching to touch the engraved words. While the individual pictures are powerful, the book sometimes seems disjointed. The photographs are not grouped chronologically; Mr. Reed has made no attempt at telling a story. His powerful images leave us grasping to find our own way through the past and into the future. Jake Miller

title: Stephen Talkhouse: Lively Music Showcase
description: MUCH like the Montauk Indian it was named after, Stephen Talkhouse is one of a kind.

title: Elizabeth Griffin and Scott Lisle
description: Elizabeth Randolph Griffin, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Gerard P. Griffin Jr. of Cold Spring Harbor, N.Y., was married there yesterday to Scott Sawyer Lisle, a son of Peter Grim Lisle of Westport, Mass., and the late Elizabeth Simmen Lisle. The Rev. Churchill G. Pinder performed the ceremony at St. John's Episcopal Church.

title: Taking the Bus to a Wider World
description: EARLY morning and late afternoon are busy times for JoAnn Miller, of New Milford, who has three children and a job outside the home. But thanks to the Kennedy Center in Bridgeport, she has one less thing to worry about -- how her sister, Jeanette Hipp, will get to work.

title: A. H. Ketchum, 92; Wrote of Uncle Sam
description: Alton Harrington Ketchum, a retired advertising executive and historian, died on April 29 at Reston Hospital Center in Reston, Va., during a family visit. He was 92 and lived in Cos Cob, Conn.

title: Lessons in Interdependence From the Lower East Side
description: THE New York art world of the mid-1980's was considerably enlivened by the rise of the East Village. The neighborhood, usually referred to as the Lower East Side, was invaded by a slew of small galleries and the bars and restaurants that always seem to go along with them.

title: From Swank to Simplicity Itself
description: FINDING the right hotel room in Manhattan can be frustrating. New York hotels are expensive. The rooms are frequently small. And more and more these days, they're full. But like the city that houses them, Manhattan's hotels are wildly varied, offering something for just about everyone, provided you hunt down the appropriate place.

title: Power of Sexuality
description: To the Editor:

title: Elite Establishment Egghead Eupatrids
description: As is well known (as communists used to say) the world is run by a snobbish, arrogant clique of rich and powerful aristocrats --- a network of the well-born and over-educated ---- who maintain a stranglehold on the all-powerful media and sneer at downtrodden commoners condemned to a lifetime in entry-level jobs flipping Bilderbergers.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STULMAN, JULIUS
description: STULMAN-Julius. On May 17, age 91, longtime resident of Longboat Key, Florida. Founder of Lumber Exchange Terminal, Lumber Industries, Inc, and numerous other enterprises, he was not only an elder statesman of the lumber industry but one of the most creative and original thinkers of our time. Salesman, problem-solver, practical visionary, poet and prophet; author, lecturer, publisher; planner, counselor and advisor to countless individuals, corporations, foundations and governments throughout the world for over 60 years. A pioneer benefactor of many American and Israeli institutions, especially relating to economic planning, scientific research and Jewish education. Husband of the late Janis Carter Stulman, he is survived by a son Stephen, daughter Joan S. Gilbert, daughter-in-law Elga, son-in-law Phil, sisters Pearl Goldenthal, Sophia Leopold, Esther Moldauer, seven grandchildren and six greatgrandchildren. Services Monday, May 19, 12:30 PM, at ''The Riverside,'' 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue. The period of mourning will be observed at 151 Central Park West, NYC.

title: Nancy Siesel: MOTION STUDY
description: Nancy Siesel, a New York Times staff member, started using a plastic toy camera a couple of years ago mainly for practical reasons. Times Square ''has always been a scary place to walk around alone with an expensive camera,'' she says, so she bought a plastic ''Tru-View'' in a thrift shop, the kind of camera that used to be sold for a few dollars in dime stores. Of course, the characteristic soft focus at the edge of the frame also suited her subject here. ''Just one part of the image is sharp and everything else is blurry, like a casual glance,'' she says. To Siesel, 34, this implicit reference to vacationers' snapshots brings out the real nature of the neighborhood: ''It's incredible the way people from all over the world flock here, looking for something. Even with the sense of danger, it's the first place people want to be -- fun and danger going hand in hand.''

title: Lynel Tully, John Rinklin 3d
description: Lynel Marie Tully and John George Rinklin 3d are to be married today in Winchester, Mass. The Rev. James W. Savage is to perform the ceremony at St. Eulalia Roman Catholic Church.

title: Correction
description: An article on May 4 about the state master plan paraphrased the position of Bill Neil, the Assistant Director of Conservation for the New Jersey Audubon Society, incorrectly. He did not say that problems with enforcement of the state plan had created extreme situations requiring extreme solutions. A letter explaining the society's position appears today on page 19.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LURIE, HELEN COULE
description: LURIE-Helen Coule. Died May 8, 1997. Actress, writer, classical guitarist. Widow of Lee Lurie. Memorial service Saint Andrew's, Stamford, CT June 21st, 12 Noon.

title: Election Turns on 2 Visions of Board's Role
description: As races for community board chairmanships go, the contest between Ann Arlen and Alan J. Gerson within Community Board 2 is a hotly contested one, pitting a longtime downtown environmental activist (Ms. Arlen), who is supported by the current chairman, against a lawyer. They represent factions in what has been described in one newspaper as an increasingly divided board.

title: Writer Says Life Has Its Own Plot
description: Fordham University held its 152d commencement at its Rose Hill campus in the Bronx yesterday. Mary Higgins Clark, the writer of suspense and mystery novels, addressed the 3,585 graduates, offering them advice on what she called the ''personal suspense novels'' they had just begun to write.

title: Nadia Adler, Robert Bernstein
description: Nadia Adler and Dr. Robert Bernstein are to be married today in Tarrytown, N.Y. Rabbi David Fass is to perform the ceremony at the Castle at Tarrytown.

title: The Enticements Of Park Ave. South
description: AJA ** $(rating: two stars$)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ENO, LAWRENCE R.
description: ENO-Lawrence R.. The tenants, friends and Board of Directors of 173-175 Riverside Drive acknowledge with gratitude the many years of honorable and devoted service Larry Eno provided everyone in this building. We all send sincere sympathy to his family. The Board of Directors 173-175 Riverside Drive

title: They're Not in Denmark Anymore
description: It began as an incident in New York City's East Village but gained international status within days. A couple, Annette Sorensen and Exavier Wardlaw, was arrested and their 14-month-old daughter put in foster care because they had left her in a stroller outside a restaurant where they were eating. The mother, a Danish actress visiting the baby's father, a movie producer from Brooklyn, claimed she was only doing what thousands of Danes do daily. Pictures wired from Denmark later showed strollers outside cafes in view of dining parents.

title: Clinton's Advisory Panel Backs Moratorium on Human Clones
description: Trying to tread a fine line between encouraging scientific progress and preventing horrendous abuses of a new technology, a Presidential advisory committee agreed today that there should be a moratorium on the cloning of human beings by public or private institutions.

title: Future Audiences
description: To the Editor:

title: David Armstrong: AT THE BLURRED EDGE OF MEMORY
description: Years ago, as David Armstrong was shooting portraits of friends, he noticed that he was becoming less interested in his subjects than in their blurry surroundings. ''I decided, why not take the person out of the portrait entirely,'' he explains. Interested in making ''an homage'' to a place, Armstrong checked into a Times Square flophouse for four days, filming from his windows by day and roaming the streets at night. ''It was a completely derelict hotel,'' he says. ''Queens and tricks going in and out, hideous furniture covered with cigarette burns, roaches charging out of the radiator.'' Still, it was a fitting place to capture a Times Square that is passing into history. ''It is more ephemeral out of focus,'' he explains. ''I was looking for something I think of as lost.''

title: In 200th Year, County Medical Society Reviews Its Legacy
description: IN 1855, Dr. George Jackson Fisher related to the Westchester County Medical Society an experience he had while delivering a baby: ''The uterus was completely inverted,'' he reported, according to minutes from the society's annual board of directors' meeting that year. ''Attempted to return it but failed. It seemed as if she would die. After I continued gradual pressure, succeeded in returning the womb. She had a usual recovery.''

title: Mobutu's Son Lingers, Reportedly Settling Scores
description: The morning after Zaire's longtime dictator, Mobutu Sese Seko, abandoned power on Friday, it became apparent that he had left behind a surrogate who was ready to act where he was not.

title: On a Bridge, a Dead Police Phone Turns Bad to Worse
description: Strolling across the Brooklyn Bridge during their lunch break on May 8, Elizabeth Rothaus and Kevin Lynch were startled when a young man abruptly handed them a wallet. The two 22-year-old Chase Manhattan Bank employees asked what was going on.

title: For Bosnia, Peace Is Coming Up Empty-Handed
description: Robert W. Farrand, the American diplomat who is this town's international supervisor under the Balkan peace accord, sat in his new office overlooking the Sava River recently talking about peace, brotherly love and tolerance. Down the street, at an outdoor rally to celebrate the Serbian Orthodox patron saint of the town, Bosnian Serb leaders issued calls for vengeance, war and annihilation.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  GUSOFF, GERRY
description: GUSOFF-Gerry. May 17, 1994. Missed immeasurably. Imprinted forever upon our hearts. Ileen

title: Audubon Society Explains Strategy
description: To the Editor:

title: The Loose Brick in the Foundation of Co-op Finance
description: HAPPINESS descends upon the members of a co-op board when it successfully refinances the building's mortgage. So Philip Prince has reason to be pleased just now.

title: B&B;'s: Charms of Homes Away From Homes
description: WITH names like Fields of Dreams and the Pink House, bed and breakfasts of the Hamptons evoke an atmosphere of allure, charm and a home away from home.

title: Kristina Sywolski, Spencer Newman
description: Kristina Jude Sywolski, a daughter of Jane Sywolski of New York and Robert J. Sywolski of Berryville, Va., was married yesterday to Willem Spencer Newman, a son of the late Dr. and Mrs. Henry B. Newman. The Rev. Paul E. Gilbert, an Episcopal priest, officiated at St. John's of Lattingtown in Locust Valley, N.Y.

title: 2 Absent Figures Looming in 'Megan' Trial
description: Two men who are not in the courtroom and are not expected to be -- have nevertheless become figures at the trial of Jesse K. Timmendequas, the man accused of killing 7-year-old Megan Kanka.

title: INSIDE
description: Korean Leader's Son Jailed

title: The Russian Economy: Notes From Underground
description: IF you want to know what is happening in the Russian economy, it helps to think about bread. Government statistics show that people are eating more bread and bakeries are selling less. Or consider vodka. Distillers are able to produce far more vodka than is officially being sold. But given the well-deserved Russian fondness for vodka there is every reason to think the distilleries are operating at full capacity.

title: 'Star Wars' System Remains Many Years and Dollars Away
description: Fourteen years and some $40 billion after President Reagan envisioned a ''Star Wars'' missile defense to shield the United States from nuclear attack, Pentagon officials say a far more modest system is still many years and many billions away.

title: An 'Albanian Hurricane' Blows Through Apulia
description: DONATO MOREA, a tourism official in Apulia, on the heel of Italy's boot, likes to compare the arrival of the Albanians to a hurricane. For as political and economic turmoil in Albania mounted in recent years, tens of thousands of Albanians stormed into this southern Italian region, wreaking occasional havoc on local tourism.

title: A Museum Fights to Survive
description: JUST one month ago, budget cuts were threatening to reduce the Connecticut State Museum of Natural History at the University of Connecticut in Storrs to a sprinkling of display cases around campus. Now there are plans to search for a full-time director and talk of endowments.

title: When Saving for Retirement Comes With the Job
description: COMPANIES have tried almost everything to get employees to sign up for 401(k) plans. They have held seminars, they have cajoled, they have offered matching contributions. Toys ''R'' Us even recruited Geoffrey Giraffe, its mascot, to spur worker interest in the subject.

title: Show Captures Friar's Work In an Elegy of Photographs
description: CONSPICUOUS in the Rockland art scene of the 1980's was Thorpe Intermedia, a gymnasium-size gallery at the Dominican convent in Sparkill. The project was masterminded by Adele Myers, a member of the convent, and the sculptor David Weinrib, and it flourished for about 15 years, presenting exhibitions that were always worth a trip across the Hudson. It closed, in 1990, but only because Sister Adele had decided to concentrate on her own career as a sculptor.

title: Correction
description: The Streetscapes column last Sunday, about the Croton Aqueduct, misstated the location of the restored Octagon House. It is in Irvington, N.Y., not Ardsley.

title: Larry Towell: THE FELT PRESENCE OF AN ABSENCE
description: Larry Towell, 43, who lives on a farm in Ontario, went to the Port Authority Bus Terminal expecting to see ''squalidness and a sense of menace.'' Finding the building sanitized of open crime and homelessness, he gained the confidence of the building's detective squad and was ushered into its detention cell. ''This place radiated the sense of hidden detective work,'' Towell recalls. ''As one officer told me, 'Our job is to hide things.' '' Towell says that the challenge of a documentary photographer is to ''work with what you have, with subjects who are not willing.'' As the detainees at the police holding center were decidedly unwilling, he instead captured the ghostly silhouettes of grease and grime left behind by countless accused felons who had been manacled to a bench there over the years.

title: Is the Lady Dressed? Or Not?
description: To the Editor:

title: Assignment: Times Square
description: The most famous photograph of Times Square is surely Alfred Eisenstaedt's chestnut of the kissing couple, which summed up the national mood in 1945 because it combined all the right elements: the returning soldier, the woman who welcomed him back and Times Square, the crossroads that symbolized home.

title: Oscars for Doorstops
description: WITHOUT LYING DOWN

title: Gee, That's an Odd Name. Ever Think of Acting?
description: IF YOUR NAME IS YOUR destiny, chances are the fates never intended for Uma Thurman, Neve Campbell, Keanu Reeves, Skeet Ulrich, Jada Pinkett, Winona Ryder, Charlize Theron, Mykelti Williamson and Ving Rhames to see their names on a marquee.

title: Tuchih Tsai and Maria Tham
description: Maria Tham, a daughter of Li Mu Fong and Tham Kien Hon of New York, was married yesterday to Dr. Tuchih Tsai, a son of Tsai Syi Chaw of Taipei, Taiwan, and the late Tsai Lin Hsueh Hsia. The Rev. Rees Doughty, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony at the Church of Notre Dame in New York.

title: What Really Happened With Hastings Land
description: To preserve land, should municipalities in Westchester take a cue from Hastings-on-Hudson, as was suggested by County Planning Commissioner Patricia Lynn Oliva (''County's Open Space: The Final Frontier,'' April 20)? The scenario she talked about was the one the county proposed. It is not, however, the scenario that actually happened.

title: At Home In the Fields A Sculptor Called Home
description: IT'S SOMETHING OF A PARADOX that at least three of the principal artists associated with the rise of New York as an art capital after World War II actually left the city to make many of their best-known works: Jackson Pollock and Willem de Kooning left for eastern Long Island and David Smith for Bolton Landing, in the Adirondacks, where he owned a former silver-fox farm.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  BERKOWITZ, KLARFELD
description: BERKOWITZ - KLARFELD - Her man. You almost made it Daddy. Happy 100th Birthday. Love Paula, Bob and David Froh

title: Small Quarters
description: To the Editor: Some advice for those readers planning their summer vacations: Don't believe everything you read in guidebooks.

title: Chuck Close -- NEVER OUT OF CHARACTER
description: Chuck Close, whose oversize portraits have become pop icons, found the idea of working with this season's Broadway stars unsettling. ''I like seeing what I've got and altering it,'' says Close, who worked here with a five-foot-tall camera, the largest mobile Polaroid ever made. ''The sitters are involved in the dialogue from the very beginning. They get off the stool and lobby for a different angle or more flattering lighting. Slowly the two of us work together toward building an image.'' Which means that he had a potential problem: vanity. But, he says, ''I found that in most every case they were easy to work with.'' Because Close began using the camera only as a tool to capture images for his paintings, he feels he brings an oddly unprofessional sensibility to photography. ''I try to engineer into photos the issues I want to work with in paint,'' he explains, ''like using the shadow that glasses cast and accenting wrinkles with lighting.''

title: Surreal
description: Times Square has long represented New York's roiling unconscious, the surreal crossroads of memory and desire. Here is where the lights are hallucinatory, where nostalgia and fantasy pay the rent and where any streetcorner might be a setting for an oxymoron: don't they look strange standing together!

title: Speak Up. There May Be a Bargain in It.
description: Q. A friend says that he rarely buys anything without asking for a discount, and that he's rarely turned down. Could he be exaggerating?

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RUBIN, RUTH
description: RUBIN-Ruth. Beloved wife of the late Jack. Loving mother of June Langbaum, Phyllis (Morris) Rubenfeld and Rochelle Rothbaum. Devoted sister of Dorothy Benofsky and Lillian Fishman. Cherished grandmother of Karen (Arthur) Mazur, Jeffrey Langbaum, Sherry (Kenneth) Grobstein, Mark (Sherry) Rubenfeld, Gail (Jonathan) Hyman, Leslie (Jeffrey) Naschek, Sarah and Michael Rothbaum. Adored great grandmother of Ian and Jessica Mazur, Melissa Naschek, Jane Hyman, Rachel Rubenfeld. We have lost the foundation of our family. She will be greatly missed. Graveside services Sunday, May 18, Beth Moses cemetery, Pinelawn, Long Island, 11:30.

title: Cairo's Subway Boon
description: To the Editor:

title: Syracuse and Princeton Reach Semifinal Round
description: Princeton and Syracuse, the sport's two dominant teams of the 1990's, won their quarterfinal games in the National Collegiate Athletic Association Division I lacrosse tournament today at Hofstra Stadium.

title: Hampton Bays
description: To the west of the Shinnecock Canal is the gateway to the Hamptons, Hampton Bays. The Southampton Town hamlet sits west of the Shinnecock Canal and is known for its groupers.

title: What's Wrong With This Picture?
description: Eagerly, I have signed onto the brand-new Corbis View web site, Bill Gates's on-line window into the fabulous electronic archive of photographs and fine art that he has been buying the rights to, like crazy, for three years. I type in my first search term: Boris Yeltsin. Less than 30 seconds later, a dozen thumbnail shots of the Russian President paint themselves onto my screen. Gee, cool, I say in Billspeak. Not bad for searching through about a million images. I decide to do another search, for President Clinton. Tap, tap, tap. Sure enough, a dozen thumbnail photos paint themselves across my screen. But they're still of Boris Yeltsin. I click on ''Reset'' and try again. Boris Yeltsin. I sign off the Web site and sign on again. Boris Yeltsin. Two days later I try again. You don't want to know.

title: Andrea Cowan, Jeffrey Mark Landes
description: Andrew Lynne Cowan, a daughter of Capt. and Mrs. Robert C. Cowan of Martinez, Calif., was married last evening to Jeffrey Mark Landes, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert N. Landes of New York. Rabbi Richard S. Chapin performed the ceremony at the Grand Hyatt hotel in San Francisco.

title: His Country, Rights and Wrongs
description: IN his newly published legal memoir Frank Askin says: ''I have been involved in trying to influence the development of public policy -- which is, at bottom, the making of law -- in one way or another all of my adult life.''

title: Correction
description: An article on April 6 about the architect Peter Eisenman's design for a new museum and an expansion of the St. George Ferry terminal on Staten Island referred imprecisely to a commission in 1992 for the design of the Whitehall Ferry Terminal in Manhattan. That commission was to Venturi, Scott Brown & Associates and Anderson/Schwartz Architects, not solely to Venturi, Scott Brown. This correction was delayed by editing lapses.

title: Thin With a Pill
description: If the new anti-obesity drug Xenical is approved, as a Food and Drug Administration panel urged last week, does it mean Americans can pig out at McDonald's, then pop a pill to absolve them of their bodily sins?

title: In the Era of the Hitter, There Is Room for Pitchers With Shrinking E.R.A.'s
description: Tim Belcher, veteran pitcher, was talking in spring training about the change in the way earned run averages are seen.

title: Peas and Pancakes, Down to the Source
description: ON any given weekday, one might find 65-year-old Alyce Block putting a vegetable garden in the trunk of her car. It's a big trunk, one that also holds a variety of fish, a cow, an apple tree, eggs, seeds and other components of the Traveling Farm program. Not all, thankfully, life-sized.

title: MARKET TIMING
description: Today

title: Give Me Shelter (Island, That Is)
description: THE Hamptons may have a corner on the big money, the big houses, the big waves and the big celebrities.

title: A Question of Privilege
description: The question whether Government lawyers and public officials can maintain a traditionally confidential lawyer-client relationship is a surprisingly unsettled one that the Supreme Court now has a chance to resolve.

title: Article on Fruit Stands Completes the Picture
description: To the Editor:

title: This Here Toaster's an All-American (Import, That Is, Sort of)
description: FOR 50 years, ''Made in the U.S.A.'' was supposed to mean just that: a product bearing such a label was assembled in the United States from American-made parts.

title: The Knicks May Replay This Forever
description: THE moment haunts Buck Williams. He reviews it in his mind, wondering how he could have stopped four of his impetuous teammates from leaving the bench during a brawl last Wednesday.

title: Of Earthy Humor And Sweet Lyricism
description: IN ''Thunder Knocking on the Door'' at the Yale Repertory Theater in New Haven, Jaguar Dupree is trying to hear the blues just the way his father, Jaguar Dupree Sr., ''the greatest guitar player who never ever recorded,'' played it.

title: Naming Names, Even of the Dead
description: To the Editor:

title: Body Left in Trash Bag, Girl's Grandmother Says
description: As the police searched a city landfill and a Bronx neighborhood yesterday for the body of a kindergartner who had been missing for weeks, the child's grandmother described how she and the girl's mother had wrapped the dead child in blankets and placed her on the sidewalk in a garbage bag about two weeks ago.

title: The Hamptons' Real Estate Market Is Surging
description: THE Hamptons are back.

title: Times Square's New Act
description: THE Times Square of my youth was neither the romantic crossroads of a great city nor a glitzy entertainment destination. It was a scary place of decay that you walked through quickly to get to someplace else, and always with $5 stuffed in your shoe.

title: Mothers, Daughters, China and America
description: THE unwieldy passage of ''The Joy Luck Club'' by Amy Tan from novel (1989) to film (1993) to play (1993, Hong Kong; 1997, New Haven) brings up an obvious question: What for?

title: Less Flying Up Front Means Fewer Ego Trips
description: ROGER A. ENRICO, the chief executive of Pepsico, can do it anytime he wants. Ann D. McLaughlin, the former Labor Secretary, not only does it, she occasionally has General Motors pay for it. Chris Evert won't say whether she does it. And at I.B.M., managers can do it only if they are going to do it for a long time.

title: 'Roseanne' and the Risks of Upward Mobility
description: SOMETIMES THE MOST revealing social statements come in unpretentious guise. ''I wouldn't pay $12.95 for spaghetti if they had Mr. Chef-Boy-Ar-Dee himself in the kitchen,'' Roseanne Conner shrieks to her family during a rare outing at a fancy restaurant. This episode of ''Roseanne'' appeared last year, during that up-and-down phase of the ABC show when the heroine owned a luncheonette; that is, after she stopped working in a factory but before she became a millionaire by winning the lottery.

title: Where Conformity Rules, Misfits Thrive
description: SITTING GLUMLY IN A COFFEE BAR, SIPPING A cafe au lait, Yu Mi Ri does her best to come across as a complete failure in life, so inept that despite several attempts she hasn't succeeded even in killing herself. A high school dropout and former shoplifter, she says she has few friends and is a total misfit.

title: Miss Pagan Duran And Mr. Howard
description: Brenda Pagan Duran, a daughter of Luz Delia Duran of Guaynabo, P.R., and Pedro Angel Pagan of Ponce, P.R., was married yesterday to Robert Howard, a son of Susan Howard and Dr. Clifton Howard of Old Tappan, N.J. Msgr. Rafael Fontanez performed the ceremony at San Jose Church in Guaynabo.

title: Nan Goldin: THE PERSISTENT ID
description: For Nan Goldin, shooting in Times Square's remaining transvestite, transsexual and gay hustler bars was something of a homecoming. ''I was a bartender on 49th Street from 1980 to '85,'' she says. ''I knew the hustlers and the pimps and the prostitutes who came to the bar.'' When she returned recently, however, she saw no familiar faces. ''Those people don't have a long survival rate,'' she says. Goldin calls the virtual abolition of the gay culture in the area a ''rewriting of history,'' but acknowledges that many in the neighborhood support the changes. ''I went to a diner with the drag queens,'' she says. ''The owner called the police and the police came and arrested all the queens on suspicion of prostitution. I hate the destruction of community, and these people really cared for each other.''

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL 3-12

title: More Irish Than Ireland: Learning a Language That's More Than a Brogue
description: Some of the growing numbers of people studying the Irish language -- complex, obscure, nearly useless in business transactions -- remember the reason they were drawn to it. And never was it to further a career, fulfill a college language requirement or order from a menu.

title: Yale Weighs In on Children's Eating Habits
description: PARENTS confused by conflicting dietary information have a new resource to help delineate fact from fiction: ''The Yale Guide to Children's Nutrition,'' Yale University Press.

title: Janice Mac Avoy, Johnson McKelvy
description: Janice Marie Mac Avoy, a lawyer, and Johnson Stoddard McKelvy, a television producer, were married yesterday in East Hampton, N.Y. The Rev. Christine B. R. Grimbol, a Presbyterian minister, officiated at the house of Ina and Jeffrey Garten, friends of the bridegroom's family.

title: East Hampton
description: East Hampton Village is a magnet for the rich and famous. You never know who will be standing next in line at the cinema, strolling down Newtown Lane or seated at the Della Femina restaurant.

title: Saudi Suspect In Canada Hints at Deal With the U.S.
description: A Saudi man who has been detained in Canada in connection with the bombing in Saudi Arabia last year that killed 19 Americans has said he might cooperate with American authorities investigating the case if he is allowed to enter the United States, Government officials said today.

title: NEW YORKERS & CO.
description: British Country Sweaters Return Wearing a New Label

title: Books in Brief: Fiction
description: MORVERN CALLAR By Alan Warner. Anchor, paper, $12.

title: Ms. Barcikowski and Mr. Graham
description: Nicole Marie Barcikowski, a daughter of Dr. Robert Barcikowski of Athens, Ohio, and the late Elizabeth Barcikowski, was married yesterday to Timothy Barry Graham, a son of Ellen Bell of Huntington, N.Y., and the late Maj. Barry F. Graham. The Rev. William Bergen performed the Roman Catholic ceremony at St. Ignatius Loyola Church in New York.

title: Have You Heard the One About Cain and Abel?
description: NO NEW JOKES

title: City of Angels In a Lower Key
description: FROM Universal Studios in the north to Disneyland in the south, from the beaches of Santa Monica on the west to the San Gabriel Mountains on the east, the marquee attractions of greater Los Angeles are as plain as the points of the compass. No one needs a road map to find the Magic Kingdom of Mickey and Minnie; just follow the crowds.

title: Elissa Rosenzweig And Jason Novick
description: Elissa Beth Rosenzweig, a daughter of Suzanne and Victor M. Rosenzweig of Chappaqua, N.Y., is to be married today to Jason Brett Novick, the son of Paula Levine of New York and the late Steven J. Novick. Rabbi Judith R. Schindler is to perform the ceremony at the Mamaroneck (N.Y.) Beach and Yacht Club.

title: Lawmakers Lay Foundation for Compromise on Rent Rules
description: While it is far from clear that state lawmakers will be able to reach a deal on rent regulations before the current laws expire on June 15, they are privately discussing ways out of the impasse, including an end to protections for wealthy tenants, a limited system of deregulation and a major construction program to ease the housing shortage.

title: Q. & A.
description: Stabilized Rent Rise Still Rising

title: The New India
description: LOVE AND LONGING

title: Montauk
description: Montauk is a mystical, magical place. Fifteen miles down the Napeague stretch and you are a far cry from the ritz and glitz of the Hamptons. No velvet ropes, movie premieres, fancy art openings or benefits..

title: Send Money, Court Says; Bootstraps Aren't Enough
description: Often when political conservatives are trying to show that we live in a society in which everyone has a fair chance, they love to trot out examples of people who defied the odds to achieve enormous success. There is the black kid who grew up fatherless and dirt poor in rural Georgia but went on to become a Supreme Court justice. Or the Bronx native and son of immigrant parents who rose to lead the country's armed forces.

title: Coast Guard's Eagle, Paint and Polish Fresh, Heading Out
description: ON a sunny weekday morning earlier this month, Capt. Robert J. Papp was going over some last minute details for getting the barque Eagle ready for its 50th annual training cruise out of the Coast Guard Academy in New London, when his telephone rang. A retired Coast Guard captain was on the pier alongside and wondered if he could come aboard the Eagle, and, by the way, he had a tour group of 25 with him. Captain Papp brought the group on, and discovered they were from Allentown, Pa. ''Really -- my wife is from Wilkes-Barre,'' Captain Papp said with a grin, instantly putting them at ease. He launched into a brief history of the sailing ship Eagle, from the time it was seized from the Germans at the end of World War II, to its upcoming trip to Europe.

title: A Suspect at Large
description: Almost everywhere he has gone in the last two and half weeks, Andrew Phillip Cunanan is suspected of leaving behind another dead man, who had either been beaten, stabbed or shot to death, including a wealthy real estate developer in Chicago and the caretaker of a New Jersey cemetery.

title: Let the Games Begin?
description: Summer, that glorious season when many of us take our vacations, is just around the corner. Even our bosses take time off. And when they do, the atmosphere around the office itself can become vacation-like. If the boss isn't there to see how hard I'm working, the thinking goes, why work so hard? What happens in your office when the boss goes on vacation? Send your best stories to On the Job, Money and Business, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036. Or send them by E-mail to onthejob@nytimes.com. Include your telephone number. All submissions become the property of The Times and may be republished in any medium.

title: 4-Wheel Drive for Easy Street
description: START with the name: when you refer to the 1997 Infiniti QX4, the first sport utility vehicle from the luxury division of Nissan, Infiniti does not want you to say ''Q times 4'' as if it were an algebraic equation. Nor is it the letter Q, letter X, 4. The correct rendering is ''Q by 4,'' as in 4-by-4, the shorthand for four-wheel drive.

title: Quogue, Remsenburg and Quiogue
description: Quogue is quaint and quiet, but Remsenburg is even more so. These are perfect towns to bike around in. Retreat to the Inn at Quogue on Quogue Street. Check out the carnivorous pitcher plants at the Quogue Wildlife Refuge.

title: Adrienne Cowen, M. F. Zammiello
description: Adrienne Debra Cowen, a daughter of Lesley J. Cowen and Edward S. Cowen of New York, was married last evening at the Essex House in New York to Michael Frank Zammiello, the son of Maria A. Zammiello and Frank J. Zammiello of Cranston, R.I. Rabbi Charles D. Lippman performed the ceremony, and the Rev. Gary Seibert, a Roman Catholic priest, took part in the service.

title: Sophie Malecki And Lee Dichter
description: Sophie Ruth Malecki is to be married today to Lee Steven Dichter. Rabbi Charles D. Lippman is to perform the ceremony at Tappan Hill in Tarrytown, N.Y.

title: Patricia Shedd, Kevin Higgins
description: Patricia Anna Shedd, a daughter of Patricia Truxell Shedd of Vero Beach, Fla., and the late William G. T. Shedd Jr., was married yesterday to Kevin John Higgins, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Kevin Higgins of Wilton, Conn. The Rev. M. Joseph Joaquin performed the ceremony at the Roman Catholic Church of the Sacred Heart in Georgetown, Conn. The Rev. Jeffrey L. Kittredge, an Episcopal priest and the bride's godfather, took part in the service.

title: Pondering Tiger, Deep Blue and Players Who Care
description: One great byproduct of the Knicks and Rangers going all the way would be that they would shove Tiger Woods off our radar screens for a while. Those constant blips were making me see things: ''Tiger: The Early Years,'' ''Putting with Amadeus,'' and ''I Am Tiger Woods'' by Norman Mailer.

title: Lore of Hudson River Is Alive in a Fisherman
description: When Henry Gourdine was a boy, his mother made him wear a red dress so he would not run off with his friends down to the banks of the Hudson River.

title: The Lights Are Much Brighter
description: IT was the perfect place for pie in the sky. When the Lower Manhattan Cultural Council honored Joe Baum and David Emil, the owners of Windows on the World, at its fund-raiser on Thursday night, the city 106 stories below glittered like Oz, and the candles and cake were carved in the shape of fantasy buildings. Even the tablecloths were covered with clouds.

title: Amy Gamerman And Kevin Conley
description: Amy Gamerman and Kevin Conley, who are both writers in New York, are to be married today in Guilford, Conn., at the home of the bride's parents, Martha and Ken Gamerman. Rabbi Robert B. Lennick is to perform the ceremony.

title: Suzanne Frerecks, Philip Clifford
description: Suzanne Serina Frerecks, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Eyvind N. Frerecks of Westfield, N.J., was married there yesterday to Philip Francis Clifford, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Clifford of Larchmont, N.Y. The Rev. Roger H. Ard performed the ceremony at St. Paul's Episcopal Church.

title: Who Wrote the Book of Love? Marivaux
description: THE playwright is Marivaux; the adapter and director is Stephen Wadsworth. Mavens know they go together the way love and marriage should.

title: Corrections
description: The Word for Word column last Sunday, with excerpts from documents describing the financial relationship between Switzerland and Nazi Germany, misstated the circumstances of an episode in World War II. The code used by the German-built ''Enigma'' encoding machine was broken by a British team led by the mathematician Alan Turing, not by the United States.

title: How Los Angeles Traffic Snarls Spawned a Word
description: Each weekday morning in the City of Angels, the realm where the car is still king, the rat-a-tat-tat of traffic reports crackles over car radios every six minutes in a jumble of jackknifed big rigs, three-car pileups and stop-and-go rubberneckers.

title: William Fearon, Yvonne Karanas
description: Dr. Yvonne Louise Karanas, the daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Arthur Karanas of New York, was married yesterday to Dr. William Fuller Fearon, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Richard E. Fearon of Woodbridge, Conn. The Rev. Dr. Robert G. Stephanopoulos performed the ceremony at the Greek Orthodox Cathedral of the Holy Trinity in New York. The Rev. Dr. H. Dana Fearon 3d, a Presbyterian minister and the uncle of the bridegroom, took part in the service.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PARTIKIAN, JOYCE S.
description: PARTIKIAN-Joyce S. At the age of 63 on May 12, 1997. A native of Massapequa, L.I. and resident of NYC and Massapequa. Friend and a Joy to many. Wife of Edwin, mother of David and Drew, twin sister of Joan. Celebration of Life Service at the Unitarian Church of All Souls, 1157 Lexington Avenue (at 80th street), NYC, on Thursday, May 22 at 7:00 P.M. Memorial contributions in the spirit of her giving can be made to the NYU Radiology Post Graduate Fund (NYU School of Medicine, 550 First Avenue, New York City 10016) or the American Heart Association.

title: Richard E. Carlton, 57; Defended Kodak
description: Richard E. Carlton, a lawyer who defended the Eastman Kodak Company in a landmark patent infringement case, died of a heart attack last Sunday while on vacation in Bath, England. He was 57.

title: The Plaque's the Thing, but How Tall Are the Letters?
description: Throughout New York City, there are plaques -- large and small, in parks, playgrounds and church windows, on benches and even on the backs of orchestra seats -- immortalizing the names of philanthropic New Yorkers in stone, bronze and cast iron.

title: When the Lyrics Go Bad, the Needle Always Sticks
description: ''DAVE BARRY'S BOOK OF BAD SONGS'' comes with a warning: ''Do not read this book. It will put bad songs into your brain.'' And so it will. It will instantly evoke lyrics like:

title: Smoky Cruise
description: To the Editor: On March 16, I boarded Royal Caribbean's Song of America in San Pedro, Calif., for a seven-day cruise to the Mexican Riviera. The ship is beautiful and the personnel outstanding, especially the recreation director and his staff.

title: Books in Brief: Nonfiction
description: Questions of Heaven The Chinese Journeys of an American Buddhist. By Gretel Ehrlich. Beacon, $20.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ENGEL, MARGORIE
description: ENGEL-Margorie. The Seawane Club records with sorrow the loss of our beloved member Margorie Engel. We extend heartfelt sympathy to her husband Philip and the family. Robert Roman, President

title: Who You Calling Mellow?
description: One of George M. Steinbrenner's most valued possessions -- acceptance by his fellow baseball owners -- was shattered when the Yankee owner's entrepreneurial zeal led to harsh sanctions and the loss of a seat on the owners' executive council.

title: Elizabeth Rocchio, David Candow
description: Elizabeth Marie Rocchio, the daughter of Mary Beth and Thomas E. Rocchio of Huntington, N.Y., was married there yesterday to David Lawrence Candow, the son of Valerie and Scott R. Candow of Placentia, Calif. The Rev. James Byrum performed the ceremony at St. John's Episcopal Church.

title: Celebrating Solitude, a Bike Takes You to Where You Choose
description: EVERY Friday as the Long Island Expressway and the Long Island Rail Road pour people into the South Fork, I worry about the container's being filled with more than it can contain. Each visit to downtown East Hampton or Sag Harbor compounds those fears -- picking up a six-pack and some charcoal briquets suddenly requires strategy -- but then I get on my bicycle and things begin to feel considerably more spacious.

title: Trivia Quiz: Debuts and Quick Departures
description: Chances are that if you blinked you missed some of the mid-season replacement shows. The networks have less patience than ever in giving fledgling programs an opportunity. New series used to be yanked after six episodes, then three, and now after just one airing. Two of the new series below are already defunct, and a third, ''EZ Streets,'' died a second uneasy death and was replaced by ''Walker, Texas Ranger'' on CBS.

title: The Modern Dramatist's Secret Weapon
description: WHOSE JOB IS IT TO decide what a play means? In the collaborative art of theater, responsibilities can blur. While playwrights write and directors direct, the gray area of ''interpretation'' lies somewhere between. In addition to actors and designers, even playbill authors and poster illustrators eventually help transform a play's originating idea.

title: 'Titanic' Adds Another Feather to His Cap
description: NEVER let it be said that Peter Stone shies away from the big subjects. In a Broadway season packed with new musicals, ''Titanic,'' for which Mr. Stone wrote the book, dwarfs the competition in bulk, weight, height and cost. The big gets the big treatment onstage, with 43 named parts, a budget of $10 million and an attention to historical detail that betrays Mr. Stone's hand.

title: Jetliner Is Bombed in Test to Counter Terrorism in the Air
description: With a flash and a boom that sent the back half of a jumbo jet leaping into the air on this old air base about 90 miles north of London, British and American military experts set off four bombs inside the front and rear cargo holds of an old Boeing 747. The experts were testing new hardening techniques that American security officials say are the best hope for protecting planes against bombs.

title: Read This, It's Good for You
description: A BEDTIME STORY By Mem Fox. Illustrated by Elivia Savadier. Unpaged. Greenvale, N.Y.: Mondo Publishing. $13.95. (Ages 5 to 9)

title: Elizabeth Corrigan, Karl Beinkampen
description: Elizabeth Anne Corrigan, a daughter of Linda Barlow of Hartsdale, N.Y., and E. Gerald Corrigan of New York, was married yesterday to Karl Newberry Beinkampen, the son of Joan S. Beinkampen and Charles N. Beinkampen of Mendenhall, Pa. The Rev. Charles J. Minifie performed the Episcopal ceremony at Christ Church in Bronxville, N.Y.

title: Devon Field, Michael Pastor
description: Devon Dana Field, the daughter of Mrs. James F. Curtis of Far Hills, N.J., and Richard D. Field of New Canaan, Conn., was married yesterday to Michael Bret Pastor, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Gerald R. Pastor of Englewood, Colo. The Rev. Lidabell Lunt Pollard performed the ceremony at the Congregational Church in New Canaan.

title: Connie Lee and Leonard Li
