description: Dr. Connie Ka Yee Lee, a pharmacist, and Dr. Leonard Lun Kang Li, a surgeon, were married yesterday in Bayside, Queens. The Rev. Dr. Paul Szto, a Christian Reformed minister, performed the ceremony at the Colonial Church of Bayside.

title: Competitors' Scores Drop, but Archer Keeps Classic Lead
description: The wind disappeared across the Hudson River this morning, and the golf scores got remarkably lower today at the $950,000 Cadillac-N.F.L. Classic at the Upper Montclair Country Club.

title: Sweeping Away A Tax-Rate Mirage
description: To the Editor:

title: Charles Henry Bendheim, 79; Industrialist Aided Jewish Causes
description: Charles Henry Bendheim, an industrialist and a supporter of Jewish causes and organizations in New York and Israel, died on May 5 at his home in Jerusalem. A former resident of Manhattan's West Side, he was 79 and also had homes in the Bronx and in Long Beach, N.Y.

title: A Young Generation
description: To the Editor:

title: ALSO INSIDE
description: F.Y.I. 2

title: Bonds May Be Just the Port In the Storm of Uncertainty
description: EXPECTATIONS are widespread that the Federal Reserve will again raise interest rates, perhaps as soon as Tuesday. But most investment advisers expect higher rates to do more damage to stock than to bond prices.

title: Strasbourg
description: Centuries of being argued over by France, which it is now part of, and Germany, which it has belonged to at various times, have left lovely little Strasbourg resolutely French in spirit but quaintly Germanic in dialect and, occasionally, esthetics. Now the city is spinning a positive approach to 2,000 years of embattlement. Encouraged because the Council of Europe and the European Court of Human Rights are based here and the European Parliament holds half of its assemblies here, Strasbourg would like to be thought of as the capital of Europe.

title: Nicholas Williams, Diana Davis
description: Diana Elizabeth Davis and Nicholas David Gwyn Williams were married yesterday at the Royal Geographical Society in London. Alison Cathcart, the Westminster superintendent registrar, officiated.

title: The Real Drama In Opera Lies Behind the Scenes
description: ''THE ROYAL OPERA HOUSE,'' BBC television's fly-on-the-wall inspection of daily life at London's Covent Garden, tells us that art is made not necessarily, or even often, by heroes in garrets but instead by people engaged in dirty, sweaty, nerve-racking jobs. The people in question, as we have been observing in weekly installments on PBS running through June 12, are of varying intelligence, uneven esthetic judgment, sometimes dubious morals and fairly equal parts courage and cowardice.

title: Author Questions Cancellation of '20/20' Report
description: ABC News management abruptly canceled a report about abuses by Congress that was scheduled to be broadcast on its news magazine program ''20/20'' on Friday night, and one participant in the report contended that the network had acted out of fear of alienating members of Congress.

title: Bill Would Separate Men and Women in Basic Training
description: With sex scandals breaking out all over the military, legislation to segregate men and women in basic training is gaining momentum in the House.

title: Alexandra Edsall And Robert Victor
description: Alexandra Harding Tileston Edsall, who was until last week a special assistant to the Deputy Attorney General, was married last evening to Robert Salomon Victor, a management consultant in Washington with the Boston Consulting Group. Rabbi Harold White officiated at the Meridian House in Washington.

title: Pamela McGreevy and Dan Newman
description: Pamela Paine McGreevy and Jeffrey Daniel Newman are to be married today at the Episcopal Church of St. Luke in the Fields in New York. The bride's mother, the Rev. Molly Paine McGreevy, who is the associate rector of St. Francis Episcopal Church in North Stamford, Conn., is to officiate. Rabbi Joseph Gelberman is to take part in the ceremony.

title: Fatal Attraction
description: INTO THIN AIR A Personal Account of the Mount Everest Disaster. By Jon Krakauer. Illustrated. 293 pp. New York: Villard Books. $24.95.

title: Southampton
description: A boulder at Conscience Point bears the inscription ''Near this spot in June, 1640, landed the Colonists from Lynn, Mass., who founded Southampton, the first English settlement in the state of New York.''

title: Mitch Epstein: THE LAST SEATS IN THE HOUSE
description: ''The challenge is to use photography in a way that can elevate the everyday,'' says Mitch Epstein, a 44-year-old New Yorker who is best known for a series of photographs evoking the conflict between custom and progress in India and Vietnam. After visiting a new virtual-reality arcade (which he says epitomizes the way Times Square is ''turning into a place like so many others in America, a generic fantasy landscape''), Epstein felt a great sense of sadness. In abandoned 42d Street theaters, he manipulated lights set up by demolition workers to create theatrical tableaus: ''I felt electrified by the decay. They were very dramatic, beautiful stage sets still in their own rights.''

title: Reviving Polluted 'Brown Fields' for New Industrial Use
description: Hundreds of urban acres that now lie dormant in Jersey City and Perth Amboy will soon be crawling with environmental engineers and local residents hoping to revitalize what heavy industry has spoiled.

title: Lariam
description: To the Editor: ''Warding Off Malaria'' (Practical Traveler, April 20) was a timely reminder that this disease is on the increase. But it downplayed the toxicity of mefloquine, or Lariam, the antimalarial recommended by the United States Centers for Disease Control and Prevention.

title: Real
description: Beneath the glitz and the greasepaint is a Times Square of hard work and hard knocks. A hit show means eight performances in six days, and that, as veteran actors and actresses will tell you, builds character. Raising girders takes strength and skill. Performing in a sex club is not for the thin-skinned. And there is no place lonelier than a 42d Street subway platform at 2 A.M. Realism is a plain-spoken esthetic, and the photographers who employ it take there subjects straight on. The pictures here are by no means all gritty or bleak. But all are faithful to the truths experienced daily by the denizens of Times Square.

title: Pathogens of Glory
description: VIRUS HUNTER

title: ON THE TOWNS
description: An opinionated guide to cultural and recreational goings-on around the state this week. To submit items for consideration, write to On the Towns, Sunday New Jersey Section, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036, or send a fax to (212) 556-7219.

title: Giorgia Fiorio: WORKERS RISING
description: For Giorgia Fiorio, a 29-year-old Italian based in Paris, shooting a group of Times Square construction workers was a natural step in her series on ''closed communities of men.'' (Previous subjects have included a boxer's training camp, the French Foreign Legion and bullfighters in Spain). Fiorio says she is drawn to groups ''with great traditions and codes and rules.'' While construction workers are in one sense the living embodiments of progress, they are also ''a social group that doesn't change even as the world changes.'' Fiorio often has her subjects pose for her or repeat actions so they can ''become the star of their own life movie'' -- an approach that may bend the rules of photojournalism but one that helps her bring out the ''image of the body and the strength of physicality -- it is what affirms life and eats it up.''

title: For Junior Achievers, Volunteers Are Key
description: ALL the emphasis recently focused on the importance of volunteers comes as no surprise to Junior Achievement, the organization that has been relying on volunteers for 78 years. Since Junior Achievement's founding in 1919, its partnerships with volunteers in the business community have been a major strength.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FRIEDEL, IRVING
description: FRIEDEL-Irving. Beloved husband, father, grandfather, great grandfather, uncle and great uncle. Survived by his wife of 65 years, Dora; loving children, Celia & Charles Reiner, Dr. Walter and Dorothy Friedel; caring grandfather of the late Michael Reiner; and Eric, Rose and Donald Reiner, Evan, Erika, Jay, and Gregory Friedel; great grandfather to Daniel Reiner. Cherished by Bernard, Myra, Debbie, Mitchell, Monica, Nina, Dr. Evan Fox, Gary and Nina Cowen and all their children plus many other loving nieces and nephews of the Friedel family. Funeral service Sunday, May 18, 1:30 PM, Riverside Chapel, Mt. Vernon, NY. Interment Mt Hebron Cemetery. Shiva at the residence.

title: Julius Dintenfass, 86, Chiropractic Leader
description: Dr. Julius Dintenfass, a chiropractor who was instrumental in the licensing of chiropractors in New York State, died on May 8 at Columbia Northwest Hospital in Coconut Creek, Fla., where he had a vacation home. He was 86.

title: When the Enemy of a Friend Is You
description: IF anyone needed a reminder to what depths Israeli-Palestinian relations have sunk, the recent murder of an Arab real estate dealer accused of selling land to Jews recalled patterns of hostility thought to have faded in an era of peace.

title: Rookie Fits With Line Of Doom
description: Other than a small patch of stubble on his chin, there is not much else to reveal that Dainius Zubrus, the Philadelphia Flyers' rookie right wing, is only 18 years old.

title: Renee Klock, James Severin 3d
description: Renee Melanie Klock, a writer and editor in Sag Harbor, N.Y., was married there yesterday to James Thompson Severin 3d, a political consultant in New York. The Rev. Christine Rannie Grimbol performed the ceremony at the Old Whalers First Presbyterian Church.

title: Study Abroad On the Rise
description: BESIEGED with exams and spring fever, college students yearn to be out. It is a likely season for the idea of a semester or a year abroad, possibly in Bora Bora, to take root in underclass minds. And colleges support such dreams, as an asset to graduates' employability and to ease pressure on dormitories.

title: Corrections
description: The biographical note on a review of ''Between Worlds: The Autobiography of Leo Lionni'' on page 13 of the Book Review today misstates the subtitle of the forthcoming book by the reviewer, Bruce McCall. Its full title is ''Thin Ice: Coming of Age in Canada.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FIELD, FLORENCE (NEE ENGEL)
description: FIELD-Florence (nee Engel). On Saturday, May 17, of Union. Beloved wife of Irving Field. Devoted mother of Dr. Steven Field. Dear sister of Evelyn Goldstein and Roslyn Lieberman. Funeral services conducted from the Menorah Chapels at Millburn, 2950 Vauxhall Rd, Union, NJ, on Sunday, May 18, at 1 PM. Interment Mt. Lebanon Cemetery, Iselin.

title: F.Y.I.
description: Current Affairs

title: Trinity School: Gyms Upstairs and Down
description: Landmark though it is, both historically and architecturally, Trinity School remains a bit of a jumble. Half of the middle-school grades are housed in the lower-school building, half in the upper-school building. And when all three schools try to schedule time in one gymnasium -- well, you get the idea.

title: Denise Spatafora, Edward Bohlke 3d
description: Denise Vicki Spatafora, the owner of Calabria, a floral design company in New York, is to be married today to Edward Harold Bohlke 3d, the owner of Empathic Development, a technology consulting company in New York. Costantino Federico, the Mayor of Capri, off the Italian coast, is to officiate at sea.

title: On the Stage, Talent Pairs With Pride To Meet A Challenge
description: THE man, stooped and no longer young, sat in a chair. He took the hand of the woman he loved and, looking into her eyes, sang with a passion that echoed through the ages.

title: Exit the Interborough
description: MY feelings about the Interborough Parkway's being renamed in Jackie Robinson's honor are decidedly mixed. While Robinson deserves every kind of tribute, I'm afraid that the Jackie Robinson Parkway will prove more popular than the drably named Interborough. This road is a secret shared by a doughty few. It's New York's least-trafficked major artery, rarely jammed even in rush hour. Shadow Traffic rarely mentions it. I've had cab drivers who didn't know where it was. Their loss is my delight.

title: Zaire's Leader Leaves His Country to Rebels
description: Mobutu Sese Seko slipped quietly out of Kinshasa Friday in a prelude to exile after nearly 32 years as President of Africa's third-largest country.

title: Haluk Aydin, Katherine Dempsey
description: Katherine Bridget Dempsey, a daughter of Eileen and Edward J. Dempsey of Avon, Conn., was married yesterday to Haluk Kaya Aydin, a son of Gulsen and Mehmet Aydin of Izmir, Turkey. Commissioner John H. Treanor Jr. of the District of Columbia Superior Court performed a civil ceremony at the Army and Navy Club in Washington. A Roman Catholic ceremony was held later at Dahlgren Chapel of the Sacred Heart at Georgetown University in Washington. Deacon Timothy F. Dempsey, an uncle of the bride, officiated.

title: Mortgages In Smaller Co-ops
description: A BORROWER'S ability to get a mortgage usually depends on three factors: the borrower's financial condition -- an indication of his ability to make monthly payments; his credit history -- an indication of whether those payments are likely to be made on time; and the value of the property being mortgaged -- an indication of the lender's protection in case the decision to grant the mortgage based on the first two factors was wrong.

title: Raising Good Bread, the Old-Fashioned Way
description: The menu says Bread and Beyond, but it takes some doing to get beyond the bread.

title: Burled, Shimmering or Plain: Wood and Ceramics in Their Glory
description: MIKE MENDELSON, a clothing manufacturer in New York, retired in 1984 when he was 60 years old. ''I had all kinds of hobbies,'' he said, ''collecting antique furniture, paintings and crafts. I was a photographer, a world traveler and liked puttering. I thought I was going to love it. I was wrong. I hated retirement.''

title: Thomas Demand: SEX AT A CERTAIN REMOVE
description: Comparing his art to a carwash, the German artist Thomas Demand says, ''I try to redo a photograph in a way that is free of the connotations of where it has been.'' To perform this ritual cleansing, Demand reconstructs scenes to scale from mass-media photographs in his Berlin studio using colored cardboard (and, in this case, a balloon as light bulb). Demand never got within 3,000 miles of Times Square but was inspired by the bare bulb in the corner of an ''otherwise bland'' news photograph of a Times Square massage parlor. He created a ''nonsexual version of sex, a photograph that could be as easily titled 'Parlor' as 'Massage Parlor.' '' But the image is not entirely sanitized: ''You look at it and you know what it is, although such things don't fit into the family picture of the new Times Square. The actual practice of sex is gone, but the memory of it is still there.''

title: BEST SELLERS: May 18, 1997
description: Weeks

title: Books in Brief: Fiction
description: Sunrise Shows Late By Eva Mekler. Bridge Works, $21.95.

title: Keep Banks Out of Corporate Claws
description: ONCE again Congress is being asked to approve legislation that would allow nonfinancial corporations to own and control commercial banks. If approved, this would eventually be harmful to all Americans because it would undermine the very essence of a democratic and competitive economy.

title: When It Comes to Take-Out, Markets Expand to Fill Need
description: THE Hamptons have long been blessed with some wonderful sources for high-quality foods. Simple fishermen's markets sell seafood from nearby waters, farm stands overflow with produce in season and charming little catering shops fill orders for salads and cocktail party fare. But the food shopping scene is changing.

title: 20 Years of Celebrating the Dances of Africa
description: TWENTY dance and music companies will return to the Brooklyn Academy of Music for the 20th anniversary of Chuck Davis's Dance Africa, making it the largest festival of African-American dance in the United States.

title: Conspiracy Theories Over a Cup Of Joe
description: COFFEE the correct response to ''Clinton re-election'' in the word association game here -- is rising alarmingly in price. As the President searches for his place in history, any voter with a modicum of candor can tell him, why it's right over there by the espresso machine. His official portraitist could do worse than to depict Mr. Clinton beaming authoritatively while sprinkling a soupcon of cinnamon atop the creamy head of a fat cat's double cappuccino at one of the now-fabled $200,000 coffees organized for his campaign donors last year.

title: Singing Wagner With an Ease Born of Hard Work
description: JANE EAGLEN SINGS LIKE A FORCE OF NATURE. Many singers have voices that are sweet and clear; a few have voices that are large. But it is rare to find those qualities combined in a single artist, and the voice of Ms. Eaglen, a fast-rising English soprano, is both beautiful and huge, with lovely color and a distinctive ringing tone.

title: Dream or Nightmare: It Depends on Game 7
description: The Knicks hoped it would never come to this. They have a Game 7 today in Miami. They have two key players, John Starks and Larry Johnson, who will be serving suspensions, unable to help. They have one game to save their season.

title: Mickey Mouse's Voice
description: To the Editor:

title: In Films by Women, the Women Are Where the Action Is
description: THREE WOMEN PILE INTO a convertible and head for Las Vegas to find disposable husbands. Two 15-year-old girls, fraternal twins, run away together to create their own private paradise in Kentucky. Three adult sisters drive off in a succession of stolen cars to visit a famous Texas sculpture and solve a 20-year-old family puzzle.

title: This Museum Exhibit Is a Laughing Matter
description: ''Let There be Laughter! Jewish Humor in America,'' an interactive exhibition, is on display at the Spertus Museum in Chicago through Aug. 17. The exhibition uses more than 400 artifacts, including photos and dozens of radio, television and movie clips, revisiting classics from vaudeville, Broadway, film and the Borscht Belt. One theme explored is how performers like the Marx Brothers and Eddie Cantor brought Jewish humor into the mainstream.

title: Father May Know Best, but Who's the Father?
description: Fathers' Day

title: Atlantic City Lighthouse Expected to Shine Again
description: When the Absecon Lighthouse was opened in 1857 at the north end of Atlantic City, it also became a tourist attraction and a symbol of the resort. In recent years, neglected and badly in need of repair, it became a symbol of decline instead. Last week, work began on restoring the lighthouse to its glory days, when visitors lined up to climb its 228 steps.

title: From Hoop Skirt to Slam Dunk Chic
description: THE first organized women's basketball game was held at Smith College in 1892. Signs were posted outside the gymnasium: MEN ARE NOT PERMITTED TO WATCH . And the hoopsters wore long dresses.

title: Jennifer Rotanz, Bruce Strikowsky
description: Jennifer Mary Rotanz, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert J. Rotanz of Watchung, N.J., was married yesterday to Bruce Michael Strikowsky, a son of Mr. and Mrs. George Strikowsky of Pomona, N.Y. Judge Wilfred J. Diana of Somerset County Superior Court officiated at the Plainfield Country Club in Edison, N.J.

title: 18,000 Bottles Under the Gavel
description: THE vintage Bentley, donated to the Conservative Party, was the first to go. Then the six-story London town house was put on the market for about $24 million. And next week, the newly ennobled Andrew Lloyd Webber plans to divest 18,000 bottles of wine, the bulk of his collection.

title: Fly-Fishing's Niche in Central Park
description: When Sara Low was growing up in Rhode Island, her father taught her to fish with a spinning rod. A few years ago, she took up the graceful, demanding sport of fly-fishing. Ms. Low, who is a senior account executive with an entertainment advertising firm, lives within walking distance of Central Park but never thought of it as fertile fishing ground. Last Tuesday morning, Edwin Valentin proved her wrong.

title: For Some, Pensions Still Find Ways to Disappear
description: WHEN Vincent Russo of Forest Hills, Queens, retired in 1993 after 31 years as an insurance agent for the New York Life Insurance Company, he expected a secure future, with money coming in every month from two company pensions. But three years after he left work, New York Life reduced the monthly payments on one of his pensions, contending that he no longer deserved the money.

title: Ethel Heins, 79, Editor of Journal That Reviews Books for Children
description: Ethel Leah Heins, a specialist in books for young readers, died on May 8 at Newton-Wellesley Hospital in Newton, Mass. She was 79, and lived in Newton.

title: CYBERSCOUT
description: A GUIDE WITH LEGS

title: Splash
description: A Drop of Water

title: Now Sailing From Houston: Passengers
description: Houston will become a home port for cruise ships on May 25 when the Norwegian Star begins cruises from Texas to the western Caribbean, calling at Cozumel and the Yucatan Peninsula port of Calica in Mexico and Roatan in the Bay Islands of Honduras.

title: Impeach Those Liberal Judges! Where Are They?
description: AS Congressional Republicans waged an intense and nonstop campaign against what they depict as an overly activist Federal judiciary, a remarkable but little-noted event occurred.

title: A Time to Open Up the C.I.A.
description: The editor of The San Jose Mercury News writes that his newspaper's reporting last year of a link between the C.I.A. and the introduction of crack cocaine into Los Angeles in the 1980's was flawed. This admission has elicited pious editorial commentary about the courage of The Mercury News in acknowledging error while reaffirming the value of investigative reporting of alleged governmental misconduct.

title: Europe's New Order: Making a Club, Not War
description: WITH Germany mobilizing for war in September 1938, the British Prime Minister, Neville Chamberlain, told his nation in a fateful radio broadcast that as ''a man of peace'' he had no stomach for war in Czechoslovakia -- ''in a faraway country,'' as he put it, ''between people of whom we know nothing.''

title: Making a Mystery: The New Deep Blue
description: In 15 months of work, which began almost immediately after Garry Kasparov defeated the I.B.M. chess computer Deep Blue in their first match, an I.B.M. team doubled the computer's calculating power and took Deep Blue to ''chess school,'' teaching it tricks that grandmasters would be proud of and that would so flummox Mr. Kasparov that he questioned its very soul.

title: Windmills From Eras Past Instill a Sense of Tradition
description: LONG ISLAND is said to be home to more historic windmills than any other part of the country, and most of them are on the East End. Picturesque reminders of the area's New England ancestry, they embody the spirit of a pre-industrial age, before continuous power from steam, gasoline and electricity replaced the unreliable wind.

title: A Bid to Ban Abortion
description: Democrats in the Senate who support abortion rights failed last week to head off the certain passage this week of a bill to ban what abortion opponents call ''partial birth abortion.''

title: Without a Parachute
description: THE CLIFF WALK

title: Let Greece Have the Marbles
description: One of the oldest international cultural disputes has begun a new turn under Prime Minister Tony Blair's victorious Laborites. Scarcely a day after taking office, Britain's new Heritage Secretary, Chris Smith, informed a BBC interviewer that the Labor Government would not return the Elgin Marbles to their ancient and rightful home in Athens.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCSHANE, EILEEN
description: McSHANE-Eileen. On May 11, 1997. Graduate of the College of Mt. St. Vincent. Retired teacherNew York City School System. Longtime member Seton Literary Circle. Beloved daughter of the late Susan and Edward. Dear sister of the late Edward. Loving aunt of James, Michael, Clay and Peter and the late Edward and Frank. Mass of Christian burial, on Tuesday, 11 A.M., St. Philip Neri Church. John J. Fox and Sons, Inc., 203 East 201st Street, Bronx 10458.

title: Absolution Could Be at Hand For Ex-Governor of Alabama
description: The battered megaphone at Guy Hunt's creaky electric security gate was silent, and the tall flagpoles outside his rural house here were rusting and flagless.

title: Women's Health Stocks Try to Be Darling Again
description: THELMA BAKER has a common complaint when it comes to looking after her health.

title: Karen Portugal And Brett Whiton
description: Karen Meg Portugal, the daughter of Helen and Joel Portugal of New York, and Brett Joseph Whiton, a son of Elyse and Kenneth Whiton of North Bellmore, N.Y., are to be married today in New York. Dr. Ronald B. Sobel, the senior rabbi of Temple Emanu-El in New York, is to perform the ceremony at the Pierre.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption on page 10 of the Travel section today, with the What's Doing column about Strasbourg, France, refers incorrectly in some copies to the festival at which ''Go-gol,'' an opera by Michael Levinas, was performed last year. It was a contemporary music festival, not France's oldest music festival, the Festival de Musique.

title: Caroline Yvernault, Antoine Labbe
description: Caroline Dominique Yvernault, the daughter of Dominique and Gerard Yvernault of Bronxville, N.Y., was married yesterday to Antoine Gordon Labbe, a son of Louanne Labbe and Dr. Frederic Labbe of Redwood City, Calif. The Rev. Fausto Penafield, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony at the Holy Family Church in Rutherford, Calif.

title: TAKING THE CHILDREN
description: Four Million Houseguests

title: Carolyn Lovelock, Patrick McGarry
description: Carolyn Jean Lovelock and Patrick Francis McGarry, municipal bond traders in New York, were married yesterday at St. Patrick's Roman Catholic Church in Brooklyn. The Rev. Martin Kull officiated.

title: Reality Check
description: I have almost two decades of family pictures in a shopping bag -- undated, unsorted, prints and negatives spilling out of their envelopes, the old and the new hopelessly jumbled. All but the latest dozen or so. These are taking up virtual space instead, on the hard disk of my computer. They are cleverly labeled: Harry at Ballpark, Harry with Astro, Harry on Stoop.

title: Mary Ellen Mark: DISNEYLAND, N.Y.C.
description: For Mary Ellen Mark, a documentary photographer accustomed to becoming deeply involved with her subjects over time, the freedom of wandering around Times Square for a few days ''really opened me up to street photography.'' The New Yorker says: ''I was walking by the same characters and getting to know the people in the neighborhood. It is an incredible place, full of life and strangeness.'' Though she loves to focus on what she calls the ''edges of the city,'' she takes issue with artists who find a romanticism in New York's grimy regions. ''It is terrible to be homeless, and there is nothing charming about living in squalor,'' she says. ''Times Square will have a loss of edge, yet it is being replaced by a clean-cut sort of American squalor that is less visual but still has a real energy.''

title: Old Rituals Contain Lessons About Harmony With Nature, and With Life
description: The scent of sage burning in a seashell, the smoke gently fanned with an eagle's feather.

title: 'Dear Cousin Julius'
description: ''Dear Cousin Julius, We Trust on Our God and on You. . . . ' '' (by Michael Winerip, April 27) is the story of my family too. On Nov. 9, 1938, Kristallnacht, my father, who was the spiritual leader of the Jewish congregation in Duisburg-Hamborn, was sent to Dachau. My parents' only chance to get to the United States was under the exempt quota, comprising two categories: professors and clergymen.

title: Fishing Parties First Have to Fish for Parking Near Docks
description: Kevin Bradshaw looked over the prow of his 90-foot fishing boat and scowled at the large Loehmann's across Emmons Avenue.

title: A World Remade by Empire State Gunfire
description: At times, the many people who love Matthew Gross can almost believe that the nightmare of the last three months is nearing an end.

title: PLAYING IN THE NEIGHBORHOOD
description: ST. GEORGE

title: Blood for H.I.V. Tests Is Lost on a Subway Ride
description: A St. Luke's-Roosevelt Hospital Center worker who fell asleep on a southbound N train in Brooklyn early Friday morning lost a valise containing six vacuum-packed vials of blood that had been collected to be tested for the virus that causes AIDS, the police said. The vials had not been reported found yesterday.

title: LONG ISLAND GUIDE
description: FREE CHOICES

title: Alice Weil, Paul Judelson
description: Alice Weil, the daughter of Vivian and Irwin Weil of Evanston, Ill., was married on Friday to Paul Alan Judelson, a son of Maria Olivia and Jim Judelson of New York. The Rev. Arthur Caliandro performed the ceremony at Marble Collegiate Church in New York.

title: With Wind and a Prayer, Ship Sails for Dream
description: Adix, one of the most majestic of the world's elite group of superyachts, set sail this weekend in a quest greater than winning. But to be successful, Adix needs wind, and lots of it.

title: A Public Mea Culpa
description: In journalism, as in life, it's sometimes hard to say you're wrong, especially when your work generates a firestorm of criticism from competitors and a furor among citizens and government officials who believed you. But that's what Jerry Ceppos, executive editor of The San Jose Mercury News, did last week when he acknowledged that a series of articles in the paper last fall suggesting that the C.I.A. countenanced the spread of crack in the nation's inner cities turned out to be not quite right.

title: Abortion Opportunity
description: A stunning breakthrough took place last week in America's generation-long abortion debate. The center suddenly became very much wider and genuine compromise is possible.

title: Roll Call
description: Fifteen million American children put on in-line skates each year. In 1995, about 65,000 of them were hurt seriously enough to become an injury statistic. That adds up to a lot of days absent from school, not to mention other costs.

title: Sights and Sounds From Tiger's Gallery
description: TIGER WOODS swung his driver and his golf ball soared up, up and away. On this 533-yard seventh hole at the TPC at Las Colinas, it would roll to a stop about 330 yards away in the fairway, but while the ball was still a white dot high in the sky, a young man in the gallery yelled, ''I did that in my dreams last night.''

title: Learning Poverty Firsthand
description: If 213 of the 214 women Edin interviewed could supplement welfare with illegal income, why aren't they able to get off welfare and support themselves? It seems that there is a lot of ingenuity involved in cheating the Government -- skills that might be translated to employment. Edin neglected to ask the most important question: If there were no welfare, what would these women be doing?

title: Ms. Palazzo, Mr. Fairweather
description: Tina L. Palazzo, a daughter of Petronilla and Antonio Palazzo of Brooklyn, is to be married today to Charles L. P. Fairweather, the son of Jo-An Franklin of Manhattan and the late George R. Fairweather. The Rev. Michael Lanning is to perform the ceremony at Holy Trinity Roman Catholic Church in Manhattan.

title: Bronx Democrats' Unity Unraveling Over Mayoral Race
description: During much of the last year, Democratic politicians in the Bronx developed an uncommon level of unity on what became their central goal: the election of Fernando Ferrer as mayor. And one by one, nearly every elected official lined up, with support for Mr. Ferrer, the Bronx Borough President, becoming virtually a matter of duty.

title: Debate on New Funds Bearing Old Records
description: THE Securities and Exchange Commission is warning fund companies to be more cautious about marketing new funds by using the past performances of portfolio managers or the records of similar funds.

title: As Bad as That
description: Busted Scotch Selected Stories. By James Kelman. 262 pp. New York: W. W. Norton & Company. $23.

title: Drinking Up Life In a Chinese Teahouse
description: IT is 8:30 on a late-summer morning in Chengdu, China -- warm, humid, the sunshine filtered through a mist as light as a watercolor wash. I am sitting in a teahouse in the heart of the People's Park. Today is Sunday, and I have nothing to do -- except drink tea and watch the people of the People's Park.

title: Lyle Ashton Harris: WORKADAY JUXTAPOSITIONS
description: With an eye toward creating a series of still-picture performance pieces, Lyle Ashton Harris brought strangers off the street and onto the stage of the derelict Liberty Theater. ''We wanted to draw in the kaleidoscopic nature of a Times Square in flux -- the juxtaposition of new and old, gender and class, tourists and New Yorkers,'' says Harris, who lives in Los Angeles. To Harris and his collaborator, Tommy Gear, the ''beauty of it all was that not everyone woke up that morning thinking they might be photographed. We were really playing with the notion of who can be on the stage.'' Wilma Prezzi, an 81-year-old sculptor and novelist who has lived in the neighborhood for years, says of the experience: ''I was chided a bit by my friends for daring to go into a theater of that condition. But when I hesitated, one of the security guards came over and took my arm and said that there was nothing to worry about.'' Fred Hakim, owner of the Limark Foods hot dog stand on 42d Street, has been on the block for 56 years, having slopped his first sauerkraut at his father's stand as an 11-year-old. ''I've seen so much. I've been through the blackout and World War II,'' he says. Referring to the area's renovation, he adds, ''I hope they let me stay when it's all over.''

title: Books in Brief: Nonfiction
description: SPIRAL OF CYNICISM

title: MOVIES THIS WEEK
description: A sleeper of a western, the third pairing of Hollywood's most famous dancers, a suspense gem and a rounded drama about a war veteran brighten the movie menu this week.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BENDHEIM, CHARLES
description: BENDHEIM-Charles, of New York and Jerusalem. It is with deep sorrow and regret that the American Israel Public Affairs Committee, AIPAC, mourns the passing of the father of our esteemed board member, Jack Bendheim. Philanthropist, pillar of the community, supporter of a myriad of Jewish organizations and causes, Charles Bendheim will be sorely missed. He leaves a legacy in the work that is being carried on by his children. We extend our sincerest sympathies to the family. May they be comforted amongst the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem.

title: Radio News, Another View
description: While I was interested in your article on the Quinnipiac College radio station (''New Haven's the Lure for Quinnipiac AM,'' May 11), and pleased the school has embarked on such a useful program for its students and future broadcasters, I must point out some inaccuracies regarding ''Fairfield County NewsRadio'' as mentioned in the article.

title: Artists vs. Writers: How a Rivalry Escalated
description: ON summer Saturdays almost 50 years ago, artists and wives, husbands and lovers would gather in Wilfrid Zogbaum's yard in Springs to play softball.

title: Zoo of the Absurd
description: To the Editor: Susan Allen Toth's rumination on the charms of the London Zoo, ''Eye to Eye With Gibbon and Snake'' (April 13), recalled a marvelous bit of absurdity I saw on display there..

title: Robert H. Krieble, 80, Dies; Was Co-Founder of Loctite
description: Robert H. Krieble, a co-founder and former chief executive of the Loctite Corporation and a former vice chairman of the Heritage Foundation, the conservative policy research institute, died on May 8 at his home in Old Lyme, Conn. He was 80.

title: Deep, Deeper, Deepest Blue
description: FOR those who worry that losing a chess match to a machine somehow diminishes humanity, Deep Blue's victory over Garry Kasparov last week was easy to explain away. Deep Blue is a powerful machine, and the outcome of the match was no more surprising than if Mr. Kasparov had tried to outrun a train. But if you think again, the whole thing is eerie. One kind of computer, made of neurons, lost to another kind of computer, made of microchips.

title: Resurgence of the Strip
description: IT was raining hard enough to bring to mind the old John Fogerty lyric. Not that it mattered who'd stop the rain given the orchid-growing humidity inside the Whisky a Go Go, the legendary Sunset Strip club where Jim Morrison and Van Halen played, given over this night to the lesser known Spaceman Spliff. ''Oh, man, I just can't drink up here anymore,'' muttered the wool-hatted lead singer as he accidentally kicked over his beer.

title: She'll Never Jog Alone
description: BARBARA ALTMAN won't decide until the very last minute if she will enter today's ''Battle of the Cities'' 10-kilometer Boardwalk run.

title: Today, Mourning's All Alone Against Ewing
description: It seemed the smart way for Alonzo Mourning to react when confronted with the specter of Patrick Ewing, 24 hours before their real confrontation in Game 7.

title: When the Performance Is a Prize
description: THE concert season is winding down but several musical enticements remain. Today at 3 the Connecticut Valley Chamber Orchestra concludes its year at Trinity Episcopal Church, Hartford, with the group's music director, Tibor Pusztai, leading the all-volunteer ensemble in Ralph Vaughan Williams's ''Fantasia on a Theme by Thomas Tallis'' and Schumann's ''Spring'' Symphony. Also featured are two soloists: the orchestra's principal clarinetist (and teacher in the Torrington Schools), Gwendolyn Winkel, playing the Nielsen Concerto, and Erin Keefe, a junior at Williston-Northhampton School and winner of Hartford Symphony's Young Artists Competition, who collects her performance prize with Saint-Saens's Violin Concerto No. 3.

title: Votes in Congress
description: Tally Last Week in Connecticut, New Jersey and New York

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  PERLSTEIN, JEANNNE
description: PERLSTEIN - Jeannne. Mother dear, our 17th Mother's Day without you. We love and miss you. Audrey, Ellen and Suzanne

title: DIARY
description: COMPUTERS

title: Why Builders Are Turning to Panelized Approach
description: IN its 85,000-square-foot factory on Route 112, Triangle Building Products, a wholesale lumber company, is building ready- made walls and roof and floor trusses for 11 developments totaling about 2,000 housing units.

title: Beyond Shocking
description: It's the spring of 1996, in Paris, and a group of retailers and journalists are sitting in a giant room in the basement of the Louvre, waiting for the next fashion show to begin. A copy of the Suddeutsche Zeitung magazine is making the rounds. In it is a series of photographs, by Juergen Teller, of Kristen McMenamy, the model. Naked and pale, she crawls on all fours in front of an electric space heater in a setting that might well be a fashion show's backstage quarters. In some pictures, the scar on McMenamy's abdomen is visible, as is the red crease where a G-string's elastic has chafed her skin. In one shot, she is seen in a doorway, facing away from the camera: ''VERSACE'' has been scrawled in black across her buttocks, which are crudely outlined in a big red heart. ''I hope that's lipstick,'' one editor seated behind me said in disgust.

title: Designing Show Stoppers For the Showroom Floor
description: THE challenge was not just to sculpture a successful line of family sedans, or to improve on an acclaimed design. In developing the 1998 Chrysler Concorde and Dodge Intrepid, Chrysler Corporation designers set out to to rekindle America's love affair with the automobile at a time when consumers are migrating, en masse, to trucks and truck-based sport utilities.

title: Son of Darien
description: In ''Son of Darien'' (April 27), Susan Cheever brands Alex Kelly a ''career criminal,'' mythologizes him as a latter-day Icarus and pop-psychologizes him as perhaps acting out his parents' inner feelings.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BARTLETT, DAVID
description: BARTLETT-David. Died May 13. Survived by his wife Stefane Abeille-Demay; his daughters Linda Miller, Victoria Donaldson & Stefane Bartlett; 4 granddaughters & his brother, Charles L. Bartlett. Memorial mass is at 4 P.M., on Tuesday, May 20, Saint Vincent Ferrer, 869 Lexington Avenue.

title: 'Dear Cousin Julius'
description: After reading the poignant exchange of letters between Julius Hess and Max Schohl, it has become clear to me that the debate over whether the F.D.R. memorial should have the wartime President standing or sitting in a wheelchair is misplaced. Roosevelt should be shown holding his head in shame over his refusal to save the lives of thousands of Jews by simply allowing the immigration quotas to be filled, instead of acceding to the refusal of his lackeys at the State Department to save Jews.

title: Meeting the Neighbors Halfway, With Korean as a Second Language
description: DEUKSHIN KIM is ready for class. She has photocopied her lesson plans. She has put on more lipstick than usual. She has been to church to pray.

title: Noting Other Work Among the Orthodox
description: I read with great interest the ''Suburbanization of Orthodox Jews,'' $(April 6$). The Orthodox community in our area has indeed grown over the past few years. Unfortunately, however, the article was very unbalanced. It did not mention the Young Israel of New Rochelle, which is about to embark on a new multi-million-dollar building; Mogen David, the Sephardic congregation, which is also building, or Anshe Sholom, the oldest Orthodox synagogue in the area, which is actively trying to revive the Jewish community near the Sound.

title: Corrections
description: An article on May 4 about mental illness in the workplace misstated the given name of a psychiatrist who has studied mentally ill people in entry-level jobs. He is Robert E. Drake of the Dartmouth medical school, not David.

title: Desperately Seeking Dee Dee
description: AT first sight, Benny Bonilla loved Dee Dee, even if she did look as much like a monkey as a kitten. His pal Mike Melendez politely said she was ''unattractive.'' But Dee Dee woke up Mr. Bonilla with kisses, cried when he went to work and jumped all over him when he came home. When it seemed as though she had walked out on him after five years, he was devastated.

title: What Deep Blue Learned in Chess School
description: Three months ago, the computer scientists at I.B.M. discovered a bug in their now-famous chess machine, Deep Blue. For some reason, as the computer searched way out along the lines of possibilities in examining certain moves, it began seeing a queen where there wasn't one, a kind of computer hallucination.

title: Bergen County Abandons Plan for Day Labor Center
description: Three years ago, Bergen County Executive William P. Schuber appointed a task force to set up a central ''work transfer site'' where day laborers could find construction and landscaping jobs and obtain medical, legal and language services, said Gina Plotino, the county's human services director and chairwoman of the task force. Last week, Mr. Schuber dissolved the body.

title: Mergers Squeezing the Loose Brokerage Alliances
description: CONSOLIDATION is much on the minds of real estate brokers and managers these days as acquisitions and mergers, announced and rumored, are widely thought to be on the way toward creating a few large national companies that will dominate markets.

title: Tests May Offer Some Clues In Crash of '96 T.W.A. Flight
description: The controlled explosions in reinforced and unreinforced baggage containers today on an old 747 here may be very helpful in investigating last summer's crash of Trans World Airlines Flight 800, the National Transportation Safety Board said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STEPHEN, ALICE G.
description: STEPHEN-Alice G. On May 16, 1997. Wife of the late Louis Steele, survived by her daughter Beverly, son-in-law Malcolm Taub, her sister Esther Edler, grandson Maxwell Stephen Taub, niece Kay Britton. Services Sunday, 12 noon, at ''The Riverside,'' 76th St and Amsterdam Ave.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: Baseball

title: Learning Poverty Firsthand
description: As I read the three superbly written articles in your April 27 Magazine, I was struck by the study in contrasts they represent. Kathryn Edin's work described in Jason DeParle's ''Learning Poverty Firsthand'' offers an intelligent approach to separating myth from reality that is the prerequisite to solving the problems of poverty. Susan Cheever depicts American culture at the other end of the economic scale, where there are squandered resources and opportunities, and family tragedies too. Michael Winerip documents the life-and-death struggle of a family. The efforts of Julius Hess are both heartening and heartbreaking. He was the rare individual who knew the right thing to do and persevered in doing it.

title: ACADEMY'S REPORT SAYS IMMIGRATION BENEFITS THE U.S.
description: Immigration produces substantial economic benefits for the United States as a whole but slightly reduces the wages and job opportunities of low-skilled American workers, especially high school dropouts, the National Academy of Sciences said today.

title: Joanie Weston, 62, a Big Star In the World of Roller Derbies
description: Joanie Weston, a strapping power hitter who passed up a promising and respectable future in softball to become the gum-chewing, power-skating, hip-bumping golden girl of Roller Derby, died on May 10 at her home in Hayward, Calif., near San Francisco. She was 62 and skated in an exhibition game only last year.

title: Dining in the Hamptons: 10 Standouts
description: HAMPTONS restaurants have come of age. As recently as the late 1980's, they were often viewed as summertime stepsisters by their more serious siblings to the west.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  BELLSEY, RONALD ERIC
description: BELLSEY-Ronald Eric May 21, 1951-August 17, 1977. BELLSEY-Peter Michael. May 14, 1953-August 20, 1990. Remembered each day with love.

title: Early Lesson
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Michael J. Murphy, 83, Dies; Led New York Police in 1960's
description: Michael J. Murphy, who served as the New York City Police Commissioner during a tumultuous period in the 1960's punctuated by riots and bitter accusations of police brutality, died early yesterday at his home in Smithtown, N.Y. He was 83.

title: The Literary Set Nurtures a Lofty Heritage
description: THE first famous writer to arrive in what is now called the Hamptons did not come for the beach, the summer breezes, or even the luminous skies that have attracted generations of artists to the cozy villages of Long Island's South Fork. James Fenimore Cooper came in 1819 to invest in Sag Harbor's growing whaling business as owner of the whaling ship Union. He also started writing here. According to local legend, he based his character Natty Bumppo partly on David Hand, a local hero who had fought in the Revolution and helped kick the British out of what had by then become a rowdy whaling town, the home of America's third largest whaling fleet.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JOSEFSBERG, SYLVIA
description: JOSEFSBERG-Sylvia. Sister of Albert Josefsberg and Martha Schecter. Beloved aunt of five nephews and one niece; grandaunt of eight. Service Sunday, May 18, 1:45 PM, at Sinai Chapels, 162-05 Horace Harding Expressway, Fresh Meadows, NY.

title: Violin and Piccolo Fill a Program
description: FROM 3 to 8 today, programs arrive every hour on the hour, and the Yonkers Philharmonic rushes the gun with a 2:30 P.M. concert at the Saunders School in Yonkers. The free program includes showcases for three soloists -- Nina Boesen playing Beethoven's Violin Concerto, Linda Tauber featured in William Zinn's Piccolo Concerto and the soprano Camille Gifford singing arias by Puccini, Verdi and Wagner. As if that were not enough, the music director, Jerome Sala, adds a suite from Tchaikovsky's ''Swan Lake'' ballet.

title: Women's Lib in Russia Isn't Just Cosmetic
description: To the Editor:

title: Hello, Columbus
description: Like an astral shower sizzling through an inclement sky, the Great White Way is burning red and yellow. They are the colors of raw meat, fire, Campbell's soup and golden arches. Primary colors for primal urges. Cheerful, hopeful, life-affirming colors. The colors that burn from truck stops and minimalls across America.

title: Correction
description: An article in the Neighborhood Report on May 4 about Mariner's Marsh, a wetlands on Staten Island, referred incorrectly to the Department of Environmental Protection, the agency that proposed putting a sludge-processing plant there. It is a city agency, not state.

title: Springtime, for the Harbor Police, Means Watching Out for Bodies
description: The men of the Police Harbor ''Charlie'' unit have the grisly task of fishing cadavers from the water. They sat in the station house listening to the gurgle of the scanner last week while eating their lunch.

title: New & Noteworthy Paperbacks
description: PURSUED BY FURIES: A Life of Malcolm Lowry

title: Woodson Summons Scouts to Prove He Is Still Fit
description: Rod Woodson is one of the best cornerbacks ever. As a member of the National Football League's 75th anniversary team, he has been honored as one of the best players ever. So why can't the former Pittsburgh Steeler get a job?

title: 'I Rescued Myself'
description: Happily Ever After By Anna Quindlen. Illustrated by James Stevenson. 43 pp. New York: Viking. $13.99. (Ages 5 to 9)

title: Philadelphia Story
description: AMERICAN AURORA

title: Fence Bars India Street Pier From Its Past and Its Fans
description: On foot, on bicycles, pushing grocery carts and baby carriages, people found their way on Wednesday to the shabby Brooklyn pier, the end of which had collapsed the evening before, heaving seven people into the surging currents of the East River.

title: Zairian Rebel And His Plan Puzzle West
description: Until seven months ago, the man who declared himself President of what he has renamed the Democratic Republic of the Congo was an obscure rebel leader with a history of starting Quixotic Marxist revolts that fell apart. He had never administered anything larger than a small socialist commune in the mountains of eastern Zaire in the 1970's.

title: Reassuring The Arrivals In a New Age
description: From the window of her new apartment, Galina Mankovskaya can see the former Russian soldiers playing chess in the courtyard. There is some friendly cursing down below, and Mrs. Mankovskaya, 65, can smile with them. It has been a tiring trip from Moscow to Flushing, Queens.

title: Books in Brief: Nonfiction
description: Patient

title: Small Parties Join in Lawsuit Against Stringent Ballot Rules
description: They are candidates so divergent and fractious that they even bicker about how to set up a group photograph. But the Libertarians, Greens, Conservatives and other representatives of small independent political groups in New Jersey have found at least one thing in common: an enemy.

title: Lillian Bassman: THE NIGHT FANTASTIC
description: Not long ago, a fashion editor at The Times told Lillian Bassman that he had had a dream about a woman on a white horse in the middle of Times Square. Naturally, Bassman says, ''I got a horse and a girl and went to work.'' Bassman, who is 79, made her reputation with fashion photography for Harper's Bazaar in the 1940's and 50's; she recalls that Broadway ''lacked excitement'' on that cold spring night, leaving the images ''stark and with a kind of coldness.'' So she doctored the prints using ''bleach, a paintbrush, my fingers, cotton and my eyes and my temperament'' to add a patina of fantasy. ''All the romance for me really takes place in the darkroom,'' says Bassman. ''That's where I transform things to my image of what they are.''

title: Edward Keating: MEAN STREETS
description: ''I'm always semiconscious that Times Square is forever changing and that I have to get some pictures that evoke the mood of the place,'' says Edward Keating, a staff photographer for The Times. For Keating, 41, seeing a woman with two black eyes was such a moment: ''Soon she will have to go somewhere else.'' Still, he says he feels that the Times Square he has watched disappear played a cathartic role in city life. ''There is a kind of gloom that sets in at a certain hour that seems to represent the darker side of something that's in all New Yorkers,'' he explains. ''It was a place where you could go to vent ideas and experience feelings that you wouldn't experience somewhere else. Even if it was a hellhole, it was our hellhole.''

title: In Recount, Schundler Is Apparent Winner
description: A preliminary recount of Tuesday's election results completed late last night put Mayor Bret Schundler 10 votes ahead of the 50-percent-plus-one majority needed to be elected, the City Clerk said.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  UNGER, DR. LAURENCE N.
description: UNGER-Dr. Laurence N. Dear Lor, we miss and treasure our happy times together. Love.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption on May 4 with the What's Doing column, about the Pioneer Valley in Massachusetts, referred incorrectly to a portrait of Emily Dickinson, who lived in Amherst. It was a drawing of the daguerreotype that is the only photograph ever made of Dickinson -- not the daguerreotype itself, which is on exhibition at Amherst College.

title: A Jazzier Approach to Pots and Planters
description: WHEN planting containers, window boxes, patio tubs and all those decorative pots, it's awfully easy just to go to the garden center and buy a few geraniums or some impatiens. After all, it worked last year and the effect is immediate. Why not repeat the same?

title: An Old-Fashioned Modernist
description: Correction Appended

title: Pursuing a Boxing Passion, but as a Judge
description: MELVINA LATHAN grew up watching the Friday night fights with her father on television, married into boxing and for six years has been one of a small group of women who judge professional boxing matches.

title: 'Third Rock' Aliens Inhabit Dreamland
description: TRYING TO MIMIC HUMAN ways, Harry, the geeky alien played by French Stewart on the NBC sitcom ''Third Rock from the Sun,'' has rarely stumbled through life with as much elan as he did on a sound stage here the other day. In a porkpie hat and a pink plaid suit, he waltzed with a group of beautiful dancers and then, as luck would have it, got the girl of his dreams.

title: The History in a Cemetery
description: Vines hang from 300-year-old trees and wrap around centuries-old gravestones in a setting so rich with history and so choked with overgrown berries, wild onions and dandelions that it could be a setting for a Southern gothic novel.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROTHENBERG, RICHARD, DR.
description: ROTHENBERG-Richard, Dr. On May 15, 1997. The entire Stuyvesant Family - students, staff, administration, alumni and parents, deeply mourn the sudden and untimely loss of their dear friend, teacher and colleague, Richard Rothenberg, Assistant Principal, Mathematics. A graduate, Class of 1963, Dr. Rothenberg epitomized the best of the academic and scholarly tradition of Stuyvesant High School. This kind and compassionate, gentle man, will be sorely missed for the strength of his character and his contributions to this Institution. His memory will live on in the hearts of his thousands of devoted students. We extend our heartfelt condolences to his wife, Rita, his children, Terri, Fran, and Jonathan, and his entire family. Stuyvesant High School Family

title: Music Fed By Many Streams
description: THERE'S NOTHING RADICAL ABOUT THE FOO FIGHTERS' second album, ''The Color and the Shape.'' David Grohl -- who writes, sings, plays guitar and socks the drums for the Foo Fighters -- was Nirvana's drummer, and his songs for the Foo Fighers draw on his previous band's musical sources: the Beatles for chords and melodies, punk rock and Black Sabbath for impact, Neil Young for plaintive bluntness and the Pixies for sudden blasting choruses. The subject matter isn't exactly unprecedented, either: breaking up and making up, anger and loneliness and confusion. But rock songs don't usually depend on grand innovations. Timing, ingenuity and conviction can be all it takes to make rock's common materials ring with passion. That's what happens on ''The Color and the Shape,'' as Grohl balances power and tenderness, whipsaw riffing and wistful tunes.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  SCHWARTZ, IVAN HARVEY
description: SCHWARTZ-Ivan Harvey. One year today... an eternity without you. Your J Z

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LUX, SISTER AGNES
description: LUX-Sister Agnes. May 15, 1997. A member of the Society of The Helpers of The Holy Souls. Dear aunt & great aunt to many nieces & nephews. Reposing Sunday, 2-5 & 7-9 P.M., Riverdale-on-Hudson Funeral Home, 6110 Riverdale Avenue, (West 261 Street, Bronx). Mass of Christian Burial Monday 10 AM, at Our Lady of The Rosary Church. (Yonkers, New York). Interment in Calvary Cemetery.

title: Dogging the Baby Boomer Money
description: FOR the same reason that Willie Sutton robbed banks -- that's where the money is -- personal-finance magazines track baby boomers, who are nearing or entering their 50's and thinking hard about retirement.

title: Annie Leibovitz: ROOMS OF THEIR OWN
description: ''One woman, Sadie, had worked at Woolworth's for like 40 years and had been in that room for decades,'' Annie Leibovitz says of a subject living in one of the Times Square S.R.O.'s where she photographed. ''Her tiny room was most impressive and cheerful and filled with stuffed animals -- it was like looking at many pages of someone's life.'' Leibovitz, famous for her celebrity portraits, is working on a book of photographs of women from every walk of life. She quickly found herself wrapped up in the stories of the women she met in the hotels and in the improbable communities they had staked out. ''You look at a woman's life and see she has only a small room and you think she has a small life -- you make that up -- but in truth she has a big life and is very active,'' Leibovitz explains. ''These hotels have bad rooms and good rooms, they are like small cities.''

title: Residents Wary of Industrial Area's 'Upgrades'
description: The view from Paul Pullo's third-floor office at Metro Oil headquarters encompasses the best and the worst Greenpoint has to offer. In the background is the midtown Manhattan skyline; in the foreground is an industrial tableau: the Newtown Creek sewage treatment plant, the Department of Sanitation's marine transfer station, the defunct Mobil Oil storage plant and a recycling company.

description: Ellen Sheryl Levy, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Norman J. Levy of Tenafly, N.J., and Dr. Fredrick Lee Coffman, the son of Mr. and Mrs. James V. Coffman of White, Pa., were married in Tenafly yesterday by Mayor Ann A. Moscovitz.

title: There Are Dining Bargains Galore, If You Sit in the Bar Areas
description: CALL it Plan B for visiting the A-list restaurants of the Hamptons. No reservation is required nor will you have to beg for a table. In fact you will have the perfect perch from which to observe the glamour and glitz of the white tablecloth crowd, while eating many of the same dishes for much less money.

title: Springs
description: Springs is a part of East Hampton that many visitors are not aware exists. People who live there -- artists, writers, baymen and working-class folks -- like it that way. Many year-round residents, in fact, refuse to leave their quiet enclave in the summer and skip the trek into the village, preferring to frequent local attractions like Michael's Restaurant, Wolfie's pub, Maidstone Market's Take Two Video and the Springs General Store.

description: A son of President Kim Young Sam of South Korea was arrested today in connection with a widening corruption scandal, raising questions about the President's own role in the affair.

title: The Essence Within, as Seen From Without
description: AS exhibition themes go, identity is one of the more pliant ones to have come around in a long time. Identity can be extremely precise, as in fingerprints or Social Security numbers, or it can be chameleonlike: some identities can be put on and removed like costumes. Some are imposed on a person by outside conditions, while others are continually being shaped by a person's changing attitudes and convictions.

title: Park Bought Building Height, and Building Gave It Locks
description: For more than 20 years, the public park at Continental Towers, one of the most expensive and sought-after apartment buildings in Manhattan, has been barely a park and only intermittently public.

title: Corrections

Shapiro, the agency's general counsel, in the handling of F.B.I. personnel files that were turned over to the White House. Mr. Shapiro led a subsequent inquiry into the matter, but was not involved in the decision to provide any files to Presidential aides.

description: BUSINESS acumen and bold timing, backed up by swarms of lawyers telling how far to the inch he could push, propelled Harold C. Simmons into the ranks of the nation's billionaires. But early last year, with his entire fortune at stake, those attributes failed him in negotiations with his own daughters.

title: Barbecue, Self-Service and No Frills
description: THE space now occupied by Buster's Bar-B-Que in Stamford has seen its share of tenants in the past few years, from Italian fancy to barbecue plain. In fact the two previous occupants served barbecue, too, but neither was as bare-bones simple as Buster's.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MICHELSOHN, THERESA
description: MICHELSOHN-Theresa. On May 16, 1997. Beloved wife of the late Adrian, devoted mother of Annette Michelsohn. Interment Sunday, Riverside Cemetery.

description: The Bronx District Attorney, Robert T. Johnson, has decided not to prosecute two police officers who were involved in the shooting death of a mentally ill Bronx man.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCNEILL, CHARLES JAMES
description: McNEILL-Charles James, 84. Publishing Executive and Doctor of Journalism. Beloved father of Sharon McGlynn. Died peacefully on May 16, at home in New York. Born in 1912 in Newton, KS, McNeill began his career in communications at the Register System of Catholic Newspapers in Denver, CO. From 1946-1957 he was General Manager of Pflaum Publishing in Dayton, OH, and maintained his affiliation with religious and educational affairs through the Catholic Press Association of which he was President from 1954-1956. In 1957 he became Assistant Director of Radio Free Europe in Munich, Germany, and in 1961 co-founder of InterTel in Brussels, Belgium, the first commercial television production company to operate in Europe. In 1963 he returned to the United States and co-founded the consulting firm Kane-McNeill. In 1972 he bought Catholic Lists, now headed by his daughter. In 1987 he was honored with the St. Francis de Sales Award by the Catholic Press Association. McNeill's wife, Mary O'Neill, died in 1994. He is survived by his only child, Sharon, sister, Elizabeth Keleher, and many family members and friends to whom he remains an inspiration. A memorial service will be held at Trinity Chapel on May 23.

title: Preserving a Delicate Balance
description: TO drive along South Orange Avenue as it crosses from a frayed section of Newark to the neatly tended village of South Orange is a jarring experience. Within a single block, an urban landscape of littered streets, roll-down security gates and graffiti-scarred apartment buildings gives way to the leafy charms of gas-fired street lamps, proud Victorians and pampered front lawns. That the owners of the gaslit Victorians and Tudors include both whites and blacks is a fact that residents of South Orange, and its sister township, Maplewood, see as a crucial part of their suburban identity. But as more and more black families replace whites in parts of their communities, there is growing concern about whether this balance can be maintained.

title: The East End Working Class: They Struggle Year-Round
description: IT happens all the time to Peg Christy, Community Development Director of this town, just as it happens so often to Edna Steck, Human Services Director for the Town of East Hampton. They are at a conference, seeking money for a housing project or a subsidy program, and people have the same predictable reaction: ''What do you need money for? You're from the Hamptons.''

title: Poster Boy for the Revolution
description: Che GUEVARA A Revolutionary Life. By Jon Lee Anderson. Illustrated. 814 pp. New York: Grove Press. $35.

title: A Remorse, No Pity
description: Federal prosecutors will be seeking the death penalty in the Unabom case. The decision, authorized by Attorney General Janet Reno, was made despite arguments that it would be an injustice to relatives who turned the suspect in.

title: Books in Brief: Fiction
description: ALL THE MONEY IN THE WORLD

title: He's Adding Director to His List of Credits
description: WHEN GRIFFIN DUNNE talks about his life, every anecdote sounds like the script of a short, darkly comic film. There's the window washer on a skyscraper, spied that very morning, who was stranded and being rescued by firefighters. Farther back, at age 3, Mr. Dunne discovered his own nanny dead on the bathroom floor. At age 5, leaping into the swimming pool to impress his parents' house guest Sean Connery, Mr. Dunne had to be saved from drowning by the man himself.

title: Spy and Counterspy
description: It is my conviction, based on some 70 years of experience, first as a Government official and then in the past 45 years as a historian, that the need by our government for secret intelligence about affairs elsewhere in the world has been vastly overrated. I would say that something upward of 95 percent of what we need to know could be very well obtained by the careful and competent study of perfectly legitimate sources of information open and available to us in the rich library and archival holdings of this country. Much of the remainder, if it could not be found here (and there is very little of it that could not), could easily be nonsecretively elicited from similar sources abroad.

title: The Farms Gave Way Just 25 Years Ago
description: RICHARD NICOTRA grew up in Bull's Head and his memories are of a rural Staten Island area where children skated on a frozen brook and residents bought fruit from ''Sam the peddler.'' Farms worked by Italians and Greeks lasted into the early 1970's.

title: Elizabeth Caronna, David Jones
description: Elizabeth Bowe Caronna and David Shumway Jones, students at Harvard Medical School in Boston, were married yesterday in Cambridge, Mass. The Rev. Benjamin R. Doolittle, a minister of the United Church of Christ, performed the ceremony at the Cronkhite Graduate Center.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ZENDMAN, PETER
description: ZENDMAN-Peter. Peter died in Rome, Italy on April 28, 1997. He is survived by his sister Carol, his brother Buddy, his sister-in-law Jeanne, 5 nephews, 3 nieces-inlaw, 3 great nephews, 2 great nieces and his partner in Ogni Bene-Zendman, Sergio Ogni Bene. Rest in peace, little brother.

title: INSIDE
description: INVESTING IT /Page 4/

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ENGEL, IRVING H.
description: ENGEL-Irving H. Our sturdiest pillar of strength has fallen. Temple Israel of Long Beach, together with its Sisterhood, mourns the loss of our President Emeritus, past President, Trustee and member of more than 50 years. His inner beauty, strength and wisdom guided this institution throughout this entire time. Together with his wife, Rose, past President of our Sisterhood, he inspired generations to share their love of Temple, Torah, and Judaism. Their generosity and commitment as well as those of their children, Sandor and Susan, Maynard and Sally, Ellen and Jean-Marie will never be forgotten. The memory of Irving H. Engel is a blessing to all who were privileged to have known him. Our deepest sympathies to his beloved wife, Rose, and the entire family. Jacob Chiger, Rabbi Karl S. Kritz, Cantor Mark I. Samuels, Bruce A. Sklover Co-Presidents Mollie Consor, Sisterhood Pres.

description: WITH the summer season looming, Hamptons Internet Web site owners can only hope traffic on the superhighway moves better than it does on Montauk Highway.

description: IN 1977, farm fields stretched along both sides of Pier Avenue, a two-lane road leading through Riverhead's farm belt to Long Island Sound. Farmers grew potatoes and cauliflower in the rich soil.

title: A Resort on a Lake In Country-Music Land
description: Branson, Mo., the bustling home of dozens of theaters featuring live country music, has a new luxury resort: the Chateau on the Lake. Situated on a mountaintop overlooking Table Rock Lake, the 302-room resort is to open Monday.

description: KEARNEY-Marcia, 46, of St. Petersburg, FL. Died unexpectedly May 12, 1997. Beloved daughter of Lee Froehlich Kearney and the late Paul. Dear sister of Marilee Bleetstein and Maureen Jacobs, and sister-in-law of Gary Bleetstein. Cherished aunt of Desiree, Michelle and Alix. We will miss her. Private graveside service.
