description: To the Editor:

title: Shelter Island
description: Shelter Island is a friendly place. Situated between the North and South Forks, and reachable from either the Greenport or North Haven ferries, the island is special.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GREENBERG, BERNARD
description: GREENBERG-Bernard. Members of The Department of Pediatrics at Maimonides Medical Center note with regret the passing of a valued colleague. Dr. Greenberg was a force in The Department of Pediatrics as a distinguished Clinician and Teacher since his appointment in 1947. He was also active in the affairs of the medical center where from 1967 to 1969, he served as President of The Medical Staff. He had continued to contribute as Chairman of The Prestigious Memorial and Dedications Committee of the hospital until his recent demise. Dr. Greenberg was greatly respected by his patients and his peers and he will be sorely missed.

title: Computer Bites Man
description: In the end it didn't make any difference whether Deep Blue beat Garry Kasparov at chess or not, because the press was going to send the same message no matter who won. Had Mr. Kasparov triumphed, the headlines would have read: ''Man Beats Machine!'' When he lost, commentators worked hard to recast defeat as a moral victory. Deep Blue is not human or intelligent, we were reassured, but just a big, fat, soulless number cruncher. Deep Blue can't write a sonnet. Deep Blue can't hug a baby. Deep Blue has no sense of humor. (As if Garry Kasparov were George Carlin.)

title: The Welfare Worker And the Minimum Wage
description: The White House said last week that most of the welfare recipients put to work should be covered by minimum wage laws. Governors from both parties and the authors of last year's landmark law were surprised and angered by the long-awaited legal interpretation; they say it might gut the legislation's work requirements.

title: Narrowing Eighth St. to Widen Its Lure to Visitors
description: For the past few years, many merchants and residents have mounted various campaigns to reverse the decades-long change in character of Eighth Street, one of the Village's main boulevards. The street once housed galleries, bookshops and other eccentric stores and then gave way to downscale successors, including a lot of small shoe stores.

title: Hyperreal
description: In the new Information- Age Times Square, where brand names and corporate logos are rewriting the skyline, you can relax in an ''authentic'' Irish pub before studying your portfolio on a multi-story stock ticker or firing off a few rounds at a virtual-reality shooting gallery. It's an eclectic, electric streetscape of intense simulation: a hyperreality.

title: The 1997 Season: Something for All
description: IT is unlikely that any other seaside art community finds itself as both presenter and resource for historical exhibitions, as a locale for exibitions of new work by talented artist-residents and as a showcase for the latest international trends. Yet the scope of events scheduled for East End museums and galleries this season suggests that all these characteristics apply to this area of Long Island , long known for its appeal to artists.

title: With 20 Hits, Yankees Score Early and Often
description: Joe Torre had a headache tonight. Not the kind that the manager of the Yankees can list as an occupational hazard. This headache came from a clubhouse where colds are being passed around, and from air conditioning in a place where summer is already arriving.

title: Yonkers-Sarah Lawrence Feud Resurfaces in Aid Request
description: THIS city has encountered an inordinate number of obstacles over the years, not the least of which is a long-smoldering feud between Yonkers and one of its leading educational institutions, Sarah Lawrence College.

title: Beyond Closing the Door: How to Close the Whole Doorway
description: SOMETIMES a remodeling scheme may require removing a door then closing the opening. This can be done to change the entrance to the room, give you more privacy or add additional wall space. Closing a doorway may seem like a complicated project, but it is, in fact, a relatively simple task for anyone who has basic skill with hand tools. The only real tricks to the job are careful planning and paying attention to proper carpentry procedures.

title: Dazzling Treasures From Asia's Fabled Silk Route
description: HEADING UP MADISON AVENUE one morning 20 years ago, Guido Goldman was struck by a dazzling image in a second-floor gallery window: red blobs as large as sunflowers. Compelled to take a closer look, he crossed the street, went upstairs and found a silk hanging seemingly drenched with fantasy flowers. He was so won over by its vibrance that he immediately bought the work, a Central Asian weaving known as an ikat.

title: In Oakland, 400 Homes on 303 Acres, 203 Open Space
description: A 303-ACRE tract of woodlands edging the Ramapo River in this Bergen County borough is beginning its transformation into a residential enclave that will have 400 homes, but still preserve much of the site's natural setting.

title: On the East End, a Trove of Riches
description: YOU can tell the people who go to the Hamptons regularly. They never, never say ''the Hamptons.'' They say ''Southampton'' or ''East Hampton,'' unless they say ''Sagaponack'' or ''Amagansett'' or ''Wainscott,'' places every bit as Hamptonesque, if not more so, as the settlements privileged enough to have their names end with the fabled seven letters.

title: Once Too Small. Now Too Old? Never.
description: He has never had a beer.

title: Mandatory Drug Costs
description: Laws requiring judges to sentence drug felons to long prison terms have been criticized as wasting lives, but a new study reported last week that they waste money, too. An analysis by the Rand Corporation's Drug Policy Research Center determined that it is twice as cost effective to spend the same money arresting more cocaine dealers, confiscating their assets and letting judges decide the sentences. It is even more economical to steer addicted felons into treatment.

title: Rangers Suffer Still Another Loss: Flatley Is Out Indefinitely
description: It is flattering for Patrick Flatley that this season he rose from a spare part on the Rangers to a right wing on Wayne Gretzky's line for the beginning of the third round of the Stanley Cup playoffs.

title: Barkley Closer to Goal As Rockets Move Ahead
description: There have been moments in the Western Conference semifinals when Charles Barkley played with such intensity that he seemed destined for a confessional on talk-show television. Next on ''Oprah'': Men Who Want a Championship Too Much.

title: Rent (The Controversy) Plays to SRO in Yonkers
description: WHEN Audrey Herman, a divorced mother of one, stood up earlier this month at a town meeting here headed by State Senator Nicholas A. Spano, she pleaded with him not to tamper with the current rent regulations, which expire at 12:01 A.M. on June 16 unless extended.

title: Lisa Chookasezian and Noel Maitland
description: SOME people would rather hold an ice cube to their forehead for an hour than attend an organized singles event. Lisa Chookasezian, 32, was one.

title: Graduating With Honors And $100,000 in Debt
description: ON Thursday, Denis Gibbs will don cap and gown to receive a Bachelor of Arts degree from Johns Hopkins University in Baltimore. Soon after he completes his four-year college journey, he will begin another long trip: paying off, over 10 years, a six-figure accumulation of loans.

title: Adventures of a Man Who Defied the Gods: A Tale Retold With a New Goal of 'Reality'
description: UNDER a brilliant Mediterranean sky last fall, in a sandy cove surrounded by forested hills, a tribe of warriors gathered around a funeral pyre as eerie chants filled the air. They laid a body on the pyre and set it ablaze.

title: Thousands of Stores, So Little Time
description: JOY WEINER never really planned to make shopping her career. It just happened that way.

title: The Great Divide
description: MASON & DIXON

title: Richard Burbridge: THE REBUILDERS
description: For Richard Burbridge, taking someone's portrait is a dynamic art form. ''One of the things I find interesting is that we are having a conversation, there is constant communication,'' the 31-year-old Englishman says of his work. In shooting these power players of the Times Square redevelopment, his idea was to portray them as ''a group, equals amongst themselves'' and to play down their authority. ''I had to use my wits,'' he recalls. ''I tried to deconstruct the expectations of these people, their power and their importance. Many of them, of course, make a great deal of money, but a good majority of the group seem to truly be working to make Times Square a better place for the people.''

title: Not Even Rockies Get Best Of Jones
description: Off the mound, Bobby Jones is about as unassuming as they come. On it, the 27-year-old right-hander has become nothing short of a bear.

title: Pathfinders
description: Exceptional women are getting attention this week in BREAKING THROUGH: BEHIND THE WHEEL and on WOMEN, INC. The first -- THUR. at 7 P.M. on LIFETIME -- chronicles the trials and triumphs of women who compete in auto racing, an arena traditionally monopolized by men. The Indy racer Lyn St. James (above) is the only woman to be named rookie of the year at the Indy 500. The second documentary -- THUR. at 8 P.M. on CHANNEL 13 -- looks at four of New York State's successful entrepreneurs, including Eileen Fisher, president and C.E.O. of Eileen Fisher Clothing, who started her company in 1973 with four designs and this year expects sales of $66 million. Yolanda A. Andrews

title: Abelardo Morell: A SIMULATION OF SIGNS
description: ''I want a sort of historical record of what a room sees,'' says Abelardo Morell, a 48-year-old Cuban immigrant who lives in Brookline, Mass. Thus his penchant for the ancient technique of the camera obscura, in this case constructed by using the room itself as a camera, blacking out all but a half-inch circle of a window -- the aperture -- in room 1123 at the Times Square Marriott. Morell then set a camera on a tripod near the aperture, directing it into the room to record the optical phenomenon. Making a single exposure over two days, he captured a scene of meditative calm -- the room -- superimposed with the anarchy of Broadway. ''Think about how many people go through this site in two days -- millions -- and no one stood still long enough to get seen,'' he says. ''It's so empty, almost a perverse picture.''

title: N.J. School Priorities
description: To the Editor:

title: Karen Fried, Bradley Young
description: Karen Joan Fried, a board-game maker, is to be married this evening to Bradley M. Young, a bond salesman. Rabbi Chaim Stern is to perform the ceremony at the University Club in New York.

title: $100,000 To Make A Difference
description: Years ago, when his Fuzzy-Wuzzies and Bupkis Family toys were just taking off, Russell Berrie donated $500 to the United Jewish Appeal. But he thought hard before he handed it over, double-checking his balance, figuring up unpaid bills, forcing himself to quit thinking of the things that the money could buy.

title: Lars Tunbjork: THE COLOR OF CHANGE
description: Standing in the spot where he was mugged a decade ago, Lars Tunbjork fixated on the temporary measures taken during Times Square's redevelopment, especially the shuttered former theaters and porn shops that have been painted in glossy, exuberant colors, like some Brobdingnagian-child's toy blocks. ''It is a ghostlike place in the daylight, always empty,'' says the 41-year-old Swede. ''Yet there was this remarkable effort to make these empty buildings look nice. I suppose they'll be knocked down soon.'' Tunbjork, who is documenting office workers on three continents, is energized by the area's mix of grit, commercialism and buttoned-down corporatism. With tchotchke shops and McDonald's abutting trading floors and the Eighth Avenue sex industry, Tunbjork says he's ''never been to a place where you find so many different things in such a small area.''

title: A Theater That Changes Shape
description: AUDIENCES at the Performing Arts Center of Purchase College here have seen ballet in the Concert Hall, heard choral music in the Recital Hall and watched opera in the Pepsico Theater. But a fourth theater, tucked into an upstairs corner of the complex, has remained more mysterious.

title: Abstinence. Any More to Say?
description: Correspondents overwhelmingly wrote that they thought sex education in public schools should include, but not be limited to, teaching abstinence.

title: Critics Attack Actions Of Harrison Supervisor
description: ALL politics may be local, but local politics in some parts of Westchester County has historically been a blood sport, and since Philip A. Marraccini became Supervisor-Mayor here in 1994, the situation has become more than just politics as usual, many residents contend, saying that beneath the surface of this attractive, affluent community lies something far from attractive.

title: Clinton Assembles a List of Kennedyesque Challenges
description: In a speech meant to echo John F. Kennedy's 1961 challenge to the nation to put a man on the moon ''before this decade is out,'' President Clinton plans to use a commencement address on Sunday to call for scientists to develop an AIDS vaccine within the next 10 years.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KRIEG, JOHN P.
description: KRIEG-John P. On May 15, 1997. Beloved husband of Mary L. Loving father of Mary E. and Alfred Pacheco, Barbara A. Krieg, John A. and Debra Krieg, Peggy M. Krieg, Kathy T. and Ronnie Rothenberg, James C. and Erica Kreig, Judy M. and Lee Reichert and Paul F. Krieg. Dear son of Anna V. Krieg and brother to Charles F. Krieg. Also survived by five grandchildren. He will always be in our hearts. Visiting Monday, May 19, 2-4 and 7-9 PM, at Dangler Funeral Home, Morris Plains, NJ. Mass of Christian Burial, Tuesday, 12:45 PM, Assumption Church, Morristown, NJ. In lieu of flowers contributions may be made to Oratory Prep Development Fund, Summit, NJ.

title: Lynn Karren, Hugh Marlowe
description: Lynn Elizabeth Karren, the daughter of Ginger Dreyfus Karren of New York and Herbert E. Karren of San Antonio, was married yesterday to Hugh Marlowe, the son of Rosemary Tory Marlowe of New York and the late Hugh Marlowe. M. Michael Grupp, a leader of the Society for Ethical Culture in New York, performed the ceremony at the Church Center for the United Nations.

title: Wives and Husbands, Parents and Children, but First and Foremost, Artists
description: GOING into the family business always inspires mixed emotions, but more constructively than usual, perhaps, when that ''business'' is the making of art. Now, 23 visual artists -- parents and children, wives and husbands, siblings and in one case three generations -- are showing the public how their shared lives influence their work.

title: When the Saviors Are Seen as Sinners
description: WHEN officers from a joint New York City Police Department-Federal anti-drug task force set up shop in Washington Heights and Inwood last September, The Bridge Leader, a popular local newspaper, was quick to offer support. The paper, which is published twice a month, contained articles praising the police effort, and each issue featured a box, in English and Spanish, on how to report drug activities, including the task force's special telephone number, 439-NARC.

title: The Writer: A New Canadian Life-Form
description: THERE was a great advantage to being a Canadian back in 1956, the year I started writing in a manner I then considered serious: there was no heritage of intimidating geniuses looming above you as you wrote, joggling your elbow and blotting out the sun. There were a few Canadian writers then, but with their usual modesty the Canadians hid them from view, and you had to dig for them at the very backs of bookstores, among the maple syrup cookbooks and the autumn scenery. All that has now changed, but still, it was interesting to have grown up in a country in which you were relegated to a minor literary subcategory just by being a citizen of it.

title: Surfing Sickness, Too?
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KLEIN, ELEANOR PHILLIPS
description: KLEIN-Eleanor Phillips. On May 16, 1997. Age 80. Beloved wife of Kalman Klein; empathetic sister of Hazel Stanley; loving mother of Joan Gandy and the late Richard Springer; devoted grandmother of Steven Gandy, Susan GandySmith, Teresa Gandy-Humphrey, David Gandy, Mark Springer, Jonna Hutchinson, Adina Klein, and Oleanna Klein; great-grandmother of Aimee Gandy and Monique Smith; stepmother of Peter Klein and his wife Andrea Klein, and Stephan Klein and his wife Judy Graf Klein. We mourn the passing of a rare, vital and joyous spirit. Among her many other contributions, for 22 years she was a dedicated volunteer to the children of the Harbor Hills School in Roslyn, LI. She touched the lives of everyone who knew her. She will be sadly missed for the happiness she brought to all the world around her. A memorial service will be held at the Frank E. Campbell Funeral Chapel, Madison Avenue and 81st St, New York City, at 2:30 PM, on Tuesday, May 20.

title: Discussion of Generators Ignored Power Authority
description: To the Editor:

title: Bridgehampton
description: The new centerpiece of Bridgehampton this summer is the addition of the Bull's Head Bar and Grill to the one-year-old Bridgehampton Cafe. Don Evans, the co-owner, envisions the two restaurants as one (they are across the street from each other on Main Street). The Bull's Head at the old Boom Bistro has a wood-burning grill run by Jon LoPresti and the bar, overseen by Kevin Hallihan, who makes a killer Bloody Mary. features domestic wines and beers. Also new to town, in the former Get Juiced space on Main Street, is River Road, a funky little shop with young designer wear by Lindsay Morris. Elaine Benson's first art show of the season, a benefit for the John Steinbeck writer's room at Southampton College, has come and gone, but the gallery on Main Street has several other shows lined up with Friday afternoon openings benefitting various charities.

title: Books in Brief: Nonfiction
description: Dickens' Fur Coat

title: TAKING THE CHILDREN
description: The Fifth Element

title: To See and Be Seen
description: Among the party beneficiaries: a group that restores chateaus and gardens, the Museum of Natural History and American Ballet Theater.

title: Amagansett
description: The small hamlet of Amagansett in East Hampton Town harbors many secrets. Bluff Cottage is a historic and elegant inn with ocean views from every room. Owned and operated by a retired doctor and his wife, the bed and breakfast is a short walk to the popular Atlantic Avenue Beach as well as the jitney and train stations.

title: Soft-Shell Crabs Herald Warmer Days
description: WITH warmer weather come soft-shell crabs, one of spring's great delicacies. The most common way of cooking them is to dust them with flour and fry them. They are also very good grilled. I like to saute them a la meuniere and sprinkle them with a little hazelnut oil, chopped chives and lemon. They are also good grilled -- cutting down on fat -- and served with sauces made with tomato, lime and basil, or a puree of red peppers with tarragon.

title: B-52 Female Pilot Requests Discharge That Is Honorable
description: The country's first female B-52 pilot has decided to submit a request to be honorably discharged from the Air Force in hopes of avoiding court-martial on adultery and other charges this week.

title: New Releases
description: VARIOUS ARTISTS: 'LA ISLA DE LA MUSICA'

title: Fleetwood Stage Offers Comedy by Ayckbourn
description: WHEN ''How the Other Half Loves'' opened on Broadway in 1971, it was not yet apparent to American audiences that Alan Ayckbourn's tricky stagecraft, his playing with time and space, was a clever cover-up for dark undercurrents. Over the next 25 years, a profusion of plays would establish Mr. Ayckbourn as the world's most prolific chronicler of lives unraveling with a comedic beat.

title: At the Casinos
description: What's happening onstage at all the Atlantic City casinos this week. Tickets are available through Ticketmaster, (800) 736-1420.

title: At Kentucky Science Fair, Enough Awe for Everyone
description: Five Nobel laureates, among the world's greatest scientists, pondered this question over breakfast on Tuesday:

title: Margaret Samek, Herman-Jan Smith
description: Margaret Ellen Samek, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Edward L. Samek of Edison, N.J., was married yesterday to Herman-Jan Smith, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Christiaan Smith of Jakarta, Indonesia. The Rev. Robert E. Martin performed the ceremony at the Crescent Avenue Presbyterian Church in Plainfield, N.J.

title: PAPERBACK BEST SELLERS: May 18, 1997
description: Weeks

title: Pre-K Parties With 10-K Favors
description: NOW is the high season for annual meetings. All shareholders are invited, but relatively few show up. They blame the distant locations or the press of other obligations, when, in fact, most people assume that an annual meeting will be pointless and dull.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BARON, SAMUEL
description: BARON-Samuel. Beloved husband of Carol. Devoted father of Pamela and David. Dear brother of Sydel Fishman. Dear son-in-law of Esther Kitzes. Cherished uncle, brother-in-law and cousin. Services Sunday, 12 noon, at Riverside Nassau North Chapel, 55 North Station Plaza, Great Neck (opposite LIRR).

title: Tending Your Portfolio
description: Too often, mutual fund portfolios grow out of control as investors add interesting or new funds but neglect to prune their holdings.

title: Why the Odd and Obscure Names?
description: HAVING bought expensive oceanfront houses on a beautiful stretch of Amagansett, some property owners joined to petition the town to change the street name in 1926.

title: War Is Heck
description: THE LITTLE SHIPS The Heroic Rescue at Dunkirk in World War II. By Louise Borden. Illustrated by Michael Foreman. Unpaged. New York: Margaret K. McElderry Books. $15. (Ages 9 and up)

title: Downtown Via Dublin
description: ON a recent Sunday afternoon, Frank McCourt stood on a stage at the Clemente Soto Velez Cultural Center on Suffolk Street, reading from ''Angela's Ashes,'' the Pulitzer Prize-winning memoir of his wretched, poverty-stricken childhood in Limerick. Behind him was the set for ''Flaherty's Widow,'' a play by another Irishman, the acclaimed young novelist Colum McCann, just finishing a successful run at the resident Daedalus Theater Company.

title: County Plan to Buy Land For Golf Course at Issue
description: A PROPOSAL for the county to buy 174 acres in New Castle for use as a public golf course was described last week as ''one of the best real estate deals the county could ever have.'' But the elected officials who have the final say on the matter were generally skeptical about the idea of spending taxpayer money on a high-priced golf course.

title: With a Deal Like This, Who Needs a Salary?
description: YOU may have heard a lot about the billionaire H. Wayne Huizenga and the kudos he received when he refused both salary and bonus upon taking over Republic Industries in 1995.

title: Along the Grand Canyon, and Down to Its Floor
description: HIGHWAY 89 north of Flagstaff, Ariz., slices straight over the flat, scrub-covered Colorado Plateau. When I drove it, late one Wednesday afternoon in early April, there were snow clouds up ahead. Across the Navajo Reservation to the east, I could see the Echo Cliffs reaching all the way into Utah, and my rear view mirror framed Arizona's crown, 12,655-foot Humphreys Peak in the San Francisco Mountains to the south.

title: Chinese Dissident Puts U.S. Policy to Shame
description: To the Editor:

title: Biblioteca: Best Translated as Library and Community Center
description: It's hard to miss the bright yellow awning that wraps around the Jemma Loan Company at Newark and Jersey Avenues in downtown Jersey City. But for two decades, many of the city's 45,000 Spanish-speaking residents failed to notice the institution just above the corner pawn shop: New Jersey's only Spanish-language library branch.

title: Costa Rica Inn
description: To the Editor: My husband and I highly recommend a little-known country inn in Costa Rica situated on a tropical plantation overlooking the Rio Grande Canyon Nature Preserve. The inn, Posada Las Palomas, is 20 minutes from the international airport and 40 minutes from San Jose. Nestled in tropical gardens are four guest cottages constructed with local woods in Japanese style. We stayed four nights in early March and were often alone in enjoying the tiled pool, whirlpool, waterfall and canyon vistas. There are two other units in the house.

title: Resisting a Development Among the Lilacs
description: When Community Board 11 rejected a developer's plan last month to tear down a 65-year-old house in Little Neck and build a small medical building in its place, the decision did little to salve the worries of longtime residents who believed that the development would ruin the beauty of their lilac-framed community.

title: The Money Is in the Stock, Not The Books
description: For a print journalist who is tired of hearing that the rise of technology, broadcasting and the Internet will soon make words on paper superfluous, the amazing success of Jeffrey Bezos is indeed satisfying.

title: Pushing a Product With Herbal Punch
description: HAVE you ever wondered about your forgetfulness? Or dreamed of the day the energy of your toddler or teen-ager could be bottled for your own consumption? If so, John Bello thinks he has a potion or two that could help.

title: Marit Larson And Adam Sobel
description: Marit Gisela Larson, an environmental scientist, is to be married in Brooklyn today to Adam Harrison Sobel, who is completing a Ph.D. in meteorology at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology. Rabbi David Posner is to perform the ceremony at the Palm House in the Brooklyn Botanic Garden.

title: No Headline
description: ''He committed some crimes, but it's my feeling he probably got convicted for a lot less than other people who haven't got caught. I mean, he got caught with his hand in the cookie jar, but there's other folks still holding that cookie jar.''

title: Another Kind of Middle-Class Squeeze
description: KARL MARX preached it. Last week, Gov. George E. Pataki of New York proclaimed it: Society's have-nots have finally converged with most of the haves into a single class.

title: U.S. Hasn't Stopped Assaulting Other Cultures
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: Because of a typographical error, an article about the Dominican Republic last Sunday in The Sophisticated Traveler, part 2 of The Times Magazine, referred incorrectly to the legendary creatures called ciguapas. They are beautiful women -- not beautiful men -- who lure men into their homes at the bottom of mountain rivers.

title: Stephanie Bunting, Steven Glaser
description: Stephanie Lee Bunting, a daughter of Diane and Richard L. Bunting of Bainbridge, N.Y., is to be married this evening to Steven Ronald Glaser, a son of Dr. Joy H. Glaser and Jack Glaser of Scarsdale, N.Y. Rabbi Stephen A. Klein is to officiate at Tappan Hill in Tarrytown, N.Y.

title: Princeton Crew Captures No. 7
description: Princeton's varsity eight won the grand final of the Women's Eastern Sprint Championship for the seventh consecutive year today on a blustery Lake Waramaug course.

title: Xerox Plans Endowment To Research Knowledge
description: Everyone knows people like this: The brilliant mechanics who can diagnose a problem by how a motor sounds, but can't describe what they hear. Or the top salesmen and women who know exactly when to shut up, mid-pitch, but can't explain how.

title: A Jazzy Day at the Beach For Laid-Back Hipsters
description: Kevin O'Day's ballet ''Open Strings,'' set to a rich, commissioned guitar score by the experimental jazz composer John King, is playful and shrewd: an entertaining beach piece that evokes a 1990's downtown version of Jerome Robbins's 1945 ''Interplay.''

title: Image Retrieval System Wins M.I.T. Entrepreneurship Prize
description: The Massachusetts Institute of Technology, which coaxes the entrepreneurial spirit out of its students each year in the $50K Entrepreneurship Competition Award, last week awarded its grand prize to a team called Imagen for its image retrieval technologies.

title: ERA OF DOWNSIZING CREATES JOB BOOM FOR CLASS OF '97
description: At colleges and universities around the country, the class of '97 is graduating this spring into the most auspicious job market in memory, a product of today's soaring economy and, in many ways, the large-scale layoffs that cut a swath through their parents' generation.

title: Let Down the Barriers
description: More than 30 years ago, in one of the many nasty fights over integrating the New York City schools, there was a huge march in a snowstorm across the Brooklyn Bridge. Fifteen thousand boisterous protesters, most of them women and all of them white, marched from the Board of Education in Brooklyn to City Hall in lower Manhattan. What they wanted was no change in their mostly white neighborhood schools. Integration may or may not have been O.K. as a concept, but steps to make it a reality got those parents out of their homes and onto the bridge in a hurry.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MASON, PATRICIA
description: MASON-Patricia. On May 18, 1997. Real estate broker, Senior Vice President, William B. May Company. Wife of Francis Mason, mother of Spencer Mason and Leslie Scarlett Mason, grandmother of Dexter Mason. Memorial service on Thursday, June 5, 1997, 12:30 PM, at the Church of St. Luke in the Fields, 427 Hudson Street, New York, NY 10014. Patricia Mason was a keen supporter of the T. H. Everett Rock Garden at the New York Botanical Garden, the Greenhouse at Wave Hill, the Garden Conservancy and the School of American Ballet. In lieu of flowers friends may wish to consider contributions to those organizations. Robert Bartolomei is Curator of the T. H. Everett Rock Garden, N.Y. Botanical Garden. 200th Street and Southern Boulevard, Bronx, NY 10458. Marco Polo Stufano is Curator at Wave Hill, 675 West 252 Street, Bronx, NY 10471. Garden Conservancy's address is Box 219, Cold Spring, NY 10516. Albert Bellas is Chairman, School of American Ballet, 70 Lincoln Center Plaza, NY, NY 10023.

title: From Suspended to Eliminated: Another Bad Ending for Ewing
description: When the game was over, when another season with the wrong ending had ticked its final second, Patrick Ewing simply stood on his tired, aching legs and walked away from the pain of seeing the other team celebrate. Ewing was near the end of the Knicks' bench, holding a towel in his right hand, refusing to look up as he began to leave. This season, more than any other, he had come to believe that he finally had a championship team behind him. But there was no one on his back as he walked off. He left alone, which, for the most part, was how he played.

title: Hardaway's 38 Points Amaze His Biggest Fans
description: There had to be ice cream in the Miami Arena somewhere. But darn if Donald Hardaway could find it, shuffling past every concession stand with 5-year-old Timothy Hardaway Jr. swinging by his hand.

title: Of Peter Pan Racers, Belmont Gets None
description: With his easy victory in yesterday's Peter Pan Stakes at Belmont Park, Banker's Gold has emerged as the most exciting 3-year-old racing in New York. Fortunately for the Triple Crown contender Silver Charm, he is not nominated to the June 7 Belmont Stakes.

title: Rebel Army Captured Zaire In T-Shirts and Tennis Shoes
description: When the Zairian rebel leader Laurent Kabila announced last October that he would topple President Mobutu Sese Seko, almost no one took him seriously. But in a scant seven months, his rebel army conquered a country as large as the United States east of the Mississippi, including thousands of square miles of some of the thickest jungle in the world.

title: Liberal Party Moves To Endorse Giuliani
description: The Liberal Party took its first step toward giving its party line to Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani, a Republican, and two Democrats yesterday.

title: Skin-Deep Generosity
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  YOUSKEVITCH, ANNA SCARPOVA.
description: YOUSKEVITCH-Anna Scarpova. Former soloist with the Ballet Russe de Monte Carlo, over 50 years distinguished and prominent New York City ballet teacher and widow of legendary Premier Danseur Igor Youskevitch. Passed away after a brief illness on May 15. Survived by an only daughter, Maria Youskevitch. Funeral services Friday, May 23, 10 AM, Russian Orthodox Cathedral, 75 East 93rd Street. A memorial fund has been established to honor her memory. Donations to go toward a new production of ''Afternoon of a Faun,'' with choreography by Kirk Peterson as part of the Hartford Ballet Tribute to Russian Ballet Series ''Fire and Ice II,'' 226 Farmington Avenue, Hartford, CT 06105.

title: Rejection From Leader Who Vows Diversity
description: The denial of tenure to a brilliant young scholar at Harvard University is hardly a rare event. Indeed, decisions over tenure -- the academic prize that confers a job for life -- are often contentious, with all the political intrigue of, say, a White House Cabinet appointment.

title: Crime and Politics
description: Donna Ratliff was 8 years old when her uncle was convicted of sexually molesting her. Two other members of her family abused her. Her mother regularly beat and threatened to kill her.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  EPSTEIN, BILLIE (STERN)
description: EPSTEIN-Billie (Stern). On May 16, 1997, of Tarrytown, NY. Beloved wife of Nathan B. Epstein. Loving mother of Barbara Rigney and Susan Bannon. Grandmother of Michael and Katie Bannon. Services and interment were private and held on Sunday May 18, 1997.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KITTENPLAN, GERTRUDE S.
description: KITTENPLAN-Gertrude S. On May 18, 1997. Beloved wife of the late Reuben. Devoted mother of Stephen Kittenplan and Juliet Goldsmith. Mother-in-law of Gail and Robert. Loving grandmother of Susan and Betsey Kittenplan, Amy and Joshua Hubbard, Richard and Linda Goldsmith, Gillian and Peter Rittmaster. Interment private.

title: Frank Slocum, 71, an Executive In Baseball and a Writer for TV
description: Frank Slocum, a former major league baseball executive and award-winning television writer who later devoted himself to aiding former players in need of financial assistance, died yesterday at his home in Greenwich, Conn. He was 71.

title: Thompson Chicago Quits Midas Account
description: J. Walter Thompson Chicago will resign the national advertising account of the Midas International Corporation, effective Aug. 15, citing a conflict with its important Ford Motor Company account. Thompson Chicago has handled the Midas account, with billings estimated at $25 million, since October 1995.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  EHRLICH, DR. HERMAN
description: EHRLICH-Dr. Herman. Of Hollywood, FL, formerly of Somerville, NJ. Passed away on May 15, 1997 at the age of 90. Beloved husband of 57 years of the late Lillian Ehrlich; adored and adoring father of Amy Tobin, Hollywood, and Joan Ehrlich-White, NY; loved and admired father-in-law of Jack Tobin and Arthur White; loving, proud and cherished grandfather of Michael and Lisa Tobin. Donations in his memory may be sent to American Cancer Society or Temple Solel of Hollywood, FL.

title: Anna Scarpova Youskevitch, 85, A Ballet Dancer and Teacher
description: Anna Scarpova Youskevitch, a prominent ballet teacher and a former member of the Ballets Russes troupes of the 1930's and 40's, died on Thursday at the Broadview Health Facility in West Hartford, Conn. She was 85 and lived in Manhattan.

title: Patricia Mason, 71, Is Dead; Greenwich Village Broker
description: Patricia Mason, a real-estate broker who handled the sales of some of New York's best-known properties in recent years and who was well-known as a horticulturist, died at St. Vincent's Hospital early yesterday. She was 71 and lived in Greenwich Village.

title: Commuting by Electric Car
description: One problem with mass transit in the suburbs is that it often does not quite take people where they need to go. But transportation officials say they have at least a partial solution. Beginning today, employees of three Morristown companies who commute by train will have electric cars waiting for them so that they can drive to work from the train stations.

title: Kabila Fields A Team Short On Seasoning
description: A day after seizing power, Zaire's new President, Laurent Kabila, remained closeted today in this sun-washed and quiet southern town with his closest advisers, struggling to transform his seven-month-old rebel movement into a transitional government.

title: Crampton Ends a Drought, But Needs 3 Extra Holes
description: It was the first playoff in the Cadillac-N.F.L. Golf Classic, and Bruce Crampton and Hugh Baiocchi made it a memorable one.

title: Unofficial Prom Wins Out
description: Officials at Camden High School came up with what they thought was a fitting punishment for about 40 seniors who misbehaved on a class trip to Disney World in March: they barred them from the senior prom.

title: Climbing Mount Everest
description: Mount Everest is an entity that accumulates numbers, but which numbers can scarcely appraise. Its peak lies 29,028 feet above sea level on the border of Tibet and Nepal -- the highest spot on earth. The first ascent took place 44 years ago this month. Since then, according to Jon Krakauer's new book, ''Into Thin Air,'' Everest has been climbed more than 630 times. Since 1921, when the first British expedition reached the base of the mountain, 150 climbers have died on its slopes, including the five who have died so far this season. The top of Everest is high enough to penetrate the jet stream, and the summit can be gained only when the jet stream has been diverted northward, during a rare interval of good weather before the summer monsoon blows in from the Bay of Bengal. What kills climbers is almost never the technical difficulty of the most familiar route, which is not extreme. It is the weather -- abruptly, unexpectedly fouling the mountain, as it did last year, when eight climbers died in the aftermath of a sudden storm.

title: Dividend Meetings
description: A partial list for this week.

title: Suspect in Student's Killing Has Prison Record
description: That a school janitor was charged with murdering 18-year-old Michelle Montoya at Rio Linda High School on Friday was shocking enough. But now residents here want to know how the school could have hired the man even though he was a gang member on parole for manslaughter.

description: KLEIN-Eleanor Phillips. On May 16, 1997. Age 80. Beloved wife of Kalman Klein; empathetic sister of Hazel Stanley; loving mother of Joan Gandy and the late Richard Springer; devoted grandmother of Steven Gandy, Susan GandySmith, Teresa Gandy-Humphrey, David Gandy, Mark Springer, Jonna Hutchinson, Adina Klein, and Oleanna Klein; great-grandmother of Aimee Gandy and Monique Smith; stepmother of Peter Klein and his wife Andrea Klein, and Stephan Klein and his wife Judy Graf Klein. description: ZERNIK-Charlotte E. May 19, 1996. Missing you very dearly. In loving memory Helmut, families, and friends

title: Fair Warning to Teachers Who Dare Fail Students
description: As human-potential movements and sophomoric talk shows continue to seduce the gullible public with questionable expectations, the question of entitlement becomes dangerously distorted. Education is one hot spot. A few months ago, Garry Trudeau's ''Doonesbury'' comic strip featured a college student threatening his professor with a lawsuit because he wasn't given a grade needed for his carefully planned career. Funny, in a ludicrous way, and a bit frightening.

title: Treasury Schedules Sales of Bills
description: The Treasury's schedule of financing this week has today's regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills and an auction of 52-week bills on Thursday.

title: INSIDE METRO
description: OFFICER KILLED A police officer in Manhattan was shot and killed in a apartment building. B3.

title: On Keeping Up, Barely, With Communications
description: THE HIGHWAYMEN

title: Irish President Favored for U.N. Rights Post
description: President Mary Robinson of Ireland has become the leading candidate for the position of United Nations High Commissioner for Human Rights, diplomats and representatives of human rights groups said today.

title: Rains Come to Wall Street And With Them, Godzilla
description: Several hundred somberly dressed people, black umbrellas bobbing over their heads, splayed across the steps of Federal Hall and into the intersection of Wall and Broad Streets. In an instant, they turned, screamed, dropped their umbrellas, bumped into one another, fell to the pavement or scrambled away in terror. A few stared, wild-eyed, into the empty sky, as though they saw something there.

title: At Wing or Center, Gretzky Is Still Great
description: FOUR measly caps. That was the entire harvest of caps on the ice when Wayne Gretzky completed his hat trick against the Flyers yesterday. Wayne Gretzky, the wing, that is.

title: With Possibly Fateful Results, Turkey Debates Islamic Schools
description: When Turkey's National Security Council met in February, military commanders who were demanding that Prime Minister Necmettin Erbakan retreat from his Islamist policies showed a startling video that police agents had secretly recorded.

title: The Block, The Blame: Ward Vows To Handle It
description: Charlie Ward kept his head up afterward, fielding all the tough questions without a blink. The point guard knows the criticism he faces will multiply now that the Knicks have been eliminated.

title: Corporate Web Police Hunt Down E-Pirates
description: Joshua Bauchner, who spends most workdays stalking suspected copyright pirates on the Internet, is about to make a big haul. Typing in the word ''warez,'' he waits for a search engine to spit out sites that include the term, which means pirated software in Internet parlance.

title: Oracle Deal for Netscape's Network Computing Unit Is Seen
description: The Oracle Corporation and the Netscape Communications Corporation will announce on Monday that Oracle will make a majority investment in Navio Communications Inc., a company established by Netscape to develop Internet software for consumer electronics, a person familiar with the investment said.

title: Where to Get a Tuneup For Your Internet Browser
description: Grandmother's house was just over the river and through the woods. But getting to places on the World Wide Web is not always so simple.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TILYOU, JOHN H.
description: TILYOU-John H. On May 15, 1997. Of Brooklyn, NY, and Palm Beach, FL. Loving brother of George Tilyou and Joan Kean. Beloved uncle of many nephews and nieces, and several great-nephews and nieces, and large family of loving relatives and friends. Visiting at the Fairchild Chapel, Franklin Ave. at 12th St., Garden City, NY, Tuesday, 7-9 PM and Wednesday 2-5 and 7-9 PM. Mass of Christian Burial, St. Joseph's R.C. Church, Garden City, Thursday, 10 AM. Interment Holy Cross Cemetery, Brooklyn, NY.

title: Giuliani's Tax-Cut Plan Faces G.O.P. Opposition in Albany
description: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's plan for $284 million in tax cuts, one of the pillars of his election-year budget, is drawing opposition from an unexpected quarter: his fellow Republicans in the State Senate, whose approval is required for nearly all of the proposals to become law.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ENGEL, IRVING H.
description: ENGEL-Irving H. The Officers, Directors, staff and children of the Hebrew Academy of Long Beach note with profound sorrow the passing of Irving Engel. Devoted friend, generous patron since its inception and member of the Board of Governors. May the Almighty console the bereaved family among the mourners of Zion. Rabbi Dr. Armin H. Friedman, Dean Emeritus Rabbi Dr. Heshy T. Glass, Principal Jerry Williams, President Rabbi Zvi H. Friedman, Exec. Dir.

title: Consumer Symbols Are Our Larger Reality
description: To the Editor:

title: For Adelphi, Graduation Follows Turbulent Year
description: With exuberant cheers, the formal trappings of caps and gowns and a collective sigh of relief, Adelphi University, in Garden City, N.Y., yesterday celebrated the end of the most wrenching academic year in its long history.

title: Digital's Suit Against Intel: Planning for the Next War
description: After the Digital Equipment Corporation sued the Intel Corporation, contending it violated a raft of Digital's patents, precincts of the computer world were variously bemused, enthused and confused.

title: At Shea, Rockies Hit Another Road Bump
description: When the Colorado Rockies opened this season on the road, the Cincinnati Reds' Deion Sanders -- a hobbyist who had not played baseball for a year -- greeted them with six hits in two games. And the Rockies lost two straight.

title: As Television Changes, '60 Minutes' Holds Its Own
description: Ten days ago, it was Mike Wallace's birthday. The famously ferocious ''60 Minutes'' correspondent had to laugh as staff members trooped into his office, following his secretary, Kay Lim, and a cake with this frosted message on top: ''You don't look a day over 79.''

title: Next Stop, Chicago: Riley Adjusts Rearview Mirror to See Knicks
description: Pat Riley heard a chant yesterday different from the ones directed at him Friday night in New York.

title: Rebel Army Consolidates Its Hold Over Kinshasa
description: After a night of wild gunfire, Zaire's victorious rebel army took complete possession of this city of five million people today, transforming themselves in the process into the new authorities of Africa's third-largest country.

title: New Jersey Law Discriminates Against Gypsies
description: To the Editor:

title: Minority Voice Fading For Broadcast Owners
description: The sparse ranks of minority radio and television station owners are growing thinner, a result of the consolidation frenzy in the radio industry compounded by the elimination of a Federal tax credit that favored minority groups.

title: Strawberry to Give It a Try
description: Darryl Strawberry's attempt to come back from his left knee injury will begin at Class AA Norwich on Monday night, a day earlier than Yankee Manager Joe Torre had hoped.

title: Even on His Bad Day, Woods Is Still a Winner
description: He was in the drink on 3 and on the edge of a storm drain on 15, and he slid enough putts off the edges of holes to break the spirit of any touring pro. But Tiger Woods, on a day he played as if he were ordinary, showed why he isn't and followed his historic Masters championship with a two-shot victory today in the GTE Byron Nelson Classic.

title: Painless Primary May Hurt Messinger
description: For months, Democratic leaders in New York had hoped for an early conclusion to the mayoral primary, thus avoiding a divisive and protracted contest that could debilitate their nominee and guarantee Rudolph W. Giuliani's re-election.

title: Accounts
description: *Pacific Health Laboratories Inc., Woodbridge, N.J., to Margeotes/Fertitta & Partners, New York, to handle its Endurox line of herbal workout supplements, previously handled by the Sawtooth Group, Woodbridge. Billings were estimated at $15 million.

title: Police Officer Is Killed In Shooting In Manhattan
description: A police officer was shot and killed early today in a Manhattan apartment building during what witnesses called a robbery attempt, police officials said.

title: A surprising poor performance by Informix has most analysts backing off the company's stock.
description: AS recently as September, shares in the Informix Corporation traded as high as $31.125, and the consensus among Wall Street analysts was to rank the stock a buy. Today, with the shares barely above $10, the consensus recommendation of 23 analysts surveyed by First Call has retreated to a hold, with three or four recommending selling the stock and just one lone optimist advising investors to buy.

title: Microsoft Set To Offer Guide To New York
description: Microsoft's ambitious march into the media business continues today as its on-line city guide, New York Sidewalk, goes up on the Internet.

title: F.C.C. Waives Foreign Ownership Rules For Nextwave Telecom
description: Nextwave Telecom Inc., which is trying to build a national network for wireless communications, can keep its foreign investors and try to raise more money overseas under an agreement with Federal regulators, the company announced Friday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BARON, SAMUEL
description: BARON-Samuel. The Juilliard School mourns the passing of Samuel Baron, distinguished member of the flute faculty since 1971 and chairman of the Woodwind Department for the past several years. His extraordinary artistry, his dedication to his students, and his exceptional creativity as an arranger of woodwind ensemble music made him a revered member of the Juilliard community. As the flutist of the New York Woodwind Quintet, he helped develop the woodwind chamber music program at The Juilliard School and brought it to new levels of excellence. He will be deeply missed by us all. Mary Rodgers Guettel Chairman, Board of Trustees Joseph W. Polisi President

title: Mother and Grandmother Charged With Fatally Poisoning Girl, 5
description: A 5-year-old girl from the Bronx who has been missing for three weeks was murdered, the police said, and yesterday her mother and grandmother were charged with killing her by forcing the girl to drink a toxic brew of ammonia, pepper, vinegar and olive oil and then throwing her body out with the garbage.

title: No, We're Not Immortal
description: To the Editor:

title: Not a Tantrum
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  BROAD, MONROE MAXIMILIAN., MD.
description: BROAD-Monroe Maximilian., MD. 25 February 1909-19 May 1987. In Loving Remembrance.

title: Motorcycle Enthusiast Is Killed at Traffic Light
description: A former maitre d'hotel and assistant manager at four SoHo restaurants was fatally shot and his motorcycle stolen Saturday night at a Lower East Side traffic light.

title: When Turk Played Chess and Fooled Us
description: To the Editor:

title: Goalie Shuffle Continues For Flyers
description: Garth Snow was knocked out today, the victim of a standing-five count. One, two, three, four, five goals on 10 shots, most of which he could have stopped, and the white towel was waved by his corner man, Terry Murray, the Flyers' coach.

title: No. 6 Line, a Maddening Mess, Could Get Worse
description: It is that crucial moment when the morning rush hour builds to a crescendo and the No. 6 trains are running amok, leaving an extended conga line backed up along the Upper East Side of Manhattan.

title: Profiting as a business-to-business middleman on the Internet is tricky.
description: THE idea seemed to be a winner. An on-line shopping mall for manufacturers, using the power of the Internet as a low-cost medium of communications to link industrial buyers and sellers. It was a classic application of technology to an economic inefficiency -- the often Dickensian business chore known as procurement. It still means thumbing through hulking directories for part numbers and product specifications and consumes millions of hours and billions of dollars a year.

title: People
description: * Janet Coombs was named president of the New York office of Wunderman Cato Johnson, a unit of Young & Rubicam Inc., succeeding Barbara Jack, now the agency's worldwide chief executive. Ms. Coombs had been chairwoman and chief executive at the Chapman Agency, New York, also part of Y.& R.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FOX, JAMES MONROE
description: FOX-James Monroe. On May 16, 1997. Retired Assistant Director F.B.I. in charge of NY Office. A graduate of Augustana College and University of Illinois Law School. A resident of NYC and Carmel Valley, CA. Beloved husband of Elaine. Devoted father of Sandra Cerdan and Tracey Van Every. Loving grandfather of Tyler James Van Every and Colton Monroe Cerdan. Dear brother of Patricia Owsley. A service and celebration of his life will be held on Wednesday, May 21, at 10:30 AM, in the Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church, 5th Avenue at 55th Street, NYC. In lieu of flowers, a contribution in his memory to one of the following charities would be appreciated: The National Center for Missing and Exploited Children, 9176 Alternate A1A-Suite 100, Lake Park, FL 33403, Guiding Light for the Blind, 611 Granite Springs Road, Yorktown Heights, NY 10598, or the Health Care Chaplaincy, 307 East 60th St, NY, NY 10022.

title: 100 Wild Chickens at Large
description: For more than six months, homeowners in Moors Landing, a 347-unit development, have been losing sleep and portions of their gardens to a band of about 100 wild chickens roving the complex's wide streets and woodsy backyards.

title: McDonald's Prepares Big Shift in Top Management Structure
description: In an attempt to jump-start its profitability and build its market share, the McDonald's Corporation will soon make sweeping changes in the top management structure of its United States business.

title: Gretzky Turns Back Time and Philadelphia
description: Even without that whiz-bang, multicolored, techno-puck enhancement gizmo used by the Fox television network, Wayne Gretzky would have left a few of his own comet trails around Core States Center this afternoon.

title: CHRONICLE
description: WILLIAM D. WALSH is not a man to hold a grudge. In 1947, his first year at Fordham University, he was cut from the football team by the freshman coach, Vince Lombardi.

title: C-Plus Is Enough For Tiger to Triumph
description: AT the Masters, Tiger Woods had what he calls his ''A game,'' and he won. But even with a two-stroke lead at 15 under par here in the GTE Byron Nelson Classic after a three-under-par 67 in Saturday's third round, he knew his golf game deserved a lower mark.

title: That Fine Spring Day in 1947
description: Looking back 50 years to the dawn of the cold war, a certain modesty is in order. We now know who won, and can itemize the mileposts of victory. The nuclear peace held, the industrial democracies hung together, and over time the Soviet empire collapsed, just as George Kennan foresaw in his pivotal ''long telegram'' from Moscow in February 1946. There he urged collective resistance to Stalin's expansionary drive, yet presciently added that the success of the Soviet system ''is not yet finally proven'' and its permanence ''need not yet be regarded as assured.''

title: A detector to let flight crews know if passenger 24C really turned off his computer for takeoff.
description: CAN a game of computer solitaire played on a laptop in seat 24B really emit electronic signals strong enough to send a jet veering off course?

title: INSIDE
description: Policeman Is Killed

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FLEISIG, ROBIN
description: FLEISIG-Robin. Suddenly and untimely, on May 16. Beloved and loving wife and best friend of Roger Greene, loving mother of Eric and Perry Fleisig-Greene, dear daughter of Beverly and Earl Fleisig and cherished daughter-in-law of Ruth Greene and the late Murray Greene, beloved sister of Merrill and dear sister-in-law of Lloyd, Sharon, and John, and loving aunt of Emily. We will miss her tremendously.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROSEN, SETH DONALD
description: ROSEN-Seth Donald. 33, passed away in Wheaton, IL on May 17 of brain cancer. He is survived by his wife, Denise (Winsouer), his parents Marvin and Patricia Rosen of NYC, brother Michael and sister-in-law Wendy Jacobson Rosen of Northbrook, IL, brother Howard of NYC. In lieu of flowers, the family requests that gifts be made to the Seth D. Rosen Memorial Scholarship Fund at the University of Illinois at Chicago. UIC College of Liberal Arts & Sciences (M/C 228), 410 UH, 601 South Morgan St., Chicago, IL 60607-7128.

title: Silver Charm Poised to Make a Clean Sweep Into History Book
description: The job is two-thirds done, but now Silver Charm has to reach down and give the performance of his career to complete it by winning the mile-and-a-half Belmont Stakes three weeks from now and becoming the 12th horse in racing history to sweep the Triple Crown.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHERMAN, JANICE G.
description: SHERMAN-Janice G. (Rubinfeld). Lake Peekskill, on May 14. Devoted wife of Joseph. Loving mother of Randi and Dorie. Grandmother of Sarah, Jessie, and Ariel. Worked and graduated from Hunter College, Summa cum laude, at age 56. We will miss her always.

title: 2d West Bank Killing Linked to Land Sale
description: A Palestinian accused of selling land to Israelis has been found slain in the West Bank, in the second such killing since the Palestinian Authority announced this month that it would impose a death sentence on Arabs who sold land to Jews.

title: Gift of an Education For the 2d Generation
description: In 1981, Eugene M. Lang surprised 61 fidgety sixth graders in a Harlem auditorium with the promise that if they graduated from high school, he would make sure they got the chance to attend college. And he did, providing mentors and scholarships that kept most of them in school and on a path to greater things.

title: Besides the Good Book, a Good Read Sells, Too
description: A shift in reading tastes among many churchgoers, especially those who patronize Christian bookstores, has opened a profitable new opportunity for publishers who specialize in religious books.

title: NATOwater
description: Does Ken Starr do diplomacy?

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEVINE, FRED
description: LEVINE-Fred. On May 16, 1997. A resident of Manhattan, an avid handball player at Central Park's handball court. Service private.

title: Avoid Overkill on Legal Aid
description: Over the last three years, as New York City confronted a tight budget squeeze, the Legal Aid Society has seen its funding from the city cut 25 percent, from $79 million to $60 million. Coping with such a steep reduction is never pleasant. But it forced the society, for three decades the city's main provider of legal help for indigent defendants, to streamline its operations and seek better ways to manage its crushing caseload.

title: NEW YORK OFFERS POLLUTION PERMITS TO LURE COMPANIES
description: New York State has long offered companies tax breaks, low-interest loans, grants and other incentives to lure them into doing business in the state. But now the Pataki administration is dangling a new kind of enticement: permission to pollute.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHARZER, EDWARD
description: SHARZER-Edward. Of Brookline, MA. Husband of Mildred (Goodman). Father of Dr. Leonard A. Sharzer of NY, and Risa Nyman of Brookline, MA. Brother of Mollie Levitt of FL, and Esther Norris of RI. Cherished grandfather of Brenda, Pamela, Devora, Jessica and Rebecca. Also survived by six great-grandhildren. Services by Stanetsky Memorial Chapels, Brookline, MA, Monday, May 19. Shiva will be at his late residence. Expressions of sympathy in his memory may be donated to Congreation Beth David, 64 Corey Rd., Brookline, MA 02146 or the New England Chassidic Center-Congregation Beth Pinchas, 1710 Beacon St., Brookline, MA 02146.

title: Economic Calender
description: Expected dates for the release of major economic indicators this week.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHONBERG, BESSIE
description: SCHONBERG-Bessie. The artists, Board of Directors and staff of Dance Theater Workshop (DTW) deeply mourn the loss of their friend, artistic guide and mentor. Her vision, inspiration and generosity will be with us forever. She now joins her eternal love, Dimitry Varley. Our heartfelt condolences to her sister, Helga Hadsall; and nieces and nephew Bessie Peterson & Pat and Jim Martine. A gathering of friends and colleagues is being planned for late June. Please contact DTW for information at 212-691-6500.

title: Clinton Calls for AIDS Vaccine as Goal
description: Hours after President Clinton today called for a ''new national goal for science'' to develop a vaccine for AIDS within a decade, several advocacy groups for people with the disease said they were skeptical about the depth of his commitment to the research.

title: Puerto Rico Teachers Resist Teaching in English
description: On an island where English is routinely spoken in government and business, heard and read in the news media and widely accepted as a ticket to economic opportunity, a plan to begin using it as a second language of instruction in public schools has prompted demonstrations by teachers and predictions of cultural suicide.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  FEINBERG, E. RICHARD, M.D.
description: FEINBERG-E. Richard, M.D. It's been a year since you left us. We miss you every day. Doris, Michael, and Steve

title: De Avila Prays, Scores and Delivers a MetroStars Victory
description: It had been so long since the MetroStars scored a goal that Antony De Avila had every right to look heavenward, make the sign of the cross and put his palms together as he knelt in the penalty area at the west end of Giants Stadium.

title: The Blind, Like Others, Fish by the Sense of Feel
description: A 100-foot aluminum party boat called the Sunshine left its dock in Sheepshead Bay under a leaden sky Saturday morning with 40 people on board. Thirteen of them were members of the Helen Keller Fishing Club, an organization that takes blind people deep-sea fishing.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LURIE, HELEN COULE
description: LURIE-Helen Coule. Died May 8, 1997. Actress, writer, classical guitarist. Widow of Lee Lurie. Memorial service Saint Andrew's, Stamford, CT June 21st, 12 Noon.

title: Wetteland Says Goodbye to the Yankees
description: The Yankees had seen it all before, in some of the most memorable moments in their professional lives. The purposeful jog from the bullpen with a game to be saved. The soiled baseball hat. One runner on base, then another. The standing ovation from a full house.

title: Left for Last: Overhauling Welfare
description: THESE are critical days for New York's welfare system. At least in theory.

title: Summit First. Then Books. Then Movies. Then . . .
description: It was the casual conversation of two ambitious professionals, idle office chatter except that the water cooler was a Web site and their communication spanned the distance between Seattle and the boulder-strewn ice of a Mount Everest base camp.

title: Microsoft Aims For Bigger Share Of Corporate Computer Sales
description: With a marketing blitz led by Bill Gates, the Microsoft Corporation begins its assault this week on the lucrative business of industrial-strength corporate computing.

title: Samuel Baron, Flutist and Conductor, 72
description: Samuel Baron, a flutist and conductor who was a founding member of the New York Woodwind Quintet and the director of the Bach Aria Group, died on Friday at Mount Sinai Hospital in Manhattan. He was 72 and lived in Great Neck, N.Y.

title: Graduation Directs Notice To American Held in Peru
description: President Alberto K. Fujimori of Peru saw his daughter Keiko Sophia Fujimori graduate from Boston University today. Earlier at a small rally outside the commencement ceremony a New York couple continued their campaign against the imprisonment of their own daughter by the Peruvian Government.

title: CHRONICLE
description: POPE JOHN PAUL celebrated his 77th birthday yesterday by celebrating Mass in a crowded, working-class Rome neighborhood, the Reuters news agency reported.

title: Russian Ballerina's Swan Is to the Manner Born
description: Nina Ananiashvili roared through ''Swan Lake'' on Saturday night at the Metropolitan Opera House as if she had been born dancing the role. It was clear that ''Swan Lake'' was in the Russian ballerina's blood and bones the way it could not be for her peers at American Ballet Theater. But those dancers, on Saturday and Wednesday nights, had subtleties of their own.

title: When Turk Played Chess and Fooled Us
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SELTERMAN, JERRY (JULIUS)
description: SELTERMAN-Jerry (Julius). On May 17, 1997. Beloved husband of the late Anne. Devoted father of Phyllis Selterman and Helen Esberg and son-in-law Andreas. Loving brother of Sara Wagner and Claire Moskowitz. Cherished grandfather of Robert and Douglas Esberg. Adored great-grandfather of Hannah and Daniel. Doting uncle and great-uncle.

title: Pensiveness, Not Glitz, Gets The Gold at Cannes Festival
description: Having celebrated its 50th birthday with an inordinate show of celebrity glitter, the Cannes International Film Festival reasserted its claim to seriousness in awarding top honors today to two quiet, pensive films. This year's Palme d'Or was shared by Abbas Kiarostami's ''Taste of Cherries'' and Shohei Imamura's ''Unagi'' (''The Eel'').

title: Reynolds to Resume Ads for Winston
description: The R. J. Reynolds Tobacco Company will resume national advertising for its flagging Winston line as part of a comprehensive revamping of that cigarette's formula, packaging and marketing.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CREEL, DANA SHANNON
description: CREEL-Dana Shannon, 84, of Sharon, CT, died at his home on Haisdan Farm on May 15, 1997. Beloved husband of Jane Haislip Creel; brother of Virginia Creel Clark and uncle of David Clark. He graduated from Emory University, its Law School and the Harvard Business School, and served in the Counter Intelligence Corps of the U.S. Army in World War II. He served as John D. Rockefeller, Jr's principal philanthropic advisor and worked closely with other members of the Rockefeller Family for more than 50 years. He was president of the Rockefeller Brothers Fund from 1950-1975. After his retirement, he remained active with many conservation and preservation organizations, including the Hudson River Valley Association, Sleepy Hollow Restorations, Boscobel and the Young-Morse Restoration Site. He was a board member of the Berkshire Taconic Community Foundation. Haisdan Farm is noted for its scenic beauty and has won state and national awards for its corn production. The funeral service will be private. The date of a memorial service will be announced. Contributions, in lieu of flowers, may be made to the Dana S. Creel Fund of the Berkshire Taconic Community Foundation, Lakeville, CT 06039.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-11

title: Bill Opposes Fingerprinting
description: The First Union Bank's policy of requiring noncustomers to be fingerprinted if they want to cash checks is drawing criticism from some New Jersey lawmakers who want the state to pull millions of dollars out of the bank. Legislation introduced earlier this month would bar the state, which has payroll and pension accounts at First Union, from doing business with banks that require fingerprints, as First Union began doing at its 327 New Jersey branches in April.

title: Beijing goes for the benefits of financial news without any of the downside.
description: WHEN Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve chairman, met recently with China's senior leaders, he delivered what was essentially a primer on fundamental characteristics of a market economy, a topic of endless fascination for the engineers of this nation's half-achieved shift from a state-run to a market system.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STULMAN, JULIUS.
description: STULMAN-Julius. On May 17, age 91, longtime resident of Longboat Key, Florida. Founder of Lumber Exchange Terminal, Lumber Industries, Inc, and numerous other enterprises, he was not only an elder statesman of the lumber industry but one of the most creative and original thinkers of our time. Salesman, problem-solver, practical visionary, poet and prophet; author, lecturer, publisher; planner, counselor and advisor to countless individuals, corporations, foundations and governments throughout the world for over 60 years. A pioneer benefactor of many American and Israeli institutions, especially relating to economic planning, scientific research and Jewish education. Husband of the late Janis Carter Stulman, he is survived by a son Stephen, daughter Joan S. Gilbert, daughter-in-law Elga, son-in-law Phil, sisters Pearl Goldenthal, Sophia Leopold, Esther Moldauer, seven grandchildren and six greatgrandchildren. Services Monday, May 19, 12:30 PM, at ''The Riverside,'' 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue. The period of mourning will be observed at 151 Central Park West, NYC.

title: Charger Promises To Extend Life Of Batteries
description: Portable microelectronic devices last only as long as their batteries do. As batteries get older, each charge seems to fade faster. But a small company in Norcross, Ga., is marketing a device that it says speeds recharging and also preserves the battery's ability to hold a charge.

title: Dana C. Creel, 84; Headed the Rockefeller Brothers Fund
description: Dana C. Creel, whose philanthropic hand helped mold the Rockefeller Brothers Fund into an eclectic charitable organization, died last Thursday night at his home, Haisdan Farm in Sharon, Conn.

title: Mets Win; It's Easy As a Walk In the Park
description: Somewhere, Burt Hooton smiled yesterday. For Hooton's distinction as the pitcher most remembered for being hooted into wildness by a frenetic crowd was retired yesterday when not one, not two, but three Rockies pitchers completely lost the plate. The result was three walks with the bases loaded and it fueled a 10-4 comeback by the Mets that even the giddy hometown team could only call ugly, wild and weird.

title: Kabila Tightens Grip On Zaire's Capital
description: After a night of wild gunfire, a victorious rebel army took complete possession of Zaire's capital, Kinshasa, transforming themselves into the new authorities of Africa's third-largest country.

title: New Prison to Open Today
description: About 120 inmates will check in to gleaming new quarters at South Woods State Prison today, marking the opening of what will be the state's largest penitentiary. The $237 million complex will house 3,200 inmates when it is completed next year, and is expected to create 1,200 jobs.

title: Belfast Might Be Cozy, but Rest of Ulster Isn't
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  FREEMAN, PHYLLIS
description: FREEMAN-Phyllis. It is with our deepest sorrow that the publisher Harry N. Abrams, Inc. mourns the passing of our esteemed colleague, Phyllis Freeman, editor of art and illustrated books for nearly twenty years. A memorial service will be held on May 22 at 5 PM at Old Merchant's House museum, 29 East 4th Street, New York City.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Oracle Seen Investing In Netscape Affiliate

title: Papers Seek More Personal Connection With Readers
description: Most daily newspapers save the front page for their most important news. But The Pittsburgh Post-Gazette is experimenting with a Sunday front page that has no news on it at all -- only highlights of features in the rest of the paper. And people seem to like it.

title: Open Door to Peace
description: To the Editor:

title: Brookhaven Lab's New Manager Seeks Break With Past
description: A seminar room full of scientists fearful for their futures at the troubled Brookhaven National Laboratory waited the other day to hear what their new interim manager had to say.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: Baseball

title: Red Cross Workers Strike
description: American Red Cross workers who draw and handle blood used by about 35 hospitals in central and southern New Jersey and about 65 hospitals in Pennsylvania voted yesterday to go on strike, The Associated Press reported. But a Red Cross spokesman said that the organization had prepared for the strike and assured hospitals that they will not run out of blood.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  SHARP, EVELYN
description: SHARP-Evelyn. A memorial service in remembrance of Evelyn Sharp will be held on Tuesday, May 20, 1997, at 5:00 P.M., at The Solomon R. Guggenheim Museum, 1071 Fifth Avenue at 88th Street, New York City, in The Peter B. Lewis Theater.

title: 2 Companies To Receive Honors
description: The New York chapter of the American Marketing Association is naming the Eastman Kodak Company and the Nickelodeon unit of Viacom Inc. to its Marketing Hall of Fame. They will be honored on June 4 as part of the chapter's presentation of the 29th annual Effie Awards for effectiveness in advertising.

title: Chinese Christians Face No Persecution
description: To the Editor:

title: ITT Expected to Sell 5 Hotels In Effort to End Hilton's Bid
description: The ITT Corporation is expected to announce, possibly as early as today, that it has agreed to sell five of its Sheraton hotels to Felcor Suite Hotels Inc., a publicly traded real estate investment trust, for $200 million in cash.

title: Bridge
description: If the Yankees move to New Jersey, the shock for baseball fans will be comparable to what will be felt this week by bridge players. The Eastern Regionals, which have been held in Manhattan for 68 years and are America's oldest tournament, will be played this week at the Sheraton Stamford Hotel in Stamford, Conn. But this migration is reversible.

title: Madness, With Slides
description: That kind Eddie Delaney, who has spent his life taking care of his mother (a woman with a definite resemblance to Norman Bates's mom in ''Psycho''), is finally released by her death. Eddie becomes Eadie. He takes up drag with an amazing sense of style for a newcomer, takes in a hunky young crack addict who can do cartwheels on skates and takes on a new all-consuming project: preparing a 3-D slide presentation about his favorite Roman emperor, a ''wild, effeminate cross-dressing boy'' named Alagapolis. Or as Eadie herself says, ''It's about madness and boredom and missed opportunities, and it has slides.''

title: Irish Governing Parties Fight for Political Life
description: The ancient Celts, a brave and ferocious tribe who settled political differences with axes and bludgeons, are said in legend to have had only one fear: that the sky would fall on their heads. Frances Fitzgerald, a member of the Irish Parliament campaigning to hold her seat in the national election on June 6, knows the feeling.

title: Israel's Fine Line
description: On Aug. 21, 1995, Suffiyan Jabarin, a 26-year-old Palestinian member of the terrorist organization Hamas, blew himself up on a bus in the heart of Jerusalem, taking the lives of four people -- three Israelis and an American -- with him.

title: Japan Reports Trade Surplus Soared in April
description: Japan's merchandise trade surplus rose sharply in April as auto makers and others cranked up exports to compensate for slower growth in domestic demand after the Government raised the national consumption tax, economists said today.

title: U.S. Plans Tighter Rules to Curb Money Transfers by Drug Cartels
description: The Clinton Administration will announce new rules on Monday in an effort to make it far more difficult for drug cartels to move their profits from the United States to Colombia and other drug centers in Latin America, building on a successful experiment in New York City, officials familiar with the plan say.

title: With No Fight Left, Knicks Make Their Nightmare Complete
description: They sat there, more subdued than stunned, realizing the season was dead: no title, no date with Michael Jordan, not even another game. For once in this grueling, crazy series, the Knicks, back where all the madness began, looked as if they did not want to leave the bench.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MALLON, THOMAS F.
description: MALLON-Thomas F., 53. Of Lake Forest, IL. Formerly of Long Island, NY. Died May 17, 1997. Born January 2, 1944 in NYC, NY. He was a member of the Chicago Mercantile Exchange and past Treasurer of the Northbrook Sports Club. Husband of Bette Mallon. Father of Erin and the late Eileen Mallon (1996). Son of Rose McDonnell. Brother of Kevin (Kim) Mallon, Tenafly, NJ; Michaele (Wolfgang) Stahl, Florida; and Marybeth (Greg) Evans, New York. Funeral Mass 10 AM, Thursday, May 22, 1997, at The Church of St. Mary, Lake Forest. Interment Lake Forest Cemetery. Visitation 5-8 PM, Tuesday and Wednesday, at Wenban Funeral Home, 320 East Vine Ave., Lake Forest, IL. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to Melanoma Research Foundation, c/o Peter Tustison, POB 426, Lone Rock, WI 53556. Information: 847-234-0022.

title: Just a Cool $1 Million
description: To the Editor:

title: Gift-Giving, Big or Small, Shoundn't Hinge on Reciprocity
description: To the Editor:

title: Man and Child Die in Blaze In the Bronx
description: A man and a child were killed and another child was critically injured yesterday in an apartment fire in a high-rise housing project in the Bronx, the authorities said.

title: Spurs Win the Tim Duncan Sweepstakes
description: Tim Duncan and David Robinson in the same front court? San Antonio fans can look forward to that dangerous combination next season.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KAISER, ABRAHAM H.
description: KAISER-Abraham H. Of Englewood, on May 18, 1997. Beloved husband of Sylvia (nee Bell). Adored father of Jeffrey M. Kaiser, Frances Kaiser-Cook, Nancy Prager and Richard J. Kaiser. Loving sister of Sadye Mlyn, and eleven wonderful grandchildren. Funeral services Tuesday at noon, from ''Wien & Wien,'' 129 Engle St., Englewood, NJ. Charitable contributions in lieu of flowers.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RAPPAPORT, MARY
description: RAPPAPORT-Mary. Formerly of Westport, CT, died May 17. Survived by son and daughter-in-law, Lawrence N. Rappaport, M.D. and Karin E. Rappaport, daughter and son-in-law Ellen R. and Richard J. Schure, grandchildren, James E. Rappaport, Amy and Julie Schure. Services Monday, May 19, 11:15 AM at Gutterman's, 175 North Long Beach Road, Rockville, Centre, NY.

title: In Weeks Before Canada Votes, Quebec Again Drives Debate
description: The leaders of Canada's main political parties completed a stormy debate today that focused on Quebec separation, picking up where they left off last Tuesday after the debate moderator collapsed and was rushed to the hospital.

title: 23 Indians Arrested In Protest Over Taxes
description: New York State Police troopers in riot gear arrested 23 members of the Onondaga Nation after the Indians blocked the northbound lanes of Interstate 81, which runs through the reservation.

title: CHRONICLE
description: MICHAEL KELLY, the editor of The New Republic, is particularly enthusiastic about the cover of the June 2 issue, on newsstands today. It shows his son, TOM, 1; GABRIELLE DENSON, 8 months, a daughter of MARGO JOHNSON, a receptionist at the magazine; and ISAAC ALLEN, 1, the son of MARGARET TALBOT, a senior editor.
