description: LACROSSE

title: Equity Offerings Set This Week
description: The following equity and convertible debt offerings are expected this week:

title: Big agency companies aren't standing pat; some are expanding, and others are consolidating.
description: THE pace of activity among large agency companies accelerated last week as several announced expansions through acquisitions and reorganizations through consolidations.

title: No Headline
description: ''It is hell now, so what level of Dante's Inferno will it sink to with these riders added?''

title: Shucking Oysters: At 5 Cents a Pound, It's a Living
description: At the far end of a shorefront littered with broken shells, where sea salt flavors the warm spring air, a handful of small women in cone-shaped straw hats waded into the water, empty baskets in hand.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  SCHERER, JULES P.
description: SCHERER-Jules P. May 19, 1962. In loving memory every day for the past 35 years. I miss you very much. You son, Michael.

title: College Minority Enrollment Slowed in 1995
description: Several years of rapid gains in the college enrollment of minority students gave way to more subdued growth in 1995, according to a report to be released today by the American Council on Education in Washington.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MAHLKE, PHILIP A.
description: MAHLKE-Philip A. Of Bricktown, NJ on May 16, 1997. Beloved husband of the late Esther. Devoted father of Philip R. and Linda Steel. Brother of Raymond and Elsa Morgan. Loving grandfather of seven, great-grandfather of seven. Funeral services Monday, 8 PM, at the Silverton Memorial Funeral Home, 2482 Church Rd., Toms River, NJ. Interment Flushing Cemetery, Flushing, NY. Visiting Monday 2-4 and 7-9 PM.

title: 11 Major Chinese Paintings Promised to Met
description: Eleven major Chinese paintings from the renowned C. C. Wang Family Collection, including a rare 10th-century silk scroll that predates all the famous hanging scrolls in China, have been promised as a gift to the Metropolitan Museum of Art.

title: Solar Power In Big Leap In California
description: A California electric utility has signed a big contract to buy solar cells that the utility and the Department of Energy say will push the cells' cost down to a competitive level by 2002.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MURPHY, MICHAEL J.
description: MURPHY-Michael J. May 17, 1997. Survived by three children, Patricia Howley and her husband James of Port Jefferson Station, Francis C. Murphy and his wife Ann Fenichel of Manhattan and Mary Ellen Quinn and her husband Patrick of Maine; daughterin-law Carole A. Murphy of Florida; and his sister Agnes Kirby of Sag Harbor. Predeceased by his wife Kathleen, his son Michael F., and his brother Rev. Msgr. Francis J. Murphy of Brooklyn. Grandfather of five, Kathleen Maloney, Megan Howley, Daniel M. Howley, Kristen Quinn and Patrick M. Quinn; and one great-granddaughter, Maeve Maloney. Wake at Branch Funeral Home, 190 East Main Street, Smithtown, NY, today, 2-4 and 7-9:30 PM. Funeral Mass Tuesday, 9:45 AM, St. Patrick's Church, Smithtown. In lieu of flowers, contributions to Covenant House, 460 West 41 St., New York, NY 10036 are appreciated.

title: Correction
description: A report in Metro News Briefs in some copies yesterday about a recount in the Jersey City mayoral election misspelled the given name of an unsuccessful challenger to Mayor Bret Schundler. He is Jerramiah T. Healy.

title: Rangers Get a Scare As Leetch Takes a Hit
description: The Rangers have lost three key players to injury during the post-season in Bill Berg, Niklas Sundstrom and Patrick Flatley. And they were already without Aleksei Kovalev, who underwent reconstructive knee surgery during the regular season.

title: METAL MANAGEMENT AGREES TO A $111 MILLION ACQUISITION
description: Metal Management Inc. agreed yesterday to acquire Cozzi Iron and Metal Inc. for about $111 million in cash and stock as part of its bid to consolidate the scrap metal recycling industry. Metal Management, based in Chicago, would pay $6 million in cash and 11.5 million of its shares to Cozzi, a privately owned company that is also based in Chicago. Metal Management's shares fell 10.9 cents yesterday, to $9. The acquisition would create a scrap metal recycling company that controls about 225,000 tons of ferrous scrap a month and generates annual revenue of $500 million.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COHEN, EDWARD S.
description: COHEN-Edward S. Passed from us peacefully on May 17, 1997. Beloved husband of Joyce. Devoted father to Craig and Brett. A man who touched everyone he met. We will miss you big Ed, but your memory will always live.

title: Straining Toward an Agreement on Global Bribery Curb
description: With less than a week in which to negotiate a compromise, the United States and its major trading partners remain sharply divided over how to enact and enforce a long-sought global ban on commercial bribery.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BARON, SAMUEL
description: BARON-Samuel. The Yale University School of Music expresses its sincere sympathy to the family and friends of Sam Baron. A faculty member of the Yale Summer School of Music in Norfolk, CT and former faculty member of the Yale School of Music, his mentoring of flutists and chamber musicians through his teaching as well as the N.Y. Woodwind Quintet and Bach Aria Group have been profound.

title: Making Science Fun Helps It Get Funds
description: To the Editor:

description: TOBIAS-Bob. The New York Times records with deep sorrow the passing of Bob Tobias, associated with the Times from 1963, until retiring in 1996.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HECHT, ALBERT
description: HECHT-Albert. On May 19, 1997. Beloved husband of Anna. Dear father and grandfather. Services at Parkside Funeral Chapel, 98-60 Queens Boulevard at 11:30am on Wednesday, May 21, 1997. Shiva will be observed at 157-04 12th Road, Whitestone, New York.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RIFKIN, DR. HAROLD
description: RIFKIN-Dr. Harold. After a long illness. Adored husband to Bibi. Beloved father to Janet, Matthew, and Phyllis. Devoted grandfather to six wonderful grandsons. Funeral private. Memorial service to be announced at a later date.

title: Prosecutorial Misconduct Is Charged in Rape Trial
description: Court recessed early in the Alex Kelly rape trial yesterday after Mr. Kelly's lawyer, Thomas P. Puccio, accused the prosecutor, Bruce P. Hudock, of prosecutorial misconduct for compensating a witness for lost wages.

title: WELLS FARGO STOCK DROPS AFTER BUFFETT REDUCES STAKE
description: Berkshire Hathaway Inc., the insurance holding company controlled by the billionaire Warren E. Buffett, said yesterday that it had sold 300,000 shares of Wells Fargo & Company, reducing its stake to 7.82 percent of outstanding stock. Wells Fargo's shares fell $14.125, to $265.50. According to documents filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission, Berkshire and its affiliates held 6.99 million Wells Fargo shares on March 31; on Dec. 31 the Berkshire group held 7.29 million shares. Investment managers like Berkshire must report stock holdings each quarter with the S.E.C. Wells Fargo, based in San Francisco, is the nation's eighth-largest bank holding company. It had 89.4 million shares outstanding at the end of April.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FLOOD, FRANCIS XAVIER
description: FLOOD-Francis Xavier. On May 18, 1997. Son of the late John and Josephine (Moore), brother of the late Mary, Michael, Maurice and Margaret. Survived by brothers John, William, and sister Bernadette. Private requiem in Manhattan. Burial Calvary cemetery, Queens, New York.

title: Old Regime Meets the New, and Hatchets Are Buried
description: For a whole day, the defeated cream of this country's past, and the confident elite of its future eyed each other warily across fan-cooled patios and plushly upholstered lounges. Since the first delegation of the new governing alliance arrived here on Saturday, the Inter-Continental Hotel has -- nervously at times -- had to house them both.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LISCHIN, SHELDON H.
description: LISCHIN-Sheldon H. of Boynton Beach Fl., formerly of NYC on Sunday May 18, 1997. Beloved husband of the late Lois Lischin. Loving father of Michael, Garry and his wife Laurie and the late Gerilyn Lischin. Devoted companion of Diane Rosenblum. Cherished grandfather of Malissa, Eliza, Jessica, Matthew, Luke and Sheila Dear brother-in-law of Gail and Fred Ruggio. Services 2pm Wednesday at the Sanctuary of Abraham & Sarah Mausoleum Chapel at Cedar Park Cemetry, Forest Avenue, Paramus, NJ. Memorial donations may be made to The Sheldon H. Lischin Foundation for Cancer Research.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ARTUS, WALTER W.
description: ARTUS-Walter W. Philosophy Professor at Saint John's University. Passed away May 19, 1997. Husband of Therese, father of Monique, Michael and Annette. For information Frederick Services Inc, 718-357-6100. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to St. John the Baptist Rectory Bread for Life Soup Kitchen, 75 Lewis Ave, Brooklyn NY 11206.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CREEL, DANA S.
description: CREEL-Dana S. We note with sadness the passing of Dana S. Creel, a dear friend, wise colleague, and thoughtful advisor. As first president of the Rockefeller Brothers Fund, Dana practiced philanthropy with gracious style and visionary intellect, anticipating some of today's most pressing social issues and needs. He set a standard for giving that inspires us still. Abby M. O'Neill, Chairman Colin G. Campbell, President Russell A. Phillips, Jr. Executive Vice President Benjamin R. Shute, Jr. Secretary & Treasurer On behalf of the Rockefeller Brothers Fund

title: Poland's Young and Restless Turn to Violence
description: On a chilly January afternoon in the bleak, working-class suburbs here, two 14-year-old girls lured a female classmate to the woods and, passing a knife between them, methodically stabbed her more than 60 times before killing her.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MANDEL, SAMUEL D.
description: MANDEL-Samuel D. Beloved husband of Sarah nee Schneider. Devoted father of Steven and Barrie. Cherished father-in-law of Barbara and Harvey. Dear brother of Marvin, Eugene, Sally Greenbaum and Helen Fogel. Loving grandfather of Rebecca, Laura, Matthew, Margo and Jon. Services were held Monday at GuttermanMusicant, Hackensack, NJ. Shiva will be observed at the family residence. Contributions to your favorite charity.

description: In percent

title: CHRONICLE
description: SYLVESTER STALLONE, 50, and JENNIFER FLAVIN, 28, the model with whom he has been linked for eight years, were married in London on Saturday, Mr. Stallone's press agent, Paul Bloch, announced yesterday

description: FOLDES-Francis F., M.D. On May 19, 1997. Loving husband of Edith. Father of Eva Travers, Judy Dickson, and Barbara Wolkowitz. Also survived by his sister Margit Salamon & grandchildren Amy, Jeffrey, David, Eva, Nick, Emily and Daniel. Services Wednesday, 10AM, ''The Riverside'', 76 Street and Amsterdam Avenue. Donations in his memory can be made to Phelps Hospice, Phelps Memorial Hospital Center, 701 N.Broadway, North Tarrytown NY 10591-1096

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BUCKY, DR. PETER A.
description: BUCKY-Dr. Peter A. President of Bucky X-Ray International Inc, passed away May 14, 1997 after a short illness. Mr. Bucky, who was 85, was pre-deceased by his wife Tina (nee McBurnie Bucky). He is survived by his son Peter R. of Endicott, New York, and his brother Dr. Thomas Lee and his sister-inlaw Doris of Weston, CT., and friend Kathy Riegel. A graveside service will be held Wednesday, May 21, 1997, 12 noon, in Calverton National Cemetery, Calverton, Long Island, New York.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DEANGELIS, GERALD
description: DeANGELIS-Gerald. The New York Times records with deep sorrow the passing of Gerlad DeAngelis, associated with the Times from 1953, until retiring in 1995.

title: Jury Finds Bank Must Pay Damages for Sex Discrimination
description: When Victoria Greenbaum went to work for a major bank in New York City nine years ago, she says she was promised a vice presidency within three months. She never got it. And even though she made $2 million one year for the bank in trading profits, she said she received only a $20,000 bonus, while her male co-workers received much more.

title: In Congo, a New Era With Old Burdens
description: Mauwa Funidi's face softens and glows for a few moments as she recalls happier days as a brilliant student, as a new college graduate, as a member of a prospering family in a nation seemingly about to enjoy an endless economic boom.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KAMMERT, JOHN
description: KAMMERT-John. The New York Times records with deep sorrow the passing of John Kammert associated with the Times from 1959, until retiring in 1978.

description: HOCHHAUSER-Eleanor. Beloved wife of the late Murray. Devoted mother of Roberta Cantor, Margery Honig and Gail. Dear sister of Sheldon Blum. Loving grandmother of Lauren, James and Fredric Cantor, Linda and Kenneth Honig, and great - grandmother of Ryleigh. Services ''Wien & Wien,'' Englewood, NJ, Tuesday, 9:45 AM.

title: Singapore Airlines Orders 8 Airbus Jets
description: Singapore Airlines placed orders yesterday with Airbus Industrie of Europe for eight narrow-body planes worth an estimated $350 million and took options to buy another 10 planes. If the airline exercises the options for all 10 planes, Airbus will get up to $470 million in additional revenue, depending on the models purchased. That gives the total order a potential value of as much as $820 million. The planes will be flown by the airline's regional unit, Silkair, to 19 destinations in Asia, including 2 in China.

title: A Recurring Theme Plays On: Auto Insurance
description: The gubernatorial campaign of United States Representative Robert E. Andrews released its first television advertisement yesterday. The Democratic primary is on June 3.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CHOFFE, FREDERICK
description: CHOFFE-Frederick. The New York Times records with deep sorrow the passing of Frederick Choffe, associated with the Times from 1976, until retiring in 1979.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SLOCUM, FRANCIS E.
description: SLOCUM-Francis E., 71, of Greenwich, CT., on May 18, 1997. Husband of Patricia Slocum. Father of William and Claudia Slocum. A mass of christian burial will be held on Thursday, May 22, at 10:30AM in St.Mary Church, 178 Greenwich Avenue, Greenwich, CT. Burial will be private. Calling hours will be held Wednesday, May 21 from 2-4 and 7-9PM, at the Leo P. Gallagher & Son Funeral Home, 31 Arch Street, Greenwich, CT. Memorial donations may be made to the Baseball Assistance Team, 350 Park Avenue, New York, New York 10022.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  TAMBURO, ANTOINETTE MILLER
description: TAMBURO - Antoinette Miller. You left us a year ago but your smile and courage will always be with those you loved. Your Third Son

title: Turkey's Aggression
description: To the Editor:

title: The Coach in Guokas Gave NBC Rare Insight
description: NBC's Matt Guokas has not always come across as an exciting, witty, must-listen analyst. He rarely seems to have the sort of fun Mike Fratello used to have with Marv Albert on NBC, or the kind John Andariese has with Albert on the MSG Network.

title: China's unruly stock markets, where 'long term' is overnight.
description: CHINA'S stock markets have been showing signs of irrational exuberance again.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CANE, ELIZABETH FRANCES (MAHER)
description: CANE-Elizabeth Frances (Maher), 90, of Wake Robin in Shelburne, Vermont died at her home on May 18, 1997. Born in East Hartford, Connecticut on February 17, 1907. She was the daughter of John and Jennie (Flynn) Maher. She was a graduate of the College of St. Elizabeth in Convent Station, New Jersey in 1927. She was married to John J. Cane, D.M.D. on April 17, 1937 and resided in Phillipsburg, New Jersey until August of 1995 when she moved to Shelburne. She is survived by her daughter, Sheila of Rowayton, Connecticut, and her son, John, his wife Vicki Knoepfel, and their three children, Charlotte Elizabeth, Andrew Paul, and Catherine McKenna of Burlington, Vermont. Funeral services will be held at St. Catherine of Siena Church in Shelburne, Vermont on Thursday, May 22, 1997. Burial will be held in Phillipsburg, New Jersey on Saturday, May 24, 1997. For more information contact Finegan Funeral Home, 302 Heckman Street, Phillipsburg, New Jersey. For those who wish, contributions in memory of Mrs. Cane may be sent to the Vermont Children's Aid Society, 79 Weaver Street, Winooski, Vermont 05404.

title: Too Bad Democracy Hasn't Been NATO's Goal
description: To the Editor:

title: The Knicks Robbed Themselves
description: After the Knicks lost to the Miami Heat on Sunday, Patrick Ewing complained that the people who run the National Basketball Association had cost him another shot at the championship ring that has eluded him for 12 frustrating years. Ewing, who played valiantly, had reason to be distraught. But in blaming the N.B.A. he was not thinking any more clearly than he was when he wandered off the Knicks' bench in Game 5, thereby earning a suspension. The real culprits were Ewing's inept teammates, who saved their worst for last, and his own mental carelessness in the fifth game.

title: Subsidized Tenants
description: To the Editor:

title: Local Officials Break Ranks Over Pataki's Welfare Plan
description: In a strongly worded letter to Gov. George E. Pataki's administration, the social service commissioners from New York City and Westchester, Nassau and Suffolk Counties, who oversee programs for nearly 80 percent of the state's poor, sharply criticized elements of the Governor's welfare proposal, arguing that it would shift the burden of caring for the poor from the state to local governments that can ill afford the expense.

title: A Death Tarnishes Fashion's 'Heroin Look'
description: After years of denial by the fashion industry that heroin use among its players had any relation to the so-called heroin-chic style of fashion photography that has become so prevalent, the fatal overdose of Davide Sorrenti, 20, a promising photographer at the heart of the scene, was like a small bomb going off.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PARLIN, JACK
description: PARLIN-Jack. The New York Times records with deep sorrow the passing of Jack Parlin, associated with The Times from 1953, until retiring in 1991.

title: Recalling an Officer and a Gentleman
description: On his first day on the job, 10 years ago, Police Officer Anthony Sanchez was dispatched to investigate a robbery in progress and saw his first gun battle. It was the same radio call -- a 10-30, or robbery in progress -- that Officer Sanchez was responding to in Chelsea very early yesterday morning, when he was caught in another gun battle, one that cost him his life at age 31.

title: Tale of Bomb Residue
description: The prosecution's main explosives expert in the Oklahoma City bombing case told the jury yesterday that the clothing Timothy J. McVeigh was wearing when he was arrested 90 minutes after the blast had explosives residues on them. In cross-examination, Mr. McVeigh's lawyers continued to attack the integrity of the investigation by the F.B.I.

title: Changes on Fraternity Row
description: Hazing and partying have been central to college fraternity life for a long time. An umbrella organization called the National Interfraternity Council is now trying to persuade fraternities to put down their beer mugs and become more civic-minded. The changes are overdue.

title: Transactions
description: Baseball

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HOUCK, JAMES D.
description: HOUCK-James D., 42, Managing Director and Chief Administrative Officer of Lehman Brothers Japan, died April 26 at Wilcox Memorial Hospital on the island of Kauai, HI. The cause of death was cancer of the esophagus. James was born in Hartford, CT., and graduated from Colby College and from the Wharton School of Business in 1984. James is survived by his wife, Marilyn, of Hawaii; his father, Dr. John H. Houck of Massachusetts; a brother, John W. Houck of New York; a sister, Katherine Houck Fredrickson of Illinois; and eight nieces and nephews. He will be missed by all who knew and loved him.

title: Not All Landlords Were Hurt by Rent Control
description: To the Editor:

title: U.S. Foreign Agents Deserve Measure of Justice
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BRODERICK, JOSEPH ALBERT
description: BRODERICK-Joseph Albert. On May 19, 1997, at home in Fearrington Village, N.C. Attorney, Professor of Law. Husband of Katharine (Tappy). Brother of Vincent L. and Francis L. Funeral Mass at Newman Catholic Student Center, Chapel Hill, N.C. In lieu of flowers, gifts to Las Casas Dominican Ministry, 524 West Pine Ave, Canton, OK 73724 or Hospice of Chatham County, Inc., POB 1077, Pittsboro, N.C. 27312.

title: For Donald O'Connor
description: Donald O'Connor, the dancer and actor, will be honored for his film career tomorrow and Thursday nights by the Film Society of Lincoln Center. The tribute is the latest in the film society's dance series. Mr. O'Connor will appear to narrate the clips from his films and to answer questions. Both programs begin at 8:15 P.M. at the Walter Reade Theater, 165 West 65th Street. Information: (212) 875-5600.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SAIDENBERG, DANIEL
description: SAIDENBERG-Daniel. The Juilliard School mourns the loss of Daniel Saidenberg. A distinguished alumnus of the School, he enjoyed an extraordinary career as a cello soloist and chamber musician, conductor and vibrant supporter of young artists. Through his generosity The Juilliard School and the general public have experienced a series of free faculty concerts for the past seven years. We extend our deepest condolences to his wife Eleanor, his sons Lawrence and Robert and all of his family. A memorial service will take place at Juilliard in the fall. Mary Rodgers Guettel Chairman, Board of Trustees Joseph W. Polisi President

title: Money Shortage Jeopardizes Fusion Reactor
description: INSUFFICIENT financial support has thrown the future of a proposed international fusion reactor so much in doubt that the project could be killed by January.

title: Corrections
description: A calendar entry in the Westchester Weekly on Sunday about a tent-raising tomorrow at Westchester Community College in Valhalla misstated the time. It is 7 A.M., not 7 P.M.

title: Navy Giving Pine Barrens Tract to New York
description: Adding to a state pine barrens preserve on eastern Long Island, the Navy is giving New York State 3,200 acres of woodlands around the former Grumman Corporation aircraft-manufacturing plant in Calverton.

title: Interpublic Buys Pair Of Specialty Shops
description: The Interpublic Group of Companies, which owns agencies like Lowe Group and McCann-Erickson Worldwide, is expanding into sports and event marketing by acquiring ownership stakes in two shops specializing in that field. Terms were not disclosed.

title: Where All Is Babel, They Spread the Good Word
description: When the highland people near here open their new Chuave-language Bibles, they will discover -- reading slowly and carefully -- that the Man With a Face thought very, very much about the names of we people who live on the ground.

title: When Mendoza Takes Mound, The Yanks Stand Behind Him
description: The progress Ramiro Mendoza has made as he works to establish himself as a starting pitcher in the major leagues cannot be found in his self-conscious smile or in his quiet, halting English. For now, a better place to look is at the words of his teammates when asked about Mendoza's credibility as a fifth Yankee starter.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  KRONISCH, DORIS
description: KRONISCH-Doris. Born May 20th. Always remembered with love. Never forgotten. Joe and Family

title: Home Shopping Seen in Deals For 50% Stake In Ticketmaster
description: Home Shopping Network has agreed to acquire the 47.5 percent stake in Ticketmaster held by Paul G. Allen, a co-founder of the Microsoft Corporation, for $210 million in Home Shopping stock, people close to the talks said yesterday.

title: No Spur to Housing
description: To the Editor

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  OMANOFF, MICHAEL
description: OMANOFF-Michael. The New York Times records with deep sorrow the passing of Michael Omanoff, associated with the Times from 1964, until retiring in 1986.

title: Leader of Tenants' Campaign Criticizes Messinger Proposal
description: The leader of the tenant campaign to defeat Republican efforts to repeal New York's rent-regulation laws denounced yesterday a proposal by Ruth W. Messinger to save the system, calling it a diversion that could derail efforts in Albany to protect existing laws.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MASON, PATRICIA
description: MASON-Patricia. On May 18, 1997. Real estate broker, Senior Vice President, William B. May Company. Wife of Francis Mason, mother of Spencer Mason and Leslie Scarlett Mason, grandmother of Dexter Mason. Memorial service on Thursday, June 5, 1997, 12:30 PM, at the Church of St. Luke in the Fields, 427 Hudson Street, New York, NY 10014. Patricia Mason was a keen supporter of the T. H. Everett Rock Garden at the New York Botanical Garden, the Greenhouse at Wave Hill, the Garden Conservancy and the School of American Ballet. In lieu of flowers friends may wish to consider contributions to those organizations. Robert Bartolomei is Curator of the T. H. Everett Rock Garden, N.Y. Botanical Garden. 200th Street and Southern Boulevard, Bronx, NY 10458. Marco Polo Stufano is Curator at Wave Hill, 675 West 252 Street, Bronx, New York 10471. Garden Conservancy's address is Box 219, Cold Spring, NY 10516. Albert Bellas is Chairman, School of American Ballet, 70 Lincoln Center Plaza, NY, NY 10023.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article yesterday about protests over the refusal of tenure to a woman at Harvard University omitted a response from Neil L. Rudenstine, the university president. He declined to comment, citing the confidentiality of the tenure process.

title: Tiger Woods Signs Pact With American Express
description: Now that he has more than enough money to qualify for credit cards and to require a staff of financial advisers, the golfer Tiger Woods has signed a five-year contract to become a spokesman for one of the biggest providers of such services, American Express.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FOX, JAMES M.
description: FOX-James M. The 35,000 members of the alumni, students, faculty and staff of John Jay College of Criminal Justice mourn the loss of James M. Fox, an admired law enforcement leader. A strong advocate for the professional development of law enforcement personnel to higher education, his contributions to public safety and leadership in the criminal justice community have made the city and nation a better place. He will be sorely missed by all those who had the privilege of knowing and working with him. We offer our deepest sympathy to the members of the Fox family. Gerald W. Lynch, President John Jay College of Criminal Justice, The City University of New York

title: Sudden Burst of Clues Shed Light on Mystery of Gamma Rays
description: IN a flurry of observations over the last 12 days, astronomers say they have at last solved one of the troubling puzzles posed by those brief and unpredictable flashes of gamma rays that are among the most powerful fireworks in the universe.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEFKOWITZ, LOUIS
description: LEFKOWITZ-Louis of Long Beach, NY, suddenly on May 18, 1997. beloved husband of Rebecca. Devoted father of Judge Joel L. and Helen Lefkowitz, Marilyn and Stuart Troy. Cherished grandfather of Stephen, Edward and Richard Troy, Charles and Michael Lefkowitz, and Julie Mendik. Adored great grandfather ''Poppa Lou'' of Max, Molly and Samuel. Loving brother of Joseph and dear brother-in-law of Mildred Lefkowitz. Also survived by many nieces, nephews, cousins and friends. Services 11am at Temple Israel of Long Beach, 70 East Park Avenue.

title: There's Hope For Knicks Next Season
description: THE New York Knicks will win the championship next season. At least, this can be the mind-set of the team, even in this bleakest, this dreariest, this most despairing of moments.

title: Lonrho in Merger Talks With South Africans
description: Lonrho P.L.C. of Britain and JCI Ltd. of South Africa have confirmed that they are talking about a possible $3 billion merger that would unite the two prominent mining companies. Lonrho and JCI would not comment yesterday beyond brief statements confirming preliminary talks, after a report in The Sunday Telegraph of London.

title: Democrats Facing Mountain of Debt
description: The Democratic National Committee is facing debts of $16 million and will be unable to eliminate them until at least the end of next year.

title: How Much Is Nature Worth? For You, $33 Trillion
description: HOW much is nature worth?

title: Woman Is Assaulted On Street in Midtown
description: There are few places to hide on 50th Street between First Avenue and Beekman Place. Tucked amid the town houses and apartment buildings and down a steep flight of stairs is a secluded alley that curves back out of view.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SEGAL KAMEN, EDITH
description: SEGAL KAMEN-Edith, on May 18, 1997. Beloved wife of the late Samuel Kamen, sister of Tess Segal, loving aunt of Shari Segel Goldberg and Peter Goldberg, great aunt of Alena Goldberg. Dancer, poet, and life long activist for social justice, she will be remembered by all whose lives she touched. Memorial service to be announced later.

title: Once-Exclusive Actors Studio Reaches Out to the Public
description: Looking back on his career, Paul Newman said recently, ''The Actors Studio can take the credit or the blame for what I've become as an actor.''

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: BOWTHORPE P.L.C., West Sussex, England, a manufacturer of electronic products, agreed to buy closely held Adwest Inc., Honolulu, a maker of electronic test equipment, for $51 million.

title: Andrews Extends Run
description: Julie Andrews will perform for an additional week as the lead in ''Victor/Victoria'' at the Marquis Theater. After missing a week of performances because of a bruised vocal cord, Ms. Andrews agreed to stay with the production an extra week to accommodate fans who had bought tickets for her final performances. She leaves the show after June 8. Raquel Welch takes over the role on June 10.

title: INSIDE METRO
description: SOLD! -- Round one of the auction of Pamela Harriman's art and memorabilia raised $4.6 million. B3.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  VALLONE, PETER
description: VALLONE-Peter. The New York Times records with deep sorrow the passing of Peter Vallone, associated with the Times from 1971, until retiring in 1982.

title: Ranger Fans Get the Goalie They Most Want to Jeer
description: Rangers fans wanted him, and now they have him.

title: Phoenix Building Is Sold
description: The Viad Corporation said today that it had sold its 24-story headquarters in Phoenix for $73 million to a company that manages foreign reserves for Singapore. Viad operates airline-catering, convention and money-order businesses. It will continue to lease the space for 15 years and will use the money from the sale to reduce debt and pay for acquisitions.

title: With Its Glory Restored, Theater Is Itself a Star
description: Nona Otero remembers the New Amsterdam Theater on West 42d Street as ''perhaps a slightly less elaborate'' place than it is now. But then, she was only 15 when she danced there in the 1923 Ziegfeld Follies, ''and, in those days, I wasn't so concerned about such things.''

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  LANDAU, SAMUEL J.
description: LANDAU-Samuel J. May 20, 1989. In remembrance. Bob

title: A Nomination for Treasurer
description: A state deputy treasurer, James A. DiEleuterio, was nominated by Governor Whitman yesterday to be New Jersey's next treasurer. If confirmed by the State Senate, Mr. DiEleuterio would replace Brian W. Clymer, who is leaving July 1 to take a marketing job at Prudential Insurance Company. ANDY NEWMAN

title: PANAVISION IN $61 MILLION DEAL FOR FILM SERVICES UNIT
description: Panavision Inc., based in Woodland Hills, Calif., agreed yesterday to buy the film services unit of Visual Action Holdings P.L.C. of Britain for $:37.5 million ($61 million) in cash to build up its worldwide film equipment leasing business. Panavision, which makes and rents cameras and other equipment for the movie and television industries, said the purchase would help it expand internationally and complete the takeover of its distribution network in the United States. Visual Action's Film Services Group, which had revenue of $70.3 million in 1996, has rental operations in the United States, Britain, France, Australia, New Zealand and Southeast Asia. It is Panavision's agent in France and Australia and in Atlanta, Chicago and Dallas.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JACOBS, FRED M.
description: JACOBS-Fred M., on May 18th, after a long illness. Loving and beloved husband of Judy; devoted father of Andrew, John, Marcie, Jeffrey and Susan; cherished grandfather of Rachel, Daniel and Michael; caring brother of Richard and loved by all. Service Tuesday, 3 PM, at ''The Riverside,'' 76th St. and Amsterdam Avenue. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made in his memory to the Jacob Perlow Hospice at Beth Israel Hospital

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WESTLIN, BERTIL
description: WESTLIN-Bertil, of NYC on May 19th, 1997. Beloved father of Olivia McKean, Linda Westlin and Aline Quint. Cherished grandfather of Vanessa, Steven, Simon and Anna. Services are private.

title: With Strobe Lights (but No Philistine Trophies), It's Disney's 'King David'
description: The catchiest song in ''King David,'' the Alan Menken and Tim Rice musical that officially opened the splendidly restored New Amsterdam Theater on Sunday night, consists of the following lyrics, repeated and repeated and repeated: ''Saul has slain his thousands, and David his 10 thousands!''

title: Honorable Discharge in Doubt for B-52 Pilot
description: With the court-martial of the country's first female B-52 bomber pilot for adultery, lying and other charges scheduled to open here on Tuesday, senior Air Force officials said today that it was extremely unlikely that she would be granted an honorable discharge instead.

title: CHRONICLE
description: Is there some connection between the ability to make beautiful music and an appreciation of food? DAVID REZITS, a cellist with the Fort Wayne Philharmonic in Indiana, is convinced that there is, and he has put together a cookbook titled ''Culinary Harmony: Favorite Recipes of the World's Finest Classical Musicians.''

title: Kovalev And Leetch Show Signs Of Healing
description: Aleksei Kovalev went through a full workout at this morning's optional skate, marking the first time since early January that Kovalev, with his reconstructed right knee, had participated in drills alongside his Ranger teammates.

title: When Wedding Gowns Go on Sale, Here Come the Brides
description: Jennifer O'Conor, in pink leggings and sneakers, with her rose tattoo showing, was determined. Twenty-one years old and a bride-to-be, she had been through 59 wedding gowns in less than an hour.

title: Big Changes for ABC's Fall Lineup
description: Faced with numerous holes in its prime-time schedule, especially in the 8 P.M. slot, ABC announced a fall lineup yesterday of sweeping change. The network will add 10 official new series, along with two more that it isn't calling new shows but that are certainly not shows that were on last year, and it will replace 8 o'clock shows every night.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BLOOMBERG, SYLVIA
description: BLOOMBERG-Sylvia, of Delray Beach, Florida, on May 17. Beloved sister, sister-in-law, aunt, great aunt, friend. Donations to ''Make A wish Foundation of Metro NY'', 85 Old Shore Road, Port Washington, New York 11050.

title: Subcontinent Summit
description: After three wars and five decades of enmity, far more than personal chemistry is needed to breach the walls dividing India and Pakistan. Still, when Prime Minister I. K. Gujral calls his Pakistani counterpart ''my personal friend,'' and when Nawaz Sharif says of New Delhi's 10th Prime Minister ''I like this man very much,'' the possibility of change can be sensed. In the first such meeting in eight years, the two agreed to begin talking about Kashmir, which together with other steps can defuse if not resolve the most intractable issue dividing the two countries.

title: Experts Link Explosives To McVeigh At Bomb Trial
description: There were residues of explosives on the shirts and jeans that Timothy J. McVeigh was wearing when he was arrested an hour and a half after the Oklahoma City bombing, the prosecution's principal explosives expert told a Federal District Court jury here today.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: YACHT RACING

title: Research Group Is Suing C.I.A. To Reveal Size of Spy Budget
description: The Federation of American Scientists sued the Central Intelligence Agency today to force it to reveal one of Washington's worst-kept secrets: the size of the budget for American espionage.

title: CHRONICLE
description: Do Americans fully appreciate the artistry involved in creating the wax renditions of celebrities that appear in Madame Tussaud's wax museum in London?

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FLORENZ, RUTH (NEE FLORENCE LEVINE)
description: FLORENZ-Ruth (nee Florence Levine). Born December 18, 1896. Died May 17, 1997. Last survivor of seven siblings: Samuel, Julius, Charles, Charlotte, Jess, Sidney and Al. Devoted friend of the late Grace Hooper. Her nieces and nephews, grandnieces and nephews, great-grandnieces and nephews and sisters-in-law, Frances Levine and Lillian Levin, mourn the passing of a remarkable woman.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STULMAN, JULIUS
description: STULMAN-Julius. The American Committee for the Weizmann Institute of Science mourns the passing of a generous philanthropist and expresses its heartfelt condolences to his son Stephen, longtime committed supporter of the Institute, distinguished member of the ACWIS Board of Directors, past treasurer and past president. Our sincerest sympathy goes to the entire family. Gershon Kekst, Chairman Weizmann Institute of Science Haim Harari, President S. Donald Sussman, Chairman American Committee Robert G. Begam, President Fran Ginsburg, Exec. Director

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Stocks Up, but Uncertainty About the Fed Limits Gains

title: CASTLE ENERGY TO SELL EAST TEXAS ASSETS FOR $54 MILLION
description: The Castle Energy Corporation agreed yesterday to sell assets in Rusk County, Tex., to the Union Pacific Resources Group, in Fort Worth, for $54 million. Castle Energy, based in Radnor, Pa., said the assets included its 77-mile pipeline and oil and gas properties. It said it planned to use some proceeds from the sale to retire bank debt. Castle Energy's shares closed at $13, up $1.375. Union Pacific's shares closed at $28.50, up 37.5 cents.

title: Beat the Can Slowly, Or Fast, or Brutally
description: The Bang on a Can Marathon is the annual circus of contemporary music. It would be wrong to expect any very deep or subtle experience: you go for the noise, the tackiness, the crudity, the thrills and spills, the sheer abundance of activity. And you go for the ringmaster, Michael Gordon, giving a completely persuasive performance as the modern-music dummy chosen to interview composers before their performances. (''Tell us a little bit about what this piece is about, Wolfgang Amadeus. . . . Thanks. I heard some of the rehearsal, and this piece is really spectacular. I'm really looking forward to it.'')

title: Season Ends in 3-D, Cameos and Cliffhangers
description: ''I love television,'' Sally Solomon, one of the pop-culture-besotted characters on ''Third Rock From the Sun,'' is fond of saying. Her whole family gets absolutely gushy in front of the set, and from them it's endearing. Of course, they're from another planet, which is pretty much the only way this year's season-ending gimmicks can possibly seem fresh.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GINSBURG, MOLLIE
description: GINSBURG-Mollie, 92, piano teacher, of Highland Park, NJ, died May 18, 1997. Loving wife of the late Dr. Joseph M. Ginsburg. Dearly beloved mother of Miriam & Ira Hyams of L.I. and Melvin & Carol Ginsburg of N.J. Cherished grandmother of 5 grandchildren and 3 great-grandchildren. Dear sister of Sarah Arky and Dr. William Rubin. This kind, gracious lady gave beauty, grace and love to all who knew her. Services 12 Noon, Tuesday, May 20, Highland Park Cons. Temple, So. 3rd Ave and Benner.

title: Tisch to Match, and Raise, Revoked Gift to Children's Zoo
description: Early this month, Henry and Edith Everett roiled the high-stakes, image-conscious world of New York philanthropy when they denounced the choice of James S. Tisch as the new head of the UJA-Federation of New York, arguing that his interests in a big cigarette company made him unfit to head the giant charity.

title: Virus That Causes Common Cold Is Tested as Cancer Fighter
description: A NOVEL treatment for cancers of the head and neck has yielded interesting results in an early trial, according to a report presented yesterday at a meeting of the American Society of Clinical Oncologists in Denver.

title: Japan's View Of Rising Yen: Not to Worry
description: What is surprising, as the yen shoots up once more against the dollar, is that no one in Japan is screaming.

title: CLINTON LAUNCHES EFFORT TO RENEW CHINA TRADE TIES
description: President Clinton began a campaign today to win Congressional renewal of normal trading status for China, in an annual exercise that threatens to be more contentious than ever this year.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MICHAELS, MAX
description: MICHAELS-Max. Born in Drohitchyn, Poland in 1905. Devoted husband to the late Ann (nee Wasserman). Loving father to Linda and Marty. Devoted grandfather and uncle. Max had a successful business career of 50 years with Farber Brothers in NYC. Former 21 year resident of Century Village, West Palm Beach, FL. The beautiful qualities of his life shall endure forever in the hearts of those who love him. Graveside services Tuesday, May 20, at Beth David Cemetery. information: Levitt-Weinstein, 800-343-5400.

title: Explorer of Aging Process Is Lighting Candles in the Dark
description: From the beginning, says Caleb E. Finch, a gerontologist at the University of Southern California here, he had ''an instinct for professionally dangerous pursuits.'' As an undergraduate at Yale University in the early 1960's, he realized that aging was an area of biology about which almost nothing was known and in which few scientists were interested. So Dr. Finch jumped in and began asking questions that today are at the forefront of aging research worldwide.

title: No Headline
description: ''Heroin chic isn't what we're projecting. It's what we are. Our business has become heroin chic. Someone taking pictures of that magnitude has to have experienced hard drugs.''

title: Bomb in Beeper Injures Woman, But Brother Said to Be Target
description: A waitress in a Mexican restaurant in Forest Hills, Queens, was seriously injured last night when a beeper secretly rigged with a blasting cap exploded in her hand and destroyed at least one finger, the police said.

title: Nonprofits Get Interstate Trade Protection
description: In a case watched closely by nonprofit organizations around the country, the Supreme Court ruled today that states offering favorable tax treatment to charities cannot draw distinctions based on whether a charity serves primarily in-state or out-of-state clients.

title: A Family Divided by a Child's Death
description: Before she moved to New York City last year, Amy Burney used to race through her Miami neighborhood with her braids flying and her big, brown eyes shining like ''50-cent pieces'' as she chattered to anyone who would listen. ''She would talk you tired,'' said Mary Burney, her great-aunt, who sometimes cared for the little girl in Florida.

title: Corrections
description: Because of a producer's repeated change of plans, a correction in this space on Sunday carried an outdated schedule for Memorial Jam, a salsa and merengue concert at Madison Square Garden. It will take place at 8 P.M. on Saturday, not Sunday. (The concert was originally scheduled for Saturday, as listed in the Arts and Leisure section, then briefly rescheduled.)

title: Keeping Baby Outside
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KITTENPLAN, GERTRUDE S.
description: KITTENPLAN-Gertrude S. On May 18, 1997. Beloved wife of the late Reuben. Devoted mother of Stephen Kittenplan and Juliet Goldsmith. Mother-in-law of Gail and Robert. Loving grandmother of Susan and Betsey Kittenplan, Amy and Joshua Hubbard, Richard and Linda Goldsmith, Gillian and Peter Rittmaster. Interment private.

title: Now Playing at a Nearby Lab: 'Revenge of the Fly People'
description: GODZILLA, genitalless, gut feeling, gouty legs, goliath, gooseberry distal, ghost, glisten, gang-of-three.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KEINER, CHARLES H.
description: KEINER-Charles H. Age 84, on May 18, 1997. Beloved husband of Ruth. Devoted father of Richard and Lois. Dear brother of Milton. Served in the U.S. Navy in W.W. II in Northern Ireland. Retired attorney. We will miss him.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BRADY, LAWRENCE K.
description: BRADY-Lawrence K., on May 18, 1997, of Forest Hills & Southamton, NY. Beloved husband of Margaret. Devoted father of Lawrence K. Jr. and Laura. Loving father-inlaw of Darlene. Future father-inlaw of John Saade. Visiting at Fox Funeral Home, Forest Hills, on Tuesday 7-10 PM. Funeral Mass at Our Lady Queen of Martyrs Church Forest Hills Wednesday May 21, 1997 at 9:30 AM.

title: Pentagon Urges Trims in Military and More Base Closings
description: The Pentagon today released a strategic blueprint for the early 21st century that calls for a new round of base closings, cuts of about 60,000 active-duty troops and reductions in the planned fleet of new jet fighters, but it asked for no major changes in battle doctrine and killed no major weapons programs.

title: Still Mayor After 3 Counts
description: After a third count of the results of the May 13 mayoral election, the winner is still -- barely -- Mayor Bret Schundler. Yesterday, the Jersey City clerk, Robert Byrne, certified that Mr. Schundler had won re-election on the first ballot by 4.5 votes. The final tally by Mr. Byrne gave Mr. Schundler 19,744 votes, or 50.01 percent.

title: Screams At the Window
description: American politics is dead. Government is scarcely breathing. Washington media people worth hundreds of millions of dollars are withering away for lack of news from the Potomac shore. Desperate columnists sob and say, ''There is no news.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MARGOLIS, CELIA L.
description: MARGOLIS-Celia L., 90, on May 17, West Palm Beach, Fla. Wife of the late Ely. Survived by her daughter Marion Aronoff and son Ira Margolis, her sister Grace Stieber, grandchildren Cheryl Heller and Mark and Elyse Margolis and great granddaughters Dana and Erica Heller. Graveside services on Wednesday, May 21, 10:30 A.M., Cedar Park Cemetery, NJ.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JOCKER, WILLIAM
description: JOCKER-William. Died May 12th. A fervent fighter for economic reform, teacher at the Henry George School, an original thinker, man of great principle, author, dance devotee and music lover. We are greatly enriched by having known him. He will be sorely missed by David, Jeanne, Andrei, Stephanie, Richard, John, Murray, Roberta and many others. Memorial services to be announced later.

title: Arms Reduction Is Key
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HEGARTY, IRENE, (SMITH)
description: HEGARTY-Irene, (Smith) 74, of Holmes Beach, Florida died May 17, 1997. Mrs. Hegarty was born in Newark, New Jersey. She was a past regent of the Plainfield, NJ Chapter of the D.A.R. She moved to Holmes Beach about four years ago from Jamesburg N.J. after having worked at Merck and Company., Inc. for 37 years, retiring as Administrative Assistant to a Division President. She was a volunteer at Manatee Memorial Hospital, Bradenton Florida with over a 1000 hours credit. Mrs. Hegarty is survived by her husband Allen G., a sister Helen Archie, a nephew John Archie, two nieces, Susan Archie and Joyce Ludwig, grand nieces and a grand nephew. There will be no local visitation or services. Memorials may be made to the Irene Smith Hegarty Fund of the New Jersey Community Foundation, P.O. Box 317 Morristown, NJ 07963-0317.

title: Mets' Staff Secret: Contact Is Your Ally
description: In retrospect -- from the secure vantage point of a 4-3 victory over Colorado yesterday -- the Mets' dugout hierarchy had to be relieved that Armando Reynoso lost his no-hitter-in-progress in the seventh inning. Jeff Reed's two-out home run relieved Manager Bobby Valentine and Bob Apodaca, the pitching coach, of the dilemma of whether to let Reynoso throw many more pitches than they would have been comfortable with.

title: Government Issues Flat In a Light Day
description: Government securities were relatively flat in light trading yesterday, as investors waited for the Federal Reserve's monetary policy arm to meet today to decide whether another interest rate increase to slow the economy was warranted.

title: Top Editor Departing Esquire Magazine
description: In a move that has been widely anticipated in the publishing world, Edward Kosner is leaving as editor in chief of Esquire magazine, which has been troubled by a decline in advertising and newsstand sales.

title: Liberal Counterpoint
description: To the Editor:

title: BELL ATLANTIC TO OFFER FASTER INTERNET ACCESS IN 1998
description: The Bell Atlantic Corporation said yesterday that starting in mid-1998 it would be able to offer Internet access over telephone lines at speeds 100 times as fast as those that are available today. Using a technology called Asymmetric Digital Subscriber Line, or A.D.S.L., Bell Atlantic will upgrade its phone network to carry data at speeds of up to six megabits a second. But other than awarding a contract for the technology to the DSC Communications Corporation of Plano, Tex., Bell Atlantic disclosed little about when or where the new service would be available. After failing to deliver on its ambitious plans to enter interactive television, the company now avoids such predictions.

title: Chess
description: There's the story of the player who works out a series of fluctuating numerical values for the pieces and pawns, depending on where they stand at any given moment, but then falls prey to checkmate. It may be fictitious, but it includes several points. Nothing is wrong with drawing up such a table and marking a knight, queen or rook as deserving additional increments for being in a strong position, say in the center. Yet there is something very much wrong with not extending the method to include the king's safety. That is always in the background of any chessboard configuration, and it must be brought into the foreground if you wish to avoid disaster.

title: A Sale of Pamela Harriman's Style and Taste, and the Result Is a Proper Success
description: Star-gazers went to Sotheby's last night to see what would happen to Pamela Harriman's artworks and snuffboxes, china and furniture. But they were disappointed. Most of the stars were either carefully concealed in sky boxes above the salesroom, or they had left bids days before the sale or simply shopped at home by telephone.

title: 2 Exporters Honored
description: Cattiva, a maker of designer dresses based in Manhattan, and Hoffman International, a manufacturer of industrial parts based in Piscataway, N.J., were selected yesterday by commerce officials for the 1997 World Trade Week Award, which honors local companies active in exports.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FINKELSTEIN, IRVING C.
description: FINKELSTEIN-Irving C., 98, of Bal Harbour, FL., passed away May 17, 1997. He is survived by daughter Mrs. Erna Finkelstein Kislak, Grandchildren; Todd (Nancy) Kislak, Marc (Lisa) Kislak and Michael (Linda) Fields, Great Grandchildren; Paul Fields, Michelle, Sarah and Sasha Kislak. Owner of Finkelstein Sewing Machine Co. The largest second hand sewing machine dealer in the world. Inventor of a Spreading Machine called C.R.A. (Cutting Room Appliances). Services Wednesday May 21, 1997 in Miami.

title: Rexene and Suitor Talk About a Deal
description: The Rexene Corporation said today that it and the Huntsman Corporation had discussed a possible takeover of Rexene for $16 a share.

title: At Megan Kanka Trial, Curiously Empty Seats
description: When they planned for the trial of the man accused of killing Megan Kanka, court officials here thought that there would be a big crowd. After all, the case had spurred a national movement to adopt new laws to notify communities of the presence of sex offenders. There had been so much publicity at the time of the murder that lawyers for the defendant, Jesse K. Timmendequas, suggested he could never get a fair trial.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  GOLDSTEIN, HARRY L.
description: GOLDSTEIN-Harry L. In cherished, loving memory. Barbara and Family

title: Italian Savings Bank Accepts a Merger Offer
description: Cariplo S.p.A., Italy's largest savings bank, accepted a merger offer yesterday from Banco Ambrosiano Veneto S.p.A. The board of the foundation that controls Cariplo voted unanimously to accept the offer, said Giuseppe Guzzetti, chairman of the foundation.

title: A Final Lesson At Seton Hall Stresses Values
description: Reminding them that they had been given an extraordinary opportunity, Tim Russert, the television political analyst, urged the 1,733 graduates of Seton Hall University yesterday to draw upon the values they had absorbed at one of the nation's largest diocesan colleges.

title: Riley's Message to Heat: Don't Give In to Fatigue
description: For the Miami Heat, the Knicks are yesterday's news. One nemesis has been beaten. An even tougher challenge awaits.

title: ADVANCED TECHNOLOGY TO BUY LAWRENCE SEMICONDUCTOR
description: Advanced Technology Materials Inc. agreed yesterday to buy Lawrence Semiconductor Laboratories for $78 million in stock. Advanced Technology, a semiconductor maker based in Danbury, Conn., will exchange about 4.2 million shares for closely held Lawrence Semiconductor, which will become a subsidiary. Advanced Technology also said it would take a charge of about $1.5 million. Lawrence Semiconductor, based in Mesa, Ariz., makes thin silicon films used in the manufacture of semiconductors. Advanced Technology's shares rose $1.625, to $20.25.

title: Magnetic Fields on Distant Moons Hint at Hidden Life
description: WHEN scientists wonder about the hidden depths of a moon or planet, they often look for signs of a magnetic field.

title: Weary Rockets No Match For Jazz
description: Houston was playing on 48 hours rest, Utah was playing on 168 hours rest and that was not Karl Malone asking for the massage.

title: Bulls' Dynasty Shows Signs of Tottering
description: A distress signal has been detected in the cool world of the Chicago Bulls, one created by an uncertainty that has snuck up on the champions like crow's-feet.

title: INSIDE
description: A Leaner Fighting Machine

title: Jobs for Welfare Recipients?
description: Twelve companies, including Bell Atlantic, United Parcel Service and National Telecommunications of Bloomfield, have agreed to ''aggressively recruit'' state welfare recipients for 7,000 new entry-level jobs over the next year, Gov. Christine Todd Whitman said yesterday.

title: Dow Chemical Cleared by Court
description: The Dow Chemical Company said today that a Federal appeals court had ruled that the company was not liable for injuries claimed by recipients of silicone jaw implants made by its Dow Corning Corporation joint venture.

title: Olerud's Clout Ends Long Day of Second-Guessing
description: Second-guessing at Shea Stadium isn't that unusual, but yesterday, most of the second-guessing was being done by the Mets themselves. When Armando Reynoso's bid for a no-hitter ended in the seventh inning, on Jeff Reed's homer with two outs, catcher Todd Hundley kicked himself for calling the pitch Reed bashed out. When Reynoso tired in the eighth and the Rockies scored twice to take a 3-2 lead, Mets Manager Bobby Valentine was disgusted that he had not relieved Reynoso sooner. When Edgardo Alfonzo did not try to take an extra base on a ninth-inning hit, he wondered whether it would cost the Mets a pivotal run.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CHANG, PIHYA C.
description: CHANG-Pihya C., at rest in Palo Alto, California on May 17, 1997. Wife of the late Dr. Kia Ngau Chang of the Hoover Institution. Friends are invited to attend the funeral service on Thursday, May 22, 1997 at 10:00AM, at the chapel of Roller Hapgood & Tinney, 980 Middlefield Road, Palo Alto. Entombment will be at the Mountain View Cemetery, Oakland.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FINKELSTEIN, BEN
description: FINKELSTEIN-Ben. The New York Times records with deep sorrow the passing of Ben Finkelstein associated with the Times from 1924, until retiring in 1964.

title: Bond Rating Questioned
description: New Jersey's prized AA+ bond rating may be threatened. Standard & Poor's, which has given the state its second-highest rating six years in a row, announced yesterday that because of unanticipated expenses and nonrecurring revenues, next year's state budget could be balanced in a way that ''may not be fully consistent with a AA+ rating.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LOIR, THANNA
description: LOIR-Thanna. In San Francisco on May 17, 1997 at age 94. Beloved wife of the late Emile Loir; loving mother of Sonia Loir and the late Germaine Loir and Maurice Loir; adored grandmother of Claudia, Rachelle, Emile and Paula; great grandmother of Michael and Lauren; dear sister of Irving and Mortimer Leav and the late Clara Chanin, Adela Raphael and Solomon Leav; loving aunt of many nieces and nephews. Services will be held at 12:30 pm on Wednesday, May 21 at Boulevard-Riverside Chapels, 1450 Broadway, Hewlett, Long Island. Contributions to the S.F. Senior Center or Cong. Sherith Israel preferred.

title: Scripps to Buy Harte-Hanks Media Assets
description: The E. W. Scripps Company said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire the newspaper and broadcasting properties of Harte-Hanks Communications Inc. for between $605 million and $775 million.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEISSGLASS, BENNETT
description: WEISSGLASS-Bennett. Died on May 11, 1997 at age 73. A physician specializing in internal medicine. He lived and practiced in Morristown, New Jersey since 1955. Born in Brooklyn he graduated Stamford University and the University of Oregon Medical School. He completed his residencies and internship at Coney Hospital in Brooklyn and Bellevue Hospital in New York City. A veteran of the US Army he served in WWII and the Korean War. He was the devoted husband of Lela and cherished father of Susan, Leslie and Jennie. He is also survived by a sister Charlotte and seven grandchildren.

title: Longtime Missions Pressed by H.M.O.'s
description: It began as a charity supported by Paul Revere that sent out doctors to the poor. It evolved into the New England Medical Center at Tufts University, a research powerhouse that ranks among the leaders in New England in liver transplants, breast-cancer research and complex heart procedures.

title: Labor Politician in Britain Accused of Buying Off Rivals
description: Faced with its first test of crisis management, Britain's Labor Government reacted swiftly today to charges that a newly elected member of Parliament may have tried to bribe three opposing candidates to withdraw from actively campaigning against him.

title: Allyn Baum, 72, Editor and Photographer
description: Allyn Zelton Baum, a retired editor, news photographer and writer, died on Saturday at Beth Israel Hospital. He was 72 and lived on the East Side of Manhattan.

title: Agassi and Becker Out of French Open
description: ANDRE AGASSI and BORIS BECKER are out of the French Open and PETE SAMPRAS is hurting with the Grand Slam tournament less than a week away.

title: New Child Support Rules
description: In a move that may reduce payments for some noncustodial parents, the State Supreme Court revised its child support guidelines yesterday. Beginning in September, noncustodial parents, most commonly divorced fathers, will get credit for the cost of feeding and transporting their children during visits. Noncustodial parents will also be allowed to deduct alimony payments from their total income, leaving a decreased base from which to figure child support, a court spokesman, Robert Seidenstein, said. At the same time, the court increased the state's estimated costs of raising a child.

title: Democratic Leader Resigns
description: B. Thomas Byrne Jr., the chairman of the Democratic State Committee since 1994, said yesterday that he would step down when his term expires next month. His resignation allows the winner of the June 3 gubernatorial primary to select a new chairman, who must be approved by state committee members. During Mr. Byrne's tenure, Democrats retained both United States Senate seats and recovered from heavy losses in the State Legislature in the early 1990's.

title: Half-Right on Public Housing
description: The House passed a bill last week sponsored by Representative Rick Lazio, a New York Republican, that is supposed to transform public housing, turning crime-ridden welfare warehouses into respectable havens for the working poor. This is a good idea. But the Lazio bill also has serious problems. In its present form, it could end up doing more harm than good.

title: A Line to Enrichment
description: To the Editor:

title: SOCCER REPORT
description: United States

title: A Kennedy Who Lost
description: To the Editor:

title: Limited Operating Net Dips, as Expected
description: The Limited Inc. said yesterday that operating earnings fell 11 percent in the fiscal first quarter, meeting expectations of analysts who have criticized the clothing retailer for a lack of focus.

title: A Quiet Force Behind the Rangers
description: When Chuck Daly coached the Detroit Pistons to two National Basketball Association championships, he used a modern approach with his high-salaried, prideful employees. You don't coach them, Daly used to say, as much as you create a climate in which they allow themselves to be coached by you. His philosophy recognized that contemporary professional coaches no longer enjoy Lombardi-like autocracy.

title: Patterns
description: New Directions at Nautica

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about New York's offer of pollution credits to companies that relocate in the state misspelled the surname of an environmentalist who expressed concerns about the plan. He is Peter Iwanowicz, not Ironowitz.

title: Dorothy Olding, Loyal Literary Agent, Dies at 87
description: Dorothy Olding, longtime literary agent for J. D. Salinger and chief guardian of the reclusive author's privacy, who at the author's request once destroyed 500 letters they had written to each other, died on Wednesday at her home in Manhattan. She was 87.

title: Antitrust Officials Argue Against Office Supply Deal
description: Government antitrust officials said today that internal company documents demonstrated that a merger of the office supply giants Staples Inc. and Office Depot Inc. would allow the new company to raise prices with impunity in dozens of markets across the United States.

title: Challengers To Whitman Find Interest Hard to Raise
description: Almost half the 18 students attending a class to become nursing assistants had left before State Senator James E. McGreevey arrived for a campaign stop last week to talk about the importance of job training. Of those who remained, none knew that Mr. McGreevey was running for governor. And none even knew that there was a Democratic primary contest in the state on June 3.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-11

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GERSON, NATHAN
description: GERSON-Nathan. The New York Times records with deep sorrow the passing of Nathan Gerson, associated with the Times from 1959 until retiring in 1979.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHULSON, HYMAN ABRAHAM
description: SCHULSON-Hyman Abraham. On May 19, 1997. Husband of Ruth Hendricks Schulson. Father of David and Sheree Schulson, Henry and Rachel Schulson and Anne Stephen Young. Grandfather of Lorree, Jaimee, Molly, Michael, Leah, Jason and Daniel. Brother of Florence Mayer, Evelyn Garfinkel and the late Sol Schulson. Funeral services at The Riverside, 76 Street and Amsterdam Avenue, Wednesday, May 21, 11:15 A.M.

title: Study Finds Secondhand Smoke Doubles Risk of Heart Disease
description: Secondhand cigarette smoke is more dangerous than previously thought, Harvard researchers are reporting today in a study with broad implications for public health policy and probable direct impact on at least one major lawsuit.

title: For Goldman, Room For More Expansion
description: Goldman Sachs & Company's long search for expansion space in the Wall Street area may finally be coming to an end.

title: For Now, He Who Can, Teaches
description: SADLY too late, Ennis Cosby will receive his master of education degree today from Teachers College at Columbia University.

title: Thwarted Robbery In Penthouse Leads To Death of Officer
description: After a three-year estrangement, Scott Schneiderman paid a visit to his father's Chelsea apartment early yesterday morning in Manhattan. He slipped a ski mask over his head, investigators said, put a roll of duct tape in his pocket and brought along a .25-caliber pistol.

title: Penske Buys Control of a Motor Speedway
description: Penske Motorsports Inc. said today that it had acquired about a 70 percent interest in North Carolina Motor Speedway in an exchange of stock.

title: Stars Adrift: Further Out, Further In
description: Michael Jackson

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JOHNSON, FRANCIS EDGAR, JR.
description: JOHNSON-Francis Edgar, Jr. Age 84. Of Peapack, NJ and Marthas Vineyard, MA. Husband of Helena (Nee Edey), father of Cynthia J. MacKay, MD of Brooklyn, NY., Helena Bienstock of Princeton, NJ and Frank E. Johnson, III of New York City. Brother of Collister of Peapack, NJ and Robert deL of Liberty Corner, NJ. Grandfather of Robert L. MacKay, Jessica Koehler, Hope W. MacKay and Christina M. Johnson, a fifth grandchild, Alison G. Fraker predeceased him. Funeral service will be held Thursday, May 22 at 11AM at the Lamington Presbyterian Church, Lamington Road, Lamington, NJ. In lieu of flowers, the family request donations be made to Morristown Memorial Hospital, 100 Madison Avenue, Morristown, NJ 07960 or The Walter D. Matheny School, Peapack, NJ 07977.

title: Delgratia Says Nevada Site Holds Little Gold
description: The Delgratia Mining Corporation said today that there was ''insignificant gold'' at its Josh Project gold property in Nevada and that it had requested a criminal investigation of possible tampering with ore samples from the site.

title: Funds for the Workfare Transition
description: New York City and other local governments will be required, under the new Federal welfare law, to find work for tens of thousands of welfare recipients over the next several years, a task no state has ever attempted let alone achieved. Yet New York's Governor, George Pataki, wants to deny local officials the money they need to get the task accomplished. An easy answer to a difficult problem is at hand. Mr. Pataki just needs to grab it.

title: Banks Set Bailout Of Korean Company
description: South Korean banks have agreed to bail out the Dainong Group to prevent a third bankruptcy of a big-name Korean company this year. Seoul Bank, a prime creditor, said yesterday that Dainong's debt totaled 1.35 trillion won ($1.5 billion), equivalent to its annual sales. The finances of the company deteriorated earlier this year as it spent heavily to fend off a hostile takeover attempt on its retail business, the Midopa Company.

title: Facing the Deniers
description: When free men and women accept their privilege of fighting for the persecuted in distant tyrannies they undertake three obligations:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MURPHY, MICHAEL J.
description: MURPHY-Michael J. The 35,000 members of the alumni, students, faculty and staff of John Jay College of Criminal Justice note with profound sorrow the passing of Michael J. Murphy, the first Acting President of John Jay College of Criminal Justice and the pioneering law enforcement leader. As New York City Police Commissioner, he had the foresight and courage to fight for the establishment of the nation's first and only college dedicated to the education and professionalization of policing. A recipient of the college's Presidential Medal, he was a tremendous supporter in the early development of John Jay College and remained so throughout its history. The law enforcement community has lost a strong advocate for progressive policing in America. We extend our heartfelt condolences to the Murphy family. Gerald W. Lynch, President John Jay College of Criminal Justice, The City University of New York

title: Police Are Stopping Drivers To Promote Use of Seat Belts
description: Police officers around the country began stopping cars at checkpoints today in a campaign to enforce seat belt and child-restraint laws.

title: Guide to Going Shopping Without the Dropping
description: When it comes to shopping, the two women are as different as Barneys and Bolton's. One sees it as the ultimate bonding experience, while the other shops only when she really needs something. One has been known to call a $900 shearling coat a bargain, while the other's idea of a good buy is a $12 pair of flats.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RICH, AUDREY BRYANT
description: RICH-Audrey Bryant, 75 of Plandome, New York. Devoted wife, mother and grandmother. Passed away May 18. Memorial service will be held at the Congregational Church of Manhasset, May 21 at 11 AM. Donations are greatfully accepted on behalf of Hospice Care Network, 900 Merchants Concource, Westbury, NY, 11590.

title: C.I.A.'s Openness Derided as a 'Snow Job'
description: The Central Intelligence Agency's years-old promises to release records on its most famous covert operations of the cold war are merely ''a brilliant public relations snow job'' and ''a carefully nurtured myth,'' says a historian who served for six years on a C.I.A. panel that helps in the declassifying of the agency's data.

title: Flat Screens Throw Mental Curves
description: YOU can never be too slim or too flat, at least if you happen to be a computer display. The idea of the big warm box that monopolizes the desktop is slowly giving way to the idea of a skinny screen not much bigger than a framed picture. Flat-panel monitors using displays much like the ones in laptop computers are already available, but they have significant performance limitations. And today's flat-panel monitors cost at least four times as much as comparable tube models; the cheapest 14-inch unit currently available costs more than $2,000.

title: Infant Mortality Drops To Below 1,000 a Year
description: The number of infant deaths in New York City, which has fallen almost every year since 1900, has dipped below 1,000 a year for the first time, the City Health Department reported yesterday.

title: Q&A
description: A South Star?

title: Ballet Violists' Sexual Harassment Suit Advances
description: Three violists who sued the New York City Ballet Company, complaining of sexual harassment in the orchestra, have won a preliminary victory in their efforts to obtain important evidence.

title: Strawberry Limps Through Return
description: Darryl Strawberry began his rehabilitation assignment with the Class AA Navigators tonight the way he left the Yankees five weeks ago -- in pain.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RUBINROTH, MARTIN J.
description: RUBINROTH-Martin J. May 19, 1997. Loving husband of Lee. Devoted father of Susan and Robert Leonard. Loving grandfather of Chloe and Carly. Services Tuesday, 10 AM, at Schwartz Bros-Jeffer Memorial Chapel, 114-03 Queens Blvd, Forest Hills, NY.

title: Sustenance And Bane Of a Region
description: Sorting out the good guys from the bad in ''The Opium Kings'' is no problem once you conclude that there are no good guys. This report on three decades of unrest in the Shan area of Myanmar, on the borders of Thailand and China, finds that revolutionary leaders can also be drug traffickers.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  SYMONDS, DOCTOR ALEXANDRA
description: SYMONDS-Doctor Alexandra. On May 20, 1992. In loving memory ''Allie'' Martin

title: U.S. Reviews A Bid Made By Microsoft
description: In a sign of the Government's continuing scrutiny of the Microsoft Corporation, the Justice Department issued a formal request to the big software company last week, seeking internal documents concerning Microsoft's planned $425 million purchase of WebTV Networks Inc.

title: Infinitesimal Yet Indispensable
description: The summer getaway season is fast approaching, and the one weekend essential is a swimsuit. This year, the fashionable choice is a bikini, with enough selections to make choosing difficult.

title: A.M.A. Votes to Support a Ban On a Late Abortion Procedure
description: In an unusual move, the American Medical Association today voted to endorse a proposed ban on what critics call ''partial birth abortions,'' approving a measure that directly involves Congress in the practice of medicine.

title: Sun Is Seeking Sales Abroad Of Latest Encryption Software
description: Sun Microsystems Inc. said today that it planned to sell advanced data-encryption software created by a Russian company to international customers, a decision that is likely to draw Federal Government scrutiny.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RAPPORT, CAROL (NEE FRIEDMAN)
description: RAPPORT-Carol (nee Friedman) on May 19, 1997. Wife of Leon of Cherry Hill, NJ. Mother of Holly Rapport and Josh Rapport. Daughter of Lillian (nee Ledvitch) and the late Leon Friedman. Sister of Susan Sharek and David Friedman. Services Tuesday, 2PM, Platt Memorial Chapels, Inc, 2001 Berlin Road, Cherry Hill, NJ. Interment private. The family will return to the late residence.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROGERS, EVELYN
description: ROGERS-Evelyn. The New York Times records with deep sorrow the passing of Evelyn Rogers, associated with the Times from 1972, until retiring in 1991.

title: Parcells Joins Action As Jets Start Minicamp
description: Until today, Bill Parcells had been following his new team from a distance. Watching from the window of his office, he liked what he saw of the offense during informal workouts.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BARTLETT, DAVID
description: BARTLETT-David. Died May 13. Survived by his wife Stefane Abeille-Demay; his daughters Linda Miller, Victoria Donaldson and Stefane Bartlett; 4 granddaughters & his brother, Charles L. Bartlett. Memorial Mass, 4 P.M., Tuesday, May 20, at Saint Vincent Ferrer, 869 Lexington Avenue.

title: L.I.R.R. Track Repairs Lead to Crowded Trains
description: Major track repairs began yesterday on the Long Island Rail Road, forcing many commuters onto unusually crowded trains under new timetables that will be in effect for four months.

title: U.S. Accepts Kabila, but Cautions on Democracy
description: The Clinton Administration moved quickly today to extend ties and recognition to the rebel alliance now ruling Zaire, pledging its help in building a democratic government and adopting the name the rebels have given the country, the Democratic Republic of Congo.

title: The Long and Winding History Of a 'Gateway to the Jersey Shore'
description: The proposed Route 92 has been on the drawing boards in New Jersey for 60 years, its path changing so much through time that the original planners would barely recognize it. After all this time, it is a road plan that is still dodging those who would make it road kill.

title: Coca-Cola goes after share of mouth with Fruitopia campaign
description: MOST consumers have yet to find Xanadu or Shangri-La, much less Utopia, inside a bottle of Fruitopia. So as that juice drink brand enters its fourth summer, its parent, the Coca-Cola Company, is intensifying efforts to gain what the beverage industry calls share of mouth.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ELY, JOHN I.
description: ELY-John I., Atty. In New Haven, CT. May 18, 1997, husband of the late Harriet Jackson Ely of 221 Everit St., New Haven, CT. Survived by five daughters and two sons. Burial Office and Eucharist will be celebrated at St. Thomas Episcopal Church, 830 Whitney Avenue, New Haven at noon on Wednesday, May 21, 1997. Memorial contributions may be made to the John I. Ely Memorial Fund, at Yale University, Divinity School, 409 Prospect Street, New Haven, CT. 06511 or to a charity of one's choice. For more information contact Beecher & Bennett Funeral Home, Hamden, CT.

title: Making Science Fun Helps It Get Funds
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   FLEISIG, ROBIN
description: FLEISIG-Robin. Brilliant, funny, talented; a woman of valor. We'll miss the holidays. We love you. Roz, Rick and Kate Jay

title: For Knicks, Time to Pack And to Ponder
description: They all had the day off, the first of many over the next five months. Before cleaning out their belongings on Hefty bag day at SUNY-Purchase on Tuesday, the Knicks were given time to reflect on their sudden demise in the playoffs.

title: On American Art Coming of Age
description: AMERICAN VISIONS

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLDBERG, NATHAN
description: GOLDBERG-Nathan. The New York Times records with deep sorrow the passing of Nathan Goldberg associated with the Times from 1959, until retiring in 1983.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEE, BENJAMIN F.
description: LEE-Benjamin F. Of Palm Beach, FL., and Scarsdale, NY. At the age of 88. Beloved husband of Doris S. Lee. Loving father of Bruce S. Lee of New City, N.Y., and Lawrence Lee of Scarsdale, NY. Cherished grandfather. Previously deceased by his first wife Ruth. A respected and loved member of the Schulman family. Services will be held Thursday, at 11:30AM, at Temple Israel of New Rochelle. Interment Jewish Community Center Cemetery, Monsey, New York.

title: Virtual Elgin Marbles
description: To the Editor:

title: Agencies Share Best-of-Show Obies
description: BBDO Canada in Toronto, Lois/ EJL in Los Angeles and J. Walter Thompson San Francisco shared top honors, winning the Best of Show awards, at the 55th annual Obie Awards for creative excellence sponsored by the Outdoor Advertising Association of America.

title: 'Seinfeld' and Guilt
description: To the Editor:

title: Alex Kelly Lied, Former Friend Testifies
description: A former friend of Alex Kelly testified today that Mr. Kelly lied to him about events on Feb. 10, 1986, the night a young woman says Mr. Kelly raped her after she accepted his offer to drive her home from a party in Darien.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BRADLEY, FREDERICK W.
description: BRADLEY-Frederick W. Bradley, 47, of 7 E. 14th Street, on May 17th. Member of New York Genealogical Society.
