Son of Reverend William Bradley and the late Barbara (MacKenzie) Bradley, stepson of Virginia Bradley, dear friend of many. Funeral service at The Dinoto Funeral Home, Mystic, CT., at 2 PM, Thursday. Visiting hours from noon until service.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SEGAL KAMEN, EDITH
description: SEGAL KAMEN-Edith. Beloved wife of the late Samuel Kamen. Dear sister of Tess Segel. Cherished sister-in-law of Judith and the late Manasseh Kamen and Fay and the late Ephraim Kamen; loving aunt of Barbara Kamen Movius and Geoffrey Movius; Mitchell and Helene Kamen; Richard Kamen; Michael and Sandra Kamen; and Shari and Peter Goldberg. Poetess, dancer and humanitarian, she will be remembered by all who knew her and were touched by her kindness and creativity.

title: Tax Breaks Squeeze Schools in Cleveland
description: The once-forsaken downtown boasts a glistening array of new office towers, hotels and sports stadiums. In the Flats, the industrial area where the brown bends of the Cuyahoga River once caught fire, the riverbanks are lined with bars and restaurants. Over all, the city's economic revival has transformed Cleveland from the Mistake on the Lake to the Comeback City.

title: GLENDALE FEDERAL ACQUIRING PORTFOLIO FROM CITICORP
description: Glendale Federal Bank said yesterday that it would buy the servicing rights to a $12 billion fixed-rate mortgage loan portfolio from Citicorp for an undisclosed amount. Glendale, a savings and loan operator based in Glendale, Calif., said the portfolio consisted of more than 45,000 loans in California with an average age of two to three years. Citicorp will acquire this portfolio on May 30 from the Norwest Corporation's Prudential Home Mortgage Company unit. That acquisition will be simultaneous with the Citicorp sale to Glendale Federal. As of March 31, Glendale Federal's servicing portfolio, consisting of about 240,000 loans, had an outstanding loan balance of $25.7 billion.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GLICK, BELLE R.
description: GLICK-Belle R. Of West Palm Beach, passed away May 18, 1997. She is survived by her husband of 55 years Sidney, her daughter Ferne Maibrunn (Bob), a loving grandson Marc. An accomplished artist and a lover of the arts. Services were Monday, May 19, in Florida. Services by Riverside Gordon Memorial Chapel, West Palm Beach, Florida.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STERN, SIMON
description: STERN-Simon. At the age of 81. Past owner of a delicatessen in Bay Shore and Farmingdale. Beloved husband of the late Sylvia. Loving father of Shari and Sholom. Cherished brother of Dinah Breiterman. Funeral services today at 10:30 A.M., at Mt. Ararat Cemetery, Farmingdale, N.Y.

title: Nothing but the Best For a New Granola
description: Granola, the signature food of the 1960's, is finding new life in the 90's. And Debra Stark, the owner of the Natural Gourmet, a health-food store in Concord, Mass., is among those leading the change.

title: Lindros's Hat Trick Brings Rangers Back to Earth
description: There is a certain symmetry about the numbers on their backs: 99 for the slender Wayne Gretzky, the Great One; 88 for the brawny Eric Lindros, the Next One. There is also a certain symmetry in the numbers on their scoresheets: three goals for Gretzky in a Ranger victory in Game 2 in Philadelphia on Sunday; three goals for Lindros in a Philadelphia victory in Game 3 in New York last night.

title: Philippines Weighing New Access to Counter China's Ambitions : U.S. Sets Sail for Subic Bay Again
description: SINGAPORE  Five years after it returned the giant Subic Bay base to the Philippines, the United States military is negotiating with Manila to use the port and its facilities more frequently to maintain a stronger naval presence in the South China Sea.

title: Albert Indicted in Virginia on Assault Charges
description: Marv Albert, the popular NBC Sports announcer, has been indicted by a grand jury here on charges of assault and battery and forcing a woman to perform oral sex.

title: Nafta Environmental Lags May Delay Free Trade Expansion
description: During his recent Latin American trip, President Clinton enthusiastically promised to extend free trade throughout the hemisphere. But a delay in an environmental study on the effect of the increased trade that has already taken place is weakening support he will need to get wider trade agreements approved in Congress.

title: Metropolitan Diary
description: DEAR DIARY:

title: New York Is Still No. 1 -- in Taxes
description: Last year there were 2.8 million private-sector jobs in New York City, down from 3.2 million in 1969. This means that New York City, once the most dynamic city economy in the world, has not created a net new job in more than a quarter century.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  EINBINDER, EDITH LEVINE
description: EINBINDER-Edith Levine. Loving wife. Devoted mother of Dorothy Levine Goldstein and Stewart Levine. Cherished grandmother of David, Daniel, Deborah, Sunny and Sophie. Funeral services on Wednesday, 11 AM at Riverside Memorial Chapel, Amsterdam Avenue at 76th Street.

title: More Than 50 Journalists Are Fellowship Recipients
description: More than 50 journalists from around the world will take time off from their jobs as reporters, editors, photographers and producers starting this fall for an academic year of study in fellowships offered by five universities.

title: Hubble Space Telescope Finds Big Shifts in Weather on Mars
description: The versatile Hubble Space Telescope has been put to use tracking the weather -- on Mars. And conditions there are much more variable than previously believed, scientists said today.

title: F.B.I. Handling of Evidence Is Attacked at Bomb Trial
description: In a concerted effort to attack the integrity of the Federal Bureau of Investigation's laboratory, a lawyer for Timothy J. McVeigh today won admissions from a senior F.B.I. chemist that some evidence from the Oklahoma City bombing could have been handled better.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MORGENSTERN, STANLEY
description: MORGENSTERN - Stanley, on May 19, 1997, formerly of New York. Loving husband of Collette. Devoted father of Raymond. Beloved son of Rose and the late Raymond. Adored brother of Penny Lamove and brother-in-law of Michael Lamove. Also survived by his sister-in-law Donna Materasso and brother-in-law Michael Materasso. Services Wednesday, 12 PM, at ''The Riverside'', 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: BILL FACES A VETO
description: The Senate passed a bill today that for the first time would ban a specific abortion procedure, but abortion opponents fell three votes short of the number needed to override an expected veto from President Clinton.

title: Barnard Graduates Told to Believe Passionately in Their Acts
description: Anna Quindlen, the author and Pulitzer Prize-winning journalist, told students at the 105th Barnard College commencement yesterday that the only way they can save the world, or any small part of it, ''is to firmly, passionately believe that it is so grand that it is worth saving.''

title: Honorary Avaiator Tends Blue Angels Shrine
description: In the cool of the morning, before even the first of the daytime drinkers enters his ramshackle bar on Palafox Street, it is just Martin Weissman and the angels.

title: Back in Goal, Hextall Turns Back the Rangers
description: With their matching Vandykes and measured, monotone deliveries, Ron Hextall and Eric Lindros of the Flyers look and talk like a couple of beefy bouncers at a nightclub.

title: Veto the Abortion Ban
description: The Senate once again approved a ban on so-called ''partial-birth'' abortions yesterday. But despite a last-minute endorsement of the ban by the American Medical Association, the 64-to-36 vote fell short of a veto-proof margin. President Clinton should follow through with his promised veto. Despite minor changes, the bill would unduly interfere with a woman's access to a procedure that may be the best and safest in her circumstances.

title: Jobless Rate Unchanged
description: New York City's high unemployment rate did not budge in April, remaining stuck at 9.7 percent, even as a booming national economy pushed down unemployment rates to low levels elsewhere around the country. The state's seasonally adjusted unemployment rate of 6.3 percent was also unchanged.

title: PERSONNEL GROUP CONSIDERS SALE OF NURSEFINDERS UNIT
description: Personnel Group of America Inc. said yesterday that it had hired an investment banking firm to evaluate alternatives, including a possible sale, for its Nursefinders unit. Personnel Group, a staffing company, hired Minneapolis-based Goldsmith, Agio, Helms & Company to assess the health care staffing operation, saying it wanted to concentrate on its other staffing businesses. Nursefinders, based in Arlington, Tex., had revenue of $122.9 million in 1996. Personnel Group, based in Charlotte, N.C., operates 193 offices in 37 states and the District of Columbia. Its shares rose $1.25 yesterday, to $26.125.

title: North Carolina TV Deal
description: Gray Communications Systems Inc. has agreed to acquire the television station WITN in Greenville, N.C., from Raycom Media Inc. The terms of the transaction were not disclosed. Raycom, which is based in Montgomery, Ala., bought WITN-TV from the Aflac Broadcast Group Inc. unit of Aflac Inc. last August, but it was required to sell the NBC affiliate to satisfy regulations of the Federal Communications Commission's governing the concentration of ownership of television stations.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GIRSCH, LILLIAN
description: GIRSCH-Lillian. On May 19, 1997. Beloved wife of the late Abraham I. Girsch. Dear daughter of the late Solomon and Henrietta Gold. Loving brother of the late Arthur Bennett Gold. Services Wednesday 1:30 PM at ''The Riverside'' 76 St & Amsterdam Ave.

title: Lincoln's Smooth Shave
description: To the Editor:

title: Scandal Puts Brazil Leader Under Cloud
description: President Fernando Henrique Cardoso's high hopes for an extended stay in Brazil's presidency have come under a cloud this week as a political scandal unfolds around the politician, who built his career on a reputation for personal honesty.

title: Mexican Bank Deal
description: GE Capital Services Mexico S.A., a unit of the General Electric Capital Corporation of Stamford, Conn., agreed today to pay $26.7 million for Banco Alianza, a two-year-old commercial bank, to expand asset-based lending and gain access to cheaper capital through deposits, officials said.

title: Woods Meets Zoeller For Lunch
description: Before continuing his effort to win three straight tournaments, Tiger Woods cleared up one major off-course distraction today. Woods met with Fuzzy Zoeller, sharing lunch at the Colonial Country Club here, and accepted Zoeller's apologies for the racially derogatory remarks he made about Woods at the Masters championship.

title: Islamic Rift in Egypt on Organ Transplants
description: To a Westerner, the declaration might have seemed unremarkable: a prominent religious leader announced his willingness to donate his organs to needy patients when he died.

title: Singapore Ranked the No. 1 Economy
description: Singapore again ranks first among the 53 economies rated in the Global Competitiveness Report, a closely watched study of countries' economic potential that is being released today by the World Economic Forum, a business-financed research organization in Geneva.

title: Los Angeles Coliseum's Problem: Its Image
description: A sports talk show host was broadcasting live from Memorial Coliseum in Central Los Angeles this week, interviewing some of the National Football League's top rookies. On his drive to the stadium, the host said, he saw rats as big as dogs, heard gun shots and saw two people having sex in a car as he approached the Coliseum.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: TENNIS

title: Battle for Jerusalem Isn't Over Religion
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KHANDALAVALA, NIVI D.
description: KHANDALAVALA-Nivi D., on April 25, 1997 in Bombay, India. Member of Association of Average Adjusters of the United States. Loving father of Dorab (Morristown, NJ), Dina (Sydney, Australia) and Rustom (Tokyo, Japan). Expressions of sympathy may be sent to the children at 7 Thomas Paine Road, Morristown, New Jersey 07960-5741.

title: Better Spy Technology to End Life of U.S. 'Town' in Australia
description: As Darth Vader's Death Star is blown to bits in the new ''Star Wars'' at the local movie theater, the audience of Australian and American Air Force personnel, and squadrons of their children, lets out a whoop. As lights go on, everyone is beaming.

title: CHRONICLE
description: HARRY A. BLACKMUN, who stepped down as an associate justice of the Supreme Court in 1994, has donated his papers to the Library of Congress, it was announced on Monday.

title: Carnival Atmosphere Packs Them In
description: It was a recent Saturday night, and Rhumba, Chicago's popular new Brazilian restaurant, was packed with a decidedly urban, casually attired crowd out for an unusual meal and a high-decibel night on the town. Servers in various shades of black shuttled between the kitchen and the jammed dining room, flanked by two equally crowded bars.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-9

title: Aaron Henry, Civil Rights Leader, Dies at 74
description: Aaron E. Henry, the gruff, blunt-speaking pharmacist who led the drive for racial equality in Mississippi all the way from the fire storms of the 1960's to a seat in the State Legislature and a position of power in the Democratic Party, died on Monday at a hospital near his home in Clarksdale. He was 74 and until he stepped down in 1993 had spent a third of a century as the decidedly activist chairman of the state branch of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FOX, JAMES M.
description: FOX-James M. It is with our deepest sorrow that the Directors, Officers and Employees of the Dime Savings Bank of Williamsburgh mourn the passing of our friend and Director, James M. Fox. We extend our sympathy to his wife, Elaine, and their entire family. We will miss him greatly. The Dime Savings Bank of Williamsburgh. Vincent F. Palagiano, Chairman

title: White House Visitors Vow Support of Welfare Hiring
description: The executives of more than 100 companies came to the White House today to announce that they were making a commitment to hiring people from public assistance rolls.

title: No Trout on Everest
description: To the Editor:

title: Kabila Reaches Congo's Capital After 7-Month Quest
description: In a voyage that marked the end of one of Africa's most spectacular campaigns for power, this country's new President, Laurent Kabila, arrived here tonight from the southern city of Lubumbashi to take over the capital, but did not announce his Government, as he had promised.

title: Heartbreak and Bitterness for Long, Hot Summer
description: John Starks, who was not allowed to play in the final game, looked on the verge of tears. A somber Patrick Ewing could not help but point the finger at Commissioner David Stern. Asked how he felt, Allan Houston shrugged his shoulders.

title: Food Notes
description: Picnics, Cantonese-Style

title: Big Feller Breaks Free From Posse
description: THIS is what happens when the Rangers do not rassle Eric Lindros to the ice and pin him there: His gigantic frame lumbers around the rink and he swats in three goals that help ruin the night for the home team.

title: Can Yanks Keep Clemens From No. 200?
description: Maybe George Steinbrenner should have stayed out of Roger Clemens's weight room last winter. Maybe the Yankee owner should have surprised the memorabilia collector with an autographed baseball from Joe DiMaggio. Maybe Steinbrenner should have looked at one of Clemens's family photo albums. Maybe then Clemens would be chasing his 200th career victory with the Yankees tonight instead of with the Toronto Blue Jays.

title: TV Notes
description: Battling NBC on Thursdays

title: Battle for Jerusalem Isn't Over Religion
description: To the Editor:

title: REGISTRY IN STOCK DEAL FOR RENAISSANCE
description: Registry Inc. agreed yesterday to acquire Renaissance Solutions Inc., a management consulting and systems integration company, in a deal valued at $430 million based on Monday's closing price. Registry, of Newton, Mass., provides information technology consultants on a contract basis. Under the agreement, Renaissance shareholders will receive eight-tenths of a Registry share for each Renaissance share held. When the deal is completed, Registry shareholders will own about two-thirds of the combined company. Shares of Registry fell $7.50 yesterday, to $49. Shares of Renaissance, which is based in Lincoln, Neb., gained $1.375, to $36.125; there are 9.5 million Renaissance shares outstanding. The purchase will be Registry's seventh acquisition since completing its initial public offering of stock last June.

title: 13 Years After Invasion, Grenada Agonizes Anew
description: The arriving tourists may not know it, but the international airport here prompted one of the most lopsided geopolitical confrontations of the cold war. Begun by Cuban construction workers, the landing strip was finished only after American troops invaded this Caribbean nation in October 1983.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CONROY, STEPHEN EDWARD
description: CONROY-Stephen Edward. On May 19, after a long illness. Husband of Catherine Kilhenny Conroy and father of Maura, Edward, and Andrew, father-inlaw of Deborah, grandfather of Alyssa, and brother of Patrick. Reposing at Fairchild Funeral Home, 1570 Northern Boulevard, Manhasset, NY, Tuesday 7-9 PM, Wednesday 3-5 & 7-9 PM. Funeral Mass at St. Peter of Alcantara R.C. Church, Port Washington, N.Y., Thursday 10:00 A.M. Interment Nassau Knolls Cemetery. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the American Cancer Society.

title: Boeing, Threatened, Sees Trade War
description: Who is Karel van Miert, and why is he declaring war on the Boeing Company?

title: Sex, Lies and Bombs
description: The military wanted women who were ready for combat. Well, they got one. Lieut. Kelly Flinn will no longer fly B-52 bombers for the Air Force, but her training in hitting the target has not been wasted.

title: Ducks' Wilson Is Dismissed
description: The Mighty Ducks of Anaheim today fired Ron Wilson, the only coach they have had, because of what General Manager Jack Ferreira called ''philosophical differences'' with the team's management. Wilson was let go, despite the Ducks having their first winning season since coming into the league as an expansion franchise in 1993.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MASON, PATRICIA
description: MASON-Patricia. The William B. May Company deeply mourns the loss of its dear friend, esteemed colleague and Senior Vice President. Pat was loved and respected by all who were privileged to work with her. Her courage and determination continues to be an inspiration to us all. We extend our heartfelt sympathy to her family. Peter R. Marra President William Bruce May Chairman

title: Trumping the 'Race Card' With Careful Analysis
description: RACE, CRIME AND THE LAW

title: Another Ranking Executive At Apple Decides to Resign
description: In the latest senior management departure from struggling Apple Computer Inc., George Scalise, the company's executive vice president for operations, resigned today to become president of the Semiconductor Industry Association. He will leave Apple at the end of the month.

title: After Asking Perfume Price, Man Shoots Store Owner
description: The owner of a midtown Manhattan perfumery was shot and critically wounded yesterday by a gunman who inquired about the price of a bottle of perfume before shooting the shopkeeper in the abdomen, the police said.

title: Administration Plan Seeks Control of Changes at I.R.S.
description: In an apparent effort to head off a more drastic measure, the Clinton Administration today proposed creating a special management board to oversee efforts to overhaul an Internal Revenue Service whose multibillion-dollar modernization plan has stumbled into disaster.

title: The Name of the Father
description: In a ruling intended to strike a compromise between two unmarried parents, a 3-year-old boy was ordered to be given the first and last name his mother prefers, but not the middle name. At birth, the baby was named Stefan Francis Joseph Romanowski, after his father, Stephen Romanowski.

title: Brokerage on Move (But Not Out of City)
description: Fahnestock & Company, a securities brokerage based in Manhattan, is moving from one downtown office tower to another, with more than $1.3 million in assistance from city and state agencies.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RAFF, BEATRICE
description: RAFF-Beatrice. Beloved wife of the late Edward, loving mother of Marsha Engelsher, dear sister of Miriam Spokny and Lillian Bernard, cherished grandmother of David Louis and Terri Lynn. Services Thursday, 1 PM, at Mt. Hebron Cemetery, Queens, New York.

title: Wasserstein Perella to Form New Fund
description: Wasserstein Perella & Company is planning to raise $250 million for a new corporate buyout fund, making it the latest securities firm to arrange such a fund.

title: A Fast Start for Mr. Blair
description: Tony Blair, the self-assured Prime Minister of Britain's new Labor Government, has set forth a plausible and interesting legislative program, blurred by fewer evasions than expected.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GREGG, DR. DOROTHY ELIZABETH
description: GREGG-Dr. Dorothy Elizabeth. Wife of Dr. Paul Hughling Scott, died May 18, 1997, at her home. The loving mother of Sharon Fox, Kim Alzerreca, Gregg Scott and grandmother of Xoli Redmond and Sophia Alzerreca. Memorial services will be held in mid June.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Fed Keeps Rates Steady Amid Few Signs of Inflation

title: School Plans to Build at Another's Site
description: The Ramaz School wanted room to grow. A logical place was the three connected brownstones of York Preparatory School, just across from Ramaz's lower-school building on East 85th Street. But York Prep, which also needed more space, had nowhere to go.

title: Pollution Drops Again
description: New Jersey continues to show progress in reducing pollution, the United States Environmental Protection Agency reported yesterday.

title: House Democratic Leader Opposes Clinton's Budget Deal
description: Representative Richard A. Gephardt, the Democratic leader in the House, broke with the White House today and said he would oppose the budget deal between President Clinton and Congressional Republicans.

title: Burnett Awarded Vitamin Account
description: The Pharmavite Corporation in Mission Hills, Calif., said yesterday that it had named the Leo Burnett Company in Chicago to handle its Nature Made brand of vitamins, which had been handled for eight years by Hal Riney & Partners in San Francisco. Billings were estimated at $15 million.

title: Readers Deserve More
description: To the Editor:

title: Four Teen-Agers Charged in Rape Of Girl in a Classroom in Queens
description: Four teen-agers were arrested and charged with gang-raping a 14-year-old girl last month by luring her from a cafeteria at a public high school in Queens to an unused classroom to carry out the attack, the authorities said yesterday.

title: Marinade, a Steak's Security Blanket
description: WHAT makes a grilled steak memorable is not just the cut of the meat or its crusty texture. More likely, it's the marinade, whether it's the piquant flavor of sweetened soy sauce made pungent with garlic or the subtle herbal flavors of olive oil and wine infused with sage, oregano and rosemary.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ANDREWS, ROBERT T.
description: ANDREWS-Robert T. of Darien, Connecticut, on May 18, 1997. Husband of Mora Spangenberg Andrews. Father of Christina M. Andrews. Step-father of Marta deLoizaga, Adela Carney, and Mario Spangenberg. Brother of Maribel Desserres. Grandfather of two. Funeral services and interment are private. In lieu of flowers, memorials may be made to Hospice Care, Inc. 1029 East Main Street, Stamford, CT. 06902.

title: INSIDE METRO
description: COURT REVERSAL -- A New Jersey appeals court threw out some convictions against three men in the sexual assault of a mildly retarded teen-ager. B4.

title: In Pact With Nynex, AT&T Gets Access to Local Market
description: Paving the way for the nation's biggest long-distance telephone company to enter the country's most lucrative local telephone market, the AT&T Corporation reached an agreement with the Nynex Corporation yesterday to connect the two companies' networks in New York State.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SOBEL, HONORABLE NATHAN R.
description: SOBEL-Honorable Nathan R. The Officers, Trustees and members of the Brooklyn Bar Association mourn the passing of the Honorable Nathan R. Sobel, past Surrogate of Kings County and past Trustee of this Association. More than a leader and supporter of the organized bar, Judge Sobel by act and deed epitomized all that is good about the profession of law. His passing leaves a void in our hearts which cannot be filled. Mark A. Longo, President Avery Eli Okin, Exec. Director

title: Deutsche Bank Profit Jumps 28% in Quarter
description: Deutsche Bank A.G. said yesterday that its pretax profits jumped 28 percent in the first quarter, mainly because of an increase in trading revenue and a drop in risk provisions. Deutsche Bank, Germany's largest banking company, said its pretax profits were 1.29 billion marks ($760 million), compared with 1.01 billion marks a year earlier.

title: Fed Inaction Sends Dollar Down but Spurs Stock Rally
description: The Federal Reserve's decision yesterday not to raise short-term interest rates knocked the dollar sharply lower and provided only a little relief for the bond market. But the Fed's inaction spurred the stock market, which continues to show an exuberance that may again worry Fed officials.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHULSON, HYMAN ABRAHAM
description: SCHULSON-Hyman Abraham. On May 19, 1997. Husband of Ruth Hendricks Schulson. Father of David and Sheree Schulson, Henry and Rachel Schulson and Anne and Stephen Young. Grandfather of Loree, Jaimee, Molly, Michael, Leah, Jason and Daniel. Brother of Florence Mayer, Evelyn Garfinkel and the late Sol Schulson. Funeral services at The Riverside, 76 Street and Amsterdam Avenue, Wednesday, May 21, 11:15 A.M.

title: Time to Get Big Sugar Off the Public Dole
description: To the Editor:

title: When H.I.V. Loosens Grip, It's Back to the Job Market
description: A year and a half ago, a 49-year-old man named Robert was planning his funeral instead of his future. His skin had become infected with festering pimples that refused to heal. His weight had dropped precipitously. He found it physically draining to visit old friends who were also dying of AIDS, fading like wilted flowers. He thought of death constantly.

title: U.S. Reports High Vacancy Rate In Housing in Israeli Settlements
description: American diplomats here have concluded that a quarter of the homes in Jewish settlements in the West Bank and half of those in the Gaza Strip are empty, raising questions about the Israeli Government's contention that it is expanding the settlements to accommodate natural growth.

title: Jury Clears Detective in the Shooting of Cook
description: A Queens grand jury decided yesterday not to file charges against a New York City police detective who shot and killed a cook during a raid in a Corona restaurant in February.

title: Sear Thy Steak, Not Thy Neighbor
description: HOLD it, all you on the verge of Memorial Day madness: don't even think about grilling there. Not, that is, if your New York City terrace, garden, yard, deck or rooftop grilling spot is within 10 feet of any combustible surface, material or building.

title: U.S. COURT ORDERS JUDGES TO STEP IN WHEN JURORS BALK
description: Stepping into a legal debate with racial and political overtones, a Federal appeals court in Manhattan declared yesterday that judges have a duty to make sure jurors do not ignore the evidence or law in a case and instead impose their own values to acquit or convict a defendant.

title: Exercise May Not Curb Depression
description: ALTHOUGH exercise is widely promoted as good for both body and mind, a new report casts doubt on one benefit that has been claimed for it. In a long-term study done by researchers at Johns Hopkins University, working up a sweat a few times a week did not prevent depression, a result that has surprised and puzzled some other scientists.

title: Toy Biz Ends Deal to Join With Marvel
description: Toy Biz Inc. said yesterday that it had canceled its agreement to combine with some units of Marvel Entertainment Group Inc. as part of Marvel's bankruptcy reorganization plan.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STEIN, FLORENCE G.
description: STEIN-Florence G. on May 20, 1997, of Long Beach, LI. Beloved wife of the late Emanuel, devoted mother of Barbara and the late Robert Rowan, Kenneth and Andrea Stein. Dear sister of Jessica Sagor. Adored grandmother of Marc, Andrea, David, Deborah and the late Richard. Cherished great grandmother of Joshua and Zachary. Services Wednesday, 11:00 AM at Gutterman's, 175 Long Beach Road, Rockville Centre, LI.

title: Real Charcoal Into the Pit
description: DESPITE the rising popularity of gas grills, for true grillers, there is no substitute for a charcoal fire. But to most Americans, ''charcoal'' has always meant those pillow-shaped briquettes that appear in every hardware store and supermarket at this time of year. For live-fire cooking, lump hardwood charcoal is re-emerging as an alternative, after being eclipsed by briquettes for decades.

title: 5 Hurt in Toll Plaza Crash
description: Three Irvington students, a school aide and their driver suffered minor injuries yesterday after their mini-van smashed into a toll plaza on the Garden State Parkway and flipped on its side, the authorities said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHORR, RABBI SEYMOUR
description: SCHORR-Rabbi Seymour, on May 17, 1997 (Shabbos). Precious darling husband of Audrey for 41 years. Most beloved father of Nanette and Ira, son-in-law Peter, daughter-in-law Bonnie, and sister Ruth Heller. He loved Hashem as no other has loved Hashem and, following his ordination from Rabbeinu Yitzchak Elchanan Theological Seminary (RIETS) of Yeshiva University where he received Smicha, he devoted more than two decades as a pulpit Rabbi where he served with distinction. He was lauded for his brilliant oratory, selfless dedication to the spiritual welfare of his congregants, his devotion to the Jewish community as well as the overall community having been Vice President of the Council of Social Agencies in one of the communities where he served. He was a was a member of the Executive Board of the ZOA during its early years having been an ardent Zionist during his youth even before the foundation of the State of Israel. Endowed with a broad intellectual curiosity, he was an accomplished Talmudic scholar, a superlative Hebrew grammarian having been instructed in his youth by the renowned Philip Birnbaum; he and Audrey were Patrons of the Metropolitan Opera for many years; he was a skilled chess player, a lover of English Literature, and a master of the English language. After retirement from the pulpit, he embarked on a successful entrepreneurial career becoming the owner of a retirement home for the elderly. He was adored by the residents for his intense, unique compassion and sense of humor, and they and the staff are devastated by his loss. He will be remembered with undying love by his heartbroken family, friends, and co-religionists at the Young Israel of North Woodmere and Young Israel of Woodmere. Please direct donations to the American Cancer Society.

title: U.S. Petroleum Data
description: In millions of barrels except refinery utilization

title: How a Body Shows a Soul
description: ''Cinderella'' once again cast a spell on Monday night when Ben Stevenson's version of the fairy tale was presented for the first time this season by American Ballet Theater at the Metropolitan Opera House.

title: Nathan R. Sobel, 91, Judge And an Adviser to Politicians
description: Nathan R. Sobel, a beloved Brooklyn lawyer, judge and adviser to several state political leaders whose career spanned seven decades, died yesterday at New York Hospital-Cornell Medical Center. He was 91.

title: Dell Computer Quarterly Profit Up 141%
description: The Dell Computer Corporation reported fiscal first-quarter earnings yesterday that exceeded analysts' estimates, as its sales growth outpaced that of other personal computer makers. Dell also announced a 2-for-1 stock split, its fourth in the last five years.

title: Kia Motors Plant in Brazil
description: Kia Motors do Brasil, a subsidiary of the Kia Motors Corporation of South Korea, said today that it would build a $50 million plant to build Bongo brand light trucks in Brazil. The factory is expected to begin operations in July 1999, with estimated initial capacity of 6,000 units a year.

title: CHRONICLE
description: JOHN CARDINAL O'CONNOR is going to New York University Medical Center this morning to bestow a blessing on a new piece of equipment known as a gamma knife.

title: Air Force to Postpone Its Court-Martial of Female Pilot
description: The Air Force announced today that it would delay the court-martial of its first female B-52 pilot for adultery, lying and other charges until Air Force Secretary Sheila Widnall could consider her request for an honorable discharge.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BAUM, ALLYN Z.
description: BAUM-Allyn Z., died Saturday May 17, of cancer. He is survived by a family of close friends including Anne Trevor Brown. A memorial service will be held on Tuesday, June 3rd at the All Souls Unitarian Church, 80th Street and Lexington Avenue at 3 P.M. In lieu of flowers, contributions to that church in his memory would be greatly appreciated.

title: Correction
description: An article on Friday about a speech by the Chinese official chosen to lead Hong Kong after the colony reverts to Beijing's control in July referred incorrectly to the group to which he was speaking. The Asia Society, a nonprofit organization with headquarters in New York, is chartered by the state Board of Regents as an educational institution; it is not a lobby group.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RIFKIN, DR. HAROLD
description: RIFKIN-Dr. Harold. After a long illness. Adored husband to Bibi. Beloved father to Janet, Matthew, and Phyllis. Devoted grandfather to six wonderful grandsons. Funeral private. Memorial service to be announced at a later date.

title: Officer Wounds a Driver
description: A plainclothes Newark police officer shot and critically wounded a man who was trying to flee from an arrest yesterday, the police said. Officer Alex Rodriguez had stopped the car on the suspicion that there were drugs inside and ordered the driver, Kevin Seaman, to get out, Sgt. Derek Glenn, a police spokesman, said.

title: CNN Offers Brokaw a Job
description: The Cable News Network has offered Tom Brokaw a multi-year contract worth more than $7 million annually to leave NBC News and become the network's on-air leader, two executives familiar with the negotiations said yesterday.

title: SHARES OF E.D.S. FALL ON LOWER PROFIT PREDICTION
description: The stock of the Electronic Data Systems Corporation fell yesterday after the concern, a computer services company, said it expected second-quarter earnings to fall below analysts' estimates as it wrestles with slowing revenue growth and higher costs. The shares fell $1.25, to $36.75, in trading of 6.5 million shares. On Monday, E.D.S. officials told more than 200 analysts at a meeting at its Plano, Tex., headquarters that the company expected earnings to be 43 cents to 45 cents a share before charges, down from 51 cents in the second quarter of last year. E.D.S. was expected to earn 50 cents a share, based on the average estimate of 18 analysts surveyed by I.B.E.S. International. The decline would follow disappointing first-quarter earnings.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEFKOWITZ, LOUIS L.
description: LEFKOWITZ-Louis L. The Board of Trustees, the Medical Staff and the Auxiliaries of Long Beach Medical Center record with profound sorrow the passing of our esteemed colleague and Past President, Louis L. Lefkowitz. For forty-five years he served our medical center with honor and distinction. He was a visionary who helped shape the growth of our institution and worked constantly to insure its future. He will be sorely missed. We extend our heartfelt sympathies to his beloved wife, Rebecca, his children, grandchildren and great grandchildren. Alfred I. Osterland, Chairman, Board of Trustees Martin F. Nester, Jr., Chief Executive Officer Mordecai Bluth, MD, Chairman Medical Staff Gloria Nicolosi, President, Auxiliaries

title: The Bulls Wake Up To Beat Heat
description: There was no rivalry to stoke their intensity. No Jeff Van Gundy to prod Michael Jordan. No Knick cockiness to tweak them.

title: ACORDIA AND ANTHEM IN TALKS OVER REVAMPING
description: Acordia Inc. said yesterday that it was in talks with the Anthem Insurance Companies about a reorganization of Acordia's health business, which might include Anthem's acquiring the 33 percent of Acordia it does not already own. And Anthem said it was in discussions with a third party about a possible sale of Acordia's brokerage business. The companies did not elaborate. Acordia, a holding company, said in February that it was reviewing its strategic opportunities, including its relationship with closely held Anthem, a health care management company. Both companies are based in Indianapolis. Shares of Acordia rose $1.25 yesterday, to $35.875.

title: Albany Rally Raises a Cry For Old Rents, New Governor
description: Thousands of tenants, wearing pink and white hats and threatening election day retribution for Gov. George E. Pataki, descended on the state Capitol today for an exuberant, placard-waving rally in support of extending the state's rent regulations.

title: A Lurking Album Is Freed
description: Borrowing a metaphor from Ernest Hemingway, John Fogerty, the 51-year-old former leader of Creedence Clearwater Revival, compared himself to a butterfly in a recent interview. But a butterfly so enamored of the beauty of his wings that he just stays still and admires them. Soon, dust and grime collect on the wings, and before long the butterfly can't fly anymore, he said.

title: An Iconoclast Accepts His Disciples' Devotions
description: Merce Cunningham as dancer, choreographer and iconoclast (although not necessarily in that order) was honored by an opera house full of friends on Monday night at the Brooklyn Academy of Music. Like many a Cunningham dance, the evening was playful and serious.

title: The London-Paris train under the channel adds a premium service with its own special cars.
description: EUROSTAR, the train that connects London and Paris via the Channel Tunnel, recently began premium service for business travelers in first and second class. The service is available in separate 25-seat cars reserved solely for premium passengers; smoking is prohibited.

title: U.N. Envoys Feeling New Yorkers' Anger Rising
description: With a truce in place but still no final agreement on how to end the parking-ticket battle between New York City and its foreign diplomatic missions, Bill Richardson, the chief United States representative at the United Nations, said today that hostility toward envoys was rising sharply.

title: Senate Panel Approves Bill On Sales Tax In One County
description: The Republicans who control the New York State Senate lent their support yesterday to a bill that would allow an upstate county to eliminate its sales tax on clothing, even as they are resisting a similar proposal from Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani.

title: Colleges Ending Investments in Tobacco Stocks
description: Harking back to the late 1980's when many colleges and universities divested themselves of the stocks of companies that did business with South Africa, some educational institutions are applying the same pressure tactic to the tobacco industry.

title: Personal Health
description: A FEW years ago, a young Las Vegas family was shattered by a 3-year-old girl who found her father's loaded revolver in a desk drawer. Thinking the gun was a toy, she aimed it at her pregnant mother, who was asleep on the sofa, and pulled the trigger. The mother died on her way to the hospital.

title: CHRONICLE
description: MERRILL ASHLEY, a principal dancer with the New York City Ballet, is celebrating a professional milestone unusual in the youth-oriented world of dance: her 30th anniversary with the company.

title: Otis Smith, Ex-Jet, Is Rescued Again by Parcells
description: Eight months after he was dropped from the woebegone Jets, Otis Smith returned today. But now he rejoins the coach who took him from despair to the Super Bowl.

title: Pirro to Seek Second Term As Westchester Prosecutor
description: Saying that Westchester County has become a safer place during her four years in office, Jeanine F. Pirro announced today that she would seek a second term as District Attorney.

title: Suicide Watch for Broker Held in Killing of Officer
description: The stockbroker accused of killing a police officer after trying to rob his own father's Chelsea penthouse on Monday was placed on a suicide watch in jail yesterday while investigators explored the theory that the man had feared that his estranged father would remarry and cut off his inheritance.

title: Athenian Democracy Bore Bitter Fruit
description: To the Editor:

title: CUNY Calls Class of 2000 Best Prepared Since 1970
description: The class of 2000, which entered the City University of New York last fall, is the best-prepared class since the system instituted its open-admissions policy, thanks to a four-year-old initiative to encourage New York City high school students to take more academically challenging courses, a CUNY report showed.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ARTUS, WALTER W.
description: ARTUS-Walter W. Philosophy Professor at Saint John's University. Passed away May 19, 1997. Husband of Therese, father of Monique, Michael and Annette. For information Frederick Services Inc, 718-357-6100. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to St. John the Baptist Rectory Bread for Life Soup Kitchen, 75 Lewis Ave, Brooklyn, New York 11206.

title: A Bit Off Key and Proud of It
description: To concertgoers with no musical training, the concept of microtonal music must seem forbiddingly complex. But the sound of it is familiar to anyone who has heard a jazz singer bend a tune with ''blue notes'' or an Indian sitarist play a raga.

title: Fossil Find Hints at Origin of Flight
description: Although most paleontologists agree that birds are descendants of dinosaurs, they have yet to figure out how and why the early birds managed to get off the ground and fly. How, in particular, did the wings of birds evolve from the forelimbs of dinosaurs?

title: West Publishing Loses a Decision On Copyright
description: In a decision that experts said would drive down the price of legal research, a Federal judge has stripped away much of the copyright protection claimed by West Publishing, the nation's dominant publisher of court cases, for its law books.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHULL, MARILYN SEVEN
description: SHULL - Marilyn Seven. We mourn the loss of the wife of our dear fellow member, Richard B. Shull. She was lovely and a true woman of the theater. Our heartfelt sympathy to Dick. The Players

title: Pettitte Is a Victim Of Porous Defense
description: When the American League's Cy Young Award winner and the runner-up for the prestigious honor oppose each other, you expect zeros to fill the scoreboard, you expect a paucity of hits and you expect to be impressed by the pitching prowess.

title: A Slowdown In the Works Whatever The Fed Does
description: Whatever the Federal Reserve does over the next few months, the American economy appears to be heading, on its own, into a period of slower economic growth.

title: REYNOLDS & REYNOLDS PLANS TO ADD CRAIN-DRUMMOND
description: The Reynolds & Reynolds Company, based in Dayton, Ohio, said yesterday that it had agreed to buy Crain-Drummond Inc. for $44.3 million in cash. Crain-Drummond, based in Boucherville, Quebec, provides business-document outsourcing services. It is a unit of Uarco Inc., which is a subsidiary of the Settsu Corporation of Japan. Reynolds & Reynolds is an information-management services company.

title: A Presidential Cold War Begins to Thaw
description: The parley had the markings of high-stakes diplomacy. A top State Department official led a delegation of Administration experts earlier this year to another capital for a day of talks with a renowned but ruffled leader, part of a quiet, months-long effort by President Clinton to restore ties that were badly strained in his first term.

title: Defend Hillary's Rights
description: Before rising to the defense of Hillary Clinton, let me do some scandal housekeeping.

title: To Cook Out, Take All but the Kitchen Sink
description: THE act of outdoor grilling is simple, but the equipment and fuel are becoming increasingly complex.

title: T.W.A. Crash Prompts a Recommendation for Safer Fuel Tanks
description: Updating its list of ''most wanted safety improvements,'' the National Transportation Safety Board today added a recommendation that grew out of the crash of T.W.A. Flight 800, a change meant to insure that the atmosphere in half-empty fuel tanks will not sustain a fire or explosion.

title: Jordache Names Lotas Minard
description: Jordache Enterprises Inc. in New York said yesterday that it had selected Lotas Minard Patton McIver in New York to handle television advertising for the apparel brand, which had been handled in-house and fielded out on a project basis. Billings were estimated at $5 million.

title: Woman Is Stabbed and Raped in Apartment
description: A 26-year-old woman was stabbed and raped early yesterday by a man who broke into a secured West Village building and forced his way into her apartment, the police said.

title: Federal Reserve Allowing Rates To Hold Steady
description: The Federal Reserve voted today to leave interest rates unchanged, betting that the economy was slowing sufficiently to avert a resurgence of inflation.

title: The Last Flight Out, Goofy Yet Gossamer
description: They also serve who fall an inch or two short of being a blockbuster. NBC's ''Wings'' had its premiere on April 19, 1990, snuggled in the comfy slot after ''Cheers.'' Tonight's special hourlong episode, No. 172, is its last. Unlike, say, ''All in the Family'' or ''Seinfeld,'' the series broke no new content barriers. It just managed to be appealing and charming in a deceptively easy sort of way. The basic form is old-fashioned romantic comedy, goofy and farcical at times but with an underlying warmth.

title: No Headline
description: ''Over the years I've negotiated with the toughest characters abroad - Saddam Hussein in Iraq, North Korea, Cuba on political prisoners, Mobutu recently. But I want to tell you, the toughest guy I've ever had to negotiate with is Rudy Giuliani.''

title: INSIDE
description: Top Democrat Breaks Ranks

title: Convictions Reversed in Assault on Retarded Woman
description: A New Jersey appellate court threw out a conviction yesterday against three former high school football stars from Glen Ridge, N.J., for sexually assaulting a mildly retarded teen-ager in the basement of a family home, ruling that the young men had not forced or coerced her because, it said, she gave her consent.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STOLLER, BETTY
description: STOLLER-Betty. The Officer's, Board of Governors, Members and employess of Metropolis Country Club mourn the passing of Betty Stoller, the wife of our good friend Leslie Stoller. Murray B. Hirsch, President Howard Ecker, Secretary

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WALLIS, WILLIAM J.
description: WALLIS-William J., of Rockville Centre, L.I., on May 20, 1997 at age 80. Beloved husband of Helen M. Brother of Leslye Perry and esteemed uncle of eleven nieces and nephews. He retired as Vice President and Secretary of the Executive Committee of Macy's. An honor graduate in 1938 of Emory and Henry College, Bill was awarded an Honorary Doctor of Laws by his Alma Mater in 1971 recognizing his many services to the college, Charitable and Business Organizations. He was a Past Master and Trustee of LynbrookMassapequa Masonic Lodge, Past President of the Metropolitan Financial Executives Assoc; Director of the Controller's Congress of the National Retail Merchant's Assoc; Ruling Elder, Clerk of the Session and Treasurer of the United Church of Rockville Centre; Secretary, Treasurer and Chairman of the Finance Committee of the Wayside Home school for Girls (Salvation Army); Trustee of the Presbytery of Long Island; and member of several other charitable and business organizations. Friends may call at the Fairchild Sons Funeral Home, 20 Lincoln Ave, Rockville Centre, Thursday, 2-4 & 7-9PM. Masonic and religious services at 8 and 8:30 PM at the funeral home. Interment Friday, 11 AM, Pinelawn Memorial Park.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WERLE, FRED
description: WERLE-Fred, of Southbury, CT., on May 15, 1997. Noted Composer and retired Dean of the Mannes College of Music in NYC. Burial was held in Paramus, New Jersey.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PETIGROW, DR. NORMAN
description: PETIGROW-Dr. Norman. On May 19th. Beloved husband of Connie; loving father of Debbi, Gary, Laura and Linda; dear brother of Sylvia, Charles and the late Marvin; cherished stepfather of Ken and Fred; adored grandfather of four. Services today 11 A.M. at ''Gutterman's'', 8000 Jericho Tpke, Woodbury, L.I. Donations to Lymphoma Research Foundation of America.

title: Defense Depleted, So Leetch Plays Hurt
description: While the Rangers wondered how effective Brian Leetch would be for last night's playoff game against the Philadelphia Flyers at Madison Square Garden, they received bad news after yesterday's morning skate. Defenseman Aleksandr Karpovtsev's mother had died during a visit to Ukraine.

title: Wine Talk
description: SENATOR JOSEPH R. McCARTHY was not known as a connoisseur. But from time to time he would, said one of his chroniclers, employ a phrase worthy of inclusion in any anthology of culinary bons mots. Asked how he liked his steak, Tailgunner Joe would reply, ''Charred -- like the soul of an unbeliever.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FIDELMAN, FIMA
description: FIDELMAN-Fima, 91. Concert violinist. The last of a family of illustrious musicians who emigrated to the United States from Tiflis, Georgia in the early part of the century. Student of the eminent pedagogue Leopold Auer. Graduated with honors from the Juilliard School. First violinist WQXR. Concertmaster of the Columbia Broadcasting Symphony. Manager and Concertmaster of the St. James Theatre Orchestra. Noted for his sweet, elegant violin playing. Beloved friend and teacher. Warm, compassionate, gentle human being. His friendship will be greatly missed. Guy and Larry Parker

title: J. Walter Thompson's chief vows 'a massive transformation.'
description: IN Hollywood, Ralph Fiennes became the English patient. On Madison Avenue, Chris Jones is becoming known as the impatient Englishman.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FOLDES, FRANCIS F., M.D.
description: FOLDES-Francis F., M.D. The Chairman, faculty and members of the entire Dept. of Anesthesiology are very deeply saddened by the death of Francis F. Foldes, M.D., Chairman Emeritus of Montefiore's Dept. of Anesthesiology. Dr. Foldes, Montefiore's first Chairman of Anesthesiology was a dedicated physician and scientist and admired colleague and a respected mentor to generations of students. He was also a close friend to many members of the department. His research, including pioneering work in muscle relaxants, had an enormous impact on the practice of anesthesiology and surgery. Dr. Foldes was awarded many honors including the Distinquished Service Award and the Award for Excellence from the American Society of Anesthesiology. He was the first American to serve as President of the World Federation of Societies of Anesthesiologists and was Chairman of the Medical Advisory Board of the Myasthenia Gravis Foundation. Born and educated in Budapest, Dr. Foldes and his wife, Edith, emigrated to the United States in 1941. He authored numerous clinical articles and co-authored four books. In 1997, Montefiore Medical Center established a Francis F. Foldes, M.D. Chair of Anesthesiology in his honor. Our deepest condolences are extended to his wife, Edith; his children Eva Travers, Barbara Wolkowitz and Judy Dickson; his grandchildren and entire family. Albert J. Saubermann, M.D. Francis F. Foldes, M.D. Professor of Anesthesiology and Chairman, Dept. of Anesthesiology Faculty and Staff, Department of Anesthesiology Montefiore Medical Center Jacobi Medical Center North Central Bronx Hospital

title: Russian Boxer Looks Ahead
description: Kostya Tszyu, the International Boxing Federation junior-welterweight champion, wants what Oscar De La Hoya has: the World Boxing Council welterweight title.

title: Profits for these insiders may really be too good to be true.
description: INSIDERS at Xircom Inc., a technology company whose stock soared then fell sharply earlier this year, showed brilliant timing in selling high then buying low. The problem is they may be forced to give up some or all of their profits.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HUROWITZ, JACOB, M.D.
description: HUROWITZ-Jacob, M.D. Beloved husband of the late Helen. Devoted father of Stephen, Donald and Laura. Proud grandfather of Peter, Aaron, Kate, Danny, Noah and Mike Hurowitz, Alex, Eric and Rachel Sherman. Brother of Murray and Irving Harrow. He lived and died in peace and with dignity. Graveside service Wednesday, 11:30 AM, at Mt. Ararat Cemetery.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HUTNER, LILY
description: HUTNER-Lily, age 94, on May 16, 1997, in Rockville, MD, formerly of NY. Adored wife of the late Dr. Louis Hutner, mother of Dr. Michael Hutner and Ora Hutner Koch. Grandmother of Lisa J. Koch and Rhea Koch-Sultan.

title: Chrysler's Chief Sees Lower Sales
description: The chairman and chief executive of the Chrysler Corporation, Robert J. Eaton, said today that he expected a double-digit percentage decline in his company's May sales and lowered his forecast for the industry's United States sales this year.

title: B C SUGAR BACKS COMPETING OFFER FROM GREAT PACIFIC
description: B C Sugar Refinery Ltd. said yesterday that it had received an offer to be acquired by Canada's Great Pacific Capital Corporation for $115 million (Canadian), or $83.8 million (United States). B C Sugar, a refiner and packager based in Vancouver, British Columbia, said it would urge shareholders to support the offer, despite a higher, unsolicited bid by Balaclava Enterprises Inc. of Vancouver. The Great Pacific offer is worth $14.75 (Canadian), or $10.75 (United States), a share. Balaclava has offered $15 (Canadian) a share for as many as 7.85 million shares, or 50.1 percent. Great Pacific's offer, which expires June 5, is conditional on 50.1 percent of the shares of B C Sugar being tendered. Great Pacific already holds a 28.41 percent stake.

title: Of a Student Who Knows The Score, After All
description: The Valley Girl school of speech has become so pervasive among young women and the actresses playing them that it's most rewarding to hear one called upon to explain it in Donald Margulies's new drama, ''Collected Stories,'' which opened last night at the Manhattan Theater Club.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Demoting Mayonnaise in a Dressing
description: Just in time for warmer weather comes a fabulous chicken salad recipe from Myra Chanin, who included it in her very funny book about her mother, ''Mother Wonderful's Chicken Soup'' (Dell, $9.95). Ms. Chanin wrote: ''You can experiment with the vegetables, but not with the dressing.'' I could not take her advice; her recipe would not qualify as low-fat because it calls for one cup of mayonnaise for three servings. But I don't think she will object to this. Sylvia Daskill, whose nickname was Tsuni, was Ms. Chanin's mother.

title: Fun Is Served At Outsider Museum
description: Visitors to the restaurant on the third floor of the new American Visionary Art Museum in Baltimore, the national museum for outsider art, receive a sticker that says, appropriately enough, ''Joy.'' Sitting on the patio of the Joy America Cafe, eye level with the myriad moving parts of Vollis Simpson's 55-foot whirligig outside, you will know why.

title: McGreevey Attacks Rivals
description: State Senator James E. McGreevey went on the attack yesterday against his two opponents in the Democratic primary, releasing television and radio advertisements calling Michael Murphy a ''tax cheat'' and portraying United States Representative Robert E. Andrews as a clone of House Speaker Newt Gingrich.

title: Travel Reservations Companies Planning a $700 Million Merger
description: In a move that will simplify the operating structure of its computer travel reservations system, Galileo International said yesterday that it planned to buy Apollo Travel Services for $700 million.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BARON, SAMUEL
description: BARON-Samuel. The Aaron Copland School of Music at Queens College mourns the untimely passing of our esteemed and dearly loved colleague Samuel Baron. He was truly irreplaceable as an artist, teacher and person. As founding member of the New York Woodwind Quintet he was responsible more than anyone else for the astounding growth that wind chamber music has had during the second half of the 20th century. He will be dearly missed. Our heartfelt condolences are extended to the members of his family. Allen Lee Sessoms, President Raymond Erickson, Dean Hubert Howe, Jr, Director

title: Profit Surge In Quarter For Honda
description: The Honda Motor Company said today that its profits more than doubled in the latest quarter, capping a record year as the auto maker reaped the rewards from a broad revamping of its product line.

title: Bozell Acquires Health Agency
description: Bozell, Jacobs, Kenyon & Eckhardt, which owns agencies including Bozell Worldwide, said yesterday that it had acquired Mediphacs Inc. in Somerset, N.J., an agency specializing in health care education services. Terms were not disclosed.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KATZENSTEIN, MARGARET ROTHSCHILD
description: KATZENSTEIN-Margaret Rothschild. Slept away in her 101st year on May 16, 1997. She was a remarkable person and was a beloved mother of Lee Louis of Hastings On Hudson, NY, Alex Katzenstein of Greensboro, N.C., Charles J. Katzenstein, Jr. of Gastonia, N.C. Her loving grandchildren are: Sandra Pomeroy, Diane Louis McClintock, David M. Louis, Lisa and Ruth Katzenstein, Steven Katzenstein, Jake Rothschild and Judith K. Berlin. She had two great grandchildren and four great, great grandchildren. A Memorial Service was held on May 18th. Gifts in her memory may be sent to the Society for Ethical Culture, 4450 Fieldston Road, Bronx, N.Y. 10471 or The Riverdale Mental Health Association, 5676 Riverdale Avenue, Bronx, New York 10471.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FOONER, MICHAEL
description: FOONER-Michael. Beloved father of Andrea Fooner Figueroa and Laura Wexler-Glass. Cherished grandfather of Sara, Elena, Ariel Antonio Figueroa, Stephanie, Helen, Eleanor, Louise and Benjamin Ian. Fond father-in-law of Antonio Figueroa and David Neville Glass. Service Thursday, Plaza Memorial Chapel, 91st & Amsterdam Ave. For time call: 212-769-4400.

title: 1999's All-Star City
description: The National Basketball Association awarded the 1999 All-Star Game to Philadelphia, the 76ers said. The team has called a news conference for tomorrow to make the announcement.The N.B.A. commissioner, DAVID STERN, is expected to attend the announcement, the 76ers said.

title: A Second Recount Is Ordered
description: The May 13 mayoral election in the state's second-largest city remains a cliffhanger. A Superior Court judge ordered a second recount yesterday in 14 of Jersey City's 179 election districts and scheduled a May 28 hearing on issues raised by Jerramiah T. Healy, the Democrat who finished second to Mayor Bret D. Schundler.

title: The Greenspan Dividend
description: Wall Street is supposed to react with horror when the Federal Reserve Board cowers from raising interest rates in the face of a raging economy. But yesterday, when the Fed announced it would keep interest rates steady, stocks soared and interest rates fell, a tribute to the market's faith in Chairman Alan Greenspan. Under Mr. Greenspan, the Fed has presided over nearly uninterrupted growth with steadily falling inflation. His record now gives him the leeway to sit back and let the economy grow without having to prove his anti-inflationary credentials by prematurely jacking up rates and slowing the economy down.

title: Offices of Bank Raided in Nomura Scandal
description: Prosecutors raided offices of the Dai-Ichi Kangyo Bank today as the investigation into the scandal at the Nomura Securities Company widened.

title: Contra-Cocaine Story Was Flawed From Start
description: To the Editor:

title: In One Town, No-Smoking Area May Be the Beach
description: Smokers in this Putnam County town of 30,000 may soon be adding the beach to the list of places where they cannot light up.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: Basketball

title: White House To Surrender Documents
description: Under the threat of a contempt of Congress citation, the White House agreed today to turn over to a House committee thousands of pages of files on central figures in the campaign finance investigations.

title: Radio Stations Are Sold
description: The Evergreen Media Corporation said today that it had agreed to sell three radio stations to Douglas Broadcasting/Personal Achievement Radio for $18 million. Evergreen, based in Irving, Tex., is selling WZHF-AM and WBZS-AM in Washington and KDFC-AM in San Francisco. The sale is part of Evergreen's divestiture of eight stations, a move required for its planned acquisition of the Chancellor Broadcasting Corporation and 10 radio stations from Viacom Inc.

title: Breakfast Junk Food
description: To the Editor:

title: Using Glue Instead of Stitches
description: THROUGH the ages, a wide range of materials have been used to close deep cuts and other wounds, including cobwebs, the jaws of leaf-cutting insects and, in modern medicine, stitches and staples. But now another material is showing promise: glue.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JACOBS, FRED M.
description: JACOBS-Fred M., on May 18th, after a long illness. Loving and beloved husband of Judy; devoted father of Andrew, John, Marcie, Jeffrey and Susan; cherished grandfather of Rachel, Daniel and Michael; caring brother of Richard and loved by all. Service Tuesday, 3 PM, at ''The Riverside,'' 76th St. and Amsterdam Avenue. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made in his memory to the Jacob Perlow Hospice at Beth Israel Hospital

title: Judging Beef By Its Grade, Cut and Eating Habits
description: STEAK on the grill turns a meal into a feast, the way Memorial Day turns a May weekend into summer.

title: PLAN TO PAY OFF U.N. DUES STALLS
description: The Clinton Administration's proposal to pay $1 billion in dues owed to the United Nations has run aground in Congress. Republicans are insisting on paying only some of the debt, over a longer stretch of time and only after the United Nations agrees to a series of demands.

title: Jordan Is Still Riley's One-Man Nightmare
description: One obstacle has followed Pat Riley from New York to Miami. That obstacle is named Michael Jordan. And until Riley tastes victory over Jordan in a playoff series, the Miami Heat coach will see one of his major goals left unfulfilled.

title: Trent Lott's Military Mind
description: ''The whole case is unusual,'' Frank Spinner, the attorney for Lieut. Kelly Flinn, observed yesterday. At about the same time, Senator Trent Lott weighed in with an endorsement of Lieutenant Flinn's request for an honorable discharge in exchange for her resignation from an Air Force that is prosecuting her for adultery. No one can doubt Senator Lott's respect for authority. So by siding with the defendant, he illustrates the strength of the political consensus supporting amnesty for her.

title: Ex-Stuyvesant High Site Is Designated a Landmark
description: The New York City Landmarks Preservation Commission yesterday designated as a landmark the former home of Stuyvesant High School, at 345 East 15th Street near Second Avenue.

title: Unorthodox Doctor Goes on Trial Again on Contempt Charge
description: A jury here heard opening arguments this morning in the retrial of a criminal contempt charge against a doctor who offers an unapproved cancer drug.

title: REPUBLIC INDUSTRIES AGREES TO BUY 4 CAR DEALERSHIPS
description: Republic Industries said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire four car dealerships for a total of $70 million in stock. Republic said it was buying the Desert Buick-GMC Automotive Group, which owns three dealerships in Las Vegas, Nev., and the Gene Evans Ford dealership in Union City, Ga. The company said the acquisitions would be its first in the Las Vegas and Atlanta markets. Republic, a diversified holding company based in Fort Lauderdale, Fla., is owned by the billionaire H. Wayne Huizenga.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HECHT, ALBERT
description: HECHT-Albert. On May 19, 1997. Beloved husband of Anna. Dear father and grandfather and fatherin-law. Services at Parkside Funeral Chapel, 98-60 Queens Boulevard at 11:30am on Wednesday, May 21, 1997.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  EVERS, JEAN (NEE) ARMS
description: EVERS-Jean (nee) Arms, age 79, of Southbury, CT., on May 11, 1997. Retired Editor and Writer of Architecture and Interior Design. Loving wife of Carl G. Evers, noted Marine Artist. Services June 8, 1997, 3 P.M., at Munson-Lovetere Funeral Home, 235 Main Street North, Southbury, CT.

title: Child Insurance Bill Opposed As Threat to Cigarette Revenue
description: Republican senators attacked a children's health insurance bill today, saying the higher Federal tax it would place on tobacco would cost the states more than $1 billion in revenues annually by cutting cigarette sales.

title: Fair Pay for Workfare
description: Under the Clinton Administration's recent interpretation of labor law, states will be required to pay people who take part in workfare programs the minimum wage -- $4.75 a hour this year, $5.15 next year.

title: Stoking the Star Maker Machinery
description: IN this balmy hothouse of eccentrics and characters, John Berendt is as prominent as a live oak, a celebrated muse of the South often pointed out by tour guides as they inch by the best-selling author in horse-drawn carriages and air-conditioned minibuses.

title: Franco and the Mets Give Up Ghost in Ninth
description: Blown leads in the ninth inning are inevitable over the course of a full season. But as closer John Franco said with a sigh in his voice, it was too bad that it had to happen to the Mets tonight.

title: N.H.L. EASTERN CONFERENCE FINALS: GAME 3
description: In a wide-open game in which the Rangers twice tied the score only to fall behind again moments later, Philadelphia got three goals from Eric Lingros to take a 2-1 lead in their Eastern Conference final.

title: When the Music Stops, The Song Is Not Over
description: The Chemical Brothers may be the first English electronic dance-music act to have a Top 20 album on this side of the Atlantic, sending a message to American record companies that all the money they've spent signing techno and electronic dance bands won't go to complete waste. But the truth is that the Chemical Brothers are in a class by themselves.

title: Stockton's Style Wins Games, Not Friends
description: He wore short shorts today, socks tugged up to his calves and low white canvas sneakers. There are places for people like John Stockton -- the 1950's -- but do not let the bowl haircut fool you.

title: Troy Ruttman, 67, Youngest Winner of Indy 500
description: Troy Ruttman, a Southern California hot-rodder who in 1952 became the youngest driver to win the Indianapolis 500, died on Monday in Lake Havasu City, Ariz. He was 67.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CARRIG, RANDY
description: CARRIG-Randy, 42, passed away May 19, 1997, due to complications from AIDS. Survived by his parents Peg & Dave Carrig; brothers Steven, David, and Jim; sisterin-law Barbara; niece Steffanie; and longtime companion Peter Straus. Visitation at Redden's Funeral Home, 325 West 14 Street, N.Y., on Thursday, May 22, from 11 AM-1 PM. A memorial service at The Manhattan Theatre Club is being planned for a date in June. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to the People with AIDS Coalition, New York, or God's Love We Deliver, N.Y.

title: Civil Servants Are Heroes In Film Script
description: MOHAN JETHWANI recently wrote a movie script filled with intrigue, corruption and big money. The backdrop is New York City, and its scenes include the verdant climes of Central Park, the gritty world beneath the asphalt and the bare-knuckle meetings where politics prevails.

title: Even Philanthropists Have Their Limits
description: To the Editor:

title: A Dough Homer Might Sing About
description: AT Molyvos, a new Greek restaurant at 871 Seventh Avenue (55th Street), the chefs are making their own phyllo. Aglaia Kremezi, who lives in Athens and is a cookbook author, has spent the last month or so teaching Rick Moonen, the restaurant's executive chef, and James Botsacos, the chef de cuisine, how to make not only the parchmentlike dough but also some unusual specialties like homemade pasta using sour milk, meatballs with zucchini and bulgur, and a pudding made with grape must.

title: Fed Meeting Gives Bonds A Modest Lift
description: Treasury prices rose modestly yesterday after the Federal Reserve decided to keep interest rates unchanged.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: OLYMPUS REAL ESTATE CORP., Dallas, and Ceebraid-Signal Corp. said they had bought four apartment properties in Florida for a total of more than $34 million.

title: New Store Offers Shopping On Line
description: When people shop on the Internet, they usually do it from the detached comfort of their homes. But starting today, New Yorkers can shop on line by going to a store stocked with computers.

title: E.P.A. Seeks Cut in Paper-Mill Pollution, but Not Elimination
description: After years of study, the Environmental Protection Agency has recommended new rules that will require paper mills to reduce greatly their emissions of dioxins and other toxic chemicals into the water and air, at an estimated cost of $1.4 billion.

title: Eating Well
description: Editor's Note Appended

title: Ballet Troupes Place Their Bets on the Warhorses, New as Well as Old
description: American Ballet Theater will be taking a big gamble when it presents the world premiere of ''Othello,'' the centerpiece of the company's annual season at the Metropolitan Opera House, on Friday. The sumptuous new three-act production was expensive. Not a restaging of a familiar ballet, ''Othello'' is a rarity in that it is an entirely new production with a commissioned score, sets, costumes and choreography.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FLEISIG, ROBIN
description: FLEISIG-Robin. We are deeply saddened to record the sudden and untimely passing of our dear member, Robin Fleisig. We extend our deepest sympathy to her loving husband, Roger Greene, their children, Eric and Perry, and their entire family. Robert N. Levine, Sr. Rabbi Jack B. Levitt, President Congregation Rodeph Sholom

title: Donald Warren, 61, Sociologist Who Studied Alienation in U.S.
description: Donald Irwin Warren, a sociologist who studied and wrote about alienation in America, died last Saturday at his home in Ann Arbor, Mich. He would have been 62 this Saturday.

title: American Topics
description: They're big and getting bigger; they're headed for huge; they're nuns! Americans, it seems, are buying nun puppets, nun greeting cards, even nun snow globes in droves. Squeak Toy Nun, "pious but not uptight," is a favorite; so are the 13 superhero nuns of the Warrior Nun comic book series.

title: Palestinians Detain Reporter Who Is Said to Have Irked Arafat
description: A Palestinian journalist was being held without charges by the Palestinian police in the West Bank city of Ramallah today, evidently because of Yasir Arafat's irritation with his live television broadcasts of meetings of the Palestinian Legislative Council.

title: Military Isn't Accountable for Officer's Conduct
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day on May 14 about the indictment of A. R. Baron & Company and 13 former employees omitted a word in a quotation from the indictment citing the defendants' sale of shares in Health Professionals Inc. The indictment said the defendants had sold the shares without disclosing important information about the company ''including felony convictions of the company and its former chief executive for fraud.''

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: Football

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RUTH, JOAN HIRSCH
description: RUTH-Joan Hirsch. On May 20, 1997. Beloved wife of the late Jacob. Dear aunt of Barbara R. Kurtin and Philip F. Ruth. Loving siser-in-law of Jean and the late Donald. Dear cousin of Jill Roth Ueland. Service Sunday, 12 Noon, at ''The Riverside'', 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article yesterday about efforts to help AIDS patients re-enter the work force referred incorrectly at one point to the founder of Leading for Life, who discussed the absence of AIDS services for many members of minority groups. The speaker was a man, Mario Cooper.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MALLET, BEATRICE
description: MALLET-Beatrice, of Hollywood, Florida. Beloved wife of the late Abraham. Adored mother of Loretta and Sam Bogarsky and Grace and Harvey Bass. Devoted grandmother of Elena and Moshe Kogos, Shari Mirman and Evan Rauch. Cherished great-grandmother of Shmuel, Chanoch, Naami, Sora and Binyamin Kogos. Dear sister of Dr. Nathan Matisoff and Lillian Rubinstein. Services Friday, 9:30AM at ''BoulevardRiverside Chapel,'' 1450 Broadway, Hewlett, New York.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: MARINE DRILLING COS., Sugar Land, Tex., an oil and natural gas drilling contractor, acquired approximately 90 percent of the outstanding shares of Deep Sea ASA of Norway for $49 million.

title: Vanishing Extractors
description: To The Home Section:

title: Burmese Project Tests Unocal Resolve
description: Ever on the hunt for rich discoveries abroad, American oil companies have long had to factor in fears about the unstable nature of foreign governments when considering huge investments in capital and equipment. But now the companies are finding that politics back home is the new focus of risk.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SERIN, STANLEY
description: SERIN-Stanley. Beloved husband of Judith. Father. Brother and Grandfather. Services Thursday 10am. Riverside Nassau North Chapels, 55 North Station Plaza, opposite LIRR.

title: Law Instructor to Challenge Pirro for District Attorney
description: After keeping silent about their plans for the Westchester County District Attorney's race and even suggesting that they might endorse the Republican incumbent, Jeanine F. Pirro, the Democrats have come up with their own candidate. She is Joanne Naughton, a law instructor and retired New York City police lieutenant.

title: N.F.L. Nearing a New Rule To Curb Owners' Lawsuits
description: Tired of being sued by members of its ownership group, the National Football League is expected to soon adopt a rule that makes any owner who sues the league responsible for all legal fees should that owner lose the lawsuit.

title: A Back Door for the Conservative Donor
description: When Floyd Coates, an Indiana businessman and one-time candidate for Congress, decided to make some big campaign donations in the last election, he wanted to be sure that the $100,000 or so he planned to give would end up supporting his brand of conservative, free-market, pro-military, anti-abortion candidates.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEE, BENJAMIN F.
description: LEE-Benjamin F. On May 18, 1997. We mourn the loss of our dear friend and business associate. He epitomized the best of traditions of our people. He was kind and compassionate to all. He was a true ''Mentsch.'' His warmth will always be remembered. We extend our heartfelt condolences to his wife Doris S., his sons Bruce and Lawrence, daughters-in-law and grandchildren. Jack Friedman Ari Friedman

title: Fidelity Selling Life Insurance
description: Moving in a different direction for a mutual fund company, Fidelity Investments has begun selling term life insurance directly to consumers through its unit the Fidelity Investments Life Insurance Company.

title: An American Jekyll And Her Gardens
description: IN 1910, a weekend gardener named Ellen Biddle Shipman, above left, went professional. Trouble was, she had no training, three children to feed and a philistine husband who could ''bludgeon a lily before breakfast and be proud of it all day,'' a friend once said.

title: Great Divide Is Widening On Rent Rules
description: IT'S not easy to find a rhyme for ''Pataki.'' So at the very least you have to give tenants who rallied here on Tuesday credit for trying.

title: Accounts
description: * P.G.& E. Energy Services, San Francisco, a new unit of Pacific Gas and Electric Co., to McCann-Erickson San Francisco, owned by the Interpublic Group of Cos., as the first agency to handle its account. Though billings were not disclosed, Advertising Age estimated that P.G.& E. Energy, a national, unregulated unit of P.G.& E., might initially spend $30 million to $40 million annually. McCann San Francisco handles Northern California consumer advertising for P.G.& E.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RIFKIN, HAROLD, MD.
description: RIFKIN-Harold, MD. We at NYU Medical Center are deeply saddened by the passing of our colleague and dear friend, Dr. Harold Rifkin, Professor of Clinical Medicine. He was a giant among physicians who were the elite of clinical researchers and stood out as a leader in the academic community of scholars and researchers who contributed greatly to the advances of medicine by bringing the results of highly productive and imaginative laboratory results to the bedside. His numerous publications and his classic textbook on diabetes expanded our knowledge of the basic and clinical sciences related to diabetes which improved and prolonged the lives of many diabetics. To his many patients, he was a model personal physician. Dr. Rifkin was always supportive and compassionate to the individual patient as well as to their families. He was highly respected, admired and recognized worldwide by professional organizations as a leading clinician, researcher and teacher. He was the recipient of the most prestigious awards from medical schools and professional organizations and served as President of the American Diabetes Association.
