His students included medical students, residents, fellows and post graduate physicians. All benefited immensely from his teaching and considered him a role model par excellence. We have lost a great physician scientist of the golden era of medicine encompassing fifty years of clinical research. Harold Rifkin was a beloved husband to his loving wife of many years Bibi, and a wonderful father and grandfather. We express our deep sympathy to his spouse Bibi, son Matthew, daughters Janet and Phyllis and to his grandchildren. Laurence A. Tisch, Chairman Board of Trustees New York University L. Jay Oliva, President New York University Thomas S. Murphy, Chairman, Board of Trustees NYU Medical Center Saul J. Farber, MD, MACP Provost and Dean NYU Medical Center

title: Tyco International finds success in an acquisition binge.
description: IN an age when many companies would rather pare down than expand, Tyco International may seem something of an anachronism. But on Wall Street the company's strategy is seen as far from obsolete.

title: Show at the Modern Purges an Architect
description: AS any Kremlinologist of the cold war will recall, when Soviet officials decided that someone had strayed from approved behavior, they simply painted the miscreant out of the photographs. In New York, the Museum of Modern Art practices its own brand of revisionist history. At the recently opened exhibition presenting architectural concepts for the museum's expansion that will engulf the former Dorset Hotel and two adjacent brownstones, the name of Cesar Pelli, the architect of the last ambitious expansion, is prominently missing from a time line displayed at the entrance to the show.

title: President of Wells Fargo To Retire, in Surprise Move
description: William Zuendt, the president of Wells Fargo & Company and the chief architect of its transition into high-technology banking, unexpectedly announced yesterday that he would retire from the San Francisco-based banking company.

title: IN TOBACCO TALKS, LAWYERS HOLD KEY
description: Until two years ago, Maryland's shopping list was like any other state's, with its government seeking bids on data processing, canned fruit and road salt. Then its Attorney General, J. Joseph Curran Jr., went looking for something special: a high-powered product liability lawyer to sue the tobacco industry.

title: Owner-Only Handgun Bill
description: Sarah Brady, whose husband was wounded during an assassination attempt on President Reagan, came to the State House yesterday to promote a bill that would require handguns sold in New Jersey to be personalized so that only their owners could use them.

title: Clinton Calls Fashion Ads' 'Heroin Chic' Deplorable
description: Asserting that ''you do not need to glamorize addiction to sell clothes,'' President Clinton today accused the fashion industry of making heroin seem ''glamorous, sexy and cool'' through advertising that enticed young people to try heroin.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HERRING, JOY
description: HERRING-Joy. Beloved Mummy of Arlene and Regina; loving wife of Sid. Born June 6, 1930 to Nate and Alice Jacobs and raised in Golders Green, London, England. Sadly taken from her loved ones on May 21, 1997. Her warmth, comfort and strength to all those graced by her presence will never be forgotten. Services are today, 1:30 PM at Shermans Chapel, 1283 Coney Island Avenue, Brooklyn.

title: Top F.B.I. Lawyer, Object of Criticism, Quits
description: The top lawyer at the Federal Bureau of Investigation resigned today after a tenure in which he played a role in prominent espionage and criminal cases like the bombing of the Federal Building in Oklahoma City, but was criticized for his contacts with the White House in matters that stemmed from the controversy over F.B.I. background files.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-13

title: Proust's Masterpiece a Self-Help Book? Well, Yes
description: HOW PROUST CAN CHANGE YOUR LIFE

title: BMC, EXERCISING OPTION, PAYS $60 MILLION FOR DATATOOLS
description: BMC Software Inc. said yesterday that it had acquired the privately held Datatools Inc. for $60 million. The Houston-based software developer said it acquired Datatools through the exercise of an option it received two years ago when it became the sole distributor of Datatools' backup and recovery products. Datatools is based in Sunnyvale, Calif. BMC Software said it would continue to sell and support the Datatools products but would also integrate some with BMC software. BMC's stock rose $1.6875, to $46.625, in Nasdaq trading.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BARON, SAMUE
description: BARON-Samue. With warmest memories of Sam Baron, facultyartist of the Yale Summer School of Music/Norfolk Chamber Music Festival. His dedication and artistry leave an indelible mark on our chamber music world.

title: Corrections
description: An education page article yesterday about journalism fellowships omitted a name in some copies from a list of John S. Knight Fellows at Stanford University. The fellowship winner was Harriet Washington, a freelance medical writer from Rochester, who will study medical experimentation on humans.

title: An Icy Nip Of Poland
description: MORE and more bartenders are shaking their drinks -- not martinis but vodka bottles. The cause? Belvedere, an imported Polish vodka, whose nifty package is part neo-classical diorama, part snow globe. Wintry trees printed on the bottle's front frame a liquid-magnified image of the 18th-century Belvedere Palace, home of the President of Poland. As for the snow-globe part, shake the bottle vigorously enough and the palace is engulfed by a brief but satisfying blizzard of bubbles.

title: Mansion Full of Honors in the Arts
description: It is one of the world's most exclusive clubs, a mansion on a hill at the edge of Harlem that almost no one ever visits. But yesterday, the American Academy of Arts and Letters, on West 155th Street between Broadway and Riverside Drive, was jammed with 200 of the country's most prominent writers, artists and composers and their guests, who gathered for the academy's annual ''ceremonial.''

title: Bank Robber Is Being Linked To 14 Holdups
description: A man who warns tellers that he will shoot everyone in the bank if he does not get money has been tied to 13 robberies or attempted robberies in a monthlong spree in the Bronx.

title: Household International To Buy Transamerica Unit
description: Household International Inc. agreed today to buy the Transamerica Corporation's consumer finance business for $1.1 billion in cash, in a move that will almost double Household's branch network.

title: INSIDE
description: New Plan to Revamp Finance

title: Movement As Inspired By Photos
description: The body is glorified, not merely used, in the choreography of Elisa Monte and David Brown, the artistic directors of Elisa Monte Dance. Limbs and torsos exist to be entwined, displayed and channeled into flight. Feet are not for steps but parts of figures stretched cursively into space.

title: CLINTON HELPS KILL PROPOSAL TO RAISE TAX ON CIGARETTES
description: President Clinton today helped kill a proposal for a tobacco tax increase to pay for children's health care, clearing the major obstacle to Senate adoption of a resolution promising to balance the budget by the year 2002.

title: Garden Q.&A.
description: Attracting Fireflies

title: Russia's Premier to Slash Budget, Trimming Military and Subsidies
description: Facing a huge gap in revenue, Russia's reform-minded Government today urged Parliament to slash spending on the military and on state-subsidized industries.

title: A Festival in Quebec Is Cutting-Edge
description: American music fans, performers and critics are often left grasping for meaning when boundaries are stretched beyond the observed traditions of jazz, rock and traditional ethnic music. Descriptions quickly become useless, and lines are passionately defended or disputed. But in this small, French-speaking, blue-collar town two hours northeast of Montreal, best known as a producer of hockey sticks before the factory burned down a few years ago, a comfortable solution has been found.

title: Nazi Gold Belongs Only to Hitler's Victims
description: To the Editor:

title: Calendar: Architecture And Design
description: Art in America

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEISSMAN, IRVING B.
description: WEISSMAN-Irving B. Beloved father of Larry. Cherished grandfather of Aaron and Nick. Loving brother of Florence and Ed Zornberg. Service 10 AM, Friday, Plaza Memorial Chapel, 91 Street and Amsterdam Ave. Contributions may be made to the Sylvia Weissman Greenberg Fund at Beth Israel Hospital, 9 Nathan D. Pearlman Place, New York, NY 10211.

title: From 1 to 9 and A to Z, How the Subways Stack Up
description: A comprehensive review of subway service by the Straphangers Campaign, a subway riders advocacy group, has found that the No. 7 line is the best in the city and the B line the worst.

title: Woman, 34, Is Charged In Beating of Foster Child
description: A Long Island woman was charged yesterday with burning and beating an 8-year-old foster child in her care after an elementary school teacher reported that the child had taken a snack from a classmate.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  VALLONE, PETER
description: VALLONE-Peter. The New York Times records with deep sorrow the passing of Peter Vallone, associated with the Times from 1971, until retiring in 1983.

title: Pity a Tyrannosaur? Sue Had Gout
description: For all the suffering she probably caused her Cretaceous prey, a tyrannosaur named Sue seems to have paid dearly. Scientists have determined that the big dinosaur probably was a victim of agonizing gout and other debilitating ailments.

title: Jazz No-Names Introduce Themselves to Rockets
description: Hall of Famers grow on trees in these Western Conference finals, but neophytes are people, too.

title: Grupo Televisa Takes $80 Million Charge
description: Grupo Televisa S.A. said today that it expected to pay a one-time charge of $80 million in connection with its cost-cutting program.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DOMINICK, ELIZABETH YALLALLE
description: DOMINICK-Elizabeth Yallalle, of New Canaan, CT., and Southern Pines, NC passed away on May 19. Beloved wife of Bayard Dominick. Survived by her children, Mrs. Jonathan O'Brien, Gayer G. Dominick II, Margrett Dominick Grummon, Edward Hoyt Dominick and Wilder Dominick Witt, 12 grandchildren and six great-grandchildren. Graveside services 11AM on Tuesday, May 27 at Lakeview Cemetery in New Canaan, CT. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be sent to Waveny Care Center, New Canaan, CT. 06840.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PEARSALL, FLORA (MAC SWEYN)
description: PEARSALL-Flora (Mac Sweyn), 95, of Kent, CT., on May 18, 1997. Widow of David E. Pearsall. Survived by sister Leora Jester, Des Moines, IA.; sons David E. II, Kent, CT., and Donald M., Port Washington, N.Y.; daughters Martha A., El Sobrante, CA., and Mary P. Stone, San Mateo, CA.; grandchildren Brenda J. Pearsall, Newport Richey, FL., Jennifer L. Pearsall, Framingham, MA., and Charles P. Stone, San Mateo, CA; great grand-daughter Jane B. McQueeny. Graveside services in Brookville, PA., on May 23 at 2PM.

title: Cable and Wireless in a Panamanian Deal
description: Cable and Wireless P.L.C. said today that it would pay $:408 million ($652 million) to buy 49 percent of Intel, the state-owned telecommunications company of Panama, and take management and operational control.

title: He Cast A Silent Shadow
description: IN sports, as in the world, some of the best people are never in the headlines or on the highlights. But even though they work in the shadows, they cast a shadow.

title: Becky Brayton Returns to Indy, Site of Her Husband's Fatal Crash
description: Becky Brayton admits that she has got some odd looks from people -- still does, in fact -- when they realize that she has come back to this sport and this place that took away her husband. But to anyone worried about her being overcome by feelings when she is here at the Indianapolis Motor Speedway, she offers the assurance that the track where Scott Brayton crashed and died last May is not any more rocky ground emotionally than anyplace else.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HALL, JOHN F.
description: HALL-John F., on May 18, 1997. Husband of late June. Father of Michael F., James M. and Charles A. Hall. Reposing at Bennett Funeral Home, 824 Scarsdale Avenue, Scarsdale, NY. Funeral will be held at the Greenville Community Reformed Church on Thursday, 11AM. In lieu of flowers, donations to Greenville Community Church or Alzheimers Association would be appreciated.

title: When Money Counts
description: AS the barbecue season gets under way, one wonders how cave men did without the array of grills and grilling accessories now on the market. How, for example, did they (or cave women, for that matter) get along without a clip-on lamp for a fashionably late dinner of saber-tooth-tiger cutlets, or a screen to hold fresh herbs under pteradactyl drumsticks?

title: Bond Prices Fall on Report Of Trade Gap
description: The prices of Treasury securities dropped sharply yesterday after the Government reported a smaller-than-expected trade deficit for March. The report suggested strong economic growth, which the Federal Reserve might eventually decide to confront by raising interest rates.

title: Furniture Dares To Give No Offense
description: CALL it Banana Republican. Or Calvin Ikea. Generic X or Po Bo (post-Pottery Barn).

title: The Pentagon's War on Thrift
description: The Pentagon's latest strategic review marks the third time in the past six years that the Defense Department has tried to adjust its strategy, its budget and the strength of the armed forces to the post-cold war world. But this review, unveiled this week, is essentially an endorsement of the status quo, just as the two previous efforts were.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DUFFY, REV. GABRIEL F.
description: DUFFY-Rev. Gabriel F., 66, of Washington D.C., formerly of Sparkill, NY, on Tuesday May 20, 1997. Loving brother and brotherin-law of M.F. Therese and Daniel Salvia. Funeral mass Saturday at 10:00 AM at St. Anthony's R.C. Church, Northvale, NJ. Internment Rockland Cemetery, Sparkill, NY. Viewing Friday 7-9 PM at St. Anthony's R.C. Church, Northvale, NJ. For more information contact Pizzi Funeral Home, Northvale, New Jersey, (201-767-3050).

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MAHLKE, PHILIP A.
description: MAHLKE-Philip A., of Bricktown, formerly of Flushing, N.Y. on May 16, 1997. He was employed by N.Y.C. Police Dept for 40 years, Chief Clerk for 5 years before retiring in 1972. Beloved husband of the late Esther. Devoted father of Philip R. and Linda Steel. Brother of Raymond and Elsa Morgan. Loving grandfather of 7. Great grandfather of 7. Funeral services were held at the Silverton Memorial Funeral Home, 2482 Church Road, Toms River, New Jersey.

title: China's Christians and Us
description: To the Editor:

title: Daniel Saidenberg, 90, Cellist, Conductor and Gallery Owner
description: Daniel Saidenberg, a cellist, conductor and art gallery owner who supported an annual series of faculty recitals at the Juilliard School, died on Sunday at his home in Manhattan. He was 90.

title: Export Surge Eases Deficit In U.S. Trade
description: The United States trade deficit narrowed in March as exports surged to a record for the second consecutive month, spurring first-quarter economic growth and suggesting more of the same in coming months.

title: Monopolies Still Rule the Local Phone Markets
description: Sixteen months after the Government opened the $100 billion local phone market to no-holds-barred competition, a new study has found that fewer than half of 1 percent of Americans receive their residential phone service from a competitor to the monopoly provider.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PFEFFER, MARY
description: PFEFFER-Mary. May 20, 1997. Beloved wife of Murray. Dear sister to John and the late Julia Osowick. Devoted aunt of Nancy Osowick. Dear friend to Helen and Selma. Visiting this evening only at Andrett Funeral Home, 353 2nd Ave (at 20th St). Interment Friday at Calverton National Cemetery.

title: Yankees Now Know Rejuvenated Clemens
description: Roger Clemens continued to demonstrate last night that reports of his demise were premature. But where has he been for four years?

title: Despite Series Inexperience, St. John's Has Confidence
description: St. John's finds itself in the same National Collegiate Athletic Association regional tournament as the University of Miami, a perennial baseball power that was a runner-up in last season's College World Series.

title: AETNA TO ACQUIRE FINANCIAL NETWORK INVESTMENT
description: Aetna Inc. said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire the Financial Network Investment Corporation, a closely held company that provides financial planning. Terms were not disclosed, but a report in The Wall Street Journal yesterday estimated the purchase price at about $50 million. Financial Network Investment, which is based in Torrance, Calif., will become an affiliate of Aetna Retirement Services. The deal, the latest sign of life insurers' efforts to expand distribution methods, gives the Hartford-based Aetna an additional 2,400 independent financial planners and 177 branch offices in 35 states.

title: Landlord Blues
description: Like most landlords in New York City, I take pride in my apartment buildings. I do my best to keep up with maintenance. Unfortunately, each year my operating expenses increase more than my income.

title: Suit Over Arena Seats
description: An organization representing disabled veterans has sued the New Jersey Devils and the New Jersey Sports and Exposition Authority, saying people using wheelchairs are denied access to low-priced seats.

title: Not Your Basic Olde Candle Shoppe
description: OFFICIALLY, the mod interior of Covington Candles, an East Side boutique, is a metaphor for the transmission of light. Unofficially, said its designer, Jeffrey Bilhuber, it is a way out of ye-olde-candle-shoppe rut. ''This is glam-o-rama,'' he added, in a mock-groovy, finger-snap croon.

title: A True Champion of Easton
description: To The Home Section:

title: Study Sees Holes in Internet Security Plan
description: A panel of computer scientists said yesterday that the Government's plans for unlocking data-scrambling software to pursue criminals and terrorists on the Internet could actually increase security risks and raise the costs of on-line commerce.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GREENSTEIN, BENJAMIN
description: GREENSTEIN-Benjamin. Beloved husband of Betty. Devoted father of Herbert and Myrna. Loving grandfather of Jonathan and Graham. Passed away May 20, 1997. He will be loved and remembered.

title: CHRONICLE
description: AARON LATHAM, a screenwriter and novelist, bills his new book, ''The Ballad of Gussie and Clyde,'' published Monday by Villard, on the jacket as ''A True Story of True Love.''

title: Standing the Heat, Wanting the Kitchen
description: They were impressive in their posture, impeccable in their toques and chef's jackets. Fourteen high school students, each standing in front of trays of chocolate shavings, eggs, chives, carrots, zucchini and guinea hens.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NOVEMBER, SYLVIA
description: NOVEMBER-Sylvia, on May 21, 1997. Beloved mother of Barbara and David Levey. Cherished grandmother of Betsy, Pattie, and Kenny and Blanca, and greatgrandmother of Emily. Dear sister of Marvin and Alma Glickman. Service today 1:00PM at ''Riverside-Nassau North Chapels,'' 55 North Station Plaza (opposite LIRR), Great Neck.

title: And the Winner Is . . . Wieden & Kennedy
description: Wieden & Kennedy in Portland, Ore., took top honors with the most awards at the One Show for creative excellence in advertising sponsored by the One Club for Art and Copy.

title: INSIDE METRO
description: RANKING SUBWAYS -- A study of the performance of New York subway lines has found that the No. 7 is the best and the B line is the worst. B3.

title: Cynical, Immoral, Neutral
description: The just-released U.S. Government report on how the Swiss aided the Nazis in laundering their looted gold during World War II contains many useful lessons. But the most important is the lesson it teaches about ''neutrality,'' and how the Swiss version was a moral fraud.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CREEL, DANA S.
description: CREEL-Dana S. The Board of Directors and the staff of Boscobel Restoration, Inc. express their sincere sympathy on the death of Dana Creel, for many years a director, a friend, and an advisor. His wise counsel in the areas of restoration and preservation will be sorely missed by Boscobel and other historic sites.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BURNS, THOMAS A.
description: BURNS-Thomas A., on May 20th. 58 years old a man of ''Wisdom and Strength''. Beloved husband of Joan M. (nee Prendergast). Loving father of Claire Elizabeth Quinn, Thomas A. Burns III, and Daniel J. Burns. Dear brother of Dr. James A. Burns, Dr. Barbara A. Burns, and Ellen Barrett Burns. The family will receive relatives and friends Thursday evening from 7-9 PM, and Friday from 2-4 and 7-9 PM, at Feeney Funeral Home, 232 Franklin Ave, Ridgewood, NJ. A Funeral Mass will be celebrated Saturday 9:15 am at Our Lady of Mt. Carmel Church, Ridgewood. Interment to follow at Valleau Cemetery, Ridgewood. In lieu of flowers donations may be made to the Ridgewood High School Football Scholarship Committee, P.O. Box 1338, Ridgewood, New Jersey 07450-1338, in memory of Thomas A. Burns.

title: Boeing Gets European Objections to Merger
description: The Boeing Company said today that it had received a 60-page document detailing the European Union's objections to Boeing's planned $14 billion purchase of the McDonnell Douglas Corporation.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PETIGROW, NORMAN, MD.
description: PETIGROW-Norman, MD. We note with sorrow the passing of a highly respected colleague. As a dedicated Family Practice physician at North Shore University Hospital at Plainview, he served our community members with skill and compassion. His expertise will be sorely missed. Our heartfelt sympathy is extended to his family. Glenn Hirsch VP/Administration Alan Mensch, MD Medical Director North Shore University Hospital at Plainview

title: Couple Agree To Guilty Plea In Illegal Gifts To Democrats
description: An Oklahoma couple who raised thousands of dollars for Democrats in recent years have agreed to plead guilty to arranging $50,000 in illegal contributions in the 1994 election, the Justice Department said today.

title: Corrections
description: A headline in some editions of Business Day yesterday about a complaint filed by the Commodity Futures Trading Commission against Prudential Securities Inc. misstated the nature of the complaint. As the article noted, the firm was accused of a failure to supervise an employee adequately and keep proper records; it was not accused of fraud.

title: Bridge
description: The final of the Reisinger Knockout Team Championship, one of the oldest and most prestigious events in the game, will be contested Monday by squads headed by Roy Welland of Manhattan and William Ehlers of West Orange, N.J.

title: Plan Is Offered To Reorganize Finance Sector
description: Retreating from its most ambitious idea allowing banks to own manufacturers or other nonfinancial companies -- the Clinton Administration today introduced a long-awaited plan to revamp the nation's financial services industry.

title: City Is Good to Business, but What About Poor?
description: To the Editor:

title: Allen & Gerritsen Wins Sybase Account
description: Sybase Inc., the software company, said yesterday that it had named Allen & Gerritsen in Watertown, Mass., to handle the creative portion of its account, with billings estimated at $12 million to $15 million. That assignment had been handled for two years by Euro RSCG Dahlin Smith White in Salt Lake City, a unit of Havas Advertising.

title: Gordon Wies Reed, Ex-Oil Executive, 97
description: Gordon Wies Reed of Greenwich, Conn., who for 22 years was chairman of the Texas Gulf Producing Company, an independent oil and gas concern, died on Saturday after a brief illness, said his son, Thomas, a former Secretary of the Air Force. He was 97.

title: This Flyer Has a Way With Foes
description: While forwards Eric Lindros and John LeClair draw all the attention and goalie Ron Hextall draws all the jeers, Rod Brind'Amour has quietly yet effectively demolished the Philadelphia Flyers' opponents during the National Hockey League playoffs.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HAYES, NORA
description: HAYES-Nora. On May 20, 1997. Loving daughter of Michael and Lena. Beloved niece of Mary O'Brien. Survived by nieces and nephews. Reposing at Martin A. Gleason Funeral Home, 149-20 Northern Blvd., Flushing. Mass of Christian Burial Fri. 9:30 A.M. St. Luke's R.C. Church, Whitestone. Interment Calvery Cemetery. Visiting hours Thurs. 2-5 & 7-10 P.M.

title: Bernard L. Gladieux, Official And Foundation Leader, 90
description: Bernard Louis Gladieux, a Federal official who helped mobilize the country for World War II, went on to advise a succession of Cabinet secretaries and later helped build the Ford Foundation into a major global benefactor, died on Sunday at his home in Oberlin, Ohio. He was 90 and a former resident of Scarsdale, N.Y.

title: Clemens, Totally in Control, Earns 200th Victory
description: From the moment Roger Clemens emerged from the third-base dugout with his usual swagger and his intense glare, he was determined to turn the game into his game, turn the evening into his evening and turn Yankee Stadium into his home away from home for a few hours. He was determined to secure his 200th career victory.

title: Playing at Less Than Full Strength, Rangers Get a Breather
description: Ranger Coach Colin Campbell is hoping an extra day off will bring some much-needed relief for his weary team. It is about all Campbell can hope for right now.

title: The Cyclist's Fix For the Cities: Just Shift Gears
description: THE neighborhood bike nuts are out in force.

title: Captain Bodgit Is Retired After Injury
description: One of the greatest Triple Crown rivalries in years came to a quiet close yesterday when the 3-year-old colt Captain Bodgit was retired because of swelling in a major tendon in his lower left front leg.

title: Welcome to a World Without Liberals
description: To the Editor:

title: In Britain, The Opera Turns Soapy
description: Viewed in isolation, Genista McIntosh's resignation as chief executive of the Royal Opera House at Covent Garden last week hardly merited much public attention. She was hardly a household name, she had been in the post only four months and she was promptly replaced by an experienced arts administrator, Mary Allen.

title: Coffee Prices Continue to Rise; Pork Bellies Hit 4-Week High
description: Coffee prices resumed their ascent yesterday after the world's largest producers decided to maintain export quotas for another year, dashing hopes for relief from lean inventories and high prices.

title: Harriman Auction Draws $8.7 Million at Sotheby's
description: The two-day, two-night sale of the contents of the late Pamela Harriman's homes in Paris, Washington and Middleburg, Va., ended yesterday afternoon at Sotheby's, and barely a teacup went unsold.

title: Final Primary Debate
description: The third and final debate of the Democratic gubernatorial primary campaign will be broadcast live on the New Jersey Network from 7 to 9 P.M. tonight.

title: He Rejects Myths, Not Miracles
description: When he was 4 years old, Mark O'Brien was struck by polio and placed in an iron lung (''It's huge and yellow and ugly,'' he says, ''but it works''), and in one sort of artificial lung or another he has lived for more than 40 years. In ''Breathing Lessons: The Life and Work of Mark O'Brien'' he recites from his poems and talks to the camera about his love for his parents and his hatred of institutions, and ruminates on his prospects for romance and the nature of disability.

title: Polytechnic Raises Money
description: In the mid-1970's, officials at Polytechnic University in Brooklyn conceived of a commercial and academic complex that would change the face of the borough's downtown area, a vision that eventually developed into the $1 billion Metrotech Center.

title: PNC BANK ENDS MERGER NEGOTIATIONS WITH OPPENHEIMER
description: The PNC Bank Corporation has ended talks to buy the securities firm Oppenheimer & Company, according to people familiar with the discussions. The Pittsburgh bank had been discussing the acquisition of the privately held Oppenheimer for about $500 million in cash, stock and options. It is the latest bank to explore buying its way into the securities business. Spokesmen for PNC and for Oppenheimer, which is based in New York, declined to comment. Analysts said reports this month of an imminent merger were exaggerated.

title: LG&E Energy Agrees to Buy Rival Utility In Kentucky
description: The LG&E Energy Corporation, the Louisville, Ky., utility that has loudly campaigned for deregulation, armed itself for the coming battles yesterday by announcing an agreement to buy another Kentucky utility, the KU Energy Corporation, for $1.5 billion in stock.

title: Stronger Models, Weaker Yen Help Lift Toyota Income 50%
description: The Toyota Motor Corporation said today that group net income rose 50 percent in the latest fiscal year, driven by a strong model lineup, windfall profits from the weaker yen and cost reductions.

title: City Is Good to Business, but What About Poor?
description: To the Editor:

title: POLO RALPH LAUREN PLANS TO OFFER 30% STAKE TO PUBLIC
description: The Polo Ralph Lauren Corporation, its founder and other shareholders plan to sell 29.5 million shares at $22 to $25 each in an initial public offering that values the company at as much as $2.46 billion. The clothing company, which is based in New York, said in a filing yesterday with the Securities and Exchange Commission that it would sell 30 percent of the company in its first-time stock sale. Ralph Lauren and his family will sell 17.9 million of the class A shares to be offered and will retain class B shares that give the family 89.8 percent of the company's voting stock.

title: Swedish Study Finds Sex Bias in Getting Science Jobs
description: Women have to publish much more often than men to compete successfully for scientific jobs in Sweden, a study has found.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: Baseball

title: $15 Million In a Fund Will Provide Housing Aid
description: A group of banks and foundations led by Bankers Trust and J.P. Morgan will announce a $15 million fund today to subsidize New York City's community development corporations, the small, nonprofit neighborhood groups that have built thousands of homes and apartments for poor people since the 1970's.

title: John Guest, 84, Investment Banker
description: John Spencer-Churchill Guest, a retired investment banker who wrote about the Middle East, died on May 14 at his home in New Canaan, Conn. He was 84 and also lived in Fishers Island, N.Y.

title: Best-Selling Trash
description: If a book spends 19 weeks on The New York Times nonfiction best-seller list, it must be nonfiction, right? Not necessarily. In this week's New Yorker, Gary Aldrich, the author of ''Unlimited Access,'' the tell-all expose of the Clinton White House, says that his book's most widely quoted revelation, of nocturnal Presidential sojourns to a Marriott hotel, was ''not quite solid'' and ''hypothetical.'' Yet less than a year ago Mr. Aldrich -- a former F.B.I. agent with a propensity for attributing salacious ''news'' to unnamed sources -- had been taken seriously by much of the national media, whose feeding frenzy made him into a No. 1 best-selling author.

title: VW Says Sales Rose 11% This Year
description: Volkswagen A.G., Europe's largest car maker, said yesterday that unit sales rose 11.2 percent in the first four months of 1997 to 1.43 million vehicles. At the introduction of the company's new Passat Variant station wagon in Hamburg on Tuesday, VW's chief executive, Ferdinand Piech, said the company expected to sell as many as 10 percent more cars in 1997, a VW spokesman, Gunther Scherelis, said. ''We see growth of about 8 to 10 percent, to around 4.4 million cars,'' in 1997, Mr. Scherelis said.

title: Albert's Accuser in Virginia Faces Criminal Charges of Her Own
description: The woman who accused Marv Albert, the NBC Sports announcer, of assault and battery and forcing her to perform oral sex is facing a criminal charge herself.

title: Brazil's Chief Wins Vote Despite Scandal
description: The Brazilian Senate gave initial approval today to a constitutional amendment that would allow the President, state governors and mayors to run for second terms, handing President Fernando Henrique Cardoso the most important victory of his presidency.

title: Hoping for Horseshoe Crabs
description: Scientists who study migrating shore birds in New Jersey said yesterday that they hope the full moon tonight will bring large numbers of horseshoe crabs to lay eggs on the beaches of the Delaware Bay.

title: Is It Surgery for Strawberry?
description: The Yankees will wait two weeks to determine if Darryl Strawberry can play with his injured left knee, but Strawberry said last night that if he does not improve in that time, he will need surgery and will probably miss the rest of the season.

title: In Berlin, Evidence of Private Swiss Banks' Role in Nazi Trade
description: In the old days, Monika Tatzkow says, it was no great shakes being a historian in East Germany. Accessible archives were few, the chances to publish were limited.

title: Moralists and Our Money
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about commencement ceremonies for the New School for Social Research misstated the given name of the school's president in some editions. He is Jonathan F. Fanton, not Robert.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: Celltech Calls Drug From Bayer Ineffective
description: Celltech P.L.C., a British biotechnology concern, said yesterday that a septic shock drug it had licensed from Bayer A.G. had proved ineffective. Celltech said it would stop developing its own successor to the drug, BAYX-1351, that could have given the company a foothold in the $350 million market for treating the blood infection. The condition, in which the body is unable to fight off bacterial infection, kills about half of the 500,000 patients it afflicts each year in North America and Europe.

title: Foul Shooting Is Unnerving For Mourning and the Heat
description: It is just Alonzo Mourning and a harmless metal rim, a one-on-one situation that seems to scare the fearless Heat center like a mouse unnerves an elephant.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: TENNIS

title: City U. To Require English Test At Hostos
description: The City University Chancellor, W. Ann Reynolds, has directed Hostos Community College, a bilingual college in the Bronx, to require its students to pass a citywide English writing examination to receive a diploma.

title: Graduates At Columbia Told to Recast Public Policy
description: Addressing more than 8,900 graduates at Columbia University's commencement ceremony yesterday morning, George E. Rupp, Columbia's president, bemoaned the fading of government's role in society before adequate substitutes were found, and called upon the graduates to help formulate them.

title: A.M.A. Abortion Stand Splits Its Members
description: The American Medical Association's endorsement of a bill banning a specific abortion method has created a rift in the organization, with some doctors suggesting that the legislation might infringe on constitutional rights guaranteed by the Supreme Court in abortion cases over the last 24 years.

title: Ex-Ally of De Klerk Forms Nonracial Party in South Africa
description: An estranged ally of former President F. W. de Klerk announced today that he was forming a new political movement that he hoped would attract both black and white voters.

title: Alfonzo's Home Run Helps Stop Marlins
description: Leo Durocher, the late manager enshrined in the Hall of Fame, described his favorite player, the plucky infielder Eddie Stanky, in this way: He can't run, he can't hit, he can't field. All he does is win games.

title: MEDPARTNERS CUTS INPHYNET OFFER TO $377.5 MILLION
description: Medpartners Inc. said yesterday that it had lowered its offer for Inphynet Medical Management Inc. to $377.5 million after Inphynet restated its earnings for 1996 and the first quarter of 1997. Medpartners, which is based in Birmingham, Ala., and is the nation's largest physician-practice management company, said it would now exchange 1.18 shares of its stock for each of Inphynet's 16.7 million shares, instead of the 1.311 shares announced in an agreement Jan. 20. Based on Medpartners' closing price of $19.125, unchanged from Tuesday, the agreement is now worth $22.57 a share, or $377 million, down from $25.07 and $419 million. The stock of Inphynet, based in Fort Lauderdale, Fla., fell 62.5 cents yesterday, to $22.125.

title: Turkey's Intellectuals
description: To the Editor:

title: Burmese Crack Down as U.S. Investment Ban Goes Into Effect
description: As an American ban on new investments in Myanmar took effect, the Burmese military Government was reported today to have carried out a new wave of arrests of members of the pro-democracy movement led by Daw Aung San Suu Kyi.

title: Bulgari Loosens Up
description: Bulgari, the Italian jeweler known for bold and very expensive gold designs, wants to have a less daunting presence on Fifth Avenue's jewelry row. So it is forging a middle ground between the democratic hubbub of Tiffany and the hushed exclusivity of Van Cleef & Arpels.

title: Bipartisan Sunshine
description: When Senators Daniel Patrick Moynihan and Jesse Helms get together to sponsor a piece of national-security legislation, Washington best take notice. The New York liberal and the North Carolina conservative have found common ground in seeking to diminish government's needless and damaging obsession with secrecy. Congress would do a service to democracy by approving their plan.

title: Vulnerable Achievers
description: To the Editor:

title: Alone Except For a Cellist And Bach
description: Jerome Robbins created ''A Suite of Dances'' for Mikhail Baryshnikov in 1994, and it has also been performed in Europe by stars of the Paris Opera Ballet. But not until this season had a member of the New York City Ballet danced this genial solo to Bach music for solo cello.

title: Evidence for a modest impact from abolishing rent controls.
description: TO economists, the persistence of rent regulation in New York -- the belly of the capitalist beast -- is a delicious irony. To some two million New Yorkers who live in rent-regulated apartments, all the tub-thumping in the world about how price controls are evil incarnate will not change a fundamental fact: While the typical rent on ''stabilized'' one-bedroom apartments in Manhattan hovers around $600 a month, the cracker boxes advertised in the Sunday papers cost $1,500 and up.

title: U.S. to Renovate Federal Buildings to Cut Energy Bills by 25%
description: The Federal Government, the nation's largest landlord, will undertake a $5 billion renovation of its buildings to cut energy bills by about one quarter, and all the money will come from private companies, the Energy Secretary, Federico F. Pena, announced today.

title: Congo's Neighbors Played Crucial Role in Civil War
description: When Laurent Kabila's rebels captured this country's capital over the weekend and catapulted him into the presidency, they did not do it alone.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HIRSCH, SHERMAN Z.
description: HIRSCH-Sherman Z., of Wesley Hills, NY died Saturday, May 17, 1997, he was 75. Mr. Hirsch was born on Sept. 20, 1921 in the Bronx to Benjamin and Frieda Hirsch. He was a resident of Rockland County since 1956. Mr. Hirsch graduated from NYU in 1941. He served for 3.5 years in the Navy during World War II attaining the rank of Lieutenant Senior Grade. Mr. Hirsch was the owner of Hirsch Industries which sold metalized film and related products. He is survived by his wife of 46 years; Sydelle (nee Hamburg); his children; Robert and Roberta Hirsch, and Ellen and John Zimmerman; and five grandsons; Benjamin, Gregory, Samuel, Ron and Jacob. He is also survived by 2 brothers: David Hirsh and his wife Betty, of Bayside; and Jack Hirsch and his wife Doris of Manhattan. The funeral was held Sunday, May 18, 1997, at Riverside Memorial Chappel, Manhattan. Burial followed at Cedar Park Cemetery, Paramus, New Jersey. The family is observing a period of mourning at the Wesley Hills residence through Friday afternoon.

title: Washington Post Co.'s On-Line Venture
description: The Washington Post Company will team with Citysearch Inc. to develop a new site on the World Wide Web for Washington, D.C., area news and information.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BREWER, C. WILLIAM
description: BREWER-C. William, of Shelter Island on May 19, 1997. Husband of the late Viola Knudsen Brewer. Father of Bruce W. Brewer and Dana C. Hahn, loving companion of Joy Micciche, grandfather of Reid and Todd Brewer, Jamie and Abby Hahn. Funeral mass today, 4:30 PM St. Mary's Episcopal Church, Shelter Island. Interment St. Mary's Cemetery. In lieu of flowers memorial donations to the American Cancer Society would be appreciated.

title: Police Investigate Gifts of Equipment to Rowland Children
description: Gov. John G. Rowland's children and members of his staff were given surplus military equipment by a state trooper, whose actions may have violated state law, the authorities said today.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SOBEL, HON. NATHAN R.
description: SOBEL-Hon. Nathan R. The Feiden family mourns the death of Nat Sobel. In addition to a life of extraordinary public service as a judge, surrogate, counsel to Governor Herbert H. Lehman, to Constitutional Conventions, he was the most unselfish, helpful person I have known. Murray T. Feiden

title: U.S. Rests on Emotional Note in the Bombing Trial
description: Helping to conclude the prosecution's case against Timothy J. McVeigh, Florence Rogers calmly told the jury today of the moment when everyone else vanished from her office in the Federal Building in Oklahoma City.

title: Connecticut Seeks to Appeal Managed Health Care Denials
description: Moving to restrict the power of managed-care companies to deny treatment to their customers, the General Assembly passed legislation today that will let the state overturn the companies' decisions on what medical procedures they will pay for.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Worries About Fed Persist, And Stocks Are Mixed

title: USA Track and Field Names Finalists
description: USA Track and Field yesterday announced three finalists for the job of executive director, which OLLAN CASSELL will relinquish next month after running the troubled sport for three decades.

title: CHRONICLE
description: Who knows if it was the best day in his life, but DAVID BOWIE had a pretty good one on Tuesday, when he had a party to celebrate the establishment with two partners of his own art book publishing company in London.

title: Marriott Set Out to Prove Itself In New York; Now It Dominates
description: When J.W. Marriott Jr. opened the 50-story Marriott Marquis in the midst of Times Square's low-rise porn shops in 1985, the hotel was described by architecture critics as a mass of concrete looming over Times Square like a giant tombstone.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: American Topics : Shame!Framingham Knows How to Use It
description: The upright residents of Framingham, Massachusetts, had had all they could take: Vacant houses in their midst were an eyesore, their windows smashed, yards untended, inhabited sometimes by drug users.

title: How Corporate America Gained the Statehouse
description: To the Editor:

title: After 27,000 Guests, the Great Gabfest Winds Up
description: At last count he has done some 27,000 interviews, though he would be the first to admit that after all the rhubarb recipes (''Is there a way to make it less stringy?''), Celtic musicians and Quebec separatists he has introduced, 27,000 sometimes seems too low.

title: Air Force Chief Has Harsh Words For Pilot Facing Adultery Charge
description: The Air Force Chief of Staff sharply criticized the country's first female B-52 pilot today, even as the Secretary of the Air Force weighed whether to grant her an honorable discharge instead of court-martialing her on adultery, lying and other charges.

title: The Spread on the Ceiling
description: To The Home Section:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  REINER, MILTON
description: REINER-Milton. Loving husband of Sylvia. Adored father of Michael. Dear brother of Betty and Shirley. Services were conducted privately.

title: Neglect Charge Dropped In Danish Baby Case
description: A Family Court judge said yesterday that he would accept the withdrawal of a child neglect petition against the parents of a Danish baby who had been placed in foster care after she was found in a stroller outside an East Village restaurant where her parents were eating.

title: Capriati Out of French Open With Injury
description: She was named the 1996 comeback player of the year, but a sprained right ankle has become the latest stumbling block in the comeback saga of JENNIFER CAPRIATI.

title: TV Stars Appear In Anti-Fur Ad
description: Ellen DeGeneres and Bill Maher, the stars of two television shows on ABC, are appearing together in a print advertisement for the advocacy organization People for the Ethical Treatment of Animals.

title: A $1.7 Billion Stake Set By Veba in Degussa
description: The German utility Veba A.G. said yesterday that it planned to buy a 36.4 percent stake in the chemical and metal company Degussa A.G. in a move that was seen as improving both companies' earnings prospects.

title: M.T.A. Delays Awarding Data Processing Contract
description: In the face of fierce criticism from Mayor Rudolph W. Guiliani and a host of city and union officials, the Metropolitan Transportation Authority announced yesterday that it would delay a vote on a $95 million contract for data processing with Lockheed Martin, a company barred from city contracts because of its involvement in previous corruption scandals.

title: Cosmo vs. Reality: It's Power Juggling
description: HIGH on a hillside above Hastings-on-Hudson on a shimmering, suburban afternoon, the Cosmo Girl in Chief was in her renovated kitchen doing what, we are told, contemporary Cosmopolites can be counted on to do.

title: Strangulation Killed Megan, Medical Examiner Testifies
description: Megan Kanka was choked to death with a belt, a medical examiner testified today at the murder and sexual assault trial of Jesse K. Timmendequas.

title: Stocks Mixed, With Dow Retreating 12.77
description: Stock prices were mixed yesterday as investors continued to worry about the possibility of higher interest rates, despite the fact that the Federal Reserve voted to leave them unchanged earlier this week.

title: Mrs. Whitman's Reality Check
description: Four years ago, Christine Todd Whitman's come-from-behind victory in the New Jersey gubernatorial election stunned politicians and transformed Mrs. Whitman into a Republican star. Her pledge to cut taxes 30 percent was copied throughout the country, and for a time last year she was even considered a possible candidate for Vice President. This year Mrs. Whitman is widely viewed as likely to win re-election, but something interesting has happened that, at the least, has given her Democratic opponents a target. The tax-cut scheme, combined with other problems, has created a serious fiscal burden for New Jersey.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GILMAN, SOL
description: GILMAN-Sol. On May 20, 1997. Beloved husband of Florence and devoted father of Norman (Harriet), loving brother of Harry and advored grandfather and great-grandfather. Services Thursday 12:15PM, ''The Riverside'', 76 Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Losing Viewers to Cable, Again
description: The television network prime-time season, along with its last ratings sweeps month, came to a crashing halt last night. It was the sound of the four broadcast networks' share of the audience falling sharply once again -- by about 6 percent from a year ago -- as more viewers turned to cable.

title: Nazi Gold Belongs Only to Hitler's Victims
description: To the Editor:

title: ABC Got Whitewater Audiotape In Legal Action, U.S. Judge Says
description: A tape recording broadcast by ABC News in which a Whitewater prosecutor discussed the possibility that Hillary Rodham Clinton could face indictment was obtained from the court clerk legally by paying a $15 fee, the chief judge of the Federal circuit and ABC said today.

title: Art Deco Enough for a Maharajah
description: MOST patrons of modern architecture have been content to build one cube-shaped house and call it a streamlined day. Not Yeshwant Rao Holkar Bahadur, the Maharajah of Indore.

title: Classical Music in Review
description: Imagining Vespers

title: Unrest Erupts In Argentina Over Austerity
description: Driven by discontent over high unemployment and declining living standards, violent protests have erupted in major cities and towns throughout Argentina in recent days. Riot policemen have clashed with tens of thousands of people blocking roads, bridges and Government buildings.

title: Virgilio Barco, Ex-Colombia Chief, Dies at 75
description: Virgilio Barco, an American-educated former President of Colombia whose dream of combatting rampant poverty with land reform and other ambitious social measures was sidetracked by an American-backed civil war with powerful drug barons, died Tuesday at a hospital in Bogota. He was 75 and had been suffering from Alzheimer's disease since shortly after leaving office in 1990.

title: Shirkers in Cyberspace
description: To the Editor:

title: A Blending Of the Unlike
description: It isn't every choreographer who can call upon the likes of Vivian Reed, a Broadway musical star, and a host of former lead dancers from the Alvin Ailey and Dance Theater of Harlem companies. But Louis Johnson did that in a program presented by his ensemble on Sunday at the Henry Street Settlement, where he directs the dance department.

title: Stopgap Spending Provision Stalls Flood Relief Measure
description: Billions of dollars in flood relief for the upper Plains remained bottled up today, held hostage to several unresolved issues including an impasse between the White House and Congressional Republicans over a provision intended to prevent Government shutdowns during budget battles.

title: Verdicts Appealed in Assault
description: Papers were filed yesterday asking the State Supreme Court to overturn guilty verdicts against three former Glen Ridge High School football stars who were accused of sexually assaulting a mildly retarded woman in 1989.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SOBEL, NATHAN R.
description: SOBEL-Nathan R. A giant of a man. A warm, spirited and brilliant judge. He had patience and understanding and treated all who came before him with respect and dignity. We will miss his smile and that cigar always in hand. Seymour D. Reich

title: Correction
description: Because of an editing error, an article yesterday about the Senate vote to ban certain late-term abortions referred incorrectly to the position of Senator Trent Lott of Mississippi, the majority leader. He has always supported such a ban, and voted against a similar bill in 1996 for procedural reasons only. He later changed his vote to reflect his true position, making the official final tally in favor of the ban 58, not 57.

title: A Calf Makes A Break for It In the Bronx
description: It wasn't exactly the last roundup, and the men with the lariats weren't wearing Stetsons. But a bit of the Wild West came to the northern Bronx yesterday, when a calf escaped from a truck and began a one-steer stampede down Ely Avenue in Baychester.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CONKLIN, THOMAS
description: CONKLIN-Thomas. Suddenly on May 18, 1997. Of Briarcliff Manor. Survived by loving family, Janet and Charles Karasick, brother John Karasick, grandparents Thomas and Pauline Holland, mother Judith Conklin and many friends. Services Ossining United Methodist Church, Route 9 and Emwilton Place on Thursday at 10 A.M. In lieu of flowers, contributions to the Briarcliff High School Scholarship Fund for Tom Conklin.

title: Classical Music in Review
description: Signs of a Poet,

title: School Officials See Lapses in the Reporting of a Girl's Claim of Rape
description: A day after four teen-age boys were charged with gang-raping a 14-year-old girl inside a Queens high school classroom, officials at the Board of Education said yesterday that an assistant principal and a counselor at the school apparently failed to follow regulations by not informing their supervisors of the girl's initial claim last month.

title: I.R.A. Wing And British Hold Meeting
description: For the first time since the Irish Republican Army broke its cease-fire 15 months ago, British officials met today with leaders of Sinn Fein, the I.R.A. political wing, and discussed the possibility of a new cease-fire that would clear the way for Sinn Fein to enter the stalled peace talks.

title: Harvard Loses A.I.D. Grant For Russians
description: The United States Agency for International Development has suspended $14 million in grants to an institute at Harvard University, saying two of its advisers on a project promoting fiscal and legal reforms in Russia used their positions for personal profit, officials said today.

title: Chiropractors and Lawyers Are Indicted in Insurance Fraud Sting
description: Since 1990, Mitchell Rachlin has collected more than $626,000 in payments from an insurance policy, claiming that neck and back injuries from a car accident prevented him from working at his law practice.

title: People
description: * Steven Farella was named senior vice president and regional director for North America media operations at D'Arcy Masius Benton & Bowles Communications, New York, a unit of MacManus Group, succeeding Rich Hamilton, who left. Mr. Farella had been executive vice president, media services director and director for business development at Jordan, McGrath, Case & Taylor, New York.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FISHMAN, MOLLIE Z. (NEE ZUCKERBRAUN)
description: FISHMAN-Mollie Z. (nee Zuckerbraun), on May 21, 1997. Wife of the late Joseph of NYC. Mother of Ethyl F. and Charles Blumenfeld and Morton and Freda Fishman, grandmother of Alan L. Blumenfeld, Toby Holtzman, Liza Blumenfeld, Gary Fishman, Kenneth Fishman, Stuart Fishman, Jane Dembling and Annie Rand. Also survived by twelve great - grandchildren. Services Thursday, 10:30 AM, Schwartz Brothers, 114-03 Queens Blvd., Forest Hills, NY. Interment Old Montefiore Cemetery. Contributions to the Jewish National Fund.

title: No Headline
description: ''That is real money, even by Washington standards.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MELTZER, SYLVIA
description: MELTZER-Sylvia. Beloved wife of the late Harold. Devoted mother of Robert and Diane, Dr. James and Sandra. Cherished grandmother of Jocelyn, Erica, Aaron and David. Services Thursday 12 noon at the Riverside Nassau North Chapel, 55 North Station Plaza, Great Neck opposite LIRR.

title: Fees Proposed For Prisoners Using Clinics
description: The Giuliani administration said yesterday that it wanted to charge inmates a fee for medical care in city jails, saying such a policy would deter inmates who are not sick from going to clinics just as a pretext for leaving detention areas.

title: Toy Biz Reaches Agreement With Marvel's Bondholders
description: In the continuing battle for control of Marvel Entertainment Group, Toy Biz Inc. defected to the other side yesterday. The move provided a gain for bondholders led by Carl C. Icahn. But the struggle is far from over.

title: When Jail Doesn't Work
description: The raw statistics on juvenile crime are alarming. But the House of Representatives overreacted when it passed a bill that would reward states for prosecuting more youthful offenders as adults and locking up more of them in adult prisons. This misguided proposal undermines the ability of the states to try more enlightened approaches. The Senate should consider a different course when it addresses the issue.

title: A Barbie Friend, Disabled, Has Wheelchair
description: Adding diversity to its Barbie collection, Mattel introduced a doll in a wheelchair today. The doll, Share a Smile Becky, became available in selected Toys ''R'' Us stores this week.

title: Abortion Opponents Begin Hunt for 3 Votes
description: Abortion opponents are already remapping their seemingly nonstop Congressional campaign to abolish what they call partial-birth abortion, focusing on a handful of senators they think might change their votes to help them prevail over President Clinton's opposition.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KLEIN, ERWIN L.
description: KLEIN-Erwin L. Peacefully on May 21. Loving husband of Marlys. Beloved father of Richard and Susan. Cherished father-in-law of Nina. Dear brother of Herbert and brother-in-law of Monika Klein and H. Karl Frensdorff. Adored grandfather of Andrew, Lauren and Sarah. Services on Friday, at 10 A.M., at Westchester Reform Temple, 255 Mamaroneck Road, Scarsdale, New York.

title: Lucent in New Identification Joint Venture
description: Lucent Technologies Inc. and U.S. Venture Partners said today that they had formed a company that would make products to help people prove their identities through electronic fingerprinting technology.

title: Now, the well-packed carry-on for a Club Med vacation contains jeans, cologne and cigars.
description: CLUB MED is counting on new marketing alliances with Levi's, Calvin Klein Cosmetics and Davidoff of Geneva, the cigar company, to lift it out of the financial doldrums in which it has floundered since 1990.

title: 2 Exchanges Set Records In Uncovered Short Sales
description: Short-sellers are betting that the General Electric Company, the first American corporation ever to be valued at $200 billion, is overvalued.

title: Love It, Feed It, Mourn It
description: A DOG may be man's best friend, but a virtual pet can be a child's worst nightmare. Children who are nurturing the tiny Tamagotchi cyberpet, a popular Japanese digital toy that went on sale in the United States three weeks ago, are discovering that virtual death can be nearly as traumatic as the real thing.

title: Novell to Cut 50 Positions
description: Novell Inc. said yesterday that it would cut about 50 jobs, or 15 percent of its 400-member work force in Europe. But the troubled network-software company, based in Orem, Utah, did not confirm a report posted on the Internet that it would cut staff at its United States operations. A Novell spokesman, Jonathan Cohen, said that the company informed European employees last Wednesday about the cuts. German law requires advance notification of pending layoffs, prompting the announcement, he said.

title: A.I.G. Chairman Names Son President
description: The chairman of American International Group Inc., Maurice R. Greenberg, named his son president yesterday, setting in motion an apparent succession plan for A.I.G., the nation's biggest publicly traded financial services company.

title: Same Play Book for Parcells and Johnson
description: They talk all the time Bill Parcells, the Jets' new coach and dominating presence, and Keyshawn Johnson, who wants to be the lightning rod.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHERIN, ARTHUR H., JR.
description: SHERIN-Arthur H., Jr. of Hopewell Junction, died May 22, 1997. He was a retired advertising sales executive for CBS Publishing and a former elder of the Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church. Beloved husband of Flora DeBenedetto Sherin and father of Suzanne Lopiano, Deborah Pell and Bonnie Kollmann. For information call McHoul Funeral Home, Rte. 82, Hopewell Junction, New York.

title: Pretax Profit Declined 20% for NEC of Japan
description: The NEC Corporation, Japan's largest producer of semiconductors, said yesterday that its full-year pretax profit had dropped 20 percent as a slump in memory prices offset strong sales for mobile communications equipment. NEC's pretax profit fell to 121.2 billion yen ($1.06 billion) in the year that ended on March 31. Sales rose to a record 4.9 trillion yen ($43 billion). The company forecast pretax profit would rise 32 percent, to 160 billion yen, in the current fiscal year.

title: Corrections
description: A report in the Daily Briefing column in New Jersey copies on Wednesday about State Senator James E. McGreevey's attacks on his rivals for the Democratic nomination for governor misstated the forum in which he referred to Michael Murphy as a tax cheat. That attack -- in which Senator McGreevey complained that Mr. Murphy was paying his campaign workers as independent contractors and avoiding Social Security and payroll taxes -- came in a news release, not in an advertisement. (Yesterday, Senator McGreevey apologized to Mr. Murphy for the characterization.)

title: Art in Review
description: Robert Smithson

title: New York City's Water Doesn't Need Filtering
description: To the Editor:

title: Private Money Saves Two Harlem Walk-Ups
description: A new owner has managed to achieve a turnaround at two side-by-side rental buildings in central Harlem, five years after a fire in one of the buildings seemed to have drained them of value. The recovery was solidified two weeks ago when a bank agreed to provide a new 15-year mortgage.

title: National Pension Fund to Be Pursued
description: Representatives from all aspects of boxing testified before Congress yesterday about the need for a national pension fund for the sport's professional athletes.

title: Lazard Names New Top Team Post-Rohatyn
description: Steven Rattner was named deputy chief executive of Lazard Freres & Company yesterday, inheriting Felix G. Rohatyn's mantle as the firm's lead banker after several months of fierce internal squabbling.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DOMINICK, ELIZABETH YALLALEE
description: DOMINICK-Elizabeth Yallalee, of New Canaan, CT., and Southern Pines, NC passed away on May 19. Beloved wife of Bayard Dominick. Survived by her children, Mrs. Jonathan O'Brien, Gayer G. Dominick II, Margrett Dominick Grummon, Edward Hoyt Dominick and Wilder Dominick Witt, 12 grandchildren and six great-grandchildren. Graveside services 11AM on Tuesday, May 27 at Lakeview Cemetery in New Canaan, CT. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be sent to Waveny Care Center, New Canaan, CT. 06840.

title: Landlords Settle Race Discrimination Claim
description: Federal prosecutors said yesterday that the owners of an Upper East Side apartment building had agreed to pay $15,000 and promised to avoid discriminating on the basis of race to settle a Federal housing complaint.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HERSHEY, ALFRED DAY
description: HERSHEY-Alfred Day. With great sadness, Cold Spring Harbor Laboratory reports the death of Alfred D. Hershey. Dr. Hershey earned the Nobel Prize in 1969 for work he did in the 1950s at the Carnegie Institution of Washington Department of Genetics at Cold Spring Harbor, where he worked from 1950 until his retirement in 1974. He directed the Institution's Genetics Research Unit 1962-72. After retirement, Dr. Hershey continued to participate in the life of Cold Spring Harbor Laboratory. Dr. Hershey is survived by his wife Harriet ''Jill'' Hershey (nee Davidson) of Syosset, NY and his son, Peter, of Texas. Dr. Hershey was 88 years old. In lieu of flowers, donations may be sent to Cold Spring Harbor Laboratory for the Alfred D. Hershey Memorial Fund, P.O. Box 100, Cold Spring Harbor, New York 11724.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ERICSON, JOHN M.
description: ERICSON-John M., 53, on May 9, 1997. Survived by mother Elizabeth Ericson, daughters Kathy Tari and Stephanie Ericson, granddaughter Alexis Dariya Tari, two brothers, two sisters, four nieces, and four nephews. Memorial services at First Presbyterian Church in New Orleans, May 24. Additional services, Corpus Christi TX, to be announced.

title: Corrections
description: A brief report in the Company News column of Business Day on Wednesday about the proposed purchase of Renaissance Solutions Inc. by Registry Inc. misstated the location of Renaissance's headquarters. It is Lincoln, Mass., not Lincoln, Neb.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BOTVINICK, EVELYN
description: BOTVINICK-Evelyn. Of Westfield, NJ and Sunrise, FL, suddenly on May 21, 1997 in Florida. Devoted member and benefactor of the City of Hope and Seymour L. Fass League. Loving wife of the late Jacob. Beloved mother of Donald and Dr. Elias Botvinick and the late Irving ''Sonny'' Lefkin. Mother-in-law of Sondra and Carroll, cherished grandmother, great grandmother and great aunt. Devoted sister of Gerry Lefkin, the late Aaron and Michael Lefkin. Sister-in-law of Libby and Sophie Lefkin. Loving aunt of Martin Lefkin and Shiela Hyams and the late Arthur Lefkin. Beloved and cherished friend to all who knew her. Funeral services Sunday noon from Garlick Funeral Home, 1700 Coney Island Ave., Bkn. Interment Beth David Cemetery, Elmont, LI

title: Israel Plans To Construct 3,400 Homes For Arabs
description: The Israeli Interior Ministry said today that it had approved construction of 3,400 homes for Arabs in a village next to an East Jerusalem hill where work on a new Jewish neighborhood has plunged Israeli-Palestinian talks into their deepest crisis.

title: Blood, Bruises and Terror Are Recalled at Kelly Retrial
description: Shortly after telling her sister that Alex Kelly had just raped her, a sobbing 16-year-old climbed into bed with her mother, who ''hugged her and tried to comfort her,'' the mother testified today.

title: Fed Rate Rise On March 25 Was Backed By Full Panel
description: Federal Reserve policy makers were unanimous in raising the overnight bank lending rate on March 25, though they have decided to take a more relaxed stance toward inflation in the interim, minutes of the meeting showed today.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SAIDENBERG, DANIEL
description: SAIDENBERG-Daniel. The members of the Art Dealers Association of America mourn the passing of their colleague who, with his wife Eleanore, have been the principals of the Saidenberg Gallery since 1950. A man of many talents, he was a great musician and an important dealer in great works of art. More than that, he was a colleague devoted to his profession and to his family. Our deep sympathy to Eleanore, and to his sons, Lawrence and Robert. James N. Goodman, President Gilbert S. Edelson, Admin VP

title: ANHEUSER-BUSCH TO INCREASE STAKE IN MEXICAN BREWER
description: The Anheuser-Busch Companies said yesterday that it had agreed to pay $605 million to increase its stake in Grupo Modelo S.A., the brewer that makes Corona beer, ending a disagreement about the price and paving the way for it to gain control of the company. Anheuser-Busch, based in St. Louis, said it now owns 37 percent of Grupo Modelo, Mexico's largest brewer, and its Diblo S.A. subsidiary, bringing its total investment to more than $1 billion. Anheuser-Busch said it intended to exercise options raising its stake to 50.2 percent.

title: U.S. Says Guards Turned Jail Into a 'Badfellas' Social Club
description: Corrupt guards let top mobsters turn a new Federal jail in Brooklyn into a Mafia social club, where they plotted crimes with visiting associates and dined in high style with smuggled-in meatballs, manicotti and chicken cutlets washed down with vodka and wine, Federal officials said yesterday.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  LIEF, LIBBIE
description: LIEF-Libbie. December 27, 1908May 23, 1995. Rembered and deeply missed, always with us in our loving thoughts.

title: Brooklyn Teacher Held in Sex Abuse of Student, 13
description: School investigators charged a 41-year-old Brooklyn music teacher yesterday with sexually abusing a 13-year-old female student in his locked classroom last month, and they criticized the school's principal for failing to reassign the teacher after learning of the allegations.

title: Some Domino Moves
description: Following Credit Suisse First Boston's 1.6 million-square-foot consolidation at 11 Madison Avenue, three corporate relatives have moved into its former offices at 12 East 49th Street. The three divisions of the Credit Suisse Group, based in Zurich, leased 106,750 square feet for a total of $65 million, or $40 per square foot, at Tower 49.

title: Last Chance
description: Here is a sampling of shows and exhibitions in Manhattan that are to close soon:

title: Swiss Reject As One-Sided Study by U.S. Of Nazi Ties
description: Two weeks after the Clinton Administration accused Switzerland of prolonging World War II by acting as a banker to Nazi Germany, the authorities here tartly rejected the accusation today as ''unsupported'' and termed Washington's assessment ''one-sided.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WOLFERMAN, ADOLPH, M.D.
description: WOLFERMAN-Adolph, M.D. On May 22, 1997. Husband of the late Pierrette Wolferman and adored husband of Irene Schleider Wolferman. Dear father of Mark (Cathy), Eric (Patricia) and Sondra. Beloved grandfather of Brian, Cassie, Benjamin, Joann and Anna Wolferman, Alex, David, Jacob, Jessica and Alexandra Schleider. Services on Sunday 1:15 P.M., at ''The Riverside'', 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue. Visiting hours on Saturday 7-9 P.M.

title: N.C.A.A. Tries to Block Fairfield Player
description: If the National Collegiate Athletic Association has its way, Darren Phillip, the freshman forward who played an important role in the Fairfield basketball team's stunning capture of the Metro Atlantic Athletic Conference tournament title last March, will be ruled academically ineligible and lose his scholarship in a dispute over less than half of a credit.

title: For Children
description: 'Butterfly Blast'

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ABRAMSON, DOVIE
description: ABRAMSON-Dovie. On May 22, 1997. Loving wife of the late Norman Abramson. Mother of Jane O'Connor and Jill Abramson. Grandmother of Robby & Teddy O'Connor, and Cornelia and Will Griggs. Devoted sister of Henry and Roxanne Brandt. Mother-inlaw of Jim O'connor and Henry Griggs. Service today, Friday, May 23, 11:30 AM, at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue, at 81st Street. In lieu of flowers contributions may be made to the New York Public Library.

title: Doctor's License Reinstated
description: Dr. Eric Braverman, the Somerset County physician who promoted alternative medicine on the radio until his license was suspended in New Jersey last July, reached a settlement with the state Wednesday to have his license reinstated.

title: YELTSIN DISMISSES 2 MILITARY CHIEFS FOR RESISTING CUTS
description: President Boris N. Yeltsin dismissed the two top leaders of Russia's military today, lambasting them for resisting spending cuts and dragging their feet on restructuring of the armed forces.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLD, ANNE
description: GOLD-Anne, 92, of Hallandale, FL. Formerly of Fort Lee and Teaneck, NJ, born in Jersey City, died May 21, 1997. Survivors are a daughter, Myra G. and son-in-law Charles I. Wrubel, of Demarest, NJ, a son, Gerard and daughter-inlaw Jane Gold, of Bethesda, MD. A sister, Martha Brenner of Memphis, TN. Grandchildren Jason Gold, William Wrubel, Robert and Lila Wrubel, Richard and Jessica Wrubel. Services are at 11 A.M., today, Cedar Park Cemetery, Paramus, NJ. Memorial donations would be appreciated to the Anne and Ben Gold Scholarship Fund, c/ o JCC on the Palisades, 411 East Clinton Ave., Tenafly, NJ 07670 or the Hospice-By-The-Sea, Palmetto Park Road, Boca Raton, FL.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary yesterday about the cellist, conductor and gallery owner Daniel Saidenberg misspelled the name of the musical competition he won in 1929. It is the Walter W. Naumburg International Competition, not Naumberg.

title: What to Do During Memorial Day Weekend
description: Memorial Day is on Monday, but festivities are planned all weekend in the three-state area. Here is a sampling. Unless noted, admission is free:

title: Russia's Budget Crunch
description: Not long after Boris Yeltsin resumed his duties as President early this year, he promised to overhaul Russia's dysfunctional tax system. That effort has so far accomplished nothing, and Russia must now pay the price of trying to operate a Government reeling from a free fall in revenues.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SOBEL, HON. NATHAN R.
description: SOBEL-Hon. Nathan R. The Feiden family mourns the death of Nat Sobel. In addition to a life of extraordinary public service as a judge, surrogate, counsel to Governor Herbert H. Lehman, two Constitutional Conventions, he was the most unselfish, helpful person I have known. Murray T. Feiden

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KRAMARIC, PETER S.
description: KRAMARIC-Peter S., 67, formerly of New York City and Wilton, CT, died Wednesday, May 21, 1997 at Wake Robin surrounded by his family following a courageous battle with cancer. He was born April 29, 1930 in Ljubljana, Slovenia, the son of Stefan and Ana (Vidic) Kramaric. He was raised in Slovenia and was a graduate of the University of Ljubljana Law School in 1954. After serving two years as a political prisoner in Yugoslavia, Peter escaped Communist rule to arrive in the United States on May 25, 1956, owning $70.00. He graduated from Yale Law School in 1960. He was an International Attorney, having worked for Union Carbide Corp., General Foods, Corp., and most recently American Home Products Corp. He retired in 1993 and moved to Colchester, Vermont to be near his daughter, Karen Dean, and her family. Mr. Kramaric was a member of The American Bar Association, New York Bar Association and the Yale Club of New York City. He was also a member of The Ethan Allen Club of Burlington, VT. He attended the College Street Congregational Church in Burlington. He is survived by his devoted daughter, Karen Dean and her husband, Laurence, of Essex; grandson, Andrew Peter Dean, of Essex; two sisters, Polona Mauer of Utah and Marijana Polak of Slovenia; nieces and nephews. He was predeceased by his wife, Susan L. Kramaric, in 1993. A memorial service will be held in the College Street Congregational Church in Burlington on Monday, May 26, 1997 at 11AM. Burial will take place in Shelburne, VT at the convenience of the family. In lieu of flowers, memorial gifts may be made to Hospice of the Champlain Valley, 25 Prim Road, Colchester, VT 05446 or to The American Cancer Society, Vermont Division, 13 Loomis Street, Montpelier, VT 05602. For information contact Corbin and Palmer Funeral Home, 71 S. Union St., Burlington, VT.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DUPONT, BETTE Y. (NEE) KATZ
description: DuPONT-Bette Y. (nee) Katz, on May 19, 1997. We mourn the loss of our beloved mother. Survived by her loving children, daughter Gale Axelrod and son Jeffrey Axelrod, both of Manhattan, son Reed Axelrod and adored grandson Benjamin Gilbert Axelrod, both of Philadelphia. Laid to rest in eternal peace with her parents, Bella and Max Katz at New Montefiore Cemetery. We will miss you dearly and will carry your love in our hearts always.

title: Gone at Last
description: ''The fashion industry should not be the easy target to blame for society's woes,'' said Fern Mallis, the executive director of the Council of Fashion Designers of America.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GELMAN, MRS. ELLEN
description: GELMAN-Mrs. Ellen, 1939-1997, of Miami Beach, Fl, formerly of NY; passed away, May 22, 1997. She was the much loved wife of Theodore Gelman and cherished mother of Bonni Gelman Harris, Mila Gelman Johnson, Duff Gelman and Karen Gelman. Adored grandmother of Nikki and Jason Harris, Jude, Devra and Ellen Gelman, and Spencer Johnson. She was dearly loved by her many relatives and friends and appreciated for her huge heart and loving ways. Her mothering soothed us all and we will always be grateful for the sacrifices she made, the consideration she gave to each of us, her deep listening and her honesty. She was truly loved and respected by all those who came to know her. We are so grateful to her for sharing herself so completely and we hope to live by her example. She will never be forgotten. The family suggests donations to the charity of your choice. Services Sunday, May 25th at 12 Noon at Levitt-Weinstein Memorial Chapel, 18840 West Dixie Highway, North Miami Beach, Florida 33180. (305-538-6371).

title: U.S., Asserting Iran Link, Bars 2 Chinese Firms
description: The United States has imposed sanctions against two Chinese companies and a handful of Chinese executives, accusing them of knowingly helping Iran make chemical weapons, Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright announced today.

title: Keep in Mind
description: MAYPOLE CELEBRATION, with maypole dancing, instruction and demonstrations, tomorrow from 1 to 3 P.M. at Children's Corner, and the INTERSCHOOL SYMPHONY ORCHESTRA, performing Sunday at 3 P.M. in the Conservatory Tent. Both events at the New York Botanical Garden, 200th Street and Southern Boulevard, Bedford Park, the Bronx. Free with admission: Adults, $3; the elderly, students and ages 6 to 16, $1; ages 5 and under, free. Information: (718) 817-8700.

title: You Can't Set Market Price for Mother Nature
description: To the Editor:

title: 'Megan' Prosecution Rests After Rape Is Described
description: A full day after he led them to Megan Kanka's body, Jesse K. Timmendequas told investigators he ''forgot to mention'' a few things, including that he had slapped and raped the 7-year-old girl, a police witness testified today.

title: Victims of Everything
description: Like you, I've seen innumerable Calvin Klein ads featuring sallow, sullen, scrawny youths. Not once have I had an overwhelming urge to rush out and buy some heroin, and probably neither have you. Yet the death of Davide Sorrenti, a 20-year-old fashion photographer who overdosed on heroin in February, is now being held up as proof that such images have the power to turn people into junkies.

title: New Colt for a Small Belmont
description: The sudden retirement of Captain Bodgit with a leg injury Wednesday left a small field of half a dozen horses booked into the Belmont Stakes yesterday. New York racing officials have been scouring the landscape for candidates to challenge Silver Charm as he stood one race short of winning the Triple Crown.

title: Voice for Change Makes Iran Vote a Real Race
description: A soft-spoken cleric whom many Iranians had not even heard of until last week has sent this country into an electoral frenzy and transformed what should have been an essentially meaningless presidential election into a major test for the ruling mullahs.

title: MTV Meets Court TV
description: Regardless of whether Timothy McVeigh is convicted in the Oklahoma City bombing or not, the Government's lawyers appear to have taken the prosecution of complex criminal cases in a whole new direction.

title: World Bank Record Is Good in Bosnia
description: To the Editor:

title: Harvard Tenure Case
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LUBY, WILLIAM J.
