description: LUBY-William J. On May 21, 1997. Most beloved husband of Lila and D.P. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81 Street, Friday and Saturday 2-5 and 7-9pm. Service Sunday, May 25 at 3:30pm at Campbell's

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RUBIN, ESTHER (ESSIE)
description: RUBIN-Esther (Essie), 94. Cherished wife of the late Arthur J. Rubin. Loving mother of Harris and Joyce, Henry and Irma, Rhoda and Gerald Segal. Devoted grandmother of Jeffrey and Ira, Steven (Laurie) and David, and Nancy (Robert) and Peter (Bryndis). Beloved great-grandmother of Laurence and Andrew Segal, and Josh Rubin. Services 1:00PM today at Gutterman's, 175 N.Long Beach Road, Rockville Centre.

title: Thomas Mallon, 53, A Finance Executive
description: Thomas F. Mallon Jr., a finance executive and trader who specialized in foreign currency futures and options, died of melanoma on Saturday in Lake Forest, Ill., his wife, Bette, said. He was 53.

title: CHRONICLE
description: PRINCE CHARLES is planning a 50th birthday party in July for CAMILLA PARKER BOWLES, the woman who has long been at the center, or at least at the edges, of his life, the London tabloid The Sun reported yesterday.

title: St. John's Loses Opener
description: After an hour-and-50-minute rain delay, St. John's pitcher Derek Adair allowed just two hits over the final four innings in the Red Storm's Atlantic Regional tournament opener today against the University of Florida.

title: Some Digital Shareholders Plan Meeting
description: Shareholders of the Digital Equipment Corporation will meet in New York next month to talk about the future of the struggling computer company and about ways it might increase its share price.

title: INSIDE
description: Teen-Agers Light Up Cigars

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  CONCEPCION, RENE
description: CONCEPCION-Rene. One year now since you left, but your smile and courage will always be with those you loved. Forever in our hearts. With love, Steven and Adolfo.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  BILDNER, PATRICIA ELMAN
description: BILDNER-Patricia Elman. 25 years have passed. So dearly remembered, so sadly missed. Love, Nina and Mossa

title: Stored Records Destroyed By Fire, Bear Stearns Says
description: The Bear Stearns Companies, which has been asked to provide information to investigators and lawyers examining the collapse of a Manhattan brokerage house last summer, was among the companies that lost records in a fire at a document storage center in Pennsylvania early this month.

title: CFM STOCK FALLS 21% ON NEWS OF INCREASED SPENDING
description: The stock of CFM Technologies Inc. fell 21 percent yesterday after the company said it would increase spending to develop new products. CFM, based in West Chester, Pa., makes cleaning equipment used in producing computer-memory chips and flat-panel displays. It said its research, development and engineering expenses rose to $2.2 million in the second quarter from $1 million a year ago. The company said it would increase spending even more as larger flat-panel displays were introduced. CFM earned $1.9 million, or 25 cents a share, for the second quarter ended April 30, compared with $625,000, or 16 cents a share, a year earlier. The earnings matched expectations. Shares of CFM Technologies fell $7.875, to $29.50.

title: The Discharge of Kelly Flinn
description: Air Force Secretary Sheila Widnall bowed to rising public anger and ridicule yesterday and called off the court-martial of Lieut. Kelly Flinn on lying and insubordination charges stemming from her adulterous affair with a married civilian. The general discharge granted to Lieutenant Flinn is less than the honorable discharge we had recommended. But it at least provides a way out of this mess for a promising officer who should never have been driven to this point, and for an embattled military culture that has a lot to learn about handling sensitive personal matters.

title: Diner's Journal
description: Warm weather at last! Time to celebrate by eating outdoors.

title: NEW VIDEO RELEASES
description: Caught

title: Art in Review
description: Knox Martin

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  CHAIFETZ, CHARLOTTE (NEE JAFFE)
description: CHAIFETZ-Charlotte (nee Jaffe). Mom, 12 years have passed since you left us. We feel your love every day. Rest in peace. With love, sons, Barry and Alan; daughterin-law, Maureen; and the family

title: Amid Much Squabbling, A Shutout for Red Wings
description: Game 4 of its Western Conference final series with Detroit would be, the Colorado Avalanche insisted, a true indicator of the team's strength and savvy. It would rank as a return to the brand of playoff hockey that brought the Stanley Cup to Colorado a year ago.

title: Guess Whom Yanks Meet Next Month
description: THERE is trouble in paradise, or at least in the Bronx. Dwight Gooden, who should be saving his life and his career every moment, had a tiff with a cabby in Texas last week. The fans are staying away from Yankee Stadium. And now the defending champions are on a four-game losing streak, what with yesterday's 8-2 loss to the Red Sox, who smacked 19 hits on three hours of sleep.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GRUETERICH, URSULA ''USCHI.''
description: GRUETERICH - Ursula ''Uschi.'' Was taken into the arms of the Lord on May 20, in Palm Beach, Florida. She immigrated from Germany to NY and became an accomplished artist. Her talents were exemplified in her oil and pastel paintings of flowers, landscapes and the underwater world. She was the loving wife of Rolf, mother of Gaby Slomka (Martin), Karin Fry (John), Peter Grueterich (Annette), grandmother of Christina and Daniela, Matthew, Sophie and Oliver. She was also the wonderful sister of Ernst Matthiensen and a cherished friend.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary yesterday about John Spencer-Churchill Guest, a retired investment banker who wrote about the Middle East, misspelled the title of his great-grandfather. He was Duke of Marlborough, not Marlboro.

title: No Headline
description: ''We have one left leg that we do not know where it belongs.''

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-12

title: Wide-Eyed Red Sox Wear Out Wells and the Yankees
description: Groggy players from the Boston Red Sox stumbled into their hotel rooms in Manhattan about 4 A.M. yesterday after losing in Chicago and then traveling to New York. They tossed and turned for a few hours before sleepwalking to Yankee Stadium at 10:30 with one victory in their last 10 games. They had 30 minutes of pre-game drills through bleary eyes to prepare for David Wells, who was tied for the highest winning percentage of anyone who has pitched in the Bronx.

title: 2d Echelon, With Cynicism
description: Some rock bands are overnight sensations; most are not. Bad timing, bad luck, an infelicitous name or songs that don't suit the peculiar needs of radio stations can keep good bands on the club and college circuit, below the radar of the mass market. Two worthwhile, hard-working bands, Failure and Poster Children, shared a bill at the Knitting Factory on Wednesday night. Failure, from Los Angeles, pondered isolation and obsession with the finesse of someone who's been brooding far too long, while Poster Children used the power of the drone to blast through its own cynicism.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WIRSING, ELSIE A.
description: WIRSING-Elsie A., age 100 of Mt. Vernon, NY on May 18, 1997. Beloved aunt of Barbara Houseman, Edward Wirsing Jr. and the late Dorothy Wirsing. Dear friend of Harold and Millicent Lohrand. Funeral service Friday, May 30, 10 am at the Wartburg Chapel, Mt Vernon, NY. Interment Lutheran Cemetery, Middle Village, New York. Visitation at the Wartburg on Friday, May 30, from 9-10 AM. For further information, please contact Burr Davis Sharpe Funeral Home, Mt. Vernon, New York.

title: Playoffs Hit a New Low As the Bulls Win Again
description: The Chicago Bulls have an image as artists, a team as fluid and graceful as a brush stroke. A masterpiece to a league full of Crayola colorings.

title: CHRONICLE
description: Despite the fact that once again SUSAN LUCCI has been bypassed for a Daytime Emmy Award, she will not be bereft of honors this year. On June 12 she is to receive the Spirit of Enterprise Award at the Women of Enterprise luncheon given by Avon Products at the Waldorf-Astoria. More than 1,400 guests are expected for the ceremony, at which Ms. Lucci will speak.

title: Woods 4 Back of Leader
description: The second leg of the Tiger Woods Does Texas tour began today a lot like the first. He stands four shots off the lead, said he is missing a vital part of his game and continues to dazzle the raucous, record crowds. And again, Woods likes his chances of winning.

title: Class Action Suit Over Strip-Search Policy
description: A woman who was strip-searched last month after being charged with disorderly conduct and resisting arrest has filed suit against the New York City government, charging that its policy of strip-searching all people arrested in Manhattan before they are taken to court is illegal.

title: Holiday on Monday
description: Memorial Day, actually May 30, will be legally observed.

title: $10 Million Gift to Princeton
description: A $10 million gift from the Leon Lowenstein Foundation will enable Princeton University to establish a center specializing in finance and economic public policy, university officials announced yesterday.

title: Lawmakers Head Home Without Passing Disaster Relief Bill
description: The House left today on a 10-day spring vacation without voting on billions of dollars in disaster relief for flood-ravaged areas from California to Minnesota.

title: Home Video
description: One advantage of home video is that it allows a long, close look at a film that may have had only fleeting exposure in theaters or on television. On Tuesday comes a perfect example: ''Paradise Lost: The Child Murders at Robin Hood Hills,'' an acclaimed documentary by Joe Berlinger and Bruce Sinofsky about the killing of three 8-year-old boys in West Memphis, Ark., in 1993 and the trials of three teen-agers, who were convicted of the crimes.

title: Frenchwomen on the Ballot Face Down Voter Sexism
description: Lyne Cohen-Solal was moving through the scented air of the Rue Mouffetard, one of the liveliest street markets in Paris, halting shoppers loading up on cheeses and strawberries and asking for votes. Just a few yards away was the man she was hoping to oust.

title: Plotters and Snoops in Old Russia
description: Elizabeth Egloff's new adaptation of ''The Devils'' is an ambitious attempt to reimagine Dostoyevsky's sprawling political novel for the theater. This is not the first time it's been tried; the Polish director Andrzej Wajda staged a brooding and apocalyptic version of the work, with its alternate English title, ''The Possessed,'' at the Yale Repertory Theater in 1974 (with a Yale Drama student named Meryl Streep in a supporting role).

title: A Jurassic Romp of Parental Mayhem
description: IT isn't the giant, carnivorous dinosaurs thundering through the jungle and pulling people apart like spaghetti that provide the scariest chills in ''The Lost World: Jurassic Park.'' It is their adorable miniature relatives known as compies (Procompsognathus triassicus) who scamper through the underbrush like a gang of famished street urchins playing cute, bloodthirsty games of hide-and-seek and follow-the-leader with their prey.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  SOMKIN, ALBERT
description: SOMKIN-Albert. 50 years apart. CEO The Somkin Group. Always remembered Forever with me-George

title: Dr. Myron Ruscoll Sharaf, 70, Educator and Psychotherapist
description: Myron Ruscoll Sharaf, biographer and interpreter of Wilhelm Reich, the Austrian-born psychiatrist and biophysicist, with whom he had an agonizingly complex personal relationship, died on May 13 while on a trip to Europe. He was 70 and lived in Newton Highlands, Mass.

title: As Primary Nears, No More Mr. Nice Guys
description: In their last public debate, with a statewide television audience and just 12 days to go before the primary, the three candidates seeking the Democratic nomination for governor abandoned any pretense at party unity tonight and sharply attacked one another.

title: Doormen's Union Hires Ex-Prosecutor
description: A buildings workers' union has hired a former organized-crime prosecutor to investigate charges that doormen and porters in New York City have often had to bribe union officials to get their jobs.

title: Push for Royalties Threatens Use of Down Syndrome Test
description: Time was, when medical researchers discovered a link between a substance produced by the body and a disease, they rushed to publish their findings in medical journals and alert the scientific world.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BOGAN, EUGENE W.
description: BOGAN-Eugene W. It is with great sadness that we note the passing of our dear friend and dedicated Trustee, Eugene Bogan. We will miss his exuberance, energy, humor and his devotion to his wife Charmain and his daughter Eushavia and to the well being of our school. The Trustees & Staff of the Brooklyn Heights Montessori School

title: Head of Circle in the Square, Bankrupt Theater, Quits Post
description: Citing personal reasons, Theodore R. Sayers resigned yesterday as chairman of the board of Circle in the Square Theater, the nonprofit theater that is fighting to return to stability after filing for bankruptcy protection.

title: Whiter Than White
description: ''What is it going to be like teaching Brown v. Board of Education,'' a law professor at the University of Texas asked, ''with no blacks in the classroom?''

title: Finding Homes for Babies
description: The State Assembly approved a plan yesterday to find homes for so-called boarder babies, who languish in hospitals when they no longer need medical care because their parents are unwilling or unable to take care of them.

title: Red Cross Strike Ends
description: American Red Cross workers voted overwhelmingly last night to end a four-day strike affecting 280 workers who draw and handle blood used in New Jersey and Pennsylvania hospitals.

title: For Now, Earnings Gap Has Stopped Widening
description: In late afternoon, as most people are heading home from work, a large, unmarked room on an upper floor at PNC Bank is just starting to buzz with activity. Among the rows of women in cubicles is Caren Good, 34, tall, thin and stylishly groomed. New to the job, she carefully slips checks into a whirring machine with her left hand, while her right records the amounts on a keyboard. Her evening's work will show up later as thousands of entries on bank statements wrapped around packets of canceled checks. For this she earns $7.10 an hour, her highest wage in years.

title: University of California Has Plan for Reversing Drop in Minority Enrollment
description: Reeling from a series of gloomy reports showing decreased minority enrollment, the University of California has announced a plan to expand its college preparatory programs significantly, focusing on students who attend the state's worst high schools.

title: Apple to Spin Off Newton Unit As Wholly Owned Subsidiary
description: Ending months of speculation about its Newton hand-held computer division, Apple Computer Inc. announced yesterday that it would spin off the division into a wholly owned subsidiary, presumably to better attract a buyer for it.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: TENNIS

title: Cigar Fad Reported to Be Recruiting Legions of Teen-Agers
description: A new trend in smoking has reached teen-agers, who are experimenting with cigars with unexpected frequency, the Federal Centers for Disease Control and Prevention said today.

title: Maman Isn't Coming Back
description: One of the most irrevocable emotional blows that could befall a small child is the sudden death of a parent. The 4-year-old title character of Jacques Doillon's heartbreaking film, ''Ponette,'' has survived a car crash that killed her mother and left the little girl with a broken arm. In the film's opening scene, her father (Xavier Beauvois) is taking Ponette (Victoire Thivisol), to live with an aunt (Claire Nebout), who has two children roughly Ponette's age. As the forlorn child with a cast on her arm clutches Yoyotte, her beloved doll, her father sternly explains to his tearful, disbelieving daughter that her mother is not coming back.

title: Tenants' Votes Don't Faze Pataki
description: For two and a half years now, Democrats have rummaged about for silver bullet issues that might sink Gov. George E. Pataki's re-election chances, from budget cuts to fund raising to transit fare hikes. Now comes the debate over rent regulations.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHWARTZ, EUGENE J.
description: SCHWARTZ-Eugene J. Devoted and beloved husband of Florence. Loving father of Carolyn Rimberg, Allan C. Schwartz and Nancy Weiner. Grandfather of Matthew, Jonathan, Alexander, Gregory, Katherine-Anne and Annabel. Funeral services at the Jewish Community Center of Harrison, Union Avenue, Harrison, New York, Sunday May 25 at 10:00 A.M.

title: Art in Review
description: Tony Feher

title: An Exquisite Empire Expands Within the Met
description: THERE'S just no doubt about it: sometimes bigger is better, and more really is more. This is certainly true of the gloriously refurbished and expanded galleries for Chinese art that made their public debut yesterday at the Metropolitan Museum of Art.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KLEIN, ERWIN L.
description: KLEIN-Erwin L. Peacefully on May 21. Loving husband of Marlys. Beloved father of Richard and Susan. Cherished father-in-law of Nina. Dear brother of Herbert and brother-in-law of Monika Klein and H. Karl Frensdorff. Adored grandfather of Andrew, Lauren and Sarah. Services on Friday, at 10 A.M., at Westchester Reform Temple, 255 Mamaroneck Road, Scarsdale, New York.

title: Disastrous Benchmarks
description: To the Editor:

title: U.S. OFFICE PRODUCTS PLANS TO BUY MAIL BOXES ETC.
description: The U.S. Office Products Company said yesterday that it would buy Mail Boxes Etc. for almost $277 million in stock, based on Wednesday's closing price, to expand into retail services aimed at small businesses. U.S. Office, a supplier of products and services to companies and schools, is to exchange one share of its stock for each of Mail Boxes Etc.'s 11.3 million shares. Shares of U.S. Office Products fell 87.5 cents yesterday, to $23.625. U.S. Office Products, based in Washington, has expanded quickly by acquiring more than 165 companies. Mail Boxes Etc., based in San Diego, has 3,300 stores and is the world's largest retail postal, business and communications services chain. Its shares rose $3 yesterday, to $22.625.

title: $25 and Under
description: If you ever wondered what makes soul food so soulful, I offer Charles' Southern-Style Kitchen in Harlem as a perfect opportunity to find out.

title: DU PONT TO SELL GRAPHICS AND PRINTING-PLATE BUSINESSES
description: E.I. du Pont de Nemours & Company agreed yesterday to sell its graphics film and offset-printing plates businesses to Bayer A.G.'s Agfa-Gevaert. The companies declined to disclose the price for the businesses, which had combined sales of almost $600 million in 1996. Du Pont said it expected a one-time charge from the sale, but the company did not elaborate. For Agfa-Gevaert, the purchase is the latest in a series of moves to increase international sales as demand in Germany dwindles. Du Pont has been selling older, less profitable businesses so it can focus on new products and form joint ventures.

title: Off-Duty Officer Is Found Shot And Critically Injured in Bronx
description: An off-duty police officer was found shot and critically wounded early yesterday outside his car in a wooded area of the Bronx.

title: Humor and 'a higher authority' help spice up a new campaign for Hebrew National franks.
description: ELEMENTS of religion like angels, clergymen, the Bible, monks and nuns have been playing an increasingly prominent role in advertising. Now a company that helped originate that trend by going right to the top of the heavenly hierarchy is returning with a good-natured pitch centered on divine intervention.

title: Out of Spotlight, Violence Tears at Mexican State
description: The dispute started with the indiscretion of two peeping Toms who crouched in the shade of a coffee tree to watch a woman bathing.

title: INSIDE METRO
description: A MOTHER'S ANGUISH -- The mother of the woman who accused Alex Kelly of rape testified of her daughter's emotional turmoil. B2.

title: Inside Photography
description: To a casual observer, Elaine Lustig Cohen seems to have led a succession of unconnected lives. Graphic designer in the 1950's and 60's. Abstract painter in the 70's and 80's. Co-manager of an antiquarian bookstore in the 70's and 80's. Photocollagist in the 90's.

title: Corrections
description: A report in the Food Notes column on Wednesday about Molyvos, a new Greek restaurant in midtown Manhattan, misstated the roles of two chefs. James Botsacos is the executive chef, not the chef de cuisine. Rick Moonen is a partner, not executive chef. He is the executive chef of Oceana.

title: Thai Airways Orders 9 Planes From Airbus
description: Airbus Industrie, the European airplane consortium, said yesterday that it had received a $1 billion order for nine planes from Thai Airways International. Thai Airways ordered four A330-300 planes, with a list price of $121 million to $129 million each, and five A300-600R planes priced at $90 million to $100 million each.

title: Far More Than an Actor or Hoofer
description: To call Donald O'Connor a song-and-dance man is like calling Shakespeare a strolling player. There may be some accuracy in the definition but it is far from complete.

title: Class of 1997 Saluted With 'Amazing Grace'
description: Wynton Marsalis had just received his honorary doctorate in fine arts at Rutgers University's 231st commencement, when the Pulitzer Prize-winning jazz and classical musician reached under his dark robe and withdrew his trumpet. To the surprise of most and the delight of all, he rose and played a soaring version of ''Amazing Grace.''

title: School Overspending
description: To the Editor:

title: NEW VIDEO RELEASES
description: The Mirror Has Two Faces

title: Playing God And Politics With Death
description: A TERRIBLE sound was heard on Long Island yesterday, the chilling thud of earth covering a coffin as Police Officer Anthony Sanchez was sent on his journey through forever. Miles away, in lower Manhattan, the absence of sound was what stood out: silence on whether the District Attorney, Robert M. Morgenthau, will seek the death penalty for the man accused of killing Officer Sanchez on Monday in a shootout.

title: A Special Delivery: Jones Wins His Eighth
description: In the first hours of her life today, Gabriela Schilling honored the tradition of all sons and daughters and robbed her father of sleep. But unlike other new dads, who might enjoy a weary and happy collapse into bed, Curt Schilling had to pitch for the Philadelphia Phillies some 12 hours after the early-morning birth of his first daughter.

title: 'Cinderella' With Breezes On the Fringe
description: Performances in two relatively minor roles saved the day as American Ballet Theater rushed like a lemming to the brink Tuesday night and Wednesday afternoon at the Metropolitan Opera House in that deadly lure known as ''Cinderella.'' The ballet seldom works, though it seems to fill theaters dependably, and the Ballet Theater production by Ben Stevenson is very thin. But Ethan Stiefel and John Selya were able to rise above it all, dancing the Jester and the lead Stepsister, respectively, at both performances.

title: Taking Ford Taurus Into the Next Century
description: The Ford Motor Company recently entered the field of high-mileage, low-emissions cars when it announced that it planned to develop and test the P2000 family of high-technology, midsize vehicles.

title: Farewell in Blue: 10,000 Gather to Bury Police Officer Slain in Chelsea Robbery
description: Bagpipes bleated a spare, tremulous rendition of ''Amazing Grace,'' thousands of blue-suited men raised their right hands in a formal salute and six pall bearers balanced a coffin high atop their shoulders. These grand gestures were the customary due of a New York City police officer killed in the line of duty, and no less powerful for their predictability.

title: Pilots in a Crash Weren't Told of Precautions, Board Says
description: Before a Comair turboprop crashed in icy conditions near Detroit on Jan. 9, the manufacturer had determined that the plane could become uncontrollable if flown slowly in those conditions and had changed its manual to recommend that pilots increase airspeed to avoid the risk. But the airline did not pass the information along to the Comair crew, the National Transportation Safety Board said on Wednesday night.

title: Gooden in the Hot Seat Over Scrape With Cabdriver
description: Dwight Gooden was involved in a fight with a cabdriver in Arlington, Tex., in the early hours last Saturday after what the Yankee pitcher said was his refusal to pay a $5 fare from a strip club to the team's hotel.

title: McVeigh Defense Team Suggests Real Bomber Was Killed in Blast
description: The lawyers for Timothy J. McVeigh opened his defense today by raising the possibility that the real Oklahoma City bomber had died in the blast.

title: U.S. Presses Congo Too Soon on Elections
description: To the Editor:

title: Offering by Hartford Life
description: Hartford Life Inc. said yesterday that it had sold 23 million common shares for $28.25 apiece, or $649 million, in an initial public offering of stock. The unit of Hartford Financial Services Group Inc. had expected the shares, which represent a 16.8 percent stake, to be offered at $24 to $27 each. The stock opened at $33 a share on the New York Stock Exchange and closed at $32.125. Hartford Life, based in Simsbury, Conn., is an insurance and financial company with variable annuity sales last year of $9.4 billion.

title: Dow Has Decline of 32.56 on Profit Taking
description: Stocks fell yesterday, hurt by profit taking and by rising bond yields.

title: Shortchanging Students at Hostos
description: Ann Reynolds, Chancellor of the City University of New York, took a necessary step when she ordered Hostos Community College in the Bronx to reinstate a writing competency test that the college had sought to de-emphasize because so many students failed it. But the Chancellor and the board of trustees will need to go further still, forcing change on a faculty that is clearly failing to do its job.

title: Japanese Companies Take New Look at Western Management Ideas
description: Japanese executives, who once sharply criticized American executives for being overpaid and for focusing too much on short-term results, now seem to be adopting some American management ideas.

title: MCCORMICK SAYS IT IS UNDER INVESTIGATION BY F.T.C.
description: McCormick & Company said yesterday that it was under investigation by the Federal Trade Commission over how it sells its spices to retailers. A company spokesman, Mac Barrett, said that the commission was looking into whether McCormick's use of exclusivity clauses in certain contracts with retailers violated antitrust laws by stifling competition. F.T.C. officials would not comment on the investigation, which is the third such inquiry into retailing practices to be made public in the last month. McCormick, based in Sparks, Md., controls more than 40 percent of the United States retail spice market.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Dow Falls 32 Points, But Small Stocks Gain

title: Art in Review
description: 'Queens Artists'

title: Jilted Duo's Sweet Revenge
description: In the future, some enterprising film scholar will probably make a big to-do over the fact that ''Addicted to Love,'' the jarringly uneven new screwball comedy starring Meg Ryan and Matthew Broderick, features the camera obscura. That scholar might interpret the movie, the first feature film directed by Griffin Dunne, as a mocking cinematic allegory about movies, voyeurism and spying in an age when electronic surveillance and the inquiring media have eroded personal privacy. Unfortunately, good photography metaphors aren't necessarily synonymous with good movies.

title: Elbridge Durbrow, U.S. Diplomat, Dies at 93
description: Elbridge Durbrow, a retired Foreign Service officer who served in Moscow as the wartime Soviet ally turned into cold-war antagonist and who later led the United States Embassy in South Vietnam at the onset of America's longest war, died last Friday at his home in Walnut Creek, Calif.

title: Magazine Executive Gets a New Post
description: Jack Kliger, one of three executive vice presidents at Conde Nast Publications, is leaving that post, effective June 2, to become executive vice president of Parade Publications. Both are units of Advance Publications in New York.

title: Glavine Now Highest-Paid Pitcher
description: The Braves now have three-fourths of their vaunted pitching rotation signed through the end of the century after signing TOM GLAVINE, the pitcher with the most victories (111) in the major leagues over the last six seasons, to a four-year deal reportedly worth $34 million. The deal announced yesterday makes Glavine the highest-paid pitcher in baseball.

title: U.S. Budget Surplus Hit Record in April
description: The United States Government posted a record budget surplus in April as the vibrant economy generated strong revenue, according to the Treasury.

title: Dinosaurs at the Museum: Art Imitating Art Imitating Life
description: In a radical departure from its usually scholarly dinosaur exhibitions, the American Museum of Natural History tomorrow opens its flashiest and most commercial show yet. With ear-splitting noises, life-size models and theatrical lighting, the show resembles a movie set more than a museum hall, and children are certain to be delighted.

title: Art in Review
description: Wayne Thiebaud

title: On Stage, and Off
description: Brother, Can You Spare a Vote?

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEISSMAN, IRVING
description: WEISSMAN-Irving. Park East Synagogue mourns the passing of Irving Weissman, beloved brother of our devoted member and Sisterhood Trustee Florence Zornberg. To Flo, her husband Ed and the entire family our sincere condolences. Rabbi Arthur Schneier Michael Scharf, President Jerry Forst, Vice President Jack Rosen, Vice President

title: Pilot Facing Adultery Charge Agrees to a General Discharge
description: The country's first female B-52 pilot has agreed to accept the Air Force's offer of a general discharge rather than face a court-martial for adultery, lying and other charges.

title: When 7 Are 10 in 3 Guises During One 165-Minute Set
description: Mere arithmetic didn't concern the Magnificent Seven, who included 10 musicians at the Mercury Lounge on Monday night. The group is a package tour, performing a continuous 165-minute set in three guises: as Mark Eitzel's band, as Scott McCaughey's Minus Five (not necessarily a quintet) and as the instrumental band Tuatara, led by Barrett Martin and Justin Harwood.

title: Big changes are in the offing for the nation's stock markets.
description: IN the last two decades, innovation and entrepreneurship have transformed the landscape of American stock markets. Now the Securities and Exchange Commission is trying to catch up and change a regulatory structure that is clearly straining to cope with the changes.

title: Rosemary Clooney, Simple and Emotional
description: Rosemary Clooney invests song lyrics with such a powerful sense of emotional solidity that she can make trite-sounding phrases seem profound. Not one for arty reinvention, she is the soul of simplicity who locates the salt-of-the earth essence of a lyric and brings it to the surface.

title: Tip Leads to Suspect In Bronx Bank Robberies
description: Acting on a tip, the police arrested a Bronx man who is suspected in a monthlong series of bank robberies, most of them in the Bronx, investigators said last night.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Sylvan Roads That Lead to Bitter Protests
description: They are only pretty little forest roads, after all, the kind that inspired Robert Frost, the kind that bring memories of bumping happily over canopied ruts on a bike. Or family outings jouncing by car past lacy walls of birches to a beloved pond or hunting ground.

title: Cold, Dry Weather in Brazil Keeps Coffee Prices Climbing
description: Coffee prices continued to climb yesterday, bolstered by concerns that dry, cold weather in Brazil could damage the world's largest crop.

title: NEW VIDEO RELEASES
description: Unhook the Stars

title: In a Shift, New York Won't Try to Tax Sales on Indian Lands
description: Facing a bitter standoff with the state's Indians, Gov. George E. Pataki announced today that the state would abandon its efforts to collect taxes on gasoline and cigarette sales on Indian reservations.

title: Times Appoints Managing Editor and 2 Deputies
description: Appointments of a managing editor and two deputy managing editors at The New York Times were announced yesterday by Joseph Lelyveld, the executive editor.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHOENBERGER, JEROME W.
description: SCHOENBERGER-Jerome W., on May 19, 1997. Formerly with NYC Health Department. Beloved husband of the late Beverly. Devoted father of Ruth and Charles and dear grandfather of Damian, Sarah, Dana and Daniel.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEISS, JEROME A.
description: WEISS-Jerome A. On May 21, 1997. Beloved husband of his devoted wife Ellen. Loving father of Dr. Michael A. Dear father-in-law of Katherine. Devoted brother-inlaw, uncle and grand-uncle. Graduate of Columbia University and Fordham Law School. Proud recipient of an award by the Brooklyn Bar Association for fifty years of service as an attorney dedicated to the principle of justice for all. Service Friday 1:15 P.M., at ''The Riverside'', 76 St. and Amsterdam.

title: Illegal Chinese Race to Get Toehold in Hong Kong
description: In the still midnight air, only the coils of razor wire glinting in the harsh yellow floodlights hinted at the divide between the vast poverty of China and the compact neon glitter of Hong Kong.

title: Goats Deemed a Nuisance
description: Nine miniature goats, including three named after Harrison Ford, Denzel Washington and Princess Diana, have become a public nuisance in Middle Township, officials say.

title: Senate Unwilling to Amend Budget Resolution
description: As House members packed their bags to leave town, the Senate today voted down the last major amendment to the budget resolution as it moved toward a Congressional commitment to balance the budget by 2002.

title: Williams Set to Make Grand Slam Debut
description: VENUS WILLIAMS, the 16-year-old American who in part because of a restricted playing schedule has yet to deliver on the hype about her ability, will make her Grand Slam debut next week at the French Open, which starts Monday at Roland Garros.

title: Sentimental Coal Dust With a Brass Band
description: You won't have any trouble separating the heroes from the villains in Mark Herman's film ''Brassed Off,'' a politically charged British comedy whose working-class characters smile bravely through their coal-dusted tears. The good guys are the working-class families of Grimley, a tightly knit Yorkshire coal-mining village whose brass band is the pride of the community. The bad guys are the duplicitous Tory Government officials who have instituted a pit-closing program that is throwing thousands of miners across Britain out of work.

title: Warner-Lambert Deal
description: The Warner-Lambert Company has purchased the 66 percent of Jouveinal Group of France that it did not already own, partly to market its cholesterol-lowering drug Lipitor better. Terms were not disclosed. Jouveinal, which is closely held, has a 200-member sales force. The French Government cleared Lipitor last month for sale and is scheduled to approve pricing by the end of 1997.

title: Thurmond Near Record For Service
description: Extolling the virtues of fresh fruit, sturdy genes and daily calisthenics, Senator Strom Thurmond, the oldest person ever to serve as a member of Congress, geared up today for another record-breaking moment.

title: Albright Outlines Moves to 'Renew Momentum' in Bosnia
description: Fearing that the American-led efforts to forge peace in the Balkans have stalled, Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright said today that the United States remained deeply committed to supporting a stable, multi-ethnic state in Bosnia and announced a series of symbolic, if small, initiatives to revive the peace efforts.

title: Bob Dole Is Not a Bank
description: House Speaker Newt Gingrich's latest plan to pay his $300,000 ethics fine is an improvement over the scheme he announced a month ago, to borrow the entire amount from former Senator Bob Dole. But it is still not a clean deal, given Mr. Dole's continuing role as the Speaker's personal banker.

title: Another Blow To Rangers: Graves Hurting
description: Add another name to the list of Rangers nursing injuries. This time it is Adam Graves, normally a left wing, who has been playing center against Eric Lindros and his Legion of Doom line in the Eastern Conference finals of the Stanley Cup playoffs.

title: Bids on Chrysler Building
description: Donald Trump, TrizecHahn Corp. and Vornado Realty Trust have each said they would bid to acquire the Chrysler Building.

title: Woman Recants Claim of Rape
description: A Manhattan woman who said she was raped on affluent Beekman Place on the East Side last week made up the story to seek attention, the police said yesterday.

title: Clinton Puts Off Effort on Trade Accords
description: Just two weeks after traveling to Mexico and Central America to renew his pledge to expand the North American Free Trade Agreement, President Clinton has bowed to political necessities and postponed until the fall his effort to get authority to negotiate further trade accords, Administration officials said today.

title: Restaurants
description: I have never met Johannes Sanzin, but after a few meals at his new restaurant, 131 Duane Street, I feel I know him.

title: From the Trove of a Many-Sided Connoisseur
description: Throughout much of the second half of this century, the name of Alice Tully (1902-1993) has stood for a particular presence in New York City. She never sought any kind of personal attention, but there is the concert hall in Lincoln Center that bears her name. Singers and singing were dear to her, and she knew a great deal about them. It was a joy to her that more and more of them, worldwide, found an ideal venue in Alice Tully Hall.

title: CBS President Resigns Over Revamping
description: Peter Lund, the president of the CBS television network, has resigned after being informed that he would no longer oversee CBS's television stations division, high-level executives within the company said yesterday.

title: Harrington Slows Down To Speak About Trials
description: Scott Harrington does not mind risking his life to make the lineup of the Indianapolis 500. He has done it twice already. It's just that he doesn't care to do it if he really doesn't have to.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DE GRASSE, CHARLES IRA
description: DE GRASSE-Charles Ira, 74, died on Wednesday, May 21 at his late Jenkintown, PA residence. Mr. de Grasse is survived by his mother, Mildred Goulding O'Connell (Hyannis, MA) and two sisters, Eleanor de Grasse McCue (Kissimmee, FL) and Irene de Grasse Valenti (Woburn, MA), five nieces and four nephews and many, many friends. A memorial Mass will be said at Immaculate Conception Church, 604 West Avenue, Jenkintown, PA., at 11:00 AM on Saturday, May 31. No flowers, please- Fox Chase Cancer Center, 7701 Burholme Avenue, Philadelphia, PA. 19111 would welcome gifts in his name.

title: First Negative Spot Attacks Opponent's Record in Congress
description: The campaign of James E. McGreevey, a state senator, Mayor of Woodbridge and a candidate for the Democratic nomination for governor, has released ''Two Democrats,'' a 30-second commercial. It is being broadcast in the southern region of the state, where one of Mr. McGreevey's opponents, Robert E. Andrews, is a Congressman.

title: In a School Gym, Professor Clinton Presides
description: Equipped with a passage from ''Charlotte's Web,'' a mathematical word problem and his studiously fatherly manner, President Clinton played teacher in a high school gymnasium here today, leading a handpicked crowd through a seminar on his proposals for improving education.

title: Jody Donohue to Sell Marketing Agency
description: Jody Donohue, president at Jody Donohue Associates in New York, said yesterday that she would sell her public relations and marketing agency to two top executives there, effective June 1. Terms were not disclosed. After the sale, Joan Deignan, 51, executive vice president, will become chief executive, and Linda Mann, 49, also executive vice president, will become president. Ms. Donohue, 61, will become a consultant to the agency.

title: Albert Stresses Innocence
description: Marv Albert yesterday reiterated his innocence on charges that he forcibly sodomized and assaulted a woman in an Arlington, Va., hotel room in February. The NBC sportscaster also said the police and prosecutors did not interview him about the charges or talk to him before his indictment was made public Tuesday.

title: Whose Democracy?
description: To the Editor:

title: CHAPARRAL STEEL STOCK UP 15% AFTER UNSOLICITED OFFER
description: The shares of the Chaparral Steel Company rose 15 percent yesterday after the company received an unsolicited offer from Texas Industries to buy the 15 percent of stock it does not already own. Texas Industries offered to pay $14.25 in cash, or $60.7 million, for the 4.26 million shares held by minority shareholders. Chaparral, based in Midlothian, Tex., is a maker of recycled steel products. Its shares rose $2 yesterday, to $14.875. Texas Industries closed unchanged at $23.625. Chaparral set up a special committee to evaluate the offer.

title: Running for New Jersey Governor With Rolodex and Stepfather's Fame
description: Hustling into an apartment complex for the elderly, the candidate extended a hand to anyone who passed.

title: Sexual Harassment Suit Filed Against Liquor Importer and a Marketing Firm
description: The Federal Government filed a sexual harassment lawsuit yesterday against a liquor importer and a marketing firm, both based in New Rochelle, N.Y., charging that top executives at Sidney Frank Importing and All States Promotions kissed and groped and made improper advances toward more than 100 women working as models for the companies.

title: Giuliani Welcomes Back Labor Negotiator as a Top Aide
description: Randy L. Levine, who has served as chief labor negotiator for both the Giuliani administration and Major League Baseball, is returning to City Hall as a deputy mayor in the next few days, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani announced yesterday.

title: Locked in His Body, but Refusing to Let His Spirit Die
description: THE DIVING BELL AND THE BUTTERFLY

title: ZIONS BANCORPORATION TO BUY SUN STATE CAPITAL
description: Zions Bancorporation said yesterday that it had agreed to buy the Sun State Capital Corporation for about $37 million, a move that strengthens its presence in Nevada. The closely held Sun State is to merge its Sun State Bank subsidiary into the Nevada State Bank of Zions. The combined business is to be called the Nevada State Bank, with 36 branches in and around Las Vegas, where Sun State is based. The agreement calls for Zions, based in Salt Lake City, to pay at least half of the $37 million in stock. Shares of Zions fell $1.375 yesterday, to $31.375.

title: For CBS, Programs Old, New and Borrowed
description: Taking the next step to rebuild its prime-time lineup, CBS announced a conservative fall schedule yesterday, introducing seven shows, only five of them new to television.

title: Oppenheimer in Shuffling Of Its Senior Management
description: Oppenheimer & Company, which has had unsuccessful talks recently with several potential suitors, has shuffled its senior management and formed an operating committee in an attempt to recognize a new generation of executives and to organize its businesses better.

title: Managed Care Protection
description: The State Senate approved a bill yesterday that would extend protections now available to members of health maintenance organizations to people covered by other forms of managed care.

title: A Century Sweeps By, Reflected in Still Life
description: IN the 1930's and 40's, the Museum of Modern Art created a splendid pyramid called modernism. Magnificent in scale, symbolic of heroic effort, it incorporated brilliant innovations at nearly every level. Picasso and Matisse were at the top. After them came Braque, Leger, Duchamp, Miro and so on.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RUTH, JOAN HIRSCH
description: RUTH-Joan Hirsch. On May 20, 1997. Beloved wife of the late Jacob. Dear aunt of Barbara R. Kurtin and Philip F. Ruth. Loving siser-in-law of Jean and the late Donald. Dear cousin of Jill Roth Ueland. Service Sunday, 12 Noon, at ''The Riverside'', 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Giuliani to Step Up Pressure On Pataki Over Rent Stance
description: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani will take a more aggressive public stance against Gov. George E. Pataki's proposal to soften the state's rent regulations, beginning with his weekly radio address on Friday, and is planning a trip here to pressure state lawmakers to keep the current system, City Hall aides and state lawmakers said today.

title: Group Plan Gives Florida Children Access to Affordable Health Care
description: In the Durrance household there were no catastrophic health needs, just the run-of-the-mill bad cough, head stitches and school-required physical examinations and hepatitis shots.

title: Some Progress Is Reported in Tobacco Talks
description: Negotiators in the tobacco talks have tentatively agreed on the outlines of several important regulatory and legal issues involving smoking but a number of hurdles remain, several people close to the talks said.

title: Officials of Bank Tied to Scandal to Resign
description: The chairman, president and five other top executives at the Dai-Ichi Kangyo Bank said today that they would resign after police raided the bank seeking evidence that it loaned $260 million to a reputed gangster.

title: Price Decline In Treasuries Continues
description: Treasury prices fell yesterday for the second consecutive session, as investors grew concerned that the economy was still growing fast enough to move the Federal Reserve toward another increase in interest rates.

title: Trial of Youth Held in Death Of His Parents Goes to Jury
description: A jury began deliberations today in the trial of an 18-year-old man on charges of murdering his parents, with his younger brother as the main witness against him.

title: Art in Review
description: George Segal

title: Herbert Hoover Jr., 79, Company Head
description: Herbert W. Hoover Jr., a former chairman of the Hoover Company, the vacuum cleaner maker that his grandfather founded at the turn of the century, died on Monday in Mount Sinai Hospital in Miami Beach. He lived in Bal Harbour, Fla., and was 79.

title: Rockets Missing Point In Series Against Jazz
description: Either they aren't warmed up yet, or three is a crowd.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GREGG, DR. DOROTHY
description: GREGG-Dr. Dorothy. The Women's Forum records with profound sorrow the death of its longtime, esteemed member and colleague, Dorothy Gregg, and extends condolences to her devoted husband, Paul Scott, and their family. Gail Blanke, President

title: From a Handkerchief to Judaic Treasures
description: WHEN Pauline Schloss married Sigmund H. Stonehill on Feb. 9, 1869, the wedding was the first to be held at the new Temple Emanu-El building on Fifth Avenue at 43d Street. Written up as one of the ''high life'' ceremonies of the year by The New York Herald, it was followed by a reception at Lyric Hall on Sixth Avenue for 150 guests, and then a ball attended by nearly a thousand.

title: When the Gift Plaque Outlasts the Gift
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEAHY, MICHAEL G. (GERRY)
description: LEAHY-Michael G. (Gerry), on May 21, 1997, age 80. Devoted husband of Elizabeth (Lily). Beloved father of Geraldine, Thomas, Anne Elizabeth (deceased), Frances and Michael. Survived by his sister, Katherine Colleran, and many nieces and nephews, particularly Jack. Loving father-in-law of Michael D. Nutley, Diana Leahy, John Hanly, and Nancy Kelly Leahy. Beloved grandpa of Michael, Tara, Chrissie, and Katie Nutley. Jennifer, Amy, Thomas Daniel, and Diana Leahy; John, Veronica, and Lauren Henley; Kelly Anne, Mary, Michael Francis, and Daniel Joseph Leahy. Uncle Gerard and Grandpa Gerry to countless others. Proud 50 year member Local Union 608 of the United Brotherhood of Carpenters and Joiners of America. Past President of Sligo Men's Association, Naval Veteran of WWII. Reposing, 2-4, 7-9 PM, Friday, Alexander-Tuthill Funeral Home, Route 25A, Wading River. Funeral Mass, Saturday, May 24, 9 AM, St. John the Baptist R.C. Church, Wading River. Interment St. Raymonds Cemetery, Bronx, N.Y. In lieu of flowers remembrance gifts may be made to American Diabetes Assn. or United Cerebral Palsy Foundation.

title: A Night of Anthony LaPaglia
description: If you flip channels on Sunday night, it might seem that you've stumbled across some strange new programming strategy: all Anthony LaPaglia all the time. It's not your imagination. Through an accident that can't possibly make the actor happy, he will compete with himself when the Showtime movie ''The Garden of Redemption'' overlaps the opening installment of a mini-series that concludes the first-rate but failed ABC series ''Murder One.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  POVZEA, FLORENCE
description: POVZEA-Florence. You were the best. With all our love, your friends at NSI. Funeral at Boulevard Chapels, 1450 Broadway, Hewlett, New York, Friday May 23 at 11:30 AM.

title: CHRONICLE
description: A nugget of happy news for the Kennedy family: COURTNEY KENNEDY HILL, 40, a daughter of Robert F. Kennedy, gave birth to a girl yesterday morning at Georgetown University Hospital in Washington. The baby has not yet been named.

title: Lott's Unmilitary Mind
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RUBINROTH, MARTIN
description: RUBINROTH-Martin. The Officers, Trustees and members of the Forest Hills Jewish Center mourn the untimely death of Martin Rubinroth, former Synagogue Vice President, Trustee and former Ritual Committee Chairman. May his memory always be a source of blessing and may his family be granted comfort and strength. Rabbi Gerald C. Skolnik Cantor Erno Grosz Carl Seldin Koerner, President

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KIVEL, BARNEY
description: KIVEL-Barney. Devoted husband of Mary. Dear brother of Max. Beloved father of Mel, Stanley and Barry and loving grandfather. Former President and spirtual leader of Temple Beth Israel, Danielson, CT. Active member of Temple Gates of Prayer, Flushing, NY. Services Friday at 1:45 PM, Sinai Chapels, 162-05 Horace Harding Expressway, Queens.

title: COLLEGE LACROSSE REPORT
description: Final Four at Maryland

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GILMAN, ANDREW M.
description: GILMAN-Andrew M. Peacefully on May 21st. Loving husband of Maureen; devoted father to Susan and Laura. Survived by brothers, sisters, nieces and nephews. Memorial mass at 5:30 on Tuesday May 27, at St. Jean Baptiste Church, 76th St. and Lexington Ave. In lieu of flowers donations to the Fresh Air Fund.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ALLEN, MILDRED
description: ALLEN-Mildred, 89. Beloved wife of the late Charles, Jr. and loving mother of the late Arthur. Cherished sister of Gladys & Al Rudner. Adoring grandmother of Cynthia and Karl Goodkin and the late Arthur, Jr. Great-grandmother of Devin. Beloved aunt of Jane and Maurice Sherman, Judy and Jerry Kessel. ''To live in the heart is never to be forgotten''. A private funeral was held May 22, 1997.

title: A Deal Is Near With Irabu, But Tampering Is Charged
description: Just as the Yankees are said to be on the verge of signing Hideki Irabu to a four-year, $13 million contract, Japanese baseball officials have asked Major League Baseball to investigate whether the club tampered with the pitcher before it had rights to him.

title: Pitchers Start Down The Long Road Back
description: There once was a doubleheader played in this town that featured Sandy Koufax and Don Drysdale against Jim Bunning and Chris Short.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: SYNBIOTICS CORP., San Diego, a provider of animal health-care diagnostics and vaccines, will buy Rhone-Poulenc S.A.'s veterinary diagnostics unit for $14.98 million in cash and shares.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MOFENSON, JACK L.
description: MOFENSON-Jack L. Sales Executive. On May 20, 1997. Age 96. Formerly of Mineola, New York and Deerfield Beach, Florida. Devoted husband of the late Theresa. Loving father of Howard and Robert and grandfather of Lynne, Jeffrey Glenn and Dayna and great-grandfather of Jeffrey, Jessica and Courtney. A private funeral was held on May 22, 1997.

title: Pakistan May Consider Suing U.S. Over Aircraft
description: Pakistan's Foreign Minister told the Clinton Administration this week that if no progress is made over the next few months on the repayment of $650 million Washington owes Pakistan for undelivered aircraft, the Islamabad Government will have to consider suing the United States.

title: New Jersey Airmen See Pilot in Harsh Light
description: There was little sympathy here today for First Lieut. Kelly Flinn, thrown out of the Air Force this week in a painful, public collision of adultery and military law. At McGuire Air Force Base here, her fellow service members saw her acknowledged transgressions in a harsher light, it seems, than the public in general.

title: Gigante Moved To 2d Hospital
description: Mount Sinai Medical Center persuaded a Federal judge yesterday to remove a suspected Mafia boss from its domain. As a result, Vincent Gigante took an ambulance ride from Mount Sinai, where he had been confined under guard but in luxury, to New York Downtown Hospital, where he is now detained in more egalitarian surroundings.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL 3-7

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KORNFELD, MAGDA RANSCHBURG
description: KORNFELD-Magda Ranschburg. On May 22, 1997, age 94. Of Medford, NJ. Wife of the late Dr. Werner Kornfeld, mother of Alice Buskin of Woodbridge, N.J., and Henry and his wife Sylvia of East Norwich, New York. Seven grandchildren, 7 great grandchildren. Numerous cousins, nieces and nephews. Services private. Memorial contributions to: Holocaust Memorial Museum, 100 Raoul Wallenberg Place S.W., Washington, D.C. 20024-2150.

title: Basketball Rules Allow for Some Discretion
description: To the Editor:

title: Trust Audiences, Christopher Reeve Tells Juilliard Graduates
description: Delivering the commencement address at the Juilliard School in Manhattan yesterday, Christopher Reeve, the actor and director, offered the students a warning.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Stocks Rise to New Highs In Broad but Quiet Rally

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  YOUNG, ALEXANDER W.
description: YOUNG-Alexander W. The New York Dermatological Society notes with deep regret the passing of our esteemed and beloved colleague, Alexander W. Young, M.D. on May 10, 1997. Dr. Young was the first Director of the Dermatology Service at St. Luke's Hospital until he resigned in 1995. He also was the Director of the Cutaneous Vulvar Service in New York. Dr. Young was Clinical Professor of Dermatology at the College of Physicians and Surgeons of Columbia University.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BYARS, JAMES LEE
description: BYARS-James Lee, internationally renowned artist whose work concentrated on minimal hermetic forms, reduction towards essence and absence, and an acute sense of the ephemeral, died on Thursday, May 23, 1997, at the Anglo-American hospital in Cairo, Egypt. He was 65 years old and his primary residence was in Santa Fe, New Mexico. He is survived by his wife Gwendolyn F. Dunaway of Santa Fe, New Mexico and two step daughters, Gwendolyn D. West of Houston, Texas and Jorie M. Waterman of Santa Fe, New Mexico. A memorial service will be announced at a later date.

title: Big Board Firms' Earnings Off 5%
description: The earnings of securities firms that trade stocks on the New York Stock Exchange fell 5 percent in the first quarter of 1997.

title: Foreign Aid for the Port Authority
description: One of my earliest memories of the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey is watching Austin Tobin, the agency's executive director for three decades, testify before a state legislative committee in 1965. Mr. Tobin carefully reminded his listeners that the authority, while a public agency, received no tax money and operated ''just like a corporation.''

title: As Iran Votes for a President, Choice Is Tradition or Change
description: Iranians went to the polls today to choose a new President, many of them convinced they were casting votes that would influence the future course of the 18-year-old Islamic revolution.

title: Criticism Never Rains But It Pours
description: AS corporate logos go, the red Travelers umbrella ranks with icons of instant recognition like Prudential's rock or Disney's mouse ears. ''It's a beautiful device,'' said Tom De Vito, a retired ad man. ''The minute you see the red umbrella, you say Travelers.''

title: Emergency Landings Are Cited : Asia Airbus to Get Change in Engine
description: Rolls-Royce PLC said Friday that it would replace potentially faulty gearbox bearings on all of its Trent 700 engines that are used to power Airbus A330 aircraft owned by three Asian carriers.

title: Corrections
description: A corporate symbol in Business Day on Thursday with a chart showing the Unocal Corporation's increased investment in Myanmar and other foreign countries was published in error. Along with a chain of gasoline stations that display it, the symbol -- the ''76'' logo, by itself -- was sold by Unocal to the Tosco Corporation in November.

title: Broad Rally Lifts Last of the Laggard Indexes to a Record
description: The stock market rolled to new highs across the board yesterday, a sign that many of this year's laggards -- including technology and small-company stocks -- are catching up to the big names in the marquee indexes: the Dow Jones industrial average and the Standard & Poor's 500.

title: Driver Says Gooden Is to Blame
description: The attorney for the cabdriver who fought with Dwight Gooden last Saturday in Arlington, Tex., said last night that the altercation occurred after the Yankee pitcher failed to persuade a woman who was in the taxi to come to his hotel room, and then declined to pay a fare of $4.20.

title: Holiday on Monday
description: Memorial Day, actually May 30, will be legally observed.

title: When Setting Limits Is Right for Mentally Ill
description: To the Editor:

title: Sphinx Is Poker-Faced, but Is It Sitting on a Secret?
description: By year's end, the Great Sphinx of Giza is to re-emerge in unfettered glory, stripped of scaffolding for the first time in a decade on the completion of the most extensive repair work undertaken since it was unburied from the sands by French explorers a century and a half ago.

title: New York, Smog Trader
description: To the Editor:

title: Let Angry Taxpayers Realize Their Wish
description: To the Editor:

title: More Retirees Discover Small-Town South
description: There are no beaches here. No mountains. The public parks are equipped for softball, not shuffleboard. If there is a regular mah-jongg game anywhere in town, it is well hidden.

title: Affiliate of Big Japanese Securities Firm Fails
description: The Yamaichi Securities Company said today that it would close a debt-ridden affiliated securities firm, the first Japanese brokerage house to fail in 17 years.

title: Award Is Cut In Dow Jones Libel Case
description: A Federal judge in Houston yesterday threw out most of a $222.7 million award against Dow Jones & Company in what was the largest libel verdict in history.

title: No Headline
description: ''My friends in New York say, 'Isn't there a big culture shock down there?' And I say, 'Yeah, people here are polite, and for no good reason.'''

title: Another Bush Irks the President
description: President Clinton told Gov. George W. Bush of Texas this month that the Administration would fight his innovative plan to streamline applications for public assistance. By providing no compelling reason for his opposition, Mr. Clinton breeds suspicion that his real motive is to protect municipal union members, which the Texas plan threatens, and to deny a policy triumph to Mr. Bush, a potential Republican threat to Vice President Al Gore's Presidential ambitions.

title: 'Part of Me Has Died,' Pilot Says in Apology
description: Even as she asked in vain for an honorable discharge, First Lieut. Kelly J. Flinn said in a letter to the Secretary of the Air Force that having to leave the service was a punishment she would carry to her grave.

title: U.S. Is Seeking To Strip 5,000 Of Citizenship
description: The Clinton Administration will seek to strip the citizenship of nearly 5,000 immigrants who were wrongly naturalized in an immigration drive last year, Federal officials said today.

title: A Team With Heart
description: To the Editor:

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: TENNIS

title: Laura Ashley Stock Falls After Resignations
description: Shares of Laura Ashley Holdings P.L.C. fell yesterday after the company said two senior executives had resigned, a month after the clothing retailer warned that 1998 profit would be lower than expected. The merchandise director, Julie Ramshaw, and the British and Europe finance director, Dominic Lavelle, left Laura Ashley this week.

title: INTEL AND SAMSUNG TO COLLABORATE ON PROJECTS
description: The Intel Corporation and the Samsung Electronics Corporation said yesterday that they would collaborate on future products, joining Intel's computer technology with Samsung's expertise in consumer electronics. The two companies will work together on new products that marry Intel's microprocessor and personal computer expertise with Samsung's consumer products, Intel said. The agreement does not cover any specific products. With the convergence of PC's, the Internet, television and entertainment, the companies said they wanted to create new products that combine these uses. Intel's chips run 85 percent of the world's personal computers.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: DELCO REMY AMERICA INC., Anderson, Ind., a maker of automotive parts, will shut down two plants in Mississippi next year, idling about 300 workers.

title: Economic Outlook in France: Gloom
description: For years, Faubourg Saint Antoine has been the heart of a trendy and often quirky furniture district, a long stretch of boutiques that cater to tastes from Louis XVI to Art Deco and draw customers from all over Paris.

title: Affluent Town Resents Poverty Aid
description: The docks at this affluent Lake Michigan resort are lined with the powerboats and yachts of wealthy Chicago and Detroit families. The bed-and-breakfasts are stately mansions where rooms go for as much as $165 a night. When McDonald's tried to open a restaurant here a decade ago, planners refused to grant the permits, successfully arguing that fast food just did not fit with the town's cultivated quaintness.

title: Seneca Unit to Sell Assets
description: The Seneca Foods Corporation has agreed to sell assets of its glass fruit business to the Pro-Fac Cooperative's Curtice Burns Foods unit for an undisclosed amount. The fruit and vegetable processing company said the business makes candied fruit and maraschino cherries. Seneca recently acquired the business from the Pillsbury unit of Grand Metropolitan P.L.C. Pro-Fac Cooperative, an agricultural marketing cooperative, processes fruits, vegetables and popcorn.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MARKS, ARTHUR D.
description: MARKS-Arthur D. The officers, fellow board members, and staff of The Jewish Guild for the Blind note with sorrow the passing of Arthur D Marks. Mr. Marks was the father of Andrew Marks, our esteemed colleague and long time board member of The Guild. We extend our deepest sympathy to Andy and his family. James M. Dubin, Chairman John F. Heimerdinger, President

title: When Setting Limits Is Right for Mentally Ill
description: To the Editor:

title: Judge's Order Blocks Repeal of Sales Tax in Indian Stores
description: A State Supreme Court justice issued a temporary restraining order today blocking Gov. George E. Pataki from repealing a state plan to collect taxes on the sale of gasoline and cigarettes on Indian reservations, as Mr. Pataki had announced he would do just a day before.

title: F. G. Watson, 85, Innovative Astronomer
description: Fletcher Guard Watson, an astronomer and educator whose innovative methods took science subjects to a wider audience, died on May 7 at the Youville Nursing Home in Cambridge, Mass. He was 85 and lived in Belmont and North Eastham, Mass.

title: Yanks Bench Boggs And Blow a Lead
description: And on the 53d day of the season, Wade Boggs rested. Maybe for good. But at least for four games. Boggs was relegated to the bench last night as Manager Joe Torre inserted Charlie Hayes over the future Hall of Famer at third base in an attempt to boost a sagging offense and jolt a sluggish team.

title: U.S. Clears New Cutting In Forest In Alaska
description: The Forest Service today authorized extensive new logging for the next 10 years in the Tongass National Forest in southeastern Alaska, the nation's last expanse of old-growth temperate rain forests.

title: Chairman Reportedly Ousted at EMI Unit
description: Charles A. Koppelman, the chairman of EMI-North America, was ousted yesterday and is likely to be replaced by Ken Berry, the president of EMI International, a person with knowledge of the company said last night.

title: Lawyers Point a Finger
description: Lawyers for a 16-year-old Cumberland Regional High School basketball player who is accused of killing a classmate pointed a finger yesterday at another student, telling a judge that the second youth had made an incriminating statement, The Associated Press reported.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SOBEL, NATHAN R.
description: SOBEL-Nathan R. The Surrogates Association of the State of New York mounrs the loss of our loved sui generis mentor and advisor. His writings and legacy will guide us in our decisions. He will be dearly missed. Hon. Angelo Lomanto, President Hon. C. Raymond Radigan, Chair

title: CHIEF EXECUTIVE OF RALSTON PURINA TO STEP DOWN
description: The Ralston Purina Company said yesterday that William Stiritz would step down as chief executive and named co-chief executives to replace him in a step interpreted as a prelude to separating its battery and pet food businesses. Patrick McGinnis, who heads the company's Purina pet foods business, and Patrick Mulcahy, who heads its Energizer battery unit, will replace Mr. Stiritz, who has been chief executive since 1981. Mr. Stiritz, 62, will remain chairman after the changes become effective Oct. 1. The appointment of co-chief executives indicates the company will separate the two businesses, analysts said.

title: Disaster or Delight? Ask the Public
description: In the summer of 1959, Gregory Peck and Deborah Kerr were two of Hollywood's biggest stars. Their movie, ''Beloved Infidel,'' about F. Scott Fitzgerald's romance with the columnist Sheilah Graham, was lavishly promoted by 20th Century Fox. And on the morning the film opened at the Roxy Theater in New York, two top executives showed up expecting to see lines around the block, even though they harbored what they thought to be a disquieting secret:

title: Reunion Is Good For Flyers
description: The Legion of Doom was reunited last night at Madison Square Garden. They dressed partly in black, carried scythes and breathed a fire that must have smelled of death to the Rangers.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RICH, RUTH.
description: RICH-Ruth. On Wednesday, May 21, 1997, in Ft. Lauderdale, FL. Beloved sister of Milton Handler, adoring mother of Helen Dinnerman. Mother-in-law of Jan Clare. Proud grandmother of Sandy Kerchner & great-grandmother of Isaac Kerchner. Funeral private.

title: Leaving a Bar, 3 Pairings Head for Sexual Skirmishes
description: In ''Touch My Face,'' at the Fourth Street Theater, three couples leave the same bar on the same night after the same come-ons, to have sexual encounters. Of the six characters, one stands out immediately: Matty (Nancy McDoniel), a lonely, attractive older woman crying audibly, with a Southern accent, into her red wine. She passes out with style, later offers to show a man photographs taken when she was really beautiful and explains her possession of a gun collection with three words: ''I'm from Arkansas.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STONE, BETTY LEA (BARNES)
description: STONE-Betty Lea (Barnes), of Needham, MA. and Marion, MA., May 23, 1997. Wife of the late Robert Gregg Stone. Mother of Galen L. of Dedham, MA., Robert G. Jr. of Greenwich, CT., David B. of Marion, MA., Elizabeth S. Trumbull of Santa Monica, CA and Henry A. of Harrisville, Michigan. Also survived by 26 grandchildren and 45 great grandchildren. A memorial service at St. Paul's Episcopal Church, 59 Court Street Dedham, MA., on Wednesday, May 28 at 11 A.M. In lieu of flowers, donations may be sent to the Betty Lea Stone-American Cancer Society, Research Fellowship Program, 20 Speen Street, Framingham, MA. 01701. For more information call J.S. Waterman and Sons, 617235-4110.

title: Abortion Bill Skips the Fine Print
description: As I watched the Senate debate on late-term abortions this week, I was struck by the surreal quality of the remarks. The oratory from both sides had nothing to do with the anguish faced by my patients and their families, yet the results will profoundly affect their lives.

title: 2 to Be Nominated For Seats on F.C.C.
description: President Clinton will nominate Harold Furchtgott-Roth, the economist for the House Commerce Committee, and William Kennard, the top lawyer at the Federal Communications Commission, to seats on the F.C.C., a key Congressional aide said today.

title: French Oil Company Buys Back Shares
description: Elf Aquitaine S.A. bought back shares yesterday from another of its original core shareholders, UAP S.A. Elf, a major French oil company, agreed to buy two million of its own shares -- a stake of seven-tenths of 1 percent worth 1.2 billion French francs ($214 million) -- from UAP Life, a unit of Axa-UAP. On Thursday, it bought 2.5 million shares from Renault S.A.

title: CBS to Run Its TV Stations Apart From Network
description: Hoping to coax higher profits from its company-owned television stations, CBS said yesterday that it would run the stations separately from the network for the first time. The move is part of a management shake-up that gives sweeping new power to an executive whose main experience has been in radio, Mel Karmazin, who was named chairman and chief executive of the newly created CBS Station Group.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Thursday about a tyrannosaur with gout, known to researchers as Sue, misspelled the surname of the fossil's discoverer. He is Peter L. Larson, not Larsen.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: COURT FILES SAY DRUG BARON USED MEXICAN MILITARY
description: Some of Mexico's most prominent anti-drug operations of the past year were undertaken at the behest of Mexico's biggest drug baron, who had enlisted corrupt generals in his war against a competitor, military officers have testified in secret court proceedings here.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BRADT, JOSEPH J.
description: BRADT-Joseph J., 84, on May 22, 1997, of Ridgefield, CT, formerly of Flushing. Husband of Winifred E. Devoted father of Winifred, Joseph, William and Anne-Marie. Also survived by ten loving grandchildren. Retired Detective with the NYPD. Korean War Veteran and lifetime member of the Elks Lodge #

title: Mazda Shows Improvement Under Ford's Leadership
description: The Mazda Motor Corporation, in a sign of partial recovery, said today that unconsolidated net profit soared in its first fiscal year under the control of the Ford Motor Company, although it still had an operating loss.

title: Council Of Trent
description: As he left the White House on Tuesday, Trent Lott threw some gorilla dust at Bill Clinton. (Ross Perot's term for one alpha male trying to out-swagger another.)

title: 'Where Did I Park the Car?'
description: Some gamblers may be humming ''Blue Suede Shoes'' or ''Brown-Eyed Girl'' after parking their cars at the Trump Taj Mahal Casino Resort.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEWIS, FAY
description: LEWIS-Fay. Beloved wife of the late Martin. Cherished mother of Linda and Arthur Gelb and Steven and Susan Lewis. Adored grandmother of Ronald and Nanci Gelb, Caren and Gary Zakon, and Laurie and Richard Gliklich, and David and Michael Lewis. Greatgrandmother of 5. Devoted sister of Minnie Greenberg, Evelyn Gotlib, and Harry Olstein. Services 1 PM, Sunday, Sherman's Flatbush Memorial Chapel, 1283 Coney Island Avenue, (Avenue J).

title: Not Giving Up on Bosnia
description: With this week's announcement of a new initiative on Bosnia, the Clinton Administration has signaled a welcome, if belated, recognition that its efforts to bring a lasting peace in that country are in danger of crashing. Since the parties to the conflict signed the Dayton peace accords in 1995, NATO peacekeepers have prevented major outbreaks of violence. But they are scheduled to leave in a little over a year, and insufficient progress has been made in building the political and civic institutions necessary to make Bosnia a tolerant and multi-ethnic state.

title: VICTIMS OF FLOOD FEAR DELAY IN AID
description: The White House called it short-sighted. Congressional Democrats said it was arrogant. And soggy Midwesterners and Californians worried it could hurt them in the long run.

title: Judge Bars Videotape In Alex Kelly Case
description: The judge in the Alex Kelly rape retrial barred prosecutors today from showing jurors a videotaped re-enactment intended to support the accuser's statement that Mr. Kelly had forced her into the cargo area of a Jeep.

title: Military Officer Must Lead, Not Mirror, Society
description: To the Editor:

title: Scoring On a Frozen Wrist
description: THIS wasn't hockey. This was medieval jousting with the armor but without the horses.

title: Union Invests in Technology
description: The A.F.L.-C.I.O. will invest $14.6 million in a state-sponsored center intended to provide emerging high-technology and biotechnology companies with lease space at a reasonable price, union officials and Gov. Christine Todd Whitman's office said yesterday.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  SELDOWITZ, RUTH R.
description: SELDOWITZ-Ruth R. May 24, 1987. In remembrance of my dearly beloved sister, today and always. Estelle

title: BARNETT AND REPUBLIC BANKING END TAKEOVER TALKS
description: Barnett Banks and the Republic Banking Corporation have ended discussions without completing a definitive acquisition agreement. The two Florida companies announced last week that they had an agreement in principle for Barnett to purchase Republic. After further discussions, they could not agree on certain issues and have mutually decided not to proceed with the proposed acquisition, the banks said in a statement. Republic is the holding company for Republic National Bank of Miami.

title: What Day Was Nafta Signed?
description: The twenty-fourth of May

title: Alfred D. Hershey, Nobel Laureate for DNA Work, Dies at 88
description: Dr. Alfred D. Hershey, who used a household blender to do experiments that made him a Nobel laureate by proving that DNA is the molecule that carries genetic information, died on Thursday at his home in Syosset, N.Y. He was 88.

title: Man Who Was Shot Atop Empire State Building Goes Home
description: Matthew Gross went home yesterday, three months after he was shot in the head in a fusillade of bullets atop the Empire State Building.

title: Upstate Town Readies Itself for a New Identity
description: You might expect the world's second largest indoor Buddha to be in some far-off land of bamboo and monsoons. Instead, it is here, at a sprawling monastery on a backwoods road, 60 miles from midtown Manhattan.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  CONCEPCION, RENE
description: CONCEPCION-Rene. One year now since you left, but your smile and courage will always be with those you loved. Forever in our hearts. With love, Steven and Adolfo.

title: CHATTEM TO BUY ASSETS OF SUNSOURCE INTERNATIONAL
description: Chattem Inc. agreed yesterday to buy the assets of Sunsource International Inc. for shares and cash, moving the maker of health care products into the expanding market for dietary supplements. The exact price was not disclosed. Chattem, which makes Gold Bond powder and Bull Frog sunblock, will issue 300,000 shares valued at about $3 million and pay an unspecified amount of cash. The purchase price will be about one and a half times Sunsource's sales, which were about $25 million in 1996. Shares of Chattem, based in Chattanooga, Tenn. rose $1.625, to $10.

title: INSIDE METRO
description: INSPECTING 747'S -- With no evidence on the cause of the explosion of Trans World Airlines Flight 800, Boeing said it would ask all airlines that fly 747's to inspect the planes' center fuel tanks. Page 22.

title: Colonial Co-leader Has a Tip for Woods
description: For the second day in a row, he had riddled the surprisingly gentle Colonial Country Club golf course. His scorecard read 11 under par, and he shared the tournament lead. But Brad Faxon was still firing high and hard at the pins today when he walked into his post-round interview.

title: On the Campaign Trail in France, Scant Mention of Economic Pain
description: President Jacques Chirac called the election on Sunday for a new Parliament in a gamble on the French voter. The French leader wanted a mandate to keep trimming the welfare state and cutting deficits so that France would meet the requirements for a common European currency in 1999.

title: Airlines Asked to Inspect Fuel Tanks
description: With no evidence from the wreckage of what made Trans World Airlines Flight 800 explode last July, Boeing said today that it would ask all airlines that fly 747's to inspect the planes' center fuel tanks for signs of anything that could create a spark.

title: CIENA SHARES HIT A 52-WEEK HIGH AS NET CLIMBS
description: Shares of the Ciena Corporation hit a 52-week high yesterday after the company, a telecommunications equipment concern, reported second-quarter earnings that handily beat expectations. The earnings report, which was released on Thursday, sent the shares of Ciena up $7.125, or 18 percent, to $46, in Nasdaq trading.
