Ciena, which went public in February, reported pro forma earnings Thursday of $27.6 million, or 26 cents a share on revenue of $86.7 million, compared with a loss of $2.7 million, or 3 cents a share, on no revenue in the quarter a year earlier.

title: Predators and the Law
description: To the Editor:

title: Yes, Yes, Nanette: 3 Times Into the Footlighted Breach
description: If you pine for the halcyon days of 1971, when flappers were all the rage and ''Tea for Two'' tickled the fancy of every Jack and Jill on Broadway, then by all means crank up the Model T and journey on out to the Paper Mill Playhouse.

title: Skimpy Effort By CityHawks
description: Shane Biggins, a high school football player from Bergenfield, N.J., wished he had not taken the New Jersey Red Dogs' Bikini Night so seriously. Wearing a pink plaid number for 9,698 fans at Continental Arena to see, all for a free ticket, he blushed and said, ''I don't know why I did this, actually.''

title: Equities Chief Leaving Putnam for Citicorp
description: Putnam Investments Inc. said today that the head of its domestic equities group, Peter Carman, had quit to become head of global asset management at Citicorp.

title: Workfare Is Replacing Union Jobs, Lawsuit Says
description: The unions representing painters and carpenters who work for New York City have sued the Giuliani administration, charging it with doing something that Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani has repeatedly denied doing: using welfare recipients to do jobs once done by unionized workers.

title: Efforts to Aid Mentally Ill Result In Happy Ending for Movie House
description: Walton's cherished old movie theater almost had the same rueful ending as the Texas theater in ''The Last Picture Show,'' with a darkened screen taking another bite out of the spirit of a struggling country town.

title: Johnson Gives Rockets A Boost From the Bench
description: The grave look on the Houston Rockets' faces faded just a bit tonight. An old soul in white-striped shorts rose off the bench like a spirit and delivered a spry performance for this desperate team.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WOLFERMAN, ADOLPH, M.D.
description: WOLFERMAN-Adolph, M.D. On May 22, 1997. Husband of the late Pierrette Wolferman and adored husband of Irene Schleider Wolferman. Dear father of Mark (Cathy), Eric (Patricia) and Sondra. Beloved grandfather of Brian, Cassie, Benjamin, Joann and Anna Wolferman, Alex, David, Jacob, Jessica and Alexandra Schleider. Services on Sunday 1:15 P.M., at ''The Riverside'', 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue. Visiting hours on Saturday 7-9 P.M.

title: Death Penalty Is Sought in a Triple Slaying
description: The Brooklyn District Attorney, Charles J. Hynes, who is already seeking the death penalty in two murder cases, said yesterday that he would seek it in a third case, involving a defendant charged with killing three people during a robbery.

title: An Actress in Search of a Character Peeks in the Mirror
description: With every new role, Shirley Knight tries to be both a portraitist and a sleuth as she ''figures out the puzzle'' of the character. In ''The Young Man From Atlanta,'' Horton Foote's Pulitzer Prize-winning drama, she is Lily Dale, the sad, sweet-tempered wife of the gruff Will Kidder (Rip Torn). Dressed neatly and sensibly and always wearing a strand of pearls, she seems to be the perfect picture of a Texas matron, circa 1950.

title: Soprano's Seven Minutes: Just a Toe in the Water
description: The British soprano Jane Eaglen made her debut with the New York Philharmonic on Thursday night, singing the ''Liebestod'' from Wagner's ''Tristan und Isolde'' in a program conducted by Kurt Masur. There has seldom been so much preconcert buzz in Avery Fisher Hall over just seven minutes of singing.

title: The Resurgent Mets Meet a Phillies Rookie
description: Naturally, Fred Wilpon enjoys the fact that the team he owns, the Mets, is winning. More than that, he said today, he likes how they are winning.

title: Doubts on Identity Of an Asylum Seeker
description: The Nigerian asylum seeker claimed that he fled to America to escape persecution after his brother was charged with plotting a coup in Nigeria. But it now appears that the man who calls himself Edwin Mutaru Bulus is an impostor. Family members of Lieut. Col. Happy Kefas Bulus, the man accused two years ago of plotting the coup, said recently in Nigeria that there is no brother named Edwin.

title: What 'Giant' Did to Texas
description: An intriguing Texas curio surfaces tomorrow at midnight on Channel 21 in the form of a documentary called ''Return to Giant.'' The giant in question is the mid-1950's blockbuster movie called ''Giant,'' directed by George Stevens and starring Rock Hudson, Elizabeth Taylor and an up-and-coming dynamo named James Dean. The documentary notes that '' 'Giant' did for Texas what 'Gone With the Wind' did for Atlanta.'' Let's not argue whether that's a plus or a minus.

title: 2 Teen-Agers Held in Stabbing Death of Man Found in Park
description: A 44-year-old man, his body slashed open by as many as 50 stab wounds, was found floating in the Lake in Central Park early yesterday, and two 15-year-olds, who the police said were sharing after-midnight beers with the victim under a full moon, have been charged with his murder.

title: Richmond Ousts St. John's
description: A pitching collapse led to the second defeat in two days for St. John's, and the Red Storm was eliminated today from the Atlantic Regional of the National Collegiate Athletic Association baseball tournament.

title: Puzo's Licensed Thugs
description: Polish jokes verboten. Black jokes verboten. Italian jokes verboten. Jewish jokes verboten. Catholic jokes verboten. Mother-in-law jokes verboten. Feminist jokes verboten. Homosexual jokes verboten.

title: All Eyes on New British Leader at European Union Meeting
description: The leaders of the 15 European Union nations gathered here today to discuss treaty revisions they are to sign next month, but the day-long session was dominated by Britain's new Prime Minister, Tony Blair, who has promised to sweeten his country's sour relations with the Continent.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  PIERCE, HALIL ALEXANDER
description: PIERCE-Halil Alexander. In loving memory of our dear friend Halil Alexander Pierce, a Memorial Service will be held on Wednesday, May 28, 1997, at I Tre Merli, 463 West Broadway from 6-8 P.M. His Friends

title: Israeli Conversion Bill Protects Status Quo
description: To the Editor:

title: Doubts Cast on Identity of Nigerian Who Says He's a Political Refugee
description: The Nigerian asylum seeker claims that he fled to America to escape persecution after his brother was charged with plotting a coup against Nigeria's military dictatorship. Amnesty International's refugee coordinator and an immigration official who grilled him for two hours were among those who found him believable.

title: There's No 'Choice' for Students Left Behind
description: To the Editor:

title: Testimony Backfires on Defense At Oklahoma City Bombing Trial
description: A defense witness who was expected to help Timothy J. McVeigh's effort to show that someone else bombed the Federal Building in Oklahoma City instead testified today that one of the men she saw fleeing the scene could have been Mr. McVeigh.

title: Tobacco Contributions
description: The tobacco industry gave more than $233,000 to political action committees for legislative leaders and state political parties during the 1995 elections, making it the top contributor, according to a study released yesterday.

title: Police and Troops Break Up Election Rallies in Indonesia
description: The Government displayed its power today, using tear gas, rubber bullets and an overwhelming armed presence on the streets of Jakarta, the capital, to quash attempts by its opponents to hold rallies on the last day of campaigning for next week's parliamentary election.

title: Data Aren't Missing
description: To the Editor:

title: Half Full or Half Empty?
description: The gap between the national unemployment rate, at 4.9 percent in April, and New York City's, at 9.7 percent, is now the greatest it has been in the 30 years extensive records have been kept, Federal labor officials said this week.

title: Man Finds His Voice, but Forgets Having Lost It
description: The Brooklyn man who had indicated to officials of a Newark hospital that he was deaf and mute has found his voice again upon returning home to New York City -- but he says he cannot remember being unable to hear or speak.

title: Suppliers Settle Complaint
description: Two medical equipment suppliers agreed to settle a complaint by the Federal Government that accused them of overbilling the Medicare program.

title: Fraud Indictment For Genesis Chief
description: A Federal grand jury has indicted the chief executive of Genesis Insurance and Financial Services Inc. on charges of money laundering and insurance fraud.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: Baseball

title: INSIDE
description: Divergent Perspectives On Punishment for a Pilot

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WOLFSON, HETTIE
description: WOLFSON-Hettie. Beloved wife of the late Benjamin. Loving mother of Irwin and Thea Wolfson, Bernice and Mike Kudysch and Horty and Jules Spodek. Devoted grandmother and greatgrandmother. Services Sunday 10:00 AM, at Sherman's Flatbush Memorial Chapel, 1283 Coney Island Avenue, (Avenue J).

title: Lindros's Late Goal Pushes Rangers to Brink
description: Last night's game was bitter for the Rangers, elating for the Flyers and enthralling for everyone who watched. It was a three-hour athletic masterpiece filled with spectacular plays, vicious aggression and constant swings and surges of emotion and energy.

title: U.S. Clergy Counsel Swiss on Atoning for War Past
description: Revelations that Switzerland provided a profitable haven for gold looted by the Nazis, some of it from Holocaust victims, have badly damaged that nation's former reputation as an island of integrity amid World War II's barbarism.

title: F.C.C. Staff Says Tower Would Harm Bronx Garden
description: The staff of the Federal Communications Commission ruled yesterday that the 45-story radio tower that Fordham University wants to build on its Bronx campus would have an adverse effect on its immediate neighbor, the New York Botanical Garden, and it asked both sides in the three-year dispute to help work out an alternate plan.

title: At Home, Beer, but Export Buzz Is About Wine
description: Peter Lehmann munches a mettwurst and tomato sandwich and jots down weights as he scans the scales in his vine-covered weighing cottage in the Barossa valley about a 90-minute drive northeast of Adelaide.

title: 'Megan' Case Defense Rests After Calling No Witnesses
description: The defense in the Megan Kanka murder and sexual assault case rested today without calling a single witness.

title: Bridge
description: New York's most prestigious event, the Reisinger Knockout Team Championship, has been declining steadily for many years. Thirty years ago, 74 teams were entered, and the winning squad included three world-famous players: Oswald Jacoby, John Crawford and Tobias Stone. This week, only 14 teams competed, and some of the best players in the metropolitan area were missing from the ranks.

title: Irate Riley Charges Refs Are Partial to Jordan
description: Outraged by what he described as preferential treatment given to Michael Jordan by the referees Thursday in Game 2 of the Eastern Conference finals, Miami Heat Coach Pat Riley said he planned to take his complaint to the league office.

title: Times Names 4 to Senior Positions on the News Staff
description: The New York Times announced appointments yesterday to four senior positions on its news staff.

title: Business Bribes To Foreigners To Be Banned By End of 1998
description: After two years of negotiations, the world's largest industrialized nations have agreed to outlaw the bribery of foreign officials by the end of next year.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MARENSTEIN, ARTHUR
description: MARENSTEIN-Arthur. Died May 22, 1997. Beloved husband of Leah. Devoted father of Lawrence and Harry. Services Sun. 12 noon ''Sinai Chapels'', 162-05 Horace Harding Exprway, Fresh Meadows, NY

title: Doctors Record Signals of Brain Cells Linked to Memory
description: A team of neurosurgeons say that in preparing epilepsy patients for operation, they have recorded signals from single human brain cells that make the associations leading to long-term memories, the first time that feat has been achieved.

title: Pepsico Bottling Operation In South Africa Is Closed
description: The Pepsico Inc. franchise bottler in South Africa, New Age Beverages, has ceased operations, ceding the country's $1 billion beverage market to Pepsi's archrival, the Coca-Cola Company.

title: When Health Care Is Refused
description: Patients in managed care can feel angry, frightened and trapped when their plan says no to a procedure or therapy they think they need. A consumer protection movement has emerged in several states, most recently in Connecticut, to require health plans to provide their patients a right to appeal disputes to an independent expert or organization external to their health plan. External review can help allay the fears associated with managed care and could become law in many states. But external review also raises troubling problems that no one yet knows how to resolve.

title: Bond Prices Little Changed On a Shortened Trading Day
description: Treasury prices were little changed yesterday in a shortened trading session ahead of a three-day holiday weekend.

title: EASTERN CONFERENCE FINALS: GAME 4
description: Despite rallying twice to tie the score in the third period, the Rangers lost Game 4 when Eric Lindros scored a power-play goal with 6.8 seconds left. The Rangers trail, 3 games to 1, in the four-of-seven series.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PHILLIPS, JOHN H.
description: PHILLIPS-John H. Psychoanalyst, died of natural causes on the weekend of May 10 at his apartment in Murray Hill. He was 76 and had practiced continuously in Manhattan since 1962. He continued to emphasize long-term, indepth treatment, often reducing fees. He was devoted to his patients, many of whom became his friends.

title: Congo Leader's Cabinet Ignites Protests
description: President Laurent Kabila, who was hailed as a liberator less than a week ago, was the object of protests here today after he formed his first Government.

title: S.& P. 500 Gives Cardinal Health a Lift
description: The stock of Cardinal Health Inc. rose more than 8 percent today after the company was moved into the Standard & Poor's 500 index.

title: Corrections
description: A critic's notebook article yesterday about a tribute to the singer, actor and dancer Donald O'Connor by the Film Society of Lincoln Center misstated the title of a new film with Mr. O'Connor. The movie, to be released in July, is ''Out to Sea,'' not ''Make 'em Laugh.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GARFUNKEL, HYMAN
description: GARFUNKEL-Hyman. Beloved husband of Bea. Devoted father of Trudy and Sandy Muroff. Dear brother of Aaron Garvin. Loving grandfather of Jared & Matthew.

title: Russia and Belarus Agree on a New Union
description: Russia and Belarus agreed today to form a new union, a largely symbolic move intended to appeal to nostalgia for the old Soviet empire.

title: Serving Up Metaphors To Ponder And Digest
description: With his customary intelligence and daring, the French choreographer Angelin Preljocaj has given the New York City Ballet something strange to see and think about. Mind and matter work hand in hand.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DALY, MARY H.
description: DALY-Mary H., in Chappaqua, May 23, 1997. Mother of Vincent, Thomas, John and Mary Daly and Anne DeHayes. Grandmother of five. Resting Beecher Funeral Home, Pleasantville, New York, where family will receive friends Monday 2-4 and 7-9 P.M. Mass of Christian Burial Tuesday 10 A.M. Church of St. John and St. Mary, Chappaqua, New York. Interment Sleepy Hollow Cemetery. In lieu of flowers a donation to the W.A.R.C. 74 Westmoreland Avenue, White Plains, New York 10606 in her name would be appreciated.

title: Richter Does His Best To Save the Rangers
description: By Coach Colin Campbell's admission earlier in this Eastern Conference finals, the Rangers asked goaltender Mike Richter to be brilliant.

title: GENERAL PARCEL SERVICES PLANNING AN EXPANSION
description: General Parcel Services Inc. said yesterday that it had agreed to buy four Southeastern trucking companies for about $30 million to $35 million in cash and stock in an effort to make the regional shipping and delivery company profitable. The company also said it would change its name to Transit Group Inc., as of June 30, as part of its plan to concentrate on its trucking business and eventually get out of the shipping business, its chief financial officer, Wayne Nellums, said. Names of the four closely held companies, which General Parcel said had combined annual sales of $100 million, were not released. G.P.S. had 1996 sales of $23.4 million.

title: On the Campaign Trail
description: New Jerseyans passing the Memorial Day weekend in traditional fashion may find themselves nose to nose with one of the candidates running in the June 3 Democratic gubernatorial primary.

title: HEALTH MANAGEMENT SYSTEMS' SHARES TUMBLE 20%
description: Shares of Health Management Systems fell 20 percent yesterday, a day after the company said it expected its second-quarter results to be lower than Wall Street estimates. The company, a New York-based provider of data management software. said it expected to earn 1 or 2 cents a share in the second quarter, which ended April 30, after a 9-cent gain related to a tax settlement with the Internal Revenue Service. It expects second-quarter revenues of $20 million. A First Call Inc. estimate called for first-quarter earnings of 13 cents a share. The company cited revenue shortfalls as one reason for the weaker quarter. Final results will be reported after May 28.

title: Pumping Your Own Gas
description: To the Editor:

title: Defense in Unabom Case Attacks U.S. Search
description: Defense lawyers for Theodore J. Kaczynski, the man accused of being the Unabomber, asserted today that Federal investigators lied in winning court permission to search the Montana mountain cabin where he was arrested in the spring of 1996.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHWARTZ, EUGENE J.
description: SCHWARTZ-Eugene J. The partners, associates and staff of Podell, Rothman, Schechter & Banfield mourn the loss of Gene Schwartz, our dear friend and colleague. A founding father in the law of tax assessment review, Gene will be missed by all who have benefited from his wisdom and foresight. Allan, we extend to you and your family our heartfelt sympathy. Podell, Rothman, Schechter & Banfield

title: Books in Brief: Nonfiction
description: Anything we love can be saved

title: Dee Dee Myers, Todd S. Purdum
description: Dee Dee Myers, the former White House press secretary, is to be married today to Todd Stanley Purdum, the Los Angeles bureau chief of The New York Times. The Rev. James Dunkerley is to perform the ceremony at St. Peter's Episcopal Church in Chicago.

title: Dr. Frankenstein of Cape May
description: BRUCE M. MINNIX formed the word as if it were an epithet, a vile obscenity that would have shocked the refined sensibilities of Cape May a century ago.

title: Wartime Envoy on Nazi Gold Bristles at Hindsight
description: Seymour J. Rubin, an enduring lawyer who arrived in this city as a Roosevelt-era Wunderkind, gently sipped his martini, deciding how to defend his reputation in a controversy rooted 50 years deep in history.

title: Books in Brief: Nonfiction
description: Somewhere in the NightFilm Noir and the American City.By Nicholas Christopher. Free Press, $25.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHOR, RUTH (NEE SHAFFRO)
description: SCHOR-Ruth (nee Shaffro), 81, of Forest Hills and Flushing, NY, on May 20. Beloved wife of the late David, mother of Carol Shapiro Joseph and Deborah Gardner. Mother-in-law of Paul Joseph and Gregory Nolan. Grandmother of Lily and Molly. Sister of Lionel. Longtime social studies teacher at Forest Hills High School. Donations in her memory to Alumni Association of Hunter College, 695 Park Ave, NY, NY 10021, Att: Scholarship & Welfare Fund.

title: A Boost for Early Reading
description: WHILE President Clinton has declared that he wants every child in America reading by the third grade, Reading Recovery, an international intervention program available in 47 schools across Connecticut, sets its sights higher and starts with at-risk first-graders.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ALTMAN, HYMAN
description: ALTMAN-Hyman. Passed away May 23. Beloved husband of Clara. Devoted father of Miriam, Judith and Stanley. Loving grandfather. Retired Manager of the Neckwear Makers Union, Amalgamated Clothing Workers. Chapel services Sunday, May 25, 1997, at the Hirsch & Sons Chapel, 1225 Jerome Avenue, Bronx, NY, 718-992-2000. Beth Moses Cemetery, Pinelawn.

title: Dueling Gift Funds: Similar Aims, Different Styles
description: COMMENCEMENT season serves as an annual reminder for parents, grandparents and others to commence saving for a young child's future education.

title: B. T. Streitwieser, Mary Beth Warner
description: Mary Beth Warner, the daughter of Mary Lou Warner and Dr. Willis A. Warner of Scottsdale, Ariz., was married yesterday to Bernhard Thomas Streitwieser, a son of Franz X. Streitwieser of Kremsmunster, Austria, and the late Katherine S. Streitwieser. The Rev. Fred Trevino performed the ceremony at the Paradise Valley United Methodist Church in Paradise Valley, Ariz.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  WACHSBERGER, FANNIE H.
description: WACHSBERGER-Fannie H. May 25, 1976. Forever in our hearts. Your Children

title: Golden Age Is Coming. Deal With It.
description: Rupert Murdoch can't buy the Dodgers soon enough for me, especially if he promises to move them to Singapore, where spitting on an umpire is punished by being flogged, naked, at second base during the seventh-inning stretch. Wouldn't that finally bring closure to Brooklyn. It would also put the team in the Global League, a future third major league, and Murdoch would be unable to compete against Ted Turner's Braves during the regular season.

title: Report Oversells Immigration's Meager Benefits
description: To the Editor:

title: EMI on the Side of the Angels? Not Entirely
description: Correction Appended

title: Pouring Itself Into the Stock Market
description: THE coffee bars that have sprung up across the country like froth on a well-made cappuccino make the point: Americans love gourmet coffee. For some investors, however, the industry may serve up a bitter brew.

title: Using Feng Shui to Create Harmony
description: IN Western culture, interior designers attempt to create a happy and harmonious environment by careful selection and pleasing arrangement of the elements within the home. They usually start with a functional furniture arrangement. They then add decorative elements -- color, texture, effective lighting and accessories -- to create a satisfying or dramatic atmosphere. Function and esthetics are the primary guidelines in Western interior design.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GESSER, REUBEN
description: GESSER-Reuben. The members and officers of Parent Assembly #

title: He May Be Sir Paul, but He's Still a Beatle
description: ON A RECENT AFTERNOON IN the kitchen of a quaint 17th-century mill house overlooking the English Channel, there was a sense of eventfulness. The room was in rigorous disarray. Newspapers spilled across a red leather banquette, bowls of snacks littered the Formica table; a stack of tea canisters teetered on the counter. Only the calendar, thumbtacked to a shelf over the sink, suggested order. Its squares were filled in with mundane engagements that mirror everyday family life -- aside from one that was conspicuously circled. The date was March 11, and printed in neat, boxy letters was the reminder ''Buck. Palace.''

title: Laurel Sherwood, M. M. Skarbinski
description: Laurel Ann Sherwood, a biology teacher and editor, was married yesterday to Michael Martin Skarbinski, a securities trader. The Rev. John S. Smylie, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony at the Hurlbut Memorial Community Church at the Chautauqua Institution in Chautauqua, N.Y.

title: Spell Is Cast On Rangers From Afar
description: NOT many people know this, but the Rangers are in grave condition today because of sinister outside forces. To be perfectly honest, somebody is plotting to get the Rangers.

title: C.I.A., Drugs and Denial
description: To the Editor:

title: A Partial-Victory Abortion Vote
description: THERE was a bizarre moment last week in the otherwise grim debate over ''partial birth abortion.'' The Senate had just voted to ban the procedure but had fallen three votes shy of the number needed to override a promised veto from President Clinton. At a news conference, Senator Trent Lott, the Republican leader, was asked if he would schedule the override vote close to next year's midterm elections.

title: Correction
description: A report in the Postings column last Sunday about a new building at Trinity School in Manhattan misidentified a financing source. About two-thirds of the $15 million cost is to come from bonds sold through the New York City Industrial Development Agency, not the New York State Dormitory Authority.

title: Is Downtown Dead?
description: DOWNTOWN, the place and the concept, has had a remarkable run in this city. For the past 100 years, downtown has been synonymous with certain neighborhoods below 14th Street and any other part of town that is cool, bohemian and a little dangerous.

title: Faces From Beyond the Grave
description: THE KILLING FIELDS

title: U.N. Reports Latin America Suffers Fewer 'Disappeared'
description: Reflecting the changes that democratically elected governments have brought to Latin America and the Caribbean, political ''disappearances'' have almost ended in the Western Hemisphere, a United Nations group of experts has concluded.

title: MOVIES THIS WEEK
description: WITH a nod to Memorial Day, high drama on television this week revisits World War II with accounts of a submarine-command feud, an Air Corps outpost, a prison camp on Bataan and a Nazi in hiding.

title: For a Suspect in an Officer's Killing, a Long Slide Into Ruin
description: He followed his family into the garment trade but left that business of sequins and velvet in a haze of distrust. He followed his childhood friend into cutthroat stock sales, but long days of cold calls only deepened his debt. When Scott E. Schneiderman finally struck out on his own, the police say, it was with a gun in his hand, cocaine in his blood and a desperate plan to rob his father.

title: In Egypt and Iran, Exceptions to Islam
description: Devout Muslims may not eat pork -- unless they are starving. They may not consume alcohol -- unless they have no other suitable anesthetic. Now Egypt's most prominent cleric has applied the same rationale to justify the transplant of human organs from the dead to the living -- an act previously viewed by Muslims as unconscionable meddling with a gift from God.

title: A Roundabout Tour of Southwest Glories
description: AROUND the turn of the century, when few people visited or even knew about remote natural wonders in the southwest like Zion Canyon, regional boosters came up with a slogan to attract tourists: ''See Europe if you will but see America first.''

title: The Big Lies
description: SECRETS A Writer in the Cold War. By Paul Brodeur. 249 pp. Boston: Faber & Faber. $24.95.

title: Elizabeth Alia, Einar Ronquist
description: Elizabeth Christine Alia, the daughter of Carolyn and Dominic Alia of Bronxville, N.Y., was married yesterday to Dr. Einar Malvin Ronquist, a son of Gunvor and Kaare Ronquist of Skauge, Norway. The Rev. Dr. James C. Zwernemann, a Lutheran pastor, performed the ceremony at the James House in Sleepy Hollow, N.Y.

title: LONG ISLAND GUIDE
description: FREE CHOICES

title: Landscapes Were Never The Same
description: More than 1,000 years ago, long before European painters discovered perspective, the Southern Tang Dynasty scholar Dong Yuan created the illusion of depth and distance as he painted mountains and rivers on silk. He was a founder of the Chinese monumental landscape style.

title: Rocking, Rolling, Etc., All Over the State
description: IT was cold and rainy on the Saturday morning this month when hundreds of pop-music fans began lining up outside ticket offices at video stores and supermarkets throughout New Jersey. Although sea breezes and beach parties seemed a long way off, the annual ritual was the beginning of the summer concert season.

title: AMERICA'S MOST WANTED
description: A cool-looking summer uniform summer uniform captured after an exhaustive manhunt.

title: High Culture For the Masses
description: To the Editor:

title: In Flower-Laden Locust Valley, A Little-Known Spot of Tranquillity
description: ONE of Long Island's hidden corners, Locust Valley Cemetery looks more like an arboretum than a burial site.

title: PLAYING IN THE NEIGHBORHOOD
description: PROSPECT HEIGHTS

title: Nicola Zesiger and Terrence Mullen
description: Nicola Lyons Zesiger, a daughter of Judith Carey Zesiger of New York and Albert Zesiger of Rowayton, Conn., was married yesterday to Terrence Maxwell Mullen, the son of Mr. and Mrs. David P. Mullen of Westlake Village, Calif. The Rev. George S. Salzmann officiated at the Roman Catholic Church of St. Ignatius Loyola in New York.

title: Scott Waxman and Julie Dugoff
description: Julie Nicole Dugoff, a daughter of Dr. Sandra K. Dugoff and Howard J. Dugoff, both of Potomac, Md., is to be married this evening to Scott Lee Waxman, a son of Marion Waxman and Dr. Samuel Waxman of Manhattan. Rabbi Stephen D. Franklin is to perform the ceremony at the New York Botanical Garden in the Bronx.

title: In Pittsburgh, Fall of the Art of Sports
description: It falls this afternoon at 3:30. Normally, these things take place just after dawn, but there's a service at a nearby church this morning, and, well, this is best done when the fewest people are around. Such is demolition.

title: Imprints of Nuremberg Before the Shadow Fell
description: AN IMPORTANT DATE IN the recovery of Europe after World War II was the 500th anniversary of the birth of Albrecht Durer in Nuremberg, Germany, on May 21, 1471.

title: International Performers Head for Israel
description: The Kirov Ballet of St. Petersburg makes its Israeli debut at the Israel Festival, which begins Wednesday and runs through June 15, offering dance, classical music, theater and jazz. The Kirov will perform ''Swan Lake'' outdoors at the Hassenfeld Sultan's Pool in Jerusalem and at the ancient Roman Theater of Caesarea on the Mediterranean, where the company will also appear in ''Don Quixote.'' Among other highlights, the Jerusalem Symphony Orchestra will be joined by the University of Notre Dame Glee Club in a Stravinsky program, and the Guarneri String Quartet and the Russian pianist Elisabeth Leonskaja will play works by Schubert, Brahms and Mozart in a program commemorating the 200th anniversary of Schubert's birth and the 100th anniversary of Brahms's death.

title: Whatever the Weather, the Bands Play On
description: THIS is the season when musical events move outdoors: ''Please bring chairs or a blanket,'' concert fliers say. (Why don't they ever mention umbrellas?) In the world of summer music, the term ''band shell'' looms as large as ''concert stage.'' From Cape May to Stanhope, towns where the winter classical season doesn't go beyond chamber music are sprouting a richly varied repertory.

title: In Bay Ridge, the Hot Race Is for Council, Not Mayor
description: From storefronts to the windows of homes, political posters already seem to be up everywhere in Bay Ridge, Brooklyn, these days.

title: A Chevelle Comes to Paradise
description: WONDERFUL WOMEN BY THE SEA (New Press, $25), a first novel by the Finnish short-story writer Monica Fagerholm, is itself wonderful. Written in an impressionistic style and subtly translated from the original Swedish by Joan Tate, the story follows the summer escapades of two families during the early 1960's. Made up of radiant vignettes that slip backward and forward in time, Ms. Fagerholm's narrative often feels like a series of snapshots in words, a linguistic photo album. Thomas, from whose perspective most of the novel is recounted, is a small child when he first goes with his parents, Isabella and Kayus, to the ''white villa,'' a summer cottage on a beautiful bay. There he meets (and comes to worship) Renee, a headstrong girl who lives nearby with her parents, Rosa and Gabriel. Renee's family has recently returned from America, bringing with them a Chevrolet Chevelle, complete with a bar in the trunk. Isabella, who has movie-star beauty and charm, befriends Rosa; they discuss Elizabeth Taylor's love life and paint their toenails white. They are among the first women on the beach to wear monokinis. With the passing of each summer, however, their little paradise is threatened by inevitable changes -- particularly the growing restlessness of these ''wonderful women by the sea.'' Although we are aware almost from the first page that Thomas's childhood world is doomed, this knowledge doesn't make its destruction any less painful. Jenny McPhee

title: Original Instruments Featured at Lyndhurst
description: THE end of May is traditionally a slow time in the concert world, with most spring seasons concluded and most summer festivals yet to begin.

title: VITTLE DEFAMATION
description: North Dakota recently became the 13th state to make disparagement of agricultural products a civil offense -- unless the disparager has a ''reliable scientific basis'' for the remarks. None of these laws, which result when food-industry lobbyists meet state legislators, have been tested in court, but that day is coming. First target: Oprah Winfrey, who last year swore off hamburgers on the air, in light of questions about the safety of beef. The Texas Beef Group is suing for damages. ''As a direct result of . . . the 'Oprah Crash,' the cattle industry suffered millions of dollars in cattle losses,'' reads the suit. Oprah isn't talking, and her spokesman won't say if the talk-show giant has stuck with her no-meat pledge.

title: Tai Chi, Cards and House Hunt
description: Until recently, the 60 or so regulars at the Park Slope Senior Center could concentrate on tai chi classes, oil painting, card playing and what was on the menu for lunch. But these days it is real estate that occupies the men and women who frequent the center.

title: Corrections
description: A chart in the Neighborhood Report pages on April 6 about Asian longhorn beetle infestation in Greenpoint, Brooklyn, misstated the beetles' size and habits.

title: One Career Path: Grooming the Bride
description: HERE come the headaches, right ahead of the bride. Will the limousine be on time? Is Aunt Margaret seated at the right table? Is there music to fill in when the band takes a break? More importantly, can you afford it all?

title: Home Security Systems
description: DESPITE reports that the crime rate has has been decreasing in most parts of the country, homeowners appear to be as cautious as ever about home security.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   SPITZ, BEATRICE
description: SPITZ-Beatrice Dear sister, remembered with love. May 25, 1978

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ESPENSHADE, DOROTHY ELIZABETH BARROWS (''DEB'')
description: ESPENSHADE-Dorothy Elizabeth Barrows (''Deb''). Age 80, of Wilmette, Illinois, died on May 22, 1997. Deb was an elegant human being, devoted wife and loving mother. She was born on July 26, 1916, in Chicago, Illinois, to Harlan Hiram Barrows and Adda Butts Barrows. She received a B.A. in History of Art from the University of Chicago in 1938. She married Edward B. Espenshade, Jr., on June 17, 1939. Her husband is Professor Emeritus (Geography) at Northwestern University and editor of ''Goode's World Atlas'' for Rand McNally and Company. She is survived by her husband, Edward, and her daughters, Jean Ellen Espenshade of Madison, WI, and Nancy Elizabeth Espenshade (Dave Kyllo) of Evanston. She is also survived by her sister Peggy J. McCormick (Jay E.) of Highland Park, and nieces Barbara Stika (Charles) and Laura McCormick (Robert Boiko). Her family benefitted especially from her gentle wisdom, fierce advocacy and mindful caring. This gracious and spunky lady will be greatly missed. Funeral services will be held at St. Matthew's Episcopal Church, Evanston, at 11:00 AM on Tuesday, May 27, 1997. Interment will be at Memorial Park Cemetery, Skokie. In lieu of flowers, Deb suggested donations be made to the Evanston Hospital Corporation Department of Nursing General Fund, 1301 Central St., Evanston, IL 60201; Chicago Botanic Garden, 1000 Lake Cook Road, Glencoe, IL 60022; or Hospice of the North Shore, 2821 Central St., Evanston, IL 60201. For information, contact Ahlgrim & Sons Ltd., Lake Zurich.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  BUCHHOLTZ, NORMA R.
description: BUCHHOLTZ-Norma R. I struggle to endure the pain of your absence. You were my life long companion and best friend. Our children, grandchildren and I will forever miss your wise counsel and concerns. Je t'aime toujours. Sid

title: Valerie Lentz, Benjamin Horowitz
description: Valerie Quinn Lentz and Benjamin David Horowitz are to be married today in Upper Montclair, N.J. Cantor Elliot D. Levine is to perform the ceremony at the couple's home.

title: Five Win in Mt. Vernon Vote
description: EARLIER this month the people of this, the second-largest school district in the county, went to the polls to elect five trustees to the Board of Education, and for the first time they also determined the fate of the school budget, a $95.9 million proposal for the 1997-98 school year..

title: Moving From Carnal Bliss to Something Truly Divine
description: MOVIEGOERS ARE talking about ''Chasing Amy,'' Kevin Smith's comedy about a regular guy from New Jersey who falls for a lipstick lesbian with a foul mouth and an adorably pouty voice, and one of the things they're saying is that it isn't at all what they expected. While the reviews have mostly emphasized the funny parts, the film also turns out to be quite dark. Holden and Alyssa, the hero and heroine of ''Chasing Amy'' played by Ben Affleck and Joey Lauren Adams, discover that love isn't enough to keep a relationship going. It takes something more, something only one of them has -- and that something may just be what theologians call grace.

title: Bikers Need Safety Headgear
description: On the same page as the ''The 17th Blessing of the Bikes: 3,000 Vivid Tales From the Road'' $(May 11$), you feature an oversize photograph of a smiling motorcyclist with his head covered by nothing more protective than a bandanna.

title: Saved From Drowning
description: DOWN BY THE RIVER

title: Light, Both Literally And Symbolically, Shows Its Influence
description: Intervals of Light

title: The Asphalt Diamond
description: CERTAIN truths hold tough no matter how hard the passing decades try to swat them down. Eddie Brennan could be counted on to trap a bullet in his hands standing on third. Charles Ballard had a knack for line-driving a spaldeen right into the rough bulge of a brick wall, where it ricocheted in ways not even a clairvoyant could predict. And John Stephens, who met his wife at a church dance, always managed to pocket a good $50 after slamming the ball past a sewer or two.

title: ON THE TOWNS
description: An opinionated guide to cultural and recreational goings-on around the state this week. To submit items for consideration, write to On the Towns, Sunday New Jersey Section, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036, or send a fax to (212) 556-7219.

title: Elizabeth Harrison, Keith Schwebel
description: Elizabeth Scott Harrison, the daughter of Marianne and Stephen Harrison of Beaufort, S.C., is to be married there today at the Rhett House Inn to Keith Jay Schwebel, a son of Elizabeth Schwebel and Dr. Sheldon Schwebel of Corte Madera, Calif. The bride's father, a notary public, is to officiate.

description: An article last Sunday about Internet sites on the East End misstated the name of a company that publicizes artists and writers. It is Hamptonclick (www.hamptonclick.com), not Hamptonsclick.

title: Graeme Lipper, Catherine Goldberg
description: Catherine Jill Goldberg, the daughter of Caren Goldberg and Dr. Paul A. Goldberg of Stamford, Conn., is to be married today to Graeme Martin Lipper, the son of Naomi Lipper and Dr. Stanley Lipper of Great Neck, N.Y. Rabbi Emily Faust Korzenik is to perform the ceremony at Temple Shaaray Tefila in Bedford, N.Y.

title: Final Analysis
description: To The Sports Editor:

title: Retailers Swim Against a Tide of Shoppers' Bad Debts
description: FOR much of 1996, retail analysts and investors were gleeful as they watched same-store sales at Sears, Roebuck & Company rise past their monthly marks of a year earlier. But a sizable chunk of those sales never made it into the company's coffers, let alone to its bottom line.

title: Susannah Nathan And John Files 3d
description: Susannah Day Nathan, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. David A. Nathan of Bethesda, Md., was married there yesterday to John Files 3d, a son of Jane B. McDermott and John R. Files, both of Portland, Me. Dr. Arthur C. Blecher, a rabbi, officiated at the Congressional Country Club. The Rev. Michael J. Kelley, a Roman Catholic priest, took part in the ceremony.

title: Signs of Gold in Latin America's Blue Chips
description: TRUE to their name, blue-chip stocks are not cheap these days. Indeed, their increase in value has been the primary engine of the bull market. But not all big companies come with big price tags: the Latin American stocks that trade here as American depository receipts are often relatively inexpensive, even though they come from one of the world's hottest economic regions.

title: Author of Book on Poppy Cultivation Cleared of Drug Charge
description: The case was enough to set any garden club atwitter. A Seattle man, Jim Hogshire, had been charged with possessing flowers.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  CHRISTY, BEVERLY M.
description: CHRISTY-Beverly M. Grace Church, 802 Broadway at 10th Street, Thursday, May 29, 5:00 PM. Reception following Service.

title: Record Crowd Sees Maryland and Princeton Win and Advance to the N.C.A.A. Final
description: Undefeated Princeton and upstart Maryland captured tense one-goal victories at Byrd Stadium today to reach the National Collegiate Athletic Association Division I tournament final.

title: A Museum for Cyclists Who Moved Beyond Training Wheels
description: To the casual cyclist, the United States Bicycling Hall of Fame in Somerville seems strangely out of the way, fronting on an alley well off Main Street. But most of the Hall of Fame's 2,000 visitors a year know where to go ahead of time, stopping by while they're in town for the annual Tour of Somerville, a world-class cycling race, to be held tomorrow. The museum of memorabilia and a gallery of 57 top bikers chosen by the cycling press, including the six being inducted today, is cycling's modest version of the Baseball Hall of Fame in Cooperstown, N.Y. (Mountain biking has its own, in Crested Butte, Colo.)

title: At the Casinos
description: What's happening onstage at all the Atlantic City casinos this week.

title: Knickerbocker Gothick
description: Along the shores of the Hudson River between New York City and Albany are to be found a surprising number of great mansions -- castles even. A few remain in private hands, others have been restored and are open to the public, and many are in ruins. These last are evocatively captured by Monica Randall's sepia-tinted photographs in PHANTOMS OF THE HUDSON VALLEY: The Glorious Estates of a Lost Era (Overlook, $55; $65 after Dec. 31). The well-known homes like the Rockefellers' Kykuit and Jay Gould's Lyndhurst don't gain much in the moody images here, but Ms. Randall's treatments of the Scottish-styled island fortress of the notorious arms dealer Francis Bannerman (near Fishkill) and the unlucky and never finished Dick's Castle in Garrison capture the haunting atmosphere of great wealth's trappings gone to seed. Ms. Randall is perhaps a little too receptive to tales of ghosts walking the riverbanks, but this is Washington Irving territory after all. And she does provide entertaining lore along with her pictures. There's the magnificent Beechwood, where the author is told Isadora Duncan once danced on the lawn. (Ms. Randall is also told that the Wright Brothers landed their new plane there and that a madman named Mathias murdered five beautiful virgins and buried them in the basement, so who knows?) The place has been turned into condominiums. And then there is Wyndcliff. Now deserted and falling down, it was built in 1852 by Elizabeth Schermerhorn Jones, a cousin of Mrs. William B. Astor. It is likely that many residents of at least some parts of the present-day Hudson Valley can relate to this Gothic monstrosity. One of the most extravagant houses of its time, it is said to have inspired the phrase ''keeping up with the Joneses.'' Robert R. Harris

description: Contrary to the assertion in ''Doctor in Forefront of Overseas Adoptions'' $(May 4$) that there is a paucity of qualified medical professionals who are involved in screening, etc., these children, there is a sizable number of pediatricians both American and foreign born who have extensive international experience in this sphere.

title: The Chanel Under the Chador
description: I would like to tell Elaine Sciolino that the chador *is* a power suit for Muslim women (''The Chanel Under the Chador,'' May 4). Unlike women in the United States, we are not measured by how short our skirts are or how we look. Eating disorders, liposuction, breast implants and cosmetics are not multimillion-dollar businesses in the Muslim community. Just because Muslim women cover our hair doesn't mean we cover our brains.

Armini of Manchester, Mass. Canon James W. Francis performed the ceremony at the Anglican Cathedral of the Most Holy Trinity in Hamilton, Bermuda.

The Rev. Mark Tremblay is to perform the ceremony at St. Andrew's Presbyterian Church in Hamilton, Bermuda.

description: In the following reports, the ''listed at'' price is the asking price when negotiations began that ended in the sale. Time on market is from most recent listing to contract.

description: The popular notion from the third round of the Stanley Cup playoffs is that a transition of power is taking place, that Eric Lindros of Philadelphia is surpassing Mark Messier of the Rangers as the premier power center in the National Hockey League.

title: An Art World Emerging Into the Cuban Sun
description: THE PASSAGEWAY IS LONG and narrow, its thick outer wall pierced by a row of lookout slits for riflemen, the opposite wall leaning oddly inward, like a side of a gravity-defying fun-house cabin. Posters of a blindfolded man juxtaposed with pictures of tanks, baby dolls, waterfalls and sunsets line this awkwardly angled stone surface that a visitor fingers gingerly for support before emerging from the cool darkness into the bright inner court and the heavy heat of another Havana morning.

title: What Exactly Is LIPA Hiding?
description: PICTURE this. Your car dies and you need a new one . . .fast. You go to a used-car lot. The salesman shows you what seems to be a serviceable vehicle, and the price is a bit steep but still within reason. You say, ''It looks like a pretty good deal, but I want my mechanic to check it out first.'' The used-car salesman shakes his head. ''No can do,'' he says smoothly. ''See, I have another buyer who wants to buy this baby. In fact, he'll be here within the hour, If you want it, you have to take it now.''

title: Pace Graduates Urged to Seek Meaning
description: Eleven hundred graduates of Pace University received their degrees yesterday in the Art Deco splendor of Radio City Music Hall. An additional 2,200 students from the school's Westchester campuses graduated in ceremonies in the last several days.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BABSON, DONALD P.
description: BABSON-Donald P., of Wellesley, Massachusetts; on April 21, 1997. He was 73. Husband of the late Susan (Averill) Babson. He is survived by 5 children: Averill Babson & her husband Gregory E. Sohns of Darien, CT, Paul Talbot Babson, II of Needham, MA, James A. Babson and his wife Asoka Bandarage of South Hadley, MA., Deborah Babson of Jaffrey, N.H. & Richard Babson of Boston, MA., three granddaughters: Olivia Louise Sohns, Antonia Averill Sohns and Juliet Susan Babson of Darien, CT, and one grandson, Maithri Bandarage Babson of South Hadley, MA. The family requests that no flowers be sent. Contributions in his name may be made to the institution or charity that best represents your affiliation with Donald P. Babson. A memorial service and celebration of his life will commence at 7:30 PM, Friday, May 30, in Knight Auditorium on the Babson College Campus. Mr. Babson was Chairman of BabsonUnited Investment Advisors, Inc. as well as chairman and President of United Business Service. For information call J.S. Waterman and Sons-Waring Funeral Home, Wellesley, Massachusetts (617235-4110).

title: Body in Park Was Mutilated To Hide Identity, Officials Say
description: The two 15-year-olds accused of killing a man whose body was found slashed and disemboweled in the Lake in Central Park early Friday had tried to cut off his hands and burn the contents of his wallet in an apparent attempt to conceal his identity, prosecutors said yesterday.

Her father suggested that she try AT&T, where he had spent his entire 45-year career as an accountant. So she donned a suit and matching hat and went to the personnel office.

description: Not long after the sun rose here above a rusty railroad bridge on a recent morning, a battered blue launch pulled away from a jetty beside the Padma River, as the Ganges is known after it leaves India and enters Bangladesh.

title: Medley of Baby Vegetables, Light but Rich
description: WHAT is more suggestive of spring than baby vegetables? Bunches of tiny carrots, downy pods of fava beans, miniature artichokes, thin-skinned potatoes no bigger than golf balls and skinny asparagus and French haricots verts can inspire soups, salads and even a rich but light main-dish ragout.

title: Nicole Kenneally, Christopher Berger
description: FROM the start, Christopher Berger was unlike anyone Nicole Kenneally had ever met.

description: IS Calvin Hill (a) the name of a former Dallas Cowboy running back (b) the father of Grant Hill of the Detroit Pistons basketball team or (c) the name of a 26-year-old day care center at Yale University in New Haven?

title: Frederick Werle, 87, Composer and Teacher
description: Frederick Werle, a composer and former dean of the Mannes College of Music, died on May 15 at his home in Southbury, Conn. He was 87.

title: The Japanese Honor Their Ancestors
description: FOR decades, the Japanese community in New York has observed Memorial Day by holding communal services at cemeteries where much of its community is buried.

title: Train Derailment Snarls Holiday Travel for Hours
description: A minor train derailment blocked rail traffic for about two hours at Pennsylvania Station yesterday, delaying travel plans for hundreds of passengers on the first day of the long Memorial Day weekend.

description: It is customary for the fanatic golfer to say that when he dies he wants his ashes scattered across Monterey Bay near the 18th tee at Pebble Beach.

title: The Last Man of Letters
description: You only have to do a little arithmetic to see that V. S. Pritchett, who died recently at the age of 96, was older than George Orwell and Evelyn Waugh, a year younger than Hemingway, an impressionable teen-ager (and young adult) during World War I, old enough to read Henry James while James was still alive, and the same for Joseph Conrad, for Kipling, for D. H. Lawrence, for Joyce. He was middle-aged when H. G. Wells died in 1946; indeed, he knew Wells, and had the same lower-middle-class background on the shabby genteel fringes of London. As with Wells, these stifling suburbs were the origin of his frustration, which found release in his clearsighted satire.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TOMLINSON, FORREST
description: TOMLINSON - Forrest. Loving husband of Olive. Adored father of John and Peter. Dearest brother of Carol Spencer. Died peacefully on Martha's Vineyard on May 22. Memorial service in New York City to be announced.

description: Randolfe Wicker heads the Cloning Rights United Front in New York.

title: Julie Gibbons, Philip Murray 3d
description: Julie Elizabeth Gibbons, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James D. Gibbons of Short Hills, N.J., was married yesterday to Philip Wilhelm Murray 3d, a son of Anne F. Murray of Newport News, Va., and the late David M. Murray. The Rev. Jude Salus performed the ceremony in St. Mary's Abbey at the Delbarton School in Morristown, N.J.

title: Here Comes the Bride, and then the Bill
description: DRIVING past the local duck ponds the other day, I saw the first bride of the season. This is always a traumatic moment for a man. Like Veteran's Day, it brings back so many memories. She stood under the flowering cherries, her gown and veil blowing out like badly reefed sails in a stiff breeze. Several bridesmaids struggled to get the billowing satin under control, while their high heels sank in the muddy turf. A photographer and a videographer danced around the wedding party, getting in each other's way as they tried to frame the bride, the cherry trees, the pond and the ducks all in the same shot, but without including the derelict restaurant or the motorcycle shop. The groom stood off disconsolately to one side, hitching up his rented pants and looking wistfully at a Harley-Davidson parked across the street.

title: WARY ON ECONOMY, A SULLEN FRANCE GOES TO THE POLLS
description: The French vote Sunday in a sullen mood, unhappy with themselves and the economy, envious but wary of American economic success and unsure that even a more closely united Europe can solve their economic problems.

title: Rental Capitalizes on Capitalists' Proximity
description: On his way to work last week Joseph Warburton decided to stop by the Exchange to check out its offerings. Not the Big Board, but the apartment building across from it at 25 Broad Street.

title: Nothing Mega About It Except the Applause
description: FOUR DAYS AFTER THE TONY Awards ceremony next Sunday, with all its attendant hoopla at Radio City Music Hall, a play that began life far from Broadway, in the impoverished world of noncommercial theater, will reopen on the strength of some of the most glowing reviews of this or any other season.

title: Assessing The Future Of Yonkers Raceway
description: IT happened more than three decades ago, but Vinny Aurigemma remembers it as if it was yesterday. Driving north one evening from the Bronx, he spied the lights of the Yonkers Raceway and a cloud of smoke billowing from the grandstand in the days when diehard gamblers smoked with one breath and placed their wagers with the next. In a tale not unusual for its time, the eager young man embraced the world of horse racing and strike-it-rich fantasies and never looked back.

title: In the Caribbean, a Mixture of Cultures
description: IN important respects the debate over multiculturalism is moot. In many places an irreversible mixing of cultures has already taken place. A paradigm of this amalgamation is the countries of the Caribbean: they are a laboratory of heady mixtures of European, African, Asian and Mesoamerican Indian cultures.

title: Blair's Undaunted Envoy to Ulster: Devil or Angel?
description: In the three weeks since she became the highest-ranking official in the British province of Northern Ireland, Mo Mowlam has emerged with two images.

title: New, Less Toxic Weapons In the War Against Insects
description: CREEPING crawlers -- bugs, flies, moths and so on -- are beginning to appear, all set for a run that will take them into the fall. The most immediate response is do something to try to get rid of them. Squashing them underfoot is one time-honored way. Powerful poisons are another. But many homeowners would rather do the right thing: choose kinder, gentler ways of control, ones that harm neither the neighborhood nor the environment.

title: Leah Binder, Sam Elowitch
description: Leah Frieda Binder, an adviser on health issues in the Mayor's office in New York, was married last evening to Sam Lyons Elowitch, a book editor. Rabbi Harry Z. Sky officiated at the Radisson Eastland Hotel in Portland, Me.

description: Seeing Double

description: Tally Last Week in Connecticut, New Jersey and New York

title: Place to Play That Invites Wheelchairs
description: Without her metal crutches, but with a soft, protective helmet, Melinda Vasquez, 8, made her way up the gently sloping ramp to the top of the climbing structure. She grabbed an overhead bar and lowered herself onto a sliding board. Across the playground, Dayquan Herring, also 8, mounded sand in a sandbox at just the right height for him to maneuver his wheelchair up to the edge.

title: When Knotweed Is Not a Weed and Other Truths
description: If you make your garden rich and hospitable for the plants you favor, it only stands to reason that you will have even more of the plants you do not favor. Weeds, that is.

title: A Visitor From Germany Brings a Gift of Grace
description: Back home in Hachenburg, Germany, they find it strange that the Rev. Horst Krueger should be so attached to a South Bronx church.

title: In, Out and Maybe In Again: Office Politics at Navellier
description: LOUIS G. NAVELLIER, who was ousted in March as manager of the Navellier Aggressive Small Cap Equity fund, appears to be on the road to regaining control of the fund's portfolio.

title: I'm Going to Yesterland!
description: It has been said that Disneyland memories last a life. Maybe so, but the attractions don't. For various reasons, old rides and pageants are frequently scrapped as part of Disney's ever-evolving campaign to build a better tourist trap. That's where ''Yesterland'' comes in. A virtual theme park maintained on the Web by Werner Weiss, a computer-systems consultant based in the Chicago area, Yesterland celebrates Disneyland attractions that no longer exist. Walt Disney once said, ''Disneyland will never be completed as long as there is imagination left in the world.'' Weiss shoots back, ''Yesterland will never be completed as long as there are attractions left to close at Disneyland.'' Here's a visit to a phantom zone of fun gone by.

title: All the World Finds a Stage in an Arts Festival
description: WHERE else can you get every kind of theater and all the ethnicities of the Lower East Side in one place at one time?'' That is the question posed by Crystal Field, executive director of the Theater for the New City, which is putting on the second annual Lower East Side Festival of the Arts next weekend.

title: Ghost Baby
description: Elizabeth Cohen's Lives column ''Ghost Baby'' (May 4) caught me by surprise. I was not prepared for the rush of emotions that overcame me. It has been a long time since my last miscarriage. (Having had five pregnancies, I am the mother of one child.)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DOMINICK, ELIZABETH YALLALEE
description: DOMINICK-Elizabeth Yallalee, of New Canaan, CT., and Southern Pines, NC passed away on May 19. Beloved wife of Bayard Dominick. Survived by her children, Mrs. Jonathan O'Brien, Gayer G. Dominick II, Margrett Dominick Grummon, Edward Hoyt Dominick and Wilder Dominick Witt, 12 grandchildren and six great-grandchildren. Graveside services 11AM on Tuesday, May 27 at Lakeview Cemetery in New Canaan, CT. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be sent to Waveny Care Center, New Canaan, CT. 06840.

title: Dear Cousin Julius
description: Just when I try to believe I will hear no new harrowing accounts of the Holocaust, Michael Winerip tells me of the murder of dear Cousin Max, with active participation of the United States Government and a rigid, uncaring bureaucracy.

title: Old Flames and Trillionaires
description: THE ACTUAL

title: Books Have Endured For a Reason . . .
description: IT'S been more than 20 years since we started hearing about ''the paperless office.'' So pause for a moment and look around: Is your office paperless yet? We'll bet not (and we'll confess that our offices aren't, either).

title: When Bike Clubs Get Rolling, the Miles Just Roll By
description: Joan Harper hadn't been on her bicycle in five years. She had become so busy teaching violin and viola, and she had moved from Brooklyn to Montclair, where she didn't know riding routes or biking buddies. But last year, Ms. Harper, who says she is in ''late middle age,'' felt the need to be physically active again and finally had the time.

title: Pollution as a Public Good
description: States have tried to lure businesses with tax breaks, grants and low-interest loans. Now, New York is offering a new incentive: permission to pollute.

title: Escape via River: Taxis on the Hudson
description: There is a new alternative to New York's crowded subways and buses and hectic cab rides: air-conditioned water taxis. Beginning this month, New York Water Taxi -- started by Tom Fox, former president of the Hudson River Park Conservancy -- is offering shuttle service aboard three 48-passenger vessels that will make stops, including the Intrepid Sea Air Space Museum, the Circle Line dock at the end of West 42d Street, the 30th Street Heliport, Chelsea Piers, Pier 25 in TriBeCa, Battery Park City, the Battery, South Street Seaport and Fulton Ferry Landing in downtown Brooklyn. The round trip takes about 90 minutes.

description: Bright Angel Time

title: Ghost Baby

Bikales of Paris and McLean, Va. Rabbi David Kornberg is to perform the ceremony at the Flynn Theater in Burlington, Vt.

description: Suzanne Katherine Ort and Hynek Wichterle were married yesterday at Letna Park in Prague by District Magistrate Karel Kotek.

title: Clinton Takes Congress to Task Over Delay in Flood Relief
description: In a harsh attack reminiscent of the budget fights of two years ago, President Clinton today accused the Republican Congress of an ''unconscionable'' failure for taking a spring vacation without voting on billions of dollars of relief for flood-soaked states.

title: Thelma Biracree, 93, a Choreographer
description: Thelma Biracree Schnepel, who danced with Martha Graham in 1926 in her first concert, died on May 12 at the Harborside Health Care center in Fort Wayne, Ind. She was 93 and lived in Fort Wayne.

title: Stacy Weiss-Sinclair, Eugene Walden
description: Stacy Michelle Weiss-Sinclair, a freelance graphic designer, was married yesterday to Eugene Marvin Walden, a computer programmer. The Rev. Sheila Davies Sumner performed the nondenominational ceremony at the Garden Valley Ranch, a rose farm in Petaluma, Calif.

title: Who Are Persecutors?
description: To the Editor:

title: Enlivening a Corridor in Downtown Washington
description: THE renovation of two vacant downtown department store buildings -- and tentative plans for redeveloping a third -- are sparking hopes that the city's long-moribund F Street retail corridor may be reborn as a mixed-use office and entertainment district.

title: Some Hope for Campaign Reform
description: It is no secret in Washington that the proponents of campaign finance reform have had trouble rounding up supporters in Congress. Despite overwhelming popular demand for curbing the flow of corporate and special-interest money into the political system, and the troubling disclosures about abuses by Democrats and Republicans, the politicians who have profited from the current system were never likely to embrace change. But the cause of reform is not as bleak as some suppose. In fact, there are signs of life and grounds for hope.

title: Game 4 Request: Malone Wants the Ball
description: There was a slight shadow across the face of Jerry Sloan from the John Deere tractor cap tilted up on his forehead. And yet, the Utah Jazz coach's bemused look was visible.

title: WITH THE WORLD AT THEIR FEET
description: IT was no small triumph, walking through the high gate past the great stone walls of the massive Castello di Brolio, where the modern formula for the blend of chianti wine was devised in the last century. For 20 minutes on a glorious afternoon in June, my companions and I had hiked up the steep hill to the castle terrace. And now, sweaty but glowing after a day of trudging through the hills of Tuscany, our tour group of 15 American walkers gazed past the formal gardens below to the distant skyline of Siena.

title: Corrections
description: A Neighborhood Report article on May 11 about a proposed trolley line in Brooklyn misstated the ownership of one trolley car, an 1897 German model. It is owned by George E. Hassoldt of Staten Island; he lent it to Bob Diamond, who runs the trolley line. A chart with the article misstated part of the car's history. It was not owned by King Oskar II of Norway.

title: Correction
description: A pop music listing on May 11 about the Belleayre Music Festival in High Mountain, N.Y., misstated the festival's telephone number. It is (800) 942-6904, not (914) 942-6904.

title: Not a Bumper-Sticker Issue, But Some Folks Are Curious
description: State Senator James E. McGreevey knew that Governor Whitman's proposed $2.75 billion borrowing for the state pension system was beginning to resonate with voters when two elderly women asked him about it after a church service.

title: A Cleric's Tolerant Orthodoxy Wins
description: Although he is known as gentle, soft-spoken, tolerant and worldly, Iran's President-elect, Mohammed Khatami, rode to victory in large part because of his black turban.

title: Haiti Takes Policing 101
description: To the untrained eye, Jean-Jacques Dessalines Boulevard in the heart of the Port-au-Prince business district looks like a carnival of commerce. Hundreds of Haitian vendors are whittling sugar cane or selling old light switches, stereos, knives, shampoo, batteries, even schoolbooks from cardboard boxes that spill out into a jumble of traffic and pedestrians. For Gus Tavernier, an officer with the New York City Police Department, however, the boulevard is a lesson to be mastered. To be a good cop, Tavernier explains to a Haitian rookie named Accius, you've got to know your environment: the street, the people, their wares, everything. And you've got to know yourself: the equipment you carry, your capabilities, your image -- what Tavernier calls ''impression management.''

title: . . . But Computers Are Clearly the Future
description: I TEACH in a computer lab at a middle school in Connecticut, and what I've learned there has guided my investments. The students thrive on multimedia computer projects that are making them high-technology wizards. And because these students are the future, I'm a firm believer in technology stocks, no matter their twists and turns in the market.

title: Playing Fields Vs. Space
description: FOR parents who have to transport children to athletic practice in the wee hours of the morning or late at night, it is no news that competition for time on the playing field is fierce.

title: Owners Have Learned Tagliabue Is Mr. Fix-It
description: When Robert Kraft and Bill Parcells were in the middle of their breakup, Kraft, the New England Patriots' owner, knew only one person in the National Football League he truly trusted to fix the situation: Commissioner Paul Tagliabue.

title: Fashion's Free Thinkers Use Their Power for Ill
description: To the Editor:

title: Answering the Needs Of Elderly Alcoholics
description: A 73-year-old Yonkers man had never been much of a drinker. He spent his career in the newspaper business and his free time collecting trophies and medals from racing his Harley-Davidson motorcycle.

title: Love, Honor, General Discharge
description: The Air Force's court-martial of its first female B-52 pilot for adultery and insubordination was spinning out of control, already talk show material, soon to be soap opera. But as the pilot, generals, politicians, the cheating husband and finally the cheated-on wife all pointed fingers, suddenly for those at the hard military heart of the issue, everything was inescapably clear: honor must be served.

title: Much Anguish On Both Sides In Pilot's Case
description: Just before 3 o'clock Thursday morning, First Lieut. Kelly Flinn turned to her two older brothers and announced in a tone more of resignation than of anger that she had changed her mind.

description: As a foam-at-the-mouth environmentalist, I think Tierney has it right this time: Government should get out of the rent-regulation business.

title: After Theater Conquest, He Excels in TV
description: WHEN Barry Harman was growing up in Westbury in the 1950's, it was not unusual for him to come home from school and encounter a band rehearsing at high decibels in his family's garage, or to be greeted by a snake dancer as he climbed the stairs to his room.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LINDQUIST, JOHN C.
description: LINDQUIST-John C. On Monday, May 19, 1997, aged 66, of Manhattan, formerly of West Milford, NJ. Husband of the late Apolineria Plocnik. Beloved father of Barbara Spooner and Michael Lindquist and the late Dennis Lindquist, 1993. Beloved father-in-law of Thomas Spooner. Devoted grandfather of Christina, Matthew and Denise Spooner. Brother of the late Charles Lindquist, 1996. Loving companion of Mona Lofton. Reposing at the Richards Funeral Home, 1440 Union Valley Road, West Milford, NJ, on Tuesday, from 2-4 and 7-9 PM. Funeral service is on Wednesday, 10:00 AM. Interment at George Washington Memorial Park, Paramus.

Bossidy of Ridgefield, Conn., is to be married there this afternoon to Scot Russell Mackie, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Norman R. Mackie 2d of Norwalk, Conn. The Rev. Thomas Thorne is to perform the ceremony at St. Mary's Roman Catholic Church.

title: Making Women Taller Safely
description: If women look taller this summer, it is because of the popularity of new platform shoes that combine the delicate straps of sandals with the hefty base of thick-soled 1990's sneakers. The feet shown here are wearing Prada platforms in velvet, leather, swede and a design of appliqued leather vines, sometimes with a matching dress. The new shoes offer an improvement in stability over 40's and 70's styles, whose higher heels were apt to cause foot and ankle injuries.
