He will be remembered as the beloved husband of Ruth, loving father of Jack and Donald, grandfather of Benjamin, brother of Deborah and Bertie. Memorial contributions may be made to the B.E.N. Scholarship Fund for graduates of Cabot School, Vermont. Date and place of service to be announced.

title: How We Live
description: THE WISDOM OF THE BODY By Sherwin B. Nuland. Illustrated. 395 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $26.95.

title: In Westport, the Mediterranean's Bounty
description: IN looks alone, Acqua in Westport is a knockout. Inside and out the walls are saffron. The ground floor has an attractive bar, with some tables; up a long flight of stairs are two dining rooms with river views.

title: The Real Rent Control: Nobody's Moving
description: I WAS once chased out of town for a while by soaring rents on the Upper West Side, so the current debate over decontrol has stirred my curiosity. And despite my current exalted position as the newly elected president of my co-op board, no one will answer my questions.

title: A Co-opera in Two Acts
description: CHRISTINA PETROWSKA and Louis Quilico -- she a world-class pianist, he a world-class opera singer -- were married four years ago, a few months after Mr. Quilico gallantly offered to fill in for Luciano Pavarotti.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  NEUBERGER, MARIE SALANT
description: NEUBERGER-Marie Salant. A Memorial Service for Marie Salant Neuberger will be held Thursday, June 19, 1997 at 5 PM at The New York Society for Ethical Culture, 2 West 64 St, New York, NY.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KOUZAN, ATHENA
description: KOUZAN-Athena. Age 67 of Brooklyn, NY. Died May 14, 1997 following a long and courageous battle with cancer. Born in the Bronx, she lived most of her life in Brooklyn. Member of the NY State Nurses Association, she worked for Kingsbrook Jewish Medical Center for most of her career retiring in 1994. Athena will always be remembered for her love and kindness. Survivors include her brother William of Plymouth, NY; six nieces and nephews, several cousins and a dear friend Crete Manolatos. Friends and relatives are invited to attend a memorial service to be held on Sunday, June 1, at 1 PM, South Presbyterian Church, 343 Broadway, Dobbs Ferry, NY.

title: Crime
description: It was a miracle that George Sueno and Ernie Bascom managed to crawl away alive from Martin Limon's ''Jade Lady Burning,'' and it's great to have these two mavericks back in SLICKY BOYS (Bantam, $21.95). George, a big, tough Mexican from East Los Angeles, and Ernie, a wild man from Detroit, are military cops stationed in Seoul, 20 years into the uneasy Korean peacetime. Prone to danger and violence to begin with, the partners step into more trouble when they pocket cash for delivering a message from a mysterious woman to an English soldier. The soldier is savagely hacked up in an alley, the lady vanishes and the cops stir up antagonisms trying to crush a cartel of ruthless black marketeers.

title: Air Force Blues
description: ''Conduct unbecoming an officer and a gentleman'' is one of those phrases that sounds as if it comes out of Kipling. It says that more is expected of the upper military class. It holds that an elite given the privileges of rank must live up to the leader's burden of higher standards.

title: Shows Mark 100 Years of Katonah Design
description: ACCORDING to all reports, the 100th anniversary of Katonah's relocation was quite a bash. Attractions included not only a parade, complete with marching band, floats, banners and a posse of suffragettes but also a structure symbolizing the original railroad station half a mile south of the present stop.

title: Books in Brief: Fiction
description: BREATHE SOMETHING NICEStories.By Emily Hammond.University of Nevada, paper, $13.

title: Loud or Luxurious In the West 50's
description: AQUAVIT *** $(rating: three stars$)

title: Books in Brief: Fiction
description: The Instructor

title: Mimi Smartypants Takes On the Assassins
description: ZIP through the aisles at the local computer store and the mayhem mounts quickly: ''Ravage,'' ''No Flesh Shall Be Spared'' and ''Assassin'' (''Shoot first, think fast . . . or get smoked'') are typical CD-ROM titles. Market research and sales show that carnage counts with teen-age boys, the target audience for many computer games.

title: Birth of an Empire
description: RUSSIA

title: In Manorial Setting, a New Steakhouse
description: THE visitor from the Midwest looked around the stately wood-paneled dining room at Christo's, gave a contented sigh and exclaimed, ''This is my idea of Long Island.''

title: In Sicily, Wildflowers and Fresh Snow
description: AH!' cried the judge, gathering up the scene with a sweep of his arm. ''Sicily!'' Dutifully we peered after him, through the swirling snow, into the fog, and laughed. Sixteen of us had chosen the Alternative Travel Group walking tour across a remote region of Sicily, the Madonie Mountains, part of which is a national park. And of course we were lured not only by the company's reputation for cosseting guests, but also by the prospect of wandering an unspoiled upland, carpeted with cyclamen and asphodel, borage and wild orchids.

title: Over Objections, U.S. Approves New Logging in Forest in Alaska
description: The Forest Service today authorized extensive new logging for the next 10 years in the Tongass National Forest in southeastern Alaska, the nation's last expanse of old-growth temperate rain forests.

title: Peter Hopkins, Leslie Roseman
description: Leslie Ellen Roseman, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Herbert Roseman of Greenwich, Conn., is to be married at her parents' house today to Peter Frederick Hopkins, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Richard O. Hopkins of Buffalo. The Rev. Nan A. Peete, an Episcopal priest, is to perform the ceremony, in which Rabbi Charles D. Lippman is to take part.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MAGRAM, ROSE
description: MAGRAM-Rose, on May 23, 1997. Devoted wife of the late Louis Magram. Beloved mother of Herbert and Saul. Loving sister of Eve Cassell. Cherished grandmother of Molly, Amy, Linda and Tracy. Truly the matriarch of the family. For information contact Gramcery Park Memorial Chapel, 152 Second Ave., NYC 1-800-462-6364.

title: Jessica Freedman, David P. Jacobs
description: Dr. Jessica Fay Freedman, the daughter of Marian and Jeffrey Freedman of Watchung, N.J., and David Paul Jacobs, a son of Willa and Edward Jacobs of Cheshire, Conn., are to be married this afternoon at the Jewish Center in Princeton, N.J. Rabbi Moshe Samber is to perform the ceremony, in which George B. Driesen, a rabbinical student and an uncle of the bride, is to take part.

title: Rule Too Rigid
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Enchantments of the Cotswolds
description: MY daughter Anne and I bought our tickets and ran through Paddington Station, sweating under heavy bags, to catch the Oxford train. A van owned by the Wayfarers, a British company that organizes European walking tours, met us at Oxford Station and took us to Burford, where we stepped out about half an hour later onto a narrow, crooked street. Forty miles west of London, we seemed to have slipped back three centuries.

title: Assemblywoman's Defection Compounds G.O.P.'s Problems
description: THE defection from Republican ranks by an Assemblywoman from Patchogue has stunned Suffolk Republicans, who were already reeling from allegations by Health Services Commissioner Mary Hibberd, who is leaving office next month.

title: For Digital's Chief, A Last Grab for Glory
description: EAGER to change its stodgy image, the Digital Equipment Corporation was host for ''a night of fun and frivolity'' for reporters and industry analysts at a Manhattan comedy club last week, a world away from its headquarters in a converted mill outside Boston. But Robert B. Palmer, Digital's chairman and chief executive, skipped the event, choosing instead to have dinner on the town.

title: Other Practitioners In Overseas Adoptions
description: Considerable attention has been paid to the medical and developmental risks associated with adopting a child from overseas. I am very familiar with Dr. Jane Aronson's work in this area and would readily agree that she is a wonderful resource to families considering international adoption. However, as director of the Developmental Evaluation Center for Adoption at Schneider Children's Hospital, I was disappointed to see Dr. Aronson described as ''the sole such practitioner on the East Coast.'' There are similar programs in Boston and in New York City.

title: Cleanup Plan In Legal Bind Over Klan's Effort to Join
description: When officials were organizing the state's Adopt a Highway program in 1994, a half-mile stretch of Interstate 55 here was routinely assigned to a local applicant, Michael Cuffley.

title: The Prosecution Rests
description: Federal prosecutors in Denver rested their case against Timothy McVeigh after less than a month of testimony. Their final witness was Oklahoma's medical examiner, who presented the jury with death certificates for the 163 people who died inside the Federal Building in Oklahoma City on April 19, 1995, when a truck loaded with explosives was detonated outside.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KIRSCHNER, MINERVA
description: KIRSCHNER-Minerva. Died May 13, 1997. Beloved aunt. Beloved friend. In her sleep. Dilday Mottell Mortuary (562-421-8411).

title: Correction
description: Because of a typographical error, a letter to the editor last Sunday about Lariam, a preventive for malaria, misstated the incidence of psychiatric side effects reported in the British Medical Journal. It is one in 140, not one in 40.

title: MODERATE LEADER IS ELECTED IN IRAN BY A WIDE MARGIN
description: In a surprising political upset, a candidate who campaigned on a platform of tolerance and social reform has been elected President of Iran in a landslide, defeating the candidate favored by the ruling Islamic clerics, according to results announced today.

title: At the Intersection of Supply and Demand
description: Tierney paints a rosy picture of life in New York after the end of rent regulations -- full of better homes and better neighborhoods, where landlords and tenants live together in perfect harmony. But we can see the success of this ''free'' housing market elsewhere in urban America -- Detroit, Cleveland, Hartford, St. Louis -- where the middle class, encouraged by tax breaks for mortgage-interest deductions, has fled to the suburbs, abandoning the inner city to its fate. That New York hasn't succumbed to this fate might very well be because of the rent regulations that Tierney so disparages for disproportionately benefiting middle-class households.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MARKS, ARTHUR D. JR.
description: MARKS-Arthur D. Jr. Corporate insurance broker in New York City, on May 23, 1997. Husband of late Alice Oppenheimer Marks, loving father of Arthur D. Marks III, Edith M. Seligson, Andrew H. Marks, & the late Alice M. Preston, step-father of John Oppenheimer, Ellen Oasis, and Joan Samuelson. He leaves behind his grandchildren, Nancy Seligson Green, Kate Friedman, Margaret MacKenzie, Elizabeth and Anne Preston, Sam and Charlotte Marks, and Michael and David Solomon, and greatgrandchildren, Drew and Chloe Alice Friedman, and Benjamin Green. Service on Tuesday, May 27, 1997, at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue, at 5 P.M. In lieu of flowers, please give to the charity of your choice.

title: Rebecca Munro, Jason Horning
description: Rebecca Harriet Munro, a daughter of Margaret W. Munro of Dallas and Allan F. Munro of Greenwich, Conn., is to be married today to Jason Earl Horning, the son of Carolee Danz of Kirkland, Wash., and James G. Horning of Los Angeles. Ann Mandel, a justice of the peace in Darien, Conn., is to officiate at the Riverside (Conn.) Yacht Club.

title: 'The Last Plantation'
description: To the Editor:

title: Toxicology Chief Solves Forensic Mysteries
description: ''I DON'T go out on Saturday night, because I know what I'll see on Monday morning,'' said Elizabeth Spratt, chief of toxicological services for the county's Department of Laboratories and Research, part of the Medical Examiner's office here. And Monday morning often means a double load of work for her department.

title: Mob Metaphysician
description: They say I broke the oath. But it wasn't the oath I thought I was taking. I thought it was about honor and brotherhood. . . . It was none of that. It was all about greed and power. In reality, it was a total joke.

title: Remembering an 1858 Greenwich Village Atelier
description: THE show opens June 8 in Southampton, L.I., but the subject is in the heart of Greenwich Village: the 1858 10th Street Studio at 51 West 10th Street. This influential building sheltered artists like William Merritt Chase, Martin Johnson Heade, Frederic Church and Winslow Homer, setting an architectural and social standard for studio quarters. But the exhibition at the Parrish Art Museum is the closest you'll get to the legendary structure -- it was demolished in 1956.

title: At the Intersection of Supply and Demand
description: John Tierney's article ''At the Intersection of Supply and Demand'' (May 4) has the makings of a splendid utopian novel, which might be entitled ''When Landlords Lie Down With Tenants!'' You might, however, have warned your readers that the Magazine has now opened its pages to fiction.

title: Civic Awareness, Public Pleasures
description: IN the early 50's, when it became apparent that developers were eyeing the thousand-acre marshland that bordered the southeastern portion of the Village of Lawrence, residents banded together to raise enough money to buy the land and give it to the community for preservation.

title: French Open for Pierce Remains a High Priority
description: Simplicity has never followed Mary Pierce anywhere, especially not to Paris, where her relationship with her favorite Grand Slam event, the French Open, has been nothing if not traumatic.

title: With Laboratory Reactor Closed, Researchers Wait, and Worry
description: Experimenting with blasts of neutron beams at the main reactor in the Brookhaven National Laboratory, Dr. Leonard F. Mausner developed a radioactive isotope that dulls the pain of bone cancer. But late last year, just as he began to make progress toward using the isotope to destroy cancer cells, a radiation leak was discovered in a laboratory storage tank. The uproar that followed now threatens to close the reactor permanently.

title: Gas-Station Designers Have Fantasies, Too
description: A ROBOTIC arm comes out of a gasoline pump and inserts itself in your gas tank. While it fills your tank, a scanner reads your credit card from a device attached to your key chain. You zoom off in two minutes flat.

title: A Street of Promises and Protest
description: Ever since Donald Trump announced plans in 1991 for a huge housing complex between 59th and 72d Streets near the West Side Highway, community groups have tried to block the project, known as Riverside South, in the courts and in the press. They say it is environmentally and esthetically unsound.

title: No Headline
description: To the Editor:

title: The Earliest Of Early Birds Tees Off First
description: THERE are people who spend every God-given gorgeous Sunday, every Government-issue three-day weekend, every year's vacation putting around a golf course. Then there are the likes of Bill Kingman.

title: A Symbol Of Beauty Unadorned
description: YOU would have thought it was a man striding through the door of the Mark Hotel on the Upper East Side. Men's Industria suit with wide shoulders, a man's shirt with unpressed collar, sensible men's shoes, hair in a near-crew cut. But the face was soft and round, the skin delicate, the hazel eyes doelike. Seemingly in drag, it was Isabella Rossellini.

title: INSIDE
description: Big Break for Drivers

title: The Writer Is Dead
description: Late in a lazy summer -- it was 1994, my wife was expecting our first child -- I received a phone call from a prominent book editor who asked to speak in absolute secrecy. I was told that a multimillion-dollar nonfiction book by a famous person had just arrived in the office, and it was incomprehensible. Since I had once been a magazine editor with a reputation for turning around long, rambling articles, I was being asked to become a book doctor.

title: Cash to Spare, Giuliani Is Set To Unleash Ad Campaign
description: The towering pile of contributions supporting Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's re-election campaign has already performed what may have been its paramount task: helping to scare off many of his most formidable contenders, including Borough President Fernando Ferrer of the Bronx. Now, as the summer season begins, the Mayor is preparing to open the vault and begin the more prosaic work of winning voters with all that cash.

title: Mayoral Hopeful Urges CUNY Tuition Cut
description: Councilman Sal F. Albanese of Brooklyn, a Democratic candidate for mayor, called on Friday for a 50 percent cut in tuition at the City University of New York and said that the city should increase its support of CUNY to pay for the reduction.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL 3-13

title: Brazil's Mighty Mite Saves the Day for African Cassava Crop
description: Researchers have greatly increased crop yields of cassava, the starchy root that is a staple food for 200 million Africans, by returning to the plant's Latin American origins to control a destructive pest.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STONE, BETTY LEA (BARNES)
description: STONE-Betty Lea (Barnes), of Needham, MA. and Marion, MA., May 23, 1997. Wife of the late Robert Gregg Stone. Mother of Galen L. of Dedham, MA., Robert G. Jr. of Greenwich, CT., David B. of Marion, MA., Elizabeth S. Trumbull of Santa Monica, CA and Henry A. of Harrisville, Michigan. Also survived by 26 grandchildren and 45 great grandchildren. A memorial service at St. Paul's Episcopal Church, 59 Court Street Dedham, MA., on Wednesday, May 28 at 11 A.M. In lieu of flowers, donations may be sent to the Betty Lea Stone-American Cancer Society, Research Fellowship Program, 20 Speen Street, Framingham, MA. 01701. For more information call J.S. Waterman and Sons, 617235-4110.

title: Swallowing the Costs
description: Fewer money market funds are absorbing expenses to bolster yields. But to get off to a good start, Zurich Yield Wise Money is doing just that.

title: Complaints on Rome Bar Have a Familiar Ring
description: To the Editor:

title: Everyone Gets Into The Act
description: A good week for charities, education, business, the arts and the military.

title: Paul's Big Adventure
description: Seething with frustration during last year's debate on welfare reform, Senator Paul Wellstone, the liberal Democrat from Minnesota, scrapped his prepared speech and declared that he would tour the poorest parts of the country in 1997, just as Robert F. Kennedy did 30 years ago. He's starting in the Mississippi Delta, and though most Mississippians aren't aware of it, Wellstone is headed their way this week.

title: Kara Lobdell and Buzz Shattan
description: Kara A. Lobdell, a lawyer, and Boaz M. Shattan Jr., an investment banker, were married on Friday in New York. The Rev. M. Bardet Wardell, an interfaith minister, performed the nondenominational ceremony at the Harvard Club.

title: Final Trip for A Venerable Flying Boat
description: SOMETIME in early June, the Excambian, a giant -- nearly 80 feet long, 16 feet wide -- and storied flying boat of another era will make its final journey of 71 miles on an oversized tractor trailer and with a State Police escort.

title: Nobody's Home
description: NORMAL

title: Prosecutors Who Still Haven't Rested
description: Hunched forward in his chair, his hand trembling, the elderly man recalled how he had been assaulted and robbed in his Brooklyn home.

title: Ranking the Airlines: Mixed Reviews
description: Southwest Airlines was rated No. 1 for the second consecutive year in a recent survey of domestic airlines. American Airlines finished second, followed by United Airlines.

title: Anti-Dieting Crusade Sponsors Own Day to Promote Health
description: DOWN with the tyranny of thinness! Smash your bathroom scale! Food is not the enemy! Those slogans were among the rallying cries of International No Diet Day earlier this month.

title: A Scenario Where Everybody Wins
description: To the Editor:

title: Youth Seeks National Geography Victory
description: DEEPAK KOLLALI, an eighth grader, does not dream of visiting exotic archipelagos or remote provincial capitals, but he does dream of naming them.

title: Anne Rubin, Lodge Gillespie
description: Anne Sarah Rubin, the daughter of Deborah B. Rubin of White Plains and Leonard H. Rubin of Irvington, N.Y., was married last evening to John Lodge Gillespie Jr., the son of Sandra and John Gillespie of Hanover, N.H. Rabbi Aaron B. Bisno performed the ceremony at the Boar's Head Inn in Charlottesville, Va.

title: Opera and Orchestra's Youth and Experience
description: THE Connecticut Grand Opera and Orchestra, like so many fine regional companies around the country, populates its productions with gifted young singers, local performers and artists from other countries who have yet to establish a major American presence. For its last presentation of the season, however, the opera and orchestra features Sherrill Milnes, for more than 30 years a leading baritone at the Metropolitan, in an evening of Puccini.

title: Recalling a First Lady's Style and Substance
description: Not everything from Jacqueline Kennedy Onassis' estate was auctioned off at Sotheby's last year. Many personal artifacts, documents and photographs were donated by Caroline Kennedy Schlossberg and John F. Kennedy Jr. to the John F. Kennedy Library and Museum in Boston.

title: Flying Into Sarajevo: Possible, but Not Easy
description: EVEN though the Bosnian war has been over for more than a year, there is still something faintly incongruous about the idea of taking a scheduled flight into Sarajevo -- a city associated for many people with spiraling descents from the air by military transport planes, sniper fire on the streets and danger.

title: A Hot Market Leads to Cold-Blooded Dealing
description: IT was a simple mimeographed sheet hanging from the corner of the receptionist's desk in the real estate office. ''Seminar,'' it read. ''How to Manage Anger, Conflict and Emotion.''

title: Pollution Alert
description: When ''Ellen'' finally came out this month, Chrysler wanted out, too -- as one of its sponsors. That didn't alter or damage the show; the hyped but chaste revelation that its heroine was a lesbian, on and off the air, attracted a huge audience and more new business than ABC/Disney cared to handle. Afraid of its own triumphant shadow, the network rejected a decorous commercial on ''Ellen'' for a lesbian travel service.

title: Helping the Young, At Whose Expense?
description: To the Editor:

title: Ms. Whitmore And Mr. Lurding
description: Elizabeth Anne Whitmore, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John R. Whitmore of Greenwich, Conn., is to be married this evening to Donald Scott Lurding, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Donald R. Lurding of Louisville, Ky. The Rev. Ervin A. Brown is to perform the ceremony at Christ Episcopal Church in St. Michaels, Md.

title: Don't Suppress Art
description: To the Editor:

title: Elisabeth Hickey, John Podhoretz
description: Elisabeth Marie Hickey, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Paul J. Hickey of Great Barrington, Mass., was married yesterday to John Mordecai Podhoretz, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Norman Podhoretz of New York. Judge Laurence Silberman of the United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit officiated at the University Club in Washington.

title: Sharon Perley, Mark Masling
description: Sharon Nan Perley and Mark S. Masling, lawyers in Washington, are to be married there today. Rabbi Robert J. Saks is to perform the ceremony at the Meridian House, a historic house.

title: Glorious Starting Points for Prayer
description: OVER THE LAST FEW YEARS, increasing numbers of religious relics -- Roman Catholic, Protestant and other -- have been crossing over into the domestic realm, appreciated anew for their esthetics alone. Victorian pews are cushioned with chintz and placed on summer porches. Italian altar candlesticks illuminate dining room tables in SoHo. And in the Paris flea market, battered crystal-bead and pressed-metal tiaras that once adorned statues of the Virgin can be found for around $100, while a shop near the Louvre does a brisk business in redundant church linens.

title: Showing Another Side of a Familiar Composer
description: HOW REFRESHING IT IS, at a time when national vocal styles barely survive and the world's singers tend toward a general blandness, to encounter an artist who has both an excellent voice and a real interpretive sense.

title: At the Intersection of Supply and Demand
description: Tierney says that an end to rent regulation will result in the construction of thousands of new apartments, an increase in supply that will keep rents affordable. But as he well knows, New York largely consists not of anomalous ''transitional'' neighborhoods like Alphabet City, where new housing would undoubtedly attract new tenants, but of thoroughly gentrified neighborhoods and neighborhoods that (for reasons of poverty or poor access to office jobs) have long been considered undesirable by white-collar tenants.

title: Mystery Women
description: LIGHTNING SONG

title: Books in Brief: Fiction
description: Remnants of the First Earth

title: Indy 500 Is Facing Questions of Survival
description: You may have seen this ad: Win a trip to one of America's five biggest sports events, including that auto racing classic.

title: Getting There Isn't Always the Point; Being There Is
description: Down past the Dairy Queen and Stewart's Root Beer, home of tray service, hot Texas Wieners and a middle-aged Elvis, a waterfall was singing to Kate Sullivan.

title: A Silver Thimble in Her Fist
description: The God of Small Things By Arundhati Roy. 321 pp. New York: Random House. $23.

title: Co-Workers' Plea Wins Reversal of Penalty
description: Reversing a decision, The New York Public Library will not dock two workers who took several hours to search for a colleague who had been missing from work and then was found dead. The earlier decision led to protests from the union, Local 1930, which represents workers of the New York Public Library Guild.

title: The 'No Violence' Light Is On
description: Secondhand cigarette smoke, already blamed for more than 3,000 deaths a year from lung cancer in the United States, faced far worse charges last week. A Harvard study found that regular exposure to other people's smoke at home or work nearly doubled the risk of heart attack, adding as many as 50,000 more deaths to the yearly toll.

title: Adriana Carrillo And James Harper
description: Adriana Carrillo, a daughter of Carlota and Jorge Carrillo of Puebla, Mexico, was married yesterday to James Vance Harper, the son of Gloria and Nelson V. Harper of New York. The Rev. Dr. Thomas K. Tewell performed the ceremony at the Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church in New York.

title: When Hotels Love Children
description: HOTELS and motels are plumping up their pillows and setting out their special offers for families taking to the road this summer.

title: Many Newspapers On the East End
description: Our two community newspapers, The Suffolk Times (Southold Town) and The News-Review (Riverhead Town), were snubbed. We're used to the North Fork being covered as an afterthought, but we can't help wondering if your reporter bothered to do any research north of Sag Harbor.

title: John Sexton Pleads (and Pleads and Pleads) His Case
description: People who choose the intellectual life tend to maintain a bemused, even disdainful distance from the hyperbolic enthusiasm and salesmanship that constitute so much of the workaday world. This is one reason that academic institutions have so much trouble finding strong leaders. John Sexton, a theologian and an expert in civil procedure, has been dean of New York University Law School since 1988. It's safe to say that almost all of Sexton's colleagues are grateful that he is able to conduct himself in a way that they themselves would find unthinkable.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: Baseball

title: Fasting, and the Beach, for Self-Renewal
description: THE sun pours into the kitchen of Pamela Serure's house in Bridgehampton, where she has created organic vegetable and juice mixtures for people like Barbra Streisand and Christie Brinkley and for customers of her former store, Get Juiced.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  DIAMOND, JUDGE THEODORE (TEDDY)
description: DIAMOND-Judge Theodore (Teddy). On June 6, 1995. We miss you everyday. Your loving family.

title: Bilingualism in Reverse
description: Puerto Rico's plan to use English as a second language of instruction in public schools seemed logical for a territory that lists both English and Spanish as official languages. But teachers unions threaten to sabotage the plan, saying it is motivated by statehood advocates' need to show Congress that Puerto Rico is linguistically ready to be the 51st state.

title: Moving the Little House 8 Miles Across the Prairie
description: DAVE and Joanne Meeuswen had found the perfect house and the perfect piece of land.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHWARTZ, EUGENE J.
description: SCHWARTZ-Eugene J. We note with profound sorrow the passing of the founder and leader our our law firm, Eugene J. Schwartz. An outstanding trial lawyer, a great intellect, an exceptional human being. For more than fifty years, he was our guiding force, our inspiration and our strength. We all will miss him dearly. We extend our deepest sympathy to his wife Florence, his daughters Carolyn and Nancy, his son Allan, the Managing Partner of our firm, his daughter-in-law Carol-Ann, his sons-in-law Alex and Avi and his grandsons Matthew, Jonathan, Alexander and Gregory and granddaughters Katherine Anne and Annabelle. The members and staff of Schwartz, Weiss, Steckler, Hoffman and Hade, P.C.

title: Reliving Myth of the Presidential Log Cabin
description: From the moment he nestled in his crib in the tiny second-floor nursery, the 6-pound, 8-ounce baby his mother called Billy was swaddled in light. He could hear the train whistles, watch the shadows in the trees and perhaps smell the okra frying in the skillet on the stove downstairs -- or so the legends may go.

title: Prague
description: Seven years into a tourist boom, Prague is no longer the hidden jewel of Central Europe.

title: Horror of Fatal Car Crash Was Decades in the Making
description: To the Editor:

title: Hey My Mom Has a Backyard. Let's Have a Day Camp
description: When Erika Goldstein remembers her childhood summers, she thinks of long, lazy hours with neighborhood kids, playing games like kickball and spud, or catching fireflies. ''We didn't have play dates when I was a kid,'' she says. ''You just went out and played.''

title: Laura M. Ries, Scott A. Brown
description: Laura Marie Ries, the daughter of Mary Lou and Alfred P. Ries of Kings Point, N.Y., was married yesterday to Scott Alan Brown, the son of Kathleen and Robert C. Brown of Peoria, Ill. The Rev. Dr. Robert F. Scholz performed the ceremony at Holy Trinity Lutheran Church in New York.

title: Q. & A.
description: Selling A House At a Loss

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ZUCKER, SYLVIA
description: ZUCKER-Sylvia April. Beloved wife of the late Samuel. Devoted mother of Leon Zucker and Caryl Hollenberg. Loving grandmother of Monte and Beth Zucker, Melinda Racklin and Robert Hilliard. Cherished great-grandmother of three. Services Temple Beth El, 2419 Kennedy Blvd., Jersey City, NJ, Sunday, 10 AM. For information ''Wein & Wein,'' 1-800-322-0533.

title: From the Not-So-Great Pretenders, an Old Song
description: IT was not exactly the reception that a king might expect: no liveried servants, not a Rolls-Royce in sight. Instead, Leka Zogu, an arms merchant from South Africa who is the pretender to the Albanian throne -- yes, there was a throne, once -- wrestled with a squeaky megaphone. Peace and unity, he shouted at an outdoor rally. ''Give us our money,'' the crowd yelled back, more concerned with the money they had lost in Albania's pyramid schemes than with the pedigree of the man before them.

title: Reach Out and Disconnect Someone
description: IT'S time again to get on those trains, buses and seaplanes to peace and quiet. But then there are those beachgoers who just can't bear to be unconnected, jabbering away, high decibel, on their cellular phones. Take heart. Just like smokers, cellular phone users are getting the segregated treatment.

title: Court Case Keeps Alive Unwanted Store
description: A SUPERMARKET could be built in the Village of Roslyn that no one there wants -- not the mayor or trustees, not the residents, not even the builder.

title: Books in Brief: Fiction
description: Saved by

title: For a Change of Scenery, Glide Down a Quiet River or Ride the Rapids
description: Canoeing in New Jersey can be a richly varied experience. Just ask the 7th and 8th graders from the Bethel Christian School in Port Republic, 15 mostly rank beginners encountered on an expedition Wednesday morning down the Wading River, a gently twisting one-lane road of a waterway that winds through the deep green heart of the Pine Barrens.

title: A Rattletrap Space Station
description: Every time I hear of some new breakdown aboard Russia's Mir space station, I think of my visit some years ago to the Space Research Institute in Moscow. The institute was home to some of the world's most advanced scientific work, and had just choreographed a rendezvous in distant space for one of its spacecraft and Halley's comet. Surely this was one Soviet organization that had eliminated the backward technology so evident in more pedestrian fields like consumer electronics. Then I saw the cashier at the institute cafeteria. She was calculating my lunch tab on an abacus.

title: A Different Kind of Traveling Show
description: IN summer, just about everyone's fancy turns to thoughts of travel, whether it's a long voyage abroad, a jaunt to the shore or simply a journey of the mind. So why should artists and curators be any different? Exhibitions and individual artworks on display in New Jersey's museums and private galleries this season seem to be urging their viewers to hit the road.

title: The New Old Testament
description: What do you call the old testament?

title: Gooden Back at Stadium
description: Dwight Gooden, embroiled in controversy once again, was at Yankee Stadium yesterday after a strong outing at Class AA Norwich on Friday.

title: Playing Diverse Roles at the Same Time
description: IN ''The Three Lives of Karen,'' a movie on USA on Wednesday night at 9, Gail O'Grady plays Karen Winthrop, a 30-ish single antiques dealer with a cozy house and a good-looking finance. All is going swimmingly, except for one thing: she has been suffering from fugue amnesia, a rare malady that causes its victims to switch off or bury their real identities and create new ones.

title: Owner of 'Cottages' Viewed Garden as a Necessity
description: To the Editor:

title: Magellan, a Year Later
description: EARLY a year after taking the helm of Fidelity Magellan, Robert E. Stansky says he has positioned the fund ''pretty much where I want it'' -- spread over a wide variety of technology, energy and finance stocks.

title: LONG ISLAND JOURNAL
description: A Rising Couturier

title: Karen Benfield and John Zucker
description: Karen Jane Benfield, a segment producer for CBS News, and John William Zucker, the senior counsel for ABC News, both in New York, are to be married today. Judge Jose A. Cabranes of the United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit, who sits in New York, is to officiate at the 200 Fifth Club in New York.

title: No Contest: Bulls Near A Sweep Of the Heat
description: Four championship rings as a coach, 230 playoff games. You would think Pat Riley would know better than to awake a napping supernova.

title: Amy Schulder And Patrick Arn
description: Amy Rachel Schulder, a daughter of Marilyn and Howard A. Schulder of New York, is to be married this evening to Patrick Bryan Arn, the son of Barbara D. Katz and the stepson of Arnold M. Katz, also of New York. Rabbi Laurence A. Sebert is to officiate at the Pierre in New York.

title: From a Barn in England
description: I HAD heard of the airfield before. I must have, talking to Harry. But I had not got to the point of imagining it. Or, if I had, I had elided it in my mind with those other, better known airfields that speckled southeastern England between 1940 and 1945: places from which awesomely young pilots took off on bombing raids and did not always return, points of departure too for the D-Day air cover over Normandy. But this place had something extra.

title: Corrections
description: A review of ''The Letters of Nancy Mitford and Evelyn Waugh'' on May 4 misstated the given name of a French politician with whom Nancy Mitford had a long romantic relationship. He was Gaston Palewski, not Gerston.

title: Garden Fever? How to Apply a Little Balm
description: SPRING is an incendiary season. People are inspired to propose marriage, buy a convertible or, upon seeing a burst of yellow daffodils, go running for a spade. But what to do with that spade? Gardening newcomers need a little help.

title: The World's New Financier Is You
description: INVESTORS flocked to Eastern Europe after the Berlin Wall fell in 1989, eager to scoop up bargains in what they were sure would be a quick economic revival. A year later, the technology boom drew their money to the Far East. Then Latin America heated up -- that is, until the Mexican peso went bust, which sent investors scurrying back to the Pacific Rim. Russia got sexy as an investment early this year, and more recently South America has had allure.

title: Copies on Exhibit  To the Editor:    Henry S. Bondi's suggestion that the Elgin Marbles be copied by the British before being returned to Greece (''Virtual Elgin Marbles,'' letter, May 20), since today's copying technology is perfect, prompts the question, Why return the originals?
description: Why not return copies?

title: Kristen Parise and Gordon Jones
description: Kristen Anne Parise, a marketing associate at Hyperion Software in Stamford, Conn., was married yesterday to Gordon Peter Jones, an advertising sales representative at Bloomberg Financial Markets in New York. The Rev. James E. Byrum performed the ceremony at St. John's Episcopal Church in Huntington, N.Y.

title: BENEFITS
description: A History of Doing Business

title: A Culture of Risk
description: SEXUAL ECOLOGY

title: A Storm Cloud Over the Proving Ground
description: BOB KNOLL was at the wheel of a lurching red Jeep, fighting to keep control as we bounced over boulders that threatened to throw us into the brambles lining the new off-road course. ''I love this,'' he said with a wide grin. ''Driving is the best part of this job.''

title: Will China Choose Power or Wealth?
description: More than two centuries ago, in 1790, a crass political deal was struck. The Virginians, Thomas Jefferson and James Madison, agreed to let the Federal Government assume debts issued by the states during the Revolutionary War, and in turn Alexander Hamilton, a New Yorker, agreed to let the new nation's capital be in the South.

title: Private Schools Offer Illusion of Diversity
description: To the Editor:

title: Not Your Average Summer Flicks
description: The summer season of the New Jersey International Film Festival, sponsored by the Rutgers Film Co-op and the New Jersey Media Arts Center, opens on Friday and continues through July 27. Unless otherwise noted, all programs begin at 7 P.M. and take place on Sundays at the State Theater, 15 Livingston Avenue, New Brunswick; Wednesdays at Borders Books and Music, Mid-State Mall, Route 18 South, East Brunswick; and Fridays and Saturdays at 123 Scott Hall, College Avenue and Hamilton Street, Rutgers University, New Brunswick. Admission: Wednesdays, free; most Fridays and Saturdays, $5 ($4 for members); June 13, 14, 20 and 21, $8 ($6 for members); Sundays, $8; $6 for members. Information: (908) 932-8482. On the World Wide Web: http://www.rci.rutgers.edu/ nigrin.

title: Shearing Time in Falls Village, With Rug At the Ready
description: ANDY RICE, above left, attached the worn No. 10 steel comb to the clippers, nodded to his helpers and waited for a ewe named Madonna. In less than 10 minutes, Madonna was clipped clean and, looking rather bare, chased off by a dog named Rug, above right with the black-faced sheep.

title: An Odyssey Tracks A Fictional Fiddle's
description: SAMUEL L. JACKSON WAS PACING backstage on the set, waiting for his cue. Decked out in a checked suit as a world-renowned violin expert, he was working on an attitude of weary sophistication. Although the film was being shot in English, he was practicing his French.

title: It's a World Record: 249 Miles Without an Extension Cord
description: A Geo Metro converted by a Massachusetts company to run on electricity set a world record by traveling 249 miles without recharging in a five-day race and rally for electric cars that ended on Friday in Portland, Me.

title: Correction
description: An article last Sunday about the decline of liberal judicial activism misidentified the city that a Federal judge ordered to raise taxes. It was Kansas City, not St. Louis.

title: Official Run Is a First for Brooklyn Dogs
description: Miro has always craved exercise. He is an 8-year-old Saluki, a breed of dog related to the greyhound. But when he moved to Carroll Gardens from Midwood, where he had a yard, four years ago, something inside of him died.

title: Hayes's Home Run Makes Up For Miscue
description: With the Yankees and Wade Boggs slumping lately, Charlie Hayes was being given his chance to be the everyday third baseman. And he was not exactly making the most of it.

title: 'Wild, Wild the Storm'
description: Rain, soon to be turned to snow, fell on the night when two writers turned their minds to the Jersey Shore, and all the words and images it has inspired.

title: At Appomattox in the Culture Wars
description: NOT long ago, one could hardly get through a week without stumbling across somebody or other's culture war -- outraged fundamentalists or neoconservatives or righteous multiculturalists raving about Hollywood or political correctness or Robert Mapplethorpe or Allan Bloom.

title: Many Newspapers On the East End
description: There is a clarification I want to make regarding the mention of The East Hampton and Southampton Independents $(''Hey, Waddya Read? Papers Slake the Thirsts,'' May 18$). The idea to develop a new East Hampton newspaper was from the minds of Jim Mackin, chairman, production manager and photographer, and Lee Minetree, treasurer and advertising sales director. I joined up as culture editor and third majority stockholder. Jodi Della Femina, who lives in New York City, is a minority partner and has little to do with the day-to-day activities of running The Independent.

title: Kerri Dubler, Glenn Kaplan
description: Kerri Lynn Dubler was married last evening to Glenn Evan Kaplan. Rabbi Joel Zion performed the ceremony at Temple Israel of Lawrence, N.Y.

title: Patricia Bevis, William Mears Jr.
description: Patricia Ann Wheeler Bevis and William H. Mears Jr. were married yesterday at the First United Methodist Church in Florence, Ala. The Rev. Barry H. Anderson performed the ceremony.

title: To Support Growth, Albuquerque Will Shift Source for Water
description: Kim Hendricks decided to install a special garden in the yard of her town house here because, she said, she thought that landscaping with low-water-use plants was the right thing to do.

title: Like, Duh: a Mercedes Instead Of A BMW for Graduation? As If.
description: FOR several years, Lauren Greenfield, a 30-year-old documentary photographer, has chronicled Hollywood from a novel angle: she focused not on the entertainment industry itself but on the children, from privileged high-school socialites to street-gang members, who grow up under its influence.

title: Robert Karron, Emily Alexander
description: Emily Sinclair Alexander, a daughter of Carolyn and Brooke Alexander of New York, is to be married this evening to Robert Lyle Karron, the son of Barbara and David Karron of Encino, Calif. Rabbi Elliot J. Holin is to perform the ceremony at the art gallery of the bride's father in New York,

title: Where's The Party?
description: If it's summer and it's a weekend, there must be a festival around (or two or three). Here is a sampler:

title: DIARY
description: TOBACCO WARS

title: Breaking Ground By Going on Tour
description: THE sounds of reconstruction, which began on Tuesday, signal a magnificent theater in the place of a makeshift one for the New Jersey Shakespeare Festival. But the grand opening of that multi-million-dollar dreamscape is next year's news.

title: Fresh Out of Florida, 1,200 Watermelons and a Smile
description: The No. 66 bus stops on Northern Boulevard and 110th Street in Corona and a schoolgirl steps out. The bus drives off, but the passengers leave their eyes behind on the watermelons stacked under a birch tree.

title: Books in Brief: Fiction
description: Bunker ManBy Duncan McLean.Norton, cloth, $25; paper, $13.

title: Jane Slotin and Jess Joseph
description: Jane Levington Slotin and Jess Abraham Joseph are to be married today. Rabbi Avigdor Slatus is to perform the ceremony at the B'nai B'rith Jacob Synagogue in Savannah, Ga.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BRADT, JOSEPH J.
description: BRADT-Joseph J., 84, on May 22, 1997, of Ridgefield, CT, formerly of Flushing. Husband of Winifred E. Devoted father of Winifred, Joseph, William and Anne-Marie. Also survived by ten loving grandchildren. Retired Detective with the NYPD. Korean War Veteran and lifetime member of the Elks Lodge #

title: Helping the Young, At Whose Expense?
description: To the Editor:

title: Woods Is a Shot Away, but Leader Isn't Quaking
description: He is an unlikely foil: portly, gregarious, a winner once in 14 years on the PGA Tour, a Texas A&M Aggie by way of working-class Waukegan, Ill. But David Ogrin, pumped from shooting a 62 to earn the tournament lead, uttered the unspeakable today for cameras and notebooks to memorialize: he has got Tiger Woods's number.

title: Jean Louisa Kelly, James A. Pitaro
description: Jean Louisa Kelly, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. J. Joseph Kelly 3d of Boylston, Mass., was married there yesterday to James Anthony Pitaro, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Anthony Pitaro of Scarsdale, N.Y. The Rev. Charles V. Ford Jr. performed the ceremony at the First Congregational Church.

title: A Fable Rooted In Gypsy Lore
description: TONY GATLIF NEVER consciously broke with his Gypsy roots after he fled his native Algeria for France as a teen-ager in the early 1960's. Yet he soon discovered a society that was more open and less self-obsessed than the one he had left behind. By the mid-1970's, he had found a way into the ''gadjo'' -- or non-Gypsy -- world, first as an actor, then as a screenwriter and finally as a movie director. Once there, he wanted to make his name as a director tout simple, not as a Gypsy director.

title: A Tale of Unraveled Fortune
description: AS Robert Z. Morris was building a fortune in southern Indiana grain and Florida real estate, his mind often flashed back to a scene from his youth. It was the middle of the Depression and his father was desperately trying to borrow money to keep his farm and grain elevator going. Finally, he turned to his life insurance policy. Mutual of Omaha came through with $500, and the family business was saved.

title: A Son, a Colleague, a Man With Problems
description: Michael McMorrow, the 44-year-old real-estate broker whose torn body was found in the Lake in Central Park early Friday morning, was a gregarious man and a devoted son who liked to drink alcohol, sometimes to excess, friends and colleagues said yesterday.

title: The Dinosaurs Return And So Do Their Fans
description: The sun was just starting a slow burn over the Manhattan skyline yesterday morning when Andrew Estrella got to the Sony Theater on the Upper West Side, pushing his mother up to the ticket booth and fidgeting excitedly behind her. He had come to see Steven Spielberg's new high-concept dinosaur romp, ''The Lost World: Jurassic Park,'' and he feared that all the tickets would be sold before noon.

title: 'Rigged' Tuning At Concert Hall
description: To the Editor:

title: Dead Men Don't Wear Bleeding Chennai
description: THINK for a minute about what Laurent Kabila has just done to Ralph Ehrenberg. Mr. Ehrenberg is in charge of 4.5 million maps at the Library of Congress, the largest map collection in the world. ''Every time this happens,'' he said after Zaire became the Democratic Republic of the Congo, ''we all have to go in there and re-catalogue and rearrange our collection.''

title: Old-Time Dining: A Spaghetti House
description: BEFORE anyone ever heard of pasta, there was spaghetti. It was often cooked by white-clad chefs stirring huge pots of steaming noodles in the windows of humble, big-city storefront spaghetti houses. Their neon signs proclaimed spaghetti 65 cents and spaghetti and meat balls 85 cents.

title: This Way to Ecstasy
description: PRIMITIVE PASSIONS Men, Women, and the Quest for Ecstasy. By Marianna Torgovnick. Illustrated. 270 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $26.

title: Margaret Kelly, Preston Trombly
description: Margaret Mary Kelly, the director of the Forbes Magazine Collection, is to be married today to Preston Trombly, the host of ''New York Weekend,'' a radio program on WQXR. The Rev. Bruce A. Southworth, a Unitarian Universalist minister, is to perform the ceremony at the National Arts Club in New York.

title: David Solomon and Sarah Long
description: Sarah Elizabeth Long, a daughter of Judith Baulch Long of Hamden, Conn., and Charles Howard Long of New Haven, is to be married this afternoon to David Frederick Solomon, a son of Howard Solomon of New York and the late Carolyn Bower Solomon. The Rev. Andrew Fiddler, an Episcopal minister, is to perform the ceremony at the Caramoor estate in Katonah, N.Y. Dr. Marcel Zimetbaum, a friend of the bridegroom's family and a member of the Woodlands Community Temple in Greenburgh, N.Y., is to take part in the service.

title: 'Coppelia' Made New and Old All at Once
description: FREDERIC FRANKLIN FIRST danced in ''Coppelia'' in 1933, at the age of 19, when an ambitious young Irishwoman named Ninette de Valois staged the work in London for her fledgling company, which eventually became the Royal Ballet. That engagement was the British-born Mr. Franklin's debut with a ballet company; although classically trained, he had performed for two years in music halls. It led to a stint with the Markova-Dolin Ballet, then to a long career as one of the Ballet Russe de Monte Carlo's most versatile principal dancers.

title: Screen Gems
description: Imagine eating breakfast in an ivory silk nightgown hemmed and cuffed in ermine. Or having a drink, in a dive, dressed in a tangerine chiffon sheath with a matching sable-trimmed shawl. It was the genius of Jean Louis that no matter what the setting, such glamour was not only acceptable or desirable -- it was perfectly natural.

title: Seen But Not Heard
description: Saturday night audiences on Broadway are notoriously overfed and slow to settle down. The one at the Belasco Theater a couple of weeks ago was at first no exception, but it was soon caught up in the story of a young woman who makes a grave mistake -- she lies on a legal document -- and yet refuses to accept her excessive punishment quietly. By the end, when the heroine walks out on her home, husband and children rather than surrender her own idea of right and wrong, the full house was as still as a full house can get. The only sound as the curtain fell was of audience members -- women and men, but especially women -- crying.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  LUBALIN, HERB F.
description: LUBALIN-Herb F. 16 years. His talent and wit live in his work, as does his person in my mind and heart. Rhoda Sparber Lubalin

title: Regina J. Kerr, Christopher Alonzo
description: Regina Jeanette Kerr, the daughter of Berta and Arnold Kerr of Wilmington, Del., is to be married there today to Christopher Paul Alonzo, the son of Margaret and Peter Alonzo of Kennett Square, Pa. Rabbi Henry Cohen is to officiate at the Greenville Country Club.

title: For Elderly, New Rule Makes Check-Cashing a Task Full of Perils
description: On paper, it might seem like a technicality. But in the sprawling Red Hook Houses, a new City Housing Authority policy is causing confusion among the complex's 690 elderly residents and spurring an effort to create an escort service for them.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHUMAN, BERNARD J., M.D.
description: SCHUMAN-Bernard J., M.D. Husband of Dee, father of James and Leslie, stepfather of David Hollander, died on May 17, 1997 in Lake Worth, FL. after a long illness. Memorial services held in Florida. Contributions to New York Hospital, Division of Hematology/Oncology, 525 East 68th St, New York, NY 10021, attn. Anne Moore, M.D. or favorite charity.

title: Rita E. Freed, Peter M. Brown
description: Rita Evelyn Freed, the curator of the department of ancient Egyptian, Nubian and Near Eastern Art at the Museum of Fine Arts in Boston, is to be married today to Peter Mason Brown, an assistant city solicitor in Somerville, Mass. Rabbi Constance Golden is to perform the ceremony at the Wellesley College Arboretum in Wellesley, Mass.

title: Better Birth Control
description: To the Editor:

title: WESTCHESTER BRIEFS
description: Park Plan Opposed

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TRAIN, GEORGE J., M.D.
description: TRAIN-George J., M.D. On May 24, 1997. 1934 graduate of NYU Medical College, Associate Psychiatrist at Maimonides Hospital and attending at Gracie Square Hospital, Clinical Assistant Professor at Downstate Medical Center. Chairman of Post Graduate Studies of Brooklyn Psychiatric Society, Life Fellow of the American Psychiatric Association, first President and Dean of the American Society of Psychoanalytic Physicians, recipient of the Sigmund Freud Award of American Psychoanalytic Physicians 1986. Beloved husband of Vita. Devoted father of Dr. John S. Train and Dr. Henry Train and daughters-in-law Cheryl and Kathleen. Loving brother of Dr. John B. Train. Adored grandfather of Oliver and Miranda. Services Tuesday, 11 AM, at ''The Riverside,'' 76th & Amsterdam Ave. In lieu of flowers donations in his memory can be made to a charity of choice.

title: Hunt for Sons Unites Grieving Families
description: WHEN a privately chartered Learjet disappeared over a rural, wooded area in Lebanon, N.H., this past Christmas Eve, two young Connecticut pilots -- one a newlywed -- were aboard. Five months later, despite official efforts and an extensive private search led by their families, neither pilot has been found.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  VOGEL, BESS
description: VOGEL-Bess. Mathematician, leftist, feminist. A woman of unwavering character and unfailing principle. Loving mother of Irene and Jonathan, delighted grandmother of Rachel. The world is much poorer without her and we grieve.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  TAFFEL, ABRAM
description: TAFFEL-Abram. Thank you for forty-six wonderful years. Truly a marriage made in heaven. Love, Helen

title: No Headline
description: ''The idea of five great big athletic strong-willed boys in this little tiny house was central to my understanding of him. He had a wonderful ability to get people to get along. He had to have learned it as a boy.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ATHA, STUART K., JR.
description: ATHA-Stuart K., Jr., on Friday, May 23, at home in Valley Cottage, NY. He was 71. Mr. Atha retired as a Senior Vice President from the Chemical Bank Co. Before joining Chemical he worked for Hanover Bank. He was a graduate of the Woodberry Forest School and received a BA from Princeton University. He served as a navigator in the Army Air Force during WW II. He is survived by his wife, Barbara; a daughter, Susan H. Atha of Valley Cottage; two sons, Peter W. Atha of Valley Cottage and Stuart K. Atha III of Darien, CT. Mr. Atha was predeceased by his first wife, Eleanor. Also survived by five grandchildren. Funeral service will be held on Wednesday at 10 AM at Hannemann Funeral Home, 88 So. Broadway, Nyack, with burial to follow in Litchfield, CT. Calling hours are at the funeral home on Tuesday, 2-4 and 6-8 PM. Donations in his memory to the United Hospice of Rockland, 5 Parkview Plaza, Thiells Mt. Ivy Road, Pomona, NY 10970.

title: New & Noteworthy Paperbacks
description: JACK GANCE

title: The Man Behind the Festival of Our Lady of Mount Carmel
description: In a few weeks, Richard Budinich, parishioner and festival director at Our Lady of Mount Carmel Roman Catholic Church, will begin his annual shopping and hauling. Summer after summer, for 30 years, he has gathered the thousands of strings that, knitted together, create the weeklong celebration that honors the Virgin Mary and raises more than $100,000 for the church's school.

title: Spiritual Presences Meet in a New World
description: THE faces of Jesus and the Virgin Mary look out from the painted icons, a style of Byzantine religious art usually associated with Eastern Orthodox Christian churches.

title: Jennifer Pancoast, J. Steven Leonard
description: Jennifer Anne Pancoast, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Norman A. Pancoast of Key Largo, Fla., is to be married this afternoon to J. Steven Leonard, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Michael Leonard of Bridgewater, N.J. The Rev. Beatus T. Lucey is to perform the ceremony at Our Lady of Perpetual Help Roman Catholic Church in Bernardsville, N.J.

title: From Department Store to Storehouse of Knowledge
description: WHEN the B. Altman store that occupies the block between 34th and 35th Streets and Fifth and Madison Avenues opened in 1914, it was a temple of commerce with floors devoted to ladies' bonnets and gentlemen's furnishings, with its own trade school and medical clinic.

title: Wok Man
description: In the Chinese circles that Eddie Schoenfeld travels in, nicknames are the stuff of ridicule and sly comment. Dreamy saps are called Long Hair and perceived idiots Knuckle Hair (or some other bodily fuzz). Schoenfeld, who is bald and looks like Buddha by way of Flatbush, should, by all accounts, be called No Hair. Instead he is called Dai Footzah, or Big Beard. It is an honor. A recognition of his eminence in the Chinese culinary world.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLDSTEIN, ROBERT
description: GOLDSTEIN - Robert. Beloved husband of Myrtle. Devoted father of the late Richard. Cherished grandfather of Claire Womack and Aaron Goldstein. Adored brother of Lil Gurian. He will be sorely missed. Services today, 11 AM, at Old Montefiore Cemetery at Springfield Blvd., St. Albans, NY.

title: Dear Cousin Julius
description: Michael Winerip's caring presentation of the remarkable wartime correspondence between Julius Hess and Max Schohl ('' 'Dear Cousin Julius, We Trust on our God and on You,' '' April 27) evoked reminiscences of a similar story, one quite personal. After my father, Louis Davids, passed away in 1970, I recall sitting with my mother as she removed (also from a locked, forgotten suitcase) a remarkable series of letters from him to close acquaintances in their native Amsterdam (he and my mother having been lucky to emigrate to New York in 1939).

title: Books in Brief: Nonfiction
description: ARE WE UNIQUE?

title: Rachel Packman and Luyen Chou
description: Rachel Celia Packman, the daughter of Dr. and Mrs. David H. Packman of Bethlehem, Pa., is to be married today to Luyen Chou, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Chou Wen-chung of New York. Natalie Funk, a justice of the peace, is to officiate at Gedney Farm in New Marlborough, Mass.

title: THE SUBVERSIVE
description: By the time Larry Pressler lost his Senate seat last November, he and Ernest Hollings were barely speaking. For most of the last Congress, the two Senators sat together during Commerce Committee hearings -- Pressler was the Republican chairman, Hollings the ranking Democrat -- doing their best to contribute to the general rancor. It was not a struggle for the fate of the earth; it was not really even a matter of principle; it was simple personal disdain, born of partisan suspicions. Hollings thought Pressler an incompetent fool; Pressler found Hollings overbearing. ''The committee was the laughingstock of Washington, a mess,'' one senior staff member says. ''Pressler had no control of things, and so Hollings rolled him every time.''

title: CONNECTICUT GUIDE
description: ON LEADERSHIP

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DELSON, ROBERT
description: DELSON-Robert. An international lawyer who devoted his life to the betterment of his fellow man, first as theoretician of the American Socialist Party, with Norman Thomas in the 1930's, later in his work with Americans for Democratic Action, The International League for the Rights of Man, The N.A.A.C.P., The American Civil Liberties Union and S.A.N.E. His major focus after World War II was that of helping bring independence and world recognition to such emerging nations as Indonesia, India, Burma, Ghana, Senegal, Guyana and others. In the latter part of his life, he worked ceaselessly for unilateral nuclear disarmament. A loving husband, father and grandfather, Mr. Delson died peacefully at his home late Thursday, after a long illness. He is survived by his sons, Eric and James and their wives, Roberta and Jennifer, as well as his grandchildren, William, Caroline and Robert. Arrangements will be private.

title: Children, Water And Plaster Equal a Sculpture
description: WANIKA FISHER lay flat on a table, looking proud but scared of the procedure to come. Soon, a plaster cast of her face would forever connect her with the Ridge Street Elementary School here, where Terry Zappala's art classes were constructing an elaborate bas relief of seven life-size figures.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JONES, MILDRED FITZ HENRY JONES
description: JONES-Mildred Fitz Henry Jones, 84, for many years the head of YWCA representation to the United Nations, died Friday, May 24, at St. Agnes Hospital in White Plains. A memorial service will be held at 2 PM, Thursday, May 29, at the Presbyterian Church of White Plains, (39 No. Broadway, 914761-8585). Memorial gifts may be made to the church.

title: The Anatomy of a Misunderstanding
description: THE date was Feb. 8, 1990. Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d was meeting privately with Mikhail S. Gorbachev, the General Secretary of the Soviet Union, over the emotionally charged issue of German reunification.

title: Finding the Real Contenders Among the Real Pretenders in Late May
description: When the schedule reached this point last season, the Chicago White Sox were leading the American League wild-card race. Until recently, the White Sox threatened to reach this holiday weekend leading the race for highest-paid, most underachieving team in the major leagues.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COHEN, JULIUS
description: COHEN-Julius. Beloved husband of Doris. Devoted father of Harvey, Roberta and Norman. Loving grandfather. Services Sunday, 11 AM, at Riverside Chapel, 76th Street and Amsterdam Ave.

title: For Victims Of Flooding, Little Anger At Congress
description: The streets here are still lined with head-high piles of flood-damaged carpets, floor boards, washing machines and refrigerators. A crane is slowly demolishing brick office buildings downtown that burned when last month's flood prevented fire engines from reaching a blaze. And the city is still struggling to provide drinkable tap water again to every home and store.

title: Holiday Tomorrow
description: Memorial Day, actually May 30, will be legally observed.

title: Dispute on 'Recycling Garden' Grows
description: For nearly a quarter-century, the Village Green Recycling Team, a volunteer group, has been the keeper of the recycling flame. Especially through the 1980's, when the city vacillated on whether to go the mandatory recycling route, the group steadfastly collected bottles, cans and newspapers.

title: 'Job Shadowing' Helps Children Discover Different Paths to Success
description: DeVan Hankerson clung to her new Tommy Hilfiger knapsack and -- though it was filled with a Hilfiger hat, a Hilfiger T-shirt, and photos of fashion models and Mr. Hilfiger himself -- proclaimed that it would remain closed forever.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHAFFER, SYLVIA
description: SHAFFER-Sylvia. Lifelong resident of Brooklyn, N.Y. Went to her eternal rest in Auburn, ME., where she was confined, briefly, after an illness. Beloved mother of Simon Peter & Jean Beth. Loving grandmother of Joshua Merlin, Jill Eileen, Deborah Anne and great gandmother of Hannah Sophie. Dear sister of Mathilda Meyers and Robert Heller. Services at ''Boulevard-Riverside Chapels'', 312 Coney Island Avenue at Prospect Park, Brooklyn, on Sunday, 11:30 AM. Interment to follow at New Montefiore Cemetery.

title: Alison Sachs and David Cohen
description: Alison Ruth Sachs, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Frederick L. Sachs of Woodbridge, Conn., and David Adam Cohen, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Sheldon Cohen of Miami, are to be married today in Mamaroneck, N.Y. Rabbi Batsheva Meiri is to perform the ceremony at the Mamaroneck Beach and Yacht Club.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FOWLER, ROBERT G.
description: FOWLER-Robert G., formerly of Lattingtown and New York City, died of heart failure on May 20, 1997 in Jacksonville, FL. A 1941 graduate of Cornell University, Mr. Fowler spent his career in the apparel industry in New York. Mr. Fowler was awarded the Silver Star for heroism in World War II. Mr. Fowler is survived by his wife, Frances S. Fowler, of Quechee, Vermont, & Jacksonville, Florida, his sister, his four children and eight grandchildren.

title: More to Say On Adoption Law
description: To the Editor:

title: From Croton To Green-Wood
description: To the Editor:

title: After Atlanta's Glory, U.S. Track Fades Fast
description: Ten months after the Atlanta Olympics, the track is gone from Olympic Stadium, and so is any naive hope that the Summer Games would sustain interest in track and field in this country. If anything, the sport at the elite level has moved backward, not forward.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: Hockey

title: How the West Side Was Won: A Party Gets Results
description: With a celebrity-studded customer base and signature dishes like thin-crust pizzas and whole fish roasted in a wood-burning oven, Nick & Toni's has been the rage in East Hampton since it opened in 1988.

title: Elegy for the Hobby
description: In his 1963 novel, ''Jubb,'' the English writer Keith Waterhouse epitomizes the hobbyist as suburban nerd. His hero -- male, 36, married -- is a rent collector in a town 30 miles from London. Jubb is trying to start a photography club because, as he explains to a teen-age boy constructing a model aircraft carrier: ''If you read Hobbies Digest at all, you'll find that many people make a second hobby of photographing their handiwork.'' Jubb's interest in photography is less than wholesome. On the novel's opening page, he says, ''Sometimes I spend the whole day going up and down the Piccadilly Line, looking at girls.''

title: Time to Play?
description: Vacation season is beginning, and many bosses will take some extended time off within the next few months, trusting that the underlings will run the office efficiently. But is that what really happens when the boss is away? Or does everyone goof off until just before the boss returns? Send your best stories to On the Job, Money and Business, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036. Or by E-mail to onthejob@nytimes.com. Include your phone number. All submissions become the property of The Times and may be republished in any medium.

title: No Clubs or Spades
description: ASKED how he felt about the exhibition of diamonds opening Thursday at Harrah's Marina, Harvey Rovinsky went through the words typically used to describe diamonds -- spectacular, unusual, amazing, unbelievable, rare -- and then paused, as if the words weren't enough.

title: Barry Bryant, 56, a Proponent Of the Tibetan Buddhist Culture
description: Barry Bryant, a writer on Tibetan Buddhism who was also an artist, died on May 16 at his home in Manhattan. He was 56.

title: A Computer Pioneer Takes a Look Back
description: MICROSOFT'S Bill Gates may still have been in diapers when Charles Machover began work on developing computer graphics in 1959. Long before there was a Deep Blue, at a time when 34-year-old Garry Kasparov was perhaps not yet born, in the 1960's, Mr. Machover was teaching computers how to play chess.

title: There's No Place Like Work
description: As the only child of a divorced woman who worked her entire life, I was dismayed at the guilt expressed by working mothers in the responses to Hochschild's article (Letters, May 11). After school, I stayed with various baby-sitters and after-school child-care programs and, as I got older, by myself. In the meantime, my mother worked a full-time job, went to night school, earned an M.B.A. and helped establish and run what is now the largest independent health-care-provider organization in the United States.

title: Skipper Cuts Costs and Thins Out Intrepid Museum
description: In the fiscal year that ended April 30, the Intrepid, a decommissioned aircraft carrier that opened as a museum in 1982, turned a small profit, $70,000. The year before it lost $1.2 million, another setback in a checkered financial history that includes bankruptcy.

title: The Novelist as Narcissist
description: A WRITER -- call him ''Gary Krist'' -- sits down and writes a novel about a writer -- call him ''Gary Krist'' -- who writes novels about writing novels.

title: The Flyers Know It Isn't Over
description: Just 12 hours or so after they won an emotional, vital game against the Rangers and took a commanding, three-games-to-one lead in the Eastern Conference finals, the Flyers were businesslike at practice today.

title: Taking Control
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: On Morning After, Rangers Find There's Little Tomorrow
description: Just after Friday night's crushing 3-2 defeat by the Flyers at Madison Square Garden, Rangers Coach Colin Campbell, seeking perspective, said, ''It's always worse when you wake up the next morning after a loss like this.''

title: Retro Rocket: When Today Was Tomorrow
description: THOUGH it's hardly as celebrated as 1984 or 2001, this year, too, is a futurist's anniversary. For it was on Oct. 16, 1997, that the space family Robinson blasted off toward the star system Alpha Centauri, only to find itself pulled off course and hopelessly lost in space.

title: Jennifer Mechem And Paul Miller
description: Jennifer Coletti Mechem and Paul Steven Miller are to be married this evening in Napa, Calif. Rabbi Toba August is to perform the ceremony at the Chimney Rock Winery.

title: Wendy Harahan and Robert Hart Jr.
description: Wendy Barbara Harahan, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas P. Harahan of Wilton, Conn., was married yesterday to Robert Talmage Hart Jr., the son of Mr. and Mrs. Hart Sr., also of Wilton. The Rev. Michael F. Flynn performed the Roman Catholic ceremony at Lyndhurst, the historic Gould house in Tarrytown, N.Y.

title: New Mission: Recording Police Interrogations
description: PETER REILLY returned to his Falls Village home on a September night in 1973 to find his mother, Barbara Gibbons, raped and slashed to death. When state police hustled him away for questioning, Mr. Reilly, 18 at the time, and badly shaken, expected to help solve the crime.

title: 4 Tours of Harlem, By Armchair or Foot
description: Four walking tours of Harlem neighborhoods -- north from Mount Morris to Central Harlem to Hamilton Heights to Jumel Terrace -- are mapped, illustrated and documented in a new book, ''Touring Historic Harlem,'' a paperback published by the New York Landmarks Conservancy.

title: Q and A
description: Putting Up the Dog in Paris

title: Alternatives To Foster Care
description: Regarding the article (''Just Who Should Care for the Children?,'' April 20), the experience of a number of the children in foster care is unlikely to improve while caring for them is so lucrative. The reimbursement rates of $578 to $649 a month far more than cover the expenses of a child, so that the motivation for some foster parents may be income supplementation rather than love and sympathy for children, in which case the child may not be much better off in the foster home.

title: Fine Tuning Expansion at Bridgewater Commons
description: FOR nine years the sole occupant at the 120-acre Bridgewater Commons mixed-use center here has been its 900,000-square-foot namesake mall.

title: Exodus, 'Moses' And a Lot Of Gaps  David Schiff is a composer who teaches at Reed College in Portland, Ore.
description: IF THE CURRENT GENESIS CRAZE moves on to Exodus, Schoenberg's opera ''Moses und Aron'' might be a good provocation for heated interpretive debate. A new Deutsche Grammophon recording, conducted by Pierre Boulez, imbues the music with a clarity that may make it more accessible than ever before. Even so, the opera remains disturbing in its theological, political and psychological implications.

title: Syria and Iraq, Long at Odds, Take the Road to Warmer Ties
description: In what could signal the easing of tensions between two Arab neighbors, a top Iraqi official has said that his Government would not object to the reopening of a border crossing with Syria that has been closed for 17 years.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: GOLF

title: Correction
description: An article on page 25 of the Arts and Leisure section today about EMI Classics and its American subsidiary Angel Records refers incorrectly to their reissue and import policies. Angel is releasing more reissues than ever before, not fewer. A number of reissue packages produced by EMI in Europe have been brought into the United States or will be released by Angel, not ignored: a set of recordings by Yehudi Menuhin was imported in July 1996 and its individual CD's were sold separately; a centenary edition of Bruckner recordings was released in March, and a centenary edition of Brahms recordings is scheduled for release this year.

title: Congress Wasn't Stingy On Workfare Incentives
description: To the Editor:

title: Primal Instinct
description: BLOOD RITES Origins and History of the Passions of War. By Barbara Ehrenreich. 292 pp. New York: Metropolitan Books/ Henry Holt & Company. $25.

title: Helping the Young, At Whose Expense?
description: To the Editor:

title: House Sales Strong as Sellers Dwindle
description: FOR the second year in a row, a strong spring selling season has brought Long Island home buyers out in force. Business has been so good that potential buyers are having difficulty finding homes to buy, real-estate agents say.

title: Norberto Soto and Eileen Torres
description: Dr. Eileen Mariette Torres and Dr. Norberto Luke Soto, recent medical school graduates, are to be married today in Ridgefield, N.J. The Rev. Javier Losarcos is to perform the ceremony at the Roman Catholic Church of St. Matthew's.

title: Why Africa Can Thrive Like Asia
description: ONE of the great paradoxes of Africa is that its people are for the most part desperately poor while its land is extraordinarily rich. East Asia is the opposite: a region mostly poor in resources that over the last few decades has enjoyed the greatest economic boom in human history.

title: A Party Made for Trashing
description: Two Thursday nights ago, at 11 P.M., the southwest corner of 57th Street and Fifth Avenue (a corner generally very serene at that time of night) -- was rocking.

title: Enduring a Few Zillionaires
description: Bette Midler's single-pane, tilt-and-turn windows were the topic of discussion at the Carnegie Hill Neighbors landmarks committee meeting a few weeks ago. Eight members were deciding whether Ms. Midler should be allowed to convert the windows of her recently purchased penthouse to double-hung six-over-sixes.

title: Surrealer Than Real
description: EXQUISITE CORPSE

title: BEST SELLERS: May 25, 1997
description: Weeks
