description: To the Editor:

title: A Decision on the Seattle Seahawks' Home
description: One could say that Paul Allen's money has bought him love.

title: The Cause Came First
description: EVERY SECRET THING

title: A 1750 Moralistic Tale Produced in the Bronx
description: EUGENIO, a middle-class shopkeeper, is a compulsive gambler, spendthrift and womanizer of the adulterous kind. Call him a brute and a fool -- shameless, heartless and remorseless, just as his wife, masked or unmasked, does.

title: Help Workers Compete
description: To the Editor:

title: So You Got Purple Hair. Try a Nice Latke.
description: THE scene at the newly opened Lansky Lounge is precisely what one would expect of a swanky downtown bar: low lights, gaunt models in fashionably side-slit skirts, rock stars famous only below 14th Street. Then the double doors leading to Ratner's, the Jewish dairy restaurant, swing open, revealing a politely startled customer in a yarmulke and uncut beard, awkwardly excusing his way through a mob of slick hipsters as he tries to reach the restroom.

title: Amelia Earhart Lived Next Door
description: IT was something Amelia Earhart's cousin said that sent me driving along a two-lane highway skirting the Missouri River on a rainy Saturday to Atchison, Kan., where she was born 100 years ago in her grandparents' house high on the bluffs overlooking the river.

title: If Yanks Don't Erupt, Then Their Boss Will
description: The Yankees arrived at Yankee Stadium for their game with the Boston Red Sox yesterday haunted by the past, confounded by the present and concerned about the future.

title: Cold Warmonger
description: WE NOW KNOW

title: Trump Shows Off His Nest
description: IT was a black-tie party to celebrate the official ''grand opening'' of the Trump International Hotel and Tower at 1 Central Park West -- the 52-story former Gulf and Western Building redesigned by Philip Johnson and tinted, like Mr. Trump's hair, an indefinable metallic hue.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TANG, CLIFTON C.
description: TANG-Clifton C., of Tenafly, NJ, and Rancho Mirage, CA, on May 15, 1997. Retired attorney and former electrical engineer. Member of New Jersey State Bar, Federal Bar of New Jersey, American Bar Association, American Judicature Society. Survived by his wife, Dr. Yu Shang Chang; his sons, Dennis and Stanley. Private services were held May 19.

title: Reynoso Lasts 7 Innings, and the Phillies Feel the Strain
description: A doctor cut into Armando Reynoso three years ago and re-created what holds his right elbow together, and this spring, Reynoso strained the joint. Now, when Reynoso pitches for the Mets, Manager Bobby Valentine watches him closely, hoping the elbow is not damaged again under the abnormal stress of Reynoso's delivery.

title: Lindsay Park Complex Is Doing Fine, Thank You
description: To the Editor:

title: Those 'Hard-Bitten' Ziegfeld Girls
description: To the Editor:

title: On a Mission to Dramatize the Space Race
description: AS ANY CONSCIENTIOUS ACTOR would, Tom Hanks did a lot of research after he was cast as the astronaut James Lovell in Ron Howard's movie ''Apollo 13.'' He read book after book, talked with astronauts and their families, visited Cape Canaveral and spent time with ground-control technicians. Yet when he was finished, he felt that he had barely scratched the surface, and he hungered to do more.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BLACKSTONE, HARRY JR.
description: BLACKSTONE-Harry Jr. The members and officers of the Parent Assembly #

title: When Straight Actors Play Gay Roles
description: To the Editor:

title: Travel Season Is Under Way; A Big Summer Is Envisioned
description: Bonnie and Jeff Hoffman of Atlanta decided to get away for the Memorial Day weekend, joining almost two million other passengers at the nation's airports on Thursday to kick off what is expected to be a record summer travel season.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STERNLICHT, LILLIAN
description: STERNLICHT-Lillian, May 22. Beloved wife of the late Benjamin Bernstein and the late Leo Sternlicht. Loving step-mother of Lenore Lerner. Loving aunt of Thomas Gutterman and his wife Lee. Service Tuesday, 4 P.M., at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street.

title: Juliana M. Wilson, Thomas P. Ruggieri
description: Juliana Mercedes Wilson, the daughter of Griselda Gonzalez Wilson and Dr. Henry Hamilton Wilson of Westford, Mass., was married yesterday to Thomas Pasquale Ruggieri, a son of Elaine Ruggieri and Pasquale Ruggieri of Cranston, R.I. Msgr. Paul Enke performed the ceremony at St. Augustin's Church in Newport, R.I.

title: A Sturdy Performer With a Precise Role
description: I HAD barely arrived home in my Isuzu Trooper test vehicle when Ron and Pat ambled across the cul-de-sac for a look-see at the new sport utility, sparkling in its maroon-and-silver dress. The Nielsens, my neighbors, have owned a Trooper for some years now, loving every minute.

title: Thanks, Dad -- For Your Job
description: Along with a new diploma to hang on the wall and old college loans to pay off, most members of the class of '97 are leaving college with something else: a job.

title: Julia Buchwald And Joseph Gatta
description: Julia Nell Buchwald, a daughter of Maggie and Don Buchwald of New York, was married last evening to Joseph Michael Gatta, the son of Barbara and Joseph Gatta of Wynnewood, Pa. Justice Charles J. Thomas of State Supreme Court in Jamaica, Queens, performed the ceremony at the Pierre Hotel in Manhattan.

title: Security Failures in the Schools
description: An outbreak of sexual violence has swept through New York City's schools, highlighting abysmal lapses in school management and security. The failure to protect schoolchildren only strengthens Mayor Rudolph Giuliani's case in calling for police control of school security.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WOLFERMAN, ADOLPH, M.D.
description: WOLFERMAN-Adolph, M.D. On May 22, 1997. Husband of the late Pierrette Wolferman and adored husband of Irene Schleider Wolferman. Dear father of Mark (Cathy), Eric (Patricia) and Sondra. Beloved grandfather of Brian, Cassie, Benjamin, Joann and Anna Wolferman, Alex, David, Jacob, Jessica and Alexandra Schleider. Services on Sunday 1:15 P.M., at ''The Riverside'', 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue. Visiting hours on Saturday 7-9 P.M.

title: Familiar Enough, in Religion It's the Stained-Glass Ceiling
description: WOMEN in the church refer to it as ''the stained-glass ceiling.'' They are gaining acceptance as pastors, priests and spiritual leaders in many denominations, but women in religion cope with career barriers remarkably similar to those of their sisters in corporate America.

title: Jane Levine, David Snyder
description: Jane Ellen Levine, an art gallery director, and David Veta Snyder, a law professor, are to be married this afternoon in Brookline, Mass. Rabbi Andrew Warmflash is to perform the ceremony at Temple Ohabei Shalom.

title: Picnic Fare: When Mortadella Sandwiches Just Won't Do
description: THE most elaborate picnic I ever witnessed was at a Metropolitan Opera performance in Central Park circa 1970. People ate dishes I didn't yet know the names of and drank burgundy without ever staining the linen. One tablecloth was lighted with candelabra.

title: At the Intersection of Supply and Demand
description: I didn't like Tierney's swipe at community gardens. As a veteran community gardener, I'm convinced that this city, like Paris and other European cities, is big enough for both houses/apartments and gardens. Poor people deserve a ''park view,'' too, even if it isn't Central Park. New York City's gardeners aren't trying to turn the city into a farm. We're grass-roots community developers; we work hands-on to reduce crime, to foster economic development and the well-being of our neighbors. What this city needs is commonsense stewardship of the land, which, perhaps more than anything else, is what Tierney's article reveals.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MASON, PATRICIA
description: MASON-Patricia. On May 18, 1997. Real estate broker, Senior Vice President, William B. May Company. Wife of Francis Mason, mother of Spencer Mason and Leslie Scarlett Mason, grandmother of Dexter Mason. Memorial service on Thursday, June 5, 1997, 12:30 PM, at the Church of St. Luke in the Fields, 427 Hudson Street, New York, NY 10014. Patricia Mason was a keen supporter of the T. H. Everett Rock Garden at the New York Botanical Garden, the Greenhouse at Wave Hill, the Garden Conservancy and the School of American Ballet. In lieu of flowers friends may wish to consider contributions to those organizations. Robert Bartolomei is Curator of the T. H. Everett Rock Garden, N.Y. Botanical Garden. 200th Street and Southern Boulevard, Bronx, NY 10458. Marco Polo Stufano is Curator at Wave Hill, 675 West 252 Street, Bronx, New York 10471. Garden Conservancy's address is Box 219, Cold Spring, NY 10516. Albert Bellas is Chairman, School of American Ballet, 70 Lincoln Center Plaza, NY, NY 10023.

title: INSIDE
description: INVESTING IT /Page 4/

title: MARKET TIMING
description: MONDAY

title: As for Best Friends, Marilyn Knew Best
description: I MAGINE Courtney Love, poured into her white Oscars dress, recreating for the 1990's the breathless whisper of Marilyn Monroe. She opens her lipstick-smeared mouth and sings, ''Diamonds are a girl's best friend.''

title: Lisa Knight And Todd Gibby
description: Lisa Macomb Knight, the daughter of Mary Franz Knight and Charles Carroll Knight of Haverford, Pa., and Todd Engel Gibby, a son of Rebecca Eckfeldt Dembo and Robert Budd Gibby Jr., both of Chatham, N.J., were married yesterday in Bryn Mawr, Pa. The Rev. Ann Stevenson-Meyer performed the ceremony at the Episcopal Church of the Redeemer with the Rev. Anthony Burrascano, a Roman Catholic priest.

title: Teril Lindquist And David Turner
description: Teril Marlene Lindquist, the creative services supervisor in New York for the Henri Bendel stores, is to be married today to David Williamson Turner, a fashion photographer for Women's Wear Daily and W magazine, also in New York. The Rev. Rodney J. Houck, a Presbyterian minister, is to perform the ceremony at the Athenaeum Hotel at the Chautauqua Institution in Chautauqua, N.Y.

title: On a Clear Day, Nary a Sludge Ball
description: IT first hit the news in August 1987. A huge garbage slick washed up on the New Jersey seashore, draping itself like a filthy necklace along the barrier islands from Point Pleasant to Surf City.

title: Tour of Kodak Alters Views of Legislators
description: In this industrial town on the shores of Lake Ontario, the Eastman Kodak Company is affectionately known as the Big Yellow Box. The film-making giant remains a powerful and ubiquitous presence here, the city's main source of jobs, taxes and philanthropy. It is the last great survivor of upstate New York's once-flourishing manufacturing base.

title: Amalia Tragos, D. S. Stachowiak
description: Amalia Nicole Tragos, a daughter of Lilli and William G. Tragos of Greenwich, Conn., was married yesterday to Douglas Scott Stachowiak, a son of Patricia Stachowiak of South Bend, Ind., and the late Leonard S. Stachowiak. The Rev. Nicholas Katinas performed the ceremony at the Greek Orthodox Church of Our Savior in Rye, N.Y.

title: The Outer Limits Of Classical Music
description: To the Editor:

title: Director Takes Cue From Mentor-Dramatist
description: AFTER the South African playwright Athol Fugard wrote ''Hello and Goodbye'' in 1965, he faced a dilemma: whether to present the play before segregated audiences or to present it at all. Speaking by telephone from Washington recently, Mr. Fugard said that he decided to stage the drama in Johannesburg, even though newly enacted legislation forbade mixed audiences or casts for public performances.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COHEN, EDWARD S.
description: COHEN-Edward S., passed away May 17, 1997. The Cohen family notes with great sorrow the sudden passing of our beloved Eddie. Loving husband of Joyce. Devoted father of Craig and Brett, and daughter-in-law, Sandy. Brother of Philip and wife, Debbie. Uncle of Lisa, Justin and Adam. All who knew him loved him.

title: A Hop, and Another, and a Lucky Library Lands on Home
description: It was five minutes to one last Thursday afternoon, and the line outside the new Gerritsen Beach Public Library was 20 people deep.

title: Elizabeth Toll, Leonard Tannenbaum
description: Elizabeth Suzanne Toll, a daughter of Robbi S. Toll and Bruce E. Toll of Rydal, Pa., is to be married today to Leonard Mark Tannenbaum, a son of Adele Fuchsberg of Great Neck, N.Y., and Calvin M. Tannenbaum of New York. Rabbi Mordecai Waxman is to perform the ceremony at the Ritz-Carlton in Philadelphia.

title: New, Less Toxic, Weapons in the Insect Wars
description: THE creeping crawlers -- bugs, flies, moths and so on -- are beginning to appear, all set for a run that will take them well into the autumn months.

title: Feminism in a Micromini
description: I was a sophomore in college when I bought my first garter belt, a black-lace contraption with adjustable closures, so I could lower my stockings and bare the straps beneath my micromini. The frozen tundra of Ithaca, N.Y., presented a less-than-ideal climate in which to advance the cause of ''underwear as outerwear.'' But what was a pair of frozen thighs compared to the revolution? With the frilly scaffolding stretched across my hips, I thought I was -- in the academic jargon of the late 80's -- ''appropriating the signifiers of my objectification'' while ''exposing the masquerade of femininity.''

title: Miss Choi, Mr. Hanbury Tenison
description: Mina Choi, a daughter of the Rev. and Mrs. Won Taek Choi of Flushing, Queens, was married on Friday to William Hanbury Tenison, a son of Sir Richard and Lady Euphan Hanbury Tenison of Clytha Park, Wales. The Rev. Kit Cunningham, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony at St. Etheldreda's Church in London.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MOHTARES, NADA (NEE SEAMAN)
description: MOHTARES-Nada (nee Seaman). On May 22, 1997, of Bronxville and Southampton, NY. Beloved wife of Alexander Mohtares. Loving mother of Philip and Victoria Mohtares and Elizabeth Mohtares Meaders. Devoted sister of Barbara Railsback and Joan Corr. A Memorial service will be held at 11 AM on Thursday, May 29, at the Reformed Church in Bronxville. In lieu of flowers a contribution in her name made to Lawrence Hospital, Bronxville, NY 10708 would be appreciated.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  HABER, BLANCHE
description: HABER-Blanche. Devoted wife, mother & grandmother; inspiring teacher; tireless advocate for social justice and world peace. In loving memory on the anniversary of her death May 13, 1996. Respond to Richard Haber, P.O. Box 297, Lagunitas, CA. 94938

title: Cemetery Tells Of Jewish Settlers Of 17th Century
description: It is a tiny spit of green, shadowed by the backs of the tenements all around it and set off from the street by a black steel fence and two padlocked gates. The residents of Chinatown normally breeze by it without a second glance.

title: Chickens by the Pound and, for Neighbors, by the Screech
description: Near the intersection of 36th Avenue and 31st Street is W & S Halal Poultry, a slaughterhouse specializing in chickens. It opened three years ago among a jumble of factories, warehouses, single-family homes and apartment buildings in a once-industrial area that is in flux as it becomes more residential.

title: On Living Where You Work
description: Residency requirements for municipal employees drew passionate responses from those who had been forced to ask, ''Should I move to take this job?''

title: Tight Race Gives Boost To CART
description: Last Memorial Day weekend, Championship Auto Racing Teams tried to throw down the gauntlet in its battle with the Indy Racing League, only to fling the glove onto its own foot. Today, however, CART and Paul Tracy, the winner of the inaugural Motorola 300 at the new Gateway International Raceway, gave the Indianapolis 500 a tough act to follow.

title: TRAVEL ADVISORY
description: INFORMATION

title: In a Scandal-Torn Land, the Screen Is a Mirror
description: FOR MONTHS TURKS HAVE been transfixed by a spectacular unfolding scandal involving Government-sponsored death squads, terrorism and drug smuggling. No film maker has yet brought this scandal to the screen, but audiences fascinated by its themes of corruption and brutality have been filling cinemas across the country to see a movie that deals with these issues while telling a charming love story.

title: Godliness vs. Cleanliness
description: WE who live on the south side of West 20th Street in Chelsea recently experienced 16 days without street cleaning because of numerous suspensions of alternate-side street-cleaning rules. In a ''normal'' week -- if there is ever such a thing -- cars have to vacate our side of the street on Tuesday and Friday morning, making way for the sweepers. But here's what happened last month, mostly because of religious observances:

title: Hot Race in Bay Ridge Is for City Council
description: From storefronts to the windows of homes, political posters already seem to be up everywhere in Bay Ridge, Brooklyn, these days.

title: As Texas Executions Mount, They Grow Routine
description: When the time came for Texas to kill Richard Gerry Drinkard on Monday, he was strapped to a gurney and wheeled into the execution chamber. The prison chaplain, the Rev. Jim Brazzil, rested a hand on the condemned man's knee. He kept it there as Mr. Drinkard was asked for any last words.

title: There's No Place Like Work
description: In her article ''There's No Place Like Work'' (April 20), Arlie Russell Hochschild misses how work contributes to the time bind in households. Why has the stress of family life increased? For too many parents, it is because the growing demands of their jobs leave them too tired to take pleasure in being with their families.

title: In Nigeria, the Price for Oil Is Blood
description: July 1994. The Oil Daily reports that Gen. Sani Abacha, chairman of Nigeria's Provisional Ruling Council and commander in chief of the armed forces, has responded to strikes by oil workers and demands for increased revenue-sharing with local communities ''by declaring the death penalty on anyone who interferes with the government's efforts to 'revitalize' the oil industry.''

title: Sarah Birnbaum, Bruce Darrow
description: Sarah Victoria Birnbaum, an associate editor of Zillions, a children's magazine published by Consumer Reports in Yonkers, was married on Friday to Dr. Bruce Jonathan Darrow, a recent medical school graduate. Judge Ingrid S. Braslow of Westchester Family Court officiated in her chambers in White Plains. Cantor Joshua Kaplan took part in the ceremony.

title: Esther Goldfrank, 100, Dies; Studied Pueblos in Southwest
description: Esther Goldfrank, an accidental anthropologist who did pioneering research among the Pueblo Indians of the Southwest in the 1920's and churned out papers on the experience for the next half-century, died on April 23 at a nursing home in Mamaroneck, N.Y. She was 100.

title: Jan M. Faust And Abe Dane
description: Jan Marie Faust, a writer in New York for ABC News Online, a World Wide Web site, was married yesterday to John Abraham Dane, a partner in Dane Brothers, a Web consulting company, also in New York. The Rev. Jeffrey S. Sievert, a Presbyterian minister, performed the ceremony at Timberline Lodge on Mount Hood, in Oregon.

title: Dispute Over Guards With Farrakhan Link Moves to Court
description: Last September, Assemblyman Jules Polonetsky, a freshman from Brooklyn, raised his political visibility a bit when he pressured Gov. George E. Pataki into breaking a $360,000 state contract with a security firm associated with Minister Louis Farrakhan and the Nation of Islam.

title: Private Schools Offer Illusion of Diversity
description: To the Editor:

title: The Action Moves Outdoors
description: SUMMER '97: Go to a crab race at Barnegat Bay. Eat peaches and cream in Bridgeton or Italian in Hoboken. Take a hike on the Appalachian Trail or one of its branches. Tilt at windmills and other hazards at a miniature golf course. (Don't drop your custard!) Send the kids to camp -- in the back yard. Rent a canoe and paddle the Delaware. Oil your bike and start pedaling. Or simply pack a picnic and eat under the sky, perhaps while listening to Mozart or the big-band sound. Unless Marilyn Manson is more your style. The fun starts on page 6.

title: Spot for Mexican Dishes in Mount Kisco
description: IN a storefront last occupied by a series of unprepossessing Italian eateries, Maria Bonita shifts the culinary scene here with a menu of Mexican dishes. Some might consider this new place a risky venture; suddenly the Mount Kisco area seems to be glutted with Mexican restaurants, several of which have opened this year. But although the kitchen at Maria Bonita is not always uniformly successful, the freshness of ingredients and the number of winning efforts make the place our favorite of this sort in the area. Mexican music and bonhomie are a plus.

title: Inmates in NOW Stage Day of Wishes
description: TO some, they might just be seen as a sea of regulation green, a collective group of nameless women, inmates with a capital ''I.'' But anyone attending the National Organization for Women Special Events Day at Bedford Hills Correctional Facility here -- anyone who stopped to meet with, talk to and listen to the participating women -- would have seen that that was not the case.

title: Killing the Bulls, With Boredom
description: The Miami Heat has been very good at making the Eastern Conference finals very boring.

title: PAPERBACK BEST SELLERS: May 25, 1997
description: Weeks

title: FLY RIGHT
description: While crammed into that European econo-flight this summer, you may want to daydream about more exotic jetting: Business Jet Solutions offers fractional ownership in your own private craft -- $2,620,000 buys an eighth of a 10-passenger Challenger 604. Virgin Atlantic's ''Virgin Touch'' upper-body massage includes aroma therapies with juniper berry, grapefruit, lavender and ylang-ylang. Book soon for the ''Millennium IV'' tour on New Year's Eve 1999, a charter outing with international stops in four time zones. If mere lavishness isn't your thing, some airlines offer adventurous ''mystery flights'' -- you don't know where you're going until you take off. ''Somebody showed up in Bermuda shorts and ended up in Milwaukee,'' recalls Jon Austin, a spokesman for Northwest Airlines. ''We gave him points for optimism.''

title: Exploring Options to Pesticides
description: LIKE ancient biblical plagues, creepy crawly creatures often cause suburban homeowners to feel besieged, especially during warm weather. Whether there are ants in the kitchen, mice in the attic, beetles on the rosebushes or lice in the children's hair, the usual impulse is to attack the pests with all the chemical artillery the hardware store can muster.

title: Ann Miller, Schuyler Baab
description: Ann Eileen Miller, the vice president of International Development Opportunities, a Washington consulting company, was married yesterday to Schuyler Jungen Baab, an independent government relations consultant in Washington. Msgr. Thomas Prendergast performed the ceremony at the Roman Catholic Mission San Diego de Alcala in San Diego.

title: A Community Learns to Overcome Its Fears
description: MARY ELLEN CONRAD had looked at 50 houses in Valley Stream when she found her dream house. It was big.

title: Acting Is One Thing, Getting Hired Another
description: THEY HAVE SPENT THREE years and a small fortune studying speech, movement and improvisation, not to mention the works of Shakespeare and David Mamet, so that when the time comes they can transform themselves into anyone from Hedda Gabler to a hot-blooded hunk on ''One Life to Live.''

title: Fireman's Fun
description: Beach season is here, and you say you've been really, really suffering in the gym? Uh huh. Meet Eric Torres and feel his pain. And then stop whining.

title: Pepsico Reaches Deal to Sell Restaurant-Supply Business
description: Pepsico Inc. has agreed to sell its PFS restaurant-supply unit to Ameriserve Food Distribution Inc. for an undisclosed price, believed to be in the half-billion-dollar range.

title: Treasury to Sell Bills and Notes
description: The Treasury's schedule of financing this week is confined to bills and notes, beginning with tomorrow's regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills. Also being auctioned on Wednesday is a new two-year note, followed Thursday by the auction of a new five-year note.

title: Bridge
description: The ninth edition of the Laws of Duplicate Bridge comes into force tomorrow. The changes from the previous edition are quite minor, suggesting the lawmakers were on target in the previous edition, in 1987.

title: AMERICAN TOPICS
description: An effort to discourage a naked soccer game at Luther College in Decorah, Iowa, led to an arrest and even more nakedness. There were no goals and, at times, no soccer ball as 200 students, many of them unclad, celebrated the end of final exams. Mirsad Zahirovic, a computer science major, was arrested after he tried to stop a police officer from videotaping the game. The arrest angered the crowd, prompting some clothed students to surround the officer, and others to doff their clothes. A wild scene  but, then, the place is called Decorah, not Decorum.

title: U.N. Is Accused of Being Part of a Cover-Up in Guatemala
description: When the Guatemalan Government and leftist rebels signed a peace accord five months ago, both sides lavishly praised the United Nations' role in ending 36 years of civil war.

title: A Cuban Flutist Who Makes Things Happen
description: The Cuban flutist Orlando (Maraca) Valle, who recently toured the country as part of the Cubanismo group, has been floating around New York for the last week or so, sitting in at clubs in New Jersey and Manhattan. On Thursday night he settled in at the Zinc Bar in SoHo, playing with a group led by the drummer Robbie Ameen, featuring some of the better, more adventurous jazz and Latin musicians in the city.

title: What's as warm as a baby's cheeks, smells like a cow and packs an incredibly potent punch?
description: MOSQUITOES beware: Alvin Wilbanks, a self-taught engineer from Arkansas, is about to introduce an invention that he believes will turn the tide in the seemingly futile battle against the pesky insects.

title: As Woods Struggles, Frost Calmly Delivers Colonial Victory
description: It was a quiet 67, completed in relative solitude two groups ahead of the duel between a cultural icon and a Texas everyman, that put David Frost in the clubhouse with a one-stroke lead today. It was not until his twisting 25-foot birdie putt dropped on No. 17 that anyone really suspected that he could win the Mastercard Colonial golf tournament.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: WEEKEND

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL 2-7

title: Rangers' Surprising Run Comes to a Finish
description: Into this cradle of liberty skated the Rangers, hoping to stave off Stanley Cup playoff elimination today against a bigger, healthier, younger Flyers team. The Blue Shirts wore the crowned head of the Statue of Liberty on their chests, and goalie Mike Richter also wore her proud face on his helmeted head.

title: Other Laws Could Expire In Rent Fight
description: While the debate over ending rent regulations has focused on whether to continue the limits on rent increases, a host of other issues affecting thousands of tenants are dangling in legislative limbo.

title: Flyers' Hextall Purges A Decade-Old Memory
description: In 1987, Ron Hextall's Flyers lost to the Edmonton Oilers of Wayne Gretzky, Mark Messier and Esa Tikkanen in the Stanley Cup finals. Today, so to speak, he got even.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BRODIE, EDNA S.
description: BRODIE-Edna S. Died on May 24, 1997. Widow of Dr. Maurice Brodie, sister of the late Hortense Singer and Miriam Stuart. Retired Dean at Fashion Institute of Technology; generous benefactor of charities. Funeral arrangements private. Contributions may be made to Albert Einstein College of Medicine or Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center.

title: Many Iranians Hope Mandate Brings Change
description: As it became clear on Saturday night that Iranians had defied their religious leaders by overwhelmingly electing a new President known for tolerance and moderation, Cyrus Mozaffarian, a jewelry and crafts vendor, had trouble keeping his mind on his work.

title: Call to Test Drinking Water
description: Not far from an area where a contaminated well has been cited as a possible cause of high cancer rates, Robert E. Andrews, one of the Democratic candidates for governor, called yesterday for tougher laws to protect drinking water. Mr. Andrews, a Congressman from Camden County, said he was drafting bills to require that all contaminants at toxic sites near drinking water supplies be identified and that water be tested for them. Currently, Federal law requires that water be tested only for about 100 pollutants.

title: 'Closing In on Death'
description: Heroin came to my high school during our senior year -- not in the hands of poor kids from the projects, but in needles dangling from the tourniquet-tied arms of guys with hot rods, lavish wardrobes and the best orthodontics their parents could buy. The heroin boys were a cult. They huddled together at lunch, nodding out on their feet, wiping noses that ran perpetually even in summer. In the evenings, they idled in side streets, passing needles back and forth, before driving home to immaculately kept houses with two, sometimes three cars in the driveways.

title: A Newspaper Can Be the Community's Glue
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLDSMITH, BERNARD MORTON
description: GOLDSMITH-Bernard Morton, a businessman and inventor died in his home on May 9. Bernard was born in New Brunswick, NJ in 1916 and graduated from Rutgers University in 1937 with a Degree in Electrical Engineering. A pioneer in his field he holds several patents in the electronic industry. He was founder of Essex Electronics in Berkeley Heights, NJ. He later became the Chief Executive Officer of Nytronics, Inc., an American Stock Exchange listed company. He also serviced as President of Barient Company of Menlo Park, CA and Intech Automation Systems in Livermore, CA. Bernard is survived by his wife Karen, his two sons Bill of Eugene, Oregon and Barry of Rumson, NJ, his daughter Fran Benson, of Ithaca, NY, two step-sons Mark Steinberg of Newport Beach, CA., and Greg Steinberg of Costa Rica. He has seven grandchildren and two great-grandchildren. In lieu of flowers donations in his memory would be appreciated to: Hospice of Contra Costa County, 2051 Harrison Street, Concord, CA 94520.

title: Mostly Mozart in the Wings
description: The 31st season of Lincoln Center's Mostly Mozart Festival is to open on July 29 with an all-Mozart program featuring the soprano Carol Vaness, the mezzo-soprano Frederica von Stade, the pianist Peter Serkin and the Festival Orchestra conducted by Gerard Schwarz.

title: Iran Vote May Bring Pressure For a Change in U.S. Policy
description: The landslide election of a relatively moderate cleric, Mohammed Khatami, as Iran's President will put pressure on the Clinton Administration from critics as well as European allies to explore policy changes and not simply isolate Iran as a ''rogue nation,'' senior American officials and Iran scholars said today.

title: For Some, Ceremony Is Tiny Part Of the Story
description: For many of this season's graduates, the road to commencement has taken a few unusual turns.

title: Will America Help Russia Reach 2000?
description: WASHINGTON  A U.S. congressman and his aide, specialists in technology issues, sat at a restaurant in earnest conversation with a Russian and his interpreter.

title: EASTERN CONFERENCE FINALS: GAME 5
description: The Rangers, plagued by injuries, were eliminated from the playoffs as Philadelphia, a younger team led by Eric Lindros, moved into the Stanley Cup final against the winner of the Colorado Avalanche-Detroit Red Wings series.

title: Accommodating the Tastes of Black Readers
description: Americans are bombared with statistics about what's hot and what's not in their culture. So deafening is the noise of American culture that it can be hard to hear what's happening in other cultures. But the differences in cultural tastes can be striking. Although the continuing globalization of mass media tends to favor the glitzy entertainment that Americans produce and enjoy, especially in movies, the Egyptians still prefer more serious television programming, while the people in Hong Kong read much more practical nonfiction books. And local music is preferred almost everywhere. What follows is a sampling of the images, sounds and ideas that are popular overseas and vignettes that try to explain them.

title: A.M.A. Support
description: To the Editor:

title: This Memorial Day, consider turning off the computer and firing up the barbecue.
description: TWO apparently unrelated events associated with today's celebrations occurred in the decade after the Civil War.

title: Indy 500 Drivers Must Wait Another Day to Put Their Engines to the Test
description: The big question all month at the Indianapolis Motor Speedway has been: Exactly how many of the new generation of Indy Racing League engines can survive 500 miles of racing? The answer was supposed to come today, until rain washed out the 81st Indianapolis 500.

title: G.M. Workers in Oklahoma Agree to End a 7-Week Strike
description: Striking auto workers at a General Motors plant in Oklahoma City agreed today to end their seven-week walkout, although a final vote on the tentative accord was delayed for a few more days.

title: Profit Sharing at Hewlett
description: The Hewlett-Packard Company said last week that it had distributed more than $176 million to almost 112,000 employees as part of its profit-sharing plan. Workers at the computer and printer manufacturer are eligible for the profit-sharing plan after six consecutive months of employment. Hewlett-Packard began its profit-sharing plan in 1962.

title: Donadoni Reigns in the Rain With a Goal and 2 Assists
description: To watch Roberto Donadoni, it was worth standing in the rain for two hours. The veteran Italian midfielder scored on a brilliantly executed free kick and set up the MetroStars' two other goals in a 3-2 triumph over the Tampa Bay Mutiny in a Major League Soccer game tonight at Giants Stadium.

title: INSIDE
description: Graduations Get Personal

title: NEW YORK TO SELL MENTAL FACILITIES
description: Thirty years after New York State began dismantling its sprawling network of psychiatric hospitals, once the largest in the nation, the Pataki administration plans to sell off all but a tiny fraction of the unused buildings and grounds at 20 centers for the mentally ill and the retarded.

title: Army Muscle Helps Tow An Overturned Ice Truck
description: A tow-truck company trying to clear an overturned ice truck from the Gowanus Expressway in Brooklyn yesterday found that its equipment was inadequate. So it called in the military.

title: A Downtown Experiment Has an Uptown Premiere
description: ''Othello,'' a new, spectacular looking three-act ballet choreographed by Lar Lubovitch to a commissioned score by Elliot B. Goldenthal, is not your usual American Ballet Theater offering.

title: 2 Charged With Murder In Slaying of Teen-Ager
description: Two people were arrested on Saturday and charged with the shooting death of a 17-year-old youth from Brooklyn who refused to give up his gold St. Barbara medallion during an attempted robbery, the police said yesterday.

title: INSIDE METRO
description: NO DETENTE IN THE BRONX Plans to expand the Russian diplomats' complex in the Bronx have Riverdale residents on edge. 27.

title: New York City to Search in Parks for Deer Ticks
description: Concerned by a jump in cases of Lyme disease after last year's discovery of infected deer ticks in Van Cortlandt Park in the Bronx, New York City will begin scouring more parks for deer ticks, health officials said yesterday.

title: Mapping Real World Gets Easier On the Web
description: Geography became big business on the Internet in 1994 when the Census Bureau released a street-level data base of the United States known as Tiger.

title: VOTERS IN FRANCE, REBUFFING CHIRAC, SWING TO THE LEFT
description: French voters gave a stinging rebuff today to President Jacques Chirac's call to renew the huge conservative majority in the legislature for another five years, voting heavily instead for the leftist opposition and protest parties.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  KRISS, BRUNO R., MD.
description: KRISS-Bruno R., MD. A unique friend, never forgotten. May 26, 1965. Always remembered. ITTOM

title: After 41 Years in the Senate, He Holds the Voters' Hearts
description: Correction Appended

title: Lese Arafat's Majeste
description: Imagine an American President having the head of C-Span thrown in jail because he broadcast sessions of Congress in which the President was criticized. That is a rough translation of what has just happened in Yasir Arafat's Palestine.

title: A Bolt of 0.2-Second Lightning In Houston
description: The emotional release occurred the split second Eddie Johnson let go of the ball, its smooth arc providing a doorway for the Rockets to spill onto the floor like scattered BB's.

title: Pivotal Force at CBS Expands His Spectrum to TV
description: Mel Karmazin does not work on the 35th floor of the CBS Building in midtown Manhattan, preferring to keep his office up the street at Infinity Broadcasting, the radio company he sold to the parent of CBS, the Westinghouse Electric Corporation, last June.

title: With big publishers absent, can the booksellers' convention remain viable?
description: FOR almost a half century, the publishing industry's annual bookselling convention was a familiar summer ritual, as ingrained as the weekend exodus of the literati to the Hamptons, as predictable as a wine and cheese book party.

title: A Drummer Joins a Tribute to His Composer Father
description: The Juilliard School's concert on Wednesday evening honoring the American composer Jacob Druckman, who was once a faculty member and who died last year, did its subject every favor but one.

title: Corrections
description: An article on May 15 about the reunion of a Danish mother with her baby, who was taken away by the authorities after she was left outside a Manhattan restaurant, misspelled the name of a Danish editor who commented on the case and the name of the newspaper she works for. The editor, who said parents often leave babies outside restaurants in Copenhagen, is Lis Schneider, not Les Schnider, and the newspaper is Ekstra Bladet, not Bladent.

title: Flinn's Only Recourse
description: To the Editor:

title: Taking It Slowly, Forgoing Brashness for Restraint
description: It was a night of slow rock at Irving Plaza on Thursday when Tortoise and Eleventh Dream Day, two bands from Chicago, performed drifty, oneiric sets.

title: More Complex Superchips Put Premium On Designs
description: The Iready Corporation represents a new breed of Silicon Valley semiconductor company -- it does not sell silicon chips. Rather, the San Jose, Calif., start-up is licensing the design of its ''Internet tuner'' integrated circuit to others to incorporate into their chips.

title: A Pair of Adventurers on the Trail of Rare Books
description: USED AND RARE

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOOR, RUTH
description: GOOR-Ruth. Beloved wife of the late Hyman, mother of Paul. Family were the proprietors of the well known ''Metropolitan Book Store.'' Graveside services to be held on Wednesday, May 28, at the Mount Ararat Cemetery, Farmingdale, NY. For information please contact the I.J. Morris, Inc. Funeral Home at 1-800-624-8282.

title: A Historian's View for Graduates at Yale
description: The author and historian David McCullough had some advice for Yale's class of 1997: find ways to serve your country and avoid cynicism.

title: Broken China
description: Last week President Clinton outlined his plans to renew China's most-favored-nation trading privileges. He made the announcement to a group of business leaders at the White House. Here's what the President should have said to them, but didn't.

title: Dozens of Lively Tunes You Can Dance To
description: Americans are bombared with statistics about what's hot and what's not in their culture. So deafening is the noise of American culture that it can be hard to hear what's happening in other cultures. But the differences in cultural tastes can be striking. Although the continuing globalization of mass media tends to favor the glitzy entertainment that Americans produce and enjoy, especially in movies, the Egyptians still prefer more serious television programming, while the people in Hong Kong read much more practical nonfiction books. And local music is preferred almost everywhere. What follows is a sampling of the images, sounds and ideas that are popular overseas and vignettes that try to explain them.

title: Theater in Review
description: Ionesco's Old Couple, Mocked and Lovingly Embraced

title: In Afghanistan, a Triumph of Fundamentalism
description: By capturing the northern city of Mazar-i-Sharif, the militant Islamic movement known as the Taliban has virtually completed its goal of reuniting Afghanistan under a single government for the first time in nearly 20 years.

title: In '97, Commencement Topics Come From Within
description: Tim Russert, managing editor of the NBC News program ''Meet the Press,'' who will give five college commencement addresses this year, says he likes to tell students at the small Jesuit schools where he prefers to speak that their education will allow them to compete successfully with even graduates of Ivy League schools.

title: As AIDS Increases Behind Bars, Costs Dim Promise of New Drugs
description: Along the grim hallways of prison, AIDS is so familiar inmates give it nicknames -- ''the beast,'' ''the monster,'' ''the beetle.'' Like a second sentence for many convicted drug addicts, AIDS now infects the nation's prisoners at nearly six times the rate of the rest of the population. But efforts to fight the disease behind bars have been hampered by uneven medical care and a short supply of the promising new treatments that are the weapon of choice in the outside world.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary yesterday about Esther Goldfrank, an anthropologist who studied the Pueblo Indians, included an incorrect reference to the publication of her memoirs, ''Notes on an Undirected Life,'' in 1978. They were published by the Queens College Press; they were not published privately.

title: Theater in Review
description: Down and Out but Dead Set On Recovering Their Baby

title: Behind the Mets' Great Start Lurks a Great Deficiency: Middle Relief
description: The Mets are basking in the glow of their surprising start, knowing that if they were playing in a National League division other than the East, they would be at or near the top of the standing. But they have a weakness hidden by their success, a problem bound to hurt them sooner or later.

title: Dividend Meetings
description: A partial list for this week.

title: Theater in Review
description: Singing a Final Goodbye On Tape, From the Heart

title: D'Amato Puts A TV Spin On His Record
description: IF you are a senator, one way to establish yourself as an environmentalist is to support energy conservation, fight pollution and vote against development on public land.

title: Insurance for the Working Poor May Provide Measure of Relief
description: As Congress looks for ways to provide health insurance for children of the working poor, more than a third of the states are exploring proposals with the same goal.

title: Chip Maker to Sell Unit
description: The DSC Communications Corporation has agreed to buy the telecommunications division of Texas Instruments Inc. for an undisclosed amount of cash. The move is part of Texas Instruments' strategy of selling off businesses to focus on its core product -- computer chips. The acquisition involves 100 employees of Texas Instruments based in Dallas and Austin, Tex.

title: At a Caribbean Hoedown, Rapture Fills the Garden
description: Communal ecstasy, the sort that dance concerts are after, comes and goes, and at Madison Square Garden on Saturday night for a show of Caribbean music, ecstasy arrived and disappeared, sometimes in the middle of an act. There was a different type of ecstasy floating around as well, one of national pride; Puerto Rican flags were in evidence onstage and in the audience. And when the singer Stevie Wonder came out unannounced to sing a duet of ''I Like It Like That,'' unaccompanied and impromptu with the old tune's newest singer, Tito Nieves, there was a sense that the outside world was paying attention. The entire place was on its feet and cheering.

title: Chirac's Gamble: Rebuff Could Turn Into Humiliation
description: In dissolving Parliament a month ago and calling early parliamentary elections, President Jacques Chirac took a deeply personal gamble. In the absence of a constitutional crisis, there was no precedent for such a move under the Fifth Republic. Now it appears the gamble may have rebounded against him.

title: Equity Offerings Set This Week
description: The following equity and convertible debt offerings are expected this week:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FENSTERHEIM, MILDRED
description: FENSTERHEIM-Mildred. May 25 1997, Lag B'omer. Loving wife of Joseph; adored mother to Simeon and Dee Dee. Savta to Dani, Yoni, Josh and Gabi; cherished motherin-law of Dianne and Victor; sister to June; aunt and great-aunt. Always devoted to her family and her people. Chapel services will take place at Riverside Memorial Chapel, in Mt. Vernon, on Monday, May 26, 1997, at 12 noon. Contributions to the Hebrew Home for the Aged, Riverdale, NY.

title: Simple Alternative
description: To the Editor:

title: Clinton's Constituency
description: To the Editor:

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: GOLF

title: Memorial Day
description: The holiday, actually May 30, is legally observed today.

title: Police Move Homeless From Boardwalk Camps
description: In most shore communities, getting beaches ready for summer tourists means picking up candy wrappers and raking the sand. In Atlantic City this weekend, it meant convincing homeless people who live under the boardwalk to seek shelter elsewhere.

title: Sisters and Censors
description: Americans are bombared with statistics about what's hot and what's not in their culture. So deafening is the noise of American culture that it can be hard to hear what's happening in other cultures. But the differences in cultural tastes can be striking. Although the continuing globalization of mass media tends to favor the glitzy entertainment that Americans produce and enjoy, especially in movies, the Egyptians still prefer more serious television programming, while the people in Hong Kong read much more practical nonfiction books. And local music is preferred almost everywhere. What follows is a sampling of the images, sounds and ideas that are popular overseas and vignettes that try to explain them.

title: New Jersey Tax Cuts Hurt Poor Homeowners
description: To the Editor:

title: Politics Defeated Health in Abortion Vote
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LYNCH, MARY MARGARET DOUST
description: LYNCH-Mary Margaret Doust. Of Middletown, NJ, on May 25, 1997. Wife of the late Thomas Edward, Sr. Mother of Thomas E., Jr., Dennis, Vincent and Maureen Lynch. Grandmother of eight, greatgrandmother of one. Visitation Monday, 2-4 and 7-9 PM, at The John E. Day Funeral Home, 85 Riverside Ave, Red Bank, NJ. Mass of Christian Burial Tuesday, 10 AM, Holy Cross R.C. Church, Ward Ave, Rumson. Memorial donations to The Riverview Medical Center Foundation, 1 Riverview Plaza, Red Bank, NJ 07701 are preferred.

title: Financial Scrutiny for Port of Miami Puts Dade County in the Spotlight
description: When Carmen J. Lunetta abruptly resigned one week ago as the director of the Port of Miami, he pointed to such accomplishments as helping to make the port the largest cruise-ship terminal in the country and a major cargo handler in his 18 years in the job.

title: Industry Group to Offer Standards for Privacy on Internet
description: In the face of growing concerns about privacy in cyberspace, a group of about 40 companies will propose standards this week intended to enable computer users to control what personal information is obtained when they visit Internet sites and how that information is used, as well as avoid unwanted junk E-mail.

title: Kafelnikov and Graf Will Put Jitters to the Test and Their Titles on the Line in Paris
description: Only the clay, dirty and dusty and destined to make a mockery of everyone's white socks, looks the same. Though the time has come for the 1997 French Open to appoint a king and queen, not even the incumbents from 1996 are possessed of anything resembling an air of regal invincibility.

title: Report Says Vigneault to Coach Canadiens
description: ALAIN VIGNEAULT has signed a contract to become coach of the Montreal Canadiens, according to a published report.

title: Crops Are on a Cold Streak
description: New Jersey's staple corn and tomato crops are off to a slow start because of last month's chilly temperatures, state agricultural officials say, but can still catch up if the weather warms up. Jerry Frecon, an agriculture agent at the Gloucester County extension office, said that farmers, who finished planting tomatoes and corn around May 15, are still hoping to harvest their first ears of sweet corn by July 4. April temperatures averaged 48 degrees, two below normal, Rutgers University meteorologists said. An unseasonably late frost on April 7 could cut the harvest by up to 15 percent, Mr. Frecon said.

title: No Excuse for Torture
description: To the Editor:

title: Pettitte, Rogers To Face Orioles
description: Joe Torre walked into the Yankee clubhouse at 4:30 yesterday afternoon and announced, ''It's off, guys.''

title: Central Park Whale Faces Tattered Retirement
description: Jonah's Whale seemed guaranteed a happy retirement after it was moved from the Central Park Children's Zoo to the Rockaways in Queens last summer.

title: In Indonesia, A Deadly End To a Campaign
description: A violent monthlong election campaign ended on Friday with 130 people killed in a shopping complex in Borneo. It was set on fire by rioters, according to reports reaching here.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KOUZAN, ATHENA
description: KOUZAN-Athena. Age 67 of Brooklyn, NY. Died May 14, 1997 following a long and courageous battle with cancer. Born in the Bronx, she lived most of her life in Brooklyn. Member of the NY State Nurses Association, she worked for Kingsbrook Jewish Medical Center for most of her career retiring in 1994. Athena will always be remembered for her love and kindness. Survivors include her brother William of Plymouth, NY; six nieces and nephews, several cousins and a dear friend Crete Manolatos. Friends and relatives are invited to attend a memorial service to be held on Sunday, June 1, at 1 PM, South Presbyterian Church, 343 Broadway, Dobbs Ferry, NY.

title: Seat-Belt Law Is Wrong Safety Focus
description: To the Editor:

title: For Saul Bellow, Seeing the Earth With Fresh Eyes
description: Saul Bellow is ''a first-class noticer,'' in common with Harry Trellman, the protagonist of his new novella, ''The Actual.'' The noticer, he said in a recent interview, ''is the pussycat in the corner.'' Mr. Bellow a pussycat? More likely his readers think of this Nobel Prize winner as an aging but still raging literary lion.

title: Iranians Demand Change
description: Iran has been jolted by a political earthquake as powerful as the geologic upheavals that have rocked it in recent years. Against the wishes of the ruling clergy, Iranian voters overwhelmingly elected a new President dedicated to relaxing or eliminating the political and religious repression that has long disfigured their country.

title: Nobility, Then Savagery
description: Fine casts made four familiar works from the New York City Ballet's repertory spring into fresh life on Saturday night at the New York State Theater.

title: Renegade Party Shuts Door on Official One
description: With upswept hair and a silky white dress, Tracey Land waited for her daughter to arrive at Garden State Park for her senior prom. She fussed over the guest book, checked on the dinner and counted the approaching limousines. Then Ms. Land proudly explained why she and other parents of Camden High School students had planned this elaborate evening, which others believed the Class of 1997 did not deserve.

title: Crowds Swamping Surf Town In Season
description: With the Memorial Day weekend at hand, another crowded summer season descends on this spit of a town on the Atlantic, about a three-hour drive from Baltimore and Washington.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STONE, BETTY LEA (BARNES)
description: STONE-Betty Lea (Barnes), of Needham, MA. and Marion, MA., May 23, 1997. Wife of the late Robert Gregg Stone. Mother of Galen L. of Dedham, MA., Robert G. Jr. of Greenwich, CT., David B. of Marion, MA., Elizabeth S. Trumbull of Santa Monica, CA and Henry A. of Harrisville, Michigan. Also survived by 26 grandchildren and 45 great grandchildren. A memorial service at St. Paul's Episcopal Church, 59 Court Street Dedham, MA., on Wednesday, May 28 at 11 A.M. In lieu of flowers, donations may be sent to the Betty Lea Stone-American Cancer Society, Research Fellowship Program, 20 Speen Street, Framingham, MA. 01701. For more information call J.S. Waterman and Sons, 617235-4110.

title: Now Playing In the Global Village
description: Americans are acutely aware of the dominance of their own popular culture at home, but in nine cultures overseas, things look different. A summary of the top movies, books, albums and television programs from Brazil to Japan begins on page 36.

title: At Commencement, Insights and Asides
description: College graduates across the nation are being serenaded at commencement speeches with humorous asides and ernest advice. They are being warned about the evils of racism and reminded about the value of leadership. The speakers are as varied -- and often as familiar -- as the speeches themselves. These excerpts were taken from transcripts provided by colleges and universities.

title: Boardwalk Homeless Moved
description: In most shore communities, getting beaches ready for summer tourists means picking up candy wrappers and raking the sand. In Atlantic City this weekend, it has meant persuading homeless people who live under the Boardwalk to seek shelter elsewhere.

title: A Cultural Renaissance Fights Crime In Naples
description: Culture is certainly good for tourism, and may also be good for the soul, but rarely has it been used to combat chaotic traffic, street hoodlums, prostitution, organized crime and even corruption. Culture, however, was Antonio Bassolino's chosen weapon to clean up Naples when he was elected Mayor in December 1993. And, remarkably, the strategy seems to be working.

title: AMERICAN TOPICS : Who Killed Froggie?
description: The frogs are dead on arrival in Christine Karlberg's middle-school science classes in Orange County, California. Her students' task is to find out why.

title: A Blue-Collar Mirror
description: Americans are bombared with statistics about what's hot and what's not in their culture. So deafening is the noise of American culture that it can be hard to hear what's happening in other cultures. But the differences in cultural tastes can be striking. Although the continuing globalization of mass media tends to favor the glitzy entertainment that Americans produce and enjoy, especially in movies, the Egyptians still prefer more serious television programming, while the people in Hong Kong read much more practical nonfiction books. And local music is preferred almost everywhere. What follows is a sampling of the images, sounds and ideas that are popular overseas and vignettes that try to explain them.

title: Theater in Review
description: A Cookie-and-Coffee Prelude To Slitting a Stranger's Throat

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  LENNARD, FLORENCE
description: LENNARD-Florence. In life, you were always there. It's been eleven years since you left-but you are still here. Everlasting love, Jules

title: It's Not Unconditional
description: To the Editor:

title: Jordan Says He Wants To Play Next Season
description: He would not issue a Game 4 guarantee as Alonzo Mourning did. But Michael Jordan sounded committed to the cause.

title: This Time, No Excuses, No Regrets
description: MARK MESSIER, off ice for the final shift, hopped the boards and took his place in the Rangers' concession procession, No. 5 on the handshake line. It was all just part of the season's end routine until Messier, on his way to a summer of hardball contract talks, came upon Eric Lindros, with whom he took a moment to stop and chat.

title: A Celebration of Africa In Ritual and Spectacle
description: The Dance Africa festival celebrated youth and old age on Friday night in the first of five 20th-anniversary performances at the Brooklyn Academy of Music. Dancing children filled the theater and the stage, some of them members of the professional companies performing and many of them participants in the Restoration Student Dance Ensemble. As always, the festival of African, African-American and Caribbean dance and music began with an affecting processional of ''elders'' and the reading of the names of the deceased.

title: Russian Diplomats Find Streets Paved With Trouble
description: For the Russians in New York, old-style deference to diplomats has unraveled in the last year like an old wool sweater.

title: Tenure Case Exposes Academia's Glass Ceiling
description: To the Editor:

title: Student Hit by Car and Killed
description: A 25-year-old engineering student from Virginia who arrived in New York for the weekend to be a bridesmaid at a sorority sister's wedding was struck and killed by a hit-and-run driver early yesterday morning in Greenwich Village, the police said.

title: Playing Loose With History
description: Fifty years ago the Mar shall Plan united but also divided -- Europe. In editorials and commencement addresses we celebrate it today as an unparalleled act of enlightened generosity.

title: On the Information Highway, E-Mail Litter Problem Grows
description: Early one morning two weeks ago, Jason Lavoie, a network engineer for a company that provides Internet access in Maine, was rudely awakened by his beeper. There was trouble on the system that demanded immediate human intervention.

title: Iraqis Laugh Again and Lather Up
description: Sometimes it is the small things that make a difference, and that may be the case in the new nexus between the Government of Iraq, the United Nations and soap.

title: Trains Offer a Beach Break
description: Taking the train to the beach may be a good way to avoid traffic, but until now, it meant that once you reached your destination you were pretty much stuck. This weekend, however, New Jersey Transit began offering a $10 beach-hopper's ticket that allows unlimited rail travel on the 10-stop run from Long Branch to Bay Head from Friday evening through Sunday night. Stations on the route include Allenhurst, Asbury Park, Bradley Beach, Belmar, Spring Lake and Point Pleasant Beach. New Jersey Transit also revived its annual beach package this weekend, which includes round-trip transportation and beach admission from Hoboken or Newark to any of six shore towns for $12, a savings of up to $4. ANDY NEWMAN

title: Rangers Resilient, Even in Defeat
description: Outside, the rain was pelting the Rangers as they headed to their team bus, and so were the harsh words of a few emboldened Flyers fans, who were encamped adjacent to the driveway and shouting obscenities.

title: Samuel Proctor, 75, Dies; Led Abyssinian Baptist Church
description: The Rev. Dr. Samuel DeWitt Proctor, a preacher, educator and former pastor of the Abyssinian Baptist Church in Harlem, died on Thursday at Mercy Medical Center in Cedar Rapids, Iowa. He was 75 and lived in Somerset, N.J.

title: A Few Moments From '97 Season
description: As commencement season unfolds, so too do the related events and special moments that help distinguish one year from the next.

title: Orioles Are Winning In a Familiar Fashion
description: Baltimore Orioles raised at the knee of Earl Weaver learned their A B C's by rote, repeating the legendary manager's mantra of pitching, defense and the three-run home run all the way up from the low minors to the top of the American League.

title: More G.O.P. Environmental Wars
description: On Memorial Day two years ago, having just approved a bill sponsored by Bud Shuster of Pennsylvania gutting the Clean Water Act, House Republicans hurried home to take the voters' temperature. To their amazement, those Republicans learned that whatever else they accomplished in the first 100 days of the 104th Congress, they had badly misjudged the country on environmental issues. The voters did not want the Clean Water Act dismembered. They did not want Newt Gingrich turning his conservative committee chairmen loose on the basic environmental laws. Whatever their reservations about Washington, they had no wish to transfer the stewardship of America's natural resources to state, local and commercial interests.

title: Puzzlement Over Teen-Agers' Suspected Involvement in Grisly Crime
description: As a wake was held yesterday for the 44-year-old victim of a slaying in Central Park, people familiar with the two teen-agers arrested in connection with the crime puzzled over the question of how the suspects could have ended up in such a grisly tableau.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Pepsico to Sell Unit That Supplies Restaurants

Also survived by five grandchildren, six great - grandchildren. Reposing Walter B. Cooke-Kennedy Funeral Home, 117 West 72 St., NYC. Mass of Catholic Burial Tuesday, 10 AM. St. Gregory's Church. Interment St. Raymond's Cemetery. Viewing Monday, 2-9 PM.

title: No Headline
description: ''It seems to all go back to our reproductive organs. You know why? We're just not smart enough to deal with this by ourselves. We need Congress's help. Now, if we did this on their health, they would be nuts.''

title: At Play With the Greatest Trout Fisherman
description: I know the railroad was not invented to please fly-fishers. Nevertheless, there is something just right and basically irreducible about walking along the tracks on a high bank above a trout stream on a sunny spring afternoon. Forget the serviceberry and wild roses and other aromas; even the creosote smells great up there.

title: Rained Out
description: It was gentlemen cover your engines, after rain washed out the Indianapolis 500 yesterday for the first time since 1986. They will try again today, at noon Eastern time, although rain remains in the forecast. $(PAGE 41$)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MAGRAM, ROSE
description: MAGRAM-Rose, on May 23, 1997. Devoted wife of the late Louis Magram. Beloved mother of Herbert and Saul. Loving sister of Eve Cassell. Cherished grandmother of Molly, Amy, Linda and Tracy. Truly the matriarch of the family. For information contact Gramcery Park Memorial Chapel, 152 Second Ave., NYC 1-800-462-6364.

title: Don't Get Personal
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JOHNSTON, DANIEL H., JR.
description: JOHNSTON-Daniel H., Jr., passed into the hands of God on Friday, May 23, 1997, after a courageous battle with cancer. He is preceded in death by his parents Daniel H. Johnston and Mary Pauline Glenney Johnston. He is survived by his loving wife of 20 years, Kathryn Herzog Johnston; his motherin-law, Norma R. Herzog; and two brothers-in-law, Larry Herzog and Norman Herzog. He was known for his integrity and was respected by his peers and co-workers at Brown, Parker, & Leahy, L.L.P. A Rosary will be recited at 6:30 PM, Monday, May 26, 1997, in the Settegast-Kopf Company Chapel, 3320 Kirby Dr, Houston, TX, with visitation to follow until 8:30 PM. A Funeral Mass will be celebrated at 1:30 PM, Tuesday, May 27, 1997, at Holy Rosary Catholic Church, 3600 Travis, Houston, TX. Rite of Committal will take place at the family plot in Glenwood Cemetery. Kathy requests that in lieu of flowers, donations be sent in Danny's name to the St. Thomas High School Scholarship Fund, 4500 Memorial Dr, Houston, TX 77007.

title: Many Women Wary of Congress's Newfound Interest in Female Health Issues
description: As a political scientist, Diana Owen hardly considers herself an expert in women's health. But in spending seven months last year examining the Byzantine ways of Congress, she observed something intriguing.

title: Train Pins Man's Leg In Times Square Station
description: A man standing on a subway platform in the Times Square station in Manhattan was seriously injured last night when he apparently slipped and his leg became pinned between the platform and a departing train, the authorities said.

title: Richter Scale Attempts to Better His Elders at Belmont
description: Three times in the past five years, the Metropolitan Mile has been won by a 3-year-old horse who outran his seniors in the $400,000 Grade I stakes at Belmont Park. And Richter Scale will try to continue that run of successes when he tackles 10 older stars today in the 104th running of the venerable stakes.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  SCILKEN, DAVID (SHADI)
description: SCILKEN-David (Shadi). 1968 -1991 We think of you daily, cherishing your humor, your insights, your talents. With love, Polly, Marvin, and Jonathan

title: Houses of Worship Struggle to Rebuild After Flood
description: At the First Presbyterian Church here, last month's flood ruined interior walls and left green and purple song books stuck to ceiling beams in the basement choir room. At St. Mary's Catholic Church and School across the street, the gymnasium, cafeteria and day-care center were destroyed. And at the B'nai Israel Synagogue several blocks away, the furnace and electrical system were wrecked and the four Torahs had to be rescued by the synagogue treasurer riding a Jet Ski.

title: Economic Calendar
description: Expected dates for the release of major economic indicators this week.

title: A Strong Debut Helps, as a New Chief Tackles Sony's Movie Problems
description: John Calley might seem an unlikely choice to run a major movie company in the late 1990's.

title: Early Start on Summer Break
description: Their peers around the state still have nearly a month of classes to sit through, but schoolchildren in Milltown will start their summer break at the end of this week. They earned their early recess, however, by giving up most of their vacations during the year so that contractors could come in at the beginning of June to complete a $3.6 million renovation of the borough's two schools. That meant no time off for Jewish holidays, Columbus Day, Veterans Day and Dr. Martin Luther King Jr.'s birthday, The Associated Press reported.

title: For Johnson and Bailey, Debate on Fastest Man Alive Enters Final Stretch
description: Having won a routine 200-meter sprint today at the Prefontaine Classic in 20.17 seconds, Michael Johnson could focus on something entirely different, not to mention spectacularly lucrative.

title: In Congo's Restive Capital, New Government Sows Resentment
description: In the week since he seized power and declared himself President of the Democratic Republic of Congo, Laurent Kabila has stirred resentment in the country's capital against his nascent Government.

title: A Money Project Is on Hold
description: A major money-making project may not come to Milford after all, at least not soon. Crown Vantage Inc., a California-based company with a plant in Milford, will not be allowed to bid on the contract to make the paper for United States currency for at least two years.

title: Gephardt Will Denounce Trade Policy Toward China
description: Breaking with the Clinton Administration again, Representative Richard A. Gephardt, the House Democratic leader, plans to denounce normal trade relations with China on Tuesday, asserting that such terms would help China's leaders and ''contribute to their tyranny and reinforce their contempt for America's resolve.''

title: BBDO Wins Ad Age Awards
description: BBDO Worldwide won the most awards in the 1996 presentation of the Best Awards for advertising excellence sponsored by Advertising Age, a publication of Crain Communications.

title: Harvard Teaches Social Change
description: It was the final meeting of Marshall Ganz's sociology class, the only undergraduate course at Harvard that requires, and gives credit for, community service. The students, who had gathered at Mr. Ganz's apartment for a potluck dinner, were talking about their plans for the summer.

title: Immigrants and the Economy
description: The presence of immigrants in the work force is raising the living standards of most Americans by a small amount. That reassuring conclusion comes from a panel of scholars convened by the National Research Council. But job competition from immigrants depresses the wages of some low-paid native workers by a small amount, and immigrants impose sizable, though remediable, burdens on taxpayers in heavily hit states. These findings should calm most anxieties over immigration while pointing Congress to some sensible reforms.

title: Turning a Sex Abuse Case Around
description: Toward the end of ''Innocence Lost: The Plea'' on PBS tonight, a North Carolina prosecutor is seen telling a judge that the Little Rascals sex-abuse case, which had dragged on for about six years, has been ''tainted'' by two ''Frontline'' programs that compared it to the Salem witch trials.

title: Chinese Catholics, Too, Face State Repression
description: To the Editor:

description: INTERNATIONAL A3-11

title: Rough Going for Greek Merchant Fleet
description: The Piraeus Yacht Club, where shipping deals are struck over heaps of grilled squid, juts out from a rocky outcrop like the bridge of a svelte cruise liner. These days, that bridge faces stiff headwinds.

title: The Murders That Strike At Us All
description: WHAT is it about the murder of Michael McMorrow in Central Park that so fascinates New Yorkers, enough for it to have dominated headlines and ordinary conversations throughout the Memorial Day weekend?

title: Roche Plans An $11 Billion Acquisition
description: Roche Holding Ltd., the Swiss pharmaceutical giant, said today that it would buy Boehringer Mannheim G.m.b.H., a large German maker of drugs and diagnostic products, in a deal valued at about $11 billion.

title: Princeton Routs Maryland to Capture Title and End on a Perfect Note
description: At breakfast this morning, Becket Wolf, Princeton's captain, told Jon Hess, the Tigers' star attackman, ''We're due.''

title: INSIDE
description: Roche in $11 Billion Deal

title: In Role Reversal, Orioles Blast Pettitte and Bullpen
description: There was no need to flip through a calendar or peruse the altered rosters of the Yankees and the Orioles or watch the World Series flag fluttering on a gusty day. All it took yesterday to determine the differences between the two teams at Yankee Stadium was to witness the seventh inning, watch the undependable Yankee bullpen and stare at the ever-changing scoreboard.

description: PIERCE-Halil Alexander. In loving memory of our dear friend Halil Alexander Pierce, a Memorial Service will be held on Wednesday, May 28, 1997, at I Tre Merli, 463 West Broadway from 6-8 P.M. His Friends

description: To the Editor:

title: Outlet for Knowledge
description: Store of Knowledge, which sells educational games and products and is based in Carson, Calif., has leased more than 8,200 square feet at 1093-99 Third Avenue, at the northeast corner of 64th Street, for its first New York City store.

title: France's Mercurial Politics
description: There is no mistaking the rebuff French voters gave the conservative Government of President Jacques Chirac and Prime Minister Alain Juppe Sunday in the first round of parliamentary elections. The opposition leftist coalition won 43 percent of the vote to the Government parties' 37 percent, with 15 percent going to the far-right, anti-immigrant National Front. Mr. Chirac's own job was not at stake. But the enormous conservative parliamentary majority elected four years ago has melted away. It is now a toss-up whether a conservative successor to Mr. Juppe, who resigned yesterday, or the leftists under the Socialist Party leader, Lionel Jospin, will win next week's decisive second round.

title: Q&A
description: The Pizza Diet

title: Kmart-Hudson's Talks
description: The Hudson's Bay Company, Canada's largest department store chain, is in negotiations to buy 36 of the Kmart Corporation's 123 Canadian outlets. Hudson's Bay officials, speaking after the company's annual meeting last week, declined to elaborate on the talks. Kmart, the discount retailer based in Troy, Mich., is understood to be interested in selling its Canadian outlets.

title: Australians Choose SoHo
description: Saba Australia, which specializes in men's and women's clothing, is planning to open its first store in the United States in SoHo in August. The company has leased 6,000 square feet at 468 West Broadway, between Prince and Houston Streets.

title: 'Lost World' Sets Record, Taking In $92 Million
description: Steven Spielberg thought he was moving too fast. Several months ago, he told David Koepp, the screenwriter for ''The Lost World: Jurassic Park,'' which Mr. Spielberg was making, that such sequels should wait at least four years, and possibly far longer, before even beginning production.

title: A Jettisoned Burden
description: Alain Juppe's announcement today of his resignation raises a fundamental question: Why did President Jacques Chirac wait so long before ditching his deeply unpopular Prime Minister?

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BECKET, ELISE GRANBERY
description: BECKET-Elise Granbery, 88, of Salisbury, CT, on May 23, 1997. Survived by brothers John and Carleton Granbery; sons James & Peter, daughter Elise; 10 grandchildren. Service 11 AM, Wednesday, St. John's, Salisbury, CT.
