Survived by wife, Elizabeth (MacNeille) and children, Anne Dennen, Tom Quantrell, JoAnn Pettengill and Jerry Quantrell, eight grandchildren, two great grandchildren and longtime friend, Karen Hoedtke. Graduate Choate School; attended Williams College; WWII U.S. Navy veteran; investor at Halsey Stuart on Wall St. before moving to Maine where he was a private investor. Memorial service 3 PM Wednesday, May 28, First Congregational Church, Camden, ME. Interment is private. Memorial gifts to Camden 1st Aid Assn, P.O.Box 368, Camden, ME. 04843 or Camden-Rockport Animal Rescue League, P.O. Box 707, Rockport, ME. 04856. For further information: Laite & Pratt Funeral Home, Camden, ME.

title: Ads to Promote Gold Metrocard
description: With just over a month to go before the Metropolitan Transportation Authority begins allowing free transfers between subways and buses for users of a new gold Metrocard, the authority is beginning a $3.96 million advertising campaign to explain the new system.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BERNSTEIN, CLAIRE
description: BERNSTEIN-Claire. Beloved wife of the late Theodore. Devoted mother of Lucille and Lou Jacobs, and George and Harriet Bernstein. Adored sister of the late Lou and Mickey Greenberg. Loving grandmother of six and great grandmother of 12. Her kindness, sincerity and generosity will be missed.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  COWIN, DANIEL
description: COWIN-Daniel. It has been five endless years since you left us. We who knew you best, continuously miss your kindness and encouragement, enthusiasm, originality, and intelligence. Joyce

title: No Town for Sissy Ears
description: An enraged horn-blower welcomes us to New York. He is on our rear fender at the Holland Tunnel and furious because we are trying to escape a traffic lane bearing us inexorably to Boston or Asbury Park, depending on which sign you believe.

title: Sex and the Female Chimp
description: O .K., so maybe nobody ever accused female chimpanzees of being the virtuous Penelopes of the forest. They've long been known to mate promiscuously, as have their male counterparts; after all, the genus name for chimpanzees, Pan, derives from the Greek god famed for his lechery. Nevertheless, it was assumed that the females restricted their dalliances to the neighborhood, and that the offspring they bore were the progeny of a male living in their social group.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BELLET, DR. MELVIN
description: BELLET-Dr. Melvin, of Delray Beach, FL., passed away May 25, 1997. Beloved husband for 53 years of Hazel, loving father of Francine Bellet and Tina and David Bellet, dear brother of Herbert (Helaine) Bellet, Dr. Jerome Bellet (Bunny) and Floyd (Natalie) Bellet, cherished grandfather of Suzanne & Stacey Bellet. Phi Beta Kappa and Omicron Kappa Upsilon graduate of University of Michigan, undergraduate and dental schools, served World War II, Naval Dental Corps, practiced childrens' dentistry in Teaneck, New Jersey for 40 years. On staff of NYU Dental School, 35 years as Clinical Professor at Fairleigh Dickinson University, past president of Bergen County Dental Society and past president of American Society of Dentistry for Children. Services Tuesday, 1:30 at Levitt-Weinstein Memorial Chapels, Coconut Creek, FL. Burial at Menorah Cemetery, Clifton, New Jersey, on Wednesday, 10:30.

title: Holiday Campaign For Veterans' Group
description: The Veterans of Foreign Wars has signed an eight-month marketing agreement with the ESPN Inc. unit of the Walt Disney Company that will include running commercials on the ESPN cable television sports network on national holidays. Terms were not disclosed.

title: Earnest Homage to Veterans and Village Life
description: At 10 A.M. on the last Monday in May for 26 unbroken years, Donna Scheeler has claimed her spot at the corner of Lefurgy and Ashford. That's where this village's Memorial Day parade always steps off, with Scott Shevlin, a Vietnam War veteran who has been announcing high school football games for 22 years, carrying the flag.

title: New Jersey Candidate Says, 'I Love Being Out There'
description: The elevator opened to the 22d floor of the downtown office building called One Newark Center, and as James E. McGreevey stepped off he was met by a short man with a big grin and a one-word greeting that rolled slowly off his lips.

title: Seeking Write-In Votes
description: Sharon Ransavage, a former Hunterdon County prosecutor, has decided a week before the primary to run for State Assembly. Ms. Ransavage, a Democrat who was not renominated by the governor when her term as prosecutor expired in February, needs 100 write-in votes in the June 3 primary to get on the November ballot. Only one other Democrat, Pat Barnes, is running for the two Assembly seats in the 23d District, which are held by the Republicans Leonard Lance and Connie Myers.

title: The Too-Common Crow, Too Close for Comfort
description: CROWS have never been popular.

title: Gephardt Planning A Break Over China
description: The House Democratic leader, Richard A. Gephardt, plans to break with the Clinton Administration in a speech today denouncing the policy of normal trade status for China.

title: 3 Companies Join in TV Tube Venture
description: Corning Inc. and the Samsung Group announced plans yesterday to join with the Asahi Glass Company to build a $340 million television picture tube and computer monitor factory in Mexico.

title: Letting Fantastic Events Echo Life's Uncertainty
description: THE AGUERO SISTERS

title: Deal Is Set; Irabu Is Expected to Sign
description: The Yankees and the Japanese pitcher Hideki Irabu have basically agreed to a four-year guaranteed contract for slightly more than $13 million and the team is expected to announce the signing tomorrow.

title: INSIDE
description: MOTHER TERESA IN THE BRONX -- Mother Teresa slipped quietly into New York City, where she plans to initiate a group of nuns into her missionary order. B2.

title: Wasted Beauty
description: Heroin chic'' is finished, kaput. Images of models who appear to be on the nod -- or dead -- will no longer find their way into fashion magazines. The trade has overdosed on the look.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BIERNBAUM, HELEN
description: BIERNBAUM-Helen. The members of Rockrimmon Country Club are saddened by the passing of their long time good friend and extend sincere sympathy to her husband and family. Leonard Danon, President

title: Another Rainout On Indy Parade
description: They made the second attempt to run the 81st Indianapolis 500 today. They completed only 15 of 200 laps before rain stopped it. But those 15 laps were enough for Mickey Nickos to become a big part of the race's story.

title: A Family Reunion for Tap on Its Day
description: It was a tap-dance family reunion. Tap Extravaganza 1997, produced on Sunday night at Town Hall by the New York Committee to Celebrate National Tap Dance Day, brought together many fine tap artists, young and old.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLDSTEIN, TUVIA
description: GOLDSTEIN-Tuvia. On May 25, 1997. Devoted husband of Henriette. Loving father of Jacob and father-in-law of Kristina of Harrison, N.Y. Dear grandfather of Talia. title: And Now for a Few Words . . .
description: The Harris poll recently reported that members of the clergy have the most prestigious occupations, along with doctors and scientists. Indeed, we have been held in high esteem for decades.

title: European Left Takes Heart From France
description: Gains by the French left in first-round parliamentary elections heartened Socialists in other parts of Europe today, offering a portent of the way Europeans will define their future in the face of a global economy dominated by the American market ethic.

title: Jordan's Performance Is Hardly Up to Par
description: Michael Jordan proved yesterday that even the greatest athletes have days they would like to forget.

title: Leftist Leads Mayoral Race In Mexico City
description: The leftist candidate in Mexico City's first mayoral election, Cuauhtemoc Cardenas, emerged from a crucial televised debate on Sunday against the governing party candidate with a large and widening lead in opinion polls.

description: Anne Sutphen, 96, sat on a park bench several blocks from the grandstand of the annual Memorial Day bicycle races here that draw tens of thousands of spectators. ''Three laps to go,'' she remarked, referring to the 20-mile women's race.

title: 2 Agencies Split Video Account
description: Midway Home Entertainment Inc., part of WMS Industries, has named DDB Needham Dallas and McCann-Erickson Southwest in Dallas and Houston to handle its video game account, which had been handled by Hal Riney & Partners/Heartland in Chicago since 1994. Billings were estimated at $10 million to $15 million.

title: Pettitte and Erickson Share a Rare Off Day
description: The hitters were ahead of the pitchers, the starting pitchers, at Yankee Stadium yesterday. In the season's first game between the top two contenders for the American League East championship, Andy Pettitte and Scott Erickson, two of the season's best pitchers, picked the worst time to produce their worst performances.

title: Congressman Fights Sale Of Garden to Cablevision
description: Representative Charles E. Schumer asked Federal authorities yesterday to block Cablevision from taking over Madison Square Garden, saying the deal would mean higher cable television fees for sports fans.

title: Furs for Dressing to the 3's, Not the 9's
description: Fur pajama pants, it should be said right away, are an example of taking the new concept of fur as sportswear to its illogical conclusion. And showing them in every color, including emerald, ruby and midnight, is to say the least beating a dead mink.

description: STUTMAN-Deena. Forever loved and remembered. Your Thanksgiving family

In lieu of flowers a contribution in her name made to Lawrence Hospital, Bronxville, NY 10708 would be appreciated.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BRODIE, EDNA S.
description: BRODIE-Edna S. Died on May 24, 1997. Widow of Dr. Maurice Brodie, sister of the late Hortense Singer and Miriam Stuart. Retired Dean at Fashion Institute of Technology; generous benefactor of charities. Funeral arrangements private. Contributions may be made to Albert Einstein College of Medicine or Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GUTTENPLAN, SEYMOUR
description: GUTTENPLAN-Seymour, 73, of Weston, FL. Formerly of Valley Stream, LI. Passed away May 26, 1997. He was the Founder and President of Tele-Wire Corp. and the past President of Congregation Tree of Life, Valley Stream. A veteran of World War II serving in the Army, he is survived by his wife of 46 years, Sylvia; two children: Dr. Susan Manella (Ross), Dr. Michael Guttenplan (Mary); four loving grandchildren: David and Morgan Manella and Kevin and Katie Guttenplan; and brother Herbert Guttenplan. Service will be today at 9:15 AM, I. J. Morris Funeral Directors, Dix Hills, NY.

title: ROUTED IN VOTING, PREMIER OF FRANCE SAYS HE WILL QUIT
description: France's unpopular conservative Prime Minister, drawing political consequences a day after the drubbing taken by the Government parties in preliminary legislative elections, announced this afternoon that he would resign from the post even if the conservative coalition wins in the second round on Sunday.

title: Venture Capital Showing Faith in Internet's Future
description: Last August, Fred Wilson obtained $50 million from Chase Manhattan Bank and the Softbank Corporation to start Flatiron Partners, immediately becoming one of the biggest venture capital firms in New York that specializes in investing in Internet companies. Since then, Flatiron, Chase and Softbank have made six investments totaling $22.7 million, with the most recent one -- $2.7 million in Resonate, a company based in Mountain View, Calif. -- coming last month.

title: High Taxes, Not Liberal Losses, Killed Charity
description: To the Editor:

title: Will the Wicked Witch someday receive top billing? Did Ford grab an idea from coffee beans?
description: IT'S time again to ask 20 questions about advertising, marketing and the media.

title: Accounts
description: * Miami Heat to Crispin Porter & Bogusky, Miami, to handle advertising for the National Basketball Association team's 1997-98 season. The account had been handled on a project basis by Crispin Porter and Wong Doody, Seattle. Billings were estimated at $1 million.

title: New British Treasury Chief Has Come In With a Bang
description: Gordon Brown, Britain's 46-year-old Chancellor of the Exchequer, has been described as youthful, brilliant and the ''most eligible bachelor'' of the new Labor Government. But the description of the moment is ''Flash Gordon,'' for the speed with which he has put his stamp on Britain's fiscal and economic agenda.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  BELSON, WILLIAM A.
description: BELSON-William A. May 27, 1973. Loving you and missing you forever. Twenty-four long years. Your loving wife Ginny Belson

title: Lapses Can't Deny The Mets Third Place
description: These Mets cannot be real, but they are. They cannot succeed with their manner of play, and they do. They cannot possibly be better than the Yankees, but they have a better record.

title: Joseph X. Dever, Society Columnist, 77
description: Joseph X. Dever, a retired journalist who covered the social scene in New York and Philadelphia, died on May 10 at Lenox Hill Hospital. He was 77 and lived on the Upper West Side of Manhattan.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHWARTZ, EVA
description: SCHWARTZ-Eva, 98. Died May 26, 1997. Beloved wife of the late Herman, loving mother of Harold and the late Alfred, loving motherin-law of Faith and Louise, loving grandmother of Randy & husband Jay, Harriet and husband Geoff, Joseph and wife Jacqueline, and Barbara & husband Brad. Loving great grandmother of Alexander, Hilary, Adam, Laura, Elliott, and Jonathan. In lieu of flowers, the family would appreciate contributions (to help fight Lou Gehrig's disease) to the ALS Assn, Great N.Y. Chapter, 40 Wall Street, Suite 2111, New York, New York 10005.

title: Still Defiant, but Subtler, Industry Awaits E.P.A. Rules
description: Corporate America is not a quick study. Again and again, companies have responded to proposed environmental rules by threatening bankruptcies, huge layoffs, foreign inroads into American markets, even an end to the car-based American way of life -- and it has never worked.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  LIPPMAN, BERT J
description: LIPPMAN-Bert J. 16 long years. Always in our hearts. We love you. Ruth, Jane, Robin, Chuck, Stefan, Bradley and Jessica

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WINN, GILBERT E., D.D.S.
description: WINN-Gilbert E., D.D.S., age 62. Beloved husband of Eleanor, devoted father of Mitchell & Maxine, Tracey and Robert, cherished grandfather of Amanda, Alison, Jason and Benjamin. Cherished brother of Dr. Stephen L. and Carolyn Winn, dear brother-in-law of Richard, Michael and Joanne Fleischman. A family dentist for over 35 years, he served as a Captain in the Army Dental Corp. in Korea and as a full teaching attending dentist at the Jamaica Hospital in Queens, NY. He will be remembered for his compassion, skill, intelligence and wit by all who knew him. Funeral Tuesday at Gutterman's Funeral Home, Woodbury, N.Y., at 11:30 AM.

title: For a New Parthenon
description: To the Editor:

title: A Weak Year For New Issues In Technology
description: A record number of technology companies went public in 1995 and 1996 as investors clamored to own a piece of what they hoped would be the next Intel or Microsoft.

title: Europe Battery Job Is Awarded to Bates
description: Ralston Energy Systems in St. Louis, part of the Ralston Purina Company, has named Bates Worldwide to handle its Energizer battery account in Europe, with billings estimated at $20 million. The account had been handled by the Paris office of Abbott Mead Vickers BDDO, a unit of Omnicom Group.

title: Nabokov's Work, on Butterflies, Stands the Test of Time
description: TWO lepidopterists have substantially completed an ambitious project begun 50 years ago by an extraordinary colleague: the novelist Vladimir Nabokov, author of ''Lolita.''

title: Boy Dies in House Fire
description: A 5-year-old Newark boy died in a house fire early yesterday, fire officials said. The child, Cory Holmes, was found unconscious in a first-floor bedroom at the house on South 16th Street and could not be revived, said Bob Swales, a spokesman for the city Fire Department.

title: Congo Demonstration Ban
description: President Kabila banned political activity and demonstrations in Congo today, and an opposition leader called a protest march. Page A10.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KERN, JACLYN T.
description: KERN-Jaclyn T. On May 25, 1997, of Locust Valley, NY. Beloved wife of Julius. Loving mother of W. Ryder. Dear grandmother of Kyle and Benjamin. Fond sister of Frank J. Tappan II. Reposing at the Beney Funeral Home, Inc, of Syosset, 79 Berry Hill Rd. Visiting Wednesday, from 2-5 and 7-9 PM. Funeral service on Thursday, 11 AM, at St. John's Church of Lattingtown. Interment Roslyn Cemetery. In lieu of flowers, please make donations to the Hospice Care Network, 900 Ellison Avenue, Westbury, New York 11590.

title: Rowland's Welfare Rule Is Criticized as Too Tough
description: The three Republican Governors in the metropolitan region have all worked aggressively to cut the welfare rolls, but only one -- John G. Rowland of Connecticut -- has cut off food stamps to able-bodied adults.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MEREN, JAN
description: MEREN-Jan. On Sunday, May 25. Of Irvington, NY and Becket, MA. Age 60. Cherished husband of 25 years to Roslyn Yasser. Devoted father to Peter and Andrew. Dear son-in-law of Esther and Mac Yasser. Loving brother-in-law to Sandra and Alan Friedman, Nan and Alan Yasser. Uncle to David, Jonathan, Lisa and Jennifer. He was the father that anyone could want-and the father that anyone could aspire to be. Services on Wednesday, May 28, at ''The Riverside,'' 76 Street and Amsterdam Avenue. In lieu of flowers contributions may be made to the United States Holocaust Memorial Museum in Washington, D.C.

title: Reports Point to Mass Killing of Refugees in Congo
description: Since the middle of last month, no outsider has been allowed down the six miles of jungle road that begin at a roadblock manned by soldiers at Kilometer 42 south of here. But a growing number of accounts emerging from that zone suggest that some form of systematic killing of refugees and disposal of the evidence has been taking place there.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MESCHI, ROSEMARIE
description: MESCHI-Rosemarie. Age 44, CPA. On May 23, 1997. Director of Human Resource Services for Ernst & Young, LLP. Beloved daughter of Catherine and the late Dominic. Dear sister of John. Loving fiancee of Robert A. Hanson, CPA. Resposing Connell Funeral Home, 934 New York Ave, Huntington, Tuesday, 2-5, and 7-9 PM. Mass Wednesday, 10:15 AM, St. Hugh's Church. In lieu of flowers donations to Gilda Radner Club, 4340 Sheridan St, Hollywood, FL 33021.

title: New Court Lets Drug Addicts Choose Treatment Program Rather Than Jail
description: On a chill November day in Brooklyn, Bonnie Hussey tried to finance her craving for cocaine by selling crack to an undercover police officer.

title: Listening to the Conversation of Neurons
description: HE might well be called the pied piper of the neurons. He lives with them day to day, he vacations with them in the summer, and in his hands, they dance.

title: John Canfield Ewers, Ethnologist, Dies at 87
description: John Canfield Ewers, ethnologist emeritus of the Smithsonian Institution, historian of the West and chronicler of the Plains Indians, died on May 7 at Arlington Hospital in Arlington, Va. A resident of Arlington, he was 87.

title: CHRONICLE
description: There will be two new leaders, both lawyers with roots in academia, at the helm of the National Coalition Against Censorship.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: COLLEGE BASEBALL

title: Corrections
description: A caption yesterday about a photography exhibit at Ellis Island, with pictures of similar religious processions in the Bronx and in Sicily, misstated the date of the Italian photograph. It was taken in May of 1996.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RICHER, IRMA
description: RICHER-Irma. On May 24, 1997. Beloved wife of Walter. Devoted mother of Laurie Solomon and Amy Russo. Adored MawMaw (grandmother) of Elyse, Joshua and Rachel. Dear sister of Sondra Rifkin. Cherished mother-in-law of Ira Russo.

title: Testimony to Start in Trash Carting Trial
description: They were once pillars in a vital New York City industry that generated $1.5 billion in fees every year.

title: Author's Quest for Identity Uncovers Universal Themes
description: Patrick Chamoiseau, the Martinican writer and an architect of the Caribbean Creolite movement, did a quick tour of the Eastern Seaboard a few weeks ago to promote his novel ''Texaco.'' Mr. Chamoiseau, a shy man given to quiet, nervous laughter, would rather have been at home. He does not like attention, he said.

title: Kabila Bans Party Activity In Kinshasa
description: President Laurent Kabila today banned political party activity and public demonstrations in the capital, setting his week-old Government on a collision course with the main opposition leader, who has called for a big march on Wednesday.

title: Tobacco Talks Weigh Benefit and Risk
description: Every day has brought a new bulletin from the tobacco talks. Cigarette makers pledge to fight teen-age smoking. Negotiators reach a preliminary plan to make it harder for smokers, current and future, to sue. And industry representatives indicate that they might give Federal authorities control over a most alluring drug, nicotine.

title: Heiress's Death Leads Police To Look at Husband's Past
description: When the body of a 65-year-old newspaper heiress was found in the shallows of a lake in Arizona 12 days ago, the police turned to her new husband.

title: 3 in Primary for Governor See Glimmer of Recognition
description: The three Democratic candidates for governor traveled from Memorial Day service to war monument to parade today, shaking hands, patting backs and searching eyes for that glimmer of recognition that would suggest that weeks of campaigning were beginning to pay off.

title: Account Changes At 3 TV Networks
description: Three television networks have made changes in their accounts.

title: Creating Scrapes for a Squirt Who Can Dance His Way Out
description: David Neumann is a gifted physical comic with a persona of a Chaplinesque squirt who finds himself in all manner of peculiar situations in ''Don't Just Do Something, Stand There,'' presented on Sunday night at Performance Space 122. Mr. Neumann is also an impressive actor who creates dance and theater pieces rich with ideas and commitment. What he needs now, however, is a director.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HEART, ROSE
description: HEART-Rose. On May 26, 1997. Beloved wife of the late Louis Heart. Loving mother of the late Candace Ella Heart. She is survived by her sisters Bertha Fields and Louise Stockman, brother Leo Cooper & many nieces, nephews, grand-nieces and grand-nephews. A member of the Brandeis University National Women's Committee and a Shakespearean scholar, Mrs. Heart authored the undergraduate outline and syllabus of the plays of Shakespeare. An active Board member of the Brandeis Women's Queens Chapter for many years, she taught and coordinated varied study groups. She will be mourned by many and eternally remembered by all who knew her. Funeral service at 1 PM, Thursday, May 29, Schwartz BrosJeffer Memorial Chapel, 114-03 Queens Blvd., Forest Hills, N.Y. 11375; 718-263-7600. Interment following the service at New Montefiore Cemetery, Pinelawn, LI, NY.

title: Williams in Fine Style At French Open Debut
description: Her father stayed home and her attempts to speak the local language did little except get her lost in Paris. But Venus Williams, with her hair trussed in white beads and her teeth wrapped in transparent braces, made a triumphant Grand Slam debut this afternoon at the French Open.

title: U.S. Actions in Postwar Europe Didn't All Inspire Admiration
description: To the Editor:

title: Seemingly Aimless 'Megan' Defense Is Seen as Trying to Save Client's Life
description: On a bathroom wall in the courthouse where Jesse K. Timmendequas is on trial for his life here, a bit of graffiti poses the most frequently asked question about the Megan Kanka murder case. ''Why is there even a trial?'' some commentator scrawled.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PISETZNER, ARTHUR
description: PISETZNER-Arthur. Beloved husband of Judy (nee Rachelle). Loving father of Sharon (William) Baker, and Bruce. Dear brother of David (Lynn). Fond brother-in-law of Bernard (Judy) Rachelle. Funeral services will be held in Chicago on Wednesday, May 28. In lieu of flowers, contributions to the Jewish Braille Institute, 110 East 30th St., NY NY 10016 or the charity of your choice. Information: Weinstein 1-800-288-5701.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BECK, SIMON
description: BECK-Simon. Beloved husband of the late Sylvia. Devoted father of Lester and father-in-law of Phyllis. Cherished grandfather of Richard and Dina and Carol. Services Tuesday, 11:30 AM, at I.J. Morris, 21 E. Deer Park, Dix Hills, NY.

title: Blue Cross Workers Strike
description: The people who answer questions and process claims at the state's biggest health insurer, Blue Cross and Blue Shield of New Jersey, went on strike at midnight, said Patrick J. Tully, a union spokesman. Negotiations between the company and the union representing 1,700 customer service representatives, claims processors and claims adjusters broke down yesterday afternoon, a state mediator said.

title: For Red Wings, Next Stop: Philadelphia
description: They pounded the opposing goaltender relentlessly, to a point where even the great Patrick Roy finally proved human. They destroyed the defending Stanley Cup champion Avalanche in its own zone, in the neutral zone, or anywhere Colorado had a notion of forming an offense.

title: Wary Hong Kong Collectors Send Art Abroad for Safety
description: Hong Kong's impending change from British to Chinese Communist rule has led to an exodus of Chinese art, with residents sending their collections overseas out of fear that China may prevent the export of items deemed to be cultural patrimony.

title: Rapid Test for Common Infection Is Proving Elusive
description: MILLIONS of women around the world have a pelvic infection that can cause chronic pain, internal scarring, infertility and sometimes death. A single inexpensive oral dose of antibiotics could easily and permanently cure the infection, but the women remain untreated.

title: Adobe Systems Selects Y&R
description: Adobe Systems Inc. in San Jose, Calif., has named Young & Rubicam San Francisco to handle the software company's account, which had been handled by Foote, Cone & Belding in San Francisco, part of True North Communications. Billings were estimated at $15 million. The decision came after a two-month review that also included: Bozell Worldwide in Costa Mesa, Calif., a unit of Bozell, Jacobs, Kenyon & Eckhardt, and Cole & Weber in Los Angeles, part of the WPP Group.

title: Churchill's Phrase
description: To the Editor:

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: Baseball

title: Clinton Girding For Stiff Debate On NATO Issue
description: As President Clinton left for Paris today for a ceremony intended to clear the way for NATO expansion, Administration officials prepared for a long, hard struggle to win Senate support for the extension of formal security guarantees to former Soviet-bloc nations.

title: When Jurors Ignore the Law
description: America's system of trial by jury depends on the willingness of jurors to do their best to reach verdicts based on the law and evidence, putting aside their own personal biases. Last week a Federal Appeals Court in Manhattan moved to protect this process by recognizing the authority of judges to remove jurors who brazenly engage in the practice known as '''nullification,'' purposely ignoring the evidence and law to acquit or convict a defendant based on their own racial, cultural or political predispositions.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JATLOW, CELIA
description: JATLOW-Celia. On May 25, 1997. Beloved wife of Jack. Survived by her daughter, Ellen Gruber, and son-in-law, Fred, grandchildren Jennifer and Marcie. Services Tuesday, 11:45 A.M. at ''The Riverside'', 76th St and Amsterdam Ave.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MARKS, ARTHUR D.
description: MARKS-Arthur D. Jr. Corporate insurance broker in New York City, on May 23, 1997. Husband of late Alice Oppenheimer Marks, loving father of Arthur D. Marks III, Edith M. Seligson, Andrew H. Marks, & the late Alice M. Preston, step-father of John Oppenheimer, Ellen Oasis, and Joan Samuelson. He leaves behind his grandchildren, Nancy Seligson Green, Kate Friedman, Margaret MacKenzie, Elizabeth and Anne Preston, Sam and Charlotte Marks, and Michael and David Solomon, and greatgrandchildren, Drew and Chloe Alice Friedman, and Benjamin Green. Service on Tuesday, May 27, 1997, at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue, at 5 P.M. In lieu of flowers, please give to the charity of your choice.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SINGER, MICHAEL
description: SINGER-Michael. Born December 9, 1927. Died suddenly May 26, 1997. Beloved husband of Barbara. Loving father of Peter, Elizabeth and John. Father-in-law of Susanna, Nathan and Rita. Devoted grandfather of Max, Rebecca, David and Samantha. Brother to J. David Singer. Memorial service 10:45 AM, Wednesday, May 28, at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 76th and Amsterdam Avenue, NYC. In lieu of flowers please make contributions to a charity to be determined by the family.

title: CHRONICLE
description: SANDRA BROWN, a best-selling author of romantic suspense novels, and her husband, MICHAEL BROWN, a video producer, are about to move into a house they have built in Fort Worth. But should they feel nostalgic for their former home, they can watch it being blown up every week on CHUCK NORRIS's program on CBS-TV, ''Walker, Texas Ranger.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STERN, DAVID
description: STERN-David. Loving father of Bette Stern Langer and Harvey and Barbara Stern. Dear companion of Audrey Gelzer. Cherished grandfather of Lisi, Adam, Emma and Sarah. Dear brother of Kieve Stern. Services ''Boulevard-Riverside,'' 1450 Broadway, Hewlett, Long Island, 9:30 A.M., today.

title: BATTLE LINES FORM IN MEDICARE FIGHT
description: Having agreed on the general outlines of a plan to balance the budget, Congress will soon begin a major effort to redesign Medicare, and the process has already set off a fierce legislative struggle that pits elderly people, hospitals, doctors and other health care providers against one another.

title: Fix the Photos, Make Them Lie
description: YOU literally cannot believe your eyes. At the touch of a button, your wrinkles vanish. The gloomy skies of your vacation brighten and turn cloudless. Your attractive rival suddenly disappears from the scene.

title: Technology Crucial To Jobs, Women Say
description: More than 7 out of 10 working women view technology as a critical factor in helping them attain higher salaries and better career opportunities. In addition, professional women earning more than $45,000 a year are three times more likely to use computers heavily than others.

title: Caring and Paying
description: To the Editor:

title: Where Love Outranks Power and Profit
description: Stuart Zimberg's eyes shine in the reflected stage light. He is slender, scrupulously dressed, with dark, crepuscular eyes that come alive with every clap, every gasp, every whispered comment in the audience at the Barrymore Theater.

title: Cablevision's Dominance in Market Draws Some Opposition
description: Nearly three months after making a deal to take over Madison Square Garden, Cablevision Systems has remained mute over exactly how much more it will eventually charge subscribers to watch Knicks, Rangers and Yankees games on the MSG Network, and Mets, Nets, Devils and Islanders games on SportsChannel.

title: Patterns
description: Another Try at Sportswear

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FELDMAN, CHESTER
description: FELDMAN-Chester. Of Englewood Cliffs, N.J. and Los Angeles CA. On Sunday, May 25, 1997. Devoted husband of Rhoda, loving father of Susan and David, doting grandfather of Hannah, William, and Nicolai. Graveside service, 1 P.M. today, at Cedar Park Cemetery, Forest Ave., Paramus, N.J.

title: Clear Inspirations
description: Those clear vinyl beach shoes known as jellies have inspired designers of accessories to adapt the idea of jellies into other forms like tote bags, hair clips and sunglass frames, sometimes clear and sometimes opaque.

title: Price Tags Help Save Louisiana's Coast
description: To the Editor:

title: Johnson: A Man With A Mission
description: THE man in dark glasses and gray gabardine suit and gripping a brown briefcase hurried into Yankee Stadium late yesterday morning, looking either like an undercover man or a man on a mission. It was the latter, since his cover was soon blown when he changed into the Baltimore Orioles' gray-and-orange double-knit suit.

title: Suspect's Ex-Teammates Recall Coldness
description: Even when she was 8 and 9 years old, the teen-age girl arrested in the lurid slaying of a man in Central Park seemed to those around her to dwell in an impenetrable and unhappy world unto herself, despite the wealthy trappings of her upbringing, and she already appeared to regard her parents with a certain frosty disdain.

title: Rail Line to Reopen
description: Rail service on the state's busiest commuter line was expected to return to normal today after a freight train derailment Sunday caused two days of delays. Crews were expected to work through the night to repair track damaged when seven cars of a Conrail freight train loaded with auto parts jumped the track also used by Amtrak and New Jersey Transit trains, Amtrak officials said yesterday. The accident may have been caused by someone tampering with a switch, an Amtrak spokesman said.

title: Republicans Resisting Census Plan to Correct Undercounting
description: While thousands of people in California and North Dakota grow anxious over the delay in further Federal aid to help them recover from devastating floods, the bill to provide it is hung up, in part, by the continuing political dispute over how the Census Bureau will count the population in 2000.

title: Flight Errors Show Increase Of 26 Percent
description: The number of errors by controllers in the last six months at one of the New York region's most vital air traffic control centers has risen by 26 percent over the same period a year earlier. But the Federal Aviation Administration has produced surprising data indicating that the errors are not linked to staff shortages.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ALLEN, MILDRED
description: ALLEN-Mildred, 89. Beloved wife of the late Charles, Jr. and loving mother of the late Arthur. Cherished sister of Gladys & Al Rudner. Adoring grandmother of Cynthia and Karl Goodkin and the late Arthur, Jr. Great-grandmother of Devin. Beloved aunt of Jane and Maurice Sherman, Judy and Jerry Kessel. ''To live in the heart is never to be forgotten''. A private funeral was held May 22, 1997.

title: SOCCER REPORT
description: Major League Soccer

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption yesterday about Senator Strom Thurmond's record filibuster misstated his party affiliation in some copies. At the time, 1957, he was a Democrat; he became a Republican in 1964.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MILBAUER, SAMUEL
description: MILBAUER-Samuel. Age 97, in FL, on May 25, 1997. Beloved husband of the late Elsie. Loving father of Gloria Steinik, Milton Milbauer, Thelma Konowitz and Carole Muehlgay. Devoted father-in-law of Irving, Marilyn, Jack and the late Stanley. Dear brother of Helen Josephy. Fond grandfather of many grandchildren, great-grandchildren, and one great-greatgrandchild. Services Tuesday, 1:30 PM, at I. J. Morris Chapels, 46 Greenwich St., Hempstead, NY. Interment to follow at New Montefiore Cemetery, Pinelawn, NY.

title: Chess
description: There are events nowadays that might be considered ''almost world championships'' because they include most of the world's best. One of these, the Dos Hermanas International Tournament in Spain in April, registered Category 19 on the International Chess Federation scale. That is, the average rating of the players was a whopping 2702; Garry Kasparov's rating is 2785.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BELFORD, ANNE
description: BELFORD-Anne. A beloved friend and confidant to three generations of the Rosen family. Miss Anne was more than a coworker, she was part of our family. For over 50 years at Junior's Restaurant she was a tremendous contributor to the success we have enjoyed. She shared more than just working hours with us. she shared in our lives. In good as well as not-so-good times, you could always count on Miss Anne. Whether celebrating a momentous occasion with the family or simply being available to listen & offer an honest opinion, she was always there for us. The Rosen family will truly miss Miss Anne & will cherish all of the memories of the time spent knowing her.

title: As Culture Wars Go On, Battle Lines Blur a Bit
description: Everyone is weary, but the culture wars rage on. On campuses and in concert halls, in art galleries and in libraries, in foundation offices and Government agencies, multiculturalists still lock horns with those who believe in the primacy of Western civilization. The fervor has decreased; the sense of resignation has increased; but differences remain despite claims of victory or suggestions of abdication.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  EPSTEIN, GERTRUDE BERKSON
description: EPSTEIN-Gertrude Berkson. On May 24. Born July 2, 1909. Beloved mother of Helen and Gordon Hammond, and Henry Epstein and Joanne Jaglowski. Cherished grandmother of John Simerman and Tiffany Graham, and the late David Simerman Jr., Jacob Epstein. Great-grandmother of Ariel Simerman. Devoted aunt of Dr. Gail Malloy, Stephen Berkson and Dr. Richard Berkson, and their children. Barnard graduate; dedicated teacher for over 40 years. Great lover of music, language and humor. Service 12:15, Wednesday, at ''The Riverside,'' 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SEXTON, VIRGINIA STAUDT, PH.D.
description: SEXTON-Virginia Staudt, Ph.D., on May 24, 1997, in Cincinnati, OH. Of Forest Hills, NY. Retired Professor of psychology CUNY and St. John's University. Beloved wife of the late Richard J. Sexton, Ph.D. Devoted mother of Richard E. Sexton, Mary Sexton Althouse, Georgina S. and Nancy E. Sexton. Loving grandmother of Katherine Althouse, Laura and Patricia Sexton. Sister of Florence C. Staudt. Reposing Fox Funeral Home, Forest Hills, Thursday and Friday, 2-5, and 7-9 PM. Funeral Mass at Our Lady Queen of Martyrs Church, Saturday, May 31, at 9:30 AM. Interment St. Raymond's Cemetery, Bronx, NY. Donations to Cathedral High School, 350 East 56th Street, NYC, 10022-4199 appreciated.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Universal Pictures Gets Lift From 'Jurassic Park' Sequel

title: Imaging Device Makes Chip-Sized Cameras a Real-World Possibility
description: The digital still camera that Toshiba will start selling this summer does not look much different from dozens of cameras that have flooded the market lately. But on the inside, the camera holds what could be the seed of a revolution.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BABSON, DONALD P.
description: BABSON-Donald P., of Wellesley, Massachusetts; on April 21, 1997. He was 73. Husband of the late Susan (Averill) Babson. He is survived by 5 children: Averill Babson & her husband Gregory E. Sohns of Darien, CT, Paul Talbot Babson, II of Needham, MA, James A. Babson and his wife Asoka Bandarage of South Hadley, MA., Deborah Babson of Jaffrey, N.H. & Richard Babson of Boston, MA., three granddaughters: Olivia Louise Sohns, Antonia Averill Sohns and Juliet Susan Babson of Darien, CT, and one grandson, Maithri Bandarage Babson of South Hadley, MA. The family requests that no flowers be sent. Contributions in his name may be made to the institution or charity that best represents your affiliation with Donald P. Babson. A memorial service and celebration of his life will commence at 7:30 PM, Friday, May 30, in Knight Auditorium on the Babson College Campus. Mr. Babson was Chairman of BabsonUnited Investment Advisors, Inc. as well as chairman and President of United Business Service. For information call J.S. Waterman and Sons-Waring Funeral Home, Wellesley, Massachusetts (617235-4110).

title: In Florida, a Revival That Came but Didn't Go
description: The first of them get here at dawn and wait all day, facing the door. By noon, the line outside the modern-looking brown-brick church stretches for a city block. Pilgrims from around the world sit or stand in the parking lot, enduring heat, sun, their own expectation.

title: 2 Wounded in Shootings Near Club on Upper West Side
description: Shootings near the China Club, a popular Upper West Side nightspot, left two young men wounded early yesterday and prompted the Mayor's Social Club Task Force to investigate the club to determine whether it should be shut down.

title: Garden's Next Battle Could Be Over Smith
description: Where there's smoke, there's smoke, only smoke. There is no reason to shout ''fire'' -- even in an empty Madison Square Garden -- unless someone gets burned, or until somebody gets fired.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOOR, RUTH
description: GOOR-Ruth. Beloved wife of the late Hyman, mother of Paul. Family were the proprietors of the well known ''Metropolitan Book Store.'' Graveside services to be held on Wednesday, May 28, at the Mount Ararat Cemetery, Farmingdale, NY. For information please contact the I.J. Morris, Inc. Funeral Home at 1-800-624-8282.

title: China's Poisonous Lie
description: The United States is helping China get away with a plain, obvious lie that is a plain, obvious threat to peace and to American armed forces.

title: Soviet Surprises
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HUMPHREY, JOSEPH H.
description: HUMPHREY-Joseph H. On May 23, 1997. Retired President of the investor firm, Calvin Bullock, Ltd. A Director of Queens County Savings Bank. Graduate of Harvard Business School, 1931. Beloved husband of the late Nancy. Loving father of Joseph and Nancy Humphrey. Devoted grandfather of Abigail and Pieter. Loving fatherin-law of Katherine Humphrey and Charles Hulten. Beloved friend of Vera Van Dyke. Reposing at Martin A. Gleason Funeral Home, 149-20 Northern Blvd., Flushing. Mass of Christian Burial Wednesday, 10:15 A.M., St. Andrew's. Interment Mt. St. Mary's. Visiting Tuesday, 2-5 and 7-10.

title: Recruiting for the Fleet
description: The national tradition of Memorial Day also means the local tradition of Fleet Week, now 10 years old. The patriotic swell brought on by the holiday, coupled with the sight of several thousand sailors in crisp uniforms and gleaming ships docked on the Hudson, is a recruiter's dream.

title: Beating the System, With Bribes and the Big Lie
description: On a tree-shaded sidewalk in a wealthy Teheran neighborhood last week, four dangerously carefree teen-agers, two boys and two girls, chose an unlucky time for a stroll.

title: Milnes Makes Debut as Conductor
description: It takes a kind of courage, or maybe bravado, for an opera singer to enter another field at 62. But that's what happened at Carnegie Hall on Sunday night, when the baritone Sherrill Milnes made his New York debut as a conductor. Mr. Milnes, who boasts an impressive legacy as a singer, has been working with diminished vocal resources for years. So it's natural for him to want another outlet.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CLYNE, KATHERINE E.
description: CLYNE-Katherine E. Passed away on Sunday, May 25, 1997. Beloved wife of the late Irving M. Clyne. Devoted mother and friend of Robert. Loving sister of Marion Hirsh, Ralph Friedberg and the late Frank Friedberg. Her kindness and caring will be missed by all whom she touched. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to the American Cancer Society. Services private.

title: Fusion Research Prompts Fears Of Future Bombs
description: DESPITE the end of the cold war, a quiet battle is heating up in the Federal Government over whether the nation's weapon scientists should be allowed to press ahead with work toward a new generation of hydrogen bombs.

title: Langfuhr Runs 1:33 To Win the Met Mile
description: Who owns New York? Maybe Langfuhr, the 5-year-old horse from Canada who continued his sweep of victories on New York tracks yesterday when he won the Metropolitan Handicap at Belmont in a blazing performance that fell one-fifth of a second short of the record for the race, which has been being run for 104 years.

title: As Vote Nears, Canada's Parties Turn Right
description: Even the speech coaching he has undergone could not hide Preston Manning's western roots or prairie individualism as he railed against big government at a campaign stop here and vowed to work for those Canadians ''who think this gov'munt doesn't give a hoot about them.''

title: Bus Terminal to Be Dedicated
description: ATLANTIC CITY

title: Restricting Teen-Age Drivers
description: State Senator Robert W. Singer, a Republican of Lakewood, said he plans to introduce a bill on June 6 to sharply restrict the privileges of teen-age drivers.

title: Palestinian Rights Monitor Charges Torture of Prisoners
description: A Palestinian human rights advocate accused the Palestinian security forces today of extensive abuse and torture of its prisoners.

title: Heat Stays Alive By Holding Off Jordan and Bulls
description: His greatness has become a given, yet people sometimes forget about his benevolence. Michael Jordan played 48 holes of golf on Sunday, and 45 minutes today. If that was not enough, he and the Chicago Bulls spotted the Miami Heat 20 points late into the third quarter.

title: Rise of Homelessness
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  THRESHMAN, NORMAN R.
description: THRESHMAN-Norman R. General insurance agent for NRT & Co., Inc. of Jersey City, N.J. Died May 24, 1997 in Callicoon, NY. Survived by his wife, Jeanette Nolet Threshman, 3 daughters: Dorothy Davies, Janet Threshman, and Nancy Eschenberg, eight grandchildren and 5 great grandchildren.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BAREK, ESTHER
description: BAREK-Esther. Passed away suddenly in Boca Raton, FL on May 26. Loving wife of Milton. Devoted mother of Dr. Dennis (Deborah) and Dr. Lowell (Elizabeth). Darling grandmother of Jonathan, Scott, Rachael and David. Dear sister of Jack and Seymour Pollack. Services were held at Eternal Light Memorial Gardens, Boynton Beach, FL on May 27th.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BABSON, DONALD P.
description: BABSON-Donald P., of Wellesley, Massachusetts; on April 21, 1997. He was 73. Husband of the late Susan (Averill) Babson. He is survived by 5 children: Averill Babson & her husband Gregory E. Sohns of Darien, CT, Paul Talbot Babson, II of Needham, MA, James A. Babson and his wife Asoka Bandarage of South Hadley, MA., Deborah Babson of Jaffrey, N.H. & Richard Babson of Boston, MA., three granddaughters: Olivia Louise Sohns, Antonia Averill Sohns and Juliet Susan Babson of Darien, CT, and one grandson, Maithri Bandarage Babson of South Hadley, MA. The family requests that no flowers be sent. Contributions in his name may be made to the institution or charity that best represents your affiliation with Donald P. Babson. A memorial service and celebration of his life will commence at 7:30 PM, Friday, May 30, in Knight Auditorium on the Babson College Campus. Mr. Babson was Chairman of BabsonUnited Investment Advisors, Inc. as well as chairman and President of United Business Service. For information call J.S. Waterman and Sons-Waring Funeral Home, Wellesley, Massachusetts (617235-4110).

title: Contract With the World
description: To the Editor:

title: Wine Talk
description: ANDREW LLOYD WEBBER finally got another hit, but don't line up for tickets. It ran for only two nights in London last week, and there are no plans to take it on the road. Reportedly, it pulled in more than $6 million for the two performances, which must put the 48-year-old showman -- Lord Lloyd Webber to you, mate -- up there in the Bruce Willis league for quickly earned money.

title: Confidence Index Soars; Home Resales Off
description: Consumer confidence rose to a 28-year high in May, the Conference Board said yesterday. A separate economic report showed that home resales fell more than expected in April as borrowing costs continued to creep up.

title: Court Agrees to Decide if U.S. Customs Can Seize All Undeclared Money
description: The Supreme Court agreed today to decide whether the Government can constitutionally seize all the money that someone has tried to take out of the country without first filing the required report with the Customs Service.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  CHRISTY, BEVERLY M.
description: CHRISTY-Beverly M. Grace Church, 802 Broadway at 10th Street, Thursday, May 29, 5:00 PM. Reception following Service.

title: Contractor Fined $1 Million
description: A total of $1 million in fines was imposed yesterday on a South Hackensack military contractor that admitted in October that it illegally sold plans for an American-made satellite communications system to a Russian company. Electrodyne Systems Corporation had also acknowledged in Federal court that it used Russian and Ukrainian parts to build a missile simulator even though the contract specified that the parts were to be American-made, Noel L. Hillman, an assistant United States attorney, said. Judge Alfred J. Lechner Jr. ordered Electrodyne to pay the fines to the Navy, Air Force and the National Air and Space Administration.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KITAINIK, IDA
description: KITAINIK-Ida. Yeshiva University and our affiliated Rabbi Isaac Elchanan Theological Seminary mourn the passing of an outstanding aishet chayil, beloved mother of Sarah (and Rabbi Myron) Rakowitz, Jay (and Riva) Kitainik, and Libby (and Sam) Stahl. Rabbi and Mrs. Rakowitz, RIETS Fellows who established the Shlomo Shabsai and Ruth Rakowitz Tutorial Fund for Talmudic Studies at The Marsha Stern Talmudical Academy-YU High School for Boys, have also provided major support for YU and Yeshiva College. We extend heartfelt condolences as well to grandchildren and the entire family. May they be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Dr. Norman Lamm, President Yeshiva University David S. Gottesman, Chairman Board of Trustees Judah Feinerman, Chairman RIETS Board of Trustees Elliot Gibber, Chairman YUHS Board

title: Where a Top-Notch Cheddar Gets the Proper Respect
description: COVENT GARDEN, a warren of streets and covered shopping areas catering to tourists, is London's version of the South Street Seaport in Manhattan or Quincy Market in Boston. But one shop here seems a throwback to the days when the area was London's breadbasket.

title: Miller Withdraws MTV Beer Ads
description: The Miller Brewing Company has withdrawn commercials for its beer brands from the MTV cable television network after a similar step by Miller's primary competitor, the Anheuser-Busch Companies.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHACK, HAROLD JOSEPH
description: SCHACK-Harold Joseph. On May 25, 1997. Beloved husband of Celestine Schack. Loving father of Celeste Schack and Valerie DeBoni and her husband Graziano. Adoring grandfather of Lorenzo and Lamberto. Dear brother of Lynn Kessler. Friends may call at the Abbey in the Frank E. Campbell Building, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81 Street today Wednesday 5-8PM. Mass of Christian burial at St. Vincent Ferrer R.C. Church, Lexington Avenue at 66th Street, Thursday at 1 P.M.

title: TALKS OVER POSSIBLE SALE LIFT BIOWHITTAKER STOCK
description: Shares of Biowhittaker Inc. rose nearly 9 percent yesterday after the company said it was in preliminary talks with several parties about a possible takeover. The company, based in Walkersville, Md., makes diagnostic testing products. In October, it hired the investment bank Alex. Brown & Sons to explore ''strategic alternatives to maximize shareholder value.'' Biowhittaker's shares were up 87.5 cents, at $10.75, giving the company a market capitalization of more than $115 million.

title: COLUMBIA GAS SYSTEM PLANS ACQUISITION OF ALAMCO
description: Columbia Gas System Inc., a natural-gas pipeline company, agreed yesterday to buy Alamco Inc. for about $83 million in cash and the assumption of about $18 million in debt. The deal, in which Columbia would pay $15.75 for each Alamco share, would enable Columbia to become the largest gas producer in the Appalachian Basin. Alamco, based in Clarksburg, W. Va., operates 1,200 oil and gas wells. Shares of Alamco rose 62.5 cents yesterday, to $15.25, while Columbia Gas shares fell 87.5 cents, to $63.875. Columbia, based in Reston, Va., said its Columbia Natural Resources unit and Alamco together represent 13 percent of the gas produced in the Appalachian Basin.

title: Bond Prices Slip as Traders Await Data
description: Treasury prices fell yesterday, pushing the yield on the benchmark 30-year bond above the psychologically important level of 7 percent for the first time in nearly a month.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  EIDELHEIT, JOEL
description: EIDELHEIT-Joel Passed away on Monday night May 26, 1997 at the age of 52 from a 6 month bout with cancer. He leaves his loving wife Ita, his daughters Elyse and Cyd and his sister Barbara Ingber. Service will be Wednesday at 10:45am at ''Gutterman's'' in Rockville Centre, NY.

title: Curtain Down, Stars Out, Adrenalin Up
description: FIFTEEN minutes before the opening-night party for the Broadway musical ''Steel Pier'' is to begin, Suzanne Tobak, the woman running it, can't find the manager of Tavern on the Green. It seems that the dinner given by Madison Square Garden to welcome Roseanne and the cast of ''The Wizard of Oz'' in one of the restaurant's smaller rooms is going on longer than expected. And for its party, ''Steel Pier'' has paid for the entire restaurant. When the manager does appear, breathless, it is clear he is dazzled by the celebrity in his midst. It is equally clear that Ms. Tobak is not.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MALES, GERTRUDE D. (NEE BERENSON)
description: MALES-Gertrude D. (Nee Berenson) of Ft. Lee. Beloved wife of Milton, devoted mother of Lynn Yablon, dear sister of Ida Rosenberg. Services ''King David Cemetary'' Putnam Valley, NY, Thursday at 11:30am. For information call ''Gutterman-Musicant'' 1-800522-0588.

title: Smith Barney Suspends Its Northeast Chief
description: Smith Barney Inc. has suspended Robert Maloney, the director for its Northeast region, pending an investigation of his role in soliciting campaign contributions, according to people familiar with the matter.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KLEINMAN, GERSHON
description: KLEINMAN-Gershon. Riverdale Jewish Center extends profound condolences to Dr. Eli Kleinman on the loss of his beloved father, Gershon. May the family be comforted amongst the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Jonathan I. Rosenblatt, Rabbi Tobias B. Schapiro, President

title: Money Doesn't Buy Test Scores, Studies Say
description: In ordering New Jersey to equalize school spending by giving more to poor districts earlier this month, the New Jersey Supreme Court made the common-sense assumption that money is a key to improving inner-city education.

title: Ideas on Art And Country, Provocatively
description: From the graceful Greek columns of Jefferson's Monticello to the garish Greek columns of Caesars Palace in Las Vegas, American art and the history behind it have taken a long downward tumble from idealism to kitsch. That, at least, is the message sent by Robert Hughes's extravagant, entertaining, altogether dazzling series ''American Visions.'' True to its claim to view America through the lens of its art, this eight-part series is at least as much about history as it is about painting and sculpture.

title: In a Surprise Move, Molinari Is Leaving Congress for TV Job
description: Representative Susan Molinari, a Staten Island Republican widely viewed as one of her party's most promising young politicians, plans to resign from Congress this summer to join CBS News as a Saturday morning news anchor, network officials and political associates said last night.

title: 2 Teen-Agers Stir Debate Over Law and Violent Youths
description: Because they are charged with second-degree murder, two 15-year-olds arrested last week for the stabbing and mutilation of a real estate broker in Central Park will be prosecuted as adults rather than youths. But because of their ages, a provision of New York law protects Daphne Abdela and Christopher Vasquez from the severity of adult sentencing.

title: A Compromise At Sallie Mae
description: Management of the Student Loan Marketing Association, or Sallie Mae, and a group of eight dissident directors have reached a compromise giving both sides an equal shot at winning control of the company.

title: Gooden's Traveling Is Curtailed
description: George Steinbrenner is so upset with Dwight Gooden for incurring misdemeanor assault charges from getting into a fight with a cabdriver in Arlington, Tex., 11 days ago that the Yankee owner is apparently going to punish the pitcher by keeping him off the coming Yankee trip.

title: Waterford Foods Takes Avonmore Bid in Ireland
description: Waterford Foods P.L.C. said yesterday that it had agreed to be acquired by Avonmore Foods P.L.C. for 337 million Irish pounds, or $512.4 million, in a combination of two Irish dairy companies. Earlier this month, the Waterford cooperative board, which controls 67 percent of Waterford Foods, and the company rejected an Avonmore offer that valued Waterford at 281 million Irish pounds.

title: After High Court Ruling, Clinton Lawyers Fall Back to New Legal Defense Lines
description: Now that the Supreme Court has ruled President Clinton has no constitutional right to avoid a trial on sexual harassment charges while in office, his lawyers today set about preparing new defenses to delay or defeat the lawsuit.

title: US WEST SELLING CABLE SYSTEMS IN THREE STATES
description: US West Media Group said yesterday that it had agreed to sell cable systems in Minnesota to the closely held Charter Communications Inc. of St. Louis and two partners for $600 million. Separately, U S West agreed to sell cable systems in Idaho and Washington to Tele-Communications Inc. for an undisclosed price. U S West is selling the systems in Minnesota and Idaho, which it acquired with Continental Cablevision Inc., to comply with Government regulations barring the company from owning cable networks where U S West Communications, the other division of U S West Inc., provides telephone service. U S West said it was not required to sell the Washington systems.

title: Lilac Blossoms Herald Season of Quirky Ritual
description: The lilac man stuck his nose in the lilac bush in the middle of the lilac grove. It smelled as sweet as, well, as sweet as lilacs. But not to the lilac man, Jack Alexander.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WERLE, FREDERICK C.
description: WERLE-Frederick C. Mannes College of Music notes with deep regret the passing on May 15, 1997 of Frederick C. Werle, a pupil of Robert Casadesus and Nadia Boulanger who fulfilled many administrative positions at Mannes between 1953 and 1976 and taught there over an even longer period of time. His presence will be missed.

title: Send Beijing a Message
description: Mike Mansfield, the great Senate majority leader after Lyndon Johnson, offered an amendment every year to draw down American forces in Europe. President Nixon and the foreign-policy establishment regularly denounced it as isolationist.

title: RYDER TO SELL AUTO-TRANSPORT UNIT TO ALLIED HOLDINGS
description: Ryder System Inc. agreed yesterday to sell its automobile-transport unit to Allied Holdings Inc. for $114.5 million in cash and the assumption of $60 million of debt. Allied Holdings, a car and truck hauler based in Decatur, Ga., expects its sales to more than double to about $1 billion with the acquisition; it had $392.5 million in sales last year. The unit, Ryder Automotive Carrier Services Inc., is one of North America's largest movers of cars and trucks from auto makers to dealerships. It had revenue of almost $600 million in 1996. Miami-based Ryder had revenue of $5.5 billion last year. It has been selling off units to focus on managing and moving goods for other companies.

title: How Friendship Was 'Feminized'
description: LOS ANGELES  Once upon a time and not so very long ago, everyone thought that men had the great and true-blue friendships. The cultural references stretched through time and art: Damon and Pythias, Hamlet and Horatio, Butch Cassidy and the Sundance Kid. The Lone Ranger never rode off with anyone but Tonto, and Laurel never once abandoned Hardy in whatever fine mess he got them into.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: Baseball

title: CHRONICLE
description: The DUCHESS OF YORK has more on her mind than Weight Watchers, cranberry juice and books she has written. She also seems to be concerned with more spiritual matters, and last week met in Minneapolis for two hours with Rabbi MANIS FRIEDMAN, a leader of the Lubavitcher movement in Minnesota.

title: No Blacks at All?
description: To the Editor:

title: Genetically Altered Food
description: To The Living Section:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CANNISTRARO, MARGARET
description: CANNISTRARO-Margaret. Beloved wife of the late Attilio. Devoted and wonderful mother of Philip and Corinne Grandolfo and son-in-law Jim. Loving grandmother of James Grandolfo, Anthony Grandolfo, Carolyn, Christine Grandolpho and Suzanne. Reposing at Farenga Brothers Funeral Home, 920 Allerton Avenue, Bronx until 8:45 AM, Thursday. Mass of Christian Burial 9:45 A.M., at St. Lucy's Church. Contributions to the Arthritis Foundation of NY will be appreciated by the family.

title: A Warehouse Venture
description: Reckson Associates Realty Corporation said it formed a joint venture with the closely held Matrix Development Group to buy and develop industrial and warehouse properties in New Jersey.

title: William Cunningham, a Guardian of the Poor, Dies at 67
description: The Rev. William T. Cunningham, a Roman Catholic priest who became a leading Detroit civil rights advocate and founder of one of the nation's largest programs to feed and train the urban poor, died here on Monday. He was 67.

title: True Equality Comes When Race Isn't a Factor
description: To the Editor:

title: Label Engineered Foods
description: To The Living Section:

title: It's Luyendyk Seeing Green, Goodyear Red
description: If you are thinking of sending Scott Goodyear a sympathy card after his second dose of Indianapolis 500 heartbreak in three years, just stay away from anything with too much green or yellow. He seems to have a lot of trouble with those colors -- when it comes to flags, anyway.

title: Former Enemies Speak of Peace
description: Following are excerpts from remarks by President Clinton and President Boris N. Yeltsin of Russia as they signed an agreement between Russia and NATO. Mr. Yeltsin's remarks were translated by a Russian Government translator.

title: AT&T and SBC Reportedly Talk of Huge Phone Merger
description: In a deal that would reunite Ma Bell with the fastest growing of her progeny, the AT&T Corporation is discussing a merger with SBC Communications Inc., people familiar with the talks said yesterday.

title: Defense Secretary Near Decision on Chairman of Joint Chiefs
description: Defense Secretary William S. Cohen is nearing a decision on a Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff to replace Gen. John Shalikashvili and has narrowed the list to a small number of candidates that includes the general's chief deputy, Pentagon officials said today.

title: With Irabu in the Wings, Rogers on Shaky Ground
description: An animated discussion about the imminent arrival of Hideki Irabu occurred five feet from Kenny Rogers's locker yesterday as a curious Andy Pettitte peppered a reporter with questions about what the Japanese pitcher's contract might be worth, when he might join the Yankees and if he would replace one of the starters in the rotation.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PERLMAN, SIDNEY
description: PERLMAN-Sidney. On May 27, 1997. Beloved husband of Claire. Devoted father of James and Ariane Mindling, Toni and Stuart Young and John and Maxine Perlman and loving grandfather of Mitchell, Ann, Betsy, Sam and Natasha. He was President of Adams & Co Real Estate. He was very active in Jewish causes, particularly UJA-Federation and Israel Bonds; a man who loved his family and friends and was always ready to help them. Service will be held on Wednesday, May 28th at 12:30 PM, at Boulevard Chapel in Hewlett, L.I. In lieu of flowers the family would appreciate contributions to UJA-Federation or the Samuel Field YM-YWHA.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: NEW ENGLAND INVESTMENT COS., -- Boston, plans to acquire Snyder Capital Management Inc., San Francisco. Terms were not disclosed.

title: C.I.A. Plotted Killing of 58 In Guatemala
description: The Central Intelligence Agency, plotting to overthrow the Guatemalan Government in the early 1950's, drew up a ''disposal list'' of at least 58 key leaders, and it trained assassins to kill them, newly declassified documents show.

title: How the Paula Jones Case Evolved
description: Following are the major events in the sexual harassment case brought against President Clinton by a former Arkansas state worker:

title: Alan Harrington, 79, Novelist Known for His Black Humor
description: Alan Harrington, a novelist whose output ranged from black humor to social criticism to chronicles of the heart, died on Friday at his home in Tucson, Ariz. He was 79.

title: Autobiography of a Shy Protagonist
description: A TALE OF TWO CONTINENTS

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  VIDAL, ROBERT
description: VIDAL-Robert, May 24, 1997 after a brief illness. Jazz, Latin bassist, bandleader Mambo Macoco, St. Marks Bar; jazz trio, Princess Pamela's. Esteemed by colleagues, beloved by friends. Born in Brooklyn Heights. Survived by sisters Margie and Gloria, brother Rudy, nephews Robert and John. Visitation today, 2-9 PM, Peter Jarema F.H., 129 East 7th St, NYC. Memorial University of the Streets to be announced, 212-254-9300.

title: Deal to Ease Teacher Duties May Be Costly
description: A contract sweetener that the Giuliani administration gave teachers to help encourage them to accept a pay freeze along with other municipal workers is likely to cost the school system at least twice what was originally estimated, about $60 million next year, or the equivalent of about $1,000 a teacher.

title: Albert Appears in Court As Judge Sets Trial Date
description: Marv Albert, the NBC Sports announcer who is charged with assaulting and sexually abusing a Virginia woman last February, was booked, fingerprinted and photographed today by the Arlington County police, and the judge in the case set Sept. 22 as the trial date.

title: South of 42d, Offices Grow on Pins, Needles and Conversions
description: With the revival of 42d Street between Seventh and Eighth Avenues, and a new, 48-story office building being constructed at the corner of 42d and Broadway, real estate investors and brokers are now looking south for new developments.

title: Damages Sought in Suit
description: Coliseum Holdings, which charges it was blocked by the Tampa Bay Lightning ownership from building the hockey team's arena, is seeking damages from the Lightning based on the projected cash flow of the arena's operations over 30 years.

title: Dow Up 37.50 to Reach Record 7,383.41
description: Stocks advanced to new highs yesterday in a rally led by computer issues.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  DESOSA, COUNT MAXIM
description: DeSOSA-Count Maxim. February 6, 1960-May 26, 1992. Time passes, the loss remains. Eric

title: Ivanisevic Fades Quietly in France
description: He did not rant, he did not rave, and after fourth-seeded Goran Ivanisevic suffered through an opening-round stumble at the French Open today and left Center Court a stunned loser, he did not even wave. Instead, he preserved his unsought reputation as the most talented firebrand never to embellish his resume with a Grand Slam title.

title: Light to Dine By
description: To The Living Section:

title: SUPREME COURT, 9-0, REJECTS CLINTON REQUEST TO PUT OFF SUIT ON SEXUAL HARASSMENT
description: Ruling for the first time that a sitting President can be sued for actions outside the scope of his official duties, the Supreme Court today decisively rejected President Clinton's request to delay proceedings in a sexual harassment suit brought by a former Arkansas state employee, Paula Corbin Jones.

title: Northwestern University takes a lead in using the Internet to add sound and sight to courses.
description: Jerry Goldman, an associate professor of political science here at Northwestern University, was demonstrating how he uses the Internet to teach constitutional law.

title: Fellows in Arts Journalism
description: Twelve journalists specializing in arts and culture have been selected as midcareer and senior fellows of the National Arts Journalism Program for the 1997-1998 academic year.

title: West Warns Croatia on Serbs With Threat to Retain Enclave
description: Washington and its European allies have warned Zagreb that they will postpone transfer to Croatian control of a United Nations-administered enclave unless Croatia lives up to its commitments under the 1995 peace accords.

title: Hemp: Out of Fields and Onto Menus
description: HEMP may be illegal to grow in the United States, but luckily for the owner of the Galaxy, a Gramercy Park restaurant, it's not illegal to eat. The seeds and oil of Cannabis sativa, the plant used to make everything from rope to plastics, is a feature on the eclectic menu at the Galaxy, one of the few places in the country to bring the plant to the plate.

title: Sauteing 101: The Secret Is in the Sizzle
description: THE key to mastering many cooking techniques is to use higher heat than you think you should. If you need proof of this, just invite a professional chef to your house to cook. It's a pretty sure bet that well before the meal is ready, the smoke alarm will go off.

title: Edward Mulhare, 74, an Actor Who Moved From Stage to TV
description: Edward Mulhare, an Irish-born actor who was a suave, handsome presence on the American stage and in films and television for four decades, died on Saturday at his home in Van Nuys, Calif. He was 74.

title: Coffee Prices Soar on Worry About Cold Weather in Brazil
description: Coffee prices surged yesterday, posting their biggest one-day gain in almost three years, after a weekend cold snap in Brazil raised concern that the world's largest crop could be damaged by frost at a time when supplies are already tight.

title: Golf's Most Improbable Threesome
description: IN golf, you usually need to win a tournament for your name to be in the headlines or for your face to be on the highlights. But not now. Not when your name is Tiger Woods, John Daly or that celebrity part-time putter, Michael Jordan.

title: From Network to Network
description: Last season, a small trend developed in shows that were canceled by one network only to be picked up by another.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KERN, JACLYN T.
description: KERN-Jaclyn T. On May 25, 1997, of Locust Valley, NY. Beloved wife of Julius. Loving mother of W. Ryder. Dear grandmother of Kyle and Benjamin. Fond sister of Frank J. Tappan II. Reposing at the Beney Funeral Home, Inc, of Syosset, 79 Berry Hill Rd. Visiting Wednesday, from 2-5 and 7-9 PM. Funeral service on Thursday, 11 AM, at St. John's Church of Lattingtown. Interment Roslyn Cemetery. In lieu of flowers, please make donations to the Hospice Care Network, 900 Ellison Avenue, Westbury, New York 11590.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BARTLETT, ELSA
description: BARTLETT-Elsa. The Department of Psychiatry at New York University Medical Center mourns the passing of our esteemed colleague, Dr. Elsa Bartlett, a valued and respected research scientist. For 15 years she made major contributions in the imaging of the action of antipsychotic drugs in the living human brain. Her devotion to quality research was marked by scientific rigor and integrity. Those who worked closest with her will miss her spirit, her work ethic, her kindness, and her loyalty. Our deepest sympathy is extended to her son Noah and all of her family. Robert Cancro, MD, Lucius N. Littauer Professor and Chairman Jonathan Brodie, MD, Ph.D., Professor of Psychiatry Dept. of Psychiatry

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: BASEBALL

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FELDMAN, CHESTER
description: FELDMAN-Chester. We have lost our dear friend. Chester was a man of humor, intelligence and sensitivity. He was a joy to know. Naomi Beck Madeline and Jack Freedman Rita, Vincent, Melissa Merendino

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEISSMAN, IRVING
description: WEISSMAN-Irving. Park East Synagogue Sisterhood records with sorrow the passing of Irving Weissman, brother of our past President Florence Zornberg. Condolences to the family. Beverly Greenberg, President Polly Etkind Hochberg, Chairman

title: Housing Bill is Prepared
description: Elderly and disabled people who are willing to share living quarters could benefit from a state bill being unveiled today that would provide low-cost loans to nonprofit groups for developing cooperative housing.

title: New York's Finest
description: With a makeshift lineup, the New York Mets probably cannot keep winning like this. But they have been winning lately, and as of Memorial Day they were, statistically anyway, better off than the defending World Series champion New York Yankees. By beating Montreal the Mets improved to 27-22, while the Yankees lost to Baltimore, dropping to 26-23. These surprising numbers have aroused fresh interest in what one overheated Met called the ''New York World Series'' -- a three-game series between the Mets and Yankees that begins in the Bronx on June 16. Now that baseball's format includes interleague play, these games will actually count in the standings, unlike past exhibition games between the two clubs.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SINGER, MICHAEL
description: SINGER-Michael. Born December 9, 1927. Died suddenly May 26, 1997. Beloved husband of Barbara. Loving father of Peter, Elizabeth and John. Father-in-law of Susanna, Nathan and Rita. Devoted grandfather of Max, Rebecca, David and Samantha. Brother to J. David Singer. Service 10:45 AM, Wednesday, May 28, Riverside Chapel, 76th & Amsterdam Ave. Donations please to Habitat for Humanity, 121 Habitat St, Americus Ga 31709, attn: Janine Brock.

title: Palestinians Free Reporter Held for Week
description: Daoud Kuttab, a Palestinian journalist who was detained a week ago evidently because his broadcasts had angered Yasir Arafat, was released tonight by the Ramallah police. He said he was never interrogated, charged, or told why he was held.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GUEST, MARGARET HETHERINGTON HOUCK
description: GUEST-Margaret Hetherington Houck. Age 81. Of New Canaan Conn. and Fishers Island, NY. On May 21, 1997. Mother of Cornelia and Richard Guest, mother-in-law of Cynthia Guest and Robert Mitchell, grandmother of Sarah Guest, Andrew Mitchell, Aune Mitchell and John Mitchell and Aunt of Henry Smith-Miller. Donations may be made to the SPCA of Westchester, 590 N.State Road, Briarcliff, NY 10510 or Pegasus Therapeutic Riding Inc., POB 2053, Darien,Conn 06820.

title: Crime, Drugs, Brutality and Love
description: Whenever Niels Arden Oplev's blood-chilling film ''Portland'' wants to remind you that it is depicting a living hell, the cinematography turns a ghastly yellow-orange. These sequences, filmed on grainy black-and-white stock then tinted, make the unidentified Danish city where ''Portland'' was made appear to be going up in flames. And the industrial-rock music that grinds and groans in the background adds an extra layer of ominous portent.

title: Personal Health
description: SO you think that you cannot consume milk or other foods that contain lactose. Think again. New studies show that even people with a laboratory-confirmed intolerance to lactose can consume ordinary dairy foods, which are the best source of the nutrients needed to prevent osteoporosis.

title: Rescuing Marriages Before They Begin
description: CALL it the toilet-seat theory of romance. Whether a man puts the toilet seat down holds a major clue to the success of a marriage: it is a sign that he understands and respects his wife's needs and is open to the kind of giving and taking of influence that leads to long-term marital stability.

title: Aggressive Strategies Pay Off for HFS
description: Since he founded what then was called Hospitality Franchise Systems Inc. in 1990 with the purchase of the Howard Johnson and domestic Ramada Inn franchise systems, Henry R. Silverman, chairman and chief executive of what is now HFS Inc., has been unrelenting in the pursuit of two goals: expanding access to consumers by acquiring new franchises and driving the stock price higher.

title: Messinger, Calling City Hall Secretive, Sues Over Information
description: Asserting that the Giuliani administration had engaged in a pattern of hiding information from the public, Ruth W. Messinger filed suit in State Supreme Court yesterday seeking to force City Hall to disclose how often it had rejected requests for information over the last two years.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Thursday about the use of tax-exempt organizations to direct political campaign donations misstated the relationship of Peter Flaherty, the head of an organization called Citizens for Reform, to Ronald Reagan's campaign for the Presidency in 1976. Mr. Flaherty was a volunteer for Mr. Reagan that year, not a campaign manager.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COHEN, DR. NATHANIEL
description: COHEN-Dr. Nathaniel. Of Ft. Lee, NJ. Beloved husband of Eileen, devoted father of Sara Sullivan, Sheila Cohen and Thomas Cohen, father-in-law of James Sullivan, Peter Goldsheider and Marie Cohen, dear brother of Aaron M., loving grandfather of Kira, Danny, Michael and Becky. Services ''Wien and Wien'' Park and Passaic St, Hackensack, N.J. Wednesday, 1:15.

title: They Call the Wind Larry
description: The official list of hurricane names for the next few years has now been published, and it contains vestiges of the age-old tradition of trying to appease the gods. The people of the West Indies used to name a hurricane for the saint on whose day the storm appeared. In 1953, wiseacres at the National Weather Service opted for social commentary instead and began to use female names. In the late 1970's they bowed to feminist pressure and alternated the Hildas and Nadines with William and Arthur.

title: Thurston B. Macauley, A Former Times Correspondent, 95
description: Thurston B. Macauley, a journalist whose assignments included seven years as a London correspondent for The New York Times, died on Saturday during a visit to Fort Lauderdale, Fla. He was 95.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CARPENTER, THELMA
