description: CARPENTER-Thelma. Mass and Memorial May 31 at 10:30 AM, Holy Name Church, 96 Street & Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Science Times yesterday about research on hydrogen bombs misstated the day when the Lawrence Livermore National Laboratory in California will break ground on a laser complex to ignite hydrogen. It is tomorrow, not Friday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JATLOW, CELIA
description: JATLOW-Celia The East 55th St Conservative Synagogue sorrowfully records the loss of its esteemed and beloved synagogue Board member. Our deepest sympathy to her husband, Jack, and the family members. Rabbi Reuven Siegel Daniel Hirtenstein, Pres. Lawrence Levine, Ch of Board

title: New York Senate Dallies on Gun Access Bill
description: To the Editor:

title: CHRONICLE
description: When VARTAN GREGORIAN, who is stepping down as president of Brown University, presented a President's Medal to NUALA PELL at commencement on Monday, he said, ''I wanted my last act as president to honor Rhode Island, the nation, women and spouses who help great leaders succeed.''

title: Witness in Bombing Trial Criticizes F.B.I. Crime Lab
description: Timothy J. McVeigh's defense lawyers continued their assault on the F.B.I.'s crime laboratory today, with the testimony of a chemist who described loose security at the laboratory.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  AMES, ARCHER, 85
description: AMES-Archer, 85. Beloved father of Daniel Ames and Peggy Bordnick. Grandfather of Sarah and Jacob Bordnick. Exuberant renaissance man who combined careers in advertising, music and painting.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HEART, ROSE
description: HEART-Rose. On May 26, 1997. Beloved wife of the late Louis Heart. Loving mother of the late Candace Ella Heart. She is survived by her sisters Bertha Fields and Louise Stockman, brother Leo Cooper & many nieces, nephews, grand-nieces and grand-nephews. A member of the Brandeis University National Women's Committee and a Shakespearean scholar, Mrs. Heart authored the undergraduate outline and syllabus of the plays of Shakespeare. An active Board member of the Brandeis Women's Queens Chapter for many years, she taught and coordinated varied study groups. She will be mourned by many and eternally remembered by all who knew her. Funeral service at 1 PM, Thursday, May 29, Schwartz BrosJeffer Memorial Chapel, 114-03 Queens Blvd., Forest Hills, N.Y. 11375; 718-263-7600. Interment following the service at New Montefiore Cemetery, Pinelawn, LI, NY.

title: Who Was Displaced?
description: To the Editor:

title: Love Is Blind; Unfortunately, So Is the Law
description: NATALIE POSNER fell in love with Arnold Goldstein without seeing his face. She can't, because she's legally blind. He is too. They met in 1990 after they had both attended guide dog school, and married four years ago. If their home were as big as their hearts, their love story would be a fairy tale. Some day her prince would unpack.

title: Hostile to Muslims
description: To the Editor:

title: Murdoch Gets Primestar Stake In Pact With His Cable Rivals
description: Rupert Murdoch is known as an entrepreneurial gambler, building his global media empire on one high-risk venture after another.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KAPLAN, DR. PAUL
description: KAPLAN-Dr. Paul, age 67 of Boynton Beach, FL. Reputed scientist in ocean engineering. Published more than 100 scientific research papers. Associated with Stevens Institute of Technology, full Professor at Penn State University and Virginia Tech. Survived by his beloved wife Evelyn and sons Steven and Robert. He will be sorely missed. Services Wednesday, 2 pm May 28, at Riverside Gordon Chapel, Del Ray Beach, FL.

title: Red Wings Feel Bolder This Time
description: There was something to cheer about today for both the Detroit Red Wings and their Stanley Cup finals opponent, Philadelphia, after Detroit's conquest of the Colorado Avalanche in the Western Conference finals.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GERSHNER, ESTHER
description: GERSHNER - Esther. Devoted wife of the late Emanuel. Loving mother of Rena Leikind and Jerry Gershner. Cherished Bubbe of Allison, Matthew, Peter and Jeffrey. Services Thursday, 10:00 AM, Parkside Chapels, 167 Street and Jerome Avenue, Bronx, NY.

title: Tiger Woods Signs Contract With Rolex
description: The Rolex Watch Company S.A. said yesterday that it had signed an endorsement agreement with the golfer Tiger Woods as part of plans to refocus its Tudor brand of watches at younger consumers. Though terms were not disclosed, the trade publication Brandweek reported that Woods was signed for five years and would be paid up to $7 million in endorsement fees and royalties.

title: In Indonesia, Megawati Warns of Poor's 'Rage'
description: JAKARTA  Excluded by the government from Indonesia's legislative elections scheduled for Thursday, Megawati Sukarnoputri spends much of her time in a suburban house with a large tropical garden where caged doves coo contentedly.

title: Trump's Bank Making Deal He Declined
description: Four months after Donald J. Trump walked away from buying 55 Wall Street, a subsidiary of the investment bank that was to have financed his purchase of the historic building has bought it and is discussing developing a ballroom and possibly a luxury hotel or apartments.

title: Russia and West Sign Cooperation Pact
description: Opening a new chapter in the post-World War II history of Europe, President Clinton and other NATO leaders joined President Boris N. Yeltsin of Russia today in signing a ''Founding Act'' of mutual cooperation and security between the alliance and its former principal adversary.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Monday about commencement speakers misstated the name of the alma mater of Tim Russert, moderator of the NBC News program ''Meet the Press.'' It is John Carroll University, not John Carroll College.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LANE, FRANK
description: LANE-Frank, of Huntington Bay NY on May 17, 1997. Co-Founder and Research Scientist of K.L.D. Associates of Huntington. Beloved Husband of Vern E. Loving father of Dorothy Suzanne Crapser. Also survived by 3 grandsons. Memorial Service 11:00AM Saturday, May 31, 1997 at the Virag-Maddex Funeral Home, Inc. 195 East Main Street, Huntington. Cremation was private. In lieu of flowers the family requests that donations be made to Memorial Sloan-Kettering Hospital Box E, 1275 York Ave., New York, New York 10021.

title: Agencies Say U.N. Ignored Pleas on Hutu
description: With reports of mass graves adding to evidence that thousands of Rwandan Hutu refugees may have been killed in recent weeks in Congo, relief agencies say they have sought protection for refugees in the region for more than two years, only to be ignored by the Security Council.

title: Food Notes
description: Where Foods Pick Up Their Wraps

title: This One Didn't Fall Mets' Way
description: This is a way of life for the Mets now, late-inning pinch-hits and comebacks, so when Matt Franco came off the bench in the eighth tonight and slammed a line drive toward the gap in left-center field, he assumed it would fall.

title: A Decision to Depart
description: For 76 straight weeks ABC's ''Good Morning America'' has finished second to NBC's ''Today'' show in the morning news-and-chat-show ratings, and this year the gap between them kept widening. Change had to come. Yesterday it did.

title: What Flinn Didn't See
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SOLOWAY, ALAN M.
description: SOLOWAY-Alan M., of Boynton Beach, FL; formerly of Merrick, NY and Cliffside Park, NJ, age 83. He will always be loved and remembered by his family for his spiritual contribution to their lives, his gentleness, kindness and inner strength. Beloved husband of Mildred, loving father of Richard, Peter and David, loving father-inlaw of Donna and Chells and delighted grandfather of Steven. His aesthetic soul was of a highly creative nature which distinguished him in his field of art direction in Advertising. The world and our lives will be diminished without him and he will be greatly missed. Private services were held on May 25.

title: 1 Blunt Bishop. Pope Steps In. Now There Are 2.
description: Devotees of Bishop Samuel Ruiz Garcia were worried in 1995 when the Vatican appointed a second bishop to join him in leading what is probably the most volatile Roman Catholic diocese in Mexico.

title: DONALDSON, LUFKIN MAKES CHANGES IN ON-LINE SERVICE
description: In an attempt to bolster its nine-year-old on-line unit, Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette Inc. said yesterday that it would offer some of its on-line brokerage customers access to the firm's initial public offerings. The firm said its on-line broker, PC Financial Network (www.pcfn.com), would be renamed DLJ Direct, and that beginning June 20 the unit would reduce commission rates to a flat fee of $20 for each trade. Donaldson, Lufkin also said it would offer a portion of the firm's research on line to investors ''who maintain an appropriate level of assets'' in their on-line accounts.

title: Virus Attacking Striped Bass
description: Recreational fishermen are reporting that an unusually large number of striped bass -- as many as 20 percent to 30 percent -- are infected with a virus that causes their scales to turn white and lumpy, state officials said yesterday. No one seems to know why the illness is so prevalent this year.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COOPER, ELEANOR FLEMING
description: COOPER-Eleanor Fleming. On May 25, 1997. Former employee of Institutional Commodities Services. Dear cousin of Joan Garity Robinson. Reposing Thursday 2-4 and 7-9 P.M., at Riverdale-on-Hudson Funeral Home, 6110 Riverdale Ave, Riverdale, New York. Mass of Christian Burial Friday, 10 A.M., at Frances Schervier Nursing Home Chapel. Interment Saint Raymond's Cemetery.

title: No Gain for Mentally Ill
description: To the Editor:

title: Israeli and Egyptian Fail in Peace Effort
description: A meeting between Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel and President Hosni Mubarak of Egypt failed today to break the impasse in Israel-Palestinian negotiations, but both leaders said they had begun a common effort to revive the stalled talks.

title: Triathlete Fulfills a 3,375-Mile Dream
description: It was only minutes before Jim Howley was due to arrive at City Hall, and word of his accomplishment had spread quickly. By the time he came jogging down the sidewalk, a small crowd had gathered on the steps to greet him. They applauded as he crossed the finish line, where he was presented with a letter from Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-11

title: Acquisition of Bandai by Sega Called Off
description: Sega Enterprises Ltd. and Bandai Company Ltd. abruptly called off their planned merger tonight after Bandai middle managers practically rose up in revolt against the deal.

title: In Animal Studies, Vitamin Treatment Reverses the Effects of Emphysema
description: Researchers said today that they had the first evidence from animal studies that a vitamin derivative might reverse the damage of emphysema, an incurable lung condition.

title: Resurgent Malone Puts Jazz Ahead
description: The rim stopped oscillating on Karl Malone tonight. He has a burden and a Barkley on his shoulders -- not to mention a chip up there, too -- but making half of your 22 shots makes the ride home a little easier.

title: Daly Signs With Callaway
description: John Daly's vow of sobriety persuaded Ely Callaway, chairman of Callaway Golf, to sign him as a spokesman for its newest driver, the Biggest Big Bertha. ''He has a new attitude about what he will and must do,'' Callaway said.

title: Maine Nuclear Plant May Be Closed Early
description: The Maine Yankee Atomic Power Company said today that it was considering shutting the state's only commercial nuclear plant ahead of schedule.

title: McWatters to Buy Mines
description: McWatters Mining Inc. has agreed to buy mining operations in Val d'Or, Quebec, from Placer Dome Inc. for $70 million. McWatters, based in Montreal, said that the Val d'Or operations include two gold mines and a package of exploration properties. The two mines produced 150,000 ounces of gold last year.

title: East German Ex-Spymaster Found Guilty, but Goes Free
description: Markus Wolf, the former East German spymaster who undermined and outsmarted his adversaries for decades during the cold war, was found guilty today on three counts of kidnapping dating from the 1950's and 1960's, but was given a two-year suspended sentence that allowed him to go free.

title: Restaurants For Shouters And Whisperers
description: AT a downtown Manhattan restaurant, over the cacophony of the Gipsy Kings, a 20-something woman in an iridescent green outfit seated at the bar is asked, ''What do you think about noise in restaurants?''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FENSTERHEIM, MILDRED
description: FENSTERHEIM-Mildred. The Ramaz School family mourns the passing of the beloved mother of its devoted teacher and Director of Student Activities, Deedee Benel, and extends heartfelt sympathy to all the members of the bereaved family. Rabbi Haskel Lookstein, Principal David Kahn, Chairman Board of Trustees

title: Carjacking Victim, Locked in Trunk, Gets Help by Disconnecting Lights
description: When two masked carjackers forced Bessie Cassaro into the trunk of her 1992 Nissan early Monday morning, the authorities said, the 64-year-old woman did not lose her composure. Instead, Ms. Cassaro quickly went to work disconnecting the wires to the signal and brake lights.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DUNCAN, KENNETH W.
description: DUNCAN-Kenneth W., 92 years young, died May 25, at Mary Manning Walsh Home. He brought beauty to life wherever he lived. Turtle Pond is his living memorial, the realization of his dreams as an architectural designer and visionary. As display director and visual merchandiser for forty years, he was a creative force, always ten years ahead of the pack. His influence remains pervasive in stores today. Passionate golfer and billiards player-he held an imaginary cue in his hands two hours before he died. He had knife - sharp wit, enormous warmth, was adored by friends, colleagues, his children, Nick and Laura Jacobs, and by me, Rea, his wife for 38 years. What a love affair. See you at the sea wall, Ken.

title: INSIDE METRO
description: A NEW TEST A new writing requirement just passed by the CUNY board may prevent some students at Hostos Community College from graduating this week. B3

title: The Heat's New Hurdle: An Angry Jordan
description: Michael Jordan is tired of the bludgeoning. He said he wants to play basketball, not box or wrestle or do whatever it is Alonzo Mourning and his henchmen pass off as skill. ''It's personal now,'' Jordan said.

title: $11 Billion Merger Plan Would Join HFS and CUC
description: CUC International Inc. and HFS Inc. said yesterday that the two companies planned to merge in an $11 billion deal that would combine such franchises as Century 21 real estate, Days Inn motels and Avis rental cars with a powerful but less known force in telemarketing, home shopping clubs and travel information.

title: Excerpts From Supreme Court Ruling on a Lawsuit Against the President
description: Following are excerpts from the Supreme Court's ruling today rejecting President Clinton's request to defer until he leaves office proceedings in a sexual harassment lawsuit against him. In the Court's usage, ''petitioner'' refers to President Clinton and ''respondent'' to the plaintiff, Paula Corbin Jones. The opinion, written by Justice John Paul Stevens, was joined by all Justices except Justice Stephen G. Breyer. Justice Breyer agreed with the result but gave his reasons in a separate opinion.

title: Mid-Atlantic Region Gains in Optimism
description: Residents of the Middle Atlantic region that includes New York and New Jersey are becoming increasingly convinced that better economic times are on the way, a nonprofit business group said yesterday. But the region still lags far behind the rest of the nation in overall optimism.

title: Santander to Acquire Argentine Bank Control
description: Banco Santander S.A. of Spain said yesterday that it would acquire control of Banco Rio de la Plata of Argentina for $594 million and eventually merge Banco Rio with its Argentine unit to create the country's biggest private bank. Santander will buy 35 percent of Banco Rio, Argentina's second-biggest private bank, from the billionaire businessman Jorge Gregorio Perez Companc, who in turn will get 6 percent of Banco Santander Chile. Santander will have 51 percent of the voting rights and will also assume management control.

title: Mother Teresa Has Quiet Day At Her Convent in the Bronx
description: After slipping into the city with little fanfare on Monday, Mother Teresa of Calcutta spent yesterday sequestered in the Bronx convent of her Missionaries of Charity order and plans to leave the city today for Washington.

title: Metropolitan Diary
description: DEAR DIARY:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MEREN, JAN
description: MEREN-Jan. On Sunday, May 25. Of Irvington, NY and Becket, MA. Age 60. Cherished husband of 25 years to Roslyn Yasser. Devoted father to Peter and Andrew. Dear son-in-law of Esther and Mac Yasser. Loving brother-in-law to Sandra and Alan Friedman, Nan and Alan Yasser. Uncle to David, Jonathan, Lisa and Jennifer. He was the father that anyone could want-and the father that anyone could aspire to be. Services on Wednesday, May 28, at ''The Riverside,'' 76 Street and Amsterdam Avenue. In lieu of flowers contributions may be made to the United States Holocaust Memorial Museum in Washington, D.C.

title: Whitman Vows She'll Track Schools' Use of Extra Money
description: Gov. Christine Todd Whitman said today that she would not challenge a recent decision by the New Jersey Supreme Court ordering her administration to send millions of extra dollars to poor school districts next fall. But she warned that before the districts received any additional money, they would have to prove that it would not be squandered.

title: Ice Cream Basics, From Scoop to Nuts
description: JUST in time to crank up the ice-cream churn comes ''Sorbets and Ice Creams,'' a little book by Lou Seibert Pappas (Chronicle Books, $14.95), which gives the basics, including equipment, ingredients and a brief history. Beginning with a simple but delicious melon ice, the book offers about three-dozen recipes, including one for a rich honey ice cream and a few for frozen mousse. Old-fashioned vanilla and strawberry ice creams share the pages with sophisticated daiquiri granita and ginger ice cream. Most of the ice creams start with a custard made of half-and-half and egg yolks.

title: Can a Top Designer Overcome a Spendthrift Reputation?
description: Editor's Note Appended

title: Short Positions on Nasdaq Rose 3.4% in Latest Month
description: Short-sellers became more active in recent weeks as the Nasdaq stock market rebounded from its recent decline, according to figures released yesterday.

title: Adultery and Regrets, in One-Acts
description: The married middle-aged men of Michael Weller's ''Mistresses'' are products of two eras: the late 20th century and the Mesozoic. They speak in the hypercivilized language of the Sensitive Male yet share the drives and instincts of a distant, primal past.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COHEN, NATHANIEL, M.D.
description: COHEN-Nathaniel, M.D. The Mount Sinai Alumni records with sorrow the passing of their longtime colleague and friend. Dr. Cohen joined the staff in 1956 and for over 30 years distinguished himself as teacher and clinician. Devoted to his patients as individuals whom he cared for with expertise and compassion and a conscientious mentor who touched the lives of countless medical students and residents, he was respected by his peers and loved by his patients. Dr. Cohen will be remembered as a dedicated physician, teacher and friend. We extend our sincere condolences to his family. Wayne S. Fuchs, M.D., President Maria Padilla, M.D., Secretary

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BIERNBAUM, HELEN
description: BIERNBAUM-Helen. The Board of Governors and Members of High Ridge Country Club acknowledge with deep sorrow the passing of our esteemed member Helen Biernbaum. We extend our deepest sympathy to her beloved husband Ralph and their beloved family.

title: Say No to 'Socialist Ideas,' Chirac Urges
description: President Jacques Chirac took charge of his battered conservative coalition's election campaign tonight, appealing on national television to voters in Sunday's elections not to impose a Socialist and Communist Government on him while he was trying to get France ready for the 21st century.

title: Detroit Institutions Are Entangled in the Politics of Race, Class and Labor
description: The Detroit Institute of Arts, the nation's fifth-largest art museum, is crumbling because of financial problems. Strong fences have been built around much of its base because of the imminent risk that sections of the outer walls will fall away from the building's corroded steel frame. Employees place sponges and mop heads just below gallery windows in the museum during snowstorms to catch the condensation dribbling down the single panes of thin glass.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: CITGO PETROLEUM CORP., Tulsa, Okla., a unit of Petroleos de Venezuela S.A., said its president and chief executive, Ralph S. Cunningham, was resigning, effective May 31. Roberto V. Mandini, executive vice president and deputy chief executive, will assume the duties of chief executive until a successor is named.

title: Officers Guilty in Beating
description: Two Essex County sheriff's officers pleaded guilty yesterday to beating a man in a bar while they were off-duty and then detaining him to keep him from reporting the incident. In November 1995, Investigator Darryle Miller and Detective Cyrus Littles took the man, Charles Tucker, into the men's room of an Irvington bar and beat him.

title: Waiting in the Wings
description: So what ever happened to ''Grace Under Fire''? The one-time ABC comedy hit was not even on the fall schedule that ABC announced last week, a development that was all the more surprising given how many new shows -- 12 -- the network was adding.

title: Communication Is Key
description: The Mets needed an out in the eighth inning Monday night, clinging to a one-run lead, but what they really needed was a translator. Standing at the mound, with the game on the line, were Steve Bieser, the utilityman who speaks English but was making an emergency appearance as a catcher; Edgardo Alfonzo, who speaks Spanish and some English but no Japanese; and Takashi Kashiwada, who speaks no English, no Spanish and who kept nodding as Bieser went through his signs.

title: Lawmakers Question Loosening of Technology Export Controls
description: The chairman of the House Judiciary Committee has asked the Justice Department to look at whether there are any links between Asian donors to the Democratic Party and the Clinton Administration's loosening of export controls on sensitive American technology, which has benefited China.

title: Officer Who Shot a Youth Is Honored by His Peers
description: A police officer who fatally shot a 16-year-old boy in the back last month has been named ''officer of the month'' for April by some of his colleagues at the 33d Precinct in Washington Heights, a designation that has angered leaders in a community where police relations are already strained.

title: Congress Wages War on Free Trade
description: The struggle between the Clinton Administration and Congress over renewing China's most-favored-nation trading status is a symptom of a much larger problem with American trade policy.

title: Body of Boy Is Found in Canal
description: The body of a 12-year-old boy who was reported missing earlier this month was found on Monday floating in a canal on the Passaic River, the police said yesterday. The boy, Andres Morales, was last seen by his family on May 17 and was thought to have drowned accidentally in the Dundee Canal while fishing, said Sgt. Cas Jasonek, a police spokesman.

title: A Los Angeles Project Aims to Nourish the City's Jazz Roots
description: The Thelonious Monk Institute of Jazz and the Music Center of Los Angeles County announced yesterday an ambitious jazz program that will include a year-round educational effort at the Music Center. The pianist Herbie Hancock has been named artistic director of the program, which will also draw on other constituents of the center, the Los Angeles Philharmonic and the Southern California Theater Association.

title: Antiquity Under Glass
description: To the Editor:

title: American Makes His Mark In Risky Paris Opera Job
description: Close to completing his first season as principal conductor of the Paris National Opera, James Conlon has fulfilled the first requirement of a high-risk job in an environment infamous for political intrigue, labor troubles, power struggles and quick-to-heckle music lovers: he has survived.

title: European Disunion
description: Just as Americans are getting accustomed to the idea that Asia is the new crucible for American economic and political interests, Europe commands attention again. The confluence of two great shifts now planned in Europe, the eastward expansion of NATO and the adoption of a common currency, could change the Continent in ways that may undermine European stability in the decades ahead.

title: Messier Says He'd Like to Stay
description: In his sixth year as a star performer for Madison Square Garden, Mark Messier has learned a little about the timetable of his corporate employer.

title: In Switch on Issue, Pataki to Use State-Owned Plane
description: Gov. George E. Pataki, who made a campaign issue out of Mario M. Cuomo's use of state aircraft, acknowledged today that the state police had acquired a surplus military plane that he and aides planned to use at least occasionally for state travel.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KORNBLAU, SARA
description: KORNBLAU-Sara. Beloved wife of the late Saul, devoted and loving mother of Allan Kornblau, Brenda and Chester Schneider. Services Wednesday, 12 noon, ''Plaza Memorial'', 91 Street and Amsterdam Ave., New York City.

title: Vote for the Adult, an Ad by a Gubernatorial Candidate Urges
description: Michael Murphy, a former Morris County Prosecutor, has began broadcasting the second television advertisement of his Democratic gubernatorial campaign in New Jersey. The primary is Tuesday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MACKINNON, ALAN D.
description: MacKINNON-Alan D., May 24, at age 49. He devoted his adult years to helping handicapped children participate more fully in life. His gentle warmth and professional skill touched many lives and will be fondly remembered. Son of the late Gladys and Gladstone MacKinnon of Hyde Park in Boston. Survived by siblings, Barbara Kenney of Columbia Falls, Mont., Donald MacKinnon of Billerica, MA., Nancy MacKinnon of Boston, and David MacKinnon of Framingham, Mass., and by life partner, John Hetland of Manhattan. A memorial gathering of family and friends will be arranged.

title: A Chinese Dish With Pork That Can Be Subtle, or Not
description: The subtle flavors of a dish like moo shu pork can be found in this main noodle dish.

title: New Running Boom Is Much More Low Key
description: On March 16, the Atlanta Track Club placed an entry form in the Sunday Atlanta Journal-Constitution for its Peachtree 10K Road Race, held annually on July 4. By March 17, 70,000 applications had been received for a 6.2-mile race that caps its field at 50,000.

title: San Francisco Utility Settles $14 Million Case
description: The Pacific Gas and Electric Company today agreed to pay $14 million to end a lawsuit filed by state and Federal officials accusing the company of filing misleading reports about the environmental impact of a nuclear reactor.

title: EMI Shakes Up New York Operation
description: The EMI Group said yesterday that it would shake up its North American unit to reduce costs and would also try to foster the development of new United States acts to match the success of its top-selling British group, Spice Girls. EMI said it would close its New York EMI Capitol office and shed about 50 staff members. It will also dismiss two top executives, Charles Koppelman and Terri Santisi, and put Ken Berry, the head of EMI Music International and Virgin Records, in charge of its North American business. It will take a charge of $:117.2 million ($192.1 million).

title: Robert E. Andrews Adds Vinegar to New Jersey Race
description: The crowd of about 100 waiting to meet Representative Robert E. Andrews had gathered under a sprawling yellow and white tent, their words full of bitterness as they talked about Gov. Christine Todd Whitman.

title: Heartland Emerges as Leader in Global Trade
description: Though ports historically have tied foreign trade to seacoasts, this interior city, 1,000 miles from the sea, will play host next month to world leaders at their annual economic summit meeting. The choice of Denver as the gathering place is symbolic of how America's heartland is becoming a major player in the world economy, leading the country in foreign trade growth and drawing investment from around the globe.

title: A Sinking Feeling in the Bronx
description: The Yankees sneaked out of town last night, knowing, as Yogi Berra once said, it gets late early in baseball when things are going bad.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LUDSIN, SAMUEL
description: LUDSIN-Samuel, passed away peacefully on May 26, 1997 in Boca Raton, FL, formerly from Clifton, NJ. Beloved husband of Sonja, cherished father of Debra (Mark) Gladstone and Steven A. and adored grandfather of Alexandra, Andrew and Marisa. He was a one in a million person loved by all who knew him. Services Thursday, May 29 at Gutterman-Warheit Chapel, 7240 North Federal Highway, Boca Raton. Donations in his memory to either Alpine Learning Group, 230B Woodland Avenue, River Edge, NJ 07661 or Remembrance of the Holocaust Foundation, C/O Ludsin, PO Box 5050, East Hampton, N.Y. 11937.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HADDAD, JOHN G., JR., MD.
description: HADDAD-John G., Jr., MD. The Paget Foundation for Paget's Disease of Bone and Related Disorders mourns the sudden loss of our dear Board member and Chairman of our Advisory Medical Panel, Dr. John G. Haddad, Jr. We will miss his great commitment and dedication to the Foundation and the patients he cared for. We will cherish the memories of his wonderful sense of humor, kindness, enthusiasm and love of life. Our deepest sympathy to his wife, Julie, their children, John George and daughter, Margaret, his staff and colleagues at The University of Pennsylvania. A memorial service will take place on Friday, May 30, 4-5pm in the Harrison Auditorium, University of Pennsylvania Museum, 33rd and Spruce St. The family has suggested that donations be made to the John G. Haddad Jr. Memorial Lecture Fund, C/O The Trustees of the University of Pennsylvania, Medical Center Development Office, Penn Tower, Suite 400, 399 South 34th Street, Philadelphia, PA. 19104-4385. For The Paget Foundation Charlene Waldman Executive Director Frederick R. Singer, MD Chairman, Board of Directors

title: City Is Given More Time For Goals On Recycling
description: A State Supreme Court justice has given New York City four more years to comply with its own recycling law but has made it clear that the Giuliani administration cannot continue to ignore recycling mandates indefinitely.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  STERN, MARK F.
description: STERN-Mark F. One year today. Forever in my mind and heart. I hope that ''all the beautiful things you wanted, somewhere along the way you had.'' Alan and the Kids

title: Leaders of Tomorrow
description: To the Editor:

title: In Bosnia, Intolerance Seems Destined to Win
description: To the Editor:

title: 'Heroin Chic' Ads Sell Young a Life Style
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WINN, DR. GILBERT
description: WINN-Dr. Gilbert. Temple Beth Sholom of Roslyn Heights, N.Y. mourns the passing of our beloved member Dr. Gilbert Winn and extends heartfelt condolences to his wife Eleanor and family. Alan B. Lucas, Rabbi Dr. Philip Adler, President

title: Doctor Cleared in Trial on Unapproved Drugs
description: A doctor who has battled the Federal Food and Drug Administration for 14 years for prescribing unapproved cancer drugs was acquitted today by a Federal jury of the last remaining charge against him: violating a judge's order banning shipments of the drugs across state lines.

title: At Victim's Funeral, Loss of Good Name Is Feared, Too
description: As eight pallbearers carried Michael McMorrow's coffin from his funeral at an Upper East Side church yesterday, a nagging concern was on the minds of some mourners: that his killers in Central Park managed to take not only his life, but also his good name.

title: Standing of Veto Plaintiffs Is Questioned
description: The Supreme Court heard arguments today on a new law that empowers the President to kill individual items in spending and tax bills that he has just signed. And the Justices repeatedly asked whether the case ought to be in court at this time.

title: The Limits of Presidential Immunity
description: With its 9-to-0 ruling yesterday allowing Paula Corbin Jones to proceed with her sexual-harassment lawsuit against President Clinton, the Supreme Court ended the suspense surrounding one of this term's most highly publicized cases with a historic ruling reinforcing a basic constitutional principle. No American, not even an incumbent President, is beyond the law's reach.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FEHER, MARGARET
description: FEHER-Margaret. On Memorial Day in NYC. Born May 16, 1911. Granddaughter of Mayor Schroeder of Brooklyn. Assisted husband, Milton in running Milton Feher School of Dance and Relaxation. Formerly associate director Morningside Heights Inc., a community planning organization. Also worked for NYS Div. of Housing and the Federal Farm Admin. and U.S. Navy School of Military Gov't. Survived by husband; brother Schroeder Boulton; sons David and Stephen Bartlett; two nieces and six grandchildren. Friends and family are invited to honor her at Susannah Harrington's apartment, 55 Pineapple Street, Brooklyn Heights, on Friday at 4 P.M.

title: Clinton Plays to History, With Renewed Panache
description: Bill Clinton was chatting animatedly with Prime Minister Tony Blair of Britain under the glittering crystal chandeliers of Elysee Palace today when his turn came to sign the new accord between Russia and NATO.

title: An Active Regulator Will Step Down
description: Reed E. Hundt, who has presided over the most turbulent era in the Federal Communications Commission's 63-year history, announced today that he intended to step down as chairman as soon as a replacement was named.

title: Landlords Take Their Case, And Pataki's, to the Radio
description: After complaining for weeks that Gov. George E. Pataki's plan did not move quickly enough to eliminate rent controls, the major New York City landlords group will begin a radio commercial campaign this week in support of the Governor's proposal.

title: AVON PRESIDENT TO STEP DOWN AFTER SUCCESSION DISPUTE
description: Avon Products Inc. said yesterday that its president and chief operating officer, Edward J. Robinson, would retire June 1 because of disagreements about management succession at the cosmetics company. Avon said Mr. Robinson had decided to step down after the company's board asked the chairman and chief executive, James E. Preston, 64, to remain with the company for at least two more years. Avon, based in New York, said there were no immediate plans to name a successor to Mr. Robinson, whose responsibilities will be assumed by Mr. Preston. Mr. Robinson, 57, joined Avon in 1989 as its chief financial officer. He has held his current position since 1993.

title: INSIDE
description: An Affluent Museum And Its Poor Cousin

title: To Graduate Sunday, CUNY Students Must Pass Test
description: Trying to demonstrate that the City University of New York was upholding high graduation standards, CUNY trustees voted last night to require that all students -- including those at the bilingual Hostos Community College who are scheduled to graduate on Sunday -- pass a university-wide writing examination before they can graduate.

title: 7 Highway Holiday Deaths
description: Seven people died in seven car accidents across New Jersey over the Memorial Day weekend, the same number that died last year, officials said yesterday. Fatigue or alcohol played a role in at least five, Sgt. Al Della Fave, a spokesman for the New Jersey State Police, said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BARON, FREDA
description: BARON-Freda. Devoted wife of the late Sidney. Beloved mother of Leonard and Phyllis, Martin and Judith. Loving grandmother of Randi, Stephen, Caryl, David, Amy and David. Proud great-grandmother of Stuart and Lindsay. She will be in our hearts forever. Services at ''Boulevard-Riverside'', 312 Coney Island Avenue (at Prospect Park), Brooklyn, today at 11 AM.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  NEUWIRTH, PAUL
description: NEUWIRTH-Paul. Died May 23, 1997. Memorial for friends and family at Hudson House, Irvington, N.Y., on Sunday, June 1 at 3 P.M.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SEXTON, VIRGINIA STAUDT, PH.D.
description: SEXTON-Virginia Staudt, Ph.D., on May 24, 1997, in Cincinnati, OH. Of Forest Hills, N.Y. Retired Professor of psychology CUNY and St. John's University. Beloved wife of the late Richard J. Sexton, Ph.D. Devoted mother of Richard E. Sexton, Mary Sexton Althouse, Georgina S. and Nancy E. Sexton. Loving grandmother of Katherine Althouse, Laura and Patricia Sexton. Sister of Florence C. Staudt. Reposing Fox Funeral Home, Forest Hills, Thursday and Friday, 2-5, and 7-9 PM. Funeral Mass at Our Lady Queen of Martyrs Church, on Saturday, May 31, at 9:30 AM. Interment St. Raymond's Cemetery, Bronx, NY. Donations to Cathedral High School, 350 East 56th Street, New York City, 10022-4199 appreciated.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCGANN, SR. ELLEN RITA
description: McGANN-Sr. Ellen Rita. Beloved member of the Sisters of Charity, Convent of Mary the Queen, dedicated educator of many students, on May 27, 1997. She is survived by her niece Anne and her nephews Neil and Denis. Reposing at the Convent of Mary the Queen, 35 Vark St., Yonkers, NY Thursday 18 PM. Mass of Christian Burial Fri. 9:30 AM at the convent. Interment St. Raymond's Cemetery, Bx., NY.

title: Weak Yen Aids Unexpected Profit for Nissan
description: The Nissan Motor Company reported group net income for its latest 12-month period today -- the first time in five years that it has been profitable.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  TOMLINSON, FORREST
description: TOMLINSON-Forrest. A Memorial Service for Forrest Tomlinson will be held on Thursday, May 29, 1997, at 4:30PM at St. Bartholomew's Church, 50th St. and Park Ave., New York, N.Y. Reception following service. Donations in his memory to Hospice of Martha's Vineyard, Oak Bluffs, MA 02557.

title: Tornadoes Ravage Central Texas, Leaving at Least 32 Dead
description: A powerful spring storm ripped through Central Texas today, spinning off tornadoes that devastated several rural towns and left at least 32 people confirmed dead and many others injured.

title: Top Court Upholds New York's Right Not to Pay for Out-of-State Care for Disabled
description: The United States Supreme Court yesterday refused to hear a case challenging New York State's plan to cease paying for the care of severely retarded and handicapped New Yorkers living in institutions outside the state.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Coca-Cola Enterprises To Buy 2 Big Bottlers

title: Big Coke Bottler Expanding In New York and Canada
description: The world's largest soft-drink bottling company, Coca-Cola Enterprises Inc., grew even larger yesterday, agreeing to acquire from the Coca-Cola Company its Canadian and metropolitan New York bottling companies for $1.01 billion in cash plus $650 million in assumed debt.

title: City to Change Policy On Strip-Searching
description: The Giuliani Administration has decided to change its policy of strip-searching everyone arrested for misdemeanor charges, New York City officials said yesterday.

title: A Loss of Ideas
description: To the Editor:

title: No Headline
description: ''Our central concern was to avoid rendering the President 'unduly cautious in the discharge of his official duties.' This reasoning provides no support for an immunity for unofficial conduct.''

title: Hal Riney Wins Magazine Awards
description: Hal Riney & Partners in San Francisco took top honors with three awards, including the $100,000 prize for general excellence, at the 16th annual M.P.A. Kelly Awards competition sponsored by the Magazine Publishers of America.

title: From Public, a Collective Ho-Hum
description: Seeking to defend the new accord with NATO he signed today in Paris, President Boris N. Yeltsin is telling voters that he still opposes the expansion of the Western alliance and is trying to minimize the threat to Russia.

title: Trials of A Busy Man
description: THE WHITE HOUSE

title: Interpublic invests in an Internet provider aimed at 'the transition generation' of young adults.
description: THE Interpublic Group of Companies is expanding its presence in the realm of on-line advertising by investing in Tripod Inc., an innovative interactive marketing and media company that focuses primarily on consumers in their 20's.

title: SUPREME COURT, 9-0, REJECTS CLINTON REQUEST TO PUT OFF SUIT ON SEXUAL HARASSMENT: A Deeper Sense of Siege
description: ''What hurts is the cloud,'' a former aide to President Clinton said this afternoon, ''because you can't see anything through it. While it's there, whatever he does will remain invisible.''

title: Putting Out the Fire When It's Not There
description: THE front gate to Hunter S. Thompson's log-cabin-style ranch is flanked by two hunks of metal folded like origami into shapes resembling vultures. These twin sentries convey both a promise and a threat: you are entering the realm of the seriously weird, and you may not get out alive.

title: Miller Settles Suit With Spin Doctors
description: The band the Spin Doctors has received a settlement in connection with a suit filed against the Miller Brewing Company and a former Miller agency, the Leap Partnership in Chicago, which accused Miller and Leap of plagiarizing the band's hit single ''Two Princes'' in a commercial for Lite Ice beer that ran nationally throughout 1995. Terms were not disclosed.

title: S.E.C. Accuses a Fund of Illegal Fee Use
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission yesterday accused the portfolio manager of the Parnassus Fund, one of the largest mutual funds that practice ''socially responsible'' investing, of the illegal use of brokerage commissions generated by the fund and of overvaluing a security in the fund's portfolio.

title: Florida to Sell Tobacco Stocks From Its Retirement Fund
description: Florida officials decided today to divest the state's retirement fund of all tobacco stocks, maintaining that the proliferation of lawsuits against cigarette companies and the growing prospect of tight government regulation made them too risky as investments.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BERNE, SELMA
description: BERNE-Selma. Passed away peacefully after a prolonged illness on May 27, 1997. Loving mother of Karen Rook and Elliot Stetzer. Beloved grandmother of eleven grandchildren and great grandmother of four with two on the way. We were all blessed to have her in our lives. Services scheduled for 11 A.M., Thursday, May 29, at Riverside Nassau North Funeral Chapel in Great Neck. All who were lucky enough to know her are welcome.

title: Wanted In Houston: Barkley, To Shoot
description: In order of appearance, it has been Hakeem Olajuwon, Hakeem Olajuwon, Eddie Johnson, Hakeem Olajuwon and Hakeem Olajuwon. The Houston Rockets purchased a loud, obnoxious power forward for days -- or Western Conference finals -- just like these, and the problem is he's passing off.

title: Fund to Revive Broadway Fare Is Taking Hold
description: In an effort to bring back the serious dramas and small musicals that have almost vanished from Broadway, an unusual coalition of theater owners, producers, and union officials is about to propose a fund of $10 million a year that it says can foster the further revitalization of the theater district.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TEPPER, REGINA
description: TEPPER-Regina, of Yonkers on May 28, 1997. In 1995 her life story was chronicled in the off-Broadway play, ''Coming Through'' which described her experiences at Ellis Island and her ensuing life. Devoted wife of the late Harry Tepper. Loving father of Bobbi and her husband Bruce Fabricant of Ardsley; Roy and his wife Annie Tepper of Greenwich, CT. Dear grandmother of Robin, Vicki, Meri and Karen. Service 10 AM today at Edwards-Dowdle Funeral Home, 64 Ashford Avenue (Exit 17 Saw Mill Parkway) Dobbs Ferry, NY. Contributions to the American Cancer Society, 2 Lyon Pl., White Plains, NY 10601, appreciated.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MARACHE, HERBERT W., JR.
description: MARACHE-Herbert W., Jr. Beloved husband and father, died May 28, 1997 in Greenwich, CT. Born in Brooklyn, NY and educated at St. Paul's School and Yale College. He is survived by five children: Nina M. King, Victoria B. Marache, Eugenie M. Pavelic, Herbert W. Marache, III and Mark A. Marache, a sister, Suzanne Geyer and six grandchildren. Memorial service, 3PM Monday June 2 at Christ Church, Greenwich, CT. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to Eagle Hill School, 45 Glenville Road, Greenwich, CT.

title: Thoughts on Annulments
description: To The Home Section:

title: Technology Helps Find Wanderers
description: NIGHT was falling over the mountains around King, N.C., when Greg Pratt, chief of the Stokes County Mountain Rescue Team, learned that an elderly man suffering from dementia had wandered away from his home. The March temperature was headed toward freezing. ''It used to be, it would take us hours to find a wanderer in these woods, bloodhounds and all,'' Mr. Pratt said. ''This time it took 12 minutes.''

title: Senate Panel Plans to Hold July Hearings on Campaign Abuses
description: The Senate committee investigating campaign finance abuses is planning to start hearings on July 8, officials familiar with the inquiry said today.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KIRBY, JOYCE A.
description: KIRBY-Joyce A., 80, died at home, May 27, 1997. Ms. Kirby was born in New Rochelle, N.Y. She received a Master's Degree in Social Work from Columbia University. She had a long, and distinguished career as a Social Worker in New York City, the Virgin Islands and Florida. She was a beloved supervisor and mentor to several generations of clinicians. She is survived by a niece Susan Pinco of New Jersey. Moss-Feaster Funeral Homes Clearwater, Florida.

title: Assembly Plan Is Outlined For Stiff Juvenile Penalties
description: Opening the door to long-awaited negotiations on revamping the state's juvenile justice system, the Assembly Speaker, Sheldon Silver, presented a proposal today that would increase sentences for violent youthful criminals and require all teen-agers convicted of crimes to experience some form of punishment.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHEPARD, RICHARD
description: SHEPARD-Richard. Beloved husband of Susan. Devoted father of Alexandra, Stephanie, Lee and Jody. Loving grandfather. Cherished brother. Caring friend and compassionate uncle. Graveside services Sunday, June 1, 1997, 2PM, Mt. Pleasant Cemetery, Valhalla, NY.

title: Environmental Fiction
description: To the Editor:

title: Restoring the Fertile Crescent to Its Former Glory
description: From the ruins of the ancient citadel that towers above this remote and dusty town, the plains of Mesopotamia stretch in every direction. Many great visionaries have reigned here, but perhaps none has had grander dreams than a 40-year-old engineer who stood atop the windswept bluff on a recent afternoon and surveyed his domain.

title: A Cyclist's Wish
description: To The Home Section:

title: J. G. Haddad, 59; Physician Created Test for Vitamin D
description: Dr. John G. Haddad Jr., an endocrinologist who created the standard test for vitamin D levels in the blood, died in Paris on May 22 while on his way to a medical meeting. He was 59 and lived in Philadelphia.

title: A New Job Requirement for Molinari: Nonpartisanship
description: Sliding into a high-back chair on a CBS News set on West 57th Street, Susan Molinari began her move from Congress to the broadcast booth yesterday, rejecting the notion that her career change might be a disservice to her constituents or to journalism.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  BOYARSKY, HENRY
description: BOYARSKY-Henry. 5/30/19-12/24/ 96. Happy birthday, Dad. I miss you and think of you every day. Your daughter, Bonnie

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FISCHBEIN, FRANCES
description: FISCHBEIN - Frances. Beloved wife of the late Saul Fischbein. Loving mother of Leslie and Peter. Cherished grandmother of Glynn, Pamela and Scott. Her love and beauty will be with us forever. Services Thursday, May 29th, at 2 PM, at Schwartz Brothers, 114-03 Queens Blvd., Forest Hills, NY.

title: President Urges Aid for East In Spirit of the Marshall Plan
description: Celebrating the 50th anniversary of the Marshall Plan to rebuild Western Europe after World War II, President Clinton said today that the West ''must complete the noble journey'' and bring the former Communist nations of East Europe into a prosperous, united Europe.

title: Table Is Set for a Stanley Cup Feast
description: It has been 22 years since the Philadelphia Flyers won the Stanley Cup. Flyers forward John LeClair said yesterday that it would be nice to win the cup this year because his city is ''starving for a championship.''

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: TRANSWORLD HEALTHCARE INC., Clark, N.J., a provider of home health-care services, agreed to buy Omnicare P.L.C., Southampton, England, a supplier of respiratory equipment to home-care patients, for about $32.8 million in stock.

title: CBS's Remake Now Includes Molinari
description: Whatever the career implications for Susan Molinari, the soon-to-be-former Congresswoman's success or failure in the plump-pillowed world of chat-show television will be a career marker for Andrew Heyward.

title: F.T.C. Charges Joe Camel Ad Illegally Takes Aim at Minors
description: In another blow to an industry under siege, the Federal Trade Commission charged today that the R. J. Reynolds Tobacco Company illegally aimed its Joe Camel advertising campaign at minors.

title: BLACKSTONE TO BUY COMMNET IN $718 MILLION DEAL
description: Commnet Cellular Inc. plans to take the company private by selling a majority stake to a Blackstone Group L.P. fund for $36 a share in cash. It said the deal totaled $718 million including the assumption of $200 million in debt. The acquisition gives Blackstone, an investment firm, 87 percent of the wireless phone company, which serves rural regions in 14 states from the northern Plains to Rocky Mountains. Commnet's shares rose $4.8125, to $34.375, in Nasdaq trading.

title: Caffeine 'High' Rises Again at Starbucks
description: The Starbucks Corporation said yesterday that it would raise coffee prices at its shops around the nation for the second time this year, reflecting coffee's rising price worldwide.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GREGG, DR. DOROTHY
description: GREGG-Dr. Dorothy. The Board of Trustees and staff of WNYC Radio deeply mourn the loss of the longtime director of the WNYC Foundation and former secretary of the Board. We are grateful for her years of dedicated service and extend our deepest sympathies to Dr. Paul Scott and the entire family. Peter H. Darrow, Chairman Laura Walker, President and CEO WNYC Radio

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  O'BRIEN, JOSEPH D.
description: O'BRIEN-Joseph D., age 81, at Stamford, CT., on May 28, 1997. Former Executive Assistant to the President of Uniroyal, Inc. Funeral and Burial, Pinehurst, N.C.

title: Congo Soldiers Break Up Sparse Protest Against New President
description: Soldiers broke up a peaceful demonstration today against Laurent Kabila, the rebel leader who took over this gigantic country just over a week ago, arresting and beating dozens of protesters and scattering others by firing guns in the air.

title: Canada's Vote Focus: 'Jobs, Jobs, Jobs'
description: With his bookstore sandwiched between the election headquarters of two political parties, Eric Aubanel cannot get to work without being bombarded by campaign promises to lower Canada's chronically high unemployment rate.

title: Germany Set To Revalue Gold Reserve
description: Despite objections from its influential central bank, the German Government said tonight that it would use a bookkeeping maneuver and amend its laws to insure that it would lead the introduction of the single European currency in 1999.

title: Last-Minute Requirement Stuns Students at Hostos
description: With classes ended and finals over, the graduating students at Hostos Community College thought they had a few days off this week before their commencement on Sunday. But on Tuesday evening, the City University's trustees took the unusual step of ordering Hostos to make sure all members of the Class of '97 had passed the university's writing test.

title: AES AND SOUTHERN ACQUIRE BRAZIL UTILITY STAKE
description: The Southern Company and the AES Corporation joined yesterday with a Brazilian partner to buy a $1 billion stake in the Brazilian utility Cia. Energetica de Minas Gerais as part of a plan to expand into the Latin American electricity market. Southern, based in Atlanta, and AES, based in Arlington, Va., bought the 33 percent stake in the regional utility, which is known as Cemig, for 1.13 billion reals ($1.05 billion). Their Brazilian partner is Opportunity Capital Partners Ltda., a Rio de Janeiro fund manager. Cemig serves 4.3 million customers and accounts for 13 percent of Brazil's total electricity sales.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ADLER, KURT, PHD, M.D.
description: ADLER-Kurt, PhD, M.D., on May 28, 1997 in New York City. The faculty and staff of The Alfred Adler Institute and The Alfred Adler Mental Health Center and Community Consultation Center as well as the students of the Institute, mourn the loss of our esteemed teacher and friend, loyal son of Alfred Adler, the internationally renowned founder of Individual Psychology. For 49 years in New York City, Dr. Kurt Adler was teacher and developer of his father's ideas and a servant of The Alfred Adler Institute of New York including time spent as Director of that Institute. Since the inception of the Alfred Adler Institute in 1948 by Dr. Kurt Adler, hundreds of psychoanalysts and psychotherapists have been trained. Dr. Adler will be remembered with gratitude and affection by his colleagues, students, patients and friends. Robert Ellenbogen, Ph.D., Director, Alfred Adler Institute of New York Barbara Berger, M.S. Director, Alfred Adler Mental Health Center

title: Blair's Muted Helpmate: Look at Her Now!
description: The face was the same one that recently figured in hundreds of photo opportunities and front-page pictures around the world. But where there had been a designer suit there was a black robe, on top of the softly layered hairstyle there was a tightly curled white wig, and in place of the perpetual broad smile there was a judicious scowl.

title: Feiffer Draws Line at Not Getting Paid by The Voice
description: Jules Feiffer, the Pulitzer Prize-winning cartoonist and New York institution whose 40 years of work in The Village Voice helped define the alternative weekly, yesterday quit the paper over a salary dispute with the new editor, Donald H. Forst.

title: Red-Hot Jones (9-2) Keeps the Mets Sizzling, Too
description: O.K., the joke's gone on long enough who are the impostors wearing Mets uniforms?

title: For Central Park's Late Shift, Darkness Is Lure, Not Threat
description: As midnight settled on Central Park, darkness hugged the footpaths and an ominous stillness enveloped the Lake. Undaunted, Salvador Campos, an 18-year-old blur on wheels, leaped from the band shell stage, a buoyant form in a baseball cap.

title: 6 Indicted in Fraud Over Use of Grants For Hasidic Groups
description: Five members of a Hasidic community in Rockland County and a man from Brooklyn were indicted yesterday on charges that they systematically defrauded the Federal and state governments of tens of millions of dollars in student loans, business assistance and housing subsidies.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WALTIER, RICHARD H., M.D.
description: WALTIER-Richard H., M.D., F.A.C.S., L.M.C.C., 86 yrs, May 21, 1997. Richard H. Waltier, M.D. graduated from Temple University School of Medicine, Philadelphia, Pennsylvania (1937). He was a Fellow of the American College of Surgeons (1952 to 1997), Diplomate of the American Board of Abdominal Surgery (1960), Licentiate of the Medical Council of Canada (L.M.C.C. - 1958). He practiced in Philadelphia from 1939 to 1945, New York 1945 to 1985, Surgical Assistant and special surgical work at Temple University Hospital, Phila. (1939 to 1945), Surgical Assistant at Anderson Hospital, Phila. (1941 to 1945), Clinical Assistant Surgeon at N.Y. Hospital (Welfare Island, Queens General Hospital (1945 to 1947), Assisting Visiting Surgeon to Queens General Hospital (1947 to 1960), Associate Visiting Surgeon to Queens General Hospital (1960 to 1967), Assistant Visiting Surgeon at French Hospital (1955 to 1977), Sr. Associate Attending Surgeon at St. Clare's Hospital (1978 to 1985), Workmen's Compensation (SAC). Dr. Waltier was the first AfroAmerican Pennsylvania Railroad Assistant Medical Examiner (1954). He was a Member of the New York County, New York State Medical Societies, Chairman, Physical Education Committee (1965) of the McBurney Y.M.C.A. He is survived by his wife, Bernadine and three sons: Richard H., William F. and Bernard A. Waltier.

title: Bridge
description: There are inferences to be drawn when the bidding takes an unexpected turn. Without looking at the hand, study the auction shown in the diagram as far as six diamonds.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEBENSON, BEATRICE
description: LEBENSON-Beatrice. Died Tuesday, May 20, 1997 in Delray Beach, Fla. after a long, courageous battle against cancer. Survived by daughter Amy Pearson, son-in-law Nick Pearson and grandson Robb. Services were private.

title: Duke Power and Panenergy Link Approved
description: The Federal Energy Regulatory Commission gave its approval today to the Duke Power Company's $7.7 billion acquisition of the Panenergy Corporation. The merger creates the Duke Energy Corporation, an energy giant with a major presence in the Eastern United States and revenue of $10 billion.

title: Baffert Predicts a Triple Crown After Silver Charm's Workout
description: Silver Charm moved one step closer to his date with destiny in the Belmont Stakes, turning in a strong workout yesterday at Churchill Downs that left his trainer, Bob Baffert, predicting victory and a Triple Crown sweep.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KAPLAN, RUTH
description: KAPLAN-Ruth. Beloved wife of the late Dr. Jacob. Devoted mother of Dr. Daniel and Sylvia Kaplan, Florence and Dr. Mark Lazar and Sydell and Sol Kopf. Dear sister of Dr. Charles Brauer, Florence Weiner and Sylvia Chessler. Loving grandmother of Laura Kaplan, Charles and Jody Kaplan, Dr. Russell & Randy Rothenberg, Lisa and Bob Krizman, Barbara Selwyn and Drs. Steven and Jan Lazar. Cherished great grandmother of Zachary & Ben Jacob Kaplan, Zachary, Amanda and Jesse Selwyn, Molly and Meredith Lazar, Mitchell Rothenberg and Jeffrey Krizman. Services at Baron Hirsch Cemetery, Staten Island, NY, Friday, 1 PM. For further info ''Wien & Wien'', Englewood, NJ. 800-322-0533.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BREITBART, ETTA L.
description: BREITBART-Etta L., on May 27, 1997. Devoted wife of the late Judge Abraham Breitbart, loving mother of Joan Gelman and William Breitbart. Beloved sister of Roslyn Gutman, and sister-in-law of Aaron Breitbart. Adoring mother-in-law of Kenneth Gelman and Myrna Margulies Breitbart. Cherished grandmother of David and Alex Gelman, and Jonathan and Molly Breitbart. Also survived by loving nieces, nephews, cousins and friends. Services will be held at 1:00PM, Friday, May 30, at the George T. Davis Funeral Home Chapel, 14 LeCount Place, New Rochelle, NY. Interment, Glenville Cemetery, Glenville, Connecticut.

title: Help Congo Now
description: The United States, France, Belgium, the International Monetary Fund and the World Bank helped create the disaster of Mobutu Sese Seko's Zaire. Today the West has a moral duty to help rebuild Congo, as the country is now called, even if the new leader isn't making the task easy.

title: Martin Agency Gets Finlandia Account
description: Brown-Forman Beverages Worldwide in Louisville, Ky., has named the Martin Agency in Richmond to handle the domestic creative portion of its Finlandia vodka account, with billings estimated at $8.5 million.

title: Restraining Order Is Sought Against ESPN's 'X Games'
description: The National Audubon Society charged in a lawsuit filed Tuesday that staging ESPN's ''X Games'' event next month on a man-made San Diego peninsula may damage a colony of endangered birds during their breeding and nesting cycle.

title: When Money Counts
description: ''ALMOST no other single home decorating product can transform a room or make it as personal as wallpaper,'' said Marita Thomas, editor of The Wall Paper, a monthly trade magazine.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  ETTINGER, SIDNEY
description: ETTINGER-Sidney. 2/11/16-5/30/ 86. Eleven years ago today my hell started. You're still my movie star, still love you madly. Rest in Peace, Your Bride

title: Four Stations to Cox Radio
description: Cox Radio Inc. said today that it would buy four radio stations serving the Birmingham, Ala., market: WENN-FM and WAGG-AM from Booker T. Washington Broadcasting Service Inc. and WBHJ-AM and WBHK-FM from H & P Radio L.L.C. Terms were not disclosed. Cox Radio, based in Atlanta, currently owns, operates or provides sales and marketing services for 43 stations in 12 markets.

title: Paraffin Balls Mar a Beach
description: Last May, beaches along the New Jersey coast were marred by balls of tar from an oil spill in the Delaware Bay. Now, officials say, small balls of paraffin have been washing up on a six-mile stretch of beach in Ocean County.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STRONG, S. JAMES
description: STRONG-S. James, on May 29, 1997. Beloved husband of Penelope. Loving father of James S. Dear brother of Stelios Strongelis. Reposing Krtil FH 1297 1st Ave, NYC Sat 7-9 PM, Sun 2-4, 7-9 PM. Funeral Services Holy Trinity Greek Cathedral 319 E 74 St. Mon 10 AM. Interment Cypress Hills Cemetery. In lieu of flowers, please donate to St. Basil's Academy R2 Box 8A, Garrison, NY 10524-9742.

title: RUMORED PURCHASES BY BUFFETT LIFT NIKE SHARES
description: The shares of Nike Inc. rose 6 percent yesterday on speculation that Warren E. Buffett, the head of Berkshire Hathaway Inc., might be purchasing shares in the maker of athletic clothes and shoes. Nike shares rose $3.875, to $64, in trading of almost 6.4 million shares. Officials of Nike, based in Beaverton, Ore., and Berkshire Hathaway, whose headquarters are in Omaha, declined to comment. Mr. Buffett typically invests in companies like the Coca-Cola Company and the Gillette Company that are dominant in their industries, have highly recognizable brand names and show consistent revenue and earnings growth. ''It's the kind of investment that he would make,'' Jennifer Black Groves, an analyst with Black & Company, said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LAIKEN, EVELYN
description: LAIKEN-Evelyn, of Hallandale, FL. formerly of Brooklyn, NY passed away May 29, 1997. Beloved wife of the late Henry. Loving mother of Amy (Tim Michel) Laiken. Dear sister of Henrietta Katz and Peter Prentky and aunt of many nieces and newphews. Graveside services Sunday, 2PM at Beth Moses Cemetery. For more information Sinai Memorial Chapel, 800-446-0406.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BROWN, AIDA (CHICKIE)
description: BROWN-Aida (Chickie). I note with great sorrow the loss of this thoughtful, supportive, gracious, joyful, special lady who I had the good fortune to know as both a patient and friend. Dr. Leonard Fox

Father of Karen Berger and Victoria Berger-Gross. Also survived by five grandchildren. Service on Friday 12:30 P.M., Assumma - Shankey Funeral Home, Pearl River, New York.

title: Strawberry Will Go On Road With Team
description: Darryl Strawberry and Dwight Gooden have been linked since their rise and fall with the Mets and then their re-emergence with the Yankees last year.

title: Dylan in Hospital With Chest Pains; Europe Tour Is Off
description: Bob Dylan, whose bittersweet love songs and politically tinged folk anthems made him an emblem of the 1960's counterculture, canceled a European concert tour yesterday, having checked into a hospital over the weekend suffering from chest pains.

title: Some at SUNY Fear Political Bent as 3d Pataki Ally Gets Post
description: The State University of New York has hired a number of former officials and intimates of the Pataki administration as top managers, stirring debate within the university community over whether the 64-campus system is being politicized as never before.

title: When Tabloids Cross the Line
description: Dogged reporters. Perspiring publicists. Anonymous tipsters. Long-lens cameras. High-speed chases. Secret sources. Flowing cash. Tedious stakeouts. Sleepless nights.

title: Daimler-Benz Plans To Expand Sales in Asia
description: Daimler-Benz A.G., Germany's largest industrial company, said yesterday that it planned to more than triple its sales in Asia as a percentage of total sales. ''About 8 percent of our sales come from Asia at the moment, and we have to increase that to 25 percent,'' the chief executive, Jurgen E. Schrempp, said. Daimler's Asian sales are mainly Mercedes-Benz cars and satellites and planes produced by Dasa, its aerospace unit.

title: A Hungry North Korea Swallows a Bit of Pride
description: With a serious famine spreading in North Korea, one of the central obstacles to getting attention and assistance has been North Korean pride, which is as enormous as the country's need.

title: Plan to Freeze Property Taxes
description: Assembly Speaker Jack Collins said yesterday that he planned to introduce legislation to freeze property tax rates for an estimated 212,000 low-income elderly and disabled homeowners.

title: Mohd al-Jamali, 94, of Iraq; A Founder of the Arab League
description: Mohd Fadhel al-Jamali, an Arab statesman who helped establish the United Nations and the Arab League and was nearly hanged for his Western leanings after the revolution in Iraq in 1958, died in exile in Tunisia last Saturday. He was 94.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHNEIDER, DORA (WOLKOFF)
description: SCHNEIDER-Dora (Wolkoff) On May 28,1997. Beloved wife of the late Samuel. Cherished mother of Shelly Berend, Martin Schneider and Ilyne Kuper. Devoted motherin-law of Richard Kuper and Robert Berend. Dear sister of David and the late Sidney Wolkoff.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BARAD, LESTER E.
description: BARAD-Lester E., on May 27, 1997. Beloved husband of Florence. Dear father of Julie, Janet and Amy. Loving grandfather of Danica. Brother of Morton Barad and the late Harold Barad. Memorial on June 16, 3:00 P.M., at Parkside, 98-60 Queens Blvd. In lieu of gift, donations to Melanoma Research at Memorial SloanKettering Cancer Center or to Amer. Parkinson Disease Assoc.

title: The G.O.P. News From CBS
description: The network news departments have been chiseling away at the wall between journalism and politics for quite a while. Now with the hiring of Representative Susan Molinari to move directly from Congress to the anchor desk, CBS has reduced the wall to dust. In fact, having already hired Laura Ingraham, CBS News now employs more famous Republican women than the Republican National Committee does. By way of Congressional balance, CBS also hired Bill Bradley, the retired Senator, as a commentator.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: Baseball

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  MEDESKE, MARY ANN
description: MEDESKE-Mary Ann. May 30, 1904-April 7, 1996. Happy birthday, Mother. No one could ever take your place. You were the best. Love, Catherine and Dolly

title: Pentagon Spurs 1.4% Rise In Orders for Durable Goods
description: Orders for big-ticket manufactured goods rose 1.4 percent in April, in part because of unexpectedly large orders by the Pentagon, Commerce Department figures showed today.

title: HOME DEPOT SPLITS STOCK AND INCREASES DIVIDEND
description: Home Depot Inc. said yesterday that it would split its stock 3 for 2 and increase its quarterly dividend by 25 percent, to 5 cents on a post-split basis. The dividend will be paid June 26 to shareholders of record on June 12, and the split will occur July 3 to shareholders of record June 12. Home Depot said it would pay cash for fractional shares. At the end of its first quarter, which ended May 4, Home Depot had 503.2 million shares outstanding. The company's shares rose $1, to $61.75, on the New York Stock Exchange. Separately, the Atlanta home-improvement retailer named its president and chief operating officer, Arthur M. Blank, 54, to the additional post of chief executive, succeeding Bernard Marcus, 68, who remains chairman.

title: A Possible Deterrent
description: To the Editor:

description: SONN-Edward. Died May 24, 1997 in CA, born Oct 2, 1905 in NJ. He served on the NYPD Detective Squad under Dist. Atty Thomas E. Dewey. Survived by his son; Eric, daughter; Ellen Grantham, sisters; Betty Sonn and Ida Perkel of NY, two grandchildren and two great grandchildren.

title: Swiss Self-Redemption
description: o the Editor:

title: Put Up, Shut Up, Hang Up
description: As the Arab-Israeli peace process continues sliding downhill, American officials say they may soon have to opt for one of two extremes: either ''The Plan'' or ''The Phone Number.'' Either the President lays down, publicly, exactly what steps the U.S. believes Israelis and Palestinians must take to get the process back on track, or he gives them both the White House phone number, 202-456-1414, and tells them to call when they're serious. As one top White House official put it: ''Either we step forward or we step backward, but where we are now is not working.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KARRIS, MARTIN
description: KARRIS-Martin. The Ocean Bay Park Association sadly notes the passing of its member. We willmiss our dear friend Marty, who had a marvelous sense of humor, and who was a kind, sensitive, gentle man, who nurtured his garden and our community.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SIMON, ETHEL
description: SIMON-Ethel. Beloved wife of Myron. Loving mother of Andrea, Peter and Vicky. Dear sister of Selma Stein. Cherished grandmother of Danielle and Joel. Service Friday, 11 A.M., at Temple Kol-Ami, 252 Soundview Avenue, White Plains, New York.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KOBLEY, ROSA M.
description: KOBLEY-Rosa M. Of Miami Beach, passed away May 27, 1997. Daughter of the late Robert and Mildred Kobley. Services Thursday (today) at 11am at Graceland Memorial Park, Miami. Riverside Gordon, N. Miami Beach, Fla.

title: Radio spectrum sales seem a success. Why the attack?
description: WASHINGTON'S three-year-old experiment in auctioning access to the radio spectrum is widely seen as a raging success, accelerating the telecommunications revolution and raising more than $20 billion for Uncle Sam. Why, then, is renewal of the Federal Communications Commission's broad authority to sell spectrum rights as quickly as possible under attack?

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ZEITZ, ANN N.
description: ZEITZ-Ann N., on Tuesday, May 27, 1997, of Bethesda, Maryland. Beloved wife of the late Abraham Zeitz. Devoted mother of Carl (Elaine) Zeitz and Deede (Larry) Snowhite. Loving sister of Harry (Fay) Black. Adoring grandmother of Josh, Andrew, Robert and Nate. Services at the Northern Virginia Hebrew Congregation, 1441 Wiehle Avenue, Reston, Virginia, on Thursday, May 29, at 10:30AM. Interment, King David Memorial Gardens. The family will be in mourning at the residence of Mr. and Mrs. Snowhite. Expressions of sympathy in her memory may be made to the Reston Interfaith Safe Places Residential Program, 11484 Washington Plaza West, Suite 400, Reston, Virginia 20190. Services by Danzansky-Goldberg.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STREIBERT, ELIZABETH T.
description: STREIBERT-Elizabeth T.. On behalf of the Trustees and Staff of The Museum of Modern Art, sadly note the death of our beloved friend and colleague, Elizabeth Streibert. For more than twenty years, she brought intelligence, energy, wit and devotion to the Museum. Her work for the International Program of the Museum, earned the respect and gratitude of the museum professionals throughout the world. We offer our most sincere condolences to her husband Marshall, her brother Thomas and her three nephews. A memorial tribute will be held at the Museum on July 9 at 10:30AM. Ronald S. Lauder, Chairman, Agnes Gund, President, Glenn D. Lowry, Director, The Museum of Modern Art, NY

title: Town Is Upended by Tornadoes Twice in Eight Years
description: Emil Danek leaned against a soda fountain at the local truck stop here today, under a sign that said ''Tornado Destroys Doc's One-Stop May 17, 1989. Reopened Oct. 23, 1989.''

title: New Records Show the Swiss Sold Arms Worth Millions to Nazis
description: Still reeling from charges that it helped prolong World War II through financial dealings with the Third Reich, Switzerland faced newly documented accusations today that its wartime arms industry profited from -- and favored -- Hitler's Germany in a weapons trade worth millions of dollars.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CONNOLLY, WILLIAM JOSEPH
description: CONNOLLY-William Joseph, of Great Neck, on May 27, 1997, beloved husband of Ann Fiore, devoted father of William Patrick. Donations to the Bishop's Annual Appeal, Diocese of Rockville Centre, would be appreciated.

title: The Memorial Day holiday seems to set the pace, with the big airlines expecting a strong summer.
description: AIR travel over Memorial Day appears to have broken the record for that holiday period, as the Air Transport Association had forecast, and travel the rest of the summer seems headed for a record.

description: To the Editor:

title: Precedent Set In Court Ruling Worries Clinton
description: In his first comment on the Supreme Court's decision to let a sexual harassment lawsuit against him proceed, President Clinton said today that he was concerned about the precedent it set.

title: People
description: * C. Norman Shaffer, senior vice president and media planning director at Jordan, McGrath, Case & Taylor, New York, was promoted to executive vice president and media services director, and Jannine Regis, vice president and marketing director, was promoted to senior vice president and business development director. They assume duties from Steven Farella, executive vice president, media services director and director for business development, who left Jordan, McGrath to join D'Arcy Masius Benton & Bowles Communications, New York, a unit of MacManus Group, as senior vice president and regional director for North America media operations.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SVENNINGSEN, JOHN A. JOHN A.
description: SVENNINGSEN-John A. John A. Svenningsen, President and Chairman of the Board of Amscan Holdings, Inc. with headquarters in Elmsford, N.Y. died on May 28, 1997. Taking a small business from the family garage in 1960, he built a world-wide enterprise of manufacuturing and distributing party goods. In 1996, he received a lifetime achievement award from the Enterpreneur of the Year Institute. He is survived by this wife, Christine and his children, Christina, Jon, Elisabeth, Melissa, Emily and Sara and his sister, Fanny Warren.

title: In SBC Talks, AT&T Head May Have Bet the House
description: AT&T's chairman, Robert E. Allen, has not hesitated to roll the dice in his nine years at the helm of the nation's largest telephone company.

title: Restive Indonesians Find Little Hope in Vote
description: Something happened on the way to the thoroughly engineered Government landslide that is widely expected on Thursday in a parliamentary election here in the world's fourth most populous country.
