title: Hypocritic Oath
description: Riddle: How do you find a doctor who says there's no need to worry about smoking? Answer: Consult the American Medical Association.

title: Ralph Horween, 100, the Oldest Ex-N.F.L. Player
description: Ralph Horween, the oldest former National Football League player and a fullback for the unbeaten Harvard team that won the 1920 Rose Bowl, died Monday at his home in Charlottesville, Va. He was 100.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RAYBURN, DR. JOHN W.
description: RAYBURN-Dr. John W., died on May 28, 1997, in Plainview, MN, from the toll taken by Alzheimer's Disease, degenerative palsy, and multiple strokes. A founding member of Mercy College in Dobbs Ferry, NY, Dr. Rayburn was Professor of Music and Fine Arts and choral conductor there from 1961-1994. He began his career in church music as organist and choir director at St. Joseph's Cathedral in La Crosse, WI, and continued in this type of service in communities wherever he taught. His most recent posts were at Edgehill Church in Riverdale and at the Dobbs Ferry Lutheran Church. Dr. Rayburn is survived by three sisters: Glorieux (James) Dougherty of New York and Marie (Fred) Stafford and Kathryn Rayburn of Rochester, MN; two nephews and three nieces. He will be buried at St. Mary's Parish in Durand, WI.

title: The Jews of Tombstone
description: To the Editor:

title: Schwab Joins S.& P. 500
description: The stock of the Charles Schwab Corporation, the discount brokerage concern, rose 8 percent yesterday after the Standard & Poor's Corporation promoted it to its 500-stock index. Standard & Poor's said that it added Charles Schwab to the index in anticipation of the proposed merger of Morgan Stanley Group Inc. and Dean Witter, Discover & Company. Schwab will replace Morgan Stanley in the index, S.& P. said, while the combined company, Morgan Stanley, Dean Witter, Discover & Company, will continue on the index. Up to now, Schwab has been a component of the S.& P. Midcap 400. Shares of Schwab rose $2.875, to $38.75.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  TRATTNER, ANN
description: TRATTNER-Ann. 2/17/13-5/29/96. Beloved wife, mother and grandmother. We miss you dearly. Forever in our hearts. With love.

title: S.E.C. Narrows Prudential Case
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission said today that it had closed investigations into the activities of at least six former employees of Prudential Securities Inc. because of a statute of limitations established by a court decision last year.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-14

title: Wells Gives Yankees Reprieve for a Night
description: When Joe Carter launched a three-run missile off David Wells in a gory third inning, it felt like another distressing night in Yankeeland. Doubts permeated the dugout, eyes bulged in astonishment and the players wondered how long before they would perform like defending World Series champions.

title: INSIDE METRO
description: POLITICIAN PLANS TO SIT ON FENCE -- Susan Molinari doesn't think she'll have problems maintaining objectivity as an anchorwoman. B3.

title: Ex-Murdoch Aide Is Named Network President at ABC
description: Preston Padden was named president of the ABC Television Network yesterday, a month after ending his seven-year tenure as one of Rupert Murdoch's top aides.

title: ENCORE TO SELL DATA STORAGE UNIT TO SUN MICROSYSTEMS
description: The Encore Computer Corporation said yesterday that it had agreed to sell its data storage products unit to Sun Microsystems Inc. of Mountain View, Calif., for $185 million. Encore, based in Fort Lauderdale, Fla., provides technologies used to store, retrieve and share data. It said proceeds from the sale would be used to reduce debt and cancel convertible preferred stock held by Gould Electronics Inc. In 1996, Encore Computer lost $70.7 million on revenue of $47.6 million. Last month, Encore's stock was delisted from the Nasdaq stock market because the company failed to meet Nasdaq's equity requirements.

description: SIMENSKY-Ruth. On May 29, 1997. Formerly of Cedarhurst, LI. Devoted wife of Arthur, loving mother of Steven, Rosalie, Linda and Carl. Dear sister of Bea and Jeanette. Donations may be made to The Heart Association or charity of your choice.

description: To The Home Section:

title: Link to Brother's Fund-Raising Seen in Suspension by Broker
description: The suspension of Robert B. Maloney, 43, as Smith Barney's New England regional director stems from questions about money he helped to raise for the Congressional election campaigns of his brother, Representative James H. Maloney, according to people familiar with the matter.

title: Jordan Loves to Putt, But He Never Putters
description: Michael Jordan came into the United Center last night without a golf bag strapped across his shoulder. To some, this meant that he was probably pretty serious about Game 5 of the Bulls' Eastern Conference playoff finals against the Miami Heat.

title: Despite the Delays, Indy Fans Tune In
description: ABC's broadcast of the Indianapolis 500 on Tuesday afternoon produced a 5.1 preliminary overnight Nielsen rating, a fairly decent showing considering the race -- won by Arie Luyendyk -- was delayed by rain from Sunday and Monday, to a work and school day.

description: CHRISTY-Beverly M. Grace Church, 802 Broadway at 10th Street, Thursday, May 29, 5:00 PM. Reception following Service.

Lipp, nephew of Don and Mary Pickering, Bill and Jenny Porter. Formerly of 245 East 63rd St., Manhattan. Memorial service at Kennedy Heights Presbyterian Church, Cincinnati, OH 45213, Thursday, May 29, at 4:30 PM. Remembrances may be directed to Aids Care Center, New York Hospital, C/O Dr. Jonathan Jacobs, 525 East 68th Street, New York, New York 10021.

title: Defense Admits the Accused Had Role in Attack on Megan
description: The lawyer for Jesse K. Timmendequas acknowledged for the first time today that he was involved in the assault on Megan Kanka. But, the defense lawyer said, ''good old compliant, suggestible Jesse'' exaggerated his role to protect his housemates and satisfy the police.

title: Bronx Police Officer Charged With Larceny
description: A Bronx police officer was arrested and charged with grand larceny yesterday after he failed a Police Department integrity test during a sting operation, officials from the Bronx District Attorney's office said.

title: Seagram Sells a Major Part Of Its Stake in Time Warner
description: The Seagram Company said yesterday that it had sold 30 million Time Warner Inc. shares, or more than half its holding, for $1.39 billion just days after the stock touched a record high.

title: Correction: Stock Performance
description: A chart in Business Day yester-day comparing stock perform-ance of four designer clothing companies was mislabelled in a way that greatly understated movements in the stocks' value. Here is a corrected chart.

title: CHRONICLE
description: For many people, a face lift is a procedure to be shrouded in secrecy, but not for HELEN BRANSFORD, a jewelry designer, who had one two years ago at the age of 47. In fact, she has written a guide to the procedure entitled, ''Welcome to Your Facelift,'' which is to be published by Doubleday on Monday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SILBER, GEORGE
description: SILBER-George, age 89, peacefully, on May 28, 1997. Devoted husband of 61 years of Lillian. Beloved father of Richard, Barbara and Marian. Loving grandfather of Laura, Lynne and Jason. Dear brother of the late Victor and Estelle. Cherished uncle and greatuncle. Adored ''boss man'' of Corrine Harris. We will treasure forever the memories of his abiding love, wisdom, humor and indomitable spirit. Service on Friday, May 30, at 1:30 PM, at ''RiversideNassau North Chapels.'' In lieu of flowers, charitable contributions may be made.

title: Virus Sickens More Than 100
description: More than 100 people who attended two end-of-year school banquets over the weekend became ill from an unidentified virus, The Associated Press reported yesterday.

title: No Headline
description: ''He's very good at polishing shoes and has been known to cook a meal -- I wouldn't say he is intimate with our washing machine, but he does know where it is.''

title: New Art and Craft Of the Kitchen
description: THERE are those cookbook recipes that presume you have all the time in the world to cook. And there are those kitchen designs that presume you have all the space. What if you don't?

title: Corrections
description: A brief report on May 1 about the indictment of several officials associated with nonprofit organizations in the Bronx on grand larceny charges misstated the affiliation of one defendant. One of those charged was the program director of Quality Vending, which is a subsidiary corporation of the Southeast Bronx Neighborhood Centers; no defendant was a former executive director of Southeast Bronx Neighborhood Centers itself.

title: MCVEIGH'S DEFENSE WRAPS UP ITS CASE AT BOMBING TRIAL
description: Five weeks after testimony began in the trial of Timothy J. McVeigh, his lawyers today unleashed their final salvo against the prosecution's most powerful witness, and then rested their case.

title: Crowd of 100 Protests Award To Officer
description: About 100 residents of Washington Heights crowded the 33d Precinct station house last night, angrily criticizing the awarding of a ''cop of the month'' plaque to a police officer who fatally shot a 16-year-old youth in the back.

title: Corrections
description: A chart in Business Day yesterday comparing the stock performances of Donna Karan International with three other designer clothing companies, carried a mislabeled scale. A corrected chart appears today on page D2.

title: Coddling The Virtual Pet
description: Knowing that novelty fades, game companies generally market new versions of their electronic toys long before children lose interest in the first one. The makers of a Japanese cyber-game called Tamagotchi have taken the strong-arm approach, however, with a dictatorial little toy that threatens to die if the child stops playing with it.

title: As a Center Closes, Front-Line Workers Are Pushed Into Turmoil
description: Income Support Center 84, which for 31 years has handled welfare for thousands of families in the Williamsburg section of Brooklyn, will close on June 30. When it does, the 7,800 welfare cases it handles will be somebody else's responsibility.

title: Elections Near, Mexican Money Supply Grows
description: The amount of cash in circulation in Mexico has recently been rising, increasing suspicion that the Government may be moving to prime the economic pump before legislative and local elections this summer.

title: Monsanto recruits the horticulturist of the San Diego Zoo to pitch its popular herbicide.
description: ROUNDUP, the world's most popular brand of weed killer, began a campaign last month with the gardener of the country's most popular zoo, the San Diego Zoo and Wild Animal Park, as its spokesman.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GININGER, DR. KHANE
description: GININGER-Dr. Khane, age 100. On May 25, 1997. Teacher of Chemistry (in Yiddish) in Czernowitz High Schools. Widow of the late Yiddish philologist and pedagogue Khayem Gininger. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to League for Yiddish, 200 West 72nd Street, Room 40, NYC 10023.

Beloved wife of the late Joseph, devoted mother of Bette Ellenbogen and Sandy Kewley, dear sister of Phylis Seides and Mildred Toberman, adored grandmother of Josh and Rebecca Kewley, dear cousin to many. Services were held Tuesday. Contributions to Alzheimers Association or Cancer Care.

title: Substitute Schoolteacher Charged With Abusing 10-Year-Old Girl in Brooklyn
description: A substitute teacher who was cleared last year of an allegation of sexual misconduct with a student was charged yesterday in a separate case with sexually abusing a 10-year-old girl while she was waiting for her mother to pick her up from a Brooklyn school.

title: INLAND STEEL SHAREHOLDERS REJECT SPINOFF PROPOSAL
description: Shareholders of Inland Steel Industries have rejected a shareholder proposal calling for the steelmaker to spin off its publicly traded Ryerson Tull Inc. subsidiary. Greenway Partners L.P., a New York investment firm that bought 7.1 percent of Inland in February, said spinning off the rest of North America's largest metals processor and distributor would increase shareholder value. Inland sold 13 percent of Ryerson to the public last June. Inland management had opposed the proposal, which was rejected by about 83 percent of the shares voted yesterday at the company's annual meeting in Chicago, where it has its headquarters. Inland shares rose $1, to $25.375, yesterday, while Ryerson shares rose 12.5 cents, to $16.25.

title: Book on a Bible Code Tempts Hollywood but Not Academics
description: With carefully orchestrated fanfare from its publisher and an army of disbelievers lined up to disparage it, a book called ''The Bible Code'' is due to arrive in stores today and tell interested readers of a secret code in the Old Testament.

title: Like Its Participants, the Cliburn Competition Is Feeling the Pressure
description: When the jurors at the Van Cliburn International Piano Competition began their deliberations just before 11 on Tuesday night, the 35 young pianists who had been competing since Friday filed into the foyer of the Ed Landreth Auditorium at Texas Christian University here and sought ways to occupy themselves.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Buying by Military Drives Durable Goods Orders

title: President of Bandai Says He Will Resign
description: The president of the Bandai Company Ltd., Makoto Yamashina, said yesterday that he planned to quit his post after his company's planned merger with Sega Enterprises Ltd. was called off. Company officials declined to elaborate, saying Bandai's board would hold a special meeting today to discuss personnel issues.

title: Donna Karan Announces Plan to Cut Costs
description: Donna Karan International Inc. said late yesterday that it would cut its work force in the United States by 4 percent and reduce its annual number of runway fashion shows in an effort to cut costs and bolster profits.

title: Stop the Ticket Scalpers
description: Every frustrated theater, sports or music fan is familiar with the problem. After a huge buildup, tickets go on sale for a big game or entertainment event and are almost immediately sold out. Then suddenly it seems as if every broker, scalper or entrepreneur with an 800 number has seats available, but at several times the price of the original ticket. There ought to be a law preventing so many tickets ending up in the hands of price-gouging ticket agents, you say. Well, there is. The problem is that it is rarely enforced. Now the New York State Legislature is giving some thought to tightening the law and stiffening the penalties for scalping. Its efforts are welcome.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  ASHWORTH, TUCKER
description: ASHWORTH-Tucker. 6/3/54-5/30/ 87. Ten years have passed but your spirit continues to inspire, support and give strength. You will always be in our hearts. The Ashworth Family

title: Chip Empire Strikes Back: Intel Countersues Digital
description: Two weeks after the Digital Equipment Corporation accused the Intel Corporation of patent infringement, Intel countersued today, and raised the possibility that it might curtail sales to Digital.

title: Mr. de Klerk's Siege Mentality
description: When he served as South Africa's last white President, F. W. de Klerk could be a man of vision and pragmatism. He saw that apartheid was collapsing, and recognized that a negotiated transition was the only way to salvage some power for whites. He freed Nelson Mandela from jail and managed a transition to majority rule.

title: Paxson to Buy 4 Stations
description: The Paxson Communications Corporation agreed today to acquire four radio stations in West Palm Beach from the American Radio Systems Corporation of Boston. Terms were not disclosed. The stations are WKGR-FM, WOLL-FM, WBZT-AM and WEAT-AM. With the acquisitions, Paxson will own 47 radio stations, including 43 in Florida. Paxson, based in West Palm Beach, is also the largest television station company in the country.

title: C.I.A. Destroyed Files on 1953 Iran Coup
description: The Central Intelligence Agency, which has repeatedly pledged for more than five years to make public the files from its secret mission to overthrow the government of Iran in 1953, said today that it had destroyed or lost almost all the documents decades ago.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FELDMAN, CHESTER
description: FELDMAN-Chester. Our hearts go out to his loving and devoted family. We have lost a dear person and a good friend. Norman and Gloria Barasch

title: Youth Is Guilty In the Slaying Of His Parents
description: A New Hampshire teen-ager was convicted here today of orchestrating the shooting deaths of his parents, assisted by his younger brother.

title: The Euro Creates European Turmoil
description: France and Germany could hardly be more different, but it is no coincidence that both countries are going through their own convulsions in the same week.

title: A Bicycling Eden
description: To The Home Section:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PERLMAN, SIDNEY
description: PERLMAN-Sidney. Boys Town Jerusalem mourns the passing of Mr. Sidney Perlman, partner of Mrs. Claire Perlman both in life and philanthropy. Mrs. Perlmanhas perpetuated her parents' legacy of care and concern via the Samuel Field Family Foundation. The esteemed Perlman name is synonymous with a multitude of noble causes, both here and in Israel, improving the quality of life for countless individuals. And, the Perman's loyal support for Boys Town spanning a decade has made it possible for the school to fulfill its mission of turning young boys from limited backgrounds into young men with limitless futures. Our heartfelt condolences to the entire family. May they be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jersusalem. Josh S. Weston, Chmn Alexander S. Linchner, Vice Chmn Rabbi Ronald L. Gray, Exec. V.P.

title: Accounts
description: * Massachusetts Office of Travel and Tourism, Boston, to Holland Mark Martin, Boston, to handle its account, which had been handled for six years by Houston Herstek Favat, Boston. Billings were estimated at $9 million for the next two years. Holland Mark was awarded the account after a three-month mandated review.

title: Liberal Endorsement Comes as a Surprise
description: Bolstering her position in the crowded race for Manhattan borough president, City Councilwoman C. Virginia Fields was endorsed last night by the Manhattan Liberal Party.

title: Whoever Wins French Election, Belt-Tightening Is Passe
description: No matter which party wins France's legislative elections on Sunday, it became clear today that Prime Minister Alain Juppe's policy of belt-tightening and deficit-cutting to get ready for a common European currency will go with him when he resigns next Monday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ARKIN, ROSE G.
description: ARKIN-Rose G., daughter of Max & Fanny Garfunkel, passed away peacefully on Wednesday, May 28, 1997, at the Sarah Newman Home in Mamaroneck. Her age was 97 years young. Her outlook, her poetry, and her joy of life remain an inspiration to her children, grand & great-grandchildren and her friends. Rose graduated from Columbia Teacher's College in 1920 and this plus Brandeis U and Einstein Hospital remained vital interests to her. From her 1976 poetry book ''Journey To Awareness'': ... oh groping soul be brave for e'en the wish to save yourself is half the fight to win. And if we seek that peace, which brings us true release, remember, it must start within''. Services are private. Thoughts from Rosie's friends will be welcomed by Andrew and Amy Arkin, Judith Ritter, and Pat and Robert Gerdsen.

title: Attacking a Rival's Record on Environmental Issues
description: United States Representative Robert E. Andrews is broadcasting a new television advertisement that attacks one of his opponents in the Democratic gubernatorial primary, State Senator James E. McGreevey. The two, along with Michael Murphy, are vying for the chance to run against Gov. Christine Todd Whitman in the fall.

title: Corrections
description: A headline yesterday about the United Nations' role in Congo referred imprecisely to complaints about a lack of support for United Nations efforts to protect refugees there. Agencies were complaining about lack of support from the major powers working through the Security Council; they were not complaining about the level of support from the United Nations itself.

title: CHRONICLE
description: It will be an evening of honors for BOB HOPE tonight when 400 people gather in the Beverly Hilton Hotel in Beverly Hills, Calif., to watch him receive the Ronald Reagan Freedom Award and to celebrate his 94th birthday. NANCY REAGAN will present the award and Secretary of Defense WILLIAM S. COHEN is scheduled to speak.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GARBER, NETTIE HELFAND
description: GARBER-Nettie Helfand, of Palm Beach, Florida and Southwest Harbor, Maine. May 29, 1912 to May 26, 1997. Died of Lymphoma. Devoted wife of Meyer (Mike) for sixty-five years. Mother of Joan of Connecticut, grandmother of Julia Levy of New York City, James Levy of Boulder, Colorado and Allison Levy of Jackson Hole, Wyoming.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COHN, RICHARD.
description: COHN-Richard. Beloved son of Ann Cohn. Adored brother of Janet Siegal. Loving father of Lisa and Lauren and grandfather of Alexandria Ann. Funeral services to be held at the Garlick Funeral Home in Monticello, New York, on Friday, May 30, at 2 PM.

title: Russia and Ukraine Finally Reach Accord on Black Sea Fleet
description: After years of frustrating diplomacy, Russia and Ukraine said tonight that they had ended their tug-of-war over the Black Sea Fleet.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CAREY, RITA A
description: CAREY-Rita A. Died May 29, 1997 in Rochester, N.Y. Formerly of NYC. She worked for the BBD&O Advertising Agency and PC Data in New York. Survived by three sisters, a brother and several nieces and nephews. Services entombment will be held Saturday, May 31 at White Haven Memorial Park. Schauman-Sulewski F.H.

title: Hispanic Network And Seiko Sign Deal
description: CBS Telenoticias, a 24-hour Spanish-language news network owned by the Westinghouse Electric Corporation, has signed the Seiko Corporation as its ''official timekeeper.'' Terms were not disclosed.

title: When Flowers Bloom, A Conflict Takes Root
description: The Pentagon prepares for all kinds of conflict, but it never planned for the Great Petunia War.

title: Tyson's Managers Insist He Won't Take Holyfield Lightly This Time
description: The people around Mike Tyson admitted yesterday that he failed to train hard enough for last November's fight against Evander Holyfield and that he mistakenly believed Holyfield was washed up.

title: Council Offers Scaled-Down Plan on Community Role in Sites for Superstores
description: Six months after blocking Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's plan to make it easier for superstores to open in the city, the City Council introduced yesterday its scaled-down version that would give communities more control over where stores would open.

title: Crash Kills Flight Instructor
description: A 61-year-old flying instructor was killed yesterday morning when the ultralight plane he was testing before giving a lesson veered into the top of a 60-foot oak tree and crashed.

title: Tiny Comets May Have Huge Impact
description: Thousands of dirty snowballs from outer space are bombarding Earth's atmosphere every day, adding water to Earth's air and seas, scientists reported yesterday. Over billions of years of planetary history, they said, the torrent of extraterrestrial slush might have played a crucial role in filling the oceans and nurturing life on the planet.

title: Lawyer for Accused Teen-Ager Says He Is Fit to Proceed in the Park Killing Case
description: The 15-year-old accused in last week's Central Park killing made his first appearance in court yesterday, and his lawyer said his client no longer needed to be under constant psychiatric care.

title: U.S. Petroleum Data
description: In millions of barrels except refinery utilization

title: Corrections
description: An article last Thursday about innovative designs for bicycles misstated the telephone number for Dekker Service, importer of the Land Rover APB, a British bicycle that can split in two for carrying on planes, buses and cars. The number is (206) 641-9639.

title: Little Is Left in Wake of Savage Tornado
description: One young survivor likened the tornado to a giant bear raging across the Central Texas prairie. A man who tried to drive away from it in his pickup truck described a black cloud hundreds of feet across, full of ''pieces of tin, plywood, boards, flying cows, cornstalks, bits of trees, everything you could imagine.'' On a homemade video of the twister, a woman can be heard crying, ''Oh, please, God, make it go away.''

title: Europe's Postwar Split
description: To the Editor:

title: Who Made Pat Riley The Law?
description: WITH all the heated discussion lately over the safe and proper way to police a professional basketball fight, it has occurred to me that Pat Riley has developed his own peculiar method for restoring law and order when a scuffle breaks out between a menace to society such as Chicago's Dennis Rodman and an innocent, helpless bystander like Riley's own Alonzo Mourning.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KING, KATHARINE PAULA (REED)
description: KING-Katharine Paula (Reed), formerly of New York City and Westport, CT., died suddenly and comfortably in Berkeley, CA., on Monday, May 26, 1997. Survived by her father, Kurtis Reed of New York City; two daughters, Victoria Lewis and Natasha Desgans, two grandsons, and husband, John Matthew King of Berkeley. In lieu of flowers, Kay's family would prefer a donation to the Bay Area Lupus Foundation of America, 2635 North 1st Street, Suite 206, San Jose, California 95134, (408) 954-8600 or the International Center for Alternative Medicine, 2509 Milvia Street, Berkeley, CA. 94705, (510) 596-8750.

title: Corrections
description: An article last Thursday about the use of tax-exempt organizations to direct political campaign donations misstated the outcome of legal proceedings involving Lyn Nofziger, a former aide to President Ronald Reagan. In February 1988 Mr. Nofziger was convicted of violating the Ethics in Government Act. The Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia overturned that conviction in June 1989, and the Supreme Court sustained that decision in December 1989.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BERL, ETHEL (NEE BLOOM)
description: BERL-Ethel (nee Bloom), on Thursday, May 29, 1997 of New Providence, New Jersey, formerly of Far Rockaway and N.Y.C., New York. Beloved wife of the late Mortimer Berl, Devoted mother of Eugene Berl and Sandra Ross, Dear sister of Harry Bloom, Loving grandmother of Joseph Berl and Michael Ross. Funeral services conducted from the Menorah Chapels at Millburn, 2950 Vauxhall Road, Union, New Jersey, on Friday, May 30, 1997 at 1:00 P.M. Interment Beth El Cemetery, Washington Township, New Jersey.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  VOGEL, HELEN M.
description: VOGEL-Helen M., on May 28, 1997 in her 96th year. Cherished wife of the late Peter Vogel, M.D. Devoted mother of Dr. James M. Vogel and Josephine V. Wolk. Adoring grandmother of Douglas D. Wolk and Jennifer N. Vogel. Beloved sister of the late Ruth J. Mandlebaum and the late Daniel Mandlebaum. Funeral service Sunday, 2 PM, at the Universal Funeral Chapel, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COLLADA, BROTHER RENE, F.S.C.
description: COLLADA-Brother Rene, F.S.C., 81, of Lincroft, New Jersey, on May 29, 1997. Surviving are a brother, Pedro Collada, and two sisters, Rina Collada, and Blanca Rosa. The Funeral Liturgy will be celebrated in the De La Salle Hall Chapel, 810 Newman Springs Road, Lincroft, NJ on Friday, May 30, 1997 at 7:30 P.M. Calling hours will be held at the chapel Friday from 2:00 P.M. to 7:30 P.M. A Committal service will be held on Saturday, May 31, 1997 at 9:30 A.M. at the chapel followed by interment at St. Gabriel's Cemetery, Marlboro, NJ. Memorial donations to the De La Salle Nursing Development, 810 Newman Springs Rd., Lincroft, NJ 07738 would be appreciated.

title: Garden Q.&A.
description: Too Many Seedlings

title: A Redeemed Jordan Sends Heat Packing
description: An angry Michael Jordan called it ''personal,'' a game in which his endangered Chicago Bulls would bond together and vanquish the evil forces of Pat Riley forever -- or at least until next season.

title: The $1 Dream That Becomes A Nightmare
description: AT first, George Q. played the lottery once or twice a week, $1 or $2 at a time. He banked on the Lotto mottos: ''You gotta be in it to win it'' and ''Hey, you never know.'' When big jackpots rolled around, as they regularly do, he'd buy a few more cards. No big deal.

title: Dinosaur Joins Illustrious Gout-Ridden
description: To the Editor:

title: Muster Outlasts Tarango in Snarling Duel
description: It was the annual kiddies' day at the French Open, when the gates of Roland Garros are opened to 8,000 high-decibel schoolchildren with no grasp of tennis decorum and no reservations about behaving like babies.

title: Corrections
description: An article on May 15 about the Senate's agreement to amend a 1990 treaty governing conventional weapons in Europe misstated Senator Jesse Helms's voting record on treaties. Mr. Helms, who heads the Foreign Relations Committee, has supported 37 treaties since 1995; the conventional weapons treaty was not the first he had supported since 1992.

title: LVMH Move May Hamper Guinness Plan
description: LVMH Moet Hennessy Louis Vuitton S.A. said today that it planned to buy Guinness P.L.C.'s half of a jointly owned distribution venture, a step that could complicate the $20 billion merger of Guinness, the British brewing company, with Grand Metropolitan P.L.C.

title: Airport Kickbacks Admitted
description: The former chief maintenance supervisor at Newark International Airport admitted in Federal Court yesterday that he took thousands of dollars in kickbacks from vendors who supplied the airport with electrical equipment and heating and air-conditioning systems.

title: David Ludlum, Weather Expert, Dies at 86
description: David M. Ludlum, a scholar who never lost his boyhood delight in the magic of snow, died on Friday at his home in Princeton, N.J. He was 86 and the nation's foremost historian of American weather.

title: New York's Newest Team Gets to Play
description: Less than one month before the New York Liberty of the Women's National Basketball Association opens its inaugural season, point guard Teresa Weatherspoon is still not sure what to think of her new team.

title: Skilled or Not, Immigrants Aid U.S. Economy
description: To the Editor:

title: Wealth of Talent, Dearth of Funds
description: It was just one play in a lopsided regular-season game, but it summed up the season for George Washington High School's baseball team.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: The Hamptons Bell Rings for Round 1
description: As a convoy of gleaming Range Rovers, Mercedes-Benzes and Bentleys inched along Main Street on the Friday before Memorial Day, heralding that inexorable rite of summer -- the lemminglike dash by prosperous New Yorkers to their overpriced East End rentals -- Jack Kehoe, a local sign painter, heaved a deep sigh.

title: Funeral Service for Proctor
description: A funeral service for the Rev. Dr. Samuel DeWitt Proctor will be held at 11 A.M. today at the Abyssinian Baptist Church in Harlem, at 138th Street and Lenox Avenue. Dr. Proctor served as pastor of the church, one of New York City's most influential black institutions, from 1972, when he succeeded the Rev. Adam Clayton Powell Jr., until 1989, when the Rev. Calvin O. Butts 3d succeeded him. Dr. Proctor died last Thursday at age 75.

title: German Company In Deal for Floor Unit
description: Tarkett A.G., a German hardwood-floor maker, said yesterday that it would acquire the floor-covering business of the French plastics maker Sommer Allibert S.A. for 705 million marks ($416.2 million) in cash and the assumption of 250 million marks in debt.

title: Dow Declines 26.18 Points, to 7,357.23
description: Stocks closed mixed yesterday, with both the Dow Jones industrial average and the Standard & Poor's 500 stock index off, even though gainers exceeded losers on the New York Stock Exchange. Moreover, bond yields above 7 percent lured some investors away from equities.

title: Future of Brokerage Firm Is a Test for Japan
description: He lived for his job as a middle manager at the Nomura Securities Company, the world's largest securities firm. Then the latest scandal hit, and his son, who had not bothered to telephone all year from college, called, worried that the firm might not survive.

title: Death Penalty Hasn't Cut Texas Murder Rate
description: To the Editor:

title: As Problems Delay 'Titanic,' Hollywood Sighs in Relief
description: Studio executives all over town, alarmed about the glut of big-budget movies being rolled out virtually every weekend, awoke this morning with the happiest news of spring. The opening of ''Titanic,'' the James Cameron epic that has had technical problems, has been moved from July 2 to Dec. 19.

title: A New Publishing House For Books on Public Affairs
description: Peter Osnos, a former vice president of Random House's Adult Trade Books and former publisher of Times Books, will become publisher and chief executive of a new nonfiction publishing company, Public Affairs, it was announced yesterday. The new house will specialize in books by public figures, journalists, historians and social critics.

title: Tort and Retort: Lawyers v. Lawyers
description: LAWYERLAND

title: Circus May Return To Yankee Stadium
description: When the Yankees went into a free fall in the American League East on their just-ended homestand, they set in motion a set of events guaranteed to jolt them back to the place most New Yorkers hoped the club would never visit again.

title: Fight Over What Was Lost in Polish Translation
description: Just days before Pope John Paul II visits his Polish homeland, the best-selling biography ''His Holiness'' has become the center of a rare international battle over censorship that pits the investigative reporter Carl Bernstein and his New York publisher against a defiant Warsaw publishing house.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CIRKER, JEROME C.
description: CIRKER-Jerome C. Beloved husband of Lillian, wedded 64 years. Devoted father of Stephanie and Bart. Loving father-in-law of Paul and Linda. Adored Pop-Pop of grandchildren Mikal and Mark, Nara, Seth, Adam and Evy and to great-granddaughter Caley. Brother of Stanley, Hayward and Beulah Levine. Services today, 1 PM, Parkside Chapel, 98-60 Queens Boulevard, Forest Hills, NY.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  REICH, HAROLD
description: REICH-Harold. On May 29, 1997. Beloved husband of Dorothy. Loving father of Stephen. Dear brother of Saul and Dorothy Joseph. Adoring grandfather of Joshua and Daniel. Service Friday, 10 A.M., at ''The Riverside'', 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue

title: Facing Truth About Incest, In Memoir And Novel
description: There is no escaping incest, not in life or in literature. And since anything that can be done must be written about, here are three excerpts from 20th-century incest narratives.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FISCHER, ARTHUR MARTIN
description: FISCHER-Arthur Martin. Died at home, May 27, age 65 after a long illness. Cherished husband of Sistie, devoted father of Wendy and Michael, beloved brother of Elaine, beloved son of the late Peter and Sadie. Funeral service Friday, May 30, 1:30 Prince of Peace Chapel, Aspen, CO. In lieu of flowers contributions can be made to The Anderson Ranch,Aspen Music Festival or Aspen Hospital.

title: McGreevey Top Fund-Raiser
description: Less than a week before Tuesday's Democratic gubernatorial primary, State Senator James E. McGreevey continues to lead his two opponents in fund-raising and campaign spending, according to campaign finance reports released yesterday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GALLUCCI, SHARON
description: GALLUCCI-Sharon. Our darling Sharon has been taken from us. We will always remember our wonderful Christmas vacations together and other happy occasions we shared with the rest of the family. A void now exists which is impossible to fill. We will always love and cherish your memory. All our love, Aunt Brenda and Uncle Carlin

title: Frogs' Best Friends: Students Who Won't Dissect Them
description: In the name of scientific enlightenment, biology students have been dissecting animals for generations. For some, the procedure has solved some of the mysteries of life. For others, it was simply disgusting. Either way, it was mandatory.

title: Toys for the Well Scrubbed
description: WHEN it comes to showers, my motto is, the less creativity the better. As someone who would rather be stuck in orbit with a rattlesnake than forced to awaken each morning, I'm generally not in the mood to focus on anything during those 10 precious, peaceful minutes of ablution. Until I dry off, my mind is in neutral.

title: Pataki Backs Small Schools Independent of Local Boards
description: Saying he wanted to provide greater choice in public education, Gov. George E. Pataki released a plan today to allow parents, teachers and community groups to create small schools that are financed by taxpayers but operate independently of local school boards.

title: Steinbrenner, Fed Up, Is Threatening More Hands-On Tactics
description: An impatient George Steinbrenner said today that the listless Yankees were experiencing a malaise after their World Series championship last season and vowed that he would become even more autocratic than usual and make changes if the team did not regroup and end its aggravating drought soon.

title: What Earhart Began, a Texan Finishes
description: Riding a strong tail wind and the legend of Amelia Earhart, a 46-year-old Texas businesswoman completed her round-the-world flight here early today, bringing a restored Lockheed Electra to a smooth landing in front of hundreds of cheering spectators and more than a few beaming sponsors.

title: INSIDE METRO
description: FIGHT FOR NUREYEV ASSETS -- A battle has broken out over the estate of Rudolf Nureyev, who left $7 million in assets, including valuable ballet mementos, above. B3.

title: Buoyant French Socialist Vows to Put Unemployed Back to Work
description: France's opposition Socialist leader, Lionel Jospin, buoyed by public opinion polls predicting that he could become the next Prime Minister, promised thousands of supporters here tonight to reverse two years of conservative austerity and tackle France's unemployment problem.

title: Clinton Sees Hope in the Election of Moderate as President of Iran
description: In his first comments since last week's presidential election in Iran, President Clinton called the victory of Mohammed Khatami, a cleric who defeated the leading conservative candidate, ''hopeful.'' He said he hoped that the estrangement with Iran's people ''can be bridged.''

title: Renewed Push in New York: More Union Cards in Wallets
description: Alarmed by a thinning of their ranks over the last two decades, unions in the New York region have stepped up recruiting efforts to a level not seen in a generation, in some cases spending 10 times what they once did to draw new members.

title: Fossils Called Limb in Human Family Tree
description: Spanish paleontologists say 800,000-year-old fossils they found in a limestone cave represent an entirely new species of human ancestor and could be the last common ancestor of modern humans and their extinct cousins, the Neanderthals.

title: Fiancee Testifies in Alex Kelly Rape Case
description: After a judge threw out kidnapping charges against Alex Kelly today, Mr. Kelly's fiancee, Amy Molitor, took the stand at his rape trial to testify that the couple had recently become engaged.

title: People
description: * Frank Marinaro Jr. was named to the new position of president of Halo Strategic Planning, Hauppauge, N.Y., a division of Halo Group. He had been president of FMA, Dix Hills, N.Y., a consulting company, which closed.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Lawyer and Unlawyer in Partnership
description: Nobody who hires Michael Richards to play a fight scene should ever have to worry about finding anyone to hit him. Mr. Richards, the rubber-limbed not-so-secret weapon of ''Seinfeld,'' can do the job hilariously all by himself. One brief, priceless bit in ''Trial and Error'' finds him auditioning for a mobster's role and flopping all over the scenery, taking a merciless beating with no assailant in sight. He's supposed to be playing a ridiculously bad actor and he rises most avidly to that challenge.

title: Reaching Outer Limits Of New Jazz
description: This year's improvised-music series with the most renegade character is the Vision Festival, running through the week at an old Lower East Side synagogue with a tragically beautiful, ransacked feel. It's a six-day omnium-gatherum of New York's best outer-limits jazz, as well as poetry, dance and visual art.

title: Peter Needs More Steps In Recovery
description: IT sounded like ''Pfffff!'' That was the sarcastic noise a female reporter made yesterday when I asked how she liked Christian Peter's responses about his history of sexual assaults of women.

title: Nureyev's Relatives and a Foundation Fight Over His Will
description: Four years after his death, family members of Rudolf Nureyev are locked in a legal dispute with his lawyer over the dancer's last wishes.

title: A Met Prospect Walks Away From Baseball
description: The quote under Ryan Jaroncyk's senior picture in his high school yearbook read, ''I play for God.'' More to the point, Jaroncyk, a bright, quiet and introspective teen-ager, played shortstop for God, and for his father, and for his mother. He was a first-round draft pick of the Mets in 1995, but Jaroncyk does not play baseball for anybody anymore.

title: Argentine Oil Company To Allow Sale of Shares
description: Y.P.F. S.A., the Argentine oil company, said yesterday that it would allow workers to sell the $1 billion worth of shares they received when the national Government sold the company to private investors four years ago.

title: Indy Pace Car: Rarely Does It Corner Market
description: The Official Pace Car is a fixture of the Indianapolis 500. The tradition began at the first Indy 500 in 1911, when the founder of the Indianapolis Motor Speedway, Carl G. Fisher, used his own Stoddard-Dayton Model 11-A touring car to lead the racers around the track before the green flag fell.

title: Endorsement for McGreevey
description: The Mayor-elect of the largest city in United States Representative Robert E. Andrews's Congressional district said yesterday that he is endorsing State Senator James E. McGreevey in next week's Democratic gubernatorial primary.

title: Poof! Magician's Assistant Disappears
description: Clare Peploe's film ''Rough Magic'' will be remembered, if for nothing else, as the year's nerviest exercise in cinematic genre bending. This whimsical adventure, set in the early 1950's in Los Angeles and points south, is the weirdest of stylistic hybrids: a magic-realist film-noir comedy.

title: INSIDE
description: Court Urged Not to Act

title: Officer Guilty Of Killing Unarmed Man
description: Yesterday, a transit officer became the second New York City police officer ever convicted of committing homicide while on duty.

title: FIRST REPUBLIC SHARES FALL AS SEARCH FOR BUYER HALTS
description: The stock of First Republic Bancorp fell 10 percent yesterday after the company said it was no longer exploring a possible sale or merger. In February, First Republic, based in San Francisco, Calif., hired Montgomery Securities to help in identifying and evaluating alternatives. But on Wednesday the company, the parent of First Republic Bank, called off the search for a buyer. It said it would continue to review alliances and possible acquisitions. Separately, the company said it had increased its stock-buyback plan by 500,000 shares, or 5 percent of its 10.03 million shares outstanding. Shares of First Republic fell $2.25 yesterday, to $20, leaving the company with a market value of $154 million.

title: A Writer in His Dying Days, Living 'in the Present Tense'
description: In his swirling and brilliant screenplays, especially ''The Singing Detective,'' Dennis Potter shattered old forms, took their bits and pieces -- nostalgic songs, flashbacks, fantasies, unrequited love stories -- and put together dazzling new ones. In his dying days, Potter devised one more genre: the televised autobiographical elegy.

title: Hold Congo to Account
description: To the Editor:

title: Looking for Quiet? This Isn't the Place
description: To the Editor:

title: Miscellany
description: * The Lloyd Northover Citigate division of Citigate Group, London, formed an alliance with Bass Yager & Associates, an identity and design agency in Los Angeles. Bass Yager will continue as an independent shop under the name Bass Yager Citigate.

title: For Children
description: 'The Prince and the Pauper'

title: Conversions Are Brisk In Downtown Manhattan
description: The transformation of office space in downtown Manhattan into apartments continues at a brisk pace, with three more buildings scheduled for conversion beginning late next month and owners reporting strong leasing activity in converted buildings that will soon be ready for occupancy.

title: Clinton and Blair: Baby Boomers Unite
description: The ''New Democrat'' (Bill Clinton) met yesterday with the head of ''New Labor'' (Tony Blair) and celebrated the baby-boom generation as perfectly suited to lead a new era. One said the generation ''prefers reason to doctrine,'' and the other that ''yesterday's ideology'' has ended.

title: Bond Prices Rise, Aided by a Good Auction
description: The prices of Treasury securities rose yesterday, helped by foreign investors' overnight purchases and reinforced by an auction of five-year notes that went better than expected.

title: In the latest industry courtship, Omnicom and True North are suitors for Bozell, Jacobs.
description: A POSSIBLE sale of Bozell, Jacobs, Kenyon & Eckhardt may be near as two bigger competitors pursue separate acquisition bids.

title: GRAND UNION TO CUT 80 JOBS AS PART OF A REVAMPING
description: The Grand Union Company said yesterday that it would cut 80 jobs, mainly at its headquarters in Wayne, N.J., in an effort to save more than $5 million a year. Grand Union, a chain of 226 supermarkets, has a total work force of 15,000. It said the cuts were part of a revamping in its financial, human resources, benefits and merchandising departments. Costs tied to the reorganization reduced profits for its fourth quarter, which ended on March 29, by $7.8 million. The company said yesterday that it lost $78.1 million for the quarter, compared with a loss of $29.2 million a year ago. Its president and chief executive, Joseph J. McCaig, resigned recently over differences with the board.

title: Taking Office, Congo's Ruler Promises Vote
description: Laurent Kabila, the rebel leader whose army swept this nation's longtime dictator out of power, had himself sworn in today as President of Africa's third-largest nation, and in his inaugural address promised a transition to democracy with elections in April 1999.

title: Corrections
description: The Autos on Friday column on May 9, about the Tour de France Auto race for vintage cars, located the town of Biarritz incorrectly. It is on the western coast of France, not on the Riviera.

title: Columbia Dedicates New Research Center
description: Columbia University is to dedicate a new center for medical research today, the second structure in a five-building complex known as the Audubon Biomedical Science and Technology Park. When finished, the Audubon complex, across the street from Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center, will add nearly one million square feet of new space to the campus.

title: Twist of Fate
description: The tornadoes that hit Jarrell, Tex., on Tuesday killed at least 27 people, a shocking loss of life. The town had been under a tornado watch for hours, and there was a 15-minute warning, broadcast over radio and television. The town siren also blew. Shouldn't any of this have made a difference?

title: Pitcher Likes Odds of His Two-Sport Talents
description: Coming out of high school two years ago, Chad Hutchinson turned down a $1.5 million signing bonus to pitch for the Atlanta Braves and decided to attend Stanford University.

title: Art in Review
description: The Art Exchange Show

title: A China Share Frenzy Blooms In Hong Kong's Tulip Mania
description: Hong Kong's latest fast-buck scheme reached the market today and climbed like a rocket as the shares of one of China's celebrated red-chip companies went public and more than tripled in price.

title: Opening Up C.I.A. History
description: The Central Intelligence Agency has a way of exceeding the worst expectations about its behavior. After stalling on the declassification of mountains of secret papers about its past actions, the agency now concedes that many of the documents were destroyed by protective officials several decades ago. The C.I.A. has clearly forfeited the right to manage the declassification of its records. That job should be turned over to an independent body.

title: Flyers' Standout Is Barreling His Way to Historic Showcase in Finals
description: During the Eastern Conference finals of the Stanley Cup playoffs, big, tough and talented Eric Lindros of the Philadelphia Flyers grew displeased with the Rangers when Luc Robitaille held him against the boards early in Game 1 and Esa Tikkanen later collided with him at full speed in the middle of the ice.

title: Insurer Is Said To Near a Deal For Scudder
description: The Zurich Insurance Group is close to acquiring Scudder, Stevens & Clark, the money management firm, for an estimated $1.5 billion, according to people familiar with the firm's talks with potential buyers.

title: Reporter's Death in Police Custody Renews Turkish Rights Debate
description: In a case being watched by human rights advocates around the world, a Turkish judge has ordered the arrest of five police officers accused of beating a journalist to death last year.

title: Bank Decides Its Veteran Performer Interferes With Desks and A.T.M.'s
description: For 20 years Anthony Polistina added a touch of warmth to the impersonal world of deposits and withdrawals, filling the bank branch in the World Trade Center with his lush piano music. Customers looked forward to his daily concerts, and there was even the occasional tussle over who got the better seat.

title: Departure of a Key Executive Adds to Problems at Sybase
description: The turnaround of Sybase Inc., a maker of data base software that has been struggling to regain its former luster as a technological leader and Wall Street darling, ran into another hurdle this month when a key executive left and became chief executive of a software start-up company.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary of the singer Thelma Carpenter on May 17 misidentified the Broadway show in which she appeared with Beatrice Lillie. It was ''Inside U.S.A.,'' not ''Ankles Aweigh.''

title: NATIONAL SEMICONDUCTOR REVISES EARNINGS UPWARD
description: The National Semiconductor Corporation said yesterday that it had revised earnings and gross margins for two quarters after a Securities and Exchange Commission review of the spinoff of its Fairchild businesses. Per-share earnings for the third quarter, which ended on Feb. 23, were revised to $1.39 a diluted share from 30 cents a share. Second-quarter earnings were revised to net income of 30 cents a diluted share from net income of 21 cents a share. As previously reported, National took a $206 million restructuring reserve in the first quarter for the estimated impairment of Fairchild assets. It completed the Fairchild sale on March 11. It will now recognize $192 million in recovery of the reserve in the third quarter and $9 million in the fourth quarter, instead of $201 million in the fourth quarter, as previously planned.

title: GENERAL REMOVED OVER RELATIONSHIP
description: The Army today relieved a one-star general of the command of all Army medical operations in the Southeast because of an apparent ''improper relationship'' with a civilian nurse who was caring for his critically ill wife, military and Congressional officials said tonight.

title: Danish Company To Form 2 Entities
description: Sophus Berendsen A/S, a Danish commercial-services company, said yesterday that it planned to split into two separately traded companies to take advantage of its 35.7 percent stake in Rentokil Initial P.L.C. The two new companies will be named Sophus Berendsen and Ratin. Ratin's only function will be to hold a 32.2 percent stake in Rentokil Initial, which is a British business-services and pest-control company.

title: For Housing: Civil Court, Chaos Part
description: YOU have to go far to find a place where the clamor is greater than in the corridors of Brooklyn's housing court. Maybe the Grand Bazaar in Istanbul. Or the kick-boxing arena in Bangkok.

title: South Korean Leader Apologizes For Election Spending Abuses
description: Two weeks after his son was arrested on bribery charges, President Kim Young Sam of South Korea today apologized again for the scandal enveloping his administration, but he refused to disclose details of fund-raising in his 1992 campaign.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: Baseball

title: Robbie Tilley Branscum, 62, Children's Author
description: Robbie Tilley Branscum, whose books for young readers bore the stamp of her hardscrabble childhood in rural Arkansas, died on May 24 at her home in San Pablo, Calif. She was 62.

title: Whitewater Counsel Urges Court to Free Notes of Talks
description: The Whitewater independent counsel urged the Supreme Court today to leave undisturbed an order requiring the White House to turn over notes taken by Government lawyers of conversations they had with Hillary Rodham Clinton about several Whitewater-related matters under investigation.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: N.F.L.

title: Restaurants
description: In the beginning it is hard to resist the charm of Il Postino. The entrance to the five-month-old restaurant, with its enticing display of prosciutto, porcini and portobello mushrooms, is warm and appealing. You pass more food -- small fragrant melons and strawberries the size of artichokes -- as the jocular maitre d'hotel leads you to your table.

title: McVeigh Described as Terrorist And as Victim of Circumstance
description: Two years after the nation looked in horror at the carnage of the Oklahoma City bombing, a Federal District Court jury was asked in closing arguments today to answer a single question: Who could do such a thing?

title: Couple Held In Abuse Of 2 Children During Flight
description: A Phoenix couple who were returning to the United States after adopting two 4-year-old Russian girls were arrested at Kennedy International Airport for physically and verbally abusing the children during the 10-hour flight from Moscow, the authorities said yesterday.

title: For Missing Girl's Family, Waiting Ends With Tears
description: Two weeks ago, a noodle-factory worker and a seamstress from the Lower East Side used a Chinese-speaking translator to tell the police that their 11-year-old daughter was missing. Yesterday, the police returned with news that would be horrifying in any language: a body found in the East River, not far from the family's battleship-gray tenement, was that of their child, and she had been strangled.

title: If Hostos Is Bilingual, Students Should Know Two Languages
description: To the Editor:

title: Saint of Auschwitz
description: To the Editor:

title: INTUIT TO SELL SOFTWARE UNIT TO BRODERBUND
description: Intuit Inc. of Mountain View, Calif., agreed yesterday to sell its Parsons Technology unit, which writes art and advice software for consumers, to Broderbund Software Inc. for an undisclosed sum. Broderbund, based in Novato, Calif., is one of the biggest sellers of educational software. Intuit, publisher of the Quicken electronic checkbook program, intends to focus on its personal finance and tax software. It bought Parsons in September 1994 for about $67.3 million. The Parsons products include Print Shop, Family Lawyer and Family Tree Maker. Intuit also reported a third-quarter profit of 1 cent a share, compared with a loss of 1 cent a share a year ago. The deal was announced after Intuit's stock closed at $27.125, down $1.25 a share.

title: James Lee Byars, 65, Creator Of Art That Lived in a Moment
description: James Lee Byars, an American performance and installation artist whose idiosyncratic, Zen-influenced blendings of Minimal and Conceptual art stressed questions over answers, absence over presence and a lush momentary experience of beauty over permanence, died on May 23 at the Anglo-American Hospital in Cairo. He was 65 and lived primarily in Santa Fe, N.M.

title: The Rural Factor
description: To the Editor:

title: A Timeout In the Trials Of Sylphs And Swans
description: This season, American Ballet Theater has concentrated on full-evening narrative ballets, usually performed at least five times in succession.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, a television review on Wednesday about ''American Visions,'' a PBS series narrated by the art critic Robert Hughes, misstated the days on which further installments will be shown. Two will be shown on each of the next three Wednesdays, not Tuesdays.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Mutual Fund Inflows Rise; Dow Average Loses 27.05

title: NEW VIDEO RELEASES
description: Jerry Maguire

title: Police Investigate Injuries To Baby Girl in Bronx
description: A 14-month-old girl found unconscious and not breathing in the Bronx yesterday afternoon had suffered head injuries and a burn to her left hand and may have been a victim of child abuse, the police said.

title: States Lead a Crackdown On Telemarketing Brokers
description: Americans who live west of the Hudson may have good reason to hate New York, based on evidence presented yesterday by securities regulators from 20 states who cracked down on stockbrokers pushing penny stocks by phone.

title: Defining A Life By Walking A City
description: TONY RANDALL stands a few feet into the traffic crush of Eighth Avenue, looking plaintively toward the Port Authority Bus Terminal for a taxi to take him back home to the Upper West Side. ''A couple more minutes and then I'll take my hat off,'' he says. ''Someone will stop and offer me a ride. They always have. Oh, I do it all the time. I'm shameless.''

title: Retailers Fill a New Apparel Niche
description: Like many young girls, Jenna Sheffield likes to keep her fashion statements simple: shirts with kittens on them, pink and blue overalls and loose-fitting skirts that she can swirl around in like a dancer.

title: Gingrich Loan Complies With House Rules
description: To the Editor:

title: CHRONICLE
description: Along with the indictments and convictions, the Whitewater case has now produced its first marriage. SAM HEUER and MAXINE PARKER confirmed yesterday that they were married last Friday at the Federal Courthouse in Little Rock, Ark.

title: 2 'Perfect Little Girls' Stun France in Suicide
description: The girls had been talking about it to their friends for a while. How, like Kurt Cobain of Nirvana, they would kill themselves. They wore his T-shirts; they worshiped his grunge rock sound. But they were model pupils from model families, and sleepy Somain is a long way from Seattle.

title: Scholastic Plans to Cut Jobs and Costs
description: The Scholastic Corporation, whose stock plunged in February after it disclosed that sales of a popular children's book series had slowed markedly, announced a series of cost-cutting measures yesterday, and investors responded by bidding up the stock.

title: Diner's Journal
description: ''Monzu'' is how ''Monsieur'' sounds in the Sicilian dialect, and it is what Sicilians called the French cooks who came to their island in Napoleon's time.

title: 'Megan's Law' Is Challenged
description: While jurors began deliberating the fate of the man accused of killing Megan Kanka, the State Public Defenders office raised new questions yesterday about the community-notification law named after the Hamilton Township girl.

title: 2 Demands on Clinton in Sex Complaint
description: The lawyer for Paula Corbin Jones said today that to avoid a trial on sexual harassment charges, President Clinton would have to acknowledge explicitly that he remembered meeting Ms. Jones in a Little Rock hotel room in 1991, as well as give her a ''significant'' cash settlement to compensate her for damage to her reputation.

title: The Spoken Word
description: WALT WHITMAN READING, Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church, Fifth Avenue at 55th Street. Julie Harris, the actress, will read from ''Leaves of Grass'' and ''Specimen Days'' in celebration of the 178th anniversary of Walt Whitman's birth; his actual birth date is May 31. Sponsored by the International Project to Promote Peace and Unity Through the Arts. Today, 12:30 to 1:30 P.M. Free. Information: (212) 247-0490.

title: Scott Bradley Named Princeton Coach
description: Princeton University named SCOTT BRADLEY, the former major league catcher, its head baseball coach yesterday.

title: Nike's Shares Tumble After Profit Forecast
description: Shares in Nike Inc. fell 13 percent yesterday after an announcement by the company that its quarterly earnings would be below expectations because of disappointing sales and a factory shutdown.

title: Enlightened, Finally, by a Grid
description: AN ambitious, nearly museum-quality exhibition at Jan Krugier Gallery on 57th Street surveys and pays homage to the mature work of Joaquin Torres-Garcia, one of the great late bloomers of modern art.

title: Honors
description: * Charlotte Beers, chairwoman emeritus of Ogilvy & Mather Worldwide, New York, a unit of WPP Group, became the first recipient of a Lifetime Achievement Award from Advertising Women of New York.

title: Yankees Sign Irabu; Mets Lose a Prospect
description: One potential baseball star arrived yesterday when the Yankees signed the Japanese pitcher Hideki Irabu, paying him $12.8 million over four years. But the Mets lost a prospect, Ryan Jaroncyk, who quit his minor league team saying he can't remember a time he ever liked baseball.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: SEQUA CORP., New York, a maker of fabrics, clothing and interior furnishings, has agreed to buy Burlington Industries' specialty chemicals subsidiary, Sedgefield Specialties, for undisclosed terms.

title: One Empire, Best Offer
description: The Royal Yacht is sailing into position, the bunting is up, the fireworks are primed: Preparations are under way for the hauling down of the Union Jack over Hong Kong one month from now. We can expect one splendid imperial farewell, which made it all the more poignant to discover recently a small classified advertisement in The South China Morning Post. ''British Forces Hong Kong,'' it announced, ''Historic Sale.''

title: NEW VIDEO RELEASES
description: Swingers

title: INVESTORS ENDORSE RYANAIR, AN IRISH NO-FRILLS AIRLINE
description: The American depository receipts of Ryanair Holdings P.L.C. soared in their first day of United States trading as investors clamored for a piece of the company, an Irish no-frills airline. The receipts, each representing five ordinary shares, closed at $25.50, sharply higher than the offering price of $14.734. Almost 8.7 million shares were traded. Analysts expect Ryanair, which flies short-haul European routes from Dublin, to use its lower costs to snatch passengers from state-supported rivals like Air France and Aer Lingus.

title: Palestinian Impressions
description: ''Chronicle of a Disappearance'' was shown as part of this year's New Directors/New Films series. Following are excerpts from Janet Maslin's review, which appeared in The New York Times on March 22. The film -- in Arabic and English, with English subtitles -- opens today at Anthology Film Archives, 32 Second Avenue, at Second Street, East Village.

title: A Quadruplet Boomlet Hits
description: At odds of one in 370,000, giving birth to quadruplets is hardly a run-of-the-mill event. But doctors at St. Barnabas Medical Center in Livingston are preparing to deliver their third set of quadruplets in six weeks, hospital officials said yesterday.

title: NatWest Unit Threatens to Go to Stamford
description: NatWest Markets North America, the investment banking division of NatWest Group, the British financial institution, is threatening to move its headquarters and 500 employees to Stamford unless the city gives it a package of tax breaks and other incentives to move from Wall Street to a luxurious midtown office tower.

title: Painter on a Pendulum, Swinging From Innocent to Elegiac and Back
description: THE artist Maria Izquierdo was born in a small town in northern Mexico in 1902. Reared in a conservative middle-class family, she entered an arranged marriage at 14 and had two children before moving with her husband, a military man, to Mexico City in 1923.

title: Inside Art
description: A Guggenheim for Berlin

title: NEW VIDEO RELEASES
description: Breaking the Waves

title: SALLIE MAE TO OFFER DISSIDENTS SEATS ON A NEW BOARD
description: The Student Loan Marketing Association, or Sallie Mae, is planning to offer board seats to a dissident shareholder group in a bid to retain control of the company, which buys about one in three United States student loans. Earlier this week, management and the dissident group agreed to hold a July meeting at which shareholders will decide which side will control Sallie Mae after the company cuts its ties with the Federal Government next year and becomes a fully private corporation. By including several dissidents on its proposed 15-member board, management hopes to marshal the majority vote it needs to stay in control. The dissidents will propose their own 15-member slate.

title: Strikers to Vote on Contract
description: About 1,600 striking insurance claims processors will vote tonight on a tentative contract agreement with Blue Cross and Blue Shield of New Jersey.

title: New Veterans Medical Center
description: The Department of Veterans Affairs will open a new medical center in September at the Coast Guard Training Center in Cape May. It will serve more than 56,000 veterans in four southern New Jersey counties, officials said yesterday.

title: Trial Near in New Legal Tack in Tobacco War
description: Norma Broin has been a flight attendant for American Airlines for 21 years. As a devout Mormon, she has never smoked a cigarette, ''never even a puff.''

title: Nigerian Military Actions in Sierra Leone Back a Larger Purpose
description: Setting the stage for a possible test of military strength, hundreds of heavily armed Nigerian troops began taking up strategic positions today around Freetown, the capital of Sierra Leone, to back demands that leaders of a military coup restore the elected President.

title: Texan Faces Big Challenge in Shaping Tax Policy
description: The White House and Republican leaders in Congress were moving into the final stages of their negotiations to balance the Federal budget late last month, and Representative Bill Archer was out to protect his turf.

title: Accord on Welfare Despite Drug Felonies
description: Gov. John G. Rowland and legislative leaders have agreed that people convicted of drug felonies should remain eligible for welfare, despite Federal rules allowing states to deny benefits.

title: No Headline
Making Israel Heard
description: Natan Sharansky is traveling in America, talking about what is going on between Israel and Yasir Arafat. These days there is nothing Israel needs more -- a clear, brave voice abroad.

title: Don't Blame Faculty
description: To the Editor:

title: Stockton Sends Jazz to Finals At Last Second
description: Sometimes a screen is a screen, and sometimes a screen is a bear hug. Sometimes a 25-footer is a 25-footer, and sometimes a 25-footer scatters 24 men.

title: Girl Being Taught at Home Is U.S. Spelling Champion
description: Derived from the ancient Greek, the vowel-laden word euonym means an apt name for a person, place or thing. And after she had laid out the letters of that word and was the last person standing at the end of the 23d round of the National Spelling Bee yesterday, the judges had an apt word to describe Rebecca A. Sealfon of Brooklyn Heights: champion.

title: Cone Takes Control, And Perfection Follows
description: David Cone stretched out his arms, breathed in and out, eased into his fluid motion and then toyed with the Blue Jays all afternoon. The fastballs soared and sailed, the split-finger pitches dived and danced and the sliders gyrated and jumped. All Toronto did was moan and mutter because Cone made absolute dominance look refreshingly routine as the Yankees prevailed, 4-0, today.

title: $25 and Under
description: As far as I can tell, Cambodian Cuisine is the only Cambodian restaurant in New York City.

title: DAMARK'S EARNINGS FORECAST SENDS STOCK UP 24%
description: Shares of Damark International rose 24 percent yesterday after the company, a catalogue retailer based in Minneapolis, said it expected earnings to beat analysts' second-quarter estimates by about 30 percent to 34 percent. Damark stock rose $2.86, to $14.98. Damark was expected to earn 18 cents in the latest quarter. It had net income of $1.5 million, or 17 cents a share, on revenue of $124.1 million in the period a year earlier. Damark said it saw sales increasing more rapidly after a two-year effort to reduce costs and improve profitability.

title: Falling Behind on Wages
description: To the Editor:

title: Success, Too, Can Distort An Image
description: The career of Freda Payne is a case study of how a couple of hit records can create a distorted public image of a pop performer. In the early 1970's, the Detroit-born singer had two singles that sold a million copies, ''Band of Gold'' and an antiwar anthem, ''Bring the Boys Home,'' that established her musical profile as a sassy Motown-style belter of pop-soul dance music. Many years earlier, however, Ms. Payne had sung pop-jazz with Quincy Jones's big band. More recently, she has toured in productions of ''Sophisticated Ladies,'' ''Ain't Misbehavin' '' and ''Jelly's Last Jam.''

title: Art in Review
description: Meg Webster

title: Home Video
description: One Quick Dog

title: The Call Goes to Nantz For Olympics in Nagano
description: This would naturally be the space to write about Fox and ESPN's telecasts of the Stanley Cup finals (in which Fox's glowing puck technology will yield goalie reaction time during Games 1, 5 and 7). Or NBC's National Basketball Association playoff broadcasts (in which Ahmad Rashad will reveal that he not only plays golf with Michael Jordan, but plays Yahtzee). Or even the start of Fox's major league baseball season (in which, by ruling of the sport's executive council, one manager per game must be wired for sound, expectoration and nail clipping).

title: Torre Says His Team Hasn't Lost Its Focus
description: Joe Torre reacted calmly but sternly today while disagreeing with George Steinbrenner's suggestion that the underachieving Yankees might be infected by a malaise following their 1996 World Series championship. The owner had insinuated that the Yankees were not focused and had threatened to become more involved if the team continues to flounder. Torre scoffed at the theory.

title: Art in Review
description: 'Abstract Expressionist Ceramics: Myth and Reality Revisited'

title: When the Court Speaks
description: Forty years ago Justice Robert H. Jackson, reflecting on the extraordinary role of the Supreme Court in our system of government, noted how the Court had been in controversy again and again -- but through it all kept the respect of the American public.

title: Finally, Air France Reports Annual Profit
description: Air France Group, the parent company of France's state-owned airline, reported yesterday that it posted its first annual profit in seven years in the year that ended on March 31 because of increases in passenger and cargo revenue and a drop in financing costs.

title: Years After Doctor's Death, Son Is Charged
description: More than two years after the body of a prominent Queens obstetrician was found stuffed in the trunk of her Mercedes-Benz, the woman's son has been charged with her slaying.

title: Irabu Agrees to Yankees' Offer of $12.8 Million
description: Completing a long journey from Japan to New York, Hideki Irabu finally joined the team of his choice yesterday, agreeing to a four-year, $12.8 million contract with the Yankees.

title: NEW VIDEO RELEASES
description: The People vs. Larry Flynt

title: Jury Awards Street Musician $37,000
description: A Federal jury yesterday awarded $37,000 to a street musician who said he was harassed and even arrested by the police when he tried to play in Times Square and Central Park.

title: Art in Review
description: 'Candy Darling: Always a Lady'

title: Breaking Ranks With P.B.A., Small Union Settles Contract
description: Breaking ranks with the city's largest police union, the much smaller union representing police lieutenants announced yesterday that it had reached a contract agreement with the Giuliani administration, accepting terms very similar to those rejected by the larger union.

title: Hearst Names a New Top Editor To Try to Turn Around Esquire
description: David Granger, the third-ranking editor at GQ magazine, was named editor in chief of Esquire yesterday, replacing Edward Kosner, who was unable to halt a decline in that magazine's fortunes.

title: In London, 2 Young Guys Sit Talking About Democracy
description: Perhaps it was predestined that America's ''New Democrat'' President and Britain's ''New Labor'' Prime Minister would give fresh life to the idea of a ''special relationship.'' For Bill Clinton and Tony Blair were having such a baby-boomer love fest today that Mr. Blair virtually issued a generational political manifesto on their behalf.

title: Mitsubishi Motors Says Profits Tumbled
description: The Mitsubishi Motors Corporation, Japan's fourth-largest auto maker, said pretax profit on its worldwide operations plunged almost 70 percent, to 9.5 billion yen ($81.6 million), in the year that ended on March 31 after it wrote down losses on its United States sales unit. Net income worldwide fell 8.9 percent, to 11.6 billion yen.

title: Wealth Whets Chinese Taste for Freedom
description: Just around the corner from where Democracy Wall was torn down more than a decade ago, a 40-year-old clothing merchant named Zhang perched himself on the stoop of his storefront and surveyed the explosion of commerce that has changed the face of China.

title: U.S. NOW AT ODDS WITH NATO ALLIES ON NEW MEMBERS
description: Just two days after NATO sealed a pact with Russia to ease Moscow's concerns about the alliance's expansion, the United States found itself sharply at odds with many of its allies today over how many nations from Central and Eastern Europe should now be invited to join.

title: Uncertain Area for Doctors: Saving Sperm of Dead Men
description: Responding to an increasing number of requests, doctors have been removing and storing the sperm of men who have just died.

title: Corrections
description: A caption in some editions yesterday about a Jules Feiffer cartoon sequence, with an article about Mr. Feiffer's departure from The Village Voice in a salary dispute, misidentified the target of the satire. Mr. Feiffer says the cartoon, relating his encounter with ''Mr. Scrooge,'' referred to the publisher of The Voice, David Schneiderman, not to the new editor, Donald H. Forst.

title: Focusing On the Work Instead Of the Person
description: The New York City Ballet has always been among us, it sometimes seems, and so one can too easily forget how very special its dancers can be. It was business as usual, for example, on Tuesday night when City Ballet presented three popular works by George Balanchine and Angelin Preljocaj's ''Stravaganza'' at the New York State Theater. But the dancers embodied the Balanchinian precept that less is more in dancing that was at once everyday and exalted.

title: Art in Review
description: Medardo Rosso

title: Hingis Displays Savvy; Williams Shows Youth
description: They are both 16, they both view themselves as worldbeaters and both Martina Hingis and Venus Williams found themselves in trouble today at the French Open, the Grand Slam event that has a history of teen-age champions. Monica Seles triumphed here at 16; Mats Wilander was 17 when he won the 1982 crown, and in 1989 both Arantxa Sanchez Vicario and Michael Chang prevailed as 17-year-olds.

title: Giants Introduce Rookie With a Past
description: This was the kind of attention usually reserved for occasions such as Phil Simms's jersey retirement or Wellington Mara's entry into the Hall of Fame. But the dozens of reporters attending a news conference at Giants Stadium today were here for something very different. The crowd was for Christian Peter, a free-agent defensive tackle and a convicted sex offender who is battling alcoholism -- and basically fighting to redirect his life.

title: Stage Set for Appellate Ruling on Class-Action Suits vs. Companies
description: Citing a 1995 law aimed at blocking frivolous securities suits, a Federal judge has dismissed a lawsuit contending officials of Silicon Graphics defrauded investors. The dismissal is expected to lead to the first appellate court ruling on just how far that law goes in inhibiting class-action suits.

title: News Summary
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-13

title: CHRONICLE
description: Hand over that gavel: two of New York's major bar associations are undergoing a change in leadership.

title: Now It's the Jury's Turn
description: ''It all adds up,'' said the prosecutor Larry Mackey as he stitched together the Government's largely circumstantial but nonetheless powerful evidence against the Oklahoma City bombing defendant Timothy McVeigh. ''It all adds up.''

title: Cloning of Humans? Unethical, EU Panel Decides
description: BRUSSELS  The cloning of human beings is "ethically unacceptable" and should be prohibited by law, but genetic research on human embryos as well as research into animal cloning should be permitted under strict conditions, a European ethics panel said Thursday.

title: John Sengstacke, Black Publisher, Dies at 84
description: John H. Sengstacke, the outspoken longtime owner of The Chicago Daily Defender and a tight-lipped perennial power in Chicago and national politics, died on Wednesday at a Chicago hospital. He was 84.

title: Newly Merged Concern Names Mutual Fund Unit Chief
description: In an about-face, Philip J. Purcell and John J. Mack told the directors of Morgan Stanley, Dean Witter, Discover & Company at a board meeting Wednesday that on Monday they would name Philip N.
