Duff to run Van Kampen/American Capital Inc., the mutual fund arm of the newly merged Wall Street giant.

title: ARCHER DANIELS MIDLAND TO BUY 45% OF UNITED GRAIN
description: The Archer Daniels Midland Company said yesterday that it had agreed to buy 45 percent of United Grain Growers in a series of transactions totaling $82 million. Archer Daniels, based in Decatur, Ill., said its strategic alliance would give United Grain Growers, based in Winnipeg, Manitoba, access to world markets. In March, United Grain Growers fought off a hostile takeover bid by the Alberta Wheat Pool and Manitoba Pool Elevators.

title: Satellite System for Airport
description: As a so-called reliever airport, Linden Airport handles private and charter flights that otherwise could delay the commercial jets at Newark International Airport, just five miles away. But in poor weather, officials say the smaller aircraft must either land in Newark or take an approach to Linden that interferes with Newark flight paths.

title: Cosmic Snowballs
description: Just when you thought scientists had pretty well explored the far reaches of this planet and found everything significant worth knowing, along comes a discovery so startling and so potentially important that it seems hard to believe it was overlooked.

title: Nigeria's Environment
description: To the Editor:

title: U.S. Moves to Prohibit Home-Loan Abuses
description: In its latest effort to eliminate fraud in Federal housing programs, the Department of Housing and Urban Development proposed a new regulation today to prohibit building contractors from arranging home-improvement loans.

title: As Flows to Mutual Funds Increase, So Do Cash Levels
description: Cash flows to stock and bond mutual funds have gained strength in the last two months, as investors have cheered a rebound in stock prices and a bond market rally. But fund managers have been less eager to invest the new money, instead preferring to raise the cash levels in their portfolios to the highest level in six months.

title: Boston Market Head Quits Amid Poor Results
description: Boston Chicken, Inc., said yesterday that it was unhappy with results in its Boston Market restaurant division and that the president of the unit, Laurence M. Zwain, had resigned. Mr. Zwain will remain on the board.

title: A Life That Sounds Like Fiction
description: RAGE FOR FAME

title: Via a Jewish School, The Face of the Gestapo
description: ''Don't worry, he won't last a week,'' a German Jew assured his family as Adolf Hitler took office. That is one of the memories of ''The Lost Children of Berlin,'' produced for the Survivors of the Shoah Visual History Foundation, created by Steven Spielberg to document the meaning of the Holocaust for those swept up in it.

title: On Stage, and Off
description: The Bulls of Broadway

title: Prosecutors In Megan Case Credit Defense After Editorial
description: The jury in the Megan Kanka murder and sexual assault case began deliberations today, and went home for the night without reaching a verdict.

title: Approaching Their Music With Great Appetite
description: There's something fantastically assured about the alto saxophonist Kenny Garrett's group. The band takes on its music the way a group of carnivores, having skipped a meal or two, might devour a clump of sheep sunning themselves in a glade. These are musicians whose work displays youthful authority.

title: No Headline
description: ''People don't want the teller to shout over the piano: 'Do you want that $2,000 in hundreds or twenties?' Financial transactions are very private. We're running a business here.''

title: Bulls Rest To Be Fit For Utah In Finals
description: Scottie Pippen will have a few days to rest his sprained left foot. Dennis Rodman can use his spare time to examine his unpredictable behavior in the playoffs. Michael Jordan can play golf until dark and not be taken to task for it.

title: Requirement Is Unfair
description: To the Editor:

title: MERIDIAN INDUSTRIAL IN $358 MILLION DEAL FOR PROPERTIES
description: Meridian Industrial Trust said yesterday that it had agreed to buy, in separate transactions, 86 industrial properties from the Ameritech Pension Trust, a unit of the Ameritech Corporation of Chicago, and the Prudential Insurance Company of America for $358 million. The purchases will expand Meridian's portfolio by 9.3 million square feet, to 21 million square feet. Meridian, based in San Francisco, will finance the transaction by issuing 7.31 million common shares valued at $161.8 million to Ameritech and pay $196.2 million cash to real estate funds run by Prudential. That cash will partly come from the sale of 7.1 million shares to Prudential at $19.73. When the deal is completed, Ameritech will have a 29.5 percent stake in the company and Prudential will own 23.4 percent. Meridian's shares closed down 12.5 cents at $22.

title: Tornado Toll Is Put at 30 as Fears Subside
description: The state authorities raised the death toll to 30 today as they concluded searches for the victims of a half-dozen tornadoes that ravaged Central Texas on Tuesday. Twenty-seven of the dead were in homes in a roughly two-mile square patch of land near this unincorporated community 40 miles north of Austin.

title: Edelman Revamps; Executives Promoted
description: Edelman Public Relations Worldwide has reorganized its New York office to form three operating units.

title: Police to Crack Down On Illegal Fireworks
description: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani announced yesterday that the Police Department will again employ a ''zero tolerance'' policy on fireworks in the weeks leading up to and on Independence Day, saying that last year's crackdown resulted in fewer visits to hospital emergency rooms.

title: Last Chance
description: Here is a sampling of shows and exhibitions in Manhattan that are to close soon:

title: Blueprint for a Meet, Greet and Marry
description: The romantic comedy '' 'Til There Was You'' trots out a lot of minor characters and announces more about each of them than any audience will want to know. Everybody here has a story, like the extra who dashes through the frame exclaiming, ''My boyfriend moves to Utah, my restaurant gets condemned and now this!'' Who is she and what's her problem? The film is seldom inviting enough to make viewers wonder on their own.

title: Accounts
description: * Wearever Health Care Products, Rougemont, N.C., to Howard, Merrell & Partners, Raleigh, N.C., as the first agency for its incontinence-protection products. Billings were estimated at $5 million to $9 million for the first year and $12 million to $15 million in the second.

title: Kravis Fund Invests $2 Million With Hospitals
description: A venture capital fund established last year by the financier Henry R. Kravis to encourage job growth and economic development in New York is investing $2 million with two distressed New York City hospitals to help them go head-to-head with giant health maintenance organizations like Oxford and U.S. Healthcare.

title: Art in Review
description: 'A Collector's Cabinet'

title: Environmentalists Try to Discredit McGreevey
description: In a state with more Superfund sites than any other, State Senator James E. McGreevey won praise from environmentalists five years ago by sponsoring an innovative environmental law that has helped clean up New Jersey's hazardous waste.

title: Election Brings 2d Look: Is Irish Economic 'Tiger' a Kitten?
description: With the approach of the national parliamentary election on June 6, the Celtic Tiger, as Ireland's surging economy is called here, is coming under increasing criticism from both academic and political snipers.

title: Africa Isn't Free to Develop Thriving Economy
description: To the Editor:

title: Painting His Way From Style To Style
description: DESPITE diligent burnishing by scholars of every stripe, there are still some 19th-century French artists whose reputations lack luster, at least for art viewers in this country. Take the painter Maximilien Luce (1858-1941), best known as a minor member of the important Neo-Impressionist movement in France, which bloomed in the mid-1880's. It's hard to believe, but his current retrospective at Wildenstein is his first solo show in the United States.

title: Indonesian Governing Party Wins Yet Another Landslide
description: The political system erected during three decades of President Suharto's rule proved today that it had lost none of its control, with the ruling party heading for the overwhelming election victory it had predicted.

title: 4 Wheels, and Off To New Horizons
description: JUST in case you were on the Long Island Expressway last weekend all by yourself and felt lonely; just in case there were no other cars at all and you yearned for the sight of a car, any old car, even a picture of one -- relief is on the way. ''Car Culture: The Automobile in 20th-Century Photography,'' at the Howard Greenberg Gallery in association with Keith de Lellis, is a convention of 119 photographs of cars from the first decade of this century on, with a couple of entries as recent as the 1990's.

title: Gypsy Boy on the Run Sees Beauty in Every Raindrop
description: Is it the kitschy film equivalent of a Keene painting? Or a deeply felt allegory of innocence betrayed by an unfeeling world? Tony Gatlif's film ''Mondo,'' based on a story by J. M. G. Le Clezio, is a gorgeously photographed tear-jerker that hovers on the line between the icky and the profound. At the very least, the movie, which follows the perambulations of a homeless Gypsy boy named Mondo (Ovidiu Balan) through the streets of Nice, France, succeeds in being a ravishing travel brochure for the Mediterranean resort city.

title: The Milk Cartel Raid
description: Dairy farmers habitually lobby Albany for one odious measure or another that would jack up milk prices for millions of New Yorkers. This year's bill, approved by a Senate committee earlier this month, would permit New York to join the Northeast Dairy Compact, a recent invention of Congress that has been challenged in court. By joining the compact, which is essentially a cartel with the power to raise prices, New York would line the pockets of dairy farmers at the expense of consumers, especially the poor who typically spend twice as much of their income on food as do better-off families.

title: Toy Biz Ends Its Deal With Marvel Bondholders
description: Toy Biz, a company at the heart of the battle for control of Marvel Entertainment, has changed sides again.

title: Editor's Note
description: An article in Business Day on Wednesday described management and cost-control problems at Donna Karan International, noting that the board had been relatively inactive in the face of the company's problems.

title: Corrections
description: A capsule front-page summary and a sports article in some editions yesterday about the Chicago Bulls-Miami Heat basketball playoff game misstated the score. The Bulls won, 100-87.

title: New Daily News Section
description: In the latest move by its new editor, Pete Hamill, to liven up its pages, The Daily News plans to unveil a new entertainment and lifestyle section on Sunday that will feature more consumer-oriented news for women, young readers and immigrants.

title: Frail Species, Endangered But Surviving
description: YES, Books & Company will close tomorrow, but don't despair. Don't believe everything you read. The independent bookstore is still with us. Endangered species that it may be, fragile as its balance sheets most surely are, there are still stores that are not mega, rooms with soft lighting, with salespeople who make recommendations to customers they recognize. The local bookstore, with a tempting selection of poetry, an idiosyncratic mixture of scholarly texts and literary criticism, is still with us. The big chains threaten, loom, offer you cappuccino, let writers read to their public, and are frequently just across the street, but they haven't driven the last nail in the coffin.

title: An Endorsement Dilemma Puts Messinger in a Bind
description: Ruth W. Messinger found herself in a political crossfire yesterday between two of her major constituencies -- blacks and homosexuals -- over whether she would endorse a lesbian or a black candidate running to succeed her as Manhattan Borough President.

title: Euonym for Rebecca: A Woman of Letters
description: Spelling, for Rebecca A. Sealfon, is systematic and serious business.

title: Pettitte Feels Insulted by Irabu Deal
description: Andy Pettitte initially stammered in responding to a question regarding how he felt about the Yankees signing the Japanese pitcher Hideki Irabu to a $12.8 million contract. Pettitte has privately been angered about the financial treatment he has received from the Yankees and expressed his displeasure to General Manager Bob Watson before the season.

title: Companies Flex New Muscle and Labor Feels the Pinch
description: For Kostas Sinis, the dream of reviving the Kassandra mines was like a vision of returning to past glory. The mines, after all, have been operating for more than 2,000 years, since the days of Alexander the Great, yielding a variety of metals, from silver to zinc. But they also contain gold, and Mr. Sinis and his Canadian mining company invested heavily to get it out.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about the manslaughter conviction of a New York City police officer, Paolo Colechia, misstated the history of homicide convictions of city police officers. It was not the first such conviction since 1977; in 1995 a housing police officer was convicted of criminally negligent homicide.

title: Making Workfare Work
description: The Clinton Administration has ruled that Federal law requires states to pay welfare enrollees in workfare slots benefits at least equal to the minimum wage. The ruling is correct legally. But it also threatens states by raising the cost of each workfare slot and by making workfare an attractive alternative to private-sector jobs. The danger is that some states will cut families off welfare rather than pay out higher benefits. Unless Congress makes imaginative adjustments, the decision could do many welfare enrollees more harm than good.

title: City Opera Drops 'Esther' From Its Fall Season
description: The New York City Opera announced yesterday that costs and technical problems had forced the postponement of Hugo Weisgall's ''Esther,'' which was originally scheduled for four performances during the company's fall season.

title: A Case of Vinous Excess
description: I just bought a bottle of wine. I almost paid $4,810 for it. I don't normally go that high. I always say that paying more than $13 for any bottle of wine is showing off. It's only wine, right?

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL 3-6

title: Donaldson Unit's Duane Reade Stake
description: A Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette Inc. unit has taken a $350 million stake in the Duane Reade Holding Corporation, becoming the largest shareholder in the drugstore chain.

title: Good Riddance to a Cloistered Port Authority
description: To the Editor:

title: Giuliani Enlists 'Latino' Backer Who Doesn't Quite Fit the Bill
description: Ever since Fernando Ferrer dropped out of the mayor's race, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani has been aggressively courting Hispanic voters with a series of news conferences on the steps of City Hall featuring endorsements from prominent Hispanic New Yorkers, preferably Democrats.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEHMANN, MANFRED R., DR.
description: LEHMANN-Manfred R., Dr. Beloved husband of Sara Anne. Cherished father of the late Jamie, Barbie and Yitzchok Siegel, Karie and David Eisner, and Marcia Herschmann. Adored grandfather of Russie, Jackie, Joshie, and Jason. Survived by his dear brothers Bert and Erik Lehmann. Oh, how the mighty have fallen! Your family and all of Israel have lost a wonderous champion, great scholar and true Ohev Am Yisrael. You are survived by legions of loved ones, friends and admirers. The Lord has given; the Lord has taken away; praised be the name of the Lord. Services tonight, 9:30 PM at Riverside Memorial Chapels, 76th Street & Amsterdam Avenue, NYC. Burial in Har HaMenuchot, Jerusalem. May flights of angels sing thee to thy rest.

title: INSIDE
description: From Welfare to Work

title: INSIDE METRO
description: LEARNING AT HOME The winner of the national spelling bee is among the growing number of children who are taught at home. Page 23.

title: Intel Says It's Having a Weak Spell and Its Stock Swoons
description: Shares of the Intel Corporation plummeted today after the company said that its second-quarter results would fall below its own and Wall Street's expectations. Intel attributed the shortfall to weaker-than-expected demand for its Pentium processors, especially in Europe.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: 2 Babies and Youth Die in Fire; Tenant Is Held
description: Two babies and a teen-ager died in an early-morning fire today, and another tenant in the house was charged with setting the blaze, apparently in anger over a dispute with her landlady.

title: Man at Heart of Megan's Law Convicted of Her Grisly Murder
description: Jesse K. Timmendequas, charged with the horrific murder that spurred a national effort to protect children from sexual predators, was convicted today of all the charges against him in the death of 7-year-old Megan Kanka.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  SCHWARTZ, HARRY
description: SCHWARTZ-Harry. Happy Birthday, Harry. You are loved and missed. Nancy

title: Jimmy Stewart Honored
description: With a screening of ''It's a Wonderful Life'' and four other film classics, Princeton University honored the movie actor Jimmy Stewart yesterday by dedicating its campus film theater in his name.

title: Fleet Plans Service Center
description: Fleet Financial Group Inc. will build a regional service center in a vacated factory building and has promised to hire 2,000 people in the next five years. Fleet will acquire a factory formerly used by the pen manufacturer, A. T. Cross Company, in Lincoln, R.I. State officials offered the bank incentives, including new bank legislation and an agreement to issue $10 million in taxable bonds to help pay for the land, building and improvements.

title: Yanks Expect Irabu to Join Rotation in Early July
description: Hideki Irabu, the most talked about nonplayer of the baseball season, will become a member of the Yankees' starting pitching rotation either just before or just after the All-Star Game in July, club officials indicated yesterday.

title: Maria Weigl Piers, 85, Authority On the Social Growth of Children
description: Maria Weigl Piers, an authority on psychosocial development in childhood and founder of the Erikson Institute for Advanced Study in Child Development in Chicago, died on May 21 at her home in Chicago. She was 85.

title: John W. Livingston, 88, Official Of Auto Union and A.F.L.-C.I.O.
description: John W. Livingston, the first organizing director of the A.F.L-C.I.O. and a longtime senior official in the United Automobile Workers, died on May 25 in Westphalia, Mo. He was 88.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEVINSON, GRACE
description: LEVINSON-Grace, age 90, died on May 29th, 1997 after a brief illness. Devoted teacher at Morris High School in the Bronx for 35 years and member of the United Federation of Teachers executive board. Avid tennis player and world traveler. She will be missed by her sister-in-law, Lillian Levinson, formerly of NY, grand-nephew, Jonathan Adolph of MA, two grand-nieces, Janis Jordan of MA and Alison Adolph of NY, and her cousin, Susan Pollack of NY. Funeral services will be held at Riverside Chapel, 76th St. and Amsterdam Ave., on Sunday, June 1, at 10:45 AM. In lieu of flowers, donations to the Jewish Labor Committee Holocaust Education Fund.

title: Pope Returns Today to His Changed Polish Home
description: As Pope John Paul II arrives in his Polish homeland on Saturday for his longest and what may be his valedictory pilgrimage, the political and religious stakes are higher than at any time since his stirring visits in the late 1970's and 80's gave strength to the Solidarity movement.

title: Four Teen-Agers Indicted in Rape At Queens School
description: Announcing the indictment of four high school seniors on charges of raping a classmate in a Queens school last month, District Attorney Richard A. Brown assailed school officials yesterday for delaying a month in reporting the crime and joined Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's persistent call for greater Police Department involvement in providing school security.

title: For Flyer Fans, a Red Scare Has Returned
description: In the milky sunshine of lunch hour, a crowd gathered outside City Hall today for a rally. Among the speakers: the Mayor and talk-show hosts from the radio station that broadcasts the event. One broadcaster drew a roar from the mob by denouncing the ''rotten Communist stinking-dog Russians.''

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  EDELMAN, HILDA W.
description: EDELMAN-Hilda W. Diva hera. Always with us. Mort, Diana, Robert, Nancy, Alex

title: By Hook or by Crook, a Fishing Village Gets By
description: This fishing village is authentic; it has been here so long that the Wagenias boast that they were the first Africans to know how to swim. But because its nets extend into the famous Stanley Falls and because it is right next to Congo's third-largest city, Kisangani, it is also something of a national monument.

title: Bombing Trial Goes to Jurors With Caveats From Judge
description: As Timothy J. McVeigh watched, pale and still, his hands clenched under his chin, the judge in the Oklahoma City bombing trial sent the case to the jury this morning, warning, ''You are not to be swayed by sympathy.''

title: A Good Deal For Yankees, No Question
description: HIDEKI Irabu finally became a New York Yankee yesterday, with no number on the back of the pinstriped jersey he modeled but with a $12.8 million price tag attached to the sleeve. Which raised probing and pertinent questions from the American portion of the attending news media, such as: Is Irabu worth it? And, does he like hot dogs?

title: ELF ENDS BRITISH MERGER TALKS WITH CHEVRON
description: Elf Aquitaine S.A., the French oil company, said yesterday that it had broken off talks with the Chevron Corporation to merge their refining and service station business in Britain. ''The two parties considered that the planned merger would not provide sufficient savings,'' Elf's chairman, Philippe Jaffre, said at the annual shareholders meeting. Gulf Oil (Great Britain) Ltd., a British unit of Chevron, will now review other alternatives, including the sale of its British refining and marketing operations. Elf, Chevron and the Murphy Oil Corporation had said in November that they would merge their British fuel businesses, which would bring up to 500 job cuts, save $:50 million, or $82.4 million, a year and close Chevron's Gulf Oil refinery in Wales. Murphy withdrew in March.

title: Crane Mishap Derails Train
description: A military crane being transported by a Conrail freight train struck an overpass yesterday morning, pulling it down and derailing 8 of the train's 154 cars, officials said. There were no injuries, and the track, which is not used for passenger traffic, was expected to be cleared by this morning, Robert Libkind, a spokesman for Conrail, said.

title: COMPUTER DATA TO BUY ANALYTICAL SYSTEMS
description: Computer Data Systems Inc. agreed yesterday to buy the privately held Analytical Systems Engineering Corporation of Burlington, Mass., for about $51 million in cash and stock. Computer Data Systems, of Rockville, Md., provides data processing support services. Analytical Systems provides engineering and technical services to intelligence agencies and Department of Defense agencies. Computer Data said the purchase price would be paid 90 percent in cash and 10 percent in stock valued at $27.50 a share.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GILLEN, ROSE R.
description: GILLEN-Rose R., 85, a retired hospital administration specialist and civic volunteer, died at home in the Boulevard Gardens, Woodside, Queens, on May 29, 1997 after a long illness. The widow of the late Patrick A. Gillen, a former officer of Local 15 of the Operating Engineers and a well known professional boxer in the 1920's, she recently retired from Western Queens, Community Hospital following 32 years of service. During her 40 year career in hospital administration she was employed at Forest Hills General Hospital, Lexington Hospital, and Triborough Hospital. At Western Queens Community Hospital she was instrumental in the organization of the union and served as a Delegate to District 37. The daughter of James McPartland and Anna Whalen and the sister of the late Anne Dooley, she was born in Manhattan and raised in Queens. Mrs. Gillen was an original resident of the Boulevard Gardens where she organized Brownie Troop 207, was instrumental in the formation of the Cub Scout Pack 127, and served as the Leader of Girl Scout Troop 4-504. When two of her daughters were stricken in the polio epidemic of 1948 she became the Queens County Campaign Manager for the March of Dimes and she led the effort to readmit recovering polio victims into the public and parochial schools from which they had been banned. She is survived by four children: Neal P. Gillen, an attorney and trade association executive of Potomac, Maryland, Carol Gillen-Costello, the Principal of P.S. 161 in the Bronx, of Woodside; Rose Collins, a supervisory nurse, of Purdys, NY; and James R. Gillen, an attorney, of Marina Del Rey, California; a daughter Patricia Sutherland Dermody is deceased; eleven grandchildren and ten great grandchildren. A funeral mass will be celebrated 10:00 AM, June 2, 1997 at Corpus Christi Roman Catholic Church in Woodside followed by interment at Maple Grove Cemetery in Kew Gardens. Reposing at the Thomas M. Quinn & Sons Inc. F.H. Visting Saturday and Sunday 2-5 and 7-9:30.

title: Bout of Malaise? Even Clergy Have to Get a Life
description: To the Editor:

title: Center Will Coordinate Plane Crash Information
description: An airline disaster center will be established in New York City by the end of the year to collect and release information nationwide to victims' families and the public, the National Transportation Safety Board announced yesterday.

title: Works on Jewish Themes In a Religous Sanctuary
description: The Avodah Dance Ensemble united the sacred with the secular on Wednesday night. The Jersey City-based troupe, directed by JoAnne Tucker, specializes in dances on Jewish themes that can be presented in theaters or houses of worship. The sanctuary of the Hebrew Union College-Jewish Institute of Religion, a high, wide hall with walls of light wood that help make it look radiant, is used for concerts as well as for religious services. It was a fine setting for Avodah.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHERMAN, FLORENCE
description: SHERMAN-Florence. Of Lake Worth, Florida, formerly of Eastchester, NY. passed away on May 29, 1997. She was the loving mother of Jay Sherman, Scott (Jolie) Sherman and Terri (William) Duff. Cherished grandmother of Michael, Margaux, Jennifer, Mark, Elizabeth and Madeleine. Graveside services will held on Sunday, June 1, 1997 at 1:00 PM at Mount Ararat Cemetery in Farmingdale, New York, (516-957-2277).

title: A Cellist Unearths A Rarity
description: String players in major orchestras are supposed to be frustrated souls who yearn for successful solo careers. The cellist Carter Brey shows how untrue this assumption can be.

title: Guilty in 'Megan' Case
description: Jesse K. Timmendequas was convicted yesterday of all the charges against him in the death of 7-year-old Megan Kanka.

title: Police Intensify Search For Killer of Girl
description: The hunt for the killer of Wu Quin-Rong, the 11-year-old girl from the Lower East Side, intensified yesterday as the police interrogated two dozen men and searched the city streets for other suspects.

title: Lawmakers Reject the Governor's Plan for a Sweeping Overhaul
description: When Gov. George W. Bush proposed a sweeping restructuring of the unwieldy tax code in Texas earlier this year, he pledged to spare no effort to get his bill enacted. ''I've got a lot of capital to spend,'' he said, ''and I'm going to spend every dime of it.'' To legislators, he was even more blunt, telling one, ''I'm going to kick some butts to get this thing passed.''

title: Retiring to the South
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEE, BENJAMIN
description: LEE-Benjamin. Temple Israel of New Rochelle records with sorrow the death of its cherished member and extends its heartfelt sympathy to the family. Amiel Wohl, Rabbi

title: Mexico's Obdurate Ruling Party
description: Mexicans vote in July for a new Congress, six state governors and, for the first time, an elected mayor of Mexico City. Despite years of modest electoral reforms, it is still not clear whether the voting will mark a real step toward pluralist democracy or repeat the pattern of manipulation and outright fraud by the ruling Institutional Revolutionary Party, or PRI, that has tainted so many past Mexican elections.

title: Convict Injures His Guards
description: Minutes after being convicted of murder yesterday morning, a city man attacked guards and sheriff's officers at the Essex County Jail and sent four to the hospital, The Associated Press reported.

title: Chip News Stuns Market, But Stocks Make Recovery
description: Stocks staged a remarkable recovery from an early tumble yesterday and ended little changed.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SAROFSKY, MIRIAM
description: SAROFSKY-Miriam. Temple Hillel North Woodmere L.I. records with profound sorrow the demise of Miriam Sarofsky and extend sincere condolences to her beloved daughter Doris Richgat and the entire family. Dr. Alan F. Lavin, Rabbi Paul Kaye, President

title: Mlicki's Dry Spell As Starter Is Over
description: If all good things must come to an end, it follows that some of the bad ones must go, too. Twenty months 11 days; 14 starts, including 10 this season: That is how long it had been since Dave Mlicki had won a start before he took the mound for the Mets last night at Shea Stadium against the hapless Philadelphia Phillies.

title: Life Sentence To Be Sought In Cosby Case
description: Los Angeles County prosecutors said today that they would not seek the death penalty against the teen-ager charged with murdering the comedian Bill Cosby's son.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHEPARD, RICHARD
description: SHEPARD-Richard. Beloved husband of Susan. Devoted father of Alexandra, Stephanie, Lee and Jody. Loving grandfather. Cherished brother. Caring friend and compassionate uncle. Graveside services Sunday, June 1, 1997, 2PM, Mt. Pleasant Cemetery, Valhalla, NY.

title: Company Briefs
description: PAPERBOARD INDUSTRIES INTERNATIONAL INC., Montreal, a maker of boxboard and packaging products, will buy Stora Kopparbergs Bergslags A.B.'s paperboard mill in Arnsberg, Germany, for about $43.4 million.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  KOPLIK, KENNETH E.
description: KOPLIK-Kenneth E., May 31,1996. One year has passed since you left us. You were the laughter in our hearts and the substance of our souls. How blessed we were to have shared your life and your love. Wherever we go and whatever we do, you will always be with us. Your spirit continues to inspire us and give us strength. We will cherish your memory all the days of our lives. Diane and David

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GALLAGHER, MARY T. (NEE REYNOLDS)
description: GALLAGHER-Mary T. (nee Reynolds). Beloved mother of William and Maureen, cherished grandmother of Elizabeth, Dawn, Sean and Matthew, reposing Vanella's Chapels, 29 Madison St., NYC, until Monday, 9:30 am. Mass of the Resurrection at St Mary's Church, 10 am, visitation Saturday and Sunday, 2:00-5:00 and 7:00 to 9:00 pm.

title: Johnson-Bailey Race On
description: Two days before a race between Michael Johnson and Donovan Bailey designed to determine the world's fastest man, the event's promoter stood today and made an extraordinary statement.

title: Corrections
description: A report in the When Money Counts column yesterday about buying name brand and designer wallpaper at a discount misstated the telephone number for Fabulous Wallcoverings in West Orange, N.J. It is (201) 673-2220.

title: Lots of Dollars Chasing a $70 Million State Lottery Dream
description: Worried that television ads cluttered with yachts and limos might be sending the wrong message, Gov. George E. Pataki asked state lottery officials last year to tone down their enticing ''Hey, you never know'' pitch. The ads should avoid raising unrealistic expectations, he said, and should stress that the lottery's primary purpose is to raise money for education.

title: New Stances in Tobacco Talks Are Reported to Imperil Them
description: Landmark tobacco negotiations are headed for a showdown next week, with frustrated cigarette companies now calling on state attorneys general to provide them firm settlement proposals just as state officials have stiffened their position on legal protection for the industry.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HEFLER, LEO
description: HEFLER-Leo. Beloved husband of the late Sophie. Loving father of Stephen and Elliott (Gail). Devoted grandfather of Jonathan, Laurie and Scott. Service Sunday 10 A.M. ''Parkside'' Chapels, Queens Boulevard, at 66th Avenue, Forest Hills, New York.

title: Red Sox Roll As Vaughn Hits 3 Homers
description: This was not the night to be a 24-year-old right-hander for the Yankees. This was not the night to be named Ramiro Mendoza or Danny Rios. This was not the night to be on the mound tossing juicy pitches to Mo Vaughn, Wil Cordero, Troy O'Leary and Scott Hatteberg. This was more like a nightmare at Fenway Park.

title: Widow Called Terror Victim
description: She was an 84-year-old widow who was hospitalized with a stroke, so she gave Paramus officials her house keys and asked them to remove two parakeets. But an animal control supervisor also helped himself to a mint-condition 1966 Cadillac DeVille parked in the widow's garage, prosecutors said yesterday.

title: 4 Robbins Works, Without Overlap
description: Four of the many faces of Jerome Robbins were on view on Wednesday night at the New York State Theater when the New York City Ballet paid tribute to the distinguished choreographer with an all-Robbins program. The evening began with Mr. Robbins in an uncharacteristically sugary but charming mood, in his 1972 ''Circus Polka.'' Created for the company's first Stravinsky Festival, the ballet fills the stage with 48 cavorting little girls and a ringmaster, played here by Robert La Fosse as a genial, proud young uncle.

title: Spinning on 2 Wheels of Fortune
description: A SHOP class at Omar Azam's school looks as if the Tour de France took a deconstructionist detour into Brooklyn. The room is filled with tires, rims and frames as well as some intact bicycles that appear to have emerged miraculously from this primordial mass of metal and rubber.

title: Judge Rejects Claim Of Age Discrimination
description: A State Supreme Court judge yesterday ruled against 60 Police Academy candidates who claimed discrimination because they were denied admission because of their age.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BERNSTEIN, SIDNEY H.
description: BERNSTEIN-Sidney H. In Hollywood, Fla. Beloved husband of 69 years to Stella. Devoted father of Richard and Sonny, Mark and Arlene and David and Pat. Adored papa of grandchildren Lori and Robert, Brad and Emily, Michael and Jeffrey and great grandchildren, Russell and Abby. If you so desire, the family would appreciate contributions to the American Heart Association.

title: Value of Low Wages
description: To the Editor:

title: IVAX IN PACT TO SELL UNIT TO GERMAN CONCERN
description: The Ivax Corporation, a generic drug maker, said yesterday that it had agreed to sell its McGaw Inc. subsidiary to B. Braun Melsungen A.G. of Germany for about $320 million. McGaw, based in Irvine, Calif., makes intravenous medical devices and products. Ivax said the unit had revenues of about $343 million in 1996 and operating income of about $23 million. The Miami-based Ivax said it would use the cash payment to pay off its existing revolving credit lines. Ivax said B. Braun might make additional payments, up to a total of $80 million, contingent upon the combined operating results of McGaw and B. Braun's principal United States operating unit, B. Braun Medical Inc.

title: Bridge
description: The Old Guard of New York bridge players has faded away, and a group of young upstarts has taken over. Roy Welland, Christal Henner-Welland, Elizabeth Reich and Brad Moss of Manhattan, Lapt Chan of Forest Hills, Queens, and Jon Heller of Brooklyn, whose average age is 33, battled to victory Monday in the final of the Reisinger Knockout Team Championship. In the 68-year history of the event, they are apparently the youngest winners.

title: Question of an English Test for a Diploma Bounces From Campus to the Courts
description: The battle over whether more than 125 Hostos Community College students can graduate went from the campus to the courts yesterday as first the students and then the school administrators won court victories.

title: A Boy Is Killed, and All Japan Is Stunned
description: The news story that has riveted Japan for the last few days has nothing to do with the normal dose of scandal and politics, but with an 11-year-old boy who was beheaded in a case that has set off alarm and soul-searching nationwide.

title: Corrections
description: The Advertising column on the Media Business page on Thursday about a national campaign for Roundup, a weed killer made by the Monsanto Company, misattributed an opinion that the product is environmentally safe. It appeared in an article in Audubon magazine; the Audubon Society itself takes no position on the product.

title: With Pippen Iffy, Bulls Are Still Confident
description: Karl Malone's bulging biceps and John Stockton's deft hands remain their primary roadblocks. But in their drive toward five titles in seven years, Scottie Pippen's left foot could also impede the Chicago Bulls.

title: Sampras and Muster Exit in Paris
description: The third-round schedule seemed harmless enough at first glance: two venerable but vulnerable titans, champions both, were pitted against two blithe spoilers barely out of their teens. But veterans beware.

title: Slovenia Discards the Yoke That Was Yugoslavia
description: A group of soldiers seated under a clump of trees, with drooping ferns tucked into the bands of their helmets, called out coordinates to companions manning four old Soviet-style mortars.

title: Keep U.N. Troops in Angola
description: At an age when American children want to become sports heroes, movie stars or President, 11-year-old Maria of Kuito, Angola, has a different ambition: She wants to defuse mines.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KENT, HELEN S.
description: KENT-Helen S. Of Staten Island, on May 30, 1997. Wife of the late William. Loving mother of Helen Halleran, Agnes and William P. Kent. Dear sister Edward Shoub. Also survived by 4 grandchildren. Reposing Harmon Home for Funerals, 571 Forest Ave, Staten Island, Sunday, 2-4 and 7-9 PM. Mass of Christian Burial, Saint Peter's Church, Staten Island, on Monday, 9:45 AM. Interment, Holy Cross Cemetery, Brooklyn.

title: Literary Splendor Among the Sheep
description: Nine years ago, when he was trying to organize the second annual Hay Festival of Literature, Peter Florence, the festival director, telephoned Arthur Miller and brashly invited him to take part.

title: Sweeter Deal Sought For Coke Bottling Unit
description: The San Miguel Corporation of the Philippines is renegotiating the sale of its Coke bottling unit to Coca-Cola Amatil Ltd. of Australia, the Australian company said yesterday. San Miguel has asked Coca-Cola Amatil to give it an additional board seat and reconsider the value of the stock swap, which would create the world's largest Coke bottler outside the United States.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  O'BRIEN, ROYALL D.
description: O'BRIEN-Royall D. On May 30, 1997 at age 70. Beloved husband of Sally, loving father of Morgan Coffey and Sarah Tierney. He is also survived by eight grandchildren, his mother Isabel B. O'Brien and a brother Peter B. O'Brien. His humor and warm heart will be deeply missed. In lieu of flowers donations can be sent to The Family Center, 40 Arch Street, Greenwich, CT 06831. Funeral services will be at Saint Michaels Church, North Street at 11AM, on Monday. No calling hours.

title: Harnisch Makes Appearance
description: Pete Harnisch was at Shea Stadium yesterday, and that represented great progress for the Mets pitcher in his treatment for depression. He was given clearance to rejoin the team on a daily basis, including road trips, and to start on a throwing program.

title: Peru's Congress Is Assailed Over Its Removal of Judges
description: Peru's Congress came under sharp criticism today from Western diplomats, human rights groups and business and political leaders for its decision on Thursday to oust three members of a constitutional court who ruled that President Alberto K. Fujimori could not seek a third consecutive term.

title: Beliefs
description: ''He came preaching and teaching, and he left preaching and teaching,'' said the Rev. Jesse Jackson on Thursday when they buried the Rev. Samuel DeWitt Proctor from Abyssinian Baptist Church in Harlem. A week earlier Dr. Proctor had suffered a fatal heart attack while lecturing to college students in Iowa.

title: In Search of Gratitude
description: To the Editor:

title: Religion of Convenience
description: To the Editor:

title: Russia Aide Cuts Ties to Harvard Center That Ousted Advisers
description: The architect of Russia's economic reform program, Deputy Prime Minister Anatoly B. Chubais, said today that he would stop working with the Harvard institute that had lent him its brightest economists to assist Russia's rocky transition to a market system.

title: Where Is the Dignity?
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ADLER, KURT A., MD, PHD
description: ADLER-Kurt A., MD, Phd. The Advanced Institute for Analytic Psychotherapy and the Advanced Center for Psychotherapy note with sadness the passing of our esteemed colleague, Dr. Kurt Adler. For many years he was President and Dean of Psychiatric Studies of the Institute and Medical Director of the Advanced Center. He was a teacher, a healer and a wise mentor. He was loved and will be missed. Our condolences to Tanya and his family.

title: Some Provisions Softened In Family Welfare Accord
description: Two years after Connecticut imposed the nation's shortest time limit on family welfare benefits, lawmakers have agreed to soften a provision that could have ended assistance to up to a tenth of the state's families on welfare.

title: Man Is Shot to Death As He Flees Carjacker
description: A man whose car was hijacked in the Bronx was shot to death yesterday evening after he jumped from the moving vehicle in an apparent attempt to flee his assailant, the police said.

title: New Investigations of Harassment in the Military
description: A two-star admiral who heads the Navy's supply system is under investigation for possible sexual harassment, a Pentagon official said tonight.

title: New Murder Trial Granted To Former Black Panther
description: When an Orange County judge decided on Thursday to order a new trial for Elmer Pratt, a former Black Panther convicted 25 years ago of murder, he left the Los Angeles County District Attorney grappling with ugly legal and political issues that trace all the way back to the turbulent era of Vietnam, Watergate and Black Power.

title: Allegations of Vote-Rigging Abound in Indonesia
description: JAKARTA  The main Indonesian opposition party, an election monitoring group and U.S. officials on Friday accused the government of holding undemocratic elections and engaging in extensive vote-rigging.

title: William McNichols, 87; Led Denver Boom in 70's
description: William Henry McNichols Jr., who as Mayor of Denver for 14 years helped transform the city from a somewhat stodgy and out-of-the-way regional center into a booming metropolis, died on Thursday at his home in Denver. He was 87.

title: U.S. Marines Evacuate 900 In Freetown
description: Ignoring an order by Sierra Leone's new military authorities closing all borders, United States Marines landed today in Freetown, the country's capital, and evacuated hundreds of foreigners fleeing looting and violence that followed an armed coup on Sunday.

title: 2 Morons Who Can Defeat Even Lady Luck
description: With Joe Pesci and Danny Glover as bait, Hollywood Pictures is trolling for dollars aboard a new comedy called ''Gone Fishin' .'' It's a sinker.

title: Price Decrease For Used Autos Reverses Trend
description: After rising briskly for four years, prices for used cars have begun to fall, and the effects are rippling through the auto industry.

title: J. Rembrandt George, Creator Of Idea of Taxi Ads, Dies at 73
description: J. Rembrandt George, an advertising executive who was instrumental in introducing the elongated, pyramid-like plasticized billboards that sit on top of many of New York City's taxicabs, died on May 23 at St. Anthony's Hospital in Warwick, N.Y., after a brief illness, his daughter, Linda George, said. He was 73 and lived in nearby Florida, N.Y.

title: Special Education Practices In New York Faulted by U.S.
description: The Federal Government last night warned New York City school officials that they must reduce the disproportionately high numbers of black and Hispanic students in special-education programs or face a lawsuit and ultimately the revocation of tens of millions of dollars in Federal aid.

title: Wooing and Cooing in a Magical Forest
description: To celebrate its 25th anniversary, the Acting Company chose ''As You Like It,'' no doubt hoping some of the magic from Shakespeare's Forest of Arden would rub off, and enlisted as director Liviu Ciulei, who has been known to provide some sorcery of his own, not to mention controversy, in his stagings of the classics for the Arena Stage in Washington, the Guthrie in Minneapolis and the Public Theater here.

title: Dinosaurs as They Really Were
description: While record crowds flock into Steven Spielberg's latest dinosaur thriller, the American Museum of Natural History has opened a temporary exhibit that tries to exploit the movie's popularity while deflating its more dubious speculations.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: Baseball

title: Dr. Kurt Alfred Adler, 92; Directed Therapeutic Institute
description: Kurt Alfred Adler, a therapist who spent a career seeking to put into practice the novel approach to psychotherapy of his father, Alfred Adler, the Viennese psychiatrist, and to extend its reach, died on Wednesday at Lenox Hill Hospital. He was 92 and lived in Manhattan.

title: Upbringing Of Killer Is Portrayed As Harrowing
description: Until now, Jesse Timmendequas, for all his notoriety, has remained a somewhat obscure figure, known only for his history as a pedophile.

title: U.S. Refits a Nuclear Bomb To Destroy Enemy Bunkers
description: For the first time since the fall of the Berlin Wall, the United States has put a nuclear weapon with new capabilities into the field, a ''bunker buster'' designed to destroy underground factories or laboratories while causing relatively little surface damage.

title: Wait Ends for Malone and Stockton
description: The power forward had the trainer mark his sneakers. Either they will go back on his feet or up on a mantel, but the size 17's were stamped with a ''K.M.'' and boxed -- as if anyone else could walk in those shoes.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BROWN, LILLIAN
description: BROWN-Lillian. Age 93, on May 30 in Miami Beach, FL. Founder and owner of Brown's Hotel, Loch Sheldrake, NY. Loving mother of Lonnie Rowley of West Palm Beach, FL. Beloved sister of Jean Harrison of Clifton, New Jersey. Devoted grandmother of Bruce Turiansky, Boca Raton, FL., Wayne Turiansky, Shelburne, VT and Cliff Turian of New Milford, CT., and six great grandchildren. Services Sunday, 11 A.M., Garlick Funeral Chapel, Monticello, N.Y.

title: Live From New York
description: ''Hey, hey, hey, hey, wake up, sleepyheads! It's Morning in America! Saturday Morning in America!''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BERNE, SELMA
description: BERNE-Selma. To my most cherished and courageous friend Selma. Whose love of life and golf will forever be in our hearts. Deepest sympathy to Karen, Elliot and family. Claire, Linda, Michael, Marcia, Suzy

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WALTNER, JULES, M.D.
description: WALTNER-Jules, M.D. A dear old friend and brilliant clinician. We will miss him. Eva and Raffaele Lattes

title: Disputed Penalty Paves the Way to MetroStars' Defeat
description: A hand ball committed by the MetroStars in the 57th minute gave the Revolution a penalty kick and propelled it to a 3-1 victory tonight at Foxboro Stadium.

title: Peru's Cut-Rate Fighter Jets Were Too Good to Be True
description: Call it a case of bargain-hunter's remorse.

title: Australian Oenophiles
description: To the Editor:

title: Giants' Ellsworth Back After Disappearing Act
description: Of all the players on the Giants' roster, Percy Ellsworth is one of the most conscientious, hard-working and intelligent. Yet something happened recently that raised questions about the safety's reliability. It appears to have shaken up Ellsworth as well.

title: Corrections
description: A brief report in the ''On Stage, and Off'' column on May 23 about New York Stage and Film's summer season at Vassar College included an incorrect name supplied by the program's publicity agent for the writer of the company's new play, ''Defying Gravity.'' It is by Jane Anderson, not Amsterdam.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HOWARD, MARILYN
description: HOWARD-Marilyn. Temple BethEl of Great Neck records with profound sorrow the passing of its long time member. We extend heartfelt sympathy to her bereaved family. Shelley M. Limmer, President Jerome K. Davidson, Rabbi

title: Corrections
description: A critic's notebook article on Tuesday about a discussion of Allan Bloom's ''Closing of the American Mind'' at the John M. Olin Center at the University of Chicago misstated the profession of a participant, Harvey C. Mansfield. He is a political scientist, not a historian.

title: The 4:49 to Port Jefferson: A Sporadic Promise of Modernity
description: Riders on the Long Island Rail Road's exotic-looking 4:49 P.M. train to Port Jefferson have seen the future of commuting, and they say it works. At least sometimes it works.

title: 'Megan's Laws' Face Court Challenges
description: Few crimes have resonated like the savage rape and murder of 7-year-old Megan Kanka.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Thursday about a round-the-world flight along Amelia Earhart's route misidentified the pilot in the first previous re-enactment. She was Ann Pellegreno, who completed Earhart's route in 1967. Geraldine Mock, who flew a single-engine plane around the planet in 1964, did not follow Earhart's flight path.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STRONG, JAMES
description: STRONG-James. In loving memory of my sweetheart, gifts to the American Brain Tumor Association, 2720 River Road, Des Plaines, IL. 60018-4110, would be deeply appreciated. Age B. Diedrick

title: Officer Got No Support From P.B.A., Lawyer Says
description: The lawyer for a transit police officer convicted of manslaughter Thursday for shooting an unarmed suspect in the back on a subway platform said yesterday that fellow officers and the police union had failed to show support for his client during the trial, and that this may have subtly harmed his case.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SIEGEL, JANE B.
description: SIEGEL-Jane B. On May 29 of Roslyn Heights. Loving wife of the late Harry J. Beloved mother of Valerie Manterfield, Pamela Filaski and Barbara Trottier. Also survived by six grandchildren. Family will receive friends at the Roslyn Heights Funeral Home, 75 Mineola Ave., Roslyn Heights, Sunday 2-4 and 7-9 P.M. Memorial service Monday 10 a.m. at the Community Church of East Williston, NY (N.W. corner of Hillside Avenue and Roslyn Road). Donations to MakeA-Wish Foundation, 382 Main Street, Port Washington, NY 11050

title: A Fighting Principle
description: To the Editor:

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Recovering From a Tumble, The Dow Average Edges Up

title: Y Cancels Opera Premiere
description: The premiere of ''Lilith,'' an opera by the American composer Deborah Drattell scheduled for Tuesday night at the Dicapo Opera Theater on East 84th Street, has been canceled because of a contractual dispute with Local 802 of the American Federation of Musicians.

title: List of Charges In 'Megan' Case
description: Jesse K. Timmendequas faced an eight-count indictment. He was convicted on all charges. These are the convictions.

title: Monetary Union at Risk In Italy's Flat Economy
description: Italy's economy ground to a halt in the first quarter, threatening the nation's hopes for entry into European monetary union and probably causing the Government to call for a cut in interest rates. The world's fifth-largest economy shrank three-tenths of 1 percent in the three months ended in March from the previous quarter and five-tenths of 1 percent in the year, according to a preliminary report of gross domestic product released by the statistics bureau Istat.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RAPPAPORT, REBECCA LYNN
description: RAPPAPORT-Rebecca Lynn. On May 29, 1997. Of Orange, Connecticut. A true loss for many friends and family.

title: The C.I.A.'s Foreign Policy
description: This week the Central Intelligence Agency revealed that it had destroyed almost all its files related to its secret mission in 1953 to overthrow the Government of Iran. Documents about other major covert operations may also have been destroyed long ago.

title: No Headline
description: ''Now we shall eat bread, like Americans. We shall have one goat for one person. Even one cow for one person, like America! We shall be very full -- like Mike Tyson!''

title: Judging Managed Care
description: To the Editor:

title: Clintons' Counsel Keeps His Own
description: Across the four years that he has been defending the Clintons in the grueling Whitewater investigations, David E. Kendall has kept a close eye on another, more lucrative client given to stirring scandals at a phenomenal rate: the weekly tabloid National Enquirer.

title: QUALCOMM EXPECTS SALES FROM JOINT VENTURE TO FALL
description: Qualcomm Inc. expects sales from its joint wireless-phone venture with the Sony Corporation to fall in the second half of the fiscal year amid slowing demand in the wireless industry during the summer. The company said late on Thursday that it would cut 600 temporary workers at the venture because of the summer slowdown. Qualcomm also plans to stop producing its current phone models this summer and introduce new models using its code-division multiple access, or C.D.M.A., digital call-transmission technology. Qualcomm shares fell $5.125, or 9 percent, to $48.25, in Nasdaq trading of almost 6.4 million shares yesterday.

title: Treasury Prices Move Higher, Aided by Foreign Purchases
description: Treasury prices ended higher yesterday, bolstered by economic reports that showed no unwelcome surprises for the bond market and also aided by overseas buying and comments by a Federal Reserve official.

title: GOLDMAN, SACHS FUND TO ACQUIRE INTEGRATED LIVING
description: Integrated Living Communities Inc. agreed yesterday to be acquired by a Goldman, Sachs & Company fund for $11.50 a share, or $77 million, and to join forces with another operator of retirement homes. Shares of Integrated, based in Bonita Springs, Fla., rose $2.0625, to $11.125, in Nasdaq trading. After the deal is completed, Integrated Living's 24 retirement facilities will be operated by Whitehall Street Real Estate L.P. VII, a $1.35 billion fund run by firm Goldman, Sachs and the Senior Lifestyle Corporation. Senior Lifestyle is a closely held Chicago-based developer, which owns 16 facilities for the elderly. The agreement makes the combination of Whitehall and Senior Lifestyle one of the largest United States operators of housing for the elderly.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PERLMAN, SIDNEY
description: PERLMAN-Sidney. Our entire organization wishes to express our heartfelt condolences to Claire Perlman on the passing of her husband, Sidney. He was truly a man of great stature and consequence in our industry and a humanitarian of great note, whose life really made a difference. Ken Carmel Jerome M. Cohen Michael T. Cohen Felix C. Fertig Robert L. Freedman Saul Joseph Martin Meyer Charles Retz Andrew Roos Edwin Roos

title: Some Artistic Neighbors Try to Lower Their Fence
description: The future relationship of the arts and the world of commerce in the United States is under intense scrutiny this weekend by leaders of foundations and corporations, academics and others gathered here at a conference called ''The Arts and the Public Purpose.''

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  LOWE, BERTRAM
description: LOWE-Bertram. Twelve years. I Love You. H.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: COLLEGE BASEBALL

title: HUNDREDS OF JOB CUTS ARE PLANNED TO REDUCE EXPENSES
description: The ARCO Chemical Company said yesterday that it would cut several hundred jobs by the end of 1998 as part of a plan disclosed this month to slash expenses by a ''double digit percentage.'' The company, based in Newtown Square, Pa., which is 82.7 percent owned by the Atlantic Richfield Company, or ARCO, plans to eliminate jobs in research and development, plant operations and management.

title: I Want a Real Wedding, Too
description: I recently put more than $100 on my credit card to rent a tuxedo. I set aside the first Sunday in June and started scouting around for the ideal present. One of my oldest friends is getting married, and I'm happy for him. But as I was making all these preparations, a thought struck me: When my time comes, will he feel the same sense of obligation toward me?

title: Don't Punish Nigerians
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COMAS, CONSTANTINE F.
description: COMAS-Constantine F. Of Crestwood, N.Y. on May 29, 1997. Husband of Teresa Comas; father of Andrew, Peter and Daniel; brother of George Comas and Marie Dimitriadis; grandfather of Kevin, Nicholas, Edith and Christopher. Calling hours the Fred H. McGrath & Son Funeral Home, Bronxville between the hours of 2-4 and 79PM Saturday and Sunday. Mass of Christian burial, Annunciation Church, Crestwood, on Monday June 2 at 10AM. In lieu of flowers contributions may be made to Inner City Scholarship Fund, 1011 1st Ave, NY 10022 or Food for the Poor, Inc., 550 SW 12 Avenue, Bldg 4, Deerfield Beach, FL. 33442.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  GEFFNER, JEANNINE VERGNES.
description: GEFFNER-Jeannine Vergnes. ''I am still trying to find a life without you''. Love and kisses from me and Tiggy and Poshka. Happy birthday. David

title: Amersham Seeks to Join Units With Pharmacia
description: Amersham International P.L.C. said yesterday that it was negotiating to merge its life-sciences unit with Pharmacia & Upjohn Inc.'s biotechnology arm to create the world's biggest maker of equipment for molecular research. The merged unit would probably operate as a joint venture under Amersham control, a person familiar with the plan said.

title: Kmart Agrees to Hire 400 Ex-Welfare Recipients
description: In a move that many experts on job creation said puts New Jersey ahead of the pack, Gov. Christine Todd Whitman announced an agreement today with Kmart to hire 400 former welfare recipients a year for the next two years.

title: CUNY Graduates Invited Inside the Political Tent
description: Denouncing the worsening of public education and the abandonment of the poor, Senator Paul D. Wellstone of Minnesota yesterday morning urged the 346 recipients of doctorate and master's degrees from the City University of New York Graduate Center to seek an active role in politics.

title: Mafia Myth Obscures Roster of Italian Idealists
description: To the Editor:

title: Promising Workout by Touch Gold
description: In the nearly two weeks since the Preakness Stakes, the foremost concern of the trainer David Hofmans had been protecting the injured left front hoof of his colt Touch Gold.

title: Ruling Party In Indonesia Tightens Grip
description: As votes were counted today from the remote mountains and distant islands of this far-flung nation, the Government party consolidated what appeared to be a record margin of victory in Thursday's election.

title: On Naming Hurricanes
description: To the Editor:

title: FRENCH FAR RIGHT MAY BACK THE LEFT IN VOTE TOMORROW
description: As France prepares to vote on Sunday in critical parliamentary elections, the swing voters who support the far-right National Front are emerging as a force that could determine who governs France for the next five years. There are signs that the party's supporters, in their zealous distaste for the establishment, may hand victory to the opposition Socialists.

title: Fire Razes 2d Black Church
description: The First Baptist Church, a converted grain mill with a predominantly black congregation, was destroyed by an arson fire early yesterday, officials said. It was the second black church in New Jersey to burn down this year.

title: First-Quarter Growth Rate Rose to 5.8%
description: The economy's growth was stronger than initially estimated during the first three months of the year, the Commerce Department reported today. It recalculated the first-quarter output to an annual pace of 5.8 percent, the highest in nearly a decade, from 5.6 percent.

title: COLONNADE CAPITAL TO ADD NATIONAL PICTURE AND FRAME
description: The National Picture and Frame Company agreed to be acquired by Colonnade Capital L.L.C., a closely held Virginia company, for $12 a share, or about $59.6 million. National Picture, a maker of discount picture frames, mirrors and art, had 1996 net income of $5.1 million on sales of $67.2 million. National Picture stock rose $1.875, to $11. The company, based in Greenwood, Miss., went public in 1993 at $21 a share. If National Picture ends the accord to accept another offer, it must pay the Richmond-based Colonnade $2.5 million.

title: Forgettable Day for Woods
description: Despite his immense talent, neither Tiger Woods nor his golf ball can walk on water.

title: Bozell, Jacobs Rejects Omnicom As Suitor in Advertising Deal
description: Bozell, Jacobs, Kenyon & Eckhardt, the New York advertising agency company being wooed by bigger competitors, spurned a takeover bid late yesterday from one of them, Omnicom Group.

title: Lloyd's of London Had $1.7 Billion Profit in '94
description: Lloyd's of London, which reports its results three years in arrears, said yesterday that its profit for 1994 was $:1 billion ($1.7 billion) as the insurance market benefited from fewer catastrophes. This is down from a 1993 profit of $:1.1 billion and is Lloyd's second profitable year after $:8 billion of losses in the five years through 1992.

title: Lotto Fever
description: Tens of thousands of people acreoss New York State stood in line yesterday to buy tickets for the state lottery, whose jackpot has reached $70 million. Page 21.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ARKIN, ROSE G.
description: ARKIN-Rose G. The Officers, Trustees and Members of Park Avenue Synagogue mourn the passing of a devoted congregant. We extend to the family our heartfelt sympathy. David H. Lincoln, Senior Rabbi Alan Levine, Ch. of the Bd. Robert P. Antler, President

title: Giving a Modern Rock Twist To Roots of Honky-Tonk
description: Sometimes great musical fluency creates its own tradition. You could point to several figures in country, rock and blues as sources for the guitarist Pete Anderson, but ultimately they amount to a broken equation. Those who know music history, as Mr. Anderson does, are destined not so much to repeat it as to make albums that can't be easily categorized at the record store.

title: Drill Sergeant Gets 6 Months For Sex Abuse at Army Post
description: A third member of the Army staff involved in an extensive sex scandal at the Aberdeen Proving Ground was sentenced today to six months in prison, a term in marked contrast to the 25 years meted out to another drill sergeant at the post who was earlier convicted of sexually abusing female trainees.
